title: Generation Limbo: Waiting It Out
description: WHEN Stephanie Kelly, a 2009 graduate of the University of Florida, looked for a job in her chosen field, advertising, she found few prospects and even fewer takers. So now she has two jobs: as a part-time senior secretary at the Florida Museum of Natural History in Gainesville and a freelance gig writing for Elfster.com, a secret Santa Web site.

title: F.T.C. Criticizes Agreements That Delay Generic Drugs
description: Some drug makers are using an indirect method to delay competition from low-cost generic products by promising not to introduce their own generic versions if a potential competitor delays its entry into the market, the Federal Trade Commission said in a report on Wednesday.

title: Judge Declines to Dismiss Case Alleging Racial Profiling by City Police in Street Stops
description: A federal judge on Wednesday rejected an effort to dismiss a case claiming that New York City police officers use race as a factor in stopping people on the streets, sometimes to frisk them, saying there is enough evidence for a jury to decide.

title: Mr. Downtown Moves On
description: TO anyone else, it would just be a barstool. But to Taavo Somer, it was a conundrum.

title: Pelfrey Struggles for Answers Against Marlins
description: With his loss on Tuesday night, Mike Pelfrey lengthened a strange run of futility against the Florida Marlins, a team he has not beaten since July 8, 2006, in his first major league game.

title: In Germany, Sex Workers Feed a Meter
description: BERLIN  The city of Bonn has begun collecting taxes from prostitutes with an automated pay station similar to a parking meter, proving again that German efficiency knows few if any bounds.

title: F.D.A. Affirms Safety of Breast Implants
description: WASHINGTON  After two days of discussion and testimony about silicone breast implants, a top government health official said he had heard nothing to shake his faith in the safety of the widely used implants.

title: Should Colleges Stop Fraternity Hazing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Space, Well-to-Do Londoners Dig Deep
description: LONDON  To compensate for the lack of natural light around his new basement swimming pool, one London homeowner installed an outdoor camera that projects real-time images of the changing sky onto the pool ceiling. To assuage the concerns of swimmers who hate cramped spaces, another resident dug down so far beneath the earth that his pool is 16 feet deep and has a high-diving board.

title: The Victims of Irene
description: To the Editor:

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Headphones and Managing Music
description: As the son of Noel Lee, the founder of Monster Cable Products, Kevin Lee grew up around audio gear. The younger Mr. Lee is now branching off into his own business, SOL Republic, and drops by the podcast to discuss his new companys line of headphones  and what elements go into creating a good audio experience for the listener in the first place.

title: Legislature in California Set to Pass a Dream Act
description: LOS ANGELES  The California Legislature is poised to pass a law that would allow illegal immigrants to receive state-financed aid for college. Known as the California Dream Act, the bill underscores the ways states are navigating their own way through controversial immigration issues, as the Obama administration has been unable to make headway on plans for an overhaul of immigration laws.

title: An Ailing Venus Williams Exits
description: Venus Williams departed the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center on Wednesday with downcast eyes, staring at an uncertain future after revealing she had received a diagnosis of Sjogrens Syndrome, an autoimmune disease that causes fatigue and joint pain.

title: Identifying Suspects
description: To the Editor:

title: More of the Same in a Mortgage Plan
Autonomy for Postal Service
description: To the Editor:

title: After Going 0 for August, Arsenal Goes on a Shopping Spree
description: Arsenal was the most active team before European soccers summer transfer period ended Wednesday night, plugging holes in its leaky defense by adding the towering German central defender Per Mertesacker and the Brazilian left back Andr Santos, and reinvigorating its midfield in one of the busiest days in the clubs history.

title: Not Born a Panhandler
description: To the Editor:

title: Solar Firm Aided by Federal Loans Shuts Doors
description: WASHINGTON  A Silicon Valley maker of solar power arrays that was started with high hopes and $527 million in loans from the federal government said on Wednesday that it would cease operations. The failure of the company  and the loss to taxpayers  is likely to renew the debate in Washington about the wisdom of clean energy subsidies and loan guarantees.

title: Book-Loving City Forgoes Free Ones for a Week
description: SEATTLE  The sun streaks across the 10-day forecast here, and its timing could not be better. After all, one of the citys most important refuges is closed because of budget cuts.

title: To McHale, Open Feels Like Home
description: With her long, dark braid flying through the air behind her, Christina McHale fired an ace to win her second-round match at the United States Open on Wednesday, then calmly lifted her arms to celebrate. She had just beaten the No. 8 seed, Marion Bartoli, in straight sets, 7-6(2), 6-2, in front of a packed grandstand stadium, prompting pockets of fans to leap to their feet in joy. But to her and her admirers, that upset was no surprise.

title: Bloggingheads: Christian Dominionism
description: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative debate Christian Dominionism.

title: Huntsman Urges Stripping Deductions From Tax Code
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. again showed himself on Wednesday to be an ideological outlier in the Republican presidential field, calling for the tax code to be stripped of all loopholes and deductions.

title: David Reynolds, Leader of Metals Company, Dies at 96
description: David P. Reynolds, a metals manufacturing executive who helped bring aluminum foil and aluminum beverage cans into the American kitchen, died on Monday in Richmond, Va. He was 96.

title: A Place Uniquely Theirs to Savor Days End
description: As summer approached, Gianluca Nardis wife, a hard-working lawyer, proposed that they live each day as if it were vacation, vacation in New York.

title: Muslim Leaders Criticize Police Response to Scuffle
description: Muslim civil rights leaders on Wednesday accused the authorities of using excessive force after a Westchester County amusement parks restrictions on head coverings provoked a scuffle a day earlier that led to the arrest of 15 people.

description: Ellicott City, Md.

title: Turning to More Provocative Shows, a Cable Channel Woos Back Some Viewers
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  The summer of 2010 was a nail-biter for USA, televisions most popular cable channel in prime time, and not just because of the spy capers and doctor dramas like Burn Notice and Royal Pains that it carries.

title: River, at 100-Year High, Ravages a City That Once Thrived on It
description: PATERSON, N.J.  The red roof of an old fried-chicken restaurant peeked out above the floodwaters. A roiling current marooned a furniture shop, while the manager of a 99-cent store watched boxes of diapers bob like buoys in her basement.

title: German Officials Alarmed by Ex-Rappers New Message: Jihad
description: BERLIN  The man German security officials call a major security risk looks like a figure from a rap video, especially with the tattoos on his hands. The right one says STR8, and the left one Thug.

title: What to Do With Qaddafi
description: Los Angeles

title: Covered Bridges, Beloved Remnants of Another Era, Were Casualties, Too
description: As the country watched scenes of devastation from Hurricane Irene, thousands of history and engineering buffs were on edge for another reason, waiting to hear the fate of hundreds of antique covered bridges that dot the Eastern Seaboard and that are especially concentrated  and beloved  in the unexpectedly ravaged state of Vermont.

title: Cervelli Wont Apologize for Playing His Way
description: BOSTON  Red Sox catcher Jarrod Saltalamacchia spoke Tuesday night about the way Latin players act and play the game as a way of explaining Francisco Cervellis emotional behavior.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: Kim Clijsters
description: David Waldstein explains why Kim Clijsters was a great U.S. Open champion and how she could defeat Martina Navratilova in an Open match.

title: Days After the Storm, Many Are Still in the Dark
description: First came the roaring winds and drenching rain, followed by devastating floods. Now, for four straight days, darkness and disconnect.

description: George Vecsey explains how Chris Every could defeat Justine Henin in a hypothetical U.S. Open match.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: Justine Henin
description: Ray Krueger explains why Justine Henin was a great Open champion and how she could defeat Chris Evert in an Open match.

title: Sorry, Wrong In-Box
description: The other night I did something silly. In a hurry to reach my friend K., I made the mistake of calling him on his mobile phone.

title: The Same Old Ball Game
description: Life in New York City requires the acceptance of a contradictory narrative about what loosely can be called ordinary existence. Even as a native of this city, I struggle to regard the punishment of its costs, the strain of its pace and the futility of its endless competitions  major, minor and residential  as normal.

title: Four-Hour Games? At Least One Yankee Sympathizes
description: BOSTON

title: California: Deal May Save Some Courts
description: Drastic cuts to the San Francisco Superior Court may be less severe under an agreement announced Wednesday, with 102 jobs and 11 courtrooms saved. The deal, which still needs the approval of the states Judicial Council, would provide $2.5 million in new funding for the citys courts, which faced the prospect of lengthy delays in all manner of civil actions, including divorce and class-action suits. The courts will still lay off 75 employees and close 14 courtrooms, but its presiding judge, Katherine Feinstein, said the deal would lessen the blow on access to justice.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: Martina Navratilova
description: Harvey Araton explains why Martina Navratilova was a great Open champion and how she would defeat Kim Clijsters in an Open match.

title: The Military and the Death Penalty
description: Racism in the application of capital punishment has been well documented in the civilian justice system since the Supreme Court reinstated the penalty in 1976. Now comes evidence that racial disparity is even greater in death penalty cases in the military system.

title: In T-Mobile Suit, Consumers Are Central
description: The Justice Department, in the suit it filed Wednesday to block AT&Ts $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile, asserted that T-Mobile places important competitive pressure on the larger cellular carriers. Keeping T-Mobile away from AT&T, the government contends, will spur innovation and give consumers lower prices and more choice.

title: Isolating Assad
description: As the killings mount in Syria, the United States and its allies are not the only ones declaring their revulsion. A number of President Bashar al-Assads longtime apologists have decided that they can no longer stand mute.

title: WikiLeaks Prompts New Diplomatic Uproar
description: WASHINGTON  In the Philippines this week, officials are fuming about criticism by a former American ambassador of the late Corazon C. Aquino, a national icon. Australians have learned that just two years ago American authorities were considering declaring that Australias air safety system no longer met international standards. People in Botswana could read a critical American account of that countrys anemic efforts against human trafficking.

title: A Blockage on Teacher Evaluations
description: New York and its teachers unions acted in the best interest of the states children last year when they agreed to replace a useless teacher evaluation system with a rigorous process that takes student achievement into account and provides clear sanctions for ineffective teachers. But a dispute over regulatory language has landed the two sides in court. Last week, a state court ruling unwisely blocked a crucial part of the plan that could label as ineffective teachers who do a particularly poor job of improving student performance. The state should appeal that part of the ruling.

title: As Williamses Age, Here Comes Youth
description: The story goes that 4-year-old Madison Keys picked up a racket for the first time because she liked the way Venus Williams looked in her stylish tennis dress. Twelve years later, on the day Williams exited the scene ominously without striking a ball, Keys looked like a budding star inside a body that is well suited for 21st century womens tennis.

title: Lottery Numbers
Misreading Francis Schaeffer
description: The New Yorkers Ryan Lizza has posted a response to my criticisms of the way his recent profile of Michele Bachmann portrayed the evangelical writer and activist Francis Schaeffer. In his post, Lizza attempts to justify his articles claim that Schaeffers 198o book A Christian Manifesto urges the violent overthrow of the government if Roe v. Wade isnt reversed. I had disputed this point, noting that Schaeffer only urged Christians to consider acts of non-violent civil disobedience against the post-Roe abortion regime (offering examples like the non-payment of taxes and public sit-ins), while explicitly warning his readers against an overreaction [that] crosses the line from force to violence. Lizza counters that Schaeffer did write that actual political violence was sometimes justified, citing this passage from the Manifesto as an example:

title: Players Union and N.B.A. Revive Talks
description: The N.B.A. lockout enters its third month without an agreement in sight, and with the start of training camps less than five weeks away. But league and union leaders are talking again, and pledging to remain constructive, diligent and discreet in the weeks ahead.

title: Thursday: Seeing Double
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  This is a puzzle that not only gives, it REGIFTS.

title: Praising NATO, and Frances Place in It
description: PARIS  On the eve of a major conference here to try to consolidate international support and reconstruction aid for Libyas fledgling government, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France praised the working of the NATO alliance in support of the rebels, calling it an indispensable tool despite Washingtons decision to take a back seat in the war.

title: Battle for Libya | August 31, 2011
description: Libyans celebrated Id al-Fitr in Martyrs Square and old intelligence files were found in Tripoli.

title: Honoring Sept. 11, With Care
description: For years, Madison Avenue steered clear of events that marked the anniversary of 9/11, anxious that any participation could be perceived as exploitive.

title: Researchers Find Antibiotic Resistance in Ancient DNA
description: An analysis of 30,000-year-old bacteria whose DNA has been recovered from the Yukon permafrost shows that they were able to resist antibiotics.

title: In the Adirondacks, Storm-Battered and Cut Off
description: KEENE, N.Y.  To those just driving through, the hamlet of Keene never looked like much, even before Tropical Storm Irene.

title: Plenty of Blame to Go Around
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives is in dire need of strong, fresh leadership. Its benighted Mexican gunrunning sting finally forced the removal this week of its acting director, Kenneth Melson, and the United States attorney in Phoenix, Dennis Burke.

title: Florida Shutting Pill Mill Clinics
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Florida has long been the nations center of the illegal sale of prescription drugs: Doctors here bought 89 percent of all the Oxycodone sold in the country last year. At its peak, so many out-of-staters flocked to Florida to buy drugs at more than 1,000 pain clinics that the state earned the nickname Oxy Express.

title: Humility by the Pack
description: Snarling relief pitchers see themselves as baseballs meanest breed. Asked to take the mound at the most pivotal, pressure-packed moments  in the late innings, with the game on the line  they often develop a steely shell to hide any rattled nerves.

title: Special Parking Rules in New York
description: In New York City, because of Id al-Fitr, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

description: TRIPOLI, Libya

title: Mets Recover From Capuanos Slow Start
description: The last time Chris Capuano took the mound at Citi Field, he produced a nearly flawless performance that ranked among the finest in his nine-year career.

title: Canada: Remains, Possibly Human, Found in Inlet
description: What appears to be a human foot in a running shoe was found floating in a downtown inlet in Vancouver, British Columbia, on Tuesday. Eight feet have washed up on British Columbias coastline, and another three have been found along the coast of Washington State since August 2007. Because people have planted animal feet as hoaxes since the cases began, the police said that testing would be needed to confirm that the foot is from a person. The police say the source of the feet seems to have no common factor, and government officials suggest the phenomenon may be partly a result of the particular geography of southern British Columbia, which has a sheltered coastline. Scientists say they believe that running shoes preserve tissue and provide floatation.

title: Baltimores Unlikely Confederates
description: When Isaac Trimble left Baltimore in May 1861 to accept a commission as a Confederate officer, he probably figured he would return to a heros welcome. This was, after all, supposedly the most pro-Southern of Northern cities, and he had every reason to expect that, by wars end, it might even be in Confederate hands.

title: Fluttering Distraction Is Trouble for Yanks
description: BOSTON  With his position in the rotation possibly at stake, and the game and first place hanging in the balance, a series of bizarre events conspired to turn an improved effort by Phil Hughes into an ultimately disappointing one.

title: Veterans Discover Allure of Jobs in Western Wilderness
description: SEQUOIA NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  On the hillside above Evelyn Lake, deep in the southern Sierra Nevada, it was surprisingly easy to tell time: precisely at noon, a loud whoop echoed amid the black-flecked granite and dust, signaling lunch hour for the 17-person crew repairing the trail to the lake.

title: Bernard Wolfman, Who Sought Tax Overhaul, Dies at 87
description: Bernard Wolfman criticized Americas tax system as being riddled with loopholes, favoring the rich and hopelessly unwieldy. But after Washingtons political quicksand repeatedly swallowed his hopes for tax reform in Congress, he concluded that only an independent commission could do the job.

title: Isner Better at Breakers
description: John Isner is best known for the tie breaker he didnt play at Wimbledon last year during an absurd 70-68 fifth set. But in truth, Isner lives and dies in tie breakers, and on Wednesday evening on the Louis Armstrong court, the big man beat Marcos Baghdatis, 7-6 (2), 7-6 (11), 2-6, 6-4, largely on the strength of how he played in the few key points that decided the match.

title: Corrections: September 1
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: China: Two Tibetan Monks Receive Lengthy Prison Terms
description: A Chinese court sentenced two more Tibetan monks to long prison terms on Tuesday, accusing them of intentional homicide in the death of another monk, who immolated himself last March, according to Xinhua. The court sentenced Tsering Tenzin and Tenchum of the Kirt Monastery in the Tibetan area of Sichuan Province to 13 and 10 years in prison, respectively. On Monday, the same court found a 46-year-old monk, Drongdru, guilty of intentional homicide in the death of the monk, a 16-year-old who was his nephew and disciple. Prosecutors said that after the teenager immolated himself, the three monks hid him and delayed emergency treatment. Human rights groups said the teenage monk was protesting government policies in Tibet.

description: NYT Front Page for 09/01/11

title: Northeast Ravaged by Flooding
description: Four days after Tropical Storm Irene, towns near the Passaic River in New Jersey struggled with flooding while wide swaths of the Northeast were still without power.

description: The Mets announced Wednesday night that they would promote two minor leaguers, pitcher Josh Stinson and infielder Josh Satin, once rosters can expand on Sept. 1.

title: Beer as an Ingredient
description: Heres a rough history of my beer-drinking career: at age 18 (then the legal drinking age in New York), I started with Rheingold  cheap, watery stuff that later went off the market. Down the road, after messing around with Narragansett (or gansett), I moved up to Heineken. (Up in status, I suppose. In quality? Questionable.) Eventually I discovered real beers: Bass Pale Ale, no longer favored by the cognoscenti but then a beacon of refinement, became a favorite. Before too long, the beer world exploded, and I found myself visiting the Good Beer store in Manhattan, which has something like 600 types of craft beers.

description: This is a dangerous time to be a black African in Libya.

description: BOSTON  When Adrian Gonzalez arrived in Florida this winter for his first spring training with the Boston Red Sox, his teammates kept telling him that he needed to make sure to watch one player in particular take batting practice.

description: Its a tennis cliche: Teenage prodigy bursts onto the scene, turns pro too early and flames out too soon. Of the many names on that list, Mirjana Lucic would certainly be near the top.

description: PARIS  As world leaders gathered on Thursday for a major conference to try to consolidate international support and reconstruction aid for Libya, Russia recognized the fledgling rebel government despite its opposition to the NATO bombing campaign.

title: Candid Moments From the British Underworld
description: PERPIGNAN, France  In 2007, 10 years after Jocelyn Bain Hogg started chronicling organized crime in Britain, one of his subjects asked to pose for a photo. No, Mr. Bain Hogg said, right away. I dont do that.

description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Is Titans Chris Johnson Worth the Money?
description: Running back Chris Johnson and the Titans appear to be making progress on ending a holdout that threatens to knock him out of the season opener. If they do reach a long-term deal, they will also be passing judgment on the value of running backs in the modern game.

title: Near Berlin, Nature and Culture Mix on Peacock Island
description: Just southwest of Berlin, within reach by public transportation, there is an island in the river Havel where peacocks roam free, goats and buffalo graze in the meadows, all amid a curious collection of castles.

title: Buyer Beware, as Damaged Cars from Tropical Storm Irene May Soon Arrive on Dealer Lots
description: Thousands of people are still cleaning up from Tropical Storm Irene, but the residual impact may be felt by people who didnt see a drop of rain over the weekend.

title: How Should Schools Address Bullying?
description: Today, the Anti-Bullying Bill of Rights becomes law in the state of New Jersey. Do you think states should have legislation about bullying? Why or why not? How is bullying handled in your school and community? Do you feel the rules and policies are adequate? Are they effective?

title: After Tropical Storm Irene, a Bounty for Birdwatchers
description: While many residents in the New York region grabbed shovels, chain saws and dehumidifiers in the wake of Tropical Storm Irene, another breed of New Yorker reflexively  and joyfully  reached for binoculars.

title: How I (Almost) Took a Two-Week Vacation From Bad News
description: I have just returned from the second two-week vacation I have ever taken, the last one being 15 years ago. I usually go away for one week, but this time I went to Argentina and two weeks was necessary. Unlike my last two-week trip, I had to make a big decision this time: bring the laptop or leave it resting comfortably at home? Disconnect partly or completely?

title: A Busy Day For Insider Trading Cases
description: The last week of the summer is supposed to be a slow time on Wall Street. Not so on the white-collar crime beat.

title: Large Protest in Bahrain After Boys Death
description: Thousands of people marched through a restive village near the capital of Bahrain on Thursday for the funeral of a 14-year-old boy killed during a protest against the government the day before, activists said.

title: In Video Resignation, Syrian Official Describes Prisoner Abuse
description: A high-ranking official in the restive Syrian city of Hama appeared in a video on Wednesday announcing that he had resigned his post over what he described as the brutal treatment of protesters detained by the government.

title: Sky Cowboys
description: The ironworkers in the air at ground zero work amid striking views and unshakeable memories. With photographs by Damon Winter.

title: Raising High Steel Atop 1 World Trade Center
description: The best view in New York belongs to the fearless ironworkers who are stacking the top floors of 1 World Trade Center.

title: In Brightest Africa
description: The Brooklyn Museum is doing some territorial reshuffling on its first floor. What has long been the gift shop will soon be a new cafe, while the shop itself will move into a former exhibition gallery nearby. The change will give the museums two primary social and commercial attractions a gain in size or visibility, but in the process art is taking a bit of a hit.

title: The Fresh Prince of Cool Air
description: This is the air-conditioning Christmas season, Mike Stoll says, punching a new address into the navigator affixed to his windshield and apologizing, in advance, for how he is going to smell later in the day. It is early morning in Dallas  during one of the hottest summers on record, with only a few days since July failing to climb over 100 degrees  and Stolls A#1 Air repair van is trying its hardest to keep us cool. Outside, its not just hot, but thanks to one of the worst droughts in Texas history, the grass is brown, the trees are wilting and bodies of water are evaporating. The few people braving the outdoors resemble sweat-soaked zombies. The apocalypse seems just beyond the next freeway overpass.

title: Ironworkers of the Sky
description: To get to the top of 1 World Trade Center as it stands in mid-August, just shy of 1,000 feet above Lower Manhattan, higher than anything else on the islands southern end, first you walk to the middle of the blast-resistant concrete cathedral that will become the buildings lobby. From there, a hoist takes you to the 39th floor, whose perimeter has already been glassed in. A sign spray-painted in screaming construction orange  EXPRESS ALL DAY  directs you to a second hoist, inside which Don McLean is singing, Bye, bye, Miss American Pie . . . and men in hard hats decoupaged with flag decals are bobbing their heads to the beat.

title: Apple Cited as Adding to Pollution in China
description: SHANGHAI  A Chinese environmental group has singled out Apple for criticism, accusing the companys Chinese suppliers of discharging polluted waste and toxic metals into surrounding communities and threatening public health.

title: I.B.M. to Buy Algorithmics for $387 Million
description: The data deals keep coming.

title: When a Persons Name Means What It Says
description: A fair number of aptronyms have been in the news lately, the most recent belonging to one Christopher Coke, who pleaded guilty in Manhattan on Wednesday to federal racketeering charges.

title: India and Pakistan Exchange Fire in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI  Indian and Pakistani troops exchanged fire over the border that divides the disputed province of Kashmir late Wednesday night, military officials in both countries said Thursday.

title: Theater Talkback: Remembering Jerry Leiber, a Reluctant Pioneer of the Jukebox Musical
description: This summer ArtsBeat is inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. Writers have examined the challenges of casting the role of Fanny Brice in Funny Girl; unusual settings for Shakespeare stagings; the buzzkill of pre-show announcements; the etiquette of booing at the theater; and the good that can come from bad reviews. This week, Jack Viertel, the senior vice president of Jujamcyn Theaters, remembers the late songwriter Jerry Leiber and his role in creating a durable if highly debated stage genre, the jukebox musical.

title: Cantor Counters
description: Steve Landsburg critiques my critique of Eric Cantors demand that emergency relief be offset by spending cuts elsewhere. But I think that he misses the point.

title: Syrian Official in Hama Resigns to Protest Bloodshed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The attorney general of the central Syrian province of Hama has announced his resignation to protest the killings and arrests of demonstrators and the accusations of torture against President Bashar al-Assads government. The attorney general, Mohammed Adnan al-Bakkour, is the highest-level official to quit over the brutal crackdown during the five months of protests.

title: Taking on a Veteran Antitrust Judge in the AT&T Fight
description: 8:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Thursday Reading: Beware of Storm-Damaged Cars for Sale
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Whisker Rebellion
description: When Jason Lee decides to take it off, he takes it all off. The 41-year-old actor, who played an affable, overweight and almost comically hirsute slacker on My Name Is Earl from 2005 until 2009, recently shed 40 pounds and a whole lot of unnecessary facial hair. I got chunky during Earl, and I had the big mustache for four years, Lee says. It was time to clean up my act.

title: Iceland Exits
description: Iceland is no longer under an IMF program; heres the IMF report (pdf) pronouncing the adjustment program successful. Indeed. Iceland still has high unemployment and is a long way from a full recovery; but its no longer in crisis, it has regained access to international capital markets, and has done all that with its society intact.

title: Excavations on Catfish Row
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  She never sings these particular lyrics. But Audra McDonald has every right to say, Bess, you is my woman now. That assertion is implicit in every aspect of her performance in The Gershwins Porgy and Bess, which opened on Wednesday night at the American Repertory Theater here, and it is made with a confidence and conviction that are otherwise lacking in this anxious and confused production.

title: Deputy Mayor Was Arrested Before He Resigned
description: Read the final version of this article that appeared in print.

title: Shoppers Shake Off Augusts Woes for Back-to-School Buying
description: Despite the volatile stock market, an East Coast hurricane and predictions of delayed back-to-school purchases, Americans continued buying at a fast pace in August.

title: Before Vote on Budget, Spain Falters in Debt Sale
description: MADRID  Spain auctioned off another round of debt on Thursday as the government rushed to enshrine stricter budget discipline in the Constitution.

title: China Benefits as U.S. Solar Industry Withers
description: HONG KONG  The bankruptcies of three American solar power companies in the last month, including Solyndra of California on Wednesday, have left Chinas industry with a dominant sales position  almost three-fifths of the worlds production capacity  and rapidly declining costs.

title: Obama Backs Bill Barring Discrimination Against Jobless
description: Weve written before about job ads and hiring practices that exclude unemployed candidates from applying. Mitchell Hirsch, an associate at the National Employment Law Project, recently alerted me that President Obama had expressed support for outlawing such practices.

title: With Activision Video Game, Nascar Seeks to Expand Fan Base Virtually
description: Nascar will soon add another branded racing title under its own flag, pairing with Activision, the veteran video game publisher and developer. The new game, Nascar Unleashed, will join a crowded category of racing simulator games dominated by Sonys Gran Turismo and Microsofts Forza series when it goes on sale in November at a retail price of $40.

title: The City Stirs | City Island, 4:38 A.M.
description: I knew I couldnt live in America and I wasnt ready to move to Europe, so I moved to an island off the coast of America  New York City.  Spalding Gray

title: At Frankies 570 Spuntino, Seasonal Cocktails You Pour
description: At Frankies 570 Spuntino, the new West Village restaurant from the team of Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, which is set to open on Tuesday, pitchers arent just for beer anymore.

title: Relief in Vermont Towns as Crews Make Inroads
description: ROCHESTER, Vt.  There is still no electricity in this town at the foot of the Green Mountains, but after days of being cut off from the world, there is a way out.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Silver Lakes Hutchins Named a Director of the New York Fed
description: Private equity is again getting a seat at the table at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Car Buyers Unfazed by Storms, Financial and Tropical, in August
description: DETROIT  Despite disruptions from Hurricane Irene and signs of a slowing economy, Americans bought more cars in August.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Motor Skills
description: An entangled motorcycle chain may seem more highway hazard than design inspiration, but not for Jane Carr, the English designer who turned the twisted metal into a vivid neckerchief for her new mens accessories line. Carr based the collection, Rebel Rebel, on James Dean and his boy toys, with brake-pedal grids, road signs and even an image of the icon himself printed on scarves and pocket squares. Gentlemen, start your engines.

title: Deal to Sell Piece of Mets to Einhorn Falls Apart
description: In a surprising development, the Mets announced on Thursday that they had ended their protracted negotiations to sell a minority share of the team for $200 million to David Einhorn, a hedge fund manager.

title: On Outdoor Experience and Environmental Values
description: Yesterdays post on The Role of Values in Driving Climate Disputes prompted reactions from a variety of people, including Richard Louv, the author of Last Child in the Woods and The Nature Principle.

title: The Friendly New Face of Goldman
description: Quick. Youre an investment bank that has fallen on hard times.

title: Sting and Brian Yorkey Embark on a New Musical, The Last Ship
description: The worlds of Sting, the lute-wielding pop-rock Renaissance man, and Brian Yorkey, the Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning book writer and lyricist of Next to Normal, are coming together with increasing synchronicity in a new musical that is being prepared for readings in October. According to a casting breakdown that was circulated for the project, the musical is titled The Last Ship, and features music and lyrics by Sting and a book by Mr. Yorkey, who is directing. Though a plot summary is not provided, descriptions of the musicals characters suggest a story that is set in the 1980s in Newcastle, the northern British city where Sting was born and raised before joining his band the Police.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Its time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

title: Gambling for Greatness
description: Patrick Healy explains why the fall premiere of The Gershwins Porgy and Bess has been the talk of the summer.

title: Artsbeat: September 1, 2011
description: Patrick Healy on a re-conceived production of Porgy and Bess, and A. O. Scott on the classic Humphrey Bogart film, In a Lonely Place.

title: This week: One-man pop obsessive Dev Hynes on his new project Blood Orange and new album Coastal Grooves; Nick Brown of the young Tennessee rock band Mona; CDs by Miguel Zenn and Red Hot Chili Peppers. Ben Ratliff is the host.
description: This week: One-man pop obsessive Dev Hynes on his new project Blood Orange and new album Coastal Grooves; Nick Brown of the young Tennessee rock band Mona; CDs by Miguel Zenn and Red Hot Chili Peppers. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: The Sky Cowboys
description: The best view in New York belongs to the fearless ironworkers who are stacking the top floors of One World Trade Center.

title: Williams Says She Struggled With Fatigue for Years
description: Venus Williams wore a lacy white short-sleeve top, blue jeans and sandals. Her hair fell in soft curls past her shoulders, her dangly silver-dollar-size earrings shimmered in the light. In the restaurant of the Upper East Side hotel where Williams is staying, she could have passed for a model headed to the Hamptons for the Labor Day weekend rather than a tennis superstar already plotting her return despite a chronic autoimmune disease.

title: Razers Sleek, Powerful and Really Expensive Laptop
description: Theres an old saying among building contractors: There are three ways a job can be donecheap, fast and welland you can only pick two out of three.

title: Deadline for Libyan Loyalists to Surrender Is Extended
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The Libyan rebels transitional government on Thursday extended by a week its ultimatum demanding the surrender of the loyalists of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi who control his hometown, Surt. Also on Thursday, the fugitive Libyan leader released an audio recording proclaiming that Surt was now the Libyan capital.

title: Sept. 11 in the Arts
description: Examples of how the events of Sept. 11 inspired and provoked various artists.

title: As Mets Deal Collapses, Einhorn Fund Shows a Decline
description: Since the David Einhorns proposed deal to buy a stake in the New York Mets was announced in May, some investors in his hedge fund grumbled that the hedge fund manager was, in fact, taking his eye off the ball.

title: Sept. 11 in the Arts
description: Examples of how the events of Sept. 11 inspired and provoked various artists.

title: Now Playing | Theophilus Londons I Stand Alone
description: T Magazine reports from the set of the new Theophilus London music video, I Stand Alone, which makes its world premiere here and now.

title: Qaddafi Vows Resistance in Audio Message
description: Not to be outshone by a message of defiance said to be from his son Seif al-Islam, who taunted the Libyan rebels in an audio message on Wednesday, a man claiming to be Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi aired his own vows of violence in an audio message on Thursday: We are not women. We will keep fighting.

title: Helping the Modern Get Over Itself
description: The permanent collection of any great museum is in a state of constant, usually subtle flux. Works go up, are shifted about and later removed from view, making way for others. Often such changes pass all but unnoticed. But occasionally the adjustments are more pronounced and widespread, achieving a kind of critical mass and creating a different sense of the institution, its holdings and its possibilities.

title: Scores of Artworks Missing in Wake of Oslo Bombing
description: More than 100 artworks that were held in buildings damaged in Julys terrorist attack in Oslo are missing, including more than 40 that were on loan from Norways National Museum of Art, The Art Newspaper reported on Wednesday.

title: J. Crew Settles Shareholder Lawsuit for $16 Million
description: The J. Crew Group and its two new private equity owners agreed on Thursday to pay $16 million to settle a shareholder lawsuit over the retailers $3 billion leveraged buyout, according to a filing in Delawares Court of Chancery.

title: Chiefs of Wendys and Costco to Step Down
description: Wendys, the operator of more than 6,500 fast-food restaurants, said its chief executive, Roland Smith, was stepping down this month as the company remakes its menu to compete with McDonalds.

title: Report Finds Naval Blockade by Israel Legal but Faults Raid
description: UNITED NATIONS  A long-awaited United Nations review of Israels 2010 raid on a Turkish-based flotilla in which nine passengers were killed has found that Israels naval blockade of Gaza is both legal and appropriate. But it said that the way Israeli forces boarded the vessels trying to break that blockade 15 months ago was excessive and unreasonable.

title: Boehner to Address Jobs a Week After Obama
description: Exactly one week after President Obama delivers his (rescheduled) speech to Congress, Speaker John A. Boehner of the House of Representatives is slated to address the Economic Club of Washington, D.C.

title: Music Video | I Stand Alone
description: A premiere of Theophilus London's latest music video, "I Stand Alone."

title: Long-Time iTunes Chief Moves Up at Apple
description: Eddy Cue, the Apple executive who has run iTunes since its inception, and is the companys primary ambassador to the music industry, has been promoted to senior vice president, Internet software and services.

title: Schiavone Overpowers Lucic
description: Seventh-seeded Francesca Schiavone overwhelmed Mirjana Lucic, 6-1, 6-1 on Thursday to gain the third round of the 2011 U.S. Open.

title: MarketRiders Tweaks Its Investment Mix
description: MarketRiders, the online service that helps you build and manage an investment portfolio, recently sent me an e-mail telling me it was time to rebalance a Roth I.R.A. Since the hurricane kept me indoors for most of the weekend, I figured it was the perfect time to check this task off my to-do list.

title: Outdone by Reality
description: VIDEO: Artists Reflect on Sept. 11

title: Iran Moves to Shelter Its Nuclear Fuel Program
description: WASHINGTON  Iran is moving its most critical nuclear fuel production to a heavily defended underground military facility outside the holy city of Qum, where it is less vulnerable to attack from the air and, the Iranians hope, the kind of cyberattack that crippled its nuclear program, according to intelligence officials.

title: Smart Previews Forvision Ahead of Frankfurt Auto Show
description: For all its, well, shortcomings, the Smart car has often been an ambitious workshop for forward-thinking automotive design. The Forvision concept, scheduled to have its debut in Frankfurt this month, appears to be a message from Daimler, Smarts parent, to BMW and its i subbrand: two can play at this city-car-of-tomorrow game.

title: How Parenting Changed One Writer
description: One of my beach books this summer was The Most Dangerous Thing, by the mystery writer Laura Lippman. I knew that her daughter had been born while she was writing this particular tale, and I found myself wondering not only What happened to those kids in the woods all those decades ago that has come back to haunt them now? but also How did Laura get this finished with a newborn in the house? and  apropos of our earlier Motherlode discussion on how the news feels different when youre a parent  Is it different writing about children in danger once you have your own?

title: Amid Favorites Easy Knockouts, Ferrero Prevails in a Lengthy Slugfest
description: In Thursdays afternoon matches at the United States Open, the winners were the top contenders who advanced with dazzling efficiency and the losers were the people who bought tickets to Arthur Ashe Stadium hoping the matches might actually involve sweating.

title: Getting Doctors to Wash Their Hands
description: A new study has a message for doctors and nurses who fail to wash their hands: Dont think about yourself. Think about your patients.

title: The Trials of Keeping Trails Hiker-Ready
description: The Atwell-Hockett trail, which runs 10 miles into the southern Sierra Nevada mountains in Californias Sequoia National Park, begins near a site where silver miners set out into the mountains more than a century ago. They used pack animals; park personnel and some vacationers still do.

title: A 21st-Century Public Space
description: In May 2010, Berlin's Tempelhof Airport became a park. A look at how Berliners and others now enjoy the public space.

title: Rethinking the Never Unsubscribe Rule for Spam
description: When it comes to junk mail, the rule, for 15 years, has been: Never respond. Dont even try to unsubscribe, even if they give you instructions for doing so. Youre just letting the spammer know that your e-mail address is live, and that youre a dummy who actually opens those messages and reads them. Youll wind up getting put on even more spam lists as a result.

title: At Historic Berlin Airport, Picnics and Roller Skates
description: Have you ever skated on a runway?

title: How She Does It
description: One of my favorite book titles is I Dont Know How She Does It. Yes, I loved the novel, by Allison Pearson. But it was the title that won me over first. It captures so much of the exhaustion, pride, snark and self-doubt that comes all rolled up into parenting.

title: T Exclusive Video | Burberrys New Body
description: Burberrys eagerly awaited new fragrance, Body, which hits counters today, has at its heart a beguiling mix of English rose (but of course), iris and sandalwood, and comes in a striking crystal-topped bottle engraved with the houses signature check. With hotter-than-hot model-actress Rosie Huntington-Whiteley as its face (and body), and Burberrys iconic trench coat as its creative touchstone, the new juice marks the companys biggest unveiling ever. Christopher Bailey, Burberrys chief creative officer, even designed a limited-edition rose gold trench (like the one Huntington-Whiteleywears in the campaign) to go along with the scent, as well as a capsule collection of nude trenches, bags, shoes and sunglasses. Here, in an exclusive video for The Moment, Bailey discusses his latest and greatest project.

title: Do Parents Put Too Much Pressure on Students?
description: Even Tiger Moms seem to think theyre pressuring their kids too much.

title: Kevin Smith Opens His Secret Stash in New AMC Series
description: After many months of behind-the-scenes drama on its costly scripted drama series, AMC, the cable home of Mad Men, Breaking Bad and The Walking Dead, said on Thursday that it was moving forward on two new reality programs  shows that will presumably be easier on the channels pocketbook and wont result in as many backstage headaches.

title: Perseverance, Perseverance, Perseverance
description: HILLSBORO, N.D.  A word or two about perseverance, which is an essential  maybe the essential  carry-on for a cross-country cyclist. If I didnt have it, it would be worth trading my rain gear for it, and I say this having ridden much of the past two days in the rain. The truth is that just about anyone can make a trip like this  you dont have to be in great shape or own a top-flight bike  as long as youre willing to keep pedaling. If you cant muster the desire to keep your legs going day after day, your physical condition wont matter, and whatever you pack in your saddlebags wont either.

title: Jankovic Holds Steady, Defeats Dokic
description: When a power-oriented player steps on the court, her game plan is clear. Hit the ball hard for winners, try not to make any errors, and win the match on her own terms.

title: They Keep Watching Big Brother
description: Big Brother on CBS continued its summer winning streak on Wednesday night, rising 10 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic compared to last weeks episode and totaling 8.2 million viewers. The bump was enough to give CBS the top spot for the night in the advertiser-coveted demo, while NBC was No. 1 in total viewers thanks to yet another episode of Americas Got Talent, which averaged 10.3 million.

title: Selling Pieces of Brooklyn (but Not the Bridge)
description: What does a doll-size Statue of Liberty, or a shot glass printed with the World Trade Center or, for that matter, a T-shirt printed in California on Chinese cotton have to do with the gritty, day-to-day city that New Yorkers live in?

title: When the Color Is Primary
description: BLOOD. Cherry. Brick. Sangria. With so many shades of red on the color spectrum, whats a poster designer to do with a show called simply Red? Almost 30 regional theaters faced this question when they put John Logans drama, about the Abstract Expressionist painter Mark Rothko, on their 2011-12 schedule. (The show was a hit on Broadway last year, winning six Tony Awards including best play.)

title: Courtside: A Womens Field in Disarray
description: The women's field lost another top player when Venus Williams dropped out of the tournament.

title: Rebels Vow to Keep Up Fight for Political Change in Sudan
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Rebels in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan, where armed conflict is inflaming tensions between the government and the newly independent Republic of South Sudan, are not only preparing for a protracted war in the region but also vowing to take the fight nationwide to pursue political change in Sudan.

title: Red Eyes
description: A selection of photographs, illustrations and posters from regional productions of the play Red.

title: Lucrative Package for Outgoing Bank of New York Mellon Chief
description: Robert P. Kelly stands to collect tens of millions of dollars on his way out as chief of Bank of New York Mellon, a figure unlikely to be dented by a successful shareholder initiative last year that sought to limit executive severance at the company.

title: All Leaked U.S. Cables Were Made Available Online as WikiLeaks Splintered
description: Updated | 5:12 p.m. A WikiLeaks computer file that allows anyone to read every word of 251,287 leaked United States diplomatic cables by typing a password made public six months ago was posted online by mistake last year, potentially endangering human rights activists and other sources who spoke to American officials in confidence.

description: In this weeks Popcast, two young pop acts stop by The Times to talk about new records, new identities and homeless guitar gods.

title: At World Championships, United States Wins Gold in Unexpected Places
description: DAEGU, South Korea  The good news came tightly packed for the Americans on Thursday night, each celebration adding another layer of gold, another layer of human interest.

title: Franken Pursues Tighter Oversight of Rating Agencies
description: The Dodd-Frank Act cracked down on the credit rating agencies, the firms that awarded rosy ratings to bonds backed by junky mortgages, but some lawmakers and consumer advocates contend that the regulatory overhaul falls short.

title: Works by Otto Dix Said to be Discovered in Germany
description: The owners of a German art gallery say they have uncovered works by the Expressionist painter Otto Dix  three watercolors and a study for a portrait  at a Bavarian estate, Reuters reported. Two of the paintings are titled Naechtens and Soubrette while the third, Strich III, shows a street-scene with prostitutes; the fourth is a study for a 1926 portrait of the art dealer Alfred Flechtheim, Reuters said. The works date from 1922 to 1925. The gallery owners, Herbert Remmert and Peter Barth, identified the works at an estate owned by the daughter and granddaughter of Hans and Martha Koch, the news agency said. Hans Koch was a doctor and art collector; Martha Koch left him for Dix and later married the artist. The gallery has collaborated in the past with the family in searching for works at the estate, Reuters said.

title: Federer Dispatches Sela in Three Sets
description: Third-seeded Roger Federer of Switzerland steamrolled his way into the third round at the 2011 U.S. Open with a thumping, 6-3, 6-2, 6-2 victory over 93rd-ranked Dudi Sela of Israel.

title: Poetry Pairing | Crystalline Weather
description: To honor the coming 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, this weeks Poetry Pairing couples Kenneth Goldsmiths Metropolitan Forecast with an article from November 2001, Weather Wont Give New York What the Calendar Says Is Here.

title: Christopher Bailey on Burberry Body
description: Christopher Bailey discusses Burberry Body, the brands latest fragrance for women.

title: Who Made That Moka Express?
description: In 1933, when Alfonso Bialetti introduced the Moka Express, Italys economy wasnt doing much better than it is today. The Great Depression was in full swing, major banks were failing, unemployment was rampant and Italians were forced to curtail their spending. Like those of us who have limited our trips to Starbucks since the start of the current recession, the Italians of the early 1930s were easing up on their trips to the cafe. The Moka Express, a stovetop espresso machine that was meant for the home, provided both an affordable espresso and a beautiful object to make it in.

title: Bearing the Brunt of the New Mortgage Cap
description: The pending end of federal guarantees for pricey mortgages will probably have the greatest effect on borrowers in counties in just a few states, an analysis by the real estate site Zillow finds.

title: Libyas Supporters Gather in Paris to Help Ease New Governments Transition
description: PARIS  With Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi effectively overthrown, representatives of some 60 nations gathered here Thursday to help the new Libyan authorities navigate a fraught transition and restore stability and a functioning economy to a country ravaged by rebellion and 42 years of dictatorship. The specter of the quagmire of Iraq kept the tenor of the day hopeful but cautious.

title: U.S. Open Replay: Day 4
description: The fourth day of play at the U.S. Open saw most top players hold seed.

title: In Flap Over Obama Speech, a Clear Winner
description: While the political world ponders the ultimate loser in Wednesdays back-and-forth between the White House and the speakers office over when President Obama could deliver his jobs speech, the real winner may be the NBC News/Politico debate itself.

title: The Minimalist: Grilled Lamb on Rosemary Skewers
description: The new Minimalist videos will return next week. For now, heres one from 2008 with an elegantly casual recipe for lamb and figs grilled on rosemary skewers.

title: Teaching 9/11 | Responding to Crisis With Students
description: Perhaps you are seeking a way to help students feel connected to 9/11. Or perhaps your school is having its own difficult moment and you want to find creative, meaningful ways to respond as a community. Either way, we hope you will find this post useful.

title: Signatures of a Bohemian Past
description: Delving into the history of over 200 signatures, scrawled on an old Greenwich Village bookshop door.

title: A Portal to 1920s Greenwich Village
description: Three years ago, a most unusual artifact resurfaced in a storage space of the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin. It was a narrow pine door, edged in bright blue paint and covered with some 242 signatures, many of them smudged or adorned with elaborate doodles. It turned out to be from Frank Shays bookstore, a popular Greenwich Village establishment that opened for business at 4 Christopher Street in 1920. It was removed by the manager when the shop closed in 1925 and bought by the Ransom Center in 1960, after a dealer spotted an ad in the Saturday Review asking, Want a door?

title: Skype Now Wants Your Landline
description: Skype, best known for providing phone calls over the Internet via PCs and the smartphones, now wants your landline too.

title: Glory Fades Quickly for First Round Upsets
description: 3:39 p.m. | Updated  Simona Halep (ouster of No. 6 Li Na in the first round), further worsened the second round record (now 1-8) of players who pulled off major first round upsets at the U.S. Open recently, falling to 76th-ranked Carla Suarez Navarro in three sets Thursday.

title: In Japan, a Tenuous Vow to Cut
description: TOKYO  As Japans fiscally conservative finance minister, Yoshihiko Noda long sounded the alarm on the nations ballooning government debt. It is more than twice the size of its $5 trillion economy  and rated more risky than that of Italy and Spain.

title: Another Departure From Huntsmans Camp
description: A bit of news from Jon M. Huntsman Jr.s presidential campaign is once again focusing attention not on the candidate, but on his staff.

title: No Slack for Obamas Uncle
description: President Obamas uncle wont be getting any slack from federal law enforcement authorities, White House officials said Thursday.

title: Cantor, Irene, and Interest Rates
description: Im not big on the favorite Beltway gotcha, which takes the form of you once said A, now you say B, so how can you explain that, huh? As I see it, its all too often a substitute for actually talking about substance. Never mind what somebody said in 2004, or 1994, since circumstances are rarely identical and views change; the thing is to ask whether what they say now makes sense and is ethically acceptable.

title: Yankees Welcome Montero to the Majors
description: 8:35 p.m. | Updated BOSTON  Jesus Montero made his long-awaited major league debut Thursday night, and what better site than Fenway Park, with his parents and girlfriend watching from the stands.

title: Neighborhood Joint | The Infinity Boutique
description: A shop at Madison Avenue and 83rd Street caters to the fashion tastes of a demographic between childhood and full-blown adolescence.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kenya, Libya, England and Russia.

title: Late September Debate Highlights Floridas Importance
description: September is the month of Republican presidential debates, with three planned starting with next Wednesdays face-off at the Reagan Library in Simi Valley, Calif. And on Thursday, Fox News released details of the debate it is sponsoring with Google on Sept. 22.

title: For Fashionistas Who Still Love Barbie Dolls
description: IT seems increasingly unlikely that I will marry Brad Pitt. But there was a time when I would sneak into my cool older cousin Margarets room, flop down on her bed with a pilfered copy of Sassy magazine and dream of the day when I could copy her funky accessories and cut-up tops and  armed with my new unmistakable cool  convince the dreamy star that I was his one true love.

title: TimesCast | September 01, 2011
description: A Syrian official details the bloody crackdown in Hama; Iran moves its nuclear operation underground; and Nicolas D. Kristof speaks with Libyans about NATO's bombing campaign.

title: Meet Tony Montana, Role Model
description: Willingly or not, we may be living in a Scarface world. The 1983 film, directed by Brian De Palma and starring Al Pacino as a Miami drug kingpin with an imitable Cuban accent, has spawned a book, Scarface Nation; a documentary, Cocaine Cowboys; a penthouse worth of novelty merchandise, from T-shirts to machine gun lamps; countless rap references; and even vocabulary  Scarfacian (adj.), defined as a certain epic, over-the-top, coked-up and profane sense of invincibility.

title: On Fishing as a Path to Caring About Fish
description: As I mentioned recently, while camping in Montauk, N.Y., earlier last month, I broke away with my younger son, Jack, and three of his friends to head offshore with Carl Safina, the marine conservationist and author, for a half-day fishing expedition. (Safina is also a masterful angler.)

title: Unemployed, and Wanting to Be Younger
description: Just ahead of the monthly jobs report on Friday, the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development has released its latest update on the wave of unemployed workers it has been following for two years now.

title: Summer Styles | White Shirt Alert
description: The white shirt is a summer staple  but as far as we know there are no rules about wearing one after Labor Day. In fact, a white shirt is the perfect transitional piece. It plays up whats left of your tan and plays nice with the pieces youve been itching to bust out for fall. Here, the actress Evan Rachel Wood offsets a shrunken jacket and tight pants with a generous swath of neo-Victorian ruffles; the Bollywood star Sonam Kapoor goes for pleats in a big way; and Alexa Chung, star of the forthcoming PBS series Thrift America, is no slouch in a boyfriend button-down.

title: Galaxy of Music (Personal Note)
description: As regular readers will have noticed, Im putting a lot of indie music on this blog to lighten things up. Wheres that coming from? A little bit from a discovery, a little bit from technology.

title: City to Release Documents in Police Shootings, Dropping Its Appeal
description: Another, and seemingly final, turn has come in the ongoing effort to unlock 13 years of data on shootings by New York City police officers: the city has withdrawn its appeal of a judges order that the Police Department turn over to the New York Civil Liberties Union the internal reports it generates whenever an officer fires at a civilian.

title: Merrily, Merrily Merrily, Merrily
description: MAYBE its just nostalgia: fond memories of going rowing with my father on Saturday mornings in Prospect Park and, when I outgrew the lake there, in Jamaica Bay from Canarsie Pier. Maybe its because at Cornell I was too short for heavyweight crew and too heavy for lightweight crew. Maybe its more metaphysical, that I savor stability and also tend to chart what lies ahead by watching the horizon and observing what was left behind. Or lets face it, maybe its completely corporeal: Im an unreconstructed klutz with a history of falling out of kayaks and canoes.

title: World Athletics Championships Replay: Day 6
description: Images from Day 6 of the track and field world championships in Daegu, South Korea.

title: In a Blackout, Nissan, Mitsubishi and Toyota E.V.s Could Function as Generators
description: Once the province of home hobbyists and a few academics, vehicle-to-grid charging, or V2G, is gaining momentum. When appropriately equipped, a plug-in hybrid or purely electric vehicle can operate like a generator on wheels, powering a house in a blackout or feeding electricity to the grid.

title: The Theme Parties That Inspired an Orgy
description: In the comedy A Good Old Fashioned Orgy,  Jason Sudeikis stars as a man who throws elaborate theme parties at the Long Island family home where he spends his summers. When he gets the news that his father is selling the house, he decides to throw the ultimate party, for which the film is named.

title: Renaissance Defies August Doldrums
description: Renaissance Technologies, the $19 billion hedge fund whose cadre of science and math Ph.D.s deploys complex computer trading strategies, has flourished amid the bloodletting of August.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Sept. 2-8
description: NEW YORK CITY UNICYCLE FESTIVAL

title: Grasping the Secrets of Being an Adult
description: Dusk seems to be descending forever on the boys at the center of We the Animals, a slender but affecting debut novel by Justin Torres. As porch lights go on, and the other kids shamble home to chores and homework, the unnamed narrator and his brothers prowl the blighted streets of their rural hometown in upstate New York like stray dogs sniffing out their next meal or a new bit of trouble. At home the rising of the moon brings a mothers absence  she works the night shift at the brewery  and a fathers frustration, which is relieved only by violence inflicted on whoever is at hand.

title: Clip: Love Crime
description: A scene from the thriller "Love Crime," starring Ludivine Sagnier and Kristin Scott Thomas.

description: LABOR DAY WEEKEND

description: Movies

title: Puck Building Subtractions Are Temporary  But, Oh, That Addition
description: The missing crenelations atop the Puck Building will be replaced. The owners are planning something bigger.

title: Serena Williams Cruises to Third Round
description: It doesnt seem that Serena Williams will be stopped any time soon. It certainly never appeared possible in any point during the three-time U.S. Open champions effortless 6-0, 6-1 second-round victory over 183rd-ranked Michaella Krajicek, a win that improved her 2011 hard court record to 14-0.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Sept. 2-8
description: Pop

title: 36 Hours on the Mendocino Coast
description: Once a collection of working-class logging, fishing and ranching communities, the city has become a stand-in for Californias left-coast eccentricities.

title: Everything You Want to Know About Food but Dont Know Who to Ask
description: The Oct. 2 issue of The Times Magazine will be devoted to food and drink. As with our health issue from last spring, it will be organized around a series of questions. Weve already assigned writersto pursue dozens of answers that we think youll want to know, but we would love to hear directly from you. What are the burning questions you have about food? Is there something youve always wanted to ask Michael Pollan? What tips and tricks do you want to know from Mark Bittman? How about dining advice from Sam Sifton? What food-related dilemma would you like the Ethicist to render a verdict on?

title: When a Bankruptcy Event Doesnt Mean Bankruptcy
description: In finance and law, bankruptcy is understood to mean a process for resolving financial distress, like those under the United States Bankruptcy Code or the Companies Creditors Arrangement Act in Canada. State law assignments for the benefit of creditors could also been seen as a bankruptcy process under this definition.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 2-8
description: Jazz

title: 36 Hours on the Mendocino Coast
description: SINCE the 60s and 70s, when a flood of artists, hippies and back-to-the-landers brought the cosmopolitan counterculture to this corner of Northern California, the Mendocino coast has made appearances on too many television shows (Murder, She Wrote, most notably) and movies (Overboard, for one) to mention. Once a collection of working-class logging, fishing and ranching communities, the Coast  as its called by residents  has become a stand-in for Californias left-coast eccentricities. This series of hamlets, small towns and rural ridges is now widely known for its intoxicants  its celebrated wine, beer and marijuana. But what makes this stretch of oceanfront real estate so stirring is its profound natural beauty and fierce independence.

title: Eugene Giscombe
description: Mr. Giscombe, 71, is the founder, president and chief executive of the Giscombe Realty Group in Harlem. Among the companys holdings is the Lee Building on Park Avenue and 125th Street. Mr. Giscombe has been involved in several neighborhood groups, including the 125th Street Business Improvement District, and is the former chairman of Community Board 10.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Sept. 2-8
description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 2-8
description: Dance

title: Refinancing While Underwater
description: MANY whose homes have fallen in value feel stranded with underwater mortgages.

title: Starz to End Streaming Deal With Netflix
description: 8:20 p.m. | Updated The premium cable channel Starz said Thursday that it would not renew its closely watched distribution deal with Netflix, delivering the online streaming service a major, although not entirely unexpected, blow.

title: Harvard scholar Randall Kennedy, columnist Ginia Bellafante, Julie Bosman and Jennifer Schuessler. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
description: This week, Harvard scholar Randall Kennedy discusses racial politics in America in his new book, The Persistence of the Color Line; columnist Ginia Bellafante talks about the new book club shes starting at the Times; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 2  8
description: Theater

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Sept. 2-8
description: Art

title: Q & A
description: Landlord Holds Tight

title: Banks Push Greek Bailout Plan
description: LONDON  No bank likes to take a loss, especially those in Europe that already suffer from a toxic mix of thin capital, troubled financing and weak loan books.

title: Edible Selby | Chez Panisse Turns 40
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#168", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Tech Blogger to Invest in Start-Ups
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Michael Arrington, whose influential TechCrunch blog covers Silicon Valley, has started a venture capital fund to invest in start-ups, including some that he and his staff write about.

title: TimesCast | Syria's Crackdown Is Exposed
description: September 1, 2011  A senior Syrian official resigns online to protest President Bashar Al-Assads brutal crackdown.

title: What? Cant Hear You! Lets Move
description: DENNY SHEEHAN liked what he saw when he checked out the ground-floor one-bedroom in Cobble Hill on his lunch hour. The apartment, with a small extra room, was larger than others he had seen for a similar price, $2,050 a month. So, last summer, he and his girlfriend, Aime Scala, moved in.

title: Rentals Fly Off the Shelves
description: THE bidding wars are going on constantly in Summit and Short Hills, and other expensive suburbs. In Jersey City, units at two brand-new 50-story towers are being snapped up at the rate of more than 100 a month  even though prices are at the top of the scale.

title: A Grand-Scale Adventure Filled With Household Names You Dont Know
description: It seems that this summer has room for one more lavish, special-effects-laden action blockbuster, though you will not find it in wide release. In a utopian, borderless world without subtitles, the arrival of Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame would be a global multiplex event, and the work of its director, Tsui Hark, would be at least as well known among American seekers of cinematic thrills as that of Jerry Bruckheimer and Michael Bay. But make no mistake, while its footprint here may be small, there is nothing modest about this spectacle.

title: A New Start for an Ambitious Queens Condo Complex
description: FROM much of Flushing, Queens, it is hard to miss Sky View Parc: a pair of wide 17-story towers, in white stucco, that rise from a mall festooned with signs for Target, B Js Wholesale Club and Marshalls.The complex is almost as recognizable as another new neighborhood landmark  Citi Field, the Mets home, directly across the Van Wyck Expressway.

title: Five More Reports of Avastin Injections Causing Blindness
description: LOS ANGELES  Five more patients who were being treated with the drug Avastin for eye disease have been blinded, according to one of the patients and medical professionals.

title: The spat over President Obamas upcoming jobs speech, predictions about what the President will say and an assessment of the state of the Republican presidential field. Michael Shear of the Timess Caucus blog is the host.
description: The spat over President Obamas upcoming jobs speech, predictions about what the President will say and an assessment of the state of the Republican presidential field. Deputy Political Editor Gerry Mullany and Chief Political Correspondent Jeff Zeleny join the Caucus blogs Michael Shear.

title: An Architectural Barometer
description: THEY go up, they go down  and thats pretty much it for any New York building, maybe with one or two alterations.

title: An Embed High Above New York
description: They call them cowboys of the sky. This Sundays New York Times Magazine features a series of images by Damon Winter, who spent five days in July with the ironworkers who are rebuilding the Manhattan skyline atop 1 World Trade Center. On Thursday, the magazine published Mr. Winters photographs online in a slide show and an accompanying video, which also appears at the end of this post. They also wrote about the project on their blog, The 6th Floor.

title: A Bunch of Friends Who Want to Party Like Its 1979
description: A friendly, ramshackle comedy that is somewhat laugh-deficient, A Good Old Fashioned Orgy brings to mind Brave New World, Aldous Huxleys futuristic satire. The cheery maxim in Huxleys superficial paradise, which holds that everybody belongs to everyone else, is tested in A Good Old Fashioned Orgy and found to be true, sort of, vaguely, not really.

title: The Last Throes of Summer
description: Cursing Irene for blowing your second-to-last summer weekend? Dont pack up your sundresses and swim trunks just yet. Theres still time to kick away those fallen limbs, wipe that rain from your eyes and plunge once more into the (cheap) events that have made us lazy, hazy and crazy (in a good way) this summer.

title: Ad by Group Supporting Bachmann Assails Perry
description: 7:45 p.m. | Updated When Representative Michele Bachmann hits the campaign trail, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named.

title: Iran's Nuclear Underground
description: David Sanger, chief Washington correspondent, on Irans effort to move its nuclear operation underground and accelerate its enrichment of uranium.

title: The Aftershocks of an Adoption Long Ago, Felt by Everyone Involved
description: The psychological crosscurrents in the sober, empathetic French drama Im Glad My Mother Is Alive include potentially fatal riptides. The film tells the story of Thomas Jouvet (Vincent Rottiers), a man with a chip on his shoulder, who with his younger brother, Patrick, was given up for adoption by his birth mother. Years later Thomas, who was 5 at the time of the separation, tracks her down.

title: To Keep but Not Be Kept
description: ONE balmy evening in Shanghai, my boyfriend and I were strolling home from dinner when two boozy blond men called to us. Expecting a plea for directions, we stopped. The men leered at me and grinned at my boyfriend.

title: 2nd Russian Raid On BPs Offices
description: Russian officials disrupted operations at BPs Moscow office, occupying the premises for a second day, adding to the oil producers woes in the country.

title: A Ride With Head-Spinning Views
description: THE journey from an Ohio theme park to Brooklyn has been long and difficult for 48 wooden horses, who today are scheduled to trot, canter, leap  O.K., be wheeled  from the Dumbo studio of Jane Walentas, the artist who spent over 20 years overseeing their restoration, to their permanent home, a carousel in Brooklyn Bridge Park. It opens on Sept. 16 and will be called, naturally, Janes Carousel.

title: A Founding Father, Back on His Pedestal
description: Last week National Park Service staff members wrestled with a white marble bust of Alexander Hamilton. They managed to stabilize the weighty sculpture, which has a faint smile tugging at its cheeks, on a stone pedestal in the foyer at his house on West 141st Street and Hamilton Terrace in Manhattan. His head now overlooks roomfuls of copies of his early-19th-century furniture.

title: On Leaf Peeping and Quiet Meditation
description: If youre not quite feeling ready for September, seek out A Sensitivity to the Seasons: Summer and Autumn in Japanese Art, the latest installation in the Metropolitan Museums Sackler Wing Galleries for the Arts of Japan.

title: Diaphanously Draped in Yards of Art
description: As a work of art Carlito Carvalhosas Sum of Days, which fills the Museum of Modern Arts atrium, is as thin as the sheer white fabric it is mainly made of. Extending 60 feet from the ceiling to a few inches above the floor, more than 18,000 square feet of translucent, flyweight polyester forms a walk-in double spiral  one path leading into an open space in the center, another leading out. Air currents cause the curtains to billow gently so that visitors may have to push the cloth away as they progress.

title: A Sly Corporate Dance That Turns Into a Duel
description: At first glance, Love Crime  the last film directed by Alain Corneau, who died in 2010  looks like a corporate All About Eve in reverse. An innocent, eager young woman named Isabelle (Ludivine Sagnier) is manipulated and preyed upon by her mentor, Christine (Kristin Scott Thomas), a high-ranking executive whose affection seems to be an especially insidious form of sadism.

title: Keeping Industrial Plants Cool and Fish Alive
description: Its hard to fathom how one sentence has sparked nearly 40 years of heated controversy and relentless litigation. But when the sentence in question is part of the Clean Water Act and its application in practice has a potential price tag of $100 billion to some of the largest power plants in the country, its even harder to imagine how the issue will actually ever be resolved.

title: Sobras de la Mesa (Table Scraps)
description: In a previous post I wrote about food and eating in Oaxaca, Mexico. Here are a few final thoughts from the perspective of an American visitor.

title: House Tour: Shelter Island
description: A small but thoughtfully designed weekend home a block from the water on Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: House Tour: Shelter Island
description: WHAT Two-bedroom house.

title: Thank You, America
description: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof speaks with Tripolitans on the importance of U.S. and NATO military intervention in overthrowing President Qaddafi.

title: Speed and Spin: Nadals Lethal Forehand
description: Rafael Nadals forehand is a rare combination of speed and tremendous topspin, making it one of the most lethal weapons in tennis.

title: Remembering 9/11 With Bach and Brahms
description: IN the topography of 9/11 memory Trinity Church stands mighty.

title: Clintons Hunkered Down in East Hampton as Irene Passed By
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  Over the years, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bill Clinton have been occasional visitors to the serene, breezy corner of East Hampton where Lily Pond Lane meets Georgica Beach amid the bayberry and beach plum. Sometimes they were guests of Steven Spielberg. But this is the first time that neighbors had seen them not as casual day visitors but as householders.

title: For Fashionistas Who Still Love Barbie Dolls
description: It seems increasingly unlikely that I will marry Brad Pitt. But there was a time when I would sneak into my cool older cousin Margarets room, flop down on her bed with a pilfered copy of Sassy magazine and dream of the day when I could copy her funky accessories and cut-up tops and  armed with my new unmistakable cool  convince the dreamy star that I was his one true love.

title: Architect and 9/11 Memorial Both Evolved Over the Years
description: AFEW years ago the World Trade Center memorial was in trouble.

title: White House Expects Persistently High Unemployment
