description: The White House budget office forecast on Thursday that unemployment would remain at 9 percent through the 2012 presidential election year, an outlook that it said calls for the sort of the job-creating tax cuts and spending President Obama will propose next week.

title: Vera Zvonarevas Tales of Two Matches
description: Vera Zvonareva, the No. 2 seed in the womens draw at the United States Open, will be talking with Straight Sets about her experiences throughout the tournament. On Thursday afternoon, she spoke about her second-round match on Wednesday against Kateryna Bondarenko of Ukraine, which Zvonareva won 7-5, 3-6, 6-3. Zvonareva was an emotional presence in a hard-fought match, and at times was clearly unhappy with her racket. Here, her account of the match:

title: Errol Morris Looks for the Truth in Photography
description: One of the first things we learn in Believing Is Seeing is that its author, the filmmaker Errol Morris, has limited sight in one eye and lacks normal stereoscopic vision  My fault, he writes, for refusing to wear an eye patch after being treated for strabismus in childhood. Its hard to think of another writer who so neatly embodies the theme of his own book. Believing Is Seeing is about the limitations of vision, and about the inevitable idiosyncrasies and distortions involved in the act of looking  in particular, looking at photographs.

title: A Newcomers Auspicious Debut, Amid a More Eclectic Opera Scene
description: After the recent decision of New York City Opera to leave its Lincoln Center home for a floating life at theaters throughout the city, something feels freer about the opera scene here. The Metropolitan is now the only big game in town, leaving the role of the other company to be played not by City Opera alone but also by a host of small groups and pickup ensembles.

title: Its About the Music, Not the Disrobing
description: Taken at face value, the notion of mixing 18th-century English opera with striptease sounds like the set-up for an obvious wisecrack: It aint over till the  well, you figure it out. That being the case, perhaps the most remarkable thing about The Judgment of Paris, a scrappy but spirited pastiche presented by Morningside Opera at the East Village bar Jimmys No. 43 on Tuesday night, wasnt its informal setting or libidinous character but its serious foundation in rigorous musicology.

title: Rethinking the Modern
description: The Museum of Modern Art has revised galleries devoted to its collection of painting and sculpture.

title: Gun Raffle in Giffords District Prompts Democrats Outrage
description: Plans by the Republican Party in southern Arizona to raffle off the same brand of pistol used in the shooting of Representative Gabrielle Giffords has prompted outrage among Democrats.

title: Jobs Report Preview
description: On Friday morning, the Labor Department will release its first estimate for the number of jobs created in the United States in August, and right now expectations are low.

title: A Saturday Storm of Rumbling Racers and Dust Clouds
description: NEW EGYPT, N.J.

title: Fast Track
description: Images from the New Egypt Speedway in New Jersey.

title: Altidore Unvarnished, and Some U.S. Notes
description: Jozy Altidore has made a sparkling start to his first season in the Netherlands playing for AZ, scoring three of his teams 10 goals through four games in the Erevdivise.

title: Robert Duvall Is Back in the Saddle, Playing a Mentor to a Young Golfer
description: Face it: the image of a golfer sinking a putt conveys little of the visceral thrill of a batter slamming a home run or a boxer scoring a knockout punch. To pretend otherwise is to risk being accused of sports hubris, an attitude that the humorless, mystically fortified golfing movie Seven Days in Utopia embraces unashamedly.

title: Teenage Romance Blossoms, Twistedly
description: Perverts prowl and womens panties tremble in Love Exposure, a tangled, tumultuous love story from the teeming mind of Sion Sono.

title: In the Green Zone, Armed With a Bottle of Hot Sauce
description: The Mexican hit Saving Private Prez has a fairly irresistible and subversive comic premise. An ailing mother demands that her oldest son  a Tony Montana-like gangster identified as the most powerful man in Mexico  do what the United States Army cant: go to Iraq and rescue his younger brother, an American soldier being held captive by insurgents.

title: Study Suggests Higher Cancer Risk for 9/11 Firefighters
description: A new study says firefighters who toiled in the wreckage of the World Trade Center in 2001 were 19 percent more likely to develop cancer than those who were not there, the strongest evidence to date of a possible link between work at ground zero and cancer.

title: My Show-and-Tell from Libya
description: Im traveling with a videographer, Ben Solomon, here in Libya, and weve done several videos (with more coming!). Heres a peek at what weve done so far. First, this is a video essentially of how we reached Tripoli. People always think that covering places like Libya is glamorous; it actually consists mostly of long, boring flights followed by long, boring car rides and a few sweaty moments. Then you reach your destination (e.g. Tripoli) and find a hotel that is jam-packed so you have to share a room with no running water; the hotel restaurant isnt functioning, so youre surviving on peanut butter.But Im getting ahead of myself. See a video of our trip in

title: Decoding the Puzzling Messages of a Recluse
description: Unearthed secrets of an eccentric recluse can be fascinating, the darker and more perverse, the better. Consider Howard Hughes or the outsider artist Henry Darger, whose trove of writings and paintings, discovered posthumously in Chicago in 1973, set off years of speculation regarding his psychological history, which hasnt abated.

title: A Hikers Plight: How to Help When Water Runs Low
description: PHOENIX  With their packs full, their canteens overflowing and their reserve bottles filled to the brim, outdoorsy Arizonans set out on foot this time of year under the scorching sun. But as they navigate the states picturesque trails, they face not only physical challenges but ethical ones, like how much water to share with strangers who have miles to go and not a drop to drink.

title: Haitian Divers Hope to Aid Ailing Reef
description: CTES DES ARCADINS, Haiti  It was an immaculately clear midsummer morning, a perfect day for diving. No trash had yet washed up on the beach. A dozen volunteers, all excited, some a bit apprehensive, donned flippers and masks and shimmied into the bathtub-warm sea, eager to join a team of eco-divers responsible for surveying, and perhaps one day helping save, Haitis endangered coral reefs.

title: Math = The Practical and the Beautiful
description: To the Editor:

title: Cinematic Collage of Sights and Sounds
description: Buttons, a collage of a movie, may not really be a movie at all, but its fun to watch, as long as you dont think too deeply about it.

title: Bono Praises Steve Jobs as Generous and Poetic
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish Overpowers Jaziri
description: Eighth-seeded Mardy Fish of the United States rolled into the third round of the U.S. Open with a convincing victory over Malek Jaziri of Tunisia, 6-2, 6-2, 6-4.

title: Scanning Eyes and Fingers in India
description: In India, workers are creating what will be the worlds largest biometric database, a collection of 1.2 billion identities.

title: Mickelson Is Turning to Belly Putter
description: NORTON, Mass.  Spectators on Friday afternoon at the first round of the Deutsche Bank Championship, the second of four events in the FedEx Cup playoffs, will get a chance to see at least one thing they have not seen before: Phil Mickelson using a belly putter.

title: A Haunting in the E.R.
description: Natalie Zeas somber glamour  a combination of earnestness, sad eyes and otherworldly cheekbones  just might be enough to hold your attention through InSight, a psychological-supernatural thriller thats light on thrills.

title: Marijuana and Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinic Rejects Immigrants After Impasse With Hospital
description: ATLANTA  After the collapse of negotiations between Atlantas public hospital and the worlds largest dialysis provider, a dozen immigrants suffering from renal failure were refused treatment at an Atlanta clinic on Thursday and advised to wait until their conditions deteriorated enough to justify life-saving care in an emergency room.

title: Verizons Tax Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: No Easy Answers for Those Who Share Williamss Disease
description: It often starts out as an uncomfortable feeling in the eyes and mouth. Patients say their eyes are dry and red, even though they are using eye drops. Often too, they say, their mouths are dry. Food is becoming tasteless. Some get swollen glands in their necks, making it look like they have mumps.

title: For Refugees, the Price of Dignity
description: Somalia is now suffering its worst drought in 60 years. A quarter of the population has fled famine and conflict, heading west into Kenya. More than 1,300 people a day stream into the complex of refugee camps at Dadaab, Kenya, which is now housing more than 430,000 people in camps designed for 90,000. Many Somalis arrive near death after journeys of weeks with little food. Large numbers of them are children, often without parents.At Dadaab they receive food, medical care, basic shelter  the emergency relief they need. But they will probably spend years in that desolate grid of white tents, eating gruel that gets thinner toward the end of the month. The camp lacks the money to provide even subsistence rations. In exchange, the refugees give up their rights to move freely and to work.

title: Purists Gone Wild
description: I reached for an Irish whiskey  two fingers, neat, as my uncle used to say in trying to teach me how to drink  just after finishing Last Call, Daniel Okrents haunting and entertaining book on Prohibition. The drink was necessary, in part, because his gallop through one of the most otherworldly episodes in American history made me shudder at the parallels to this age.

title: Bloomberg Hid Crucial Detail as Aide Resigned: An Arrest
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs management style has its hallmarks: unwavering loyalty to aides and a deep distaste for exposing private lives to public scrutiny.

title: Desormeaux Prevented From Riding After Arrest
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The Hall of Fame jockey Kent Desormeaux was not permitted to ride at Saratoga Race Course on Thursday afternoon, one day after he was arrested and charged with reckless endangerment.

title: A Little Give in the Dress Code
description: As more and more schools adopt dress codes, back-to-school shopping is often a rather dull exercise. Polo shirts. Khaki pants. Plaid skirts. As the students might say, bo-ring.

title: Greens Gain in Germany, and the World Takes Notice
description: BERLIN  A string of Green Party victories and strong electoral showings across Germany, from the conservative south to the port cities of the north, are helping to redefine politics among voters who are increasingly losing faith in the more established parties.

title: Oh, Grow Up
description: Whenever we think Washington couldnt get more cynical or more craven, it proves us wrong. So we will resist the temptation to say its hard to imagine anything more base than the food fight over President Obamas planned speech to Congress.

title: T-Mobile May Suffer if AT&T Deal Fails
description: When AT&T agreed to buy T-Mobile USA in March, the deal looked like a happy fate for a company that had been losing customers and facing declining sales.

title: Return to Hydrate Ridge
description: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from off the coast of Oregon, where he is studying life around deep ocean vents.

title: In Libya, Former Enemy Is Recast in Role of Ally
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Abdel Hakim Belhaj had a wry smile about the oddity of his situation.

title: Justice Dept.s Top Officials in Pursuing the AT&T Lawsuit
description: The names of 25 government lawyers are listed on the last page of the Justice Departments lawsuit seeking to block the proposed $39 billion merger between AT&T and T-Mobile USA.

title: Hockey Players Deaths Pose a Tragic Riddle
description: Three N.H.L. players, all enforcers entrusted with protecting teammates through intimidation and the occasional flurry of fists, have been found dead since May, stirring debate over the role of fighting in hockey, the stress placed on enforcers and the possible impact of brain trauma on the men who absorb the sports biggest beatings.

title: Stormy Weather for a Utility Merger
description: Hurricane Irene may not have done much damage on Wall Street. But she ought to blow one deal off course: the $4.2 billion merger of the electric companies Northeast Utilities and NStar. Huge blackouts after the storm have exposed Northeast Utilities deficiencies in serving customers despite charging some of Americas highest rates. Regulators should take a critical look before approving the deal.

title: Natures Stimulus Package
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Governor of Vermont, a Crash Course in Disaster Management
description: PITTSFIELD, Vt.  After helicoptering into this flood-ravaged town and delivering a pep talk to residents who had been stranded for three days and counting, Gov. Peter Shumlin asked if anyone had questions for him. It took a minute for anyone to speak up, and even then, the queries were polite to the point of apologetic.

title: Different Leaders, Different Approaches
description: Here is how some governors in the East handled Hurricane Irene.

title: Epstein or Cashman Moving on? Not Likely
description: BOSTON

title: The Confederate of the Sierra Madre
description: Jos Quinteros reputation was soaring upon his return to Richmond in mid-August 1861. He had travelled the width of the Confederacy to deliver the rarest of gifts for the Southern capital: much better than a fine box of cigars, the Cuban-born Southern special agent brought good news from Mexico.

title: The Vigorous Virtues
description: Theres a specter haunting American politics: national decline. Is America on the way down, and, if so, what can be done about it?

title: Beauty Might Not Be Blind, but the Casting Call Was
description: ARE you just another pretty face? Or are you truly beautiful? A new campaign from the mineral cosmetics company Bare Escentuals hopes women will realize that the former is not enough.

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 1, 2011
description: Libyan rebels waited on the road between Misurata and Surt for the Saturday deadline for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his fighters to surrender to expire.

title: Aerial View of Beaches Shows More Danger Than Damage
description: Its doors opened wide and the wind whipping, a Black Hawk helicopter swooped low alongside the carnival rides in Coney Island on Thursday. Then it cut across the Rockaways and hugged the shoreline heading east.

title: Eric and Irene
description: Have you left no sense of decency? Thats the question Joseph Welch famously asked Joseph McCarthy, as the red-baiting demagogue tried to ruin yet another innocent citizen. And these days, its the question I find myself wanting to ask Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, who has done more than anyone else to make policy blackmail  using innocent Americans as hostages  standard operating procedure for the G.O.P.

title: Lottery Numbers
Manor That Has Stood for Centuries Teeters in Storms Wake
description: AMSTERDAM, N.Y.  Ann Peconie pressed her face close to the shattered glass windows of the Guy Park Manor.

title: Plan to Create Jobs Is a Balancing Act for the President
description: WASHINGTON  Anticipation of President Obamas plan for creating jobs while cutting deficits, now heightened by the scheduling controversy over his prime time address to Congress next Thursday, has turned on a question: Will he go big and highlight his sharp differences with Republicans, or will he be pragmatic and downsize his ideas to get Republican votes?

title: Port Jervis Train Line Will Take Months to Repair
description: The 2,300 weekday commuters on the Metro-North Railroads Port Jervis line through the mountains and lush valleys of Orange and Rockland Counties compare the line to a small-town community. On homeward rides that can last more than two hours, they sit together as if they are at a town meeting, catching up on gossip, sharing their latest vacation photos and planning their annual on-train holiday reception. And they still seem to be awed by the views.

title: Argentinas Turnaround Tango
description: Buenos Aires

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,740 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: Stefan Edberg
description: George Vecsey explains how Stefan Edberg could defeat Roger Federer in a hypothetical U.S. Open match.

title: Dr. William Wolff, Colonoscopy Co-Developer, Dies at 94
description: Dr. William I. Wolff, who with a colleague revolutionized the diagnosis and treatment of colon cancer by developing the colonoscopy as the procedure is practiced today, died on Aug. 20 at his home in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: Roger Federer
description: Gerry Marzorati explains why Roger Federer was a great U.S. Open champion and how he could defeat Stefan Edberg in a hypothetical Open match.

title: Political Repression 2.0
description: Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Rebels Yank Open Gates of Infamous Libyan Prison, Seeking Clues to a Massacre
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The liberators of Abu Salim prison came swinging sledgehammers. The inmates flashed victory signs, locks fell, a crowd cheered and the doors swung open.

title: Defendants Plea Bargain Leads to Buyers Remorse
description: As one might imagine, agreeing to go to prison is a decision a person might easily balk at.

title: Feldman, Embattled Writer, Leaves ESPN for CBS
description: For six weeks, Bruce Feldman had been silent about the outsize Twitter reaction that followed his one-day benching by ESPN over the book he wrote with the former Texas Tech football coach Mike Leach.

title: In Parks and on Streets, a Toll of Thousands of Trees
description: While New York City may have dodged a bullet from Tropical Storm Irene, its trees did not. From shade trees on side streets in Elmhurst, Queens, to towering tulip trees in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, many toppled, snapped or splintered.

title: Bare Escentuals Advertisement
description: The companys new campaign says, Be a force of beauty.

title: Gravenstein Apples Struggle to Survive in Sonoma County
description: SEBASTOPOL, Calif.  It would be almost impossible to visit this town, in the heart of Sonoma County, and miss the Gravenstein, the sweetly tart (or tartly sweet) apple whose name suggests a Transylvanian undertaker. The Gravenstein is harvested in August and often gone by Labor Day, and its name emblazons a local highway, a couple of schools, a town shopping center and an annual festival that draws thousands of visitors  and apple-a-day acolytes  to this mellow Bay Area getaway.

title: Friday: Fresh Air
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Take a deep breath, everyone  its Friday.

title: Protecting Innovation and Competition
description: After a decade-long merger spree in which AT&T and Verizon amassed more than 60 percent of the nations cellphone subscribers, the Justice Department was right to call a halt to the consolidation process, filing an antitrust suit on Wednesday to block AT&Ts $39 billion attempt to buy the nations fourth-largest carrier, T-Mobile.

title: U.S. Is Set to Sue a Dozen Big Banks Over Mortgages
description: The federal agency that oversees the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is set to file suits against more than a dozen big banks, accusing them of misrepresenting the quality of mortgage securities they assembled and sold at the height of the housing bubble, and seeking billions of dollars in compensation.

title: Mets Seeking Small Ball Investors
description: Now that the Mets are no longer planning to sell a $200 million share of the team to David Einhorn, their owners are dusting off Plan B: selling smaller stakes to people willing to invest perhaps $20 million each.

title: Driver in Deadly Bus Crash Knew He Was Dangerously Tired, Prosecutor Says
description: When Ophadell Williams climbed behind the wheel of a bus to drive to New York City from a Connecticut casino, prosecutors said on Thursday, he knew that he lacked a valid drivers license and enough sleep.

title: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Roger Federer vs. Stefan Edberg
description: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? Its up to you to decide, with a little help from The Timess tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will advance to the next round of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

title: Power Out to Hundreds of Thousands Around New York
description: House by house and block by block, power was steadily restored on Thursday to parts of the New York City area that had lost electricity because of Tropical Storm Irene.

title: Ruin and Hope on Haitis Reefs
description: Volunteers from Port-au-Prince begin training for a team of eco-divers that will be responsible for surveying, and perhaps one day helping save, Haiti's endangered coral reefs.

title: Mars Rover Discovery Elates NASA
description: It has been driving on and off for more than seven years, but now it has reached its new destination. Opportunity, a small exploratory rover that landed on Mars in 2004, has trundled to a crater called Endeavour.

title: In House Race, Democrat Is Far Ahead in Fund-Raising
description: The Democratic candidate running in the special election to replace former Representative Anthony D. Weiner has raised more than twice as much as his Republican opponent, according to campaign finance filings made public on Thursday.

title: His Fathers Name, His Own Success
description: TAMPA, Fla.  After his first day of kindergarten, Skip Holtz returned home and told his parents the teacher never called his name. He mentioned there was another boy in the class named Holtz, with the first name of Louis. He wasnt there, he said, but Im looking forward to meeting him.

title: Consumer Advocates Withdraw From Talks on Improving the Safety of Window Blinds
description: Four consumer advocates said that they would no longer participate in discussions by a task force that was intended to draft new guidelines to make window blinds safer for children.

title: Sloane Stephens, Another Rising American
description: After Sloane Stephens upended Shahar Peer, the 23rd seed,on Thursday, Stephens seemed less enthused with advancing to the third round and more excited about the car she planned to buy when she returned home to California.

title: Reverie in Yellow
description: Most New Yorkers depend on public transportation. And when it is suspended  as it was during Hurricane Irene  we realize just how much we need it. But there are times when, if you can afford it, only a taxi will do. You raise your arm, a cab pulls over, and off you go. Sometimes it occurs to you that if you raised an arm at the curb on most of the streets in America, nothing would happen. Someone might wave, but thats about it. Sometimes you realize that in most of America, two adults in a car almost never ride one in front, one in back.

title: Holtz Sees the Good in College Sports
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Dont tell Skip Holtz that college athletics is broken and cant be fixed. Holtz, whom I wrote about in advance of South Floridas game Saturday in South Bend, Ind., walked on at Notre Dame to play football, and he continues to regard college sports much as he did then: as a privilege that affords the lucky few an opportunity to compete and be part of something bigger than themselves.

title: At Columbia, Faith of Some in President Is Shaken
description: Several Columbia University professors said this week that the recent resignations of two high-ranking black administrators have shaken their confidence in the institutions president, Lee C. Bollinger, and reignited concerns among their colleagues about other aspects of his leadership.

title: Holiday on Monday Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: G.O.P. vs. Obama: Disrespect or Just Politics?
description: WASHINGTON  American presidents often have highly disagreeable relationships with members of Congress from the opposing party.

title: Jets and Eagles Hit by Quarterback Injuries
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets and the Eagles can only hope that their regular-season meeting in Philadelphia on Dec. 18 will bear no resemblance to their preseason finale Thursday night at MetLife Stadium. If it does, then Michael Vick and Mark Sanchez have much to worry about.

title: Giants Pluck Cornerback From His Living Room
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  When Giants cornerback Terrell Thomas sustained a season-ending knee injury against the Chicago Bears last month, it did not take long for the teams front office to fall into a familiar routine.

title: A Vital Liberty
description: In an important decision last week, a federal appeals court affirmed that the First Amendment protects the right to videotape the activities of police officers in public. When three officers arrested a man in Boston Common one evening in 2007, a bystander named Simon Glik, concerned that the officers were using excessive force, pulled out his cellphone and made an audio and video recording of the arrest. Unhappy about being recorded, one officer handcuffed and arrested Mr. Glik, too. He was charged with wiretapping, along with other crimes.

title: Scanning 2.4 Billion Eyes, India Tries to Connect Poor to Growth
description: KALDARI, India  Ankaji Bhai Gangar, a 49-year-old subsistence farmer, stood in line in this remote village until, for the first time in his life, he squinted into the soft glow of a computer screen.

title: Two Mets Debuts: A First Start and a First Day
description: The Mets 7-5 win over the Florida Marlins on Thursday night marked the franchise debuts of sorts for two players with disparate paths in baseball but intriguing backgrounds away from the game.

title: Traveling Far and Wide to Treat the Players Aches
description: It was the third day of the United States Open qualifying tournament and Elaine Brady was already sipping an afternoon coffee during a rare break from the training room, where many of the 128 qualifiers had been filing in and out. The Open was just beginning, but Bradys hectic schedule was already forcing her to rely on a caffeinated boost.

title: Ronald Fernandez, Scholar on Plight of Puerto Ricans, Dies at 67
description: Ronald Fernandez, a professor of sociology whose curiosity about a daring $7 million armored car robbery near his Connecticut home set him on a career path of scholarly investigation into the history of American colonialism in Puerto Rico, died on Tuesday in West Hartford. He was 67.

title: Scrutinizing Perrys Extensive Execution Record
description: As Gov. Rick Perry touts his tough-on-crime policies on the national political stage, the case of Cameron Todd Willingham will continue to be scrutinized. Scientists have raised questions about whether Mr. Willingham set the blaze that killed his three daughters and led to his 2004 execution.

title: Bogomolovs Resiliency on Display at Open
description: Theres a stereotype of tennis  fair or not  that it is a gentlemens sport. The players, like the game itself, are supposed to be polite and mild-mannered individuals with affluent backgrounds.Alex Bogomolov is not like that. And he knows it.

title: Spread of Leaked Cables on Web Prompts Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  All 251,287 diplomatic cables obtained by WikiLeaks last year are now accessible in multiple locations on the Internet, a development that touched off a dispute on Thursday between the group and the British newspaper The Guardian about who was responsible for their release.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Doggett vs. G.O.P. And a Democrat as Well
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Same Top Ranking, but Worlds Apart
description: Late Thursday, Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark and Novak Djokovic of Serbia shared twin billing in the night session at the United States Open. Both took the court in the second round at Arthur Ashe Stadium seeded first and ranked No. 1 in the world.

title: For Disabled, Cuts Could Affect Lifelong Improvement
description: For Milla Powell, a 12-year-old from Austin with cerebral palsy, the little things make all the difference. Massage therapy to ease her tightened muscles. Recreational programs, in which therapists take her into the community to help her build her social skills. Music therapy to help Milla, who cannot speak, connect without words.

title: Cable Implicates Americans in Deaths of Iraqi Civilians
description: A recently disclosed diplomatic cable shows that a top United Nations human rights official warned the United States government five years ago that he had received information indicating that Iraqi reports of American troops executing a family were true.

title: Burnett Pitches Better, and Rally Beats Red Sox
description: BOSTON  Through all of A. J. Burnetts recent failings, the Yankees have supported their struggling pitcher. They took a lot of criticism for allowing Burnett to continue to start, but on Thursday night Burnett finally rewarded them for their faith.

title: Arrest of Pair Adds to Woes of Berlusconi
description: ROME  An Italian businessman and his wife were arrested Thursday, accused by Naples prosecutors of extorting money and favors from Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in return for what prosecutors described as cooperation in an investigation into a high-end prostitution ring in the southern city of Bari.

title: City Is Subpoenaed for Files on Minority Company
description: Federal investigators, who long have found corruption in City Halls minority-contracting efforts, have subpoenaed the citys files on a construction company that was paid at least $26 million in taxpayer money in the past decade.

title: TIF Report Cheers Reformers, but Only as a Start
description: The king of Chicagos public-policy nerds, Representative Mike Quigley, a Democrat, basked in the hype surrounding this weeks release of a report from Mayor Rahm Emanuels TIF Reform Panel.

title: Word of the Day | myopic
description: myopic \mi-o-pe-\ adjective

title: Emanuel Puts His Stamp on a Daley Tradition
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Commissioners Big Ten, Rich and Tarnished
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: NYT Front Page for 09/02/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/02/11

title: A Haunting Old Photographic Process Reappears
description: David Bornfriend, a San Francisco-based photographer and filmmaker, began researching wet-plate collodion, a format made famous during the Civil War by battlefield photographers, after his brother returned home from serving in the Middle East in 2007 with post-traumatic stress disorder.

title: France: Reporters Phone Records Were Reviewed, Government Says
description: Interior Minister Claude Guant confirmed Thursday for the first time that the Central Directorate of Interior Intelligence had requisitioned the telephone records of a reporter for the newspaper Le Monde in an effort to trace the source of a leak in a politically charged case. The reporter, Grard Davet, had obtained leaked police testimony in the case, a tangled controversy over claims of tax evasion and political malfeasance involving the LOral heiress Liliane Bettencourt, Frances wealthiest woman and a supporter of President Nicolas Sarkozys political party. Le Monde last year accused the government of violating a law protecting journalists during its investigation of the Bettencourt case. French laws protect the right of journalists to refuse to disclose the identity of confidential sources, and restrict communications surveillance to matters involving the defense of national interests. The government has said that any surveillance it employed in the Bettencourt case met that standard. Mr. Guant said the government did not wiretap Mr. Davets telephone but did review his telephone records.

title: A Small Iron Squatter Whos Soon to Be Evicted
description: When construction workers begin taking apart the old Bay Bridge, they will have to contend with a squatter.

title: A New Plan for Public Toilets Shows Promise
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Tech Industry Becomes a Force in Local Politics
description: Last spring, in an effort to spur economic growth in San Francisco, Mayor Edwin M. Lee and David Chiu, president of the Board of Supervisors, engineered legislation to waive millions of dollars in taxes for technology companies like Twitter and Zynga.

title: PGA Tour and Networks Reach Lengthy Rights Deal
description: NORTON, Mass.  The PGA Tour said Thursday that it had reached an agreement with CBS Sports and the NBC Sports Group that secured the tours network broadcast rights into the next decade.

title: Highway Bill Could Face Congressional Gridlock
description: Here we go again?

title: With the Yankees in Town, Its Always a Boston Marathon
description: BOSTON  A weary Terry Francona slumped into his seat at the postgame news conference at Fenway Park, a few minutes before midnight on Thursday. Franconas Red Sox had just taken 4 hours 21 minutes to lose a nine-inning game, 4-2, to the Yankees.

title: Evert, Connors and the Significance of Sept. 2
description: Forty years ago Friday, Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors, two Americans who defined their era and helped create a tennis boom in the United States, won their first matches at the Open.

title: The North Dakota Paradox
description: North Dakota was barely dented by the recession. Its unemployment rate never rose above 4.3 percent and sits at 3.3 percent today.

title: Corrections: September 2
description: FRONT PAGE

title: News Quiz | September 2, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 2, 2011
description: Todays question was written by Susan Behrens, who is a professor at Marymount Manhattan College and the author of Grammar: A Pocket Guide. Her question comes from the article The Mets Next Blockbuster Is Expected to Stay for 10 Years.

title: Tormenting the Tenderfoots
description: WHO are being forced to wear schoolgirl backpacks to transport baseball gear?

title: What to Watch on Friday
description: On Wednesday, Christina McHale scored one of the biggest upsets of the tournament, ousting the No. 8 seed Marion Bartoli in straight sets. Things dont get any easier as the 19-year-old steps on court against the 25th-seeded Maria Kirilenko.

title: Sept. 2, 1945 | Japan Formally Surrenders to End World War II
description: On Sept. 2, 1945, Japan formally surrendered in a formal ceremony aboard the U.S.S. Missouri, ending World War II.

title: South Korean Police Detain Island Activists Opposed to Base
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The police on Friday detained nearly three dozen activists and villagers on the southern island of Jeju who have been camping for months to resist the construction of a naval base in their scenic seashore village.

title: Japan Leader to Keep Nuclear Phase-Out
description: TOKYO  Japans new prime minister, Yoshihiko Noda, promised on Friday to keep Japan on its path of phasing out nuclear power, saying it was unrealistic to build any new reactors in the wake of the Fukushima nuclear crisis or to extend those at the end of their life spans.

title: In Mexico, the Glamour of Narco-Culture
description: PERPIGNAN, France  Shaul Schwarz was among the first photographers to focus on documenting the drug wars that have ravaged the Mexican city of Jurez. Mr. Schwarz has been working in Jurez, a few yards from the border with the United States, since 2007. He cant get the story of a city so vicious and so close to home out of his system.

title: South Korea Will Allow a Buddhist Group to Visit the North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said Friday that it would allow a 37-member Buddhist delegation to visit North Korea, a sign that it might be ready to ease restrictions on civilian contacts with the North.

title: What Are the Right and Wrong Ways to Commemorate 9/11?
description: As the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, approaches, people, organizations and institutions are gearing up to commemorate it. The question is, how? Wheres the line between respectful remembrance and crass opportunism? When are tributes meaningful and when are they excessive?

title: Giants Clint Sintim Out for Year With Another Knee Injury
description: In a game in which one of the major goals was not to have someone get hurt, one of the Giants was hurt Thursday night.

title: The Psychology of the Comeback
description: Allen Fox coaches Igor Kunitsyn, a Russian journeyman who came back from two sets down to defeat Germanys Matthias Bachinger on Tuesday. (Kunitsyn plays Jurgen Melzer of Austria on Friday.) Fox is a former world-class player who has written Tennis: Winning the Mental Match, and other superb books on the psychology of tennis. He coached Pepperdine to the top of the college rankings, and passed on a lot of his coaching wisdom to Brad Gilbert, who credits Fox with helping him develop his game and his mental toughness.

title: 2011 N.F.L. Season Previews
description: A look, via links, of the N.F.L. season previews written by Andy Benoit for The Fifth Down. If youve missed them, the analysis and level of detail are impressive.

title: How a Chevy-Powered Boat Delivered Five Dutchmen From the Nazis
description: A new exhibition in the Netherlands commemorates the North Sea escape of five Dutchmen from Nazi occupation in 1944, a voyage made possible by Chevrolet power and a Hispano-Suiza racecars fuel tank.

title: What Does Economic Growth Mean for Americans?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Prague Towers Offer More Than Just Views
description: Prague has many nicknames, of of which are the City of 100 Spires and the Golden City. Experience both at a new exhibition on alchemy in the Malostranska Bridge Tower on the Lesser Town side of Charles Bridge. Not only will you learn more about the golden period of alchemy and Rudolf II in Prague, youll get superb views of Charles Bridge and Prague Castle.

title: Tip of the Week: An iPod Nano as an Alarm Clock
description: School is starting up again  which means many people will reluctantly have to start paying closer attention to the time. As some music lovers have discovered, the small, square iPod Nano model can also pull double duty as a wristwatch with one of the optional watchband accessories available for it. Getting to the clock function is easy  just tap the Clock icon on the Nanos home screenbut there are other time-related functions built into the Nano that are not as obvious.

title: Lessons Learned
description: New Yorkers came away from the 9/11 attacks with greater understanding of their country, the world and themselves.

title: Turkey Expels Israeli Envoy in Dispute Over Raid
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Turkey said Friday that it was downgrading its diplomatic and military ties with Israel and expelling its ambassador in a display of anger at Israels refusal to apologize for a deadly commando raid last year on a Turkish ship bound for Gaza.

title: London Stock Exchange Owner in Talks With Clearinghouse
description: London Stock Exchange Group confirmed Friday that it was in talks with the LCH.Clearnet Group, the latest effort by a suitor to woo the swaps clearinghouse.

title: Perrys Book Gives Rivals Ammunition
description: Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, talks in broad, vague terms on the campaign trail about the need to get America working again.

title: SABMillers Takeover of Fosters Gets More Hostile
description: 2:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Workers Wearing Toeshoes
description: IN 1903, when ballet had been a prolific subject of Edgar Degas for over 30 years, an American collector, Louisine Havemeyer, asked him, Why, monsieur, do you always do ballet dancers? His quick reply was, Because, madame, it is all that is left us of the combined movements of the Greeks.

title: Zero Job Growth Latest Bleak Sign for U.S. Economy
description: August brought no increase in the number of jobs in the United States, a signal that the economy has stalled and that inaction by policy makers carries substantial risk.

title: Friday Reading: Getting Doctors to Wash Their Hands
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Lineup for Telluride Film Festival Is Announced
description: The Venice Film Festival started on Wednesday, at or below sea level. I headed in the other direction, to Telluride, the former mining town in Colorado whose high-altitude festival occurs every year on Labor Day. Some people  and a handful of movies  manage to be in both places at once.

title: Here Comes the Groom
description: Start your day with our curated set of grooming products.

title: The Beatles on the Beach
description: Beatles photos from the Astrid Kirchherr archive,.

title: Hugh Laurie's 'St. James Infirmary'
description: Actor Hugh Laurie releases an album of 15 New Orleans blues covers, titled "Let Them Talk."

title: Decision Fatigue
description: John Tierney doesnt mention one form of decision fatigue with major consequences. Seriously ill patients face many choices about how to manage their conditions. Add these decisional demands to the other burdens of illness, and you have a recipe for bad outcomes. When I was going through intensive chemotherapy and radiation treatment for cancer, I eventually shut down and refused to cooperate with medical recommendations. Fortunately, I was talked out of my bad choices. Patients today are free to make their own decisions, but this freedom can be exhausting.

title: What Would Hillary Have Done?
description: Rebecca Traister writes that Hillary Clintons presidency would probably not have looked so different from Obamas. Really? Would Hillary have spent all her political capital passing a watered-down health care act? Would she have bailed out the banks and corporations? Surged in Afghanistan? Extended the Bush tax cuts? Signed a deficit-reduction act that balances the budget on the backs of the poor and working people of this country? I think not. The difference between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama is that Clinton knows that the Republicans dont play fair. People have a right to be bitterly disappointed, and it is only human nature to ask, What if?

title: What They Think Now
description: I immediately recognized the cover photo of Jaime King and well remember the story that appeared with the original photograph in 1996. It was a disturbing portrait of exploitation and abuse, and prompted me to write a letter that was published in the magazine on March 3, 1996. My fears then were partially realized. Today, King appears diminished, less vital and  in an apparent contradiction  young and vulnerable, yet so old and weary. But I found her reflection about the photo to be positive: she has clearly matured. The portraits and updates made Time Lapse wonderful reading.

title: What the Left Doesnt Understand About Obama
description: This has been the summer that liberal discontent with Obama has finally crystallized. The frustration has been simmering for a while  through centrist appointments, bank bailouts and the defeat of the public option, to name a few examples. But it has taken the debt-ceiling standoff and the threat of a double-dip recession to create a leftist critique of the president that stuck.

title: Dollar-Store Economy
description: Jack Hitts article on dollar stores missed the mark. The article focused on gee whiz, what unusual things one can find when slumming in a dollar store. That misses their real significance. The dollar store is the new A. & P. for many Americans. I am disappointed that The Times approached this from the perspective of an economic tourist exploring an exotic destination, rather than from the viewpoint of the underprivileged citizens who have no choice but to dwell in the land of the dollar store.

title: Dangerous Lesions
description: Recently, I was at an outdoor concert where I sat next to a woman who was wearing a halter top. I could clearly see that she had two growths on her back that looked like ones that I had had removed because they were basal-cell carcinomas. I am not a doctor, but I felt conflicted about whether or not I should have said something to alert her. She left, and I felt guilty about not having mentioned it to her. Did I have an obligation to do so? JERI Y. GREENBERG, WASHINGTON, D.C.

title: Questions for Carine Roitfeld
description: Before you became editor of French Vogue in 2001, you were best known for being an inspiration to Tom Ford. And in your new book, Irreverent, you include a handwritten note from him in which he writes that hed like to take you out for a romantic dinner. What exactly is a romantic dinner like between a gay man and a straight woman?  Ask each woman that ever met Tom, and they will tell you that they were under the charm of Tom. O.K., Tom, unfortunately for the woman, is gay. But he is very not so gay. Even the way he touches a woman, the way he puts his hand on your back or the way he opens the car for you, hes a gentleman. Youre dying that he likes everything youre wearing, everything youre doing, because his taste is very important to you. You want to seduce him all the time.

title: How Tabloid Trainwrecks Are Reinventing Gothic Literature
description: In the blustery wilds of Suffolk County on Long Island, in a seaside hamlet that was once a thriving whaling village, a young girl is raised by a prominent family. Her father  an impulsive and reckless figure given to fits of sudden rage  had been beset by legal troubles and was sent to prison for three years. During this time, the girl is pressed into service, perhaps to help with the cost of rearing her younger siblings, and soon she is projecting her phantasmagoric doppelgnger out into the cinemas of the world.

title: The Beatles on the Beach
description: On Saturday, April 27, 1963, the Beatles played Memorial Hall in Northwich, England  the concert poster described them as Hit recorders of Please, Please Me. The next day, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr flew down to Tenerife to unwind with two of their closest Hamburg pals, the graphic artist Klaus Voormann and the photographer Astrid Kirchherr. (John Lennon took his own holiday in Barcelona with the bands manager, Brian Epstein.) For the upstart combo, it would be their first taste of the jet-set life and, in the saga of their ascent, a momentary breather about halfway up Mount Olympus. The first No. 1 record was in the bag, the next one was heading up the charts and full-blown Beatlemania was just a few months off. The islands black sand, towering volcano and opportunities for sunstroke were as exotic to the Beatles as their newfound celebrity. But none of that notoriety followed them to Tenerife, where they stayed at the Voormann family cottage. The bandmates ran around asking the locals: You know us? The Beatles?  only to be met with bewilderment.

title: Hugh Laurie Sings the Blues
description: Hugh Laurie was in pain. This is often true, but usually its because of self-inflicted psychic wounds. The immediate source of his torment, though, was a female voice, flat and affectless, inside a glass elevator at the Natural History Museum in London.

title: Block Quotes: Gothic Writing, Then and Now
description: Young Conrads birthday was fixed for his espousals. The company was assembled in the chapel of the Castle, and everything ready for beginning the divine office, when Conrad himself was missing. Manfred, impatient of the least delay, and who had not observed his son retire, despatched one of his attendants to summon the young Prince. The servant, who had not stayed long enough to have crossed the court to Conrads apartment, came running back breathless, in a frantic manner, his eyes staring, and foaming at the mouth. . . . In the meantime, some of the company had run into the court, from whence was heard a confused noise of shrieks, horror, and surprise. . . .

title: In a Quiet Period, Groupon Feels the Noise
description: Groupons initial public offering is about to hit some very rough turbulence.

title: Bolt, Back in Character, Advances to 200 Final
description: DAEGU, South Korea  It was always a long shot that Usain Bolt would have a long look in the mirror after his now-notorious false start and decide that the way forward was to become a poker-faced introvert.

title: The City Stirs | Midtown, 5:15 A.M.
description: Never miss a chance to have sex or appear on television.  Gore Vidal

title: Bloomberg Cancels Radio Talk Amid Furor Over Aide
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg canceled his weekly radio appearance, scheduled for Friday morning, amid a growing outcry over his handling of a top aides arrest over a domestic violence complaint, said a person told of the mayors decision.

title: Hope, Fear and Insomnia: Journey of a Jobless Man
description: On June 25, 2010, Frederick Deare punched out for the last time from his job driving a forklift at the Old London factory in the Bronx. That summer, everyone at the plant was being laid off: the oven operators, the assembly-line packers, the forklift drivers, the sanitation workers. Total jobs lost: 228. Old London, the snack manufacturer that invented the Cheez Doodle, was moving its operations to North Carolina. At 53, Mr. Deare, known as Freddy or Teddy Bear to his co-workers, would have to find a new job.

title: Comparing Recessions and Recoveries: Job Changes
description: Source: Labor Department. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: When Wheels Pile Up: Plant a Bike; Save the City
description: In 1880, New York City removed 15,000 dead horses from its streets, the historians Joel Tarr and Clay McShane wrote in an essay called The Centrality of the Horse to the Nineteenth-Century American City. Horse carcasses, they added, were sometimes dumped with garbage into the bays or the rivers, often floating there or washing up on the beaches.

title: Wall St. Tumbles After Bleak Jobs Report
description: A grim report on the job market and news that major banks are facing federal lawsuits hit Wall Street on Friday, sending the broader market lower as crucial financial and industrial stocks spiraled down by more than 3 percent.

title: Accels Breyer to Join News Corp. Board, as 2 Depart
description: News Corporation, which is in the midst of a phone-hacking scandal, is reshuffling the board.

title: Curtain Calls | John Lithgow
description: In his revelatory memoir, Drama (HarperCollins, $27), John Lithgow, the consummate character actor, talks about infidelity, Oedipal striving and the awfulness of acceptance speeches.

title: Lots of Vitriol for Fed Chief, Despite Facts
description: Attacks on the chairman of the Federal Reserve arent new. For years Ive received a well-organized volley of vitriolic e-mails every time I mention Ben Bernanke. I dismissed them as missives from the lunatic fringe, at least until recently.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Calling on the Fed
description: What I would give to be a fly on in the wall at the Federal Reserve right now, where Ben S. Bernanke is probably doing a double take on Fridays horrible jobs report.

title: News Corp. Board Undergoes a Shuffle
description: 7:24 p.m. | Updated The News Corporations board of directors underwent significant reshuffling on Friday with the departure of two long-serving members and the nomination of a new independent voice.

title: How Are You Preparing for the First Day of School?
description: Its that time of year again: a hint of fall is in the air, and New York Citys youngest will re-enter the halls of learning, leaving parents and caretakers in peace.

title: E.U. Bans Syrian Oil as Protests Continue
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  European Union members escalated the pressure on Syrias government on Friday by banning all imports of Syrian oil in response to its violent suppression of the nearly six-month-old uprising there. It was the most punitive action by the European Union to date over the crackdown in Syria, which sells nearly all its oil to Europe and relies heavily on that export income.

title: Bank of America Loses Its Bounce
description: Bank of America shares have shed the Warren E. Buffett bounce, opening sharply lower on Friday morning after a flutter of bad news for the financial firm.

title: G.O.P.s New Obama Label: President Zero
description: It took the Republican National Committee exactly 94 minutes to coin a new, demeaning title for Barack Obama: President Zero.

title: For M.L.S., Fixtures at an Exhibition
description: The world is focused over the next five days on two international game days  World Cup qualifiers, African Cup of Nations, Euro 2012 qualifiers  around the world.

title: Spin City
description: Justin Miller, the handsome face of DFA Records and a regular fashion-event D.J., suggests a playlist to get the party started.

title: The Bachmann Namestorm
description: Yesterday we asked for your help naming Michele Bachmanns currently untitled new memoir. Below, a few of your best responses, tweeted to us at @nytmag using the hashtag #namebachmann.

title: A Challenge for Unions in Public Opinion
description: A new Gallup poll has found that a slim majority of Americans, 52 percent, approve of labor unions and that the difference in views between how Democrats and Republicans feel toward unions has reached record levels.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Justice Dept.s Top Officials in Pursuing the AT&T Lawsuit | The names of 25 government lawyers are listed on the last page of the Justice Departments lawsuit seeking to block the proposed $39 billion merger between AT&T and T-Mobile USA.

title: Obama Administration Abandons Stricter Air-Quality Rules
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama abandoned a contentious new air pollution rule on Friday, buoying business interests that had lobbied heavily against it, angering environmentalists who called the move a betrayal and unnerving his own top environmental regulators.

title: A New Sideline for Serena Williams: Relationship Advice
description: When shes not delivering aces, Serena Williams doles out relationship advice. She and her sister, Venus, were in the locker room Wednesday at the United States Open when they bumped into Caroline Wozniacki, the world No. 1 and girlfriend of the golfer, Rory McIlroy, the reigning United States Open champion from Northern Ireland.

title: A Veteran Questions a Proposed Overhaul of Military Pensions
description: Proposed changes to the militarys retirement system have been much in the news lately. According to the Defense Business Board, a Pentagon advisory committee tasked by former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates with finding ways to reduce the Department of Defense budget, the current system is unsustainable and in dire need of repair. The board proposes that the military abandon its traditional pension system in favor of a 401(k)-style contribution program.

title: In Reykjavik, a Glittering New Home for Music
description: After the economic meltdown and a couple of ash-spewing volcanoes, Iceland still has plenty to be optimistic about.

title: Straw Dogs, Then and Now
description: A look at the film Straw Dogs.

title: U-Turn for T.I.: From Halfway House Back to Prison
description: 1:34 p.m. | Updated The rap artist T.I. was sent back to prison Thursday after he showed up at a halfway house in Atlanta in a luxury bus with an entourage.

title: A Helping Hand, Paid on Commission
description: Lets say you are wading into the deep water. You think your parent or another older relative needs more care, perhaps at home, perhaps in an assisted living facility or other residence. You dont know where to turn, which places or agencies to consider. Online, you find a referral service that can provide assistance  and its free.

title: Reader Photos and Recipes: Essential Summer Dishes
description: This week, food writers for The Times shared recipes for warm-weather dishes they consider essential eating. The Times asked readers to chime in by submitting the best dishes theyve made since Memorial Day. The first batch of photos and recipes is up, with more to come. The collection includes the above photo by Nikki Gardner of Massachusetts, who submitted a recipe for summer squash noodles with tomato-basil cream sauce (the sauce, she wrote, was inspired by recipes from Alice Waters and Lauren Ulm of the blog VeganYumYum).

title: Randall Kennedys The Persistence of the Color Line; Ginia Bellafante on the Big City Book Club; best-seller news
description: This week, Harvard scholar Randall Kennedy discusses racial politics in America in his new book, The Persistence of the Color Line; columnist Ginia Bellafante talks about the new Big City Book Club at the Times; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: German Farmer Captures a Famous Runaway
description: Yvonne, the bovine runaway that confounded German authorities and tickled the funny bone of the international press, was back on the farm on Friday after three months of evading capture in a Bavarian forest.

title: TimesCast | Banks Face Mortgage Lawsuits
description: September 2, 2011 - Lawsuits by a federal agency are expected to accuse the banks of misrepresenting the quality of mortgage securities they assembled and sold at the housing bubble's peak.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 2
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include dogs in bars, a dinner in white, and Tropical Storm Irene.

title: Samurai Shopper | Hair Cares
description: Not long ago the Samurai popped into Sally Hershbergers Downtown Salon to slap palms with the superstar stylist Matt Fugate. How can you tell a superstar stylist from the rest? Hes the one with the worst hairstyle in the place. The late John Sahag taught me that and its true. So heres Matt with his hair bunched up like a pregnant Milk Dud protruding from his nape. After some mutual whats ups, Matt cops a feel of my hair and goes glum.

title: A Texas Mans Campaign Results in Recall of 241,000 BMW 3 Series Models for Faulty Tail Lamps
description: BMW is recalling almost a quarter of a million vehicles as the result of a Texas mans request that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration investigate what he thought was a safety problem.

title: Choosing Cinematheque Over Cineplex
description: ONE way to trace the history of the movies is to look at the evolution of alternative cinemas  to consider, in other words, how an inventive approach to showing films can foster a new way of understanding them.

title: A One-Touch SOS for BlackBerry Users
description: It is a time of rapid-fire earthquakes and hurricanes. Wouldnt you like a panic button in your pocket?

title: AOL Says Arrington No Longer Works at TechCrunch
description: 6:38 p.m. | Updated

title: Weekend Fare
description: For the first time since it opened more than 25 years ago, Union Square Caf, will begin serving brunch this weekend, from 11 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday. Carmen Quagliatas menu features traditional brunch fare and dishes inspired by produce available at the nearby Greenmarket. 21 East 16th Street (between Broadway and Fifth Avenue), Reservations can be made at (212) 243-4020 or on Open Table.

title: The Too Black, Too White Presidency
description: The next time you see Barack Obama gliding into a White House press conference, take note of that jazzy walk. It is a dead ringer for the strut that was the bearing of choice among inner-city cool guys in the 1960s, when Barry Obama was still a tyke growing up in the exotic precincts of Hawaii and Indonesia. The Obama glide represents his embrace of a black aesthetic that was not his by circumstance of birth. It speaks on an intimate frequency to African-American men, who have been smiling in recognition and rating it for style ever since he stepped into the national spotlight. President Obama is acutely aware of how to deploy the physical self to excellent effect. If we looked back closely at 2008, we would no doubt notice him amping up the glide for black audiences and dialing it back elsewhere.

title: Steven Millhausers Ghost Stories
description: Among the various impostures of book reviewing, the suggestion that a book is encountered in a vacuum of preconceptions is one thats bound to be debunked when faced with the phrase New and Selected Stories. Presented with a career capstone on behalf of a writer good enough to receive the honor, yet not only still walking the earth but also still adding goodies to the pile  thats no time to play dumb. If you werent already reading the fellow, what business would you have weighing in now?

title: Cuomo Calls for Volunteers to Clean Up After Irene
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Friday a statewide volunteer effort aimed at cleaning up the damage in upstate communities that were hit hardest by Tropical Storm Irene.

title: From New Haven to Northern Montana
description: In one chapter of her new memoir, This Is Not the Ivy League, Mary Clearman Blew splices the story of a shooting spree in Moscow, Idaho, into an account of raising her children while going to graduate school: When cornered, I lashed out, if not with a rifle, and then turned the blame on myself. This is extreme, to say the least, and Blew admits it. But she insists the comparison holds.

title: Heres Looking at You, Katydid
description: In the realm of insects, unlike in the realm of mammals, say, theres plenty of room at the bottom. Room for millions of species  and quintillions of individuals  to coexist, and room for biologists to make significant discoveries about them by peering closely at their behaviors and their brains. In Sex on Six Legs, the biologist Marlene Zuk argues that insects  because they are both unlike us and, in surprising ways, like us  provide excellent fodder for studying the relative value of inheritance versus environment, the evolution of personality, the definition of language and the downside of growing bigger brains.

title: Gender-Free
description: Hilton Als, a writer for The New Yorker, probably did Justin Vivian Bond a disservice by contributing the preface to Bonds novella-length childhood memoir, Tango. Thats not to say that the preface is bad  quite the opposite. It is poetic and affecting, and it features revealing descriptions of Bond, a transgender singer-songwriter and performance artist with a fervent following among New York Citys avant-garde. Justin Vivian has learned to dance with Vs self, Als writes, to wear the heels and the suit that fit Vs being, all cut and formed to suit Vs soul, having earned it as so many of us earn it, through being brutalized and suppressed and sometimes through love, too. (V is Bonds preferred, gender-free pronoun.)

title: Why Good Writers Arent Good Talkers
description: Theres a hall-of-mirrors quality to writing about a book by a writer who writes about books. For example, By candlelight a goat is ladylike. Thats me quoting Arthur Krystal quoting A. Roger Ekirch quoting an old French adage.

title: Daughters Under Duress
description: The women in Elissa Schappells new story collection ought to come with a warning label. Danger: Contents under pressure. Emotionally sensitive compounds may be present. Toxic sentiments could be released if disturbed or shaken. Prone to self-destruct. Unprotected contact may result in shock, burns, emotional distress or, in rare cases, death. Keep hands out of reach at all times, because also: These women bite.

title: In Africa, a Childs Nightmare Becomes a Writers Dream
description: Im going to write an Awful Book and this time it really will be about you, Alexandra Fuller promises when her mother complains over a favorite walking sticks being broken in a battle with a poisonous snake. Another Awful Book, as far as her mother is concerned. Fuller had not yet been forgiven for publishing the first one in 2001, the intoxicating Dont Lets Go to the Dogs Tonight.

title: The Sugary Secret of Self-Control
description: Ever since Adam and Eve ate the apple, Ulysses had himself tied to the mast, the grasshopper sang while the ant stored food and St. Augustine prayed Lord make me chaste  but not yet, individuals have struggled with self-control. In todays world this virtue is all the more vital, because now that we have largely tamed the scourges of nature, most of our troubles are self-inflicted. We eat, drink, smoke and gamble too much, max out our credit cards, fall into dangerous liaisons and become addicted to heroin, cocaine and e-mail.

title: Living the Varieties of Virtual Experience
description: In the first lecture from The Varieties of Religious Experience, entitled Religion and Neurology, William James criticizes as simple-minded what he calls medical materialism, the system of thought that finishes up St. Paul by calling his vision on the road to Damascus a discharging lesion of the occipital cortex, he being an epileptic or that snuffs out St. Teresa as an hysteric, St. Francis of Assisi as an hereditary degenerate. Such thinking, James said, isnt strictly wrong, but extremely wrongheaded, since all thoughts and feelings, including those of the medical materialists themselves, are organically conditioned and thus equally prey to being dismissed. James concluded that St. Paul very likely did have a seizure, but that this had no bearing on the spiritual significance of his visions, which needed to be judged pragmatically, by the extent to which they offered delight or good consequential fruits for life.

title: The Man Who Ruled the Lodz Ghetto
description: The diabolically well-planned implementation of genocide that was the Holocaust has been narrated many times over, in the form of fiction and non-fiction. Indeed, it has been argued that the Holocaust, like everything else in our mercantile culture, has become commodified (Theres no business like Shoah business), and the existence of an item like the Holocaust Survivor Cookbook as well as the fetishistic value placed on Nazi memorabilia (this past July an ultra-Orthodox Jewish buyer snapped up a collection of writings by Dr. Josef Mengele for $245,000) would suggest that there is some uneasy truth to the charge.

title: Was Coco Chanel a Nazi Agent?
description: Gabrielle Chanel  better known as Coco  was a wretched human being. Anti-Semitic, homophobic, social climbing, opportunistic, ridiculously snobbish and given to sins of phrase-making like If blonde, use blue perfume, she was addicted to morphine and actively collaborated with the Germans during the Nazi occupation of Paris. And yet, her clean, modern, kinetic designs, which brought a high-society look to low-regarded fabrics, revolutionized womens fashion, and to this day have kept her name synonymous with the most glorious notions of French taste and lan.

title: Fate, Feathers and Death
description: Sometime in the late 1990s, Anders Brekhus Nilsen started drawing little comic strips about birds: tiny doodled finches with dots for eyes, chatting about seeds and philosophical inquiries. In 1999 he put together a bunch of those strips as a photocopied comic book he called Big Questions. A few more issues followed, in which he started imagining more about the birds personalities and establishing who was responsible for the crumbs that fed them: an old, bent-over woman, living in a shack with her idiot grandson.

title: A Piece of the Action
description: The big question left hanging at the end of THE CUT (Reagan Arthur/Little, Brown, $25.99), George Pelecanoss latest Washington, D.C., crime novel, is whether he can keep his cocky new hero from flaming out. At 29, Spero Lucas, an unlicensed investigator for a criminal defense attorney (and anyone else wholl give him a cut of the action), is considerably younger and friskier than the heavy-lidded private eyes who have imprinted their world-weary stamp on this genre. His values are also different, shaped by the street culture of his tough neighborhood and by his experiences as a Marine in Iraq. Even his musical tastes are more contemporary. (No moody blues for this guy, who prefers reggae, ska and dub.) There are certain bars I dont hang in, Lucas explains. Im not gonna sit around and have drinks with people who are, you know, ironic. Hes also man enough to put flowers on his fathers grave and pay regular visits to his mother.

title: Class Warfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Intimate Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing From the Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: MY HOLLYWOOD,  by Mona Simpson (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.95.) This novel of manners about modern motherhood revolves around Claire, a Guggenheim-winning composer and new mother living in Los Angeles, and Lola, a mother of five from the Philippines hired by Claire as a nanny. Shifting between the perspectives of these two women, Simpson highlights clashes of culture and class.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE LEFTOVERS,  by Tom Perrotta (St. Martins, $25.99.) In Perrottas novelistic version of the biblical prophecy known as the rapture, Hindus, Buddhists and Muslims as well as Christians mysteriously disappear.

title: Inside the List
description: READING SEPT. 11: After the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Graydon Carter, the editor of Vanity Fair, declared the end of irony. It may not also have been the end of inanity on the best-seller list, but it was the beginning of a new interest in the Muslim world among Americans previously more preoccupied with Anne Heches Call Me Crazy and the television psychic John Edwards Crossing Over, to name two top sellers for the week that ended Sept. 8. At first, Americans seemed too stunned to go to the bookstore, but by Sept. 22, Germs, an account of biological weaponry and Americas readiness against it by the New York Times reporters Judith Miller, Stephen Engelberg and William Broad, had hit the hardcover list (no doubt thanks in part to the anthrax scare that killed five Americans and landed a threatening letter laced with white powder in Millers own mailbox), while titles like Ahmed Rashids "Taliban" and Yossef Bodanskys Bin Laden started climbing the paperback list.

title: Up Front: Brent Staples
description: Brent Staples, who reviews Randall Kennedys Persistence of the Color Line in this issue, is working on a history of mixed-race identity in the United States. One of the things that interested me in the last campaign, Staples wrote in an e-mail, was the byplay having to do with Obamas racial origins. It struck me that the press and the public generally reserve the mixed race label for the offspring of racially mixed marriages. But there is a paradox here. Obama, half black and half white, is, genetically speaking, not much whiter than I am, even though my nearest white forebears were Virginia slave owners who lived and died in the 19th century. Similarly, there are people who think of themselves as black who are, genetically speaking, 70 percent white or more.

title: From Scroll to Screen
description: Something very important and very weird is happening to the book right now: Its shedding its papery corpus and transmigrating into a bodiless digital form, right before our eyes. Were witnessing the bibliographical equivalent of the rapture. If anything we may be lowballing the weirdness of it all.

title: Is the New York Times Biased Against Religion?
description: My column urging journalists to be less squeamish about questioning candidates on their religious beliefs drew a heated response  some pro, more con, many stimulated by conservative pundits, a few not suitable for a family newspaper. Among the readers who took issue was Wilburn Smith III, a lawyer in Laguna Niguel, Calif. Our e-mail exchange this week is excerpted below with Mr. Smiths permission.

title: Using an Inheritance to Teach Your Problem Child a Lesson
description: PARENTS want to raise their children to be independent and successful and to use whatever resources they have to give their offspring a leg up in life.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Bloody Wolverines, Vampires and Baked Goods
description: Our Best Sellers lists are filled with movement this week: The deluxe edition of WE3, by Grant Morrison and Frank Quitely, enters at No. 1 on the hardcover list with their compelling and beautifully illustrated tale about household pets turned into lethal weapons. Theres also a particularly bloody Wolverine story by the novelist Charlie Huston at No. 6, which introduces the X-Man to a new foe named Contagion. Fan reaction was not kind. On IGN.com, one review declared, Stay as far away from this book as possible and gave it a 1.5 rating out of 10.

title: Fatal Distraction
description: Zero job growth, with unemployment still at nosebleed levels. Meanwhile, the interest rate on 10-year US bonds is down to 2.04%, and its negative on inflation-protected securities.

title: About That Inheritance
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about an issue many parents  no matter their wealth  deal with: how to encourage their children to grow into independent adults. The issue gets more complicated when money is involved.

title: Across the Hall, Diversity of Incomes
description: MARIETTA HILL lives in a luxurious studio in one of Manhattans newest rental high-rises.

title: PETA Aims Campaign at an Older Audience
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, the organization known as PETA, is aiming a new campaign about the treatment of circus elephants at older Americans.

title: The Bright Side of Unemployment?
description: On Thursday the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development released its latest report on the hundreds of unemployed workers it has been following (and surveying) for two years. As you might expect from the reports title  Out of Work and Losing Hope: The Misery and Bleak Expectations of American Workers  the reports findings are discouraging.

title: Venus Williams Brings Attention to Sjogrens Syndrome
description: Before this week, many people had probably never heard of Sjogrens syndrome, one of the most prevalent autoimmune disorders. But the recent announcement by tennis star Venus Williams that she was suffering from fatigue and other symptoms related to Sjogrens has brought needed attention to a troubling condition.

title: Sex on Six Legs
description: CHAPTER 1

title: For the Recently Widowed, Some Big Financial Pitfalls to Avoid
description: There are few more wrenching events in life than losing your spouse.

title: The Conservative Hot Tub Time Machine
description: I was struck by a passage in David Brookss column today:

title: On Dutch Game Show, Competing for Cash Before Being Deported
description: It sounds like a cruel joke: a game show in the Netherlands that pits failed asylum seekers against one another in a test of their mastery of the countrys language, history and culture, with the prize being a little extra pocket money to take back home after the Dutch government shows all of them the door.

title: On Project Runway, Two Strikes and Youre Out
description: This weeks challenge on Project Runway was to create an avant-garde look based on a piece of artwork the designers would collaborate on with young students from the Harlem School of the Arts.

title: Steve Jobs Changed Games, Too, Without Trying
description: Playing Angry Birds the other day, I was struck by what I no longer play: Xbox and PlayStation. Having children has something to do with that. So does Steve Jobs.

title: Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness
description: Nicola Fuller of Central Africa Learns to Fly

title: The Best Financial Advice for Widows
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I took the best shot I could in 1,400 words or so at helping widows avoid the financial pitfalls that so many of them fall into. They need not rush into making financial decisions, they should think hard about housing, they should not be a purse for anyone and they should be wary of blindly following financial orders left by their dead husbands.

title: How to Know When the River is Rising
description: Consistent with the predictions of climate science, we seem to have entered an era of erratic weather and rising weather extremes. We are only halfway through 2011 and its already been a crazy weather year  the third such year in a row. The science offers us no reason to believe this situation is going to get better, so it is time to start thinking about ways to cope.

title: The Caucus | No Lull in Partisanship
description: Jackie Calmes on the dysfunction in Washington after the fight over the timing of the President Obama's jobs speech. Also, a look at the heath care records of three governors running for president.

title: One Citys Plague Years, in Small Details
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: On a Manhattan Rooftop, Talking Tail Fins With the Designer of the Cadillac Ciel
description: After its debut at Pebble Beach last month, the Cadillac Ciel concept has been on a whistle-stop tour en route to the Frankfurt auto show, turning up in Michigan on Monday and New York on Thursday. The car was displayed on the rooftop of a gallery building here in Chelsea, against a backdrop of wooden water towers and blue September skies.

title: Ravenous | Thit Heo Kho
description: In this new column, Monique Truong, author of The Book of Salt and Bitter in the Mouth, shares food stories and recipes from her kitchen table.

title: Caucus Video: Dysfunction in Washington Continues, Health Care Records vs. Campaign Rhetoric
