description: Jackie Calmes on the dysfunction in Washington after the fight over the timing of the President Obamas jobs speech. Also, a look at the health care records of three governors running for president.

title: A Shorter Charlie Parker Festival Is Rescheduled
description: Postponed last weekend because of inclement weather, the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival will be pared back to one day with a smaller lineup later this month, the City Parks Foundation said on Thursday.

title: Wellington, New Zealands Flyover Capital, a Must-Stop
description: IT was a Saturday night in Wellington, New Zealand, and the denizens of Cuba Street were proving that the 80s arent dead. A performance group decked out in unitards, Lycra G-strings, leg warmers and fluorescent wigs was dancing almost in rhythm to tunes like Pour Some Sugar on Me and Like a Virgin, occasionally inspiring the crowd to join in. Farther down Cuba Street, clutches of the young and restless spilled out along the pedestrian mall on their way from bar to restaurant to cafe, many ending up at nightspots like the Matterhorn to catch the latest hot D.J. from Ireland or Ethiopia. In the middle of the mall, one of the citys signature landmarks, the Bucket Fountain, dropped water from one bucket to another and onto passers-by, causing them to shriek and jump into one anothers arms to dodge the spray.

title: Wellingtons Revival
description: Once a flyover city, Wellington has become a tourist draw in its own right.

title: In Bollywood, Female Directors Find New Respect
description: Mumbai, India

title: StellaService Revises Airlines Hurricane Grades
description: StellaService, a customer research firm that says it provides mystery shoppers on steroids, has issued a mea culpa to some big airlines. The firm concedes that it made some mistakes while ranking carriers responses to inquiries sent via Twitter, as Hurricane Irene approached.

title: Sorting Through the Mystique of the Morgan
description: FEW motor vehicles have remained as true to their heritage as those made in England by Morgan Motor Cars. The new 3-Wheeler model, which the company has promised will arrive in American showrooms at the end of this year, may be the purest expression yet.

title: 2 Wheels or 4? Lets Just Split the Difference
description: Malvern Link, EnglandNOT everything good has to be an iPod or iPad, said Charles Morgan, the dashing chairman of the Morgan Motor Company. Brand new ideas are wonderful when they happen, but sometimes theres good in older ones, too.

title: Opera Recalls A Heros Life, Love and Song
description: HAVING coined the phrase the banality of evil, Hannah Arendt went on to suggest that the most heinous crimes have often been committed by morally desensitized ordinary people. The inverse may be equally true: that ordinary heroes like Rick Rescorla, who saved almost 2,700 lives on Sept. 11, 2001, only to lose his own, are the yang to Arendts yin, demonstrating what you might call the profundity of virtue.

title: Grilled London Broil: Try It Spicy and Smoky
description: A LONDON broil is one of those mystery steaks without a firm identity.

title: Oahus Windward Side
description: A quieter world away from Honolulu.

title: For Niculescu, a Soft Touch Leads to Victory
description: In sharp contrast to the bludgeoning that the tactic of choice for the majority of modern W.T.A. players, 68th-ranked Monica Niculescu, who has a style built on smothering softness, became the first woman to reach the second week of the 2011 U.S. Open.

title: Making Vegetables the Meal
description: Vegetables are often relegated to the side of the plate, but in the latest Recipes for Health series, Martha Rose Shulman shows how stuffed vegetables can make the meal. She writes:

title: The Package
description: Yesterday, while riding the N train uptown, I started chatting with a young woman I knew to be a model. Of course she was: the elongated body, the strawberry-blonde hair, the pale, vague face.

title: Letters: When Teenagers Fly Alone
description: To the Editor: Re the Practical Traveler column (Aug. 28), minors traveling alone should have a mobile phone and a debit card, and should be briefed about going through security, changing planes, etc. If they are reasonably mature teenagers, they should be able to handle it just fine. Ive let my 12- and 14-year-olds travel unaccompanied, and will probably do so again. No way should I have to pay an extra $200 for my kid to go to camp.

title: Lessons of a Daybreak Rider
description: TO begin my cross-country cycling trip, I spent a day and a half on the Oregon coast, climbing to witness glorious vistas above the Pacific. Then I rode east up the verdant corridor alongside the Columbia River Gorge, the river itself keeping me company as I made my way into sun-blanched wheat country. I turned north through the Palouse region in eastern Washington, where the undulating hills and scorching heat nearly wore me out, and made it to Spokane, where the world turned green again. My stay in Idaho was brief  I crossed the panhandle  though I stopped to relax for a day on the beach at Sandpoint, where you can look out over Lake Pend Oreille at the distant hills of a national forest.

title: Restaurant Report: El Real Tex Mex in Houston
description: In the darkness of the Montrose neighborhood of Houston, the blaring neon Art Deco sign of a 1930s former movie theater stretches high into the sky. Its bright letters now spell out El Real Tex Mex.

title: Jewels of Olmsteds Unspoiled Midwest
description: FEW people can claim to know America as deeply as Frederick Law Olmsted did. During a long, full and peripatetic life (1822-1903), he crisscrossed the country by rail, stagecoach, horseback and on foot. I was born for a traveler, he once said.

title: Hotel Review: Crystal Hotel in Portland, Ore.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Charlestons (Now) Great Hall
description: ON the June morning when the Great Hall at the Charleston City Market, in Charleston, S.C., reopened to the public after an 18-month renovation, spotting the locals amid the vacationing throngs was easy. While the outnumbered Charlestonians tended to favor muted office attire over the kaleidoscopic cruisewear of some tourists, what truly set them apart as they entered the overhauled, 204-year-old structure was their amazed expressions.

title: In Amman, Unwinding From the Citys Snarl
description: The historic Jabal Amman neighborhood is a retreat from the traffic-clogged streets of Jordans capital city.

title: Gigantic Montana
description: It took Bruce Weber two weeks to cycle across the state, persevering across hundreds of miles of windswept prairie.

title: Sharpton Explains Silence in Strauss-Kahn Case
description: The Dominique Strauss-Kahn case has inspired exhaustive and perhaps exhausting public venting. But some have wondered why one person who would normally be expected to weigh in on such a controversial episode had been notably silent: the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: Sept. 4  Sept. 10
description: Art

title: The Jam | Henrik Vibskov
description: This weeks playlist  which the Jams Sean Hanratty calls atypical  comes from the Danish designer Henrik Vibskov, who is known primarily for his untraditional, fantastical and almost childlike take on fashion. But Hanratty says that Vibskovs wildy inventive talents extend far beyond just clothing. I have always had such a love for his work, but even more because of his varied interests and artistic nature, says Hanratty of the established artist whose autumn-winter 2009 show featured models donning oversize Amish hats while powering black and white striped, human-size hamster wheels in an echoing warehouse outside of Copenhagen. His collection was called Human Laundry. He is an interdisciplinarian and renaissance man in the truest sense, Hanratty says. Vibskov also drums for the Danish electro outfit Trentemoller. His new unisex fragrance line, which will be introduced during New York Fashion Week, is called Type. It reflects geographical locale rather than specific mood, says Hanratty of the three scents, each called Type A, B and C. I knew, given his varied interests, that I would get a very atypical selection.

title: Video: Out this Week
description: X-MEN: FIRST CLASS  In this origins appendage to the comic book franchise, two lives unfold in fateful parallel: in 1950s New York the future Professor X (Laurence Belcher) grows up amid wealth and plenty, while in Soviet-dominated Poland the boy who will become Magneto (Bill Milner) lives in want. Eventually they become James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender (on their way to evolving into Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellen). Matthew Vaughn directed; with Kevin Bacon, Rose Byrne and Oliver Platt. Like Mad Men, this new X-Men indulges in period nostalgia as it gazes into the future, using the backdrop of the cold war (and its turtlenecks) to explore how the past informs the present (while also blowing stuff up), Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times in June. (Fox, Blu-ray $39.99, DVD $29.98, PG-13)

title: Living in Mott Haven
description: Enthusiasts describe Mott Havens current state as challenging but filled with potential.

title: Clip: The Black Power Mixtape
description: A scene that includes a speech from Eldridge Cleaver, the Minister of Information for the Black Panther Party in 1968.

title: Del Potro Defeats Junqueira in Straight Sets
description: Juan Martin del Potro and Diego Junqueira traveled more than 5,000 miles from their native Argentina only to meet in the second round of the U.S. Open on Friday. When their encounter ended after barely two hours, del Potro was the almost-easy victor, 6-2, 6-1, 7-5.

title: Brooklyn No Longer Left Off Disaster List
description: Brooklyn, it seems, is a disaster after all.

title: Oahus Windward Side
description: A quieter world away from Honolulu.

title: Potential Awaits Its Moment
description: DECADES have gone by, but all around Mott Haven in the South Bronx, certain physical characteristics provide an echo of the bad years in the 1960s and 70s. Of the scores of lots emptied by fires and neglect back then, some have been transformed into lush community gardens, and some have been rebuilt into tidy subsidized town houses by nonprofit developers. Others are just empty, with signs on their fences advertising developments that never materialized.

title: My Kailua
description: WALKING to the beach with my family on a hot Kailua afternoon, lets say 1972. My toy foam surfboard clip-clopping against my knees, towel scratching my neck, rubber slippers squeaking on steamy blacktop. Around the corner of Kuuala Street, across Kalaheo Avenue, then down the skinny beach path, hugging a cinderblock wall under a thick, shady row of octopus trees and bougainvillea. Footfalls echoing on packed dirt.

title: Power to the People, but Quietly
description: IN 1967 a young Swedish journalist named Ingrid Dahlberg traveled to New York to interview the black militant activist Stokely Carmichael for the Swedish National Broadcast Company. As she sat in the home of his mother, Mabel, she found herself unable to make the older woman feel at ease on film. Suddenly Carmichael, who had met Ms. Dahlberg on a Scandinavian book tour several months earlier, and who had popularized the term black power the previous year, rose from his seat and grabbed the microphone. With the camera running, he gently prodded his mother into recalling the struggles of her husband, who had died but in his lifetime attributed his constant layoffs during Carmichaels childhood to the prevailing racial biases of the era.

title: Boldface Name Is Added to Upset List
description: For much of her third-round match at the United States Open on Friday, Maria Sharapova played with all the outward joy of someone watching her car being repossessed. For every great shot and gritty turnaround she fashioned and celebrated with a pumped fist, she inevitably followed with a flurry of errors that brought the agonized look back to her face.

title: Democratic Field to Challenge Scott Brown Narrows
description: The field of Democrats planning to run against Senator Scott Brown in Massachusetts next year just got smaller.

title: Block by Block | West 181st Street
description: West 181st Street, from Fort Washington Avenue to Riverside Drive, cuts through a part of the city that seems caught in time.

title: Student Crossword | Remembering Sept. 11, 2001
description: Play our crossword (PDF) to honor the 10th anniversary of the events of Sept. 11, 2001. You can find the answers here.

title: On the Fringe, With Benefits
description: HEY, look out! cried a man on the street as he grabbed an elderly woman from the path of a bicyclist whizzing down the steep slope of West 181st Street, toward Riverside Drive. The cyclist was gone in a flash, trailed by a few choice expletives from the pedestrians in his wake. No one was hurt, yet there was plenty of harrumphing on the sidewalk. People gathered to commiserate, to make sure the woman was O.K., and to see if anyone needed help carrying packages up the hill.

title: Big Deal | Chronicle of a Project Foreclosed
description: Every detail of 5 Franklin Place was mapped out: Bosch washers and dryers, cantilevered staircases wrapping around cylindrical glass elevators and a facade with reflective black metal bands that would twist like ribbons and, just maybe, make Frank Gehry squirm.

title: One on One: Cole Stryker, Author of Epic Win for Anonymous
description: Cole Stryker, a freelance writer and media consultant living in New York, spent years digging into Internet culture and communities, both as a participant and as a blogger covering viral phenomena. Hes the author of a new book called Epic Win for Anonymous: How 4chans Army Conquered the Web. He discussed with me what its like exploring the seedy underbelly of the Internet, the rise of Anonymous, and why it and 4chan, widely considered one of the darkest and most subversive corners of the Internet, may be one of the most important and influential creations to emerge from the modern Web.

title: In Board Nominee, News Corp. Scores a Savvy Investor
description: So what does News Corporation want with James W. Breyer?

title: You, Too, Suffer from Decision Fatigue
description: John Tierneys article, Do You Suffer From Decision Fatigue? lit up the Internet last week.

title: Not on the Option List, but You Can Install It Yourself
description: AUTOMOTIVE technology does trickle down to motorcycles, but it takes a while. Antilock brakes, widely available on cars, are offered on just a small number of 2-wheel models. Likewise, the air bag that Honda introduced on its Gold Wing touring bike in 2006 has yet to proliferate, and adaptive headlights are just making a debut on BMWs new K1600 flagship.

title: Kawasakis Famed Fighter Learns a Few New Tactics
description: BAKER, Calif.

title: At World Police and Fire Games, a Home-Wave Advantage
description: It may not be the most well-known aspect of the New York Fire Department, but there is a large subset of firefighters who surf. Many of them hail from the Rockaways and the south shore of Long Island, and many manage to work in firehouses in southern Brooklyn and Queens, which makes it easier to catch a few waves before or after work.

title: World Athletics Championships Replay: Day 7
description: Images from the seventh day of the world track and field championships in Daegu, South Korea.

title: Small Subtractions and Big Addition at Puck Building
description: The queen without her crown, John Lankenau thought as he watched, with growing dismay, the demolition of the brick crenelation atop the landmark Puck Building at Lafayette and Houston Streets.

title: Resources | Teaching and Learning About 9/11 With The New York Times
description: On that day  the Sept. 11 that requires no year  the sun set on crushed buildings in a reimagined world. It set on a recontoured skyline and a haunted city. The equations of life no longer worked. Thats the way it seemed.

title: Atheism, Amorality and Animals: A Response
description: Socrates is in heaven (or Hades). I would like to thank the hundreds of readers who have posted comments and sent me emails about the Confessions of this ex-moralist. Since the best hope of mutual understanding lies in dialogue, I will now reply to my many interlocutors, and in particular, to those who disagreed with my amoralist thesis.

title: Straw Dogs, Stirring Up Trouble Again
description: LIKE the children poking at scorpions in the opening shots of The Wild Bunch Sam Peckinpah knew how to stir things up. In 1971, two years after that exhilarating and phenomenally bloody western made him one of the most famous  or infamous  directors in America, Peckinpah took a crew to the Cornish countryside and came back with a movie called Straw Dogs, which upset audiences in a new, and perhaps more intimate, way.

title: Big Deal | Sold for $36,500,000
description: Selling for $36.5 million, the Harkness Mansion, the Upper East Side town house that broke records when it sold for $53 million in 2006, was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.

title: Zvonareva Advances (But It Takes a While)
description: Because of the ruthless speed with which won early-round matches, five-time Grand Slam champion Tony Trabert once joked that Steffi Graf played as if double-parked.

title: Chic in Review | Babies and Ladies
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Cooper Square Transformed by Zip Ties
description: Who knew that 32,000 zip ties could animate the awkard public space of Cooper Square? Apparently, the Animus Arts Collective did.

title: And About Those Leftovers
description: In this weeks A Good Appetite, I write about grilling up beefy London broils, and the leftovers that inevitably ensue. One of my favorite ways to use them up is to make hash.

title: Before Release, a Hydraulic Fracturing Study for the State Draws Skepticism
description: New York State environmental officials commissioned a study of impacts of natural gas hydraulic fracturing from a consulting firm that counts oil and gas companies among its clients and that could gain business from increased drilling in the state.

title: Big Brother Triumphs on a Night of Preseason Football
description: Thursday night will once again be safe for nonfootball programs, now that National Football League preseason is coming to an end. Pre-emptions and repeats were plentiful on the broadcast networks Thursday because of various N.F.L. games. Of the nonfootball players, Big Brother on CBS (one of two network programs not in repeats) was the nights victor, according to Nielsen estimates. CBS finished the night in first place in overall audience and won the 18- to 49-year-old category most coveted by advertisers.

title: Book Review Podcast: Errol Morriss Believing Is Seeing
description: On the cover of this Sundays Book Review, Kathryn Schulz reviews the filmmaker Errol Morriss new book, Believing Is Seeing, a work that addresses the limitations of vision and the distortions involved in the act of looking  in particular, looking at photographs.

title: After Irene, a Recovering New England
description: Hurricane Irene has given parts of New England a severe beating just before the start of fall foliage season, when city-dwellers flock to the area for leaf-peeping and apple-picking. But roads and attractions are being repaired, and New England businesses are imploring travelers to keep the region in their fall itineraries.

title: Readers Street Style Photos: Summer Knits
description: The best of readers chic summer knits for the week of Aug. 28.

title: Budget Panel to Start Meeting Next Week
description: The bipartisan Congressional committee charged with finding $1.2 trillion in deficit reductions will hold its first official meeting and hearing next week, both open to the public.

title: Thus Proving the Tunas Habitat Is Not a Can
description: SAY you had a can of tuna, an onion and some cooked white beans. A splash of olive oil, a little red wine vinegar, and couple of basil leaves. Maybe some garlic. Salt, pepper. Sounds good, yes?

title: Janes Carousel
description: A restored carousel goes up in Dumbo, Brooklyn.

title: The Little Bullies Are the Worst
description: On my daily walk to the subway, I pass a schoolyard where a gang of 10- and 11-year-old boys taunts me by pointing and shouting: Botox! Botox! I am not sure whether they think I need Botox, or are trying to tell me I look 10 years younger than my actual age. At any rate, I havent come up with an adequate response, and I hope you can help.

title: Luminarium
description: Picture yourself stepping into a small, cuboid room. In the center squats an old recliner, upholstered in black vinyl. To the chairs back is affixed a jointed metal arm, possibly on loan from a desk lamp. At the end of the arm, where the bulb and shade would have gone, hangs instead a sparkly gold motorcycle helmet, a vintage, visorless number with a chin strap.

title: Retrial for Clemens, and More Scolding for the Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled Friday that Roger Clemens, one of baseballs greatest pitchers, will face a new trial on charges that he lied to Congress about using performance enhancing-drugs.

title: Benefits of Some Benz Beneath the Skin
description: TESTED 2011 Dodge Durango Crew

title: Courtside: Lacking Star Power
description: So far the matches haven't been competitive at Arthur Ashe Stadium, a place where fans have come to expect good tennis.

title: Janes Carousel': Ponies Prance Across Dumbo
description: Twenty-seven years after being rescued from a burned-out Ohio theme park, 48 exquisitely restored carousel horses trotted, pranced, jumped  O.K., were pushed and pulled  some three or four blocks through the streets of Brooklyn on Friday morning. Their triumphant journey took them from the Dumbo studio of Jane Walentas, the artist who oversaw their restoration, to their new home, a transparent acrylic pavilion in Brooklyn Bridge Park designed by the French architect Jean Nouvel.

title: Courtside: Lacking Star Power
description: So far the matches havent been competitive at Arthur Ashe Stadium, a place where fans have come to expect good tennis.

title: New Arrest in Britains Phone Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  A 30-year-old man was arrested Friday as part of investigations into phone hacking, the police said in a statement. He became the 15th person held since a wide-ranging new inquiry into criminality at Rupert Murdochs News of the World newspaper began early this year.

title: TimesCast | September 02, 2011
description: The Obama administration abandons plans to tighten air-quality regulations; big banks may face federal lawsuits over mortgages; and upsets and injuries at the United States Open.

description: PROLOGUE

title: Wheelies: The Homecoming Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Europe Alarmed as Italys Austerity Plans Unravel
description: ROME  Just a few weeks ago, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi announced a sweeping 45.5 billion-euro package of austerity measures to help Italy stave off a sovereign debt crisis. Today, those measures are unraveling, subject to so much backtracking and political wrangling that European leaders are raising the pressure on Italy to deliver as promised.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Washington, Yemen and South Korea.

title: Sudan Attacks Disputed Border State
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Sudans internal conflicts have spread to yet another part of the country, with the Sudanese military shelling opposition strongholds and beginning a major ground offensive in Blue Nile State, Sudanese officials said Friday.

description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Washington, Yemen and South Korea.

title: The Emperor of Lies
description: Chapter One

title: Federal Regulators Sue Big Banks Over Mortgages
description: A bruising legal fight pitting the countrys most powerful banks against the full force of the United States government began Friday, as federal regulators filed suits against 17 financial institutions that sold the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac nearly $200 billion in mortgage-backed securities that later soured.

title: U.S. Open Replay: Day 5
description: Images from Day 5 of the United States Open in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Into the Air in Libya, With Hope and a Prayer
description: ZINTAN, Libya  Allahu Akbar. God is great.

title: Pennetta Defeats Sharapova
description: No. 3 seed Maria Sharapova was done in by her erratic second serve once again, falling to No. 26 seed Flavia Pennetta 6-3, 3-6, 6-4.

title: Stuyvesant Alumni Fail to Win Approval for 9/11 Vigil
description: Ten years after they watched and felt the World Trade Center towers crumble from their classroom windows, alumni from Stuyvesant High School have been trying to organize a vigil to commemorate that day. Theres only one problem: No one will let them back in or near their school on Sept. 11, 2011.

title: Bank Suits Over Mortgages Are Filed
description: Federal regulators filed suits on Friday against several of the nations leading banks, seeking billions in compensation for huge losses by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on mortgage-backed securities the banks assembled during the housing boom, The New York Times reports. Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, Citigroup, Barclays and Nomura are among the defendants in the suits, brought by the Federal Housing Finance Agency, which oversees Fannie and Freddie. Read more

title: Changing With the News
description: ALINA CHO, 40, a CNN national correspondent since 2004, has reported on topics like North Korea, President Barack Obamas election and Hurricane Katrina. She is now shooting Fashion: Backstage Pass, her third half-hour special devoted to New York Fashion Week, set to be shown on Sept. 17. Ms. Cho will then take the show overseas for the first time to cover the Paris fashion collections.

title: Reaching the Heights
description: To get pictures like the ones in this weeks cover story  a photo portfolio of ironworkers 70-plus stories off the ground at One World Trade Center  you have to do more than ride a couple hoists, climb a couple flights of temporary stairs and then open the camera shutter. You have to decide a year earlier that you want to get to the top, and then spend months persuading the Port Authority to let you do so. Then your photographer has to take two five-hour Occupational Safety and Health Administration classes devoted to construction-site safety, and a four-hour fall safety-awareness class. (Otherwise, how would you know that you really dont want to be tethered to anything that cant hold at least 10 times your weight? Because falling has the effect of making you heavier.) Finally, you have to go back-and-forth with the Port Authority for days to make sure youre on the building at the very beginning of a new two-floors-per-fortnight cycle, before the safety cocoon goes up, so your photographer can get the best possible views of the ironworkers against the skyline.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 2
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 2
description: More Photographs

title: Western N.Y. Flash: W.P.S. Champions
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Life is a constant series of moments. There are those that flow by, fleeting and unremembered. Then, there are the few among those millions that define an important part of us. Sometimes this happens in retrospect, but other times you can feel the importance of the impending moment right while its happening.

title: For Bank of New York Mellon, an Expensive Goodbye to Kelly
description: Parting is such costly sorrow.

title: Marcus Samuelsson Opens a Pop-Up at Alice Tully Hall
description: For a week starting on Thursday, Marcus Samuelsson will have a pop up, in the cafe at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, called Global Street Food. From 10:30 a.m. to 11 p.m. through Sept. 15 it will serve dishes like peri peri shrimp salad, fish falafel with yogurt sauce, and doro wat with injera bread, priced from $5 to $12.

title: Los Angeles Has Room for a Briton in Need of It
description: I HAVENT become a Bridezilla, Petra Ecclestone cooed languidly over the phone in her British accent. I think Ive been really relaxed. Thats just my personality.

title: Cuomo Faults Utilities on Slow Return of Power on L.I.
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, acknowledging widespread dissatisfaction with extended power failures on Long Island after Tropical Storm Irene, suggested on Friday that the Long Island Power Authority should consider replacing the energy company it pays to run its electric system, National Grid, when the contract expires.

title: Muller Defeats Gulbis in Four Sets
description: Gilles Muller of Luxembourg dashed the comeback hopes of Ernests Gulbis of Latvia on Friday, claiming a 3-6, 7-6 (4), 6-4, 7-6 (5) victory in a U.S. Open match played before a crowd of chanting supporters for both men.

title: New York Was Calm as Irene Stormed Through
description: LIKE most MetroCard-carrying New Yorkers, Sara Schwartz normally spends Saturday night flitting about the city. But as Hurricane Irene approached last week, the only place Ms. Schwartz was heading was to a sleepover party in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.

title: Students Find Ways to Thwart Facebook Bans
description: BANNING Facebook at school? Ha!

title: Pediatrician to Head Lets Move
description: Signaling its commitment to tackling the social issues that affect childhood obesity, the White House announced on Friday that Dr. Judith S. Palfrey will head Michelle Obamas Lets Move campaign to fight childhood oebsity.

title: Whos Making More Small-Business Loans Now? You May Be Surprised
description: Last weeks news that total commercial lending is up for the first time in three years but small-business lending continues to fall got The Agenda wondering: Is that true across the board? Or are some banks actually making more small-business loans, while others are making fewer?

title: The Week That Was, in Verse
description: Lazy August doldrums, right? Wrong. This week, as the summer comes to a close, DealBook brings you its final weekly installment of Wall Street poetry, the biggest stories of the week set in verse.

title: Long Story Shortlist, Tennis Edition
description: Gerald Marzorati, the former editor of the magazine, not only writes a tennis story with a mean topspin, but he can pick em, too. Some of his favorites from the archives (the annotations are his):

title: TimesCast | U.S. Open Tennis Update
description: Women's tennis sees upsets and injuries at the United States Open.

title: Lisicki Ends Falconis Run
description: Though she was a Georgia Tech Yellow Jacket, Irina Falconi plays her tennis like a bulldog.

title: Vivid Scenes of Defiance in Syria
description: Syrian activists said that another 11 protesters were killed by the countrys security forces on Friday, as my colleagues Nada Bakri and Steven Erlanger report.

title: In the Art World, No Lack of Ryans
description: ART lovers can be forgiven for mixing up some names. Consider the confusion between Steve McQueen, the British artist, and Steve McQueen, the 1960s Hollywood legend. Or between the American steel sculptors Tony Smith and David Smith. Or how about Judy Chicago, Gary Indiana and Marfa Texas? (Trick question: two are places, and two are people.)

title: Three-Wheeled Wonder
description: The Morgan Motor Company is bringing back a sports car with a classic, if unconventional, design.

title: This Sunday: Working It Out
description: As we were thinking about how to mark the 10th anniversary of 9/11, we had the luxury of knowing that our colleagues at The Times were preparing an ambitious package in print and on the Web site, allowing us to focus our efforts and not feel the need to cover every base. We chose to highlight the pictures that Damon Winter took for us of the ironworkers atop the rising One World Trade Center.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 2
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include dogs in bars, a dinner in white, and Tropical Storm Irene.

title: Obama Backs Down on Clean Air Rules
description: The Obama administration abandons its plan to tighten air-quality regulations.

title: A.I.G. Aircraft Leasing Unit Files for I.P.O.
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation, the aircraft leasing subsidiary of the American International Group, filed for an initial public offering on Friday, giving the insurance company a way to spin off the business and raise money to pay off its government bailout.

title: Meanwhile, in Europe
description: The Spanish and Italian interest rate spreads  the difference between their borrowing costs and Germanys  are widening again. So were drifting back toward the point at which these countries might enter vicious circles of falling confidence and rising debt burdens.

title: Cant Find a Job? Play the Lottery
description: Another economic indicator: Lottery ticket sales are up.

title: In a Marathon, Young Advances
description: Donald Young has long been burdened by the lofty expectations that came with being the youngest-ever world junior number one at age 16. Pegged as a talented underachiever who flailed due to poor coaching, the Chicago native went a long way to silencing his critics on court 17 Friday, showing stamina and heart in a dramatic, potentially career-changing, four-hour, 21-minute victory over the No. 14 seed, Stanislas Wawrinka, 7-6, 3-6, 2-6, 6-3, 7-6 (1).

title: Huge Teeth and Teenie-Weenie Bikinis
description: Shark movies are irresistible to Hollywood for many reasons, not the least being their limitless hospitality to close-ups of thrashing, bodacious young women wearing wet bikinis. Even in that sense, however, Shark Night 3D disappoints, despite its directors frequent attention to below-the-waist activity.

title: Albacore Deserves a Little Extra Attention
description: Albacore, which I write about this week in City Kitchen, is quite delicious when it is fresh, but most of it ends up in cans. When buying canned, it is a good idea to look for albacore that comes from small boats that take smaller fish: tastier, sweeter and lower in mercury. These cans are usually marketed by cooperatives, and contain no additives, like soy or vegetable broth. And at the risk of sounding un-American, generally speaking, better-quality canned tuna comes from elsewhere, like Italy or Spain. Imported tuna belly, ventresca, packed in olive oil, tends to be pricey, best thought of as a delicacy rather than a commonplace lunchbox item.

title: Group Says It Has New Evidence of Ciscos Misdeeds in China
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An advocacy group that accuses Cisco Systems of aiding the Chinese government in monitoring and apprehending members of the banned Falun Gong organization said Friday that it had new evidence to suggest that Cisco specifically tailored its technology for that purpose.

title: A Queen Pushes Out a King, Squashes a Jack
description: The turnout at the second World Youth Congress in Opatija, Croatia, last month was disappointing. This was partly explained by the tournaments proximity to the 23rd European Youth Team Championships, held in Albena, Bulgaria, from July 13 to 23.

description: To the Editor:

title: How to Find the Best Prices for Your Used Tech
description: Maybe its anticipation for the new iPhone 5, but something has electronics trade-in sites coming out of the walls. They pretty much all offer the same proposition: the best price for your used electronics. They cant all be right, which leaves it to you to find the sites, enter your data and sort out the results. Hardly worth the $2 youd get for a fourth-generation iPod Shuffle.

title: Reviewing the Morgan 3-Wheeler
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Jamie Lincoln Kitman reviews the Morgan 3-Wheeler, a spirited if anachronistic slice of automotive design unveiled earlier this year at the Geneva auto show.

description: The governments report on hiring, which showed no gain in jobs in August, provided fresh evidence that the recovery has fizzled without ever gaining momentum.

title: Brian Dennehy as a Troublemaker, Times Two
description: STRATFORD, Ontario  Brian Dennehy is making mischief all over the place at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival this summer. I refer not to the actor himself, of course, but to the two contrasting miscreants hes portraying onstage here in the fine productions of Shakespeares Twelfth Night and Harold Pinters Homecoming that are among the highlights of the companys season.

title: Why Wireless Markets Are Concentrated
description: In its suit to block AT&Ts $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile, the Justice Department leans heavily on the argument that consolidated market power is bad for consumers. More companies in an industry mean more competition and all the benefits that flow from competition  lower prices, more choices and more innovation.

title: Clip From 'Straw Dogs'
description: A scene from Sam Pekinpah's 1971 film "Straw Dogs."

title: Struggling to Keep Up With Those Mormons
description: The new Broadway musical The Book of Mormon has been setting box office records, and this has been the best summer yet for the long-running hits Wicked and The Lion King. But this blockbuster bounty has not trickled down to everything on Broadway; several major musicals have struggled to fill seats during an especially lucrative time of the year, with some shows closing, while others are bracing for the traditionally slow-selling fall.

title: Apples Unusual Hunt for a Missing iPhone
description: 9:58 p.m. | Updated  Revised throughout to reflect new information about the search for the phone.

description: NEW ORLEANS  A slow-moving and soggy storm that has been dawdling in the Gulf of Mexico for days is expected to come ashore this weekend, bringing rainfall so heavy that officials say excessive flooding is all but inevitable in areas along the coast.

title: Euro 2012 Qualifying: If You Took San Marino Getting 10 Goals, You Lost
description: No one, well, almost no one, is pining for the days of the Soviet Union. But you have to say this, the dissolution of the original Evil Empire also unleashed a cascade of new nations. Wonderful for those peoples, but for European soccer, it has injected creatures beyond the cliched minnows  plankton, if you will  into a sea already inhabited by the likes of Andorra, San Marino and Liechtenstein.
