title: The Caucus | Health Care Records
description: Kevin Sack looks at the heath care records of three governors running for president: Mitt Romney, Rick Perry and Jon Huntsman Jr.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Stances on Health Care Mask Their Records as Governors
description: The three most prominent current or former governors running for president  Rick Perry, Mitt Romney and Jon M. Huntsman Jr.  are firmly united in their commitment to repealing President Obamas health care law. But that unanimity masks a broad divergence in their approaches to the issue while in office, spanning the spectrum of Republican positioning.

title: Pass, Fail and Politics
description: ITS a foolish question, asking how smart a politician is.

title: New Conservatism in Europe Impedes Two of Its Nations
description: SVILENGRAD, Bulgaria  The infrared cameras here near Bulgarias borders with Greece and Turkey are high powered enough to pick up rabbits scampering across farm fields in the dead of night.

title: A Libyan Prisoner Lives to Tell His Story
description: TAJOURA, Libya

title: The Netsuke Survived
description: London

title: The Jobs Crisis
description: The August employment report, released on Friday, is bleak on all counts, but at least it leaves no doubt that the United States is in the grip of a severe and worsening jobs crisis. That should lend a sense of urgency to the speech on jobs that President Obama plans to deliver this week.

title: Libyas Dark Lesson for NATO
description: Steven Erlanger is the Paris bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: Evensong
description: Cynthia Zarin is the author, most recently, of The Ada Poems. This essay is excerpted from her forthcoming book An Enlarged Heart.

title: Violence Against Women: Walter Astradas Global View of A Global Problem
description: PERPIGNAN, France  Walter Astrada doesnt view his four-chapter project, Violence Against Women, as a story about a serious problem for women. Though it is.

title: The Limping Middle Class
description: Robert B. Reich is the former secretary of labor, a professor at the University of California, Berkeley, and the author of Aftershock: The Next Economy and Americas Future.

title: Do Happier People Work Harder?
description: Teresa Amabile, a professor at Harvard Business School, and Steven Kramer, an independent researcher, are the authors of The Progress Principle.

title: One Path to Better Jobs: More Density in Cities
description: Ryan Avent is an economics correspondent for The Economist and author of the Kindle Single The Gated City, from which this essay is adapted.

title: Cano Cleans Up in the Fourth Spot for the Yankees
description: Robinson Cano grounded into an inning-ending double play in his first at-bat Saturday, but he did not allow himself to forget about it. He loves to be dropped into situations  the tenser the better  in which he can make something happen. He had wasted his first chance to do so, but fortunately for the Yankees, it was not his last.

title: Fears in Miami That Port Expansion Will Destroy Reefs
description: MIAMI  As Miami prepares to dredge its port to accommodate supersize freighters, environmentalists are making a last-ditch effort to protect threatened coral reefs and acres of sea grass that they say would be destroyed by the expansion.

title: Im on Facebook. Its Over.
description: Curtis Sittenfeld is the author of the novels Prep and American Wife.

title: What Remains to Be Done
description: The 9/11 Commission has issued a disturbingly mixed report on the progress made in national security in the 10 years since the terrorist attacks. It found considerable improvements but also grave shortcomings that could leave the nation vulnerable to new and likely successful attacks. These include:

title: Words Failed, Then Saved Me
description: Philip Schultz is a winner of the Pulitzer Prize for poetry and the author of the forthcoming memoir My Dyslexia.

title: Novelists Predict Future With Eerie Accuracy
description: John Schwartz is the national legal correspondent for The New York Times.

title: New Dramas on the Hill (and a Few Reruns)
description: Congress returns to work this week, with spending cuts and regulations on its agenda. Before leaving for August recess, lawmakers were caught up in the Republican-created debt ceiling crisis, which ended with a compromise that is supposed to cut $917 billion from the federal deficit over 10 years. They also kicked the can on finding $1.5 trillion more to a supercommittee that is expected to release a plan by Nov. 23.

title: California Dreaming
description: California is on the brink of making a wise investment in its future and delivering a powerful rebuke to poisoned immigration politics at the national level. This week, the Legislature is expected to pass the California Dream Act, a bill to allow undocumented immigrants to receive state-financed college scholarships and loans. Earlier this summer, the state gave such students access to privately financed aid. The new bill should open even more doors to college degrees for young Californians, and Gov. Jerry Brown should quickly sign it.

title: Matthew Ferguson
description: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: Do Columnists Voices Reflect on The Times?
description: Re In an Age of Vitriol, What Is Out of Bounds? (Aug. 14):

title: Sunday Dialogue: Which School Reforms Will Work Best?
description: Readers discuss teacher quality and curriculum as schools deal with budget cuts and mandates.

title: Arizona Redistricting Panel Is Under Attack, Even Before Its Work Is Done
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Even before the drawing of new political boundaries, Arizonas redistricting commission has faced a barrage of criticism and a chorus of boos, not to mention a state investigation. Next up, a lawsuit.

title: The Fuller Story from Libya
description: My Sunday column tells the extraordinary tale of Salem al-Madhoun. A year ago, he was a senior naval officer in Qaddafis Libya. Six months ago, he was a defector and a leader in the underground battle to overthrow Qaddafi. Two weeks ago, he was enduring torture in prison. And now hes the military commander for the Tajoura area.

title: Palin Rails Against Crony Capitalism and Career Politicians
description: INDIANOLA, Iowa  Sarah Palin did not say whether she would seek the Republican presidential nomination, but she made clear during a speech here on Saturday that she has no intentions of simply falling into line behind one of the partys leading candidates.

title: What Will School Look Like in 10 Years?
description: Computers, electronic whiteboards and other interactive technologies are fundamentally changing American education. That is the view of the experts whom The Times spoke with about what the classroom will look like 10 years from now. Listen to excerpts from their predictions below, and share your own thoughts about their comments and Matt Richtels article about technology in schools in the comments section.

title: In Classroom of Future, Stagnant Scores
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  Amy Furman, a seventh-grade English teacher here, roams among 31 students sitting at their desks or in clumps on the floor. Theyre studying Shakespeares As You Like It  but not in any traditional way.

title: Sunday: Thats Disgusting!
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Dana Delany and I share a title, and no, its not celebrity. She was a guest-blogger back in April, and now she has teamed up with Matt Ginsberg to bring us this Sunday puzzle which, contrary to its title, is actually very pleasant.

title: The Keys to Schiavones Comeback Victory
description: Theres a wonderful book by Madeleine Blais about a girls high school basketball team (and much, much more, of course) called In These Girls, Hope Is Just a Muscle, that seemed to describe Francesca Schiavones comeback win5-7, 7-6(5), 6-3over Chanelle Scheepers.

title: One and Done?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Where Do You Find Value? Discussing the M.V.P. Criteria
description: Jose Bautista is a strict constructionist. To Bautista, the slugging right fielder for the Toronto Blue Jays, voting for the Most Valuable Player award should not be open to interpretation.

title: At Fordham, Steps to Return to Glory
description: Fordham football has a national championship to its credit and a glorious past that includes figures like Vince Lombardi, who was a member of its famed Seven Blocks of Granite. Sellouts at Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds were once the norm, so much so that the program generated enough interest to play in the first two televised football games.

title: Santanas Rehab Gets Back on Track
description: Johan Santana resumed his comeback from a torn capsule in his shoulder with a rehab start Saturday afternoon for the Class A Port St. Lucie Mets against Palm Beach. Santana threw 30 pitches, 21 of them for strikes, during two innings of work. He gave up three hits, one run and no walks and struck out two batters.

title: Fish Wins, But the Last Two Sets Are Tough
description: Eighth-seeded Mardy Fish of the United States built a two-set lead in two hours of energetic shotmaking against Kevin Anderson of South Africa, then dropped into a lower gear before forging a straight-set victory, 6-4, 7-6 (4), 7-6 (3). The win moved him into the fourth round.

title: On the Trail in New Hampshire, Perry Focuses on Jobs
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  You can just call him Superman.

title: Veterans Take Flight
description: The latest generation of disabled veterans are increasingly returning to the thrill-seeking activities they enjoyed before their injuries, for example, paragliding.

title: Wheels Up
description: The Able Pilot program in Ketchum, Idaho, puts paraplegics formerly in the military in the air with paragliders.

title: Accustomed to Wheels, Thrill-Seeking Injured Veterans Take Wing
description: KETCHUM, Idaho  Searching for ways to keep his adrenaline pumping after a motorcycle accident forced him out of the military and into a wheelchair, Darol Kubacz recast himself as something of a pioneer of extreme sports.

title: Rev. Eugene A. Nida, Who Spurred a Babel of Bibles, Is Dead at 96
description: The Rev. Eugene A. Nida, a linguist and Baptist minister who spurred a Babel of Bibles, recruiting and training native speakers to translate Scripture into a host of languages around the world, died on Aug. 25 at his home in Madrid. He was 96.

title: N.F.C. Scouting Report
description: East

title: Azarenka Battles, But Serena Williams Advances
description: Because of the U.S.T.A.s decision not to adjust Serena Williams No. 28 seeding, one of the top eight seeds was destined to draw her in the third round.

title: U.S. College Student Makes a Stand at the World Cup
description: The Chess World Cup has been an important part of the world championship cycle since 2005. There was no guarantee, given the history of the World Chess Federation, that it would continue to play such an important role. But it has.

title: Strauss-Kahn Appears Headed Back to France
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the embattled former head of the International Monetary Fund, emerged on Saturday afternoon from a building in TriBeCa where he had been staying for the past few months, dragging heavy pieces of luggage and loading them into the back of a dark blue van.

title: Man Charged With Stealing Laptops at U.S. Open
description: A Queens man has been charged with stealing two laptops from inside the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center at the United States Open this week, the Queens district attorney said Saturday.

title: More Eyes on Europes Borders
description: Bulgaria and Romania want to join the European Unions visa-free travel zone, but concerns about corruption linger.

title: Surf Stars of New York
description: New Yorks shores are home to the most promising crop of surfers in a generation. Here are a few.

title: Local Grocery Stores Try to Find Traction in Tough Times
description: Bessie Morris went into Bayviews new Fresh & Easy supermarket for the first time last Sunday. She needed to pick up just some ground turkey and sandwich cheese, but one thing led to another.

title: Heart Failure Program Has Reduced Readmissions by 30 Percent
description: Since July, Mochun Li has been hospitalized at the U.C.S.F. Medical Center three times. On some nights, Ms. Li had struggled so hard to breathe that she had not been able to sleep.

title: Surfing New Yorks Shores
description: The Association of Surfing Professionals competition will put the spotlight on the surfing scene on Long Island.

title: City Photos, Mapped Out and Online
description: When Dan Vanderkam moved to San Francisco in 2007 to work at Google, he became fascinated with his new citys history, listening to local podcasts on the subject and digging into the San Francisco Public Librarys online repository of old pictures.

title: The Oakland Temple
description: The five-spired white granite landmark known simply as the Mormon Temple is a center for Northern California members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The public may enter the grounds and the visitors center but not the temple itself; entry there requires a membership card.  LOUISE RAFKIN

title: Williams Moves On, Gathering Steam
description: Victoria Azarenka never publicly complained about her draw at the United States Open, which aligned her to meet the three-time champion Serena Williams in only the third round.

title: Its Time to Learn to Think Like Steve Jobs
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Big 12 to Pac-12? Oklahoma Ponders a Move
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The fragile collegiate conference landscape appears to have cracked. As uncertainty has surrounded the Big 12 Conference the past few weeks, Oklahoma appeared to be the linchpin holding the conference together.

title: Application of First Strike Policy Is Questioned
description: Nothing could have prepared Jessica Moore for the morning 19 Chicago police officers rushed her front door around 8 oclock.

title: Players Bowing Out in a Record Number
description: Six days into the United States Open, tournament organizers released a rare tennis-tournament injury report. This is common in the N.F.L., in which teams are required to release similar lists each week. But for the Open to take such measures took a retirement rate of record proportions.

title: With Online Filing System, Property Tax Appeals Get Easier
description: Beginning Tuesday, for the first time, owners of the 1.83 million real estate parcels in Cook County will be able to file online appeals of their tax bills.

title: Winds Jostle Top Players
description: Roger Federer beat Marin Cilic on Saturday at the Open to win his 225th match at a major. On the womens side, top-seeded Caroline Wozniacki rolled through a blustery afternoon to advance.

title: Another Day for Bolt
description: Usain Bolt remained the star attraction at the track and field world championships, claiming an electrifying victory in the 200.

title: Fight for Longer School Day Shifts to Principals Level
description: Just days after ruling out a strike, the Chicago Teachers Union finds itself grappling with dissent among members and fighting for public support as district leaders have begun circumventing the union in their push for a longer school day this year.

title: No Longer Just a Sideshow, Golfs Home Run Hitters Climb the Leader Board
description: NORTON, Mass.  There is just something about the long ball. The tape-measure jobs  the kind that scream power, raise the hair on the backs of necks, bring gasps and ovations from the crowds  have always been a vital part of golfs appeal, even if very long hitters themselves often occupied the fringes of the sport.

title: Battle for Libya | September 3, 2011
description: As rebels continued their hunt for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, residents in Tripoli and elsewhere were sorting through the aftermath of the rebellion.

title: Having Lost Big When It Counted Most, Democrats Place Their Hopes on a Trial
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: U.S. Is Appealing to Palestinians to Stall U.N. Vote
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has initiated a last-ditch diplomatic campaign to avert a confrontation this month over a plan by Palestinians to seek recognition as a state at the United Nations, but it may already be too late, according to senior American officials and foreign diplomats.

title: Divisive Pollution Rule Remains on Schedule
description: As the Obama administration pulls back on a broad rule to combat ozone pollution, a different rule that would also reduce smog-forming chemicals in Texas remains on track.

title: Lottery Numbers
With Texas Network, U.T. Remakes the Playing Field
description: The Longhorn Network came to life on Aug. 26 with a stirring introductory montage narrated by the actor Matthew McConaughey. Ours is the color of the sunset and leather, Mr. McConaughey, a famous University of Texas alumnus, intoned. Then, a few lines later: One flag, one star, one state, one school.

title: Summer of Protest in Israel Peaks With 400,000 in City Streets
description: JERUSALEM  As many as 400,000 Israelis demonstrated on Saturday night against the high cost of living and for social justice in one of the largest protests in the nations history, although questions remained about about what it might achieve.

title: At Telluride Screenings, the Awards Race Begins
description: Telluride is a friendly, informal, remote place where movie stars shed some of their glamor and mingle with the friendly crowds. George Clooney strolled into the patrons brunch on Friday  an al fresco, invitation-only event held on the first morning of the film festival at a mountainside ranch with stunning views  and suddenly everyone seemed to be plotting a route to the beverage tent that would allow for an accidental elbow-brush and an impromptu chat. Eventually Mr. Clooney found his way to a table, and later to a semi-secret screening of The Descendants, Alexander Paynes new film, his first feature since Sideways in 2004.

title: Havre de Grace Becomes Second Filly to Win Woodward Stakes
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  When 4-year-old filly Havre de Grace trounced seven older males in the Woodward Stakes on Saturday, the best reaction did not come from her owner, her trainer, or the jockey who rode her to victory.

title: College Football Replay: Sept. 3
description: The first Saturday of the season included last-minute victories and long weather delays.

title: Rare Homer by Bay Cant Save Gee, Parnell and the Mets
description: WASHINGTON  As the Mets season limps toward its conclusion, the progress of individual players will take the spotlight from actual wins and losses.

title: What to Watch on Sunday: Junior Edition
description: A year ago, Jack Sock wasnt playing Andy Roddick in front of 22,000 fans in Arthur Ashe stadium. Instead he was on the outer courts, where a few aluminum bleachers suffice for the smattering of college coaches, equipment representatives, agents and family members who are the primary spectators at junior matches.

title: Stumbling on Big Stage, Last Teenager Goes Out
description: The American Sloane Stephens moves fast, talks faster and is the fastest-climbing teenager in the womens tennis world rankings. So swift was her progression at this years United States Open that Stephens was rushed onto Arthur Ashe Stadium for her third-round match against Ana Ivanovic on Saturday night without having played first on Louis Armstrong Stadium, the intermediate show court.

title: Goddesses and Beasts in a Dusky, Lilting Roar
description: LONDON

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: CHRIS RAINEY The Florida receiver scored three different ways in a victory over Florida Atlantic. Rainey touched the ball 18 times, scoring on a 14-yard reception and a 14-yard run. He also scooped up a blocked punt and sprinted 22 yards for a touchdown.

title: Corrections: September 4
description: NATIONAL

title: L.S.U. Sends Message in Clash of Conferences
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Off the field, where seemingly all the action is in college sports these days, the Pacific-12 and the Southeastern Conferences appear poised to grow.

title: In Georgia, Another Show of Dominance by Boise State
description: ATLANTA  There will always be one more reckoning, or one more referendum placed on the Boise State football program. The skeptics cannot believe a program with a blue rug for a football field can break the lance of a college from a powerhouse conference.

title: A.F.C. Scouting Report
description: East

title: The Americanization of Romulus and Remus
description: Just as Paul from Bellerose Terrace weighed in nervously on Arsenals future two weeks ago, Michael J. Agovino offers a fans perspective on what the purchase of Roma by a Boston businessman might mean for the famed Italian club. Read his thoughts here, and come back to comment.

title: What to Watch on Sunday
description: Remember Donald Young, the onetime tennis prodigy who signed with an agent at 14? Donald Young who was being touted by national magazines like Sports Illustrated as the next big thing before he was old enough to drive?

title: Back in France, Strauss-Kahn Is Eye of Media Tornado
description: PARIS  It was not quite like the arrival of a pope, with a kiss of the tarmac, but the press attention was comparable on Sunday morning when a relieved Dominique Strauss-Kahn returned to France.

title: The Repository
description: For nearly a decade, a large white tent has stood on Manhattans East Side, out of urban context and hard against the sooty Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. A gauzy drapery divides the tent space: on one side, a quiet makeshift chapel; on the other, three walk-in storage units containing nearly 14,000 human remains from the World Trade Center catastrophe, air-dried and vacuum-sealed.

title: Music Festivals to Take Over Berlin
description: As Berlin embraces its increasing popularity as a tourist destination, the city is also learning how to capitalize on what might be its biggest draw: its profuse music and night-life offerings. And so the bells and whistles are out for the second edition of Berlin Music Week, which will engulf the citys many bars, clubs and various repurposed urban spaces from Sept. 7 to 11.

title: Q&A: Getting a Webcam to Work With Skype
description: Q.

title: In Classroom of Future, Stagnant Scores
description: Schools are embracing digital learning, but evidence is scarce that the expensive technology is improving educational outcomes.

title: Two Thin Cameras Packing Fat Lenses
description: To paraphrase a famous saying, a camera can never be too (feature) rich or too thin.

title: Bloomberg Defends His Handling of Aides Arrest
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged on Sunday that he had concealed the domestic violence arrest of former Deputy Mayor Stephen Goldsmith, but said he would not apologize for his actions, even as Mr. Goldsmith said he regretted keeping the event secret.

title: Portraits Redrawn: Talat Hamdani
description: Talat Hamdani's son, Salman, gave his life helping others on Sept 11. But early on, the mystery that surrounded the disappearance of the young American Muslim caused suspicion.

title: Anne and Kimmy
description: In this homemade video, Dr. Anne Rounds and Kimmy Szeto illustrate the start of their relationship together, which began when Dr. Rounds was an undergraduate student and Mr. Szeto was her teacher.

title: Ndidi & Vincent
description: In this homemade video, Ndidi Oriji recalls testing the waters of internet dating, where on her third attempt she found Vincent Southerland.

title: A Storm in Louisiana, a Tinge of Envy in Texas
description: 5:30 p.m. | Updated Tropical Storm Lee made landfall in Louisiana on Sunday morning, bringing heavy rain, tornadoes and flash flood watches to much of the Southeast.

title: Zombies on ABC
description: Boy, that was a morning of the undead.

title: The Supply-side Virus
description: A correspondent suggests that now might be a good time to get my old Slate article on supply-side economics back into circulation. It does look pretty good, 15 years later.

title: At Open, a New Look for the Bookstore
description: Four or five straight hours of tennis doesnt seem to faze the playerseven if Donald Young looked a bit wobbly after his marathon Friday nightbut its tough on spectators. Not the matches themselves, but the heat, the sun, above all the surging crowds moving in a constant swarm through the grounds and inducing the claustrophobic feel of a subway platform with no train in sight.

title: Journal Economics
description: Rereading my old supply-side article, I was reminded of just how consistently, awesomely wrong the Journal opinion section has been for two decades now. Think about it (no time for full links); by reading that section you could have learned, either from the editorial page proper or from the papers favorite op-ed guys, that

title: Leaked Cables Offer Glimpses Into Relations of U.S. and China
description: BEIJING  This capital citys skies were clogged with pollution, as is often the case, and Chinas government was concerned. So it summoned officials of the American Embassy here to a meeting.

title: After the Storm, a Treasure Hunt
description: Ana Ramirez, 35, of Coney Island swung her metal detector over the sand just off the Coney Island Boardwalk in the shadow of the Wonder Wheel ride.

title: China Aims to Rein In Car Sales
description: TIANJIN, China  After a decade of nurturing Chinas auto industry to become the largest in the world, this countrys leaders are having second thoughts.

title: China Sought to Sell Arms to Qaddafi, Documents Suggest
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  In the final weeks of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis battle with Libyan rebels, Chinese state companies offered to sell his government large stockpiles of weapons and ammunition in apparent violation of United Nations sanctions, officials of Libyas transitional government said Sunday. They cited Qaddafi government documents found by a Canadian journalist, which the officials said were authentic.

title: In Final Event, Jamaica Sets a World Record in Relay
description: DAEGU, South Korea  It was not the most symbolic finish: Usain Bolt sprinting unaccompanied with a 10-meter lead on his way to another world record.

title: Cheney Wonders: What Would Hillary Do?
description: It has become a popular refrain for Democrats bemoaning a president who has spent the summer slamming into one political road block after another: If Hillary Rodham Clinton had won the partys nomination and the general election in 2008, would she have been a more effective president?

title: In New Jersey, Obama Vows Federal Help, Not Washington Politics
description: PATERSON, N.J.  President Obama, surveying some of the most crippling flood damage from Tropical Storm Irene, vowed on Sunday that budgetary wrangling in Washington would not delay federal aid to stricken communities.

title: The Help Holds No. 1 at the Box Office
description: The Help officially achieved blockbuster status over the weekend by holding onto the No. 1 spot at North American multiplexes for a third consecutive week. That DreamWorks Studios movie, based on the best-selling novel about black maids in the 1960s and their white employers, took in an estimated $14.2 million for a new total of $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Second place went to The Debt, a Focus Features espionage drama that sold a surprisingly robust $9.7 million in tickets for a total of about $14 million since opening on Wednesday; solid reviews and the potential thrill of seeing Helen Mirren as a retired but still derrire-kicking Mossad agent probably drove interest. The weekends other two new releases came in neck and neck: Apollo 18, a thriller from the Weinstein Company, was a limp third with an estimated $8.7 million in ticket sales, and Shark Night 3-D (Relativity Media) took in about $8.6 million for fourth place. Rounding out the top five was 20th Century Foxs Rise of the Planet of the Apes, which sold $7.8 million in tickets for a five-week total of about $160 million.

title: TNT Ends Jada Pinkett Smiths Show
description: As TNT approached the end of a summer that gave it two new hit shows, Falling Skies and Franklin & Bash, the cable channel pulled the plug on an older show, HawthoRNe. The channel said on Friday that it had elected not to order a fourth season of the show, which featured Jada Pinkett Smith as chief nursing officer at a hospital. TNT truly appreciates the tremendous dedication of everyone involved, it said in a statement. TNT recently ordered a second season of Falling Skies, which was the most popular new cable show of the summer with an average of 6.9 million viewers, and Franklin & Bash, which averaged 3.9 million. The third season of HawthoRNe typically had about 3.3 million viewers. The cancellation may also make room for one of the shows that TNT is developing, like its remake of Dallas or its spin-off of The Closer, Major Crimes.

title: Nadal Dispatches Nalbandian
description: If youve ever noticed that Rafael Nadal looks fresh and ready for action when he arrives on court for a match, the secret is out. He takes a cold shower.

title: Kerber of Germany Strolls Into Womens Quarterfinals
description: The random nature of tennis draws rarely makes for an even, linear progression in difficulty through a tournament.

title: Bloomberg and Goldsmith Make First Comments on Deputy Mayors Arrest
description: On Sunday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made his first public comments responding to the firestorm of criticism over misleading information that he gave to the public regarding the resignation of former Deputy Mayor Stephen Goldsmith. Also on Sunday, Mr. Goldsmith emailed The Times with a statement. Heres a transcript of Mayor Bloombergs remarks, given outside the Christian Cultural Center in Brooklyn, followed by the text of Mr. Goldsmiths email.

title: Looking for a Game
description: Martin Emmrich of Germany and his doubles partner, Andreas Siljestrm, from Sweden, flew to New York with the hope that someone would withdraw from the United States Open and give them a chance to play in their first Grand Slam event.

title: Jets Put McElroy on Injured Reserve; Juggle Roster
description: Greg McElroys rookie season ended Sunday when the Jets placed him on injured reserve as part of a series of roster-sculpturing moves.

title: A Survivor in Libya
description: Salem al-Madhoun, a Libyan Navy officer who defected to the rebels, was imprisoned and tortured by Qaddafi's forces. He's recently been set free and tells his story.

title: Rare Power From Jeter, Standard Quality From Sabathia
description: Derek Jeter did two things Sunday that he does not usually do. He pulled a three-run homer into the left-field bleachers, and he knocked in five runs.

title: When the Mayors Management Style Becomes a Study in Arrested Development
description: Now 10 years into his mayoralty, Michael R. Bloomberg still tends to view the office of the mayor as akin to a hallway at Bloomberg L.P.

title: What Is Naturalism?
description: Many contemporary philosophers describe themselves as naturalists. They mean that they believe something like this: there is only the natural world, and the best way to find out about it is by the scientific method. I am sometimes described as a naturalist. Why do I resist the description? Not for any religious scruple: I am an atheist of the most straightforward kind. But accepting the naturalist slogan without looking beneath the slick packaging is an unscientific way to form ones beliefs about the world, not something naturalists should recommend.

title: Close Out the Summer With 2-For-1 Broadway Tickets
description: Interested in two tickets for the price of one to Wicked? How about seeing either The Lion King or Martin Luther King Jr. (subject of the new play The Mountaintop)? A promotion from the marketing and tourism organization NYC & Company will say farewell to summer with a discount deal that includes these shows and several more as part of Broadway Week, which runs Sept. 18-30.

title: For Satin, a Mets Farmhand, 1 Hit, 1 Run, Plenty of Thrills
description: WASHINGTON  Josh Satin strolled into Nationals Park just after 10 a.m. on Sunday and quickly fell into step with a reporter, who asked him about being in the Mets lineup for their game that afternoon.

title: When the Camera Takes Over
description: Amateur photographers become a part of the art at the Venice Biennale.

title: When the Camera Takes Over for the Eye
description: SCIENTISTS have yet to determine what percentage of art-viewing these days is done through the viewfinder of a camera or a cellphone, but clearly the figure is on the rise. Thats why Ruth Fremson, the intrepid photographer for The New York Times who covered the Venice Biennale this summer, returned with so many images of people doing more or less what she was doing: taking pictures of works of art or people looking at works of art. More or less.

title: Tennis Channel Pulled From Cablevision and Verizon Systems
description: Cablevision and Verizon FiOS customers abruptly lost their access to Tennis Channel on Sunday midway through the United States Open.

title: Roddick Shows Another Side in Latest Victory
description: There just might be something left to Andy Roddick at this years U.S. Open after all. Roddick roared back to life with a convincing 6-1, 6-4, 7-6 win over Julien Benneteau, mixing power with patience, serving with authority but also playing with a high shot tolerance. Compared with his first two rounds, in which he looked tentative and defensive, Roddick worked the point until he got a short ball then approached with a knifing backhand slice. His ground game and movement were visibly improved from his awkward win over Jack Sock on Friday night.

title: Monday: Feels Great!
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Well, hello there! I hope you all had a good week, and before we tear into another weeks worth of crossword puzzles, Id like to sincerely thank Thomas Gaffney for stepping up to the plate and batting them out of the park while I was off mopping my brow. Tom did an excellent job, as did the wonderful players in the dugout who helped support him, and they all deserve a round of applause from the fans in the stands. Id throw some more baseball metaphors in there, but thats pretty much all Ive got. My point is, he did a great job and I had a wonderful vacation, so thanks again, Tom.

title: Postal Service Is Nearing Default as Losses Mount
description: The United States Postal Service has long lived on the financial edge, but it has never been as close to the precipice as it is today: the agency is so low on cash that it will not be able to make a $5.5 billion payment due this month and may have to shut down entirely this winter unless Congress takes emergency action to stabilize its finances.

title: China Challenges U.S. Supremacy in Shale Gas
description: China has a chance of challenging the United States for shale supremacy. So far, only the United States has significantly exploited domestic reserves of shale gas. But Sinopec, Chinas major state-run oil company, is now taking shale seriously and lacks many of the roadblocks that have held back developers in other countries.

title: Counterstrike
description: KNOW THINE ENEMY

title: What We Kept
description: A selection of items kept by Times readers who were living in New York City on Sept. 11.

title: Townsend Advances in Juniors
description: The first round of the U.S. Open junior girls singles draw got underway on Sunday and the 15-year-old Taylor Townsend just needed 60 minutes to advance. Townsend, who lost in the third round of the womens qualifying tournament a week and a half ago, defeated No. 15 Jesika Maleckova with ease, 6-1, 6-4.

title: The Power of Bill
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

title: Palin Is Running, but in a Half-Marathon
description: DES MOINES  Sarah Palin decided on Sunday that she was running  a half-marathon, that is.

title: Deterring Enemies in a Shaken World
description: In an audacious operation that unfolded like a Hollywood thriller, the Navy Seals executed a daring raid deep into Pakistan to kill Osama bin Laden. The departing members of the Seals took not only the body of bin Laden but also a cache of invaluable intelligence on his organization, Al Qaeda. It is fitting that Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker, veteran security correspondents for The New York Times, begin and end their insightful new book about United States counterterrorism efforts with this triumph. The United States, they argue, could not have pulled off the same raid 10 years ago. The bin Laden strike was the logical culmination of nearly a decade of missteps, mistakes, trial and error under fire, and ultimately lessons not only learned but taken to heart.

title: Film Is Skeptical About Domestic Efforts on Terrorism
description: LOS ANGELES  The film Better This World introduces itself with the frightening sounds of television anchors filtering the news of a terrorist plot against the Republican National Convention in 2008. Disturbing news tonight about homegrown terror, one of the anchors says, not for the first time and not for the last.

title: In California, Amazon Pushes Hard to Kill a Tax
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The struggling state of California thinks it has found gold in taxing e-commerce. But that money is proving much more elusive than it seemed just a few months ago.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for August (Tuesday); the Federal Reserves beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and the July trade deficit and consumer credit figures (Thursday), and wholesale trade for July (Friday).

title: Chunks of Memory, Reassembled Onstage
description: Last year Rock the Bells, the touring hip-hop bonanza, picked up on the voguish festival concept in which an artist performs an old record from beginning to end. It went well, and this years edition bought in twice as hard. On Saturday on Governors Island, amid other, more ordinary sets, 11 albums were performed in their entirety.

title: An Island Sways to Dance Moves and Disco Balls
description: Clean or dirty? Uplifting or brutal? Those were choices dance-music fans could make on Saturday, the second day of the weekend-long Electric Zoo 2011 on Randalls Island. They could go for the polished tones, warm chords and step-by-step buildups of trance and house, the overlapping styles that have long dominated dance clubs worldwide and that gave Electric Zoo its headliners: Tiesto on Friday, David Guetta on Saturday and Armin van Buuren on Sunday. The unsubtle four-on-the-floor beat of trance has been a longtime staple of European pop hits, and in recent years American acts like Black Eyed Peas, Lady Gaga and Rihanna have also embraced it.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Nuclear Bunker Comes In From the Cold as an Art Gallery
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  The Yugoslav Army would have been hard pressed to find a more scenic spot to build a nuclear bunker.

title: Standard Fare Upended, to Reinvent and Explore
description: Among the numerous innovations instituted at Bargemusic by the violinist Mark Peskanov since he became its president and executive and artistic director in 2006, the least likely wrinkle has proved the most durable. Here and Now, an irregularly scheduled but consistently active series devoted to contemporary music, has enlivened the offerings at this longtime bastion for conventional fare.

title: Nadal Wins; Then Comes the Hard Part
description: In his recently published autobiography, Rafael Nadal paints an unvarnished picture of professional tennis, one that exposes unsightly wrinkles like the friction between him and the loved one who is his coach, and the pain and insecurities and loneliness of the gilded life.

title: With or Without an AT&T Deal for T-Mobile, Sprint Faces Daunting Challenges
description: If the Justice Department succeeds in blocking the $39 billion merger of AT&T and T-Mobile, the deepest sighs of relief may well come from the executives at Sprint Nextel, the countrys third-largest wireless carrier.

title: Delaying Diamonds at Youth Congress
description: As I have mentioned, the American performances at the second World Youth Congress in Croatia last month were disappointing, However, Roger Lee of Monrovia, Calif., would have won the award for the best-played deal had there been one. It is in the diagramed deal and occurred during the Knockout Teams.

title: A Squeaky-Clean Shot at Pop Stardom
description: The musical childrens television series The Wannabes, a synthetic but inoffensive piece of international entertainment product, wont add much to the Starz channels reputation as sources of original content. Its virtues lie more in the area of brand extension.

title: World Track and Field Championships
description: The nine-day meet in Daegu, South Korea, ended with excitement in the 4x100-meter relays.

title: Rosel Zech, a Movie Actress Favored by Fassbinder, Dies at 69
description: Rosel Zech, a German actress best known to American audiences for playing the title role in Rainer Werner Fassbinders grim 1982 satire, Veronika Voss, died on Wednesday in Berlin. She was 69.

title: Vermont Turns Out for Its Dairies as They Take Stock and Dig Out
description: SOUTH ROYALTON, Vt.  As soon as the news of the disaster at the Perley Farm began to spread  how the fast-rising waters of the White River had washed away nearly 200 bales of hay, flooded the farmhouse and then swept some of the cows down the river to their deaths  neighbors and strangers alike began arriving at the muddy barn here to offer help.

title: Facebook Page for Jesus, With Highly Active Fans
description: A North Carolina diet doctor has come up with a formula to create the most highly engaged audience on Facebook in the world, far surpassing marketing efforts by celebrities and sports teams. He draws on the words of Jesus and posts them four or five times a day.

title: Ways to Use The Learning Network
description: For school year 2011-12.

title: Neither Smurf Nor Wizard Could Save Summer Movie Attendance
description: LOS ANGELES  It was the summer that North American movie attendance continued to slide, Hollywoods reliance on overseas ticket sales intensified, the Smurfs flexed their minimuscles and a cadre of A-list stars flopped  again.

title: Ex-Premier Faces Charges for Icelands Fiscal Woes
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  The dust from Icelands spectacular financial disaster  the failure of its three biggest banks and then the collapse of its economy in the fall of 2008  had barely begun to settle when the country set about finding someone to blame.

title: Partisan Fighting Carries Risks at Election Time
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas renewed engagement with Congressional Republicans this week may seem all too familiar, but it comes with a darkly unpredictable component.

title: For Some Eagles, a Dream Situation
description: In his first news conference with Philadelphia, Vince Young set the tone for the team and the city when he was asked to characterize the Eagles collection of high-profile talent.

title: Lee Loses Strength, but Still Poses a Flooding Threat
description: NEW ORLEANS  The remnants of what was once Tropical Storm Lee, a slow-moving but extremely wet system that lumbered its way onto the Louisiana coast on Sunday, were still bringing high winds and rains to the Gulf Coast on Monday morning, leaving a wet Labor Day but less damage than had been feared.

title: Amid a Large City, a Noisy Racing Village
description: BALTIMORE  For the inaugural Baltimore Grand Prix, a three-day event featuring major IndyCar and Le Mans-style street races, downtown Baltimore was transformed into a festive street fair, with just a dash of disaster-movie quarantine zone.

title: Anger After a Raid Kills a Wealthy Afghan With a Murky Past
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In life and death, Sabar Lals story was riddled with conflicting narratives.

title: Discharged for Being Gay, Veterans Seek to Re-enlist
description: They lived shadow lives in the military, afraid that disclosure of their sexuality would ruin carefully plotted careers. Many were deeply humiliated by drawn-out investigations and unceremonious discharges.

title: Tough Times in the Second City
description: Chicago

title: Chinas Challenge at Sea
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Inmate Visits Now Carry Added Cost in Arizona
description: For the Arizona Department of Corrections, crime has finally started to pay.

title: How The Help Depicts Race Relations
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Romney Draws Sparse Protest at Tea Party Event
description: Mitt Romneys keynote speech Sunday night at a Tea Party Express rally in Concord, N.H., was perhaps more notable for what did not happen  there were no fiery clashes with Tea Party protesters, or angry hecklers  than for what did  Mr. Romney delivered a lively version of his standard stump speech.

title: Leaving Detroit for Tulsa, the Shock Lost Their Way
description: TULSA, Okla.  Once, it seemed an intriguing idea for prefab success, dismantling a three-time W.N.B.A. championship team in Detroit and relocating it brick by brick to this regional hotbed for womens basketball.

title: Radio D.J. in the Catskills Offered a Lifeline During the Storm
description: WINDHAM, N.Y.  In these days of smartphones and social media, a small-town radio D.J. like Big Jay Fink may seem like an improbable source of emergency information.

title: Libyans Turn Wrath on Dark-Skinned Migrants
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  As rebel leaders pleaded with their fighters to avoid taking revenge against brother Libyans, many rebels were turning their wrath against migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, imprisoning hundreds for the crime of fighting as mercenaries for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi without any evidence except the color of their skin.

title: Injury Sidelines Bud Collins and His Pants
description: Bud Collins had picked out a gaudy purple pair of slacks, with appropriate floral patterns, but he never got to wear them to the United States Open on Sunday.

title: Migrants Face the Suspicions and Wrath of Libyan Rebels
description: Libyan rebels have imprisoned hundreds of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, accusing them of being mercenaries for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: A Tech Blogger Who Leaps Over the Line
description: When Michael Arrington, the editor of the popular Web site TechCrunch, told his bosses at AOL that he was forming a venture capital company to finance some of the technology start-ups that his site wrote about, they did not fire him or ask for his resignation. Instead, last week, they invested about $10 million in his fund.

title: The Fatal Distraction
description: Friday brought two numbers that should have everyone in Washington saying, My God, what have we done?

title: Migrants Face the Suspicions and Wrath of Libyan Rebels
description: Libyan rebels have imprisoned hundreds of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, accusing them of being mercenaries for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Samsung Removes Tablet From Trade Show After Injunction
description: Samsung Electronics will not showcase the Galaxy Tab 7.7, its latest tablet computer, at one of the largest electronics shows after Apple won a second injunction blocking sales of the computer in Germany.

title: Hopes Rising, G.O.P. Voters Seek a Winner
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Roy Barbuto is on the hunt. For the past few months, he has been searching for the perfect Republican candidate, and he shows no signs of flagging.

title: Home-Court Edge? Roddick Takes It, Happily
description: Late in the match, Andy Roddick heard a team-sport cheer, the kind the Yankees hear from their Bleacher Creatures, the kind the Rangers hear from the upper rows of the Garden.

title: Its Still the 9/11 Era
description: Osama bin Laden is dead. So is Saddam Hussein, and Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, and too many Qaeda No. 3s to count. Khalid Shaikh Mohammed is awaiting his military tribunal. George W. Bush is home on the ranch, Dick Cheney is on book tour, and even Gen. David Petraeus is a general no more, having traded in his stars for a civilian position atop the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: A Debate Arises on Job Creation and Environment
description: Do environmental regulations kill jobs?

title: L.S.U.s Coach Makes People Chuckle, but His Team Usually Has the Last Laugh
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  With his stiff-brimmed hat, penchant for straight-to-YouTube sound bites and a legacy of play calls as daring as his clock management is baffling, Louisiana States Les Miles is equal parts cult figure and football coach. Miles eats grass, kissed a pig at a charity event this off-season and can rival Yogi Berra for his meandering turns of phrase.

title: On Flood Plain, Pondering Wisdom of Rebuilding Anew
description: PHOENICIA, N.Y.  For all the destruction and heartache left by Tropical Storm Irene in the Catskill Mountains, the storm was only the latest to cause catastrophic flooding in the region in recent years. With each one, residents have cleaned up, rebuilt and moved on, as resolutely as ever. Now, though, some are asking a once-unthinkable question: Should the rebuilding come to a halt?

title: Lessons on Health Care
description: Rick Perry and Mitt Romney, two of the leading candidates right now for the Republican presidential nomination, have declared themselves fiercely opposed to President Obamas health care reform.

title: With One Day to Go, Leader Board Shows a Throng at the Top
description: NORTON, Mass.  It is a fairly safe bet that cars heading north on Route 95 out of Cape Cod on Monday will not be packed any tighter than golfers on the leader board after three rounds of the Deutsche Bank Championship.

title: State Election Adds to Gains by Social Democrats in Germany
description: BERLIN  Parties on the German left prevailed in a regional election in the northeastern state of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania on Sunday, with the center-left Social Democrats swept back to power and the Greens elected to the regional parliament for the first time, according to preliminary results.

title: Once-Rising Star Finds Closer View of the Top
description: Donald Young, once a teenage prodigy with the future of American tennis on his shoulders, entered the United States Open as an afterthought.

title: All-American, Floor to Roof? Not So Simple
description: BOZEMAN, Mont.  Anders Lewendal, a general contractor who managed to survive the housing collapse, has hit upon a plan that he thinks will revive the construction industry and help lead the nation out of the economic wilderness: build houses using only American-made materials.

title: A Tiny New Stage for High-Energy Tennis
description: The latest attraction in Flushing Meadows resides eight feet below ground level, in a virtually private corner of the National Tennis Center, past the chaos of the food court and beyond the shadow of Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Media Strive to Cover 9/11 Without Seeming to Exploit a Tragedy
description: Anniversaries are hard to resist for most media outlets. The stories are evergreen, the advertising potential plentiful.

title: Suspect Is Sought After 8 Are Wounded in Bronx Shooting
description: Eight people, including three children, were shot at a crowded backyard party in the Bronx early Sunday, and the police said they were looking for a 17-year-old in connection with the shooting.

title: Japans Latest Prime Minister
description: Little remains of the bright promises of reform that swept Japans Democratic Party to power two years ago. The ruling Democrats choice of Finance Minister Yoshihiko Noda to become prime minister  the partys third since that historic election  is uninspired and unlikely to provide the strong and creative leadership Japan needs to recover from the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster or its longer-term economic malaise.

title: Catholic School Teachers Wrestle With Faith and Obedience in Negotiating a Contract
description: Wednesday morning, on the first day of the new school year at St. Pauls Roman Catholic School in East Harlem, Gertrude Zagarella expects to arrive, as always, at 7:05. By 7:45, the children  mostly Hispanic, black and poor  will be done with breakfast, and then it is Ms. Zagarellas responsibility to lead all the students, from kindergartners to eighth graders, into the gym for morning prayers.

title: For Civil Court: Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: New Yorks system of electing the citys Civil Court judges makes no sense. Candidates run in a particular district or borough, but they can end up sitting anywhere in the city, and not even on the court for which they were chosen. Right now, most new Civil Court judges are reassigned for a year or more to relieve pressures on the citys Criminal and Family Courts, a situation that, in turn, puts strains on the workings of Civil Court.

title: City Learns Lessons From the Storm, Many of Them the Hard Way
description: Changes both large and small will be made to the way New York City responds to hurricane emergencies in the future, including how evacuations will be publicized and executed, after officials learned valuable lessons from the unprecedented emptying of the waterfront as Tropical Storm Irene bore down on the five boroughs.

title: To Celebrate Holy Months End, Libya Rebels Open Government Offices to Public
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  After the Muslim holy month of Ramadan ends with the Id al-Fitr holiday, Libyan employers traditionally throw a reception for their workers. On Sunday, the interim rebel government decided to make its reception a little different and declared an open house.

title: This Labor Day
description: There is something a little puzzling about Labor Day. On Thanksgiving we do give thanks, but on Labor Day we do not labor. To the proverbial visitor from outer space, the name of the holiday might suggest 24 hours of national housekeeping, a communal exertion of effort toward some unspecified end.

title: Corrections: September 5
description: FRONT PAGE

title: As Sports Medicine Surges, Hope and Hype Outpace Proven Treatments
description: Until she tore her hamstring a year and a half ago, Tina Basle ran marathons. Since then, she has been on a desperate search for a cure.

title: As Murray Manhandles Lpez Again, Only the Score Is Ugly
description: Feliciano Lpez sauntered on court at Arthur Ashe Stadium late Sunday, his long brown hair pulled back in a ponytail, his beard trimmed just so, his shirt very tight and very bright and very blue. He received an ovation appropriate for a tennis heartthrob.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Record-Breaking Tie Breaker
description: On Sunday night at the United States Open, with a quarterfinal berth in womens singles on the line, Samantha Stosur of Australia and Maria Kirilenko of Russia began a second-set tie break. It was not decided for 32 points, which, according to tournament officials, made it the longest tie breaker in womens Grand Slam history.

title: The Key Player in the Pac-12s Expansion Outlook: Its Texas, Again
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The eyes of college sports are again on Texas, where the next move in the seismic shift of the major conference landscape is expected to begin.

title: Frank C. Arricale, Youth Board Leader Who Calmed Race Tensions, Dies at 81
description: The summer of 1966 was long and hot, and racial tension crackled on the streets of Brooklyn. Frank C. Arricale, as the director of New York Citys Youth Board, reached out to people from different ethnic groups to keep unrest from erupting into violence.

title: Julio Casas Regueiro, Cubas Defense Chief, Dies at 75
description: HAVANA  Gen. Julio Casas Regueiro, the Cuban defense minister, who spent two decades at the helm of the militarys powerful complex of businesses and was a close associate of President Ral Castro, died Saturday in Havana. He was 75.

title: Fantasy Tournament Reaches Semifinals
description: Stunning upsets, close and gritty battles and a few routs marked the first round of The Timess fantasy United States Open Tournament, with the thoughts of modern technology and big serves resonating with voters.

title: The Tennis Channel Has Been Removed
description: 2:58 p.m. | Updated Tennis fans are used to going to great lengths to follow their sport. We endure tape delays, mid-match channel switches, pre-empted matches, and, in some cases, having to buy pricey top-tier cable packages in order to get the Tennis Channel. Nothing surprises me any more when it comes to tennis coverage, but the subject line of an e-mail I received from my cable provider, Verizon Fios, on Sunday managed to catch my attention.

title: Stosur Outlasts Kirilenko
description: It took Samatha Stosur of Australia a while, but she was able to beat Maria Kirilenko of Russia on Sunday and advance to the quarterfinals of the United States Open.

description: NYT Front Page for 09/05/11

title: Moore Is Once Again the Star for Boise State
description: ATLANTA  The end zone resembled the grandstands for moment in the third quarter Saturday night. It was a lot of red, a little bit blue. Three Georgia defenders were around one Boise State receiver. Another Georgia defender was dropping into coverage and it looked like four on one.

title: Full Steam Ahead
description: Rafael Nadal, the defending champion, defeated David Nalbandian to advance to the fourth round.

description: Libyan rebels have imprisoned hundreds of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, accusing them of being mercenaries for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Remembering Lee Roy Selmon, Hall of Famer
description: Lee Roy Selmon was one of the best all-around defensive ends in N.F.L. history. He excelled against the run and the pass, and did it modestly, without bringing attention to himself. Selmon died Sunday, two days after a stroke on Friday at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 56.

description: Images of five strong performances from the fall movie season.

title: What to Watch on Monday
description: Francesca Schiavone survived a heck of a scare to get here, facing match point against unseeded South African Chanelle Scheepers in the second set before coming back to win in three.

title: Banks Lead Sharp Declines in Global Shares
description: PARIS  Fears of a new financial crisis and worries about the health of the United States economy sent share prices tumbling in Europe on Monday and also led to declines in Asia. Markets in the United States were closed for the Labor Day holiday, but sharp declines in the overseas trading of stock index futures indicated the sell-off was likely to continue on Tuesday.

description: Artisan Social Designer, a new gallery and concept store in a converted grocery store in Paris, is giving traditional craft a makeover.

title: India Charges Mining Baron With Fraud
description: NEW DELHI  One of Indias most powerful mining barons, whose political clout and wealth have made him a controversial national figure, was arrested Monday as investigators raided his offices and seized about $1 million in cash and more than 66 pounds of gold.

title: Fights in Court as Police Accounts Favor Mubarak
description: CAIRO  The criminal prosecution of former President Hosni Mubarak stumbled badly on Monday after four senior police officials denied that he had ordered Egyptian security forces to use live ammunition against demonstrators challenging his rule.

title: Complaint Box | Labor Daze
description: Every morning, I sweep the 30 feet of sidewalk in front of my store in Chelsea, and often several more times a day, to keep the area attractive and to avoid getting the nasty fines the city loves to hand out. While I wish that there werent so many New Yorkers who just blindly drop their garbage wherever they are walking or standing (there is a trash can only 20 feet from my shop), I know that is too much to expect.

title: A Graveyard Shift in Mission Control
description: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from a workstation off the coast of Oregon, where he is studying life around deep-ocean vents.

title: Beijing Says Qaddafi Officials Sought Chinese Arms Supplies
description: BEIJING  Chinas Foreign Ministry admitted on Monday that state-run arms companies met Libyan officials this summer to broker arms sales to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis besieged regime, apparently confirming information in Libyan government documents found by a Canadian journalist in Tripoli.

title: Monday Reading: Airlines Offer V.I.P. Treatment for a Fee
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

Between Fridays US job report and todays economic news from the rest of the world, its hard to avoid the sense that things are going bust all over. Austerity is really biting, and the global economy is sputtering.
