title: Analyzing the Mens Second Week
description: After a decent 10 for 16 record in first-week picks on the mens side, a look at how the second week matches of the 2011 U.S. Open will shape semifinals on Super Saturday.

title: The Beatings Must Continue
description: Oh, my  at first I missed this op-ed by Wolfgang Schaeuble. If you had any doubts about where key figures in Europe are going, this should clear them up:

title: Syria Allows Red Cross Officials to Visit Prison
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syria opened its main prison in Damascus on Monday to a delegation from the International Committee of the Red Cross for the first time since the uprising started in mid-March, amid hopes that the move could begin to reveal the fate of thousands of political detainees.

title: Tech Support
description: Tim Coppenss first complete mens collection is a wonder not just of technical proficiency  Coppens was formerly the design director of Ralph Laurens futuristic sportswear line, RLX  but also of economy. Coppens, a Belgian-born Royal Academy of Fine Arts grad, has no office, no employees and hes financing his 45-piece collection by himself. The design references are varied. They include a spit and polish riff on the leather jackets and baggy sweats of the Paris banlieues and also a curious repurposing of a Persian Farahan rug, which Coppens chopped up to form the back of a leather-sleeved varsity jacket. Characteristically, that jacket is assembled with almost clinical precision, but the carpet segment is left frayed on the bottom  an inspired touch. I dont want to be brand-marked as a technical designer, Coppens says. I want to make beautiful collections with classic fabrics. But the technical aspect gives me a good starting point.

title: On the Inadequacy of the Stimulus
description: Hmm. I dont think Ive ever put up a simple explanation of why the stimulus was so clearly inadequate to the task. By the way, my point here is not what Obama shoulda-coulda done; I just want to look at the straight economics.

title: Can Obama Escape the Alberta Tar Pit?
description: President Obama is in a situation right now somewhat akin to that facing the creatures that once prowled the edges of the La Brea tar pits  a sticky trap that caught and consumed the least wary or agile members of many species.

title: Even in Victory, Roddick Loses the Spotlight
description: After a wobbly performance against journeyman Michael Russell in the first round and an adequate performance over young Jack Sock in the second, Andy Roddick finally seemed to come into his own in his third-round match Sunday at the 2011 U.S. Open, defeating Julien Benneteau 6-1, 6-4, 7-6(5).

title: The TV Watch: No Jerry Lewis, but Telethon Still Offers Suspense
description: Jerry Lewis wasnt there.

title: European Bankers Urge Leaders to Move Quickly on Debt Crisis
description: PARIS  As the stock and bond markets seem eerily similar to the dark days of 2008, Jean-Claude Trichet and Mario Draghi, the current and incoming chiefs of the European Central Bank, pointedly urged European leaders to move quickly to ensure that the euro zones debt crisis does not become seriously worse.

title: Imps of the Perverse
description: Two guys meet in a bar. Its an awful place. The music is terrible, and they are the only people in it with any sense of style. One is 6-foot-2, dark and dazzling. The other is just as tall and good-looking, but with yellow hair and a droll expression. They blow out of the bar and discover they both live not only on the same street but also in the same building.

title: British Panel to Examine Libya Rendition Reports
description: LONDON  A British panel investigating the behavior of the countrys intelligence agencies toward terrorism suspects will examine new accusations of close cooperation between British spies and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis government, Prime Minister David Cameron said Monday.

title: For Monaco, Its All in the Details
description: Juan Monaco has advanced to the fourth round with three convincing wins, besting Andreas Seppi, Radek Stepanek, and Tommy Haas with a relentless, passionate style that has impressed me. I watched him beat Stepanek and Haas, and his ability to play high-percentage, patient backcourt tennis, coupled with his back-arching, athletic serve, makes him an atypical claycourter.

title: Pakistan Points to Help From U.S. in Qaeda Arrests
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  American and Pakistani officials celebrated their cooperation on Monday as Pakistan announced the arrests of three men they identified as senior operatives of Al Qaeda who had been planning attacks on American and other Western targets.

title: Perry Skips Forum to Focus on Texas Fires
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, will skip a forum for Republican presidential candidates here on Monday afternoon so he can deal with wildfires raging across his state, a spokesman confirmed.

title: Strike at La Scala Forces Cancellation of Vienna Staatsoper Performance
description: Citing the extremes of an anti-union attitude, workers at La Scala opera house in Milan have announced a strike that will cause the cancellation of a performance of Beethovens Fidelio by the Vienna Staatsoper this week, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Europeans Talk of Sharp Change in Fiscal Affairs
description: As leaders in Europe try to contain a deepening financial crisis, they are also increasingly talking about making fundamental changes to the way their 17-nation economic union works.

title: Romney Plays Down G.O.P.-Tea Party Strife
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, tried to bridge the gap between himself and the Tea Party on Monday morning, telling a gathering of supporters that the differences between the Tea Party and traditional Republicans were not as wide as many people seem to believe.

title: One Sperm Donor, 150 Offspring
description: Cynthia Daily and her partner used a sperm donor to conceive a baby seven years ago, and they hoped that one day their son would get to know some of his half siblings  an extended family of sorts for modern times.

title: Ancient Woolly Rhino Points to Himalayas
description: Researchers in the Himalayas have uncovered a woolly rhinoceros fully a million years older than the ones that roamed Europe and Asia in the ice age.

title: The Stolen Skull
description: The skull thought to be Ned Kellys

title: Lawyers for Michael Jacksons Doctor Fight to Have Jurors Sequestered
description: Lawyers for Michael Jacksons doctor are trying to overturn a judges refusal to sequester jurors for the doctors manslaughter trial, saying they will be poisoned by the media frenzy surrounding the trial unless they are kept in isolation.

title: Newly Found Star Puzzles Scientists
description: A newly discovered star in the constellation Leo  too faint to be seen through any but the most powerful amateur telescopes  has so little mass and such a low level of metal elements that scientists were previously unaware that such a star could exist.

title: Perry Stirs Supporters, Then Heads Home
description: CONWAY, S.C.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas ended his South Carolina schedule early on Monday to oversee the emergency response to wildfires spreading in his state, but not before giving a large and friendly audience here a significant spoonful of his latest campaign theme: fiscally focused and folksy.

title: U.N. Officials Say Famine Is Widening in Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The United Nations announced Monday that Somalias famine had spread to a sixth area within the country, with officials warning that 750,000 people could die in the next few months unless aid efforts were scaled up.

title: Chirac Trial to Go On Without Him
description: PARIS  The trial of former President Jacques Chirac of France on corruption charges will proceed without Mr. Chirac having to be present, a court decided Monday, citing the poor state of Mr. Chiracs mental health.

title: Really? The Claim: To Reduce Heartburn, Dont Eat Four Hours Before Bed
description: THE FACTS

title: Like Former Mayors, a Statue Fades From View
description: He donated a plot from his backyard garden for New Yorks original City Hall, where George Washington would be inaugurated as president. He presided as mayor over a government that assumed responsibility for paupers and banned slaughterhouses within the city limits. He even covered municipal deficits out of his own pocket.

title: Madonna in Venice: From the Directors Chair to the Red Carpet
description: The Venice Film Festival has kicked off the fall red carpet season with a bang, one that the Emmys on Sept. 18th will have a hard time topping. Among the standouts: Madonna, there to promote her debut as a film director, W.E., (a film loosely based on the affair between Wallis Simpson and the Prince of Wales), and who showed up last Friday in a scene-stealing, floor-length, dove-grey gown adorned with red butterflies, a dress reportedly created for her by the French designer Vionnet (corrected from an earlier post). You can get a look at it from almost angle here.

title: With New Center, Manning Must Get Snaps, and Relationship, Right
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The hallway near the meeting rooms at the Giants training center is a relatively quiet place, an area typically reserved for intense film study and instructive conversations among players and coaches.

title: For Injured Athletes, Few Proven Treatments
description: In the new series, The Athletes Pain, medical reporter Gina Kolata explores how the hope and hype of many promising sports medicine treatments often outpace the evidence that they actually work.

title: Nutrition: A Low-Calorie Meal Is Shown to Pay Off
description: Some dieters say that eating less at one meal is ineffective, because people compensate by eating more at other meals.

title: Childbirth: Neonatal Deaths Slow, but U.S. Still Lags
description: According to a new analysis, the United States now ranks 41st in the world in terms of neonatal mortality, the death rate of infants less than one month old. The rate is higher in the United States than in, among others, Cuba, Slovakia, Croatia and all of Western Europe and Scandinavia.

title: Judge Allows Suit Against Hungary Over  Artworks to Proceed
description: A United States District Court in Washington has rejected Hungarys motion to dismiss a lawsuit filed against it and its museums and a university for artworks claimed by the heirs of the Jewish banker and renowned collector Baron Mor Lipot Herzog.

title: Patterns: Unexpected Benefits of Statin Drugs Found
description: Statin drugs, proven effective for the prevention of heart attack and coronary heart disease, may reduce the risk for infectious disease as well, according to a new study.

title: A Fashion Brand Introduces Edun Pioneers
description: The anticipation of fashion week has marketers brimming with promotions and ad campaigns. One company, Edun, the fashion brand started by Ali Hewson and Bono, is taking its message to a new audience  men.

title: Abbas Affirms Palestinian Bid for U.N. Membership
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said Monday that he was going to the United Nations this month to seek membership for a state of Palestine, not instead of negotiations with Israel, but in addition to them. His goal, he said, was for a Palestinian state and Israel to live in peace and security next to one another.

title: Diplomatic Strains Intensify Between Turkey and Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Tensions between Israel and Turkey mounted further on Monday, as Turkish officials ordered senior Israeli diplomats to leave the country by midweek and Israeli passengers arriving at the Istanbul airport were taken aside and questioned for 90 minutes by officials. Turkish officials said that Turkish tourists were treated the same way at the Tel Aviv airport last week.

title: Children of Sperm Donors May Have Many Siblings
description: As the number of children born through artificial insemination increases, many young people are discovering they have several or even dozens of half siblings in the world, reports todays Science Times.

title: Haiti: Cellphone Tracking Helps Groups Set Up More Effective Aid Distribution, Study Says
description: Populations on the run during disasters can be tracked by cellphone signals, which could help guide life-saving aid to the right places, a new study has concluded.

title: Fortress D.C.
description: Photos showing scenes in Washington, D.C. on and after Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Cleaning the Soil
description: Q. When a virulent strain of E. coli from manure contaminates produce, how do farmers clean the soil in their fields?

title: Why Vanishing Sharks Deserve Attention, and Even Affection
description: One of natures oldest, most successful and least visible predators is in profound trouble.

title: A Good Death? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Cholera and Climate (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Reaching Out to the Tea Party in S.C.
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Several of the leading Republican candidates for president gathered here Monday afternoon for a forum hosted by a leader of the states Tea Party movement as the presidential campaign moved into the fall sprint to 2012.

title: Eating Locally (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Djokovic Show, Waiting Is Half the Fun
description: They had been standing in line to get into the 10,103-seat Louis Armstrong Stadium for over an hour and there were 400 people ahead of them. At the rate the line was moving, it would take Rohan Menon, Rahul Sabhnani and Mira Bhatia, George Washington University students, longer to get in to see Novak Djokovics fourth-round match against Alexandr Dolgopolov than the 2 hours, 7 minutes it took Djokovic, the top seed, to polish off his third-round opponent.

title: Another A.L.S. Holy Grail (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Vandals, or at Least One, Sack a Roman Fountain
description: The Moro Fountain on the southern end of the Piazza Navona in Rome was drained on Monday as restorers began reattaching two chunks of marble that were knocked off by a vandal.

title: Bike Crash Wiped Details; GPS Data Filled Them In
description: WOODSIDE, Calif.  After racing and biking back roads on the San Francisco Peninsula for almost half a century without serious incident, on July 3 I crashed while riding downhill at more than 30 miles an hour. I knocked myself out, broke my nose and was left with lots of road rash and stitches on my face, as well as a deep gash above my knee that went all the way to the patella.

title: Bloomberg Again Defends Handling of Deputys Arrest
description: For a moment on Monday, it looked as if Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would escape a second round of questions over his decision to conceal the domestic violence arrest that prompted the resignation of former Deputy Mayor Stephen Goldsmith.

title: In an Upset, Its Pavlyuchenkova
description: 4:19 p.m. | Updated Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova of Russia pulled off a stunning upset by outhitting seventh-seeded Francesca Schiavone of Italy, 5-7, 6-3, 6-3, to reach the quarterfinals of the U.S. Open on Monday.

title: 9/11 Books Released Into a Sea of Others
description: Publishers are releasing a new round of books timed to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks despite lukewarm sales of many books about the events in the past. But the question remains whether people will want to read more about Sept. 11, especially after weeks of magazine covers, newspaper articles and wall-to-wall cable news coverage.

title: When Lapses Are Not Just Signs of Aging
description: Who hasnt struggled occasionally to come up with a desired word or the name of someone near and dear? I was still in my 40s when one day the first name of my stepmother of 30-odd years suddenly escaped me. I had to introduce her to a friend as Mrs. Brody.

title: When a Chomp or a Slurp Is a Trigger for Outrage
description: For people with a condition that some scientists call misophonia, mealtime can be torture. The sounds of other people eating  chewing, chomping, slurping, gurgling  can send them into an instantaneous, blood-boiling rage.

title: When Normal Sounds Are Excruciating
description: People with misophonia have an extreme reaction to certain sounds, often becoming enraged or anxious at the sound of chewing or someone clearing his throat, reports todays Science Times.

title: Salvatore Licitra, Operatic Tenor at Met, Is Dead at 43
description: Salvatore Licitra, a tenor with a ringing, powerful voice who rode a sensational surprise Metropolitan Opera debut to dozens of performances with the company, died on Monday in Catania, Sicily, nine days after being severely injured in a motor-scooter accident. He was 43. His death was reported on his Web site, salvatorelicitra.com.

title: Illness Wont Keep Buddy Ryan From Watching Sons Game
description: 3:05 p.m. | Updated Buddy Ryan will not miss the latest edition of his twin sons football rivalry  not even after being diagnosed with cancer for a fourth time. Rob Ryan, the Cowboys new defensive coordinator, said Monday in Irving, Tex., that his father plans to delay surgery until after Dallas faces the Jets, coached by Rex, on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium. Rob Ryan said his father learned last week that he had cancer in his glands. It also spread to his neck, Rob said.

title: Blown Around, but Not Down
description: For a stretch of Monday afternoon, the top mens player and the womens favorite shared a stage at the United States Open, but only one left the door to their current shared dominance open just a crack.

title: Rainbow Peppers and Shrimp With Rice Noodles
description: You can now find brown rice noodles in many supermarkets and whole foods stores. For a vegetarian version of this dish, try it with tofu instead of shrimp.

title: The Caregivers Bookshelf: A Doctors Decline
description: It cant be coincidence that as more of us confront the anguish of dementia, artists are becoming intrigued with shifting memory and altered personality, with dementias deeply unsettling effect on the self and on others.

title: Herzlich Celebrates When Phone Doesnt Ring
description: Mark Herzlich went with an age-old remedy for nerves Saturday as the Giants were cutting their roster to the league-mandated 53 players: food.

title: Caregivers Dont Always See the Spirit Diminishing
description: As a loved one arrives at the end of life, how do we know when its really over?

title: Protest May Hinge on Use of Replay
description: Philadelphia played Sundays game with the Florida Marlins under protest after Hunter Pence was ruled out because of fan interference following a video review by umpires in the sixth inning. Pence had hit a drive to the top of the right-field wall, where a couple of fans helped prevent the Marlins Bryan Petersen from catching it (video via MLB.com). The Phillies went on to lose, 5-4, in 14 innings.

title: Bond Funds Gains Help Buoy Support for Money Manager
description: Twelve jurors will decide the fate of Jeffrey E. Gundlach, the star fixed-income manager, in the civil trial pitting him against his former employer, Trust Company of the West.

title: Human Papillomavirus, 1985
description: The search for a germ that could cause cancer began in the late 19th century, and on Feb. 14, 1912, The New York Times reported the first success in the hunt.

title: Palin Praises Influence of the Tea Party
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  While again giving no clear indication of whether she intends to run for president, Sarah Palin on Monday urged a spirited crowd of Tea Party supporters to remain open to candidates who are now embracing the partys views even if they had not done so in the past.

title: Minor Changes for U.S.
description: The U.S. national team left four players at home and met three new ones in Brussels for Tuesday nights friendly against Belgium (2:30 p.m., ESPN).

title: Russian Away
description: OK, Im about to board a plane for Moscow, back at the end of the week. Column schedule as usual, but blogging will be doubtful.

title: Wisdom of Having That Tooth Removed
description: We had still not found the perfect duvet cover for my daughter Emmas college dorm room when she went for a routine dental checkup and was told that her wisdom teeth had to come out, A.S.A.P.

title: My Chemical Romance Fires Drummer
description: The New Jersey-based band My Chemical Romance has fired its drummer, Michael Pedicone, just a year after he joined the group and replaced him with Jarrod Alexander of Dead Country. According to a statement posted on the bands Web site by the guitarist Frank Iero on Friday, Mr. Pedicone was caught red handed stealing from the band and confessed to the police after our show last night in Auburn, Washington. (Neither the Web site nor reports that followed have said what Mr. Pedicone is accused of having stolen.)

title: Critics Picks: Black Girl
description: A. O. Scott looks at Ousmane Sembenes film about a Senegalese maid working in a French home.

title: Summer Journey to an Isle of Many Musical Languages
description: Governors Island is a bit off the beaten path, as concert sites go. But the idea of staging a summer music festival there, devoted mostly to contemporary works, is inspired. The island has already been transformed into a hybrid sculpture park and playground, and the flat open field at Colonels Row, bounded by elegant 19th-century houses, is as comfortable a setting for concerts as any park in Manhattan. Whats more, given the brevity of the offerings at the Rite of Summer Music Festival  the free concerts last an hour, without intermission  listeners have every reason to explore the islands other artistic lures.

title: Its Not a Breeze, but Serena Williams Advances
description: In a blustery Arthur Ashe Stadium, Serena Williams blew hot and cold with the wind, beating No. 16 seed Ana Ivanovic 6-3, 6-4 in a streaky 75-minute fourth-round match.

title: Sound, the Way the Brain Prefers to Hear It
description: LOS ANGELES  There is, perhaps, no more uplifting musical experience than hearing the Hallelujah chorus from Handels Messiah performed in a perfect space. Many critics regard Symphony Hall in Boston  70 feet wide, 120 feet long and 65 feet high  as just that space.

title: Montero Hits First Major League Homer, Then His Second
description: Yankees designated hitter Jesus Montero hit his first major league home run Monday afternoon, leading off the fifth inning with a blast into the right-field seats against Jim Johnson, a right-handed Orioles reliever. The hit gave the Yankees a 9-8 lead.

title: The Art of Fielding
description: Chapter 1

title: School Curriculum Falls Short on Bigger Lessons
description: Now that children are back in the classroom, are they really learning the lessons that will help them succeed?

title: Not Walking Alone, Telethon Takes Steps Without Lewis
description: Jerry Lewis wasnt there.

title: Memory Process Takes Years to Fully Develop
description: Children have memories, but the ability to remember the origin of memories develops slowly. A new study reports that this ability matures during adolescence and fully develops only in adulthood.

title: Beware of September
description: Investors who spent August on the beach were fortunate to miss a bout of roller-coaster trading. And they will be rested for the next round, a taste of which came on Friday. The concerns behind the last volatile patch still have not been addressed.

title: Optimism in Libya on Talks With Remaining Loyalists
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Rebel negotiators have resumed talks with loyalist holdouts in the desert town of Bani Walid in an effort to persuade them to surrender peacefully before a Sept. 10 deadline set by the interim government, Libyan officials said Monday.

title: Yankees Top Prospect Fits In Quickly
description: The Yankees unleashed another onslaught on Monday afternoon as the stars of their relentless offense pounded the overmatched Baltimore Orioles. There was Mark Teixeira hitting another home run. There was Robinson Cano blasting his third grand slam of the season. There was Curtis Granderson smacking a two-run double. There were all three adding to their triple-digit runs-batted-in statistics.

title: U.S. Open Replay: Day 8
description: Images from Day 8 of the United States Open in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Day the Colts Dreaded Is Finally Here
description: During the 208 consecutive regular-season games and 19 playoff games Peyton Manning has started since he was a rookie in 1998, no player in the N.F.L. has been more intrinsic to his teams success than he has. The Indianapolis Colts have gone to the playoffs in all but two of Mannings 13 seasons, including the last nine, and his brilliance has covered a multitude of holes on their roster.

title: A Constant Traveler, and Impromptu Nanny
description: I ALWAYS have to laugh when people say theyre Zen about flying. I have no clue what that means. Theres nothing really calming about it.

title: Tressel Will Wait to Work for Colts Until Week 7
description: When the N.F.L. suspended the former Ohio State quarterback Terrelle Pryor for the first five games of the season  a punishment that mirrors a suspension he would have served for rules infractions had he stayed in college  it angered players and created a sticky situation. Had the league created a precedent it would be willing to follow for coaches who get in trouble with the N.C.A.A. but then jump to the N.F.L.?

title: A Bounty of Documentaries at Toronto Festival
description: LOS ANGELES  When I talk to you, it does not necessarily mean that I have to like you, Werner Herzog, off-camera, can be heard telling the death-row inmate Michael Perry in the opening minutes of Into the Abyss, a new documentary about Mr. Perrys execution in Texas last year for the murder of a 50-year-old nurse, Sandra Stotler.

title: Retailers Summon Optimism as They Enter a Critical Season
description: HOPE you enjoyed the Labor Day weekend. Did you know there are only 109 shopping days left until Christmas?

title: Numberplay: A Flutter on the High Seas
description: Hi folks, Im back from one of the most relaxing vacations of my life  on a cruise ship to the Caribbean. Its an experience Id heartily recommend for everyone, with activities suitable for people of all temperaments. You would imagine there was no scope for Numberplay to intrude on my blissful relaxation, but on the contrary, I had to construct and solve several Numberplay-type puzzles while on the cruise  and Id like nothing better than to share them with you.

title: Glamour in the Skies
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Judging from the popularity of the Broadway show Boeing Boeing and plans for a television series based on the world of Pam Am stewardesses, the public seems to long for the days when airlines prided themselves on their flight attendants and the pampering they provided.

title: Hiding Up in Telluride, Silver on Screens
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  In the local vernacular, the Telluride Film Festival is known as The Show. Each screening  of an Oscar aspirant, a restored classic, a provocative documentary, a slow and quiet piece of cinematic art  is its own show, but so is this town itself, a silver-mining outpost high in the San Juan Mountains long ago converted to an oasis of western-bohemian chic. The Show, which occurs every Labor Day weekend (this is the 38th edition), evokes the eager, collective do-it-yourself spirit of Mickey Rooney and Judy Garland musicals, as a school gymnasium, a restored opera house and a pocket-size park on the main street are converted into movie theaters. There is also plenty of the business of show, manifested in the names of sponsors read out before every screening, and in the presence of renowned filmmakers and big movie stars on the streets.

title: Police Detain Brooklyn Councilman at West Indian Parade
description: A city councilman from Brooklyn was handcuffed and briefly detained by the police on Monday afternoon during the West Indian Day Parade after an argument with officers over whether he was allowed to use a closed sidewalk, said Public Advocate Bill de Blasio, whose aide was also detained in the dispute.

title: Twist of Fate Derails Path of Athlete
description: Chad Harbachs book The Art of Fielding is not only a wonderful baseball novel  it zooms immediately into the pantheon of classics, alongside The Natural by Bernard Malamud and The Southpaw by Mark Harris  but its also a magical, melancholy story about friendship and coming of age that marks the debut of an immensely talented writer.

title: Rooming Together, Yet Poles Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: Online Courses for College Credit: Boon or Bane?
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Mouth of No One
description: To the Editor:

title: The Immortals
description: To the Editor:

title: Since Sept. 11, Years of Change for Airlines
description: A LOT of frequent flier miles have been piling up in the 10 years since the terrorist attacks brought the domestic airline industry to its knees in autumn 2001.

title: New Music
description: TERIUS NASH

title: Let the Traveler Beware: Bogus Raves on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Heart of Ground Zero
description: At the heart of the World Trade Center redevelopment is the memorial plaza, designed by Michael Arad and Peter Walker.

title: Time to Revive Home Ec
description: East Lansing, Mich.

title: Yes, We Need Jobs. But What Kind?
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Ireland: Diplomatic Tensions With Vatican Grow
description: The diplomatic rift between the Irish government and the Vatican deepened Monday after Ireland accused the Holy See of missing the point in a weekend statement defending its conduct in the sexual abuse scandals involving priests. The Irish foreign minister, Eamon Gilmore, left, said the government was holding firm to its claims that the Vatican had attempted to frustrate an inquiry into abuse in the Diocese of Cloyne as recently as three years ago. The Vatican, in a strongly worded report on Saturday, said there was no evidence to support such an accusation.

title: Lee Roy Selmon, Buccaneer Cornerstone, Dies at 56
description: Lee Roy Selmon, the Hall of Fame defensive end who became a cornerstone of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers during their first decade in the National Football League and remained a revered figure in Tampa, Fla., died there Sunday. He was 56.

title: Adjusting, More M.D.s Add M.B.A.
description: Under heavy pressure from government regulators and insurance companies, more and more physicians across the country are learning to think like entrepreneurs.

title: For Obama, a Familiar Labor Day Theme
description: DETROIT  Labor Day must seem like the movie Groundhog Day to President Obama. On Monday, for a third year he celebrated the holiday that honors workers with union members and their families in a political swing state, promising job-creation measures to reduce a 9 percent unemployment rate and calling on the Republican opposition to put country before party.

title: Life in Syrias Capital Remains Barely Touched by Rebellion
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  As protests broke out across a restive Syria on a recent Sunday, and crowds were dispersed yet again by gunfire that left many dead, the conversation in the capital dwelled not on the uprising but rather on nails, along with the choice of polish and hair color and the latest in makeup trends.

title: Tsonga Sweeps Past Fish, the Top American Seed
description: The questions swirling around Mardy Fish as the United States Open approached had less to do with his game or health than his steeliness. How would Fish, a mellow man with a history of modest success in the tournament, weather the pressure of being the top American seed?

title: Getting a Grip on the Grid
description: One of the crucial factors that limits the capacity of the electricity grid is the temperature of the lines; as their metal is heated by the current flowing through them, the lines get longer, and they sag, and can contact trees or other objects.

title: G.O.P. Hopefuls Vying for Tea Partys Support
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The leading Republican presidential candidates spent Labor Day declaring their fealty to limited government as they sought to demonstrate credibility with a Tea Party movement that has seized the political energy of their party.

title: F.D.A. to Review Safety of Popular Bone Drugs
description: Two advisory panels of the Food and Drug Administration will consider on Friday whether to recommend requiring women who use popular bone drugs like Fosamax to take drug holidays because of rising concerns about rare side effects with long-term use, according to people involved in the review.

title: West Indian Day Parade
description: A glimpse at the annual West Indian Day Parade in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: American Men Make Progress, Not an Actual Breakthrough
description: Early Monday, with four American men into the fourth round of the United States Open for the first time since 2003, Patrick McEnroe called Jay Berger.

title: Where the Jobs Arent
description: With the economy stagnating and unemployment high, where are the jobs of the future going to come from? A few years ago, it seemed as though the Green Economy could be a big part of the answer.

title: What Should Obama Say?
description: Everyone else is giving President Obama advice, so why not me?

title: Facing Danger to Aid Daughter
description: Paula Liverpool had the guts and motivation to work as a bartender in a notoriously dangerous Miami strip club, but she could not muster the nerves to watch her daughter, Sachia Vickery, play two sets of tennis Monday.

title: The Last Moderate
description: WASHINGTON

title: Closed, Says Google, but Shops Signs Say Open
description: In mid-August, Jason Rule learned some surprising news about the coffee shop that he owns and operates in Hays, Kan.: the place had closed for good.

title: Fukushimas Long Link to a Dark Nuclear Past
description: ISHIKAWA, Japan  Kiwamu Ariga skirted the paddies of ripening rice, moving briskly despite his 81 years to reach a pile of yellowish rocks at the foot of a steep, forested hillside.

title: How Many Leaves on the Tree of Life?
description: How many species are there on this planet? In 1691, the scientist John Ray estimated that there were 20,000 species of insects. His numbers were significantly off  at least a million insect species have been described so far. But he reached it the way most scientists still do, by extrapolating from the number of already known species. Three centuries later, there is still no scientific consensus on the total number of species.

title: A Husband and Wife Team: A Detailed Look Through Berkleys Actions
description: Representative Shelley Berkley has advocated for measures in Congress to expand kidney care that have indirectly benefited her husband, who runs one of the largest chains of dialysis centers in Nevada.

title: Artists Respond to Sept. 11
description: The choreographer Bill T. Jones talks about Sept. 11.

title: Laura Poitras
description: The filmmaker Laura Poitras talks about Sept. 11.

title: Hybrid in a Trade Squeeze
description: TIANJIN, China  For General Motors and the Obama administration, the new Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid represents the automotive future, the culmination of decades of high-tech research financed partly with federal dollars.

title: T-Mobile USA Owner to Study Deal Options
description: Deutsche Telekom said on Monday that it would evaluate options for T-Mobile USA to help support a $39 billion sale of the business to AT&T, a deal that is being contested by the Justice Department.

title: Senior Aide to Bachmann Leaves Post
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Ed Rollins, the veteran campaign operative who helped engineer an Iowa straw poll victory for Representative Michele Bachmann this summer, has stepped down from running the day-to-day operations of her presidential campaign, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Bachmann said Monday night.

title: What the City Didnt Lose After 9/11
description: Cosmopolitan parochialism is woven into the collective soul of New York. Do ya miss the city, a Queens councilwoman asked me in 1998 when I was working in Washington. She supplied the answer before I could open my mouth: Of course you do!

title: Easing Stance, Iran Offers Inspectors Supervision of Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  Iran on Monday made its first counterproposal in two years to ease the confrontation with the West over its nuclear program, offering to allow international inspectors full supervision of the countrys nuclear activities for the next five years, but on the condition that the mounting sanctions against Iran are lifted.

title: A Congresswomans Cause Is Often Her Husbands Gain
description: LAS VEGAS  At the University Medical Center here, alarms were set off three years ago  kidney transplants were failing at unusually high rates, and some patients were even dying.

title: Where Manners Go Missing
description: Mixed doubles was front and center at Arthur Ashe Stadium one afternoon last week. Not on the court, where a United States Open womens singles match was being played, but in a midlevel suite where two men and two women, drinks in hand and backs to the court, carried on as if they were at a cocktail mixer.

title: In a Storms Wake, Bracing for More Rain
description: The murky Passaic River sloshed just steps away from the door of Mayra Gutierrez-Amadors business on Monday, but she was too busy to notice, spending her ninth straight day salvaging a life overturned by Tropical Storm Irene.

title: Elite Schools Rethink Saving Seat for Little Sister
description: Heres a back-to-school math problem: There are 62 kindergarten seats at the Trinity School this fall, and 756 children wanted them. What percentage made the cut?

He had lived in all the surrounding states, often uncomfortably, before moving away in search of work. Residents of all these states would find things even more uncomfortable after his wartime return.

title: Knitting Factory
description: Nubby yarns arent the most obvious springtime players. But Lindsay Degen, the Brooklyn-based 23-year-old behind the new hand-knit sock and lingerie line Degen, is a different sort of designer. Growing up in the suburban Midwest, she dabbled in cheerleading and Girl Scouting before going on to study fine art at the Rhode Island School of Design, where she joined a performance group called Knitting Nation that practiced endurance-building marathon stitch training. Soon, Degen says, a hobby turned into a job, and she started collaborating with brands like VPL, Cooperative Designs and Mischa Lampert. Knitting for people who see fashion and art as equals bent my previous view that they had to be separate worlds, she says. Indeed, Degen the line, which makes its debut during Fashion Week, is a clever blend of the two; the stripy, woven lingerie and cheerful one-off socks featured are just conceptual enough. Ive never wanted to buy a matching pair of anything, Degen says about offering singles instead of matching socks. Plus, when I spend eight hours knitting one, its dreadful to think that Id have to spend another eight hours making the exact same thing. Restless and inspired, she confesses shes already in need of a new hobby. Lets hope its sweaters.

The purchase price was $44.5 million with a 12-month earn-out payment to shareholders and employees that is valued at up to an additional $27.5 million. Augme said it expected to keep all Hipcricket employees. Ivan Braiker, chief executive of Hipcricket, becomes president of Augme and Eric Harber, president and chief operating officer of Hipcricket, becomes chief operating officer of Augme. The deal came a month after Augme bought Jagtag, which specializes in bar codes and Q.R. codes.

title: Parenting Reading for Back to School
description: Labor Day has always been my New Years. A fresh page in a marbled composition book. Sharpened pencils, metaphorical and actual. A fresh start with a sharpened mind.

title: Original Model Ts | Bryan Christopher Baker
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#297", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: New French's Ad
description: A new ad for French's french fried onions features a  dinner recipe.

title: Sprint Sues to Block AT&Ts Deal for T-Mobile
description: 7:02 p.m. | Updated

title: Courtside: Rain Arrives at The Open
description: Rain always seems to be a problem at the U.S. Open, and this year is no different, with the cancellation of play on Tuesday. Lynn Zinser reports on the matches that were scheduled to be played Tuesday night, and will hopefully be played on Wednesday.

title: Frenchs Wants You to Know Your Onions
description: Another prosaic packaged-food brand is getting dressed up to appeal to consumers who are still economizing by eating at home more and eating out less.

title: Dropbox Said to Raise as Much as $300 Million
description: Investors are looking for gold in the cloud.

title: James Levine Withdraws From Met Fall Season
description: James Levine, the Metropolitan Operas music director, has withdrawn from all performances at the Met for the rest of the year after falling while on vacation in Vermont and damaging a vertebra, the house said on Tuesday. Mr. Levine had emergency surgery on Thursday. The injury comes after a series of health problems, including back operations and periods of rehabilitation to correct a painful spinal condition called stenosis, have curtailed Mr. Levines activities.

title: Sentence of the Week, Life-Precepts Edition
description: Its time to crown our August Sentence of the Month. The choice, as always, will be hard. But isnt that what the Internet is all about: exerting ourselves through sustained hard thinking, ignoring all distractions, in order to make extremely difficult choices? (Have you watched Googles Freddie Mercury tribute yet, by the way? Its amazing. After that, definitely watch the official nonanimated video for Dont Stop Me Now to see awkwardly sustained close-ups of Mercurys amazing mouth.) Here are our winners from August:

title: Councilman Says Racial Bias Led the Police to Detain Him at a Parade
description: City Councilman Jumaane D. Williams, backed by more than two dozen city, state and federal officeholders, charged on Tuesday that racial bias had prompted the police to detain him and another city official at a parade one day earlier.

title: A Banker Explains Why Some Small Businesses Have Trouble Getting Credit
description: After a recent post about the bad news embedded in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporations second-quarter good news  business lending broadly was up for the first time in three years, but small-business lending continued to fall  The Agenda heard from a representative of Sterling National Bank, a small institution based in New York City that lends exclusively to small and medium-sized businesses. Contrary to what I had reported, loans were way up at Sterling, the representative said. Did I want to find out why?

title: Study Finds State Unionized at Twice National Rate
description: The percentage of New Yorkers in labor unions is twice as high as the nationwide rate, a new study finds. In a pessimistic sign for New Yorks unions, though, the unionization rate for older workers is considerably higher than for younger ones.

title: Food Links for Your Pleasure
description: Philly continues to be among the most inspiring cities, food-wise: the Food Bucks program now offers a whopping 40% subsidy for foods stamp purchases at Philadelphia farmers markets, which has skyrocketed SNAP sales at farmers markets. And then theres this afterschool program in Philadelphia that uses food and gardening to inspire kids to write. (My Philly column from last spring.)  Meanwhile, the always excellent Union of Concerned Scientists released a report urging public investment in farmers markets as a means to create jobs and strengthen regional food economies.

title: New York Fashion Week Calendar: Spring 2012
description: Full schedule of events during New York Fashion Week from Sept. 7-15, 2011.

title: Site Aims to Simplify Moving and Stop Junk Mail
description: About 18 months ago, David Greenberg was a corporate lawyer in the midst of relocating and notifying contacts of his new address. I was moving and creating a list of all the places I needed to reach out to, he recalled. I realized it was going to take me a couple of hours. I figured there must be a good Internet site to help, but I didnt find it.

title: Policing Your Power-Hungry Appliances
description: Before they leave the house, my friends in England literally pull the plugs on many of their appliances.

title: Archbishop Dolan Adds Ceremonies to Commemorate 9/11
description: With a full slate of appearances scheduled for Sunday, the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11, Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York will attend two additional events in the days leading up to the anniversary: a Police Department ceremony at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center on Thursday morning and a prayer service for the Fire Department at St. Patricks Cathedral on Saturday afternoon.

title: Interior Employee Set Off Inquiry on Polar Scientist, Official Says
description: The allegations that led to an Interior Department investigation of Charles Monnett, a federal biologist specializing in Arctic wildlife, were made by a seasoned career Department of the Interior employee in March 2010, the departments acting inspector general wrote last month.

title: They Signed Up to Fight
description: VIDEO: War Stories

title: War Stories: Video Profiles
description: Starting soon after the attacks of Sept. 11, the United States has been at war for nearly a decade. The New York Times talked to four people  three veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan and one widow of a Marine  about how those wars changed their lives.

title: The Gender Gap in Travel: Myths and Revelations
description: Readers often write in to remark that I am a man, a fact of which I am generally aware. But then they point out something that often slips my mind: my travel experiences are those of a man, as well.

title: Eddie Murphy to Host the Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  If the idea is to stage a goofy television show about a very serious bunch of movies, next years Academy Awards are pointed in the right direction.

title: Times Makes Masthead Promotions
description: In her first day as executive editor of The New York Times, Jill Abramson announced the appointment on Tuesday of two new assistant managing editors to help round out her senior management team.

title: 5 Die, Including Gunman, in Nevada IHOP Attack
description: LOS ANGELES  A man armed with an AK-47 assault rifle opened fire Tuesday morning on a group of uniformed National Guard members as they ate breakfast at an IHOP restaurant in Carson City, Nev. He hit all five Guard members, killing three of them, and killed another woman and wounded five other people before taking his own life.

title: Challenges in Defining an Israeli-Palestinian Border
description: There are major hurdles in drawing borders between Israel and a future Palestine.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 6
description: The day in sports included the 16th stage of the Tour of Spain and washouts of both sessions at the United States Open.

title: Pataki Says He Is Content to Be a Noncandidate
description: Eleven days after canceling a planned visit to Iowa and announcing he would not run for president, former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York said on Tuesday that he remained content in private life and was at peace with his decision.

title: Letter From Copenhagen | Feeding Frenzy
description: For two rainy days last week, some 250 chefs, scientists, foragers and farmers gathered beneath a blue and red circus tent in Copenhagens Harbor for the first annual MAD Food Camp Symposium. Entitled Planting Thoughts, the symposium was organized by Claus Meyer and Rene Redzepi, the founders of the current worlds best restaurant, Noma, along with the newly formed Food Organisation of Denmark (FOOD). The mission was to ask the big questions about the role of chefs in society, touching on issues of urban farming, food microbiology and social responsibility. At the podium was a parade of acclaimed chefs, among them Inaki Aizpitarte, David Chang, Andoni Aduriz and Alex Atala.

title: Stuyvesant Alumni Will Observe 9/11 at School
description: A few days after alumni from Stuyvesant High School were told that they could not hold a vigil to commemorate Sept. 11 in their school, they are now getting their wish. All it took was a few phone calls and a three-day weekend.

title: Fashion Weeks Impact, by the Numbers
description: 10:26 a.m. | Updated

title: The Chevy Bow Tie: a Paean to Parisian Wallpaper, the Swiss Flag or Soup?
description: The Chevrolet bow-tie logo, which was introduced in 1913, may be among the worlds most recognizable trademarks, but its origins are a mystery. The design is one of many points of brand heritage being reexamined by General Motors in this, the centennial year of the founding of Chevrolet.

title: Harvards Madoff Connection
description: Even a hypochondriac occasionally gets sick  and even Bernard L. Madoff, who confessed to running a Ponzi scheme built on decades of lies, occasionally tells the truth.

title: 12 Ways to Use The Learning Network This School Year
description: Happy 2011-12 school year!

title: Deficit Panel Names Democrat as Deputy
description: The bipartisan Congressional committee charged with tackling the nations deficit has named a Democrat as deputy staff director, perhaps to balance out the Republican director of a committee whose leaders are hyper conscious of partisan advantage.

title: Univision Reigns on Labor Day
description: In what was a very low prime-time turnout for the Labor Day holiday, Univision was the highest-rated broadcast network in both total viewers and the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. The Spanish-language network averaged 5.6 million viewers Monday night, aided by the three-hour season finale of Pequeos Gigantes (Small Giants), a talent show where children compete for a cash prize and are judged in three categories: singing, dancing and charisma.

title: A Jets Rookie From the Roads of Hutto, Tex.
description: HUTTO, Tex.  Behind the beige trailer in which Jeremy Kerley once lived, there is a field brown with dirt and grass scorched by the ruthless central Texas sun. It is small enough for grandparents, both sets of them, to sit on their front porches and mind children tossing a football or playing Red Rover. But it is big enough, about two acres, for boys with lively legs to run and run and run, to high school stardom, to a decorated career at Texas Christian, to the N.F.L.

title: The Dutch Will Open a Miami Beach Branch
description: Andrew Carmellini is opening a Miami Beach branch of the SoHo restaurant the Dutch, and he calls it kind of a homecoming.

title: U.S. Takes Hard Line in Suits Over Bad Mortgages
description: The Federal Housing Finance Agency, which oversees the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, is suing 17 leading banks that sold them nearly $200 billion worth of subprime mortgage-backed securities that fell sharply in value when the housing market collapsed.

title: The Troops After 9/11
description: Specialist Evan Bozajian was wounded by a roadside bomb in 2005 while serving with the First Battalion, 184th Infantry, Army National Guard, in Iraq.

description: Richard Cordray, President Obamas pick to lead the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is taking the hot seat on Tuesday.

title: An Invitation to Reflect: The 9/11 Years
description: As the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks approaches, we invite readers to offer brief reflections on their experiences and thinking.

title: The Troops
description: Staff Sgts. Ivan and Christian Bengtson are identical twins who joined the Army Special Forces together right out of high school in 2002. They both served in Afghanistan, where Ivan was injured.

title: The Troops
description: Janina Bitz Vasquez is the widow of Sgt. Michael E. Bitz of the Marine Corps, who was killed during the opening days of the invasion of Iraq in 2003 while he was serving with the 2nd Marine Division.

description: Reviewing Craft

title: Building a School, Halfway Across the World
description: Students from the Bronx Center for Science and Mathematics traveled in July to Mali, Africa, where they started the foundation for a house of learning.

title: Steve Martin Honors Another Banjo Player
description: Though it hasnt been a great year, economically, for almost anyone, Steve Martin continues to do what he can to spare bluegrass musicians the worst of the lingering downturn. On Tuesday Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian and cultural omnivore, announced that Sammy Shelor, the banjo player and leader of the Lonesome River Band, is the second winner of his Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass, which comes with $50,000.

title: Reviewing Craft
description: This weeks restaurant review takes as its subject Craft, the luxe American restaurant Tom Colicchio opened on East 19th Street in spring 2001. William Grimes, one of my predecessors in the titanium-and-velvet chair issued to the chief restaurant critic of The New York Times, awarded the place three stars a few months later. It was not reviewed again, until now. (Though Bill Clinton had a rock summit there not so long ago, with Keith Richards.)

title: Craft
description: LIKE drawing a circle or walking a high wire, the act of cooking simple food well requires years of training and experience, and a self-confidence that must sail close to arrogance. Above all, it requires mastery of the intersection of culinary talent and acquired knowledge.

title: Flow Starts in Gas Pipeline From Russia to Germany
description: MOSCOW  Russian natural gas began to flow Tuesday through the Nord Stream  pipeline under the Baltic Sea, inaugurating a controversial and expensive Russian-German project with geopolitical overtones.

title: Groupon May Delay Its Plans to Go Public
description: Groupon is considering a delay to its long-awaited initial public offering amid turmoil in the stock market.

title: TimesCast | September 06, 2011
description: Wildfires burn hundreds of Texas homes; a convoy of soldiers loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi flees into Niger; and President Obamas approval rating hits a new low.

title: Turmoil Helped Push Temple-Inland Into Deal With International Paper
description: Normally, market turmoil inhibits deal-making. But in the case of International Paper and Temple-Inland, it helped.

title: For Federer, Tough Opponents Arent an Obstacle
description: In the wee hours of Tuesday morning, Juan Monaco met the same fate as the previous 29 men who had the misfortune of tangling with Roger Federer in the fourth round of a major.

title: Near a Libyan Holdout Town, a Waiting Game
description: WISHTATA, Libya  At this village on the highway to the loyalist stronghold of Bani Walid on Tuesday, negotiators from both sides sat down in the small mosque to talk peace, an event broadcast live by Al Jazeera.

title: Floods Continue to Threaten, as a Rainy Week Is Expected
description: For many counties ravaged by Tropical Storm Irene, the flooding has stopped, but not for long, meteorologists say.

title: Grand Slam Sportswear Takes Center Court
description: Stylish looks from the 2011 United States Open.

title: Pictures of the Day: Australia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Australia, Texas, Sudan and Libya.

title: Elusive Line Defines Lives in Israel and the West Bank
description: BARTAA, West Bank  For decades Israel has tried to erase from public consciousness the Green Line, the pre-1967 boundary with the West Bank at the heart of stalled negotiations for a Palestinian state.

title: Soft Spot | With & Wessel
description: Growing up in Norway, Stian Tolnaes and Cathrine Wessel had plenty of opportunities to wear wool  and lots of it. Its a Norwegian tradition, Tolnaes says. If you see Norwegian fishermen, who are exposed to cold weather all the time, they wear layers of wool because it keeps them warm even when its wet. Wool is incredibly insulating. After observing that Greek fishermen toiling in the balmy Aegean also favored wool but for entirely the opposite reason  its insulating qualities keep warm air out, too  the couple had a light-bulb moment. We wanted to develop a clothing line that was completely natural and eco-friendly, Tolnaes says. And we wanted to take the layering tradition of our childhoods and make it fashionable.

title: Americas Grocery Behemoth
description: In his great poem Next Day Randall Jarrell describes a woman in an American supermarket moving in the detergent aisle from Cheer to Joy, from Joy to All. The woman thinks to herself:

title: Have You Had Your Daily Moment of Climate Dread?
description: Frequent visitors here know about my comparison of shifting concerns about human-driven climate change to water sloshing in a shallow pan  lots of motion but little real significance. Today The Onion took a bitingly amusing look at the (lack of) depth of climate worries in America in a piece titled, We Need To Do More When It Comes To Having Brief, Panicked Thoughts About Climate Change. Heres the closing thought, but if you need a laugh I encourage you to read it all:

title: Taking the Score From West Side Story
description: Two versions of a scene from West Side Story, one with the films original score and the other with it removed.

title: Tavis Rookie Goes Live
description: In this weekends issue of the Sunday magazine, Amanda Fortini wrote about the new online magazine Rookie, headed by the cult teen fashion blogger Tavi. It is now up, and you can look at it here. A few highlights:

title: Afghan Army Attracts Few Where Fear Reigns
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Every morning, jobless young men gather by the hundreds at the busy central square here in this southern city, desperate for whatever work they can find. In other places, this would be an army recruiters dream. Not so in Kandahar.

title: Chandler Arnold, Amir Katz
description: Chandler Frank Arnold and Amir Daniel Katz are to be married Sunday evening at the Pilgrim Monument in Provincetown, Mass. The Rev. David Johnson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to officiate.

title: Now Playing | ManiaManias The Third Mind
description: The Australian designers Melanie Kamsler and Tamila Purvis of the cult-status jewelry line ManiaMania are announcing their new spring collection with three trippy, gem-laden films. The beautifully uncontrolled manifestoes of Andr Breton put us both in a surrealist spirit, says Kamsler of the inspiration behind the starring wooden pendants, crystal balls and cubes cut from things like pyrite and labradorite(a feldspar mineral). Here, the headlining short, The Third Mind, directed by Elle Muliarchyk and featuring Abbey Lee Kershaw, pays homage to Brion Gysin and William Burroughs and their smoky, bohemian lifestyle.

title: Polls Show Declining Support for Obama on Economy
description: Two new polls have found low levels of support for President Obama and his economic stewardship of the country, with an increasing number of Americans saying that Mr. Obamas policies are making the economy worse. The surveys show that Americans have a pessimistic outlook for economic recovery and raise the stakes for the presidents speech on Thursday before a joint session of Congress in which he is expected to offer plans for creating jobs and stimulating the economy.

title: Classic Score by Bernstein Is Remade
description: When it came time to make a movie of his West Side Story, a busy Leonard Bernstein entrusted the score to Hollywood and his loyal arrangers.

title: An Afghanistan Gallery
description: A portfolio of civilians and troops by Kuni Takahashi.

title: Sleep No More, but Move Nonstop
description: In Sleep No More, a roving retelling of Macbeth by the English theater company Punchdrunk, the masked audience is in constant motion as it chases the action from room to room at the fictional McKittrick Hotel. But in the end, no one is more breathless than the cast, which is largely made up of some of the most fearless dancers around.

title: A Reality Check on Clouds and Climate
description: I am often in awe of clouds, as was the case when I shot this video of a remarkable thunderhead somewhere over the Midwest. But Im tired of the recent burst of over-interpretation of a couple of papers examining aspects of clouds in the context of a changing climate.

title: Romney Lays Out His Economic Plan
description: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev.  Mitt Romney unveiled his plan to rejuvenate the American economy here Tuesday, offering a detailed outline that includes repealing President Obamas health care law, cutting the corporate tax rate, placing sanctions on China as a currency manipulator and immediately reducing taxes on savings and investment by the middle class  and promised to push many of these policies on his first day in the Oval Office.

title: Chinas New Cultural Revolution: A Surge in Art Collecting
description: As auction houses prepare for their fall sales, Chinese collectors are expected to be a major boost for the market, raising their paddles for big-ticket artworks despite a backdrop of global economic turmoil.

title: Borders and Barriers: An Overview

title: Denis Leary
description: The actor Denis Leary talks about Sept. 11.

title: Christopher Shinn
description: The playwright Christopher Shinn talks about Sept. 11.

title: Thank Goodness | Elettra Wiedemann Feeds Fashion Week
description: Convenience is key when it comes to refueling during Fashion Week, and more often than not, quick, carry-in-your-pocketbook processed foods are what many models and editors resort to between shows. The model and activist Elettra Wiedemann has set forth to change that by opening Goodness, a pop-up restaurant installed at Eds Chowder House just across Columbus Avenue from Lincoln Center. From Sunday through next Wednesday, Goodness will offer a healthy, locally sourced menu, with daily specials designed by some of the citys best-loved chefs, including Christopher Rendell, an Iron Chef winner; Nicholas Wilber from the Fat Radish; and Robert Newton of Seersucker restaurant in Brooklyn. I wanted to be eco-conscious without forcing it too much and create a place where people can go to escape, says Wiedemann, who teamed with Ed Brown, the Chowder Houses Michelin star-rated chef, to design an especially soothing atmosphere in which to enjoy things like duck confit salad, pan-seared bream mash with a truffle vinaigrette and a fried chicken that Wiedemann calls goodness (with a little bit of badness). Check, please!

title: More Children Living in Poverty
description: A fifth of children in the United States are living below the federal poverty limit.

title: Small-Town Star in New York
description: Jeremy Kerley has risen from the small Texas town of Hutto to a spot on the Jets roster.

title: It Came From the Suburbs: New Life for a Swamp Creature
description: For an awfully nice guy, Scott Snyder has a rather awful imagination. And its his ability to spin a dark tale that has landed him the awfully desirable chance to reboot two key titles in the DC Comics franchise.

title: Player Ratings: Belgium (1) vs. U.S. (0)
description: In Brussels, the home of the New Europe, the latest new era in U.S. soccer brought Game 3 of the Jurgen Klinsmann reign. (Back in the United States, a washout at the U.S. Open enabled ESPN to shunt its coverage to ESPN2 because of overtime in the Left-Turn Derby  make that the Nascar race  on the mother ship.

title: Things That Go Bump in the Night Dont Even Budge on TV
description: Criminals robbing convenience stores have not been able to escape them. Fathers taking a soccer ball to the groin  la Americas Funniest Home Videos have not been able to escape them. Couples having sex on a supposedly secluded beach have not been able to escape them. And yet ghosts and other paranormal entities so far have proved amazingly adept at avoiding the millions of security cameras, cellphone cameras and video cameras that now seem to record virtually every moment of life on earth.

title: In Dispute With Verizon, Union Invokes Members 9/11 Work
description: For almost a decade, Sept. 11, 2001, was a kind of third rail for Madison Avenue, almost never brought up in advertisements for fear of being perceived as exploitative or tasteless.

title: Enlisted in the World of Airborne Spying
description: For four years, a doctor commuted between his clinics in Texas in a $5 million turboprop with jazzy metallic stripes and ruby stones embedded on the drink cabinet inside. The plane featured exotic wood veneers and polished chrome, and his daughters initials were in the tail number.

title: Bachmanns Steep Path to the Nomination
description: Following the departure of two of her key advisers over the holiday weekend, youre likely to see a lot of speculation about whether Michele Bachmanns campaign is headed for the political graveyard.

title: App Smart Extra: CIA World Factbook Apps
description: Last weeks App Smart column, on reference apps, elicited an incredulous note from a friend.

title: P.J. Harvey Nabs a Second Mercury Prize
description: P.J. Harvey became the first singer on Tuesday to win the prestigious Mercury Prize twice, when she accepted the award for her album Let England Shake. Adele, the young soul-singer who had dominated the charts for much of the summer with her hit record 21, was left in the also-ran category. It was the second time that Ms. Harvey, the 41-year-old singer-songwriter from Yeovil, England, had taken home the prize, which is given every year to the best album from an English or Irish act. She first won in 2001, when the ceremony was held on Sept. 11. She was on tour in the United States at the time and got caught up in the chaotic day of the terror attack.

title: Q&A: Adding Locations to Old Photos
description: Q.

title: Rain Washes Out Play at U.S. Open
description: Rain again paid an unwelcome visit to the United States Open on Tuesday, washing out the day and night sessions and postponing the mens and womens fourth-round singles matches until Wednesday. Weather has created such regular chaos with the Open schedule  it has delayed the mens final from Sunday to Monday each of the last three years  that cancelations and delays have become as much a part of the scene at the National Tennis Center as overpriced sandwiches.

title: State Reveals Official Sept. 11 Memorial Flag
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday unveiled the official New York State Sept. 11 Memorial Flag, which was raised at the State Capitol and will be flown at the entrance to the memorial at the World Trade Center site.

description: Mary Kocys circumnavigation of Manhattan on water skis began with a wrong number. Lots of wrong numbers, actually.

title: Spicy, Crispy, Modern and Korean
description: MANY factors had to flow together to produce Jung Sik, which will be the first high-end, thoroughly modern Korean restaurant in New York when it opens in TriBeCa later this month. The greatest may be an epically popular television mini-series: imagine a Korean Rachael Ray starring in a combination of Downton Abbey and C.S.I.

title: Alison Returns, but Not to Dominick Street
description: THERE were deep-blue banquettes, black-and-white photographs of France and a SoHo address by the Holland Tunnel that cabdrivers could never find. There was hushed jazz, a famous lamb shank and proposals of marriage, sometimes several in one night.

title: Take My Gefilte Fish, Please: Kutshers Comes to Manhattan

title: The Seasons New Restaurants
description: ALONG with the imported chefs and restaurateurs bringing Danish open-faced sandwiches, avant-garde Korean and Spanish fare, specialties from Beirut and Moscow, and even the flavors of Portland, Ore., to New York, some familiar faces on the local restaurant scene will try something new. A pizza master is opening a diner, and a high-end chef is doing a sports bar. Well see the latest from Danny Meyer, Jeffrey Chodorow and that former downtown dining star, Alison Price Becker.

title: Foreign Restaurateurs Arrive in New York
description: This season, Manhattan is witnessing a surprisingly robust invasion of new restaurants from abroad.

title: The Melting Pot Just Got a Whole Lot Richer
description: AS business-news alerts warn of credit downgrades, jobless recoveries and double-dip recessions, New York City is witnessing a surprisingly robust invasion of new restaurants from abroad, and it seems to have everything to do with Frank Sinatra.

title: A Transformed Bernardin Is Set to Reopen
description: IN the 25 years since Maguy Le Coze and her brother, the chef Gilbert Le Coze, opened the Midtown Manhattan version of Le Bernardin, their high-end Parisian seafood restaurant, the menu has changed more than the dining room. Flavors from Asia and Spain were added, along with new techniques and new ingredients, particularly after Eric Ripert took charge of the kitchen and became a partner after the death of Mr. Le Coze, in 1994.

description: PANE PANELLE, opening Wednesday, is takeout, mostly Sicilian, from a tiny storefront at Stuzzicheria in TriBeCa. It sells arancini, meat pies, muffulettas and the cheese sandwiches cum chickpea fritters known as pane e panelle ($5 to $10). All are prepared by Paul DiBari, pictured, the restaurants new chef: 305 1/2 Church Street (Walker Street), TriBeCa, (212) 219-2357.
