description: Carol Bartz, Yahoos chief executive, sent this e-mail message to Yahoo employees on Tuesday, according to one person who received it:

title: Razing a Neighborhood and a Social Engineering Idea
description: LA COURNEUVE, France  At the foot of the dilapidated Balzac housing tower, an 11-year-old boy bled to death here on a summer afternoon in 2005, stray bullets in his heart and neck. Nicolas Sarkozy, who was interior minister at the time and is now president, arrived the next day in this hard-luck Paris suburb, famously pledging to clean the area with a Krcher, a brand of high-pressure hose.

title: Boats Banned From Dumping Sewage in Long Island Sound
description: Boats will be prohibited from dumping sewage in New York State waters in Long Island Sound under a ban announced on Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Injury-Plagued Giants Turn to Rookies
description: When the Giants cut their roster to the 53-player maximum Saturday, they opted to keep four rookie linebackers, a decision that highlighted, once again, the teams commitment to building organizational depth.

title: Beyond Refugee Camps, a Better Way
description: In Fridays Fixes column, I wrote about alternatives to keeping refugees in camps for years. The hundreds of thousands of Somalis streaming today into the camps in Dadaab, Kenya, are getting lifesaving food, medical care and shelter. Camps like Dadaab are designed for emergency care and do it well  but most refugee situations are long-term. Camps condemn refugees to years, maybe decades, of dependency. There are people in Dadaab who have not stepped outside the camp since it opened in 1991.

title: Living With Loss
description: INTERACTIVE: Portraits of Grief

title: Consumer Pick Vows to Streamline Regulations
description: WASHINGTON  The nominee to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau told a Senate committee on Tuesday that he would make it a priority to streamline and cut back a mountain of regulations that has grown up over the last 30 years, which he said excessively burdened some banks and discourages them from lending money to consumers.

title: Amid Tensions With Israel, Turkey Threatens Increased Naval Presence
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey is prepared to fortify sanctions against Israel and increase its naval presence in the eastern Mediterranean Sea, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said Tuesday, as relations between the countries continued to fray over an Israeli raid on a Turkish-flagged ship last year.

title: In Miami, Long and Bitter Feud With Mayor Pushes Police Chief Close to Dismissal
description: MIAMI  Police Chief Miguel A. Exposito, whose nearly two-year tenure has been marked by numerous clashes with the mayor and a series of police shootings of unarmed black men, was suspended from his job on Tuesday in a move that could be the prelude to his dismissal.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: Roger Federer
description: Lynn Zinser makes the case for Roger Federer against Rafael Nadal.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: John McEnroe
description: George Vecsey makes the case for John McEnroe against Pete Sampras.

title: Yahoo Board Fires Chief Executive
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Carol A. Bartz, Yahoos chief executive, was fired Tuesday, ending a rocky two-year tenure in which she tried to revitalize the online media company.

title: TimesCast | Wildfires Rage Across Texas
description: Wildfires cut a path of destruction across Texas. Hardest hit was the town of Bastrop in Central Texas.

title: In a Game of Physical Prowess, Its the Mind That Matters
description: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga was talking about how a tennis match is won between the ears as much as between the lines. My game, you know, is very good when I have nothing in my head, when I just play my game, he said Monday after defeating Mardy Fish in five sets at the United States Open.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: Rafael Nadal
description: David Waldstein makes the case for Rafael Nadal against Roger Federer.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: Pete Sampras
description: Harvey Araton makes the case for Pete Sampras against John McEnroe.

title: New York City Schools Poll
description: The results of a city-wide New York Times poll on Mayor Bloomberg and New York Citys public schools.

title: New Yorkers Say Mayor Has Not Improved Schools
description: New Yorkers are broadly dissatisfied with the quality of their public schools, and most say the citys school system has stagnated or declined since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took control of it nine years ago, according to a New York Times poll.

title: Jeremy Kerley High School Highlights: QB
description: Watch some of Jeremy Kerleys highlights from high school as a quarterback. Aside from leading the offense, Kerley was a star defensive back, and played baseball, basketball and ran track.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 9 to 15 in New York City with 1,027 adults. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

title: S.E.C. Wont Fight Ruling Striking Down Proxy Access
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that it would not dispute a recent court ruling that struck down one of the agencys new rules for corporate America.

title: TimesCast | Low Approval of Obama
description: President Obama's approval rating hits a new low as the campaign season kicks into gear.

title: More Feistiness, but More Frustration
description: BRUSSELS  After Fridays 1-0 loss to an aggressive and physical Costa Rica squad, the United States national soccer team coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, challenged his players to adopt an edgier brand of soccer. He said he wanted his team to become more determined, and he authorized it to play with a bit more nastiness in their pursuit of victory.

title: Old Tax Relief Seen as Anchor in Obama Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The centerpiece of the job creation package that President Obama plans to announce on Thursday  payroll tax relief for workers and perhaps their employers  is neither his first policy choice nor that of many economists. But it is the one that they figure has the best chance of getting Republicans support.

title: With Bartz Out as Yahoos Chief, Is a Deal in the Future?
description: With the Yahoo board firing Carol A. Bartz as chief executive, the the onetime Internet giants already clouded future just got murkier  and might make it a takeover target once more.

title: Invest in Workers
description: THE last four years have been difficult for American workers. Employment collapsed in 2008-9 in the wake of the financial crisis. There are no signs of recovery in the labor market. Public-sector employment fell in the last year and private-sector employment growth remains tepid. The employment crisis has exacerbated the longer-term trends of rising inequality and a decline in middle-class jobs. Bold action by the federal government is needed.

title: Keith Tantlinger, Builder of Cargo Container, Dies at 92
description: Nearly six decades ago, Keith W. Tantlinger built a box  or, more accurately, the corners of a box. It was a seemingly small invention, but a vital one: it set in motion a chain of events that changed the way people buy and sell things, transformed the means by which nations do business and ultimately gave rise to the present-day global economy.

title: Freeze Public Wages
description: IN the face of this economic crisis, the federal government has all but declared unilateral disarmament. The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has vowed to keep real interest rates near zero, but even at that level few are borrowing. Over at the White House and on Capitol Hill, the pursuit of deficit reduction has taken on a religious fervor just when the economy needs a stimulus.

title: Plan Would Keep Small Force in Iraq Past Deadline
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is supporting a plan that would keep 3,000 to 4,000 American troops in Iraq after a deadline for their withdrawal at years end, but only to continue training security forces there, a senior military official said on Tuesday.

title: Treasuries, TIPS, and Gold (Wonkish)
description: (Yes, its 4:30 AM where I am. I found myself wide awake, thinking about gold prices. You got a problem with that?)

title: Many Top Umpires Decide to Skip the Open
description: This weekend, the mens and womens singles champions at the United States Open will take home at least $1.8 million each. The total prize money is a record $23.7 million. The tournaments revenue is expected to exceed $200 million.

title: A Capitalist Idea
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA needs to go big. Jeffrey R. Immelt, chairman of the presidents Council on Jobs and Competitiveness, may have suggestions, but considering that Fortune 100 companies have killed 2.9 million jobs in America over the past decade while adding 2.4 million abroad, that may not be the best input. Im an entrepreneur and Im creating jobs. Here are eight suggestions:

title: Fashion Week, 10 Years Later: A Bond Forged in Tragedy
description: IT started out as the most exciting morning of my life, said the maternity designer Liz Lange, who, long before the date, had circled Sept. 11, 2001, on her calendar. Her first fashion show, under the tents of Bryant Park, was scheduled for 9 a.m. that day.

title: The Designers Touched by 9/11
description: Ten years later, then up-and-coming designers look back at 9/11s impact on their work and the fashion world.

title: White House to Propose Plan to Help Postal Service
description: The Obama administration said on Tuesday that it would seek to save the deficit-plagued Postal Service from an embarrassing default by proposing to give it an extra three months to make a $5.5 billion payment due on Sept. 30 to finance retirees future health coverage.

title: Struggling Bank of America Shakes Up Its Top Management
description: Bank of America shook up its top management team on Tuesday, as the beleaguered financial firm contended with a flagging share price and mounting legal liabilities.

title: Equity Crown Eludes Carlyle
description: It wont be easy for David M. Rubenstein to snatch Stephen A. Schwarzmans private equity crown. Mr. Rubensteins firm, the Carlyle Group, manages about $150 billion of assets, roughly the same as Blackstone, which Mr. Schwarzman leads. But Carlyle reaps considerably less of the steady fee income that comforts investors. That means its valuation when it goes public is likely to wind up well short of Blackstones.

title: Not More of the Same
description: WHEN he introduced Alan B. Krueger, his new economic adviser, in the Rose Garden last week, President Obama offered a few hints about his new economic plan. So far it sounds much like the old plan, which is too bad because that plan didnt work very well.

title: Never Mind the Hour or the Rain, Yankees Defeat Orioles
description: Phil Hughes fired a strike through a fine mist past Baltimore Orioles left fielder Matt Angle at 11:08 p.m. Tuesday, and a surreal game was under way. Cheers arose from about a thousand fans still at Yankee Stadium who had endured a 4-hour-3-minute rain delay.

title: Bloggers Dont Follow the Script, to ConAgras Chagrin
description: IN August, food bloggers and mom bloggers in New York were invited to dine at an underground restaurant in a West Village brownstone run, apparently, by George Duran, the chef who hosts the Ultimate Cake Off on TLC.

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 6, 2011
description: Elder representatives of the Libyan Warfalla tribe met National Transitional Council fighters at the Malti mosque in Wishtata village to talk peace.

title: Gaza: Israelis Kill Militant
description: A Palestinian militant in Gaza was killed Tuesday by an attack helicopter after Israeli forces carried out an incursion into Gaza near the southern city of Khan Yunis and clashed with members of a small militant group, shooting at them and receiving mortar fire back, according to the Israeli military and officials of the group, the Popular Resistance Committees. The militant was identified by his group as Khaled Sahmoud, 23. Israeli forces said members of that group carried out the terrorist attack from the Sinai region of Egypt on southern Israel last month that killed eight Israelis.

title: Lottery Numbers
Race Tighter Than Expected, Democrats Aim to Bolster Candidate for Weiner Seat
description: Democratic Party officials, concerned about an unexpectedly tight special election for Congress in Brooklyn and Queens, are rallying to support their partys nominee and prevent the embarrassment of losing a seat in a traditionally Democratic district.

title: Longtime Liberal Advocate to Lead Generic Drug Group
description: Ralph G. Neas, a longtime advocate for liberal causes and the face of some of the biggest Supreme Court nomination fights in recent decades, has been named the new chief executive of the Generic Pharmaceutical Association, a Washington-based industry group representing generic drug makers and suppliers.

title: Peculiar Doping Case Takes Another Twist
description: An Athens appeals court acquitted two Greek sprinters on Tuesday of faking a motorcycle accident to evade a drug test on the eve of the 2004 Olympics, adding yet another twist to one of the most bizarre doping cases in sports history.

title: A Campaign Challenge: Defining Obama
description: LOS ANGELES  President Obama may have escaped the burden of a Democratic primary challenger. Yet the battle to define him is rapidly escalating  not only by Republicans competing to run against him, but also within his own team inside the White House.

title: Wildfires Continue to Burn in Texas
description: Firefighters sought to use slowing winds to their advantage as they battled blazes that have already chewed up tens of thousands of rain-parched acres in central Texas.

title: With Financing Still Rare, New York Developments Start to Rebound
description: When the development firm Hines began exploring plans for a state-of-the-art, ground-up office tower overlooking Bryant Park in April 2009, the notion seemed far-fetched at best, given the economic mood.

title: To Bolster Family Tourism, Fields of Play for Young Athletes
description: ELIZABETHTOWN, Ky.  Since 1937, when the Treasury Department established a bullion repository at nearby Fort Knox, gold has been the principal attraction of this city of 28,531 south of Louisville. Now, travel and tourism executives are counting on a $29 million youth sports complex under construction northwest of town to help fill Elizabethtowns 1,525 hotel rooms and drive development of hundreds more.

title: Paging History
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Whole Truth and Nothing But
description: Kishore Mahbubani, a retired Singaporean diplomat, published a provocative essay in The Financial Times on Monday that began like this: Dictators are falling. Democracies are failing. A curious coincidence? Or is it, perhaps, a sign that something fundamental has changed in the grain of human history. I believe so. How do dictators survive? They tell lies. Muammar Gaddafi was one of the biggest liars of all time. He claimed that his people loved him. He also controlled the flow of information to his people to prevent any alternative narrative taking hold. Then the simple cellphone enabled people to connect. The truth spread widely to drown out all the lies that the colonel broadcast over the airwaves.

title: Wednesday: Richard With a Much-Used Thumb
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  The word FOLLOW has evolved in meaning as we become more reliant on social media. People used to just follow the leader, follow their intuition, or simply follow the boy you had a crush on home from school (what, you didnt do that?). These days, however, you might follow someone straight into the ether, on Facebook or on Twitter.

title: Clip: 'West Side Story'
description: A scene from the musical "West Side Story."

title: Families Feel Sharp Edge of State Budget Cuts
description: LANSING, Mich.  Stretched beyond their limits and searching for new corners of their budgets to find spending cuts, states are now trimming benefits for residents who are in grim financial shape themselves.

title: Clip: West Side Story
description: A scene from "West Side Story" with its original score removed.

title: Newark Deputy Mayor Expected to Be Named Connecticut Education Chief
description: Stefan Pryor, a deputy mayor in Newark who was a founder of a well-known New Haven charter school, is expected to become Connecticuts education commissioner.

title: G.O.P. Legislators Balk at a Call to Tie Storm Aid to Budget Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  As Congress prepares to tackle the issue of providing aid to areas ravaged by Tropical Storm Irene, a rift has opened among House Republicans over the federal governments role in providing disaster relief.

title: Plea Deal for Killer of Woman, 92
description: A 20-year-old Bronx man pleaded guilty on Tuesday to second-degree manslaughter in the 2009 killing of a 92-year-old woman who was shot as she watched television in her living room.

title: In the Land of Denial
description: The Republican presidential contenders regard global warming as a hoax or, at best, underplay its importance. The most vocal denier is Rick Perry, the Texas governor and longtime friend of the oil industry, who insists that climate change is an unproven theory created by a substantial number of scientists who have manipulated data so that they will have dollars rolling into their projects.

title: A Ride to Remember on Home Waves
description: The surfing experiment that is Quiksilver Pro New York began Tuesday with one of the most anticipated heats of the competition  the 10-time world champion Kelly Slater of Florida against the hometown hero Balaram Stack and Daniel Ross of Australia.

title: Amazons Tax Dodge
description: Amazon.coms no-holds-barred fight to avoid collecting sales taxes in California is an abdication of corporate responsibility. The online behemoth is battling to repeal a state law enacted in July that would force it to do what every brick-and-mortar retailer in California is obligated to do: collect a sales tax of 7.25 percent from its customers.

title: Apple Seeking Product Security Manager
description: Dont be fooled by how easy this job might sound: Apple hopes to hire a new product security manager, or in layman terms, someone who can stop new iPhones from being lost in bars.

title: Haitis Needless Cholera Deaths
description: A cholera outbreak has killed more than 6,000 people in Haiti since October and is far from under control. More than 420,000 people have been sickened since the disease emerged in a rural area north of Port-au-Prince, apparently after sewage from an encampment of United Nations peacekeepers contaminated the Artibonite River.

title: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Roger Federer vs. Rafael Nadal
description: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? Its up to you to decide, with a little help from The Timess tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will advance to the finals of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

title: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Pete Sampras vs. John McEnroe
description: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? Its up to you to decide, with a little help from The Timess tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will advance to the finals of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

title: Trapped in a Tapestry of Ice and Fire
description: A few weeks ago, I gave in to the ubiquity of George R. R. Martins best-selling fiction series A Song of Ice and Fire, the origin of the HBO series Game of Thrones, and picked up the first volume. Im now somewhere in the recently published fifth volume, A Dance With Dragons, and Im ready for an intervention. Please help. I feel as if Im being stitched, nerve by nerve, into a possibly infinite tapestry. I want to put the book down, but if I do Ill instantly forget who killed whom and why, who is related to whom and how, and who has broken troth and who remains trothful.

title: U.N. Body Warns of Risks of Global Austerity
description: UNITED NATIONS  The global economy faces a decade-long stagnation because governments are pursuing deficit cuts and other austerity measures rather than providing the needed stimulus packages, said a United Nations economic report released Tuesday.

title: Shot Dead on Her Stoop, Caught in a Rush of Violence Over a Holiday Weekend
description: Denise Gay had lived her entire life in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and most everyone on the block seemed to know the woman, just as she knew them.

title: Staging a School Tour in Harlem
description: One of the many affecting scenes in the documentary Waiting for Superman shows a mother on a personal tour of a high-performing charter school in Harlem she wants her son to attend. She looks with perceptible longing at baskets of books and welcoming classrooms, and says Wow when told how children struggling with reading, like her first grader, Francisco, receive tutoring.

title: Reyes Has Something to Chase: The Mets First Batting Crown
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Like many athletes, Jose Reyes says he does not concern himself with individual accolades. Still, he is well aware that he has the opportunity this season to earn a singular place in Mets history.

title: Corrections: September 7
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Highlights of Ed Rollinss Career
description: Ed Rollins, below, stepped down this week from running the day-to-day operations of Representative Michele Bachmanns campaign for the Republican presidential nomination. It was the latest in a series of jobs, often short-term ones, in Mr. Rollinss busy political career.

title: In Euro Zone, Banking Fear Feeds on Itself
description: Remember the collapse of Lehman Brothers? Europeans certainly do.

title: Loss of Top Two Aides Raises Questions About Bachmann Campaign
description: The departure of Representative Michele Bachmanns top two campaign aides raises fundamental questions about how she moves forward over the coming weeks, and whether she can remain a top-tier contender for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Markets Lifted by Signs of Progress on European Debt
description: Stocks in the United States surged on Wednesday, snapping a three-day losing streak as the broader market rose almost 3 percent on momentum from a court ruling in Germany backing euro zone bailouts.

title: Court Weighs Who Defends Proposition 8
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a hearing that suggested no quick resolution to the long-contested legal battle over Proposition 8, the same-sex marriage ban in California, several members of the states highest court seemed skeptical of arguments on Tuesday that the measures supporters should not have a chance to defend it in federal court.

title: S.E.C. Wont Fight Proxy Ruling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced late Tuesday that it would not dispute a recent court ruling that struck down one of the agencys new rules for corporate America.

title: Democrats Press Obama for New Works Programs; Republicans Say Theyve Failed
description: WASHINGTON  House and Senate Democrats are urging President Obama to propose spending on a host of new public works and job programs in his speech to a joint session of Congress on Thursday. But Republicans vowed to resist such initiatives, saying they had been a spectacular failure in the last two and a half years.

title: The Early Word: Dissent
description: Todays Times:

title: Super PAC Plans Major Primary Campaign for Perry
description: A new Super PAC with close ties to Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is laying plans to spend as much as $55 million to help him win the Republican presidential nomination, a sign that outside groups are likely to play a pivotal role in the partys selection of its candidate.

title: Heavy Rain Moves North With the Remnants of Lee
description: NEW ORLEANS  The remnants of what was once Tropical Storm Lee continued to wash over the South and mid-Atlantic on Tuesday, bringing heavy rains and high winds as the weather system made its soggy way northward.

title: Police Shoot Man Interfering With Arrest in Upper Manhattan
description: A plainclothes police officer shot a 43-year-old man on Tuesday while trying to make a drug arrest in Upper Manhattan, the Police Department said.

title: Amid Washington Gloom, Strasburg Casts a Light
description: WASHINGTON

title: Afghan Jails Accused of Torture; NATO Limits Transfers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO has temporarily stopped transferring detainees to a number of Afghan jails after accusations of torture and abuse were uncovered in a report to be published soon, NATO and United Nations officials said Tuesday.

title: Steven Alan: Spring 2012 RTW
description: New York

title: Jenni Kayne: Spring 2012 RTW
description: New York

title: Rachel Comey: Spring 2012 RTW
description: New York

title: Freezing Athletes to Speed Recovery
description: Last week, the American sprinter Justin Gatlin showed up at the World Outdoor Track and Field Championships in Daegu, South Korea, with frostbite on his feet. This condition was painful  he told reporters that he had blisters on both heels  but it was also improbable, given that hed developed the frostbite in Florida in August. But Mr. Gatlin had been sampling one of the newest, trendiest innovations in elite athlete training. Hed gone into a whole-body cryotherapy chamber, and his feet had frozen there.

title: Hong Kong TV Officials Resign Over False Report
description: BEIJING  Two months after Asia Television, a broadcaster based in Hong Kong, carried an apparently false report that the former Chinese president Jiang Zemin had died, two of the broadcasters top news executives have taken responsibility for the report and resigned.

title: Bad News for Newspapers
Reinforced Playground Opens in Sderot
description: The Jewish National Fund has opened a fortified playground in Sderot, Israel, where children can play safely away from rockets and mortar rounds.

title: Minnesota: Catholic Diocese Settles Abuse Case
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Crookston has agreed to pay $750,000 to settle a lawsuit with a 21-year-old woman who said she was sexually molested as a teenager by a priest from India who was serving parishes in the diocese. The victim, Megan Peterson, said the Rev. Joseph Palanivel Jeyapaul sexually abused her when she went to speak to him about becoming a nun. As part of the settlement, the diocese will contact the priests home diocese in India and express grave concern regarding the suitability for ministry of Father Jeyapaul. The diocese said the $750,000 would be covered by insurance.

title: Petraeus Takes Oath as Director of the C.I.A.
description: David H. Petraeus, the Army general who commanded American troops in Iraq and Afghanistan, was sworn in on Tuesday as the 20th director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Petraeus, 58, retired from the Army to take the top job at the civilian intelligence agency, which has worked closely with special operations units in the campaign against terrorism.

title: Word of the Day | solvent
description: solvent \sl-vnt, sl-\ adjective and noun

title: Golden Cyberfetters
description: Over the past few months a number of people have asked what I think of Bitcoin, an attempt to create a sort of private cybercurrency. Now Alexander Kowalski at Bloomberg News directs me to this Jim Surowiecki article on Bitcoin, which is very interesting.

title: New Injury and New Questions for Mets Maestro
description: Maestros are more used to reviews than medical bulletins.

title: NYT Front Page for 09/07/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/07/11

title: Stephen Strasburg: Still an a Mission
description: WASHINGTON  It was a classic case of under-promise and over-deliver, but the Nationals did not plan it this way. Ideally, this would have been Stephen Strasburgs 29th start of the season, and the weather would have been gorgeous on Tuesday at Nationals Park. But it was Strasburgs first start, a year and three days removed from Tommy John surgery, and it rained all day.

title: Mets Make Most of Chances
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Terry Collins has said the month of September will be his chance to learn something about each of his young players.

title: Videos Show Fire and Destruction in Texas
description: As my colleague Manny Fernandez reports, the most destructive wildfires in Texas history have been churning through the state since Sunday, fueled by high winds from Tropical Storm Lee and the worst one-year drought the state has ever recorded.

title: TimesCast | Loyalist Convoy Flees
description: Africas desert Sahel region is among of the poorest in the world and has long seen Muammar el-Qaddafi as a hero.

title: Peter Twiss, Record-Setting British Pilot, Dies at 90
description: Peter Twiss, a British test pilot who set a world aviation speed record in March 1956 when he became the first flier to officially exceed 1,000 miles an hour in level flight, died on Aug. 31 in Titchfield, England. He was 90.

title: Double Suicide Bombings Strike Southwest Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 21 people, including a senior army officer, were killed on Wednesday when two blasts were detonated by separate suicide bombers in southwest Pakistan, police officials said.

title: Deadly Explosion Strikes Courthouse in New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI  An explosion ripped through a reception area of an Indian courthouse on Wednesday morning, killing at least 10 people and wounding more than 60 others in a bombing that renewed concerns about Indias vulnerability to terrorism. It was the second bombing of the courthouse in less than four months.

title: What to Watch on Wednesday
description: With Tuesday a washout, whats not to watch today? Tuesdays matches got moved up, and assuming the weather cooperates, holders of day session tickets Wednesday are in for an amazing smorgasbord of tennis. To add to what I wrote Tuesday:

title: Sept. 7, 1940 | Nazi Germany Bombs London in First Day of the Blitz
description: On Sept. 7, 1940, Nazi bomber planes launched an attack on London, killing an estimated 450 people in day and night raids. James B. Reston reported for the Sept. 7 New York Times, Bombs fell in a district of the London area this morning before the sirens sounded and most of the residents were caught unprepared. At least five persons were killed outright and several others were seriously injured or burned by the fire that broke out. Search parties worked through the early hours looking for victims under wrecked houses. Many who escaped with their lives lost all their belongings in the fire.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 7, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 7, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article When SMores Arent Enough: The New Economics of Summer Camp.

title: Saab Files for Court Protection While It Awaits Chinese Cash
description: PARIS  The Swedish carmaker Saab, awaiting investments from companies in China, sought court protection from creditors on Wednesday, heading off a legal challenge from unions that could have forced the breakup of the company.

title: German Court Rejects Challenges to Euro Bailouts
description: KARLSRUHE, Germany  Germanys ability to come to the rescue of troubled European partners won crucial backing from the countrys constitutional court on Wednesday, a victory for Chancellor Angela Merkel that also provided at least a temporary reprieve for markets that had begun to worry that Europes common currency could collapse.

title: The Deadliest Park in the Country
description: WHO are some of the 18 people who have died in Yosemite National Park this year?

title: Civil Liberties Today
description: There is a place for alarmism when threats to civil liberties are concerned. Too much worry about our freedoms is better than too little, particularly in the face of a government shrouded in wartime secrecy after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Fortress D.C.
description: Some things are obvious: the Capitol Hill police armed with assault rifles, standing on the Capitol steps; concrete barricades blocking the once-grand entrances to other federal buildings; the surface-to-air missile battery protecting the White House; the National Archives security guards, almost as old as the Declaration of Independence enshrined inside, slowly waving a magnetic wand over all who enter. But most of the post-9/11 security measures have simply been embedded in the landscape and culture of the nations capital.

title: Far From Home, at Work in Dubai
description: Most of the faces gaze straight into the camera, very little air between them and the lens; very little space between them and us. Many have the stubble of laborers. Some are wearing headgear  a hard hat, a bandana striping the forehead, a kerchief over the skull with the knot-end extruding from behind. The expressions show curiosity, fatigue, bemusement, tolerance.

title: U.S. Slips to Fifth Place On Competitiveness List
description: LONDON  The United States is slipping and emerging markets are improving, but European economies still dominate the list of the most competitive economies in the world, according to a World Economic Forum report released Wednesday.

title: What Are You Really Learning at School?
description: Some child development experts are concerned that schools today arent teaching kids the skills they need to succeed. A culture of testing, they say, is inhibiting the development of life skills. Curricular content aside, what do you think you are really learning at school? Are you developing skills that will carry you through life?

title: Who Lost Work During the Great Recession?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Rimac: An E.V. Dark Horse Heads to Frankfurt
description: Croatia has no auto industry, says Mate Rimac, a 23-year-old entrepreneur and automotive designer. But that is about to change.

title: Experimental Film the Focus at Madrid Festival
description: Experimental video art takes the spotlight at Optica, a festival featuring works produced by filmmakers from around the world. From Sept. 16 to 18, fans and filmmakers alike will gather to screen recent films at La Casa Encendida arts center (2 Ronda Valencia), and other Madrid galleries.

title: Digital Diary: Excavating Your iPhones Past
description: A few days ago, I sent my sister a simple multimedia message  nothing out of the ordinary, just a quick picture Id snapped and wanted her to see. But seconds later, my phone flashed the Apple logo before shutting itself off. Not a good sign.

title: In the World Cup, History Weighs on New Zealand
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand  When David Kirk held aloft the Webb Ellis Cup after his team won the inaugural Rugby World Cup in 1987, he could not have imagined that nearly a quarter-century later he would still be the only New Zealand captain to have done so.

title: How We Increased Our Manufacturing Productivity (and Turned a Profit)
description: The other day, I was working on a budget for our current operations, part of which involved totaling up payroll costs per hour. Right now, the company employs 14 people, and the pay totals $337 per hour (assuming a 40-hour week, and pro-rating the salaried employees). With that number of workers, using our current manufacturing methods and equipment, we can produce $2 million a year worth of goods. The projected profit should be in the range of 10 percent, $200,000 or so.

title: A Poetic Mentor Who Minces Few Words
description: The woman climbs the stairs in the shabby East Village tenement and enters while Larry Fagin is finishing a call with another poetry student.

title: Timely | King Krule
description: Deceptively diminutive, Archy Marshall fidgets onstage. He is 17, angsty and awkward. But he is no teeny-bopper. A pleasant dissonance arises when he opens his mouth, and from his slight body emerges a deep, rich sound. His barked out lyrics are first person and loop through cryptic, emotionally raw experiences. A dubstep influence is there, but mostly in his modern sensibility as his music is guitar-anchored. For the last year or two, Marshall has played around Britain under the name Zoo Kid, heading to gigs after school, on weekends and over holidays. This past July he played under his new moniker, King Krule, at a festival in Hyres, France. With his second release due out in October, his seriousness is a welcome counterweight to the YouTube-driven fame of his contemporaries like Justin Bieber and Cody Simpson. Teenager need not be pejorative when it comes to lyricism. After all, Arthur Rimbaud was one.

title: Ten Years Time: Images From a Post-9/11 World

title: A Free-for-All on a Decade of War
description: The American reaction to being attacked on Sept. 11 was in many ways an intellectual one. President George W. Bush tended to frame it that way: the attack was on our values, and the war against terror was a war of ideas meant to advance the idea of freedom. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld was the administrations epistemologist, worrying over the question of knowability; Bernard Lewis was its historian, Paul Wolfowitz its moralist in arms. That Americas actions (as opposed to precautions) after 9/11 almost all took place far from home, with a professional army, strengthened this sense of abstraction. The possibility of anything like victory over our enemies was discounted early on (by Rumsfeld). Little wonder that, unlike in earlier wars, we have talked so much about what this conflict means, rather than simply working to end it as soon as possible.

title: Plight of the Lemur: A Movie

description: Who doesnt love buying online? It offers a bigger selection for less money, ordered from the privacy of your home and delivered there too. But if e-commerce is great for consumers, it is more problematic for citizens. The sales tax that people pay in physical stores helps pay for the upkeep of their communities. The physical stores also provide employment; these workers can afford in turn to buy things and thus keep the economy afloat. Few such benefits flow from e-commerce.

Bloomberg gave a workmanlike speech on Tuesday about the phoenix known as Lower Manhattan, how a neighborhood that many thought would never recover from the 2001 terrorist attacks had been reborn. title: Syrians Report Killings as Troops Hunt for Defectors

The reason: the city Buildings Department has ordered the musicians and artists living in the old industrial building to vacate it unless an extensive renovation is done.

title: Type Wars
description: Graphic designers are fickle consumers of typographic fashion, their preferences changing on a whim. Some popular typefaces symbolize the future, or something even more fleeting; others are classic and exude elegance. A pass font returns from the wilderness, while others are exiled until they are rehabilitated by younger generations because they really are too cool for words  or too cool not to be made into words. Nothing is neutral about type. Designers so love their pet typefaces, and argue their merits so vociferously, that declaring ones type preferences can be as risky as calling oneself a Republican at a Democratic fund-raiser.

title: Study Is Ended as a Stent Fails to Stop Strokes

Those who got the device actually had so many more strokes than those assigned to control risk factors, like blood pressure, cholesterol and diabetes, that the study was abruptly terminated.

title: A Name for the Montreal Symphony Orchestras New Hall

Until now there had been only a tentative name, LAdresse Symphonique, for this hall, which sits on a corner of Place des Arts, this lively citys equivalent of Lincoln Center. But the government of the Province of Quebec announced Wednesday morning that the hall will be called La Maison Symphonique de Montral.

title: Military Rulers Called to Testify in Mubarak Trial

title: Print That!
description: The unofficial mascot for Alexa Chungs second collection for Madewell has to be the palm tree print, a black-and-gold repeat that shows up mostly on pajama-inspired pieces and looks like a polka dot from a distance. Chung, who wears the print in the lines new ad and will effectively motivate girls all over the world to go online and buy bits of it  pants, shirt or jersey ice skater dress  by doing so, drew the palm by hand. I sketch so much in meetings, she says. The Madewell team insisted. In fact, Madewell loves Chungs scribbles so much that they published a zine called Magaxine full of them. (Copies will be given to the first who buy pieces from the collection, which lands in stores and online on September 22.) You know me, Im obsessed with polka dots and Peter pan collars  British things like that  so theyre all in there, too, Chung says.

She has set up an advocacy group to support young people making the transition from foster care to independence. And she has compiled her own flower dictionary, modeled on one from 1885.

description: A note for the uninitiated: noodlers are people who use their arms for bait, fishing around in the underwater lairs of giant catfish. The Look feature in last weeks magazine showed several veteran noodlers and their gummy catches at the 12th annual Okie Noodling Tournament. Unbeknownst to our photographer, Matt Rainwaters, his shoot was captured by an unrelated YouTube video (check out the adorable family around 7:30).

title: Success of Sons of Anarchy Season 4 Premiere Puts Creator  on the Hook

Last week, the shows creator and executive producer, Kurt Sutter, announced on his blog that if the Season 4 premiere was up more than 10 percent in both major ratings categories over last seasons premiere, he would award one of his more than 54,000 Twitter followers and one reader of his blog with a trip to Los Angeles, where the two lucky scion anarchists will be invited to a viewing party at Mr. Sutters home. With a gain of 19 percent in total viewers and 17 percent in the 18-to-49 category compared to the Season 3 debut episode, Mr. Sutter will have to make good on his offer. FX also expects that when the final numbers are in, it will be the most watched original series episode in the cable channels history.
