description: If every great jazz pianist needs a Live at the Village Vanguard album, made with a fine trio, the time is ripe for Geri Allen. True, she already released such an album, for a Japanese label, with two of the best possible partners  the bassist Charlie Haden and the drummer Paul Motian  but that was 20 years ago, and its no longer in print. (Look to iTunes for your copy.) A lot can happen to a determined and introspective artist since then.

title: The Endless Runway
description: THIS summer, one of the hottest attractions in Paris was the Madame Grs exhibition at the Muse Bourdelle. Grs was an inscrutable genie of haute couture whose weird demise in 1993 (her only child kept the news of her death secret for more than a year) capped one of the strangest, most productive lives in fashion. I know of several American designers who went out of their way to catch the show before it closed in late July.

title: Why Im (Still) Reluctant to Hire
description: The August jobs report that came out last week showed no job growth, and now President Obama and lots of other politicians are talking about how to create jobs. But Im not sure they fully understand what prompts a business owner to hire someone  and why so many owners are still reluctant to hire, even if they think business might be improving.

title: The Only America Theyve Ever Known
description: When I joined the Army almost 10 years ago, I was already an old man  by the measure of my fellow recruits anyway, most of them only 18 or 19. I was all of 25, but it was enough to make a difference. Even though I got used to how my sergeants and lieutenants were often younger than me, I never got used to how young some of my fellow privates and Pfc.s seemed. They were hardly more than boys, some of them, with bright ruddy cheeks, and bright eyes that grew hard during our year in Iraq.

title: Nadal Reveals the Toll of Being a Top-Tier Athlete in Rafa
description: After advancing to the fourth round of the U.S. Open on Sunday afternoon, Rafael Nadal gave the fans a scare during a post-match press conference when he abruptly stopped speaking and leaned back in his seat, his face twisted in pain.

title: House Hunting in ... Antigua
description: A THREE-BEDROOM HOUSE OFF THE SOUTHERN COAST OF ANTIGUA

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 7
description: The day in sports brought tragedy to international hockey and more rain to the United States Open tennis tournament.

title: Consumer Bureau Reaches Out to Military Families
description: After the financial crisis of 2008, regulators found that military families were proving to be particularly vulnerable to financial rip-offs. Abusive mortgage practices, deceptive car loans, unscrupulous lenders and sellers of all kinds of financial products have caused headaches for many military families, particularly those with service members abroad.

title: TimesCast | September 07, 2011
description: A terrorist bomb rips through a courthouse in New Delhi; the Op-Ed columnist Ross Douthat previews the Republican debate; and a major surfing tournament in, of all places, New York.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Egypt and Gaza.

title: Bloomberg Responds to Weekend of Shootings
description: Mayor Bloomberg on Wednesday blamed last weekends spate of violence on what he said was a national scourge of young, disaffected people with guns. He said there were remedies, however, including stricter gun regulation and social programs like his new initiative to help black and Hispanic young men.

title: Qaddafi Family Video Shows Despot as Doting Grandfather
description: As the search for Libyas deposed leader continues, a family video obtained by Reuters in Tripoli on Wednesday appears to show that while Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi may have ruled Libya with an iron fist, he was, among many other things, a doting grandfather.

title: Afraid to Quit Work, Even if You Hate the Job
description: With so much uncertainty about the economy, Americans appear reluctant to quit their jobs, a new Labor Department report shows.

title: For Champions Series, a Charity Partner
description: The expanded and reformatted 2011 Champions Series announced a partnership with the United States Tennis Associations national charitable foundation U.S.T.A. Serves on Wednesday.

title: Water Works
description: To kick off Fashion Week and celebrate the Quiksilver Pro New York Surf Competition, an 11-day surf extravaganza on Long Island with a $1 million prize purse, Rogans Bowery Street store is showing a collaborative installation called Rogan vs. LOOMSTATE-SRF CTY. On display starting today: cool surf clothes and the artist Maria Moyers exclusive Blue collection, which consists of a delightful, ocean-inspired mix of jewelry and homeware, all handcrafted and cautiously sanded to simulate the effects of spending years under the sea. Limited-edition ultramarine discs and unglazed porcelain objects evoke the work of the Austrian sculptor Carl Aubock and are gratifyingly minimal and calming. The collection is available at Rogan through late October, and 10 percent of all proceeds from the capsule will go to Waves for Water, a nonprofit that helps bring clean water to impoverished communities.

title: Introducing SchoolBook
description: Our colleagues on the Education desk have launched a new site that features news, data and conversation about schools in New York City.

title: My Futuristic Familys Closet
description: WHEN it comes to clothes, I am my mothers son. My mother, her mothers daughter. My grandmother, her mothers daughter, too. Different styles, each, but committed to their choices.

title: Officials See Nevada Shootings as Random Attack
description: CARSON CITY, Nev.  Officials here offered new details Wednesday about a shooting rampage in an IHOP restaurant, a seemingly random attack on Tuesday morning that left five people  including three National Guard members  dead and several others clinging to life.

title: Tents, but No Circus
description: ELEPHANTS used to walk through the streets every year when the circus came to New York City, trunks swinging, leg chains scraping, lumbering through Midtown as mist rose off their leathery flanks. Anachronistic and enchanting, the vision of these exotic beasts being herded through the concrete canyons never failed to produce a shiver of excitement in even the most jaded bystander. It made you feel part of the circus, the great urban one, even if you never made it to the Big Top.

title: Mitt Romneys Tightrope Walk
description: Mitt Romneys 159-page jobs plan, which his campaign released in advance of tonights Republican debate, is getting dismissed as standard Republican fare, but its contents are more interesting than that. Romney spent most of his 2008 campaign for the presidency in full-on pander mode, but this time around hes trying a more difficult two-step. With the exception of a semi-backpedaled comment on global warming, hes refraining from challenging any conservative shibboleths directly, and his rhetorical flourishes can still sound like the lets double Gitmo! Romney of 2008 infamy. But at the same time, hes going to great to lengths to leave himself more room to maneuver on policy than the current right-wing line would normally allow  more room for the general election, and presumably for his hoped-for presidency as well.

title: Speed and Mideast Echoes Add to a Pianists Palette
description: Soheil Nasseris piano recitals in New York over the last decade have shown him to be a thoughtful, if assertive, interpreter, given to surprises. A Californian of Iranian descent who now splits his time between New York and Berlin, Mr. Nasseri takes a cosmopolitan view of the repertory and has been known to devote concerts mostly to new music by Iranian, Israeli and American composers, music he plays with passion and discernment. He has also shown a fondness for the core Romantic repertory, for which his big sound and iron-clad technique are well suited.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Egypt and Gaza.

title: TimesCast | Deadly Bombing In India
description: September 7, 2011  A New Delhi courthouse gets hit by the second terrorist bombing in less than four months, raising questions about Indias ability to provide security.

title: Way Off the Runway: Live Streaming of Fashion Week
description: THE first time I saw the "Mona Lisa," it was in the glossy pages of an art book. Years later, I finally saw the real thing in the Louvre, and like many people, I was disappointed: the real "Mona Lisa" was smaller than my art book facsimile, obscured behind thick glass. It was surrounded by so many people, I could barely make out her smile. As scholars like Walter Benjamin and Jean Baudrillard would put it: the virtual "Mona Lisa" seemed better than the actual one.

title: Oh, to Be Fashion Weeks In Spot
description: FASHION WEEK is more than willowy models traipsing runways in a seizure-inducing flurry of flashbulbs. Its also an opportunity to shake up the citys night life and anoint a new A-list pecking order.

title: The Buzz
description: ECCENTRIC socialites, chain-smoking models, dancing till dawn. It must be Fashion Week again. Here, a preview of the buzzing party each night (invitation only).

title: In Race for Weiners Seat, $75,000 From Foes of Same-Sex Marriage
description: After the New York State Legislature voted in June to allow gay couples to wed, opposition groups vowed that they would make trouble for lawmakers who supported the marriage bill the next time they had to face the voters.

title: NBC Universal Hires Top Morgan Stanley Media Banker
description: NBC Universal said on Wednesday that it had hired Stuart J. Epstein, the head of Morgan Stanleys media and communications banking group, as its chief financial officer.

title: In Rafa, a Personal Look at the Game
description: Rafa, the new memoir by Rafael Nadal written with John Carlin, is a revealing look at the toll tennis takes on playersand the joy the game gives them. Our colleague Des Shoe has a report on the book, a bestseller, on ArtsBeat.

title: A House Built Out of Boulders in Uruguay
description: Pilar Acevedo and Enrique Saulle, a New York City couple looking for a change, built a home in a remote part of Uruguay.

title: Short on Product, but Not Ambition, at Frankfurt Auto Show
description: More than 50 automakers will introduce new vehicles during the press preview at the Frankfurt auto show on Sept. 13. Among them will be the worlds largest manufacturers  BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Audi, Volkswagen, Ford and so on  but so will a few hopeful start-ups. Here is a roundup of what some of these auto industry Davids are offering, in the shadows of the Goliaths:

title: Undaunted by Past Setbacks, Hands Resumes EMI Fight
description: 8:08 p.m. | Updated

title: John Romita Jr.
description: The illustrator John Romita Jr. talks about Sept. 11.

title: Recapturing the Spirit of a City as It Reeled From Its Wounds
description: After 10 years the devil is still in the details. And we see them, again and again, in the modest exhibition opening at the New-York Historical Society on Thursday, Remembering 9/11.

title: A Closer Look at Romneys Economic Plan
description: Now that weve had a day to digest Mitt Romneys economic plan, Matthew Yglesias looks between the lines and finds what he calls an agenda on social welfare policy thats basically every bit as extreme as anyone elses.

title: Compounding the Curves
description: NOT everyone is down with minimalism. Still, it was something of a surprise to see such like-minded modern designers as Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough of Proenza Schouler and Nicolas Ghesquiere of Balenciaga adding baroque-flavored flourishes to their fall runway collections. At Proenza Schouler, fancifully curved matte black and white metal necklaces were shown with stark button-down shirts; at Balenciaga, clutches and shoes in flowery embossed leather were extravagant enough to be at home in Versailles.

title: Are the RepliKates Ready to March?
description: AS he lounged near a pool in Southampton, N.Y., last month, Wes Gordon had an epiphany. A group of young women gathered nearby were poring over an issue of People, its pages teeming with images of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge. Sheathed in trim-fitting dresses, her slender arms covered almost to the wrist, the duchess impressed them as a model of regal aplomb.

title: Ross Douthat on Tonights Debate
description: The Op-Ed columnist Ross Douthat previews tonight's Republican debate, the first with Gov. Rick Perry.

title: Homes for $1.25 Million
description: A barnlike contemporary in Upstate New York; a house in Sedona, Ariz., and a Queen Anne in Portland, Ore.

title: What You Get for ... $1.25 Million
description: SEDONA, ARIZ.

title: iZon Webcam Sees a Lot, but Misses a Little
description: Consumer tech is filled with enduring mysteries.

title: Tip of the Week: Retrofitting Internet Explorer 9
description: If that Web page you are looking at in Internet Explorer 9 does not look quite right with menus and other elements out of place, it may be because the site was created before this latest version of Microsofts browser was released.

title: 5 Easy Steps to Stanch the E-Mail Flood
description: Perhaps you have heard of an organizational expert named David Allen. Over the years, Mr. Allen has helped many people organize their time, their tasks and  perhaps most important  their e-mail in-boxes with a method he calls, Getting Things Done, or GTD, for short.

title: Steve Reich
description: The composer Steve Reich talks about Sept. 11.

title: Lumire | Leg Work
description: September, the month when France makes its post-vacation rentre and social, cultural and political life resumes, is also the month when women dress up again, exchanging loose summer garb and tropziennes for form-fitting skirts and high heels.

title: Are Other Commodities Like Gold? (Quick and Wonkish)
description: A number of commenters on my gold post have asked whether the same logic doesnt apply to all commodities, oil in particular. And the answer is, no, not quite. (Im reliving my youth here  I really got into economics as an undergraduate, when I took a seminar by Tjalling Koopmans and Bill Nordhaus on exhaustible resources that led to my becoming Nordhauss research assistant; and the rest is personal history).

title: Operator Seeks to Block British Telecom Collaboration
description: The mobile phone provider Three U.K. on Wednesday asked the European Commission to block a joint venture of Britains three largest operators to sell a common mobile payment and advertising platform for retailers, arguing that the companies influence in the market would result in high fees for consumers.

title: Day Matches Canceled
description: The United States Tennis Association announced late Wednesday that it had canceled the day session. A handful of matches did start, including Rafael Nadal against Gilles Muller and Donald Young against Andy Murray, but while the tournament dried the courts periodically, match play never resumed.

title: The Battery-Saving Tips a Family Learned From Irene
description: Maybe the best thing that could be said about a widespread electrical failure is that it brings you closer to your smartphone.

title: Moseying in Thailand as a Sad, Distant Slacker
description: A not-so-cruel story of youth, the Thai film Hi-So, in the ContemporAsian series at the Museum of Modern Art, is a little like its hero: thoughtful but a bit aimless. At ease in two cultures if not quite at home in either, Ananda (Ananda Everingham) has returned to Thailand after college in America. In the first part of the movie, which splits neatly into two, he tries his hand at acting in a film being shot near the sea; in the second, set in high-rise Bangkok, he putters around his apartment building, hangs out with his girlfriend, drinks with pals.

title: Setback for Plans for Restaurant in Union Square Park
description: Plans to put a restaurant in the historic pavilion on the northern end of revitalized Union Square Park have been set back with the withdrawal of the concessionaire selected by the citys Department of Parks and Recreation.

title: The Lifespan of a Link
description: Pop quiz. How long do you think a fresh new link lasts online before people stop clicking on it? The answer: on average, just shy of 3 hours. If you ask the same question about a news-related link, the answer is a measly 5 minutes.

title: Design Sponge at Home
description: The daily readership of Grace Bonneys blog Design Sponge could fill Madison Square Garden, she writes in the introduction to her new book, Design Sponge at Home (Artisan; $35). Its a claim that might sound boastful were it not an understatement (actually, it could fill the arena several times over) and immediately followed by How cool would it be if we could all meet up every day like that?

title: No Summer Is Endless
description: Even Mother Nature seemed to send a message: Get off the beach. Get back to work.

title: Summers Over; the Game Begins
description: I am being swept along by a tidal surge of densely packed wool, silk and anxiety. I can no longer move to the back or side. My only path is forward, stepping by inches into the cramped silver box full of silent faces.

title: And Now, a Kardashian of Your Own
description: WHEN you think of Sears (if you think of it at all), what comes to mind?

title: Digital-media marketing for Hollywood movies; the dark Web; tech news.
description: Jason Yim, the president and executive creative director of the digital-media marketing company Trigger, explains how movie advertising has evolved over the years to include interactive sites, games and mobile apps. Pedro Rafael Rosado takes a peek at the area of the Internet known as the dark Web. The weeks tech news includes Sprint filing its own lawsuit over the proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile and Googles recent bit of housekeeping, while the Tip of the Week offers a way for Internet Explorer 9 users to sometimes make sense of scrambled Web sites.

title: Introducing SchoolBook
A Clip From 'Stand In'
description: The South Park co-creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone appear in a clip from the mtvU show Stand In.

title: Scene City: A Peek at the Kardashian Kollection
description: The sisters unveil their line of clothing and accessories.

title: Week 1 in Fantasy Football: Favorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Promoting Hollywood
description: Movie marketing has evolved far beyond lobby posters and trailer clips to elaborate campaigns that sometimes start even more the film itself begins shooting. In this weeks Tech Talk podcast Jason Yim, the president and executive creative director of Trigger, a digital-marketing company, discusses some of the sites and apps his company has created for different Hollywood movies.

title: A Romanian Passes Happily on the Road to a Team Victory
description: There were 12 players representing the United States at the second World Youth Congress in Croatia two weeks ago.

title: Heat-Seeking Missiles Are Missing From Libyan Arms Stockpile
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The sign on the wall reads Schoolbook Printing and Storage Warehouse, but the fact that the double gates in the wall have been crudely ripped off suggests that something more interesting might be inside.

title: Uprooting Their Lives for a View of the Hills
description: PILAR ACEVEDO and Enrique Saulle were living in a loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and working as translators and editors four years ago, when they decided they wanted to change their lives.

title: Seaport Museum Takeover Planned
description: The Museum of the City of New York will take over the beleaguered Seaport Museum New York using a $2 million grant from the corporation in charge of developing Lower Manhattan, according to state, city and museum officials who made the deal public on Wednesday.

title: Eve Brent, Played Jane in Tarzan Movies, Dies at 81
description: Eve Brent, a longtime character actress whose most recognizable role was Jane to Gordon Scotts Tarzan, died on Aug. 27 in Sun Valley, Calif. She was 81.

title: Times Names Joe Kahn Its New Foreign Editor
description: The New York Times named a new foreign editor on Wednesday, the latest in a series of high-level appointments by Jill Abramson, who became executive editor this week.

title: No Beginner Discounts at Lincoln Center
description: FOR industry insiders (and those who desperately yearn to be), there is nothing quite like Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week at Lincoln Center. Editors clutching their BlackBerrys lead gaggles of well-coiffed assistants, p.r. women in headsets and stilettos vibrate on cocktails of Red Bull and agitation, celebrities don free outfits by designers, and camera flashes illuminate rehearsed poses everywhere.

title: Shopping for Rocking Chairs With Brady Wilcox
description: The designer and chief creative officer of ducduc, which makes modern childrens furniture, went shopping for urbane rocking chairs.

title: Rocking Chairs
description: ROCKING chairs are often not that high on the shopping lists of city dwellers looking for furniture, simply because interiors evoking Little House on the Prairie do not have a lot of urban appeal. Yet this age-old design has had a number of modern makeovers, from the likes of Jacques Adnet and Charles and Ray Eames to more-recent versions from companies like James UK and Iglooplay, which have appeared in the last few months.

title: Museum of Natural History, 4:08 p.m.
Crosby Says His Concussion Symptoms Continue
description: Sidney Crosby, the N.H.L.s marquee player, said Wednesday he still had not recovered from the concussion that sidelined him last January. But he said he expected to return to hockey. .

title: When it Comes to Fixing the Roof, Look Before You Leap
description: LAST years severe winter was a costly beatdown for homeowners who dont understand ice dams, those frozen chunks that block their roof gutters and allow snow and ice to pile up.

title: Textured Wallpaper, Inspired by Lace
description: Lace, Beaded Black, a new wallpaper from Jocelyn Warner, a British textile and wallpaper designer, is the highly tactile result of Ms. Warners longstanding interest in lace.

title: Murray Moss on Putting Sex Back Into the Bed of Ware
description: With pricey designer objects displayed in glass cases and on pristine white risers, the SoHo design store Moss has often been compared to a museum. Later this month, Murray Moss, the stores founder and an owner, will have his way with a real museum: the Victoria and Albert Museum, in London. From Sept. 17 to 25, during the annual London Design Festival, Mr. Moss will present Industrial Revolution 2.0: How the Material World Will Newly Materialise, with eight installations throughout the museum.

title: On 1stdibs, Dreams, at Least, Are Free
description: WHY arent country songs written about being unable to afford a luxury item you really want? In my experience, the heartache and longing can be equal to that of any busted love affair Willie Nelson has sung about.

title: Axors First U.S. Showroom to Open in Manhattan
description: Axor, a division of the German kitchen and bath company Hansgrohe, has made a name for itself by commissioning high-profile designers like Philippe Starck and Patricia Urquiola to design fixtures. But while its products have been available in this country for some time, the retailers that carried them often sold only part of the collection.

title: Sales at Green Depot and Others
description: All items in the Westin Hotels and Resorts Retail Collection are 20 percent off, through Sept. 15 (the Westin Heavenly bed, originally $2,670 to $3,420, is $2,136 to $2,736); (877) 777-5418 or westin.com/store.

title: Tableware With Something on Its Mind
description: I keep a kind of mental notebook of phrases that resonate in my mind, said Rob Wynne, an artist who lives in Manhattan. Some are made up, some come from reading or from being overheard.

title: Creating Instant Old-Money Patina
description: The Charleston, S.C., home-stagers Sheila and Peter Potter have packed and unpacked their prized possessions 14 times in as many years.

title: The Art of Living Well
description: Charleston, S.C.

title: Beloved Brooklyn Cow Dies of Natural Causes
description: Aggie, the Dexter cow who spent her days beside the alpacas, sheep and miniature horses in the stable and barnyard at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, has died of old age, zoo officials said. She was 18.

title: Curfew Is Lifted, Shoppers!
description: LIGHTS, camera, fashion! Fashions Night Out, the annual retail bacchanal, is back tonight. The citys fanciest retail corridors will teem with celebrities, designers and the tipsy shoppers who love them until long after posted store hours say they should. This year, the most exciting events offer a first peek at something new: Missoni for Target, the fashion photographer Bruce Webers unmentionables line for the guys who dont wear underwear and a range of clothing at Opening Ceremony inspired by the Muppets. For real. So put on a reasonably comfortable pair of shoes (or, if you dare, hop aboard the double-decker Barbie bus that will be making the rounds) and shop your heart out.

title: Obamas Courtesy Call to Perry
description: Gov. Rick Perry was no doubt getting his game face on for the debate tonight when the phone rang.

title: Live Blog: Perry Makes His Debate Debut
description: 10:21 P.M. | Thats a Wrap

title: Dont Call Them Losers
description: On cable news these days Republicans are warring for attention, as the presidential primary season reaches a boiling point, and Democrats are wondering how to win despite a wretched economy. Meanwhile the C-SPAN staff is doing what almost no one else on television does: reaching back into history for campaign lessons.

title: Harvard Researcher Chosen as New Dean of Weill Cornell Medical College
description: A Harvard University researcher and professor with strong ties to the pharmaceutical industry has been selected as the new dean of Weill Cornell Medical College in Manhattan, as Cornell University seeks to greatly expand its research programs and obtain more federal and private financing, college officials said Wednesday.

title: Presidential Debate at the Reagan Library
description: The candidates for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination face off in Simi Valley, Calif.

title: Yemens Leaders Fail for Second Time to Resolve Stalemate
description: SANA, Yemen  Hampered by internal divisions, leaders in Yemens governing party on Wednesday appeared to fail for a second time to reach an agreement on how to move the country out of its prolonged political deadlock.

title: Bill Cunninghams 9/11, Fashion Week Photos
description: Where was Bill Cunningham during 9/11? At New York Fashion Week. Here are a few images that he captured amid the chaos.

title: Quinn Backs Israel at Ceremony for Kidnapped Soldier
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, told a group of Jewish leaders on Wednesday that the Council supported Israels right to defend itself and to respond to attacks.

title: Vietnam Accused of Abusing Drug Addicts
description: BANGKOK  The Vietnamese government calls it labor therapy, a program to move drug addicts off the streets and into treatment centers, where they process cashew nuts, sew garments, weave baskets  any work that might help them get back on their feet.

title: Breaking Up Could Be Good for Goldman Sachs
description: Goldman Sachs often helps chief executives increase the stock prices of their companies by carving them up. The bank, run by Lloyd Blankfein, is currently advising Kraft Foods on how it should split its operations and is counseling McGraw-Hill on whether it should do the same.

title: Where Showmanship Meets One-Upmanship, Singers Seek a Partnership
description: The millennial Steve and Eydie: that was Michael Feinsteins half-joking description of his sometime musical partnership with Linda Eder on Tuesday evening at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, where they appeared with a small swing band. This odd musical couple has sung together here and there over the last several years but not at the club that bears Mr. Feinsteins name: until now.

title: Drugs in Stimulants Banned for a Year
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration will temporarily ban three synthetic chemicals found in recreational drugs known as bath salts. The stimulants have been linked to episodes of violence and extreme paranoia. The three chemicals, mephedrone, methylenedioxypyrovalerone and methylone, will be banned for at least a year while the government studies whether to ban them permanently.

title: $265 Million Promised to Carnegie Mellon
description: William S. Dietrich II, 73, has pledged $265 million to Carnegie Mellon University, to take effect at his death. The gift  the largest in the history of the Pittsburgh-based university, and one of the 10 largest individual gifts to a university  is not yet designated for a particular purpose. Mr. Dietrich, who never attended Carnegie Mellon, is former chairman of Dietrich Industries Inc., a leading supplier of steel building materials. He has served as a trustee of Carnegie Mellon, on and off, since 1997.

title: Serbian Boom Defies an Easy Explanation
description: Up in the mountains in Serbia, Janko Tipsarevic spied a boy, maybe 10 years old, with ground strokes so clean it seemed a robot was delivering them. Tipsarevic, older by three years, had never heard of the boy. But he did hear the boys father, who kept going on about how my Novak is going to be No. 1 in the world.

title: Does Tenure Work?
description: Benjamin Ginsberg, left, of Johns Hopkins University and Naomi Schaefer Riley, author of "The Faculty Lounges," debate tenure for professors.

title: All Fashion, All the Time
description: Thursday marks the official start of Fashion Week, with more than 250 designers showing their spring 2012 collections at dozens of locations around the city, including Lincoln Center, now in its third season as home of Mercedes-Benz New York Fashion Week.

title: Patent Bill Viewed as Bailout for a Law Firm
description: A bill to overhaul the patent system that is before the Senate contains a provision that could get an influential law firm off the hook for a possible $214 million malpractice payment.

title: As Some Syrian Soldiers Record Trophy Videos, Others Join the Protesters
description: Updated | Thursday | 1:08 p.m. While video of Syrian soldiers taking part in the crackdown on dissent with enthusiasm continues to appear online  one new clip shows snipers laughing as they fire from rooftops, another the casual way troops record the beating of a prisoner on their phones  Syrian activists are also drawing attention to clips said to show soldiers who have decided to defy their orders and join the protesters.

title: The Art Of Summer
description: Since July critics for The New York Times have reviewed the inadvertent artistry of everyday life. Photographer Chang W. Lee put images to their words.

title: Wardell Quezergue, R&B Hitmaker, Dies at 81
description: Wardell Quezergue, a prime mover in New Orleans rhythm and blues since the early 1950s as a producer, arranger and bandleader for a long list of artists including the Dixie Cups, Professor Longhair, the Neville Brothers and Dr. John, died on Tuesday in Metairie, La. He was 81.

title: Obama Is President, but Football Is King
description: Like a coverage team racing downfield for a kickoff, here comes King Football. This day was always going to happen, come hell or high water or labor issues.

title: Britain: Police Question Reporter Over Leaks From Hacking Case
description: The newspaper The Guardian said Wednesday that one of its reporters, Amelia Hill, was questioned in recent days by police officers investigating leaks from the phone hacking inquiry that has enveloped Rupert Murdochs newspaper group in Britain. That followed the arrest last month of a Scotland Yard detective assigned to the phone hacking investigation, a step that British news reports linked to Guardian reports on the scandal. In a statement confirming that Ms. Hill had been questioned in connection with alleged leaks, The Guardian raised concerns about the implications for reportersrelations with their sources.Journalists would no doubt be concerned if the police sought to criminalize conversations between off-record sources and reporters, the newspaper said.

title: Some Hedge Funds, to Stay Nimble, Reject New Investors
description: Since the financial crisis, big hedge funds like Paulson & Company, Millennium Management and Och-Ziff Capital Management Group have not turned away money, eagerly collecting billions of dollars from investors who have tended to stick with the industrys marquee firms.

title: With Unfamiliar Names, Mets Close Out the Marlins
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  One night after Bobby Parnell failed to close out a game with a two-run lead in the ninth inning, the Mets handed a dicier situation to a pair of unheralded pitchers.

title: In Immigrant Areas, a Culture Clash Over Gay Marriage
description: Molly Blooms, a Victorian-accented Irish bar in Sunnyside, Queens, recently raffled off a free same-sex wedding reception, with a three-hour open bar, a D.J., a photographer and a horse-drawn gilded carriage to deliver the winning couple to the festivities. The bars owner thought the idea would be good for business and for the largely working-class and immigrant neighborhood.

title: Ex-White House Scientist Pleads Guilty in Spy Case Tied to Israel
description: WASHINGTON  A former senior government scientist who held the highest security clearances pleaded guilty to espionage on Wednesday and agreed to a 13-year prison term for selling top-secret information on military satellites and other technology to an F.B.I. agent posing as an Israeli spy.

title: Chinas Rise Isnt Our Demise
description: WASHINGTON

title: In a New Libya, Ex-Loyalists Race to Shed Ties to Qaddafi
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Khalid Saad worked for years as a loyal cog in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis propaganda machine, arranging transportation to ferry foreign journalists to staged rallies, ensuring that they never left their hotels without official escorts and raising his own voice to cheer the Libyan leader.

title: Texas A&Ms Move to SEC Hits a Snag
description: The only holdup for Texas A&M to leave the Big 12 for the Southeastern Conference has been the potential for legal action. And with the Aggies on the cusp of changing leagues Wednesday, enough legal roadblocks have arisen to at least delay the move.

title: Aiming Economic Plans at Elusive Independents
description: WASHINGTON  By proposing a jobs package filled with items that Republicans have supported in the past, President Obama is betting that moderate and independent voters he so desperately needs in next years elections will flock to his camp.

title: Inspecting a Virginia Plant for Quake-Resistance
description: The North Anna nuclear plant in Mineral, Va. is serving as a test case on earthquake safety for Northeast designs.

title: Lessons Maybe Learned
description: The Council on Foreign Relations asked its fellows for a pages worth of thoughts on lessons learned since 9/11. The result was a series of 10 posts on the Councils Web site late last month on such topics as immigration policy, counterterrorism, intelligence reform, unconventional warfare. There was nothing about the courts.

title: The Challenge of Creating Good Jobs
description: In their new book, Good Jobs America: Making Work Better for Everyone, Paul Osterman and Beth Shulman argue that the United States needs to worry about not just creating millions more jobs but also ensuring that the jobs are good ones.

title: Peacekeepers Sex Scandals Linger, On Screen and Off
description: UNITED NATIONS  On screen, two senior United Nations officials in Bosnia are arguing about firing Kathy Bolkovac, an American police officer battling to stop peacekeepers from both trafficking in young women and frequenting the brothels where they became indentured prostitutes.

title: Mogul Plans Another Run, to Succeed Lieberman
description: WASHINGTON  Linda E. McMahon, the wrestling mogul who spent $50 million of her own money in an aggressive but failed Senate run in Connecticut last year, will announce in the coming week that she will try again, according to two Republicans who are close to her.

title: After a Late Win, a Long and Sloppy Loss
description: The low line drive zipped into the glove of Baltimore shortstop Robert Andino. Keeping in the spirit of 10 errors in 20 often torturous innings over 18 waterlogged hours, Andino dropped the ball. Curtis Granderson sprinted hard to second base, then dived.

title: Romney and Perry Clash, Drawing Lines in G.O.P. Sand
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  The fight for the Republican presidential nomination began narrowing into an intense and ideological battle at a debate here Wednesday night, with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Mitt Romney sharply clashing over Social Security, health care and each others long-term prospect against President Obama.

title: Talks Resume but N.B.A. Keeps Quiet
description: If progress can be measured in hours spent in conference rooms, then the N.B.A. lockout would appear to be moving  slowly, methodically  toward some sort of conclusion. But no one sitting in those conference rooms is willing to confirm or refute that premise, at least publicly.

title: Once a Leader, Yahoo Now Struggles to Find Its Way
description: SAN FRANCISCO Yahoo has been one of the most-visited sites on the Internet since its glory days as a Web portal. Yet as the rest of the Internet moved on to social networks and mobile devices, Yahoo has failed to keep up.

title: Blunt E-Mail Raises Issues Over Firing at Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Ive just been fired.

title: Speed Bumps on a Hardcourt
description: After barely sidestepping Hurricane Irene and then waiting out a deluge that caused the postponement of Tuesdays matches and weather delays Wednesday, the players who remain in the United States Open  have much riding on the condition of the playing surfaces at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. But rain-slickened show courts are only part of their concerns. Some say they have noticed a difference this year in the hardcourts that are beneath the puddles.

title: A Gentler Touch Atop the Schools, After Years of a Hard Push for Reform
description: As he begins his first full year leading the citys public school system, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott is trying to move away from the place that a predecessor, Joel I. Klein, so comfortably occupied: the spotlight.

title: Lottery Numbers
Why I Needed a Doorman
description: I was 21 when I moved to New York City, and I couldnt tie my own shoes.

title: The Iron Horse at War
description: Among many other things, the Civil War marked the first significant use of the railroad as a military tool. Between the opening of the first European and American railroads in 1830 and the outbreak of the war in 1861, there had been a few short wars in which railways had played a supporting role in moving troops and supplying armies with ammunition. Never before, however, did it play such a central role in the strategic and tactical planning of both sides.

title: After Quake, Virginia Nuclear Plant Takes Stock
description: MINERAL, Va.  After weathering the East Coasts recent quake, the North Anna nuclear plant finds itself in a situation that no American reactor has ever faced before.

title: Rising Fears of Recession
description: If history is a guide, the odds that the American economy is falling into a double-dip recession have risen sharply in recent weeks and may even have reached 50 percent.

title: Waiting for a New Blueprint From Bank of America
description: Brian T. Moynihan takes the stage at a Midtown Manhattan hotel on Monday to tell investors what is in store for Bank of America, but already the chief executives plans are generating the kind of buzz reserved for the opening of a Broadway show down the street.

title: Man Shot in Upper Manhattan Scuffle With Officer Dies
description: A man who was critically wounded in a police-involved shooting in Upper Manhattan died in the hospital from his injuries, the police said Wednesday.

title: Fatal Shot on a Stoop May Be Tied to the Police
description: A bystander who was fatally shot on a Brooklyn stoop may have been killed by a police officers errant round, ballistics testing indicated on Wednesday.

title: Challenges Would Come With Building a Roof
description: If the Romans could put a roof on the ancient Colosseum, why cant the United States Tennis Association add a roof to one of its show courts at the United States Open? The question has, well, hung over the premier domestic tennis event for 20 years, since the U.S.T.A. opted for the sensational over the sensible in constructing Arthur Ashe Stadium, the tournaments marquee court.

title: Delivered Just in Time for Kickoff
description: IF professional football did not exist, Madison Avenue would probably try to invent it. The sport delivers large audiences for the important fall and Christmas shopping seasons. Those audiences almost all watch the games live, meaning there is no fast-forwarding through commercials during DVR playbacks. And each season culminates with a mid-winter event during which viewers are known to focus on the ads as much as the action.

title: FedEx Commercial
description: A FedEx commercial uses humor to make the companys customers aware of all of its offerings.

title: Going Green but Getting Nowhere
description: YOU reduce, reuse and recycle. You turn down plastic and paper. You avoid out-of-season grapes. You do all the right things.

title: Finding Hope in Libya
description: When I was entering Libya last week from Tunisia, a rebel soldier named Ayman objected that I didnt have a visa.

title: Debating With the Stars
description: It was a dark and stormy night.

title: Thursday: Man of Tomorrow
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  This is a very groovy puzzle, man. You might or might not agree with the philosophy behind the book it pays tribute to, but the grid rocks. Give yourself a chance to swing with it, daddy-o. Dont be a square.

title: Bloody Weekend Shows Intractable Gun Problem
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs efforts to stamp out gun violence in New York were challenged over the Labor Day weekend by a spate of shootings: Bullets flew at house parties, along parade routes and across stoops and street corners.

title: Job Program for the Supercommittee
description: Just in time to be irrelevant to the nations most pressing task, the Congressional supercommittee officially starts work on Thursday to come up with a plan to cut $1.5 trillion from the deficit. Fortunately, a few Democrats are trying to steer the committee toward the far more practical goal of creating jobs and stimulating the down-bound economy. If they succeed, there may still be a chance for the group to play a useful role.

title: Fair Lending and Accountability
description: The banking industry is complaining loudly in Washington about the growing number of fair-lending investigations started by the Obama administration. Given the discriminatory policies used by lenders before the housing meltdown, the banks and mortgage companies deserve the scrutiny. Borrowers need more protection.

title: A Familys Wishes
description: Four years ago, the Bush administration issued a regulation to protect families of veterans distressed by the intrusion of volunteer honor guards offering unsolicited prayers and recitations at national cemetery funeral rites. The administration chose the only sensible course, directing that the family of the deceased  and only they  would identify any text to be read, not outside groups, however much they invoked God and country.

title: Defense Team for Clemens Is Criticized by Judge
description: A federal judge said Wednesday that Roger Clemenss defense team had violated court rules by contacting jurors after Clemenss mistrial in July.

title: Intervening in Libya
description: To the Editor:

title: A Signal From Koch
description: To the Editor:

title: Progress in Vietnam? Concerns About Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Bowl Winners Give Warm Welcome to Rookies
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Its a cute little story, though the background runs deeper.

title: Doctor Fees Major Factor in Health Costs, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  Doctors are paid higher fees in the United States than in several other countries, and this is a major factor in the nations higher overall cost of health care, says a new study by two Columbia University professors, one of whom is now a top health official in the Obama administration.

title: Obama Blocks an Air Pollution Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Outlines Rewards and Risks of Upstate Natural Gas Drilling
description: Natural gas drilling using a controversial technique known as hydraulic fracturing could create up to 37,000 jobs and generate from $31 million to $185 million a year in added state income taxes for New York at the peak level of well development, according to analyses in a report commissioned by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation that was released on Wednesday.

title: Bad News Is Now Official for Scorched Texas Town
description: BASTROP, Tex.  It was one simple line of text, one out of 243: 112 South Buckhorn Drive. Bettye Porterfield found it on Wednesday as she ran her finger over a piece of paper taped to a window. She and her husband, Ken, had lived at that address for nearly nine years  they called it their little cottage in the pines  but now her home was gone. The list made it official.

title: Humanitarian Aid for Rape Victims
description: On his third day in office, President Obama issued an executive order lifting the odious global gag rule that denied federal money for family planning work abroad to any group that performed abortions or counseled about the procedure, even with its own money. But he left standing another policy that imposes similar speech restrictions and bans using foreign aid money for abortions  even to save a womans life or in cases of rape in war zones like Congo, Sudan and Burma.

title: The Matches Pile Up as Rain Wins Again
description: The United States Open continued Wednesday under both a cloud of controversy and actual clouds. The latter dumped, sprayed and misted rain throughout the afternoon and into the night, which left frazzled tournament officials rearranging a gridlocked schedule, players angered by an early afternoon false start and fans in dire need of umbrellas, ponchos or hooded sweatshirts.

title: From a Summer Focused on the Debt, Congress Now Pivots to Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  A mere six weeks ago, the animating word on Capitol Hill was debt. Republicans and Democrats obsessed about it, campaigned against it, fought over how to tame it and deployed it as a tool of mutual embarrassment. This fall, same template, new word: Jobs.

title: TV Executive Behind Springer Tries to Win House Seat for G.O.P.
description: Robert L. Turner has seen his share of tawdry sex scandals.

title: Intensity Increases in Republican Debate
description: Eight candidates gathered at the Reagan Library in Simi Valley, Calif., at a moment of increasing intensity in the fight for the partys presidential nomination.

title: Mets Patience Tested by Parnell
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The Mets have been exceedingly patient with Bobby Parnell this season. A losing season has afforded them that small indulgence.

title: Newly Published Audio Provides Real-Time View of 9/11 Attacks
description: For one instant on the morning of Sept. 11, an airliner that had vanished from all the tracking tools of modern aviation suddenly became visible in its final seconds to the people who had been trying to find it.

title: The 9/11 Tapes: The Story in the Air
description: A selection of audio recordings from the morning of September 11, 2001.

title: Big Hole to Repair on Giants Defense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The scene in the Giants locker room Wednesday provided a snapshot of the reality of their decimated defense. In the stall next to Jonathan Goffs vacant locker, the rookie Greg Jones sat on a stool with an open playbook at his feet.

title: In Congress, Storm Relief Is Grist for Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  Disaster relief proposals touched off a political storm on Capitol Hill on Wednesday as Senate Democrats moved to provide immediate assistance to victims of Hurricane Irene without cutting other programs to offset the cost.

title: Video of Russian Plane Wreckage
description: As my colleagues Ellen Barry and Andrew E. Kramer report, a plane carrying a popular Russian hockey team crashed during take-off on Wednesday near the Russian city of Yaroslavl, killing 43 of the 45 people on board.

title: Stoudemire Touts the Benefits of School
description: In front of about 70 people at the Polo Grounds Community Center in Harlem, Amare Stoudemire of the Knicks on Wednesday entertained rapt school children and inquisitive adults at a Department of Youth program.

title: 2 More Solar Companies Get U.S. Loan Backing
description: Undeterred by the bankruptcy filing of a California solar company that got $535 million in federal loan guarantees, the Energy Department is issuing two more large loan guarantees, albeit to companies that look like safer bets.

title: From the Archives: The First Day of School
description: Upon starting classes year after year, New York City students have tearfully said their goodbyes and cheerfully greeted their friends, no matter the decade.

title: New Injuries Weaken Cowboys Secondary and Offensive Line
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  After rattling off the Jets injury report Wednesday, which numbered 14 players, Coach Rex Ryan, his voice dripping with sarcasm, said, With that list, its going to be amazing that we can play.

title: The Republican Debate at the Reagan Library
description: The following is a transcript of the 2012 Republican presidential debate on Sept. 7, 2011, in Simi Valley, Calif., as transcribed by Roll Call.

description: Rebels found a large cache of weapons in Tripoli while 35 bodies were buried in Al-Qalaa.

description: NEW YORK

title: Crane Repairing Cathedral Topples
description: WASHINGTON  A 500-ton crane erected to allow workers to repair the earthquake-damaged National Cathedral toppled over on Wednesday, injuring the operator and damaging two nearby buildings and several cars.

description: NYT Front Page for 09/08/11

title: Finding an Instant Date Nearby, With an App
description: There are online dating services, and then there are location-based social services like Foursquare. A new application called Blendr combines the two, letting users cut to the chase and find someone to meet nearby, right now.

title: When Dogs Tangle With Snakes
description: One reason I like having a dog is to see how much she enjoys being in the outdoors. This summer my dog, Betsy, a shepherd mix I rescued five years ago, and I joined my friend George for a hike in the Sandia Mountains, which rise dramatically on the edge of Albuquerque. As we laced up our boots at the trailhead, with Betsy already checking out the smells of the forest, we were told by a ranger to look out for bears, which had been bothering picnickers in the area.

title: TimesCast | Hang 10 in New York
description: The worlds best surfers descend on Long Island for a new competition in Long Beach, home ground for local surfer Balaram Stack.

title: Word of the Day | cohabit
description: cohabit \()ko-ha-bt\ verb

title: Attacking the Democrats, but Not Always Getting It Right
description: During more than an hour and 45 minutes of intense debate on Wednesday night, the Republican presidential candidates did not shy away from exchanging blows with each other. But some of the toughest criticism  and some of the most factually problematic  was reserved for the policies, programs, and principles traditionally associated with Democrats, from tackling climate change to broadening access to health care to providing retirement insurance for the elderly.

title: Where Early Dinosaurs Lived, Deal Expands a National Park
description: PHOENIX  Call it Triassic Park.

title: George Kuchar, Underground Filmmaker, Dies at 69
description: George Kuchar, a filmmaker whose campy yet ardent low-budget movies inspired underground directors like John Waters and David Lynch in the 1960s, and helped kindle the do-it-yourself moviemaking aesthetic now ubiquitous on YouTube, died on Tuesday in San Francisco. He was 69.

title: Electability a Primary Liability for Perry
description: Ive developed a habit  its probably a bad habit  of assigning letter grades to the Republican candidates based on my initial reaction to their performance in debates. After Wednesday nights debate in Simi Valley, I gave Rick Perry a B-minus, meaning an average performance. Meanwhile, I gave Mitt Romney, his primary rival for the Republican nomination, a higher grade of A-minus.

title: tk
description: tk

title: Getting Here From There
description: On that day  the Sept. 11 that requires no year  the sun set on crushed buildings in a reimagined world. It set on a recontoured skyline and a haunted city. The equations of life no longer worked. Thats the way it seemed.

title: In Love With Death
description: Outside, the desert sky had been darkened by a sandstorm. In the tent, an Army officer pulled up a chair. It was early in the invasion of Iraq, late March 2003. With the war postponed on account of weather, there was time to talk. As I remember, the officer was a lieutenant, wary of reporters, but squirming with curiosity.

title: Police in Puerto Rico Are Accused of Abuses in Justice Dept. Report
description: WASHINGTON  In a blistering condemnation of the second-largest police force in the United States, the Justice Department is accusing the Puerto Rico Police Department of a profound and longstanding pattern of civil rights violations and other illegal practices that have left it broken in a number of critical and fundamental respects.

title: Investigation of the Puerto Rico Police Department
description: A copy of the Department of Justices investigation into the Puerto Rico Police Department.

title: Firehouse
description: Supporters send letters to NYC firehouses

title: Witness to Apocalypse
description: Days after the attacks, researchers at the Columbia Center for Oral History began asking New Yorkers to describe their experience of the most harrowing day in the city's history. The following account, the fall of the trade center told moment by moment and person by person, is drawn from the more than 600 interviews collected in the September 11, 2001 Oral History Project.

description: GRAPHIC: One 9/11 Tally: $3.3 Trillion

It takes the shape of a leather-bound firefighters logbook, where usually the ruled paper is filled with the departure times of the companys fire trucks as they ferry crews out to emergency calls.

title: What We Kept
description: After the roar, after the first ground-trembling collapse sent clouds of pulverized matter billowing through Lower Manhattan, a man paused from his hurried retreat to take in a world now coated with the dust of uncertain gray. For reasons he still cannot explain, he bent down, scooped some of this grayness into an envelope  and kept on moving.

title: Growing Up in a Hurry
description: It took a few weeks for Annette Vukosa to finally break it to her elder son, Austin, that his father would not be coming home, and for a long time after that, the two spoke only sparingly about him.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 8, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: The Age of the Eco-Citadel
description: To understand how building security has evolved since 2001, consider the rise and fall of the Jersey barrier.

title: The Lexicon
description: Unlike some other momentous events in our history  World War II, say, or the Vietnam War  the attacks that took place on Sept. 11, 2001, have not particularly changed or enriched our vocabulary. Sometimes these things take a while. It wasnt until the 1960s, for example, that the term holocaust, which used to mean any large-scale massacre, took on the specific connotations it has today. For now, though, you could argue that the events of 9/11 still seem so unfathomable that they have actually impoverished the language a little, leaving us with a vacuous phrase like war on terror, which manages to empty both war and terror of much their meaning, or the creepy, Nazi-sounding homeland, which seems a far less pleasant place to live than just plain America.

title: The Lessons
description: What do schoolchildren around the world learn about 9/11 and its aftermath?

title: Generation 9/11

She had imagined this moment for months, yet her mouth fell open as a bus from Knoxville pulled up, and then one from Memphis, delivering the first of hundreds of Muslims to her charge.

title: Muslims Now
description: American-Muslims who came of age in the 9/11 decade.

title: A Radical Revolution
description: Shortly after President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was forced from power, radical Islamists, with their long beards and rigid views, joined in street protests in Cairo. That sight quickly stoked the same Western fear that for decades helped justify support for Middle Eastern dictators: Democracy might allow radical Muslims to come to power.

title: Moms Last Lesson

title: Hit Hard by 9/11, a Piece of Queens Struggles to Let Go
description: Just off the boardwalk, towheaded children bounced on a blow-up trampoline. Grown-ups bantered and showed off babies. An annual charity event was starting off summer on the Rockaway peninsula, a sliver of Queens jutting into the Atlantic Ocean. In the usual place of honor, between the Budweiser and the barbecue, stood photographs of grinning young men: all childhood friends, all dead.

title: What to Watch on Thursday
description: Wednesday was a virtual repeat of Tuesday weather-wise. Sure, there were a few balls struck during the day, but the rains came soon after and never let up. So here we are again, with the 2011 United States Open stuck in neutral. Thinking optimistically about the forecast, here are our posts from Tuesday and Wednesday looking at the matches that may be played Thursday.

description: Todays question was written by Shannon Doyne. Her question comes from the article De Niro, in a Very Limited Engagement, Takes the Witness Stand.

description: HOW many children were conceived with sperm from the same donor that Cynthia Daily and her partner used to conceive a baby seven years ago?

title: Libyan Transitional Council Prepares to Move Its Capital to Tripoli
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Three weeks after Tripoli fell to rebel forces, the man acting as their interim governments prime minister, Mahmoud Jibril, made his first public appearance in Tripoli, the capital, at a news conference.

title: The Faces of a Towering Project
description: On the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, Fred R. Conrad, a New York Times staff photographer, was fertilizing his lawn in New Jersey. I was in shorts and Wellies, said Mr. Conrad, whose wife called him from a New York-bound bus with the news.

title: You Get What You Pay For
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: What Do You Wish Your Teachers Knew About You?
description: Teachers at a school in New York City, where the students come mostly from poor and immigrant families, visited their new students just before the first day of school. Would you like your teachers to visit you at the start of the new school year? Would it be helpful if they knew something about you and your home life?

title: GreenTech Intends to Build E.V.s in Mississippi
description: The MyCar is a Smart-sized, two-seat electric vehicle with an international pedigree to match its manufacturers outsize ambitions. Designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro, one of the auto industrys most famous stylists, the MyCar was originally intended for a manufacturer based in Hong Kong. But the diminutive E.V. is now scheduled to be produced by GreenTech Automotive, based in Mississippi, and shipped to Denmark for European distribution later this year.

title: Techno Parade Gets Paris Dancing Once Again
description: Thousands of dance lovers will take to the streets during the annual Techno Parade, on Sept. 17, to hear the pulsing music supplied by more than 150 D.J.s riding 20 floats. Part of Rendez-vous lectroniques, an electronic music festival, the parade runs for three miles through the lively neighborhoods of St.-Michel and St.-Germain, starting at Place de la Rpublique at 10:30 am and ending around 5 p.m. at Place dItalie. The action then moves to clubs when night falls.

title: Has Balance of Power in N.F.L. Swung Back to the N.F.C.?
description: Was it really only two seasons ago that the A.F.C. was in the midst of a 13-year-long stretch of dominance over the N.F.C.?

title: The Early Word: The Roll Out
description: In Todays Times:

title: Seeking Your Back-to-School Questions on Admissions
description: As the nations high school students stream back to school, The Choice has lined up the authors of a new book  which bills itself as the ultimate users manual  to field questions about what seniors and juniors (and their parents) should be doing now as the beaches of summer become dotted with fall leaves.

title: Militant Band Claims Role in Western China Attacks
description: BEIJING  A little-known Islamic group has claimed responsibility in an online video for recent violent attacks that killed dozens in Chinas western Xinjiang region, according to an American organization that tracks militant activity.

title: Two Men Arrested in German Bomb Plot
description: BERLIN  Two men were arrested here Thursday on suspicion of planning a terrorist attack, after the police tracked their purchases of bomb-making materials, a Berlin police spokesman said.

title: U.S.S. New York to Return to City for 9/11 Commemoration
description: The ship borrows its name from the city. More than seven tons of World Trade Center steel are built into the bow stem.

title: Step by Step With an Automated Start-Up
description: In my last post, I described a Web-based service called Wicked Start that can bring a measure of automation to the process of getting a new business off the ground. Wicked Start lays out a sort of template for each of 10 major steps in starting a company, suggesting ways to proceed, pointing out what might be overlooked, and offering various resources and advice. I also briefly mentioned a Wicked Start user: Hari Kaur, a yoga instructor who four months ago opened her own jazz-yoga studio in Manhattan, called Hari NYC. Ms. Kaur tried the Web site at the suggestion of one of her yoga students, who just happens to be the founder of Wicked Start, Bryan Janeczko.

title: Citing Global Weakness, Central Banks Hold Interest Rates Steady
description: FRANKFURT  The president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, warned Thursday that the risk of slower growth in Europe had intensified amid a climate of enormous economic uncertainty, and signaled that the bank was unlikely to raise rates again soon.

title: Could Ashes Low-and-Slow Strategy Work Today?
description: Thirty-six years ago this summer, Arthur Ashes reputation as a professional tennis player had begun to crumble.

title: For Fosters, a Small Win in Takeover Fight With SABMiller
description: An Australian regulatory panel has declined to move forward on claims that Fosters made misleading and deceptive statements in its full-year financial results, a charge lobbed by SABMiller in its hostile takeover battle.

title: Backpack? Check. New Sneakers? Check. Its Back to School Time.
description: Its the first day of school for more than 1 million New York City public school students, and across the city, new sneakers are being laced up, uniforms are being pressed, tears are being shed, hair is being sprayed and first impressions are being cultivated.

title: Northeast Is Soaked Again, Forcing Evacuations
description: As the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee deluged states across the Northeast on Thursday, rivers that had overrun their banks after Tropical Storm Irene were again swelling past the breaking point, prompting officials to order the evacuation of at least 120,000 people while surging waters threatened major population centers.

title: Romney and Perry Unleash Testy Rivalry at Debate
description: Mitt Romney and Rick Perry kicked off a full-throated political rivalry during the Republican debate on Wednesday night at the Reagan library and provided an early glimpse of the very different strategies that will propel their presidential campaigns forward in the next several months.

title: A Gallery of Masters
description: Alec Baldwin, Kelly Macdonald and other great performers who turn television into art.

title: Morning T | Rag & Bone
description: In this Fashion Week special, Ts Online Editor Jane Herman talks to Rag & Bones David Neville and Marcus Wainwright about cholo style, parachutes and the cool things can happen when you give a model a camera.

title: Behind the Scenes With the Creator of Downton Abbey
description: Pulling into the driveway of Julian Fellowess manor house in Dorset, in the west country of England, with its 50 acres of grass rippling and trees swaying, as if a director had just called Action! to the scenery (indeed, one massive tree was featured in the film Emma, starring Gwyneth Paltrow), I recalled the advice Fellowes once said his father gave him: If you have the misfortune to be born into a generation which must earn its living, you might as well do something amusing.

title: Court Convicts Galliano in Anti-Semitism Case
description: PARIS  John Galliano, the British fashion designer whose career imploded after a videotaped anti-Semitic rant, was found guilty and given a suspended fine of 6,000 euros on Thursday by a French tribunal in connection with two separate bar clashes in Paris with people who accused him of hate crimes.

title: European Leaders Escalate Tough Talk on Greece
description: FRANKFURT  European leaders escalated their hard-line talk on Greece on Thursday, with the German finance minister threatening to leave the country to the mercy of financial markets if it does not meet the conditions set for receiving aid.

title: Tweet! Tweet! Its Fashion Week!
description: A picture may paint a thousand words, but what can 140 characters tell you about Fashion Week? A lot, actually. Throughout New York Fashion Week, our writers will be posting live updates on Ts Twitter feed, http://twitter.com/themoment, giving you our impressions from the shows as well as from attendant parties and events.

title: When an Earthquake Shuts a Reactor
description: One of the revelations emerging in Dominions continuing inspections of its quake-shaken North Anna nuclear plant  in Mineral, Va., is just why its reactors shut down. Oddly, modernization of the plant, which is filled with devices that were state-of-the-art for the 1970s, may have played a role in the events there.

title: Remembering 9/11, and Remembering Who We Are
description: Somebody once said  actually, he said it more than once  that in the continuing struggle to protect this land from those who would harm it, we need to bear in mind not so much who they are as who we are. Maintaining our core values, he meant, is as important as fending off threats.

title: Thursday Reading: The Ins and Outs of Fixing Your Roof
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: His Highnesses
description: I love brands that have a niche, something that they do incredibly well time and time again, says the designer Wes Gordon. For Gordon, few fit this description better than Manolo Blahnik. What I love about Manolo is that theyve been making the same consistently beautiful shoes for as long as theyve been in business, says Gordon. No one nails the timeless, forever-feminine aesthetic quite like them. This praise explains his excitement about collaborating with the Italian shoe company for his spring presentation, taking place on Thursday at the Hosfelt Gallery in Chelsea. Using elements of Manolos existing vocabulary  a heel here, a strap there  Gordon designed two different shoes for the show, an updated Mary Jane for day and a streamlined, stacked-heel sandal for night. It was something of Manolo Legos, the designer says of the process. The look is very Gwyneth from Great Expectations. Clean 90s minimalism done in a very luxe way. Expect timeless silhouettes done in surprising fabrications, like Lurex and stretch tulle. So many shoes out there are very aggressive or very cool, and make a statement. But I think at the end of the day what a woman wants is something really sexy, beautiful and clean.

title: George Carlin Street? Hed Have Something to Say About That
description: Three George Carlin fans laughed on a rainy West 121st Street stoop Wednesday afternoon as they imagined naming his boyhood block after him.

title: Hello! Matt Stone and Trey Parker Crash a Class at N.Y.U.
description: It turns out a Tony Award really can get you in anywhere. Having run the table at the Tonys in June with their hit musical, The Book of Mormon, the South Park co-creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker were back in New York on Tuesday, where they showed up as instructors at New York Universitys Tisch School of the Arts. Approximately 25 freshmen who perhaps expected to doze their way through the first day of a Storytelling Strategies course were instead treated to a surprise visit by Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker, who discussed the creation of projects including South Park, Team America: World Police and The Book of Mormon. (Among the nuggets of wisdom offered by Mr. Parker, a self-confessed addict of the Food Network, was to not use too many ingredients in your writing: Get one piece of salmon and cook it just right, he said. Boil it down to one thing.)

title: ESPN Extends Deal With N.F.L. for $15 Billion
description: Hours before the N.F.L. season began Thursday, ESPN demonstrated what Monday Night Football means to the cable empire by renewing it for $15.2 billion through 2021, according to a person briefed on the details. The completion of the contract was delayed by the leagues player lockout.

title: One 9/11 Tally: $3.3 Trillion
description: Al Qaeda spent roughly half a million dollars to destroy the World Trade Center and cripple the Pentagon. What has been the cost to the United States?

title: Morning Take-Out
description: To Stay Nimble, Some Hedge Funds Reject New Investors | After the financial crisis, some small and midsize hedge fund managers are flourishing and turning away new investors, rather than put their returns at risk.

title: Spotted on the Street | Alexandra Pezenik
description: The Girl: Alexandra Pezenik, a student in literature, philosophy and sociology at Sarah Lawrence College.

title: New Fossils May Redraw Human Ancestry
description: An apelike creature with human features, whose fossil bones were discovered recently in a South African cave, is being greeted by paleoanthropologists as a likely watershed in the understanding of human evolution.

title: Court Denies Saab Protection From Creditors
description: 6:06 p.m. | Updated

title: Day of Pain, Through TVs Prism
description: Nobody who remembers Sept. 11 wants to relive it.

title: The Rick Perry Experiment
description: Under the traditional rules of American politics, last night was a very bad night for Texas Governor Rick Perry. In his debut debate, his first introduction to a national audience, he found himself first explaining and then doubling down on his description of Social Security as a Ponzi scheme, with a few references to the monstrous lie of its long-term promises thrown in for good measure. It was precisely the kind of moment that the Romney campaign must have been hoping for, and thanks to the moderators questions and Perrys answers, it fell into Romneys lap without him having to even raise the issue. As soon as the exchange happened, a Romney adviser e-mailed Politicos Ben Smith: [Perry] has lost. No federal candidate has ever won on the Perry program to kill Social Security. Never has. never will. Thats spin, yes, but Im sure the Romney people believe the basic premise. As well they should. Everything we know about American voters  and yes, Republican primary voters very much included  suggests that Perrys comments will eventually be deadly to his electoral prospects.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Morning T: Rag & Bone
description: Jane Herman, online editor at T Magazine, talks with the designers behind the clothing line Rag & Bone.

title: At the Open, Bagels for the Men
description: Despite the well-publicized trend of top A.T.P. players such as Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray turning to gluten-free diets, male players at the 2011 U.S. Open have shown a voracious appetite for bagels.

title: Kids in the 9/11 Decade
description: How children coming of age in the 9/11 decade respond to the events of Sept. 11.

title: DuPont Offers Compensation for Dead Trees
description: The chemical manufacturer DuPont has set up a process through which people can make monetary claims for trees that have been damaged or killed by its product Imprelis, a new-generation herbicide that was used by commercial applicators on lawns across the country this spring for the first time.

title: In the Morning, Optimism at the Open
description: Shortly after 9 a.m. on Thursday, subway workers opened the gates below the tracks for the 7 train, and workers for the United States Open made their way onto the boardwalk. One woman wore rainbow striped galoshes. A man carried an oversized umbrella.

title: Art on Your Sleeve | Amy Yao for JF & Son
description: Not many fashion labels can boast an in-house art curator, but for Jesse Finkelstein and Katie King, the designers behind the New York label JF & Son, Travis Boyer is an accessory they cant live without. Through my My Favorite Things, JF & Son works on at least four collaborative collections per year as well as various one-off collaborations. Last year, for example, the artist Ulrike Mller translated her 8.5-by-11-inch pencil drawings into quilts; a version of this project was part of the 2010 Cairo Biennial. Were trying to be a little more spontaneous, Finkelstein explains. Its not about creating a lifestyle for our customer. Adds King: Its more about creating a vision that appeals to the community.

title: Knopf Speeds U.S. Publication of Julian Barnes Novel
description: Trying to capitalize on Booker buzz, Knopf has moved up the publication date of The Sense of an Ending, a novel by Julian Barnes that was one of six books chosen for the shortlist of the 2011 Man Booker Prize for Fiction. Mr. Barnes has been widely cited as a favorite for the prize, which is the most celebrated literary award in Britain. The Sense of an Ending, a slim volume of only 176 pages, will be released by Knopf, part of Random House, on Oct. 11, three months ahead of its scheduled U.S. publication date. Four of the other shortlisted books have already been published in the United States, and the remaining book, Half Blood Blues by Esi Edugyan, is not yet available in the United States, said a spokeswoman for its London-based publisher, Serpents Tail. The winner of the Booker will be announced on Oct. 18.

title: Welcome to India Ink
description: Welcome to India Ink, The New York Times first-ever country-specific site for news, information, culture and conversation.

title: Ironworkers of the Sky
description: To get to the top of 1 World Trade Center as it stands in mid-August, just shy of 1,000 feet above Lower Manhattan, higher than anything else on the islands southern end, first you walk to the middle of the blast-resistant concrete cathedral that will become the buildings lobby. From there, a hoist takes you to the 39th floor, whose perimeter has already been glassed in. A sign spray-painted in screaming construction orange  EXPRESS ALL DAY  directs you to a second hoist, inside which Don McLean is singing, Bye, bye, Miss American Pie . . . and men in hard hats decoupaged with flag decals are bobbing their heads to the beat.

title: Ford Focus ST: An Already Familiar Face Turns Toward Frankfurt
description: The series production version of the Ford Focus ST will show its face formally  and finally  next week at the Frankfurt motor show. The hot hatch will be sold in the United States later in 2012.

title: Some Channels Are Forgoing 9/11 Shows
description: By the time the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks has passed, American television networks will have presented more than 75 hours of new programming  documentaries, memorials, dramas, live broadcasts  connected to the event. That tide will continue into the night of the anniversary on Sunday, when ABC, CBS, PBS and several cable channels are devoting some or all of their prime-time schedules to shows related to the attacks.

title: Plane or Train? Sites to Help You Decide
description: Some travelers would take the train rather than plane if the price was right, but entering an itinerary at multiple travel sites is inconvenient. Two search engines, Hipmunk and TripAdvisor Flights, are fixing this problem by allowing users to do one-stop shopping for airplane and intercity rail tickets.

title: Play Resumes at the Open
description: The United States Open resumed play Thursday morning. But for Andy Roddick, the No. 21 seed, and fifth-seeded David Ferrer, the resumption did not last long at Louis Armstrong Stadium. Roddick was part of a group of players who visited Brian Earley, the tournament referee, on Wednesday, after three matches were started briefly in the afternoon, then eventually canceled. Roddick said that officials may have jumped the gun a little bit, in trying to force the players on the court. Other matches were being played on other courts.

title: Yankees Playing Orioles Under Overcast Skies
description: 1:51 p.m. | Updated With Game Under Way

title: Exhibition of Bob Dylan Paintings Will Be Shown at Gagosian Gallery in New York
description: From the rubble-filled streets of Rome to the sunny, aqua-blue skies of Mozambique, Bob Dylan has traveled the world in his music and his real-life exploits. Now a series of his drawings and paintings that chronicle his journeys in Asia will be coming to the Gagosian Gallery, the first time that Mr. Dylans art will be exhibited in New York City, the gallery said.
