The exhibition, The Asia Series, will run at the Gagosian on the Upper East Side from Sept. 20 through Oct. 22, and will include works that Mr. Dylan created on trips to Japan, China, Vietnam and South Korea. (Dylanologists will recall that the singer-songwriter played his first shows in China and in Vietnam last spring.)

title: Monza:  A Weekend of Anniversaries, Good and Bad
description: MONZA, Italy  It feel likes a typical, warm, sunny Thursday of the Italian Grand Prix weekend here in Monza. But as I think about the themes of the weekend, one thing comes through predominantly: The number of anniversaries, good and bad. They are coming in from all sides.

title: Monza:  A Weekend of Anniversaries, Good and Bad
description: MONZA, Italy  It feel likes a typical, warm, sunny Thursday of the Italian Grand Prix weekend here in Monza. But as I think about the themes of the weekend, one thing comes through predominantly: The number of anniversaries, good and bad. They are coming in from all sides.

title: Leading M.&A. Lawyer to Join Greenberg Traurig
description: Big news in Big Law: Dennis Block, one of the countrys leading mergers and acquistions lawyers, is joining Greenberg Traurig. He is leaving Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft.

title: Fall Trends | Feet First
description: Walk softly and wear a big trend. Go to  interactive feature >>

title: Google Details, and Defends, Its Use of Electricity
description: Google disclosed Thursday that it continuously uses enough electricity to power 200,000 homes, but it says that in doing so, it also makes the planet greener.

title: The Price We Pay for Medical Care
description: Americans seem to be paying the price for the unrelenting rise in health care costs in this country, according to several studies being published on Thursday in Health Affairs, an academic journal.

title: In a Twist, Google Reviews Zagat, and Decides to Bite
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Mourners Gather at Arena of Russian Hockey Team
description: YAROSLAVL, Russia  Toward evening on Thursday, a column of government officials in dark suits filed out of the hockey arena and began their journey back to Moscow. They were watched from a distance by a crowd made up largely of teenagers, many in hockey jerseys, their eyes swollen from crying.

title: A Tale of Jacob, Esau and Muscles
description: At one point in Warrior we see Brendan Conlon, a high school science teacher, laying down the law  the law of physics that is  for his students. Force equals mass times acceleration, he writes on the board. That formula might be of use in thinking this new film from Gavin OConnor, which grasps the Newtonian principles at the heart of pugilistic melodrama.

title: Regulator Further Delays Derivatives Rules
description: A top federal regulator will further delay a flood of new rules for the $600 trillion derivatives market, another setback for the sweeping overhaul passed in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

title: Spotting a Few Sharks and Jets at New York Philharmonics West Side Story
description: When they stood up, several looked like New York Philharmonic patrons: older men in suits.

title: Tips for Negotiating the Cost of Medical Care
description: Readers of Bucks know that we usually advocate negotiating discounts on all sorts of things, on the theory that it never hurts to ask. But what about medical care? Is there room to discuss the cost of, say, your annual checkup?

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Its time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

title: Just One Look | Organic by John Patrick
description: A collection dominated by khakis and white cotton linen has safari written all over it, even with the offbeat addition of Belgian loafers and silk pajama pants. Here, a very American white shirt, wide-leg jeans and a cape-shaped parka in a look full of basics that should be the easiest to shop for, but often arent. Bookmark it. Youll be happy you did.

title: No Search for Profits, but Troupe Finds Hits
description: LONDON

title: Google Buys the Zagat Guides
description: Our colleagues at DealBook are reporting that Google has purchased the Zagat Survey company for an as-yet undisclosed sum.

title: Subversive Tongue and a Sharp Focus on Identity Politics
description: IF Caryl Churchill, Franz Kafka and Ali G were to goof around one night and play their music too loud until the Department of Homeland Security came knocking on their door, they might emerge (eventually) the next morning holding something like the script to Invasion! In that play  Jonas Hassen Khemiris blistering dark comedy, which opens at the Flea Theater on Tuesday  one characters harmless memories of his Lebanese uncle, Abulkasem, morph into a genre- and language-scrambling fantasia on fear, confusion and the Other. Along the way the evasive Abulkasem re-emerges as everyone from a world-renowned terrorist to a female avant-garde theater director to a super pro pimp at a singles bar.

title: Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea Asks a Friend to Help It Grow
description: Doug Zell, the founder of Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea, announced that he will share his duties as chief executive with the philanthropist and former real estate developer Robert Buono. Mr. Zell and Mr. Buono will both have the title of Co-C.E.O. in a professional association that Mr. Buono characterizes as a partnership.

title: Man Pleads Guilty in 4 Killings at Long Island Pharmacy
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The man accused in the shooting deaths of four people in a pharmacy in Medford, N.Y., pleaded guilty on Thursday to five counts of first-degree murder and faces the likelihood of spending the rest of his life in prison.

title: Japan Official Ordered Nuclear E-Mails, Inquiry Finds
description: KYOTO, Japan  Investigators concluded Thursday that a nuclear plant operator that tried to manipulate public opinion with fake e-mails was acting under instructions from a high-ranking local government official, adding a new twist to a scandal that has hampered Japans efforts to restart idled nuclear reactors after the Fukushima disaster.

title: Court Blocks Suit Against Health Law
description: A federal appellate court in Richmond, Va., on Thursday threw out a pair of cases challenging the constitutionality of President Obamas 2010 health care law, ruling for varying reasons that the plaintiffs did not have legal standing to sue.

title: [title of show] Team Will Return to Vineyard With Newest Show
description: The creators of the critically acclaimed but short-lived Broadway musical [title of show] will mount their new project Now. Here. This.  once more, a blend of autobiographical stories and songs  at the Vineyard Theater in March and April 2012, the Off Broadway theater company announced on Thursday.

title: Mississippi Lures Green Manufacturing Jobs
description: Calisolar, a Sunnyvale, Calif.-based manufacturer of silicon for solar cells, has decided to build its next factory in a faraway locale known for generous government subsidies, low taxes and relatively inexpensive labor rates: Mississippi.

title: Lazard Hires a Greenhill Founding Partner
description: Lazard, the independent investment bank, said on Thursday that it had hired Timothy M. George, a founding partner of the boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company, to expand its consumer and food advisory practice.

title: Hedge Fund Takes Big Yahoo Stake, Calls for Board Shake-Up
description: Daniel S. Loebs hedge fund, Third Point Management, disclosed in a filing on Thursday that it had acquired a 5.15 percent stake in Yahoo and hinted at a proxy challenge if changes were not made on the Internet companys board.

title: Roddick-Ferrer Match Moved to Court 13
description: 1:48 p.m. | Updated Andy Roddick seemed to take his anger over the botched drying of Armstrong Stadium out on David Ferrer. After play resumed on Court 13, Roddick quickly grabbed the first set 6-3 and then the second set 6-4.

title: Miles Davis, Live at the Apogee
description: AROUND this time last year it became hard not to see the Miles Davis reissue juggernaut as a snake swallowing its own tail. What cinched the impression was the arrival of The Genius of Miles Davis, encompassing all of Daviss output for Columbia. It wasnt a bricklike compendium of albums  that had been done, with great fanfare, the previous year  but rather a stockpile of the eight multidisc sets released by Columbia/Legacy over the last 15 years. A boxed set of boxed sets. It came housed in a reproduction of Daviss trumpet case, along with a reproduction of his mouthpiece, a lithograph of one of his paintings, and a T-shirt. Original retail: $1,199. (Its a well-fed snake.)

title: Ironworkers in the New York Times Lobby
description: We invite all of our local readers to check out an amazing exhibit of New York Times photography in honor of 9/11. Come to the New York Times lobby, at 620 8th Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets. Its free and open to the public from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. between Sept. 8 and 12.

title: Patient Data Posted Online in Major Breach of Privacy
description: A medical privacy breach led to the public posting on a commercial Web site of data for 20,000 emergency room patients at Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., including names and diagnosis codes, the hospital has confirmed. The information stayed online for nearly a year.

title: How Much Information Do You Share With Employees?
description: Do you tell your employees everything thats going on? Or only what you think they need to know? I have grappled with this question since I started managing a business.

title: A Boa, an Autopsy and More About Goldsmith
description: As Tropical Storm Irene was making landfall in the city on Aug. 28, flooding erupted in an apartment at a public housing complex in Brooklyn, and officers from the departments elite Emergency Service Unit answered the call for help.

title: Sex, and Kids, and Rock n Roll
description: Each generations definition of good music seems to include the fact that it offends, or at least baffles, the generation before.

title: Library of Congress Acquires John Raitt Collection
description: The Broadway and personal memorabilia of John Raitt, the dynamic baritone and Broadway leading man who played Billy Bigelow in the original 1945 production of Carousel and Sid Sorkin in The Pajama Game a decade later, has gone to the music division of the Library of Congress. The extensive collection is a peek into six decades of Mr. Raitts life and includes scrapbooks, publicity photos, recordings, annotated scripts, musical scores, tapes he made of himself, and correspondence, said Denise Gallo, the head of acquisitions and processing at the librarys music division.

title: Hertz on Demand Enters Car-Sharing Race
description: With a Kermit-green ethos and paperwork-free, right-around-the-corner rentals, car-sharing schemes like Zipcar  have built a loyal following among auto-less urbanites and college students, customers that Zipcar refers to as Zipsters. Now one of the biggest names in car rentals is rolling out some new competition.

title: Divining Perrys Meaning on Galileo Remark
description: In one of the more curious moments in the Republican debate on Wednesday night, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas invoked 17th-century science in discussing his doubts about climate change. He cited the astronomer and mathematician Galileo Galilei  often called the father of modern science  in suggesting that the current thinking that climate change is a result of human activity could be overturned. Galileo got outvoted for a spell, he said.

title: Phillies Protest Is Denied
description: The Phillies protest regarding fan interference and the umpires use of video replay in their game with the Florida Marlins on Sunday was denied on Wednesday by Major League Baseball.

title: Firefighters Names Endure in St. Patricks Towers
description: You and I can think of many words to describe the ceiling of St. Patricks Cathedral: Intricate. Fussy. Medieval. Gloomy. Mysterious. Celestial. Uplifting. Inspirational. Awesome.

title: Nadal Defeats Muller
description: In a battle of powerful left-handers, Rafael Nadal of Spain took top billing over unseeded Gilles Muller of Luxembourg and rushed into the quarterfinals of the United States Open on Thursday with a 7-6 (1), 6-1, 6-2 victory on a dried-out Arthur Ashe Stadium court.

title: Lost & Found | Hanna Liden at Karma
description: A couple of weeks ago, the artist Hanna Liden forgot her backpack on a bench in the East Village. When she went back to look for it some 20 minutes later, it was still there. Thats scary! Liden exclaimed the other morning, sitting at a table at Karma, Brendan Dugans bookshop and design studio on Downing Street in the West Village. The New York Liden lays bare in her new book, Out of My Mind  Back in 5 Minutes, is not the sort of place youd want to leave your personal belongings unattended. Trash bags pile up in the streets like body bags, a slick of dark liquid might be oil or it might be blood, even a rock in central park has the menacing look of a giant, gaunt-eyed skull. This is, of course, all a lot funnier than it sounds. The book is compiled from images swiped from the Internet, photos taken with a BlackBerry and installation shots from Lidens recent shows at Maccarone and Salon 94 including a series of self-portraits in which she wore various plastic deli shopping bags. A recurring chorus of slogans appropriated from souvenir T-shirts delivers the punchline. Of all the things Ive lost, I miss my mind the most.

title: At La Scala, the Show Will Go On as Workers Cancel Strike Plans
description: Workers at La Scala opera house in Milan have rescinded a strike threat, meaning a concert performance of Beethovens Fidelio there on Friday by the Vienna Staatsoper will go on, a spokesman for the company said on Thursday.

title: Obama Challenges Congress on Job Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Mixing politically moderate proposals with a punchy tone, President Obama challenged lawmakers on Thursday to pass this jobs bill  a blunt call on Congress to enact his $447 billion package of tax cuts and new government spending, designed to revive a stalling economy and his own political standing.

title: Richard Chai: Back to School
description: At New York Fashion Week, particularly with the September shows, there is always a slight back-to-school feeling whenever all the editors and retailers reconvene, as they did this morning in Lincoln Center, in all their latest finery. This morning also happened to be the first day of school for most New York City students, and at least in my neighborhood in Brooklyn, the students were better dressed than the fashionistas. I was particularly taken with a young woman who was wearing an oversize white dress shirt backwards and belted. (Its also Fashions Night Out, so that may explain why so many people look done-up today.)

title: The Cycle of Revenge
description: Ive never understood the proverbial wisdom that revenge is a dish best served cold. Some seem to like it hot. Better is the Chinese proverb, attributed to Confucius, Before you embark on a journey of revenge, dig two graves. Osama bin Ladens grave was watery, but the other still appears empty. Is it intended for us?

title: Romney Hits Perry Again on Social Security
description: If there was any doubt about what Mitt Romney thought was the most significant moment of Wednesday nights debate, an e-mail from his campaign should clear that right up.

title: Opel-Vauxhall Concept Joins Suddenly Crowded E.V. Runabout Segment
description: Add another contestant to the city-car sweepstakes kicking off next week in Frankfurt: the battery-operated Opel-Vauxhall runabout concept.

title: New York Fashion Week Diary | Tom Bull
description: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week. In this clip, the duo attends a Perry Ellis casting. Im already an option for the campaign, so hopefully the shows a given, Bull says. Our fingers are crossed for you, Tom!

title: New York Fashion Week | Tom Bull
description: The Moment follows Tom Bull on a casting call for Fashion Week.

title: Divining Perrys Meaning in Galileo Remark
description: In one of the more curious moments in the Republican debate on Wednesday night, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas invoked 17th-century science in discussing his doubts about climate change. He cited the astronomer and philosopher Galileo Galilei  often called the father of modern science  in suggesting that the current thinking that climate change is a result of human activity could be overturned. Galileo got outvoted for a spell, he said.

title: A performance by the English singer-songwriter Nick Lowe; a flood of Miles Davis live releases; and new albums from Terius Nash, George Strait and Cymbals Eat Guitars.
description: This week: a chat with and performance by the English singer-songwriter Nick Lowe; a deep dive into a new Miles Davis live set; and a look at new releases by Terius Nash, George Strait and Cymbals Eat Guitars. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: Poetry Pairing | Images of Transit Riders
description: What images strike you and linger in your mind when youre on a subway platform awaiting an arrival or leaving the station? Do you notice the faces and expressions of your fellow riders when youre on a train?

title: Wal-Mart to Bring Back Layaway for Holidays
description: Wal-Mart said on Thursday that it planned to bring back its layaway payment plan for the holidays, an indication that shoppers at the nations largest retailer were feeling more and more strapped.

title: Brian Dennehy stars in two productions at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival.
description: Brian Dennehy portrays two contrasting miscreants in productions of Shakespeares Twelfth Night and Harold Pinters Homecoming at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival.

title: Memory in the Making
description: MILAN

title: Fed Chief Describes Consumers as Too Bleak
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered a new twist on a familiar subject Thursday, revisiting the question of why growth continues to fall short of hopes and expectations.

title: Dodging Raindrops and Seeking a Title, Federer Moves On
description: That man trying to sell New Yorkers a Rolex by the side of the road? That would be Roger Federer, whose image graces a billboard along the route from Manhattan to the National Tennis Center in Queens.

title: A Hummingbirds Musical Tail
description: David Rothenberg, a musician, author and environmental philosopher (and friend and neighbor last seen here covered in cicadas), has contributed a Your Dot reflection on some fascinating research published in the Sept. 9 edition of Science. The work reveals how the males of certain hummingbird species go beyond the usual avian song-making methods, exploiting the turbulence around tail feathers to add to their conventional vocalizations when trying to attract a mate.

title: ArtsBeat: Sept. 8, 2011
description: Excerpts from interviews with artists reflecting on the Sept. 11 attacks ten years later. For the full interviews, please go to nytimes.com/arts.

title: Many Views on a Greek Bonds Value
description: Is there one set of international accounting standards, or can each country choose its own when the going gets tough?

title: HBO Picks Up Aaron Sorkin Series About Cable TV News
description: Aaron Sorkin is a man who likes getting deep inside high-pressure work environments  see his rsum, which includes the television series Sports Night and The West Wing, and his Academy Award-winning screenplay for The Social Network. And his latest project should offer plenty of opportunities for the verbal fireworks and walk-and-talk tracking shots he favors. HBO said on Thursday that it had picked up a new series from Mr. Sorkin set in the competitive world of cable-television news.

title: For the Mets, Injuries Never End
description: Jay Horwitz, the longtime spokesman for the Mets, fractured his ankle Thursday morning while walking to work and will undergo surgery Monday.

title: F.B.I. Raids Solar Firm That Got U.S. Loans
description: The F.B.I. on Thursday raided the office of a California solar company that borrowed $528 million from the federal government before filing for bankruptcy, as House Republicans announced that they would call two top Obama administration officials to testify about the case next week.

title: Head Injuries on the Football Field
description: College football players beware: Linebackers and linemen suffer more head impacts during a game than players in other positions, but running backs and quarterbacks endure the hardest and most severe blows to the head, a new study reports.

title: Discussing the Opening Sequence of 3
description: Tom Tykwer, the director of 3, discusses the collage-focused opening credit sequence of his film.

title: Popcast: Nick Lowe, an Interview, Performance and Album Preview
description: This week the English singer-songwriter Nick Lowe stopped by to talk about his career and perform a song from his new album, The Old Magic. An exclusive stream of the record is below.

title: Canada Extends Trading Ban on Sino-Forest
description: OTTAWA  The Ontario Securities Commission on Thursday extended until next year its trading ban of shares of Sino-Forest, a controversial Chinese forestry company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Cloudy, With A Chance Of Tennis
description: After two days of washouts, tennis matches have resumed with Roger Federer facing Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the Quarterfinals of the US Open at Arthur Ashe Stadium tonight.

title: Profile in Style | Scott Sternberg
description: Ask him about his childhood troll collection, his penchant for old Time Life tomes or his worship of baked goods  but please dont ask the Band of Outsiders designer to expound on his personal style. Thats such a magazine question, he says with a groan. Like the cool subversions of mens and womens preppy classics his fast-growing label is known for (the first BOO store opens in Tokyo this winter), Sternbergs L.A. home is a playful amalgam of vintage references and bright color combinations with a winsome splash of navet. Go to  interactive feature >>

title: Courtside: Cloudy, With a Chance of Tennis
description: After two days of washouts, tennis matches have resumed, with Roger Federer facing Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the Quarterfinals of the U.S. Open at Arthur Ashe Stadium tonight.

title: Boys in Briefs
description: Go figure. The combination of an open bar and the promise of young, attractive men in skimpy underwear is quite the crowd-pleaser. At least that was the conclusion to be drawn from the 2(X)ist 201fashion show at the Hiro Ballroom in Chelsea last night.

title: Pictures of the Day: New Jersey and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the United States, Libya, Russia and Britain.

title: Report Details British Abuses in Iraq
description: LONDON  A major inquiry into the most notorious case of detainee abuse by British soldiers in Iraq described a very great stain on the reputation of the army in its report issued Thursday, detailing a series of gruesome abuses by servicemen in a regiment with a 300-year history of battle honors abroad.

title: Internet Memes 101: A Guide to Online Wackiness
description: In the olden days, it was simple to keep up with pop culture. There were only three channels on TV, and everybody saw the same shows at the same time.

title: Fall Hacking Season Underway!
description: General Assembly, on Broadway, between 20th and 21st streets, will host noteworthy hackfests the next two weekends.

title: Saab, Denied Court Protection, Faces Bankruptcy
description: On Thursday, a Swedish district court rejected Saabs bid for protection from its creditors, leaving the automaker with few options other than filing for bankruptcy. The company reportedly owes its suppliers 150 million euros ($210 million).

title: At the Toronto Film Festival, the Publicists Invade
description: TORONTO American Airlines Flight 1586, nonstop from Los Angeles to Toronto on Wednesday, was packed to the bulkheads with what looked very much like Geoffrey Rush, a journalist or two (this one included), and publicists, of every size, shape and function. Ryan Goslings publicist. International publicists. Sony Pictures publicists. The whole gamut.

title: Serena Williams Wins in Straight Sets
description: Serena Williams of the United States won an error-plagued encounter with Anastasia Pavlyuchenko of Russia on Thursday to advance to the semifinals of the U.S. Open, 7-5, 6-1.

title: The Vote That Delayed Obamas Speech
description: WASHINGTON  Last week there was a small hoo-ha over choosing a day for President Obama to address a joint session of Congress. Mr. Obama wanted to give his jobs speech on Wednesday, the same night as a Republican presidential debate. But he was rebuffed by John A. Boehner, the House speaker, who said late votes on Wednesday would prohibit an ample security sweep.

title: Fete Accompli | The Couture Council Honors Valentino
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#892", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);What:The annual benefit luncheon for the Couture Council of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. This years event was in honor of Valentino, who was presented with the Artistry of Fashion Award. In attendance were many of the retired designers friends and fans  many in Valentino red to brighten up a dreary, gray day.

title: Does the Return of Lost Items Require a Reward?
description: Many of you have probably experienced that sinking feeling when you realize that youve lost your wallet, a phone, or perhaps even worse, a laptop.

title: Rating the No. 1s: Batgirl and More
description: Two Times staffers and comic-book fans, George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler, will review all of the 52 DC Comics titles that have been rebooted as part of a companywide effort to revive the brand. In the second of five weekly installments they discuss Batgirl, Animal Man, Action Comics and others that came out on Wednesday. Next week theyll look at Batwoman, Green Lantern and more.

title: Plans Focus on Social Security Taxes Reflects Its Modest Ambitions
description: WASHINGTON  The centerpiece of President Obamas job-creation plan, a proposal to further reduce Social Security taxes, is emblematic of a package of modest measures that some economists describe as helpful but not sufficient to lift the economy from its malaise.

title: A Big Risk in the Health Care Handoff
description: Care transitions  those times when someone enters a hospital, transfers from one department to another, gets discharged to a rehabilitation center or goes home  are risky times. Health care professionals have long known that these handoffs provide prime opportunities for mistakes, most often because of communication lapses.

title: 36 Hours in Bern
description: In Bern, you can dance till dawn or rise early and take a walk under the gaze of the Alps and be back in time for lunch.

title: 36 Hours in Bern, Switzerland
description: ASK a Swiss to describe Bern and you may hear a joke about how the people move so slowly that even their souls take centuries to reach heaven. While it is true that this city of about 130,000 people in western Switzerland must be counted among the most relaxed of Europes capitals, Bern is also one of the most beautiful, a pocket-size Prague of arcades and whimsical fountains, all framed by leafy hills and the glacial-green currents of the Aare River. The urban and rural mingle closely here. Forests of ash and oak push up against a clutch of embassies off a city square. You can dance till dawn or rise early and take a walk under the gaze of the Alps and be back in time for lunch. Why rush through that?

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Inside the Bush White House
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheneys memoir debuts at No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week. How some other books written by authors with ties to the Bush administration fared.

title: Brothers in, and Beyond, Arms
description: Last fall, as a new student at Columbia University, I endured the hallowed tradition of new student orientation, picking classes, and trying to fit in. The only difference being that I was not a 17-year-old leaving his parents nest for the first time, but a 24-year-old soldier who had spent a large majority of his early 20s training for war and deploying to war.

title: The Different Audiences for Obamas Speech
description: President Obamas jobs speech on Thursday evening will take place in front of a joint session of Congress, underlining the coming legislative clash over how best to jump-start the nations flagging economy.

title: Faculty Strike Delays Classes at L.I.U.
description: Classes at Long Island University were supposed to start Wednesday, but the new school year has been delayed for thousands of students at the main campuses in Brooklyn and Long Island, where the faculty is on strike.

title: Stosur Defeats Zvonareva
description: Samantha Stosur of Australia, a finalist a year ago at the French Open, upset Vera Zvonareva of Russia, 6-3, 6-3, on Thursday to catapult into the womens semifinals of the U.S. Open.

title: Talent Lifts NBC
description: Riding on the back of Americas Got Talent, NBC finished first in average total viewership and tied CBS for the top spot in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic on Wednesday night. Talent definitely has some momentum heading into its season finale next week, rising 11 percent in total viewers to 11.8 million compared to last weeks episode.

title: TimesCast | Obama's Jobs Speech Preview
description: President Obama presents his jobs and economic growth plan tonight amid a darkening economic forecast.

title: Backstage at BCBG
description: Wet, slicked-back hair and minimal makeup at the BCBG show.

title: Morgan Stanley Names 3 to Head Media and Telecom Group
description: Morgan Stanley has named three new heads of its media and communications banking group, after the teams current head left the firm for NBC Universal, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

title: A Push-Button Hemingway Soundtrack
description: IN a game of Six Degrees of Ernest Hemingway it might take a while to get to David Lee Roth, the founding frontman for the rock band Van Halen. But Papa Hemingway and Diamond Dave are united in virility at the New York Theater Workshop, where Mr. Roths arena-size yelps are among the atmospheric audio effects in The Select (The Sun Also Rises), a show based on Hemingways 1926 novel.

title: TimesCast | Potential New Human Ancestor
description: Paleontologists in South Africa may have discovered a new species of hominid, potentially redrawing the tree of human evolution.

title: When Computers Come Between Doctors and Patients
description: Despite being considered by some as a hospital of last resort, the sprawling city hospital where Ive spent 20 years is at the forefront of electronic trends. Although some hospitals are computerized, most do not have fully functional electronic medical records, as promoted by the health care reform law of 2010. And more than half of all outpatient practices still use paper charts, making health care the only major industry that is not fully computerized.

title: Just One Look | BCBG MaxAzria
description: New York Citys public schools resumed classes just hours before the 10 a.m. BCBG MaxAzria show, the first to take place under fashions big top at the Theater at Lincoln Center. Indeed, the distinctive back-to-school buzz was a good one to ride during the show, which starred piece-y silk chiffon dresses and colors called clover, saffron and jade. On Jacquelyn (above): a striking layered look with a pleated side panel and the collections defining diamond embroidery up top.

title: Figuring Out How Children Learn With Technology
description: Schools are stocking classrooms with computers. And outside of school, children are increasingly glued to screens, be they on phones, personal computers or TVs hooked to gaming consoles.

title: Imagining a Blur of Fracking Activity
description: As I reported in Thursdays Times, the complete environmental document detailing how horizontal hydraulic fracturing could affect the communities in upstate New York where most of this gas drilling would take place is out for public review. It may take days for state residents to sift through it.

title: Amazon and California in Deal on Tax
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The pitched battle between Amazon.com and the state of California over taxes is threatening to turn into a draw.

title: Backstage Beauty at BCBG
description: The hair and makeup at the BCBG Max Azria show today were pretty basic. Well, it looked basic  fresh-faced, barely there. But for someone who has been trying to achieve the minimal makeup look all summer, I will be the first to say its harder than it looks.

title: U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 8
description: Images from Day 11 of the United States Open in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Rating the Designers
description: Just when you thought stylists and editors were the only ones passing judgment during New York Fashion Week, Klout  the company that scores people on their so-called digital influence  has ranked the top 10 Fashion Week designers.

title: Isner Wins in Four Sets
description: While there was chaos and confusion on other parts of the grounds, No. 28 seed John Isner quietly blasted his way into his first career Grand Slam quarterfinal on Court 17, defeating No. 12 Gilles Simon 7-6(2), 3-6, 7-6(2), 7-6(4).

title: Jerry Swartz
description: Mr. Swartz, 72, is a partner in HKS Capital Partners, a boutique real estate capital advisory and financial brokerage firm that he helped start in April.

title: When Real Estate Agents Make Referrals
description: A REAL estate agent recommends two mortgage brokers whom she describes as experienced in closing loans. You go to the first one, and dont bother shopping around on rates or fees.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Compleat Sculpture
description: An artists supply shop in SoHo provides sculptors everything they need  instruction and supplies  except talent.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Sept. 9-15
description: 92ND STREET Y

title: Millennium Attracts $4 Billion in New Money
description: As Millennium Management, the New York hedge fund run by the industry titan Israel A. Englander, looks to grow and diversify, it has been on a fund-raising tear, with more than $4 billion in new commitments this year from sovereign wealth funds, pensions and other big investors, according to people with knowledge the fund.

title: A Front-Seat View of a Back-Seat Robbery
description: Here is a brief tale told in two surveillance photos. On Monday night, the police say, the man pictured above got into a livery cab at Waterbury and East Tremont Avenues in Schuylerville in the Bronx and directed the driver to go to Faile Street and Lafayette Avenue in Hunts Point, about four miles away.

title: Spare Times for Sept. 9-15
description: Spare Times

title: Rules of Engagement in the Elephant World
description: Caitlin OConnell-Rodwell, who teaches at the Stanford University School of Medicine, writes from Etosha National Park, Namibia, where she is studying elephant societies.

title: S.E.C. Clashes With Deloitte in China Over Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is involved in an increasingly heated battle with Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, the Shanghai-based accounting firm that discovered bookkeeping fraud at Longtop Financial Technologies of China, over access to the financial software companys records.

title: Reaction to Gingrichs Plan for Alaska
description: Among the Republican presidential candidates proposing economic and energy solutions in their debate on Wednesday night, Newt Gingrich cast one of his ideas as particularly bold.

title: Blame the iPad for Slow PC Sales
description: Shipments of personal computers are expected to grow only 3.8 percent this year, according Gartner, far slower than the 9.3 percent gain it previously forecast.

title: Theater Listings: Sept. 9  15
description: Theater

title: The Education Bonus and the Gender Gap
description: We at Economix have been fairly persistent in demonstrating why college is worth it. Say it together, now: you are overwhelmingly likely to earn more.

title: Europe Steers Into a Zone of Uncertainty
description: PARIS  With markets still volatile, and politicians only marginally closer to a solution of the euros troubles than they were two years ago, the future for the euro zone remains uncertain at best.

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 9-15
description: Movies

title: TimesCast | September 08, 2011
description: David Leonhardt previews President Obama's jobs speech; questions arise about Gov. Rick Perry's electability; and a potential new human ancestor is discovered in South Africa.

title: Theater Talkback: When a Bare Stage Fills The Theater
description: Theatergoers, especially the kind who regard Broadway as Mecca, expect their seats to come with a breathtaking view. I mean of scenic scenery that gives its own spectacular performance, regardless of whats happening in front of it. Not for nothing is the longest-running musical ever on Broadway, The Phantom of the Opera, a major eye-filler, replete with fat Belle poque designs, the occasional falling chandelier and a stage-crossing gondola.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Sept. 9-15
description: Pop

title: Smoke and Mirrors
description: We asked the Paris-based designer Rick Owens, a native Californian, to make the T for our fall mens issue because hes our favorite independent American abroad. And indeed, he went straight to his home state for inspiration, recalling rapturous moments at stadium concerts in Fresno and at basement discos in Bakersfield to create the fog-filled installation that was then captured in this photograph by Fernando Stangelo. We knew that Owens would give us something arresting, original and distinctly American. His reference to the band Kiss and tips on what a man can do to make his masculinity pop, below, are just brilliant bonuses.

title: Fresh Off Debate Debut, Perry Turns Down the Heat
description: CORONA DEL MAR, Calif.  Gov. Rick Perrys first debate was a hot and unapologetic barbfest with his fellow Republican candidates in which he did not back down from his remarks that Social Security was a Ponzi scheme. But Thursday, speaking to the Orange County G.O.P. here, Mr. Perry was more muted in his attacks, never mentioning the entitlement program and offering his own assessment of the debate.

title: Clip: Lost Tribes and Promised Lands
description: An excerpt from a silent video installation by Elisabeth Subrin. (Courtesy of Sue Scott Gallery and the artist)

title: A Database of Names to Trace Slave Ancestry
description: Scholars at the Virginia Historical Society in Richmond have set out to leaf through eight million documents dating back to the 17th century, seeking the names of slaves. The preliminary results, listing about 1,400 enslaved people and 180 owners, will start appearing on Wednesday in a database posted at vahistorical.org.

title: Elisabeth Subrin
description: An artist and filmmakers video installation Lost Tribes and Promised Lands deals with 9/11.

title: Twitter Reaches 100 Million Active Users
description: When Jack Dorsey, co-founder of Twitter, sent the very first tweet five years ago, he most likely didnt expect that the site would soon be home to tens of millions of people doing the exact same thing.On Thursday, Twitter said that it now has 100 million active users.

title: Clap Clap, Here Comes Beetle
description: Two years after a childrens game called punch buggy provided the basis for a popular Volkswagen commercial, VW is turning to another childrens game for a commercial to help introduce the 2012 Beetle.

title: The 9/11 Decade: Colum McCann
description: Colum McCann, the author of five novels and two collections of short stories, won the 2009 National Book Award for Let the Great World Spin.

title: Pictures of the Day: New Jersey and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New Jersey, Libya, Afghanistan and England.

title: Redskins Owner Dan Snyder on Being a Marked Man
description: You created a billion-dollar business, which made a mint in direct marketing, but since buying the Redskins in 1999, you have been losing a major P.R. war. There has been this constant drumbeat of negative stories about you.  You mean overkill? I think the media overblows most things. My father was a University of Missouri journalism grad, and when he was alive, hed say, At U.P.I., we werent allowed to do what theyre doing on the Internet, putting stuff out whether its true or not.

title: Where Stone Waits to Become Works of Art
description: THE snide No Rock Climbing sign in the basement of the Compleat Sculptor makes it clear that the 300 tons of marble, alabaster, granite and soapstone there are not meant for rappelling; they await a finer destiny wrought by human hands wielding sharp tools. The same goes for the slabs of 80-year-old ebony, their resemblance to old telephone poles purely coincidental. Someday they will be works of art in the eye of the beholder who buys and transforms them.

title: On Court 13, Roddick Prevails
description: As water continued to gurgle up onto the court of Louis Armstrong Stadium, 2003 U.S. Open champion Andy Roddick took control. He forcefully convinced both tournament referee Brian Earley and opponent David Ferrer to move their match to tiny Court 13, which seats fewer than 600 spectators. Follow me, he said to Ferrer as he charged out of Armstrong and toward their new venue.

title: Testimony Implicates a Mubarak Co-Defendant
description: CAIRO  Testimony on Thursday in the criminal case against former President Hosni Mubarak implicated top officials for the first time in ordering the use of force against demonstrators. The evidence added to a patchwork of contradictory accounts that have cast a shadow over the first days of the proceedings.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 9-15
description: Jazz

title: Kurt Cobains Sweet, Sweet Ax
description: Is it appalling, or is it perfectly logical that Fender Guitars is manufacturing a limited-edition Kurt Cobain Jaguar? The sunburst Jaguar is an exact replica of the original that Cobain used on Nevermind, from its nonstandard humbucker pickups to the glamorous scar on the back, where Kurts belt buckle wore away the finish. It retails for $1,849, and I think its axiomatic that if you can afford it, youre not the next Kurt Cobain.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Sept. 9-15
description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 9-15
description: Dance

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Sept. 9-15
description: Art

title: Casting Announced for Stick Fly, Blue Flower and Atmosphere of Memory
description: Faces familiar to New York theatergoers will take the stage this fall in three productions  two plays and one musical  that recently announced casting.

title: Bruce Conner: Falling Leaves: An Anonymous Memorial
description: Paula Cooper Gallery

title: Alexandra Bircken: Think of Me
description: Kimmerich

title: Self-Referential Nonobjective
description: Feature Inc.

title: More on Tar, Oil, Pipelines and Presidents
description: I sought reactions to my post on President Obama and the Alberta tar pit from a variety of analysts and campaigners examining the economics and environmental impacts of a proposed pipeline linking that Canadian source of oil with American refiners.

title: Lorna Williams: brown baby
description: Dodge Gallery

title: Empty Seats and Defeat for Yanks
description: BALTIMORE  The crowd at Camden Yards was sparse on Thursday afternoon. It was one of those days when a fans yell could reach the field, and it seemed as if beer vendors were speaking into microphones.

title: A Vanished Row of Unusual Grace in the West Village
description: THE back-and-forth preservation controversy over the odd, saw-toothed National Maritime Union building, on Seventh Avenue and 12th Street, appears to be at an end, with city approval in August of its restoration and renovation as a health care center. A white monolith, it is a peculiar presence in the toy-scale West Village, just as unusual as the strange little string of 1840s houses it succeeded, the charming Rhinelander Row.

title: Waxing Brazilian
description: Brazils most famous assets usually end up prancing down a Victorias Secret runway, but with the publication of Brazilian Style ($65 at assouline.com), the countrys more obscure offerings  pink dolphins, anyone?  join Carmen Miranda and the caipirinha in a colorful look at Brazils cultural legacy. Armand Limnander, the books author and a former T editor, says the tome grew out of a 10-year love affair with the country. Its a very personal take on the people, places and things that resonate with me, he says (like the idyllic island of Fernando de Noronha, shown here.) He adds, Brazil is already an economic superpower  its hosting both the Olympics and the World Cup in the next few years  so the next logical step is for it to begin exporting its culture, which is rich, varied and above all, fun.

title: Picking Your Slice of New York
description: The digital carrier pigeon flew into Mr. Critics window this week with questions about bringing Vermonters south for memorable eating, about the sense and sensibility of brunch and about a rising tide of chefs tasting menus. My answers follow. As always, you may send questions about dining out in New York restaurants to dinejournal@nytimes.com. And follow me on Twitter: @SamSifton.

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 8, 2011
description: Rebel fighters found a grave containing four dead men in Tripoli, and searched through a rest house belonging to the Qaddafi family in Sadaada.

title: Mens U.S. Open Final Headed for Monday, Again
description: The United States Tennis Association announced the revised schedule for the rest of the United States Open, which pushes the mens final to Monday for the fourth straight year.

title: TimesCast | Rick Perry's Electability
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas laid out several positions in the Republican debate that veered far from many of his competitors.

title: How Republicans Plan to Respond to Obama
description: President Obama has not started his speech yet, but House Republicans have talking points ready to go.

title: Working Stiffs
description: Political correctness has rarely been a consideration for the designers Daniel Silver and Steven Cox of Duckie Brown, who often take inspiration from elements of London subcultures that are not always savory. It is from them, years ago, that I first heard the term chav used to describe a group of binge-drinking, disaffected underclass teenagers who once embraced the brand Burberry to such a degree that they began to undermine the companys brand image.

title: Whos Sitting With the First Lady
description: A sushi chef, a third-grade teacher facing a layoff and an Iraq war veteran are among the two dozen guests who will be seated with Michelle Obama on Thursday night when President Obama lays out his jobs plan before a joint session of Congress.

title: Excerpts From 'Cymbeline'
description: Scenes from the Fiasco Theater's production of "Cymbeline." (Video courtesy of the Fiasco.)

title: Deficit Panel Member Already Talks of Quitting
description: Generally in this town, people serve on a committee at least a few days before threatening to quit. But underscoring the incredibly difficult task before the 12-member bipartisan Congressional committee charged with finding $1.5 trillion in deficit reductions, Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona, one of the six Republicans on the panel, told a conservative group on Thursday that he was already pondering his potential exit.

title: Kerber Defeats Pennetta
description: Unseeded Angelique Kerber of Germany defeated Flavia Pennetta of Italy, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, in a tense, hard-fought match that sent the German into the U.S. Open womens semifinal, where she will face another surprise victor, Samatha Stosur of Australia.

title: Showcasing Sound in a New Space
description: MONTREAL  When a major new orchestra hall is opened, welcoming speeches from public officials and board members are almost inevitable. So it was here on Wednesday night for the inaugural program of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra at its handsome new home: more than 30 minutes of speeches, including remarks from Jean Charest, the premier of Quebec, and a ceremonial ribbon cutting onstage, with four charming children holding the ribbon and the orchestras popular music director, Kent Nagano, conducting the official cutters.

title: A Nightmare Pox on Your Civilized World
description: Contagion, Steven Soderberghs smart, spooky thriller about a thicket of contemporary plagues  a killer virus, rampaging fear, an unscrupulous blogger  is as ruthlessly effective as the malady at its cool, cool center. Set in the world-is-flat now, the movie tracks a mystery pathogen after it catches a ride on a flight from Hong Kong to Chicago, an early hop for a globe-sprinting pandemic that cuts across borders and through bodies as effortlessly as Mr. Soderbergh moves among genres, styles and eras, this time by updating 1970s paranoia freakouts like All the Presidents Men for the anti-government, Tea Party age.

title: Once a Fast Track, Now a Real Hike to the Top
description: Beacon, N.Y.

title: Simplest Roast Chicken
description: Mark Bittman reveals the secret to roasting the perfect whole chicken.

title: The Minimalist: Simplest Roast Chicken
description: I did five recipes for whole roast chicken over the 13-year history of the Minimalist column, and, modesty aside (what does that mean, actually? Get ready for me to be immodest?), theres no need for me to apologize for the redundancy.

title: Revving Up
description: Coveralls, quilting, army surplus and collegiate classics as spotted at the fall mens shows make their way onto the men who wear them best. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Feasting on Paperwork
description: The amount billed by Debevoise & Plimpton to write a 17-page letter on a new rule intended to rein in risky banking  around $100,000  would make most authors jealous.

title: As Concert Halls Open, Programs Follow a Blueprint
description: Concert halls continue to open around North America, and each one is a big deal for classical music lovers and performers, even if orchestras are increasingly falling into serious financial trouble. The inaugural concert program has become a ritual, almost as codified as haiku.

title: Q&A: Taking the Upgrade Leap From Windows XP to Windows 7
description: Q.

title: Pretty Girls, Seemingly Pursued by an Evil Eye
description: I have a mistake to admit. Four years ago I reviewed Lucette Lagnados book The Man in the White Sharkskin Suit and called it, as her publisher did, a memoir. But after reading what is being billed as its sequel, Ive come to realize that her earlier book was, in fact, a biography.

title: A Beloved Film Gains a Live Sound
description: Orchestras have discovered in the last few years that film nights  concerts that present live accompaniments to movies  are huge audience draws. Often they involve excerpts, usually without dialogue, and sometimes edited for the occasion, though silent films with newly composed scores have been popular too, as have quirky productions like the Godfrey Reggio dialogue-free Qatsi trilogy, with its through-composed scores by Philip Glass.

title: Fighting Backlog in Patents, Senate Approves Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate approved a sweeping reform of the nations patent laws on Thursday, sending to President Obama a bill that changes the system for determining priority for inventions at the patent office and provides more financing for an agency beset by application backlogs and outdated computer systems.

title: From a Gaffe, Some Good for Little Sisters of the Poor
description: OREGON, Ohio  For at least a half-century, Little Sisters of the Poor has been used as a euphemism in college sports to describe a weak opponent. Its roots trace back to an emphatic victory by Senator Robert Taft of Ohio in his 1950 re-election, which the mayor of Cleveland compared to the Notre Dame football team beating the Little Sisters of the Poor.

title: At Clinic for Young Players, Graf Emphasizes the Fun
description: At the Harlem Tennis Center, the Hall of Fame tennis player Steffi Graf was trading shots Thursday morning with a scrawny boy using a scaled-down racket. They were playing on the backcourt of a regulation-size court, with a net stretched from the service line to the baseline, and using oversize foam balls.

title: Part of a Whole, but Still Me
description: I BECAME a feminist the day my sixth-grade math teacher dismembered and spit on a white rose, telling us, This is you after you have sex. Other girls had other interests; horseback riding and ballet were two trendy ones in the Mississippi neighborhood where I attended elementary school. I did try ballet, and stuck with it for a while, but I barely had room in my duffel bag for pointe shoes and feminist texts.

title: A Tumultuous Time, Captured by Outsiders
description: The Black Power Mixtape 1967-1975, among other things an extraordinary feat of editing and archival research, takes up a familiar period in American history from a fresh and fascinating angle. In the late 1960s and early 70s, Swedish television journalists traveled to the United States with the intention of showing the country as it really is. Some of the images and interviews they collected have been assembled by Goran Hugo Olsson into a roughly chronological collage that restores a complex human dimension to the racial history of the era.

title: Tracking the Global Food Situation
description: The latest numbers suggest that the situation with the global food supply continues to be deeply worrisome.

title: A Masters Thin Skin, Etched for Posterity
description: The artist Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres was famous for reacting, and overreacting, to criticism. As a young student in Rome, he broke off an engagement to his longtime love in Paris because he couldnt stomach a return to the salons there, the scene of my disgrace, he said. And later, in midcareer, the bad press from another salon outing prompted a second extended stay in Rome.

title: John Jays New Building
description: The enormous new building of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice was opened for the first time on Sept. 8 for a 9/11 memorial service.

title: The Arrogant Years
description: The Avenger of Sixty-Sixth Street

title: At Obama Jobs Speech, Small Business Is in Audience
description: Whenever a president addresses Congress, the White House invites a panel of Americans, distinguished and not, to watch the speech with the first lady from prime seats in the gallery above. The guests tend to be demographically diverse, but they also tend to be united in representing priorities the president intends to emphasize in the speech.

title: G.I. Killed Afghan Journalist, NATO Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO acknowledged Thursday that an American soldier killed an Afghan journalist working for the BBC after mistaking him for a suicide bomber during a complex attack in southern Afghanistan in July.

title: F.D.A. Panel Endorses New Blood Thinner Drug
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel voted 9 to 2 on Thursday to endorse a new anticoagulant drug, Xarelto, to help prevent strokes in people with atrial fibrillation.

title: Poll: Now vs. 5 Years Ago
description: New York Times/CBS News polls describe a city and a nation that have not fully recovered.

title: Feeling Safer but Wary
description: GRAPHIC: New York and America: Now vs. 5 Years Ago

title: How the Three Surveys Were Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News polling project consists of three telephone surveys: of the United States, of New York City, and of friends and relatives of 9/11 victims.

title: After Conquest, Subtle Emblems of Protest
description: Its hard to see, when you walk into the Chinese painting galleries at the Met these days, that youre entering a scene of catastrophe, with lives about to be lost right before your eyes. All seems calm in the show called The Art of Dissent in 17th-Century China: Masterpieces of Ming Loyalist Art from the Chih Lo Lou Collection. There are no smoking ruins among the bamboo groves in a 17th-century handscroll painting, no anguished cries emerging from columns of calligraphic script.

title: City Campaign Finance Board Seeks Greater Disclosure From Donors
description: In a move that could affect the 2013 municipal elections, the New York City Campaign Finance Board on Thursday released proposed rules requiring more disclosure of campaign spending by independent groups like unions.

title: Where Every Second Counts
description: COLUMBIA, Pa.  What exists everywhere in the universe but occupies no space? a wall panel asks. What can be measured  but not seen, heard, smelled, tasted, nor held in our hands? What can be spent, saved, frittered away or killed  but never destroyed?

title: Day 1: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 8.

title: Social Media Gears Up for Obama Address
description: While the Republican Party will not deliver a formal response to President Obamas job speech on Thursday, some members of Congress and Republican presidential candidates will be turning to Twitter to get their message across.

title: Democrats Seek to Impose Tougher Supreme Court Ethics
description: House Democrats, seeking to capitalize on recent questions about the political leanings of several Supreme Court justices, are pushing for toughened ethics standards that would hold the justices on the high court to the same judicial requirements as federal judges.

title: Scenes From the Republican Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Joy of (Print) Books, Passed On, With Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Is There a Place for Islamic Law in the Melting Pot?
description: To the Editor:

title: Weekend Miser
description: They say you dont get many second chances in this life, but not so, according to the  FringeNYC Encore Series. Beginning on Friday, you can catch some of the most popular shows that were performed at this summers New York International Fringe Festival. These include the Telly Savalas-inspired lounge act, Who Loves You Baby?, starring Tom DiMenna as a ranting Savalas who is disappointed by this decades leading men; facebook me, the Arts Effect Theater Companys look at what status really means to the six million adolescent girls trolling Facebook these days; and Jersey Shoresical, a musical based on the reality television show Jersey Shore and a FringeNYC Excellence Award winner for best ensemble. Those and other productions will play in repertory at the SoHo Playhouse and the Players Theater through Sept. 26. ($18; 866-468-7619, FringeNYC-EncoreSeries.com.)

title: Georgias Voter Law: The Election Chiefs Rebuttal
description: To the Editor:

title: Clybourne Park Eyes Broadway
description: Clybourne Park, Bruce Norriss Pulitzer Prize-winning play about race relations and neighborhood gentrification, is looking for its own real estate on Broadway.

title: Three Times the Effort, but Not the Cost
description: SEVEN years ago Lucy Danziger, the editor in chief of Self magazine, was looking for a way to get excited about exercise again. She had been running almost daily for years, but a marathon had left her with painful shin splints, and she was tiring of her routine.

title: Wozniacki Defeats Petkovic
description: W.T.A. No. 1 Caroline Wozniacki made her third consecutive U.S. Open semifinal with an impressive 6-1, 7-6(5) win over No. 10 Andrea Petkovic.

title: Popular Ascendance to Grim Downfall
description: Its impossible that The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu is the monument that the former Romanian dictator would have produced in his own honor. Among other things, it has an unhappy ending, at least for him and his wife, Elena, who were executed on Christmas Day, 1989. Yet in many respects Ceausescu turns out to be as much the author of this brilliant documentary as the director, Andrei Ujica, who waded through more than 1,000 hours of filmed state propaganda, official news reports and home movies to create a cinematic tour de force that tracks the rise, reign and grim fall of its subject.

title: Transcript: Obamas Speech to Congress on Jobs
description: The following is a transcript of President Obamas speech to a joint session of Congress about jobs and the economy, as provided by the White House.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Counsels Students to Be Moderate With Digital Media
description: Julius Genachowski, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, welcomed students back to school on Thursday by asking them to walk a line: use technology to learn, but dont get distracted by it.

title: Pants on Fire
description: Fifteen years ago, Primary Colors meant politics, in the form of the novel written anonymously by Joe Klein.

title: Bloggingheads: Monogamy and Morals
description: Dan Savage, left, of Savage Love and Ross Douthat, Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, debate the morality of non-monogamous marriages.

title: U.S. Ambassador to Syria Responds to Critics on Facebook
description: Two days after he attacked the Syrian governments violent response to peaceful protests in a blunt note posted on Facebook, Robert Ford, the American ambassador in Damascus, returned to the social network on Thursday to spar with some of his critics.

title: Fear and Loathing at Parker Prep
description: Beware the Gonzo is Revenge of the Nerds redux, but instead of a college, its setting is Parker Prep, a private New York City high school celebrating its 150th anniversary. Leading the student uprising against a vile clique of alpha teenagers and their smug enabler, Principal Roy (James Urbaniak), is Eddie Gilman (Ezra Miller), a self-righteous hotshot reporter for the school newspaper who is waiting to hear if he has been accepted to Columbia.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 1s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Palestinian Leader Says U.S. Is Too Late on U.N. Bid
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Thursday that last-ditch American and international efforts to prevent the Palestinians from applying for membership in the United Nations this month were too late.

title: Senator Introduces Online Security Bill
description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, introduced a new bill Thursday that aims to protect citizens personal information from online data breaches. The bill would also punish companies that are careless with customers information.

title: Merrill Lynch Cuts Several Hundred Jobs
description: Following a pattern that is expected to be repeated across Wall Street in the coming months, Bank of America Merrill Lynch began handing out pink slips to several hundred employees on Thursday. The job cuts are expected to fall across the entire organization, including sales and trading operations as well as investment banking.

title: Bloombergs Beer Summit Idea Antagonizes Many in Council
description: Perhaps it seemed like a conciliatory idea at the time.

title: With Rainouts, Fans Have to Scramble
description: The decision by the U.S.T.A. to rework the schedule and finish the U.S. Open on Monday has created all sorts of headaches for fans.

title: Obamas Speech to Congress
description: The president spoke to a joint session of Congress.

title: When Quoting Verse, One Must Be Terse
description: COPYRIGHT law is so often a matter of guesswork and loopholes, small print and obscure provisions. One such provision, dating from the 70s, has recently come to the music industrys attention. Termination rights allow musicians to reclaim the copyrights on their songs after 35 years  meaning songs from albums like Funkadelics One Nation Under a Groove may soon be back in the hands of George Clinton and his funkified compatriots. Late last month, Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the senior Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, called on Congress to clarify the statute in question in order to protect artists rights.

title: Does America Have a Future?
description: Failure after failure after failure. Bubbles that end in busts. Wars that arent won. Stimuli that dont stimulate. All together plunging the United States into the worst economic slump since the 1930s. Meanwhile, across the Pacific, America faces a geopolitical rival that is also an effective economic competitor  a combination not seen since the kaisers Germany.

title: When He Was Good, He Was Very, Very Good
description: One evening in the summer of 1972, John Chancellor of NBC began his newscast with a rundown of the days reports. War, economic turmoil, the growing Watergate scandal  all of that would be dealt with in due course. But first, Chancellor said, Bobby Fischer.

title: Manning Sidelined by Another Operation
description: Peyton Manning had his second neck operation since late May on Thursday, casting his availability for the season in considerable doubt.

title: Where Stone Waits to Become Works of Art
description: The snide No Rock Climbing sign in the basement of the Compleat Sculptor makes it clear that the 300 tons of marble, alabaster, granite and soapstone there are not meant for rappelling; they await a finer destiny wrought by human hands wielding sharp tools.

title: In a Citys Plague Years, Caring for Their Own
description: There was nothing extraordinary about the fact that you lose the people you love because its going to happen to all of us, observes Ed Wolf, a gentle, gay San Franciscan in his mid-50s who devoted years to counseling dying AIDS patients during the peak of the epidemic. Its just that it happened in this targeted community of people who were disenfranchised and separated from their families. And a whole group of other people stepped up and became their family.

title: A Christies Loss Is the Kimbells Gain
description: By all accounts, Nicolas Poussins Sacrament of Ordination (Christ Presenting the Keys to Saint Peter) should have been a winner. Executed between 1636 and 1642, the painting is part of the artists groundbreaking series depicting the seven sacraments. It is in perfect condition and has a pristine provenance. So why was there not a single bidder interested in the painting at a Christies auction in London last December?

title: Getting a Little Lost in a Secluded Spot on the Coastline
description: The day was turning golden at El Matador State Beach here on the Pacific as the end of the afternoon approached. Matador is a secluded stretch of rock formations, beach and tide pools, with views miles down the coast. Its not easy to reach: take the steep and rutted path off a dirt parking lot along the Pacific Coast Highway that leads to 80 precarious steps finally spilling out onto soft sand.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Plan to Aid Cuba in Case of an Oil Spill
description: HAVANA  The United States should urgently make plans for helping Cuba in the event of an offshore oil spill as it prepares to begin exploring fields opposite Florida this year, William Reilly, the co-chairman of a commission that examined the Deepwater Horizon spill, said during a visit here.

title: The Lingering Injustice of Attica
description: Philadelphia

title: For Mets, Few Fans and a Pair of Losses
description: The Atlanta Braves one-day, two-game visit to Citi Field on Thursday had a distinct coulda-woulda-shoulda aspect to it. Maybe, just maybe, these games could have had legitimate implications for the National League wild-card race.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,466 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,744 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Russian President Warns Against Xenophobia
description: YAROSLAVL, Russia  In one of the last major addresses of his presidential term, President Dmitri A. Medvedev on warned Thursday against allowing xenophobia into Russias political mainstream.

title: Open Skies, Bouncing Balls, Tough Critiques
description: Dont let the obstacles beat you. Its always been that way at the United States Open, from the stench of burning meat wafting across the court to the rumble of garbage bins to the rattle of the railroad train, to say nothing of the weather.

title: U.S. Is Investigating Wages Among Residential Builders
description: The federal governments top wage enforcement official said on Thursday that the Labor Department had begun a far-reaching investigation into possible minimum wage and overtime violations in the residential construction industry.

title: The Now-or-Never Apartment
description: AT last, Lee Zegar was ready to upgrade to a one-bedroom.

title: A Persistent Puddle, a Determined Roddick
description: It was the perfect metaphor for the sodden 2011 United States Open.

title: Romney and Perry Assume Contrasting Republican Brands
description: The full-throated sparring between Mitt Romney and Rick Perry during the Republican debate on Wednesday night provided an early glimpse of the very different strategies that will propel their presidential campaigns forward in the next several months.

title: Q & A
description: A Regulated Tenant Cant Find the Lease

title: Investigators Assess Threat of Bombing Tied to 9/11
description: WASHINGTON  Counterterrorism officials on Thursday were assessing a report about the threat of an attack in New York City or Washington using a car or truck bomb and timed to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, according to several officials briefed on the matter.

title: Stall in Realignment Process Gives Big 12 Hope
description: Conference realignment, which once appeared to be an inevitability, has reached a holding pattern. The threat of legal action by Baylor and other Big 12 universities has stymied Texas A&Ms move to the Southeastern Conference, reviving the chance that the Big 12 can save itself.

title: New-Form Press Release, in Blog, Tweet and Haiku
description: Press releases were created to break news, not make it.

title: How Flooding Hurts Home Values
description: AFTER the shrewd and wary real estate blogger known as Grim (real name: James A. Bednar of njrereport.com) bought his first house in Wayne last spring, he quickly announced where he would start with renovations: the damp basement.

title: The Even Longer Road to Sold
description: ERIC FRIEDLANDER of Oyster Bay, the owner of the Windemere Development Corporation, used to build subdivisions and single-family homes from Southampton to Smithtown and Bellmore, sometimes on speculation.

title: College Football Live Blog: Join the Conversation
description: Paul Myerberg of The Times will be hosting his own college football watch party all day Saturday, right here at The Quad. He will bring you highlights and analysis from games around the country and spend some time answering your questions.

title: N.B.A. Talks Show Hints of Progress
description: When N.B.A. labor talks resumed Wednesday, for an extended session in Midtown Manhattan, officials from the players union opened with a broad premise: Tell us what it will take to end the lockout and save the 2011-12 season.

title: Renting Is All the Rage
description: BROKERS these days, wrestling with dwindling sales, would have their clients believe that there is no better time than the present to buy a home. Prices are down, they say, and mortgage rates are at all-time lows.

title: In Italy, the Old Lady Opens a New Stadium
description: 12:37 p.m. |Update

title: Iraq: Radio Host Is Killed Before Protest
description: A radio talk show host who had been a prominent government critic was killed by gunmen in his home on Thursday, a security official said. The host, Hadi al-Mahdi, had organized protests, including one planned for Friday, to call for more government accountability and better services. In a posting on Facebook just three hours before he was killed, he said that he had received threatening messages from people trying to deter him from holding the protest. He said the demonstration would go on. I firmly believe the political process is a trash can of economic and political failure and we deserve to have it changed and we deserve a better government, he wrote.

title: Quinn Hires Pollster Tied to President for 2013 Race
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, has added a big political name to her campaign team as she prepares for an expected mayoral bid in 2013: Joel Benenson, the pollster for President Obama and, until recently, for Anthony D. Weiner.

title: Omitting Clergy at 9/11 Ceremony Prompts Protest
description: The second Sunday after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, New York clergy members of many faiths joined elected officials at Yankee Stadium in a city-sponsored memorial ceremony that melded the sacred and the secular, replete with flags, prayers and tears.

title: Deciding Whats Next After Deadly Crash
description: Russian hockey officials said Thursday that they were struggling to deal with a contingency they had yet to develop a plan for, if a plan could ever really be developed to replace an entire team wiped out in a tragedy.

title: Barbour Joins Rove-Affiliated Super PAC
description: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi is joining American Crossroads, the influential Republican Super PAC, to help the group raise money during the 2012 election, the group announced on Thursday.

title: A Story as Old as Gentrification
description: This film has been designated as a Critics' Pick.

title: Lawmaker Offers Plan to Lure Migrant Farm Workers
description: A leading Republican lawmaker has proposed creating a program to bring 500,000 foreign migrant farm workers to the United States each year, responding to an outcry this summer from American farmers who said shortages of legally authorized labor were imperiling their crops.

title: Beyond Baby Mozart, Students Who Rock
description: With school underway, I asked my eight-year-old son this week if he had any interest in learning guitar. He said hed prefer the piano. I was pleased, but hesitant. I had my own stint with after-school piano lessons at age eight  plinking out notes from classical pieces that were foreign to me. My progress was agonizingly slow and I gave up within months.

title: Union Dispute, Turning Violent, Spreads and Idles Ports
description: The busy ports of Seattle and Tacoma, Wash., were shut down on Thursday as an increasingly violent dispute between unionized port workers and the owner of a grain export terminal in Longview, Wash., spilled over to the other facilities.

title: The Jobs Speech
description: With more than 14 million people out of work and all Americans fearing a double-dip recession, President Obama stood face to face Thursday night with a Congress that has perversely resisted lifting a finger to help. Some Republicans refused to even sit and listen. But those Americans who did heard him unveil an ambitious proposal  more robust and far-reaching than expected  that may be the first crucial step in reigniting the economy.

title: For Obama, a Moment Speech at a Time of Great Obstacles to Change
description: Enshrined in the mythology of the American presidency, there is something called a moment speech, an address to the nation so forceful and eloquent that it changes the way the country feels about its leadership and even itself.

title: Theres Something Odd About This Hospital
description: This is not a movie, a bogus producer insists at the beginning of the mockumentary Grave Encounters, the latest found-footage scam and the directing debut of Colin Minihan and Stuart Ortiz, otherwise known as the Vicious Brothers. By the time this derivative clunker sputters to a close, many in the audience may find themselves agreeing with him.

title: Chinas Flawed Inflation Figures
description: When China reports this week that the consumer price index rose at an annualized rate of about 6 percent in August, economists may say inflation has peaked. They said the same last year, when the C.P.I. was running half as fast. The problem isnt bad forecasting: Chinas headline inflation measure is flawed.

title: Setting Their Hair on Fire
description: First things first: I was favorably surprised by the new Obama jobs plan, which is significantly bolder and better than I expected. Its not nearly as bold as the plan Id want in an ideal world. But if it actually became law, it would probably make a significant dent in unemployment.

title: Obama Presents Jobs Plan
description: President Obama challenged lawmakers in a blunt address Thursday evening to enact a sweeping package of tax cuts and new spending designed to revive the stagnant job market.

title: Somali Terrorism Suspect Appears in Civilian Court
description: A Somali accused of supporting Al Qaeda made his first public court appearance in New York on Thursday, a prelude to a highly anticipated international terrorism trial in civilian court.

title: On the First Day of School, a Million Students Finding Their Seats
description: The rain cleared, and the sidewalks of New York filled with all the familiar sights and sounds: the Cinderella backpacks, the complaints about school uniforms, the comparing of schedules, the shrieks and giggles. As 1.1 million students and 77,000 teachers returned to school Thursday, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott made the traditional five-borough tour, saying his goal is to set a high bar for our parents, our teachers, to aspire to.

title: Clouds Part, Revealing Close Quarters and Short Fuses
description: On Thursday, the sun returned to Flushing Meadows, and the beleaguered United States Open resumed play. The chaos, though, continued, even worsened, as this tournament, marred by delays and marked by player discontent, plowed forward through the muck, eventually shifting the schedule into a third week. Again.

title: Judge Widens Antitrust Suit Against Private Equity Firms
description: A federal judge has greatly expanded the scope of an antitrust lawsuit against the worlds largest private equity firms, broadening the case to include some of the largest leveraged buyouts in history.

title: No Plot, No Story, No Kicks: Want to Back My Movie?
description: The career of the actor Dax Shepard hasnt skyrocketed, but neither has it sputtered: a regular on the NBC sitcom Parenthood, he supported Jessica Simpson and Dane Cook in Employee of the Month and probably enjoyed his finest hour as Amy Poehlers clueless boyfriend in Baby Mama. Brothers Justice, his flailing, ultralow-budget directorial debut, will not accelerate his professional trajectory.

title: General Frmonts She-Merrimac
Lottery Numbers
From Prison to Pickles
