description: If Paul Levesque, the professional wrestler better known as Triple H, hopes to follow the career path of, say, Dwayne Johnson, who is now a credible action-adventure leading man, hes going to need movies a lot better than Inside Out to do it.

title: Despite Talk of Taming Partisanship, a Show of It for Presidents Remarks
description: WASHINGTON  It was, for a moment, Bizzaro World, with Republicans giving the president of the United States a standing ovation, while Democrats, in large part, remained firmly fixed in their seats as he expressed his desire for new trade agreements.

title: A Diamond Maker Joins Hearst to Show Power of Print and Dazzle
description: IN the current economy, some can afford to buy diamonds and some might need a little help to do so. A new advertising campaign by Hearts On Fire, the Boston-based diamond company, hopes to have something for all types of buyers.

title: For Abkhazia, Recognition Is Coming Piece by Piece
description: SUKHUMI, Georgia  After nearly two decades of searching mostly in vain for international acceptance, Abkhazia, a tiny rebel region in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, has found an unusual ally.

title: Rich Girls Have All Kind of Drama
description: Tanner Hall, an uneven drama set at a girls boarding school, rarely rises above the generic, though its atmosphere of coddled young people indulging themselves in opulent surroundings is palpably authentic. Fernanda (Rooney Mara), an otherwise sensible senior, pursues the older Gio (Tom Everett Scott), a family friend who has impregnated his sometime girlfriend (Tara Subkoff); the British Victoria (Georgia King), a neglected daughter, seeks to thwart Fernandas fortunes; the tomboyish Lucasta (Amy Ferguson) is ambivalent toward a boys overtures; and Kate (Brie Larson) flirts with a teacher (Chris Kattan), disregarding potential consequences.

title: President Obama Addresses Congress
description: The President challenged lawmakers in a blunt address Thursday evening to enact a sweeping package of tax cuts and new spending designed to revive the stagnant job market. (Video: NBC)

title: Stimulus for Skeptics
description: A few years ago, Kenneth Rogoff and Carmen M. Reinhart wrote the definitive guide to the current economic downturn, a book called This Time Is Different. Rogoff and Reinhart studied data from eight centuries of financial crises. They found that banking-crisis recessions are worse than normal recessions. They last longer.

title: In Shift, Irans President Calls for End to Syrian Crackdown
description: For years, posters celebrating the decades-old alliance joining Syria and Iran festooned the streets and automobiles of the Syrian capital  the images of Presidents Bashar al-Assad and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad embroidered with roses and daffodils.

title: Welcome, Madamji
description: Shes back. At least, we think she is.

title: In Last Push, Rivals in House Race Try to Provoke a Blunder
description: With just days remaining before the special election on Tuesday to replace former Representative Anthony D. Weiner, the two major-party nominees on Thursday sought to trip each other up at their only widely televised debate, while national Democratic groups bought expensive television time in a last-ditch effort to buoy their candidate.

title: Settlement Said to Be Near for Fannie and Freddie
description: Regulators are nearing a settlement with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac over whether the mortgage finance giants adequately disclosed their exposure to risky subprime loans, bringing to a close a three-year investigation.

title: Friday: Be Unable to Get the Rest
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Joe Krozel seems to be on a quest to set crossword-constructing records and he nearly makes it today. With a wide open grid and eleven 15-letter entries, Mr. Krozel misses the record set by David Levinson Wilk in 2009 with his twelve 15s (Across Lite, Solution, blog) by a square. See what I did there? Mr. Krozels grid also has one more black square than Mr. Wilks does. Dont try this at home.

title: A Bipartisan Move to Tackle Benefits Programs
description: WASHINGTON  In a significant shift driven by bipartisan concern about the looming long-term debt, Republicans and Democrats are no longer fighting over whether to tackle the popular entitlement programs  Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security  but over how to do it.

title: Lost in the Fog
description: As they debated at the Reagan library Wednesday night, the Republican presidential candidates seemed lost in a separate, frivolous galaxy from the sobering economic reality that President Obama was trying to confront. A public desperate for ideas about economic revival heard an astonishing argument about whether Social Security is a hoax, along with a fight about which states were more effective in luring low-wage jobs from other states.

title: A Scion of Queens Democrats Vies for a House Seat
description: David I. Weprin still remembers the moment he realized his family was just a little different from other families in Queens.

title: Finding Romance in All Kinds of Places
description: Just when Americas trade balance needs all the help it can get from Hollywoods global entertainment dominance comes the latest challenge to its supremacy: a China that can make chick flicks.

title: Shifting the Schedule, Paying a Price
description: When Rafael Nadal muttered on Wednesday that its always about money, he mostly had it right.

title: Damage From Brain Stents
description: Americans eager to try the newest cures and willing to trust their doctors judgment might have second thoughts about seeking experimental treatments given the disturbing results of a clinical trial of a new brain procedure. The trial involved inserting wire mesh stents into the brain arteries of patients at high risk of a second stroke. The stents were supposed to keep the arteries open, but the patients suffered strokes and died at such an alarming rate that the trial had to be stopped.

title: Search for the Searchers
description: This summer, a team of Canadian archaeologists went searching for the remains of the Arctic expedition led by Sir John Franklin, which vanished somewhere northwest of Baffin Island in 1845. People have been looking for Franklin, on and off, ever since. This time the scientists were scouring the sea bottom for Franklins ships, the Erebus and the Terror. Last year, the same team discovered the sunken remains of a ship that was searching for Franklin in 1854.

title: Michael Hart, a Pioneer of E-Books, Dies at 64
description: Michael Hart, who was widely credited with creating the first e-book when he typed the Declaration of Independence into a computer on July 4, 1971, and in so doing laid the foundations for Project Gutenberg, the oldest and largest digital library, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 64.

title: Killer of Denise Gay, an Innocent Bystander, Is Still a Mystery
description: It was barely four hours after the gunfire stopped on Park Place in Brooklyn when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared at a hospital to announce what officials believed had happened: one of two criminals involved in a gun battle killed an innocent woman as she sat on her stoop; one of those men exchanged shots with the police; one of the gunmen died at the scene, and the other died shortly afterward.

title: Tom Brokaw: Unknowable Future
description: A decade after 9/11, Tom Brokaw reflects on his Op-Ed from Sept. 28, 2001, and the need for the whole country to share some of the sacrifices made by military families.

title: Kevin Hart Is On the Road
description: Some of Kevin Harts fans may be disappointed that Laugh at My Pain, a film version of his recent stand-up tour, offers less than an hour of Mr. Hart onstage. But a couple of adornments  one before the concert footage, one after  flesh out this funny, profanity-heavy movie nicely.

title: Court Rejects Restitution for Victim in Porn Case
description: A victim of child pornography seeking restitution should not receive court-ordered payments from those who possessed the images but had no hand in creating them, a federal appeals panel ruled Thursday. The young woman, referred to in court papers as Amy, was known as Misty in pornographic images created by her uncle. The uncle was convicted and imprisoned on child pornography charges, but the images continue to be widely circulated and downloaded.

title: Before a First Start, a Football for a Friend in Iraq
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jake Ballard cornered Justin Tuck outside a meeting room at the Giants training center here earlier this week. Ballard had a football with one panel whited out, the kind designed for autographs, and he asked if Tuck wouldnt mind giving a signature. Tuck took the ball and uncapped his pen, but hesitated when he saw that the only other signature on the ball was Eli Mannings.

title: Easy Money From Body Parts
description: When an American director uses a bunch of well-known English actors to tell a Scottish tale centered on two Irish immigrants, you might expect some inconsistencies of tone and accent, and you get them in Burke & Hare, so nitpickers beware. But those who care less about such stuff than about being entertained will find plenty to like in this ghoulish comedy, a droll take on one of the most notorious mass-murder cases of the 19th century.

title: Illinois: Students Lose E-Mails to Prosecutors
description: Hundreds of e-mails between Northwestern University students and a former journalism professor must be turned over to prosecutors in a closely watched case, a Chicago judge ruled Wednesday. The students, working with the colleges Medill Innocence Project, were investigating the case of Anthony McKinney, a man convicted of the 1978 murder of a security guard. The states attorney subpoenaed the students notes, e-mails and other materials in 2009, but the university argued that many of the materials were protected by the state reporters privilege law. Judge Diane Cannon ruled that the students actually acted as investigators for Mr. McKinneys lawyers and not as journalists. The professor, David Protess, who has left Northwestern, said he was disappointed with the decision.

title: Vegetable Gardens Are Booming in a Fallow Economy
description: WEST LIBERTY, Ky.  As the economy continues to stagnate in towns and cities across the country, here in eastern Kentucky it is causing things to sprout.

title: 1.4 Million Lose Electricity in Area Around San Diego
description: LOS ANGELES  A power failure swept through Southern California on Thursday afternoon, leaving more than a million people without electricity in an area that extended from the coast east to Arizona and south into Mexico.

title: Green Shoots in Eastern Kentucky
description: As the economy continues to stagnate in towns and cities across the country, in eastern Kentucky garden plots are dug into the green hills.

title: Fashion Week: @whatdidIjustsee
description: Maybe a year ago  or was it longer?  Prabal Gurung answered Demi Moores Twitter post with his own. Until then, Mr. Gurung, an up-and-coming designer who started his company two years ago, had been on the Twitter fence. He really didnt know what it was and, as he said, it seemed too much about yourself. But after replying to Ms. Moore, he quickly got 500 followers. Today he has 32,604 followers, and as he calculated the payoff from the social media network, says, Its a business. It has helped him build his brand.

title: A Tax Deal in California Is Bipartisan
description: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Jerry Brown of California announced a rare bipartisan agreement with legislative leaders Thursday, eliminating a tax loophole for out-of-state businesses that opponents said encouraged moving jobs out of the state. The deal will allow the state to lower personal income taxes and provide more incentives to small companies based in the state.

title: Lifes Intersections, Random Twists of Fate
description: The High Cost of Living, a somber morality tale set in Quebec, bears all the hallmarks of an uncompromising indie drama: a downbeat scenario, flawed protagonists, a strongly regional inflection. This debut feature by the Canadian director Deborah Chow is so artistically well-intentioned and earnest in its ambitions that you can almost forgive the banality of its every scene.

title: S.E.C. Asks Court to Force a Release of Papers From China
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked a federal court on Thursday to force a Chinese affiliate of Deloitte, the accounting giant, to produce documents related to an investigation into one of its former auditing clients, Longtop Financial Technologies.

title: Buddha Stars in a Kung-Fu Flick
description: Sadistic warlords square off against noble monks in Shaolin, Benny Chans satisfying kung-fu action-and-redemption film starring Andy Lau. If the movie feels old-school (with new-school production values), consider its pedigree. Its no wonder: Shaolin is a reimagining of the 1982 Shaolin Temple, in which Jet Li made his debut.

title: Taking Up Swords and Arias in Prenationalist China
description: The North-South power divide of prenationalist China provides the hazy historical backdrop for My Kingdom, an intermittently kinetic epic about rival opera warrior clans. Though its reverence for Peking Opera gives the film a thinly heritage sheen, its generic mix of backstage musical and swordplay spectacular is vintage discount bin.

title: For High School Team, a Loss That Goes Beyond Any Game
description: LINWOOD, N.J.  The pursuit of normalcy was momentarily derailed by a simple, understandable mistake.

title: The Bachmann Response
description: Apparently Representative Michele Bachmann did not get the memo from House Republican leaders advising them to seek some common ground in responding to President Obamas proposed $447 billion package of new spending and tax cuts.

title: Grist for Left and Right in Perry Immigration Record
description: Ann Coulter, the conservative pundit, has called Gov. Rick Perry a little bit too much like George Bush on immigration and she does not mean it as a compliment. Tea Party loyalists have decried Mr. Perrys opposition to a border fence and Arizona-style enforcement laws. And Mitt Romney has taken not-so-veiled jabs at Mr. Perry, criticizing officials who provide incentives that promote illegal immigration.

title: For Mara and Jos, All Work and No Play
description: No one eats free, but children eat least of all in The Inheritors, Eugenio Polgovskys unvarnished portrait of the rural poor in modern-day Mexico.

title: Stoudemire and Designer Team Up on Fashion Line
description: The second floor of Macys in New Yorks Herald Square was packed Thursday evening. Fashions Night Out merged with basketball as the designer Rachel Roy teamed with Amare Stoudemire to unveil a limited edition womens fashion line.

title: China Inflation Rises Less Than in Previous Month
description: BEIJING  Inflation in China retreated from a three-year high during August, the government said on Friday, reducing concerns that state planners may have to raise interest rates and take other measures at a time when the economy already is showing signs of slowing down.

title: Preparing for 2012, Police Create Counterterrorism Unit
description: As the city prepares to host two international summits next year, and with the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks approaching, the Chicago Police Department is creating a counterterrorism unit, which will bolster security and incorporate lessons from academic research and from New York Citys counterterrorism tactics.

title: Muslim High School Football Players Stay Close to Home
description: As the title credits roll in Fordson: Faith, Fasting, Football  a documentary about Fordson High Schools football team, whose ranks are drawn from the predominantly Arab population of Dearborn, Mich.  we hear a gripping audio montage of anti-Muslim tirades.

title: From Michigan to Afghanistan, and Back
description: In Michigans snowy Upper Peninsula, job opportunities are few, and friends are usually for life. For Dominic Fredianelli and his high school buddies, joining the National Guard offered a $20,000 windfall and assistance with college tuition  all for only one weekend a month. Little did they know.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: On Stores Late Night, Stars and Packs of Fans Mingle
description: Shortly before 6 p.m. on Thursday, the first floor of Saks Fifth Avenue was virtually empty. An hour later, there was barely enough room to pass between the customers clogging the Este Lauder counter and the exit.

title: Setting a Tale of Heroism and Loss to the Right Music
description: Last week, the San Francisco Opera was rehearsing a troublesome passage in Heart of a Soldier, an opera based on real events on Sept. 11, 2001, which makes its world premiere Saturday at the War Memorial Opera House.

title: Steps Urged to Cut Cheating in Test Grading
description: Citing heightened concerns about educators cheating that have emerged after recent scandals in Atlanta and Philadelphia, a New York State panel has recommended an overhaul in how the state administers and grades its standardized tests.

title: Recipes: Fruit Desserts
description: Sure, you could just bake fruit in a crust. Or you could let the seasons bounty really shine with these crust-less recipes.

description: New York

description: New York

description: New York

description: New York

description: New York

description: New York

description: New York

description: New York

description: New York

title: Tommy Hilfiger: Spring 2012 Menswear
description: New York

title: Peter Som: Spring 2012 RTW
description: New York

title: Bye, Bye, American Pie
description: Here we are: berries, peaches, plums and cherries are all still around, and fall fruits like figs, grapes and especially apples and pears are at their peak of both flavor and supply. You may feel the call of traditional American cooking and be tempted to make pie.

title: Introduced Full of Promise, Mass Transit Clipper Cards Stumble
description: Bright blue Clipper cards are supposed to work as universal payment for seven Bay Area public transit services. But when Travis Stone swiped his card at the MacArthur BART station in Oakland last month, the turnstile failed to open. He tried another, and another, to no avail.

title: Risk of Wildfires Forces Military to Alter Training
description: CAMP SWIFT, Tex.  Camp Swift, a training area for Texas soldiers, lies several miles north of the area charred this week by the most destructive wildfire in Texas history. But 1,500 acres of the camp burned in a different fire last month, after a soldier used a grenade simulator in an unauthorized place.

title: In Perrys Crisis Dealings, Lessons From His Father
description: Rick Perrys dad served as a county commissioner in a rural county. Those are the people who command the road crews and do the other nuts-and-bolts work in local politics.

title: Word of the Day | fidelity
description: fidelity \f-de-l-te, fi-\ noun

title: Packers Start Game and Season Strong
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  There was a time during the N.F.L.s lockout when some players decided it would be a good idea to hold informal workouts with their teammates, to keep their timing and chemistry sharp and avoid the anticipated pratfalls from a lost off-season.

title: Behind Oakland Toddlers Death, a Drug Dealers Story
description: For many years, Robert Hudson and more than a dozen men gathered early each morning at the corner of 65th Avenue and International Boulevard in East Oakland to sell drugs.

title: NYT Front Page for 09/09/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/09/11

title: Candidates for Mayor Submerged in Crowd
description: It took Paul Ekmen, a silver-haired professor emeritus at the University of California, San Francisco, to bring some life to the mayoral candidates forum in North Beach on Wednesday.

title: Educators Tackling Problems in Two Crucial Age Groups
description: On the first day of school nearly two weeks ago, Jillian Carew quickly realized that getting all of her freshman algebra students on the same page would be a monumental task.

title: Those Longer School Days Are Only a First Step
description: Given the well-orchestrated hoopla over how they circumvented their union and voted for a longer school day, you might think that teachers at STEM Magnet Academy were Chicagos version of the workers at the shipyards in Gdansk, Poland, who fought Communism 30 years ago.

title: Mayor Addresses Terrorism Threat Information
description: Counterterrorism officials on Thursday were assessing a new report of a threat of an attack in New York City or Washington using a car or truck bomb, timed to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, according to several officials briefed on the matter, Scott Shane reports.

title: Movement Is Nearing on Bill for Casinos
description: Despite delays and debunked predictions, as well as a never-ending wait for Gov. Pat Quinns decision on a gambling expansion bill that narrowly passed the state legislature this spring, supporters of expanded gambling said they expected to find common ground by Oct. 25, the first day of the fall veto session.

title: Closing Down Main Street
description: The recession has taken a heavy toll on the small businesses of Beacon, N.Y., a decade after a renewal attracted antique stores, restaurants and other shopkeepers.

title: Newswallah: In the National English-Language Press Today
description: Investigators puzzled over an e-mail from a second terror group claiming responsibility for the blast at the New Delhi High Court that killed at least 12 people and injured dozens more. Police detained five people in Jammu connected to the Internet cafe from which the first e-mail was sent, claiming Harkut-ul-Jihad al-Islami was responsible. The second e-mail came from the Indian Mujahideen. (Indian Express) The investigation has been hampered by lack of security camera footage. Installation of surveillance cameras has been planned for the past three years, but the work was never completed. (Times of India)

title: Corrections: September 9
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Jobs, Jobs, Jobs Versus the S-Word
description: There have not been very many polls recently about proposals to stimulate the economy  perhaps a signal of how the conversation in Washington has shifted toward deficit reduction. Nevertheless, we can get some basic sense of how the major elements of President Obamas American Jobs Act poll.

title: Appreciating Balotellis Hidden Appeal
description: It has been a difficult week for Manchester Citys enigmatic striker, Mario Balotelli.

title: Taylor Steps
description: Photos from the Paul Taylor Dance Companys 2009 season.

title: Trivial Secrets
description: At the airport lounge, finally  Moscow traffic lives up to its reputation. So a quick note.

title: How We Failed
description: My address to the Eastern Economic Association.

title: What to Watch on Friday
description: Consider today a sort of amuse-bouche for what should be a spectacular day of tennis on Saturday, which will feature both the mens and womens semifinals. But that doesnt make todays offerings any less appealing.

title: News Quiz | September 9, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Securing a National Sport
description: Despite a continuing turf war between rival drug cartels that threatens the security of many in Mexico, the Indios soccer club and its fans soldier on.

title: Pakistan Crackdown Collapses
description: The Pakistani governments efforts to suppress a demonstration collapsed, and what had been a clash between police and protesters turned into a huge anti-government rally.

title: Natasha Richardsons Career
description: A look at the actress's life and performances on stage and screen.

title: Sept. 9, 1976 | Mao Zedong, Chinese Communist Leader, Dies
description: On Sept. 9, 1976, the Chinese Communist leader Mao Zedong died at age 82. Mao was a leader of the Chinese Revolution, which brought the Communist Party to power and led to the founding of the Peoples Republic of China in 1949. Chairman Mao maintained authoritarian control over China until his death and oversaw a massive transformation of the country.

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 9, 2011
description: Todays question was written by Shannon Doyne. Her question comes from the article Generation Limbo: Waiting It Out.

title: Pass This Jobs Bill
description: WHO in Congress signaled a willingness to consider at least some of the measures outlined by the president in his speech about jobs and the economy last night?

title: On Twitter, President Obamas Job Speech Drives the Conversation
description: President Obamas job speech Thursday night prompted more than 125,350 mentions of his name on Twitter, the highest number of mentions in a day since he announced Osama Bin Laden had been killed, according to an analysis by Trendrr, a social media analytics firm.

title: A.I.G. Chief Calls For Partial Return of Bonuses
description: Edward M. Liddy told a House committee that he had asked employees who received bonuses of more than $100,000 to return half the money.

title: What Are the Most Important Changes, in Your Life and in the World, in the Last Decade?
description: The Times has created a special section commemorating the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11, 2001. In it, many talk about the changes in their own lives and in the world over the last decade. Though you may be too young to remember 9/11 itself, what would you say are the most important things that have happened to you and to the world since then? Why?

title: Human Error Investigated in California Blackouts Spread to Six Million
description: LOS ANGELES  The day after the largest power failure in California history left millions in Southern California, western Arizona and northern Mexico without electricity during one of the hottest weeks of the year, local and federal officials promised Friday to investigate the cause.

title: A Jobs Program in Need of Reform
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: The Early Word: Pass This Bill
description: Todays Times:

title: The Net Price Calculator: Financial Aid Game Changer?
description: The term net price calculator will soon be ubiquitous, at least in college admissions circles (and around more than a few kitchen tables).

title: I.B.M. Study Quantifies the Pain of the Commuting Motorist
description: I.B.M. knows your pain. Not the pain of the frustrated desktop user or the stymied motherboard programmer, but of the commuting motorist.

title: Expat-Owned Bakeries Soothe Berlins Sweet Tooth
description: In Berlin, a number of expat bakers  from Israel, France and the United States  are putting a new spin on the age-old German tradition of afternoon cake.

title: Q&A: Fixing Incorrect Photo Dates in Flickr
description: Q.

title: Long Story Shortlist, 9/11 Edition
description: Filling The Void: A Chance To Soar,by Herbert Muschamp (Sept. 30, 2001)The terrorists left many voids besides the loss of human lives and two big footprints in the earth. Holes in the social fabric, fissures in the patterns of public and private life, emotional as well as physical disruptions in the streets where public and private intersect. Many futures got blown out of the water. Nothing will take their place. Meaning collapsed with the towers. Read more

title: Q & A With Aston Villas Charles NZogbia
description: Membership in the rarified fraternity that is the English Premier League has its privileges. Just ask Charles Pierre NZogbia of Aston Villa.

title: The Autumn of Discontent
description: It seemed like an innocuous enough idea: bring together the writers and readers in one of Indias most beautiful places to talk about literature. But the Harud Literature Festival, which was supposed to be held in Kashmir later this month  Harud means autumn  has become the subject of a bitter dispute that has played out in the pages of Indias best newspapers, magazines and blogs.

title: In Store | Cutting Edge
description: Richard James, the London tailor, known for kitting out rock stars, royals, actors and moguls in killer bespoke suits, is loosening his tie a bit this season. Go to interactive feature >>

title: After Cat Vanishes at J.F.K., an Anxious Audience Urges More Action
description: Karen Pascoe left for Kennedy International Airport two weeks ago ready to make a fresh start. After 22 years in New York City, she was moving to San Jose, Calif., to take a job at a software design company. Naturally, her two cats, Jack and Barry, would be going with her.

title: 2011 Week 1 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Steelers at RavensSunday, 1 p.m.Line: Ravens by 2

title: A Story of Two Presidents
description: Abraham Lincoln in New York is an exhibit at the Federal Hall National Memorial presented by The Rail Splitter, a national organization of Lincoln Scholars.

title: Turning Back the Clock on Rockwell
description: In the spring, the Norman Rockwell Museum will reopen the artists studio on the grounds of the museum, and it will look just as it did in October 1960.

title: Celebrating Lincoln
description: Exhibits for Lincoln celebrating the bicentennial year of his birth have sprouted all over the United States.

title: Retouching Dillinger's Reputation
description: A relative of John Dillinger waged a court battle, forcing changes in an exhibit about the alleged killer.

title: Scotiabank to Buy 20% Stake in Bank of Guangzhou
description: Scotiabank, the Canadian financial firm, announced on Friday that it would buy a 20 percent stake in Chinas Bank of Guangzhou for roughly $723 million.

title: Can the Human Race Shift From Sprint to Marathon?
description: An interview on the Canadian public affairs program The Agenda may be of interest. After a week of segments on climate confusion, oil sands and cities and efficiency, we moved out to the broadest view of the human adventure, with a discussion of the notion that Earth has entered an epoch called the Anthropocene.

title: Impasse Persists on Drugs in Drinking Water
description: Five years after the federal government convened a task force to study the risks posed by pharmaceuticals in the environment, it is no closer to understanding the problem or whether these contaminants should be regulated under the Clean Water Act. Thats the finding of a new report from the Government Accountability Office.

title: A Hockey Enforcer Has His (Dark) Day
description: TORONTO  Hockey fans, and you know who you are, you will not be the first to see The Last Gladiators, Alex Gibneys latest documentary, about the busted-up world of hockey enforcers. Some 100 movie fans beat you to it, at a Thursday-afternoon press and industry screening here at the Toronto International Film Festival.

title: Strung Together
description: The one rivalry that I thought you missed was Big Bill (Tilden) versus Little Bill (Johnston). After losing the finals of the U.S. Championships in 1919 to Johnston, Tilden realized that he would never beat him until he found an answer to Johnstons forehand drive to his own slice backhand. Tilden took the entire winter off to develop a backhand that he could hit flat, with top spin or with slice. Many consider it the finest stroke in tennis history. In 1920 he defeated Johnston in five sets in the U.S. Championships and never lost another important match to him. I often wonder why todays pros dont do the same thing. Its pretty clear that Djokovic has come up with a stylistic advantage over Nadal (similar to what Nadal has over Federer). It is a clich to say that the mental part of the game determines rivalries when style of play is significantly more important. Looking back over the past 10 years of mens tennis, you have to wonder: if Andy Roddick had been willing to make the changes to his game to beat Federer, would we be talking about the great Roddick-Federer rivalry?

title: Manufacturing
description: Reading Jon Gertners article reminded me of industrial-policy talks I participated in as a State Department official in the mid-80s between U.S. and Japanese officials. We aired our complaints about their aid to business; the Japanese responded that we also backed industry with R&D tax credits and Darpa subsidies, among many programs. At the conclusion of our meetings, the head of the Japanese delegation aptly summed up as follows: We in Japan have an industrial policy and wont admit it; you have an industrial policy and dont know it.

title: The Losing Ticket
description: Many state lotteries (some of which have hired me as a consultant) continue to sell scratch-off lottery tickets regardless of whether the winning tickets have already been claimed. Some states print a disclaimer stating that some prizes may not be available sometime after the tickets have been issued. But even so, is a state within its ethical purview to continue selling those tickets on the false premise that a $1 million payout is attainable? STANLEY I. COHEN, GLEN ROCK, N.J.

title: Untying the Knot in Japan
description: On a Saturday night in Tokyos Asakusa district, a woman in a floral kimono and a man in a boxy dark suit silently waited side by side. First, one black rickshaw pulled up to them. Moments later, another cart arrived. With a small nod to each other, the couple moved to board their separate chariots en route to the nights main event: their divorce ceremony.

title: Asking Candidates About Their Faith
description: I agree with Bill Keller that we must overcome our squeamishness about asking candidates how spiritual beliefs would inform their governance. I too remember the controversy surrounding John Kennedy, then a candidate, and his Catholicism. Today this attitude seems antiquated, ridiculous. But had he sought the popes endorsement or sponsored a prayer rally hosted by Catholic bishops, it would have been a different matter. Who knows whether Rick Perry believes the radical ideas of the leaders featured in the Response rally. The fact that he chose representatives from movements that are antigay, anti-Muslim, anti-Buddhist, antichoice, who believe that foreign policy toward Israel and the Middle East should be determined by religious beliefs, is troubling. Would these ideas affect his political decisions? Would he appoint people with such beliefs to his administration? Voters need to know before they cast ballots.

title: In New Sitcoms, Parents Need the Growing Up
description: When I was 33 and single, I moved in next door to a family who threw big parties throughout the summer. There seemed to be an inflatable jumpy castle in their front yard almost every weekend: an enormous, unsightly purple or red or orange blob that would quiver and wobble as little kids and big kids shrieked and giggled and barely missed injuring one another inside. I tried to ignore it, but the thing was just a few feet from my bedroom window, and the racket would go on way past a reasonable hour. Screaming, laughter, sobbing; the jumpy castle boiled life down to its essential elements. And every now and then, one of the smaller kids would roll right out onto the grass, like a baby tumbling out of a gigantic, shaking womb.

title: A Failure of Happiness
description: We met one cold day on Columbia Universitys indoor track, weeks before the 1992 New York Marathon. My workout called for 10 miles, or 100 laps, a lonely affair until a lean, chipper young grad student pulled alongside me. With his booming voice, he announced that he was studying philosophy because philosophers were the only people who could change the world.

title: Fashion Week Casting | Rag & Bone
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#937", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: The Bard Graduate Center Gallery
description: A panoramic view of the exhibition English Embroidery From the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1580-1700: Twixt Art and Nature at the Bard Graduate Center Gallery.

title: Treasures in the Back Room
description: Most museums own far more art than they can display, and viewing that art is made difficult by space, staff and security constraints.

title: Chances Are Good for a Tangent
description: THE films of the German director Tom Tykwer make a point of never standing still. His best-known characters  the sidewalk-pounding heroine of Run Lola Run, the globe-trotting Interpol agent of The International  are perpetual-motion machines. His pinballing plots take shape as intricate series of actions and reactions: stories as demonstrations of chaos theory.

title: Old Footage Haunts General and a Director
description: AMERICAN filmgoers may not know what a granito is, but Pamela Yatess new documentary of that name comes with a subtitle whose meaning could not be clearer: How to Nail a Dictator. The tyrant in question is Gen. Efran Ros Montt, who for 17 bloody months in the early 1980s led a military junta in Guatemala, and the granitos are the many human-rights advocates, metaphorical grains of sand who, by working together, have now managed to bring him up on genocide charges in a Spanish court.

title: Pressing the Flesh | Craig McDeans Sumo
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#821", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: VW and Porsche Shares Slip as Deal Hopes Are Dashed
description: Shares of Volkswagen and Porsche slipped on Friday, as the automakers merger plans faced difficulties.

title: Obama Stumps for Jobs Plan, Calling for Action Now
description: RICHMOND, Va.  A day after throwing down the gauntlet to Congress, President Obama took his new $447 billion jobs plan on the road on Friday, exhorting college students here to contact their lawmakers in the first salvo of what the White House says will be a sustained campaign by the president to sell his legislation this fall.

title: Friday Reading: Patient Data Exposed in Big Breach
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: BlackRock Hires HSBC Executive
description: BlackRock bolstered its presence in Hong Kong, announcing on Friday that it had hired Mark McCombe of HSBC to be chairman of the asset management behemoths operations in the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Poll Finds Turner Strong Against Weprin in Race to Replace Weiner
description: Updated, 12:20 p.m. | The Republican candidate is in a strong position heading into Tuesdays special election in the heavily Democratic Congressional district formerly represented by Anthony D. Weiner, according to a new poll released on Friday.

title: Bookshelf
description: In [sic] (W.W. Norton, $25), the young classical composer Joshua Cody outstrips the weepy conventions of a cancer memoir by mixing aggressive, intelligent prose with shocking confessions, like the time he had cocaine-fueled sex with a stranger after chemotherapy.

title: Qaddafi Strongholds Are Attacked
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Libyan rebels began what they called full-scale attacks to subdue the loyalist holdouts of Bani Walid and Surt on Friday night, breaking their own deadline for surrender after taking enemy fire.

title: Wall St. Follows Europes Markets Down on Economic Uncertainty
description: Stocks on Wall Street declined sharply, and 10-year bond yields hit fresh lows on Friday as developments in Europe related to sovereign debt problems weighed on the financial markets.

title: The Shut Up Guys Find Their Boswell
description: IN the late 1980s, two University of Wisconsin grads living in a run-down building in San Francisco taped the interminable drunken tirades of two next door neighbors, Peter Haskett and Raymond Huffman, initially without the mens knowledge. The profane poetry of abuse  I can kill you from a sitting position!; You always giggle falsely  was shared with friends on cassettes, heralded by fanzines, sampled on a radio show, adapted by comic-book artists and distributed on CD under the title Shut Up, Little Man!, a reference to Mr. Hasketts favorite put-down. Artists like Kurt Cobain expressed their appreciation; movie producers plotted deals; and a play about the bickering roommates was produced. But, while their private conflicts were played and replayed, first Mr. Huffman and then Mr. Haskett died, with only Mr. Haskett learning about the fuss near the end.

title: Seth Rogen Will Answer Reader Questions
description: 12:22 p.m. | Updated TORONTO  The Toronto International Film Festival has begun, and we are here watching films, interviewing directors and stars, providing critical analysis of the films and peeking into the business side of the festival.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: On Solemn Note, Curtain Rises on the New John Jay College
description: Updated, 11:52 a.m. | John Jay College of Criminal Justice took a long step into the future on Thursday with a deep bow to the past.

title: A Few of the Many Jobs at the U.S. Open
description: Over the course of two weeks, more than 700,000 people attend the US Open. It takes various jobs to keep things running.

title: A Setback for the Euro Zone
description: FRANKFURT  Discord over the handling of Europes debt crisis spilled into full view on Friday when an influential member of the European Central Banks executive board unexpectedly resigned. The news intensified fears over the euro currency unions ability to cooperatively resolve its problems.

title: More Scenes From Fashions Night Out
description: On the subway home late Thursday night after Fashions Night Out had begun to wind down (good luck getting a cab in Midtown), a lot of young people were comparing notes about celebrity sightings, and some near misses. One young woman, an editor at Fast Company, told me that she was appalled by the crowds in SoHo who had descended upon, of all people, the DJ Pauly D.

title: Morning T | Elettra Wiedemann
description: T's Online Editor Jane Herman talks to Elettra Wiedemann about her new pop-up restaurant Goodness, her work with Lancome and the things she learned from her mother.

title: Morning T | Elettra Wiedemann
description: Ts Online Editor Jane Herman talks to Elettra Wiedemann about her new pop-up restaurant GOODNESS, her work with Lancme and the things she learned from her mother.

title: Data Explosion Lifts the Storage Market
description: Workers suffering from information overload, and companies drowning in the Internet-era exaflood of data? These are good problems indeed, if you are in the data storage business.

title: Hands-On Brand Name Composer For a Ballet
description: THE composer, dressed down in denim and Nikes, strolled into rehearsal at the New York City Ballets Studio 2 late last month to see for the first time what the choreographer Peter Martins had made of his score, Oceans Kingdom.

title: Louis XIV Hummed a Few Arias
description: PARIS

title: A Master of Impossible Camera Angles
description: IN Leonard Retel Helmrichs Shape of the Moon (2004) a barefoot man crosses a railroad trestle a thousand feet above an Indonesian valley, stepping briskly along a beam barely wider than his feet. We see him from behind. We see him from above. Most alarming, we see him from the side, by means of a camera that seems mounted in midair. Its breathtaking, what the subject is doing. But a man with a camera is doing it too.

title: Sept. 11  Sept. 17
description: Art

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Kevork Kiledjian
description: If you look good, you dont have to try so hard, said Kevin Ryan backstage at Kevork Kiledjian, a funny declaration from a hairstylist surrounded by assistants and assorted Rsession Tools curling irons and dryers. Still, this was the idea behind the loose, mussed hair for the show. It takes work to look like youre not trying too hard.

title: Hearing Rumors of a Plot, Cities Make Their Security Forces Seen
description: WASHINGTON  Bomb-sniffing dogs were deployed in the Washington subway, and the police searched vehicles at the Brooklyn Bridge on Friday as counterterrorism officials with frustratingly imprecise clues hunted for at least two men reportedly dispatched by Al Qaeda to set off a car or truck bomb in New York or Washington.

title: Directors Adapt to Shooting 3-D With Depth
description: EVEN as Hollywood prepares for an autumn onslaught of 3-D movies from big-name directors (including Hugo from Martin Scorsese and The Adventures of Tintin from Steven Spielberg), the future of the format remains uncertain. Resentful of premium ticket prices and burned by too many films hastily and unconvincingly converted from 2-D to 3-D, audiences arent flocking to stereoscopic films the way they did a year ago. The novelty is fading.

title: Getting Medieval
description: Emilia Clarke is the nice English girl who plays Daenerys Targaryen in HBOs hugely successful pork-sword-and-sorcery drama series, Game of Thrones. In the show, which is adapted from George R. R. Martins equally huge series of cod-medieval fantasy books, A Song of Ice and Fire, Daenerys is one of the two remaining children of the ousted Targaryen dynasty, forcibly married, aged 15, to Khal Drogo, another huge thing (played by the 6-foot-4 Hawaiian-born actor Jason Momoa), a warlord of the horse-mad Dothraki people who live beyond the Narrow Sea.

title: Channel Surfing: Mel Brooks and Dick Cavett Together Again
description: With a combined total of 159 years on the planet, Mel Brooks and Dick Cavett still have a ways to go to catch the 2,000-Year-Old Man. But they have managed to accumulate some amusing stories nonetheless, which they share in Mel Brooks and Dick Cavett Together Again, a pleasant hourlong special Friday night on HBO.

title: Juror Describes Deliberations and Doubts in Police Rape Case
description: After days of deadlock and arguments, a holdout juror in the trial of two police officers accused of rape started the day with a joke.

title: Flooding Persists in Southern Tier of New York
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y.  Stacey Gould, 43, and her son, Aidan Ehmke, 7, stared at their charming two-story home on the banks of the roiling Susquehanna River on Friday as rushing, muddy waters engulfed the house.

title: KTM Recalls 6,000 Off-Road Bikes for Faulty Handlebar Clamp
description: About 6,100 off-road motorcycles are being recalled by KTM North America because their handlebars may slide out of their normally fixed positions and cause a crash, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Settlement Said to Be Near for Fannie and Freddie | A proposed agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission would end an investigation into whether Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac adequately disclosed their exposure to risky subprime loans.

title: A Rowdy New Addition to the BMW M Family
description: AMONG the ranks of BMW fundamentalists, one nightmare incites the deepest primal fears: an unrelenting attack by a vampire army of thirsty, darkly complicated Bimmers.

title: On Thursday, Another Serving of Bagels
description: No. 1 Novak Djokovics new gluten-free diet hasnt stopped him from baking up some starchy scorelines at the 2011 U.S. Open.

title: Gonzo Fishing
description: Last weekends Look, and a related video in Rachel Nolans post below, furnish the perfect occasion to revisit  and recommend strongly  an article that appeared 15 years ago in The Atlantic Monthly: In the Monsters Maw, by Burkhard Bilger. Where we only had room enough to skim over what goes into noodling, or catching catfish barehanded, Bilger was able to dive deep into the thoroughly American (it goes back to the Indians) subculture of using your fingers as fishing lures.

title: How to Ask a Proper Question at a Public Event
description: You have probably heard it said that there is no such thing as a bad question. Thats not true; of course there is such a thing as a bad question. But the upside of that is that there is such a thing as a good question.

title: The Pain of the Daily Commute
description: Today the Wheels blog offers an interesting study and graphic from I.B.M. that attempts to quantify the pain and frustration of commuting to work around the world.

title: A Reminder of Great Sacrifice
description: Stephen Obie was a senior trial lawyer in the Commodity Futures Trading Commissions enforcement division at the time of the Sept. 11 attacks. A 13-year agency veteran, he is now the regional administrator for the New York office and head of its enforcement section.

title: Just Me and My Shadow, Pedaling Toward Chicago
description: BROOKLYN CENTER, Minn.  Early Thursday morning, I saw something I havent seen in weeks.

title: Europe Is Urged to Take Bolder Action on Debt
description: MARSEILLE, France  If anyone was counting on finance officials of the powerful Group of 7 nations to help map a way out of Europes debt crisis and calm the markets, consider this: the G-7 met on Friday, the crisis grew worse and the markets plummeted.

title: Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman, co-author of That Used to Be Us, talks about Americas decline; Bill Keller on Christopher Hitchens; best-seller news.
description: This week, Times Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman, co-author of That Used to Be Us, talks about Americas decline and possible recovery; Bill Keller surveys the career of Christopher Hitchens; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: China: Drought Leaves 14 Million Chinese and Farmland Parched
description: A persistent drought in China has left more than 14 million people short of drinking water and damaged large tracts of farmland, according to a report on Friday by Xinhua, the state news agency. The drought is concentrated in the southwest, where 12.6 million people are short of water. The drought began in early July and has caused reservoirs and rivers to dry up. The areas hardest hit are Yunnan and Guizhou Provinces, the Guangxi Autonomous Region and the dense municipality of Chongqing. About 14 million acres of farmland across China have been affected, Xinhua reported. This drought and others that have devastated southern China this year have raised questions about the wisdom of a giant and expensive government project to transfer water from rivers in the south, in particular the Yangtze, to the parched north.

title: Combine and Conquer: Your Place and Mine
description: IN New York City real estate, there is a little-known and somewhat mystifying equation, and that is: 1 + 1 = 2.5.

title: Yahoo Is Said to Look to Allen & Co. for Strategic Options
description: 2:47 p.m. | Updated

title: Blood, Sweat and Trophies
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#198", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Man United!
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#850", 592, 500, true, chameleonData);

title: Creating Spaces for Tweens and Teens
description: IT may seem improbable to suburban tweens, whiling away the after-school hours in front of a video-game console in a friends basement, but even in Manhattan, people in their age group get bored.

title: Christopher Hitchens, a Man of His Words
description: Anyone who occasionally opens one of our more serious periodicals has learned that the byline of Christopher Hitchens is an opportunity to be delighted or maddened  possibly both  but in any case not to be missed. He is our intellectual omnivore, exhilarating and infuriating, if not in equal parts at least with equal wit. He has been rather famously an aggressive critic of God and his followers, after cutting his sacrilegious teeth on Mother Teresa. He wrote a deadpan argument for trying Henry Kissinger as a war criminal, then was branded an apostate by former friends on the left for vigorously supporting the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. (He memorably  a lot of what Hitchens has written merits the adverb  shot back that his antiwar critics were the sort who, discovering a viper in the bed of their child, would place the first call to People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.) And he is dying of esophageal cancer, a fact he has faced with exceptional aplomb.

title: Big League Anxiety on the Baseball Diamond
description: To defenders of baseball and literary fiction, the charges against each are familiar, and overlapping: too slow, too precious, not enough action. The only realistic response is a resigned shrug. Guilty, and so what? You may as well complain that lemons are too yellow. The indictment amounts to a kind of category error; detractors went looking for entertainment, and found art instead.

title: Up Front: Robert F. Worth
description: When this years momentous upheavals in the Middle East began, Robert F. Worth had just returned from lengthy stints in Baghdad and in Beirut, where hed run the New York Times bureau. Soon, he was on his way back to the area to report on the revolts in Egypt, Libya and Yemen for The Times Magazine, where he is now a staff writer. Covering the Arab uprisings, he told us, has been a transforming experience. By the end of last year, after more than seven years in the region, I had become a dour cynic about the potential for change in the Arab world. I had covered far too many bombings and fraudulent elections, and heard Arabs themselves complain too often about their own inability to transcend the morass of corruption and thuggery. Seeing all that explode has been a welcome challenge to my own assumptions about this place and its people.

title: A Libyan Author Writes of Exile and a Vanished Father
description: Ever since a Tunisian street vendor named Mohamed Bouazizi set himself on fire last December, people around the world have been asking how a new generation of Arab rebels learned to do what their parents could not: resist and even defeat a brutal police state. But a darker corollary soon arose. Why did it take so long? Why did the earlier rebellions fail? And how much damage has been done to the fabric of the societies that are now struggling, at the cost of so much blood, to reinvent themselves? For Western readers, what often seemed lacking  as in Iraq in years past  was an authentic interpreter and witness, someone who could speak across cultures and make us feel the abundant miseries that fueled the revolt.

title: Welcome to the Counter-Jihad
description: The Arab world is poised for an era of political and cultural renewal. In dramatic succession, popular uprisings have toppled long-reigning dictators even as others cling to power. Amid these momentous events, scholars, journalists and politicians are scrambling to explain how these revolutions came about after years of political stagnation and dashed attempts at reform.

title: The Waning Appeal of Radical Sheik
description: In The Missing Martyrs, Charles Kurzman suggests that even before Osama bin Laden was killed, his movement had failed utterly. Al Qaedas ideological trademark is to exhort ordinary Muslims to engage in individual acts of violence against those deemed enemies of Islam, specifically Americans, Jews and the infidel rulers of Muslim-majority states. And yet very few such attacks have occurred in the United States since Sept. 11, and certainly none comparable to the devastating events of that day. To emphasize just how surprising this is, Kurzman cites a 2006 online manual for aspiring jihadists that lists 14 simple tools that are easy to use and available for anyone who wants to fight the occupying enemy  they include running over someone with a car and setting fire to homes or rooms at sleep time. Kurzman, a sociologist who has written widely about Islamic reform movements, asks: If terrorist methods are as widely available as automobiles, why are there so few Islamist terrorists? In light of the death and devastation that terrorists have wrought, the question may seem absurd. But if there are more than a billion Muslims in the world, many of whom supposedly hate the West and desire martyrdom, why dont we see terrorist attacks everywhere, every day?

title: What Do Egypts Writers Do Now?
description: The Egyptian revolution is over, the army wields power and the new government is in disarray. Tensions between Christians and Muslims are ascendant and members of the elite are leaving the country in droves while those who remain bemoan the masses as ignorant ideologues. This is the Egypt of Waguih Ghalis Beer in the Snooker Club, a coming-of-age novel set in 1952 that, much like The Catcher in the Rye in America, articulated the identity crisis of a generation. Ghalis characters  young, precocious, cosmopolitan  are lost in the bewildering aftermath of the military coup that overthrew the pliant boy-king Farouk. They pine for the easeful gambling, womanizing and drinking of the past even as they scorn both the ancien rgimes sordid pretensions and the new regimes inability to deliver on its vaulted promises; We have the worst of both systems, one of them declares, exasperated. Ghali, who published his novel in 1964 and committed suicide five years later in the bathtub of his British editors Primrose Hill apartment, took the fall of the monarchy as his subject. Still, his tale presents uncanny parallels to todays Egypt, where artists, intellectuals and youth at large are beginning to fashion a new cultural republic of sorts even as they also struggle to find their bearings.

title: Brooklyn by the Book
description: Late in Literary Brooklyn, Evan Hughes quotes the opening words of a Paul Auster novel: The address is unimportant. But lets say Brooklyn Heights, for the sake of argument. For Hughes, the address is terrifically important, as he charts New Yorks most-populated but (his description) less exceptional borough. We learn which writers lived where, which were neighbors or enemies; which houses no longer stand and which are now worth $18 million. Meanwhile, the argument that emerges, recedes, rallies and falters throughout is that Brooklyn, because more human in scale, is more American than Manhattan and has particular stories to tell about the rest of the land.

title: A Novel of Pirates, Zealots and the Somalia Crisis
description: Some in the media may paint Somali pirates as womanizers with lavish tastes and an eye for Nairobi real estate, but Nuruddin Farah exposes the shallowness of such depictions in his 11th novel, Crossbones. This timely book, which can be read as a stand-alone work or as the final volume in the authors acclaimed Past Imperfect trilogy, is politically courageous and often gripping.

title: A Story of Sun, Sand and Street Smarts
description: Miami comes alive in Birds of Paradise, a lush new novel by Diana Abu-Jaber, the author of a culinary memoir (The Language of Baklava) and three previous novels (Arabian Jazz, Crescent and Origin). From the verdant streets of Coral Gables to the back lots of Little Haiti and the seedy underbelly of Miami Beach, the metropolis is floridly, meticulously detailed. Its every breath and scent, its hallucinations, its beckoning torpor, the ambitions and accents of its inhabitants become as impossible to resist as a postprandial siesta in the tropics. (Hurricane season. The trees have grown dense as rooftops; the plumerias hold their flower-tipped branches up like brides with golden corsages.)

title: Jane Fonda, Constantly Evolving
description: Theres often a moment in a biographers life when the subject, once nonchalantly inaccessible or perhaps even hostile, decides that he must satisfy his curiosity about the project at the price of tossing scraps to this desperate soul. For Patricia Bosworth, a biographer of Montgomery Clift, this moment came in 2003, when she was invited to a weeklong respite at the 2,500-acre ranch in New Mexico that Ted Turner had bestowed on Jane Fonda as a divorce present. Fonda, with her breast implants newly removed and her shapely legs encased in terrific bluejeans (I have 50 pairs, she explained), plied Bosworth, a friend from the Actors Studio in the 1960s who had profiled her for magazines over the years, with red wine in enormous goblets, showed off her man-made lake stocked with fish, and introduced her to her six horses, including a white stallion purchased from Mike Nichols, and a golden retriever, a gift from Larry David.

title: Tyler and Odd Future Join Adult Swim
description: Tyler, the Creator, and his group of irreverent young rappers known as Odd Future, have landed a television show on Adult Swim, the nighttime incarnation of the Cartoon Network, which has become a showcase for underground pop-music genres in recent years.

title: Why Vasco da Gama Went to India
description: The Portuguese navigator Vasco da Gama set sail from Belm, a village at the mouth of the Tagus River now part of greater Lisbon, on July 8, 1497. An obscure but well-connected courtier, he had been chosen, much to everyones surprise, by King Manuel I to head the ambitious expedition to chart a new route to India. The king was not moved chiefly by a desire for plunder. He possessed a visionary cast of mind bordering on derangement; he saw himself spearheading a holy war to topple Islam, recover Jerusalem from the infidels and establish himself as the King of Jerusalem.

title: Leaving Egypt, Finding Brooklyn
description: The coming-of-age memoir is centered on a premise that anyone would grant: growing up is hard. The genres challenges lie in how to articulate memory and the passage of time, how to express whats forgotten as well as whats recalled, how to capture the shifting self  challenges to which we have a short history of solutions. Memoir writers are enticingly free to forge innovations.

title: Can Darwinism Improve Binghamton?
description: My undergraduate students, especially those bound for medical school, often ask why they have to study evolution. It wont cure disease, and really, how useful is evolution to the average person? My response is that while evolutionary biology can explain, for example, the origin of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, we shouldnt see evolution as a cure for human woes. Its value is explanatory: to tell us how, when and why we got here (by we, I mean every organism) and to show us how all species are related. In the end, evolution is the greatest tale of all, for its true.

title: Beryl Bainbridges Bobby Kennedy Novel
description: On May 30, 1888, Anton Chekhov wrote exasperatedly to a friend, the newspaper editor A. S. Suvorin, complaining about the state of contemporary Russian literature, filled with its moral injunctions and its pious prescriptions for human behavior. The writer, he insisted should not be a judge of his characters or what they say, but an impartial witness. . . . Its time for writers, especially writers of real artistic worth, to realize . . . that in fact nothing can be understood in this world. In a real sense, these phrases encapsulate the Chekhovian credo: nothing makes sense, mediocrity is the true demonic force, life is weird and vulgar, judgment is irrelevant. And to many writers, post-Chekhov, this point of view has appeared very attractive. In English literature since World War II, two writers in particular have made this take on life and the human predicament their personal forte  Muriel Spark and Beryl Bainbridge. Bainbridge, who died last year, of cancer, at the age of 77, pushed this attitude of amused, quietistic indifference to its ultimate level. Her succession of short novels (17 in all) demonstrates a beguiling relish in peoples fundamental opacity, eccentricity and inability to conform, however hard they may happen to be trying.

title: Carol Bartz Has a Few More Words for Yahoo
description: After being fired on Tuesday, Carol A. Bartz, Yahoos former chief executive, still has a close tie with her old employer: she remains a board member.

title: Editors Choice
description: BELIEVING IS SEEING: Observations on the Mysteries of Photography,  by Errol Morris (Penguin Press, $40.) The filmmaker is chiefly interested here in the nature of knowledge, in figuring out where the truth lies  in photos, yes, but not exclusively so.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE TWILIGHT OF THE BOMBS: Recent Challenges, New Dangers, and the Prospects for a World Without Nuclear Weapons,  by Richard Rhodes (Vintage, $17.) In The Making of the Atomic Bomb (1986), Rhodes explained how the United States came to build atomic weapons. His next volume, Dark Sun (1995), traced the early years of the cold war. Arsenals of Folly (2007) told the story of its end. The Twilight of the Bombs, the absorbing fourth and final volume of the series, describes the fate of nuclear weapons since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

title: Inside the List
description: BEHIND THE WHEEL: One of the goofier, more endearing features to appear each week in The Globe and Mail newspaper in Toronto is the column My Car, in which Canadian celebrities discuss what they drive and why. (Sample headline: Curler Likes an S.U.V. With Room for the Brooms.) Last year, the column included an interview with the Qubcois crime writer Louise Penny, who enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 4 with A Trick of the Light, the seventh novel in her Chief Inspector Armand Gamache series. (Marilyn Stasio reviews it in the Sept. 18 issue of the Book Review.) Penny, a former CBC radio host who turned to writing as a second career, said she gets most of her ideas as she drives around in her 2006 powder blue Volkswagen Beetle convertible. The best thing about the car, she said, is the color. The salesman was going on and on  it has this feature, it has that feature, and all Im trying to say is, What color is it? Powder blue?  she said. I put a down payment on it over the telephone. There was no sort of second thought here. He could have said it was double the price and I would have said, Is it powder blue?

title: As Auto Show Opens, an Industrys Balance Shifts
description: WHEN the 64th Frankfurt Motor Show opens on Tuesday for two days of press previews, some 50 automakers and specialty builders will begin unwrapping upwards of 100 new models for journalists.

title: House of Strings and Feathers
description: THE pre-Civil War town house at 197 Amity Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that is home to Stan Stanford, Judith Albert and their four children has enjoyed two brushes with fame.

title: Apps and Sites for Restaurant Hunters
description: The news on Thursday that Google is buying Zagat, the longtime publisher of restaurant reviews, got us thinking over here at Gadgetwise, mostly about the fact that we havent really used Zagat all that much in the last few years. There are times where it can be useful (if youre going to a city with limited restaurant-review options, Zagat can steer you to a place that will probably be just fine, and possibly great), but what Zagat used to have to itself has become its own industry with plenty of competitors. Heres a look at some of the bigger and better players in the restaurant search world.

title: Anatomy of a Disappearance
description: Chapter 1

title: Another Ryan Awaits His Star Turn
description: IRVING, Tex.  Not 10 months after saying he would be shocked if he were not an N.F.L. head coach this season, Rob Ryan stood outside his teams locker room Monday, surrounded by television cameras and microphones and recorders, and praised the man who had hired him: Jason Garrett, the head coach of the Dallas Cowboys. So, is Ryan, imported to resuscitate one of the leagues worst defenses of last season, shocked again that his prediction has gone unfulfilled?

title: European-Specification Honda Civic Gets a Mugen Special Edition
description: For car enthusiasts who subscribe to the grass-is-always-greener theory, the 2012 Honda Civic Mugen Type R offers yet another point of corroboration.

title: Questions for a Father Lost on 9/11
description: I was going to write about what we have learned in 10 years. About how love, family and community were all that mattered on that awful day, and how we should use each anniversary of Sept. 11 to try to reclaim the sliver of good that was forged in the flames. About how all our lives are measured not by what happens to us, but by what we do in response. And about how we must use this day to honor what was clear as the September sky that morning. We must cherish the sheer luxury of normal.

title: In Spain, Hiking Along the Volcanoes of Catalonia
description: A BLACK-AND-WHITE bird, perhaps a magpie, looking not unlike a soaring penguin, floated above my wife, Jessie, and me as we walked out of Olot, deep in the foothills of the Pyrenees in Spanish Catalonia. We werent exactly lost, but an old ladys directions, in rambling Catalan, seemed somewhat improbable: go until you see a path that looks like it used to be a railroad, she said. Then follow it for about 35 miles until you reach Girona.

title: Safe and Sound, Sweet and Spacious
description: I SAW four people out on the road the other day, Roland Brown, a recent transplant to Cambria Heights in southeastern Queens, joked the other day about his new neighborhood. It was like rush hour.

title: Greens Frittata With Mozzarella and Prosciutto
description: Time: About 15 minutes

title: Italy, So Close You Can Taste It
description: WHEN Im in a hurry to get dinner together, the last thing I want is to stand in line at the supermarket. More often than not, I will pop into my local Italian deli, really a little hole in the wall but a treasure trove of ingredients.

title: A First-Rate Madness
description: To the Editor:

title: The Well-Read Book
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than a Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Officers Also Risked Lives on 9/11, and 3 Were Lost
description: The four court officers hurried down a long corridor until they were beneath the burning south tower of the World Trade Center.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: True Life Comics
description: Last week, I lamented that Feynman, a biography about the physicist Richard P. Feynman published by First Second, had not yet appeared on the list. But now it has arrived  and it sits atop the hardcover graphic novels list. Feynman is an engaging read. For more on the man, visit the robust collection of articles on his Times Topics page.

title: So, This Is Mans Best Friend?
description: Animal Planet runs up the white flag on Saturday night. The dogs have won.

title: Not Just Cold Cuts at My Italian Deli
description: In this weeks City Kitchen, my local Italian deli provides the inspiration and ingredients for a simple supper.

title: Peter Som Smells the Roses
description: At 10 a.m., Tommy Hilfiger, looking cool in a lightweight gray suit and no socks, walked into Milk Studios to check in on his daughter Ally, who was preparing to show her new Nahm collection (with Nary Manivong) at noon. Mr. Hilfiger himself is scheduled to show his mens wear at 5:30 this afternoon. Neither one looked especially stressed when they sat down in the front row of the show of Peter Som, who is also a consultant on Mr. Hilfigers womens collection.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Governors Island becomes a pig fest Saturday from 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. during the Pig Island event, which benefits Food Systems Network NYC. A team of 20 chefs will cook 80 hogs raised by local farmers. Craft beers and New York wines will be poured, and cooking demonstrations will take place throughout the day. There will be options for vegetarians, too. Tickets range from $43.19 to $74.84.

title: Democrats Plan Briefings on Jewish Outreach
description: Its no surprise that the Democratic National Committee meeting in Chicago on Friday will include briefings on jobs and health care, issues critical to President Obamas re-election. But Jewish messaging will be the third topic presented to top party donors and fund-raisers, according to a schedule obtained by The New York Times.

title: Visiting Artists | Frank Benson
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#381", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: An Immigration Lottery Won, Then Dreams Lost
description: Earlier this year, the United States State Department notified some 22,000 applicants from around the world that they were among the winners of its lottery drawing for a permanent resident visa, known as a green card. A few days later, however, the State Department changed course, saying the winners were not winners after all because the required random-selection process had been done improperly. The dreams of applicants from Venezuela to Egypt and Uzbekistan to Fiji were dashed. Months later, that disappointment continues. Two would-be winners, each from Russia, talk about what it was like to have won  and then lost.

title: House Freshmen Emerge as G.O.P. Power Brokers
description: CONWAY, S.C.  Voters here were showing Representative Tim Scott the love, and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas looked as if he might jump across the stage and give Mr. Scott, a Republican freshman, a kiss himself.

title: Embracing Serena
description: Its time to go beyond respecting Serena Williams and start embracing her as a true American sports icon, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Brooklyn Man Accused of Seeking to Join Terror Group
description: A 27-year-old man living in Brooklyn was arraigned in federal court on Friday on charges that he provided material support to terrorists and had been planning to join a radical Islamic group in Pakistan.

title: The Lowdown | Erik Foss
description: The founder and owner of Lit Lounge, a singular source of some of the most embarrassing I blacked out moments in New York, the almost legendary Erik Foss also devotes a fair amount of his time and energy to supporting and creating art. His gallery, Fuse, has given an invaluable vote of confidence to countless young New York artists (including me a year ago), by showing their work before anyone else would so much as bat an eyelash at them. Over the last few years, Fosss own cheeky (and often pornographic) paintings have appeared in numerous group shows internationally, and hes had two solo gigs at White Walls Gallery in San Francisco. I caught up with Foss on the eve of his first solo show in New York, the town he has called home for almost two decades. Catch the artists reception for Avarice at Malick Williams and Co. (150 11th Avenue), on Sept. 11 from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Sports of The Times: Embracing Serena
description: Its time to go beyond respecting Serena Williams and start embracing her as a true American sports icon, says William C. Rhoden.

description: IN 2008, a new boy showed up at Puget Sound Community School in Seattle wearing a green pompom hat, and Juliana Rotskoff had a feeling that she had found a new best friend.

description: Sept. 9, 2011  President Obamas political strategy after a jobs speech to a skeptical Congress. Also, the Op-Ed columnist Gail Collins on the state of the Republican primary.

title: This Time, the Downsizing Will Happen Under the Hood
description: WILL Americans buy a $50,000 BMW with 4 cylinders under its hood? Well soon find out.

title: Mel Gibson Takes on Judah Maccabee
description: Mel Gibson, the actor and director whose comments about Jews have drawn charges of anti-Semitism, is working on a movie about the life of Judah Maccabee, the Israelite warrior whose victory over the Greek and Syrian forces is celebrated during Hanukkah, according to The Los Angeles Times and Deadline Hollywood.

title: Obama and Abbas: From Speed Dial to Not Talking
description: WASHINGTON  Among the very first foreign leaders President Obama called after entering the Oval Office on Jan. 21, 2009, was the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas. The last time the two men spoke was in February, when Mr. Obama failed, in an awkward, 55-minute phone conversation, to persuade Mr. Abbas not to go to the United Nations to condemn Israel for building Jewish settlements.

title: Triathlon Training on a Budget
description: The popularity of triathlons, which combine biking, swimming and running, has surged in the last two decades, writes Shivani Vora in the latest Urban Athlete column.

title: A Tart Wins Praise, but Not for Neatness
description: WHETHER you call it a crostata, a galette or a rustic fruit tart, this juicy, messy confection has a charm that lies with its flavors rather than its looks.
