title: Mean Irene
description: Clotilde Hryshko runs a farm and CSA in a beautiful valley in Brookfield, VT. I go there every chance I get (usually three or four times a year, and three years ago bought the vegies for my wedding there) and truly love the place and the job she does. I wrote about the farm on my Diners Journal blog, Bitten, and Clotilde has written some lovely pieces that have appeared on www.markbittman.com. Heres her post-Irene report, and if it doesnt bring you to tears check your ductwork:

title: Roddick vs. Nadal: The Keys to the Match
description: Andy Roddicks stirring win over David Ferrer surprised many tennis analysts, who thought the indefatigable Spaniard would return well enough to neutralize Roddicks cannon of a serve. But Roddick showed signs of returning to the form he displayed at Wimbledon in 2009. He also played superbly from the backcourt, committing fewer unforced errors than the notoriously stingy Ferrer.

title: Improvised Crostata
description: As I mention in this weeks column, you can use practically any fruit to make a crostata, as long as you follow a few extremely basic rules.

title: Gail Collins on the Republican Primary
description: The Op-Ed columnist Gail Collins reviews the Republican debate.

title: Pope Sends Letter Mourning 9/11 and Condemning Terrorism
description: Pope Benedict XVI, saying that he has been thinking about the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11, has written a letter expressing his concern for the families of those killed on that day and decrying terrorism.

title: Eager to Help, and Rebuild
description: Joseph C. Noviello is the executive vice president and chief products architect at Cantor Fitzgerald. He was a senior executive at eSpeed on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Party Leaders Appeal to Yemens President to Help End Stalemate
description: SANA, Yemen  Having failed so far to bring an end to the nations political crisis, a delegation of governing party officials traveled to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Friday, hoping to persuade the absentee president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, to help break a stalemate that has paralyzed the country for months.

title: Lady Gaga to Ring in the New Year With Dick Clark
description: Lady Gaga will be the featured guest performing at Times Square during the annual New Years Eve celebration on ABC hosted by Dick Clark and Ryan Seacrest, The Associated Press said. The show is in its 40th year and Mr. Clark has been hosting it much longer than Lady Gaga, the pop diva given to euro-dance grooves and wacky costumes, has been alive. (She was born in 1986.) Fergie, of the Black Eyed Peas, will host the Los Angeles portion of the show, which will go for three hours in prime time, break for the local news, then return for two and a half hours.

title: Employers Say Jobs Plan Wont Lead to Hiring Spur
description: The dismal state of the economy is the mainreason many companies are reluctant to hire workers, and few executives are saying that President Obamas jobs plan  while welcome  will change their minds any time soon.

title: Red Bulls Re-Engage
description: The Red Bulls  remember them?  will be back on the field for a game in Major League Soccer for the first time since Aug. 20 when they face the bottom team in the entire league, the Vancouver Whitecaps, at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., Saturday night.

title: Seeking Universal Life Lessons in Story of Baseball Nerdery
description: TORONTO  Its a safe bet that nobodys picture got a green light on Sony Pictures Culver City lot on Friday. The companys top brass  including the studio chief, Amy Pascal, and the president of the Columbia Pictures unit, Doug Belgrad  were crammed into the front row of a news conference at the Toronto International Film Festival here, watching Brad Pitt introduce their sports-and-business drama, Moneyball.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 1
description: Scenes from Thursday night, The Roots play at John Varvatos and Imitation of Christ kicks off Fashion Week.

title: 9/11 Truthers to Tone Protests Down, for a Day
description: No bullhorning during the memorial.

title: Fashions Night Out in New York City
description: Fashionistas celebrated the start of New York Fashion Week during Fashions Night Out, a shopping event held at various venues in New York City.

title: Whats in the Obama Jobs Plan for Small Businesses
description: In his speech to the joint session of Congress on Thursday night, President Obama proposed a jobs bill, the American Jobs Act, with several specific, if not yet particularly detailed, tax initiatives that would benefit small businesses  though most in fact would bring the same relief to all companies, large or small. The initiatives can be sorted into two flavors, incentives to promote investment broadly and incentives to promote hiring in particular.

title: Embracing the Positive
description: My sister and I both had a positive lookout for life, said Marisa Berenson, now in her 60s and still an arresting beauty, at a Fashions Night Out event held in Donna Karans Madison Avenue store on Thursday to celebrate Marisa Berenson: A Life in Pictures, due out in October from Rizzoli books.

title: Strapping
description: For the Bulgarian-born shoe designer Gio Metodiev of Gio Diev, seven-inch heels arent always a prerequisite for seductive footwear. Its really not about height anymore, he says. You can make a statement without having to be sky high. The 30-piece offering, which Metodiev will introduce at Premiere Classe in Paris later this month, includes color-blocked heels with ankle cuffs inspired by armor and flats strapped with leather wire. Dievs meticulous construction  he shares a factory in northern Italy with Manolo Blahnik; he has his mother wear and test every new style  and intuitive sense of what strong women want have already made him a favorite of actresses like Emmy Rossum and Rose Byrne. His dream feet, though? Gwyneth Paltrows. Shes so beautiful and she does it all, Metodiev says, going on to explain that at the end of the day its all about taking chances. Who wants to wear the same old safe thing? Not we, says T.

title: Combo Platter, Ethical Dilemma on the Side
description: We buy it, we prepare it, we order it, we think about it, we worry about it, we talk about it, we read about it, we watch TV about it, and if theres any time left over, we actually eat and digest it. Whatever your relationship to food, practically every aspect of contemporary existence is influenced by food culture. So how does it affect your ethical life? Probably more than most of us realize.

title: Threat by Turkish Premier Raises Tensions With Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Israel was wrestling on Friday with growing tensions with Turkey after the Turkish prime minister threatened to use his navy to accompany aid flotillas to Gaza and to challenge Israels plans for gas exploration and export in the Eastern Mediterranean.

title: Letting Vegetables Inspire a Stir-Fry
description: Few dishes are as simple as the stir-fry, which just requires some basic chopping, a few seasonings and a hot pan. As Martha Rose Shulman explains in this weeks Recipes for Health, the vegetables on sale at the farmers market can inspire variations on the recipes offered here.

title: A Chicago Market of Food and Fashion
description: EVERY summer in Chicago, most neighborhoods put on their own street fair, with generally the same mix of homogeneous items: cheap sunglasses, tacky art, deep-fried food and music by local bands. But recently, a new concept  lets call it the curated flea market  has caught on, thanks to the introduction this year of Dose Market by a group of young and intrepid media and style experts.

title: Hotel Review: The Langham in London
description: UPSHOT

title: A Bit of Switzerland in Wisconsin
description: MY wife and I hitched our bikes to the rack at the trailside picnic shelter and unloaded our lunch: landjger and mettwurst sausages; blocks of aged Cheddar and Swiss cheese; a cookie assemblage, including pfeffernusse and nut horns; and two cold bottles of lager.

title: Snooki Slept Here. So Did I.
description: THE Jersey Shore did not get the worst of Hurricane Irene, though the storm left its mark. Boarded-up shops and houses, battered dunes, broken trees and buckled hunks of boardwalk provided a jarring tableau of pleasure aborted.

title: In Mumbai, Glamour Shopping at the Waterfront
description: High-end spa products, evening gowns and designer caftans are just some of the finds in this seaside enclave.

title: Letters: Elite in Coach, for a Fee
description: To the Editor: Regarding Elite for a Day, in Coach, for a Fee (Practical Traveler, Sept. 4), I have no desire to be fawned over, or need to impress. How about a flat fee of $100 for a civil flying experience? Reasonable legroom, checked bags, no being bounced, short security lines  basically, all the services we used to take for granted. Joshua P. Hill

title: Digging in Colorado (but Not for Gold)
description: ON a sunny Saturday morning in July, a group of nearly two dozen gathered at the foothills of the Arapaho National Forest in Colorado, in one of the many scenic areas between Denver and Vail. They might have easily been mistaken for typical hikers if not for their accouterments: baskets filled with small waxed bags, pocket knives and paintbrushes of varying sizes. Soon, the group dispersed into the woods alongside the rocky trail, on a hunt for fungi. These were people interested in mycology, the study of mushrooms.

title: The Jersey Shore
description: Where reality television meets reality.

title: High-Class Problem: Sudden Money
description: In this weeks Your Money column (and in an accompanying slideshow), Nadia Taha and I catalog many of the ways that athletes run into financial trouble and what we can learn from them.

title: The World (or Some Interesting Parts) Under One Scottish Roof
description: The National Museum of Scotland recently reopened in Edinburgh after a 46.4 million (about $75 million) refurbishment, with 16 new galleries. This multidisciplinary museum, with four million objects in its collection, was founded in 1866 with the goal of showing all the world under one roof.

title: Frankfurt Motor Show
description: More than 100 new vehicles, including the Audi Urban Concept, are expected to be unveiled in Frankfurt.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 1

title: State Heeds Minor Parties on Voting-Machine Complaint
description: New York States minor parties scored a major victory Thursday when the states Board of Elections agreed to alter a vote-counting anomaly that the parties argued was a threat to their very survival.

title: N.F.L. Season Opener Kicks Off NBCs Ratings
description: While the final outcome of the National Football League season opener on Thursday between the Green Bay Packers and the New Orleans Saints was in doubt until the end, what was never in doubt was the ratings dominance the N.F.L. would give NBC. (The Packers ultimately won the game, 42-34.) According to Nielsen estimates, an average of 27.2 million total viewers tuned in for the game. It was the second-most-watched N.F.L. opener of all time, trailing only last seasons Brett Favre-enhanced contest between the Minnesota Vikings and The Saints. CBS, which was led by Big Brother at 9 p.m. with 6.5 million viewers, came in far behind NBC for second place among the broadcast networks.

title: From 9/11/2001 to 9/11/2011 and Beyond
description: Sept. 11, 9:53 a.m. | Updated For me, like anyone either physically close to the Sept. 11 attacks or linked to them by losses of loved ones or friends, the anniversary elicits a flood of thoughts and feelings.

title: Replacing Panic With a Sense of Pride
description: Robert Moir, 42, joined Merrill Lynch in 1997. On Sept. 11, 2001, he was a business manager for NASDAQ Trading. He is now a managing director and chief operating officer of the Americas cash equity sales and trading at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

title: Really Big Bands
description: If youre gonna play music, play it big  in size, sound or influence  and dress big in the falls loudest pieces. That was the lesson learned at Bonnaroo, the festival in remote Tennessee, where our team at T Magazine photographed Deerhunter, Florence & The Machine, Gogol Bordello and the Scissor Sisters to name a few.

title: Your Head Belongs to You
description: Ive been going to the same hairstylist for seven years. When she took her vacation this summer, I tried another stylist in the salon. My hair has never looked better! The cut, the color, even the little massage at the end were vastly superior with the new girl. Is it possible to make a permanent switch, or would that be too disloyal to my original stylist? How do I maneuver it? And why do I feel like Im cheating?

title: Keeping Score: Lees Value to Phillies Can Be Measured in Zeros
description: Cliff Lee, the left-handed Philadelphia Phillies starter, is on quite a tear. In August he was 5-0 with a 0.45 earned run average in 39 2/3 innings. And it was not even his best month this season: in June he was also 5-0, with three shutouts and a 0.21 E.R.A. in 42 innings.

title: On 9/11, the Seeds of the Infinite Grapevine
description: One of the last times I remember actually waiting for film to be developed was in mid-September 2001. I was a college student living in downtown Manhattan, and had taken dozens of photographs from the roof of my dorm, where I watched the World Trade Center collapse, and then from ground zero and Union Square, where I spent most of the next day. When I ran out of film, I dropped it off at a storefront on Waverly Street and waited.

title: The Ethical Dilemmas of Eating

title: Russia Identifies Defect in Rocket That Crashed
description: MOSCOW  A Russian commission has pinpointed a clogged fuel pipe as the reason a Soyuz rocket crashed into a forest in Siberia last month before it reached orbit, but the panel offered no guidance on when this type of rocket would again be considered ready for manned missions.

title: Rwanda Lays Out Charges Against Ex-Presidential Hopeful
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  The Rwandan government on Friday presented its charges against a former presidential aspirant in a highly anticipated trial, accusing her of denying the nations genocide, spurring divisionism and working with a terrorist group, among other charges.

description: BCBG Max AzriaDesigners: Max and Lubov AzriaDate and Location: Thursday, Lincoln Center, StagePhotos: slide show

title: To Earn an A, Set the Alarm Clock Early
A Boys Bar Mitzvah Lessons Bridge a Cultural Chasm
description: Right on time for his 3 p.m. appointment, Sam Botwin climbed the stairs of Dave Halls row house in Brooklyn, making his way to the rehearsal room on the second floor. There he stood at a makeshift lectern in his baggy shorts and floppy shirt and mop-top hair, a boy of 13, and began to read from a speech about the Jewish martyrs of Masada.

title: Hot Times in Monza as Vettel and Hamilton Battle
description: MONZA, Italy  There is a microclimate here in Monza, it seems, as the weather feels as if were still in the midst of a summer heat wave. But things dont change at the front of the grid all that much. Again, the battle lines at the Italian Grand Prix appear to be drawn between Sebastian Vettel of Red Bull and Lewis Hamilton at McLaren Mercedes. Vettel was fastest in the afternoon practice session on Sunday; Hamilton was fastest in the morning.

title: In Chevrolet Equinox, Engine Revs Are Muted With Headphone Technology
description: The noise-canceling technology that typically goes into audio headphones has found application at General Motors. The same principles are applied to mask unpleasant engine noises produced by the Chevrolet Equinox crossover S.U.V. at low engine speeds and is expected to appear in other G.M. vehicles in coming years.

title: Protesters Topple Wall Outside Israels Embassy in Cairo
description: As Reuters reports, Egyptian protesters demolished a wall protecting the Israeli embassy in Cairo on Friday, following a rally demanding a quick transition to civilian rule.

description: THE human mind deserves any number of admiring adjectives. But given its flair at misremembering the past, misjudging the present and misforecasting the future, prescient and precise are not among them.

description: On the cover of this Sundays Book Review, David Frum reviews Thomas L. Friedman and Michael Mandelbaums new book, That Used to Be Us, an in-depth examination of Americas grim economic situation  and the steps that could be taken to help the country improve.

title: A Last Sweep of the Gown

It was a nod to the retro fashion Ms. Bryant has become known for as the Emmy-award winning costume designer for the television show Mad Men. Ms. Bryant also wore a strapless white silk chiffon gown she described as almost modern Grecian. But the dresss maker was a name also synonymous with a bygone era in American glamour  Priscilla of Boston.

title: Murray Defeats Isner
description: You know what hes going to do, man, Andy Murray nagged at himself as his first set against John Isner was knotted at 5-5, lurching toward a seemingly inevitable tiebreak.

Along the way, meet the Fletchers, a family of surfer outlaws; the actress Emilia Clarke, who is more than a sex symbol; and King Krule, a teenage musician. See more from the issue >>

Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, White House correspondent Jackie Calmes, chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris and Politics Editor Richard Stevenson join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: At Indochine the Buzz Just Keeps Buzzing
description: SAYING that Andy Warhol ate at a restaurant is like saying that George Washington slept there. Warhol has been gone that long. It would pretty much require the rest of the allotted space here to list the number of eating establishments that have gone to the restaurant graveyard over the decades since the artist died in 1987, and so we will focus instead on one of the rare survivors, Indochine.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: Justine Henin
description: Thomas Lin makes the case for Justine Henin against Steffi Graf.

title: For Isner, Tie-Breaker Goes the Other Way
description: Well, so much for that.

title: Northeast Flooding
description: Overflowing rivers continued to tumble into roadways and neighborhoods across the Northeast.

title: Readers Respond to Bill Kellers Last Column
description: Bill Kellers last column for the magazine generated plenty of conversation.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy: Steffi Graf
description: Lynn Zinser makes the case for Steffi Graf against Justine Henin.

title: Sarah & Robert
description: In this video Sarah Swanson recalls meeting Robert who wasn't like the other guys buying her drinks at the bar.

title: Guitars, a Federal Raid and a Jobs Speech
description: If President Obama was concerned that Republican threats to play hooky during his job speech Thursday night would result in a shortage of disgruntled faces in Congress, he neednt have worried. On Thursday night, House Republicans hosted 13 business people to drive home the myriad ways in which they say that federal regulations are destroying American jobs.

title: Financial Lessons From Sports Stars Mistakes
description: Michael Vick will take the field on Sunday wearing the uniform of the Philadelphia Eagles, who took him in after his imprisonment for helping to run a dogfighting ring.

title: When Athletes Go Broke
description: A look at professional competitors who lost the millions of dollars they earned in sports.

title: Pigeon Portraiture
description: The photographer Andrew Garn has spent years trying to get as close to the much-loathed pigeon as possible, and the results have been gallery-quality work.

title: Latest Update: Lede Blogger Moves On
description: Readers will be relieved to learn that I am not, in fact, going to live blog my last hour at the helm of The Lede, but I did want to briefly explain that Im moving on.

title: Perspectives on Sept. 11
description: Three exhibitions offer different but complementary ways to reflect on the Sept. 11 attacks and the aftermath.

title: Nadal Defeats Roddick
description: Second-seeded Rafael Nadal erased the last American from the 2011 U.S. Open mens singles draw with a 6-2, 6-1, 6-3 victory that put the Spaniard in the semifinals for the fourth time in four years.

title: Jamie Mitchell, James Reme
description: Jamie Lynn Mitchell and James Vincent Reme were married Saturday in a gazebo at the beach in Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Catherine Cook Davis, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Kimberly Ward, Ross Green
description: Kimberly Anne Ward and Ross Terence Green were married Saturday evening at the Westin Riverfront, a hotel in Avon, Colo. The Rev. Susan Wayne, a minister of the Chaplaincy Institute, officiated.

description: Janis Dionne McDavid and Clarence Alvin Smith were married Friday evening at the Gassaway Mansion, an event space in Greenville, S.C. The Rev. Leon Jenkins Jr., a Baptist minister, officiated.

description: Lindsey Lund Mortensen and Hrishikesh Chandra Hirway were married Saturday evening at Korakia Pensione, a bed-and-breakfast in Palm Springs, Calif. The bridegrooms sister, Priya S. Hirway, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated with Brian L. Mortensen, the brides brother, participating.

description: Logan Blair Rich and C. Scott Chabina were married Saturday evening at Fresh Meadow Country Club in the Village of Lake Success, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated.

description: Breanna Lind Hawes, the daughter of Tammy L. Constancio of Brea, Calif., and Taylor L. Hawes of Redmond, Wash., was married Saturday afternoon to Eliahu Jordan Schultz, the son of Sheri and Howard D. Schultz of Seattle. Town Justice Barbara L. Wilson of Southampton, N.Y., officiated at the summer home of the bridegrooms parents in East Hampton, N.Y. Later, Phillip Rothman, the executive director of the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York, led a Jewish ceremony.

description: Holly Elizabeth Ensign-Barstow, a daughter of Susan Ensign and James F. Barstow of Oakland, Calif., was married Saturday evening at her parents weekend house in Boonville, Calif., to Samuel Twining Globus, the son of Dorothy Twining Globus and Stephen E. Globus of Manhattan. Jonathan Blatteis, a friend of the brides family, who was temporarily named a deputy marriage commissioner by Alameda County, Calif., officiated.

title: College for Illegal Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kay Tidwell, Richard Daniels
description: Kay Lee Tidwell and Lt. Cmdr. Richard Thomas Daniels were married Saturday at the Admiral Kidd Club, an event space in San Diego. The Rev. Dr. Edward E. Jayne, a retired Navy chaplain and a Methodist minister, led the nondenominational service.

title: Deborah Muller, Branden Fisher Jr.
description: Deborah Anne Muller, a daughter of Vicki M. Muller and Gordon Muller of Weston, Conn., was married in Washington Saturday to Branden McCormack Fisher Jr., the son of Tamyra T. Fisher and Mr. Fisher Sr. of Terrace Park, Ohio. The Rev. Sarah Duggin, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Johns Episcopal Church, Georgetown Parish.

title: Eliza Stamps, Ethan Covey
description: Eliza Lipnack Stamps, a daughter of Jessica Lipnack of West Newton, Mass., and the late Jeffrey Stamps, was married Saturday evening to Ethan Hopkins Covey, a son of Marcy Smith Covey and Laird P. Covey of Poland, Me. Ion Sokhos, a friend of the couple who received a one-day solemnization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated at the home of the brides mother.

title: Aliza Melley, Nicholas Madden
description: Aliza Nicolina Melley, the daughter of Nancy E. Southard and Steven M. Melley, both of Rhinebeck, N.Y., was married Saturday to Nicholas Edward Madden, a son of Christine C. Madden and J. Kevin Madden of Purchase, N.Y. Cynthia Kilburn, a Vermont justice of the peace, officiated at the Equinox Resort in Manchester, Vt.

title: Julia Kidder, Charles Kulwin
description: Julia Malone Kidder, a daughter of Judith Malone and Stephen W. Kidder of Belmont, Mass., was married Saturday evening in Cambridge, Mass., to Dr. Charles Glen Kulwin, a son of Dr. Elizabeth H. Brown and Dr. Dwight R. Kulwin of Cincinnati. The Rev. Victor H. Kazanjian Jr., an Episcopal priest and the dean of intercultural education and religious and spiritual life at Wellesley College in Wellesley, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard.

title: Sara Levine, Zack Rosenblum
description: Sara Block Levine, a daughter of Shelley Block and Lee Levine of Chevy Chase, Md., was married Saturday evening to Alvin Isaac Rosenblum, the son of Candice Sutton Rosenblum and Howard Walder Rosenblum of Mandeville, La. Rabbi Peter Hyman officiated at the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay in Cambridge, Md.

title: Genlson Brando and Mark Lenhart
description: Genlson Brando and Mark Sibley Lenhart were married Saturday at their summer home in Provincetown, Mass. Joseph T. DeMartino, a minister of the Universal Life Church, officiated.

title: Chen Zhang and Kent Cheng
description: Chen Zhang, a daughter of Yini Zhu and Huiming Zhang of Livingston, N.J., was married in New York Saturday evening to Kent Yee Cheng, a son of Nina Cheng and Bill Cheng, also of Livingston. Gerald Fierst, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at Cipriani Wall Street, an event space in New York.

title: Judith Andiman, James Pagnam
description: Judith Aliza Andiman and James Thomas Pagnam were married Saturday at Sankaty Head Golf and Beach Club in Nantucket, Mass. John Downey, a retired judge of the Connecticut Superior Court in New Haven, officiated with the assistance of Rabbi William Cutter.

title: Lauren Lefton, Paul Resnek
description: Lauren Meredith Lefton, a daughter of Rochelle S. Lefton and David Lefton of San Antonio, was married Saturday evening to Paul Benjamin Resnek, the son of Barbara Resnek and Frank M. Resnek of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl officiated at Temple Beth-El in San Antonio.

title: Allison Kupfer and Daniel Poteet
description: Allison Macy Kupfer and Daniel Charles Poteet were married Saturday afternoon at the Claremont Hotel in Southwest Harbor, Me. Linda Martin, a Maine notary public, officiated.

title: Ali Rosof, Andrew Fedder
description: Ali Renee Rosof, the daughter of Patricia J. F. Rosof and Alan H. Rosof of Manhattan, was married Monday to Andrew Scott Fedder, a son of Linda S. Fedder and Dr. Marc F. Fedder of Lexington, N.C. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Laura Weidman, Michael Powers
description: Laura Elizabeth Weidman and Michael Parker Powers were married Saturday. Judge Jody Adams of the Family Court of New York officiated at the Wlffer Estate Vineyard in Sagaponack, N.Y.

title: Robin Steinberg, David Feige
description: Robin Gail Steinberg and David Lawrence Feige were married Saturday evening at the Bronx Borough Courthouse. Rabbi Marc Margolius officiated.

title: Theodore Kaplan, Henry Tobin
description: Theodore Nalitt Kaplan and Henry David Tobin were married Friday afternoon in their garden in Northport, N.Y. George J. Doll Jr., the mayor of the Village of Northport, officiated.

title: Lauren Hill, Jonathan Patrick
description: Dr. Lauren Marie Hill, a daughter of Catherine R. Hill and Dr. Robert B. Hill of Hockessin, Del., was married Saturday to Dr. Jonathan Edward Patrick, a son of Joan Patrick and Robert A. Patrick of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Richard G. Malloy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Josephs Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: Emily Janney, Nicholas Elliot
description: Emily Phipps Janney, the daughter of Lynn B. Janney and Stuart S. Janney III of Butler, Md., was married Saturday to Nicholas Thomas Elliot, the son of Martine Aubin of Knysna, South Africa, and Dr. Michael S. Elliot of Cape Town. The Rev. Dr. James L. Haddix, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Pot and Kettle Club, a private club in Bar Harbor, Me.

title: Michelle Guest, Peter Carter
description: Michelle Rachel Guest and Peter Smathers Carter were married Saturday at the Golden Gate Club in San Francisco. Alan F. Neckritz, a friend of the brides family who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Susan Resley, David Shalleck
description: Susan Diane Resley and David Shalleck were married Saturday afternoon at Old St. Hilarys, an event space and former church in Tiburon, Calif. Irene Kane, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Heather Miles, David Lombino
description: Heather Elizabeth Miles and David Albert Lombino were married Friday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Washington Depot, Conn. The Rev. Matthew Kappalumakkel officiated. On Saturday afternoon, the Rev. Edward J. Hanrahan, another Roman Catholic priest, performed a wedding mass at the home of Jill F. Lloyd and Michael A. Lloyd, who are friends of the bridegrooms family, also in Washington Depot.

title: Amanda Talbott, Joshua Schuler
description: Amanda Danielle Talbott and Joshua Benjamin Schuler were married Saturday aboard Fireball, a Fire Island ferry. James Mallot, the mayor of Ocean Beach, N.Y., officiated.

title: Colleen Newman, David Silk
description: Colleen Patricia Newman and David Robertson Silk were married Saturday afternoon in Hoboken, N.J. Msgr. Robert S. Meyer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at SS. Peter and Paul Church, where he is pastor.

title: Michelle Bright, Devin Lyons-Quirk
description: Michelle Ashley Bright and Devin Lyons-Quirk were married Saturday at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park in Escondido, Calif. Officiating was Patricia A. Labosky, an aunt of the bride, who was designated a deputy marriage commissioner by San Diego County.

title: Kate Barbera, Bryan McShane
description: Kate Lindsay Barbera and Bryan Patrick McShane were married Saturday at St. Bernards Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. William F. Feus, the churchs rector, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. James C. L. Arimond, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Robin Rosenbloom, Darin Goldman
description: Robin Gail Rosenbloom and Dr. Darin Ryan Goldman were married Saturday evening at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Dennis G. Shulman officiated.

title: Starting New York Cool, Ending Atlanta Hot
description: The hottest artist in the world! DJ Esco shouted from the S.O.B.s stage Wednesday night, teasing the impending arrival of the Atlanta rapper Future. He repeated it a couple of times for emphasis, but maybe also because not everyone in the room was paying attention. They were milling about, probably wondering why they were so alone.

title: Laura Quist, Daniel Ponickly
description: Laura Zoe Quist and Daniel Joseph Ponickly were married Saturday evening at a farm in Fairbanks, Alaska, that is owned by the brides family. Christopher L. Quist, the brother of the bride, who was appointed a marriage commissioner for the day by the State of Alaska, officiated

title: Women With Wrenches
description: ON most days, Katlyn Hershman can be found smeared with grease, plying her skills as a mechanic at Bike Works NYC, a shop on the Lower East Side. When she answers the store phone, though, all that toil and expertise can suddenly seem invisible.

title: The Limits of Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviewing the BMW 1 Series M
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the BMW 1 Series M Coupe, which had its formal debut at the Detroit auto show in January.

title: Obamas Message to Congress on Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: This Sunday: What Does Alec Baldwin Have to Do With 9/11?
description: A friend who saw a copy of this weeks issue shortly after it arrived in our office remarked that it was a relief not to see another 9/11 image. I understood what she meant, but that was not our intention, nor was it a reflection of how I personally feel. In fact, Ive been surprised by how absorbed Ive been in the coverage of the 10th anniversary, particularly some of the excellent stories Ive listened to in the morning on WNYC radio.

title: In Indochine, a New York Mainstay for the Fashion Elite
description: Drawing a fashionable, artsy, loyal crowd since the 1980s, the buzz surrounding the restaurant Indochine is not about the food.

title: Florida Museum to Hold On to Disputed Painting
description: Federal officials have ordered a museum in Tallahassee, Florida, not to return a painting on loan from Italy because it may have been stolen by the Nazis during World War II, the head of the museum said.

title: Atlanta Cheating Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuban Coffee and True Blood
description: The designer Narciso Rodriguez says that preparing his runway show for fall fashion week is like taking a stress test on a treadmill. It even ruins a few of his Sundays, otherwise languorous, unstructured days dedicated to things like eating Cuban food and sipping red wine. Mr. Rodriguez, 50, has a minimalist aesthetic and a lengthy list of celebrity clients that includes Michelle Obama, Julianna Margulies and Kate Winslet. He lives in a penthouse in Chelsea with his partner, Thomas Tolan, an advertising executive, and their three dogs, a Chihuahua and two Yorkies. They also have a country house in Westchester County.

title: Police Investigating Finances of Man Left in Suitcase
description: After she was charged with improper burial for stuffing her dead roommate into a suitcase and leaving his body behind an abandoned building in the Bronx  topped by a handwritten sign saying Rest in Peace  Monique Exum told detectives in the Bronx that she did not report his death for fear of being punished for it.

title: Obama Jobs Plan Would Boost the City, Comptroller Says
description: President Obamas plan to temporarily cut payroll taxes in half would yield big benefits in New York City, if Congress passed it as proposed, the city comptrollers office said on Friday.

title: Magazine Covers on a Topic Known All Too Well
description: Choosing the right magazine cover is a challenge in any ordinary week. But capturing the right sentiments surrounding the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks presented questions more fraught and delicate than most.

title: Remembering P.S. 2
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Ways to Look Back, None Easy
description: Many people assured us that we would never forget, and they were right. The attacks of Sept. 11 were the most extensively witnessed and recorded events in history, a spectacle, as the hijackers intended. The towers exploding against the crystalline blue sky, the white dust cascading, the panicked office workers  these are all seared in collective memory.

title: Cold Hands, Warm Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tighter, Lighter, Smaller Mahler
description: The Orchestra of St. Lukes, now comfortably settled in its new home at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music, is understandably intent on showing off the buildings flexible, freshly renovated performance spaces. For its first offering of the season, on Thursday evening at the centers Jerome Robbins Theater, the orchestra fielded its core musicians  the St. Lukes Chamber Ensemble, 14 players strong  for a centenary commemoration of the premiere of Mahlers hefty orchestral song cycle, Das Lied von der Erde.

title: Podcast: The Economy, Manufacturing and Commercialized College Life
description: The economy has been slowing and unemployment in the United States is stuck at 9.1 percent. President Obama has come up with a program that he says will help.

title: Using a Side Suit to Control Trumps
description: If you asked bridge aficionados to name the three greatest players of all time, Benito Garozzo would be on almost everyones list. Born in Italy but a United States resident for many years, Garozzo had his 84th birthday on Monday.

title: Flooding Brings New Wrinkle to Fracking Report
description: The floods in upstate New York are raising new concern about plans for natural gas drilling in New York.

title: For Banks, Unfortunate Echoes of 2008
description: THREE years ago, financial stocks tumbled as worries about the health of the banking system grew. By Sept. 12, indexes of financial stocks were down 28 percent from the end of 2007 in both the United States and Europe.

title: Day 2: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 9.

title: Protest of Thousands in Cairo Turns Violent
description: CAIRO  A demonstration that brought tens of thousands to this citys central Tahrir Square turned violent on Friday, when thousands of people  led by a heavy contingent of soccer fans  tore down a protective wall around the Israeli Embassy, while others defaced the headquarters of the Egyptian Interior Ministry.

title: Super Fly Musical Struts a Step Closer To the New York Stage
description: Could blaxploitation meet Broadway? Its an obvious question that comes up with news that Bill T. Jones, the director and choreographer, will spend three weeks next month developing Super Fly: The Musical in New York.

title: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
description: What do a councilman, a comedian and a catcher named Jesus have in common?

title: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Steffi Graf vs. Justine Henin
description: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? Its up to you to decide, with a little help from The Timess tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will be the champion of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

title: They Messed With Texas
description: A funny thing happened at the Republican debate at the Reagan Library in California on Wednesday night, when the evenings co-moderator Brian Williams asked a question of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. (Not funny ha-ha, funny peculiar.) Lets go right to the video.

title: An iPhone Case for Tiny Hands
description: Most toddlers, being the intelligent creatures they are, like to mimic adults. Give them a toy cellphone to play with, and they demand yours instead. But who wants to put their mobile device in the hands of a 2-year-old?

title: Some Crazy Colors
description: As she made the rounds of shows today wearing purple and scarlet, Linda Fargo, the fashion director for Bergdorf Goodman, seemed to signal her commitment to a crazily colorful spring. Some designers parading their collections this Fashion Week were just as dedicated to a brash new palette: Peter Som offering exuberant mashups of pink and teal: BCBG splicing bright tones into otherwise subdued silks; and Jason Wu unveiling a party frock in raucous caution yellow. Complementing those hues, or clashing with them outright, were hairstyles streaked, in some cases, with fuchsia or aquatic green. Can full-on psychedelia be far behind?

title: Killed on Sept. 11, 2001, but Destined to Be Mourned Only Quietly, Only by a Few
description: Three deadly weapons struck down their victims in New York City on Sept. 11, 2001. Two were hijacked jets. The third was a .40-caliber pistol on a dark corner of Brooklyn, with just 18 minutes remaining in that day.

title: Teenage Immigrant Dreams in the City
description: EVERYBODY has The Outfit  the outfit they bought for America, Brooke Hauser writes in The New Kids: Big Dreams and Brave Journeys at a High School for Immigrant Teens (Free Press).

title: Smoke Signals
description: I.

title: A Play That Will Not Come to Dust While Its a Troupes Lucky Charm
description: Cymbeline, which opened at the New Victory Theater in January, reopened on Thursday night at the Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village; (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantleys review, which appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 18; the full text is available here.

title: Netherlands: Lebanon Tribunal Will Weigh Trial in Absentia
description: The United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the killing of Lebanons former prime minister, Rafiq Hariri, and 22 others, has formed its first trial chamber, even though the four Hezbollah members indicted in the case remain at large. A panel of three judges, from Switzerland, Lebanon and Australia, are to decide whether to go ahead with a trial in absentia anyway. The court, which follows Lebanese law, is based near The Hague.

title: Trinity Church Calls; Composers Respond
description: In the days leading up to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, on Sunday, Bach, Brahms, Mahler and their ilk have once again been pressed to serve, their historically distant, emotively durable works lending voice to public expressions of grief in manners broad enough to enfold diverse beliefs and perspectives.

title: Making the Most of the Very Least, and Other Lessons
description: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star is the tale of a small-town boy from Iowa, with a Prince Valiant haircut, a bad overbite and big dreams, who comes, like so many other small-town dreamers, to the San Fernando Valley to become a pornographic film star. There he meets a bunch of other performers who seem to be desperate for work and willing to submit to unimaginable degradation for a chance to appear on the big screen.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 9
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include treasure hunting on the beach, flooding in New York and New Jersey, and the first day of school.

title: Deal May Be Near in L.I.U. Strike
description: A faculty strike that disrupted the first week of school at Long Island University could come to an end on Monday, both sides said Friday after a new round of negotiations produced the outlines of a deal.

title: Chock-Full of Gator Bait, Most of It Human
description: On television the backwoods are a trendy place to hang out lately, what with shows like Swamp People on History and Hillbilly Handfishin on Animal Planet. At the movies, though, the boggy undergrowth is apparently still where young people go to be eaten by strange beasts, as we learn from Creature, a long-on-gore, short-on-brains horror film that opened on Friday.

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: The man who rebuilt Cantor Fitzgerald after 9/11, continuing economic turmoil in Europe, doctors who add an M.B.A. to their credentials and more.

title: A Movie About Scandalously Familiar Politicians
description: TORONTO  Its probably not our best moment in politics, offered George Clooney, who was on a stage at the Toronto International Film Festival on Friday being asked about the message of his movie, The Ides of March. The films take on American democracy left some viewers here feeling stunned, if not disillusioned.

title: A Jam Band Plays, and Occasionally a Song Even Breaks Out
description: Every now and again during its energetically sprawling two-part show at Brooklyn Bowl on Thursday night, Umphreys McGee outlined the clear parameters of a song. Typically this involved Brendan Bayliss, the bands lead singer, delivering gauzy lyrics in his thin, nearly featureless voice. Often it felt faintly dutiful, in stark contrast to the urgency and unpredictability of the bands instrumental outflow.

title: Hackers Take Over NBC Twitter Account
description: A Twitter account belonging to NBC News was hacked on Friday evening by an entity that claimed, falsely, that an airplane had crashed at the site of ground zero in New York.

title: Deal Reached on Dialysis for Immigrants
description: ATLANTA  Twenty-one illegal immigrants will continue to receive regular dialysis at no cost for three years under an agreement disclosed Friday by Atlantas public hospital, Grady Memorial, and the worlds largest dialysis provider, Fresenius Medical Care.

title: Ethiopia Calls for Aid Corridors to Protect Food for Somalia
description: Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia called on Friday for the creation of corridors of humanitarian assistance in neighboring Somalia to ease the delivery of life-saving aid. A famine is steadily spreading across southern Somalia but the Shabab, a militant Islamist group, has been blocking many aid groups from reaching starving people. United Nations officials seemed cool to the idea of establishing humanitarian corridors, which can be a pretext for military intervention.

title: Wordless Vocals and a Complex Whisper
description: Wild Flag

title: Womens Scheduling Draws Criticism
description: Vocal complaints lodged by several top mens players about scheduling at the 2011 U.S. Open resulted in dramatic schedule changes, giving the men more rest between matches that might have otherwise been closer together due to rain interruption earlier in the week. But while the men were appeased, the four women who had advanced to the semifinals were done few favors by the revised schedule.

title: Antitrust Suit Is Simple Calculus
description: Have you looked at your cellphone bill lately?

title: Teamwork on the Hudson
description: The Army football team practices and trains together.

title: Annals of Conference Planning
description: Two impressions:

title: The Optimism Is as Blinding as the Colors
description: The first days of Fashion Week are sort of the childrens hour, when a lot of young designers show. But dont expect bratty behavior from these kids. Theyre so nice its sickening.

title: Another Shift in Late Night?
description: Late night is undergoing what may be a long-term shift thanks to changing viewing habits, the rise of social media and the high cost of production.

title: No More Desk Potatoes?
description: JIMMY FALLON had them crying in the aisles on July 14  and he couldnt have been happier.

title: Tough Assignment for an Accidental Conductor
description: WELL before Nine Rivers, a major work by the Scottish avant-garde composer James Dillon, was given its premiere by the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra in Glasgow last November it had acquired a singular reputation. Interviewed in The Telegraph, a London newspaper, Mr. Dillon referred to his nine-part cycle as the most canceled premiere ever. Five previous attempts to mount it had been called off, casualties of its elaborate technical requirements, daunting difficulty and four-hour duration.

title: Obama Asks for $5.1 Billion in Disaster Aid
description: President Obama formally asked Congress on Friday for $5.1 billion to cover the federal cost of the response to recent natural disasters, including the tornadoes in the Midwest and Hurricane Irene. In a letter to Speaker John A. Boehner, the president wrote that the added money would help bolster the Disaster Relief Fund, which is down to less than $900 million, according to W. Craig Fugate, administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The House majority leader, Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, has said that added money for relief should be matched by budget cuts elsewhere. The administration argues that under the debt-ceiling measure enacted last month, Congress can provide the money without offsets.

title: An Efficient Move Is No Longer Saved for Clay
description: In the fourth set of his United States Open quarterfinal, Novak Djokovic sprinted forward. His opponent, Janko Tipsarevic, had placed a drop shot low, short, wide and across the court.

title: 30 Seconds With Desmond Howard
description: Desmond Howard, who was inducted to the College Football Hall of Fame in July, is one of four Heisman Trophy winners who were also named most valuable player in a Super Bowl. Howard, 41, played for five teams in 11 N.F.L. seasons, winning the Super Bowl with the 1996 Green Bay Packers. He holds the N.F.L. record for most punt return yards in a season (875) and the longest kickoff return in Super Bowl history (99 yards). Now a college football analyst for ESPN, Howard has chronicled his Michigan career in the book I Wore 21: The Legend of Desmond Howard, which will be released Saturday.

title: Stronger Cautions Backed on Bone Drugs for Women
description: Two advisory panels to the Food and Drug Administration on Friday recommended increasing the cautionary language on the product labels of bone-building drugs taken by more than five million women in the United States.

title: In July Data, Inventories Rose More as Sales Fell
description: Inventories at wholesalers rose more in July than a month earlier, bolstered by automobiles and computer equipment, as sales stagnated, the Commerce Department said on Friday.

title: Charles Dubin, Television Director, Is Dead at 92
description: Charles S. Dubin, whose career as a daring director in televisions early years stalled after he refused to answer questions before Congress about Communist involvement, then robustly rebounded as he went on to direct more episodes of M*A*S*H than anyone else, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 92.

title: Perry and Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: On Coachs Long Road to Michigan, His Marriage Provides a Compass
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Every night when either Brady or Laura Hoke finishes with tooth brushing, one makes sure to put toothpaste on the others toothbrush. It is a small sign of the bond between a couple that met in seventh grade, married in college and have thrived while hopscotching through places like Yorktown, Ind.; Kalamazoo, Mich.; and Corvallis, Ore., where lifes consistency came from the soundtrack of marching bands.

title: Life Is a Game of Doubles
description: Fort Collins, Colo.

title: Clans Battle for Control as Shabab Loses Ground
description: In Somalia, a weak transitional government is struggling to fill the vacuum left by the Shabab militant group, leaving clans and Islamist militias to battle it out.

title: The Great Melvino, or Our Mr. Brooks
description: Have you, perchance, decided  as I have  not to spend the weekend re-wallowing in 9/11 with the media? Aside from allowing Saint Rudolph, former tenant of Gracie Mansion, to trumpet once again his self-inflated heroism on that nightmare day, the worst feature of this relentlessly repeated carnival of bitter sights and memories is that it glamorizes the terrorists.

title: On Anniversary of Attack, Many New Yorkers Will Try Not to Dwell on It
description: Laurel Wells is not going to the official Sept. 11 ceremony on Sunday morning at ground zero.

title: As an Enemy Retreats, Clans Carve Up Somalia
description: DHOBLEY, Somalia  Adan Dahir Hassan sits in a bald office, wires dangling from the ceiling, handing out death sentences. Recently installed by an Islamist warlord, Mr. Hassan recalled how he had ordered a soldier who had killed a civilian, possibly by accident, to be delivered to the victims family, which promptly shot him in the head.

title: Bloggingheads: Regulating the Regulators
description: Glenn Loury, left, and Ross Levine, both of Brown University, debate the failure of financial regulators.

title: With Studio Space, Musicians Get Sneakers
description: IF it were not meant to flog sneakers, it could be a sociology experiment. In July, Converse opened a recording studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and invited musicians to use it free. Who would come? With the recording industry on life support, who in New York still wants to be a musician?

title: Lottery Numbers
Artistic Tributes on a Solemn Day
description: DUSK over The Rising, the memorial to the Westchester residents who perished during the attacks of Sept. 11, will be ushered in on Sunday evening by the plaintive strains of Samuel Barbers Adagio for Strings. The composition, considered a musical embodiment of grief, will be performed by the Westchester Philharmonic as part of the countys candlelight ceremony at Kensico Dam Plaza, in Valhalla, commemorating the 10th anniversary of the attacks.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Pipeline Spills Put Safeguards Under Scrutiny
description: DENVER  This summer, an Exxon Mobil pipeline carrying oil across Montana burst suddenly, soiling the swollen Yellowstone River with an estimated 42,000 gallons of crude just weeks after a company inspection and federal review had found nothing seriously wrong.

title: Two Decades of Spills
description: Since 1990, more than 110 million gallons of crude and petroleum products have spilled from Americas pipeline network.

title: City Hall to Give Council Role in Bike-Share Program
description: The Bloomberg administration, facing unexpected resistance from the City Council over its plan to bring a large-scale public bike-sharing network to New York, agreed on Friday to hold hearings with politicians and community leaders before the program is up and running.

title: Re-envisioning Pollock, Paint-Spattered Cowboy
description: Jackson Pollock, the American painter who became famous for pouring and dripping paint on canvases in the mid-20th century, has become a tourist attraction. In Springs, up the road from East Hampton Village, you can visit the house he shared with his wife, the painter Lee Krasner, which also served as the location for the 2000 film Pollock, and buy a mouse pad or coffee mug decorated with Pollockesque drips. Nearby is Green River Cemetery, where the grave of Pollock, who died in an alcohol-related car accident in 1956, is marked by a huge boulder. And currently the Pollock experience can be enhanced with Richard Prince: Covering Pollock at Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Open Dominated by News of the Weird
description: This United States Open keeps getting weirder and weirder.

title: And the Good News Is ...
description: Finally, were coming to a consensus about whats wrong with the economy. Its us. And our bad attitude.

title: The Delicate Task of Reshaping Remnants of 9/11
description: THE three long, narrow pieces of aluminum being hosed down outside David Boyajians  studio in New Fairfield were instantly recognizable  they were about eight feet long, with the distinct corrugations of the exterior cladding that once formed the multistory gothic arches of the World Trade Center towers.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: A Burial for Victims of Flight 93
description: The families of 40 passengers and crew members who lost their lives on Flight 93 have struggled to purchase the land and raise the money to memorialize their loved ones in Shanksville, Pa.

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 9, 2011
description: Libyan rebels began what they called full-scale attacks to subdue the loyalist holdouts of Bani Walid and Surt on Friday night.

title: Mr. Banker, Can You Spare a Dime?
description: Not long ago, I received an e-mail from David Rynecki, an old friend and former colleague who left journalism a half-dozen years ago to become a small businessman. Davids firm, Blue Heron Research Partners, does research for investment professionals; he was writing to share his frustration in trying to build a business in the aftermath of the recession.

title: G.O.P. Is Cautious in Jobs Response
description: WASHINGTON  Armed with worrisome poll data and seeking to maintain the legislative upper hand, Congressional Republicans who have spent the balance of the year pouring buckets of criticism on the Obama administration are shifting to a more restrained approach as they ponder how to respond to the presidents jobs plan.

title: Get Me Rewrite: Its a Fresh Newsies
description: THE 1992 Disney movie Newsies, inspired by the 1899 newsboy strike against the publishing tycoons Joseph Pulitzer and William Randolph Hearst, was hardly a box-office smash.

title: Heroism and Resistance Amid the March of the Nazis
description: Hannah Senesh was a remarkable young woman whose short life (1921-1944) exemplified selfless bravery and idealism in the midst of the Holocaust.

title: A New Start for Libya
description: After 42 years of erratic dictatorship, it would be unrealistic to expect a smooth transition in the early days of Libyas post-Qaddafi era. There have been water and fuel shortages, episodes of vigilante justice, and power struggles among the victorious rebel forces. There are also signs of progress on military, diplomatic, economic and political fronts.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Devoted to Keeping Lobster Divers of Honduras Alive
description: La Ceiba, Honduras AT a modest clinic down a dirt road, there are rocking chairs on the front porch and a hyperbaric chamber in the front room where Dr. Elmer Meja treats deep-sea lobster divers who arrive paralyzed but walk out days later.

title: The Enlightened Rich Want to Be Taxed
description: Some of the worlds wealthiest people are calling for higher taxes on the rich. They seem to recognize that the burden of the economic downturn cannot be borne entirely by the poor and middle class.

title: Saturday: Man of Steel
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Oh boy. I like David Quarfoot puzzles. They dont come up nearly enough for my taste, but when they do, you can definitely see the youth in the entries. Fresh. Crunchy. Scrabbly. Good.

title: Violent Protest in Cairo
description: A demonstration that brought tens of thousands to this citys central Tahrir Square turned violent on Friday.

title: They Want to Re-up
description: The end of discrimination against openly gay men, lesbians and bisexuals in the military takes effect officially on Sept. 20. As historic as that good news is, it is further burnished by word that hundreds of veterans ousted by the dont ask, dont tell policy want to rejoin military service.

title: At a 9/11 Site, a Last Funeral
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  Jerry Bingham, whose 31-year-old son was a passenger on United Airlines Flight 93 when it crashed near here a decade ago, has participated in so many memorial services for his son Mark that he can barely remember them all.

title: September on a Patio: Bring a Sweater and Enjoy
description: I LOVE to eat dinner outside in September, when mosquitoes call a general cease-fire and the sun gives way in a hurry to dusk, leaving a nip in the air. You can pull a sweater around your shoulders and linger at the table, extending the day, and the season, just a bit longer.

title: For an American in Paris, a Stern Lecture by Police and an Exploded Suitcase
description: PARIS  When the stern policeman finished his lecture, I turned to my sister, Paula, whose command of French puts mine to shame, and said, You know, its funny, for a second there, I thought he said they exploded my suitcase.

title: Syrian Protesters Call for International Protection From President Assads Crackdown
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Tens of thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Friday to call for international protection from President Bashar al-Assads crackdown on pro-democracy activists who have been trying to topple his government for more than five months.

title: Somalia: A Country Broken Into Pieces
description: Warlords and clan-based militias are creating ministates in Somalia.

title: In the Tasting Room, the Cheese Plate Evolves
description: CUTCHOGUE, N.Y.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fashion's Night Out
description: Fashions Night Out marked its third year on Thursday with an extensive turnout. Fifth Avenue suggested Times Square on New Years Eve.

title: The Goal Standard
description: This weekends issue of T: The New York Times Style Magazine includes something for soccer fans, as Tim Adams looks at Alex Ferguson, the man who built the team by which most of the rest are measured, and the photographer Max Vadukul makes him and some of his current and former players look like the sexiest team on earth. Online, Rob Hughes offers a peek inside the clubs Carrington training ground, where all those trophies were cultivated. The Arsenal and Chelsea fans among you should probably skip the articles  too painful  but T has something for you, too. Like the chance to chuckle at a photo of Wayne Rooney in a $5,000 Tom Ford overcoat. Whats more likely to be in the breast pocket: a cellphone, a Twix bar or a fancy new tortoise shell hairbrush?

title: Catching a Wave and Some Cash Off Long Island
description: LONG BEACH, N.Y.  In crisp, overhead barrels, the Quiksilver Pro New York competition concluded Friday with a display of performance surfing that highlighted both the past and the immediate future of the sport.

title: White House Plans Effort to Refinance Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is seeking to broaden access to a two-year-old refinancing program that has helped far fewer homeowners take advantage of low interest rates than initially expected.

title: Hooky-Playing Crowds and Strong Waves Energize Competition
description: LONG BEACH, N.Y.  There were plenty of reasons to be skeptical of Quiksilver Pros inaugural surfing contest in New York, among them the quality of the waves and the effects of Tropical Storm Irene, which had damaged the community and threatened to dampen the enthusiasm for the event. Indeed, the festival that accompanied the event, including skateboard, motocross and music events, was canceled.

title: Strong Waves and Crowds Energize Competition
description: Images from the Quiksilver Pro New York surfing event in Long Beach, N.Y.

title: Instead of a Runway, a Half-Pipe Ramp
description: Oil and water. Cats and dogs. Stilettos and subway grates.

title: The Fields of Our Youth
description: Sullivan Farm has been a part of Litchfield Countys fertile landscape for 170 years. Its undulating fields are dotted with corn, tomatoes, pumpkins, squash and more; the retail shop, a red barn with windows and doors trimmed in white, is the very model of a Connecticut farm store.

title: Array of Greek Dishes, Best Served Outdoors
description: GREEK restaurants in Fairfield County exist, but they are not ubiquitous. In New Canaan, Kouzina is actually a first. The name means kitchen in Greek, which implies a casual setting  an apt description of this luncheonette-style cafe, although plain would be a more accurate assessment of its interior. Weather permitting, it is much more pleasant to sit outside and enjoy the pedestrian traffic.

title: Barking Dogs and Other Threats to Backyard Diplomacy
description: AS the old saying goes, good fences make good neighbors, but as Ive found out, its more complicated than that. Is the fence on the right side of the property line? Are there any overhanging branches or roots sneaking under the fence? Is there a really annoying dog barking behind that fence?

title: From Wall Street to a Bakery
description: After working for three years as a credit underwriter on Wall Street, Tracy Silverman left the world of finance behind in 2008 and threw herself into her second career and true love: baking. She graduated in 2009 from the Institute of Culinary Education in Manhattan, apprenticed at Brownie Points Bakery in Summit, then opened her own shop, Sweet Lucys, in March in a former bank.

title: Quad Q&A: Michigan Coach Brady Hoke
description: When Brady Hoke was hired as Michigans coach, his first three congratulatory phone calls were from Tom Brady, Charles Woodson and Steve Hutchinson. Hoke has returned some swagger and bravado to the Wolverines after Rich Rodriguezs inglorious three-year stay in Ann Arbor. Hoke has talked big in promising that in Year 132 of Michigan football that everyone will be accountable, right down to the managers and grounds crew. Theres consequences for losing, he said, flatly. So who is Brady Hoke? He sat down for an extended interview during training camp about everything from his desire to work in the Secret Service, to marrying his junior high sweetheart and whether he would make Denard Robinson tie his shoes.

title: With a Bite of Fish, the Sound of the Surf
description: TWO visits in August produced two different experiences at the Dauphin Grille in Asbury Park. The first, on a patio within earshot of the surf on a busy Saturday night, earned a solid A for effort and a low C for execution. The second, in a nearly deserted dining room on a Thursday night, again earned an A for effort. But that time, execution was a solid B, sometimes rising to an A.

title: Rise of the Fallen?
description: The man was on fire!

title: Corrections: September 10
description: NEW YORK

title: Recent Pipeline Ruptures in the U.S.
description: An analysis shows that the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration is chronically short of inspectors and struggling to safeguard a transport network laced with risks.

title: For Museum and Memorial, Issues of Money and Fence-Mending Lie Ahead
description: On Sunday, 3,652 days after it was reduced to a smoldering pyre, an eight-acre patch of Lower Manhattan will finally be prepared for its ultimate purpose: remembering 2,983 people who were murdered by terrorists.

title: Titan of Tennis vs. Next Big Thing
description: The United States Open semifinal between Caroline Wozniacki and Serena Williams is a study in contrasts.

title: Setting Sail to the Barn
description: This is the time of year when projects pile up at the farm. I realize about now that most of the projects I started when the snow melted last spring either need finishing before the snow falls or can never really be completed, like cleaning the barn. Let me not depress you with a list of them. All I know is that instead of pounding posts for a new fence or cleaning up the garden, Ive been gazing idly at small sailboats for sale on the Web.

title: Turner Delivers Win for Mets, While Santana Offers Bit of Hope
description: Justin Turners arrival with the Mets this season came quickly. Although his defense has been questioned, he reaffirmed his strength at the plate, quickly setting a franchise record for consecutive games with runs batted in.

title: Bill Kunkel, an Early Chronicler of Video Games, Dies at 61
description: Bill Kunkel, who helped invent video game journalism and create the first video game magazine in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in White Lake, Mich. He was 61.

title: Crime Is Focus of Guatemala Election
description: As Guatemalans prepare to go to the polls in a presidential election, the dominant issue has been organized crime, by drug cartels and gangs, that has increasingly gripped the country.

title: Desperate Guatemalans Embrace an Iron Fist
description: COBN, Guatemala  They burned villages, killed children and, just a winding road away from here in 1982, the Guatemalan military also massacred hundreds of Mayan peasants, after torturing old men and raping young women.

title: Disney Reorganizes Its Retail Sales System
description: The Walt Disney Company said that it would reorganize its approach to mass-market retailers and named a movie distribution executive to lead the effort. The executive, Robert Chapek, formerly president of distribution for Walt Disney Studios, will take over as president of Disney Consumer Products, succeeding Andrew P. Mooney, who resigned as chairman of that division on Tuesday. Mr. Chapeks first assignment will involve working with Disneys various units to create a more consolidated way of interacting with retailers like Wal-Mart. Disney currently handles merchandising in a decentralized fashion. The companys movie studio controls DVD sales. Disney Consumer Products manages apparel, toys and publishing. Another group oversees packaged video games. That means three different Disney teams typically interface with Wal-Mart and other big-box retailers. Disneys goal is to increase efficiency by having one point of contact.

title: The American Jobs Act
description: President Obamas cost outline for spurring job growth.

title: Joseph S. Nye: Protect the Homeland
description: Joseph S. Nye reflects on his Op-Ed from Sept. 25, 2001, about the strategies needed to defeat terrorism.

title: Third City in Three Days Brings Break in Clouds
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  After three of the wettest, craziest and longest days and nights that the Yankees have endured in years, the team had to travel 2,800 miles to see something they had not seen in days.

title: Embracing the Game, Preparing for Reality
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  They were gathered here on the banks of the Hudson at Trophy Point among captured artillery, a one-of-a-kind setting for a one-of-a-kind college football moment. The speaker was First Lt. Tyson Quink, and he was here to remind the Army Black Knights of why each of them had chosen to come to the United States Military Academy, of what the Long Gray Line really meant.

title: Editorials: The Aftermath of 9/11
description: A collection of editorials traces the Times editorial boards observations and policy proposals for a shaken country and a shifting world.

title: Fearing Loss of Weiners Seat, Democrats Make a Late Push
description: Panicked Democrats are releasing a barrage of negative television advertising, turning to the national party for a cash infusion and pleading with President Obamas network of supporters for help as they confront what seemed impossible two months ago: defeat in the heavily Democratic House district last represented by Anthony D. Weiner.

title: Suns Chief Executive Quits, Calling Decision Personal
description: Rick Welts is resigning as the president and chief executive of the Phoenix Suns, only four months after becoming the most prominent sports executive to publicly say that he is gay.

description: New York

title: Off the Track in Honor of an Ill Friend
description: Lukas Verzbicas is one of only five Americans to run a mile in less than four minutes in high school, but he is more than a track star. Now an 18-year-old freshman at Oregon, he will be a medal favorite Sunday in the junior world championships  in the triathlon  in Beijing. He did not plan on riding and swimming this summer, but he made an impulsive decision on March 8.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NOTRE DAME AT MICHIGAN

title: Jordan Belson, Experimental Filmmaker, Dies at 85
description: Jordan Belson, an experimental filmmaker whose work  abstract, mutable and hypnotic  is a series of studies of color, movement and light, died on Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 85.

title: Sidney H. Asch, a Judge and a Scholar, Is Dead at 92
description: Sidney H. Asch, a New York judge with a Ph.D. in sociology who wrote scholarly works about civil liberties and made notable decisions about landlord-tenant law, employment of gay people and a mans right to get his hair cut in a womens beauty salon, died on Sept. 1 in a nursing home in North Carolina. He was 92.

title: Belgian Prevails in Quebec
description: Philippe Gilbert of Belgium, who has won 23 races this year, passed Cadel Evans, the winner of this years Tour de France, as the leader of the World Tour points ranking with a victory in the Grand Prix of Quebec. Robert Gesink made several attempts to catch Gilbert but finished three seconds behind. Levi Leipheimer was the first American, finishing fifth.

title: Quiet Bats Doom Yankees to a Loss in the Ninth
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Jet-lagged and water-logged, a weary group of Yankees finally played baseball under perfectly dry conditions Friday night. For the first time in four days, there was nary a hint of moisture in the air, but there was also scant offense.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: A selection of news from around the country.

title: Q&A: Security Expert Faults Indias Counter-Terrorism Preparations
description: Ajai Sahni is a founding member and executive director of the Institute for Conflict Management, a New Delhi-based think tank focused on counter-terrorism, as well as a member of the Council for Security Cooperation in the Asia Pacific, a pan-Asian academic group that advises governments.

title: Japan Investigates Online Posting of Obama Flight Plans
description: TOKYO  Japanese officials moved to control diplomatic damage after an air traffic controller was questioned here for posting secret American flight information on his blog, including the detailed flight plans of Air Force One last November.

title: What to Watch on Saturday
description: On a day loaded with star power, the marquee match of todays Super Duper Saturday is Serena Williams taking on the top seed Caroline Wozniacki.

title: Crime Is Focus of Guatemala Election
description: As Guatemalans prepare to go to the polls in a presidential election, the dominant issue has been organized crime, by drug cartels and gangs, that has increasingly gripped the country.

title: In Afghanistan, Unbelievable Force of Life
description: Zalmai Ahad, known professionally as Zalmai, is an Afghan photographer. Now 47, he moved to Switzerland when he was 15. He was featured on Lens in September 2009, when his work on Afghanistan was a highlight of the Visa Pour lImage photojournalism festival in Perpignan, France. He has been photographing Afghanistan for almost 10 years.

title: After Attack on Embassy, Egypt Vows a Tougher Stance on Protests
description: CAIRO  Acknowledging a credibility crisis after it allowed a mob to invade the Israeli Embassy here, the military-led transitional government said Saturday night that it would exploit a reviled emergency law allowing extra-judicial detentions as part of a new crackdown on disruptive protests.

title: Will Jets Offense Regress in 2011?
description: Chase Stuart of Pro-Football-Reference.com is weighing in on the 2011 Jets.

title: In Radio Address, Obama Says, Weve Taken the Fight to Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, President Obama called for continued vigilance against terrorist threats, but declared that Al Qaeda and other groups are no match for the character of our people, the resilience of our nation or the endurance of our values.

title: The Weekend Word: Remember
description: Todays Times

title: Facing Resistance, Rebel Assault on Key Qaddafi Loyalists Stronghold Slows
description: NEAR BANI WALID, Libya  A rebel push to take control of the loyalist holdout Bani Walid stalled Saturday after encountering resistance, with rebel spokesmen giving varying accounts of the fighting there and NATO carrying out airstrikes against the defenders.

title: Urban Forager | That Gasoline Smell? Time for Guacamole
description: I was walking recently with a friend near Stuyvesant Town, on the East Side of Manhattan, when we spied a low-lying plant, about knee-high, growing just outside an apartment building. The leaves gave off the unmistakable scent of gasoline that is characteristic of epazote. I immediately considered the culinary possibilities: guacamole, quesadillas or black-bean dip?

title: Germany Recommends Asmussen for Central Bank Post
description: MARSEILLE, France (AP)  Germanys finance minister said Saturday that he wanted his long-serving deputy to succeed Jrgen Stark, who resigned unexpectedly, on the executive board of the European Central Bank.

title: Ristretto | The Coffee Collective in Torvehallerne
description: I was recently in Copenhagen, where I took a sneak peek at the Coffee Collectives new coffee bar in Torvehallerne, a gastro-complex of modernist glass sheds that opened last week. Copenhagens amenities might be the envy of the civilized world  that airport, those parks, a network of bike paths so comprehensive and easy to use that cars are almost pointless  but until Torvehallerne, the city didnt have a central food hall.

title: A Burial for Victims of Flight 93
description: The families of 40 passengers and crew members who lost their lives on Flight 93 have struggled to purchase the land and raise the money to memorialize their loved ones in Shanksville, Pa.
