title: Small-Business Owners Respond to Obama Plan
description: President Obama, in his speech on Thursday before a joint session of Congress, promised to deploy the power of the federal government to induce small businesses to hire out-of-work Americans. But even some of the small-business owners who watched the speech live in the House chamber at the White Houses invitation said they would not be swayed by the carrots the president proposed to dangle.

title: Starkness Falls
description: Update: Via Mark Thoma, similar sentiments from Barry Eichengreen; see addendum at the end.

title: 1919 And All That
description: Sylvia Nasar has a fascinating look back at the roles Keynes and Schumpeter played in the plague year of 1919, as both in their own ways tried to protest the folly of that eras Very Serious People.

title: Photos of the Moment | Jason Wu
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#245", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Where The Big Girls Are | Rag & Bone
description: The photographer JD Ferguson gets close up on the biggest faces in fashion.

title: Are These Men the Best Ever? Making the Case
description: In the U.S. Opens mens semi-finals matches being played in Arthur Ashe today, the four best mens players will be on the court  not simply the four best of this moment, which they surely are, and by no small measure: Andy Murray, the tours fourth-ranked player, is 2,300 points ahead of fifth-ranked David Ferrer, 2,300 being more than half the points Ferrer has accumulated in the past twelve months.

title: With Vettel on Pole,  the First Female Racer Reflects
description: Every country in which Formula One has a race attracts a certain number of local residents who are not seen at other races. Phil Hill would often come all the way from the United States to visit the race at Monza, where he won the world title  as I mention in todays F1 preview. Monza also tends to attract Luca di Montezemolo, the Ferrari president who occasionally visits other races.

title: With Vettel on Pole,  the First Female Racer Reflects
description: Every country in which Formula One has a race attracts a certain number of local residents who are not seen at other races. Phil Hill would often come all the way from the United States to visit the race at Monza, where he won the world title  as I mention in todays F1 preview. Monza also tends to attract Luca di Montezemolo, the Ferrari president who occasionally visits other races.

title: Photos of the Moment | Fenton Jewelry
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#911", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: For the Poet Laureate, the Joy of Tennis Is in the Effort
description: After a summer of dispiriting headlines, one piece of news made me yelp with joy: Philip Levine was named poet laureate of the United States. I was happy because I have loved his sublime, subversive poems for years; now, more people would read his work. And I was happy because the new poet laureate loves tennis, and was a pretty good player.

title: In K.C., Nice House, but Yard Needs Work
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan.  It has been lauded as perhaps the best soccer stadium in the country, but Sporting Kansas Citys Livestrong Sporting Park has received some negative attention recently for one of its most integral parts: the grass playing surface.

title: California Lawmakers Give Amazon Tax Reprieve
description: SAN FRANCISCO  California lawmakers overwhelmingly approved a compromise bill Friday night giving Amazon.com a one-year reprieve from having to collect a sales tax from its customers in the state.

title: For Federer, Its All About Court Position
description: It is not an easy task to pinpoint exactly what makes Roger Federer so great.

title: Live Analysis: Second Saturday of September
description: Paul Myerberg will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can alsofollow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: In Seeking Statehood, Palestinians Stir Concern
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Less than two weeks before Palestinians plan to defy the Obama administration by requesting membership and statehood recognition at the United Nations, there is a growing fear that the Arab-Israeli conflict is entering an explosive new phase.

title: Ties of Tennis
description: Rich Lynch of Queens was one of the best young tennis players on the East Coast in the early 1980s. Years after his tennis career was over, on Sept. 11, 2001, Lynch found himself on the 84th floor of the World Trade Centers south tower.

title: German Nominated to Central Bank Post
description: FRANKFURT  Germany moved swiftly to install a guardian of its interests in the European Central Bank Saturday, nominating a top technocrat to replace a senior bank official whose unexpected resignation Friday hinted at divisions over the conduct of monetary policy.

title: Runway In Review
description: Jason WuDesigner: Jason WuDate and Location: Friday, Center 548, 548 West 22nd StreetPhotos: slide show

title: Variety: A Musical Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  There will be much talk of loss today even without this puzzle, so I wont belabor the point, but the quote in todays acrostic would be moving even if this wasnt the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

title: A Snapshot of the World, Hours Before It Changed Forever
description: The front page of The New York Times from Sept. 12, 2001, with its U.S. ATTACKED headline, has become one of the more widely seen images of Sept. 11 attacks.

title: The Trouble With Homework
description: Annie Murphy Paul is the author of Origins" and is at work on a new book about the science of learning.

title: Golden Spikes
description: As some readers may have guessed, Im having some fun thinking about gold price economics  nothing like a good intellectual puzzle to keep you occupied while the world collapses. Anyway, some people have asked about previous gold price fluctuations, and in particular whether my low-interest-rate story can fit with the last time gold soared.

title: A Time When Anything Was Possible
description: He was a tennis prodigy from an Irish Catholic family in Douglaston Manor, a leafy neighborhood in Queens. A gifted athlete, he swayed back and forth at the baseline before attacking the net behind a wicked left-handed serve. He played with a wooden Dunlop racket, wore Sergio Tacchini clothes and gracefully moved around the court in Nike shoes.

title: Tournament Has Suffered in This Year of the Plague
description: In this year of the deluge, the symbol of the United States Open remains the water oozing in the surface of Louis Armstrong Stadium, alongside the soggy estuary of Flushing Bay.

title: Djokovic Defeats Federer to Advance to Open Final
description: Following a script eerily similar to that of the U.S. Open semifinal the two played last year, Novak Djokovic saved two set points to defeat Roger Federer, 6-7(7), 4-6, 6-3, 6-2, 7-5, booking a spot in his second consecutive Open final.

title: Want to Inspire? Dont Sugarcoat Your Feedback
description: This interview with  Tiffany Cooper Gueye, chief executive of BELL, a nonprofit organization that assists urban children, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Florida Forces Towns to Pull Local Laws Limiting Guns
description: MIAMI  The signs  No Guns Allowed  are being stripped from many Florida government buildings, libraries and airports. And local ordinances that bar people from shooting weapons in their yards, firing up into the air (think New Years Eve) or taking guns into parks are coming off the books.

title: Lets Twist Again, Like We Did in 61
description: COME on baby, lets do the Twist.

title: In Shanksville, Thousands Gather to Honor Flight 93 Victims
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  The dedication of a memorial here on Saturday to the 40 passengers and crew members who died on United Airlines Flight 93 on Sept. 11, 2001, provided an opportunity for two former presidents to appeal for unity.

title: In Mixed Doubles, a Title for the Americans
description: In the category of unexpected Grand Slam champions, it would be hard to top the fresh-faced pair that captured the 2011 mixed doubles trophy at the U.S. Open. Nineteen-year-old Melanie Oudin and 18-year-old Jack Sock, a wild card entry playing together for the first time, beat No. 8 seeds Gisela Dulko and Eduardo Schwank of Argentina 7-6(4), 4-6, 10-8 Friday evening to give the United States its first championship of the tournament.

title: New York Fashion Week Diary | Tom Bull
description: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week. In this clip, Bull tells T about the struggles of staying in shape during Fashion Week. I really do try my hardest to eat as healthily aspossible, Bull says. It gets really hard when youre flying two nights a week and staying in hotels. Sigh.

title: Google Warns Users in Iran About Security Issue
description: Google took the unusual step of warning Gmail users in Iran to secure their accounts, a week after an unidentified hacker generated fake Web site verification certificates that may have allowed the Iranian state to monitor communications by its citizens, including dissidents.

title: Making Headway in the Movement to Protect the Worlds Sharks
description: For sharks, life at the top of the ocean food chain is becoming safer  at least from human predators.

title: Yemen Forces Are Said to Be at Taken City
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni armed forces freed a cornered military brigade and appear to be preparing to enter the city of Zinjibar, which has been under the control of Islamic militants for months, according to the official Saba news agency.

title: In Case You Wondered, a Real Human Wrote This Column
description: WISCONSIN appears to be in the drivers seat en route to a win, as it leads 51-10 after the third quarter. Wisconsin added to its lead when Russell Wilson found Jacob Pedersen for an eight-yard touchdown to make the score 44-3 ... .

title: Japanese Official Resigns Over Radiation Joke
description: TOKYO  Just over a week after he took office, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda of Japan suffered his first political setback on Saturday when the new minister of trade and industry resigned after a joke about radiation caused a public uproar.

title: Remote Control, With a Wave of a Hand
description: PLAYING a computer game once meant sitting on the couch and pushing buttons on a controller, but those buttons have been disappearing of late, replaced by human gestures that guide the action.

title: For Sanchez, a Season to Become a Presence, Not Merely Present
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  If a quarterbacks rookie year is roughly equivalent to an endless first day of school, learning playbooks and defenses instead of locker combinations and classroom assignments, then his third season is akin to his going away to college. No more pampering, no more coddling, no more excuses. For Mark Sanchez, MetLife Stadium will double as his freshman dormitory  if more than 80,000 people were paying to watch him study.

title: Uptown/Downtown
description: Friday night, after checking out a cheeky and borderline shameful Parke & Ronen runway show that suggested the male modeling industry may soon be facing its own steroid scandal, I popped over to Jason Wus afterparty at Adour in the St. Regis Hotel. After muscle-bound mutants in skimpy swimwear, it was a pleasure to see some grown-ups in evening attire. Nacho Figueras and Delfina Blaquier looked smashing, he in a sharp black suit, she in a one-shouldered black dress, standing next to a D.J. booth that was covered over with hydrangea blossoms. I almost had my appetite back when I picked up what appeared to be a mint-colored petit four, only to bite into a watercress-wrapped piece of salmon.

title: Battery Park, 8:45 A.M.
Backstage Beauty Report | Rag & Bone
description: It was really embarrassing, said Revlons Global Artistic Director, Gucci Westman, dressed in a tweed aqua blazer, baggy white pants and leopard slippers backstage at Rag & Bone. My husband (Rag & Bone designer David Neville) called and said, Where are you? We need the turquoise trousers for the show.' By accident, Westman had selected a look that made it into the final collection, instead of an edit, to wear today, a mistake that was quickly corrected. Its the strongest Spring, yet, she said explaining her excitement at the 70s surf vacation and 90s rave culture-inspired pieces. She chose a minimal makeup look, so as not to compete with the bright colors of the clothes. Eyes were simply taupe Revlon 16H shadow in Addictive with a touch of Sueded Brow liner. Cheeks were tinted with a light bronzer and blush in Tawny Peach while lips were pale pink, coated with shine and patted with powder. Personally, I dont think lip gloss is cool. What is cool and consistently Rag & Bone appears to be grey nails. Jin Soon Choi took last seasons slate to a lighter shade of concrete- Revlons Smoky Canvas or Hazy. As for hair, Guido Palau admitted the idea was effortless, though the process was anything but. Eighty percent of the New York designers want ease. It always looks glamorous, he said. To achieve this, Palau tightly braided the underside of the models hair and then added extensions for length to create the illusion of fineness. He then used Redken Satinwear all over damp hair which he dried with a Mason Pearson brush and Sultra tools. The hair was then clamped at the neck with a Velcro strap to create a bob-like effect. Ah, this explains the rave reference.

title: How to Make Business Want to Invest Again
description: DURING the last week, the nation has witnessed much partisan wrangling over the economy. So it might be worth stepping back and assessing what we know and what we dont. Lets start with five propositions about which there is little doubt:

title: Rich Tax Breaks Bolster Makers of Video Games
description: The United States government offers tax incentives to companies pursuing medical breakthroughs, urban redevelopment and alternatives to fossil fuels.

title: And Hate Begat Hate
description: Ahmed Rashid is a journalist and the author of Taliban and Descent into Chaos.

title: So Many Gadgets, So Many Aches
description: LOOK around, theyre everywhere: hunched shoulders, angled necks and wrists, hands twisted like claws. As people harness their bodies to use more electronic devices in more places, they may unknowingly be putting themselves at a greater risk of injury.

title: Name Your Price, Then Get Ready for the Fees
description: THE Haggler recently rented a car with Hertz at Logan Airport in Boston and was amazed to learn that while the vehicle would cost a reasonable-sounding $126 for the week, an assortment of fees and assessments would add $75 to the total price.

title: Friends, on and Off the Court
description: Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan and Rohan Bopanna of India discuss how friendship helps them succeed as a doubles team.

title: Clawbacks Without Claws
description: AFTER the grand frauds at Enron, WorldCom and Adelphia, Congress set out to hold executives accountable if their companies cook the books.

title: How to Read the Minds of Other Investors?

description: The architect Daniel Libeskind reflects on his Op-Ed from June 23, 2005, about his embattled master plan for rebuilding ground zero.

title: Is Manufacturing Falling Off the Radar?
description: PELLA, Iowa

title: Sleeping Barry Awakes
description: WASHINGTON

title: Getting Back to a Grand Bargain
description: THIS is not an easy time to be president or minority leader. Our cupboard is bare, and the only thing we have in surplus is political venom. Indeed, if political venom could be turned into a transportation fuel, wed be energy independent today.

title: Were Rich! (In Nature.)
description: AT a time when Americans fret about terrorism and war and are afflicted by the worst economic downturn in 70 years, lets embrace a remarkable treasure possessed by every citizen of our country.

title: Loss and Hope
description: It is painful and puzzling to look back to that day, to the chasm after the second tower fell, when we knew nothing except that fires were burning, an untold number of lives had been lost, and Lower Manhattan was gasping in a cloud of what looked like Pompeian ash. That mornings terrible events marked a border between one realm and another, a boundary none of us would ever wish to have crossed. Everything had changed  that was how it seemed.

title: Bicycle Visionary
description: SOMETHING lovely and all too rare happened to Janette Sadik-Khan, New York Citys frequently demonized transportation commissioner, as she and I rode our bikes down Park Avenue South one morning last month: Sadik-Khan got unsolicited, unfettered praise.

title: Voices from the Flood Zone
description: Homes in and around Binghamton, N.Y. were devastated by the record-high floodwaters of local rivers.

title: Many Iraqis Have Second Thoughts as U.S. Exit Nears
description: BAGHDAD  Sheik Kamal Maamouri, the leader of one of the largest Shiite-dominated tribes in Iraq, used to call the United States troops here occupiers, demanding that they withdraw because he said they killed and imprisoned innocent members of his tribe.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Helmut Lang
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#45", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Mandy Coon
description: We usually have a strong beauty concept, said the stylist Natasha Royt backstage at Mandy Coon. This time its modern, approachable, realistic, low maintenance cool. We want to let the graphic, modern clothes speak for themselves. Last seasons wig-wrapped hair and black, fringed, pastel falls turned into effortless glamour this season, according to Rolando Beauchamp. Loose waves came by way of Bumble + Bumble Gel, a blow dry, and then a one-inch curling iron wrapped at the shaft of the hair, all set with Bumble + Bumble Grooming Creme and roughed up with BB Texture for a messy, matte finish. The last step ensured that nothing was too pretty or too shiny. Coons color-blocked looks were translated into Mark Rothko-inspired, multi-step eyes at the hands of the makeup artist Francelle Daly for NARS. Lavender-grey Lhasa was the primary shadow. Im obsessed with this shade, Daly said. Its rarely used for spring/summer collections. She also added a trio of pinks with an icy tone at both corners of the eye. The Rue Bonaparte Larger Than Life Eyeliner pencil, a natural beige, was used to neutralize under the eye while white Santa Monica Boulevard lined inside. Madison Avenue grey was drawn as triangles on the outer edge of the lid. Without mascara on the bottom lashes, this all contributed to a special effect accompanied by a raspberry lip. An effect that caused one model to comment, I look like Ive been crying. Her friend countered, No, you look beautiful.

title: In Seasons Long March, Every Step Can Be Painful
description: They are young and rich, world travelers who play a gentlemans game. Hours of training outdoors have given them, men and women alike, bodies that are taut and tanned. Often exceedingly photogenic, they are the smiling faces for some of the worlds most exquisite consumer products.

title: The Commercial Campus
description: Corporations are hiring popular students to promote their brand on campus. At the University of North Carolina, American Eagle helps first-year students move-in, while Target hosts the inaugural party

title: Ferry Capsized Off Tanzania
description: Nearly 200 people drowned when an overloaded ferry capsized off east Africa as it sailed from Zanzibar to Pemba island, police said on Saturday.

title: On Campus, Its One Big Commercial
description: At colleges, the promotions are everywhere as companies use peer-to-peer marketing by students to build their brands.

title: On Campus, Its One Big Commercial

title: The Flashy Side of Prabal Gurung
description: Here is something you do not expect to see at a Prabal Gurung fashion show: Nicki Minaj, the colorful hip-hop star who gives Lady Gaga a run for her money in the outrageous attire department, making a slow entrance with John Demsey, the carefully groomed, straight-faced Este Lauder executive, and followed by an entourage of men wearing black T-shirts that said $WAG. Ms. Minaj, who will appear in a new MAC Viva Glam campaign, wore a bikini top that was half hot pink and half purple, some crazy graffiti-covered tights, a silver ballerina skirt and, in her big curly blonde hair, an iridescent pink bow that matched the chain of her necklace that had attached to it a hot pink pendant in the shape of a pretzel.

title: The New Guy at Lacoste
description: Felipe Oliveira Baptista had a nice debut at Lacoste this morning with a collection that featured womens looks largely based on rugby shirts, some cool outerwear pieces and, for men, a larger-than-usual piqu used on blazers and polo shirts that looked nice and breathable. Mr. Baptista, who is Portuguese by birth, shows his own line in Paris and took over Lacoste this season from Chistophe Lemaire, who scooted over to Herms.

title: Giants First Line of Defense Becomes Main Line of Defense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On a recent day in the Giants locker room, a crowd of reporters lingered near the wall that is defensive-line territory, and the scene was like happy hour at a bar. One segment of the horde surrounded defensive end Justin Tuck, while another hovered near the locker of Osi Umenyiora, the injured All-Pro enigma, hoping for a glimpse of him. A smattering chatted up Jason Pierre-Paul, and at the end of the row, even Chris Canty could not escape without offering a few platitudes.

title: Dress Code | Prabal Gurung
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#360", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Friends, on and Off the Court
description: The Indo-Pak Express made its last stop at the United States Open on Friday. Rohan Bopanna of India and Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan, the No. 5 doubles team, fell in the semifinals to the sixth-seeded team from Poland, Mariusz Fyrstenberg and Marcin Matkowski, 6-2, 7-6 (4).

title: Sweeping Security Effort Planned for 9/11 Events
description: To fortify New York and Washington on Sunday, federal and local law enforcement officials are piling security plans atop security plans, making it not just the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, but also a milestone in a decade-long state of alert.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Quietly, Rivera Nears an Underrated Record
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  With surprisingly little hype and fanfare given the magnitude of the achievement, Mariano Rivera is on the verge of another milestone. After he earns just a few more saves, he will take his place as the career leader in that category, a fitting honor for the man widely considered the greatest closer ever.

title: On 10th Anniversary of 9/11, Social Media Is a Forum for Reflection
Beyond Cairo, Israel Sensing a Wider Siege
description: JERUSALEM  With its Cairo embassy ransacked, its ambassador to Turkey expelled and the Palestinians seeking statehood recognition at the United Nations, Israel found itself on Saturday increasingly isolated and grappling with a radically transformed Middle East where it believes its options are limited and poor.

title: Streaks Built on Preparation, Day After Day
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Archie and Olivia Manning took their family on vacations, each of their three sons would pack cleats. The boys played catch in Hawaii and ran the beach in Destin, Fla. Days off did not exist.

title: Susquehanna Floodwaters Recede, but the Threat Remains
description: WILKES-BARRE, Pa.  As the Susquehanna River began a rapid retreat toward its banks Saturday after days of record flooding here and in parts of New York, tens of thousands of evacuated residents began a gut-wrenching return home, some finding little more than mud-caked chaos where their lives used to be.

title: Surprise Semifinalists, from Evert to Kerber
description: Because its equitable playing surface and place in the calendar present most top players with ample opportunity to succeed, the U.S. Open historically has had fewer unknowns scuttling through the draw than the other three Grand Slams.

title: So How Do We Best Experience Wilderness?
description: My favorite vacation involves backpacking in the mountains with my family  unplugged, out of contact and engaging with the most beautiful scenery in America. And thats what inspired my Sunday column: If Americas best idea is its public lands, then its an idea under assault. But while environmentalists focus on Republican efforts to reduce protections of those lands, it seems to me that an equal challenge is the way the public is withdrawing from nature. Conservation should be about preserving nature, yes, but also about giving people a chance to experience it.

title: Runway Grooming Report | Antonio Azzuolo
description: Unlike some creatives who choke under pressure, the menswear designer Antonio Azzuolo, a finalist for this years CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, gracefully eased the reins and took a more relaxed approach to his Spring/Summer collection. Mr. Azzuolo explained backstage, My first collection was very formal, all about suits. This season I designed more liberally, drawing inspiration from Les Minets, a French/British hybrid movement of mod culture. These young men shunned bourgeois culture, but still dressed up. They were rough and rebellious, but chic and sophisticated as well. Noting the designers departure from his norm of neat, the hairstylist Andre Rodman casually styled models hair with his hands and a healthy dollop of Shu Uemura Shape Paste, to enhance each guys individual hair texture. Mr. Rodman completed looks with a brisk shake of the dryer, along with lots of Oribe Dry Texturizing Spray, for a subtly messy, matte look. The makeup artist Gregory Arlt paired hair and clothes with M.A.C. products that conveyed, Healthy tired. It might sound strange, but we imagined the guys looking warm and attractive, despite their penchant for partying. Using just moisturizer (as opposed to foundation) for a base, Arlt slathered onto the models faces a yet to be released product from M.A.C.- Mineralize Charged Water Moisture Gel (hitting shelves this December). Brows were then defined and filled in with Kid eyeshadow, while lips were smoothed with lip conditioner. Lastly, he dotted on Select Moisturecover Concealer as necessary, so models looked handsome, even after that long night out.

title: Tilda Swinton Talks About Kevin
description: TORONTO  Parenting has rarely looked as painful and difficult onscreen as it does in Lynne Ramsays drama We Need to Talk About Kevin, which screened last night at the Toronto International Film Festival. The film focuses on the experience one woman (Tilda Swinton) has raising a son (Ezra Miller) who turns out to be a very, very bad seed.

title: At the Open, a Different Role for Womens Coaches (and the Players)
description: The obstacles male players face when transitioning from A.T.P. Tour events to the Grand Slams are well-documented. Best-of-three matches are traded in for best-of-five, increasing the physical and mental difficulty of winning significantly.

title: View Comments: Where Were You?
description: The New York Times asked readers to share stories, emotions and memories  tens of thousands responded on a map of the world. Browse and filter by most frequently used words and locations.

title: Nadal Beats Murray to Advance to Finals
description: Rafael Nadal of Spain applied relentless pressure on Andy Murray of Britain to win a place in the U.S. Open mens final for the second successive year with a 6-4, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2 victory on Saturday night.

title: Womans Body Found Near East Village Church
description: Word began spreading just after 9 on Saturday morning. The body of a woman had been discovered at Avenue B and East Seventh Street in the East Village.

title: De Niro Brings Casual Saturdays to Toronto Film Festival
description: TORONTO Casual chic is one thing. But did Robert De Niro go a sneaker too far?

title: N.C.A.A. Strife, and How to Ease It
description: After the N.C.A.A.s meeting last month to discuss the state of college sports, the organizations president, Mark Emmert, sounded offended when a reporter asked whether the university presidents had addressed having separate commissioners for football and mens basketball to tackle problems in a timely manner.

title: The 181st Draft Pick Becomes a Superstar
description: WASHINGTON  The OMalley family sold the Los Angeles Dodgers in 1998, but artifacts from decades of stewardship remained. One was a brochure for Dodgertown, the lavish spring training campus in Vero Beach, Fla., where Jackie, Pee Wee, Campy and the Duke once roamed. Mike Leuzinger, a longtime team scout, kept the pamphlets after the OMalleys left. He liked to show his draft picks where they would go to carry on the tradition.

title: A Breakthrough for Italy by a Player of the World
description: In the 1950s, Domenico Liddi emigrated from Italy to Southern California and found work as a tailor. He took his 2-year-old son, Agostino, and raised him in the United States.

title: On Campus, Studying the Needs of Veterans
description: Dung Mai, a student at the University of Texas at Arlington, had a hard time taking tests. He would know the material, but once he walked into class, his mind would go blank.

title: Relics of a Tribes Eviction Are Unearthed in Montana
description: ABSAROKEE, Mont.  The bitter tale of Indian-white conflict that unfolded at this spot more than a century ago was told not in blood and battle, but in the legalese and fine print of a contract.

title: Porochista Khakpour: 'My Nine Years'
description: Porochista Khakpour reflects on her Op-Ed My Nine Years as a Middle-Eastern American from September 12, 2010, and the heated response from readers.

title: 9/11: A Decade Later
description: For the tenth anniversary of 9/11, Op-Ed contributors reflect on what they wrote after the attacks.

title: G-8 Nations Pledge New Aid to Arab Spring Economies
description: MARSEILLE, France  With economies crumbling in the countries that touched off the Arab Spring, leaders of the Group of 8 industrialized nations on Saturday pledged $38 billion in new aid to help underpin the regions transition to democracy, amid complaints that hardly any money from a $20 billion aid package promised in May has materialized.

title: School Cafeterias Fruits and Vegetables Vie With Food Trucks Sweet and Salty Treats
description: On Tuesday afternoon, Edgar Cardenas, 16, stood on the curb outside Novato High School buying his lunch from a food truck that was peddling ice cream, candy, soft drinks and chips.

title: St. Patricks Cathedral, 2:53 P.M.
The Biographers New Best Friend
description: Stephen Mihm is an associate professor of history at the University of Georgia and the co-author of Crisis Economics: A Crash Course in the Future of Finance.

title: Europes Fiscal Fantasies
description: Europes leaders believe they can stave off economic disaster without taking real action. They keep pretending that they will not have to ask taxpayers to help shore up fragile banks, that ever larger doses of austerity will let weak economies like Greece pay off their debts, and that Europe can continue to reap the benefits of monetary union without the shared responsibilities of greater fiscal union.

title: No Job, No Insurance, No Health Care
description: Workers who lose their jobs in the economic downturn typically suffer a double whammy: they lose not only their incomes but their employer-based health insurance as well. Millions are forced to forgo the medical care that they cannot pay for.

title: Separating the Moment From What Came After
description: A few days after Sept. 11, 2001, I received a stack of drawings and poems in the mail. They were by schoolchildren whose teacher had given them the lead article from The New York Times about the attacks and told them to write and illustrate a poem. Because I wrote the piece, she sent them to me. Many of the children picked up on my description of the planes as gorged with fuel, and their jets were huge and red, dwarfing the doomed black towers before them. Some of the drawings also had disproportionately huge stick figures falling from the towers.

title: Housing for the Truly Vulnerable
description: The recession has made it increasingly difficult for low-income people to afford decent housing. Federal statistics show that record numbers of people now pay more than half their incomes in rent, causing them to skimp on essentials like food, medical care and other basics, and increasing the chances that they will end up homeless.

title: Mayor in Mexico Rejects Calls to Step Down
description: MEXICO CITY  The mayor of Mexicos third-largest city, where a fire set in a casino last month left 52 dead, on Saturday rejected a call days earlier from leaders of President Felipe Calderns governing party to step down amid questions over his brothers ties to the gambling industry.

title: In India, 11-Year Hunger Strike Is Waged in Shadows
description: IMPHAL, India  She arrived in an ambulance, thin and ghostly pale, a tube dangling from her nostril. Flanked by police officers, she was ushered into the judges chambers for a fortnightly ritual she has repeated hundreds of times. Was she ready to end her fast?

title: Legend of a Commander Flourishes, but Cant Bridge an Afghan Chasm
description: JANGALAK, Afghanistan  Each September, thousands of people flock to this tiny village along the rushing waters of the Panjshir River like pilgrims to a holy shrine, coming to commemorate the death of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the most celebrated hero of the Afghan resistance.

title: Sunday: Cornered
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Do you have stars in your eyes? You should, after solving todays puzzle by Kay Anderson.

title: Love and War
description: Janine di Giovanni is the author of the forthcoming book Ghosts by Daylight: Love, War, Redemption.

title: Plugged In at Last, Regretfully
description: Steven Kurutz is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Alexander Wang
description: Backstage at Alexander Wang, 3:30 pm: Liya Kebede, in black jeans and Doc Martens, is having her hair examined by Guido Palaus team. Nearby, Frankie Rayder is pulling on a black and red plaid lumberjack shirt over the plastic-bag poncho shes wearing around her neck. Its a makeshift protective cover for hair damp with product and oil. Like the look at Helmut Lang earlier today, the mandate is wet, but Alexander Wang-style, which translates into Palau using Redkens Full Frame 07 All Over Volume Mousse to coat the head and then finishing off with Argan-6 oil right before the girls go out. To get a glint in the hair, is how Mr. Palau explained the addition of the multipurpose product. He is also adding extensions where needed and uses his Sultra curling iron for a little movement. With prints hitting the collection this season, Mr. Palau wanted to be sure the hair was edgy. Pulled back can look too pretty, he said, explaining the switch from last seasons low ponytail. Today shes let her hair down. Both Mr. Palau and Diane Kendal agree that Mr. Wang has a very specific vision for his woman. Shes cool, downtown, beautiful and raw, as Ms. Kendal sees it. For makeup, this means M.A.C.s black kohl pencil blended out around the eye and then removed with M.A.C. studio moisturizer and a cotton swab, only to be reapplied thereafter. Theres nothing on the face or lip. Nails are painted with Sally Hansens natural Parchment. Ms. Kendal has done this look before circa 1990. Calvin went there, she said before also calling out Helmut Lang. No doubt Mr. Wang remembers this girl and is now making her his own.

title: Remembering a Hungry Childhood
description: Peter Kimeu is a small-scale farmer in Machakos, Kenya, and a technical adviser for Catholic Relief Services, a humanitarian organization.

title: If Obama Is a One-Term President
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: How to Really Save the Economy
description: Robert Barro is a professor of economics at Harvard University and a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution.

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country.

title: Christian Louboutin
description: Christian Louboutin is a French shoe designer known for his sexually suggestive stilettos and distinctive red soles. He has shod everyone from Lady Gaga to Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, the first lady of France. In time for Fashion Week, we asked him what he finds interesting.

title: 9/11 Recalled  The West Bank
description: I spent the early part of September 11, 2001 talking to suicide bombers, or at least the men alleged to be sending them.

title: Wounded Warriors Weekend
description: Video: Each summer Rockaway, Queens remembers 9/11, honoring veterans who served since the attack. View slide show.

title: Stosur Reaches First U.S. Open Final With Three-Set Win
description: No. 9 seed Samantha Stosur toughed out a 6-3, 2-6, 6-2 over 92nd-ranked German Angelique Kerber, becoming the first Australian woman to reach the U.S. Open final since Wendy Turnbull in 1977. It will be Stosurs first career U.S. Open final and second career Grand Slam final.

title: Mets Pitch to Ramirez and Pay a Price
description: First base was open when Chicago Cubs third baseman Aramis Ramirez, a .300 hitter, walked to the plate with runners at second and third and two outs in the ninth inning Saturday. The Mets were hanging on to a one-run lead in a game that turned from a snooze to a thriller in an instant.

title: The Ryan Boys: Loud and Clear, Mostly Loud
description: As young coaches, Rex Ryan and Rob Ryan were known as Buddy Ryans twins but now, with Rex the Jets coach and Rob the Dallas Cowboys defensive coordinator, Buddy is better known as their father. With a thud heard round the world of pro football, each of these swaggering apples fell not far from the tree.

title: Sept. 11: A Decade Later, a Day of Reflection
description: For the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, we invited readers to offer their thoughts.

title: Recalling That Day, and How It Changed Us
description: To the Editor:

title: The Daily Shoe | VPL by Victoria Bartlett
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.Tiffany Tuttle of LD Tuttle has been making innovative anti-trend shoes for the VPL show for more than a few seasons now. Here, a typical LD Tuttle silhouette  triangle heel, ankle-height cuff  done in neoprene to match that which Victoria Bartlett used in the collection on everything from swimsuits to jackets.

title: Thoughts From Jill Abramson, Executive Editor
description: ON Tuesday, Jill Abramson succeeded Bill Keller as executive editor of The New York Times, the first woman to serve as top editor since the papers founding in 1851. I spoke with her about her new post.

title: Democrats Fret Aloud Over Obamas Chances
description: Democrats are expressing growing alarm about President Obamas re-election prospects and, in interviews, are openly acknowledging anxiety about the White Houses ability to strengthen the presidents standing over the next 14 months.

title: Court Case Asks if Big Brother Is Spelled GPS
description: WASHINGTON  The precedent is novel. More precisely, the precedent is a novel.

title: Commemorations Begin Throughout the Region
description: The commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks began in earnest on Saturday, with major ceremonies not only in Shanksville, Pa., but also New Jersey, Lower Manhattan and Midtown Manhattan. Most, if not all, were somber events.

title: Kemp May Be Most Valuable, but Will Dodgers Pay?
description: As the agent for Matt Kemp, Dave Stewart has an obvious bias in the National League Most Valuable Player Award discussion. But Stewart, the former star pitcher, looks at the recent trend in awards voting and feels good about the chances of his client, who is profiled in the Sunday New York Times.

title: Getting There Is Just a Piece of the Puzzle
description: ABOARD THE M/V HYAK, Wash.  Washington State Ferries is the largest such system in the United States, but it is small, too. Amid all the comings and goings, the getting theres and leaving heres, there is the middle part  people making their way.

title: Iraqi Cleric Tells Followers to Halt Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  The anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr called on his followers on Saturday to cease their attacks on United States military forces in Iraq, saying that he did not want the Americans to have an excuse to remain in the country, according to a statement posted on a Web site of his political party.

title: Betty Skelton, Air and Land Daredevil, Dies at 85
description: The inverted ribbon cut was one of Betty Skeltons most daring maneuvers, in which she flew her single-seat, open-cockpit biplane upside down at about 150 miles per hour, maybe 10 feet above the ground, and sliced through a ribbon stretched between two poles.

title: Rutgers Doesnt Make Most of What Its Given
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano talked about toughness and coming back, and those noble thoughts may offer comfort in weeks and months to come.

title: From Firebrand to a Bit of a Grump, a Hippie Mayor Evolves
The Making of the Helmut Lang Show

title: Djokovic Rallies From Two-Set Deficit to Beat Federer
description: Novak Djokovic went for it. What other choice did he have?

title: Battle for Libya | September 10, 2011
description: A rebel push to take the loyalist holdout of Bani Walid stalled after encountering resistance from the defenders.

title: Christopher Small, Cultural Musicologist, Is Dead at 84
description: Christopher Small, a New Zealand-born writer and musicologist who argued that music is above all an active ritual involving those who play and listen to it and only secondarily a matter of black dots, as he once called written music, died on Wednesday in Sitges, Spain. He was 84.

title: Rodriguez Is Out Again
description: ANAHEIM  With his sprained left thumb not completely healed, Alex Rodriguez was kept out of the lineup for Saturday nights game against the Los Angeles Angels. Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Rodriguez would be shelved for the next three to four days.

title: Close Loss Raises Pressure on Georgias Coach
description: ATHENS, Ga.  There is little vitriol in sports, both in pitch and emotion, that compares with a Southeastern Conference fan base fed up with its coach.

title: A Nation Remembers
description: Americans took part in ceremonies and other events commemorating the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: In a Show of Power, a Joyful Williams Storms Into the Final
description: Serena Williams screamed, but it was nothing like the cry that pierced Arthur Ashe Stadium the last time she had appeared in a United States Open semifinal.

title: Utilitarian Streetwear by Alexander Wang
description: Mesh was a strong look at Alexander Wangs show this afternoon, held in his usual space on a pier on the West Side Highway, seen in the loose-fitting parkas, bombers and anoraks that opened the collection in an inky color he called petrol. They were shown over bright blue and orange polo shirts in technical fabrics that constituted Mr. Wangs nod to the color trend of the season. Its nice to see several designers continuing to show sporty jackets for spring, reprising a dominant look from the fall collections. Fashion has been moving so fast these days, I was half afraid they would have already moved on to something else.

title: Display of Sportsmanship Makes News at World Cup
description: Cheating and temper tantrums get a lot of attention at chess tournaments, but two players at the World Cup are making news for all the right reasons.

title: Bruce Dan, Who Helped Link Toxic Shock and Tampons, Is Dead at 64
description: Dr. Bruce Dan, who as a leading federal researcher helped establish a link between the life-threatening disease toxic shock syndrome and the use of tampons, prompting a major shift in the way tampons are produced, died Tuesday in Baltimore. He was 64.

title: Employee Lawsuit Exacerbates Issues at Livermore Lab
description: Marian Barraza, like many who have worked at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, considered Livermore more than just an employer. Mrs. Barraza, a soft-spoken administrator, worked at Livermore, the federal weapons research lab, for 38 years. She met her husband there. One of the couples two daughters and many of Mrs. Barrazas friends still work there.

title: Arranging the Music for Austins Influential Festival
description: Amy Corbin has been pursuing Stevie Wonder for years. Hes been on a shortlist, alongside Bruce Springsteen and Radiohead, of acts Ms. Corbin has long hoped would agree to headline the Austin City Limits Music Festival. This year she got her man. Mr. Wonder, Coldplay and Arcade Fire are among the 130 acts that will draw 75,000 people each day next weekend to Zilker Park in Austin for the three-day festivals 10th anniversary.

title: Caldecott Tunnel Edges Forward, Tribute to Stimulus Bill
description: On Thursday morning, miners deep in the fourth bore of the Caldecott Tunnel spent 10 grueling hours drilling six feet farther into the bedrock.

title: Wanting the Hard to Get Simply Because It Is
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Alderman Narrows Her Chicken Ban and Tries Again
description: Alderman Lona Lane is hard boiled when it comes to her vendetta against live chickens raised in the city.

title: Homer Lane
description: A tiny street near Palo Alto in an unincorporated part of San Mateo County is one of the few relics of the days when the area was a hotbed of anti-Vietnam War sentiment, groovy rock music and experimental drugs. Currently, 10 families live in a string of cottages at the end of the road. JAMIE HANSEN

title: Williams Overpowers Wozniacki and Advances to Final
description: Shrugging off the effect of a bandaged right foot layered with adhesive, Serena Williams of the United States bounded into the U.S. Open womens final with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark, the worlds top ranked and top seeded player.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Roger Federer vs. Pete Sampras
description: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? Its up to you to decide, with a little help from The Timess tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will advance to the finals of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

title: State Challenging Hospitals Tax Exemptions
description: Facing a budget deficit exceeding $11 billion, the State of Illinois in recent weeks has begun challenging the property tax exemptions of some of its best-known hospitals,saying they should pay more because they are not providing enough charity care.

title: Whos That Guy Behind the Plate?
description: ANAHEIM, Calf.  For the first time all season, Jorge Posada is behind the plate catching for the Yankees.

title: Bears Wont Pull Chicago Out of Sports Slump
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: United Flight Attendants Gather to Mourn 5 Colleagues
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  As dusk settled over the Flight 93 National Memorial here Saturday night, a group of 70 United flight attendants in their crisp blue uniforms came to stand vigil for their five colleagues who went down with the plane on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Leppert Runs a Campaign of Ideas, on an Uphill Track
description: Like other Texas politicians before him  Republican Tom Luce and Democrat John Odam come to mind  Tom Leppert, a former mayor of Dallas, is trying to attract support for his Senate campaign with a detailed jobs program that combines his business experience with his public-policy vision. His seven-second sound bite? You just cant put this in a seven-second sound bite.

title: Teachers Must Clean Up Mess Left by Budget Cuts
description: DRIPPING SPRINGS, Tex. Just as Judy Gardner answered the phone on Wednesday afternoon, a coach stuck his head into her empty classroom.

title: A Very Festive Weekend for Sony Classics
description: TORONTO It was a big night Saturday for Sony Pictures Classics at the Toronto International Film Festival, but that seems to be true of the entire weekend. Sonys arthouse unit and its two co-presidents, Michael Barker and Tom Bernard, have been celebrating the companys 20th anniversary with a series of parties that just keeps getting longer.

title: College Football Replay: Sept. 10
description: The second week of the season saw Georgia struggle again and U.S.C. escape with a win.

title: Cliff Robertson, Oscar-Winning Rebel, Dies at 88
description: Cliff Robertson, the ruggedly handsome actor who won an Oscar for Charly but found himself frozen out of jobs for almost four years after he exposed a prominent Hollywood studio boss as a forger and embezzler, died Saturday on Long Island. He was 88 and lived in Water Mill, N.Y.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Before 9/11 only the language of weapons worked in Afghanistan, and the educated of our society did not dare to talk in front of the warlords and the armed factions.

title: Banged-Up Yanks Drop 4th Straight
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  As the vocal minority of Yankees fans in attendance cheered the unexpected sight, Jorge Posada squatted down behind home plate in the bottom of the third inning; mask, chest protector and shin guards in place.

title: Photo Replay: U.S. Open Semifinals
description: A look at Saturdays semifinals from the hardcourts of Flushing Meadows.

title: Parts of Dulles International Airport Temporarily Evacuated
description: Dulles International Airport outside of Washington, D.C., was partially evacuated for nearly four hours on Saturday after suspicious boxes turned up on a cargo pallet, The Associated Press reported.

title: An Exhibit That Honors Players Who Went to War
description: Spectators encountering bad weather at the U.S. Open may want to spend a rain delay viewing an International Tennis Hall of Fame and Museum exhibit at the Chase Center, across the walkway from Louis Armstrong Stadium.

title: SXSW Wrap-Up
description: Images from the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference and Festival in Austin, Tex.

title: Downtowns Rebirth, 10 Years and $24 Billion Later
description: A DECADE after the Sept. 11 attack, downtown Manhattan is resurgent. The residential population has doubled. Two skyscrapers  1 and 4 World Trade Center  are rising at ground zero, due to open in 2013. The next year, the exuberant PATH transit hub is scheduled to come online. The national memorial is open; two streets have been built. A far more diverse array of businesses call downtown home today, including a large cluster of media companies, law firms and nonprofit organizations. And just last week, both the northbound and southbound platforms of the Cortlandt Street subway station were open.

title: Suit Up
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#713", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);This is our life!! e-mails Maayan Zilberman when asked if she and her design partner, Nikki Dekker, of the Lake and Stars ever wear swimsuits as bodysuits. We were both wearing bikini tops as bras, with the straps poking out at the tops of our tanks when we met, says Dekker days later, in their TriBeCa studio. True to form, the Lake and Stars label is all about intimates that can be purposefully layered to wear with outerwear. Our lingerie lives in the world of fashion, says Zilberman about their four-year-old line. In anticipation of their presentation today, which includes swimwear for the first time, the Lake and Stars gives T a lesson in wearing bathing suits as bodysuits.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: A look at some of the long form Indian journalism India Ink has been reading this week:The much-discussed profile of Arvind Kejriwal, the man who is in many ways the brains behind the Anna Hazare anti-corruption movement, gives some fascinating details of the careful planning and execution of Mr. Hazares high-profile fasts. One nugget: when Mr. Hazare and Mr. Kejriwal were planning the first fast in April, they deliberately selected a date that would fall between the end of the Cricket World Cup and the start of the Indian Premier League. (The Caravan)

title: Photos by Pirkle Jones, 1914-2009
description: Pirkle Joness images of threatened California towns and valleys and the Black Panthers at the peak of their power made him one of the most admired photographers of his generation.

title: The Reach of Mexico's Drug Cartels
description: Mexican drug trafficking cartels represent the greatest organized crime threat to the United States, according to a recent Justice Department report. The cartels have waged increasingly violent battles with one another, as well as with the Mexican government, which began an aggressive crackdown in 2006.

title: Drug Violence Invades Tucson
description: Tucson is coping with a wave of drug crime the police suspect is tied to the bloody battles between Mexicos drug cartels.

title: West Side Story
description: Okay, I didnt see Valentino do his karaoke number at the Carine Roitfeld party tonight and maybe Ill sleep better without that memory. Barneys gave the party, at a former strip club near the West Side Highway, across from Alexander Wangs even bigger party at Pier 40. I got to the club right after the Joseph Altuzarra show and ran into Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, the Suno designers. I knew Saturday would be a long day, and it was, starting at 9 a.m. with a tour of the hat exhibit that Stephen Jones has organized at the Bard Graduate Center on the Upper West Side. I saw a bunch of shows, had a good lunch with my friend Simon Ungless, dropped by to see Oscar de la Renta, who was watching the tennis match and casting models, and got locked out of the Christian Siriano show, though I managed to see the clothes backstage. That was around 5 p.m.

title: What to Watch on Sunday
description: Samantha Stosur is an exciting player who breaks the mold of the typical baseliner. Shes got a big serve, and one of the best forehands going. Where many of her peers will be content to stand back and wait for errors, Stosur prefers to take the offensive  even sneaking into net occasionally.

title: Yemeni Forces Are Said to Enter Coastal City
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni armed forces have entered the city of Zinjibar for the first time since armed Islamic militants seized the southern coastal city in May, according to state-run media.

title: Historic Madrid Theater Celebrates Spanish Directors
description: Film buffs may recognize Madrids Cine Dor from the silent film sequence in Pedro Almdovars film Talk to Her. But the Art Nouveau movie theater (Calle Santa Isabel, 3; 34-91-369-1125), which is also the public face of Filmoteca Espaola, a Spanish film preservation association, is very much alive. This month, the theater, which dates to 1923, is screening films from two prominent Spanish directors, Luis Garca Berlanga and Carlos Saura.

title: 9/11 Recalled  Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  September 11. Although it was 10 years ago it was just like yesterday. I was 21 years old when I went home from college, and when I first went into the house my eyes fell on the TV with a live broadcast of the second airplane hitting the tower.

title: Bush and Obama, Shoulder to Shoulder
description: On Sunday, for the first time, President Obama and former President George W. Bush stood together at the site of the Sept. 11 attacks, listening as family members read the names of lost love ones and bowing their heads in silence to mark the moments the planes hit.

title: On 9/11, Vows of Remembrance
description: They played the bagpipes again and recited the names of the dead like poetry. Bells tolled, and requiems by President Obama and other dignitaries filled the amphitheater of ground zero on Sunday as America looked back upon a contagion of terrorism and war and renewed its vows of remembrance.

title: The City Remembers
description: The Tenth Anniversary of the 9/11 Attacks

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: JAMES WHITE The Iowa State running back ran for two touchdowns in overtime to help the Cyclones beat their rival Iowa, 44-41, in three overtimes and give his teammate Stephen Ruempolhamer, right, a chance to hoist the Cy-Hawk Trophy, which is given to the winner.

title: Ten Years On, Remembering a Day of Grief and Horror
description: A decade later, in a city and a nation transformed, Sept. 11 dawned in the year 2011 and the loved ones of the dead gathered beside where the Twin Towers stood to repeat a memory lesson that harnessed still-raw emotion to factual accounting: the reciting of the names of the 2,983 victims of the terror attacks of 2001.

title: 4 Suspects Arrested in Swedish Terror Plot
description: LUND, Sweden  Four people were arrested in Goteborg on Saturday night on suspicion of planning acts of terrorism there, the police said. The authorities also evacuated an arts center in the city.

title: Blast Hits NATO Outpost in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A cargo truck packed with explosives struck a NATO outpost south of the capital late Saturday, killing at least 5 people and wounding dozens more, including 77 members of coalition troops, NATO and Afghan officials said Sunday.

title: Marking the 9/11 Anniversary
description: Visitors gathered at ground zero for the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: The Years of Shame
description: Is it just me, or are the 9/11 commemorations oddly subdued?

title: At Pentagon, No Words Will Fill Void
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Sunday told the families of the 184 men, women and children killed at the Pentagon a decade ago that I know what its like to receive that call out of the blue that the dearest thing in your life is gone.

title: Tennis Video Games Have a History But Not Yet a Big Hit
description: Tennis has had a historically important, if sometimes forgotten, role in the history of video games. As the U.S. Open concludes at Flushing Meadows, its worth looking roughly 60 miles east of the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, where one of the first video games ever made was a tennis game, created more than 50 years ago on Long Island.

title: The Spanish Prisoner
description: One of the good ideas in Paul De Grauwes now-essential paper (pdf) was to do a head-to-head comparison of Spain and the UK to illustrate the problems the euro faces. Heres an update.

title: In Pennsylvania, a Wall of Names
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  The sun rose brightly here on Sunday morning, burning off the mist that hovered over the field where United Airlines Flight 93, hurtling through the sky at more than 575 miles per hour, crashed on Sept. 11, 2001. At the moment of impact, 10:03 a.m., the field was empty.

title: 9/11 Recalled  Fort Benning
description: Under a blue, cloudless sky I waddled along the flight line toward a waiting C-130 Hercules. This was going to be my second jump, and the first with combat equipment. The day prior I had taken my first jump, and with four more I would earn my Airborne wings. I was nervous about getting injured.

title: Vettel Cruises to Victory, and Nearly Almost a Second World Title
description: MONZA, Italy  Sebastian Vettel drove to an easy victory in his Red Bull at the Italian Grand Prix on Sunday, winning his eighth race of the season and extending his grip on the championship lead. With six races left in the series, he is in an unassailable position.

title: Vettel Cruises to Victory, and Nearly Almost a Second World Title

title: What to Watch Sunday: Junior Finals
description: Caroline Garcia versus Grace Min, Court 7, noon  Garcia, the No. 1 seed, has powered her way to a final of a junior slam after having reached the semifinals in the other three this year. The 17-year-old from France, who has lost only one set in her five victories this week, is a big favorite over the unseeded Grace Min of the United States. But an upset is certainly possible if Min can sustain the level of play she displayed in her semifinal victory over Nicole Gibbs, who was also a semifinalist for the N.C.A.A. singles title.

title: At Toronto Film Festival, Los Angeles Has Some Screen Time
description: TORONTO  Aficionados of the Los Angeles street film  Colors, Collateral, To Live and Die in L.A., the list is endless  might be a little surprised by Rampart, Oren Movermans latest contribution to the genre. Mr. Movermans movie, which stars Woody Harrelson as a cop who makes all the wrong turns, has been screening at the Toronto International Film Festival here.

description: Alexander WangDesigner: Alexander WangDate and Location: Saturday, Pier 94, West Side Highway at 55th StreetPhotos: slide show

title: Markets Brace as the Crisis in Europe Flares Up Again
description: Fears about Europes deteriorating finances intensified on Sunday as new doubts about the health of French banks, as well as Germanys willingness to help Greece avert default, left investors bracing for another global stock market downturn this week.

title: Remembering September 11
description: Families gathered at the World Trade Center site, the Pentagon and Shanksville, Pa., to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks on September 11.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Altuzarra
description: The amazing thing with Joseph is hes this super young guy with a point of view, said Tom Pecheux of the designer backstage at the Altuzarra show. Hes not thinking of clothes, but of a woman.

title: Somali Gunmen Attack British Tourists in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A boatload of Somali gunmen attacked an exclusive beach resort in Kenya on Sunday, killing a British tourist and kidnapping his wife before racing back into Somalia, Western diplomats said.

title: How Are You Marking the 9/11 Anniversary?
description: As the official Sept. 11 commemorations take place at ground zero, in Shanksville, Pa., and at the Pentagon, millions of people around the world are reflecting on the 10-year anniversary in their own private ways. We asked our readers on Facebook to tell us how they are spending the day. Below, a selection of their responses. Use the comments box below to tell us what youre doing today, or post a comment on our Facebook page.

title: Victoria Beckham: Fashion Goes On
description: The atmosphere before Victoria Beckhams runway show at Astor Hall in the New York Public Library Sunday morning was somber, with the lights dimmed and some guests noting the queasiness of getting on with the business of Fashion Week, even as the 9/11 memorial services were taking place downtown. Ms. Beckham did away with her customary routine of narrating each look during the show, though you could still hear her say, Id like to start by thanking everyone, just before the music cut her off.

title: Stosur vs. Williams: Keys to the Final
description: Most people have already engraved Serena Williams name on the U.S. Open womens singles trophy for 2011 following her dominating semi-final victory over world No. 1, Caroline Wozniacki, Saturday night.

title: A Journey of Heroism That Led to the Towers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Halfway through James B. Stewarts nonfiction book Heart of a Soldier, which has been adapted into an opera that had its premiere on Saturday evening at the San Francisco Opera, Rick Rescorla tries to write a novel.

title: Contagion Is No. 1 at Weekend Box Office
description: North American moviegoers, jumping at the chance to see Gwyneth Paltrow and a host of other stars die of a horrible disease, drove Contagion to No. 1 at the weekend box office with an estimated $23 million in ticket sales. That Warner Brothers film, directed by Steven Soderbergh and made in conjunction with Participant Media, cost about $60 million to produce; an all-star cast (Kate Winslet, Matt Damon, Laurence Fishburne and Jude Law in addition to Ms. Paltrow) and strong reviews contributed to audience interest. The Help (DreamWorks Studios) was second, taking in about $8.7 million for a five-week total of $137 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. Warrior, a mixed martial arts drama from Lionsgate, was a disappointing third with about $5.6 million in ticket sales. The Debt (Focus Features) took in roughly $5 million for fourth place, lifting its two-week total to $22 million. Colombiana (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fifth with about $4 million in ticket sales and a new three-week total of $29.8 million. On the gloomy side, Bucky Larson: Born to be a Star, a Sony comedy produced by Adam Sandlers company, took in just $1.5 million and placed far outside the top 10.

title: New York Fashion Week Diary | Bruce Pask
description: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes talks to Ts mens fashion director Bruce Pask about the best of fashion week so far.

title: Across the Nation, Tragedy Spawned Inspiration
description: FRISCO, Colo.  The Sunday after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, several dozen friends climbed a mountain to make a declaration, and to do something to work off their awful, anxious energy.

title: Where Do We Go From Here?
description: Today, a large share of the Sept. 11 reflection in this country and worldwide has been focused on the attacks themselves and the events of the decade that followed. We were curious to hear from you about what goals the U.S. should set for itself in the next 10 years, taking into consideration where we are now, and where we have been ever since that Tuesday morning in 2001.  We asked our Twitter followers on @NYTimes for ideas and suggestions and we are featuring a selection of their responses here. Post your own comment in the box below, or tweet to us at @NYTimes with the hashtag #911plus20.

title: Another Rain Delay at the Open
description: Another day at the U.S. Open and yet another rain delay.

title: New York Top 5 | Siki Im
description: Siki Ims first runway show here in New York City, titled The Topography of Globalization, was the perfect combination of concept and clothing. Bespectacled models walked the runway in stark multiculti clothing that was a combination of American sportswear staples like denim jeans and tailored sport jackets and Middle East style scarfs and wrapped coats. Smart military style cargo pockets and oversize flaps provided the fine finishing touches in this highly styled yet utterly wearable collection.

title: Trendspotting: Athletic Wear
description: This season, some designers are drawing inspiration from the locker room, the racetrack, sand and surf.

title: Stosur Defeats Serena Williams for 2011 Open Title
description: Live Coverage of Womens Open Final: On Saturday, The New York Times brought you live analysis, photos and chat from the womens championship match of the United States Open between Serena Williams and Samantha Stosur.

title: Boardwalk Empire Wins Creative Arts Emmys
description: Boardwalk Empire, the Prohibition-era drama set in Atlantic City, picked up seven awards at the creative arts Emmys on Saturday, making it the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences most-honored television program a week ahead of the prime-time awards. Boardwalk Empire, shown by HBO, won for art direction, editing, sound editing and visual effects, among other categories. HBO also received awards for the mini-series Mildred Pierce, a Lady Gaga tour special and a childrens program called A Childs Garden of Poetry. The annual creative arts ceremony also recognized Justin Timberlake twice  once for guest-hosting Saturday Night Live and once for co-writing the lyrics to his SNL monologue song. Other stars who were recognized on Saturday include Gwyneth Paltrow, for her guest-star turn on Glee; Jay Leno, for his car Web site JayLenosGarage.com; and Jeff Probst, for his hosting of Survivor. The ceremony will be shown on the ReelzChannel on Saturday, a day before the prime-time awards are shown live on Fox.

title: Team Players
description: Designers casting about for a credibly American fashion identity could do worse than to mine the sports arena. An influential cohort did just that, drawing inspiration from the locker room, the racetrack, sand and surf.

title: Global Memorials, Tinged With Weariness
description: PARIS  On Sunday, however briefly, nations around the world came together with the United States to remember the attacks on New York and the Pentagon that killed nearly 3,000 people from 90 countries.
