title: Muted in Last Debate, Bachmann Looks to Rejoin Conversation
description: Representative Michele Bachmann burst like a nova onto the presidential race thanks to a smooth and confident performance that lit up the stage at a Republican debate in June.

title: I.S.S. Comes Out Against Transatlantics Deal With Allied
description: The proposed merger of Transatlantic Holdings with Allied World Assurance experienced a fresh setback on Friday, as a major shareholder advisory firm recommended that investors vote against the $2.86 billion deal.

title: The Truth? Europe Cant Handle The Truth!
description: Im a big fan of the FTs Alphaville blog  although I have to say that their explanation of my views on gold left me feeling a bit confused.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Victoria Beckham
description: Its not every morning that starts with someone referencing Catherine Deneuve and drugstores in the same sentence. It happened backstage at Victoria Beckham where Guido Palau explained that he was using quite a lot of product and Goody hair barrettes to channel Deneuve-like elegance with a masculine bent. This meant Redken Thickening Lotion spread throughout the hair for texture, with Hardwear at the center to make a wet-looking panel at the crown, which was pulled back with a classic silver clip (heres where we get drugstore). Then loads of Hairspray 23 on the loose hair, for texture, not hold, Palau said. Wet and dry, shine and matte, is how he described the contrasts within the style. As the girls walked out, Palau added a little Glass Panel to heighten this effect.

title: Tuck Inactive for Giants Opener
description: LANDOVER, Md.  The Giants opened their season Sunday afternoon against the Washington Redskins without their defensive leader, Justin Tuck, who was declared inactive just before the game because of a lingering neck injury.

title: Hacker Rattles Security Circles
description: He claims to be 21 years old, a student of software engineering in Tehran who reveres Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and despises dissidents in his country.

title: Qaddafi Son Found in Niger
description: NIAMEY, Niger  A son of the deposed Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has entered Niger, crossing the desert from Libya, the Niger government said Sunday.

title: Fashions Experienced Hands, a Long Walk From SoHo
description: Jean Salvemini wrapped her arms around a pair of headless mannequins  one in a wedding dress, the other in a suit and tie  and made a fashion statement: You know, we really dont have a glamorous address, she said, but we do glamorous work.

title: Backstage Grooming Report | Robert Geller
description: At a cozy table mere yards away from the pre-show shuffle, the mens wear designer Robert Geller quietly shared, This season I thought a lot about proportions, and how to play with them. If a guy wears a slim pant, Id think about juxtaposing it with a rounded sleeve or shoulder. In this collection, I emphasized how men really need to loosen up, but still be masculine, with a certain coolness.

title: Underground Musicians Lose a Haven
description: Man Forever, a five-piece band, was making some decidedly unmarketable noise. Two drummers sat on either side of a snare drum, rolling out an undercurrent of cadences, while an organist with wild hair played endlessly sustained dissonant chords, and the bass and guitar thrummed muddy harmonies that fed back on themselves. The effect was of a primordial drone in which overtones clashed and warbled, phasing in and out in waves, chaos seeking order.

title: Bartz Departs Yahoos Board
description: Days after she was fired as Yahoos chief executive, Carol A. Bartz resigned her seat on the Internet companys board, according to a spokesman for the directors.

title: Remembering September 11 With Music
description: Like a solo Bach line, music wove its way through Sept. 11 remembering on Sunday. Pockets of people formed in halls and churches around New York to hear musicians form the consorts of consolation.

title: Biggest Carry for Greene: The Jets Offensive Load
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Shonn Greene, the 226-pound running back whom the Jets plan to lean on harder this season, does not talk much, even to his teammates. But he will say he likes to think of himself as the kind of player who becomes stronger as games wear on.

title: New Seasons: N.F.L., Serie A
description: O.K., it is only a coincidence  the N.F.L. regular season turned over into gear and the Serie A season in Italy began, finally.

title: Big Names Join Cast of Les Misrables Movie
description: Russell Crowe has been cast as Inspector Javert opposite Hugh Jackman as Jean Valjean in the coming film adaptation of the musical Les Misrables, according to deadline.com. The film will be directed by Tom Hooper (The Kings Speech) and is scheduled for release in December 2012. The most recent theatrical adaptation based on that 1862 Victor Hugo novel  released in 1998 and starring Liam Neeson and Geoffrey Rush  earned less than $14 million at the domestic box office despite generally positive reviews.

title: You Look Familiar Somehow
description: Technically speaking, there was nothing groundbreaking in the T-shirts and utility jackets printed with big eyeballs, or a buttoned-up black polo shirt slashed with white stripes, that Daisuke Obana created for his N. Hoolywood collection. And yet, Mr. Obanas show, in a pitch-black theater at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center on Friday night, was utterly engrossing.

title: Photos of the Moment | Altuzarra
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#576", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Matthew Kristalls New York fashion week photo diary.

title: The Meaningfulness of Lives
description: Who among us has not asked whether his or her life is a meaningful one? Who has not wondered  on a sleepless night, during a long stretch of dull or taxing work, or when a troubled child seems a greater burden than one can bear  whether in the end it all adds up to anything? On this day, too, when many are steeped in painful reminders of personal loss, it is natural to wonder about the answers.

title: Never Seeking the Presidency, Yet Swept Into Office Nonetheless
description: In both of the books she has written about American presidents, Candice Millard has zeroed in on events that other historians largely overlook. Her first book, The River of Doubt, followed Theodore Roosevelts strenuous efforts to regain his confidence after his failed 1912 third-party bid for re-election and described his near-disastrous journey down the Amazon tributary of the title. The details of this trip were hardly unknown, but they were easily overshadowed by other aspects of Roosevelts hugely eventful life. Ms. Millard turned a relative footnote into a newly mesmerizing story.

title: Shuffling and Mirroring in a Sort of Simon Says
description: Nomie Lafrance is a site-specific choreographer, which means that in her works, place is paramount. Shes staged dances in a 50,000-square-foot drained swimming pool and on the swooping rooftop of a Frank Gehry building. Her new installation, The White Box Project, is set at the Black & White Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn  or, rather, behind it. A door at the back of the gallery opens onto a concrete courtyard, enclosed by whitish brick walls and exposed to the sky. Its like a handball court thats seen better days, a space small enough that when the cast of 20 dancers start running, everyone else better get out of the way. Unfortunately Ms. Lafrances guiding idea is even smaller.

title: You Can See Spring Coming
description: Self regard has been a cultural driver for some time, so the intersecting mirrors at the center of Alexander Wangs show made perfect sense. The audience of editors and star photographers could regard themselves while regarding the clothes.

title: Capturing a Yearning Fit for a Prince
description: It might seem a stretch to ask audience members at Bargemusic, the floating concert hall on the East River with an expansive view of the Manhattan skyline, to imagine themselves next to the Rhine in 1475, as the tenor and lutenist Eric Redlinger did before a concert on Thursday evening.

title: Monday: Popular Bar Game
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  In another lifetime, I earned my living as a canine behaviorist. This means that I spent a lot of time explaining to people who hired me that their dogs would be much more well-behaved once the dog clearly understood what the people wanted from the dog. For example, if you train your dog to eliminate outside on the command Hurry up!, you should not be surprised if, the moment you yell Hurry up! to your spouse when youre late to a social engagement, the dog eliminates as directed, most likely on your Persian rug. Its all about communication, people.

title: A Bollywood Bride, but Whos the Groom?
description: Free spirit or spoiled brat? Dimple, the heroine of the Bollywood romantic comedy Mere Brother Ki Dulhan (My Brothers Bride), is a bit of both, though as portrayed by Katrina Kaif the brat often has the upper hand. Still, Dimple, the London-raised daughter of a diplomat, barely resembles the demure Hindi-film heroines of yore. She knows what she wants, likes to have fun and enjoys being a bad girl. She even stages an unauthorized rock concert at the Agra fort, where  with the Taj Mahal for a backdrop  she wails on a shiny electric guitar in ripped pink jeans. (Youve come a long way, Bollywood baby.)

title: A Modern Update on Musical Tradition
description: Before conducting the inaugural concert of the West Side Chamber Orchestra at St. Peters Church in Chelsea on Saturday evening Kevin Mallon said he had been amazed  given the struggles of many orchestras to survive  to receive a call from the oboist Kathy Halvorson about founding a new ensemble.

title: A Celebration of Bach, as a Counterpoise to Painful Memories
description: What does Bach, or any classical composer, have to do with Sept. 11? For most people nothing, but for some of us everything.

title: New York Exhales With Mahlers Resurrection, Symphonic Salve
description: The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, came as the classical music season in New York was about to begin. In the aftermath the citys stunned performing arts organizations were not sure how to respond, or even whether to begin performances at all.

title: Where The Big Girls Are | Alexander Wang
description: The photographer JD Ferguson gets close up on the biggest faces in fashion.

title: A 92-Year-Old Former Champ Who Doesnt Play by the Book
description: Wednesday is the 92nd birthday of one of the former stars of the game: Leonard Harmon of East Hampton, N.Y.

title: DVF: New Kids on the Catwalk
description: 11:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Monster Island
description: A haven for struggling artists and musicians in Brooklyn is headed for redevelopment.

title: The Select (The Sun Also Rises)'
description: Photos of the show from Elevator Repair Service.

title: Mass Grave in Iraqi Town Held Bodies of 40 Cabbies
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq has been so inured by years of war, terrorism and sectarian strife that what would be a horrific crime of shocking proportions in most countries has gone barely noticed here.

title: PBSs Need to Know Turns to Roster of Guest Hosts
description: PBSs Friday newsmagazine Need to Know is turning to a rotating group of well-known guest hosts for the next several months, as it seeks a new permanent anchor in the wake of Alison Stewarts departure on Friday.

title: The Lion King Has a New Life
description: Theater owners are furious with movie studios for speeding up the release of movies on DVD and video-on-demand services. Except when theyre not upset about it at all.

title: Critics See Drop in Talent as U.S.T.A. Grapples With Player Development
description: A deluge forced the United States Open junior tournament to be moved Thursday from Flushing Meadows to indoor courts in Port Chester, N.Y. To the young players, it was a reminder of how far they have to go in tennis, a sport to which many have dedicated much of their lives.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Duro Olowu
description: Chic with a beautiful, sensual quality showcasing an elongation of the neck and the profile of the face, said Johnnie Sapong backstage at Duro Olowu of the style he created to channel the photographer Jacques Henri Lartigues women, who were among the inspirations for both the beauty look and the clothes in the collection. Sapong molded an undone chignon using TIGI Catwalk Session Series Work It hair spray, the loose ends of the upswept hairdo dusted with Transforming Dry Shampoo. Like a piece of raveled rope, is how he described the bun. As for makeup, Luc Bochard kept it modern and feminine, as well, with M.A.C. Metal X Crme Shadow in Gold Carbon over the eye and Russian Red and Film Noir on the lips. Among the hair and makeup team was Olowus wife, Thelma Golden, watching the crew prep for the presentation. Beautifully combined, broad influences, is how she described the cumulative effect of her husbands sensibilities. Spoken like a true art aficionada.

title: A Shrub Back From Oblivion and in Need of Care
description: The extinction-defying shrub is informally called Franciscan manzanita, for its home near San Francisco Bay, but maybe someone should rename it the Lazarus manzanita. It was given up for extinct some 60 years ago, then rediscovered in a traffic island in 2009 by a botanist driving home from a climate-change conference.

title: Campaign Trains Viewers for TV Everywhere
description: PUTTING in place TV Everywhere, a long-promised system for online television, calls for new contracts between channels and distributors and for new technology to check that viewers have paid their cable bills. And it takes something else: training. Viewers, after all, are not accustomed to being able to go online and see a librarys worth of television on demand.

title: Fashion Week Casting | Thakoon
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#397", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: So Far, Ryans Legacy Lives in Words, Not Deeds
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Ceremonies Mark 10th Anniversary of Sept. 11
description: In Washington, New York and Pennsylvania, officials and victims families gathered to commemorate the attacks.

title: Huber and Raymond Win Womens Doubles Title
description: The last time Liezel Huber and Lisa Raymond were on the same court at a United States Open doubles final, it was as opponents. That was in 2008, when Huber teamed with Cara Black to defeat Raymond and Samantha Stosur to win the doubles title.

title: Is Technology in Class the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Perils of Glitter Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors as Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: The Benefits of Urban Density
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Reform in Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Threat of Contagion
description: I ADMIT I was wary when I was approached, late in 2008, about working on a movie with the director Steven Soderbergh about a flulike pandemic. It seemed that every few years a filmmaker imagined a world in which a virus transformed humans into flesh-eating zombies, or scientists discovered and delivered the cure for a lethal infectious disease in an impossibly short period of time.

title: Reports See Fiscal Woes Undermining Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  With the Palestinian Authority seeking United Nations membership and statehood recognition this month, two new reports say Palestinian public institutions are gaining traction, but there is trouble on the economic front  growth has slowed amid a fiscal crisis.

title: Veto a State, Lose an Ally
description: Jidda, Saudi Arabia

title: News Trends Tilt Toward Niche Sites
description: It was a rough week for the big guys on the Web. Yahoo unceremoniously dumped its chief executive, Carol Bartz, and AOL faced a mutiny from TechCrunch, the Silicon Valley news site it bought last year.

title: YouTube Founders Revamping a Site for Link Sharing
description: SAN MATEO, Calif.  Chad Hurley and Steve Chen have some experience with turning a small Web site into Internet gold. In 2006 they sold their scrappy start-up YouTube to Google for $1.65 billion.

title: The Daily Shoe | Derek Lam
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Giants, Needing Some Early Wins, Stumble in Opener
description: LANDOVER, Md.  After a training camp filled with injuries ranging from torn chest muscles to shredded knees, the Giants began their season Sunday by absorbing perhaps the most painful blow of all: the stomach punch.

title: Yankees Offense Stirs to Life With Assist From the Angels
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  It had been five days and three cities since the Yankees last won a game. Their offense was sagging, their bullpen was depleted, and the injuries were stacking up so high that by the weekend they had used three catchers they never thought would squat behind the plate this season.

title: Anderson Cooper Seeks to Show His Daytime Side
description: This year, Anderson Cooper spent 10 days in Japan covering the aftermath of the devastating earthquake; he spent nine days in Egypt and was roughed up by supporters of Hosni Mubarak during the uprising there.

title: Changing the Rules
description: Some south Louisiana business owners say new regulations on guest workers could put many of them out of business.

title: In Russian Leadership Battle, Medvedev Hints He Lacks Fire
description: YAROSLAVL, Russia  When President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia took the lectern here at his annual political forum last week, the circles under his eyes suggested he had barely slept.

title: On the Field, All Is Well
description: ATHENS, Ga.  After an off-season in which college football fans could barely stand to watch, the star-kissed fans at Michigan Stadium did not want to leave. After an off-season with seemingly endless descriptions of the ills of college football, Iowa State Coach Paul Rhoads was reduced to tears when his teams triple-overtime victory ended. After an off-season of relentless controversy, fans saw an abundance of thrills, almost like the sports version of an N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments opening Thursday.

title: In Tapes, Candid Talk by Young Kennedy Widow
description: In the early days of the Cuban missile crisis, before the world knew that the cold war seemed to be sliding toward nuclear conflict, President John F. Kennedy telephoned his wife, Jacqueline, at their weekend house in Virginia. From his voice, she would say later, she could tell that something was wrong. Why dont you come back to Washington? he asked, without explanation.

title: Mens Final Could Punctuate, or Puncture, the Years Narrative
description: A defeat on Monday will hardly ruin Novak Djokovics greatest season. He has already won 9 tournaments and 63 matches, beating up on the best repeatedly, on everything from the cushioned acrylic of Melbourne to the red clay of Madrid and Rome to the deep-rooted grass of Wimbledon.

title: Look of the Moment | Sofa Sanchez Barrenechea
description: The Look: Ravishinga most dramatic metal collar and black ankle boots sharpen a showstopping red halter dress.

title: Returning Greece to the Drachma
description: The standard of living reached in Greece since it joined the European Union means austerity will be inadequate to rebalance the economy. Returning Greeces currency to the drachma, on the other hand, would allow market forces to set the countrys wage levels, induce other indebted European Union members to reform without Continental prodding and thus solidify the euro.

title: Stosur Captures the Title After a Williams Outburst
description: Samantha Stosur endured the longest womens match in tournament history in one round and the longest tie breaker in another on her way to the United States Open final. When the rain came in the second week, she endured being moved like a pawn around the National Tennis Center.

title: In Guatemalan Election, a Focus on Security Issues
description: MEXICO CITY  Guatemalans streamed to the polls on Sunday to elect a new president, Parliament and local leaders in an election defined by rising concerns about gangs and drug cartels. Voters waiting to cast ballots from the countryside to the capital said they were motivated mostly by the fear of violent crime, and demands for a stronger government response.

title: The Presidents Do-Over
description: A week after President Obama took the oath of office, Alice Rivlin, budget chief to President Bill Clinton, testified before a Congress that was about to consider sweeping stimulus legislation. In her remarks, Rivlin voiced her support for a swift and substantial federal intervention to prop up the sagging economy. But she offered lawmakers three warnings as well.

title: Sony Slate a Big Bet on Dramas
description: TORONTO  This was not by design, said Michael Lynton, the chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment.

title: G.O.P. Senators in Albany Block Federal Aid to Fulfill Part of Health Law
description: With 2.6 million uninsured residents, a popular Democratic governor and tens of millions of federal dollars at stake, New York would seem to be one of the least likely states to join a growing revolt in the nations capitals against facilitating a federal overhaul of health care.

title: Raid on Egyptian Al Jazeera Affiliate Seen as Part of a Broader Crackdown
description: CAIRO  Egyptian security forces raided the offices of an Egyptian affiliate of the Al Jazeera news network known for attentive coverage of street protests, eliciting allegations on Sunday of a crackdown on the news media as the military-led transitional government seeks to ensure law and order after allowing an angry mob to invade the Israeli Embassy over the weekend.

title: A Day to Take Stock of What Really Matters
description: Landover, Md.

title: An Impeccable Disaster
description: On Thursday Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank or E.C.B.  Europes equivalent to Ben Bernanke  lost his sang-froid. In response to a question about whether the E.C.B. is becoming a bad bank thanks to its purchases of troubled nations debt, Mr. Trichet, his voice rising, insisted that his institution has performed impeccably, impeccably! as a guardian of price stability.

title: Report Details Rise of Social Media
description: 11:20 a.m. | Updated As social media like blogs, Facebook, Twitter and YouTube grow increasingly popular among consumers, marketers are seeking more data about the changing behavior of their customers.

title: Julia Marcums Civil War
description: At around two in the morning on Sept. 7, 1861, Confederate soldiers burst into the home of Julia Marcum, intent on killing her father. They broke the door open with bayonets on their guns and said there was 36 men around who had come to kill him, she later wrote. The 16-year-old girl lived with her parents and five siblings on a farm in Scott County, Tenn., northwest of Knoxville near the Kentucky border. Like most of their neighbors, the Marcums were strong Unionists. Early in the war Julias father, Hiram, made his farm available as a way station for the thousands of Southern men traveling north to join Lincolns army, guiding many of them to the border himself.

title: Joe Torre
description: The manager Joe Torre talks about Sept. 11.

title: A 9/11 Gesture Curtailed
description: On Sunday night, as Mets players and coaches observed a ceremony commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, they donned caps representing the police and fire departments of New York City.

title: Palestinian Statehood
description: A United Nations vote on Palestinian membership would be ruinous. Yet with little time left before the U.N. General Assembly meets, the United States, Israel and Europe have shown insufficient urgency or boldness in trying to find a compromise solution. The need for action is even more acute after alarming tensions flared in recent days between Israel and two critical regional players  Egypt and Turkey.

title: Video: Joe Torre Talks About Sept. 11
description: Former Yankees manager Joe Torre shares his memories.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Cites High-Level Dysfunction Over 9/11
description: WASHINGTON  In a new memoir, a former F.B.I. agent who tracked Al Qaeda before and after the Sept. 11 attacks paints a devastating picture of rivalry and dysfunction inside the governments counterterrorism agencies. The book describes missed opportunities to defuse the 2001 plot, and argues that other attacks overseas might have been prevented, and Osama bin Laden found earlier, if interrogations had not been mismanaged.

title: Closing a Nursing Home, and a Chapter of New York History
description: Her 98-year-old father lies under white sheets, frail and incoherent, attached to a feeding tube and a catheter. But Rose Lauria visits him nearly every day, taking a 10-minute bus ride to the historic block where the Bialystoker Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation has towered over the Lower East Sides tenements for 80 years, then greeting her father with a Hey, cutie pie!

title: Cheering On the Death Machine
description: Even supporters of the death penalty used to consider execution a solemn state responsibility, not an occasion for celebration. But the crowd of Republicans who gathered at the Reagan Library last week to watch their presidential candidates debate actually applauded and cheered when a moderator noted that Texas had executed 234 inmates under Gov. Rick Perry, by far the most under any governor in modern times.

title: Lottery Numbers
First Downer: Colts and Others Begin Season With Clunkers
description: Late last week, Kerry Collins was musing about the odd turns his career had taken, the latest being the head-spinning journey from retiree to rescuer of the Indianapolis Colts less than three weeks before Sundays season opener.

title: Secret Bid to Arm Qaddafi Sheds Light on Tensions in China Government
description: BEIJING  At a United Nations conference in Indonesia this summer, an official of the agency that oversees Chinas weapons industry ticked off the hurdles that any proposal to sell Chinese weapons abroad must clear. Among them: arms sales must not alter another nations internal security. They must not violate United Nations arms embargoes. And they must win government approval.

title: Justice for Women Veterans
description: Women in the military who are sexually assaulted or harassed face obstacles not seen in the civilian workplace. They cant decide to take time off or quit, often have no way to avoid a predatory colleague or supervisor, and certainly in combat zones, no way to visit the human resources department. They often work in a culture that has long tolerated misogynistic behavior. And they can be further traumatized by the indifference or hostility of the bureaucracy that is supposed to help them.

title: Heralded Girls Basketball Star Is Shot to Death in Manhattan
description: A star player in high school girls basketball was shot dead early Sunday in a building stairwell in Morningside Heights in Manhattan, the police said.

title: A Choice Made Decades Ago Comes Back to Haunt a Town
description: WEST PITTSTON, Pa.  On a flood-ravaged street on the west bank of the Susquehanna River, a pointed question is literally writ large now in white spray paint on the side of a building: Levee or view?

title: Bank Chief Has Big Job to Reassure Stockholders
description: Like a magician facing a weary audience, Bank of America faces pressure to pull another rabbit out of its hat.

title: From a Voice to a Roar, Again
description: Serena Williams was not going to win that match, anyway. Even shouting Come on! in the middle of the point was not going to lift her out of her morass.

title: Too Fast on Drilling
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has long vowed that extraction of natural gas reserves with hydraulic fracturing in New York State will not come at the expense of human health or have adverse environmental impacts. It will be hard to keep that promise if his administration moves too fast in permitting such drilling into deep shale formations. It must not rush the process of creating detailed regulations that will be crucial to reducing risks to the environment.

title: After the Match, Federer vs. Djokovic Continues
description: For all the thrills the Djokovic-Federer semifinal offered, and there were manythe fifth set alone was enough to satisfy the most rabid fanthere were additional ones to be found in the two mens post-match interviews, which exposed the chasms that separate them as competitors.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Proxy Firm Opposes Allied Bid
description: The proposed merger of Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance suffered another major blow late on Friday, as a major shareholder advisory firm recommended that investors vote against the $2.86 billion deal.

title: About These Proposals
description: The baseline figure for the total Gaza/West Bank area is 6,195 square kilometers (about 2,392 square miles), which is the relevant area won by Israel in the 1967 war. It includes the northwest portion of the Dead Sea, one-half of No Mans Land, and all of East Jerusalem, except Mount Scopus.

title: Cam Newton Appears to Be Ready for the N.F.L.
description: The only problem with Cam Newtons passing for 422 yards in his N.F.L. debut was that his Carolina Panthers needed 423.

title: Remembering Lost Loved Ones
description: Families and friends of 9/11 victims attended the tenth anniversary ceremonies.

title: Mapping Mideast Peace
description: David Makovsky proposes three land-swap scenarios that could lead to an Israeli-Palestinian peace deal.

title: Connecting With Lost Loved Ones, if Only by the Tips of Fingers
description: They clutched slips of paper bearing letters and numbers, trying to navigate a strange new map created by computer algorithm that was designed to place people next to other people whom, in life, they had cared about. The visitors looked hopeful, dazed, afraid.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include import prices for August (Tuesday); retail sales for August, business inventories for July and the Producer Price Index for August (Wednesday); the Consumer Price Index for August, the current account deficit for the second quarter, industrial production and capacity utilization for August, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for September and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and theThomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for September (Friday).

title: Cobo Victorious in Vuelta a Espaa
description: Juan Jos Cobo won the Vuelta a Espaa, protecting his 13-second lead over Christopher Froome during the traditional finish in Madrid. Peter Sagan edged the pack in a sprint to win the 21st stage, a 59-mile ride from the Circuito del Jarama race track to the city center in 2 hours 20 minutes 59 seconds. It was Sagans third stage win of the event.

title: Jacqueline Kennedy Speaks
description: In 1964, just months after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, his widow spoke about his presidency for an oral history project.

title: On Wikipedia, Echoes of 9/11 Edit Wars
description: AS the nation marked this terrible anniversary, people invariably turned to Wikipedia to learn about the events of Sept. 11, 2001. Nearly two million page views were registered last September for the article September 11 Attacks, a typically Wikipedian effort with exhaustive, even picayune, details of the events, bolstered by nearly 289 footnotes. This September, the total page view number could be something like six million.

title: Traveling Different Paths to Get the Job Done
description: The owner of Riceland Crawfish and the companys workers speak on the state of employment at the plant and in the community.

title: Seeking Citizenship and Civics
description: Do you have any title of nobility in any foreign country? If so, have I got a show for you.

title: A Lost Generation Drinks Up, Always on Jake Barness Tab
description: It takes great discipline to stay sloppy drunk for three hours and still be smart and engaging. I bet youve never achieved that. (If you think you have, your memory is lying.) So raise a brimming glass to Elevator Repair Service, which exists in what appears to be a state of perpetual and severe intoxication for the entirety of The Select (The Sun Also Rises), which opened Sunday night at the New York Theater Workshop.

title: Angels Include Yankees in Pregame Ceremony
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Before the Yankees game against the Los Angeles Angels on Sunday three first responders and survivors who took part in rescue efforts at ground zero and the Pentagon, and three Navy Seals threw out ceremonial first pitches to Derek Jeter, Mariano Rivera and Jorge Posada of the Yankees, and Torii Hunter, Jered Weaver and Manager Mike Scioscia of the Angels. Joe Torre, who was the Yankees manager in 2001, joined the Yankees as they lined up along the first-base line for the pregame ceremony.

title: Market Swings Are Becoming New Standard
description: The stock market just cant seem to make up its mind.

title: La. Business Owners Sue Over New Rules for Guest Workers
description: EUNICE, La.  The workers have been in fine spirits this summer in the small plant where Dexter Guillory cuts up alligator meat to feed the growing demand from Southern restaurants for the swamp creatures steaks.

title: Yankee Souvenir Scrutiny
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Elections Tuesday in New York State
description: Voters in New York State on Tuesday will elect a new representative from Brooklyn and Queens, as well as six members of the Assembly from around the state. Voters in some areas will also elect party nominees for a variety of local offices.

title: Battle for Libya | September 11, 2011
description: Rebel fighters advanced toward Surt and headed to the front line in Bani Walid, Libya.

title: Prosecution Seeks to Focus Trial on Election Aide, Not the Mayor

title: Wall Street Recovers After Fresh Worries Shake European Markets

title: Daniel Snyder, Owner of the Redskins, Keeps on Talking
description: Here are a few extras from my interview with the billionaire owner of the Washington Redskins, Daniel Snyder. We spoke on the afternoon of Aug. 22, just after he came off the field from watching his team practice at their Ashburn, Va., headquarters. Snyder was very eager to talk about the initiative hed embarked upon to install solar panels atop FedEx field. He sent assistants scurrying about to bring in renderings of what the field will look like after NRG, the energy company, installs them. (NRG gets some very prominent signage at FedEx for its efforts.) He seemed less eager to discuss the general antipathy that has greeted his ownership from the media, fans and even a beloved Redskins Hall of Fame Running back. Throughout the interview, he kept glancing uncomfortably at Tony Wyllie, the Redskins head of communications, who was sitting in. I honestly couldnt tell whether he was shocked that I was pursuing that particular line of questioning, or if he was so insulated that he didnt understand the depth and breadth of the criticism of the decisions hes made as owner.

title: Now Listening | Stillspotting
description: Sometimes all a New Yorker wants is a little peace and quiet. And on the extended weekends of Sept. 15-18 and Sept. 22-25, it will be available, in a very carefully fashioned version, at various locations around Lower Manhattan, as part of To a Great City, the second installment of Stillspotting Nyc, a two-year multidisciplinary program by the Guggenheim Museum. Organized by David van der Leer, the museums associate curator in architecture and urban studies, and Sarah Malaika, a project associate, To a Great City is a collaboration between the Estonian composer Arvo Part and the Norwegian architecture firm Snohetta. It creates urban soundscapes in five downtown locations that, according to the museums press release, quietly celebrate the city, 10 years after the Sept. 11 attacks. The locations include a green labyrinth created by the Battery Conservancy, an underground chamber at the Governors Island National Monument, and spaces in landmark skyscrapers that are normally inaccessible to the public. For a $10 admission fee, visitors will be given a map, directions and a one-day pass to each of the stillspots for a self-guided tour, which takes about three hours; reservations are recommended. In conjunction with the project, visitors can identify and map their own favorite quiet spots as part of Create Your Own Stillspot at stillspotting.guggenheim.org.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Diane von Furstenberg
description: Am I done? Joan Smalls asked Orlando Pita backstage at Diane von Furstenberg as he fixed her teased out beehive. Done, he said as she coyly examined his curly hair. Done done? Smalls asked knowing there may be yet another round of Orlando Pita hair spray to keep the look in place. Surprisingly, it wasnt the 60s that inspired the up-do that Pita referred to as Kim Novak-y, rather Von Furstenbergs starting point for the collection: New Beginnings. For makeup, this meant James Kaliardos used M.A.C. products for a face inspired by the land where it all began: Africa. The idea was to highlight the planes and tones of the face using an earthy (literally) palette of eight Crme Color Base shades, including Ochre, Pale Peach and Dark Brown. The inner and outer corner of the eye was highlighted with a khaki variation, while the middle of the lid was done in white or yellow. There was no lip, just as nails were kept clean, coated with only Sally Hansens Hard as Nails. Kaliardos described the ingenuity of the woman who inspired him, No matter her economic situation, she finds a way to look beautiful regal even.

title: The Arctic Ice Watch

For a reminder of just how dynamic the ice is, click on the video above, which I shot near the North Pole in March, 2003, while standing with Tim Stanton, an expert on ice and oceans at the Naval Postgraduate School, next to a developing ridge where two floes were colliding. (We were drifting around 400 yards an hour at the time; all the sound is the crunching and huffing of the ice.)

title: Dustin Hoffman Graduates to Film Director
description: Hey, Im directin here! Im directin here! Hes an excellent driver, a two-time Academy Award winner for Kramer Vs. Kramer and Rain Man, a magnet for New York taxis (at least in the guise of Ratso Rizzo from Midnight Cowboy) and now, finally, Dustin Hoffman has become a film director. On Monday, production began on Quartet, Mr. Hoffmans feature-directing debut, its press representatives announced. The film, which is expected to shoot for nine weeks in Buckinghamshire, England, stars Tom Courtenay (whose previous films include Doctor Zhivago in 1965), Billy Connolly (Mrs. Brown) and Pauline Collins (Shirley Valentine) as residents of a home for retired opera singers. Their annual plans for a fund-raising concert, held on Verdis birthday, are disrupted by the arrival of a down-on-her-luck grande dame (played by Maggie Smith, the Downton Abbey, Gosford Park and Harry Potter star). The screenplay for Quartet is by Ronald Harwood, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of The Pianist and The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, and adapted from his play of the same title. Mr. Hoffman is also a producer on the film, which is financed by BBC Films, DCM Productions and Decca. An American distributor and release date for Quartet were not immediately announced.

title: Horwich Wins Lasker Award by Straddling Science and Medicine
description: NEW HAVEN  Medicine is a divided world. On one side are the doctors, who come face to face with illness each day and try to heal their patients with whatever tools they can get their hands on. On the other are the researchers, who explore the bodys microscopic complexity, never sure whether their discoveries will ever end up in the hands of the doctors.

title: Forsaken Fisher
description: Another nice piece from Sylvia Nasar, this time about Irving Fisher and the foundations of macroeconomics. Fisher remains hugely relevant to this day, and in particular to my own thinking about the mess were in.

title: Now Screening | Co, in Mysterious Company
description: To celebrate their spring/summer 2012 collection, theCo designers Stephanie Danan and Justin Kern collaborated with Daft Punks Thomas Bangalter and the actress lodie Bouchez on a short film.

title: A.N.C. Official Convicted of Hate Speech
description: In a ruling that tugged at South Africas racial wounds, a judge said Monday that a firebrand youth leader was guilty of hate speech for singing an apartheid-era freedom song that includes lyrics calling on people to shoot white farmers.

title: No Makeup Makeup at Diane Von Furstenberg
description: James Kaliardos, the makeup artist who led the MAC Pro team for Diane Von Furstenbergs spring 2012 collection, took a few minutes backstage at the designers show on Sunday to talk about trends, and to explain the look he created. One of his inspirations, he said, was an African face, because African women have found this way to look absolutely stunning no matter what the situation is. So he wanted to use makeup strategically to give the models natural features more impact.

title: Romo Admits It Was His Fault
description: Sometimes a quarterback points the finger at himself to shield a teammate from criticism. It can be part of leadership.

title: The Numbers Behind an Urgent Fight
description: If the trend that, since the 1970s, has led to striking increases in the proportion of Americans who are overweight or obese is not halted, about three of every four Americans will be overweight or obese by 2020.

title: Nadal vs. Djokovic: Keys to the Final
description: Rafael Nadal must significantly update his game plan if he has any hope of beating Novak Djokovic in todays U.S. Open mens singles final.

title: New Song From Winehouse and Comments From Her Father
description: On the same day it was announced that Amy Winehouses last recording  a duet with Tony Bennett  would be released on Wednesday, her father said she had been experiencing seizures related to alcohol withdrawal in the weeks before her death.

title: Runway In Review
description: Derek LamDesigner: Derek LamDate and Location: Sunday, Lincoln Center, StagePhotos: slide show

title: Bourdain to Have His Own Line of Books
description: Anthony Bourdain, the celebrity chef, author and reality TV star, will acquire books for Ecco, an imprint of HarperCollins, the publisher said on Monday. Mr. Bourdain has been given a line of books that is expected to release three to five titles each year, which Ecco said in a statement would reflect his remarkably eclectic tastes. Daniel Halpern, the president and publisher of Ecco, said that Mr. Bourdain has been an informal adviser to him for about 10 years, a period during which Mr. Bourdains own books were published by Ecco. His intuition has been unerring  suggesting such authors as Ferran Adria and Fergus Henderson, Mr. Halpern said in an e-mail. Now hes becoming one of us, sort of.

title: It Was Raining Glass and Metal
description: Ronald Carletta has spent nearly 20 years at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. In September 2001, he was a supervisory auditor at the agencys New York office in the World Trade Center. Ten years after terrorist attacks destroyed that office, Mr. Carletta has become a branch chief for the Division of Clearing and Intermediary Oversight. He remains in the New York office, which has relocated a few blocks from its former home.

title: Shark-Fin Vote Adds to Pressure on Hong Kong
description: As Elisabeth Rosenthal reported in Sundays Times, the battle to protect the worlds endangered shark population has passed another major milestone with a California Senate vote that bans the possession, sale and distribution of shark fins.

title: Chemotherapy for Dogs
description: When a beloved pet is found to have cancer, many owners arent sure whether they should pursue aggressive treatments. John Rennie, the former editor of Scientific American, faced this decision when brain and lung tumors were diagnosed in his dog. He chose to give his dog chemotherapy treatment, an issue he wrote about recently in the online magazine Txchnologist. One of the surprises he encountered: Chemotherapy, while it creates many challenges for dogs, is often less grueling than it is for humans.

title: Martha Plimpton in 'Raising Hope'
description: The actress was nominated for an Emmy for her performance in the Fox sitcom "Raising Hope."

title: Rare Birds at Carolina Herrera
description: A sociologist looking to understand the vast diversity of species that cohabitate the fashion kingdom would do well to observe the audience at a Carolina Herrera show.

title: Giffords to Appear With Diane Sawyer
description: 5:59 p.m. | Updated | ABC News said Monday that its top anchor, Diane Sawyer, had booked the first sit down interview with Representative Gabrielle Giffords, the Arizona Democrat, since she was critically injured in a shooting spree in Tucson eight months ago.

title: Finding the Next NetLogic
description: Broadcom is opening its wallet wide  to the tune of $3.7 billion  to acquire NetLogic, a maker of advanced chips for routers.

title: At a Bronx Hospital, a Teenage Milestone
description: Jessica Earnshaw recalls feeling somewhat overwhelmed while she photographed the childrens prom at Montefiore Medical Center, talking and laughing with the participants as she worked.

title: Arrington Is Out at AOL and TechCrunch
description: Michael Arrington, the TechCrunch blogger turned venture capitalist, is no longer an employee of AOL.

title: New York Fashion Week Diary
description: The Moment follows model Tom Bull during New York Fashion Week. Directed by Isaac Hindin Miller of the blog isaaclikes.com.

title: Just One Look | The Row Spring 2012 Collection
description: At Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsens presentation Friday morning, spring was heralded not with a bang but a whisper. The predominantly all-white collection was almost Zen-like in its restraint (among the few accessories was a strand of oversize prayer beads), but moments of breathtaking embellishment, like a kimono-inspired gown with a silver beaded bodice or this look with its mother-of-pearl-button cuffs, sent the spirits soaring.

title: Attacking the Obesity Epidemic by First Figuring Out Its Cause
description: If you have gained a lot of unwanted pounds at any time during the last 30-odd years, you may be relieved to know that you are probably not to blame. At least not entirely.

title: Social Status and How the Elected Vote
description: FiveThirtyEight extends a hearty welcome to John Sides, a political scientist at George Washington University, who will be writing a series of posts for this site over the next month.

title: Statistics, M.L.S. and the Castrol Index
description: Soccer will never make it in the United States, or so goes the conventional wisdom. It was once called the sport of the 80s. The 90s brought the World Cup and the start of Major League Soccer. A new century began with a run to the quarterfinals of the World Cup.

title: Anthony Bourdain to Acquire Books for Ecco
description: Over at the culture desks ArtsBeat blog, Julie Bosman has a post announcing a new job for Anthony Bourdain. In addition to his work on television, Mr. Bourdain is set to acquire a number of books each year for Ecco, a subsidiary of HarperCollins run by the polymath epicure and poet Daniel Halpern.

title: Madonna Finds Friends in Toronto
description: TORONTO  Madonna showed up on Monday to fight for her new film, W.E., at the Toronto International Film Festival. But nobody called her out.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 4
description: Scenes from Sunday: Wren screening and Timo Weiland after party

title: Detroit Sets Its Future on a Foundation of Two-Tier Wages
description: DETROIT  They are a cornerstone of Chryslers unlikely comeback: 900 employees turning out a Jeep Grand Cherokee sport utility vehicle every 48 seconds of the working day at an assembly plant here.

title: On Eve of 9/11, Celebratory Fireworks Rattle Nerves
description: On Saturday evening, many New York and New Jersey residents were preparing for the somber ceremonies of the next day when they heard noises from a different kind of ceremony.

title: For Many Older Gays, a Toll of Time and Isolation
description: Long after I had asked the paramedics to stop chest compressions, I was more dejected and frustrated by this patients death than by almost any I had experienced as a physician.

title: Sleeping Sickness: Blood Test Could Be a Breakthrough in Field Diagnosis of Tropical Diseases
description: A new blood test for sleeping sickness that may prove to be the first major breakthrough in the field diagnosis of tropical diseases is to be unveiled in Mali this week by a Geneva-based foundation working with a Japanese chemical company.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Derek Lam
description: It was the architect Richard Neutras rigorous West Coast houses that inspired the beauty look at Derek Lam  that and the color yellow. Both may be odd inspirations for hair and makeup, but thats what makes them so welcome. Better yellow and geometry than another repeat reference, though the look wasnt totally different from last time around. This collections an evolution from last season, not a complete change, Orlando Pita said. The hair has that feeling too. This meant a low side-parted ponytail instead of hair pulled back at the crown without a visible barrette. Clean, simple lines, is how Pita described the look he created using Phyto Volume Active Mousse, blow drying with a T3 featherweight Luxe, then sealing the ends with Phyto 7 and a T3 Single Pass iron. The hair was then scraped back into a ponytail with a part over the right eye. Pita used Phyto Finishing Spray and a little Shine Defining Wax to make it perfectly done. Nails were painted Este Lauders Nude Attitude, but it was the eyes that went a little wild. Tom Pecheux (Este Lauders creative makeup director) explained the Neutra connection by making references to large windows that let the outdoor weather into the house, which became a ray of yellow from Este Lauder Rain Boots shadow on the lid highlighted with Cyber Copper brown shimmer all the way to the brow bone. Citron Kiss lip gloss was the final step. Canary colored in the vial, its the perfect way to warm up another lip color or let the light in for spring.

title: Interview: Guy Maddin
description: The director Guy Maddin discusses the varied elements of his film "Keyhole," which tells a gangster ghost story.

title: A Childs Nap Is More Complicated Than It Looks
description: What makes a child nap? Most parents cherish toddlers naps as moments of respite and recharging, for parent and child alike; we are all familiar with the increased crankiness that comes when a nap is unduly delayed or evaded. But napping behavior has been somewhat taken for granted, even by sleep scientists, and napping problems have often been treated by pediatricians as parents limit-setting problems.

title: White House Videographer Writes Book
description: Arun Chaudhary, the first official White House videographer, has written a book about the experience, to be published by Times Books, a division of Henry Holt and Company. Mr. Chaudhary, who was hired in 2007 to work on the Obama campaign, followed Mr. Obama to the White House and recently left the staff. His book will tell the story of what it means to follow the president and be available 24/7 to record history; to be a video Boswell, as it were; how to use art, media and politics as a prism to capture history and record the quotidian moments even of the president, a statement from the publisher said. The book is scheduled for publication in summer 2012.

title: Trendspotting: Ophelia
description: Looks from Helmut Lang, The Row, Band of Outsiders and more.

title: Drifting Away from Hard Edged
description: As the has week progressed, a handful of designers turned their backs on hard-edged urbanity in favor of a style as pale and wraithlike as Ophelia. Their fabrics, which sometimes drifted in sheer panels to the floor, lent their collections an air of fragile dishabille.

title: New Knorr Ad
description: A new ad for Knorr stock features a chef, Marco Pierre White.

title: Macro Photography 101: Extreme Close-Ups
description: If, as poetess Ella Wheeler Wilcox is right, a weed is but an unloved flower, then there are no weeds in the work of Tony Sweet. Mr. Sweet is a macro photographer whose close-up pictures practically caress the petals of the flowers that are his primary subject.

title: The Caucus | Tea Party Debate Preview
description: Sept. 12, 2011 - A look ahead to Monday's Republican debate focused on the Tea Party. Also, the White House photographer on covering President Obama during the 10-year anniversary of 9/11.

title: Bug Labs and Ford Team Up on Geeky Gear for Cars
description: Get ready to start hacking your own car.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Arnold Worldwide, Boston, opened an office in Shanghai. The office has 10 employees and there are plans to hire about 20 more by the end of the year. Arnold Worldwide is part of the Havas Worldwide division of Havas.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Unilever Tries to Corner Stock Market
description: Once, it was fashionable for marketers of packaged foods to center their campaigns on brand characters like Betty Crocker, Martha White and Aunt Jemima. Today, Madison Avenue is following a new recipe.

title: Union Square Pedestrian Plaza Is Declared a Success
description: The citys Department of Transportation has declared its pedestrian plaza on the north side of Union Square, the fourth such major street revamping along Broadway, an out-and-out success, despite some early qualms from residents.

title: Ban on E. Coli in Ground Beef Is to Extend to 6 More Strains
description: The federal government will ban the sale of ground beef tainted with six toxic strains of E. coli bacteria that are increasingly showing up as the cause of severe illness from food. Officials have been under pressure from food safety advocates and some elected officials to do more to keep the potentially deadly bacteria out of meat, but the beef industry said the move was not needed and could force the price of ground beef to rise.

title: BMG Rights Buys Music Publisher for $300 Million
description: BMG Rights Management, a new music company backed by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is buying Bug Music, a midsize publisher of songs like What a Wonderful World and I Walk the Line, the company announced on Monday.

title: Ristretto | Some Coffee in Your Milk
description: This Fashion Week, Blue Bottle Coffee set up shop on the ground floor of Milk Studios in a converted loading dock with a view of the sidewalk paparazzi snapping the editors and bloggers heading to the shows upstairs. Blue Bottle shares the space with Bleach London, Butter London Nails and Creatures of Comfort as a part of the Aldo Salon pop-up. Shoes, hair, nails, printed matter, coffee  its a concentrated little scene, a lot of taste and style distilled into a tiny storefront.

title: Caucus Video: Tea Party Debate Preview; A Photojournalist on the 9/11 Anniversary
description: A look ahead to tonights Republican debate, focusing on the Tea Party. Also, Doug Mills, The Timess White House photographer, on covering President Obama and former President George W. Bush on Sunday at the ceremony at ground zero for the 10th anniversary of 9/11.

title: Emmys Watch: Martha Plimpton
description: We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards telecast on Sept. 18.

title: In Crisis Mode, and Focused on a Return to Normalcy
description: Jonathan Doyle is a managing principal of Sandler ONeill, an investment banking and brokerage firm, and member of the firms executive committee. On Sept. 11, 2001, he was a senior executive in the firms fixed-income unit.

title: Strauss-Kahn Questioned on Accusations of 2003 Sexual Assault
description: PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund who returned to Paris last week after New York prosecutors dropped rape charges against him, was questioned for three hours on Monday about a sexual assault complaint dating to 2003, his lawyers said.

title: The Cough That Launched a Hit Movie
description: When Hollywood turns to medicine, accuracy generally heads for the hills. But the creators of the new action thriller Contagion went to unprecedented lengths to fact-check their story of a destructive viral pandemic, retaining a panel of nationally renowned virologists and epidemiologists as consultants. The intent was to infuse the usual hyperbole with an extra frisson: This is the way it could really happen. Be very afraid.

title: More About the 9/11 Anniversary
description: It looks as if I should say a bit more about yesterdays anniversary. So:

title: A Squirt of Insulin May Delay Alzheimers
description: A small pilot study has found preliminary evidence that squirting insulin deep into the nose where it travels to the brain might hold early Alzheimers disease at bay, researchers said on Monday.

title: The New American Muslim
description: Though Peter Casey was raised by a Christian dad and a Jewish mom, he converted to Islam as a young teenager. Now, he uses social media to find out what it means to be Muslim in America.

title: In Frankfurt, Ford Wont Wait for Tuesday
description: The press previews for the Frankfurt auto show wont begin until 8:30 Tuesday morning. That wont stop some automakers, including Ford, from showing their most important production vehicles and concept cars on Monday evening around the city.

title: Savoring That Djokovic Shot
description: Down double match point, with Roger Federer serving at 5-3 in the fifth set, Novak Djokovic looked like a beaten man. The crowd stood ready to explode at Federers triumph, clearly rooting for the upset. But Djokovic decided to gamble, to double down on his bet and give the wheel one more spin. He guessed right on Federers choice of a wide slice to the forehand, unleashed a huge forehand crosscourt winner on the return, then seemed to laugh at the absurdity of the moment.

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at Bard
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 12th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Bard College.

title: Learning to Love Okra
description: Until lately, I hadnt been a fan of okra. But then I learned how cooks in the eastern and southern Mediterranean treat this popular vegetable: they cook it whole, after tossing it with salt and vinegar and marinating it for an hour to make it less, well, slimy. Some regional cooks dry okra in the sun after salting it.

title: Serena Williams Is Fined $2,000
description: One day after her latest outburst at the United States Open, Serena Williams received a $2,000 fine for a code violation of verbal abuse during Sundays womens singles final.

title: Susan and David
description: Susan and David discuss their first encounter and travel plans for the future.

title: Maxim Healthcare Pays $150 Million in Fraud Case
description: Maxim Healthcare Services, a privately held company with 360 offices nationwide offering home health care services, has agreed to pay about $150 million to settle civil and criminal charges over claims of false billings to Medicaid and the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department of Justice announced Monday.

title: The Black Banners Excerpts
description: The Central Intelligence Agency redacted what it considered to be classified information from a memoir by Ali H. Soufan, a former F.B.I. counterterrorism expert, including references to I, me and my.

title: New York Fashion Week | Tom Bull
description: Isaac Hindin Miller follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull to a fitting for Marith + Franois Girbaud.

title: New York Fashion Week Diary | Tom Bull
description: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week. In this clip, Bull heads to a fitting for Marith + Franois Girbaud. I am able to self-discipline in this industry, Bull says. I have sat in these huge queues, and it has paid off.

title: Critics Picks: Goodfellas
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Martin Scorseses ultra-violent mob film from 1990.

title: Hospital Executive Is Convicted of Political Bribery
description: A former hospital chief executive was convicted on Monday in a far-reaching scheme to pay bribes to three New York State legislators in return for beneficial treatment toward his health care organization, MediSys Health Network.

title: Jim & Jamie
description: Jim and Jamie describe bonding over good food and a shared love of sea glass.

title: In Study, Fatherhood Leads to Drop in Testosterone
description: This is probably not the news most fathers want to hear.

title: A Delayed Flight, and a Lucky Break
description: Jeanette Schwarz Young is the director of the Chartered Market Technician program for the Market Technicians Association and the president of the American Association of Professional Technical Analysts. On Sept. 11, 2001, she was working as a broker at the New York Board of Trade.

title: Rajaratnams Defiant Approach to Sentencing
description: Raj Rajaratnam and Zvi Goffer both went to trial to fight insider trading charges, and both were convicted largely on the strength of wiretap evidence. As their sentencing dates approach later this month, they are taking almost diametrically opposed approaches in asking for sentences well below the prison terms called for by the advisory federal sentencing guidelines.

title: Replacing Schwabs Late, Great Rewards Card
description: Holders of Charles Schwabs Invest First Visa credit card, which paid 2 percent cash back on all purchases, are learning this month about their replacement options for the card, which, sadly, was discontinued by Schwab. Bucks has written previously about the demise of the card, which was one of the best deals out there in the world of rewards plastic.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 12
description: The day in sports included the world wrestling championships in Istanbul and volleyball championships in Europe.

title: At Frankfurt Show, German Auto Firms Hope to Rise Above the Gloom
description: FRANKFURT  There may be no better cure for a banker suffering the sovereign debt blues than a new Porsche, and few cities with more bankers in need of solace than Frankfurt.

title: Fears Rattle Big Banks in France
description: PARIS  French banks moved toward the center of the European debt storm Monday as investor concern about their ability to handle a potential Greek default raised the possibility that Frances government might need to shore up the banks financial positions.

title: A new experiment in gene therapy for cancer, tracking a tree-killing insect and comparing the movie Contagion to real-life epidemics.
description: A new experiment in gene therapy for cancer, tracking a tree-killing insect and comparing the movie Contagion to real-life epidemics.

title: Where the Big Girls Are | Tommy Hilfiger
description: The photographer JD Ferguson gets close up on the biggest faces in fashion.

title: Guy Maddin Looks Through the Keyhole
description: TORONTO  Not even the director Guy Maddin is certain how to classify a Guy Maddin movie. The Winnipeg-born filmmaker is known for his experimental, black-and-white, sometimes silent, often strange films that tackle issues in a surreal way. He delivers another puzzler with Keyhole, a film starring Jason Patric that could be described as a gangster ghost drama, although it is loosely based on Homers Odyssey. Mr. Maddin offers an explanation of the film and gives some insight into his creative process.

title: Attacking a Tumor
description: An annotated video showing how cells have been engineered to attack tumor cells.

title: Axa Equitable Pitches in an Online Game
description: 3:55 p.m. | Updated Playing games online, known as online gaming or casual gaming, is becoming increasingly popular with marketers because it is becoming increasingly popular with consumers. Even companies in categories that have not been taking part in the trend are starting to, well, play.

title: Where They Were: Using Maps Across the Curriculum
description: Because The New York Times features multimedia every day, and because we believe that being literate means being able to read images and graphics as well as text, each Monday this school year well present a short lesson plan using Times multimedia.

title: Fortunate to Survive, but Left Wondering, Why Me?
description: On Sept. 11, 2001, Britt Newhouse was the president of the Americas operations of Guy Carpenter & Company, a reinsurance intermediary and a subsidiary of Marsh & McLennan. Of the 295 Marsh employees who died in the attacks on Sept. 11, 29 were Guy Carpenter employees. Today, Mr. Newhouse is Guy Carpenters chairman.

title: The Moral Hazard of Underwater Zombies
description: On a happier topic, I think Brad DeLong has come up with a brilliant hypothesis here. Regarding European policy makers,

title: Rome Opera Not Happy About Losing Conductor to the Met
description: The Rome Opera has leveled unusually harsh criticism for the outwardly genteel world of opera houses at the conductor Fabio Luisi, who canceled performances there and elsewhere to fill in for James Levine at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Luisi has long been on standby for the ailing Mr. Levine and was elevated from principal guest conductor to principal conductor, the Met said last week in announcing his last-minute substitute role.

title: Bernadette Peters: Ghosts of Follies
description: The actress talks about playing Sally in the Broadway revival of the musical "Follies."

title: Is SpongeBob SquarePants Bad for Children?
description: New research on children and television has put SpongeBob Squarepants on the hot seat.

title: Videos Depicting Beating of Protesters in Syria Spread Online
description: The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Navi Pillay, gave a staggering death toll from the violence in Syria as she addressed the opening session of the human rights council in Geneva on Monday. With regard to Syria, let me note that, according to reliable sources on the ground, the number of those killed since the onset of the unrest in mid-March 2011 in that country, has now reached at least 2,600, she said.

title: With Ruling, Mayors Spending May Enter Trial of Former Aide
description: A Manhattan judge on Monday refused to bar defense lawyers from exploring Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs campaign spending habits in the trial of one of his former political consultants.

title: Passes in the Air, and Points in Bunches
description: The groundwork was laid Thursday night at Green Bay. Seventy-six points, 731 passing yards, no interceptions, defensive coordinators reaching for the antacid. Its a quaint idea that defenses are ahead of offenses early in the N.F.L. season because offenses require more precise timing that takes longer to hone. But it probably hasnt been true for a while, not since football tilted so heavily to the pass. And it certainly isnt true this season.

title: On Carrie Bradshaws Block, Romance Over 6 Decades
description: The house where Carrie Bradshaw lived, supposedly on the Upper East Side but actually at 66 Perry Street in the West Village, still draws a steady stream of Sex and the City fans. They snap photosof the row house, which was built in 1866, as if to partake in the fictional life of a New York writer and the foibles of her quest for lasting romance.

title: Blue-Eyed Muslim Convert Challenges Stereotypes
description: Peter Casey, or AbdulMalik as he is known online, often rides a skateboard to the mosque and rarely thinks twice about performing his prostrations at a Starbucks. Mr. Casey, a 23-year-old recent Queens College graduate, does not do it out of a rebellious impulse to defy Muslim orthodoxy. Rather, he says he seeks to challenge stereotypes and misconceptions others have about his faith.

title: Rwandan Leader, in Paris, Seeks to Ease Tensions
description: PARIS  President Paul Kagame of Rwanda met President Nicolas Sarkozy on Monday in a fence-mending exercise on the Rwandans first official bilateral visit to France since the genocide in his country in 1994.

title: TimesCast | September 12, 2011
description: Fresh European economic fears lead to historic market volatility; a study shows that fathering children can lower testosterone; and a Times presidential photographer reflects on the 9/11 anniversary.

title: Self-Regulatory Group May Gain Power in House Plan
description: Lawmakers on Capitol Hill are weighing plans to outsource the governments authority over Wall Street, aiming to shift some power from the Securities and Exchange Commission to groups backed by the financial industry.

title: Donna Karan, to a Tribal Beat
description: Just a quick dispatch about Donna Karan on a busy Monday afternoon of back-to-back shows. Ms. Karan held her  show in a gallery in far-off Chelsea, where Wyclef Jean showed up in a cute straw ball cap and rhinestone studded jeans. Ms. Karan said she has been traveling to Haiti over the last year and plans to have a party tonight celebrating a group of Haitian artists.

title: Callahan Fills Drurys Role as Captain of Rangers
description: Ryan Callahan was named the captain of the Rangers on Monday, succeeding Chris Drury, who retired in August after agreeing to a buyout from the team in June.

title: Understanding a Childs Nap Time
description: In this weeks 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass focuses on every parents favorite subject, the childhood nap. She writes:

title: Dress Code | Carolina Herrera
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#857", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Jindal to Endorse Perry
description: Bobby Jindal, the Republican governor of Louisiana, has decided to endorse Gov. Rick Perrys presidential bid, according to a source familiar with the discussions between the two men.

title: Keys to the White House Historian Responds
description: Allan J. Lichtman, the presidential historian at American University whose Keys to the White House system we posted a critique of here last week, has kindly prepared a response. (Mr. Lichtmans system forecasts that President Obama is a heavy favorite to be re-elected in 2012.)

title: Buildings in 2 Southeastern Cities Are Evacuated as 9/11 Security Concerns Linger
description: The 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks passed without major incident, but jitters about terrorism that led to alerts across the country on the ground and in the skies were still being felt on Monday.

title: Back to School | Tatiana von Furstenbergs Tanner Hall
description: When Hurricane Irene rained all over the planned Southampton screening of Tatiana von Furstenberg and Francesca Gregorinis coming-of-age boarding school drama, Tanner Hall, the duo  best friends since their own teenage years at Brown  decided to move the festivities to Los Angeles. Pulled together in three days by Von Furstenberg, last Tuesdays low-key premiere at the Vista Theater in Los Feliz (followed by food-truck fare at picnic tables instead of dinner at Nobu) nonetheless boasted the star wattage of the cast members Brie Larson, Amy Ferguson, Chris Kattan and The Girl With the Dragon Tattoos Rooney Mara, in one of her first lead roles as the films protagonist, Fernanda.

title: Scientists Pursue an Unusual Tactic Against Alzheimers
description: A small experimental pilot study has found preliminary evidence that aerosolized insulin, squirted deep into the nose, might hold early Alzheimers disease at bay, The Times reported on Monday. Read the full article, Squirts of Insulin May Delay Alzheimers, and share your thoughts in the comments section.

title: A Jekyll-and-Hyde Act for the Feathered Set
description: Honeyguides, as the name suggests, are birds that guide humans to beehives. After the people take their fill of honey, the birds feed on the remaining beeswax.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kenya, Libya, Thailand and New York.

title: Post-Labor Day Slump, and Security, Hit Broadway Box Office
description: Ticket sales for most Broadway shows fell sharply last week, marking the traditional start of the post-Labor Day slump for musicals and plays when the tourist season is over and families are focused on the start of school. Some Broadway producers also said the 9/11 anniversary ceremonies and the heavy security in Times Square were factors in relatively weak sales for Sunday performances.

title: Perrys Tone on Social Security Takes a Turn
description: The language Rick Perry used to describe Social Security in a USA Today opinion article on Monday was anything but inflammatory  and strikingly different in tone than his recent book and statements on the campaign trail.

title: Cavefish Keep Time Without the Sun
description: Cavefish are ancient, scaleless, live in total darkness and lack any pigment. Now researchers have discovered that they have another unusual feature: a circadian rhythm, or body clock, of 47 hours, about twice the length of most animals, including humans.

title: The Grandparents of 9/11
description: So many things I had forgotten in 10 years, all of it brought back yesterday as I read and watched and remembered.

title: The Tricks and Tech Keeping Charlie Kimball, Diabetic IndyCar Driver, on the Track
description: BALTIMORE  Charlie Kimball has spoken often about how he learned at age 22 to manage the disease that threatened to end his career. Less has been said, however, about the technology and trial-and-error engineering that enabled him to race at the highest level of motorsports.

title: Surface Matters for Tennis
description: So, for the fourth year in a row, the mens final at the U.S. Open is taking place on a weekday. At least it will be easier to watch online at work this afternoon than this seasons midweek Champions League soccer games, which start tomorrow. For the latter, youre stuck with match trackers and minute-by-minute commentary (admittedly, a kind of keyboard art form in the fingers of the Guardian writers)  or maybe pirate video feeds from the likes of Vietnam  whereas the U.S. Open live-streams the match.

description: SANA, Yemen  Yemens official news agency published a decree on Monday signed by President Ali Abdullah Saleh granting his deputy the authority to negotiate and sign a deal to transfer power, a move that appeared to offer a nod to the governments formal opposition without actually meeting its demands.

description: Although the models backstage at Band of Outsiders may have looked like Princess Leia, the double buns were just a step in the process of creating a look inspired by a very different 1970s film, Picnic at Hanging Rock. The Australian cult classic about a group of Victorian-era schoolgirls who have gone missing  I think Im the only one besides Scott [Sternberg, the Band of Outsiders designer] in this building who has seen it, said the makeup artist Dick Page  set the tone for the girl-girl look, one of two for the spring 2012 show.

title: An Immune System Trained to Kill Cancer

Mr. Ludwig, then 65, a retired corrections officer from Bridgeton, N.J., felt his life draining away and thought he had nothing to lose.

title: 36 Light-Years From Here, New Hope for an Earth-Like Planet
description: European astronomers said Monday that they had found what might be the best candidate for a Goldilocks planet yet: a lump of something about 3.6 times as massive as the Earth, circling its star at the right distance for liquid water to exist on its surface  and thus, perhaps, to host life, as we narrowly imagine it.
