description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#706", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Day 5: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 12.

title: For Family, 9/11 Is Uninvited Guest
description: Richard Nelson knows what you were thinking on Sunday. Oh, not everything, of course. But if you see (and you need to) his soul-stirring new play, Sweet and Sad, at the Public Theater, the odds are that youll experience the kind of shivery moments that come when someone articulates ideas that have been lurking in your head, unexpressed and perhaps even unrecognized.

title: NFL Puts NBC on Top of Ratings
description: Another nail-biting National Football League game provided NBC with record-breaking numbers on Sunday, soundly beating the other broadcast networks in overall viewers and among the advertiser-coveted demographic of 18- to 49-year-olds. After the New York Jets completed their comeback against the Dallas Cowboys with a 50-yard field goal, winning the game 27-24, preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates revealed that it was the highest rated Sunday Night Football game since the program moved to NBC in 2006. Final audience figures were not available on Monday.

title: Suzuki Seeks to Dissolve Volkswagen Partnership
description: TOKYO  In a sharp rebuff to its partner of nearly two years, Suzuki Motor announced Monday that it would seek to end its alliance with Volkswagen, saying no progress had been made on joint projects. It is also asking Volkswagen to sell back its 19.9 percent stake in Suzuki.

title: Europe Extends Copyright on Music
description: In a victory for the financially troubled recording industry, the European Union on Monday extended the term of copyright on sound recordings to 70 years from 50, while declining to include provisions that would allow artists in Britain and elsewhere in Europe to recoup ownership of their music easily. Had the Council of the European Union not acted, many of the most famous and popular recordings of the British Invasion of the 1960s, including albums by the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, the Who and the Yardbirds, would have fallen into the public domain in the coming years. For example, the Beatles first hit record, Love Me Do, which was released in 1962, could have been treated next year in much the same way as works by classical composers whose exclusive ownership of their music has expired. With multiple versions available at cheaper prices, the four major record labels would be deprived of one of their biggest sources of income.

title: TimesCast | Testosterone Lower in Dads
description: A new study shows that fatherhood leads to lower testosterone.

title: Rental Car Roulette
description: Travelers who rent cars frequently may wonder why the same four-door midsize sedan has a drastically different price tag depending on where the car is rented.

title: A Bird in Flight (Actually, Perched in the Cabin)
description: ILOVE flying, especially takeoff. For me, its a great feeling rolling down the runway, and when the nose of the plane goes up I feel like Im breaking away a little bit from all of the bonds and stresses of daily life.

title: Bloomberg Gives Larry David a Hard Time
description: It was a gig that a thousand out-of-work actors would die for: a cameo on Sunday nights season finale of Curb Your Enthusiasm, Larry Davids homage to his own bottomless neurosis on HBO.

title: Halibut in Foil Packets With North African Flavors
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Good Things Inside Foil Packages
description: FOLDING fish fillets, boneless poultry or almost any vegetable into a tightly sealed foil package, ready to be baked to order, is an easy standby for the indoor and outdoor cook. In fact, this method could have been made for campfires, where the closed packages may be partly buried in the embers to steam-cook.

description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: 9/11 Recalled  Islamabad
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Had 9/11 not happened, I would have had a different life, a different profession.

title: Taking Advantage of a Destructive Insects Weakness for Purple
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  The cartoon-purple boxes are hard to miss. The foresters who hang them from roadside trees all over the country call them Barney traps, for the friendly dinosaur whose color they resemble, but their purpose is anything but gentle.

title: Young Attention Spans Impaired by SpongeBob and Rapid Games, Study Says
description: Studies have found that children who watch television and play fast-paced interactive games can, in the long run, experience challenges with focus and attention. A study published today in the Journal of Pediatrics suggests that such activity can also have immediate impact on a childs neurological functions.

title: In Toronto, a Film That Altered Many Lives
description: TORONTO  Documentarians, those habitual defenders of lifes losers, do not often get to win one.

title: In 3-Way Race for Assembly, Tough Last-Minute Campaigning
description: In the final, frantic hours of campaigning for that other special election in Brooklyn  in the 54th Assembly District  the three-way race has taken on a muddy cast.

title: Inspiring Young Minds and Holding Some Secrets
description: Surely youve heard this story before. Its about a charismatic high school teacher named Will. Hes in his 30s, and hes comfortable around his students, so he doesnt mind when some call him dude or Mr. S. He challenges their religious beliefs, politicizes the apolitical among them, helps the meek to find their voices; at one time or another, nearly everyone in his class develops a crush on him. But no matter what the school administrators say, he understands and respects the boundaries between teacher and pupil. Or at least thats true most of the time.

title: With Fees Here to Stay, Trying to Crack the Code
description: ELLEN TROTOCHAUD works for a firm that helps companies manage travel and expense costs, and even she acknowledges that shes often baffled by the subject of airline fees.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Tommy Hilfiger
description: Im not reinventing the wheel, was how Eugene Souleiman introduced the sleek, simple ponytail at Tommy Hilfiger, before adding, But for Tommy, I am. Because Tommy does that healthy, American girl with bouncy hair, and Im doing something very clean, very sharp, and very chic. This shift from previous seasons (it was Souleiman who was behind those healthy, bouncy heads of hair at the fall 2011 show) was implemented through flat ironing strands with the help of Wellas Shine Finish, which he called liquid gold, then tucking hair back behind the ears before pulling it into a low ponytail tied with a thin black elastic. To achieve a graphic but not hard, product-y look, Souleiman squirted a bit of Wella Professionals Stay Essential Finishing Spray on a brush blush before running it over the surface of the hair to smooth down flyaways. As it turns out, it takes almost as much work to not reinvent the wheel as it does to invent it; as he noted, Its so easy to do something really wacky  I could do that with my eyes shut. But to think of something that has a subtlety and beauty to it, its so much harder.

title: Live Blog: Republicans Meet in Florida for Tea Party Debate
description: Just days after a debate in California, the eight Republican presidential candidates will square off again Monday night at a forum in Tampa, Fla.

title: Geoscientists Get to Work as Quake Memories Fade
description: Remember the earthquake?

title: Dont Look Back or Ahead
description: Hardly anyone thinks of fashion as a pursuit for people gifted at living in the moment. You could hardly expect it in a Gold Rush business, where clothes for next May are shown this September and jackpot fabulousness is always over the next hill.

title: Gay-Marriage Plays Headed to New York
description: Standing on Ceremony: The Gay Marriage Plays, a compilation of one-acts focusing on marital equality, will begin an Off Broadway run next month, the producers announced. Directed by Stuart Ross, the production includes original works from Neil LaBute, Moiss Kaufman and Doug Wright, among others, with a portion of ticket sales to be donated to marriage-equality groups. Conceived by Brian Shnipper as a series of benefit events, a Los Angeles run included performances by Matthew Broderick, Judd Hirsch and Debra Messing. A rotating cast for the New York incarnation has yet to be announced. Previews are scheduled to begin at the Minetta Lane Theater on Oct. 18 with an Oct. 24 opening.

title: Sawyer Lands Giffords Interview
description: ABC News said on Monday that Diane Sawyer, its top anchor, has booked the first sit-down interview with Representative Gabrielle Giffords, below, Democrat of Arizona, since she was critically wounded in a shooting spree in Tucson eight months ago. The hourlong special would be broadcast on Nov. 14, one day before the publication of a memoir, Gabby: A Story of Courage and Hope, written by Ms. Giffords and her husband, Mark Kelly. An ABC spokesman said Ms. Giffordss exact participation will hinge on her medical condition; in other words, the interview may not be shown on TV, but video clips of her recovery would be shown.

title: Thom Browne, Layer Upon Layer
description: The security guard at the New York Public Library took one look at Anna Dello Russo in her platform heels and pink Versace minidress and said: Youre going to the fashion show, right? Third floor.

description: When male hummingbirds perform valiant dives in front of females, they are actually enticing them with high-frequency vibrations produced by their tail feathers, a new study reports.

This was certainly so on Sunday afternoon when the Wordless Music Orchestra presented Remembering September 11, a program for contemplation and healing, in the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

description: Of the dances that blossomed during the months following Sept. 11, a frequent moment in many was a gaze, punctuated by stillness, in which dancers tilted their chins and stared into the distance above. It got to be draining.

title: Friending Yahoo May Make Sense
description: Now that Yahoo has fired its chief executive, anything could happen to the company, which has become a rudderless Internet hodgepodge. Private equity firms, one of Yahoos founders and even AOL are said to be pondering bids. But consider a more radical option: a takeover by the rival most responsible for Yahoos fall from grace  Facebook.

title: Mary Fickett, a Pillar of All My Children, Dies at 83
description: Mary Fickett, who acted in theater, film and prime-time television before becoming a legend among followers of the daytime drama All My Children as Ruth Martin, a nurse unafraid to speak her mind, died on Thursday at her home in Callao, Va. She was 83.

title: Smoking a Cigarette, Making a Film
description: TORONTO  Dont be fooled by the smoke, James Benning told a sold-out audience at the Toronto International Film Festival screening of his latest film Twenty Cigarettes. A collection of living portraits, in which 20 smokers, all friends of his, face the camera for the time it takes to consume a cigarette, it is both an homage to Andy Warhols fabled screen tests and a quintessential film for Mr. Benning, 68, a giant of American experimental cinema whose conceptually minimalist works tend to open up vast spaces for reflection.

description: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate the sources of anti-scientific beliefs.

title: Serena Williams Fined $2,000 for Outburst
description: For her latest United States Open outburst, Serena Williams received a $2,000 fine Monday from the tournament referee Brian Earley. The fine accounted for about 14-hundredths of a percent of her $1.4 million payday the night before.

description: Three major authors groups and eight individual authors filed suit against a partnership of research libraries and five universities on Monday, arguing that their initiative to digitize millions of books constituted copyright infringement.

description: The share of federal student loan defaults rose sharply last year, especially at for-profit colleges and universities, where 15 percent of borrowers defaulted in the first two years of repayment, up from 11.6 percent the previous year.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Local police forces trained and financed by the United States have killed and raped civilians, stolen land and carried out other abuses against the Afghan villagers they are charged with protecting, according to a report released on Monday by Human Rights Watch.

description: As voters went to the polls in a closely watched special election in the heavily Democratic House district last represented by Anthony D. Weiner, the Republican candidate expressed confidence that an upset was within reach, while his Democratic opponent played down the anxiety in his party and predicted that a strong turnout effort would propel him to victory.

title: A Red Sox Collapse Would Be Matched by Few
description: What a difference nine days can make.

description: Live Coverage of Mens Open Final: On Monday, The New York Times brought you live analysis, photos and chat from the mens championship match of the United States Open between Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic.

description: The Texas and Oklahoma athletic departments have historically been defined largely by their rivalries on the field. With the fate of conference realignment hinging on them, they are now locked in an administrative staredown.

title: German Leader Faces Key Choices on Rescuing Euro
description: BERLIN  As Europe struggles to reverse a plunge in financial confidence, the world waits for Germanys chancellor, Angela Merkel, to make a fundamental choice. She, more than any other European politician, will have to either summon the leadership to rescue the euro or concede that the political will is not there.

title: Accused of Defying Orders, Miami Police Chief Is Fired
description: MIAMI  Miamis embattled police chief was dismissed by the City Commission on Monday after being accused of failing to follow orders from a city official.

title: Its Form, Not Dysfunction, on Final Day
description: The weirdest United States Open ever  preceded by an earthquake and a hurricane, prolonged by rainouts, with a mysterious watery fissure opening on the Louis Armstrong Stadium court  came down to the 15th and final day.

title: Tech Blogger Parts With AOL
description: SAN FRANCISCO  AOL last year paid $30 million to buy the TechCrunch blog, in large part for its outspoken, controversial and well-connected founder, Michael Arrington.

title: Rockefeller on the Attica Raid, From Boastful to Subdued
description: Hours after 1,000 New York State troopers, sheriffs deputies and correction officers stormed Attica prison to crush a four-day inmate revolt in 1971, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller telephoned President Richard M. Nixon to claim victory unambiguously.

description: Perry Debates Himself on Social Security

description: SOME advertising agencies weathering the economic downturn are getting a shot in the arm from the most suitable of sources: hospitals.

title: Former Hospital Chief Convicted of Offering Bribes to Albany Legislators
description: A former hospital chief executive was convicted on Monday in a far-reaching scheme to pay bribes to three New York State legislators in return for beneficial treatment toward his health care organization.

title: Wary Investors Start to Shun European Banks
description: When a $225 million loan to BNP Paribas comes due Thursday at Legg Masons Western Asset management unit, managers at its money market fundswill be exercising caution.Instead of renewing the loan as they would have as recently as two months ago, they are looking to park investors money elsewhere,avoiding BNPand other Continental banks in favorof institutions inScandinavia, Canada and Britain.

title: Dominant Victory in Dominant Year
description: Forecasting nobility in sports is tougher than predicting the weather, which mercifully held Monday at the sodden United States Open for the final between Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal.

title: Gentlemen, Start Conserving
description: Is green Nascar an oxymoron? After all, the sport is all about watching gas guzzlers drive at high speeds in circles for hours. Until 2007, race cars used leaded fuel. Tens of thousands of fans still drive to races in recreational vehicles and other gas hogs.

title: The Misuse of Life Without Parole
description: The Supreme Court ruled last year that it is cruel and unusual punishment to sentence a juvenile to life without parole when the crime is short of homicide. In the majority opinion, Justice Anthony Kennedy noted that life without parole shares some characteristics with death sentences that are shared by no other sentences in altering the offenders life by a forfeiture that is irrevocable.

title: Government Pays More in Contracts, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Despite a widespread belief that contracting out services to the private sector saves the federal government money, a new study suggests just the opposite  that the government actually pays more when it farms out work.

title: Somalias Worsening Famine
description: Famine has pummeled the Horn of Africa generally, but Somalia has been the hardest hit  and the situation is getting worse. Severe drought-induced scarcities of food and water would pose a daunting challenge for any nation. It is even more daunting for Somalia, where a barely functioning central government and ruthless militant groups are undermining international efforts to respond to the most devastating famine in 60 years.

title: With Many Holes to Fill, Giants Secondary Regroups
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Deon Grant heard the hysteria on the airwaves Monday. Driving in his car, listening to sports talk radio, Grant, a safety, heard callers screeching about how the Giants secondary had been exposed by the Washington Redskins a day earlier. The Redskins are an inferior offense, the callers said, but they still dominated the Giants defensive backs.

title: Libyas War-Tested Women Hope to Keep New Power
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Aisha Gdour, a school psychologist, smuggled bullets in her brown leather handbag. Fatima Bredan, a hairdresser, tended wounded rebels. Hweida Shibadi, a family lawyer, helped NATO find airstrike targets. And Amal Bashir, an art teacher, used a secret code to collect orders for munitions: Small-caliber rounds were called pins, larger rounds were nails. A bottle of milk meant a Kalashnikov.

title: I.M.F. Chiefs Change of Tune on Bank Capital
description: Over the weekend, Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was desperately trying to back-pedal. A report had surfaced citing an internal I.M.F. document estimating that Europes banks were woefully short of capital  by a whopping $273.2 billion.

title: G.O.P. Debate in Florida
description: Republican presidential candidates debated in Tampa, Fla.

title: Bad Grades on Long-Term Care
description: New York has a surprisingly poor record in providing long-term care for its residents, according to a new score card comparing all 50 states and the District of Columbia on the availability and quality of services. New York ranked a dismal 41st. Minnesota, Washington and Oregon were at the top of the list, while Mississippi, Alabama and West Virginia brought up the rear.

title: Name Misspelled on 9/11 Memorial
description: The first name of one of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack was misspelled on the memorial in Lower Manhattan, a spokesman for the memorial said Monday.

title: Exploding Kansas
description: By late summer 1861, most Americans, North and South, were just coming to grips with the prospect of a long and bloody civil war. Not so the people of western Missouri and eastern Kansas  they had already been fighting over slavery for over five years. Although Kansas admission to the Union as a free state in January 1861 had effectively settled the slavery question and calmed the partisan violence in most of that territory, bloody guerrilla warfare still roiled the border with Missouri, a slave state, especially the region south of Kansas City and the Missouri River.

title: Lottery Numbers
Niger Fears an Influx From Libya of Soldiers Loyal to Qaddafi
description: NIAMEY, Niger  Officials in this mostly desert nation bordering Libya are warily watching and bracing for what they call the disaster scenario that has not yet happened: a huge influx of defeated soldiers loyal to the fallen Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Ryan Watches Film but Hopes Theres No Sequel
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The next day, Rex Ryan studied videotape from the Jets season-opening game against the Dallas Cowboys. He came away relieved to discover that one aspect, at least, matched what he saw on Sunday night.

title: New York Election Choices
description: Here are our endorsements for the election to fill the seat in New Yorks Ninth Congressional District and the two contested Civil Court seats in New York Citys Democratic primary Tuesday. Poll hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: A Woman on Libyas Front Lines
description: NEAR BANI WALID, Libya  The rebel fighter, in a billowing white Free Libya T-shirt, jeans, scarf and camouflage cap, was leaning against a car, talking in a businesslike manner with other rebels.

title: Her Bank Got Enough Help When It Was in Trouble. She Didnt.
description: For those who live in the alternate universe that is New York outside of Manhattan, brownstone Brooklyn and assorted upper-income offshoots, Mimi Pierre Johnsons story is depressingly familiar.

title: Numberplay: Phi  The Magic and the Myth
description: Last week I attended a wonderful presentation given by Keith Devlin, a Stanford University mathematician and NPRs Math Guy, on Fibonacci & the Golden Ratio: Exposed Common Myths and Fascinating Truths as part of the public lecture series Math Encounters organized by the Museum of Mathematics. The golden ratio or phi (1.61803) is a fascinating number that we have explored before in the puzzles, Moonlighting Triangles and The Golden Ratio Treasure. The ratio, which is approached to greater and greater precision by two adjacent numbers of the related Fibonacci sequence (1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13), has become part of popular culture, attaining almost mystical status. Images and video clips like the one above abound on the Internet, connecting the golden ratio and the Fibonacci sequence with art, architecture, cosmology, biology, aesthetics, poetry, music and many other fields. But how much of all this is true and how much is myth? Professor Devlin, who recently published a scholarly book titled The Man of Numbers: Fibonaccis Arithmetic Revolution, examined the evidence with a scientific eye and separated the wheat from the chaff. I present some of his findings below  in the form of questions to you, of course.

title: Uniformity Sought in Sept. 11 Sentiments
description: Major League Baseball told the Mets not to wear caps honoring the first responders of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks during their game Sunday night because it is trying to streamline the way that various causes and tragedies are commemorated.

title: Protect Our Right to Anonymity
description: Washington

title: If It Feels Right ...
description: During the summer of 2008, the eminent Notre Dame sociologist Christian Smith led a research team that conducted in-depth interviews with 230 young adults from across America. The interviews were part of a larger study that Smith, Kari Christoffersen, Hilary Davidson, Patricia Snell Herzog and others have been conducting on the state of Americas youth.

title: MSG Varsity Nears Deal to Show High School Games
description: For years, television stations around the country have shined a light on high school sports, including hockey in Boston and Friday night football in Texas. Yet, New York Citys high school teams received little TV time despite producing scores of players who went on to college and even professional fame, and despite staging tournaments in all sports.

title: Unheralded Mets Relievers Trying to Make Their Mark
description: As far as athletic archetypes go, these two pitchers, at first glance, would be polar opposites.

title: Mets and Montero Share a Brief and Scary History
description: SEATTLE  Five years later, Omar Minaya can still recall the sound of a bone-crushing thwack and the scream of pain that followed from 16-year-old Jesus Montero.

title: Tuesday: Of Base 8
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  You might not appreciate the cleverness of todays theme until you get to 37 Across. I know I didnt, but once I filled in CON GAME, the sun came out. Sometimes a good payoff can really take a common homophone theme and turn it into something elegant.

title: Long Days Journey Into Laughter
description: Stage directions, those humble, practical and occasionally ignored players in the art of dramatic composition, are the stars of the show at the Kraine Theater in the East Village, where the New York Neo-Futurists are presenting a handful of early Eugene ONeill plays, shorn of all dialogue. The Complete & Condensed Stage Directions of Eugene ONeill Volume 1: Early Plays/Lost Plays sounds like the title of an exceptionally dreary doctoral thesis, but the show, adapted and directed by Christopher Loar, is something far more enjoyable, an impish illustration of how lively entertainment can be created from theatrical spare parts.

title: Darkness Around the Spotlight
description: Somewhere along the road from Washington to Broadway, the Kennedy Center production of Follies picked up a pulse. A vigorous heart now beats at the center of this revitalized revival of James Goldman and Stephen Sondheims 1971 musical, which opened on Monday night at the Marquis Theater. And though the subject is the ghosts of show business past, dont expect gentle nostalgia. This Follies looks back as much in anger as in fondness. Thats what makes it so vibrant.

title: On 9/11, the View From the Train
description: Id been away for a few days, just me and my dog, but Sunday morning I rose early and drove the 100 miles to New York City. On the 10th anniversary of 9/11, I felt a deep need to be with my family. As I began to cross the Triborough Bridge into Manhattan, I could hear the whoosh of police helicopters overhead. I looked up. There were five of them.

title: Amid Cheating Complaints, Regents Move to Improve Test Security
description: ALBANY  Acknowledging that New York lags behind the best practices for detecting and deterring cheating by educators on high-stakes standardized tests, a Board of Regents committee on Monday authorized an independent investigator to look at how the State Education Department handles complaints of cheating.

title: In Deal, Hundreds of Mentally Ill People Will Leave Confinement of Nursing Home
description: Hundreds of mentally ill people who have been confined to nursing homes, sometimes in prisonlike conditions, would move to apartments or other housing within three years under a legal settlement with New York State.

title: Battle for Libya | September 12, 2011
description: Photographs from the front lines as Libyas rebels fight to take complete control of the country from Col. Qaddafis loyalists.

title: U.N. Count of Syria Dead Now at 2,600
description: The United Nations on Monday raised its estimate of the number of protesters killed in the Syrian uprising to 2,600, as it announced the appointment of three investigators to look into human rights abuses in the country, where President Bashar al-Assad has defied international condemnation of the crackdown, even among his dwindling allies.

title: Out of Prison, Ex-Procurers for Client 9 Get New Jobs
description: An untold number of customers were willing to pay $5,000 an hour for an escort from Emperors Club VIP, the Internet prostitution ring run by a 62-year-old former Israeli tax official and his bubbly 20-something girlfriend that in 2008 helped end the political career of Eliot Spitzer, also known then as Client No. 9.

title: Perry Is Target as Republican Candidates Take Aim
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Republican presidential candidates aggressively confronted Gov. Rick Perry at a debate here on Monday night, and pressed him to explain his views on Social Security and his decade-long record in Texas, including an effort to require the vaccination of schoolgirls and granting children of illegal immigrants a college tuition break.

title: Terms Met, Payout Rises for Workers at 9/11 Site
description: More than 10,000 ground zero rescue and cleanup workers who settled lawsuits with New York City over damage to their health will share an extra $55 million in bonus payments but will not have to pay lawyers fees on the increase, a federal judge has ruled.

title: Jailed 5 Years Without Trial, Prisoner Issues Airborne Plea
description: He has been blogging about his case from jail, pleading his side in lengthy writings. He says he has cut his hand and written on the wall of his cell with blood. And he has hired a pilot to fly a banner along the New York skyline proclaiming what he sees as an injustice.

title: Premier of Turkey Takes Role in Region
description: CAIRO  Seeking to capitalize on Turkeys growing stature and influence across the Arab world at a time of regional upheaval, its prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, appeared on Egyptian television late Monday once again calling Israel the Wests spoiled child.

title: Madonna on the Red Carpet: Are the Golden Globes Folks Watching?
description: TORONTOOnly Madonna.

description: Florence, Italy

title: For Debate Partners, an Unusual Pairing
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In the pantheon of strange political bedfellows, CNN and the Tea Party could go down as one of the oddest pairings since James Carville and Mary Matalin.

title: Yankees Cervelli Has a Concussion
description: SEATTLE  Francisco Cervelli was found to have a concussion Monday after visiting Dr. Kirk Roberts, a neurologist at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital specializing in concussion syndromes, the Yankees said.

title: Marc Jacobs: Secondary Line in Prime Time
description: Marc Jacobs, citing production delays caused by Hurricane Irene, decided a couple of weeks ago to move his main collection show from its usual perch on Monday night to Thursday, at the end of Fashion Week. He instead showed his diffusion line, Marc by Marc Jacobs, in the usual Monday time slot. And that turned out to be a good move, for more reasons than the extra design time he was able to buy.

title: At Neighboring Libraries, Differing Views
description: Two new exhibits in California expose the different positions that two former presidents hold in the nations and the Republican Partys memory.

title: Obama Offers Jobs Bill, and the G.O.P. Balks
description: WASHINGTONPresident Obama sent his jobs bill to Congress on Monday, urging lawmakers to put aside political games and pass the $447 billion plan meant to increase hiring as the government struggles to curtail persistent high unemployment.

title: U.S. Spending Billions on Rural Jobs, but Impact Is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is investing billions of dollars to promote economic development in rural areas by bringing broadband service and small-business financing to regions with chronic poverty and high unemployment.

title: Whats a Presidential Library to Do?
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  When Republicans gathered at the Ronald Reagan Library and Museum here for the presidential debate last week, the backdrop was an overhauled exhibition on the Reagan presidency, done under the watchful eye of Nancy Reagan. It is intended, in part, to be a more complete depiction of the Reagan presidency, replacing one that many had seen as a bit too worshipful and airbrushed.

title: As Perry Rises, G.O.P. Elite Look Toward Romney
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The rising presidential candidacy of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is stirring excitement for many Republican voters but is creating unease in some quarters of the partys establishment, particularly over his views of Social Security, which are at the root of an intensifying competition with Mitt Romney.

description: After the Mets 3-2 loss to Washington on Monday night, Manager Terry Collins suggested his team may not have been completely focused on the game.

description: Rafael Nadal had shifted the momentum his way by winning an exhilarating third set. His nemesis, Novak Djokovic, who had been breathing heavily and was visibly frustrated with his inability to put Nadal away, was lying on his stomach, receiving treatment for a bothersome back strain.

title: Corrections: September 13
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Your Femininity Is Showing
description: For the last few days, the runways have been awash in sporty anoraks and bright flower prints, leading you to imagine either a giant stockpile of orange mesh or those designers meeting a lot for coffee this summer. In any event, regular women might think there was no reason to watch.

title: Photo Replay: United States Open
description: Novak Djokovic defeated Rafael Nadal to win the mens singles title and his third Grand Slam title this season.

title: Newswallah: In the National English-Language Press Today
description: The 2002 Gujarat riots dominated the days headlines after the Supreme Court ruled that a lower court should look into a massacre at Gulberg Housing Society that left 69 people dead, including a former member of Parliament. Calling the riots abominable and woeful, (Indian Express) the court said it would cease to directly monitor the case. The court directed the court-appointed (Hindustan Times) special investigation team to submit its final report before an Ahmedabad trial court. Leaders of the Bharatiya Janata Party issued statements celebrating the ruling as proof that there was no evidence (Times of India) to link the Gujarat chief minister, Narendra Modi, to the riots.

title: Seattle Council Votes for Paid Sick Time
description: The Seattle City Council voted Monday to require employers with five or more workers to provide paid sick days. Supporters said they expected Mayor Mike McGinn to approve the legislation, which would make Seattle one of three major cities, along with San Francisco and Washington, to require paid sick days. Connecticut is the only state to enact paid sick days for private employers. The Seattle vote was 8 to 1, with the City Council president, Richard Conlin, opposing. Companies with 5 to 49 workers would have to offer full-time workers at least five paid sick days yearly, while the largest companies would have to provide at least nine. Supporters said it was important for public health that food-service and health-care workers have paid sick days, but business opponents said the legislation was an expensive mandate.

title: A Conversation With Archie Panjabi
description: Immediately after warmly greeting me on the Greenpoint, Brooklyn set of the popular CBS drama The Good Wife, British actress Archie Panjabi started apologizing.

title: Yankees Batter Mariners Hernandez for an Easy Victory
description: SEATTLE  The Yankees, whose offense awoke Sunday from a two-day slumber, demonstrated in convincing fashion Monday that the previous game was no fluke. The postseason creeping into view, this team has started to amass hits and score runs again, even against one of the best pitchers in baseball.

title: At Monk Competition, a Sound Worth Returning To
description: WASHINGTON  Hod Moshonov, a 22-year-old pianist from Israel, had already loosened his tie by 1 p.m. on Sunday, and his wine-colored dress shirt was coming loose from his waist. Super-revved, he seemed to dump his whole conception of jazz on his instrument.

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 13, 2011
description: Todays question was written by Shannon Doyne. Her question comes from the blog post, Efforts to Rein In Executive Pay Meet With Little Success.

title: A Plea to Bring the Sexy Back Back
description: We are so conditioned to be wary of the wayward celebrity hyphenate  the misguided actor-painter, say, or the pop star-actor  that weve forgotten the tragic other side of this condition: the successful hyphenate who never returns to the thing they were famous for in the first place.

title: Battle-Tested Women
description: The six-month uprising against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has propelled women in this traditional society into roles they never imagined.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 13, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: South African Seeks to Heal Party Split
description: In the latest twist to a political standoff that has riveted South Africa, President Jacob Zuma seemed on Tuesday to offer an olive branch to a firebrand youth leader under investigation for dividing the governing party and sowing discord in its ranks.

title: The India Growth Story: Glass Half Full or Half Empty?
description: Reading the foreign and domestic newspapers these days, it is hard to avoid the conclusion that the bloom has come off the rose of the India growth story. For instance, a leading Indian business daily, Mint, recently ran a series questioning Indias future growth prospects, and pointing to the unfinished economic reform agenda.

title: Bronx Students Finance and Build a School in Africa
description: WHO collaborated to build a new school in West Africa?

title: Sept. 13, 1993 | Israel and P.L.O. Sign Accord Granting Limited Palestinian Autonomy
description: On Sept. 13, 1993, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasser Arafat, shook hands in a public ceremony at the White House after signing an agreement that granted limited autonomy to Palestine and laid the foundation for future peace talks.

title: Part 2: Answers to Your Back-to-School Admissions Questions
description: The Choice has lined up the authors of a new book  which bills itself as the ultimate users manual for college applicants, and loosely follows, as its model, the What to Expect When Youre Expecting series  to field questions about what high school seniors and juniors (and their parents) should be doing now on the college admissions front.

title: Do You Know Your First Amendment Rights?
description: Should citizens be able to videotape the activities of police officers in public? Should a college student be disciplined by her university for a video she made disparaging Asian students? Should people have to use their real names on the Internet? Can violent video games be sold to children? Should anti-gay protesters be allowed to picket at military funerals?

description: Q.

title: Forget Whos No. 1 or No. 138: How to Use the U.S. News Rankings
description: At 12:01 Tuesday morning, the editors of the latest edition of the U.S. News and World Report ranking of best colleges posted their findings online.

title: Can  Jets Make Hurry Up Their 12th Man on Offense?
description: With just over three minutes to go in the first half against the Cowboys on Sunday, the Jets were looking for a spark. After four offensive possessions, the numbers were dismal: 3 first downs, 3 three-and-outs and a 10-point deficit on the scoreboard.

title: How to Raise Revenue Without Violating the Tax Pledge
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

title: Lewis Hine Spotlighted in Paris Photo Show
description: The photographs of Lewis Hine (1874-1940) fuse humanism, artistic vision and remarkable anthropological insight about the early 20th century. A new exhibition on Hine, running through Dec. 18, the Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson (2 Impasse Lebouis; 33-156-802-700; henricartierbresson.org) in Paris has assembled 150 original black-and-white prints.

title: American Hikers to Be Freed in 2 Days, Ahmadinejad Says
description: LONDON  Irans president said Tuesday that two Americans arrested two years ago while hiking the Iran-Iraq frontier and imprisoned on espionage charges would be freed within two days as a humanitarian gesture. The move seemed timed to portray him more favorably before he attends the United Nations General Assembly meeting next week.

title: U.S. Embassy and NATO Headquarters Attacked in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Heavily armed insurgents wearing suicide vests struck Tuesday at two of the most prominent symbols of the American diplomatic and military presence in Kabul, the United States Embassy and the nearby NATO headquarters, demonstrating the Talibans ability to infiltrate even the most heavily fortified districts of the capital.

title: Abuse Victims Ask Court to Prosecute the Vatican
description: Human rights lawyers and victims of clergy sexual abuse filed a complaint on Tuesday urging the International Criminal Court in The Hague to investigate and prosecute Pope Benedict XVI and three top Vatican officials for crimes against humanity for what they described as abetting and covering up the rape and sexual assault of children by priests.

title: Maybe Someone Should Make a Documentary About Documentarians and the Press?
description: TORONTO  Any honest, independent, critically minded journalist had to get a little nervous at Mondays documentary conference here, part of the Toronto International Film Festival, on hearing that some documentarians consider the press to be a willing adjunct to their advocacy. The subject came up several times in the first 30 minutes or so of an afternoon panel that was titled How Films Can Change the World.

title: A Wilderness Ranger, Age 21
description: Im a senior in college, which means that everyone I meet feels entitled to ask me, So, what are you planning to do after you graduate? But Im at a liberal arts school, so I always respond with an Im not sure yet or an Im going to take what comes my way.

title: A Keen Use of the Wind Aided Djokovic
description: Novak Djokovic won his first U.S. Open and his fourth Grand Slam title, defeating Rafael Nadal in four grueling sets. The match had many twists and turns, as conditions varied from blustery to calm. As night fell over Arthur Ashe Stadium, the points became brutally physical, with both players delivering forcing body blows in an attempt to knock the other out.

title: Deluxe Apartment, Village Town House or Staten Island Manse?
description: This weeks Appraisal tells the tale of one of the town houses that stood in for Carrie Bradshaws Upper East Side pad on Sex and the City and the real-life couple, Harold Eliot Leeds, an architect and Pratt professor, and Wheaton Galentine, a filmmaker, who lived there for 50 years.

title: Seth Rogens Answers to Your Questions
description: TORONTO  You asked, he answered! We had some time with the actor Seth Rogen at the Toronto International Film Festival, where he is representing the movies 50/50 and Take This Waltz, and we picked some of the best questions submitted by our readers and posed them to Seth. Here are his responses.

title: What the Presidents Job Plan Means to Me
description: I am trying to decide when exactly small businesses became the official poster child of the latest economic disaster. This is a relatively new phenomenon, but its been building for a few years. Sometimes, the attention feels good. I didnt know everyone cared! Sometimes it feels like pandering. I have a suspicion that some of the people who are always arguing that we will destroy small businesses if we raise income taxes on the wealthy dont really care that much about small businesses, but it sounds noble.

title: H.P. Extends Autonomy Offer
description: Hewlett-Packard has extended its offer for the Autonomy Corporation, as it tries to win over shareholders.

title: From Europe, Mounting Pressure Over Greeces Debt
description: PARIS  Facing market pressure to resolve the Greek debt crisis once and for all, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany will hold a video conference call Wednesday evening with the embattled Greek prime minister, George Papandreou, French officials announced on Tuesday.

title: British Hacking Inquiry to Recall James Murdoch
description: LONDON  A parliamentary panel investigating the phone hacking scandal in the British outpost of Rupert Murdochs media empire said on Tuesday that it would recall his son James Murdoch to answer more questions about the case.

title: Perry Wrestles With His Political History
description: Presidential candidates have three options when they are presented with past positions or actions that become political liabilities once they are facing voters.

title: A Contrarian Since Childhood
description: In 2001 Christopher Hitchens published a slim, engaging how-to book titled Letters to a Young Contrarian. Among its most consequential advice was this: The noble title of dissident must be earned rather than claimed; it connotes sacrifice and risk rather than mere disagreement.

title: Eavesdropping on the Nursing Home Staff
description: Because we were just discussing the angst-ridden process of selecting a nursing home, I was particularly interested in a new survey from the federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Australian Miners Shares Hit by Insider Trading Inquiry
description: Australian authorities are investigating a Chinese mining executive for insider trading in connection with potential takeover targets.

title: Special Election! So Whats So Special?
description: Whatever his flaws  and where to begin counting them?  the self-destructive Anthony D. Weiner was not yawn-inducing. Too bad the same cant be said about the two men running in a special election on Tuesday for the Congressional seat that Mr. Weiner forfeited after he sexted himself into political oblivion as the Twit of Tweets.

title: Tuesday Reading: Attacking the Causes of the Obesity Epidemic
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: How Much Hoc to Add? (Wonkish and Methodological)
description: Mark Thoma objects to Tyler Cowens attempt to pigeonhole some of us as Old New Keynesians, and makes the case for flexibility in use of models. Indeed. But theres something more systematic to the macro story  something that very much informs my work. Namely, old Keynesian and new Keynesian models represent two intelligent but imperfect responses to the problem of thinking about an economy in which people must make future-oriented decisions. Neither is fully convincing, but there are no better alternatives at this point. So what I do, and I hope others do as well, is to think about policy issues both ways, and try to bracket things in a way that leads to reasonably secure conclusions.

title: Vain Glorious | Barbershop Quartet
description: Weve discovered a quartet of Portland barbershops to get your mop and mug tidied up  in perfect harmony. All four establishments, much like the citys famed eateries and wineries, are exceptional in skill and gentle in pricing.

title: Know Your Enemies
description: I took it personally the first time I saw a Barney trap hanging from a tree in Delaware County where my family has a cottage. It brought to mind the time, about 20 years ago, when I transplanted a sapling that I found growing behind a shed to a spot near the stump of a century-old butternut tree that had fallen victim to wind and rot.

title: Wall Street Self-Regulator Makes Case for More Power
description: Wall Streets self-regulator is stepping up its bid for more power, telling Congress on Tuesday that it is well equipped to replace the Securities and Exchange Commission as overseer of the investment advisory industry.

title: Republicans Are Clear Favorites in New York and Nevada Special Elections
description: Voters will go to the polls in opposite corners of the country on Tuesday. In New Yorks Ninth Congressional District in Brooklyn and Queens, they will be picking a replacement for Democratic Representative Anthony D. Weiner. And in Nevadas Second Congressional District, which encompasses nearly all of the state outside Las Vegas, they will be choosing someone to replace Dean Heller, a Republican, who was appointed to the Senate in May after John Ensign resigned.

title: Visions of the Renaissance at Machiavelli
description: The Italian Renaissance is firmly in place at Machiavelli, an elaborately decorated trattoria opening on Friday on the Upper West Side.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: How Many Wins Is Peyton Manning Worth?
description: Before the season, the N.F.L. statistical community pulled out its calculators and protractors  do they still use protractors?  to determine how damaging the absence of Peyton Manning might be.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Fears Ease in France, and Shares Edge Higher
description: Stocks rose on Tuesday, sending the Standard & Poors 500-stock index higher for a second day, as French banks eased concerns over their access to funding and investors watched for signs of progress in solving Europes debt crisis.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | The Lake & Stars
description: Its like they just came out of the ocean. Theyve been hanging out on holiday, said Emiko Kaneko of the makeup backstage at the Lake & Stars. A recent trip to Mexico City prompted the designers Maayan Zilberman and Nikki Dekker to create this seasons presentation of pieces in red, gold, passion fruit, peach and mint. We thought of a girl gang that was strongest as a unit. Together they emote this heat, Zilberman said of the lineup of 16 bronzed models wearing lingerie, red socks and sandals. Kaneko used minimal makeup on the face, simply M.A.C.s tawny brown Photo lipstick with a touch of gloss, and focused instead on creating glowing skin with Studio Sculpt in a variety of shades. The center-parted pulled back hair was more labor intensive. Andre Gunn channeled Frida Kahlo and Apache Native Americans with tight fishtail braids coiled in single or double loops and fastened with black or blond ribbon.

title: Bill Would Provide Federal Funds for 9/11 Memorial
description: Under a plan proposed to Congress last week, the federal government would assume ownership of the National September 11 Memorial and Museum and would provide $20 million in annual financing.

title: Vincent Reinhart Joins Morgan Stanley
description: Vincent R. Reinhart, an economist and former head of the Federal Reserves monetary division, is joining Morgan Stanley as its chief United States economist in New York.

title: See You in the Next Life: Point Break Is Hollywoods Latest Planned Remake
description: In the 1991 thriller Point Break, a squad of surfers-cum-bank robbers commit their crimes while wearing masks of Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson, Richard Nixon, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, so well assume that in a newly announced remake of this film, theyll disguise themselves as Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, Barack Obama and Hu Jintao of China. Thats just a guess, but we can tell you for certain that the original Point Break was directed by Kathryn Bigelow, the future Academy Award-winning director of The Hurt Locker, and starred Keanu Reeves as a young F.B.I. agent on the trail of the Ex-Presidents gang, whose philosophical leader is played by Patrick Swayze. The new version was announced late Monday by Alcon Entertainment, a production and finance company based at Warner Brothers, which has been on a rebooting binge; last month the company announced that it was producing a new Blade Runner film that could serve as a sequel or prequel to Ridley Scotts original movie.

title: The Problem With Quasi-Monetarism
description: This seems to be a methodology Monday Tuesday (oh well)! But not as wonkish this time.

title: Volkswagen Group Brings the Pomp and Power on Eve of Frankfurt Motor Show
description: FRANKFURT  On Monday night, the Volkswagen Group rang every bell, blew every whistle, trotted out a troupe of dogs and ponies and, quite literally, nearly set the stage on fire.

title: Open Moment: A Tiebreak to Remember
description: I write just hours after leaving Arthur Ashe, where Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal had four or five rallies that I will be replaying in my mind as I fall asleep tonight.

title: In Frankfurt, Ford Emphasizes Speed and Efficiency
description: FRANKFURT  Ford was eager to showcase its new commitment to speed in small packages on Monday night.

title: General Motors Europe Chief Says Opel Is (Still) Not for Sale
description: FRANKFURT Nick Reilly, the president of General Motors Europe, has said numerous times that the companys Opel unit was not for sale, but that didnt prevent the question from arising again when he sat down with a small group of reporters at the Frankfurt auto show Tuesday.

title: Rick Perry as Howard Dean
description: Last week, I compared Rick Perry in 2012 to Barack Obama in 2008: Like Obama four years ago, Perry doesnt have the profile of an ideal general election candidate, but hes the kind of figure that an influential portion of his partys primary electorate is eager to find a reason to support. As Perry fumbled his way through last nights Republican primary debate, though, the Texas governor seemed a lot more like Howard Dean in 2004  a candidate, again, who many Democratic primary voters wanted to support, because he was speaking their language and gleefully throwing insults in the teeth of a president they hated, but also a candidate whose weaknesses were obvious enough that he couldnt finally make the sale.

title: Morning T | Olivier Theyskens
description: In this fashion week exclusive, T's Online Editor Jane Herman talks to the designer Olivier Theyskens about his preparations for today's runway show and how he'd like to see women dress for work.

title: Turkish Leader Urges Vote for Palestinian Statehood
description: CAIRO  Capitalizing on Turkeys growing stature and influence across the Middle East at a time of regional upheaval, its prime minister ramped up the pressure on Israel and the United States on Tuesday, telling the Arab League ministers they must vote for Palestinian statehood at the United Nations this month.

title: Are Bills That Good, and Chiefs That Bad?
description: This time last year, I wrote that an opening day loss wasnt necessarily a harbinger of things to come. But Week 1 isnt meaningless, and no team knows that better than the Chiefs. Last season, Kansas City pulled off the biggest upset in Week 1 and rode a hot start directly into a division championship.

title: How Rebalancing Takes Emotion Out of Investing
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

description: FRANKFURT  How does a brand make a battering ram of a vehicle at a time of increasing concerns about fuel economy, tailpipe emissions and curb weight?

title: Soaring Poverty Casts Spotlight on Lost Decade
description: WASHINGTON  Another 2.6 million people slipped into poverty in the United States last year, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday, and the number of Americans living below the official poverty line, 46.2 million people, was the highest number in the 52 years the bureau has been publishing figures on it.

title: At Rodarte, a Van Gogh Exhibition
description: Before the Rodarte show, one of the photographers made a crack about the teenage front row. Elle and Dakota Fanning, next to Tavi Gevinson, were facing Taylor Swift (who is an adult), next to Anna Wintour. While it is true that Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the Rodarte designers, skew young in their fan base, I think that is part of what fuels the appeal of their collections, at least among a fashion set that is eternally nostalgic for that moment in high school when anything seemed possible. (See Rookie.) Beyonc and Solange Knowles made a late entrance, so maybe the appeal is even broader.

description: Hewlett-Packard has extended its offer for the Autonomy Corporation to Oct. 3, as it attempts to win over shareholders.

title: Open Moment: Before (and After) That Djokovic Shot
description: Novak Djokovics audacious return of serve winner match point down against Roger Federer will be remembered as the shot of the Open. But for me, the tournaments most intriguing moments occurred right before and after The Shot.

description: In a new posting on its Web site, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it had intensified an investigation into headlights on 622,000 Chrysler and Dodge minivans from the 2005 model year.

title: Mashable Expanding Its Coverage
description: Mashable, the popular Web site for information about technology and social media, said Tuesday that it was expanding coverage to include new sections for entertainment, United States news and world news, and that it was hiring a veteran technology editor to oversee all editorial content.

title: Livents Drabinsky Loses Court Challenge on Fraud Charges

title: Lamborghini Sesto Elemento and Gallardo Super Trofeo Stradale to Enter Limited Production
description: FRANKFURT  Lamborghini will produce its Sesto Elemento, the lightweight hypercar introduced at the 2010 Paris auto show, as a technology demonstrator concept. The automaker also confirmed production of the Gallardo Super Trofeo Stradale, the last of the Gallardo special editions.

title: Where the Big Girls Are | Marc by Marc Jacobs
description: The photographer JD Ferguson gets close up on the biggest faces in fashion.

title: Jay Rayner Versus the Chefs
description: Over at the The Guardian, the restaurant critic Jay Rayner has taken a group of chefs to task for a letter they wrote to the Chefs of Tomorrow, from a gastronomic festival in Lima, Peru.

title: New Take on Chekhov to Highlight Soho Rep Season
description: The playwright Annie Baker and the director Sam Gold, who drew critical acclaim for their recent Off Broadway collaborations Circle Mirror Transformation and The Aliens, will reunite for Ms. Bakers adaptation of Chekhovs Uncle Vanya, which Soho Rep will mount in June, the theater company said on Tuesday.

title: South Korean Family Conglomerates Pressured
description: SEOUL  In Parliament, lawmakers call them beasts. Newspaper editorials liken them to unfettered predators robbing ordinary people of their livelihood. President Lee Myung-bak, once an ally, has withdrawn his promise to cut taxes for them, instead urging them to win respect from the people by doing more to help the poor.

title: The Death of the Confidence Fairy
description: In the first half of last year a strange delusion swept much of the policy elite on both sides of the Atlantic  the belief that cutting spending in the face of high unemployment would actually create jobs. I went after this stuff early and hard (I suspect that the confidence fairy will be one of my lasting contributions to economic discourse); still, its good to have a steadily mounting weight of evidence about just how wrong that view was.

description: Mashable, the popular Web site for information about technology and social media, said Monday that it was expanding coverage to include new sections for entertainment, United States news and world news, and that it was hiring a veteran technology editor to oversee all of its editorial content. description: Facing a strike that has lasted a month, the owner of the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park has made several major concessions in the hope of ending the walkout, among them agreeing to recognize and negotiate with a union, representatives of the two sides said.

description: As Alissa J. Rubin and Jack Healy report from Kabul, the Afghan capital, the United States Embassy there came under sustained attack on Tuesday, a brazen strike on one of the most secure locations in the country.

title: Letter From J. D. Salinger, One Sentence Long, Is Offered for $50,000
description: Weve heard that contributors to The New Yorker get paid handsomely for their work, but J. D. Salinger might outpace them all if a Las Vegas-based company realizes its asking price for a brief letter by that reclusive writer it is selling on eBay for $50,000.

title: Help Us Choose Our Series

title: Subaru BRZ Prologue: A Spiritual Return to Sporty Quirk?
description: FRANKFURT  The Subaru rear-wheel-drive sports car (yes, a Subaru that isnt driven by four wheels) took a baby step closer to reality here, with a new architectural see-through rendering of the BRZ Prologue concept. The production version of the coupe is expected to be shown at the Tokyo auto show later this year.

title: Interview: Glenn Close
description: Glenn Close discusses her role in "Albert Nobbs," where she plays a woman posing as a man.

title: Thinking Cap: Understanding Dostoyevsky Courtesy of Woody Allen
description: Thinking Cap is about work in progress in the world of ideas.

title: More New Yorkers Living in Poverty
description: New York States poverty rate climbed to 16 percent last year, the third consecutive annual increase and the highest rate since 1998, according to census figures released Tuesday. Nearly 3.1 million New Yorkers were living below the official poverty rate in 2010, also the highest total in 12 years.

title: Photos of the Moment | Zero + Maria Cornejo
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#761", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Kava Gornas New York fashion week photo diary.

title: G.O.P. Gains House Seat Vacated by Weiner
description: A little-known Republican businessman from Queens, channeling voter discontent with President Obama into an upset, won election to Congress on Tuesday from the heavily Democratic district in New York City last represented by Anthony D. Weiner.

title: North Korean Defectors Rescued Off Japan Coast
description: TOKYO  Nine North Korean defectors, including three children, were rescued off the coast of Japan after drifting some 500 miles in a small wooden boat, the Japanese Coast Guard said Tuesday.

title: Bursting the Nutty Bubble
description: People who spend a lot of time around the luxury-goods trade live in what Linda Fargo, the fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, termed the other day a nutty bubble. While the world outside the Fashion Week tents teeters on the economic brink, the people inside them teeter around on shoes, she said, for which they think nothing of spending $1,500 a pair.

title: Boathouse Restaurant Capitulates to Union
description: Facing a strike that has lasted a full month, the owner of the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park has agreed to several major concessions in the hope of ending the walkout, among them agreeing to recognize and negotiate with the union, officials from the two sides told City Room.

description: 8:25 p.m. | Updated

title: Spain Revives Rape Case Against Saudi Prince
description: MADRID  A Spanish judge has reopened an abandoned sexual assault case against a Saudi prince who is one of the worlds richest men, reviving accusations that he raped a 20-year-old model on a luxury yacht in the Spanish Mediterranean in August 2008.

title: Farewell to an Acronym
description: The awkwardly named hybrid agency responsible for the regulation of offshore drilling, the Interior Departments Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement, is being reorganized out of existence at the end of the month, barely 16 months after its creation.

title: Turntable.fm Spins Early Success Into $7 Million in Financing
description: Turntable.fm, a streaming music site that lets people take turns at virtual D.J. booths, playing songs for other online listeners, quickly caught fire after it first appeared earlier this summer.

title: Backstage Grooming Report | Timo Weiland
description: We imagined a New Yorker going coastal, or heading to the beach, explained Alan Eckstein, Timo Weilands design partner, minutes before the labels first runway show. He is resourceful, youthful in spirit and loves an adventure. James Boehmer, the Nars makeup artist, let clothes take center stage by keeping male models faces bare. When guys are wearing bright colors and bold patterns, even a little bit of makeup can borderline on precious, Boehmer said. Instead, I prepped the guys faces with massage, and applied Nars Hydrating Freshening Lotion and Hydrating Moisture Cream to mildly exfoliate and minimize dryness. Thats it.

title: TimesCast | Taliban Attacks in Kabul
description: On Tuesday, insurgents launched coordinated attacks on the U.S. Embassy and NATO headquarters in Kabul. The Taliban claimed responsibility.

title: New Director for Nederlands Dans Theater
description: Paul Lightfoot, who has spent nearly his entire career with the Nederlands Dans Theater as a dancer and choreographer, has been elevated to artistic director, replacing Jim Vincent, the company said. Mr. Vincent, who took over in the post in the 2009-2010 season, will stay on as co-artistic director until the end of the year, the company added in a statement on its Web site.

title: Volvo Continues to Aim Upmarket With the Concept You
description: FRANKFURT  A few years ago, Volvo unveiled the Y.C.C., a concept designed by women, for women. Concept You, introduced here on Tuesday, must be for the gents.

title: Student Loan Defaults Rise Again
description: As Tamar Lewin reports in todays Times, defaults on student loans rose again last year, and sharply. Of all borrowers, 8.8 percent  the highest rate since 1997 were unable to pay their loans, while 15 percent of borrowers at for-profit institutions defaulted on their payments. As Ms. Lewin writes:

title: Its No Con: Bobby Cannavale to Play Nick Arnstein in Funny Girl Revival
description: The actor Bobby Cannavale, a Tony Award nominee last spring for the biting play The ____________ With the Hat, will make his musical theater debut this winter in the Broadway-bound revival of Funny Girl as the con man Nick Arnstein, starring opposite Lauren Ambrose as the comedian Fanny Brice, the production announced on Tuesday.

description: On Monday, I reported on the plans of Steve Chen and Chad Hurley, best known as two of the founders of YouTube, to transform Delicious, a social bookmarking service that never quite caught on among mainstream Web users, into a popular, sleek and modern service.

description: WASHINGTON  As Congress opens a politically charged exploration of ways to pare the deficit, President Obama is expected to seek hundreds of billions of dollars in savings in Medicare and Medicaid, delighting Republicans and dismaying many Democrats who fear that his proposals will become a starting point for bigger cuts in the popular health programs.

title: Still Unearthing Discoveries in de Koonings Brush Strokes
description: The first thing visitors will see at the entrance to the Museum of Modern Arts sprawling Willem de Kooning retrospective, which opens on Sunday, is a wall of photographs that chronicle six stages in the creation of the legendary painting Woman I (1950-52). John Elderfield, MoMAs chief curator emeritus of painting and sculpture, said he chose these images as a starting point because they illustrate that de Kooning was an artist about process.

description: Im not quite sure what those words are saying, but saturation seemed to capture the general mood at the Open last Friday. So did baked.

description: WASHINGTON  The director of the Congressional Budget Office painted a grim near-term picture of the American economy on Tuesday and said cuts in federal spending and increases in taxes will tend to slow the economic recovery.

description: Updated 2:15 p.m. to add details after Google made its announcement about the new service.

Or maybe micro-credit for thousands of micro-businesses in many of those same places. Now add to those accomplishments the ability to book Lady Gaga, Usher, and Bono and the Edge of U2 for a party.

description: Sarah Palin might have sounded like an ally of Representative Michele Bachmann on Monday night when she assailed an executive order in Texas mandating that girls receive the HPV vaccine, calling it a possible product of crony capitalism.

Weprin, Democrat, and Bob Turner, Republican, is also known for something else: its interestingly irregular shape, a gift from the gods of redistricting.

description: MOSCOW  The announcement on Tuesday by the Russian space agency that it will delay the launching of the next crew to the International Space Station is a concern for NASA, which is relying solely on the Russians for astronaut transportation.

title: Julianne Moores Favorite Books from Childhood
description: Today marks the publication of Freckle Face Strawberry: Best Friends Forever, the third in a series of Freckleface books by Julianne Moore, also known as an Academy Award-nominated actress. This spring, Ms. Moore introduced a breakfast panel of childrens book authors  Brian Selznick, Kevin Henkes and Sarah Dessen  at Book Expo America, the publishing industrys annual convention, and demonstrated a long-standing interest in and firm grasp of childrens literature. Her enthusiasm was infectious.

title: One Quick Thought About Newspapers and Grief
description: Sometimes a story in the newspaper arrests your attention not because you want to read it but because you want to show it to someone who is dead. For a moment that you wish would last longer, your impulse to share the article overrides your conscious understanding that the person who would have liked it, in this case my mother, is beyond reach. Then you do remember.

You can read other interviews here.

title: Web Site Makes It Easy to Create a Training Program  and to Charge for It

title: Oh, Pioneers
description: Just as Bono created the template for the modern, globally minded rock star activist, he and wife Ali Hewson have been working to bring a greater sense of social responsibility to the fashion community through their label Edun. Since the brands start in 2005, the couple has paid just as much attention to where and how their clothes are made as to how they look, winning Edun ample praise for its commitment to sustainable manufacturing practices and community-building initiatives throughout Africa.

title: Coal Bear
description: Im on tonight. Al Gore, too.
