description: In the 1970s, Leland Bobb, a New York photographer, turned his camera to the citys streets.

title: A Republican in the Ninth? Its Been a While
description: For decades, winning the Democratic nomination in New Yorks Ninth Congressional District has been tantamount to election.

title: Senate Tries Again on Disaster Aid
description: UPDATE 6:50 p.m.: The Senate on Tuesday cleared the way for consideration of a large aid package for communities and people affected by this summers hurricanes and tornadoes by tucking $6.9 billion in new disaster aid into a Republican-sponsored bill to renew sanctions against the Burmese government.

title: Deadline Extended for Mortgage Help
description: The federal government has extended the deadline until Sept. 15 for strapped homeowners in 27 states to apply for emergency help.

title: Abarth 695 Competizione: The Fiat 500 With a Scorpions Sting
description: FRANKFURT  Walking the convention floor here, Sergio Marchionne, the chairman of Fiat, stopped to admire an arachnid known to devour Beetles and lesser beasts whole.

title: To the Arctic, in Search of the Unknown
description: Bernard Coakley, a marine geologist with the University of Alaska at Fairbanks, writes from the Arctic Ocean, where his team is reconstructing the geologic history of the Chukchi Shelf and the Chukchi Borderland.

title: Backstage Beauty at Marc by Marc Jacobs
description: The hair and makeup at the Marc by Marc Jacobs spring 2012 show.

title: Forget Your Umbrella
description: Slicked-back hair has been all over the runways: Donna Karan, Rebecca Taylor, Derek Lam. Monday night, at Marc by Marc Jacobs, Guido Palau, the creative consultant for Redken, made a half-knot, half-ponytail inspired by the mid-90s with a wet-looking, shiny front.

title: Restaurant Brings Your Name Here to Life
description: A restaurant company with a penchant for attention-getting stunts is at it again, offering to change the name of one of its restaurants to salute devoted customers.

title: Glenn Close Explores Gender in Albert Nobbs
description: TORONTO  In Albert Nobbs, Glenn Close plays a 19th-century woman who, having fallen on hard times, poses as a man to get work as a butler. The character lives for over 20 years in that guise with nobody knowing her secret, until she comes in contact with a painter at the hotel where she works who might have a secret of his own.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Marc by Marc Jacobs
description: You know youre a beauty industry rock star when a designer makes references to your past work in his preshow brief. Nineties Guido, was what Marc Jacobs wanted for Marc by Marc Jacobs according to Guido Palau backstage before the show. They got out all my old pictures, he said of the stack of images unearthed by Jacobss team. In the end, Palau came up with a half pulled-through ponytail created by first blow-drying the hair with Redken Satinwear, then pulling it back with an elastic. The next step was attaching the tail to the back of the head with a silver Goody clip and coating the hair with Shine Enrich and Forceful 23 Spray. A little bit spiky  aerodynamic, is how Palau described the finished look. Nails were painted Zoyas Olivia with a custom matte top coat to make a nude velvet effect. For makeup, Dick Page conceived what he referred to as the appropriately collegiate Pretty 101, just a healthy face. This was done using Shiseido gold blush dusted just above the cheek bones with a rosy tone below. Eyelids were spread with Shiseido Maquillage Lip Gloss and brows were colored with Shimmering Cream eyeshadow in one of four shades: Sable, Gold Meadow, Caviar or Leather, a reddish brown for those with auburn hair. Roseate was dabbed onto the bare mouth with the finger. Said Page, Nothing too complicated, no tricks.

title: Look of the Moment | Solange Knowles
description: The Look: Divine Disco  Super 70s long sleeves, a groovy watercolor print and mylar-metallic heels.

title: Bachelor Pad Finale Delivers for ABC
description: Blanketing prime time with three hours of the Bachelor Pad paid off on Monday, as the season finale of that show averaged just over seven million total viewers while lifting ABC to first place in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for the night among the broadcast networks. On the CW, the French designer Jean Paul Gaultiers interview of Lady Gaga, Gaga By Gaultier, averaged 1.4 million viewers, a small figure to be sure, but it was still the networks largest audience since the season finale of Supernatural in May. The 2011 Miss Universe Pageant, meanwhile, produced diminishing returns for NBC: the event was down 16 percent in the 18-to-49 demographic when compared with last year, its lowest rating ever.

title: Regulators Fear Legal Challenges to Derivatives Rules
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is moving to safeguard dozens of derivatives regulations from legal challenges after a federal appeals court recently struck down a new rule for corporate America, an agency official said Tuesday.

title: 14 Gun Seizures, 16 Arrests and a Bit of Dirty Dancing
description: The police at the West Indian Day Parade last week were extremely busy. There were three shooting episodes, and the police seized 14 firearms and made 16 arrests. But along the peaceful stretches of the parade some officers apparently found time to enjoy themselves, perhaps with a little too much abandon.

title: Peter King in the Hot Seat  in London
description: Representative Peter T. King testified about terrorism on Tuesday before a legislative committee, but the committee was in London, not Washington, and the New York Republican found himself the uncomfortable object of tough questioning. In a hearing on Roots of Violent Radicalization, Mr. King was asked about his own past support for the Irish Republican Army.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Hiccups Solved!
description: On Monday I challenged Well readers to figure out a medical mystery involving a middle-aged man with persistent hiccups.

title: A Hells Kitchem Mural in Distress
description: Arnold Belkins 1972 mural, Against Domestic Colonialism, is in dire need of restoration. A team of expert conservators inspected it on Tuesday.

title: At Frankfurt Show, Automakers Are Optimistic
description: FRANKFURT  Norbert Reithofer, the chief executive of BMW, correctly called the last big auto industry crisis in 2008. So if the sage of Munich was predicting another sharp downturn, that would be cause for concern.

title: Reviewing Hospoda
description: Reviewing Hospoda

title: In Ohio, Obama Emphasizes School Upgrades as Part of Jobs Proposal
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  President Obama took his jobs sales pitch to a high school in this politically crucial swing state on Tuesday, challenging Congress to act swiftly on his $447 billion proposal of tax cuts and stimulus projects to buck up the economy.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Rodarte
description: Backstage at Rodarte, James Kaliardos was touching up Kate Mulleavys makeup while one of his assistants prepped the model Samantha Gradoville (wearing her own webby, iridescent knit) nearby. Odile Gilbert was on the other side of the space getting girls ready for what she calls the Sweet 16, an off-center part with a natural wave and one side twisted up and tucked in with a comb. Soft, innocent  not pretentious, she said of the style created with Krastase Volume Active Mousse and Double Force hairspray. It looks easy, but its not easy. Deborah Lippman painted toes Fashion, her opaque beige, and fingers a custom variation of Lady Sings the Blues. The Mulleavy sisters asked her to up the amount of large graphite glitter in the polish rather than the standard mix of paillettes. Like Lippman, Kaliardos channeled Van Goghs Starry Night with dark navy, shimmering eyes. Using Nars products, he drew all over lids with the shadow pencil in Dark Night and then added Night Flight and Tropic, a turquoise glitter. Looks a bit like Edvard Munchs The Scream,' Kaliardos said laughing as he moved on from Van Gogh. Penny Lane cream blush was used high on the cheeks and to cover the lips, which were then coated with Pearl Beach eyeshadow and Na Na gloss. Dreamy and aggressive at the same time, he said. A cool, ethereal girl.

title: Reviewing Hospoda
description: This weeks restaurant review takes us to the Bohemian National Hall on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, for a look at the Central European cuisine of Hospoda, on the buildings ground floor.

title: Big Flavors in Delicate Portions
description: THERE is something charmingly Old World about Hospoda, the sleek new restaurant on the ground floor of the Bohemian National Hall on the Upper East Side. With its plain bare tables, elegant inlaid wood floors, high ceilings, whimsically engraved wood walls and soaring glasswork, the dining room suggests a beautifully renovated Prague apartment.

title: In the Belly of the East
description: TORONTO  The glass case in the lobby of the Toronto Blue Jays executive office holds World Series trophies from 1992 and 1993. Between them is a small stand, just a few inches high, with a $1 coin. Cito Gaston, the manager of those teams, gave the coin to the receptionist for good luck when he retired two years ago. She displays it as a placeholder for the next trophy, because the coin is dated 1993.

title: Return of the Man Who Used to Rock
description: The 40-year career of the English singer-songwriter Nick Lowe constitutes a paradox: the songs he has written are better known than he is. He cheerfully acknowledges that many people think that Elvis Costello is the author of the Lowe song (Whats So Funny Bout) Peace, Love and Understanding and that the Johnny Cash version of The Beast in Me has come to overshadow his own, which was used on the soundtrack of the HBO series The Sopranos.

title: The Daily Shoe | Rodarte
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Self-Driving Audi A2 Concept, for the Reluctant Motorist
description: FRANKFURT  When conceiving the A2 concept, Audi engineers might have been thinking about the 405.

description: TRIPOLI, Libya  American forces are back on the shores of Tripoli  albeit in a small way.

description: BOSTON  Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard law professor who has battled the financial industry as a consumer advocate, will announce her candidacy Wednesday for what will probably be a high-profile race against Senator Scott P. Brown.

title: After His Open Victory, Djokovic Is the Happiest Guy
description: Fresh off a convincing and thrilling United States Open final victory over Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic admitted he was feeling anything but fresh Tuesday morning.

title: TimesCast | September 13, 2011
description: Militants attack United States and NATO targets in Kabul; Iran agrees to free jailed American hikers; and a heated Congressional race to replace Anthony D. Weiner.

title: Pairings: Braised Spiced Veal Brisket
description: Autumn approaches. Say hello to braising. Its just right for an esoteric cut of veal, the brisket, actually the meatier, less fatty part of a boned breast. Spices, a touch of smoked paprika, and onions and mushrooms in a sauce with real depth give the meat what it needs alongside a graceful red wine with a piquant, smoky bite. I used free-range veal. Like most braises, this was best with patience. When done, refrigerating it overnight and reheating it only improves it. And for Rosh Hashana, consider potato pancakes alongside.

title: A Complex Red With an Austrian Accent
description: EVERYBODY knows that wine is intimidating. The terminology and the connoisseurship can set even the most confident person atremble. But nothing scares wine consumers so much as an umlaut.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, Pakistan and Yemen.

title: When Empty Seats Just Wont Do
description: THEY are monkeying with the 75-year-old Monkey Bar again, and an urgent reason suggests itself.

title: Elmhurst College Asks Applicants About Sexual Orientation
description: The Common Application may have opted earlier this year not to ask students about their sexual orientation, but Elmhurst College in Illinois has recently announced that it will do so on its admission application.

title: Happy Birthday, Roald and James
description: Today would have been Roald Dahls 95th birthday had he not died at the age of 74 in 1990. This year also marks the birthday of one of his most beloved books, James and the Giant Peach, which was published in the United States 50 years ago. (Interestingly, it wasnt published in Britain, Mr. Dahls home until six years later.)

title: A Guide to Cutting Through Special-Election Spin
description: I used to take the view  and I think Ive been pretty consistent about this  that special elections to Congress, while interesting on their own merits, should more or less be ignored in terms of their national implications.

title: Macedonia Is Wild Card of EuroBasket Quarterfinals
description: Most of the quarterfinalists at EuroBasket 2011 do not come as a surprise. Greece, Slovenia and Russia are no strangers to this stage of the competition. And Spain, France, Serbia and host Lithuania were touted as pretournament favorites. But Macedonia? It is bound to turn some heads when the quarterfinals begin Wednesday.

title: G.M. Looks to Shepherd U.A.W. Pact
description: DETROIT  General Motors is aiming to set the framework of a new labor agreement with the United Automobile Workers union that would increase entry-level wages and establish a new profit-sharing formula for workers at all three Detroit car companies.

title: Mercedes-Benz B-Class Is Coming to America
description: FRANKFURT  Mercedes has long hesitated to export its A-Class and B-Class models to America, fearing that the compact cars prosaic, minivan looks did not fit with the super-premium image that the company cultivated in the United States.

title: A Reporter Shields His Identity and an Iranian Exile Groups Viewpoint Goes Missing
description: Reporting on the Peoples Mujahedeen of Iran and their complicated plight at Camp Ashraf in Iraq has proved challenging for The New York Times. So when reporter Tim Arango had the opportunity to visit the camp with Ambassador Lawrence E. Butler, an American diplomat negotiating with the group, he took it.

title: Thelonious Monk International Jazz Piano Competition
description: Polish, understatement and breadth were what the judges were looking for in this jazz competition.

title: Okra, Avocado and Tomato Salad With Chili and Lime Juice
description: This lively combination is inspired by one of my favorite Mexican salads, which is made with diced cooked cactus paddles (nopales), onion, tomato and avocado. Cactus paddles are gooey, like okra, so I figured okra could stand in for nopales in this salad. The result is prettier and, I think, tastier -- and certainly easier to work with than cactus.

title: The Toll From Tree-Boring Pests
description: As Anthony DePalma explained here this morning, the Forest Service went to great lengths to get inside the mind of the emerald ash borer, a vivid-green, bug-eyed invasive insect that is wreaking havoc on trees in 15 states.

title: A Flight to Newark, Later Than the Usual Late
description: It was a flight predisposed, if not predestined, to being late.

title: G.E. Will Pay Back $3 Billion to Buffett
description: Mario Anzuoni/ReutersWarren E. Buffett will get back $3 billion that he invested in General Electric during the financial crisis, plus a $300 million bonus.

title: Tory Burch on Fantasy Island
description: Theres always been a sense, when walking into a Tory Burch store or into her Fashion Week presentations, that you are arriving at the Fantasy Island of fashion. You half sense that Mr. Roarke will tap you on the shoulder at any moment and turn you into an Upper East Side blonde with a car and driver, at least for the day.

title: Vieira Named Special Correspondent for NBC News
description: Three months after she tearfully signed off the Today show, Meredith Vieira confirmed on Tuesday that she was sticking with NBC News as a special correspondent.

title: Web Show Booted From CBS After Bogus Tweet About Steve Jobs
description: Live by the tweet, die by the tweet. That was the lesson for the weekly online news and chat show Whats Trending, which up until Friday appeared on the Web site of the old-media behemoth CBS News. The events that led to the end of the relationship between the show, independently produced by Disrupt Group, and CBS were recounted by its host and executive producer, Shira Lazar, in a long and fairly excruciating on-camera mea culpa at the beginning of Tuesday afternoons episode:

title: The Making of Grit Tape Installation
description: The artist Stephen Doyle taped, across multiple surfaces, the words for the traits being taught at KIPP Infinity middle school in Manhattan. Watch the word grit being made.

title: Tipping the Balance for Kitchen Scales
description: CONSIDER the Parmesan problem: Imagine that youre making lasagna with a recipe that calls for topping it with a cup of grated cheese.

title: N. Carolina Puts Same-Sex Marriage Ban on Ballot
description: North Carolina may soon lose its status as the last state in the Southeast without a Constitutional amendment making marriage legal only when there is a bride and a groom.

title: Trummer Pleads to a Violation in Bar Fire and Avoids Jail
description: Albert Trummer, the celebrity mixologist who was charged last year with illegally setting alcohol aflame on the bartop of his haute cocktail haunt Apothke in Manhattan, pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct, a violation, on Tuesday in Manhattan Criminal Court.

title: Debates Continue to Attract Viewers
description: The Republican presidential primary debate on Monday night attracted 3.6 million viewers to CNN, far fewer than the summers earlier debates on Fox News and MSNBC. But the audience was still big enough for CNN to claim a rare ratings victory over its rivals.

title: Ill Drink What the Monkeys Drinking
description: Back in the 1920s, when a well-heeled gentlemans vim and vigor were flagging, he would visit a Paris surgeon for an implant of monkey testicle tissue.

title: Tradition, Stripped Down and Set to a New Tune
description: Pity the poor Irish dancer. Before Riverdance took the world by surprise in 1994, there were practically no performance opportunities outside of a closed circle of competitions. Since that blockbuster made its debut there has seemed to be only Riverdance and its progeny of lucrative spectacles, mostly assaultive and inane. Presenting Irish dance any differently has proved a daunting challenge.

title: Designers Shop the Cultural Bazaar
description: Some designers this week released their inner gypsies, unveiling collections that brimmed with violently colorful, multicultural references.

title: Day 6: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 13.

title: Humans and Their Planet  One Big Design Space
description: Brad Allenby is at it again, and thank goodness for him and for his ability to prod people out of their cognitive comfort zones in a time of astonishing change.

title: Designers Shop the Cultural Bazaar
description: Some designers this week released their inner gypsies, unveiling collections that brimmed with violently colorful, multicultural references. Some shows carried a whiff of Haiti or Hawaii, while others mined the landscapes and cultures of India and North Africa. Embracing a vagabond spirit,Thakoon Panichgul married the exoticism of Bollywood with broad hints of the American West; Donna Karan combined Haitian-inspired geometry with a dusky African palette, Duro Olowu offered an homage to his Jamaican-born mum, and Joseph Altuzarra showed a smattering of hothouse florals redolent of the South Pacific. Its a global marketplace, they say, in more ways than one.

title: Hugh Jackman Will Sing and Dance Again on Broadway
description: Hugh Jackman is 2-for-2 at turning a profit on Broadway, with his 2003 musical The Boy from Oz and his 2009 play with Daniel Craig, A Steady Rain  a golden track record in a business where only 25 to 30 percent of shows even recoup their investment each year. Now Mr. Jackman has a chance at a hat trick: He will return to Broadway this fall with an 18-piece orchestra for his one-man show, Hugh Jackman, Back on Broadway, featuring a selection of his favorite musical numbers, the producers announced on Tuesday.

title: Order Moves in on Chaos, as Rappers Go Legit
description: Early Das Racist shows were chaos. Not organized chaos (a term of forgiveness), but actual chaos: a thrilling unreliability perpetrated by a duo  notionally a hip-hop outfit but more interested in being provocateurs  who seemed to know exactly what the audience would tolerate. It had to be believed to be seen.

title: Over Objections, New Brooklyn Historic District Is Created
description: Brooklyns latest historic district  a cluster of 21 skyscrapers and office buildings surrounding Borough Hall downtown  was created on Tuesday over the objections of some of its landowners and inhabitants.

title: Excerpt: 'Up All Night'
description: Christina Applegate and Will Arnett play new parents in this new NBC sitcom.

title: So, Like, You Hate Me, You Really Hate Me
description: All you philosophers and physicists can stop speculating because its now official: there is more than one reality.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Dining Calendar
description: Glorious Corn

title: Ill Have the Absurd, Please
description: THE smoked salmon pt arrived in an ashtray. Breadblunt? a waiter murmured, proffering breadsticks from a battered Dutch Masters cigar box.

title: Pork Jowl With a Backwoods Whiff
description: In Italy, the bacon called guanciale is made of pork cheeks. Down South, thats hog jowls, honey. S. Wallace Edwards & Sons of Surry, Va., has introduced Surry Farms-brand Jowciale, made of Berkshire pork. It is suitably fatty, just streaked with meat and easy to slice or dice so it renders nicely. Unlike guanciale, it is smoked and gives a backwoods whiff to bucatini allamatriciana or other sauce, stew or braise.

title: For Once, the Guys Go First
description: Wherever there has been a mens wear show this week, there has been a womens collection not far behind it. Were not talking just about man-skirts and rose prints, but actual mens designers trying their hand, with mixed results, at womens wear.

title: New Spud on the Block
description: The new Peter Wilcox is a potato for New York Fashion Week, cloaked in deep purple and lined in gold. Its as appealing to the palate as it is on the plate, beautifully textured, firm but not waxy, whether roasted, boiled or sliced into wedges and fried, with a full, earthy flavor that hints of hazelnuts. It was developed by researchers in Maryland and Maine and named for a professor at Loyola University in Baltimore. Cooking fades the inside color a bit. For best effect, use these potatoes with the skin on.

title: The Volume Stays Up
description: There seems to be no escape from the orgy of prints and color consuming the runways.

title: Governor Sandoval of Nevada Endorses Perry
description: Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, on Tuesday picked up the support of Brian Sandoval, the governor of Nevada and a fellow Republican.

title: Marchesa: Under the Sea
description: Making the switch from a presentation, with models standing on platforms, to a formal runway show this season allowed Georgina Chapman and Keren Craig of Marchesa to do a lot of things differently. They could hire supermodels like Karen Elson and Karolina Kurkova. They could seat their guests, including Tinsley Mortimer and Courtney Love. They could show in a beautiful space, the Palm Court of the Plaza Hotel.

title: Wall Street Journal Adds to Live Video Programming
description: Operating a bit like a stealth business news network, The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday announced a major expansion of its video unit, which is now producing three and a half hours of live programming each weekday and will soon produce even more.

title: CNN-Tea Party Republican Debate in Tampa, Fla.
description: The following is a transcript of the CNN-Tea Party Republican presidential debate in Tampa, Fla., as provided by Federal News Service:

title: 2011 Frankfurt Motor Show
description: Dozens of new models were introduced as automakers vowed to shed some weight from their vehicles.

title: Creating a Cinematic Picture of a Flemish Masterpiece
description: Even before the opening credits run, The Mill & the Cross casts a transfixing spell, as Pieter Bruegel the Elder, the great 16th-century Flemish artist, chats with his patron Nicholas Jonghelinck while he sketches studies for a large work he is preparing. Then the camera pulls back, blending scores of actors and animals with computer-generated effects, painted backdrops and location shots to restage Bruegels 1564 masterpiece, The Way to Calvary.

title: Stocking Up on Warehouse Properties
description: Developers and investors are starting to make big bets on industrial real estate, following signs that consumers may be starting to spend again. Sales of such properties have jumped nearly threefold from last year, according to figures from commercial real estate companies, and the vacancy rate has fallen for three consecutive quarters.

title: Theater Producers Fraud Convictions Are Upheld
description: OTTAWA  An appeals court on Tuesday upheld the fraud convictions of the Canadian impresario Garth H. Drabinsky and his former business partner, Myron I. Gottlieb.

title: Mets Announcer Weighs In on Cap Controversy
description: In the bottom of the third inning Monday night during the Mets-Nationals game, the SNY announcer Gary Cohen took on Major League Baseball for refusing to let the Mets commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks by wearing New York Fire Department caps when they played the Cubs on Sunday night.

title: Hearing on Solyndra Wont Include Executives
description: Two weeks after the bankruptcy of a solar company that got $527 million in government loans, the House Energy and Commerce Committee will hold a hearing on Wednesday to explore what went wrong.

title: Schrager Makes Over a Legendary Chicago Hotel
description: CHICAGO  Ian Schrager, whose indefatigable pursuit of buzz over the last 30 years has produced memorable hotels like the Royalton and the Gramercy Park in New York, the Mondrian in Los Angeles and the Delano in Miami Beach, is about to open his first new project as an independent hotelier since the 2008 financial crash.

title: A Return to Guatemalas Civil War, in Black and White
description: The cold war may be over, but Washingtons history of intervention in Latin America remains a hotly contested legacy. Its involvement is also, in its sprawling historical detail and far-reaching ideological implications, a necessarily complex inheritance, a fact nowhere suggested by Pamela Yatess new documentary, Granito: How to Nail a Dictator, a follow-up to her first feature-length film, When the Mountains Tremble (1984).

title: Regulators Aim to End Too Big To Fail
description: Nearly three years to the day that Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy and Wall Street teetered on the brink, federal regulators are seeking to wipe out the infamous phenomenon that Wall Street is too big to fail.

title: ConAgra Gives Ralcorp a Deadline to Accept Its Offer
description: After months of unsuccessfully trying to persuade Ralcorp to accept several takeover proposals, ConAgra on Tuesday set a Monday deadline  for the food company to accept its $5.2 billion merger bid.

title: Looking Up in the Standings, With Hope
description: When I was growing up, there was a childrens book called Nothing Ever Happens On My Block. A gloomy kid sits on a curbside, so convinced that theres nothing worth seeing behind him that he never even turns around. Meanwhile, all sorts of stuff is going on in the background, and he misses it all.

title: The Battle of the Barrier
description: The West Bank security barrier is a source of contention in establishing a border between Israel and a future Palestinian state.

title: Kucinich Is Likely to Stay Put
description: Representative Dennis Kucinich, the very liberal Ohio Democrat, evidently wont be heading West in an unusual effort to remain a member of Congress.

title: For Some, Confusing Finish to U.S. Open
description: Television viewers in the Albany, Buffalo and New Orleans markets were entitled to feel a bit confused by Mondays coverage of the United States Open mens final: it was not initially carried on local CBS stations.

title: Rock Is Not the Enemy
description: On Friday, I wrote about an organization called Little Kids Rock, which has helped to revitalize and broaden music education in more than a thousand schools by encouraging children to learn to play popular music, form bands and compose their own songs. The column sparked a little bit of a culture war: some readers were aggrieved by the idea that children should learn popular music in schools, others suggested that classical composers would love rock n roll. Some feared that teaching pop would dumb down music education, others felt it was vital to make music education more relevant to children. Id like to clarify some misconceptions and explain why I think the program is a valuable addition, rather than a threat to the classical tradition.

title: At TechCrunch Conference, Talk of a Bubble
description: This years TechCrunch Disrupt conference in San Francisco sometimes felt more like an episode of E! True Hollywood Story than a high-priced technology gathering.

title: For a Few Weeks, Horse Shows Alter a River Town
description: Every year, the elite competitive equestrian circuit makes its way around the country, from Ocala, Fla., to Culpeper, Va., to Thermal, Calif. These traveling troupes of privilege and skill also take with them small armies  of trainers, grooms, farriers, veterinarians, even equine acupuncturists and masseuses.

title: How Google-Motorola Deal Came Together
description: It took less than seven weeks, but it became more expensive quickly.

title: The Merrill Lynch and Lehman Deals, 3 Years Later
description: This is a tale of two deals.

title: Banks Brace for a Season of Fall-Offs
description: The worries of Wall Street banks keep growing.

title: Scientists Hint at Why Laughter Feels So Good
description: Laughter is regularly promoted as a source of health and well being, but it has been hard to pin down exactly why laughing until it hurts feels so good.

title: In Republican Race, a Heated Battle Over the HPV Vaccine
description: An unlikely issue  whether to vaccinate preadolescent girls against a sexually transmitted virus  has become the latest flashpoint among Republican presidential candidates as they vie for the support of social conservatives and Tea Party members.

title: C.I.A. Examining Legality of Work With Police Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has opened an internal inquiry into whether its close cooperation with the New York Police Department in the decade since the Sept. 11 attacks has broken any laws prohibiting the agency from collecting intelligence in the United States.

title: For King Pimp, a Name-Dropping Defense Only a Panic Attack Can Slow Down
description: By now, a fair number of people are familiar with the modus operandi of Jason Itzler, proud promoter of female companionship and champion of hyperbole.

title: Baying at the Bard, Appropriately and Otherwise
description: Hundreds of people had come to Griffith Park for a night of Shakespeare, carrying blankets and picnic baskets filled with wine, artisanal cheeses and heirloom tomato salads (dressing packed separately in Tupperware, of course).

title: Amid the Deluge and the Drama, Dazzling Play
description: A little more than two weeks ago, the United States Open started under the threat of Hurricane Irene, a harbinger, perhaps, of the tumult that lay ahead.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Mideast Prospects
description: To the Editor:

title: Orient Express Trailer
description: A new campaign for Orient-Express luxury hotels includes commercials like this one.

title: Luxury Hotels Market the Memories They Can Make
description: SINCE the financial crisis began, millions of wealthy consumers have decided to play down the joy of accumulating things in favor of the pleasure of accumulating experiences. As a result, purveyors of premium-priced products and services are embracing the notion that they provide customers with moments to remember rather than with more stuff that needs dusting (by the help, most likely).

title: In Woodstock, Values Collide Over Housing
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.  If they had decided to pave paradise and put up a parking lot, the issues might have seemed simpler.

title: The Glass-Half-Full Department
description: Maybe its back-to-school fever, but everyone I know seems besieged by pessimism. Im distressed by water shortages, the state of the labor movement and the Somalian famine, which may needlessly kill 700,000 people this year. Friends are overwhelmed by their memories of 9/11 and of the horribly blown opportunities to use an excruciatingly painful event to move us towards a better place.

title: The Season of Djokovic Challenges All Others
description: If prize money is the measuring stick, Novak Djokovics magnificent season is already the best in mens tennis history  $10.6 million earned and more than two months of paydays still to come.

title: Seeking a Fiscal Plan That Will Work
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.S. Extends Estate Taxes Deadline
description: The Internal Revenue Service said on Tuesday that tax returns for estates that are worth more than $5 million for people who died in 2010 will be due on Jan. 17, instead of Nov. 15.

title: Tax Plan for Jobs Bill Has Familiar Ring
description: To pay for his $447 billion jobs bill, President Obama is once again proposing an assortment of tax increases on wealthy individuals and corporations.

title: Our Wealth in Lands
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea's First Cruise
description: Edward Wong travels on a trial run of the first-ever tourist cruise to the secretive authoritarian nation of North Korea.

title: Jobs in a Green Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Import Prices Fall for Second Time in 3 Months
description: Prices of goods imported into the United States fell in August for the second time in three months as the cost of oil and food dropped, while autos stabilized, the Labor Department said Tuesday.

title: Fees for Inmate Visits
description: To the Editor:

title: The Name to Beat in the FedEx Cup Is a Long One
description: LEMONT, Ill.  Surely it isnt his face that gets Webb Simpson noticed in airport security lines  a preposterously smooth, sunburned visage set off by a pair of steely blue eyes that fairly screams tennis player, surfer, golfer or skier.

title: North Korean Cruise Seeks Tourists, 8 to a Room
description: ABOARD THE MANGYONGBONG, off North Korea  It was billed as a cruise ship, but the creaking, nearly-40-year-old vessel that set sail from the remote North Korean town of Rajin had more of the trappings of a tramp steamer. With its cramped cabins, cut-rate cuisine and foul, water-deprived bathrooms, it was not about to compete anytime soon with Cunard or Carnival in the leisure industry.

title: Demand at Target for Fashion Line Crashes Web Site
description: Targets Web site came crashing down on Tuesday as Missoni-loving fashion devotes invaded, scrambling to buy the high-end Italian designers clothes for a song.

title: Toyota Restores North American Pace
description: Toyota on Tuesday said that it had resumed full production at its North American plants for the first time since it began experiencing parts shortages after the earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan in March.

title: Lottery Numbers
North Carolina Voters to Decide on Same-Sex Marriage
description: ATLANTA  North Carolina on Tuesday took a big step toward losing its status as the last state in the Southeast without a constitutional amendment making it clear that marriage is legal only when there is a bride and bridegroom.

title: EBay Discloses Inquiry Over Craigslist
description: EBay, the online auction site, said on Tuesday that it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into Craigslists disputes with the company.

title: Some People Like Citi Fields Size. Theyre Called Pitchers.
description: Amid growing speculation that the Mets will shrink the daunting dimensions of Citi Field this off-season, the issue has become an open topic of discussion among players in the clubhouse. After a recent game, David Wright lamented that he had hit 800 feet worth of doubles and added, perhaps only half-jokingly, that he hoped such an effort would yield a couple of home runs next season.

title: The Terrifying Tigers
description: Lt. Col. Charles de Choiseul was not a happy man. It was September 1861, and de Choiseul, a well-educated French Creole, had been ordered to take temporary command of Maj. Chatham Roberdeau Wheats First Special Battalion of Louisiana Infantry while Wheat recovered from a serious wound suffered at the First Battle of Bull Run. It was no routine assignment: a Virginia officer had been given the position previously, but he was unable to control the rowdy men and quit after only a few days. Now it was de Choiseuls turn to try to rein in what was known as the Tiger Battalion. He wrote a friend, I am a victim of circumstances, not of my own will.  Whether the Tigers will devour me, or whether I will succeed in taming them, remains to be seen.

title: Photo Replay: Saugerties Horse Shows
description: More than 2,200 equestrians and their entourages descend on Saugerties, N.Y., every summer, and the influx of cash has played a part in transforming the village.

title: A Well-Regulated Wilderness
description: Vienna, Va.

title: Airport Security Officers Charged in Drug Case
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Three Transportation Security Administration officers have been charged with accepting bribes to let couriers smuggle painkillers and cash undetected through security checkpoints at airports in New York and Florida, federal prosecutors said Tuesday.

title: Tuck Hopes to Play Against the Rams
description: Defensive end Justin Tuck said the neck injury that kept him out of the Giants Week 1 defeat at Washington had improved, and he hopes to play in the Giants game against the St. Louis Rams.

title: A Good Jobs Program
description: President Obama has often trimmed his ideas to what he thinks he might possibly get from an opposition that intends to give him nothing. So it is a relief to see him demanding that Congress do what the country really needs.

title: The Cost of Inaction
description: The latest figures from the Census Bureau show the devastating cost of the recession and why putting Americans back to work must be Washingtons top priority.

title: Retired Players Sue Players Union
description: A group of retired N.F.L. players, led by the Hall of Famer Carl Eller, filed a class-action lawsuit in federal court against the N.F.L. Players Association seeking damages and asking that the terms of the new collective bargaining agreement that relate to retiree benefits be renegotiated between the retired players involved in the lawsuit and the N.F.L.

title: U.S. Scrambles to Avert Palestinian Vote at U.N.
description: WASHINGTON  The United States is facing increasing pressure as the Palestinian quest for statehood gained support from Turkey and other countries, even as the Obama administration sought an 11th-hour compromise that would avoid a confrontation at the United Nations next week.

title: U.S. Inquiry Traces Foreigners With Visas
description: A vast investigation by the Department of Homeland Security of 1.6 million cases of foreigners suspected of remaining in the United States after their visas expired has shown that more than half of them have already left the country or obtained legal immigration status, officials told Congress on Tuesday.

title: No Justice for Anna Politkovskaya
description: Five years after the Russian journalist Anna Politkovskaya was brutally shot in her Moscow apartment building, there have been no convictions for her murder.

title: Actions by States to Require the HPV Vaccination
description: Actions by states to require vaccination against HPV.

title: Income and Poverty Rate at 1990s Levels
description: Median household income and poverty rate at 1990s levels in the United States.

title: Comparing Internet Speeds Across the Nation
description: Comparing Internet speeds across the nation.

title: Wednesday: Reply to a Knock
Champions League: Sky Blue Over Manchester
description: The UEFA Champions League on Wednesday brings the second series of matches in the form of six group-stage games, with Manchester City hosting Napoli and Bayern Munich traveling to Villarreal in Spain in Group A, which has been nominated as the tournaments group of death. The schedule (all games start at 2:45 p.m. Eastern):

title: Young Science Geeks Try to Make Love Add Up to Something
description: If Mary can shuck three ears of corn in a minute, and John can shuck four ears of corn in a minute, and there are 150 ears of corn in a bushel, how many bushels of corn can Mary and John shuck in an hour? Aarrgh! Remember word problems on math quizzes? The rebellious young mind, faced with such vexing questions, would be hard pressed to resist the desire to tear up the test paper and shout out, Who cares how many bushels of corn Mary and John can shuck?

title: Evicted for Manhattan Starbucks No. 188, but Defying the Coffee Octopus
description: One day about three weeks ago, the morning rush in the Bean coffee shop in the East Village was reaching its crest when one of the baristas dashed downstairs to get the boss.

title: 4 Council Members, Each With $1 Million, Will Let Public Decide How Its Spent
description: Four City Council members, intrigued by experiments begun in Brazil to let ordinary citizens determine how government uses tax dollars, say they plan to allow their constituents to decide how $4 million is spent next year.

title: The Spirit of the Game
description: Gracious losers, and winners, are, sadly, rare in professional sports. Rafael Nadals performance Monday night, after losing this years United States Open, was the very essence of graciousness and a reminder of what good sportsmanship really means.

title: Photo Replay: Sept 13
description: A look back at the day in sports, from soccer in Jordan to Usain Bolt in Croatia.

title: Is It Weird Enough Yet?
description: Every time I listen to Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota talk about how climate change is some fraud perpetrated by scientists trying to gin up money for research, Im always reminded of one of my favorite movie lines that Jack Nicholson delivers to his needy neighbor who knocks on his door in the film As Good As It Gets. Where do they teach you to talk like this? asks Nicholson. Sell crazy someplace else. Were all stocked up here.

title: Looking to Raise Revenue
description: The Obama administration has proposed to pay for its jobs bill by eliminating tax breaks in four areas.

title: Bystanders Lift Flaming Car to Save a Man
description: On a stretch of road by the crest of a hill in Logan, Utah, on Monday, a motorcycle and a BMW collided, throwing the cyclist under the car and causing the bike to burst into flames, which quickly spread to the sedan. Rather than fleeing those two flaming vehicles, a dozen bystanders rushed toward the blaze, lifted the car and pulled the injured man out by his ankle.

title: In City of Cyclists, Pedestrians Feel the Squeeze
description: COPENHAGEN  Mikael le Dous has it in for bikers.

title: Vacation Cut Short by Chance to Help Yanks in the Stretch
description: SEATTLE  Austin Romine was walking out of a Wal-Mart in Kentucky last Saturday night, carrying supplies for his girlfriends new apartment there, when his phone rang.

title: Memoirs of a Geisha
description: WASHINGTON

title: Richard Hamilton, British Painter and a Creator of Pop Art, Dies at 89
description: Richard Hamilton, a British painter and printmaker whose sly, trenchant take on consumer culture and advertising made him a pioneering figure in Pop Art, and who designed the cover of the Beatles White Album, died on Tuesday at his home near Oxford. He was 89.

title: Board Urges Cellphone Ban for All Commercial Drivers
description: WASHINGTON After a Kentucky truck crash that killed 11 people, top federal safety investigators vastly broadened their recommendations on cellphones on Tuesday and said all commercial drivers should be forbidden to use them, whether hand-held or not, except in emergencies.

title: Auditors Find Chaos in U.S. Marshals Asset Sales Record-Keeping
description: The unit of the United States Marshals Service that manages complex assets seized in criminal cases, including that of Bernard L. Madoff, kept such shoddy records that it could not say who bought assets or how much was paid for them in 8 of the 55 sales it handled from 2005 to 2010, according to an audit released on Tuesday.

title: Baghdad Assailed Over Attack in Anbar
description: BAGHDAD  Just a few hours after the bodies of 22 executed Shiite pilgrims were found in western Anbar Province, Sunni leaders there erupted in anger on Tuesday at Iraqs Shiite-led government, exposing yet another fault line in the countrys sectarian tensions.

title: For Idaho and the Internet, Life in the Slow Lane
description: POTLATCH, Idaho  Barry Ramsay, who owns a small manufacturing company here between two mountains, remembers the day his Internet connection crashed for several hours. Work crews had to ride up in snowmobiles to discover the problem.

title: A Night for Everyone but the Mets
description: It was Star Wars Night at Citi Field on Tuesday.

title: A Go To Accountant Is Accused of Fraud
description: LOS ANGELES  For almost 15 years, Kinde Durkee has been one of the go-to accountants for Democratic candidates in California. She and her firm kept track of expenditures and contributions and made sure that candidates and party committees campaigns complied with Californias tangled election finance laws.

title: With Bipartisan Support, Law on Expansion of Charter Schools Passes the House
description: In a rare display of bipartisanship, the House approved a bill on Tuesday supporting the expansion of charter schools, the first part of a legislative package planned by Republicans to carry out a piecemeal rewrite of the main federal law on public education, No Child Left Behind.

title: In Milestone Victory for Wakefield, Red Sox Ease a Collective Panic
description: BOSTON  The panic and fear that had gripped all New England, that the Red Sox would throw away what looked like an insurmountable lead in the wild-card race, has tempered. At least for one night.

title: Bigger Economic Role for Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Just weeks ago, economists and financial analysts were dismissing Washington as largely irrelevant to the economys course in coming months, if only because it chose to be. They are not dismissing it anymore.

title: Serious Error Found in Carbon Savings for Biofuels
description: The European Union is overestimating the reductions in greenhouse gas emissions achieved through reliance on biofuels as a result of a serious accounting error, according to a draft opinion by an influential committee of 19 scientists and academics.

title: Wal-Mart to Announce Women-Friendly Plans
description: Wal-Mart planned to announce on Wednesday new programs aimed at helping women-owned businesses and women workers, as the company continues to deal with the possibility of individual claims of sex discrimination after the Supreme Court threw out a class-action suit by women workers this summer.

title: U.N. Accuses Yemen of Using Deadly Force in Protests
description: GENEVA  A United Nations report published Tuesday says the Yemeni government has used excessive and deadly force against peaceful demonstrators, killing hundreds and wounding thousands since the beginning of the year.

title: Abuse of Xanax Leads a Clinic to Halt Supply
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Gayle Mink, a nurse practitioner at a community mental health center here, had tired of the constant stream of patients seeking Xanax, an anti-anxiety drug coveted for its swift calming effect.

title: Israeli Company Taken Off Iran Trade Blacklist
description: JERUSALEM  The State Department on Tuesday removed Ofer Holdings Group Ltd., a leading Israeli company, from a sanctions blacklist for trade with Iran, reversing a step taken four months ago that dealt a blow to the reputation and businesses of the Ofer family, one of the richest in Israel.

title: Spending Inequity in Colleges Has Risen
description: As income inequality has increased in the United States over the last decade, so too has the gap between rich and poor colleges and universities.

title: Word of the Day | deflect
description: deflect \di-flekt, de-\ verb

title: Lapses by American Leaders Seen in Syphilis Tests
description: The highest medical and legal officials of the American government and experts at Harvard and other top medical schools approved venereal disease experiments on people in the 1940s, which led to the deliberate infection of Guatemalan prisoners and mental patients with syphilis to test penicillin, a White House bioethics panel reported Tuesday.

title: Kashmir: Top Militant Is Killed
description: The authorities in Indian-administered Kashmir said they killed a top officer of Lashkar-e-Taiba, a Pakistan-based militant group that was responsible for the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, in a gun battle on Tuesday. The officer, Azhar Malik, was shot after the police surrounded a house where he had been hiding in the town of Sopore, the district police chief, Imtiaj Hussain, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Malik was involved in at least 20 cases of terrorist activities, the police chief said, the latest being the bombing in April that killed a moderate separatist religious leader in the Kashmir Valley.

title: Arab League Asked to Act on Syria
description: Scores of Arab and international human rights organizations have submitted a petition to the Arab League demanding that it suspend Syria as a member until that nation halts its crackdown on demonstrators who are demanding democratic change. The petition, signed by more than 175 organizations, also said Arab League members should support United Nations actions including a travel ban and the freezing of assets and should go even beyond those measures with an arms embargo. The lack of a unified Arab position against the Syrian government, unlike the reaction to the uprising in Libya, has helped block international action against Damascus.

title: Carl Oglesby, Antiwar Leader in 1960s, Dies at 76
description: Carl Oglesby, who led Students for a Democratic Society as it publicly opposed the Vietnam War but who was later expelled by a radical faction that became the Weather Underground, died on Tuesday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 76.

title: Obama Campaign Launches AttackWatch.com
description: President Obamas re-election campaign launched a Web site on Tuesday called AttackWatch.com that encourages supporters to help dismiss false accusations made about the presidents record and to report what they believe is misinformation about his policies.

title: John Calley, Hollywood Chief, Dies at 81
description: LOS ANGELES  John Calley, who was known for his unusually artistic approach in running three major Hollywood studios and overseeing some of the most successful movies of the last 50 years, died Tuesday at his home here. He was 81.

title: Democratic Party Pick Wins Brooklyn Race
description: The Democratic machine whirred and then roared in northern Brooklyn on Tuesday, churning out a significant victory for Rafael L. Espinal in a fiercely contested three-way race for the 54th State Assembly District seat.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Today
description: A train collision in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu last night killed at least 10 people (The Hindu) and injured more than 70 when a passenger trained rammed into a stationary one near Arrakonam, which is about 50 miles from the state capital, Chennai. This is the third major train accident (The Times of India) in the country in the past two months.Is Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi on the fast track to center stage (Hindustan Times), after announcing a three-day fast starting September 17? While fasting is most recently associated with the Anna Hazare anti-corruption movement, Modi said in an open letter that his fast will strengthen the states environment of peace, unity and harmony (Gujarat government Web site) after Mondays Supreme Court decision ended an unhealthy environment created by the unfounded and false allegations against him and his government.

title: Battle for Libya | September 13, 2011
description: Residents continued to flee Bani Walid.

title: Rivera Notches Save No. 600 in Seattle as Yankees Win
description: SEATTLE  In the end, Mariano Rivera did what millions of baseball fans have been doing for 15 years. He watched as the final out was recorded in one of his saves.

title: Indian Police Say Terror Chief Killed In Kashmir
description: Police in Indian-administered Kashmir said they killed a top officer of a Pakistan-based terrorist group in a gun battle yesterday.

title: For Democrats, Its 2010 All Over Again
description: The outcome of any individual election to the United States House, even in a highly partisan era where Congressional elections have a relatively strong correlation with presidential voting and national trends, is going to be determined based on a combination of local and national factors. One congressional districts outcome may diverge significantly from anothers  even if they seem similar on the surface  based on the quality of the candidates, the demographics of the region and issues highly pertinent to the district but not to the nation at large. Any one race may or may not be representative.

title: TimesCast | Iran to Free Prisoners
description: September 13, 2011 - Iran agrees to release two American hikers it suspected of being spies.

title: Ms. India: The Womens Printing Press
description: Ms. India, a regular feature by Nilanjana S. Roy, offers snapshots of the changing lives of women in the country, from the perspective of the Bharatiya Naari, or ideal Indian woman, whether she lives in urban, small-town or village India.Everyone in Karaikal knows the Womens Press, whose colorful pink sign advertises the press and its stationery shop just outside the Old Bus Stand, on a dusty street perfumed by the scent of jasmine sold everywhere. The Karaikal Women Society Co-operative Printing Society Ltd., to give the press its full name, was started in 1979 in this thriving port town in the Union Territory of Puducherry, making it the oldest  and perhaps the only  printing press in India run by women.

title: Sept. 14, 1959 | Soviet Space Probe Is First Human-Made Object to Reach Moon
description: On Sept. 14, 1959, the Luna 2 space probe crashed onto the surface of the moon. Though Luna 2 was shattered on impact, the mission was a major success, as it represented an important first in the history of space exploration.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 14, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Raiders Put Trust in Janikowski
description: When Sebastian Janikowski tied the N.F.L. record by making a 63-yard field goal to end the first half against the Broncos on Monday night, few on the Oakland side of the field were surprised. Janikowski routinely kicks 65-yarders in practice, and made one from 70 in pregame warm-ups Monday.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 14, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Atop TV Sets, a Power Drain That Runs Nonstop.

title: In Rebuke to Irans President, Courts Void Release of Hikers
description: CAIRO  To pave the way for his annual visit to the United Nations, Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, announced with great fanfare this week the imminent release of two American hikers sentenced to eight years for espionage.

title: An Antigay Bullying Battle
description: WHO has brought a lawsuit against a suburban school district contending that school officials have failed to stop relentless antigay bullying?WHO has demanded that the schools there avoid any descriptions of homosexuality or same-sex marriage as normal?WHO is the Congressional representative for most of this school district?

title: Does Your Homework Help You Learn?
description: New research suggests that a lot of assigned homework amounts to pointless busy work that doesnt help students learn, while more thoughtful assignments can help them develop skills and acquire knowledge. How would you characterize the homework you get?

title: Terrorists Kill More Than 20 Across Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Terrorist attacks across Iraq killed more than 20 people on Wednesday, including in Anbar Province, where an increase in violence has heightened sectarian tensions.

title: How Payroll Tax Cuts Can Create Jobs
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: At London Show, Comic Book Heroes Combined to Create Real-Life Ones
description: To commemorate the 10-year anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, one London gallery is honoring the real-life heroes  the firemen and policemen who protect us every day  by imbuing them with the invincible spirit of fictional superheroes.

title: At Frankfurt Motor Show, the Future Toys of the Very Rich
description: FRANKFURT  At every auto show, a certain number of impossibly exotic vehicles are introduced. The brands that manufacture these pieces of the unattainable dont usually make a point of discussing how only ultra-high-net-worth individuals can afford their creations, and nobody seems particularly surprised or perturbed if these playthings of the very rich wind up in the garages of oil barons, drug lords, Far Eastern nouveau capitalists or various Third World despots.

title: Tebow Becomes the Broncos Burden
description: Tim Tebows critics cant blame him for this.

title: Part 3: Answers to Your Back-to-School Admissions Questions
description: The Choice has lined up the authors of a new book  which bills itself as the ultimate users manual for college applicants, and loosely follows, as its model, the What to Expect When Youre Expecting series  to field questions about what high school seniors and juniors (and their parents) should be doing now on the college admissions front.

title: Austere Italy? Check the Traffic
description: COMITINI, Italy  With only 960 residents and a handful of roads, this tiny hilltop village in the arid, sulfurous hills of southern Sicily does not appear to have major traffic problems. But that does not prevent it from having one full-time traffic officer  and eight auxiliaries.

title: The Early Word: Piecemeal?
description: Todays Times

title: They Didnt Win, but They Deserve Some Applause
description: More than the physical and mental battles that playing an elite-level match necessitate, the true brutality of a tennis tournament is the near-inevitability of leaving as a loser. One hundred and twenty eight men entered the singles competition at the 2011 United States Open, and all but oneNovak Djokovicleave New York as a loser.

title: Codecademy Offers Free Coding Classes for Aspiring Entrepreneurs
description: When Zach Sims, a political science student at Columbia, and Ryan Bubinski, a developer and former classmate, were batting around ideas for their start-up pitch to present at Y-Combinator, a well-known start-up incubator based in Silicon Valley, they had more than a few stumbles while settling on an idea.

title: When Rockefeller Criticized Lindsay, He Was Wrong
description: Defending his decision not to go to the Attica Correctional Facility in September 1971 where inmates were holding guards hostage and where a siege by the state police ended in 39 deaths, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller made a disparaging assertion about New Yorks John V. Lindsay. Except, Rockefeller was wrong.

title: Can This Web Site Match Employers and Employees?
description: After Helen Rosen was laid off in 2008, she found herself frustrated by the job search process. Ms. Rosen, who had worked in the financial industry for 15 years, didnt get the results she was hoping for from online job boards. In fact, she found the process of matching jobs to job seekers terribly inefficient.

title: Replacing Coal With Gas Is No Panacea, Study Says
description: Although power plants fired by natural gas emit about half the carbon dioxide that conventional coal plants do, shifting from coal to natural gas to generate electricity will do little to slow climate change, according to a new study from the National Center for Atmospheric Research.

title: U.S. Blames Pakistan-Based Group for Attack on Embassy in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Raising the death toll sharply, American and Afghan officials said Wednesday that the complexity and execution of the siege of the American Embassy and NATOs headquarters in Kabul bore the hallmarks of a militant group based in Pakistan that has become one of the American militarys most implacable foes.

title: Elizabeth Warren Announces Senate Run
description: Elizabeth Warren officially announced her candidacy for the United States Senate in Massachusetts on Wednesday morning in a short video posted to her new campaign Web site, www.elizabethwarren.com.

description: How well able to direct a computer with our thoughts using an ECoG (electrocorticographic) implant.

title: The Cyborg in Us All
description: Fingers! Gerwin Schalk sputtered, waving his hands around in the air. Fingers are made to pick up a hammer. He prodded the table, mimicking the way we poke at computer keyboards. Its totally ridiculous, he said.

title: The Name Might Escape, Not the Work
description: THE golden age of Hollywood may have passed, but these are boom times for great character actors. On the big screen and the small, in movies and in television, beautiful sad sacks like Paul Giamatti, Bryan Cranston and Steve Buscemi are running away with some of the best roles and lines going, and Viola Davis is suddenly on the verge of stardom.

title: A Heartthrob Finds His Tough-Guy Side
description: THE not uncommon view that Ryan Gosling is among the most disarming of young actors took on another meaning last month with the emergence of a viral video of a New York City street fight. In a scene that could be out of Laurel and Hardy, two men are going at it in an East Village crosswalk while bystanders, to no avail, try to pull them apart. A young man in a tank top and a baseball cap strolls into the melee. In the time it takes for the excited voices behind the cellphone camera to realize that this movie starlike good Samaritan is in fact the guy from the movie  The Notebook he has somehow orchestrated a cease-fire.

title: What if the Secret to Success Is Failure?
description: Dominic Randolph can seem a little out of place at Riverdale Country School  which is odd, because hes the headmaster. Riverdale is one of New York Citys most prestigious private schools, with a 104-year-old campus that looks down grandly on Van Cortlandt Park from the top of a steep hill in the richest part of the Bronx. On the discussion boards of UrbanBaby.com, worked-up moms from the Upper East Side argue over whether Riverdale sends enough seniors to Harvard, Yale and Princeton to be considered truly TT (top-tier, in UrbanBabyese), or whether it is more accurately labeled 2T (second-tier), but it is, certainly, part of the citys private-school elite, a place members of the establishment send their kids to learn to be members of the establishment. Tuition starts at $38,500 a year, and thats for prekindergarten.

title: MF Global Holdings to Eliminate Jobs
description: MF Global Holdings, the giant commodities and derivatives brokerage firm, said on Wednesday that it would reduce equity sales, trading and research jobs in Europe and Asia by more than 30 percent.

title: Election Reflects New Dynamic in Brooklyn and Queens
description: The Democratic Party in Queens ended Tuesday night exposed as a tottering old dame, her inability to push a loyal  if severely charisma-challenged  son into Congress testament to her infirmities.

title: A Next-Generation Cooking App by Dorie Greenspan
description: Dorie Greenspan, whose books on baking have launched a thousand sables, has a new app for the iPad dropping today. Baking With Dorie ($12.99) has several nifty and useful features that we didnt see in the first generation of cooking apps, including step-by-step video for every recipe, like tarte tatin; crisp, airy visuals; and a choice among several recipe layouts, all of them designed for the needs of the cook, not the programmer.

The adult entertainment and publishing company will operate its contest, called the Playboy Shorts Series, viaTalenthouse.com, a social networking site that aims to foster artistic collaboration.

title: The Somber Shadows of Attica
description: There was talk of crucifixion and resurrection Tuesday night at Union Theological Seminary, not a surprising topic for that setting. The context was unusual, though. The speakers werent referring to Calvary. They had in mind a muddy cellblock yard at Attica state prison where the blood had flowed freely 40 years earlier to the day.

title: Baryshnikov Breaks Out His Russian For In Paris
description: PARIS  In 1978, the first time Mikhail Baryshnikov performed in Paris, he was booed. Loudly. He was dancing the role of the doomed Herman in Roland Petits interpretation of Queen of Spades, and the audience hated it.

title: Another Day, Another Odd Literary Collectible for Sale: J. K. Rowlings Boots
description: Finally, something for the J. K. Rowling fan who has everything, including some extra space in his or her shoe closet. Arriving on the heels, so to speak, of Tuesdays announcement that a one-sentence letter from J. D. Salinger to his maid was being offered for $50,000, a company in Omaha is putting up for auction a pair of boots that Ms. Rowling wore while she wrote the first book in her best-selling Harry Potter series. The boots, which are being sold by Blue Earth Benefit Auctions in an online auction that starts Friday at proxibid.com, were given to a fifth-grade class at Harrison Elementary School in Omaha in 1999. At that time, the class was conducting a project called Operation Shoe Tree, in which celebrities or other people the pupils admired were asked to write about their lives from the perspective of their footwear.

title: Istanbul Reimagined
description: Design is not about objects anymore; its more pervasive, says Vasif Kortun, a director of Istanbuls new arts center Salt (Istiklal Caddesi 136; saltonline.org). Turkey is picking it up belatedly. And quickly. Since the opening of Adnan Kazmaoglus austerely geometric Yesil Vadi Mosque in Istanbul last year, a design and architecture movement is sweeping through the city. Salts Beyoglu building, a columned space by the local architect Han Tumertekin on the boulevard Istiklal, features the work of a different Turkish designer in each room  theres a cinema by Hakan Demirel, a bookstore by Omer Unal and a cafe by Ali Selcuk and the chef Murat Bozok. Regular symposiums cover everything from urban planning to electronic music, and later this fall a second outpost will open nearby in Galata.

title: Where the Bargains Are
description: LOOKING for five-star service at three-star prices? Try Latin America for your next vacation. Whether its due to a good exchange rate (as in Argentina) or simply because a destination is just coming into its own (Colombia), travelers will find that they will often pay less for a boutique hotel experience and that meals are more reasonable, if not downright cheap, compared with Europe or the United States.

title: Boys at Play
description: When little boys arent jumping off furniture, kicking their big sisters in the shin or wrenching Transformers from the hands of other children, their habits of play can be quite endearing. Three new picture books capture the singularity, stubbornness and, yes, sweetness in the ways young boys find to amuse themselves.

title: Waste Not, Biden Tells Cabinet

Towards that end, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday convened the first Cabinet meeting dedicated solely to looking at how to reduce waste at federal agencies.

description: The New York Times on Tuesday named two new editors to senior leadership positions, the latest in a series of appointments by the new executive editor, Jill Abramson.

title: Furor Over Loans to Failed Solar Firm
description: WASHINGTON  Republican lawmakers, escalating the political furor over the collapse of a solar equipment manufacturer that received a $528 million government loan, released excerpts from Obama administration e-mails on Wednesday suggesting that the White House pressed federal officials to wrap up their review of the loan quickly for political purposes.

title: Designing a Greener Commute in the Bay Area
description: What can data do for your daily commute? A team of energy policy consultants and software developers met in San Francisco to brainstorm how data sets could be used to make the typical urban commute shorter and greener.

title: Watch Out for Lethal Branches. Bats, Too.
description: For my job at the Nature Conservancy, I spend a lot of time planning fieldwork in remote places where I study how conservation benefits people in poor communities. So I approached my familys year in the woods as if it were fieldwork in a new country. I read all I could before going and talked to people who were already living off the grid in the woods of Maine to understand the local risks.

title: The Places Where Nowhere Is Home

He poured over a rare collection of archival photographs collected from community members. He helped shape a comprehensive, and largely unseen, visual narrative of the culture.
