title: Bike Sharing vs. Sidewalk Sharing
description: It is a conceit of New Yorkers that their city is a breeding ground for all manner of new ideas on making life in a big town more bearable. In fact, the opposite is usually true. Just as the United States has a chronic trade deficit when it comes to goods, New York runs a deficit in ideas. Innovations tend to originate elsewhere, whether in education, mass transit, homelessness, health  or bicycles.

title: Kiwi Confections
description: By the standards of global hipness, New Zealand  where local food is a way of life and youre as likely to see a beard on a farmer as on a barista  has been cool for years. Which may be why the windy capital city of Wellington is getting buzz as the Portland of the Pacific. Fueled by an abundance of fishing and agriculture, the restaurant scene is brimming with experimentation.

title: Inflation Slowed in August, Reflecting a Weak Economy
description: The rate of inflation in the United States slowed slightly in August, when a rise in food prices was tempered by easing prices for gasoline and automobiles, according to government statistics released Thursday.

title: Anti-Israel Rally in Jordan Also Exposes Arab Rifts
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Efforts to organize a million-person march on the Israeli Embassy in Jordans capital concluded on Thursday with about 200 pro-Palestinian protesters cordoned off by nearly as many Jordanian police and security officers in a vacant lot about a mile away from the diplomatic mission.

title: Wade Mainer, a Pioneer of Bluegrass Banjo, Dies at 104
description: Wade Mainer, a singer and banjo player whose clean, emphatic style and devotion to old-time mountain songs made him a pivotal figure in the transition to bluegrass music, died on Monday at his home in Flint, Mich. Mr. Mainer, who once performed at the White House for President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was 104.

(I was a recipient of this award, administered by the Academies Keck Futures Initiative, in the newspapers/magazines category in 2003, the first year it was offered, for coverage of climate science and policy.) [Theres more on the award, and my blogging approach, from Pace University.]

title: Video of Deadly Cruise Ship Fire Off Norway
description: A fire aboard a cruise ship off the coast of Norway early Thursday killed two people, injured nine others and forced the evacuation of nearly half of the 262 people aboard as the vessel limped into a harbor in a thick cloud of smoke.

title: Take Two: Polanski Plans Another Trip to Zurich Film Festival
description: Two years after his attempt to travel to the Zurich Film Festival resulted in his arrest in connection with a decades-old sex crime Roman Polanski will return to that festival to receive the lifetime achievement award he was to have received in 2009, Reuters reported. Mr. Polanski, the director of films including Rosemarys Baby, Chinatown and The Pianist was arrested at the request of the United States when he arrived in 2009 at the Zurich airport en route to the festival. Prosecutors in Los Angeles and Washington were seeking to extradite the filmmaker, who fled the United States in 1978 to avoid facing punishment after he pleaded guilty one year earlier to having sex with a 13-year-old girl. Mr. Polanski spent several months under house arrest in Gstaad before Swiss prosecutors said they would not extradite him.

title: Grandson Disputes New Play Attributed to Oscar Wilde
description: Perhaps there is something worse than being talked about, and that is having words attributed to you that you never wrote. At least, thats the case being made by Merlin Holland, the grandson of Oscar Wilde, who says that a coming play promoted as a rediscovered Wilde text is not the handiwork of his illustrious grandfather, The Guardian reported.

description: DETROIT  The United Automobile Workers union turned its full attention to General Motors on Thursday to reach a new national labor agreement after postponing talks at Chrysler.

title: Just a Little Moonlighting on Broadway
description: THE drive from Times Square to the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., takes an hour, but the journey that Jeremy Jordan must complete during the ride is much longer. On Broadway, where Mr. Jordan will soon spend his days rehearsing for the new musical Bonnie & Clyde, he is one of the outlaw lovers who terrorized and seduced East Texas during the hungry years of the Depression.

title: Also Waiting in the Wings
description: Theres busy, and then theres Theresa Rebeck busy. Besides being writer and executive producer of Smash, an NBC series about the making of a Broadway musical, Ms. Rebeck has three plays having premieres this season: Poor Behavior, a comedy about adultery now in previews at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles; Seminar, starring Alan Rickman and Lily Rabe, to open on Broadway in November; and Dead Accounts, which begins in January at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park. (Another play, What Were Up Against, had its premiere in February and will be at Alley Theater in Houston in the spring.)

title: Boehner Argues G.O.P. Case in Jobs Speech
description: 1:07 p.m. | Updated  Speaker John A. Boehner on Thursday called President Obamas jobs plan a poor substitute for pro-growth policies and accused him of offering initiatives that seem to have more to do with the next election than the next generation.

title: Z Is the First Letter of the Alphabet
description: What goes on behind the walls of your childrens school is usually something of a mystery. You drop them off in the morning, they disappear inside, and perhaps at night you glean a few details from them about their day. But imagine receiving a trove of videos, hundreds of hours worth, that documented your childrens other life at school. And not just any school, but one in a foreign country, where they seemed miserable at first, then managed to cope and finally began to thrive.

Investigators say they believe the man, Damark King, opened fire after approaching the girls father and another man in the courtyard of an apartment complex.

title: Familiar Faces Wear Classic Roles
description: SHAKESPEARES saddest monarch will be out on the heath again this fall, yelling at the elements and courting death by lightning, when the Public Theater opens its new production of King Lear, starring Sam Waterston, in November. New Yorkers may feel that this demented curser of the gods has been hanging out a lot in their neighborhood recently. You could even say hes become sort of a cautionary fixture in this town, like that homeless guy on the corner who talks to space aliens and throws rotten fruit at passers-by.

title: Sticking to His Web: Carney Extends Run as Spider-Man

title: Playwrights Bring Uncommon Bond to Broadway
description: TO the casual theater observer, and sometimes even to the obsessed aficionado, one Broadway season can look very much like the next. Names of stars more familiarly splashed on movie trailers are glowing from marquees around the district. The London-to-Broadway express delivers its usual cargo of prestige attractions. New musicals based on popular movies cause devotees to lament the days when Broadway was not a recycling plant but a hotbed of cultural creativity.

title: Giles Deacon Out at Ungaro
description: Well, there goes another one. The troubling times at Emanuel Ungaro seem to be continuing, as the company announced Thursday that Giles Deacon, the designer who had the great fortune of following in the footsteps of Lindsay Lohan and Estrella Archs at the house, was out after his second season. According to a release from Jeffry M. Aronsson, the companys chief executive, Ungaro and Mr. Deacon mutually decided to end their collaboration.

title: My Three Favorite Journeyman-Athlete Memoirs
description: The barrier for entry into the jock memoir genre is, unsurprisingly, pretty low. For every Open  Andre Agassis much-acclaimed, lovely autobiography  there are a dozen or so books like Outrageous!, the decidedly less literary reminiscences of Charles Barkley, in which the author famously claimed he was misquoted. Sure, ghostwriters have something to do with this, but at least Outrageous! was about Charles Barkley  a controversial N.B.A. Hall of Famer who played with and against some of the leagues all-time greats. What has always confounded me is the sheer number of ordinary, even journeyman athletes who cash in by documenting their rise to midlevel greatness between hard covers. But since so many of them do it, here are my favorites. (Intentionally missing is Jim Boutons totally awesome, gossip-laden Ball Four. Though Bouton was the definition of a mediocre player, he remains the Homer of the genre he created. Simply put, its not fair to compare him to anyone.)

title: In Praise (Mostly) of Bike Trails
description: BARABOO, Wisc.  Cyclists revere bike trails; we dont get too many signs from the world that we have a place in it, and bike trails, those routes on which you can get from one place to another on two wheels without the interference of motorized traffic, well, they tell us we belong on the great transportation grid that caters to the natural restlessness of humankind.

title: Ralph Lauren: Everything in Its Place
description: Walking into Ralph Laurens runway shows in the Skylight Soho studios, where he has held them for the last several years, is like entering the set of a theater, where every detail is precisely placed. Actually, the industry veterans Stan Herman and Ellin Saltzman, on their way out of the show, were saying it was just like seeing a movie.

title: Photos of the Moment | Philosophy di Alberta Ferretti
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#578", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Should You Automatically Reinvest Dividends?
description: As a long-term investor, I tend to automatically reinvest any dividends that my investments throw off: it allows you to put that money to work as soon as you can, without having to think about it. And as an added bonus, since youre reinvesting those small drips of money over time, it would seem to help improve the odds that youre not buying too heavily at market peaks.

title: Seeing Things | Getting Hubbied
description: Her last name means partner or husband, and her parents have married and divorced each other more than once. So its no surprise that the Los Angeles artist Bettina Hubby is fascinated with the institution of matrimony. Marriage is a big topic for me, she said. I was married and so were my parents, several times, and I wondered why marriage hasnt changed or evolved the way other things have changed. In 2009 she initiated Get Hubbied, a multitiered art project to investigate the idea of marriage, which she describes as both fragile and resilient. Hubby and the artist and musician Tif Sigfrids, who have been working together for the last four years, conducted intensive research into all aspects of marriage and the rituals surrounding the wedding ceremony.

title: New Hampshire Governor Will Not Seek Re-Election
description: 6:15 p.m. | Updated  Gov. John Lynch of New Hampshire, a Democrat, announced Thursday that he would not run for re-election, leaving the state with an open 2012 race expected to involve primaries on both sides.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 26 Funeral Mourners in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A funeral for a carpenter killed in a road accident near here turned into a massacre on Thursday when a suicide bomber struck the gathering of mourners, killing 26 of them and wounding at least 50, the police said. A hospital official said he expected the death toll to rise.

title: Stage to Screen, Branford Lawyers Story Told
description: A New York Times article by Jacqueline Weaver. The story was published on November 8, 1992.

title: A Surplus of A Few Good Men
description: In the movies, there have been quite a few handsome and noble defense lawyers. And one of the best known may be the military lawyer played by Tom Cruise in A Few Good Men, the 1992 courtroom drama about a hazing gone awry at the Guantnamo naval base in Cuba.

title: Feathers Trapped in Amber Reveal a More Colorful Dinosaur Age
description: Color is coming to the formerly black-and-white Mesozoic world of dinosaurs and early birds.

title: Emmys Watch: Johnny Galecki of The Big Bang Theory
description: ArtsBeat has been talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards show on Sunday. We discussed comedy with Martha Plimpton from Raising Hope; drama and fantasy with Michelle Forbes from The Killing; the excitement of live TV with Beth McCarthy-Miller, a director of 30 Rock; and we asked Peter Berg about the long-delayed recognition for Friday Night Lights. You can read those and other interviews here.

title: Busy Busy Busy
description: Stuff + travel. If I manage to post at all before Sunday, it will be in the cracks.

title: Amodei and Turner Join the House
description: The Republican majority in the House just grew.

title: Stephen Hanson to Open Kibo in Japonais Space
description: Stephen P. Hanson and BR Guest Hospitality have taken over what had been Japonais, and plan to open Kibo, a Japanese restaurant with a robata grill in the space in early October. Though the company serves sushi and teriyaki dishes at its Ruby Foos near Times Square, this is the first time it will open a strictly Japanese place.

title: Design Unveiled for New Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive
description: The University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive on Wednesday presented the schematic design for the transformation of a former printing plant into its new home, designed by the New York firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro.

title: Famine Ravages Somalia in a World Less Likely to Intervene
description: DOLO, Somalia  Is the world about to watch 750,000 Somalis starve to death? The United Nations warnings could not be clearer. A drought-induced famine is steadily creeping across Somalia and tens of thousands of people have already died. The Islamist militant group the Shabab is blocking most aid agencies from accessing the areas it controls, and in the next few months three-quarters of a million people could run out of food, United Nations officials say.

title: In Mexico, Social Media Become a Battleground in the Drug War
description: The bodies of a man and a woman were found hanging from a pedestrian overpass in the Mexican border city of Nuevo Laredo this week with notes threatening similar action against other Internet snitches.

title: A New Executive Producer for ABCs World News
description: Jon Banner, who managed ABCs nightly newscast World News through nearly a decade of turbulence and through four periods of anchors, is moving off the program and into a special projects position at the news division.

title: Boehners Jobs Speech
description: The following is a prepared text of Representative John A. Boehners speech about jobs to the Economic Club of Washington on Thursday, as provided by the House Speakers office:

title: Artsbeat: September 15, 2011
description: September 15, 2011 -- The Times reporter Dave Itzkoff previews this Sunday's Emmy Awards; and the iconic images of the photographer Charles Peterson, who documented the rise of grunge.

title: Cat Found 5 Years, 1,800 Miles and One Microchip Later
description: Any pet owner still debating the merits of the microchip will be swayed by the story of Willow the calico cat.

title: In Boeing Case, House Passes Bill Restricting Labor Board
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted on Thursday to approve a Republican-backed bill that would prohibit the National Labor Relations Board from trying to block Boeing from operating a new $750 million aircraft assembly line in South Carolina. The largely party-line vote was 238 to 186.

title: Call Him Congressman: Turner Is Sworn In
description: WASHINGTON  During his campaign for office, Bob Turner preferred to describe himself as a citizen candidate and businessman. Now he can call himself something else: a congressman.

title: New York Fashion Week | Tom Bull
description: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week. In this clip, Bull receives a runway-walking tutorial ahead of the Perry Ellis show, which he both opened and closed.

title: NASA Detects Planet Dancing With a Pair of Stars
description: From double sunrise to double sunset the show goes on, always changing.

title: A Planet With Two Suns
description: A video illustration of the first directly detected circumbinary planet.

title: Court Allows Richard Prince to Appeal Copyright Decision
description: In a closely watched visual-arts copyright case, a federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday to permit an appeal by the artist Richard Prince, who was found in March by a lower court to have unlawfully used images by a French photographer to create a series of collages and paintings.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, Pakistan and Russia.

title: A UBS Trader, From Typical to Rogue
description: Kweku Adoboli, identified as the rogue UBS trader who racked up $2 billion in losses, followed a traditional path in finance.

title: Another View: Why C.E.O.s Need to Engage Washington
description: Nels Olson is vice chairman and co-leader of the Board and C.E.O. Services Practice at Korn/Ferry International.

title: Cathy Horyn's Spring 2012 Report
description: Cathy Horyn discusses themes that have emerged during New York Fashion Week so far.

title: A Lost Homestand for Wright
description: 6:47 p.m. | Updated

title: Senators Hold Pep Rally for Deficit Panel
description: A bipartisan group of senators gathered on Capitol Hill on Thursday to voice their support for the panel tasked with proposing $1.5 trillion in deficit reductions. Though the senators, who cheekily dubbed themselves the Group of 36, were weak on specifics, Democrats and Republicans alike emphasized their willingness to back the Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction.

title: Watchlist: Alloy, Media Purveyor to Teenage Girls, Tries a Web Series
description: The continuing efforts of Alloy Entertainment to capture the attention of teenage girls, examined recently in Arts & Leisure, do not end with book series (Sweet Valley High), television shows (The Vampire Diaries, Pretty Little Liars) and movies (Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants). Its tentacles extend online, where a new Web series, Wendy, went up Thursday, an effort to distill the brands dreamy-schemey, supernaturally tinged formula into five-minute episodes. (The series is scheduled for six episodes; No. 2 goes up Tuesday.)

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Phillip Lim
description: On whats supposed to be the last day of summer weather, a cool breeze was appropriately the inspiration for Odile Gilberts hair backstage at Phillip Lim. After coating strands with Krastase Fibre Architecte, a yet to be released product thats both a texturizer and a treatment conditioner, she parted straightened hair on the side and separated it into two low ponytails. These were then knotted at the neck and four little strands were pinned to the head as if blown back by a gust of wind. Perhaps in an allusion to the raincoats in the collection, nails were painted a custom blend of CND Raspberry Parfait, Guava and Speedy top coat. Francelle Daly for Nars created what she described as dewy, fresh, skin with Radiant Tinted Moisturizer intended to contrast a edgy, heavy metallic eye. Night Life shadow was applied in the crease to make a demi lune; underneath it, a hollow of bare skin. The silver Paris Duo was used along the eyebrow and Rue Bonaparte neutral liner in the duct. Not one but six coats of mascara were applied to lashes. Romantic and rebel, is how Daly explained this juxtaposition. Lips were covered in concealer and topped with Gaiete blush to create color in a fresh way. You know, these things change with the wind.

title: Deportation Program Sows Mistrust, U.S. Is Told
description: A task force advising an Obama administration deportation program has sharply criticized immigration officials for creating confusion about its purposes and has found that the program had an unintended negative impact on public safety in local communities.

title: In Honduras, Land Struggles Highlight Post-Coup Polarization
description: TOCOA, Honduras  The settlement on the giant Maraones plantation looks like a refugee camp, where children play between rows of huts and chickens peck at garbage heaps. But the farmworkers living here plan to stay, laying claim to land owned by one of the countrys richest men.

title: Percentage of New Yorkers Lighting Up Is Down, to 14%
description: The number of New Yorkers who smoke has declined 35 percent since 2002, bringing the adult smoking rate to what city officials said was an all-time low of 14 percent, the lowest level since they started tracking the habit, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Thursday.

title: Video of Medal of Honor Presentation
description: President Obama is awarding Marine Cpl. Dakota Meyer the U.S. Medal of Honor for his valor during a 2009 battle in Afghanistans Kunar Province. Corporal Meyer, 23, is credited with saving the lives of 36 Marines and soldiers  13 Americans and 23 Afghans, when he charged repeatedly into a Taliban-held area after learning that four American military personnel  three fellow Marines and a Navy corpsman  were missing. Corporal Meyer came under heavy fire, but located and retrieved his fallen comrades from the battlefield with the help of a Afghan troops. He is only the third living veteran to receive the award for service in Afghanistan or Iraq and the first living Marine to receive the award since 1973.

title: Enzyme Drug Is in Short Supply
description: Genzymes flagship drug, Cerezyme, is in short supply again.

title: Nick Broomfields Alaska
description: TORONTO The documentary style of the English director Nick Broomfield often puts him at the center of the action, making films that focus on the process of creating a documentary as well as the films subjects. In his new film, Sarah Palin: You Betcha!, he sets his sights on Ms. Palin, the former governor of Alaska, and travels to her hometown of Wasilla to interview her friends and family. Mr. Broomfield spoke about why he chose Ms. Palin as a subject and elaborates on his technique.

title: Where the Big Girls Are | Proenza Schouler
description: The photographer JD Ferguson gets close up on the biggest faces in fashion.

title: Poetry Pairing | The Beautiful and the Bad
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing couples Dana Gioias Pity the Beautiful with an article about Amy Winehouse, A Bad Girl With a Touch of Genius.

title: New York Fashion Week | Tom Bull
description: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 7
description: Scenes from Wednesday: US Weekly, Barneys Dinner and V Magazine.

title: The Enthusiast: Hashtag Games
description: This weeks Enthusiast comes from Rob Sheridan, a television writer based in Los Angeles.

title: Fairfield County Concours dlgance Salutes Hemis, Motorcycles and a Hometown Hero
description: The end of summer is marked by public pool closings, neighbors firing up the leaf blower and the kids whining about the burdens of furthering their educations. But for car collectors, at least those in temperate climate zones, it is a chance to plan the seasons last long drives and visit the final car shows of the season, among them the Fairfield County Concours dlgance, which takes place this weekend.

title: NBC on Top After Networks Slug It Out
description: In a night of fierce competition among the broadcast networks on Wednesday, NBC claimed victory in total viewers and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. The finale of Americas Got Talent scored 15.5 million viewers in its final hour, an impressive number, but down from 18.2 million for last seasons finale.

title: Hotel Agrees to Make Changes to Aid the Disabled
description: The swank Gramercy Park Hotel prides itself on its freewheeling, creative design. Madly eclectic and entirely unpredictable, the hotels Web site boasts about its rooms, no two of which are laid out alike.

title: Does the New Normal Include Private Unemployment Insurance?
description: With unemployment hovering around 9 percent, many Americans are relying on government unemployment benefits to make ends meet. Now, a new, private option is available that can help replace, at least temporarily, more of the income forfeited when you lose your job.

title: Rocking It Out: Exploring Music Teaching Methods
description: Overview | What is the purpose of music education? Does teaching rock-and-roll threaten or help preserve the future of classical music and jazz? In this lesson, students learn about a controversial hands on approach to musical instruction, investigate its benefits and drawbacks and find parallels in areas like language acquisition.

title: Patient Voices: Sjogrens Syndrome
description: Severe dry eyes, joint pain and chronic fatigue: five men and women speak about living with Sjogrens syndrome.

title: Photos of the Moment | Oscar de la Renta
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#996", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);
