description: The bill for a drink at Nitehawk Cinema in Williamsburg, Brooklyn? The State Legislature took care of it.

title: In Diamonds Flaws, Finding Clues to Earths Carbon Cycle
description: Diamonds that once lay more than 435 miles beneath the earths surface have provided researchers with an unexpected window into the planets history.

title: 36 Seconds in Quito, Ecuador
description: A snapshot of Quito's rich mix of architectural heritage and cultural traditions.

title: Senate Democrats Want More Details on Obamas Jobs Bill
description: The White House brought its jobs proposal before Senate Democrats on Thursday, meeting hesitant support as many senators said they backed job creation measures but wanted more specifics about this bill.

title: 36 Hours in Quito, Ecuador
description: Nestled amid snowcapped Andean peaks, Ecuadors capital has long been overlooked.

title: La MaMa Cantata to Celebrate Ellen Stewart
description: The composer and writer Elizabeth Swados has created a new musical work, The La MaMa Cantata, comprising decades of quotations by Ellen Stewart, the founder of La MaMa Experimental Theater Club, and is set to direct the piece at the downtown theater on Nov. 7 and 8, a La MaMa spokesman said on Thursday.

title: 36 Hours in Quito, Ecuador
description: NESTLED amid snowcapped Andean peaks, Ecuadors capital has long been overlooked by travelers on their way to the countrys most famous destination, the Galpagos Islands. But visitors who bypass this lively historic city of some two million people are missing out. At 9,350 feet above sea level, on the eastern slopes of the Pichincha Volcano, Quito offers breathtaking vistas around nearly every corner. Its historic center, a Unesco World Heritage site, is one of the largest in South America, with 40 colonial churches and chapels, 16 convents and monasteries and picturesque plazas. In recent years, museums have been opened; mansions restored; hotels, restaurants and cafes opened and safety improved. And this year, in recognition of Quitos rich mix of architectural heritage and cultural traditions, the International Cultural Capitals Bureau chose the city as its 2011 American Capital of Culture.

title: Clorox Puts Focus on Bleachable Moments
description: Decades ago, there were habits and customs that boys and girls would take up as they became young men and women. The young men would wear hats and drink bourbon. The young women would wear hats and learn about doing laundry.

title: Lacking 2012 E.P.A. Certification, Mahindra & Mahindra Trucks Are Longshots for U.S. Sales
description: For Americans waiting to purchase a Mahindra & Mahindra diesel pickup truck, the wait just got longer.

title: C.I.A. Kills Top Qaeda Operative in Drone Strike
description: WASHINGTON  An armed drone operated by the Central Intelligence Agency this week killed a top Qaeda operative responsible for plotting terrorist attacks inside Pakistan, two American officials said on Thursday.

title: Steel Tycoon With Links to a Mubarak Is Sentenced
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian criminal court sentenced the steel tycoon and former political power broker Ahmed Ezz to 10 years in prison and fined him the equivalent of about $11 million for corruption on Thursday, satisfying one of the most visceral demands of the revolution that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Will Obama QuickPay Policy Mean Billions to Small Businesses?
description: On Wednesday, the White House made good on President Obamas pledge, in his jobs speech to Congress last week, to speed up government payments to small-business contractors. The new policy, which has its own product-like branding, QuickPay, reduces the governments payment time from 30 days after receiving an invoice to 15 days. In a statement, Karen Mills, Small Business Administration administrator, lauded the new policy: QuickPay is a smart and powerful boost that effectively delivers billions more dollars into the hands of small contractors so that they can do what they do best  create jobs.

title: Battle Over Israel's Separation Barrier
description: Israel has been building a barrier around and through the West Bank since 2002. Israel's government says it protects against terrorism. Palestinians argue it is an attempt to seize territory.

title: Update Urged on Childrens Online Privacy
description: Aiming to catch up with fast-churning technology that touches childrens lives every day, the Federal Trade Commission on Thursday proposed long-awaited changes to regulations covering online privacy for children.

title: West 40th Street, 3:52 P.M.
Brooklyn Becomes Book Country Again
description: IN 2006, when the Brooklyn Book Festival was in its first year, a panel discussion focused on how Brooklyn had shaped the writing of Jonathan Lethem, Paula Fox and Emily Barton. Pete Hamill and Jennifer Egan, both of Brooklyn, talked about their literary inspirations. Dramatic readings from the work of legendary Brooklyn writers were staged in a plaza outside Borough Hall. This year, the festivals sixth, it remains centered in the same pocket of downtown Brooklyn. But its borders have spread far beyond.

title: Hills Alive With Sound of Huckleberries
description: Seventeen years ago, on a baseball field outside Vienna, Phil Rizzuto tried to wedge a batting helmet onto his head. What you really need is a square one, Ralph Branca cracked from his seat in the dugout, a former Brooklyn Dodgers pitcher incongruously wearing a Yankees uniform.

title: TimesCast | September 15, 2011
description: French and British leaders visit Libya; central banks including the Fed act to ease European fears; and sectarian unrest simmers under a police clampdown in Bahrain.

title: Tailgating Recipes: On Wisconsin
Photo Replay: Sept. 15
description: The day in sports included quarterfinal games in the European basketball championships and a win by the United States at the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand.

title: Northern Lights on the Midnight Watch
description: Bernard Coakley, a marine geologist with the University of Alaska at Fairbanks, writes from the Arctic Ocean, where his team is reconstructing the geologic history of the Chukchi Shelf and the Chukchi Borderland.

title: Rating the No. 1s: Batwoman, Demon Knights and More
description: Two Times staffers and comic-book fans, George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler, will review all 52 DC Comics titles that have been rebooted as part of a companywide effort to revive the brand. In the third of five weekly installments they discuss Batwoman, Green Lantern, Red Lanterns and others that were published on Wednesday. Next week theyll look at Wonder Woman, Batman and more.

title: Steuben Glass Factory and Store to Close
description: For decades, they have solved the riddle of what to give those who seem to have everything. Pieces of Steuben glass, those quintessential samples of American artisanship, have proved suitable for queens and presidents, brides and retiring executives.

title: Devin Troy Strother: The Me and You, Your Mother and Maybe Even Your Cousin Too & The Hey Sister, Soul Sister Go Sister, Woah Sister.
description: Monya Rowe Gallery

title: T Exclusive Video | Paris Kain
description: From Paris Kain comes an exclusive preview of the upcoming collection for his Abraxas Rex jewelry line. The film was inspired by Carl Jungs work (specifically Anima and Animus) and the ancient Greek phrase Gnothi Seauton, which translates to the clips title, Know Thyself.

title: Know Thyself
description: An exclusive preview of Paris Kains spring jewelry collection for his Abraxax Rex line.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Tropical 128
description: Part billiards hall, part tiki bar, a Lower East Side hangout offers a relaxed atmosphere and a four-foot-tall glass of beer.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, Pakistan and Italy.

title: Metro-Norths Port Jervis Line Slowly Returns
description: Metro-North Railroad is restoring parts of the Port Jervis train line faster than expected after 14 miles of tracks were uprooted and wiped out by Tropical Storm Irene.

title: An Escape to the Tropics in the City
description: THE Lower East Side has more than its share of cross-cultural mash-ups, but few surpass Tropical 128, a combination pool hall and tiki bar. A first visit can be a little disorienting, with or without one of its potent cocktails, as Chinese lanterns compete for attention with the clack of billiard balls. Watch your step or you might fall into the koi pond.

title: Frederick Hammersley: Organic and Geometric
description: Ameringer McEnery Yohe

title: Driving Home
description: In the spring of 1990 I packed up as much of my life in London as would t into a suitcase and four large plywood boxes and ew to Seattle to set up house. It was a selsh and irregular move. I had met someone and liked what Id seen of the Pacic Northwest during a two-month stay there the previous autumn. I liked the aquarium lighting, the sawtooth alps forested with black rs, the compact cities encrusted in dirty Roman esque stucco. Most of all, I liked the places wateriness. At forty-seven I felt cracked and dry. My new home territory was as rainy as Ireland, puddled with lakes and veined with big rivers. Seattle was built out on pilings over the sea, and at high tide the whole city seemed to come aoat like a ship lifting free from a mud berth and swaying in its chains.

title: Some for the Road: The Odds and Ends From a Travelers Tales
description: Given its title, some readers will pick up Jonathan Rabans new book, Driving Home: An American Journey, and assume that its among his excellent travel volumes, like Bad Land and Passage to Juneau. They may be distressed to find instead that its a collection of B sides, odds and ends, acoustic versions and rarities: book reviews, leftish political essays, introductions to reissued classics and meditations on seafaring and on Seattle, where this British writer has lived since 1990. Its prose mostly cooked to order.

title: Thinking Pink at Milly
description: While some designers went for soft beauty looks this season  including BCBG, Diane Von Furstenberg and Reed Krakoff  Michelle Smith, the designer for Milly, chose color. In an interview backstage, she described her collection as young and fresh (as well as other marketable keywords). Romy Soleimani of the MAC Pro Team created a bright pink lipstick to accompany the geometric prints in the collection. She mixed MACs white and fuchsia lip color. From a distance, the pink looks very similar to the popular matte summer pink that a lot of women, especially young women, have been wearing the last few seasons. But close up, the pink has more of an opaque base and looks like a mix of Pepto-Bismol and neon pinks.

title: Photos of the Moment | Proenza Schouler
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#538", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Kava Gornas New York fashion week photo diary.

title: Timmy Chandler: Twitter Me This
description: The Twitter universe was alive on Thursday with words, news, whispers  no, a tweet that the German-American defender Timmy Chandler could be about to slip through the fingers of Jurgen Klinsmann and the U.S. national team.

title: Jordan Kantor
description: Churner & Churner

title: Day 8: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 15.

title: Vik Muniz: Pictures of Magazines 2
description: Sikkema Jenkins & Company

title: Huston Ripley: Drawings
description: Adam Baumgold

title: Cheery Christmas Cards? Bah, Humbug!
description: Scrooge and the Grinch would come across as hopelessly mushy about holiday traditions compared with the debunking exhibition catalog for American Christmas Cards, 1900-1960, which opens on Wednesday at the Bard Graduate Center: Decorative Arts, Design History, Material Culture in Manhattan.

title: Backstage Beauty at Milly Spring 2012
description: Hot pink lips and orange nails hit the spring 2012 Milly runway.

title: Calvin Klein: X-Ray Vision
description: The celebrities on the front row at Calvin Klein wore dresses in solid colors that looked covered up. Uma Thurman (in blue), Lara Stone (in red) and Naomi Watts (in gray) were three of a kind.

title: Creamy Curried Celery Root Soup
description: Mark Bittman uses an unusual root vegetable in a delicious creamy soup.

title: The Minimalist: Creamy Curried Celery Root Soup
description: Hulking, bristly, bulgy, khaki-colored celery root (also known as celeriac) isnt going to win any beauty contests. When you see one, you instantly understand why the stalks are more popular.

title: City Unemployment Rate Ticks Up to 8.7%
description: The two-week strike by unionized employees of Verizon offset all of the hiring that occurred last month in New York City and pushed the citys unemployment rate up slightly, according to figures released Thursday by the State Department of Labor.

title: Berlin 36
description: Tasteful to a fault, Berlin 36 turns real-life controversy into disappointingly tepid drama.

title: Obama Administration Removes Doctor Disciplinary Files From the Web
description: Three journalism organizations on Thursday protested to the Obama administration a decision to pull a database of physician discipline and malpractice actions off the Web.

title: Prince of Swine
description: Unpleasant in every way imaginable, Mark Tomas Prince of Swine, a repulsive farce about sexual harassment in the double-D-movie industry, opens, hilariously, with a quotation from The Odyssey. But not even Homer can elevate this ugly ode to our basest instincts, a film so drenched in bile and profanity there is little room for anything else.

title: Mosaics of the East From the Met to San Francisco
description: THE big institutional news in New York City this fall is the reopening, after eight years of renovation and rethinking, of the Metropolitan Museums Islamic collection, in what are now being called the Galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia. The wrap-around suite of 15 spaces, which opens on Nov. 1, will hold some 1,200 works (out of a collection of 12,000) from dozens of cultures that have, during 13 centuries, shared Islam as a religious faith.

title: For Spectacles Sake, Museums Get Specific
description: THE offerings from New York museums this fall vary widely, from the much-heralded de Kooning retrospective opening Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art to Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture, a survey of the role of sexual identity in a centurys worth of American art that will arrive at the Brooklyn Museum after its controversial run at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington. But right down the center some of New Yorks major museums promise a fair amount of high-production-value Conceptual-art spectacle.

title: Shut Up Little Man!
description: Matthew Bates Shut Up Little Man! is a dandy little documentary whether you view the story it captures as a precursor to the flash fame of the Internet age or as one of the last genuine underground phenomena before the Internet made that whole concept obsolete.

title: Spare Times for Sept. 16-22
description: Around Town

title: Mockery, Alive and Well Through the Ages
description: It is not nice to make fun of other people, but it is hard to resist. There is even a genre of art devoted to this often uncharitable impulse of human nature: caricature. Fine and popular artists have been producing comical, grotesque and weird images of people at least since the days of Leonardo da Vinci.

title: The Weird World of Blowfly
description: Outside of the recording industry or a convention of pop-music connoisseurs, youre not likely to hear anyone name-check Clarence Reid, a 66-year-old songwriter whose funk-and-R&B-heavy back catalog has been sampled by the likes of Beyonc, Puff Daddy and the Jurassic 5.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Sept. 16-22
description: NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL CHILDRENS FILM FESTIVAL PRESENTS DOLPHIN TALE

title: Janes Journey
description: This breezy biographical profile of Jane Goodall, the primatologist and rock star of conservationism, as one environmentalist introduces her, skimps on intellectual substance but skirts by on the lightly likable charm of its subject, who appears throughout.

title: Home Prices Are Down, but Rentals Are Rising
description: The housing market is gasping for air, and home prices are down to 2003 levels, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Indices.

title: Silent Souls
description: Sex and death are inextricably entwined in Silent Souls, a melancholy poem to love, loss and the tug of tradition.

title: Bedrooms for 2, Dinner for 6 Guests
description: AFTER three years of sharing a two-bedroom rental on West 99th Street, Tamar Fox and her two roommates were fed up with their buildings bad maintenance. They decided to go their separate ways.

title: My Afternoons With Margueritte
description: Drearily sentimental, Jean Beckers My Afternoons With Margueritte is the chaste love story between a genial, unlettered lug of a working man (Grard Depardieu in unflattering blue overalls) and an older woman he meets on a park bench in a town in the Charente-Maritime region of France. She reads to him (Camus, Romain Gary). He blossoms.

title: One Fall
description: One Fall, a star vehicle Marcus Dean Fuller created for himself, starts out with an intriguing premise but grows muddier as it grows more mystical.

title: Roughed Up by Horses
description: WEST 83rd Street between Columbus and Amsterdam is a Sesame Street kind of block, with stoops, horses heads, brownstones, apartment houses by McKim, Mead & White, rent-a-car places, and Jerry Seinfelds garage. Everybody seems to be in a hurry here, and that means it is just the place for a leisurely late-summer saunter.

title: New Evidence for an Apple a Day
description: The old adage promoting an apple a day for better health just got a boost from science. A large Dutch study has found that eating apples and pears is associated with a lower risk of stroke.

title: A Stormy Housewarming
description: JENNIFER TAUBER and her husband, Hayes, closed on their new home in New Canaan on Aug. 24  just in time for Tropical Storm Irene.

title: New Rentals Planned for Elmwood Park
description: ELMWOOD PARK

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Yigal Azroul
description: While I was inspired by architecture and the idea of uniforms, I designed these clothes to feel more relaxed, almost effortless, Yigal Azroul said of his collection backstage. Think sophistication in structure. This translated into a look the hairstylist Anthony Campbell called a reverse mohawk. After dampening hair with Cutler Specialist Protectant Treatment Spray, Campbell gathered a healthy horseshoe section from the top and pulled it forward, using a flat brush and dryer. The sides were then pressed down with fingers. Campbell finished styles by showering hair with Redken Shine Flash 02 Glistening Mist and Cutler Shine Tattoo for an extreme, wet-looking finish. The makeup artist Yadim kept things aglow by moisturizing with Sisleum Global Revitalizer for Men, then tapping Sisley Radiant Immediate Lift on the high planes of the face to highlight. Phyto-Ombre Eclat Eye Shadow in Quartz was smudged on upper and lower lash lines to enhance tone, like the boys have been out all night. Yadim said. And just minutes before the show, Yadim slicked Confort Creme Lip Balm on lips and eyelids to complete a face that looks as its been flooded in light.

title: The cultural impact and staying power of Nirvanas Nevermind 20 years after its release; and new records by Daniela Mercury and Gilad Hekselman.
description: This week: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff assess the cultural impact and staying power of Nirvanas Nevermind 20 years after its release; and we take a listen to new records by Daniela Mercury and Gilad Hekselman. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: Storm Left Some Buyers in the Dark
description: JENNY GRAHAM BRUGO stayed up all night when Tropical Storm Irene swooshed across Long Island a few weeks ago, hoping the two giant pine trees in front of the four-bedroom Cape she was about to buy for $380,000 in Locust Valley would not fall.

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 16-22
description: Movies

title: Thomas Z. Scarangello
description: Mr. Scarangello, 54, is the chairman and chief executive of Thornton Tomasetti, a structural engineering and forensic investigation firm.

title: Saving on Mortgage Taxes
description: HOMEOWNERS looking to refinance their mortgage will need to compare interest rates, loan termsand fees, but some who live in New York may also want to arrange for whats known as a mortgage assignment, when the balance on the loan is transferred to the new lender from the old.

title: Back Door Channels: The Price of Peace
description: Having just commemorated the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks, another, more hopeful, September anniversary on Saturday is likely to draw no comment. On Sept. 17, 1978, after 13 days of negotiations at Camp David, President Jimmy Carter brought President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel to the White House to sign an accord to end the state of war between their two countries.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Sept. 16-22
description: Pop

title: Sound It Out
description: The Web site for Sound It Out, Jeanie Finlays documentary about the last independent record store in the Teesside region in northeast England, calls it High Fidelity with a northern accent, and theres no getting past the similarities with the Nick Hornby novel (and the movie starring John Cusack). Customers of the store, Sound It Out, would all feel quite at home at Championship Vinyl.

title: Q & A
description: Liability Insurance for Condo Renters

title: Everything Makes Them Sick
description: The photographer Thilde Jenson captures people who suffer from Multiple Chemical Sensitivity.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 16-22
description: Jazz

title: In a Pop Twist, Sting Joins a Trio, and the Evening Closes on a Note of Paul Simon
description: I have some experience in my life with musical trios, Sting said on Wednesday evening at the 92nd Street Y, and the audience laughed. He was referring, of course, to the Police, the rock band he led to stardom in the 1970s and 80s.

title: The Buddy System, or the Buyers Broker
description: IN this do-it-yourself era of online real estate listings, it is easy to find out what is on the market, visit open houses and even research sales data to come up with a reasonable price to offer for a home.

title: Aaron & Mi Jung
description: Mi Jung introduced herself to Aaron on a rooftop in Brooklyn six years ago. Now theyre getting married on the anniversary of their first meeting.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 16-22
description: Dance

title: Two special congressional elections that may or may not be bellwethers.
description: Two special congressional elections that may or may not be bellwethers. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, White House correspondent Mark Landler and Deputey Political Editor Gerald Mullany join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Sept. 16-22
description: Art

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Sept. 16-22
description: Classical

title: App Smart Extra: More Kids Apps
description: Last weeks App Smart column offers a few strategies for overcoming a week without power in a house full of children.

title: The Daily Shoe | Proenza Schouler
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.The shoes at Proenza Schouler were like an ode to midcentury furniture design  a glossy, painted-stripe platform with clean, curvy lines and a rubbery stopper for a heel. Alternate versions of the theme came in colors (red and turquoise) and with platforms carved to look like oak, then lacquered black most modernly.

title: Trendspotting: Hemlines
description: Longer hemlines are making a comeback at spring 2012 show.

title: A Stable Hemline
description: After vacillating for several seasons, an influential band of Seventh Avenue taste makers settled on a length for day that was fresh, youthful and, at times, even disarmingly sexy. Forsaking the fashion schizophrenia that led in past seasons to thigh-high skirts that alternated randomly with versions that plunged to the floor, designers like Derek Lam, Ralph Lauren and Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein put their money on hemlines ending just below the knees. Loosely cut and flattering, they showed off the models calves and offered flirty glimpses of the area just behind their knees.

title: Mets Conclude a Humiliating Homestand
description: As the Mets played out the last innings of an abysmal homestand on Thursday, the stands were virtually empty, the players seemed to be going through the motions and Manager Terry Collins was just getting started.

title: A Short Life and Its Consequences
description: Leah Hager Cohen is one of our foremost chroniclers of the mundane complexities, nuanced tragedies and unexpected tendernesses of human connection. She earned her reputation with heralded books of nonfiction like Train Go Sorry and the novel House Lights. Impressively, her fourth novel, The Grief of Others, is her best work yet. Six complex but fundamentally decent characters hurt one another and are hurt by forces greater than themselves, whether those forces be the impersonal cruelty of natures accidents or the very personal torments of marriage and middle school. The overarching question is whether the members of the Ryrie family will piece themselves together and re-find who they all were during a halcyon vacation eight years past, or whether they will let sorrow, secrets and shame drive them irreparably apart.

title: Real World Quileutes Lobby for Their Land
description: Twilight fans, take heart. Jacob Blacks cousins finally got their day before Congress on Thursday.

title: The TV Watch: An A for Effort on Emmy Night
description: Emmy Awards dont factor in the degree of difficulty, but they should. Its at least one way to choose between equally good performances.

title: Seeking Reality on Climate
description: 7:02 p.m. | Updated Former Vice President Al Gore and organizers of the Climate Reality Project should be commended for building a worldwide forum on human-driven climate change over the past 24 hours. Ive had a chance to dip in a few times and there were some useful discussions amid more predictable efforts to cast the climate challenge as an us-versus-them problem (to my mind its much more an us-versus-us problem). The organizers reported more than 6 million views as of late afternoon.

title: Papas Damn Good Pictures
description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY the hunter, Hemingway the fisherman, Hemingway the drinker  theyre all part of the legend. Among the motifs in The Select, the Elevator Repair Service staging of The Sun Also Rises, currently at the New York Theater Workshop, is an inside joke about how much imbibing takes place in that book.

title: N.Y.U. Relents a Bit on Acquiring Parkland Near Planned Housing
description: New York University, trying to placate critics of it plans to build more dormitories and offices in Greenwich Village, announced on Thursday that it would not seek to purchase two park-like strips of land bordering two giant housing complexes.

title: Fasten Your Seat Belts, the Chevy Is Taking Off
description: A long time ago, as a young filmmaker besotted with the hard-boiled pleasures of classic Hollywood, Jean-Luc Godard claimed that all anyone needed to make a film was a girl and a gun. In his new movie, Drive, Nicolas Winding Refn, in thrall to a later Hollywood tradition, tests out a slightly different formula. In this case all you need is a guy and a car.

title: A Painting That Begat a Whole Show
description: Kehinde Wiley, 34, is an artist preoccupied with global culture. He is also a history painter whose multicultural images of primarily good-looking men recall the work of old masters like Rubens and Jacques-Louis David. The lush and intricately painted backgrounds make them more interesting still.

title: Apple Brings Back Final Cut 7
description: When Apple replaced its movie-editing software Final Cut 7 with Final Cut Pro X, the pros were outraged.

title: Photos of the Moment | LWren Scott
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#938", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Skye Parrotts New York fashion week photo diary.

title: His Credit Cards and Fancy Words Cant Help Him Here
description: Straw Dogs  Rod Luries odd and interesting remake of Sam Peckinpahs venerable and violent button pusher  begins with a clash of cultural stereotypes. David Sumner (James Marsden) is a Hollywood screenwriter with an Ivy League education (or at least a Harvard T-shirt and fond memories of the Harvard-Yale game), newly arrived in his wifes hometown, Blackwater, Miss. He is an effete coastal liberal, the kind of person who orders light beer at the local bar and grill, disdains its celebrated fried pickles and tries to pay with a credit card. He listens to classical music, uses big words like acutely and stays in shape by jumping rope. He cant fix a roof or change a tire.

title: Top Medal for Marine Who Saved Many Lives
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama awarded the Medal of Honor on Thursday to a young former Marine who ignored orders to stay put and fought his way five times into an ambush in an Afghan ravine, helping to rescue three dozen Afghan and American troops and to recover the remains of four dead American servicemen.

title: This Cheating Couple Have a Lot in Common
description: Tom Tykwers 3, a forbiddingly sober and sophisticated comedy of adultery and sexual experimentation, is unburdened by the usual emotional markers found in films whose characters push conventional boundaries. Hanna (Sophie Rois) and Simon (Sebastian Schipper), who have lived together for 20 years and who separately embark on an affair with the same man, are childless hard-working Berliners in their 40s.

title: Goldman Sachs to Shut Its Global Alpha Hedge Fund
description: Goldman Sachs is closing Global Alpha, one of its best-known hedge funds, after it rung up big losses this year.

title: A Founders at Home
description: When you look at Alexander Hamiltons home comfortably nestled on the sloping hillside of St. Nicholas Park in an area of northern Manhattan that has long been known as Hamilton Heights, it almost seems to be ... well ... at home.

title: Reputation and Monolith, Both Stand Tall
description: GARDENA, Calif.

title: Showing It All in Toronto
description: TORONTO  Having muscled its way forward with ambition and mountains of money, the Toronto International Film Festival stands supreme as the leading cinema event after Cannes. This years event was the first time that the Bell Lightbox, the festivals permanent home here, was fully operational. For much of the festivals 11 days (it ends on Sunday), the five public theaters of the Lightbox are a home away from home for locals and globe-trotting professionals who also make camp in adjacent theaters, including a 14-screen multiplex with its own Burger King. They do things big here: more than 300 movies on 33 screens for admissions that, last year, topped a quarter-million.

title: The Future, Retrenched
description: WHAT may be the biggest architecture event of the year ahead has not yet been scheduled. But when it happens, itll be a doozy: MGM Resorts International recently announced its intention to demolish the Harmon, a tower by Norman Foster that is a prominent component of the new CityCenter development in Las Vegas. Construction flaws were found years ago, and the building was never completed or occupied. Still, the spectacle of a boom-time project by one of the worlds most celebrated designers razed by a controlled implosion is sure to spark talk about the state of architecture today.

title: Altering Landscapes for Art
description: ON paper it resembles a subplot from David Foster Wallaces deliriously satiric novel Infinite Jest: a billionaire heiress builds a spectacular art museum on family property somewhere in the Deep South and gives it the suspiciously New-Agey name Crystal Bridges. But this is nonfiction. On Nov. 11 Alice Walton, daughter of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton, will unveil the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in the small city of Bentonville, Ark.

title: RIM Suffers as Profit Falls 58.7%
description: OTTAWA  The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion delivered more grim financial news on Thursday that caused some analysts to question the future of RIM, the company that created and once dominated the smartphone market.

title: Theater Listings: Sept. 16  22
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information: nytimes.com/theater.

title: An Escape to the Tropics in the City
description: The Lower East Side has more than its share of cross-cultural mash-ups, but few surpass Tropical 128, a combination pool hall and tiki bar. A first visit can be a little disorienting, with or without one of its potent cocktails, as Chinese lanterns compete for attention with the clack of billiard balls. Watch your step or you might fall into the koi pond.

title: Shes Dying Gracefully, and Its Killing Him
description: The story of a dying girl and the morbid young man who loves her, Restless rolls Elisabeth Kbler-Rosss five stages of dying into a single, dreamy state of feeling. It is hard to say, though, if this film, directed by Gus Van Sant from a script by Jason Lew, is an argument for denial or a treatise on acceptance. Curiously, and in a way that is sometimes touching and sometimes icky, it does not seem to perceive much of a difference.

title: Rick Ludwin to Leave Late Night Post at NBC
description: One of the longest-serving network television executives, Rick Ludwin, is leaving his job as the top overseer of all NBCs late-night programs.

title: The Schumacher Debate Considered
description: Since the Italian Grand Prix in Monza on Sunday, Michael Schumacher has been at the center of a debate about his driving tactics. As I wrote in my final race report, I thought the Schumacher/Lewis Hamilton battle made the race worth watching.

title: The Schumacher Debate Considered
description: Since the Italian Grand Prix in Monza on Sunday, Michael Schumacher has been at the center of a debate about his driving tactics. As I wrote in my final race report, I thought the Schumacher/Lewis Hamilton battle made the race worth watching.

title: Even a Things-to-Do List Seems to Be Multitasking
description: The curse of Carrie Bradshaw infects I Dont Know How She Does It with a severe case of what might be called post-Carrie Parkeritis. Parkeritis, if you havent heard, is the term given to a new ailment named after Sarah Jessica Parker, in which a star finds herself condemned to eke out the last drops of freshness from the role (in this case in Sex and the City) that made her world famous eons ago. In its chemical structure it closely resembles the Roberts Syndrome (as in Julia), first identified in Pretty Woman and last seen in Larry Crowne.

title: Plenty of Chatter About a New iPhone
description: Were just weeks away from the announcement of the new Apple iPhone 5, according to an Apple employee who asked not to be named because he was not allowed to speak publicly for the company.

title: Six-Year Extension for Isles Tavares
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  John Tavares said Thursday that he had signed a six-year contract extension with the Islanders, ending speculation that he would return to his native Toronto in the next couple of seasons.

title: Hemingway the Museumgoer
description: When in New York, Ernest Hemingway was as likely to visit the Metropolitan Museum as Toots Shors.

title: Ruling May Jeopardize Dolphin Safe Label
description: A ruling on Thursday by the World Trade Organization could imperil dolphin safe labeling on tuna in the United States.

title: Where Banks Proliferate, So Do Rules
description: The more banks a country has, the less political power they have.

title: A Veneer to Hide Crumbling Poise
description: The title of Happy, Happy, the debut feature of the Norwegian director Anne Sewitsky, presumably refers to the facade of garrulous cheer thrown up by its obsequious central character, Kaja (Agnes Kittelsen). A schoolteacher who lives in the snowy countryside with her glowering husband, Eirik (Joachim Rafaelsen), and young son, Theodor (Oskar Hernaes Brandso), Kaja is compulsively chipper until the moment her composure crumbles, and she collapses in tears.

title: Requiems Premiere Is Conductors Farewell
description: Kent Tritle devoted the opening of the 23rd season of the Sacred Music in a Sacred Space series at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola to the New York premiere of Juraj Filass grandly scaled requiem Oratio Spei (Prayer of Hope) on Wednesday evening. Technically, the work is not a response to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, but it has a connection that makes it a fitting commemoration.

title: Long-Term Stock Plans Help to Avoid Impulsive Moves
description: JUST as you caught your breath after the stock market mayhem of 2008 and 2009, it has become increasingly clear that this ride isnt over just yet.

title: British Dubstep Singer Crosses the Pond, Leaving the D.J. for a Band
description: I havent played a little venue in a while, Katy B said from the little stage in the little room that is the Studio at Webster Hall on Tuesday night. Ive just been playing muddy fields in England.

title: Who Should Win Emmy Awards
description: Alessandra Stanleys picks.

title: The World Maker Faire in Queens Draws Inventors
description: As a Brooklyn resident in my 30s, I am required, by local social standards, to be able to hold my own with do-it-yourself projects. At the very least, I can brew a little craft beer and cross-stitch heavy-metal lyrics onto throw pillows. But soldering a 70-foot steel dragon onto the frame of a 1963 Dodge dump truck and turning it into an interactive kinetic playground? Ill leave that to the do-or-die DIY-ers gathering in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens this weekend for  the World Maker Faire.

title: Moodys May Downgrade UBS After Trading Loss
description: Moodys Investors Service said late Thursday that it might downgrade UBSs credit rating, after the Swiss bank disclosed that a London-based trader lost about $2 billion in a series of unauthorized trades.

title: Perry Repeats Socialist Charge Against Obama Policies
description: In an interview with Time magazine, Gov. Rick Perry showed that he had no intention of softening the cactus-thorned rhetoric he developed during his decades in Texas politics, notably repeating his characterization of President Obamas policies as socialist.

title: U.S. Hails Deal With Turkey on Missile Shield
description: WASHINGTON  The final legal and diplomatic building blocks fell into place this week for the Obama administrations rejiggered defense of Europe against a potential Iranian missile attack. Romania signed a deal for 24 interceptor missiles to be based there, and Turkey officially agreed to have in its territory a sophisticated American radar system that could be on the watch by the end of the year.

title: For a Day, Its All Good
description: Wednesday was a double-bonus day with outstanding shows from Ralph Rucci and Proenza Schouler. The next morning, Ralph Lauren concocted one of his romances out of straw picnic purses and robins egg blue, ending it with a gown as triumphant as the Chrysler Building.

title: With Stakes for Bachmann Higher Now, Her Words Get in the Way
description: In the pugilism of this weeks Republican presidential debate, Representative Michele Bachmann seemed to have landed a clean blow against Gov. Rick Perry over an order he issued requiring Texas schoolgirls to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus.

title: New York Fashion Week
description: Eric Wilson highlights the season's emerging trends.

title: Teaching as a Second, or Even Third, Career
description: AT 65, Walt Patteson has two careers behind him and is relishing his third as a high school chemistry teacher. He is one of the retirement-age Americans who are finding new uses for their skills by deciding to teach.

title: Walter Bonatti, Daring Italian Mountaineer, Dies at 81
description: Walter Bonatti, one of the worlds greatest mountaineers, who pioneered some of the most difficult and breathtaking climbs on the earths tallest mountains, often alone, died Tuesday in Rome. He was 81.

title: The Moral Values of Americas Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: TimesCast | Cameron & Sarkozy in Tripoli
description: September 15, 2011 - British and French leaders visit Tripoli to meet with the new Libyan leaders.

title: China Consolidates Grip on Rare Earths
description: BEIJING  In the name of fighting pollution, China has sent the price of compact fluorescent light bulbs soaring in the United States.

title: Keeping Themselves Fit for Going to the Rescue
description: THIS weekend, the last of the lifeguards still on duty at two of Long Islands largest public beaches  Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Park  will climb down from the stands and lock up their shacks for the winter.

title: A Two-Step Plan That Strengthens Your Nest Egg
description: BY now, you may have accepted, with grim reluctance, that you must delay taking your retirement benefits.

title: Fine-Tune a 401(k) or I.R.A., and Cut Costs
description: YOU have to dig deep into your retirement accounts to find out how to optimize their performance and bolster your nest egg.

title: In Annuities, Better Rates Come With Complexity
description: IF youre unhappy with the wretchedly low rates that many savings vehicles offer today, imagine how you would feel earning meager income until the day you die. If you recently began collecting on a fixed-rate annuity, you dont need much imagination.

title: The Risks of Investing Like the Big Pension Funds
description: OVER the last several years, the managers of many big, traditional pension plans have become increasingly cautious. Instead of viewing high returns as their top priority, these managers have focused on avoiding risk. Some have shifted assets from stocks to bonds, while others have changed the way they analyze their investments or hired special risk officers. An old investment strategy called liability-driven investing has been revived, in which pension plans buy a series of bonds with maturity dates timed to match the years when cohorts of employees are expected to retire.

title: The Dividend as a Bulwark Against Global Economic Uncertainty
description: DESPITE the gyrations in the stock market this year, one sweet spot has been dividends. These cash payments from mature, profitable companies have been a welcome addition to retirement portfolios.

title: The Company You Keep
description: ONE of the biggest challenges of relocating after retirement is making new acquaintances.

title: Staying Fit to Stay on the Job
description: Older people in need of inspiration to stay fit as they age might consider the example of lifeguards. Facing a tough physical test each spring, they train hard in the off-season  and keep their jobs well past the age of 50.

title: Coming Together to Make Aging a Little Easier
description: LAST summer, Shoya Zichy was about to drop off a prescription at a friends house when she tripped and dislocated her elbow in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Contagion Puts a Focus on Infectious Diseases
description: To the Editor:

title: City Hands Off Part of Teacher Evaluation Effort to the State
description: New York City education officials announced Thursday that they would end their effort to rank teachers based on their students standardized test scores, adding a surprise twist to one of the most contentious issues facing the citys teaching force.

title: The Israeli Embassy View: Dont Blame Netanyahu
description: To the Editor:

title: Beneath the Hoodie, the Many Layers of Belichick
description: The public personality that Bill Belichick presents is a shield of his own making. That grim coach in the hoodie, that somber football genius, that unrevealing news conference speaker  all of it is what he wants outsiders to see. Those who know him are aware of a man with a depth of emotion and a sense of humor, but he has kept those in reserve as if revealing them would cause him to lose his soul.

title: Brain Stent Trial: The Investigators View
description: To the Editor:

title: France: Time Limits on Begging
description: In an enhanced campaign against petty crime and criminality, the government of President Nicolas Sarkozy has banned begging for the next six months on the famous Avenue des Champs-lyses from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., as well as prayers in the streets outside crowded mosques, according to Interior Minister Claude Guant. Mr. Guant has offered Muslims a large, unused barracks for a prayer space. He also announced a renewed crackdown on non-French Roma who overstay their visas, saying that delinquent minors will be deported.

title: Bipartisanship of the Wrong Kind
description: As soon as he proposed to pay for his $447 billion jobs plan with tax increases, President Obama knew he was going to do battle with Republicans. But he is also being challenged by Democrats because they cannot face another big pre-election fight or are thinking more about campaign contributors than the countrys best interests.

title: Negotiations Continue Over U.S. Hikers
description: The Iraqi president has been negotiating with Iranian officials in an attempt to gain the release of two American hikers held in Iran on espionage and trespassing convictions, according to Kurdish officials in Iraq. The president, Jalal Talabani, has been told by Iranian officials that the hikers will probably be released, the officials said. Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, had said that the hikers, Shane M. Bauer and Joshua F. Fattal, would be freed by Thursday, but Irans judiciary ruled otherwise. The conflicting messages are believed to reflect a power struggle between Mr. Ahmadinejad and Irans conservative establishment. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Thursday the United States had received word through a number of sources that the men would be released, despite the apparent confusion in Iran.

title: Good Time for Yanks Very Rare Day Off
description: The Yankees spent their last off day of the regular season resting in Toronto for the final push toward the playoffs. The precious day of rest was their first since Aug. 22, not counting the 24 hours they spent closeted in their Baltimore hotel rooms five days later because of Hurricane Irene.

title: Spagnuolo, Giants Monday Night Foe, Is Still a Friend
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Steve Spagnuolo has had more important things to worry about than crossing paths again with Tom Coughlin, his old boss, on Monday Night Football. Spagnuolos St. Louis Rams are pretty banged up, too.

title: Yemen: Fear as Fighting Resumes
description: Violence escalated across the country on Thursday as the government shelled a volatile neighborhood in the capital, Sana, and security forces fired on antigovernment protesters in Taiz, killing a 21-year-old man. Three civilians were killed early Thursday morning by mortar fire after fighting broke out in northern Sana, according to an employee inside a compound that had come under attack. The clashes brought fears that despite a cease-fire brokered in June, war has ignited again between the government and the Ahmars, tribal leaders who are accused of fomenting protests by Yemens government.

title: Customers Angry Over Revamped Pricing Are Deserting Netflix
description: Some of Netflixs popularity lies in its simplicity  in its ability to serve up films and TV shows and renew subscriptions automatically, without any thinking on the part of the customer.

title: Morgan Executive Fits a Choir Robe Beneath Her Pinstripes
description: Wall Street banks are not known as particularly religious workplaces. But Carla A. Harris, a managing director at Morgan Stanley and a part-time gospel singer, has found a way to blend profits with piety.

title: Where All Work Is Created Equal
description: School went badly last year for Jos, Angel and Estefani. The 8-year-old twins and their 7-year-old sister are recent immigrants to the Washington Heights neighborhood of Manhattan. In part because they didnt speak much English, late in 2010 all three were notified they were in danger of failing.

title: Metal Hips Failing Fast, Report Says
description: In a troubling development for people with all-metal artificial hips, a registry that tracks orthopedic implants in Britain reported on Thursday that the failure rate of the devices was increasing.

title: China: Recycled Cooking Oil Poses Risk
description: At least two million tons of cooking oil are recycled illegally every year and used by restaurants in China, posing a serious health hazard to diners, according to a report on Thursday on the Web site of Xinhua, the state news agency. Recycled oil has become an increasing concern as the country tries to grapple with food safety issues. On Wednesday, Chinese news organizations reported the police had detained 32 people who are part of a ring spanning 14 provinces that collected recycled oil and peddled it at a discount to restaurants.

title: Hedge Fund Chief Takes Major Role in Philanthropy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Until last year, Tom Steyer was just another billionaire hedge fund manager intent on keeping a low profile.

title: Amnesty Program Yields Millions More in Back Taxes
description: More than 12,000 American taxpayers have voluntarily revealed their secret offshore bank accounts to the Internal Revenue Service as part of the governments latest tax amnesty program, agency officials said on Thursday. The move will allow the United States Treasury to collect at least half a billion dollars in unpaid taxes.

title: Racial Bias Seen in Study of Lead Dust and Children
description: A class-action lawsuit was filed Thursday against a prominent Baltimore medical institute, accusing it of knowingly exposing black children as young as a year old to lead poisoning in the 1990s as part of a study exploring the hazards of lead paint.

title: The Planning Fallacy
description: When the Nobel Prize-winning psychologist Daniel Kahneman was a young man, he led a committee to write a new part of the curriculum for Israeli high schools. The committee worked for a year, and Kahneman asked his colleagues how long they thought the rest of the project would take. Their estimates were around two years.

title: Uncertainty on Wall Street, Big Deals on Madison Avenue
description: THREE years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers produced worldwide financial disruption, advertising agencies continue to face significant challenges. But Madison Avenue is, by and large, in better shape than many of the industries for which it creates ads.

title: Judge Sets Schedule in Case Over Googles Digital Library
description: Googles plan to build a huge digital library remained stalled on Thursday when a federal judge set a proposed schedule for a lawsuit against the giant search company that could take the case to trial next year.

title: Free to Die
description: Back in 1980, just as America was making its political turn to the right, Milton Friedman lent his voice to the change with the famous TV series Free to Choose. In episode after episode, the genial economist identified laissez-faire economics with personal choice and empowerment, an upbeat vision that would be echoed and amplified by Ronald Reagan.

title: New Ranger Joins Call for Safer Hockey
description: Brad Richards, the prize of the off-season free-agent market and the N.H.L.s highest-paid player, skates for the first time as a Ranger on Friday, when the team opens training camp. He says he is ready for the challenge and the pressure of trying to win in New York.

title: Book Details Dissension in Obama Economic Team
description: WASHINGTON  A new book claims that President Obamas response to the economic crisis was hampered by a White House economic staff plagued by internal rivalries, a domineering chief adviser and a Treasury secretary who dragged his feet on enforcing decisions with which he disagreed.

title: Belly Up to the Bistro
description: PARIS  Youre reminded hourly, even while walking along the slow-moving Seine or staring at sculpted marble bodies under the Louvres high ceilings, that the old continent is crumbling. Theyre slouching toward a gerontocracy, these Europeans. Their banks are teetering. They cant handle immigration. Greece is broke, and three other nations are not far behind. In a half-dozen languages, the papers shout: crisis!

title: TimesCast | Police Apartheid in Bahrain
description: September 15, 2011 - Six months after Bahrain's brutal crackdown on democratic protests, sectarian tension is brewing.

title: By Car or by Paw? Trying to Retrace a Cats Travels
description: Maybe she came on foot, charming strangers along the nations plains like a character out of Mark Twain.

title: Exploits, Now Not So Daring
description: Watertown, Mass.

title: House Republicans Push Stopgap Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  In last years campaigns, Republicans ripped into Democrats for failing to perform one of Congresss most basic duties: providing money in a timely way for the operations of government.

title: The Point Is That You Dont Have to Spend a Lot of Money to Do What You Love
description: Just two words on the back of a motorcycle, and half of Midtown Manhattan was stopping  well, lets say slowing  to gawk:

title: Marinovich Breaks Family Mold
description: LOS ANGELES  With little fanfare, the last of Marv Marinovichs football-playing sons is coming home.

title: Making Tyrants Do Time
description: Minneapolis

title: Koch May Test His Political Voice on National Stage
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Kochs strategy seemed almost nutty at first: ask Jewish residents in Brooklyn and Queens to vote against an Israel-loving observant Jew for Congress to send a message to President Obama.

title: Rumors of Revolt
description: Ever since Abraham Lincolns election in November 1860, rumors of a slave insurrection had been growing along the plantations in the lower Mississippi River Valley. By September 1861, with battles breaking out from Missouri to Virginia and a Union blockade stretching across the Gulf Coast, those rumblings had reached a fever pitch.

title: For Lundqvist, a Summer of Joy and Sorrow
description: For Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist it was a busy summer, highlighted by his marriage in his hometown, Gothenburg, Sweden. But it was also a sad summer, marked by the death by overdose of his Rangers teammate Derek Boogaard, the apparent suicides of two other N.H.L. enforcers and the plane crash in Russia that killed the players and coaches of Lokomotiv Yaroslavl. Last week in a conversation with Jeff Z. Klein of The Times and Jeff Blair of The Globe and Mail, Lundqvist talked about his career, his hopes for the Rangers, and the shock of a sobering off season.

title: Aid for Baffled Weekend Subway Riders
description: Have trouble figuring out the subways on weekends? Get ready for a little help from an old friend.

title: Stand or Fall Together
description: European leaders have at last begun edging, haltingly and reluctantly, toward the only realistic solution to the continents debt and banking crises: refinancing unpayable government debts and reinforcing weakened banks. If their monetary and political union is to survive, all members must start acting more like a union and less like a collection of jealous sovereign states.

title: Arrest of UBS Trader Rattles Banks in Europe
description: Kweku Adoboli traveled from Ghana to Israel to a Quaker boarding school before attending a leading university in Nottingham, England. With his education pedigree, he landed a coveted job at UBS, the giant Swiss bank, right after graduation.

title: Pandering to the Gun Lobby
description: How low can the Florida Legislature go in pandering to the gun lobby?

title: Lottery Numbers
In Kansas City, an Arts Center Makes a Debut
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  As arts organizations from one coast to the other wrestle with cuts in grants and declines in ticket sales, an ambitious new performing arts center in the middle of the country is defying the trend.

title: Pitching-Rich Rays Continue Late Charge
description: Boston

title: New F.A.A. Shutdown Is Averted
description: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  The Senate passed legislation on Thursday to avert a second partial shutdown of the Federal Aviation Administration, extending the agencys financing for four months.

title: Humane Housing for the Mentally Ill
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo brought an end to a shameful chapter in New Yorks history last week when he agreed to settle a suit over the mistreatment of mentally ill people who have been unnecessarily confined in nursing homes.

title: At White House, Weighing Limits of Terror Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations legal team is split over how much latitude the United States has to kill Islamist militants in Yemen and Somalia, a question that could define the limits of the war against Al Qaeda and its allies, according to administration and Congressional officials.

title: Delta One Desks Are Big Moneymakers
description: The $2 billion trading loss that has rocked the Swiss banking giant UBS has also cast a spotlight on a relatively unknown but increasingly profitable corner of Wall Street  Delta One desks.

title: Advantage, Tight Ends, Against the Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  By Rex Ryans count, the Jets made seven glaring defensive mistakes in their victory over Dallas, and one of them seemed more than a bit familiar. Like many tight ends before him, Jason Witten burned the Jets over the middle, exploiting a mismatch in coverage to rumble for a 64-yard gain in the fourth quarter.

title: Potential Buyers Renew Their Interest in Yahoo
description: With potential buyers circling above, Yahoo, the once-mighty online empire, is preparing to sell.

title: Friday: Generally Speaking
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Some weeks are like this. I begin on a buoyant note, solving smoothly and confidently, which carries me through the themed puzzles for the week, and just as Im hitting my stride I get derailed by a tough themeless, like todays grid by Joe DiPietro.

title: The Dance of the City on a Day in June
description: From the very first moments of Septimus and Clarissa, Ellen McLaughlins relentlessly, almost nerve-rackingly ambitious adaptation of Virginia Woolfs Mrs. Dalloway, a bold visual gauntlet is thrown down.

title: Some Cabbies Given Right to Say No to Racy Ads
description: For Mohan Singh, the breaking point came last year when his granddaughter, who was 6 at the time, saw a seductive woman in an advertisement affixed to the roof of his taxicab. She proudly announced that she suddenly knew what she wanted to be when she grew up.

title: Withdrawal of Database on Doctors Is Protested
description: Three journalism organizations on Thursday protested a decision by the Obama administration to remove a database of physician discipline and malpractice actions from the Web.

title: Lawmaker Takes Office and Learns Some Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Thursday was a day of firsts for Bob Turner, who is New Yorks newest congressman and the Republican Partys newest hero.

title: Malcolm Wallop, Senator From Wyoming, Dies at 78
description: Malcolm Wallop, a three-term Republican senator from Wyoming who was a leading conservative light in Washington, pressing for a strong national defense, tax reform, states rights and other elements of the political sea change swept in by the Reagan administration, died on Wednesday at his home near Big Horn, Wyo. He was 78.

title: Newark Is Betting on a Wave of New Principals
description: NEWARK  There is Sonn Sam, a Rhode Island transplant who could be mistaken for one of the students at his alternative high school, with his shaven head, sneakers and tattooed left arm.

title: Mets Pitchers Not Helping Themselves
description: Mets pitcher Mike Pelfrey has adjusted his view on the Mendoza Line to suit his performance at the plate. He is simply hoping to improve his batting average 4 points, to .100, by the end of the year. That is 100 points below the actual Mendoza Line.

title: UBS Has Some Explaining to Do
Sam DeLuca, a Former Jet and Broadcaster, Is Dead at 75
description: Sam DeLuca, a scrappy guard for the Jets in the 1960s who became a broadcaster after sustaining a career-ending injury, died on Tuesday at his home in Pelham, N.Y. He was 75.

title: In Syrian Town, Uprising Turns Into Grim Standoff
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Daraya, a town on the outskirts of Damascus famous for its carpentry and fertile fields, has emerged as an example that illustrates the dichotomy of the Syrian uprising: a revolt that seems too resilient to fail and too vulnerable to endure.

title: Aiming to Become the Best, Against Some of the Worst
description: There is nothing glamorous about the 5-year-old gelding named Rapid Redux. He will never make the Hall of Fame, win an Eclipse Award or race on national television. He just shows up, usually at small tracks with empty grandstands, usually against one-time claimers, and does his job.

title: Denmark to Be Led by Its First Female Premier as Leftists Win
description: LONDON  A closely contested election in Denmark resulted in victory on Thursday for a center-left coalition led by the Social Democratic Party, ending a 10-year run in power for a center-right coalition that adopted some of Europes toughest immigration controls.

title: Bahrain Boils Under the Lid of Repression
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The battle began soon after sundown. And for the next six hours, in air heavy with heat and tear gas, phalanxes of police officers in helmets battled scores of youths in ski masks, as customers at a Costa Coffee not far away sat like spectators.

title: Survey Finds Decline in New Yorkers Who Smoke to 14%
description: Just 14 percent of New York City adults said they were smokers in 2010, the lowest level since the city began tracking the smoking rate nearly two decades ago, according to a survey released on Thursday.

title: Players Show Their Unity at Key Juncture of Talks
description: LAS VEGAS  On an afternoon of showy symbolism and strident commentary, Derek Fisher took the podium, flanked by 33 constituents in matching shirts, and flipped the script on the N.B.A.s festering labor drama.

title: Boehner, in Washington Speech, Reaffirms No-Tax-Increase Position
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner on Thursday rejected tax increases as part of a sweeping effort to reduce the nations debt, delivering his prescription for a Congressional deficit-cutting committee ahead of a competing presentation by President Obama early next week.

title: Brazilian Couple Traverses the Americas
description: At midlife, Sinomar Godois Tavares met Edivania Marques and bought a motorcycle. Then they took off to see the world.

title: Market Risks Are Seen in Energy Innovations
description: WASHINGTON  The same market forces that doomed Solyndra, the solar cell manufacturer that received $528 million in government loans and then went bankrupt, could imperil other manufacturing ventures that have received loan guarantees from the Energy Department, energy experts warned this week.

title: Giants Chief Executive Is Stepping Down
description: Winning the World Series last year did not create longtime harmony atop the San Francisco Giants hierarchy. On Wednesday night, the team said that Bill Neukom, its bow-tied managing general partner and chief executive, would retire at the end of the year.

title: Virginia Health Board Tightens Rules on Abortion Clinics
description: WASHINGTON  The Virginia Board of Health on Thursday approved a set of regulations for abortion clinics that abortion rights advocates say could result in the closing of a number of the states more than 20 clinics. Supporters of the measures say they will make the clinics safer.

title: Rose Leads the Attack on One Tough Course
description: LEMONT, Ill.  Whether it is called going low or posting a number or shooting nothing or simply shooting a good score, it is axiomatic wherever touring pros gather to play for money: someone always seems to do it.

title: Americans and Cubans Still Mired in Distrust
description: MEXICO CITY  Bill Richardson had chits to offer Cuban officials in Havana this week if they released Alan Gross, the American contractor serving a 15-year sentence for distributing satellite telephone equipment.

title: Ex-Basketball Prodigy Dies on Streets Where He Lived
description: LOS ANGELES  Lewis Brown, a high school and college basketball prodigy who spent the past 10 years living on a sidewalk in Hollywood, seemed on the verge of a second chance. He had scraped enough money together to get a California identification card so he could fly to visit a sister in New York who had thought him dead. Friends said that he would finally get off the street.

title: Repressing the Religious Majority
description: Five months after the start of a ferocious crackdown against a popular uprising  so sweeping it smacks of apartheidlike repression of Bahrains religious majority  many fear that no one can win.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Palestinians Resist Appeals to Halt U.N. Statehood Bid
description: JERUSALEM  Senior American and European diplomats tried without success on Thursday to persuade the Palestinian leaders to skip or modify their planned United Nations membership bid, officials involved said.

title: Import Helps Macedonia Find Unity
description: A look at the scoring leader board at the European championships reveals some familiar names  Deng, Bargnani, Parker and Gasol, to name a few. But sitting fourth, averaging 20.9 points a game, is a previously obscure player from New Orleans playing for Macedonia  population two million  which earned a highly improbable berth Wednesday in the tournaments semifinals with a 67-65 win over host Lithuania.

title: The Voices of Sjogrens Syndrome
description: When the tennis great Venus Williams announced she was withdrawing from the United States Open this month because of health reasons, she put the spotlight on a common yet little-known disorder called Sjogrens syndrome.

title: More Schools Choose to Teach Abstinence-Plus
description: In the spring, public school students in Midland will touch what until recently was the political third rail of sex education. For the first time they will be taught about contraception  and how to practice safe sex.

title: The Dewhurst Profile: Unexciting but Atop Polls
description: David Dewhurst is the Mitt Romney of the United States Senate race in Texas.

title: Budget Cuts Threaten Underenrolled Physics Departments
description: The physicist Carlos Handy moved from Georgia to Texas in 2005, excited about building a physics program at Texas Southern University. But after serving as chairman of the department for six years, he may soon have to oversee its dismantling.

title: Skeptics Cast Wary Eyes on Plan to Finance Cal Stadium Upgrade
description: Are there buyers for $225,000 college football tickets?

title: Syrian Opposition Council Forms in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  Syrian opposition leaders announced on Thursday the formation of a national council to support the revolution against President Bashar al-Assads government and communicate with other nations in a unified voice.

title: Homelessness Live on a Tenderloin Stage
description: The first sign that Hunters Point, a new play by Elizabeth Gjelten of San Francisco, is not a typical theatergoing experience is at the door.

title: Abalone and a Rite Fall Victim to Red Tide
description: Since he was a child, Matt Mattison has taken part in an enduring summer ritual of the spectacular and rugged Sonoma Coast: donning fins and a mask, and diving to the ocean floor in search of abalone.

title: Living at the Intersection of Public Need and Housing Pride
description: Valencia Gardens, located in San Franciscos Mission neighborhood, is considered by many to be the Eden of public housing.

title: Just Children, but Training for the Center Ring
description: Regina Meirmanov is 8. She likes pizza, hula hoops, the TV show iCarly and the singer Katy Perry. When she grows up,she wants to be a contortionist, or maybe a trapeze artist.

title: Battle for Libya | September 15, 2011
description: The leaders of Britain and France visited Libya on Thursday and anti-Qaddafi fighters advanced southwest of Surt.

title: Three St. Johns Recruits Fail to Qualify
description: The revamping of the St. Johns basketball program hit a significant roadblock Thursday when three top recruits failed to qualify academically, leaving the team with just eight scholarship players to start the season. Amir Garrett, Norvel Pelle and JaKarr Sampson, each considered one of the countrys top 100 players, failed to make it through the N.C.A.A. Clearinghouse.

title: Glib Announcements on Job Creation Cant Hide a Grim Reality
description: If Mayor Rahm Emanuel can generate jobs as well as he creates solicitous publicity, work-hungry citizens will be hitchhiking to Chicago from San Diego. If only it were that easy.

title: Aftermarket Groupon Sites Eat Into Revenues
description: As skepticism mounts over Groupons long-term business prospects, this Chicago-based daily-deal giant, already facing a possible delay in its initial public stock offering, could be facing a new challenge in the form of the $1.2 billion market for resale of the companys signature deep-discount coupons.

title: NYT Front Page for 09/16/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/16/11

title: Community Is Torn Over Expansion of Oil Refinery
description: Steve Kozel was 7 in August 1955 when the Standard Oil refinery near his familys Whiting, Ind., home was badly damaged by a huge explosion and fire. His father, who worked at the nearby Sinclair oil refinery, had been planning to buy a house in Whiting. My mother said no way, Mr. Kozel said, and they moved farther away.

title: No Stranger to Suspense, L.S.U. Outduels Mississippi State
description: STARKVILLE, Miss.  When Louisiana State bumbled its way to the national title in 2007, it raised the crystal football despite two losses, six overtime periods and six games decided by one touchdown or less. The season is remembered for a flurry of close calls, head-shaking finishes and fourth-quarter gambles by Coach Les Miles that fluctuated from daring to baffling.

title: Pennsylvania Electoral College Plan Could Backfire on G.O.P.
description: Republicans in Pennsylvania are considering a proposal that would award 18 of the states 20 electoral votes to the winner of each of its congressional districts, leaving the remaining 2 to the winner of the state at large.

title: Rays Gain Ground (Again) on the Red Sox
description: BOSTON  It was the kind of freakish play that happens to teams in a free fall. With two out and two on in the third inning of a scoreless game Thursday, Tampa Bays B.J. Upton broke his bat on a ground ball to shortstop. Major league infielders  incredibly, when you think about it  almost always find a way to ignore bouncing shards of wood in their vicinity. But this one skipped too quickly to Boston shortstop Marco Scutaro.

title: West Side Story
description: Photos from the new Broadway revival, which opened at the Palace Theater.

title: Telling a New Story
description: A look at the many lives of the musical West Side Story.

title: Playing It Cool
description: West Side Story, the 1957 musical that changed the way we think about how dance can tell a story, is reopening at the Palace Theater.

title: Word of the Day | supplant
description: supplant \s-plant\ verb

title: Fashion Week Finale: Marc Jacobs
description: Sometime between Calvin Klein, at 3 p.m. Thursday, and Marc Jacobs that evening, the weather changed, and suddenly Fashion Week seemed over before it actually was. We saw Ralph Lauren, LWren Scott (who served her guests salade Nioise and French fries), Calvin Klein and Mr. Jacobs. It was a pretty good day, with good fashion  Ms. Scotts tart colors and then a sharp, finishing slap of glamorous black; Francisco Costas languid minimalism, and Mr. Jacobss very personal ode to dance halls and Bob Fosse.

title: Post-Grunge, Seattle Rocks On
description: SEATTLE  Three months before he killed himself, Kurt Cobain spoke of his bands breakthrough single at a concert here that turned out to be one of Nirvanas final performances in the United States.

title: 20 Years of Seattle Sound
description: Twenty years ago, Nirvanas Nevermind album introduced the world to the Seattle sound of grunge. Now a new exhibit and documentary are celebrating the antiestablishment music.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Today
description: Government oil companies raised the price of petrol (Times of India) by 3.14 Indian rupees per liter yesterday in a move that is expected to stoke inflation and upset household budgets. This is the third substantial increase since January. Oil companies argue that a fall in the rupee against the American dollar increased their cost of crude, forcing them to raise the price. Theres more bad news for households. A group of ministers is likely to consider limiting the supply (Hindustan Times) of subsidized liquefied petroleum gas cylinders today in an effort to cut the governments overwhelming fuel subsidy bill.Less than 24 hours after the arrest of two high school students, police nabbed two more students (Indian Express) in connection with the bombing of the Delhi High Court last week, which killed 14 people and injured dozens more. Apart from these four young men, police are questioning a cybercaf owner and his manager in relation to the e-mail sent to the media soon after the blast.

title: Quiz: Test Your Grunge Knowledge
description: Grunge music helped define Seattle in the early 1990s and has left its mark on rock n roll in the 20 years since. How well do you know the genre? Test your knowledge.

title: Seattle, Post Grunge
description: Twenty years after Nirvana soared from obscurity to superstardom, a new exhibition, a film and a tribute concert make clear how different things really are here now.

title: North Korean Accused of Plotting Against Fellow Defector
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas top government spy agency said on Friday that it had arrested a North Korean defector on suspicion of plotting an attack on a fellow defector who is a vocal critic of the North.

title: The Old Master
description: The Picasso biographer discusses several works by the artist featured in a new show at the Gagosian Gallery.

title: Le Corbusier at the Barbican
description: Views of an exhibition devoted to the Modernist architect at the Barbican Center, which is itself part of a Corbu-inspired complex.

description: Tent cities have sprung up in Sacramento and Fresno, Calif., as more people lose jobs and housing in the economic downturn.

title: Questioning of Reggae Artist Led Police to 300 Pounds of Marijuana
description: When Denroy Morgan blew through a stop sign in the Bronx on Wednesday, he began a chain of events that ended with the arrest of two people and the discovery of a stash of shrink-wrapped bales of more than 300 pounds of marijuana.

title: Lille Entertains, but Then Spoils the Ending
description: Lille may be the kings of free-flowing French football, but on Wednesday night in their opening bow in this years Champions League they learned a valuable lesson: attack isnt always the best form of defense.

title: Stage Scenes: Joan Allen
description: Photos of some of the actresss performances on stage and screen.

title: The Grammar of Anarchy
description: As Western democracies contemplate the ravages of debt and recession, in India the global economic crisis has manifested itself this summer as a burning debate about corruption. Led by a 74-year old farmer from Maharashtra, Baburao Anna Hazare, the popular outcry against this scourge of the Indian polity has consumed the months of summer and monsoon from April to September. While the Indian media have read Annas appearance in public life as a historic moment, in fact it is an old tension within Indias founding principles that has once again come to the fore.

title: Corrections: September 16
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Malaysian Premier Proposes Replacing Laws on Detention
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia has promised to abolish two contentious security laws that allow for detention without trial and to relax a law governing the media in what analysts say is an attempt to revive his public support before elections that could be called by early next year.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 16, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Sept. 16, 1974 | Conditional Amnesty for Vietnam Draft Dodgers and Military Deserters
description: On Sept. 16, 1974, President Gerald R. Ford issued a proclamation that offered amnesty to those who evaded the draft during the Vietnam War. Mr. Ford also granted amnesty to those in the military who deserted their duty while serving. However, the amnesty came with certain conditions, namely that those involved agreed to reaffirm their allegiance to the United States and serve two years working in a public service job.

description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, Women With Wrenches.

description: Its Fashion Week in New York City, and a recent article shares playlists from the D.J.s hired for keeping runway models on their toes. Read about, and hear, some of the music, then tell us whats on your favorite playlist these days and why.

description: The Choice concludes its reader Q&A with the authors of a new book that bills itself as the ultimate users manual for college applicants and that loosely follows, as its model, tWhat to Expect When Youre Expecting the perennial best seller.

description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

description: LOS ANGELES  Darrin Prescott, the stunt coordinator for the movie Drive, which opens nationwide on Friday, is a proponent of the minimalist car chase.
