description: Todays Times:

title: The Role of Prices in Health Care Spending
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: At Maxxi in Rome, Urban Gardens Bloom
description: At Maxxi, the museum of contemporary art in Rome that opened in 2009, its the buildings design, by the architect Zaha Hadid, and the art inside that usually get most of the attention. But this summer, the museums outdoor spaces has captured the publics fancy as well.

title: Make Room for Hinglish
description: Language is no barrier to writing a novel, author Animesh Verma told the Indian Express newspaper in a 2010 interview, a statement that caused many novelists and book lovers to recoil in disbelief.

title: Approval of Congress Matches Record Low
description: Congress faces historically low approval ratings as it wades into the debate over the $447 billion jobs package proposed by President Obama, with just 12 percent of Americans now approving of the way Congress is handling its job, matching its all-time low, recorded in October 2008 at the height of the economic crisis, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Site Specific
description: When she traveled, Pavia Rosati used to scour 90 Web sites for hours, then narrow down the information into a 40-page mega-Word document. To save the rest of us the trouble, Rosati started Fathom (fathomaway.com): guides, postcards and resources by journalists, tuned-in travelers and readers eager to share. Its crowd sourcing with an editorial filter, says Rosati (above right, in Capri with Fathoms editorial director, Jeralyn Gerba, left). Everyone loves the voice of the people, but can you trust them?

title: Going Behind the Scenes With Four Owners
description: What happens when women who own businesses get together to talk openly about their challenges, strategies and goals? Beginning next week, well find out when I start to meet regularly with the owners of four businesses. Our continuing conversation will become an important feature of She Owns It. This post introduces the women and the companies we will get to know.

title: Fill-In | The 1,800-Mile Cat
Ahead of Its Time | An Icon Goes Digital
description: In 1972, Massimo Vignelli designed a diagrammatic map for the New York City subway. It was a radical departure. He replaced the serpentine maze of geographically accurate train routes with simple, bold bands of color that turned at 45- and 90-degree angles. Each route was color-coded, its stops indicated by black dots. Its abstract representation of the routes was elegant but flawed. To make the map function effectively, a few geographic liberties were taken, something that didnt sit well with New Yorkers.

title: A Trickle of Aid for Tripolis Zoo Animals
description: The International Fund for Animal Welfare has had several unusual missions in the past few years, sometimes involving the rescue of zoo animals in conflict zones.

title: Transatlantic Ends Deal With Allied World
description: Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance called off their proposed $2.94 billion merger on Friday, after the two insurers faced stiff shareholder opposition and two rival bids for Transatlantic.

title: How About  Now?
description: As tech geeks might remember, in an interview six weeks ago with The New York Times, Indias Minister for Human Resource Development, Kapil Sibal, promised to unveil a $35 laptop in six weeks.

title: Syrias Protesters, Long Mostly Peaceful, Starting to Resort to Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias uprising has become more violent in the countrys most restive regions, in what may signal the start of a protracted armed struggle after six months of largely peaceful protests in the face of a ferocious government crackdown, diplomats, activists and officials say.

title: Libya Counts More Martyrs Than Bodies
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Where are all the dead?

title: Friday Reading: How to Avoid Impulse Moves in Retirement Investments
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Week 2 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Eagles (1-0) at Falcons (0-1)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Eagles by 2 1/2In honor of Michael Vicks return to Atlanta, the Eagles have starting using their 1989 throwback offense. The scheme pays homage to Randall Cunninghams glory days. The Eagles do not really drive down the field; they just string together amazing highlights, interspersing the occasional punt or baffling mistake. A typical play begins with two defenders knifing untouched through Philadelphias porous, inexperienced offensive line. Vick either gets flattened or performs some Matrix-style escape, scrambling for a big gain or tossing to a receiver who used the confusion to get wide open. Andy Reid calls for a timeout four or five times per half to impose order (teams only get three timeouts per half, but a 5-yard penalty is a small price to pay for the chance to install a precisely designed sequence of plays for Vick to scrap).

title: Russian Drama
description: After closing its doors in 2005 for a rafters-to-orchestra-pit renovation, Moscows Bolshoi Theater still kicked up controversy  embezzlement, corruption, sex scandal. Now, three years past due and way over budget, the hall, which dates to 1825, will reopen next month with a gala performance of the ballet and opera companies greatest hits. In attendance will be President Dmitri Medvedev and other heads of state, who will finally see what $760 million restores. It took more than 3,500 workers to restore the Apollo and the Muses ceiling piece, replicate the missing Villeroy & Boch tiles and hang 617 pounds of crystal from the main chandelier. Much of the work was supervised by the presidents office itself, which stepped in when construction faltered in 2009, after a contractor was paid three times for the same work. Now the acoustics are fixed, subterranean hydraulic stages are built, and, for the finishing touch, the Romanov coat of arms has been reinstated above the lintels, in place of the hammer and sickle.

title: Advice on Debt? Europe Suggests U.S. Can Keep It
description: WROCLAW, Poland  The United States has long been considered a financial adviser to the rest of the world. But these days, American officials come carrying baggage.

title: Announcing the Learning Network Reading Club
description: Updated | Oct. 21:

title: Emma Thompson to Give Peter Rabbit a New Tale
description: And so the day finally came when even Peter Rabbit, the vegetable-nibbling, clothes-losing, tea-sipping bunny created by Beatrix Potter more than 100 years ago was the subject of a planned sequel-slash-reboot. But at least in this case his latest adventure is being written by an author with the sense and sensibility to preserve the voice and spirit of Potters original stories.

title: Police Charge UBS Trader With Fraud
description: LONDON  London police charged Kweku M. Adoboli, a 31-year-old UBS trader, with fraud on Friday after the Swiss bank said it lost $2 billion because of unauthorized trades.

description: Arrest of UBS Trader Rattles Banks in Europe | Kweku Adoboli traveled from Ghana to Israel to a Quaker boarding school before attending a leading university in Nottingham, England. After graduation, he landed a coveted job at UBS, the giant Swiss bank.

description: This week The New York Timess music critics reassess a blockbuster album with a cultural impact that may have eclipsed its multiplatinum sales, for better or worse.

description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: London Design Festival | Faye Toogood at Phillips de Pury
description: This years London Design Festival, which starts tomorrow and runs through Sept. 25, will offer visitors over 300 exhibitions and events  a daunting number even for the most die-hard design fan. One of the first of these, which also promises to be one of the most interesting, is an exhibition of Faye Toogoods third furniture collection, Delicate Interference: Assemblage 3, at Phillips de Pury & Companys Brook Street space at Claridges in Mayfair (until Oct. 4).

title: My Three Favorite Cities in Fiction
description: Three cities in fiction. Not fictional places, like the Celestial City, Minas Tirith or Bikini Bottom, but real-world cities made better than real.

title: L.S.U. Makes an Argument for No. 1
description: STARKVILLE, Miss.  Louisiana State beat Mississippi State on Thursday night with a suffocating defensive effort, dominating the line of scrimmage, smothering receivers with press coverage and swarming the ball with a scary tenacity.

title: Interview: Gerard Butler
description: The actor Gerard Butler discusses playing the role of a biker-turned-missionary in "Machine Gun Preacher."

title: New York Top 5 | Michael Kors
description: The vacation destinations of Michael Kors have often served as rich fodder for his collections, and his latest locale is one more for that enviable list. The African Bush of Peter Beard and Brad and Angie (see video) set the scene for a safari most of us can just dream about. Utility jackets in actual mudcloth and ombred leather were worn with colorfully dyed linen scarves and loose pants. My favorite look was a multipocketed khaki jacket with treated seams worn with voluminous knee-length olive cargo pocketed shorts, with a natural linen scarf dip dyed to match. Book my plane ticket now.

title: Seven Eras of Willem de Kooning
description: De Kooning: A Retrospective, a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, includes about 200 paintings, drawings and sculptures created by Willem de Kooning, who helped define the shape of postwar American art.

title: Subaru Recalls 70,000 Outbacks and Legacys for Loose Moonroof Glass
description: 11:26 a.m. |Update

title: Electric Cars, the Do-It-Yourself Way
description: Seth Walker, a communications consultant for sustainable enterprises, sent this photo yesterday from Portland, Ore., of a Volkswagen Beetle with an unusual accessory  an extension cord:

title: Channel Surfing: A Gift of Life With Linda Ellerbee
description: Linda Ellerbee has long been showing the way in making thoughtful programming for children, and part of her skill is knowing when to let her young subjects tell their own stories. Thats what she does in A Gift of Life, a lovely, honest segment of Nick News With Linda Ellerbee that has its premiere on Nickelodeon on Sunday night.

title: Photos of the Moment | Calvin Klein
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#965", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Solar Loan Gets Daily Show Treatment
description: The Daily Show with Jon StewartGet More: Daily Show Full Episodes,Political Humor & Satire Blog,The Daily Show on Facebook

title: Retrofitting the Feminine Mystique
description: BUNNY tails, bustiers and white-glove deference. It almost seems like men have gone mad on Mad Men, wresting network television backward to the boom-boom, coffee, tea or me 1960s.

title: Jolynn & Robert
description: In this homemade video, Jolynn Baca and Robert Jaekel recall falling in love after a long weekend of wine tasting in Norfolk.

title: For Sale: Prison Coffee and Other WikiLeaks Memorabilia
description: How much would you pay for Julian Assanges prison coffee?

title: Citys Battle Against Smoking Goes Back Centuries
description: Updated, 3:12 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has snuffed out smoking more audaciously than any of his recent predecessors, as the latest figures attest: only 14 percent of New Yorkers now smoke, the cityreported Thursday, discouraged in large part by the ever-cresting wave of Bloomberg-driven taxes and bans.

title: Taking Manhattan by Bike (the Russian Way)
description: Cosmpolitian Muscovites have been taking to cycling, and one of their new traditions, the Moscow Architectural Velonight, which drew more than 5,000 participants in July, is coming to Manhattan on Oct. 1 as Velonight New York. Velonights creator, Sergey Nikitin, is an associate professor of Russian art, architecture and sociourbanistics at the Peoples Friendship University of Russia in Moscow.

title: Lifeguards Going Gray, but Still Going
description: An estimated 10 percent of the lifeguards who work New Yorks public beaches and parks are over the age of 50. Their secret? Intense winter exercise so they can stay in shape to pass the lifeguard fitness test year after year.

title: Holding Fast in a Churning City
description: Across New York City, as the populations and landmarks of neighborhoods change, some businesses stay their ground.

title: On the Phone With Maurice Sendak
description: This month marks the publication of Bumble-Ardy, the first book that Maurice Sendak has written and illustrated in 30 years. Mr. Sendak has been promoting the new book largely from his home in Connecticut.

title: What Kind of Job Is Bradley Walking Into?
description: If Bob Bradley is indeed headed to Egypt this weekend to sign on as the coach of its national team  not a done deal, according to at least one source close to Bradley  then what kind of a job is he walking into?

title: Weekend Fare
description: The NYC Dumpling Festival features an international array of dumplings, from Ukrainian pierogi to Korean mandoo, on Saturday from noon to 5 p.m. at Sara D. Roosevelt Park, on Chrystie Street between East Houston and Canal Streets. Four servings will be $20. The event benefits the Food Bank for New York City.

title: Staying Put in a City of Change
description: LOUIS SAVARESE, the son and grandson of butchers, was raised to know the difference between a rib-eye roast and a cross-rib roast, but he is the first in his family to appreciate the finer points of cow hooves and chicken feet.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | LWren Scott
description: Rock n roll on the Riviera is the beauty catchphrase backstage at LWren Scott. A contessa from wherever, is how Serge Normant described the woman that inspired the undone French twists he created using his own line of products. He coated hair with Meta Lush Volumizer and Meta Revive Dry Shampoo before blow-drying and using a small barrel curling iron to create the base for finger waves. Then, the back was swept to the side and tucked into a twist secured with pins. Sophistication becomes disheveled, Normant said, using his fingers to pull apart the up do. Nails went the way of the lady, as well. She wanted something sexy, nothing dark or overpowering of the clothes, Yuna Park said of Blush, the custom mauve polish she created for Scott to replace last seasons black varnish. Its less Gothic, more feminine  not so harsh. For makeup, Aaron De May translated Scotts directive with a dense shiny eye, bronzed skin and a subtle lip. Normally, LWren always likes strong, smoky, colorful, this was also about decadence, the duchesses, princesses arriving on boat in the 40s and 50s, he said. De May used Lancme Star Bronzer  in Solaire to make each girls skin color two tones darker. He then applied Le Crayon Kohl in Black Coffee all around the eye and in the crease. This was blended with Mochaccino shadow on the top and Vintage Brown on the bottom. He painted the inner corners of the eye gold from the 5 Pan Palette in Gold Frenzy and spread Juicy Tubes Pure clear lip gloss on the lid. It can look dull or muddy with all that brown, De May said. This brings life to the face in need of a little bit of sparkle.

title: Jerry OConnell Coming to Broadway in Theresa Rebeck Comedy
description: The television and film actor Jerry OConnell (Sliders, Jerry Maguire) will make his Broadway debut this fall as a self-satisfied young writer in Theresa Rebecks new comedy, Seminar, which stars Alan Rickman as a no-holds-barred writing teacher.

title: Robertson Stirs Passions With Suggestion to Divorce an Alzheimers Patient
description: With his suggestion this week that a man whose wife was far gone with Alzheimers should divorce her if he wanted a new companion, the television evangelist Pat Robertson stumbled into treacherous moral terrain, setting off storms of criticism and questions about a disease that shatters lives and families.

title: Strange Case of Willow the Cat Is Solved, to a Point
description: It is looking as if the mystery of how Willow the calico cat crossed the country may have the most prosaic possible solution. No death-defying four-paw trek out of The Incredible Journey; no stowing away on Amtrak or Greyhound; no Toonces-like turn at the wheel of a careering car.

title: Can Antioch College Return From the Dead Again?
description: The long corridors of Antioch Hall are dark. The fluorescent lights, perhaps 50 years old and never updated, do not work. The vinyl floor tiles are loose. There are cobwebs and puddles on the floor, and the whole place smells of mold. You have to squint, almost, to picture this four-story brick building as the birthplace of one of the most vaunted experiments in American higher education.

title: Why We Need For-Profit Colleges
description: Last month, a company called Education Management Corporation was sued by the Department of Justice. Education Management is a for-profit education company; in fact, it is the countrys second-largest such company, with more than 150,000 students attending classes on more than 100 campuses, where it offers degrees in business, accounting and nursing, among other subjects.

title: There Is No Escaping Whitney Cummings
description: This fall, youre coming out of relative obscurity to have two shows on network TV: Whitney, which you star in, and Two Broke Girls, which you co-created. What do you remember about being broke?  There was a time in L.A. when I drove to 7-Eleven to go grocery shopping, and I locked my keys in my car, which wasnt insured. My wallet was in there, and I couldnt call AAA, because I only had $7 in my bank account. It was one of those moments where I was like, O.K., I literally have nothing right now.

title: The 83-Year-Old Money Tree
description: Earlier this summer, I found myself in the passenger seat of 83-year-old Mary Donnellys Ford Escape as she darted around Block Island, dodging dozens of half-drunk tourists spilling into the street.

title: Stolen Property?
description: I bought a house that a previous owner had nearly destroyed. He knocked holes in walls and doors, trucked away the deck and trashed the aboveground pool, etc. I assumed he was angry at his wife, but it turned out that he was angry at the bank, which had foreclosed, taking everything the couple had put into the property. When a mutual friend invited the former owners to visit, the wife wept and said she could never bear to see our improvements on a house that had been stolen. I know we didnt steal her home, but I resolved never to buy a foreclosed house again. It seems to be an evil thing to do, to profit from another familys misfortune. Is it? ELIZABETH MURPHY, NORFOLK, VA.

title: College Football Live Blog: Join the Conversation
description: Paul Myerberg and Karen Crouse of The Times will be hosting their own college football watch party all day Saturday, right here at The Quad. Theyll bring you highlights and analysis from games around the country and spend some time answering your questions.

title: Dear Important Novelists: Be Less Like Moses and More Like Howard Cosell
description: To start with, look at all the books. Thats the promising first sentence of Jeffrey Eugenidess new novel, The Marriage Plot, due in bookstores this fall. The book is about three college friends from Brown University, and at first taste  Ive been toting around an advance copy  it appears to be luscious: humane, recondite and funny. Part of the heavy anticipation for The Marriage Plot, though, is a simple emotional response: Weve missed this man. It has been nine years since Eugenidess last novel, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Middlesex. It has been a long, lonely vigil. Wed nearly forgotten he was out there.

title: The Re-Education of an Amnesiac
description: Im not your typical undergraduate. I am a 46-year-old wife and mother with three adult children. Depending on how you count, I may be twice as old as the traditional students or essentially the same age as they are. After all, my life as I know it began 23 years ago, when, in a freakish accident, I was hit in the head by a ceiling fan in our home in Fort Worth, Tex. At that moment, everything and everyone I ever knew, and all I had ever learned, was erased completely from my mind.

title: What Would Hillary Clinton Have Done?
description: Every week, several letters rail against Republicans. I find the claim in last weeks letter about Hillary Clinton that Republicans dont play fair particularly delicious, because the Clintons are hardly known for playing political softball. To all of you paranoid folks, however: Republicans are not the cause of all of the problems of the Western world. We genuinely believe that government needs to live within its means, that it is not the governments role to try to socially engineer every problem and especially that the government is not the solution to our jobs problem. The Democrats controlled the House and the Senate since 2006, and Obama certainly got his health care program through. So what is it exactly that the Republicans have kept Obama, Pelosi, Reid and Co., from doing?

title: Beatles on the Beach
description: Every Beatles fan knows that the iconic images of them starts, and arguably ends, with Astrid Kirchherrs work. Her incredible influence on their tastes, interests, appearance, clothes and even music is as legendary as she is. She is a fabulous icon of that era, an accomplished artist in her own right and really a sixth member of the band in so many ways in the early days. And her tragic link to Stu Sutcliffe is another reminder of her rightful place in Beatles history.

title: Hugh Laurie Sings the Blues
description: Heres my favorite Laurie story: Before House, the producers were auditioning actors for the lead role. Laurie was on location in the Sahara or someplace equally remote, filming Flight of the Phoenix, so he sent in a video audition. They hired him on the basis of that video. I read a comment the producer made that they were not familiar with Laurie and had no idea that he was British; his American accent is that good. Ive watched a lot of BBC, and I can attest that Britons often do appalling American accents (I can only presume the reverse also holds true). Watching every episode of House, I think Ive caught only one accent mishap.

title: Where Steel Meets Sky
description: I used to build scaffolding for ironworkers some years ago, and I never met a tougher or tighter-knit group of guys, their silver hats distinguishing them as the aristocrats of blue-collar workers. Much of their banter recalled fliers, fellow workers who had gone down on past jobs. Rather than braggadocio, I took this as their way of reminding themselves to avoid making a fatal misstep. No one ever took more pride in their job than those guys.

title: What the Left Doesnt Understand About Obama
description: Jonathan Chait fundamentally misunderstands the lefts disapproval of President Obama. Yes, dissatisfaction with his handling of the stimulus and recession factors into it, but more important, the left finds him politically feckless and to have abandoned principles without having won political battles. His desire to create comity is admirable in theory, but compromise for its own sake is neither effective nor politically desirable. Perhaps we on the left misjudged Candidate Obama, but his campaign rhetoric was far more progressive than his presidency has been. We know hes constrained by the Republican House, though there are areas in which he could achieve change, like closing Guantnamo, protecting whistle-blowers or, most important, withdrawing forces from Afghanistan. He could use ye olde Bully Pulpit to advocate progressive ideals vocally. Thats what the left wanted to see from Obama and why we are dissatisfied with him now.

title: Questions For Carine Roitfeld
description: Is Carine Roitfelds antimules screed a shoe jab at Anna Wintour? Is it a coincidence that Wintour, editor of Roitfelds once-frenemy magazine, American Vogue, spends half the year wearing Manolo Blahnik slides  which, for all intents and purposes, are open-toe mules?

title: Syrias Sons of No One
description: Terrific reporting and a rare insight into the why of the revolution. This reporter risked his life for this article. Thank you for that.

title: The Old Fish Market Cleans Up Good
description: The South Street Seaport is emerging as a residential neighborhood.

title: How Parenting Has Changed in 10 Years
description: I Dont Know How She Does It, the movie, opens today, a decade after Allison Pearson wrote I Dont Know How She Does It, the book. They are both about a mother of two, Kate Reddy, who works in finance and frantically juggles home and office. But its the differences between them that I want to talk about on Motherlode today.

title: Childrens Bookshelf: Fairy and Folk Tales
description: Pamela Paul reviews new childrens books about fairy and folk tales.

title: Photos of the Moment | Marc Jacobs
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#319", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Kava Gornas New York Fashion Week photo diary.

title: Palestinians Set Bid for U.N. Seat, Clashing With U.S.
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, announced Friday that he would seek membership for a state of Palestine from the United Nations Security Council next week, putting him on a collision course with Israel and the United States as both face an Arab world in turmoil.

title: Steps Away but Worlds Apart in New York
description: For decades, the intersection of Park Avenue and 96th Street has remained one of the citys most obvious and despairing emblems of disparity, with East Harlem and its challenges spreading out to the north, and a vast gridlock of extraordinary privilege colonizing the acreage below. It is worth debating whether a visit to this corner ought to be mandated for tourists; few spots so profoundly render the truths of New Yorks economic extremism. Liberal parents hoping to foster their own political values in their children might consider pilgrimages. When I stood there, as a teenager, for the first time in the early 1980s, I felt a call to fierce and equalizing justice, ready, suddenly, for Latin American guerrilla work and the Red Brigades.

title: The Fish Market Cleans Up Good
description: WHEN Gary Fagin began renting in a dilapidated former sausage factory in the South Street Seaport area 25 years ago, fishmongers plied the cobblestone streets, carcasses of mackerel and cod were often underfoot, and the bar at Jeremys Ale House was packed at 8 oclock in the morning.

title: Maglen & Louis
description: In this video, Maglen Kaiser says she first noticed Louis Epsteins eyes and Louis says he noticed Maggies dry sense of humor.

title: At San Gennaro, Offerings More Worthy of a Saint
description: O tourists with your plastic bongs brimming with banana daiquiris: pause a moment as you weave down Mulberry Street in the coming week and consider the saint in whose honor  you are blessed with free refills and fried Oreos and sound-activated light-up T-shirts.

title: An Essayist in Love with Seattle, Sailing and the Open Road
description: For the essayist the past is less a foreign country than a home address, a lodestar or touchstone, in Phillip Lopate's words the Aladdins lamp which he or she never tires of rubbing. It is more markedly so in a collection assembled over time, or in the case of Jonathan Raban, over the two decades this eloquent Englishman has spent in America. Raban presents his selections humbly, mindful of the gap that separates American from British English. The longer I stay here, he writes, the more conscious I am of nuances to which I must still remain deaf. It is impossible not to take to the author of a book called Driving Home who reveals that on his arrival he made the greatest of idiomatic American mistakes: he bought the wrong car. Less than gently, the woman for whom he had crossed the ocean translates. What message does his black Dodge Daytona communicate? Midlife crisis, she answers. Who drives them? he asks. Kids. Black teenagers. Gang members, she replies, crisply. She sounds very much aware that she is interpreting for a man who previously assumed Oregon to be an invention of Bernard Malamud.

title: H.G. Wells, the Man Who Invented Tomorrow
description: The stupefyingly prolific H. G. Wells published more than a hundred books and slept with well over a hundred women in his lifetime. But whos counting? David Lodge, thats who. Some of Wellss works, including the briskly entertaining science fiction classics The Time Machine and The War of the Worlds, are as familiar as any in English; others, like the appallingly named novel The Bulpington of Blup (you can look it up) have sunk from view.

title: What Happens When a Mathematician Marries a Painter?
description: The novel opens with a hand growing cold. Nina Hoffman is sitting by the body of her husband, Philip, who has died of heart failure on his bed while she was making supper, boiling new potatoes, taking the chicken out of the oven. In her all-night vigil by his side, her mind moves back over the past, remembering, imagining, wondering.

title: Famine, the Unnecessary Evil
description: You and I and everyone we know are always living only a few weeks of food away from famine psychosis. Heres how it goes. Deprived of meals, your body starts to consume itself. It uses up the glucose stored in your liver and body fats. It uses up the proteins in its own muscles and cells. Rapidly, your body starts to mock you: your belly swells as if you are becoming fat, because the breakdown of muscle causes the remaining fat to bunch there.

title: Blacks, Whites and the Wedding Gap
description: The unmarried black woman is a figure of cultural fascination these days. Cable news specials, popular books by Steve Harvey and T. D. Jakes, the films of Tyler Perry, and newspaper articles about single black women and their children born out of wedlock send waves of dismay through the American public. The explanations offered for this phenomenon tend to be of two sorts: prurient accounts of black male promiscuity and irresponsibility, or caricatures of aggressive and unreasonable black women. It is rare for the popular media to include careful social or historical analyses. Rather, they are often purveyors of a moral panic presented without root or reason.

title: The Dinner Guest Who Never Left
description: Ali Smith loves words. She loves playing with them, calling attention to them, listening to them as if they were members of a vast extended family, each precious in its own right and she their fair-minded parent, determined not to play favorites. She can give the word but such a star turn that you wonder why youd ever taken it for granted.

title: From Gandhi to Gatsby
description: The project of the Indian republic has never been short on ambition. It now cinches 1.2 billion people into a pluralist democracy, and its recent experiments with economic reform have made the project still bolder. Perhaps this is why the moment seems to call for nonfiction about India that must match its subject for ambition. The platonic ideal of this book requires it to be rewarding to both Indians and outsiders; to possess the fluid art of literature but also the sweat-stained craft of journalism; to be encyclopedic and anecdotal; and to seek, within its characters, metaphors for their country at large.

title: Coming to Terms With the Experience of Combat
description: A soldier comes home from war. His wifes welcome is extravagant, fit for a god. Refusing to let his feet touch the ground, she unrolls a new carpet, plush and crimson. She tells him he is like the sun, bringing warmth in winter, and predicts that he will again be master . . . of his house, fulfilled. Then the man takes a bath, an act of literal and symbolic cleansing after a long journey and an even longer, deeply compromising war. And there he dies, stabbed by his wife, in bath water polluted by his own blood.

title: By the Ayatollahs Decree
description: On the night of Sept. 17, 1992, two armed men entered the Mykonos restaurant in Berlin and shot dead a visiting Kurdish leader of the Iranian opposition, his two aides and an exiled dissident. The visiting dignitary, Sadegh Sharafkandi, was the chairman of Irans Democratic Party of Kurdistan and had come to Berlin to address the International Congress of the Social Democratic Party. The dinner at Mykonos, attended by members of the exiled Iranian community, was to honor his visit. It had been arranged at a moment of optimism for many of the exiles, when the president of Iran, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, was calling on them to return home, promising moderation and reconciliation.

title: When Spain Led the World
description: Hugh Thomass big new book falls firmly into the genre of Nobody Does This Anymore. The Golden Empire is the second installment in a multivolume history of the rise of the Spanish Empire. The whole enterprise will surely comprise 2,000 pages or more; this present book clocks in at almost 700 pages, including five of intricate genealogical charts. The last historian of imperial Spain to work on this scale published his first volume in 1918, and the fourth and final volume didnt appear for 26 years. Baron Thomas of Swynnerton, as Thomas is officially known, works much faster. If he keeps up the present rate of production, he might be able to lay down his pen after only 16.

title: Denis Johnsons Tragedy-in-the-Woods Novella
description: Sometimes, if you wander long enough out-of-doors, you look up and find yourself in a suddenly devastating place: on a glittering slab of granite, say, hanging a thousand feet above a mountain lake. Your blood quickens, the clouds stretch, the light turns everything to gold and something enters you, shakes you, seizes some root of your soul and pulps it. Maybe you make your way down to the lake for a swim, or just sit beneath the sky for an hour, dazzled, but what lasts is the feeling that you have found something important, something precious, something that would be world-renowned if only it werent so hard to find.

title: Northern Exposure
description: Joe Fresh, the popular Canadian fashion brand, is finally coming stateside. Its first Manhattan location, at 110 Fifth Avenue, opens in early November, and a splashy Midtown flagship will follow in the spring. Joe Mimran, the companys founder and creative director, knows a thing or two about making covetable but affordable clothing: he founded Club Monaco in 1985. An avid art collector, Mr. Mimran was inspired by the painter Peter Doigs magical landscapes when designing this chunky hand-knitted sweater, which will be available when stores open.

title: The Unacknowledged Victories of the American Left
description: We might as well call it: The American left is dead. Faced with the greatest crisis of capitalism in almost a century, the left has mounted no effective mass protests, inspired no significant uprisings, spawned no major institutions or policy revolutions. In Wisconsin, labor unions lost their greatest public battle since Ronald Reagans showdown with air traffic controllers. In the midterm elections, the Tea Party, not the left, took advantage of economic discontent to upend the status quo. Today, the dream of socialism exists mostly as a far-right phantom, to be conjured up when Democrats dare to imply that Medicare or Social Security might serve the public good.

title: A Novel of India, Pakistan and How Their Elites Failed
description: Rehan Tabassum is in a bad way. Although, strictly speaking, the trouble isnt of his making. Hes just got that kind of family  prone to falling in love with the servants, scheming against one another, messing with the wrong fundamentalist and leaving sensitive home videos lying about. The Tabassums, owners of a telecommunications empire in Pakistan, are a brutal, blundering clan grown crooked and strange after years of bending to the will of their autocratic patriarch. Their methods are medieval, but theyre punished for their excesses and brutality in distinctly modern ways: theyre blackmailed via text messages and pilloried in the comments of Internet articles.

title: The Love for One Orange
description: WHEN asked what they like best about living in South Orange, residents almost invariably cite three attributes: the rich and varied architecture, the demographic diversity, and the easy commute into Manhattan. The latter two have a lot to do with the fact that New York City is the point of origin for a high percentage of South Oranges residents.

title: A Hail-Mary Pass as the Clock Runs Down
description: THE phrase troubled adoptions brings to mind rescued pit bulls or the neglected children from third-world orphanages. Now theres an automotive analog to trouble prospective parents: the cars of Swedens embattled Saab.

title: Flexing Some Korean Muscle
description: TESTED 2012 Hyundai Genesis 5.0 R-Spec

title: A Deaf Boys New York Quest
description: Sequels and seconds-in-a-series are as often as not better than the starter volume, and yet it seems incumbent upon us all to doubt them anyway. Through the Looking Glass is an incomparably better book than its predecessor  its chess-problem structure more ingenious; its nonsense poems far more inspired  but we still say Alice in Wonderland and always shall when we refer to Carrolls world. Freshness of vision is in all departments of life an aesthetic category not to be sneezed at.

title: Big Deal | Jehovahs Witnesses List Prime Properties
description: As the Jehovahs Witnesses prepare to move their headquarters out of Brooklyn, where their Watchtower sign has long been a fixture of the cityscape, they are selling two town houses, two brownstones and a carriage house on prime Brooklyn Heights blocks.

title: More Accidental Drug Poisonings of Children
description: The growing use of prescription drugs by adults, from pain relievers to sleep aids and heart medications, has led to an increase in accidental drug poisonings of children, new research shows.

title: A Decemberists Tale of a Fantastical Portland
description: Portland, Ore., is an analog town, a city of bicycles and bookstores and Douglas firs and old pubs with splintery wooden bars and hulking industrial-era bridges. Its a town where the bookish, bewhiskered, occasionally bowler-hatted band members of the Decemberists can play perfect homegrown rock. Now the bands singer, Colin Meloy, has written a fantasy adventure set, appropriately, in the green heart of the city.

title: Car of Tomorrow Gets Fuel System of Today
description: WHEN the 2012 Nascar season roars to life in Florida next February, racecars in the Sprint Cup series will have undergone one of their biggest changes in decades. But the difference wont be visible to spectators in the stands or fans watching on TV.

title: How to Win at Scrabble in a Parallel Universe
description: Even in a literary cosmos populated by teenage wizards and smart alecks, the characters in Meg Wolitzers first young adult novel might seem fantastical bordering on ridiculous. Kids obsessed with Scrabble? Who play in a national championship? With a first prize of $10,000? Come on.

title: What the Zagabog Knew
description: For this revival of The Flint Heart, a wonderful British fantasy by Eden Phillpotts first published in 1910, we can thank Katherine Paterson, the well-known author and current national ambassador for young peoples literature, and her husband, John, who at the request of their publisher freely abridged the original.

title: Bookshelf: Fairy and Folk Tales
description: KING HUGOS HUGE EGO  Written and illustrated by Chris Van Dusen 36 pp. Candlewick Press. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: Bound by Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Preferred Pronouns
description: To the Editor:

title: Concept of Mine
description: To the Editor:

title: Chanel and the Germans
description: To the Editor:

title: Voltaires Punching Bag
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Sprites
description: Ryan McGinley captures dancers from New York City Ballet's Ocean's Kingdom on the Hudson waterfront.

title: The Childrens Authors Who Broke the Rules
description: The stylistic eccentricities of Maurice Sendak, Shel Silverstein and Theodor Geisel, a k a Dr. Seuss, are so much a part of the childhood vernacular today that its hard to imagine their books were once considered by some to be wholly inappropriate for children.

title: Art, Poetry, Murder
description: After dispatching Chief Inspector Armand Gamache to Quebec City in her last novel, Bury Your Dead, Louise Penny finds good cause to draw the discerning head of the homicide division of the Sret du Qubec back to Three Pines, a village so tiny and secretive it doesnt appear on any maps. It could not be found unless you were lost, she explains, with the exactitude of language thats crucial to the psychological subtlety of her characters  and the delight she takes in them.

title: Up Front: Imani Perry
description: Imani Perry, a distinguished scholar of law, literature, and American culture and history who is currently on the faculty of the Center for African American Studies at Princeton, this week reviews Is Marriage for White People? by the Stanford law professor Ralph Richard Banks. Combining academic research with personal interviews, Bankss book investigates trends in marriage among African-Americans and asks how these may extend to society at large. Perry said via e-mail that she favors Bankss approach: Its wonderful to match up human voices with more abstract analyses. I believe in employing many tools for pursuing an answer to a challenging problem. Ill read poetry, neuroscience, psychology, media studies, and political, literary and social theory, all for a single project.

title: Digital Diary: Becoming an Alarmist
description: Im in the market for a new gadget. But Im not shopping for a shiny new tablet or phone, no. Neither of those.

title: At the Tippler: High-Concept Blender Drinks and Shot Pairings
description: Tad Carducci  one of the founders of the new Chelsea bar the Tippler and half of the cocktail consulting team called the Tippling Bros.  wants his new saloon to be a local bar that appeals to all thirsts, not another haute cocktail emporium.

title: Editors Choice
description: THAT USED TO BE US: How America Fell Behind in the World It Invented and How We Can Come Back,  by Thomas L. Friedman and Michael Mandelbaum (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) A call for more public-spiritedness on the part of elite Americans.

title: Paperback Row
description: A JOURNEY: My Political Life,  by Tony Blair (Vintage, $19.) In this engrossing memoir the former British prime minister traces his political ambitions and principles, and assesses his role in shaping recent historical events: the remaking of the Labour Party, the power-sharing agreement in Northern Ireland and the divisive decision to go to war in Iraq.

title: Leah Cohen on her new novel, The Grief of Others; the art of childrens books; and best-seller news.
description: This week, Leah Cohen talks about her new novel, The Grief of Others; Adam Gopnik and Pamela Paul discuss the art of childrens books and the art of writing about them; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Guest No Longer, Conductor Raises His Profile at Met
description: WITH the news this month that James Levine had slipped and injured a vertebra while vacationing in Vermont, necessitating emergency surgery and forcing him to withdraw from all of his commitments at the Metropolitan Opera at least through the rest of the year, Fabio Luisi became the companys music director in all but name.

title: Christina Hendricks in 'Mad Men'
description: The actress is nominated for best supporting actress in a drama for her work on the AMC series.

title: On Common Ground: The Pairing of Piano Men
description: JAZZ pianists spend a lot of time alone with their craft, and often just as much in the context of a rhythm section. Its less common for them to sit down and make music with each other, though it does happen every now and then. (It happened a lot in the 1930s among Harlem stride masters, behind closed doors, in clubby camaraderie.) The scarcity is enough to make you notice a good piano-duo album when it arrives. This fall, oddly enough, there are a few, two of them due out on Tuesday.

title: Inside the List
description: LESSONS FROM TWAIN: Next month, the perennial best sellers David Baldacci, John Grisham and Jodi Picoult will appear together at Yale to discuss Mark Twains influence on their work. Its not the most intuitive topic, as Picoult acknowledges: Most of my Twain was read when I was a student, the same as most American kids, she said by phone recently from her home in New Hampshire, and I havent had the time to reread him since. Yet Picoult  who spent nine weeks on the hardcover fiction list this spring with Sing You Home, a novel about gay parenthood and embryonic rights  argues convincingly for Twain as a role model, emphasizing how he balanced social commentary with a commercial fiction appeal.

title: Conjuring Abstraction and Subtlety Onstage
description: IWILL watch Jodi Melnick do pretty much anything. More than watch, I will be transfixed. All she has to do is unfurl one of those marvelously expressive arms of hers or step through a phrase so delicately wrought it might almost not be there, and Im hooked, sent over the moon by her ability to conjure, just for a moment, those subtle, passing states of mind and emotion that suffuse the human condition.

title: A Writer of Bodies Delves Into Survival
description: WITH so much turmoil in the world, isnt it time for some inspiring dance? Something that indicates the delicate line between struggle and hope? Rachid Ouramdane is coming to town, and Ive never seen anything by him that hasnt made my jaw drop.

title: Philip Glass, A Minimalist Maximized
description: WHEN the notion of the Park Avenue Armorys becoming a temporary home for the New York Philharmonic during a proposed refurbishing of Avery Fisher Hall (still waiting) was raised, listeners were understandably skeptical: could the hangarlike Wade Thompson Drill Hall possibly be configured as an acoustically appropriate space for concert performances? Those doubts began to vanish in 2008, when the Lincoln Center Festival presented Bernd Alois Zimmermanns opera Die Soldaten at the armory. And in February, the armory itself brought in Eighth Blackbird, the adventurous new-music ensemble, to assemble its first Tune-In Festival, which was judged a hit.

title: Preaching With Gerard Butler
description: TORONTO  The Marc Forster film Machine Gun Preacher is based on the true story of Sam Childers, a Pennsylvania biker and former drug dealer who found religion and became an advocate for the children of war-torn Sudan. Mr. Childers is played by Gerard Butler, who also is appearing in another Toronto film: Ralph Fienness version of Coriolanus. Mr. Butler spoke about his role in Machine Gun Preacher and the techniques he used to embody the character of Mr. Childers.

title: For This Director, Mozarts Message Is That Love Hurts
description: CHRISTOPHER ALDENS production of Mozarts Cos Fan Tutte for New York City Opera will be set in a park as night falls, enveloping the characters in darkness as they play out the plots cruel game: two men, egged on by an older friend, disguise themselves to test their fiances fidelity, a test both fail.

title: Pride at the Piano: Schiff Playing Bartok
description: PIANOPHILES in New York are privileged to hear many first-rate concerts each season by rising stars and established pianists. But only a few of them  including Mitsuko Uchida, Martha Argerich and Andras Schiff  can be counted on for revelatory and transcendent interpretations.

title: Photos of the Moment | Threeasfour
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#690", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Perry Sharpens His Attacks on Romney
description: NEWTON, Iowa  On the campaign trial in Iowa, Texas Gov. Rick Perry isnt answering questions  or even taking questions  on any of the key issues his Republican rivals attacked him on during last Mondays debate. Instead, hes sharpening his attacks on Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor.

title: Romney Tries to Pin Familiar Flip-Flop Label on Perry
description: Mitt Romney has struggled for years to shake off a politically damaging reputation as a flip-flopper.

title: DC Comics Writer Resigns From Static Shock Series
description: A few days into a much-publicized shakeup of its superhero titles, DC Comics has experienced a less pleasant tremor with the resignation of the writer of Static Shock, one of 52 comic books that the publisher restarted at issue No. 1 this month.

title: U.A.W. Reaches Tentative Agreement With General Motors
description: DETROIT  The United Automobile Workers and General Motors said late Friday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new labor contract.

title: Calls for Shakeup in White House That Prizes Constancy
description: He has probably been quoted more than any pundit on the planet since 1992 (which, by the way, was the last time he actually won an American campaign), but when James Carville opens his mouth, Democrats still tend to listen. And so it got a lot of people talking this week when Mr. Carville, in an open letter for President Obama on CNNs Web site, urged the struggling president to follow the example of some of his predecessors and just fire a bunch of people.

title: The Bounty of Solitude
description: LESLIE FEIST, the songwriter who records as Feist, led a visitor up a winding trail to a hilltop with expansive views of treetops and a reservoir. Bounding ahead were her two mongrel dogs: the white Sasha, described by her owner as hyperemotional, sometimes gets depressed, and the black Bentley, whos just out for a good time. Feist added, Theyre both like me.

title: The Golden Empire
At Audi Display in Frankfurt, One Ring to Rule Them
description: FRANKFURT  From the company identified by four rings, came one very big ring.

title: There but for the
description: There

title: Korea Envoys to Discuss Resuming Nuclear Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The top nuclear negotiators from North and South Korea plan to meet next week in Beijing to discuss terms of restarting the long-stalled six-nation talks aimed at ending North Koreas nuclear weapons program, a senior government official here said Friday.

title: The Caucus | Cooperation Remains Elusive
description: In Washington, developments this week tempered some of the hope for bipartisan cooperation. Meanwhile, a new Times/CBS News poll shows Congressional disapproval at record levels.

title: This Time Its Crosswords (Not Cross Words) That Surface From Sondheim
description: For decades they have been an elusive collectors item sought by puzzle fans and musical theater aficionados alike: The cryptic crosswords that the celebrated composer Stephen Sondheim created for New York magazine in the late 1960s and that were later compiled in a book that has long been out of print. But earlier this week some online chat sites devoted to puzzles began to buzz about a Web site that included scans of 19 crosswords that were apparently the Sondheim mother lode. These are the gold standard for sure! one commenter gushed on Facebook.

title: Gundlach Found Liable in Trade Secret Case, but He Wins Back Pay
description: A bitter trial that rattled the normally quiet world of mutual funds came to an unusual end on Friday, as a jury awarded Jeffrey E. Gundlach, a star bond fund manager, millions of dollars in unpaid compensation even though it found him liable for breaching his fiduciary duty and stealing trade secrets at his former firm, Trust Company of the West.

title: Runway In Review
description: Calvin Klein CollectionDesigner: Francisco CostaDate and Location: Thursday, 205 West 39th StreetPhotos: slide show

title: Ameriprise Speaks With a New Voice
description: With Labor Day in the rearview mirror, Madison Avenue is fully engaged in bringing out new advertising campaigns for scores of marketers. The idea is to connect with consumers during the important fall and Christmas shopping seasons.

title: Caucus Video: Hope Tempered for Cooperation; Voter Disapproval of Congress at Record Levels
description: In Washington, developments this week tempered some of the hope for bipartisan cooperation. Meanwhile, a new New York Times/CBS News poll shows Congressional disapproval at record levels.

title: Artists Support Global Fund Health Efforts
description: A diverse group of actors and artists has come out in support of a global charity that fights some of the worlds deadliest diseases.

title: Drop of Opera in a Downpour of Pop
description: Ordinarily it is difficult for officials to estimate the crowd size for a concert in Central Park. But every attendee at Thursday nights free performance there by the superstar crossover tenor Andrea Bocelli had to have a ticket, obtained in advance. And 60,000 were given out.

title: Step Away From the Fashion Police
description: I work with a woman who never left 1985: She clips a fake ponytail into her hair (with scrunchies to match her outfits), curls her bangs and wears blue eye shadow. We got along pretty well  until I got drunk at a company party and told her she was one banana clip away from appearing as a Dont Do This! model in a womens magazine. (I also told her shes a great person.) The next day, the fake hair was gone, which she made a point of showing me. Now I feel guilty. Who am I to tell her how to look? Should I apologize?

title: Two Venture Capitalists Exit Twitter Board
description: Twitter confirmed on Friday that two of its board members, Fred Wilson, a principal at the venture capital firm Union Square Ventures, and Bijan Sabet, a general partner at Spark Capital, have left the board.

title: Retired, Perhaps, but Still on the Case
description: If you were looking to stick up a restaurant on Thursday night, the Battery Gardens restaurant in Lower Manhattan would have been a bad choice.

title: Faces to Watch
description: Five performers from this season of fall movies find themselves on the verge.

title: Sept. 18-Sept. 24
description: Theater

title: How to Rate 401(k) Plans and Investment Advisers
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I chronicle the adventures of the BrightScope brothers, two young men who aim to rate every 401(k) and 403(b) retirement plan and publish a directory of every investment adviser, too.

title: Spotlighting 401(k) Plans, Thanklessly
description: SAN DIEGO  Up the stairs from the Chicken of the Sea offices in the northern reaches of this city, two brothers and about three dozen of their employees mine databases in a fledgling effort to help Americans retire a little sooner and manage their money a little better.

title: Multimedia | Rauschenbergs Photos
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#263", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: There Shall Come a Titan
description: The New Teen Titans omnibus, Vol. 1, sits atop the hardcover list this week. It reprints the first 16 issues of the 1980s series that brought together a few sidekick heroes (Robin, Kid Flash and Wonder Girl) and teamed them with some new ones (Cyborg, Raven and Starfire). These Titans, written by Marv Wolfman and illustrated by George Prez, become one of DCs most popular books. The stories reprinted in this omnibus edition chronicle the formation of the team, faceoffs with the assassin Deathstroke and the Fearsome Five, a misguided confrontation with the Justice League and a battle royal against Trigon, a demon who is also Ravens father. About midway in there is a day in the life story that focused on the civilian lives of the heroes. That issue cemented this series as doing something different: the creative team was developing three-dimensional characters and exploring new directions.

title: Unbeaten Boxer Pioneers Ways to Make Money Hand Over Fist
description: LAS VEGAS  On Saturday night, Floyd Mayweather Jr. will make tens of millions of dollars for an hours worth of work, if that. He will be paid for what happens inside the ring and outside it, paid far more than any other boxer fighting today, for far more than just his performance in a welterweight title fight against Victor Ortiz.

title: Cold-Water Detergents Get a Cold Shoulder
description: Newly formulated laundry detergents can wash most clothes perfectly well in cold water, manufacturers say, but customers are stubbornly refusing to turn down the temperature. Although some of these detergents have been available for several years, customers cling to moms age-old advice that hot water washes best  squandering energy and contributing to greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Decoding the Wide Variations in House Appraisals
description: IRECENTLY decided to refinance a condominium my wife and I owned in Florida and quickly got caught up in the frustrating and often baffling world of real estate appraisals.

title: Alabama Countys Debt Deal Averts Bankruptcy
description: The governing board of Alabamas most populous county voted Friday to accept an agreement on how to restructure more than $3 billion of debt, avoiding what could have been the biggest municipal bankruptcy filing in American history.

title: Was Pat Robertson Right?
description: The question from a viewer of The 700 Club had likely crossed the minds of hundreds of thousands of people experiencing the slow and inevitable loss of a spouse to Alzheimers disease or another dementia. Could a healthy partner justify a relationship with someone else as a demented spouse declined?

title: Handling Disasters, on Screen or Off, With Aplomb
description: IN the first of two acclaimed performances by Kirsten Dunst at the 64th Cannes Film Festival in May, a rapt audience watched as a dozen emotions  amusement, stoicism, distress, weariness, embarrassment and rue among them  played across her features in a scene in which she was required to maintain her composure at every moment and express an extraordinary range of feeling with almost no dialogue.

title: Wanting to Get Into the Fight, and Failing
description: Just because you volunteer to serve your country does not mean you will ever be sent into harms way, even if you want to. No matter how patriotic or noble your intentions, the needs of the military come first, and that organization is a very focused machine that maintains a combat force structure based on units and their capabilities, not individuals and their desires. That policy has a side effect of leaving some of us bearing a burden of guilt at not having done more.

title: Love, Divorce and Alzheimers
description: The television evangelist Pat Robertson has sparked controversy with his suggestion that a man could divorce his wife with Alzheimers once she no longer recognized him.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $23,680,000
description: A penthouse condominium at the Mayfair on Park Avenue was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.

title: Defiant Crowds Face Deadly Gunfire in Syria
description: Protesters faced down deadly gunfire from Syrian security forces on Friday as they returned to the streets of several restive cities, as Anthony Shadid reports. Videos captured their marches, as well as some of the violence that left dozens dead, the latest in the six-month crackdown that has left more than 2,600 dead.

title: Top Offshore Drilling Regulators Named
description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar on Friday appointed leaders for the two entities that will assume responsibility for offshore oil and gas development.

title: The Kindly Ones
description: Via Reihan Salam, I see that Virginia Postrel has published a tart response to Harvard Colleges attempt to pressure its incoming freshmen into taking a public pledge promising to place the exercise of kindness  on a par with intellectual attainment during their undergraduate careers.

title: Gassing Up Nascar V-8s
description: THE fuel injection systems that will replace four-barrel carburetors on all cars in Nascars top-level Sprint Cup series for 2012 will use some components similar to those found on todays passenger cars and others that are little changed from current racing engines.

title: Musicals Festival Diary: New Mother, Old Habits
description: Being a new mother hasnt stopped the actress Donna Lynne Champlin (Sweeney Todd) from returning to the stage. She is starring in Jane Austens Pride and Prejudice, a Musical, part of the eighth New York Musical Theater Festival, which begins Sept. 26.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday: A Test for Oklahoma
description: No. 1 Oklahoma at No. 5 Florida State 8 p.m., ABC

title: The Taormina Sisters and the Misuraca Brothers
description: THE back-to-back weddings on a rain-drenched day in Gloucester, Mass., might never have happened if Caterina Taorminas older sister Patty Hodges did not have a big mouth.

title: A Park With a Past
description: Coiba National Park in Panama, an isolated marine preserve 14 miles off the Pacific coast, is a paradise for nature lovers.

title: A Panamanian Marine Preserve With a Past
description: A LOGGERHEAD turtle swiveled its spotted head toward me, then disappeared beneath the waves as I slipped over the side of the boat with my snorkel, mask and fins. Instantly, a Technicolor underwater world revealed itself: pastel-patched parrotfish, tiny purple-fairy maidens, big-eyed red squirrelfish and a school of purple finned sturgeonfish darting in and out of orange stag coral and purple sea fans. I followed a slow-moving grouper into deeper water and suddenly, swimming out of the depths, six white-tip sharks emerged, sending me thrashing in the boats direction, calling for a lift out.

title: Emmys Watch: Christina Hendricks on Mad Men
description: Christina Hendricks began as a guest star on Mad Men  she was in only two scenes in the pilot  but her Joan Holloway (now Joan Harris) quickly became one of the most recognizable characters on AMCs perpetually praised midcentury drama.

title: Yanks on the Tube: A Weekend TV Guide
description: You have got to have a plan these days.

title: Meatloaf Again? Not Exactly
description: MY mothers meatloaf was correct  moist, well seasoned, part oatmeal, mostly beef, with a band of bottled red chili sauce down the center. It was dependable, but it was not the stuff of dreams. Other mothers meatloaf recipes sometimes appeared, like a stuffed, cheesy one I liked, but mostly the house version prevailed throughout my childhood. To my emerging sensibilities, the occasional stuffed cabbage was more interesting, and chafing-dish Swedish meatballs had a certain appeal. I also liked the smell of hamburgers before they were cooked, sprinkled with salt and pepper and resting on wax paper.

title: In Buenos Aires, Sips From All Over
description: FOR visitors to Argentina, missing out on Mendoza, the countrys main wine region, doesnt mean missing out on its wines  or, for that matter, those of other Argentine regions. In the last few years, a number of wine-tasting opportunities have opened in Buenos Aires, offering samples of the best the countrys vineyards have to offer.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Mio in Buenos Aires
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Letters: My Kailua
description: My Kailua

title: Suriname, South Americas Hidden Treasure
description: THE road to Atjoni got more interesting as the wind grew stronger, making the surrounding ceiba trees of the Surinamese jungle murmur with whispers of an impending storm. We were hours into the countrys interior when we came across a solitary hunter. He had a shotgun slung from his shoulder and a machete sheathed at his waist. We stopped to talk. After brief introductions, things became complicated.

title: In Uruguay, Bohemian-Chic at the Beach
description: WHEN summer arrives in December, La Pedreras main street bustles with families dining al fresco, sandy-haired teenagers hanging out in board shorts, jazz musicians entertaining passers-by and artisans selling handmade jewelry on makeshift stands.

title: In Argentina, Glaciers by Way of Patagonia
description: THE boat slid across the teal waters of Lago Argentino, and soon we were 900 feet from the Perito Moreno Glacier. Through the morning rain, the glacier loomed above us  a jagged wonder glowing with colors: aquamarine, pure white, pale gray and an otherworldly, nearly fluorescent blue. Every few seconds there was a thunderous crack, and a chunk of ice, distant and unseen, went crashing into the ice field.

title: Street of Art by Buenos Aires
description: In Tigre, outside Buenos Aires, Boulevard Saenz Pea reflects the interests of art lovers.

title: The Charm of Suriname
description: Suriname proves that there are still corners of the world that can provide surprise and adventure.

title: Practice Time for Injured Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  There seemed to be promising developments for the banged-up Giants at practice Friday, with defensive end Justin Tuck and receiver Hakeem Nicks participating in individual drills. Even Osi Umenyiora looked good.

title: New York Fashion Week Diary | Tom Bull
description: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes followed the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigated New York Fashion Week. In this clip, Tom Bull discusses his edgy beard: The amount of commercial clients asking me to get rid of it is crazy. Unless its something big, I wont.

title: New York Fashion Week Diary | Tom Bull
description: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week.

title: Will a Powerful Bank Act the Part?
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank still has plenty of ammunition left in its monetary policy bandoleers. The question is whether it will use it.

title: This week: Jeff Sommer and Gretchen Morgenson on the European crisis and the United States; David Gillen and Graham Bowley on would-be Guggenheims; Robert Frank on The Darwin Economy; and Natasha Singer on online ID privacy.
description: This week: Jeff Sommer and Gretchen Morgenson on the European crisis and the United States; David Gillen and Graham Bowley on would-be Guggenheims; Robert Frank on The Darwin Economy; and Natasha Singer on online ID privacy.

title: For Mercedes-Benz, Its Smart 2.0
description: Mercedes-Benz USA is taking another crack at selling Americans on the mini-size Smart car, which has recently been selling in mini-size numbers after a good start.

title: On Project Runway, a Dose of Reality
description: Real women have curves. That simple fact of anatomy seemed to flummox the contestants on Project Runway last night as they faced what appeared to be their most challenging task of the season: designing clothes suitable for women who dont consider a cigarette and a couple of Altoids a satisfying meal.

title: A People Story, but It Has Dinosaurs, Too
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Video View: Climate Refugees
description: Anyone tracking global issues these days is flooded with multiple fire hoses of material  books, documentaries, blogs and more. This makes it impossible for any individual to assess whats out there. One film I missed is Climate Refugees, a documentary thats done well on the film festival circuit and been lauded by environmentalists. You can read about it on the Green Blog.

title: The Beautiful and the Damned
description: A phenomenally wealthy Indian who excites hostility and suspicion is an unusual creature, a fish that has managed to muddy the waters it swims in. The glow of admiration lighting up the rich and the successful disperses before it reaches him, hinting that things have gone wrong somewhere. It suggests that beneath the sleek coating of luxury, deep under the sheen of power, there is a failure barely sensed by the man who owns that failure along with his expensive accoutrements. This was Arindam Chaudhuris situation when I first met him in 2007. He had achieved great wealth and prominence, partly by projecting an image of himself as wealthy and prominent. Yet somewhere along the way he had also created the opposite effect, which  in spite of his best efforts  had given him a reputation as a fraud, scamster and Johnny-come-lately.

title: A Brother, Lost and Found
description: MY brother Dario was kidnapped for two years. He was taken when he was 7 and returned when he was 9. During his absence, he grew six inches and lost most of his baby teeth.

title: Texas Execution Stayed Based on Race Testimony
description: HOUSTON  In May 1997, a psychologist took the stand in a courtroom here during the sentencing hearing of Duane E. Buck, a black man found guilty of killing his former girlfriend and her friend.

title: Interview: Frederick Wiseman
description: The director Frederick Wiseman discusses his craft and his new documentary "Crazy Horse."

title: Train Dreams
description: Chapter One

title: Berlin Hopes Growing Tech Community Will Lift Citys Economy
description: BERLIN  The courtyard of the nightclub Picknick was packed with partygoers dancing, shouting over the music and snapping photographs of one another, by all appearances just another night in this dilettante party capital. But appearances, on this recent Saturday night, were very much deceiving.

title: Tchaikovsky, Dress Codes, And 3-D Opera
description: Dates and performers are subject to change.

title: More Food Links Than You Can Handle
description: The Nations food issue. (A lot.)

title: Stretching in New Ways and Places
description: Ryo Kase in Restless

title: China Trade Numbers Bear Watching, Up or Down
description: With its imports rising faster than exports, Chinas overall trade surplus is down sharply from where it was before the credit crisis of 2008 and 2009 caused world trade levels to fall drastically. But its surpluses with the United States and some major European countries have risen to record levels.

title: The Problem With Living Wills for Financial Firms
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took an important step this week toward getting big financial institutions, foreign and domestic, to submit resolution plans  also known as living wills or funeral plans  as required by the Dodd-Frank Act. If the new, so-called orderly liquidation authority is going to work, it is going to depend on F.D.I.C.s ability to understand and plan for financial distress in advance. And thus the living wills are key.

title: It Girls, Mad Men and Monster Slayers
description: Dates and titles are subject to change, and all shows are subject to never actually making it on the air.

title: Take Two: T.I. Returns to Halfway House
description: The rapper T.I. finally made it from a federal prison cell to a halfway house in Atlanta, two weeks after officials sent him back to prison because he arrived at the halfway house in a luxury bus with his manager and a television producer who wants to put him in a reality show.

title: Built to Last? Debating the Merits of a National Register of Historic Cars
description: Since 2009, the Historic Vehicle Association, an advocacy group founded by Hagerty Insurance, a company that specializes in insuring vintage vehicles, has advocated for classic autos to be included on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Styled to a T | Tom Marchant
description: The Trend

title: Character Transcripts: Application Components of the Future?
description: This New York Times Magazine this Sunday is dedicated to education.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 16
description: The day in sports included Usain Bolt running the fastest 100 meters of the season in Brussels and sailing in Plymouth, England, for the Americas Cup World Series.

title: Netanyahus Partners, Democracys Enemies
description: Tel Aviv

title: TimesCast | September 16, 2011
description: Palestinians will seek statehood at the United Nations Security Council; Syrian pro-democracy protesters consider armed resistance; and the Tea Party takes on Constitution Day.

title: Giving Okra a Second Chance
description: Okra is one of those foods you either love or hate, depending on your first experience with it. My first okra tasting was at a Texas barbecue joint, where the okra was rolled in cornmeal and fried. Whats not to like?

title: Congo and Kabuki and Salutes to Mr. B
description: Dates are subject to change.

title: Second Time a Charm for CBS
description: In what can be described as a broadcast television calm before the storm of the fall season, CBS won the night over all on Thursday with a slate of repeats. Wipeout on ABC was the only original program on the four big networks, and it finished the season rather meekly, down by 19 percent from last years two-hour finale in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic according to Nielsen data.

title: Perry and Romney Change Tone, and Targets
description: Now, its getting personal.

title: 7 States Join Justice Dept. Suit to Block AT&T Deal
description: Seven states, including California, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois and New York, said Friday they had joined the Justice Departments efforts to block AT&Ts $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA.

title: Members Disapprove of Debt Ceiling Increase, No Matter What Their Votes Say
description: Wednesdays House vote disapproving the recent increase in the nations debt limit was unusual in at least one respect: it drew opposition from five Republicans, including a committee chairman, two of whom now say they didnt mean to oppose the nonbinding resolution.

title: George Shultz on Politics and Budgets
description: I called George Shultz, the former more-or-less everything, this week to see what he thought of the government now. I discovered that he is rankled by the budget process but impressed by at least one candidate for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Q. and A.: The Quest of the Earth Scientist
description: Ralph J. Cicerone, president of the National Academy of Sciences, was back in his old haunt this week, celebrating the 20th anniversary of the University of California, Irvines Department of Earth System Science, which he founded. He later served as the universitys chancellor. Dr. Cicerone spoke with The New York Times about scientific research on the campus, the national attitude toward science today and the scientific questions he would most like to see answered. Following are excepts, edited for brevity and clarity.

title: Baton Diplomacy: Korean Conductor Aims for North-South Concerts
description: 5:26 p.m. | Updated The conductor Myung-whun Chung, who has completed a trip to North Korea, said on Friday that he had pushed for orchestra joint performances involving musicians from the North as well as South Korea.

title: September Release Schedule
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: Debuts, Duets And Bootlegs
description: Dates are subject to change.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Pakistan and France

title: It All Leads to This: Cunninghams Final Bow
description: WHEN the impresario Serge Diaghilev died in 1929, the Ballets Russes  the company he had formed in 1909  folded with him. The sense of loss was so abysslike that in the years that followed several new companies around the Western world (some also bearing the name Ballets Russes) were established to recapture his achievement. Still, much had been lost. Some of his most celebrated dancers retired at once or soon after. Only one of his five choreographers (George Balanchine) went on  eventually  to bigger and better things. Seldom since then has ballet had the same force as a vehicle for the new.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 16
description: Subjects include the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, a special election in the Ninth Congressional District of New York, and new principals for Newark schools.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Pakistan, France and England.

title: Fathers and the XX-Factor
description: SCIENCE confirmed last week what A. J. Jacobs had already feared.

title: How Dads Feel About Lower Testosterone
description: In the Styles section this weekend, Alex Williams looks at how men are taking that study out of Northwestern University showing that testosterone, the most male of hormones, decreases substantially after a man becomes a father.

title: Not Quite Gone, A Punk Band Is Coming Back
description: PROPOSITION: No punk band of the 1990s has been more influential than Blink-182.

title: A Glimpse Into the World of House Appraisals
description: Paul Sullivan writes about the daunting, frustrating world of real estate appraisals in his Wealth Matters column this week. He writes from personal experience, after getting two different appraisals on his Florida condominium, neither of which made sense to him.

title: A Father-Son Journey Continues
description: AMERICANS have elected men to the highest office in the land in the hope that they would be tough but fair, regular guys but still presidential. You know, like Josiah Bartlet, who reigned with dignity for seven seasons on The West Wing on NBC. During some of the more feckless stretches of the presidency people have even suggested that Martin Sheen, who played Bartlet, should give it a whirl for real. Mr. Sheen has heard the cry of the people and is in the midst of a 55-day cross-country bus campaign. But its to persuade his supporters to go out and see The Way, his new film, which was directed by his son Emilio Estevez.

title: The Storyteller Who Returned From the Cold
description: THE Englishman David Cornwell, who writes under the name John le Carr, has been a best-selling novelist for nearly five decades, and he has been, right from the start, an unusually perverse member of that select class: he writes books that practically beg not to be turned into movies. Of his 22 novels nearly all of them about the perennially popular and movie-friendly subject of espionage, a mere 7 have made the perilous border crossing to the big screen. (Three others have been adapted as television mini-series and one more as a stand-alone television movie.)

title: Myung & Aaron
description: In this homemade video, Myung Joh and Aaron Wesner recall meeting at a rooftop party.

title: TimesCast | Constitution Day Politics
description: The Tea Party movement uses a little-known holiday to push its view of the United States Constitution.

title: Movies That Said, Look What I Can Do
description: Citizen Kane (1941)

title: Pasta Swims With the Clams
description: A BOWL of garlicky clams, steamed in their own juices, with white wine, good oil and plenty of fresh herbs, begs for something to sop up the sauce.

title: Legal Assistance in Civil Cases Under Growing Threat
