description: Both houses of Congress have indicated that they plan to cut back federal financing for the Legal Services Corporation, the nations largest provider of money to assist people who cannot afford lawyers in civil cases, according to an article in The National Law Journal.

title: Shooters Face Off, and the Legend of Zelda Continues
description: THIS fall will be the seventh for the current generation of video game consoles, which began with Microsofts introduction of the Xbox 360 in 2005. That means artists, designers and programmers have had a long time to master the intricacies of the 360, as well as two Japanese consoles that arrived in 2006, Sonys PlayStation 3 and Nintendos Wii.

title: On Top of Country but Also Above It
description: THE 27-year-old country singer Miranda Lambert, whose fourth and latest album, Four the Record, comes out Nov. 1, is in the rare position, for any young performer, of having nothing in need of proving. But Four the Record tries hard anyway, moving into layers of alternativeness and smeared genre, in country and rock and folk, and sound itself.

title: Ronaldus Shamask Returns
description: Ronaldus Shamask thinks he was the first designer to show at the New York Public Library, in the Celeste Bartos Forum. He cannot recall the year, but suffice to say the tents and all the hoopla had not yet arrived. I paid $1 for the library, Mr. Shamask, 66, said with a grin on Friday morning in his studio on West 38th Street.

title: TimesCast | Syria's Bloody Uprising
description: Syrian security forces kill at least 29 pro-democracy protesters, as the six-month uprising shows signs of even greater bloodshed to come.

title: The Daily Shoe | Marc Jacobs
description: There was a little bit of everything on the dance floor at Marc Jacobs last night  the Charleston (fringed, dropped-waist flapper dresses); A Chorus Line (models backlit and posed on bentwood chairs); a good old honky-tonk two-step (sharp-heeled cowboy boots). Whats here: a witchy Mary Jane that feels curiously Dirty Dancing-esque in its sexiness.

title: Composer (and Others) Rethinking His Works
description: THROUGHOUT a lengthy, influential career the composer and vocalist Robert Ashley has designed his groundbreaking series of operas  dizzying confluences of spoken and sung words, electronic music, video elements, mystery and charm  to be performed by himself and a tightly knit group of regular collaborators.

title: Sony Changes Gaming Policy to Thwart Future Lawsuits
description: Sony quietly updated its PlayStation Network terms of service agreement on Thursday, adding a new section that will prevent users from joining future class-action lawsuits against the company.

title: Ryan McGinleys Excellent Excursion
description: The setting was stunning. The dancers were heavenly. The magical sunset light was exactly what we aimed for. The smell was not so good.

title: Obama Warns Iceland on Whaling Activity
description: In a move hailed by conservation activists, President Obama initiated potential diplomatic sanctions against Iceland this week for its commercial whaling activity. The sanctions include six measures ranging from possibly limiting cabinet-level visits to Iceland to limiting cooperation with Iceland in the Arctic region.

title: New AIDS Cases Dropped 25% This Year, City Reports
description: In a sign of progress against one of the great plagues of the last generation, a dwindling number of New Yorkers have been diagnosed with AIDS over the last eight years, according to new statistics released Friday.

title: United Technologies Said to Pursue Goodrich
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

title: This Sunday: Exiting the Comfort Zone
description: I met Cliff Levy for the first time when he was in New York to collect his Pulitzer Prize last spring. He came up to my office and pitched a story about how he put his three Brooklyn-bred kids in a Russian school, even though they didnt speak the language, when he was sent to Moscow as a correspondent for The Times. I could hardly say yes fast enough to his story, which I knew would fascinate the many people on this earth obsessed with how best to educate their children. But I also privately wondered if maybe Cliff wasnt a little insane. I have twin daughters who just started kindergarten this week, and though their school could not be a warmer, more welcoming place  they even speak English there!  I still worry about their adjustment to an unfamiliar environment.

title: No Blood, No Gore, Just Megatons of Steel
description: When I could have been doing something healthy recently, like going to the gym, I was probably sniping with a Panzer IV from the escarpments of a desert called El Halluf. When I should have been doing something responsible, like scrubbing the tub, I was probably barreling around a European town called Himmelsdorf in an Easy Eight Sherman. Even when I should have been playing some other game, I was probably playing World of Tanks, a concussively enjoyable, shrewdly designed armored-combat game.

title: New Fantasy: Viewing Like Its 1979
description: IN advance of the debt-ceiling debate in Congress this summer, morning-show pundits repeatedly compared the moment with 1979 both in terms of specific economic realities and the bleak, broader cultural mood. In 1979 the country similarly faced the danger of defaulting on its financial obligations; growth lagged; the Iranian revolution sparked turmoil in the Middle East. Catastrophists found validation for their unease in the disaster at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania just as bizarre shifts in weather patterns today seem to confirm our darkest worries about global warming.

title: Beethoven, Messiaen and Background Checks
description: Listeners and performers are often curious about what inspired a particular piece of music. But in the opening program of his engaging Reflections series on Wednesday evening, Divine Inspiration or Intelligent Design?, the violinist Gil Morgenstern pondered whether knowing the source of inspiration actually enhances the experience for musician or audience.

title: A Mash-Up of Extras
description: Forget the fascinator, the Duchess of Cambridges topper of choice. Some of the most arresting heads this week were wrapped and tied retro-style in a manner evoking Lucille Ball.

title: Book Review Podcast: Leah Hager Cohens The Grief of Others
description: On the cover of this Sundays Book Review, Susann Cokal reviews Leah Hager Cohens new book, The Grief of Others, a novel in which a family sinks beneath the weight of a terrible secret.

title: Too Little, Too Late?
description: The company may be on the verge of collapse, but Saabs 9-4X luxury crossover shows plenty of merit.

title: Ads Promote Butcher Shops Sultry Poultry
description: Two students who just graduated from the Miami Ad School have something more to show prospective employers than portfolios.

title: A Mash-Up of Extras
description: Forget the fascinator, the Duchess of Cambridges topper of choice. Some of the most arresting heads this week were wrapped and tied, retro-style, in a manner evoking Lucille Ball.

title: It Sure Beats Sitting on the Tarmac
description: Imagine Borat doing dinner theater, and youll have a pretty good sense of whether youll enjoy The Lapsburgh Layover.

title: Where the Big Girls Are | Outtakes From New York Fashion Week
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#105", 592, 400, false, chameleonData);

title: F.Y.I.: George Never Shows
description: I had high hopes about George Clooney.

title: Excerpt: 'Terra Nova'
description: The ambitious time traveling Fox series begins on Sept. 26.

title: Excerpt: 'The Playboy Club'
description: The period drama on NBC is set in a Playboy Club in Chicago in the 1960s.

title: Excerpt: 'Free Agents'
description: The NBC sitcom revolves around co-workers who became involved.

title: House Republicans Outline Common Ground on Jobs
description: House Republican leaders Friday rejected key elements of President Obamas jobs plan, but told their rank-and-file members they would support other components, from the well-publicized - like a extension of the current payroll tax holiday - to the more obscure, such as continuing depreciation write-offs for businesses.

title: Obama Presses Iceland Over Fin Whale Hunt
description: On Thursday, President Obama ordered government agencies to ramp up pressure on Iceland to end its slaughter of endangered fin whales, the second largest whale species. But the president stopped short of imposing trade sanctions. He issued a Message to Congress with the details, including this passage:

title: Amid Talk of Expansion, No. 1 Oklahoma Pulls Attention to Its Play
description: College footballs continuing turmoil has provided a protective cloak of sorts around the Oklahoma Sooners and their No. 1 ranking.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 10-15 with 1,452 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,356 said they were registered to vote.

title: Cuomo to Cruise in His Corvette on Long Island
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, like many elected officials, is an old hand at walking parade routes. But this weekend, he is planning a more unusual public appearance: driving in a car cruise, scheduled for Sunday on Long Island.

title: Support for Obama Slips; Unease on 2012 Candidates
description: President Obamas support is eroding among elements of his base, and a yearlong effort to recapture the political center has failed to attract independent voters, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, leaving him vulnerable at a moment when pessimism over the countrys direction is greater than at any other time since he took office.

title: Ensuring the Safety of Oil and Gas Pipelines
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackies White House Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Times Poll on Jobs and Election
description: President Obamas support Is slipping, poll finds, but his jobs plan is well received. Republican remain uneasy on their presidential candidates.

title: Bringing Nascar to Race Fans, One Spray n Wax at a Time
description: For a sport whose founding myth is steeped in Appalachian mud and moonshine, Nascar has a curious preoccupation with cleanliness. Drivers are expected to play nice with the media, talk glowingly of their sponsors and avoid, for the most part, racing dirty. Now, stock-car fans can affect the same virtue as their favorite drivers, if only for a few minutes at the car wash.

title: Kill the Alarm and Rev Up the Vespa
description: David Karp, 25, the founder and chief executive of Tumblr, lives his life out loud on his sleek blogging platform. He and his girlfriend, Rachel Eakley, who is a trained chef and a graduate student in psychology, recently moved to the West Village, where they spend their weekends exploring their new neighborhood and playing with their puppy, Clark, a French-English bulldog mix. Pictures from their meandering Sundays just might end up on Mr. Karps Tumblr.

title: Jane Lynch Finds Herself
description: THIS is like a bad first date, I think. I discreetly dab my face, sweating like Albert Brooks in Broadcast News, as Jane Lynch sits quietly beside me, all eight feet of her.

title: Excerpt: 'Pan Am'
description: The ABC period drama follows Pan Am stewardesses in the 1960s.

title: Verlander Could Reach Rarefied Air
description: The wins just keep piling up for Justin Verlander, the Detroit Tigers ace. On Tuesday, his seven scoreless innings propelled Detroit to a 5-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox, the 23rd time this season that Verlander was the pitcher of record in a Tigers win. If Verlander can win his final two starts of the regular season, he will become the first 25-game winner in more than 20 years.

title: The U.N. Vote on a Palestinian State
description: To the Editor:

title: A Way Out of the Labor Stalemate
description: Somewhere between the foolish ravings of hard-line owners and the players union myopia lies an N.B.A. collective bargaining agreement that is ready to be wrapped and tied  just not too tight.

title: Bikes in the City: Pleasures and Perils
description: To the Editor:

title: Striding Confidently Toward the Light
description: By the end of Fashion Week, we had seen many a woman with a wan, scornful mouth. We had seen a surplus of blue crepe de Chine, rippling white, and rooms gaudy with primary colors, and hair shorn in strange new ways. If any of us had looked, we might even have seen Daisys green light.

title: Fast and Furious for a Designer Week
description: OLIVIA MUNN, 31, is a correspondent for The Daily Show With Jon Stewart and a featured actress in the film I Dont Know How She Does It. She is based in Los Angeles but visited New York for Fashion Week.

title: Even in a Swoony Show, Innocence Stays Intact
description: For how long can one singing actor embody an ingenuous golden boy exempt from the laws of nature? That question occurred to me while watching Howard McGillins swoony show Isnt It Romantic? at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 16
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, a special election in the Ninth Congressional District of New York, and new principals for Newark schools.

title: Where Graffiti Met Old Masters, Under Riverside Park
description: From 1980 to 1996, Chris Pape painted huge murals on the walls of an abandoned underground freight train passageway. Surprisingly, many survived leaks, soot and other vandals.

title: Words With Strangers
description: MY frequent online Scrabble opponent of the last few days has sent me a message saying hes sorry, but he cant play right now. He has a stomach bug/malaria, he writes. Such are the considerations when your opponent lives in Ghana.

title: TimesCast | Palestinian Statehood Vote
description: September 16, 2011 - Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas says he will seek formal recognition of a Palestinian state at the U.N. Security Council next week.

title: October Release Schedule
description: OCTOBER

title: Driving the Saab 9-4X
description: A couple of weeks ago, when I took delivery of a Saab 9-4X test car for a few days, a wistful thought arrived with the keyfob: this could well be the last new Saab Id ever drive.

title: November Release Schedule
description: NOVEMBER

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 8
description: Scenes from Thursday: The Daphne Guinness show at F.I.T. and Marc Jacobs at the Gallery.

title: December Release Schedule
description: DECEMBER

title: Sgt. Brian Keith
description: After a year in Afghanistan, Sgt. Brian Keith talks about seeing his young son for the first time.

title: Interview with Sgt. Jerry Price
description: Sgt. Jerry Price describes the experience of being trapped in a minefield on Qurghan Tapa hill in Afghanistan.

title: Staff Sgt. Jonathon Clark Interview
description: About halfway through his deployment, Staff Sgt. Jonathon Clark reflects on what it was like to see his family while on leave.

title: James Franco and Other Art Stars of the Toronto Film Festival
description: TORONTO  It is increasingly de rigeur for film festivals to encompass much more than film. Many major festivals now supplement screenings with installations and performances, and entire sections are devoted to exploring the intersection of cinema and the other arts. The Rotterdam Film Festival pioneered this kind of cross-disciplinary programming in the 90s. Berlin has an annual Forum Expanded mini-festival, which spills logically into the museums and galleries of an art-centric city. Sundance has a New Frontier sidebar. And since 2007 the Toronto International Film Festival has made room for film-based art installations in the Future Projections program.

title: Staff Sgt. Jonathon Clark Interview
description: About halfway through the deployment, Sergeant Clark reflects on how it is going.

title: Male Models at the Line of Beauty
description: CONSIDER the red-backed fairy wren. The males, one of natures dandies, have coal-black plumage, scarlet capes and wings with yellow trim. The females are gray-brown with just a bit of speckling. If a female flew by, youd think: wren. If a male flew by, youd think: wow.

title: Digital Age Drives Rally to Keep a Georgia Inmate From Execution
description: ATLANTA  As Troy Davis faces his fourth execution date, the effort to save him has come to rival the most celebrated death row campaigns in recent history.

title: Sgt. Robert Smith Interview on Family
description: About halfway through his deployment, Sgt. Robert Smith talks about changes that have happened in his relationship with his daughter and her mother.

title: Sgt. Robert Smith Interview
description: About halfway through his deployment, Sgt. Robert Smith reflects on how it is going.

title: Ride This Bike? Nay. This Beautys Made for Framing.
description: STEP into the tight entryway of Noah John Gellners compact studio apartment on the Upper West Side, and try to squeeze past the everyday bicycles perched on their hooks. There is his road bike  a titanium rocket from Colorado  and hanging below it, a customized mountain bike, also titanium.

title: Dodgers Biggest Foes Could Be M.L.B. and Fox
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers are seeking a bankruptcy court judges approval to auction off the teams future cable television rights. But in so doing, they might run into stiff opposition from Major League Baseball and Fox.

title: Sgt. Henry Negron-Diaz on Family
description: About halfway through his deployment, Sgt. Henry Negron-Diaz gives an update on his family.

title: Sgt. Henry Negron-Diaz Interview
description: About halfway through his deployment, Sgt. Henry Negron-Diaz reflects on life in Afghanistan.

title: A Man of God and Technology, Trying to Steady Libya
description: Tripoli, Libya

title: A Big Twist in a Career, but Not Quite a 360
description: Anderson, a new syndicated daytime talk show, has been on only a week, and viewers already know more about Anderson Cooper than theyve learned in the decade he has spent as a CNN anchor and correspondent.

title: A Site-Specific Work Without the Site
description: Deganit Shemy & Companys 2 kilos of sea began life last year as a short, site-specific piece for two men and four women in a concrete churchyard near City Hall. During its move inside to the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the dance has expanded a little, shed a man, swapped two women and acquired a set. Lenore Doxsee has partitioned the stage with bright orange plastic netting and patches of fake grass. The artificial environment plays an important role, particularly the photo backdrop (of an empty pool) behind which the dancers can hide. But the work is now less about architecture and more about story.

title: A Pacifist College Considers the National Anthem
description: At most American colleges, hearing The Star-Spangled Banner before sporting events is a regular feature of campus life, like getting shut out of the psychology lecture you needed or seeing pledges humiliated during fraternity rush. But at Goshen College, a Mennonite school in Indiana with a historical emphasis on pacifism, the tradition was not hearing the national anthem.

title: Podcast: The European Crisis, the Guggenheim Family and Online Privacy
description: The European financial crisis has already roiled markets around the world, but its likely that worse is yet to come.

title: Moving to a New Borough and Banking on Name Recognition
description: From its founding in 1978, the performance space Roulette has served as a crucial home base for a vast, amorphous mass of activity that could collectively be lumped under the imprecise rubric of avant-garde music. Originally established in the TriBeCa loft space of Jim Staley, a trombonist and composer whose genius for improvisation has run parallel to his skill as an entrepreneurial impresario, Roulette survived the waning of the downtown loft scene during the early 1980s and outlasted storied nightclubs like the original Knitting Factory and Tonic.

title: Hot Seat for Sheen Promises the Warmth of the Limelight
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Long before television and the Web crystallized our build-celebrities-up-then-knock-them-down culture, there were roasts: smoky, boozy affairs made famous by the Friars Club, where comedians privately traded barbs and pushed boundaries and, above all, bonded. The Friars motto: We only roast the ones we love.

title: Magnate Ousted as Party Leader Cites Kremlin Discord
description: MOSCOW  Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire who this week denounced the entire political system here as a sham, said in an interview on Friday that he had fallen victim to infighting in the Kremlin.

title: A Scavenger Hunt by Smartphone
description: APP: The Pegleg

title: Dance in America for a New Generation
description: If you came of age in the late 1970s and 80s, odds are you first encountered Martha Graham and modern dance not in a theater, but via television. Over the years the Dance in America program, which made its debut on PBS in 1976, introduced millions of Americans to major dance artists and their greatest works.

title: Bloggingheads: A Moral Foreign Policy
description: F. Gregory Gause, left, of the University of Vermont and Shadi Hamid of the Brookings Doha Center debate morality in U.S. foreign policy.

title: Unusual Benefactor Finances Book Tour
description: It is trickier than ever for an author to persuade a publisher to finance a traditional book tour. Brick-and-mortar bookstores are decreasing, travel is expensive, and money for marketing and promotion is increasingly being spent online.

title: Where Diplomats and Young East Siders Collide
description: When Eduard Frauneder and Wolfgang Ban brought their brand of seasonal Austrian cooking down to a not-entirely-gentrified stretch of Avenue C near Seventh Street last December, many of their fans from the commissary at the German Mission to the United Nations and their high-end restaurant Sesonal in Midtown followed along. As a result, on any given evening or weekend afternoon, Edi & the Wolf plays host to a mix of funky young Lower East Siders and buttoned-down diplomats. The room and its enclosed garden out back are fashioned after a Viennese wine tavern, with wood reclaimed from church benches, a church bell rope draped over the bar and a confessional bench in one of the bathrooms. On Tuesday night at Table 1, just inside the door, two Austrians and a German discussed travel and the anticipated street snarls when the worlds leaders flood the city for the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly this week. DIANE CARDWELL

title: A Lost Girl of Ireland, Dealing With Its Lost Boys
description: Brigit, the recovering addict at the heart of Deirdre Kinahans BogBoy, having its United States premiere as part of the 1st Irish Theater Festival, has the kind of voice that stays with you. Combative and wry, she can make the simplest things sound sadly funny. Not that her life is a laughing matter. Its too crowded with failure for that. And yet she seems to be doing better than Hughie, her reclusive neighbor in the bleedin wilderness of Navan, where shes been sent from Dublin to get herself together.

title: After Generations of Making Do, Yemenis Take Their New Hardships in Stride
description: SENNA, Yemen  In this stone village perched in the mountains surrounding the capital, Sana, people make do. The state-owned company that normally doles out cooking gas rarely provides these days. Even when it does, the price is prohibitive. Days go by with only a couple of hours of electricity.

title: Questions Raised Over Letting Another Lender Help a Failing Solar Company
description: WASHINGTON  The political brawl over Solyndra, the solar array manufacturer that received $528 million in government aid and then went bankrupt, shifted focus Friday to a decision by the Energy Department that allowed another lender to step in to help rescue the company.

title: Hadid to Design a Garage in Miami Beach
description: Miami Beach certainly values its parking. The city announced on Friday that Zaha Hadid, left, has joined the ranks of prominent architects lending their talents and star power to Miami Beachs garages. Ms. Hadid is to design the garage at Collins Park, a neighborhood shared by the Miami City Ballet, the Bass Museum and the City Library. Among the starchitects who have designed garages are Frank Gehry; Herzog & de Meuron, Arquitectonica, Enrique Norten and Perkins & Will. Even our parking garages are more than a group of parking spaces, Matti Bower, the Miami Beach mayor, said in a statement. Some have become destinations within themselves and have attained individual iconic status. Every building can be a work of art.

title: Lets Talk About Death
description: As medical science has proven, death is hard to avoid. But it was especially hard this week.

title: Where Football and Higher Education Mix
description: CHICAGO  The University of Chicago, well known for Saul Bellow, Milton Friedman and its links to 85 Nobel Prizes, was once famous sea to shining sea for football. It boasted a legendary coach, a Heisman Trophy winner and a national championship.

title: Happy Illegal Holiday!
description: Newton, Mass.

title: Americans Give Beijing Team Its Sole Loss at Hua Yuan Cup
description: At the Hua Yuan Cup world womens elite tournament in Beijing this month, the highlight for the United States team of Lynn Baker, Karen McCallum, Cheri Bjerkan, Rozanne Pollack, Renee Mancuso and Pam Wittes was inflicting the only defeat on the victorious Beijing Hua Yuan team.

title: Vito Perrone Sr., Who Fought Standardized Tests, Dies at 78
description: Vito Perrone Sr., a leading advocate for humanistic, regimentation-free public education and a mentor to several generations of liberal reformers who fought the tide of standardized testing, died on Aug. 24 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 78.

title: Tuck Praises Spagnuolo and a System He Built
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Justin Tuck thought for a moment, his head cocked as he walked toward the cafeteria at the Giants training center. All week Tuck had been asked about the impact that Steve Spagnuolo, the former Giants defensive coordinator, had on the franchise, and minutes earlier, Tuck had praised Spagnuolos game-planning acumen to a group of reporters.

title: Obama Adviser Discusses Using Military on Terrorists
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  John O. Brennan, the top counter-terrorism adviser to President Obama, on Friday defended a broad conception of where the United States can use military force against members of Al Qaeda and its allies.

title: Jess Silva, Priest Who Founded Spanish Boys Town, Dies at 78
description: Jess Silva, a Spanish priest who responded to the problems of poor and neglected children in his native province, Galicia, by founding a self-governing Boys Town, whose childrens circus toured the world to great acclaim in the 1970s, died on Sept. 2 in Ourense, Spain. He was 78.

title: U.N. Takes Steps to Assist Libyas Transitional Leaders
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations moved on two fronts on Friday to bolster the nascent Libyan government, with the Security Council lifting some economic sanctions and the General Assembly accepting the credentials of the transitional government to represent Libya in the world body.

title: Off Radar and Flying Into Share of Lead
description: LEMONT, Ill.  There really was no logical way to predict that Justin Rose of England would follow his opening-round 63 with a 68 on Friday to share the 36-hole lead in the BMW Championship. Especially after his lackluster 2011 season in which he was winless on the PGA Tour and missed the cut at the Memorial and the United States Open.

title: Learning From Hammarskjold
description: Tyringham, Mass.

title: For Adoptive Parents, Questions Without Answers
description: IN almost any adoption, the new parents accept that their good fortune arises out of the hardship of the childs first parents. The equation is usually tempered by the thought that the birth parents either are no longer alive or chose to give the child a better life than they could provide.

title: Separated in Foster Care, Siblings Reunite in Camp
description: KATTSKILL BAY, N.Y.  The crisp morning swims in Lake George were quite a change of pace for Shakeema, an 8-year-old from Far Rockaway, Queens. But so was spending five days straight with her sisters, Kendra, 10, and Marquia, 7, who live in the Bronx.

title: Charging $1 to Use the Restroom, and Paying the Price
description: Sure, you could have gotten a haircut at the Phenomenon Barber Shop in Brooklyn in the early morning hours of Labor Day, but that was just one of any number of reasons to have stopped by. It was also a place to dance, to relax, to hang out with friends and  regrettably, in hindsight  to use the restroom after a few drinks.

title: Lottery Numbers
Gay-Marriage Foes See Message in House Race
description: Bob Turners victory over Assemblyman David I. Weprin in Tuesdays special Congressional election has been chalked up to many factors: unhappiness with President Obama, the sluggish economy and the Middle East peace process, to name three.

title: Quick as a Cat, a Coach and His Message Find Fame on the Internet
description: Truth be told, the man with the thick-as-grits Southern accent looked a little crazy on a video that went viral last week.

title: Brothers and Sisters, Reacquainted
description: A camp in upstate New York offers siblings who have been separated in foster care a chance to send precious time together.

title: No Language Like Song
description: Frederick Douglass spent much of his life speaking about the hardships of slavery  but even he, at times, realized that words were not enough. Instead, he turned to music: The mere hearing of [slave] songs, he said, revealed the physical cruelties of the slave system; for the heart has no language like song. Today, spirituals like Go Down, Moses and Gods Going to Trouble the Water continue to convey American slaves anguish, frustration and hope.

title: Once a Redoubt Against China, Taiwans Outpost Evolves
description: KINMEN, Taiwan  Burrowing just a few feet beneath the surface of this island in the Taiwan Strait turns up remnants of what was once the most militarized zone on earth.

title: Wood-Fired Tribute to Pizzerias of Naples
description: THERE is no doubt that ZaZa (erstwhile Rustico) in Scarsdale ranks as one of the more accomplished pizzerias around, and its pizza oven is a structure of wonder, an imported Neapolitan wood-burning beauty that does its job splendidly.

title: Killing Jobs and Making Us Sick
description: In January, Mr. Obama signed a food safety law that provides broad new authority to the Food and Drug Administration, wrote Robert Pear in Fridays Times, in an article about the Congressional appropriations mess. But House Republicans, he added, had voted to cut the agencys budget.

title: UBS Faces Questions on Oversight After a Trader Lost $2 Billion
description: Until this week, Kweku M. Adoboli was riding high, a young trader for a big bank, with a stylish apartment in a fashionable London neighborhood and a steady girlfriend.

title: WikiLeaks Goes on eBay to Raise Cash
description: The opening bid for a steely portrait of Julian Assange  one of only four photos of Julian in the world that he signed on his 40th birthday in July, according to the accompanying text  was set at more than $900. It is among 10 pieces of memorabilia and services being auctioned online by WikiLeaks, the group that he founded.

title: Jets Step Into the Past With Their Uniforms
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan likes to make references to the long-gone American Football League every chance he gets. On Friday, he was asked to compare Maurice Jones-Drew, the stocky and elusive Jacksonville Jaguars running back, to other ball carriers.

title: Extra Fuel for Students
description: With school back in session, Maurizio Belli, the owner of Gianfrancos, in Bedford Hills, finds his phones pretty much ringing off the wall. From his sprawling take-out menu of Italian specialties, one item in particular inspires calls: the boss wrap ($6.95), a high-calorie, supersize answer to the most extreme craving.

title: Another Reason to Avoid His Friends
description: THE GIST His sex life suffers when she is too close to his friends.

title: Lets Hear It for Aunthood
description: FOR simplicitys sake, lets call me a childless spinster. So when my younger brother and his wife announced their first pregnancy, I  then in my mid-30s  listened hopefully for that famous tick-tock, and when it didnt sound, slunk back to my familiar unknown. My indecision, I was forced to accept, was fast reaching its expiration date. And then on a bright March afternoon I entered a hushed delivery room, and my brother handed me a small white bundle, and I felt something, not maternal exactly, but decidedly formidable: a primal pull, a plummet. It was my niece, Sophie, 2 hours old.

title: Saturday: Cause For Some Spatial Relationships
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  It is said, within some circles of crossword puzzle construction, that Saturdays are when the heavy lifters like to show off their stacks. Long, crunchy entries abound, foreign and complex words get shined up for their turn in the spotlight. Solvers are asked to ignore the sweat stains left after trying to formulate coherent Down entries all the way across rows of stacked 15s. I wont even get into the cluing; you know what Im talking about. Saturday is not for the faint of heart.

title: Two Directors Leaving Twitters Board
description: Twitter said Friday that two of its board members, Fred Wilson, a principal at the venture capital firm Union Square Ventures, and Bijan Sabet, a general partner at Spark Capital, have left the board. Mr. Wilson, who writes a popular blog, is widely seen as an important figure in the companys development. Union Square Ventures, which made its first investment in Twitter in 2007, and Spark Capital are two of the companys earliest investors.

title: Couple Accused of Stealing Millions Intended for Preschoolers Meals
description: A Staten Island couple stole at least $2.5 million in federal funds meant for nutritious meals for preschoolers, prosecutors asserted in a criminal complaint unsealed on Friday.

title: Transatlantic and Allied Cancel Merger Plans
description: Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance called off their proposed $2.94 billion merger on Friday after the two insurers faced stiff shareholder opposition and two rival bids for Transatlantic. Transatlantic has been fending off a higher $3.01 billion takeover bid by another reinsurer, Validus Holdings, and had been in talks with a unit of Berkshire Hathaway that had offered $3.25 billion.

title: Borderline Ridiculous
description: The United States is home to 11 million illegal immigrants. The undocumented hold jobs, have children, pay taxes, use government services  and too often live in fear. What is to be done about them? Its a difficult question, and one the Republican presidential candidates in the last two debates spent a great deal of effort avoiding.

title: On Day Devoted to Constitution, a Fight Over It
description: In the 100 years since Constitution Day was first established, most Americans have lumped it with holidays like Grandparents Day and Administrative Assistants day  a noble cause, lightly observed.

title: Tehrans Ambitions
description: Five years after the United Nations Security Council ordered it to halt, Iran is still enriching uranium and refusing to come clean about its nuclear program. Tehran is clearly hoping the world will either forget or acquiesce. That would be very dangerous.

title: Stay of Execution
description: After granting a stay of execution to Duane Buck just hours before he was to be put to death in Texas on Thursday, the Supreme Court must now review the case or, at the very least, order a lower federal court to consider Mr. Bucks plea for a new sentencing hearing. It cannot allow a terrible injustice to stand.

title: Just Singing, and Mingling With Trumps, in the Rain
description: Several thousand people ringed Central Park in the rain on Thursday night, lining up for hours for a free concert by Andrea Bocelli. We pitied them as we flounced past the snaking line into the V.I.P. area, we swear. But our smugness was short lived: we were no better off.

title: Sleek and Snappy, With No Gilded Dragons
description: THE stunningly modern black-and-white interior of China White, in Greenwich, is a far cry from the gilded dragon dcor of old-time Chinese restaurants. Coupled with the snappy service of waiters and waitresses in immaculate white jumpsuits  outfits that evoked thoughts of the places former life as a Lotus car showroom  the smart look led to hopes of a fresh take on Chinese cuisine. But after three visits, those expectations were only partly fulfilled.

title: New Yorks Benighted
description: Cant they get anything right? New York Citys hapless Board of Elections finally got new voting machines operating last year, replacing the 60-plus-year-old clunkers with electronic devices that are supposed to register and count votes quickly while retaining a paper trail for any recount. But the board has concocted such an overly complicated counting process that it took an extra day to report 100 percent of preliminary returns for the few races in this weeks primaries and special election. We shudder to think what will happen in the 2012 vote.

title: Vietnamese Classics
description: With a menu listing largely traditional dishes, Miss Saigon Vietnamese Restaurant is a satisfying alternative to the plethora of Chinese and Pan-Asian eating spots in Connecticut. Its service is predictably efficient, portions are ample, and, most notably, pricing is quite reasonable.

title: Quarterbacks Impressive Delivery Catches the Eye of Big Ten Coaches
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  The annual Big Ten news media luncheon is largely a predictable affair. Coaches deliver optimistic clichs. Joe Paterno says something technologically backward that showcases his Internet navet. Everyone eats lunch and goes home.

title: Red Apple Complaint
description: United States of America vs. Joanna Fan and Ziming Shen

title: Turkish-Persian, in a Multiethnic Setting
description: THERE is a narrow ribbon of storefront restaurants at the top of East Palisade Avenue in Englewood that is an international food court of sorts. One can choose among Mexican, Greek and Lebanese, a kosher deli and a place called Hummus Elite, all squeezed into the same block. All seem inviting in their own way, and most spill out onto the sidewalk when the weather allows. But the most promising-looking may be Levant Grille, dedicated to what the menu calls authentic Mediterranean cuisine.

title: Syracuse and Pitt in Talks With A.C.C.
description: Syracuse University and the University of Pittsburgh, two bedrock members of the Big East Conference, are engaged in talks about joining the Atlantic Coast Conference, according to a person with direct knowledge of the talks.

title: Venezuela: Victory for a Dissident
description: The Inter-American Court on Human Rights ruled on Friday that Venezuela must allow Leopoldo Lpez, a prominent opposition leader, to run for public office. The decision could shake up a presidential election scheduled for October 2012, opening the way for a strong opponent to run against President Hugo Chvez. Mr. Lpez, a former mayor of Chacao, a municipality in Caracas, was disqualified by Mr. Chvezs government from running because of legal claims against him from his time as mayor. Mr. Lpez argued that the disqualification, a method used by Venezuelas government against other opposition figures, amounted to political discrimination. In a statement, the Foreign Ministry called the ruling politically partial. Venezuela is believed to be required to respect the decision by the court, a judicial entity of the Organization of American States.

title: For Jobs, Its War
description: The American political discussion has finally turned to the right target: jobs.

title: Officials Eye Role of a Lawyer in Madoff Case
description: Federal ethics officials are expected to recommend that the Justice Department begin a criminal investigation into actions taken by David M. Becker, the former general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who determined the agencys proposal for compensating victims of the Bernard Madoff Ponzi scheme when he had a financial interest in the outcome.

title: Cuban Flavors, Especially Garlic
description: Tony Gonzalez, who runs the Cuban restaurant El Caney (the hut in Spanish) in Bergenfield, spent 16 years at Bear Stearns on Wall Street before taking a buyout in 2008.

title: Battle for Libya | September 16, 2011
description: Forces aligned with the provisional Libyan government fought their way Friday into two cities still held by fighters loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in a bid to end weeks of standoff around the fugitive former leaders remaining strongholds.

title: Court Filing Details Shortcomings of Airport Screeners on 9/11
description: The five terrorists who boarded United Airlines Flight 175 in Boston on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, passed through a security checkpoint that was staffed by some screeners who could not speak or understand English, did not know who Osama bin Laden or Al Qaeda were, and, in one case, could not identify what Mace was, according to new court documents.

title: Britain: Law Is Changed On Arrests of Foreign Officials
description: Britain has altered a law to make it more difficult for private citizens and activist groups to seek the arrest of foreign politicians for crimes like torture, genocide and war crimes. The change, which took effect Thursday, means that Israeli officials who had feared traveling to Britain because of threats that they might be arrested will now be able to visit again. Under the old law, people could apply to magistrates to have arrest warrants issued against people suspected of committing crimes against humanity. But now the director of public prosecutions will have to consent before such arrest warrants can be issued. The law has been a bone of contention between Israel and Britain for some time, after former Foreign Minister Tzipi Livni canceled a trip to Britain amid reports that activists would seek to have her arrested in connection with the Gaza offensive in 2008 and 2009.

title: On a Swing Through Early-Voting Iowa, Perry Finds Kindred Spirits
description: JEFFERSON, Iowa  At several levels, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas seemed a perfect fit for this small Iowa farming community.

title: A Place for Families With Hungry Teenagers
description: SOME restaurant locations seem to have revolving doors, with occupants rotating through in quick succession. One of them is 4 Berry Hill Road in Syosset. Last year, it was home to Moules et Frites; in June, it became 516 American Kitchen and Bar.

title: Ice Cream Made to Order
description: At Nitro, a new neon-bright ice cream parlor in Syosset, there is no freezer to store the ice cream and frozen yogurt sold there. Instead, frozen desserts are made to order at the display counter, where employees pour icy pitchers of liquid nitrogen, shrouded in clouds of vapor, into cream-filled stainless steel mixers. At minus 325 degrees, the nitrogen is cold enough to flash-freeze the ice cream as it churns.

title: Fall Happens Every Year, but Still Gets People Talking
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Suddenly its as if it never happened. All those furnace-stoked, sweat-streaked days  a smothering gauntlet of triple digits that strained thermometers, primed wildfires, aggravated droughts and stripped away all the fun of one summer afternoon after another. Gone.

title: Rangers Remember Boogaard at Camp
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Derek Boogaards absence from the Rangers first day of training camp was noted by several players Friday, but it seemed especially keen for one in particular: his fellow enforcer, Brandon Prust.

title: Satellite to Land, Somewhere
description: A defunct, six-ton NASA satellite will plummet out of orbit in about a week  on Sept. 23, give or take a day. But where it will land nobody knows. The orbit of the Upper Atmosphere Research Satellite passes over latitudes as far north as Edinburgh and as far south as Cape Town, and the trail of debris will stretch to about 500 miles long. NASA puts the chances that anything would hit anyone at 1 in 3,200 and notes that there are no known cases of injury by falling satellite, not even when its Skylab space station crashed into western Australia in 1979. The falling satellite, about one-tenth the mass of Skylab, was launched in 1991 from the space shuttle Discovery to study the dynamics and chemistry of the upper atmosphere and was decommissioned in 2005 when its fuel ran out and its batteries failed.

title: Britain: Seeking a Papers Sources
description: The Metropolitan Police Service is seeking a court order to force The Guardian to disclose confidential information about its reporting on the phone hacking scandal, The Guardian reported on Friday. Among the materials being sought are documents that would reveal the sources for articles by the reporters Amelia Hill and Nick Davies, including those that accused The News of the World of illegally intercepting the voicemail of a girl who was kidnapped and then murdered. The police say that Ms. Hill and Mr. Davies may have violated a law that forbids the dissemination of potentially damaging material leaked illegally by government officials.

title: Corrections: September 17
description: NATIONAL

title: House G.O.P. Leaders Find Some Things to Like About Obamas Jobs Plan
description: WASHINGTON  House Republican leaders rejected some main elements of President Obamas jobs plan on Friday but told their rank-and-file members that they would support other components. Approvals ranged from the well-publicized parts, like an extension of the payroll tax holiday, to the more obscure, like continuing depreciation write-offs for businesses.

title: Rodriguez Expects to Return Saturday
description: TORONTO  Alex Rodriguez was not in the Yankees starting lineup for Fridays game against the Toronto Blue Jays because he wanted to try out an experimental tape job on his bat first.

title: Plane Crash in Reno
description: A plane crashed during an air show in Reno, Nev., on Friday.

title: France: Strauss-Kahn to Speak Out
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund who returned to Paris after New York prosecutors dropped charges of attempted rape against him, will be interviewed on Sunday on Frances most-watched news program, a spokesman at the TF1 television channel said. It will be Mr. Strauss-Kahns first interview since his arrest in New York in May. Mr. Strauss-Kahn, 62, who had been considered a strong rival to the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, in the 2012 presidential election, is expected to be asked about his political future, the future of his party and the current crisis of the euro, among other things.

title: F.B.I. Chided for Training That Was Critical of Islam
description: Arab-American and Muslim groups deplored on Friday the Federal Bureau of Investigations use of training material that characterized the prophet Muhammad as a cult leader and linked Muslims religious devotion to a potential for violence.

title: Iraq: Seeking Jobs and Electricity
description: Several thousand followers of the anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr took to the streets in Iraqi cities on Friday, calling for the government to provide more electricity and jobs. Far fewer people took part in the protests on Friday than in previous demonstrations organized by Mr. Sadr, a Shiite. In the Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City in Baghdad, slightly fewer than 1,000 people protested for about 20 minutes immediately after prayers on Friday. In addition, about 3,000 followers of Mr. Sadr protested in Najaf.

title: Two Orchestras, Two Approaches to Leadership
description: WHEN Itzhak Perlman resigned as the Westchester Philharmonics artistic director halfway through last season, leaving the orchestra without a designated artistic leader for the first time in its 28 years, few thought that, on the eve of a new season, it would neither have a new leader nor actively be seeking one. But that is the case. The orchestras administration has warmed to the leaderless approach.

title: South Side Odyssey
description: The University of Chicagos football team has had a complicated history.

title: Bloomberg, on Radio, Raises Specter of Riots by Jobless
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg takes every opportunity these days to mention what he says are two major problems facing the countrys economy: enormous public debt and high unemployment. But on the radio show he appears on with John Gambling on Friday mornings, Mr. Bloomberg took his comments further than usual.

title: Riveras 601st Will Have to Wait as Yanks Fall
description: TORONTO  With Trevor Hoffmans record of 601 saves just one rung ahead of him on the career list, Mariano Rivera brought his family to Canada in the hope that they could share in the celebration when he tied, and then broke the record.

title: Seeing the Humor in a Shakespearean Tragedy
description: For a tragedy, Othello has always been pretty funny. But not every director has the courage to bring the humor front and center, as Bonnie J. Monte does in the Shakespeare Theater of New Jerseys top-notch, smoothly executed new production.

title: Falling Approval Ratings
description: Fewer than a quarter of Americans say the country is on the right track, and approval ratings for President Obama and Congress are at record lows, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Motivated Mets End Their Slump
description: ATLANTA  Drifting aimlessly through the final weeks of a draining and disappointing season, the Mets have appeared at times to be devoid of purpose.

title: These Witches Arent in Puritan New England Anymore
description: Dont be alarmed if your eyes start to smart even before the house lights dim at The Crucible, Hartford Stages industrial-strength production of the classic Arthur Miller play about the Salem witch trials. Its only the fake smoke fogging your eyeglasses and providing a little screening  very little  for the near-naked ladies who will in a moment be dancing wildly among the boughs above the stage.

title: Plane Crash in Reno
description: A World War II-era fighter plane plunged into the grandstands Friday during a popular annual air show, killing at least three people and injuring more than 50 spectators.

title: Superefficient Home With Big Ambitions, Built by Students on a Hoboken Lot
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  On summer evenings, the running path along the riverfront here is clogged with businessmen on smartphones tripping over dog leashes and joggers weaving through a stream of strollers. It had gotten even more congested recently as curious pedestrians congregated around a fenced-off parking lot on Sinatra Drive to guess the purpose of the structure being built inside.

title: Shakespeare Can Wait, Till Spring at Least
description: DARKO Tresnjak likes the way his new job has started.

title: For the Red Sox, a Curative Victory
description: Boston

title: An Early Setback for St. Johns
description: For almost 18 months, it seemed like a perfect match: a coach overseeing a resurgence and a university that yearned for renewed basketball glory. Now, for Steve Lavin and St. Johns, the honeymoon may be over.

title: Exploring a Career Before, and Beyond, John and Yoko
description: IN 1968, Kevin Concannon was a 12-year-old Beatles fan when an avant-garde artist named Yoko Ono started appearing in press stories linking her with John Lennon. It was my first exposure ever to a real live artist, and especially a real live avant-garde conceptual artist, recalled Dr. Concannon, who has a doctorate in art history from Virginia Commonwealth University and is now the director of the School of Visual Arts at Virginia Tech.

title: 2 Are Dead and Dozens Injured in Crash of Vintage Plane at Show
description: A small vintage plane crashed into a crowd at a Nevada air show at the Reno-Stead Airport on Friday, killing at least two people, including the pilot, and injuring more than 50 others, officials said.

title: Reviving a Rachmaninoff Connection
description: WHEN Ellie Horn, 13, heard the name Sergei Rachmaninoff at a party for Huntington Historical Society volunteers in December, her ears perked up.

title: Jonathan Saunders: Spring 2012 RTW
description: London

title: Sure, Obama Can Fire His Staff. So Should He?
description: WASHINGTON  He has probably been quoted more than any pundit on the planet since 1992 (which, by the way, was the last time he actually won an American campaign), but when James Carville opens his mouth, Democrats still tend to listen. And so it got a lot of people talking this week when Mr. Carville, in an open letter to President Obama on CNNs Web site, urged the struggling president to follow the example of some of his predecessors and just fire a bunch of people.

title: Detroiters Make the Case for a Lifeline
description: A cross section of Detroiters say they wish they could persuade the country why G.M. and Chrysler, and by extension Detroit, deserve to be saved.

title: To Sleep, Perchance to Dream
description: An exhibition at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington explores how 17th-century thinkers perceived the mysteries and science of sleep.

title: Fashion Week: Fantasy or Reality
description: Designer visions are often quite wonderful, but for most working women, reality is tailored clothing.

title: Author, 90, Sees Her Essays Brought to Life Onstage
description: JAN SLEPIANS reaction to the Dreamcatcher Repertory Theaters adaptation of her book Astonishment: Life in the Slow Lane has been, well, astonishment.

title: The World This Week, Part 1
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: The World This Week, Part 2
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Killer Rent, a Plea and a Petition to Keep Selling Books
description: BOB CONTANT was working the information desk at St. Marks Bookshop on Thursday when a woman came in looking for German Expressionist poetry.

title: AIDS Cases Drop Again
description: In a sign of progress against one of the great plagues of the last generation, a dwindling number of New York City AIDS cases has been diagnosed over the last eight years, according to new statistics released on Friday.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Tensions Roil on Bahrains Streets
description: Nightly clashes between protesters and the police reflect the Shiite Muslim majoritys resentment of minority Sunni rule.

title: A Profile of Peter Orszag
description: Forty-year-old Peter R. Orszag, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, is the youngest member of President Obamas cabinet.

title: New Center Will Develop Teaching Tools
description: The White House on Friday announced the creation of a national research center that will focus on developing new technologies like software and games for teaching and learning in public schools. The center, called Digital Promise, was created with bipartisan Congressional support and is to be an independent nonprofit organization, overseen by a board of leaders in education and technology appointed by Education Secretary Arne Duncan. It will work with researchers, entrepreneurs and schools. Administration officials said the center builds on the presidents call in a speech this month to create jobs by focusing on new approaches in education. The project evolved from efforts by private foundations and scientists as well as civic and business leaders.

title: A Circuitous Route to a Celebration
description: Constitution Day was apparently first observed in Iowa in 1911, at the urging of the Sons of the American Revolution, who later reported that appropriate exercises were held in every school in the state. It was to be celebrated on Sept. 17, to mark the day in 1787 that the Constitutional Convention signed the document.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: The state government in Jammu and Kashmir has introduced autumn cocoon rearing in the Kashmir Valley for the first time. This silk worm-rearing program is aimed at creating employment opportunities for the unemployed youth in the valley. (Kashmir Times)

title: Math Is Hard, Euro Edition
description: Its astonishing how many European officials and unofficial wise men insist, with a great air of wisdom, that the euro crisis was caused by failure to enforce the stability pact  that is, limits on deficits and debt.

title: Waving the Flag Against Corruption
description: Like other politically correct people, I too shrink away from those who wave or wrap themselves in flags.

title: Columbia Professor Is Linked to Insider Trading Case
description: He was described only as Doctor 1 in a Massachusetts insider-trading complaint against a hedge fund operator.

title: Double Dutchess
description: A Brooklyn high school team gears up for the Public Schools Athletic Leagues inaugural double Dutch season.

title: Guy's Guy
description: Images from the film career of Paul Rudd. I Love You, Man is on DVD.

title: The Jelly Boys
description: Sam Bompas and Harry Parr are seeking to make gelatin fashionable again.

title: South Side Odyssey
description: The University of Chicagos football team has had a complicated history.

title: The Weekend Word: Vulnerability
description: Todays Times

title: Romane-Conti: It's All About Terroir
description: Worried about the future of Burgundian winemaking, Aubert de Villaine decided to lead a campaign to add the wine region to the list of UNESCO World Heritage sites.

title: Spectators Deaths Highlight Risks of Popular Aerial Racing
description: RENO, Nev.  It was, for fans and followers of the high-speed sport of air racing, a sure sign of serious trouble: the vintage P-51 Mustang, the World War II fighter known as the Cadillac of the skies, pitching violently skyward in a frantic effort by the pilot to gain altitude  and to buy time.

title: Emmys Watch: A.D. Miles on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon
description: A. D. Miles had never worked on a talk show when he was hired as the first head writer for Late Night With Jimmy Fallon. But that was kind of the point.

title: Saturday Morning Levity
description: So while Arsenal is struggling (and losing) early in Blackburn, how about something (else) to bring a smile to your face?

title: Fashion Week Casting | J. W. Anderson
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#17", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Reasons to Stay In the Dark
description: A look at some of the films releasing this fall.

title: Palestinians See U.N. Bid as Their Most Viable Option
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian decision to apply for full United Nations membership at the Security Council, announced Friday by President Mahmoud Abbas, was the most viable of the only options possible: surrender, return to violence or appeal to the international community, a senior Palestinian official said Saturday.

title: Bare Market
description: There are cities you love for what they offer in terms of superficial diversion  the joy of hunting down a perfect piece of passementerie in Paris or of locating a wonderfully sinuous leather journal in Milan  and there are cities you love for their significant history and scope, despite their lack of good shopping. Athens is one of those cities, offering up the Parthenon and not much else, as is (so Im told) St. Petersburg. Jerusalem is one of my favorite cities on the planet; its yellow stone and golden light draw me back time and again, but when I was there this past July as a judge for the Jerusalem Film Festival I was reminded of the serious absence of retail therapy.

title: Charles Percy, Former Ill. Senator, Is Dead at 91
description: Charles H. Percy, a former United States senator from Illinois and a moderate Republican who clashed with President Richard M. Nixon over Watergate and whose own presidential ambitions were stymied by Nixons resignation, died Saturday in Washington. He was 91.

title: General Motors Is Said to Offer Bonuses and Reopened Plant
description: DETROIT  The United Auto Workers union won $5,000 signing bonuses for its workers and a promise to reopen an assembly plant in Tennessee as part of its tentative new contract with General Motors, according to people briefed on the negotiations.

title: Variety: The Most Important Diagramless
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert!  There is a Notepad on todays Diagramless puzzle that says: This diagramless is 17 squares wide by 17 squares deep and has regular crossword symmetry. 1-Across begins in the first square of the first row.

title: Live Analysis: Third Saturday in September
description: Paul Myerberg and The Times Karen Crouse will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can alsofollow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: Eleanor Poling, Daughter of Former Vice President, Dies at 51
description: Eleanor Mondale Poling, a former television and radio personality and the daughter of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, died early Saturday at her farm in Prior Lake, Minn. She was 51.

title: If Syracuse and Pitt Exit, Things Could Get Interesting
description: From Walnut Creek, Calif., to Birmingham, Ala., where the offices of the Pacific-12 and Southeastern Conferences are located, the big question for a week has been which commissioner would blink first. It turns out that SEC Commissioner Mike Slive and Pac-12 Commissioner Larry Scott didnt have to.

title: Anti-Qaddafi Forces Capture, Then Lose, Last Redoubts
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  In a conflict that has seen more than its share of martial ineptitude, the struggles for the town of Bani Walid and the city of Surt stand out.

title: Rupture With Vatican Reveals a Changed Ireland
description: DUBLIN  Even as it remains preoccupied with its struggling economy, Ireland is in the midst of a profound transformation, as rapid as it is revolutionary: it is recalibrating its relationship to the Roman Catholic Church, an institution that has permeated almost every aspect of life here for generations.

title: Ted Williamss .406 Is More Than a Number
description: Inside his room at Philadelphias Ben Franklin Hotel on Saturday, Sept. 27, 1941, Ted Williams was jumpy and impatient. That might have been an apt description of the mercurial Williams at most times, but on this evening he had good cause for his unease.

title: Kara Kennedy, Daughter of Edward Kennedy, Is Dead at 51
description: Kara Kennedy, the daughter of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, died Friday after a workout at a Washington-area health club. She was 51. The cause was a heart attack, according to the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate in Boston, which announced the death.

title: A Jet Whos Easy to Root for and Hard to Keep Down
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  At 8:13 p.m. last Sunday in Gilbert, Ariz., Kevin Guy stared at his big-screen television and cheered for the smallest player on the MetLife Stadium turf. In Las Vegas, Jim Fassel broke into a wide smile. In Cheney, Wash., Chris Hansen received a two-word text message. It read: Trufant Scores.

title: Meetings on European Debt Crisis End in Debate, but Little Progress
description: WROCLAW, Poland  European finance ministers ended a two-day meeting here Saturday without making substantial progress toward solving the regions debt crisis, or any pledge to recapitalize Europes banks.

title: Ireland Upsets Australia; South Africa Routs Fiji
description: Ireland upset Australia, 15-6, to move atop its group at the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand, as the defending champion, South Africa, routed Fiji, and Argentina beat Romania for its first win.

title: After Losing Manning and Game, Colts Try to Keep Perspective
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Peyton Mannings third neck operation had already been completed, perhaps keeping him out for the season, and before the Indianapolis Colts played their first game of the season, defensive end Dwight Freeney was looking for another kind of diagnosis. How do you measure civic panic? Freeney turned on his radio.

title: Rodriguez Returns to Third Base and Bats Fifth
description: TORONTO  For the first time Since Sept. 9, Alex Rodriguez is back in the Yankees starting lineup. After missing the past six games because of his sprained left thumb, Rodriguez is playing third base and batting fifth in Saturdays game against the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: A Mothers War on Germs at Fast-Food Playlands
description: GILBERT, Ariz.  One of those who kicked off her shoes and slithered her way through the multihued plastic tubes of a fast-food restaurant playground here one recent morning was not enjoying herself in the least. In fact, she had a frown on her face.

title: Unusual Trade Propels Three Teams Toward Playoffs
description: Max Scherzer was drafted by the Arizona Diamondbacks in the first round in 2006. When they traded him after three years, it changed his outlook on his profession.

title: Car Is Stolen With Boy Still in the Back Seat
description: When a thief jumped into a car in the Bronx and drove off with it on Saturday morning, he apparently did not realize that a 2-year-old boy was in the backseat.

title: The Guggenheim Connection
description: LADY CATARINA PIETRA TOUMEI and her benefactor, David B. Guggenheim, late of the New York Guggenheims, will never rank among the great impostors. Victor Lustig sold the Eiffel Tower. Anna Anderson masqueraded as Anastasia. David Hampton posed as the son of Sidney Poitier, snookering high-caste Manhattan.

title: Vikings McNabb Has Something to Prove
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Impressionable and eager to learn, the Minnesota Vikings rookie quarterback Christian Ponder gravitated to the veteran Donovan McNabb almost as soon as McNabb dropped his bags at training camp. A first-round draft choice from Florida State, Ponder said McNabb helped him with everything, from grasping the nuances of a West Coast offense to teaching him how to politely ask autograph seekers for privacy during dinner in a restaurant.

title: Front-Office Strife Put Rams in a Fix
description: The St. Louis Rams, who face the Giants at MetLife Stadium on Monday night, have not had a winning season in eight years. They finished second to last in the N.F.L. in points allowed four times from 2005 through 2009. They posted a 6-42 record from 2007 through 2009, and although last seasons 7-9 finish offered hope that the franchise was finally headed in the right direction, a season-opening 31-13 loss to Philadelphia proved that the Rams still have a long way to go.

title: Suddenly, Over There Is Over Here
description: THE debt crisis in Europe has finally, and officially, washed up on American shores. Last week, the mighty Federal Reserve moved to help European banks that have been having trouble finding people who are willing to lend them money.

title: Runway In Review
description: Ann-Sofie Back AteljeDesigner: Ann-Sofie BackDate and Location: Friday, BFC Show SpacePhotos: slide show

title: Call It Your Online Drivers License
description: WHOS afraid of Internet fraud?

title: An Unlikely Contributor to an Unexpected Contender
description: In the heat of a pennant race with Boston on Friday, the Tampa Bay Rays made a curious choice for their cleanup spot. Batting fourth was Casey Kotchman, the journeyman first baseman who was hitting .312  between Bostons David Ortiz and Chicagos Paul Konerko that night on the list of A.L. batting leaders.

title: Clashes Erupt in Yemen, and a Sit-In Is Attacked
description: SANA, Yemen  Explosions rocked Yemens capital early Saturday morning as clashes broke out between security forces loyal to President Ali Abdullah Saleh and fighters aligned with opposition tribal leaders.

title: Gordon Pursuing Cup and His Own History
description: Jeff Gordon turned 40 last month and is married with two young children. Ten years have passed since he won his last championship in Nascars top series, and only Richard Petty and David Pearson have won more races. Who could blame Gordon for downshifting now?

title: Darwin, the Market Whiz
description: WHO was the greater economist  Adam Smith or Charles Darwin?

title: Why I Am a Naturalist
description: Naturalism is the philosophical theory that treats science as our most reliable source of knowledge and scientific method as the most effective route to knowledge. In a recent essay for The Stone, Timothy Williamson correctly reports that naturalism is popular in philosophy. In fact it is now a dominant approach in several areas of philosophy  ethics, epistemology, the philosophy of mind, philosophy of science and, most of in all, metaphysics, the study of the basic constituents of reality. Metaphysics is important: if it turns out that reality contains only the kinds of things that hard science recognizes, the implications will be grave for what we value in human experience.

title: After Open, Everybody Still Talking About the Weather
description: During another United States Open battered by rain, the worlds top players were full of suggestions on how to minimize the effect of bad weather that compressed the schedule, sent marquee matches to outer courts, caused the Louis Armstrong Stadium court to be unusable and forced the mens final to Monday for the fourth year in a row.

title: The Data Buffet Is Open (Grazing Welcome)
description: ALL the data you need on a smartphone, at full speed, for a single price  Sprint Nextel is the only major wireless carrier in the United States that still offers this with new cellphones.

title: From an American in London, Global Warnings
description: WOTTON-UNDER-EDGE, England

title: Dreams of Perfection Dont Float
description: A sailboat is a beautiful thing, and you begin building it possessed by a vision of exquisite and perfect beauty. Then, across the sprawling hours needed to build it  3,500 in my case  this perfect vision crashes into the rocky reality of uneven skills and imperfect character. In the end, unless you negotiate peace with the demon of perfectionism, youre left with the ruins of a dream and a painful testament to personal shortcomings.

title: The Joy of Making Things
description: MY mother was a German war bride. I was born in Albany, and my parents divorced when I was 2.

title: Asking Why Employees of Solar Firm Lost Jobs
description: The Department of Labor has become the latest federal agency to open an inquiry into the bankruptcy of Solyndra, the solar panel manufacturer in Fremont that President Obama once hailed as a testament to American ingenuity and dynamism.

title: Battle for Libya | September 17, 2011
description: Fighting resumed in the besieged Libyan town of Bani Walid on Saturday after Qaddafi loyalists dug in there shelled a key checkpoint controlled by transitional government forces on its northern outskirts.

title: Speak Frankly, but Dont Go Over the Net
description: This interview with  Andrew M. Thompson, co-founder and C.E.O. of Proteus, a biomedical company based in Redwood City, Calif., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Wall Street Protest Begins, With Demonstrators Blocked
description: For months the protesters had planned to descend on Wall Street on a Saturday and occupy parts of it as an expression of anger over a financial system that they say favors the rich and powerful at the expense of ordinary citizens.

title: Handshakes, Not Hugs, as Rivera Ties Saves Mark
description: TORONTO  Mariano Rivera had long ago passed bullpen luminaries like Lee Smith, John Franco, Billy Wagner and Dennis Eckersley on the career saves list, and had only one man to catch.

title: 30 Seconds With Nolan Ryan
description: Nolan Ryan threw baseballs past hitters for 27 years with the Mets, the Angels, the Astros and the Rangers, and set major league records with 5,714 strikeouts and 7 no-hitters. Ryan, 64, who was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1999, is part owner, chief executive and president of the Texas Rangers. He recently made an appearance at the Steiner Sports corporate offices in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Chicagos Mayor Challenges Teachers Union
description: CHICAGO  One by one, teachers at public elementary schools here have been voting to buck their own union and take Mayor Rahm Emanuel up on an unusual offer: to accept bonus pay in exchange for waiving union contract provisions and keeping children at some schools longer each day.

title: Helping Revive Oklahoma on the Way to Texas Tech
description: This article, excerpted from Swing Your Sword: Leading the Charge in Football and Life (Diversion Books) by the former Texas Tech coach Mike Leach, recalls Leachs season as offensive coordinator under Bob Stoops at Oklahoma. The Sooners, who are ranked No. 1, played at No. 5 Florida State on Saturday night.

title: A Home in a Tree, at Least for a Night
description: One recent night, four travelers from Atlanta on their way to a wedding on the Georgia coast headed to a hostel on a friends recommendation. As they approached in the dark, mosquitoes buzzed and frogs croaked, and silhouettes of other guests appeared dimly.

title: Photos of the Moment | J. W. Anderson
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#875", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: When Retirees Are Shortchanged
description: THE world needs more newspaper reporters like Ellen E. Schultz of The Wall Street Journal. For nearly a decade, Ms. Schultz and her colleagues have been rooting through the minutiae of accounting regulations, government filings and corporate retirement plans to expose how many of the largest American companies have systematically plundered their employees pension funds, at once robbing their workers of hard-won benefits and enriching their own profits. Her work has led to Congressional hearings, to a Washington investigation or two and to numerous journalism awards.

title: The Impoverished States of America
description: Tom Kuntz and Bill Marsh are editors at The New York Times.

title: Soviet Unions Fall Gave Birth to a Host of New Rivalries
description: The Soviet Union dominated chess for so many years partly because it could tap the talent pool in such a vast area. But after the Soviet system collapsed two decades ago, many of those players began playing for the independent countries that rose from the ashes  nations that quickly assumed their own place among the elite.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Affliction of Comfort
description: Milan

title: Egghead and Blockheads
description: WASHINGTON

title: Rick Perry, Uber Texan
description: YOU think of Rick Perry, you think of Texas. And more Texas. Perry the cowboy coyote-killer, the lord of the Texas job-creation machine, the g-dropping glad-hander with a howdy for every stranger in the room. He barely exists in the national mind outside of the Texas connection.

title: Israel: Adrift at Sea Alone
description: IVE never been more worried about Israels future. The crumbling of key pillars of Israels security  the peace with Egypt, the stability of Syria and the friendship of Turkey and Jordan  coupled with the most diplomatically inept and strategically incompetent government in Israels history have put Israel in a very dangerous situation.

title: Glimpses of the Next Great Famine
description: DADAAB REFUGEE CAMP, Kenya

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: The rogue trader at UBS, President Obamas jobs plan, the turmoil over Greek debt in Europe and the Frankfurt Motor Show.

title: The Famine in Somalia, and How to Help
description: My Sunday column is about the famine in Somalia, threatening 750,000 lives in the coming months. Ill probably have one more column from Dadaab Refugee Camp, and I should make the point that at Dadaab the conditions arent so bad, relatively speaking. The problem for the refugees is the starvation in Somalia and the difficulties getting to Dadaab.

title: Leadership Crisis
description: As the economy faces the risk of another recession, and the 2012 campaign looms, President Obama has been groping for a response to the biggest crisis of his career. All he has to do is listen to the voters.

title: The Political Provocateur
description: Sam Tanenhaus is the editor of The New York Times Book Review.

title: Keynes: The Sunny Economist
description: Sylvia Nasar is the author of Grand Pursuit: The Story of Economic Genius.

title: Israel and Turkey, Foes and Much Alike
description: Ethan Bronner is the Jerusalem bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: Governor Perrys Vaccine Tribulations
description: Gov. Rick Perrys rivals for the Republican presidential nomination have been pummeling him for his attempt to require sixth-grade girls in Texas to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted disease that can cause cervical cancer. The attacks are absurd.

title: Before the Emmys Were Gay
description: Norman Sunshine is an artist and the co-author, with Alan Shayne, of the forthcoming Double Life: A Love Story From Broadway to Hollywood.

title: Runaway Spending on War Contractors
description: Tales of waste, fraud and mayhem by private contractors have been commonplace during 10 years of military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq. Now a Congressional study commission has put a conservative estimate on waste of between $31 billion and $60 billion in the $206 billion paid to contractors since the start of the two wars.

title: The Facts on the Fed
description: David Leonhardt is the Washington bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: How the Big Money Finds a Way In
description: Companies, unions and other interest groups poured about $300 million into campaign ads in the 2010 Congressional elections after the Supreme Courts Citizens United decision opened the sluices to unlimited spending by independent groups.
