That will look like a trickle compared with the gusher coming in 2012.

title: Autumn: Party Time Across the World
description: Richard Cohen is the author of Chasing the Sun: The Epic Story of the Star That Gives Us Life.

title: Putting Parents in Charge
description: Peg Tyre is the author of The Good School: How Smart Parents Get Their Kids the Education They Deserve.

title: Talking With ... Andr Leon Talley
description: ONLY city people think that no one interesting lives in the suburbs. Case in point: Andr Leon Talley, a contributing editor for Vogue who seems to represent everything urban: stylishly dressed, a force of nature who stands out visually even in a world filled with unceasing competition for the eye. After hes finished with fashion shows in New York or Paris or Milan, Mr. Talley retreats to a quiet Westchester hamlet. His home there reminds him of his childhood in North Carolina, and happy moments on his grandmothers front porch.

title: The South Aint Just Whistlin Dixie
description: Karen L. Cox is an associate professor of history at the University of North Carolina, Charlotte, and the author of Dreaming of Dixie: How the South Was Created in American Popular Culture.

title: A Hill Country Town That Whispers, Not Shouts
description: Each year thousands of vacationers flock to the Hill Country, the Central Texas destination that often draws comparisons to Tuscany for its tree-covered hilltops and rolling valleys. Fredericksburg is the hub of this tourist activity; there, crowds amble through antique shops, and boutique B&Bs fill up faster than an IHOP after church. But not all towns in this area require reservations for a plate of schnitzel.

title: Paul Ryan
description: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

title: Wait Wait... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: Sunday Dialogue: Pieces of the Israeli-Palestinian Puzzle
description: As Palestinians seek a United Nations vote on statehood, readers discuss the Mideast impasse.

title: How Should New York Proceed on Hydrofracking?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reads & Reactions
description: In this edition: Romneys strategy, Pennsylvania plans, special election tea leaves and hurricane-centered media criticism. Also, a special edition of Reads.

title: How Privatized Social Security Works in Galveston
description: GALVESTON  Gov. Rick Perry has repeatedly called Social Security a Ponzi scheme and said that people ought to control their own retirement money. But if the social safety net program created in 1935 were eliminated  something President Eisenhower once said would be a politically stupid move what might take its place?

title: Sunday: Dont!
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  DONT QUOTE ME ON THIS, but I do believe this is one of my favorite Sunday puzzles in quite a while. Im not much for negativity, but even with all of the DONTS! it was a lot of fun hunting for the theme phrases. One word (O.K., several words) of warning: this kind of fun is what makes people get into constructing to begin with. Construct all you want, but whatever you do, DONT QUIT YOUR DAY JOB. Its a fun business, but not a lucrative one.

title: Obama Tax Plan Would Ask More of Millionaires
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday will call for a new minimum tax rate for individuals making more than $1 million a year to ensure that they pay at least the same percentage of their earnings as middle-income taxpayers, according to administration officials.

title: The Vital Importance of Manufacturing
description: To the Editor:

title: Tumult of Arab Spring Prompts Worries in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  While the popular uprisings of the Arab Spring created new opportunities for American diplomacy, the tumult has also presented the United States with challenges  and worst-case scenarios  that would have once been almost unimaginable.

title: Running Now for 2014, With Eyes on the Money
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: All Across Europe, a Long Summer of Discontent
description: After the European Central Bank and governments implemented bailouts and austerity measures to alleviate the debt crisis, citizens across the continent took to the streets.

title: The Practice Round
description: A year with Justin Canha, a young man with autism who is part of an new transition program to ready him for an independent life as an adult.

title: Justin's Paintings
description: Roger Ricco, co-owner of the Ricco Maresca Gallery, discusses Justin Canhas paintings, many from a recent show at the gallery.

title: Transitioning to Adulthood with Autism
description: Justin Canha is among the generation of autistic youth who are the first to have benefited throughout childhood from more effective therapies and education opportunities.

title: Health Officials at Risk as Indias Graft Thrives
description: LUCKNOW, India  The first doctor to die, a senior government health administrator, was shot on his morning walk last October by two men on a motorbike. Six months later, his successor, a cardiologist, was shot to death while out on a predawn stroll. A third government doctor, accused of conspiring to murder the first two, was found dead in jail in June, lying in a pool of blood with deep cuts all over his body.

title: Posadas Not-So-Great Chances of Catching Rivera
description: TORONTO  Many Yankee fans, perhaps even most of them, would love to see Jorge Posada behind the plate to catch Mariano Riveras record-setting 602nd career save, whenever it comes.

title: Dickeys Knuckler Dances Again, but Braves Sinker Does in Mets
description: ATLANTA  R. A. Dickey, an avid reader, has for the length of this season personified a most unfortunate literary archetype: the gracious loser.

title: Justin and Paloma
description: Justin Canha and his friend Paloma Kalisch, who is also autistic, draw cartoons and swap stories about their favorite shows.

title: Julian Signs
description: A home video from the Canha family of Julian Canha using sign language to communicate with his brother Justin, who has autism and didnt speak as a boy.

title: Life
description: A short animated film by Justin Canha of cartoon clich violence.

title: Justin Teaches
description: Justin Canha volunteers as a grade school art instructor, teaching his technique for drawing dinosaurs.

title: Recess Is Making a Comeback in Schools
description: As more Chicago public schools cash in on Mayor Rahm Emanuels longer-day financial incentives by adding 90 minutes to their school day, the previous votes by a dozen schools to add about a half hour to the day by bringing back recess are going unnoticed.

title: Valuing a Starting Pitcher Soon to Be a Free Agent
description: A September collapse featuring two straight series sweeps by Detroit has the enigmatic White Sox sinking toward the Cubs homely perch in the baseball standings, with less than two weeks remaining in an unsightly season.

title: End Nears for a Pizza Landmark
description: The very first Rays Pizza in the Little Italy neighborhood in New York is slated to close.

title: That Rare Political Debate: Both Civil and Full of Consequence
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Rays Pizza, the First of Many, Counts Down to Its Last Slice
description: It did not call itself the flagship Rays Pizza because it never really had a fleet. It was not Original Rays or Famous Rays or Original Famous Rays or Real Rays or Rays on Ice or any of the other cloned shops sprinkled like shredded mozzarella all over town. It was simply Rays Pizza, and in the great pizza wars of New York City, it was respected as having been the first, standing more or less above the fray at 27 Prince Street in Little Italy, with tree limbs holding up the basement ceiling and an owner whose name wasnt even Ray.

title: An Urban Garden Prepares Inmates for Green-Collar Jobs
description: As a boy, the only thing Darius Jones knew about what lies beneath the soil is that the ground is filled with the coffins of young men from his gritty West Side neighborhood.

title: After a Relaxing Week of Golf, a Revived Rose Plays for Keeps
description: LEMONT, Ill.  Nothing like a week of fun, frivolity, adult beverages and golf with your friends at some of the top clubs on Long Island to prepare an elite professional for a return to form just in time to make a run at the FedEx Cup and a $10 million bonus.

title: The C & H Sign
description: In 1906, the California and Hawaiian Sugar Refining Company opened a plant in Crockett, on the site of a former flour mill. The plants shimmering sign, with its porcelain C and H rising 22 feet high, went up in 1956. Thanks to 900 40-watt bulbs, the sign illuminates the spot where San Pablo Bay meets the Carquinez Strait.  LOUISE RAFKIN

title: Marin Countys Efforts Against Whooping Cough Pay Off
description: Last year, California experienced its worst outbreak of whooping cough in more than 60 years, and the disease hit hardest in an unexpected place: bucolic Marin County.

title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Presses Pakistan on Militant Havens
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, expressing deep concerns about violent attacks mounted by the Haqqani insurgent network, has again pressed the Pakistani military to take action against militant havens, American officials said on Saturday.

title: Steely Powell Helps Liberty Stay Alive in the Playoffs
description: NEWARK  The Liberty have taken up residence across the Hudson River while Madison Square Garden is being renovated. The team has largely struggled to draw fans to home games outside Manhattan, but the Liberty have provided Prudential Center with something that it has lacked with the Nets: playoff basketball.

title: Autistic and Seeking a Place in an Adult World
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  For weeks, Justin Canha, a high school student with autism, a love of cartoons and a gift for drawing, had rehearsed for the job interview at a local animation studio.

title: Cautionary Lessons From Michigan
description: CHICAGO  In the search for models to navigate the nations unemployment misery and the states budget woes, Michigan is rarely mentioned.

title: Bishop Walter C. Righter, 87, Dies; Faced Heresy Trial
description: Walter C. Righter, an Episcopal bishop who in 1996 was brought to trial and absolved of a charge of heresy for having ordained an actively gay man as a deacon, died on Sept. 11 at his home outside Pittsburgh. He was 87.

title: Gavitts Influence and Friendship Are Recalled
description: The death of the basketball giant Dave Gavitt did not come as a shock to those who knew him best. Though he had been battling an extended illness, Gavitt still called his friend and protg Mike Tranghese every day. Tranghese said that Gavitt refused to talk about himself and would insist on talking about how Tranghese was doing, supporting him through the death of his wife, Susan, 15 months ago.

title: Ralph J. Lomma, Who Shaped Miniature Golf, Dies at 87
description: Ralph J. Lomma, who at midcentury helped set the static pastime of miniature golf in motion, letting players tilt at windmills, shoot across rising drawbridges and, at games end, watch the ball vanish forever into the maw of a voracious clown, died on Sept. 12 in Scranton, Pa. He was 87.

title: Prosecutor Candidates Support Restorative Justice
description: On Wednesday, Betty Renee Ricks stood inside San Francisco County Jail and told 40 inmates how she was first prostituted at age 12, and how one pimp broke her teeth, beat her with hangers until she bled and poured Brut cologne into her wounds.

title: From Bad to Worse (Arsenal) and From Bad to Wonderful (Barcelona)
description: Heres the difference between Barcelona and Arsenal these days. (O.K., O.K., heres one of the many differences between Barcelona and Arsenal these days.)

title: Corrections: September 18
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lottery Numbers
State Tries to Reduce Head Injuries in a Rough Game
description: WIMBERLEY, Tex.  In this Hill Country community, as in most other Texas towns, high school football is a way of life. Whether they are playing under Texan Stadiums bright lights on a Friday night or in the sweltering afternoon heat, boys clad in navy blue and white uniforms show up day after day to live out their dreams of gridiron glory.

title: Who Killed the Doctors?
description: Authorities in India's Uttar Pradesh are trying to figure out how the killing of three prominent doctors fit into the country's systematic corruption.

title: Big Ten Commissioner Says No Change Is Imminent
description: Any notion that the Big Ten will become proactive in conference expansion was dismissed by Commissioner Jim Delany on Saturday night.

title: Dave Gavitt, Founding Force of the Big East Conference, Dies at 73
description: Dave Gavitt, the force behind the founding of the Big East Conference in 1979 and the leagues first commissioner when it emerged as a national collegiate basketball powerhouse, died Friday in Providence, R.I., near his hometown, Rumford. He was 73.

title: Eligibility All Aside, Hurricanes Prevail
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  With the N.C.A.A.s sickle looming over Miami and Ohio State, waggish commentators had plenty of fun in the buildup to their game Saturday night.

description: In the 70 years since Ted Williams batted .406, no one in the major leagues has hit .400 or better.

Walsh and Mr. Walsh Jr. of North Kingstown, R.I. The Rev. Louis J. Hammann, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the South County Museum at Canonchet Farm.

Douglas Hoffman, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at the Union Chapel in the Grove in Shelter Island, N.Y.

description: Pamela Michelle Roth and Geoffrey Alan Goldman are to be married Sunday evening at Maritime Parc, an event space in Liberty State Park in Jersey City. Cantor George Lindenblatt is to officiate.

description: Dr. Amy Stephanie Ost, the daughter of Beth Ost and Richard Ost of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., was married Saturday evening in Philadelphia to Jonathan David Brown, the son of Sherry Brown and Richard Brown of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Lawrence R. Sernovitz officiated at the Hyatt at the Bellevue.

description: Erin Michelle Hollingsworth and David Brendan May are to be married Sunday at Round Hill House, an event space in Washingtonville, N.Y. Benjamin Dickinson, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate, with Jessica Sherry, also a Universal Life minister, taking part.

description: Nessia Sevin Sloane, the daughter of Jaar-mel Sloane and Howard G. Sloane of New York, was married Saturday evening to Taylor Andrew Kushner, a son of Karen M. Kushner and Robert J. Kushner of San Juan Capistrano, Calif. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in New York, where he is the senior rabbi.

description: Jennifer Deborah Kim and Jason Alan Harman were married Saturday evening at the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore. The Rev. William Y. T. Jin, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Diana Reiter, Sean Mersten
description: Diana Elizabeth Reiter, a daughter of Marilyn B. Reiter and Glenn M. Reiter of Montclair, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Sean Daniel Mersten, the son of Sheryl Mersten and Robert Mersten of Douglaston, Queens. Rabbi Daniel M. Cohen is to officiate at the Dr. Daniel Fisher House, a historic home in Edgartown, Mass., on Marthas Vineyard.

title: Heather Steinberg, David Schuster
description: Heather Lynn Steinberg and David Isaac Schuster are to be married Sunday in North Haledon, N.J. Rabbi Cathy Felix is to officiate at the Tides Estate, an event space.

title: Stephanie Rachlin, Gregory Munves
description: Stephanie Erica Rachlin and Gregory Brackman Munves were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Todd Chizner at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y.

title: Emily Grishman, Susan Sampliner
description: Emily Barbara Grishman and Susan Jill Sampliner are to be married Sunday by Rabbi David S. Wolfman, a cousin of Ms. Grishman, at the Brasserie, a restaurant in New York.

title: Joanna Mattis, Colin Evans
description: Joanna Hochberg Mattis and Colin James Kenneth Evans are to be married Sunday at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Shlachter is to officiate.

title: Laura Owen, Kevin OKeefe
description: Laura Hazard Owen, the daughter of Ann Hodgman and David Owen of Washington, Conn., was married there Saturday to Kevin Patrick OKeefe, a son of Helen Sorensen OKeefe and Ronald P. OKeefe of West Roxbury, Mass. The ceremony, at St. Johns Episcopal Church, was performed by the Rev. Susan J. McCone, the priest-in-charge of the church.

title: Erin Miller, Brendan Cunningham
description: Erin Elizabeth Miller and Dr. Brendan Joseph Cunningham were married Saturday in Jersey City. The Rev. Thomas J. Ciba, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Czestochowa Church.

title: Elisabeth Barbiero and Daniel Bilar
description: Elisabeth Dawn Barbiero and Daniel Jacob Bilar are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club in Oyster Bay, N.Y. Rabbi Marc Gellman is to officiate.

title: Stephanie Lam, William Dolan
description: Stephanie Rene Lam and William Edward Dolan were married Saturday at the Holy Family Cathedral in Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. John J. Sotak, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Mark Davis and James Howe
description: Robert Mark Davis and James Donald Howe were married Saturday at a home in Dorset, Vt., that was rented for the occasion. The Rev. Dr. Donald R. Ferrell, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated, with Rabbi Dennis N. Math taking part in the ceremony.

title: Sally Pressman, David Rogers
description: Sally Pressman Bernstein and David Clayton Rogers, both actors, were married Saturday afternoon at Bacara Resort and Spa in Santa Barbara, Calif. Yair Lotan, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions.

title: Megan Low, Matthew Weinstock
description: Megan Elizabeth McPherson Low and Matthew Jonathan Weinstock were married Saturday afternoon in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Bryan F. Summers, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Memorial Church on the Harvard University campus.

title: Jennifer Hendi, Matthew Trovato
description: Dr. Jennifer Michelle Hendi and Dr. Matthew John Trovato were married Saturday afternoon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Ugo Nacciarone, an associate pastor at the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Talia Rosenberg, David Kaden
description: Talia Judith Rosenberg and David Michael Kaden are to be married Sunday evening in New York. Rabbi Jordan D. Rosenberg, a brother of the bride, is to officiate at the Metropolitan Club, with Judge Jos A. Cabranes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit taking part.

title: Veronika Ruff, Brainerd Taylor
description: Veronika Lis Ruff, the daughter of Carolyn Ruff of Wayzata, Minn., and the late Stephen Ruff, was married Saturday to Brainerd Ingram Taylor, the son of Marilyn Taylor of New York and the late Brainerd Ocampo Taylor. Thomas Hickey, a minister of Universal Ministries, led a nondenominational ceremony at Oak Hill, a private estate in Hudson, N.Y.

title: Neelofer Shafi and Aslam Khaja
description: Dr. Neelofer Shafi and Dr. Aslam Mohammed Khaja were married Saturday evening at the Sheraton Boston Hotel, Back Bay. Imam Dr. Talal Eid officiated.

title: Caitlin Kelly and Jose Lopez
description: Caitlin Kelly and Jose R. Lopez were married Saturday by the Rev. Michael Marshall, an Anglican priest. The ceremony was held at St. Andrew-by-the-Lake Church in Toronto.

title: Jolynn Baca, Robert Jaekel
description: Jolynn Baca and Robert Evan Jaekel were married Friday. The Most Rev. Richard A. Gundrey of the Church of Antioch at Santa Fe officiated at La Posada de Santa Fe Resort and Spa in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Vampires and Arias
description: Photos from the Wooster Groups production of La Didone.

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: ORWIN SMITH The Georgia Tech running back, right, rushed for 157 yards and a touchdown on only five carries, caught two passes for 108 yards and another score and helped the Yellow Jackets accumulate a team-record 768 total yards, including 604 rushing, in a 66-24 victory over Kansas. Georgia Tech averaged 12.1 yards a carry, an N.C.A.A. record. When were making our blocks, its like a video game, said Embry Peeples, who had a 63-yard touchdown run.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: A look at some of the long form journalism we have been reading this week:

title: Oklahoma Fends Off Ambitious Florida State
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Given their No. 1 ranking and national championship expectations, the Oklahoma Sooners will most likely face extra scrutiny for even allowing No. 5 Florida State to get within striking distance Saturday night.

title: Mayweather Takes a Head Butt, Then Takes Out Ortiz in the Fourth Round
description: LAS VEGAS  The final sequence came quickly, brutally, four rounds into Floyd Mayweather Jr.s latest boxing triumph on Saturday at the MGM Grand.

title: Response to the Rocket Launch
description: North Korea launched a Taepodong 2 missile that landed in the Pacific Ocean in an action that drew swift international condemnation.

title: College Football Replay: Week 3
description: The third week of the season saw few upsets but plenty of close games.

title: The Sequence of Events in the Binghamton Shooting
description: Diagram showing the sequence of events in the Binghamton, N.Y., shooting on April 3, 2009.

title: The Shooting in Binghamton
description: A gunman opened fire at the American Civic Association in Binghamton, N.Y., killing at least 12 people.

title: Violent Assault in a Working-Class Town
description: A gunman invaded an immigration services center in downtown Binghamton, N.Y., during citizenship classes and shot 13 people to death and critically wounded 4 others before killing himself.

title: Michelle Obama Fashion Watch
description: The first ladys style is front and center again as she and the president make their first trip to Europe.

title: Michelle Obamas Style Choices
description: Michelle Obamas fashion sense was on full display during her first European visit as first lady.

title: Syracuse and Pittsburgh Switch Conferences, Sowing Chaos
description: In a move that was as swift as it was stunning, the Atlantic Coast Conference introduced Syracuse and Pittsburgh as conference members Sunday morning. Citing the desire for more long-term financial stability, the two universities departed the Big East to make the A.C.C. the countrys first major conference with 14 football teams.

title: Seeking a Place in an Adult World
description: Justin Canha, who barely spoke until he was 10, falls roughly in the middle of the spectrum of social impairments that characterize autism.

title: In Hong Kong, a Trio of Forward-Looking Art Shows
description: With the fall season comes a new crop of art exhibitions in Hong Kong. As an antidote to some of the glitzy shows in Soho, check out this trio of forward-thinking galleries tucked away on Aberdeen Street.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, September 18
description: President Obamas job creation proposal is a hot topic in Washington, and this week it will dominate the Sunday shows. Former President Bill Clinton joins NBCs Meet the Press, ABCs This Week and CBSs Face the Nation ahead of the annual meeting of the Clinton Global Initiative this week, which will focus on the global employment crisis.

title: Fashion Week Casting | Acne
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#732", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Photos of the Moment | Jonathan Saunders
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#794", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Linda Brownlees London Fashion Week photo diary.

title: Gains of Pro-Russian Party in Latvia Show Worries on Economy and Graft
description: MOSCOW  A pro-Russian party has gained the most votes in a snap parliamentary election in Latvia, with economic worries and anger over perceived government malfeasance trumping the anti-Russian sentiments that have kept such parties at bay since the small Baltic country gained independence from the Soviet Union 20 years ago.

title: Stimulus, Austerity, and Double Standards
description: Just a quick thought: in much discussion of economic policy these days, the presumption is that stimulus had its chance, it failed, and thats that. Never mind those of us who say that we actually didnt do nearly enough  and were saying that from the beginning, not as an after-the-fact rationalization. Its one strike and youre out.

title: Hysteresis Begins
description: The slump in the United States and other advanced economies is the result of a failure of demand  period, end of story. All attempts to claim that it is somehow structural, or maybe the result of reduced incentives to produce, have collapsed at first contact with the evidence.

title: Runway In Review
description: Clements RibeiroDesigners: Suzanne Clements and Inacio RibeiroDate and Location: Saturday, MBFPhotos: slide show

title: UBS Says Trading Losses Were Closer to $2.3 Billion
description: LONDON  UBS, the Swiss banking giant, said Sunday that unauthorized trades in equity index futures during the last three months were at the center of rogue trading that led to a $2.3 billion loss.

title: Republican Voices Express Disapproval of Obama
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll offers an in-depth look at the publics view of the presidents stewardship of the economy and how his jobs plan is being received.

title: Obama Offers Plan to Cut Deficit by Over $3 Trillion
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will unveil a plan on Monday that uses entitlement cuts, tax increases and war savings to reduce the federal deficit by more than $3 trillion over the next 10 years, administration officials said.

title: Charting the Jets Win Probability
description: Were going to try something new with todays Jets game, using a Web feature from Advanced NFL Stats that charts win probability live during games. (Well start with the Jets, but their site has them for every game here; just click on the matchup youre interested in.)

title: Setting Boundaries for Internet Privacy
description: BERLIN  Watchful European privacy regulators are wielding increasing influence beyond the Continents borders. Last week, they pressed Google, as they had Apple, to change the way it collected data on cellphone locations worldwide.

title: M.L.S.: Red Bulls Have a Pulse
description: After teetering on the brink of irrelevance for the entire summer, the Red Bulls have a pulse, a heartbeat and designs on collecting a clamorous nine points in seven days.

title: Spideys Girl No More
description: A look back at the films of Kirsten Dunst.

title: The Films of Ryan Gosling
description: A look back at the work of the actor.

title: Protesters Shot, Starting Battle in Yemen Capital
description: SANA, Yemen  Firing from rooftops and from the back of pickup trucks, security forces turned heavy-caliber machine guns and other weapons on demonstrators here on Sunday, setting off battles between army defectors and forces loyal to the government in the worst day of violence in the capital since March.

title: As an MSNBC Host, Sharpton Is a Hybrid Like No Other
description: At 50 minutes to airtime, the Rev. Al Sharpton, in pinstripes and cufflinks, was sitting in his office at Rockefeller Center, tinkering with Tuesdays introduction to PoliticsNation, his new nightly show on MSNBC.

title: Greeks Discuss Drastic Moves to Receive Aid
description: FRANKFURT  Greek leaders struggled through the weekend to agree to a set of radical budget reductions that would satisfy foreign lenders demands even as they tried to stave off mounting resistance to those cuts at home.

title: Chinese Protesters Accuse Solar Panel Plant of Pollution
description: BEIJING  In a fresh indication of growing public anger over pollution, hundreds of demonstrators in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang on Sunday were camped outside a solar panel manufacturing plant that stands accused of contaminating a nearby river.

title: Strauss-Kahn Concedes Error in Sexual Encounter With Maid
description: PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn said Sunday that his sexual encounter with a New York City hotel chambermaid was an error and a moral failure he would regret his whole life, but not a criminal act.

title: No New F-16s for Taiwan, but U.S. to Upgrade Fleet
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has decided not to sell F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan but instead to help it refurbish its existing fleet, prompting criticism in Congress that the United States is buckling to pressure from China.

title: Dominant Defense Propels Jets Over Jaguars
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the Jets locker room Sunday, the loudest team in football dressed in silence. There was no shouting or whooping or any other perceptible signs that the Jets had just dismantled the Jacksonville Jaguars, administering a 32-3 beating that featured about as much suspense as a romantic comedy.

title: 16-Year-Old Becomes Youngest to Win on L.P.G.A. Tour
description: PRATTVILLE, Ala.  The historical record will show that 16-year-old Lexi Thompson became the youngest winner of a Ladies Professional Golf Association event with her victory Sunday in the Navistar L.P.G.A. Classic.

title: Jellyfish Swarm in the South
description: Swarms of dinner-plate-size moon jellyfish are gathering in the Gulf of Mexico around the Mississippi and Alabama barrier islands in numbers and sizes so large that they look almost like steppingstones, The Press-Register in Mobile, Ala., reports.

title: Fox Edits Phone-Hacking Joke From Emmys; Replaces Baldwin With Nimoy
description: The commercials for the Emmy Awards this year promised unexpected moments.

title: A Lot of Schubert and a Touch of Poetry
description: As their engagements have become more prestigious, and their recording career has grown, the Knights, the excellent young chamber orchestra, have kept up their longstanding relationship with Bargemusic. On Friday evening members of the group returned to the idyllic performance space  which floats, sometimes gently and sometimes less so, next to the Brooklyn Bridge  for a program mixing old and new.

title: Even Jeter, Having a Strong Second Half, Can Appreciate a Day Off
description: TORONTO  Derek Jeter was one of three regulars given the day off Sunday as the Yankees completed a challenging 11-day, four-city trip with a 3-0 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays. Normally, Jeter wants to play every day, but Manager Joe Girardi said Jeter and several of his teammates had showed signs of fatigue.

title: Glimpses of Obama Among Friends
description: The portrait of the Obama White House that the veteran journalist Ron Suskind draws in his searing new book, Confidence Men, is that of a young, inexperienced president lacking the leadership and managerial skills to deal effectively with the cascading economic problems he inherited; a brainy but detached executive with a tendency to frame policy matters intellectually like a journalist, or narrator, or skilled observer; an oddly passive C.E.O. whose directive on restructuring the banks in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis was, the author says, ignored or slow-walked by his own economic team.

title: Sweden Wins Both Events at the Mens Elite in China
description: Immediately after the womens tournament in Beijing the Tianjin Binhai Cup world mens elite event took place from Sept. 10 to 14. The location was on the coast of the Yellow Sea, about 80 miles southeast of Beijing.

title: A Minty Chewing Gum, Named for a Snowboarder
description: WHEN celebrities attach their names to products, it generally is for fashion-related items like fragrances or clothing lines that dont come cheap. But the price for a new product that Shaun White, the gold medalist snowboarder, has licensed: $1.49.

title: Austerity USA
description: Goldman Sachs (no link) has a nice chart showing just how much fiscal policy has been a drag on the economy since the second half of last year, and also shows that the Obama jobs plan, even if enacted in full, would only be enough to put it in neutral:

title: Ive Never Actually Seen the Resemblance
description: But several people have sent me this:

title: Facebook to Offer Path to Media
description: For cloud-based digital music services like Spotify and Rhapsody, which stream millions of songs but have struggled to sign up large numbers of paying users, being friended by Facebook could prove to be a mixed blessing.

title: I Need to Get Over This Canadian Thing
Shakespeares Words Echo Amid the Music Those Words Inspired
description: For an orchestra that has not yet opened its season, the New York Philharmonic has been awfully busy. In the last two weeks it played two performances of West Side Story, offered Mahlers Second Symphony as a 10th anniversary commemoration of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and accompanied Andrea Bocelli in Central Park. It topped off the list on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall with a program built around William Waltons film score for Shakespeares Henry V.

title: A Channel Woos the Man With Spare Cash for Toys
description: When Discovery Communications set out to reformat HD Theater, the nine-year-old home of high-definition documentaries, its executives assessed the crowded cable programming landscape and asked what was missing  where there was white space, as one later put it.

title: Cigars? Cigarettes? Catty Rivalries?
description: At the end of the first episode of The Playboy Club on NBC Hugh Hefner, in voice-over, delivers a thesis statement: It was the early 60s, and the Bunnies were some of the only women in the world who could be anyone they wanted to be.

title: Monday: Immature Egg Cell
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  SHIVER ME TIMBERS, its international Talk Like a Pirate Day! This be an occasion for keelhauling, or swashbuckling, or whatever it is pirates do when theyre happy. All I know is, I wont be able to keep this up for the entire post, or Im going to wind up sounding like a character from SpongeBob.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Republican Calls for a More Honest Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Four months after he decided against jumping into the Republican presidential race, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana says that he has occasionally been frustrated by the discourse in the campaign and that the field could benefit from at least one more contender whose candidacy was rooted in a message of fiscal discipline.

title: New Crop of Sitcom Women Can Dish It Like the Big Boys
description: In Romy and Micheles High School Reunion the heroines bicker over who is the Mary in their relationship and who is merely Rhoda. They are referring of course to The Mary Tyler Moore Show, which cemented the rule that the prettier, nicer friend is the star and the sarcastic one is the sidekick.

title: As Consumers Tighten Belts, Advertisers Adjust
description: The economic downturn and high rates of unemployment have forced consumers to spend less, and advertisers have taken notice. Figures from Nielsen, to be released on Monday, show the amount of money that advertisers are spending to bring their message to consumers has increased in certain categories.

title: After Disney, After Rehab, a Singer Tries Growing Up
description: Good luck Demi was trending on Twitter in New York on Saturday night as Demi Lovato  singer, actress, former Disney sparkplug, meltdown survivor  sang the morbid power ballad Skyscraper at the Hammerstein Ballroom: Would it make you feel better/To watch me while I bleed?

title: Godhood Will Soon Become His Art
description: At New York City Ballet George Balanchines Apollo (1928) is a touchstone, the fountainhead of neoclassical values and a proving ground for generations of storied dancers. These facts exert pressure on a performer making his first appearance in the title role. Yet the role itself offers solace. Balanchines Apollo is a god also making a debut, just beginning to figure out what he can do.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: 30 Years on, Focus Remains on Opposites to Attract an Audience
description: New Yorks dancegoers are learning to use a new name, New York Live Arts, for the place that used to be Dance Theater Workshop. No physical change is apparent in the theater or its foyer. The new institution, described as an artist-led, producing, and presenting arts organization that strives to create a robust framework in support of the nations dance and movement-based artists, has come about as a merger of the old Dance Theater Workshop and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company. A busy season, looking lively on paper, lies ahead. I wish it well.

title: Requiem for a New York Newsman
description: Its one thing to sign a petition protesting an article that suggested a rape allegation had been a hoax, but when a friend of the Daily News columnist Mike McAlary casts aspersions on his motives as a journalist, McAlary grabs him by the lapels. I dont turn on my friends, the newsman shouts defiantly. I dont sign petitions. Im McAlary.

title: River Elegy That Covers a Wide Sonic Terrain
description: The Miller Theater at Columbia University has long been a hotbed of contemporary music and adventurous programming. The work that Melissa Smey, the executive director, chose to open this season, James Dillons Nine Rivers, was so long, complex and unconventional in its demands that it was presented over three nights, on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday. It was a co-production with the Guggenheim Museums Works and Process series.

title: Arias With a Twist
description: Photos of Joey Ariass show at the Abrons Arts Center.

title: Nickelodeons Capital Play Day
description: Nickelodeons eight-year-old Worldwide Day of Play is going big time this year.

title: A Movable Sesame Street, Where Children Can Grieve
description: 6:42 p.m. | Updated Elmo danced alone beside the stage, flapping his arms as he waited for fans to approach. Cookie Monster tracked blue fuzz across the hardwood floors. The voice of Oscar the Grouch extolled the virtues of trash over the speaker system.

title: Dead Sea Scrolls on View
description: A new exhibition of more than 500 ancient artifacts from Israel  including 20 of the Dead Sea Scrolls, four of which have never been made available for public viewing  is set to make its world premiere on Oct. 28 at Discovery Times Square in Manhattan, the producers announced. Ten scrolls at a time will be displayed in Dead Sea Scrolls: Life and Faith in Biblical Times, which has been assembled by the Israel Antiquities Authority. The producers describe the show as one of the most comprehensive of its kind ever mounted; it will also include an in-scale re-creation of the Western Wall in Jerusalem, with a three-ton block of stone from the wall itself.

title: Now in 3-D, Lion King Returns to Lead at Box Office
description: Take a 17-year-old animated movie, gussy it up with 3-D visuals, and give it a two-week stunt release in theaters when competition from other family films is weak. Presto: The Lion King roars again. This Walt Disney Studios movie, which sold $1.2 billion at the global box office in 1994 (after adjusting for inflation), was No. 1 over the weekend with an estimated $29.3 million in ticket sales, a result that significantly exceeded expectations. Second place went to Contagion, the Warner Brothers-Participant Media disease thriller; it took in about $14.5 million for a two-week total of $44.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. The violent crime drama Drive (FilmDistrict) was third with about $11 million, while The Help (DreamWorks Studios) was in fourth place, taking in $6.4 million for a six week total of $147.4 million. Rounding out the top five was a remake of Straw Dogs (Sony Pictures Entertainment) that sold an estimated $5 million in tickets.

title: The Winners in Toronto
description: The Toronto International Film Festival announced its audience award winners on Sunday, with Nadine Labakis Where Do We Go Now?  aLebanese dramaabout the lengths a group of women will go toin order protecttheir village  receiving the Cadillac Peoples Choice Award, the most prestigious award at the festival. (Above, Ms. Labaki in a scene from the film.) The award for best documentary was given to Jon Shenk for The Island President, which follows Mohamed Nasheed, the president of the Maldives, as he battles to save his nation from the threat of rising sea levels. The Raid, directed by Gareth Huw Evans, won the Midnight Madness Award, and Philippe Falardeaus Monsieur Lazhar, which took home the City of TorontoAward for best Canadian feature.

title: Euro Bonds Unlikely to Solve Problems
description: Euro bonds are not the answer to Europes raging financial crisis. The idea behind the bonds, that euro zone countries would guarantee each others debts, wont be agreed to in time to solve the problem. And, once the crisis is over, neither euro bonds nor fiscal union will be desirable. Market discipline is a better way of dealing with the current crisis and for running monetary union in the long run.

description: Maybe its the battered economy that is driving the publics longing for a different era. Or maybe its Hollywoods own obsession with the 1950s and 60s, as witnessed by the lineup of fall television offerings like Pan Am and The Playboy Club that are following on the success of Mad Men.

description: RAMS (0-1) at GIANTS (0-1), Monday at 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

title: In Kabul, Its Not MTV, Its a Mission
description: Tom Freston is a pretty mellow guy, but sitting in the corner of a downtown Manhattan restaurant last week he was getting very excited as he talked about his new project. Every time I go there, there are kids doing a bunch of new things, making all kinds of interesting programming, he said. The work they are coming up with is remarkable.

description: A few notes and a question from the Jets 32-3 victory against Jacksonville on Sunday.

title: Jets Replay: Sept. 18
description: Behind four interceptions by their defense, and two touchdown passes from Mark Sanchez, the Jets improved to 2-0 with a 32-3 rout of the Jacksonville Jaguars.

title: In E-Books, Publishers Have Rivals: News Sites
description: Book publishers are surrounded by hungry new competitors: Amazon, with its steadily growing imprints; authors who publish their own e-books; online start-ups like The Atavist and Byliner.

title: Once Again, Mayweather Wins Lots of Money but Little Love
description: LAS VEGAS

title: A Little Inflation Can Be a Dangerous Thing
description: IN all the commentary about Ben S. Bernankes recent speech in Jackson Hole, Wyo., little attention has been paid to six crucial words: in a context of price stability. Those words concluded a discussion by Mr. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, of what tools the central bank could consider appropriate to promote a stronger economic recovery.

title: Turkey Predicts Alliance With Egypt as Regional Anchors
description: ANKARA, Turkey  A newly assertive Turkey offered on Sunday a vision of a starkly realigned Middle East, where the countrys former allies in Syria and Israel fall into deeper isolation, and a burgeoning alliance with Egypt underpins a new order in a region roiled by revolt and revolution.

title: How to Stop the Drop in Verbal Scores
description: Charlottesville, Va.

title: Plenty of Cheer All Around as Rookies Fuel Mets Victory
description: ATLANTA  The visitors clubhouse at Turner Field was bustling with energy Sunday. Hip-hop blared from two speakers as heaps of luggage bound for St. Louis barreled around the room.

title: Djokovic Retires in Pain as Serbia Loses
description: It would have been a suitably grand finale to a memorable tennis season: Novak Djokovic and Serbia against Rafael Nadal and Spain for the Davis Cup in December.

title: British Tourist, Kidnapped in Kenya, May Be in Central Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A British woman kidnapped from an exclusive Kenyan resort last weekend was snatched by a Somali pirate gang and is being held in central Somalia, witnesses said on Sunday night.

title: Changes to Police Lineup Procedures Cut Eyewitness Mistakes, Study Says
description: The push for procedures to help overcome the weaknesses of eyewitness identifications gains support with a new study being released on Monday that sees significant advantages in techniques promoted by many experts and a growing number of police departments.

title: Wild-Card Gap Drops to Two Games as the Rays Hammer the Red Sox Again
description: BOSTON  The standings say that the Boston Red Sox have a two-game lead on the Tampa Bay Rays in the American League wild-card race with 10 games to play. On paper Boston is in good shape, but only on paper.

title: Scrutinizing Googles Reign
description: Googles slogan may be dont be evil, but a growing chorus of antitrust regulators in the United States and Europe want to know if the company has lived up to that creed.

title: Friends of U.S., Terrorists in Eyes of Law
description: Nassir Al-Rifahe never thought his love for America would be questioned.

title: On the Red Carpet at the Emmys
description: The 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards were held Sunday night in Los Angeles.

title: In Blunt and Sometimes Crude Rap, a Strong Political Voice Emerges
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A revolution led by rappers says something about a countrys politics or its music, or maybe both.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include housing starts for August (Tuesday); existing home sales for August (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims and leading economic indicators for August (Thursday).

title: Great-Aunt Hatties Little Book
description: Harriet Beecher Stowe was my great-great-great aunt. My family was proud of her, and of the famous book she wrote. My mother used to say, When Mr. Lincoln met Great-Aunt Hattie he said, So youre the little lady who started this big war. But I didnt read The Book.

title: Buying Local, Feeding Needy, Till Fordham Calls a Halt
description: The project seemed tailor-made for a university brochure: Students promoting locally grown food. A soup kitchen taking in the leftovers. An aspiring lawyer, from bucolic Essex, Vt., making Manhattan feel closer to some green space.

title: Responding Before a Call Is Needed
description: EAGLE, Colo.  Emergency medicine carries a deep aura of romance in America, with its first-responder traditions of adrenaline, acuity and bravery. But here in this rural mountain area of the West, and in a handful of other places around the nation, a new vision is gaining ground  that emergency workers should not wait around for crises to happen, but rather go out and prevent them.

title: For a Governor Partial to Corvettes, a Chance to Indulge His Inner Gearhead
description: EAST MEADOW, N.Y.  From a distance, he looked like any other middle-aged gearhead, gingerly parking his sleek Corvette, its tires freshly shined, and then making the rounds among scores of other muscle cars lined up at an auto show here.

title: All Eyes, and All Hopes, Are on a Work in Progress
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Fed Runs Risk of Doing Less Than Investors Expect
description: WASHINGTON  Investors have concluded that the Federal Reserve will announce new measures to promote economic growth after a meeting of its policy-making committee ends Wednesday. Long-term interest rates have moved as if the Fed had already spoken.

title: Roses Victory Creates a Lucrative Opportunity
description: LEMONT, Ill.  For all the seesawing of emotions, and possibilities that rose like the roars and fell like the rain at Cog Hill during the final round of the BMW Championship, the end result Sunday was as cut and dried as any in the brief history of the PGA Tours FedEx Cup playoffs.

title: Adventurous Pets and Earthquake Experiences
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Flight Data Recovered in Crash at Air Race
description: RENO, Nev.  Federal officials announced on Sunday that they had recovered real-time flight information and a possible memory card from a video camera aboard the plane that crashed into a crowd at a Reno air race, killing nine people and injuring dozens of others.

title: The Bleeding Cure
description: Doctors used to believe that by draining a patients blood they could purge the evil humors that were thought to cause disease. In reality, of course, all their bloodletting did was make the patient weaker, and more likely to succumb.

title: Retiree Benefits for the Military Could Face Cuts
description: As Washington looks to squeeze savings from once-sacrosanct entitlements like Social Security and Medicare, another big social welfare system is growing as rapidly, but with far less scrutiny: the health and pension benefits of military retirees.

title: China and India Making Inroads in Biotech Drugs
description: Chinese and Indian drug makers have taken over much of the global trade in medicines and now manufacture more than 80 percent of the active ingredients in drugs sold worldwide. But they had never been able to copy the complex and expensive biotech medicines increasingly used to treat cancer, diabetes and other diseases in rich nations like the United States  until now.

title: Judge Considers Pledge for Jurors on Internet Use
description: As a federal judge looked over lists of proposed questions for prospective jurors in the case of Viktor Bout, a Russian businessman accused of planning to sell weapons to Colombian rebels, one question suddenly stood out to her: Do you go on the Internet?

title: Packing Heat Everywhere
description: Some bad ideas refuse to die. Include in that category an extreme proposal percolating in the House to strip states of their authority to decide who may carry a concealed loaded firearm. This gift to the gun lobby, the subject of a hearing last week by a House Judiciary subcommittee, is nearly identical to a provision the Senate defeated by a narrow margin two years ago.

title: The Last Days of the Old Parking Meter
description: Motorists bane, magnet for thieves, and memorialized in the Beatles Lovely Rita, the diminutive parking meter has led an outsize life. But its days in New York City are about to expire.

title: No Room for Tolerance
description: There have been a slew of local controversies in the past decade over the proposed construction of mosques and Islamic community centers. Mayor Michael Bloomberg rightly stood up for religious liberty against vitriolic opposition to the construction of an Islamic center in Lower Manhattan. With the mayors support, the citys Landmarks Preservation Commission unanimously allowed the project to proceed and it is, slowly.

title: Murder Trial Hinges on Questions of Domestic Abuse
description: She stood outside the courthouse, emotionally spent but resolute, on trial for killing her husband  an act that she does not dispute. But there were extenuating circumstances, she said, and sometimes killing someone is not the same as committing murder.

title: An Open Court
description: The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press proposed last week that the Supreme Court adopt a new rule saying every document filed in or by the court shall be available to the public for inspection unless it orders that the document be sealed. That presumption of openness would be in the interest of everyone  the Supreme Court, lawyers who practice before the court, scholars who study the court and, of course, the American public.

title: Brady and Patriots Make the Most of the Chargers Mistakes
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  If New Englands opponent Sunday were one that was less prone to self-inflicted mistakes, odd play-calling and general misfortune, maybe the Patriots would have been in danger of losing a game they appeared to have in hand.

title: Postscripts to the Attica Story
description: It was eerie 40 years after the deadly riot at Attica state prison to hear the voice of the late Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York employing his breathless signature adjective  fabulous! He was speaking back then to President Richard Nixon and attributing a fabulous job to the state troopers hours after they took the prison in a barrage by rooftop riflemen who killed 10 hostages along with 29 inmates. The president is heard complimenting the governor for the courage you showed, their voices resounding from newly available White House tape recordings.

title: A Superconference? Obstacles Remain for the Pac-12
description: The possibility that Texas, Oklahoma, Texas Tech and Oklahoma State will head to the Pacific-12 from the Big 12 is inching toward reality, though the formation of the first so-called 16-team superconference in major college sports still has significant hurdles to overcome.

title: Ex-Giants Case Is a Window on N.F.L. Aid
description: Ron Johnsons private room is large but sparse: a couch, two chairs, a flat-screen television and a computer that has been programmed to accommodate Johnsons favorite games: chess, backgammon, poker.

title: Home May Be Where Riveras Record Is
description: TORONTO  The Yankees 3-0 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays on Sunday meant that Yankees closer Mariano Rivera was not given the opportunity to break Trevor Hoffmans career saves mark of 601.

title: Glorifying the American, Uh, Alien
description: The revival on Broadway of Follies, a eulogy to the age of Ziegfeld, has refocused New Yorkers thoughts on a long-vanished star-spangled chapter in showbiz. That was the age when long-limbed beauties were goddesses, and stages were spectacle-filled altars to their, er, talents. Such a sensibility is as dead as the Brooklyn Dodgers, of course, though you can still catch some arch nods to it in the mega-concerts of mega-pop stars like Lady Gaga.

title: Merkels Efforts in Euro Crisis Complicated by Berlin Vote
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels conservative party held its own in the closely watched Berlin regional election on Sunday. But her junior coalition partner is now in a political free fall, complicating her fight to contain the European debt crisis despite the infighting within her bloc.

title: Fill In the Blanks
description: Just a few winters ago my wife and I took our daughters to witness the inauguration of a man who had campaigned on hope and embodied possibility. We are pretty immune to political euphoria, but, circulating among the footsore pilgrims, we could imagine our country had embraced the idea that we were all in this together. When the newly sworn-in president congratulated us all on choosing unity of purpose over recriminations and worn-out dogmas, we wanted to believe that we had done exactly that.

title: Lottery Numbers
Paint Creek, the Town Perry Left Behind
description: PAINT CREEK, Tex.  In the early 1960s, at a tiny, rural school here in the rugged plains of West Texas, little Ricky Perry waged his first campaign. Seeking the office of Halloween King, he stocked up on penny candy at Mas convenience store and then doled it out to classmates.

title: A British Soccer Team? Whats That? Say Scots, Welsh and Irish
description: LONDON  The plan seems eminently reasonable: field a soccer team to represent Britain at next years Olympics, which after all are being held here, the home of the modern game.

title: Siemens Abandoning Nuclear Power Business
description: BERLIN  Siemens, the largest engineering conglomerate in Europe, announced Sunday that following the German governments decision to phase out nuclear power by 2022, it would stop building nuclear power plants anywhere in the world.

title: Palestinians Turn to U.N., Where Partition Began
description: UNITED NATIONS  The original two-state solution designed to establish separate countries for Jews and Arabs anticipated the day that both would seek United Nations membership.

title: A Nervous Hamas Voices Its Issues With a Palestinian Bid for U.N. Membership
description: GAZA  As West Bank Palestinian leaders head to the United Nations to seek membership for a state of Palestine, their rivals in Gaza, the Hamas faction, are watching nervously, complaining of not having been consulted and warning against any recognition of Israel or yielding of a refugee right of return.

title: Wilma Lee Cooper, Grand Ole Opry Singer, Dies at 90
description: Wilma Lee Cooper, a perennial favorite with the Grand Ole Opry and a member, with her husband, Stoney, of a popular tradition-steeped country singing duo, died on Tuesday at her home in Sweetwater, Tenn. She was 90.

title: The Emmy Awards: Modern Family and Mad Men Win Again
description: Modern Family gathered up five awards at the 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards show on Sunday night, including best comedy, the second consecutive year the ABC sitcom won the top comedy award. And Mad Men received its fourth consecutive Emmy for best drama, staving off competition from the acclaimed HBO drama Boardwalk Empire and the last-ditch, sentimental push from Friday Night Lights.

title: When Free Trips Overlap With Commercial Purposes
description: In recent years, the Pearson Foundation has paid to send state education commissioners to meet with their international counterparts in London, Helsinki, Singapore and, just last week, Rio de Janeiro.

title: Frances Bay, Actress Known for Old Lady Roles, Dies at 92
description: Frances Bay, a character actress who late in life became a mainstay of television  playing roles from Arthur Fonzarellis grandmother on Happy Days to the woman who scraps with Jerry Seinfeld over a loaf of marble rye  died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 92.

title: Corrections: September 19
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Campaign Redux as Obama Pushes for Taxes on Rich
description: WASHINGTON  Four years ago this month, the candidate Barack Obama paused after a rally to reflect on his aspirations for economic change. His words still explain President Obamas policies.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Papers Today
description: An earthquake measuring 6.8 on the richter scale shook Sikkim, leaving eighteen people dead, of which 13 are Indian and five Nepali, and dozens injured (NDTV). Although the epicenter of the earthquake was 40-miles north-west of Gangtok, Sikkim, tremors were felt across North and East India. The three aftershocks triggered massive landslides causing National Highway 31, the only road link to Sikkim, to cave in in four places, disrupting rescue operations (Indian Express). Most telephone lines remain dead and the region faces extensive power cuts.

title: The 2011 Emmy Awards
description: In a repeat of last years Emmy Awards, ABCs Modern Family was awarded best comedy and Mad Men took home the statue for best drama.

title: Spain Defends European Title
description: Spain became the first team to repeat as EuroBasket champions since 1997 on Sunday night when it defeated France, 98-85, in Kaunas, Lithuania.

title: Veiled Apologies and Few Surprises
description: It was a good night for penitence. Or damage control. Dominique Strauss-Kahn told a French interviewer on Sunday that he regretted his moral failure with a hotel maid in New York. At the Emmys, Charlie Sheen took a moment to ruefully make amends for his rants about Two and a Half Men, which carries on with Ashton Kutcher and without him.

title: Battle for Libya | September 18, 2011
description: Rebels and Qaddafi loyalists clashed in Surt, Libya.

title: Word of the Day | vicarious
description: vicarious \vi-ker-e-s, v-\ adjective

title: Sports Replay, Sept. 18
description: A look at the day in sports, from soccer in Europe to the National Football League in America.

title: NYT Front Page for 09/19/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/19/11

title: Modern Family Takes Home Five Emmys
description: LOS ANGELES  If, after 48 episodes, there was still any doubt that Modern Family is the most adored sitcom on television, it was eliminated here at the 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards on Sunday night.

title: UConn and Rutgers Keep Options Open Amid Big East Upheaval
description: The Atlantic Coast Conferences formal introduction of Syracuse and Pittsburgh as its newest members on Sunday morning left officials from Connecticut and Rutgers not-so-quietly exploring their options of finding a landing spot outside the Big East.

title: Olympic Soccer and the Myth of Britishness
description: Jer Longman and Sarah Lyall write for Mondays Times on the efforts of British Olympic officials to create unified mens and womens soccer teams for the 2012 London Games, to compete under the flag of Great Britain. Not surprisingly, the idea has not been warmly received by Scots, Welsh and Northern Irishmen, who have cherished their soccer independence since the earliest days of the modern game, and who have chafed at English domination even longer.

title: Pennsylvania G.O.P. Weighs Electoral Vote Changes for 2012
description: The newly empowered Republicans in Pennsylvania are considering changing the way the state awards its electoral votes in presidential elections despite growing concerns by some Republicans that the move could backfire.

title: Netflix to Break Business in Two
description: In a letter posted on the Netflix Web site late Sunday night, the companys chief executive, Reed Hastings, apologized for the way he handled recent changes in pricing and subscription services, and announced that the company would split into two businesses, with the DVD-by-mail service to be renamed Qwikster.

title: A Conversation With: Rashmi Bansal
description: India Inks recent piece about the rise of Hinglish publishing sparked a lot of debate, and some of the authors shot back quickly to defend their writing style. I dont write in Hinglish, Chetan Bhagat told his 513,000 followers on Twitter. Simple English yes, Hinglish no.

title: London: Tom Town
description: On Sunday evening, Tom Ford held another of his intimate shows that causes everyone to panic about missing it or feel bitter about being left out in the first place. But attention should also be paid this season in London to Thomas Tait, whose spring clothes were imaginative and inspiring.

title: Sept. 19, 1881 | President Garfield Dies
description: On Sept. 19, 1881, President James A. Garfield died 11 weeks after being shot. The Sept. 20 New York Times reported: At a few minutes after 10 oclock last night, however, the sufferer complained of a severe pain in the region of the heart and almost immediately became unconscious. Dr. D. W. Bliss, who was hastily called, at once announced that he was dying, and Mrs. Garfield and the consulting surgeons were summoned. Within 15 minutes President Garfield had drawn his last breath and the sorrowful intelligence was being sent with lightning speed throughout the country. Everywhere, notwithstanding the lateness of the hour, the bells were tolled as a mark of respect and sorrow for the long-suffering, patient, and heroic president.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 19, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article On Campus, Its One Big Commercial.

title: Making Headway in Concussion Prevention
description: HOW many concussions do high school-age students experience every year, according to studies?

title: News Quiz | Sept. 19, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Taliban Claim Attack on Pakistani Police
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Taliban claimed responsibility for a suicide car bombing on Monday whose target was a senior police investigator in the southern port city of Karachi.

title: Death Toll in Himalayan Earthquake Exceeds 50
description: NEW DELHI  Rescue workers in India scrambled on Monday to reach villages in remote Himalayan regions that were hit Sunday night by a strong earthquake.

title: Focusing on Prison Photography
description: Pete Brook is the writer and editor of the Web site Prison Photography and the lead blogger for Raw File, the photography blog from Wired.com. Mr. Brook, 31, is undertaking a 12-week journey across the United States to interview photographers who have focused on American prisons. For more information, see Kickstarter. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: British Police Announce Terrorism Arrests in Birmingham
description: LONDON  The British police said on Monday that officers arrested six men and a woman overnight on terrorism-related charges in the central city of Birmingham, as part of what they called a large, intelligence-led counterterrorism operation.

title: Clashes Erupt for 2nd Day in Yemeni Capital, as Troops Fight Defectors
description: SANA, Yemen  Deadly violence convulsed the streets here in Yemens capital for a second day on Monday as government security forces battled soldiers who have joined antigovernment protesters in their seven-month-old movement to force President Ali Abdullah Saleh to resign.

title: What Makes Teachers Productive?
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: Hindi Cinema, in Poster Form, at a Mumbai Shop
description: It was Haji Abus grandfather, and then his father, who passed on their love for Hindi cinema to him. Mr. Abu turned his hobby into his profession, opening the Poster Shop some time in the early 1990s. Twenty or so years later, his tiny shop at Chor Bazaar (91-98704-40970) is crammed with thousands of old film posters, lobby cards and assorted film memorabilia, Mr. Abu explained as he showed off carefully preserved ticket stubs for blockbuster movies from the 1960s and 70s.

title: N.F.L. Week 2 Quick Hits:  Woodsons Big Day
description: Heres something to take away from each of Sundays games. (Did you see something youd like to share? Put it in the comments section.)

title: Who Are Your Opponents in Online Gaming?
description: Online gaming against real opponents is a popular pastime. Do you, or have you ever, played such games? Do you play against people you know in real life or random strangers? What is that like?

title: Who Made That Hudsons Bay Blanket?
description: The multistripe Hudsons Bay point blanket (also referred to as the Glacier National Park Blanket and the Chief Blanket) follows a very simple aesthetic pattern: green stripe, red stripe, yellow stripe and indigo stripe on a white background, mirrored on the top and bottom of each blanket. Lately, that recognizable motif has adorned a number of items from travel mugs to boots to Swiss Army knives to snow boards. The versatility of the pattern is a testament to the endurance of that basic color combination. While the palette is mainly prized today for its aesthetic value, back in the early 1800s, those colored stripes bore special significance for aboriginal people of North America, who were Hudsons Bays original customers.

title: China Shuts Solar Panel Factory After Antipollution Protests
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities have suspended production at a solar panel factory after protests by residents who blame the plant for fouling the air and water, a government Web site said Monday.

title: Q&A: Connecting the Gmail Dots
description: Q. In my Gmail address, I have a period in there to separate my first and last names for easier reading. When I was logging in the other day, I mistyped my user name into the Gmail Web site without the period but my password still worked. How is that?

title: Tyco to Split Itself in 3, Hoping for More Value
description: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg News Tyco wants to separate its North American residential alarm system unit, its flow control group and its commercial security business.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell Ends This Week With Celebrations, Revelations and Questions
description: The era of Dont Ask, Dont Tell, the militarys ban on openly gay service members, will come to an end on Tuesday. And while supporters of the ban continue to warn of impending problems, advocates for open service are planning a host of celebratory events, ranging from book releases to film openings to gay service members going public with their identities.

title: Behind the Poster: Venus in Fur
description: For the Broadway production of Venus in Fur, David Ivess two-character dark comedy about lust, power and a sexually charged audition, the photographer Jason Bell decided to leave the whips and chains behind.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Marios Schwab
description: Do you mean what was the hair meant to look like or what did it end up being? said Duffy, laughing backstage at Marios Schwab as a few models arrived within 10 minutes of starting time. Turns out the style was to be 40s waves  la Veronica Lake, Ingrid Bergman or Rita Hayworth. This was achieved using Clairol ColorSeal Gloss to prep the hair and then Frdric Fekkai mousse before blow-drying and creating a low side part. A large-barrel curling iron set the front wave, clamped very tight until the end (really cooking the hair), when it was brushed out. For makeup, Val Garland created what she called a film noir Fellini-flick look: liquid liner on the top of the lid, a sooty matte on the bottom and M.A.C.s Carbon shadow in between. M.A.C. Creme Colour Base contoured the face at the corners of the cheeks, the temples, even the cupids bow of the lips.

title: Complaint Box | Get Out of Line
description: A few weeks ago, on a muggy summer afternoon, I had to fight my way through the throng outside the Palace Theater. My Aunt Emma wanted tickets to Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, and I was getting them for her. An usher brushed against me, ordering people to stay back. Nearby, a young man in a pink boa, struggling to set up his souvenir program booth, was hemmed in by the crowd.

title: This Week in Small Business: Spending More on Gas but Still Stalled
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Airbus Raises Its Forecast for Demand
description: PARIS  The European plane maker Airbus raised its long-range forecast for commercial aircraft demand Monday, citing expectations of increasing wealth in fast-growing Asia and the continued expansion of low-cost airlines in the United States and Europe.

title: Asked & Answered | Bruce Jay Friedman
description: If there is an advantage to being an underappreciated novelist, it might be that when you get around to writing a memoir, the anecdotes of your life have not already been trotted out ad infinitum by book reviewers the world over. Such is the case with Bruce Jay Friedman, whose memoir, Lucky Bruce, will be published next month. On the strength of his early novels  Stern (1962), A Mothers Kisses (1964) and About Harry Towns (1974)  Friedman was a literary star, frequently mentioned alongside Bernard Malamud and Philip Roth. He hung out at Elaines; edited for legendary Magazine Management pulp journals, where he hired Mario Puzo onto the staff of True Action; and, later, moonlighted as a screenwriter (Stir Crazy, Splash), rubbing shoulders with Warren Beatty and Richard Pryor. Yet Friedman has always remained somewhat under the radar. In Lucky Bruce, readers get fresh, amusing stories from Friedmans life in letters  the time he provoked Norman Mailer into a fistfight by mussing his hair at a party, say, or was hired to write a script and introduced to his new secretary, a between-marriages Natalie Wood. The Moment caught up with Friedman, now 81, at one of his favorite Chinese restaurants in Manhattan, Chin Chin, to talk about his latest book.

title: As Folk Art Museum Teeters, a Huge Loss Looms
description: Please. Someone, everyone, do something to save the American Folk Art Museum from dissolution and dispersal. Or at least slow down the process, so that all options can be thoroughly considered. New Yorks contemporary artists, and New York as a whole, need the creative energy of this stubborn, single-minded little institution, its outstanding exhibition program and its wondrous collection, an unparalleled mixture of classic American folk art and 20th-century outsider geniuses.

title: Stocks Slide as Greek Talks Drag On
description: In a sign of increasing pessimism over the prospects for a resolution to the Greek debt crisis, investors sold some of their riskier assets in the United States and Europe on Monday.

title: Tracking the Cracks in Greenlands Ice Sheet
description: In a new study, researchers have observed an expansion of the crevasse fields in one portion of the Greenland ice sheet, a change that they suggest may influence how the ice sheets move toward the ocean and raise sea levels.

title: Three Favorite Novels by Le Carr
description: When I first read John Le Carr, there was still an Iron Curtain, and it seemed impossible that the world he described would ever change much, never mind as significantly as it has. He moved beyond that territory, of course, to tailors in Panama, Palestinian terrorists and, later, big pharma in Nairobi, but for me,Le Carr will always be synonymous with the Cold War. My three favorites are from that era:

title: Sikkims Vulnerable and Vital Roads
description: The very remoteness that makes the misty, mountain-locked Indian state of Sikkim a growing draw for tourists has made it difficult to provide relief to victims of the earthquake this Sunday, which has claimed at least 22 lives in the state so far.

title: Welcome to the Annual Circus of Foreign Leaders
description: As September wanes, people in other parts of the Northeast know that they will soon be knee-deep in fallen leaves. They are to be envied. For us New Yorkers, the approach of autumn means finding ourselves knee-deep in visiting foreign leaders.

title: Heritage Meat Comes to the Essex Street Market, With Brooklyn Taco
description: Since Patrick Martins founded Heritage Foods USA after leaving Slow Food USA he has been selling only online. On Tuesday, hell open a retail outlet at the Essex Street Market in some of the space that had been Jeffreys Meat Market, which closed in the spring after more than 70 years. (Dionisio Silva, a butcher from Jeffreys, is working at Heritage.)

title: All Banked Up With Nowhere to Go
description: Some not so cheerful thoughts on the political/economic situation:

title: Vain Glorious | Antonia Burrell
description: Though wed like to believe that there was a magic time between the youthful distress of pimples and the more mature worry of wrinkles, when skin simply behaved, the evidence points increasingly to the contrary. Just because youre 35 doesnt mean youre not going to have breakouts, says Antonia Burrell, a straight-talking facialist-turned skin-care guru, whose namesake, all-natural year-old line has a rabid following in her native Britain. The problem, according to Burrell, is our higher levels of exposure to a host of complexion-wrecking factors like stress, pollution and the chemicals and hormones in food. Ive been doing this for 18 years and the phenomenon of older women breaking out is not something I would see 10 years ago, Burrell says. After having so many clients moan to me about their skin, I decided to do something about it  but I wanted products that were holistic and a pleasure to use, not harsh chemicals that would dry out your skin. And I wanted to make them anti-aging, too. At Shen Beauty in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, the only store in the United States that sells Burrells products, her multitasking, plant-extract-packed Cream Supreme moisturizer and deep cleaning Natural Glow Cleansing Oil are perennial best sellers. The co-owner Jessica Richards first tried the line just before the store opened late last year. My skin was completely broken out from the stress of launching a business, and this cleared it up in, like, three days, she says. Its like a natural version of Proactiv. People cannot get enough of this line. Burrells products are so popular at Shen that hers is among the 12 lines that will be available to order online when the boutiques retail Web site goes live later this week. Also in the works are plans to get Burrell to Shen sometime this fall so she can work her facial magic on the Brooklyn faithful. For those unwilling to wait, Burrell has a standing gig as a guest facialist at Harrods and also sees clients at the Urban Bliss spa in Notting Hill; appointments can be made through her Web site. But be aware  shes usually booked three months in advance.

title: Monday Reading: For Travel Bargains, Look to Latin America
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: In Connecticut, Gruesome Case Set to Be Relived Again
description: NEW HAVEN  It began again on Monday, in the same claustrophobic courtroom here: accounts of the arson fire that killed two girls, descriptions of bloodstains on a garden-lined street, testimony about a familys night and day of horror.

title: Transatlantic Says Berkshire Bid Remains $3.25 Billion
description: Transatlantic Holdings said on Monday that Berkshire Hathaways takeover bid for the reinsurer remains $3.25 billion in cash, ensuring that the two companies will not strike a deal.

title: A Day Catching Birds
description: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

title: $13.5 Million in Incentives Lures a Publishing Company
description: What does it cost to persuade a publishing company to move several hundred jobs into the city that calls itself the media capital of the world? The answer Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to give on Monday is at least $13.5 million.

title: Your Admissions Essay, Live on Stage
description: College applicants  and, in some cases, their advisers, friends and parents  spend incalculable time poring over the personal statement.
