description: Lewis Alexander, a former Treasury Department official, is joining Nomura as managing director and United States chief economist.

title: In a Globalized Industry, Jaguar Lets Some Britishness Slip Through
description: A couple of months ago, I wrote a piece about the globalization of the car industry and how traditional national reputations are largely outdated, to the extent that they were ever really true in the first place.

title: Rediscovered Novel by Mildred Pierce Author Will Be Released
description: The news was mixed for Mildred Pierce at Sundays Primetime Emmy Awards, where that HBO mini-series won awards for Kate Winslet and the supporting actor Guy Pearce, but lost the overall category to the PBS presentation of Downton Abbey.

title: A Blockbuster Case Yields an Unexpected Result
description: WASHINGTON  People who hate Citizens United, last years blockbuster campaign finance decision by the Supreme Court, tend to blame it for allowing secret money from corporations and unions to flood the political landscape. But the critique is wrong on at least one point  the bit about secrecy.

title: In Ancient Pines, a Startling Shift in Tree Rings
description: Nearly 50 years have passed since a glaciologist by the name of Donald R. Currey got his tree-borer stuck in a remote Great Basin bristlecone pine (Pinus longaeva) about 10,750 feet up in the little-visited Humboldt National Forest of eastern Nevada. It would have been an unremarkable inconvenience had it not led to the death of what was shortly thereafter found to be the most ancient living thing known to exist on the planet.

title: Now Screening | Burberry
description: The Spring 2012 womens collection from Burberry at London Fashion Week.

description: Rams (0-1) at Giants (0-1), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

title: Singles Less Prepared for Retirement, Survey Shows
description: Even though most Americans seem to think its easier for single people to plan for retirement, unmarried people tend to be less prepared financially for life after full-time work, according to a quarterly survey from Charles Schwab & Company.

title: How to Bring Our Companies Foreign Profits Back Home
description: Boston

title: Why Even Resolute Dieters Often Fail
description: If youve been trying for years to lose unwanted pounds and keep them off, unrealistic goals may be the reason youve failed. It turns out that a long-used rule of weight loss  reduce 3,500 calories (or burn an extra 3,500) to lose one pound of body fat  is incorrect and can ultimately doom determined dieters.

title: Numberplay: Which Way Will It Roll?
description: Spools. Youve seen them. You probably have some around the house. Handy for things like thread and ribbon and telephone cables. But its probably been a while since youve really rolled one around.

title: Obama Draws New Hard Line on Long-Term Debt Reduction

title: The Truth About What Your Business Is Worth
description: About two years ago I told a business owner a number of things she wasnt ready to hear about the sale of her business. She was disappointed with our meeting, called later to tell me she disagreed with what I had said, then listed her business for sale with one of my competitors. I didnt lose much sleep over it at the time. In fact, I happened to admire both her and her business, and I slept better knowing that I had told her what I thought.

title: London Design Festival | Pawsons Perspectives
description: The emphasis at the London Design Festival  as at any contemporary design exhibition  is on the new new new. Perspectives opens to the public today, and remains open until mid-January 2012.

title: Sentence of the Week, Fall Harvest Edition
description: The sentences fell this week like plump acorns out of the slowly reddening oak tree of my reading, stirred by the brisk early autumn breeze of my admiration, into the woven wicker basket of my Twitter feed. Please huddle around the toasty fire of your Web browser and enjoy the harvest:

title: S.E.C. Official to Join Sidley Austin
description: James A. Brigagliano, a major Securities and Exchange Commission official, is leaving the agency to join the law firm of Sidley Austin as a partner.

title: A Summer of Humans vs. Grizzlies
description: The summer of grizzlies continues in the Rocky Mountain West.

title: Aging: Health Gains From a Small Drink a Day
description: Middle-aged women who have an alcoholic drink every day may increase their chances of enjoying health in their old age, according to a new report.

title: Prevention: Flu Shots Benefits Seen in Hospital Study
description: A federal government recommendation to give preschoolers the flu vaccine has resulted in a large decrease in emergency room visits among 2- to 4-year-olds, new research has found. And there were benefits for older children as well.

title: Five Playwrights Named in Signature Theater Initiative to Stage New Works
description: In a considerable expansion of its Off Broadway profile Signature Theater Company announced on Monday that five respected playwrights  Annie Baker, Will Eno, Katori Hall, Kenneth Lonergan, and Regina Taylor  would be charter members of a program to develop and stage their new works.

title: Repaying Buffett Has Its Upside
description: When Warren E. Buffett invests in companies like General Electric or Goldman Sachs, markets almost always interpret it as a great vote of confidence. But is it not an even more positive signal when those same companies, returned to health and flush with abundant profits, pay him back? If so, then investors might want to use G.E.s decision to return Mr. Buffetts money  which served as a life raft to the company during the 2008 crisis  to reflect on just how much better off the American financial system has become.

title: Investor Who Talked to Mets Buys Part of Yankees
description: Ray Bartoszek, the wealthy former oil trader who spent his entire life rooting for the Mets, had a chance this spring to buy a large minority share of the team. He came close to doing so, but the Mets instead chose to team up with David Einhorn, the hedge fund manager whose $200 million deal with the Mets eventually collapsed amid accusations that the team changed the terms of the arrangement at the last moment.

title: A Big Drip
description: Q. What can I do about postnasal drip, sometimes so severe that I cough, choke or vomit?

title: Life-Changing Learning: Reading and Writing About Educational Experiences
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City, the author Junot Daz, the guitarist Amy Klein and 12 more people from varied backgrounds told The New York Times about the educational experiences that changed their lives for a special issue of the Sunday magazine.

title: New York Top 5 | Patrik Ervell
description: Patrik Ervell, a member of Opening Ceremonys extended fashion family, showed his signature military-inspired jackets and slim-fit trousers for spring, adding a bit of whimsy to his often neutral landscape with a vivid watercolor print that appeared on everything from silky bomber jackets to short-sleeved camp shirts and ties. My favorite look had was a Hawaiian-style shirt paired with slim trousers with a gathered elastic cuff  a look that was more rad than trad.

title: Bimmers, a Briggs and a Band of E-Types at Fairfield County Concours dlgance
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  The best thing about the 2011 Fairfield County Concours dlgance was the classic cars. The worst thing was all those other cars.

title: Study Finds Higher Number of Pedestrians Hurt by Bikes
description: More than 500 New York City residents are injured badly enough to be treated in hospitals after being struck by bicyclists each year, according to an analysis by Hunter College professors. The number, while small compared with the number of pedestrians injured by cars, is a much higher figure than an earlier study by the same researchers found.

title: N.F.L. Beats Emmy Awards in Ratings
description: The 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards  televisions celebration of, well, television  performed to expectations on Sunday, up slightly when compared with last year in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by advertisers. But the show on Fox was down in total viewers, to 12.4 million from 13.5 million. Those are respectable numbers considering that last years ceremony did not have to compete for viewers against the National Football League. This time, Sunday Night Football on NBC dominated the night in both ratings categories, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates (the Atlanta Falcons defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 35-31). Final audience figures were unavailable on Monday.

title: Glenn Beck, Joel Klein, Amare Stoudamire and Others Reflect on Their Education
description: Sometimes in the process of putting a magazine together, a late-breaking idea emerges that seems worth taking a flier on. In the case of our education issue, that idea  to ask all sorts of influential and creative and inspiring people about the formative educational moments of their lives  was very, very late-breaking, indeed. Too late, really, for us to have much faith that it was going to work out. People are busy, after all. They have metropolises to run and rock shows to rock in and explanations for the fabric of the universe to nail down. And yet . . . when they received a call or an e-mail from someone here (in most cases, that person was the great Tony Gervino), many of those we reached out to agreed to sit down more or less immediately and type something out. Fifteen of those submissions are in this weeks issue. What follows below are several bonus tracks, arguments for the necessity of doing your homework (Glenn Beck) and reading Thucydides (David Brooks). Read, enjoy, and feel free to leave a comment describing the educational experience that made the difference for you.

title: On Our Radar: Asian Climate Refugees
description: More than 30 million people in Asia were displaced last year by environmental and weather-related disasters, the Asian Development Bank warns. It predicts that climate change will uproot tens of millions more through sea-level rise, droughts, floods and food shortages in decades to come, and that governments must start to prepare. [The Guardian]

title: Fatal Bar Shooting Exposes Burundis Instability
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A group of gunmen clad in army fatigues and armed with military-grade weapons burst into a crowded bar in Burundi on Sunday night and opened fire, Burundian officials said, killing more than 30 people and laying bare how combustible the country is a year after a disputed election.

title: Look of the Moment | Victoria Beckham
description: The Look: The Cats Meow  a whimsical print spiked with killer platforms and a serious, structured bag.

title: Bats Turn Up the Volume to Find Food Amid Clutter
description: Fruit bats make a clicking sound with their tongues to help them navigate their way to the fruits they feed on. The clicking produces a fan-shaped sonar beam that bounces off an object and returns an echo to the bat.

title: Examining the Charges Against a UBS Trader
description: The $2.3 billion trading loss at UBS shows once again how a single employee who knows how to game internal accounting and reporting systems can wreak havoc at a financial firm. A trader at the Swiss bank, Kweku M. Adoboli, has been accused of making unauthorized trades and charged with fraud and false accounting. The charges outline a type of white-collar crime that does not involve theft so much as what looks like an effort to cover up bad decisions that ultimately spiraled out of control.

title: Reader Photos: New York Fashion Week
description: We asked readers to send us their favorite photographic moments during New York Fashion Week. Here is a selection of the top images.

title: The Last of the Fresh Greens
description: Depending on how far north you live, in September and early October farmers markets may still offer a great mix of vegetables that includes the last of the produce we associate with summer -- eggplant, peppers, summer squash, tomatoes -- and a wide selection of greens that will continue well into winter. This week Ill offer a few ideas for entrees made with some of my favorites: Swiss chard, broccoli rabe, beet greens and bok choy, among others.

title: Drilling Off Cyprus Will Proceed Despite Warnings From Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  In the face of menacing warnings from Turkey on Monday, the Greek Cypriot government said it was proceeding with exploratory drilling for oil and gas off the coast of the disputed island.

title: A Magnet for Women? Try a Deep Male Voice
description: Its official: Women are drawn to low male voices, like the basso profundo of the actor James Earl Jones. And they are more likely to remember what the owners of those voices say to them.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Bangladesh, New York and Libya.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Bangladesh, New York and Libya.

title: A Little Deception Helps Push Athletes to the Limit
description: The trained bicyclists thought they had ridden as fast as they possibly could. But Kevin Thompson, head of sport and exercise science at Northumbrian University in England, wondered if they go could even faster.

title: Bachmann Takes Aim at Buffett and Obama
description: SHEFFIELD, Iowa  Representative Michele Bachmanns message to the billionaire who inspired the so-called Buffett Rule is simple.

title: Navigator in Russian Crash Was Drunk, Report Says
description: MOSCOW  The navigator on a passenger airliner that crashed in June because it missed the runway was drunk, Russian aviation authorities have found, and the navigators condition and other errors by the crew and on the ground were to blame for the accident that killed 47 people.

title: Sexuality in 1950s Hollywood
description: The opening scenes of Play It Cool, a new musical about a gay jazz club in 1950s Hollywood, promise mystery, scandal, provocation, eroticism and moral outrage. Unfortunately, the show is so busy bragging about its potential for these enticements that it fails to deliver on any of them.

title: Moscows Ousted Mayor Criticizes Russian Politics
description: MOSCOW  Yuri M. Luzhkov, the former mayor of Moscow who was once one of Russias most powerful politicians, dismissed his countrys political system as a charade in an interview published on Monday, comparing Russia to an outsize Byzantium beholden to the whims of the Kremlin.

title: Lawyer for Accuser Calls Strauss-Kahns Interview a Publicity Stunt
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahns interview with a French television station was nothing but a publicity stunt, a lawyer for the woman who accused him of sexual assault said on Monday.

title: Rivera Gets His Record 602nd Save in Classic 1-2-3 Fashion
description: Just before 10:30 a.m. Monday, Mariano Rivera walked into the Yankees clubhouse in street clothes. Less than 15 minutes later, he was dressed and ready to go. By 4:30 p.m., he had passed Trevor Hoffman as the major league career leader in saves with 602.

title: The Daily Shoe | Peter Pilotto
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Monday Motorsports: Tony Stewart Starts the Chase With First Win of 2011
description: Having only qualified for the Nascar Sprint Cup playoffs in the final race of the regular season, just nine days ago in Richmond, Va., Tony Stewart was not expected to threaten the 2011 seasons frontrunners at Chicagoland Speedway on Monday afternoon. But because of a conservative fuel strategy and perhaps the overeagerness of more highly ranked competitors like Kyle Busch, Jimmie Johnson and Matt Kenseth, Stewart cruised to a surprising victory at the Joliet, Ill., track.

title: How to Make the Sauce Pan a Pasta Pot
description: In this weeks column, I wrote about an Italian technique for cooking pasta that calls for finishing it in a pan of simmering sauce. Ever since I learned how to make pasta this way, I havent gone back to the usual drain-dump-and-toss-in-a-serving-bowl method.

title: Dolores Hope, Singer and Bob Hopes Widow, Dies at 102
description: Dolores Hope, who gave up her singing career to spend 69 years at the side of her husband, Bob Hope, pursuing philanthropy and projecting with him the image of an enduring Hollywood marriage, died on Monday in the home she and her husband bought in 1940 in the Toluca Lake section of Los Angeles. She was 102.

title: In London, Burberry Mixes Artisanal Details With High Tech
description: Burberry staged another of its big live-stream events Monday, under a clear plastic tent in bucolic Kensington Park. Pedestrians and joggers got to see the fashion people arrive, and, of course, celebrities like Rachel Zoe and Kanye West, who attended the Christopher Kane show earlier in the day. The scene at Burberry was one big camera-flashing moment before the designer Christopher Bailey sent out the clothes to music by Jeff Beck and George Harrison, among others. His idea this season was to give Burberrys trenches and bags an artisanal dimension, with crochet, beading and latticed leather on collars and sleeves. Shapes included full linen skirts with smallish knits and super-slim coats, as ruched and knotted skirts.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Christopher Kane
description: Dear Diary, was the reference bandied about backstage at Christopher Kane. This girl was young and cool, and collected, well, stickers (flowers, holograms, etc.), to decorate her secret-filled notebooks. In beauty terms, this translated into youthful, easy rolled buns created by Anthony Turner with TIGI Catwalk Volume Mousse and dry shampoo. Makeup was all about a gorgeous flushed cheek, said Lucia Pieroni of the three Chantecaille shades (Laughter, Emotion and Joy) she used to make the models appear as if theyd just run up a mountain. For eyes and lips, it was taupe-shiny Valerian shadow from the beauty brands new Classic Palette for lids and Lip Sheer in Comet on the mouth. Rose-tinted, very girly, is how the model Romee Strijd described the look. Nostalgic, fresh, suited to the season. Did she once keep a diary? Yes, but I only wrote insignificant things down, she said, avoiding any further questions.

title: Remark on HPV Vaccine Could Ripple for Years
description: During a debate last week for Republican presidential candidates and in interviews after it, Representative Michele Bachmann called the vaccine to prevent cervical cancer dangerous. Medical experts fired back quickly. Her statements were false, they said, emphasizing that the vaccine is safe and can save lives. Mrs. Bachmann was soon on the defensive, acknowledging that she was not a doctor or a scientist.

title: ConAgra Withdraws $5.2 Billion Bid for Ralcorp
description: 5:02 p.m. | Updated

title: Q&A: Morocco in Winter
description: Q.

title: In a Married World, Singles Struggle for Attention
description: Heres a September celebration you probably didnt know about: Its National Single and Unmarried Americans Week.

title: With Stricter Rule on Hits to the Head, Some N.H.L. Stars Are Split on a Full Ban
description: The N.H.L. began its preseason Monday with a tightened Rule 48, which outlaws most checks to the head as part of the leagues response to the spate of concussions in hockey.

title: Before Panama Canal, Snails Hitched a Ride
description: Long before there was a Panama Canal, at least two marine snails made a fantastic journey between oceans, crossing not on land or water but in the air.

title: Rollins Has More Tough Words for Bachmann
description: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

title: Critics Picks: A Face in the Crowd
description: A. O. Scott examines the creation of a media sensation in Elia Kazans film.

title: Settled In
description: Israeli settlers and Palestinians living in and around the Jewish settlement Ariel, on the eve of the Palestinians' bid for statehood in the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.

title: A Few Strokes of the Past in an Artist Who Lost Her Memory
description: Can I draw something for you  what should I draw? Lonni Sue Johnson asked, but she didnt wait for an answer. She drew a squiggly line that became a curly halo of hair around the cheerful face of a seated man stretching one leg upward, balancing a large bird on his foot.

title: For Obama, Peer Pressure from Nobel Laureates
description: With his approval rating among American voters at an all-time low, President Obama could use a little support from his peers. But this month nine fellow recipients of the Nobel Peace Prize, including Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa and the Dalai Lama, sent the president a letter urging him to veto the construction of a huge pipeline that would bring bring crude oil to the United States from Canada.

title: Panthers Newton Exceeds Expectations With Fast Start
description: Just a few weeks ago, Carolina Panthers Coach Ron Rivera was despairing over all the preparation time his team  young and rebuilding  missed because of the lockout. The rookie camp, the minicamps, the hours of practices, the hundreds of repetitions.

title: Family and United Airlines Settle Last 9/11 Wrongful-Death Lawsuit
description: The last remaining wrongful-death lawsuit stemming from the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has been resolved, according to a lawyer for the victims family and court papers filed on Monday.

title: B and C Lines Suspended After Morning Water Main Break
description: 11:19 p.m. | Updated The water main rupture at 106th Street and Central Park West in Manhattan continued to keep the B and C trains out of service on Monday night, and A and D lines were still knocked out in much of Manhattan.

title: New Tick-Borne Disease Is Discovered
description: A new tick-borne disease that may be stealthily infecting some Americans has been discovered by Yale researchers working with Russian scientists.

title: For Le Grand Fooding, a Frontman Follows Directions
description: What do you do after you retire at 41 from a popular and influential rock band?

title: Pandemic Fact and Fiction (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Aging Alone (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting the Staff Up in Style
description: Years ago, a new worker or an employee visiting the home office for a week or two might be put up in a bare-bones company-owned apartment.

title: Atys Returns to BAM
description: William Christie and Les Arts Florissants presented Lullys 1676 opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater.

title: Its Not Easy to Be a Goddesss Boy Toy
description: When William Christie and Les Arts Florissants presented Lullys Atys at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the first time, in 1989, it was as if a curtain had been pulled aside to reveal an alternative operatic universe. The work was so different in sound, spirit and look from the 19th-century Italian operas that dominate the mainstream opera world that it seemed almost a different art form.

title: TimesCast | Protesters Killed in Yemen
description: Violence in Yemen's capital continues into its second day, the worst since pro-democracy protests began in the spring.

title: Neil Young Joins the Rock Star Memoir Parade
description: Neil Young, easily one of the most influential and enigmatic musicians of his generation, will write a memoir, his publisher said on Monday. Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA, acquired the book after several years of discussions with Mr. Young, said David Rosenthal, the president and publisher.

title: The Presidents Deficit Plan
description: Last week, in the wake of President Obamas jobs speech, I wrote that the president seemed poised to campaign for re-election on an essentially centrist policy agenda: A short-term payroll tax stimulus, a plan for tax reform that would close loopholes while lowering corporate rates, and a long-term plan for deficit reduction modeled on the grand bargain that the White House and John Boehner were supposedly close to striking during the debt ceiling negotiations. The presidents goal in 2012, I suggested, would be to try to paint himself as the moderate bipartisan grownup, and dismiss the Republicans as extreme, intransigent, and hyper-ideological.

title: Newsroom Diversity Groups in Partnership
description: Unity: Journalists of Color, an organization whose goal is to promote newsroom diversity, is forming a partnership with the National Lesbian and Gay Journalists Association, the two groups announced Monday. This will be the first time that the lesbian and gay association will be on the board of Unity, and it will participate in the Unity convention in Las Vegas in 2012.

title: From the Fire Hose: Fukushima Examined; Extreme Weather Probed
description: Here are a couple of important reads snagged from the nonstop fire hose of news:

title: Inside Amazons Very Hot Warehouse
description: Amazon.com did not create the notion of buying things online, but it has done more than any other retailer to move the experience into the mainstream. It has exceeded its customers expectations so often it must constantly struggle to top itself. At first people were incredulous that the mouse on their computer was connected to their doorbell, the Amazon executive Russell Grandinetti said recently. Now they say: Its been 12 hours. Wheres my stuff?

title: Critics Picks Video: A Face in the Crowd
description: In A Face in the Crowd, Andy Griffith plays Larry Rhodes, a drifter who is taken from an Arkansas jail and turned into a media sensation. He is first tapped to sing on the radio, but then lands his own television program as Lonesome Rhodes. His down-to-earth sensibilities make him a hit with audiences seeking someone with a voice similar to their own.

title: Photos of the Moment | Erdem
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#796", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Tops in the Ninth
description: Mariano Riveras career with the Yankees began with his days as a starter in 1995 to his record 602nd career save on Monday afternoon.

title: Remembering All but a Sisters Murder
description: Stop me if this sounds familiar: A former police detective who left the force after being unable to get over or solve the murder of a loved one is still a valuable consultant to the police because of freakish powers of observation, and is still driven by a determination to find that loved ones killer.

title: Prequel for a Heavyweight: Hero Gets His Back Story
description: Lee Childs books usually concentrate on the strategic genius of Jack Reacher, who has long since earned his prominent place in the pantheon of cool, smart-talking American heroes. But The Affair shows off the gifts of a different strategist: the author himself. Mr. Child understood how and why the 16th book in this series had to be different from the first 15. He knew it was time for a big, exciting surprise.

title: Austin City Limits Festival
description: The 10th installment of the three-day music festival happened in the citys Zilker Park last weekend.

title: Praying for High Hill Country Rain, and Other Austin Pursuits
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Win Butler, the lead singer of Arcade Fire, wasnt just talking idly about the weather on Sunday night during the early stretch of the bands closing slot at the Austin City Limits Music Festival. I can honestly say that this is the first time weve ever been to a festival where were just praying that its going to rain the whole time, he said, eliciting a cheer. So its all happened now. Anythings possible.

title: With Nods to Schoenberg and Dr. King
description: The new collaborative work Black Moon (La Lune Noir) Act I, which was performed at Dance New Amsterdam on Friday night, started out with a question: What was it like to be alive in the era of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.? In the voice-over that followed, the answer had much to do with the strength of solidarity. At times, in the words of an unidentified woman being interviewed, it was an experience of total unity.

title: TimesCast | The Deficit Debate
description: President Obama presents his deficit reduction plan, vowing to veto any plan that doesn't raise taxes on the rich.

title: Elite, All-Male University of the Wild West To Go Coed
description: Deep Springs College, the historically all-male two-year institution located on a cattle ranch in California, voted on Saturday that it would admit women.

title: Rick Perry Takes Upper Manhattan
description: Just as President Obama was landing at New Yorks John F. Kennedy Airport, preparing to take a chopper to lower Manhattan before driving up the East Side to the United Nations, Gov. Rick Perry was wrapping up his own event at the opposite tip of the borough.

title: A New Album by Mick Jagger and Friends
description: SUPERHEAVY

title: Boltons Holden to Return on Tuesday
description: United States midfielder Stuart Holden, who has not played for Bolton since sustaining a knee injury in March, will return to the Premier League clubs first team on Tuesday for a Carling Cup match against Aston Villa.

title: Delay in New Rules for Retirement Account Advisers
description: After receiving much criticism from the financial services industry and lawmakers, the Labor Department said Monday that it would rethink a proposed new rule requiring more investment professionals to take responsibility for the advice they provide to investors in retirement plans, including 401(k)s and individual retirement accounts.

title: Lens: Lori Grinker
description: Lens: Lori Grinker

title: Swinging and Growling to an Optimistic Beat
description: It says everything about Tony Bennett that his Metropolitan Opera concert on Sunday evening was an intimate, no-frills affair: a great popular singer and his quartet casually doing what they do better than anybody else.

title: Google Wallet Makes its Debut
description: Updated 8:30 p.m.: Added an interview with Google.

title: UBS Scandal Is a Reminder About Why Dodd-Frank Came to Be
description: Adrian Dennis/Agence France-Presse  Getty ImagesKweku M. Adoboli of UBS was charged on Friday in London with one count of fraud and two counts of false accounting.

title: U.S. Is Quietly Getting Ready for Syria Without Assad
description: WASHINGTON  Increasingly convinced that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria will not be able to remain in power, the Obama administration has begun to make plans for American policy in the region after he exits.

title: Pirates Strong Showing in Berlin Elections Surprises Even Them
description: BERLIN  With laptops open like shields against the encroaching cameramen, the young men resembled Peter Pans Lost Boys more than Captain Hooks buccaneers when they were introduced Monday as Berlins newest legislators: They are the members of the Pirate Party.

title: Edible Selby | Next, by Grant Achatz
description: In our interactive feature, Grant Achatz discusses Next, a restaurant where the entire concept changes every three months.

title: Restoring a Meadow to Grandeur
description: At six acres, the East Meadow is neither the largest nor the most heavily used of Central Parks seven major lawns. But its reopening on Tuesday morning represents an important milestone for the park. It is the final meadow to be restored, in the culmination of a three-decade experiment in which an outside group, the Central Park Conservancy, was created to raise private funds, map out an ambitious restoration plan and then execute it.

title: Philadelphia Frets as Eagles Take Their Time With Vick
description: PHILADELPHIA  Fans in this city awoke Monday with a sense of unease. Their beloved Eagles lost the night before. There were second-guesses about moves, or the lack thereof, by Coach Andy Reid. And it became worse: Michael Vick had sustained a concussion.

title: Millions May Go to Girls Family in Hacking Case
description: LONDON  The family of Milly Dowler, the teenage murder victim whose voice mail messages were illegally intercepted by The News of the World, has been offered a multimillion-dollar settlement by the tabloids parent company, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said Monday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,759 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Climate Change: Science vs. Skepticism
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mexican Soft Drink Tries to Step Outside Its Niche
description: JARRITOS, a Mexican soft drink popular among Hispanics in the United States, is introducing new advertising to win over non-Hispanic young men in the hope that they will spread the brands message even farther.

title: Good Enough, Not Old Enough, for L.P.G.A.
description: PRATTVILLE, Ala.

title: Led by Demand in China, Energy Use Is Projected to Rise 53% by 2035
description: Global energy demand will increase 53 percent from 2008 through 2035, with China and India accounting for half of the growth, the United States Department of Energy said on Monday.

title: Without Jobs, Apple Shares Hit All-Time High
description: At the end of regular trading Monday, Apple shares closed at $411.63, up 2.78 percent, with a new record-high market valuation of $381.62 billion. It is now clearly the most valuable company on the stock market, displacing Exxon Mobil, with a market capitalization of $358.34billion.

title: The Palestinian Bid for U.N. Recognition of a State
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Schools Face the Rising Costs of Serving Lunch
description: The federal government is making school meals more nutritious this year, but also more expensive.

title: Children in Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: 2010 Data Show Surge in Poor Young Families
description: WASHINGTON  More than one in three young families with children were living in poverty last year, according to an analysis of census data by the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University.

title: Iraq: 11 Inmates Die in Prison Fire
description: A fire at the Rusafa prison in Baghdad killed 11 inmates and wounded 22 others on Monday, security officials said. All the time we hear about these kinds of incidents and we have to put an end to them, and we will investigate it, said Joma Ibrahim, a Parliament member. Another official, seeking to quell speculation that the fire might have been started in an attempted jailbreak, said the fire was caused by an electrical malfunction, The Associated Press reported.

title: Republican Requests for Clean Energy Funding
description: Some of the letters sent by or signed by Republicans in support of aiding clean energy efforts who are now publicly criticizing the Obama administration over Solyndra.

title: Chinese Official Calls for Korea Talks
description: The Chinese foreign minister, Yang Jiechi, called on Monday for the resumption of international talks over North Koreas nuclear program. The negotiations, involving the two Koreas, the United States, Russia, Japan and China, stalled in 2009. In August, Kim Jong-il, left, the North Korean leader, said that he was willing to return to the talks as long as there were no conditions and that he would consider a moratorium on the nuclear program if talks resumed. The United States and South Korea have said they will resume the talks only if North Korea meets promises related to the nuclear program. The top nuclear envoys from North Korea and South Korea are scheduled to meet in Beijing on Wednesday.

title: The Use of Internet Databases for Research
description: To the Editor:

title: With Their All-Pro Center Hurt, Jets Are Turning to an Undrafted Rookie
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On the morning when everything changed for Colin Baxter, nothing did. After arriving at the Jets facility Monday, he lifted weights, ate breakfast and watched videotape of their 32-3 mauling of Jacksonville.

title: California: Tiny All-Male College Will Admit Women
description: Resolving decades of debate, the trustees of Deep Springs College, a tiny, free, all-male college in an isolated eastern California valley, voted over the weekend to admit women. In a Sunday e-mail to alumni, David Hitz, the president of the board, said the earliest conceivable date women might be admitted to the two-year liberal arts college is the summer of 2013, but added that it was too early to know whether that would be possible. The 26 students at Deep Springs, in Big Pine, have had unusual control over the colleges admission, hiring and curriculum since its founding in 1917. They are required to work at least 20 hours a week on the colleges farm or cattle ranch. Most graduates complete their bachelors degrees at Ivy League colleges.

title: In Galleon Case, Prison Term Is Seen as Test
description: Peter Foley/Bloomberg NewsProsecutors want Raj Rajaratnam, who was convicted of securities fraud and conspiracy, to be sentenced to as much as 24 years.

title: Georgia: Tyson Agrees to $32 Million Settlement
description: More than 17,000 workers employed by Tyson Foods at 41 poultry plants in 12 states will receive back pay as part of a $32 million settlement that ends a 12-year-old federal lawsuit, the United Food and Commercial Workers Union announced on Monday. The workers accused Tyson of violating the Fair Labor Standards Act by failing to pay them for time spent putting on and taking off gear they were required to wear to protect themselves and the poultry. The union, which helped bring the lawsuit, said that current and former Tyson workers would receive payments averaging about $1,000. A federal district judge in Georgia approved the settlement last Thursday.

title: Israel Reoccupies Embassy in Cairo
description: CAIRO  The Israeli Embassy here appeared to reopen Monday, ending a 10-day shutdown after a mob broke into the building and its staff was hastily withdrawn.

title: Massachusetts: Ex-Probation Commissioner Charged
description: The former commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Probation was indicted Monday as part of a continuing investigation into patronage hiring there. According to the indictment, the commissioner, John J. OBrien, conspired with the chief of staff to Timothy Cahill, then the state treasurer, to organize a fund-raiser for Mr. Cahill in 2005 in exchange for a job for Mr. OBriens wife. Mr. Cahills former chief of staff, Scott S. Campbell, was also indicted. Mr. OBrien resigned last year after an independent report detailed rampant patronage in the probation department.

title: Republicans Sought Clean-Energy Money for Home States
description: WASHINGTON  On the Senate floor and the television airwaves, Senator Mitch McConnell has lambasted the Obama administration over what he has described as its failed efforts to stimulate new jobs through clean-energy projects backed with billions of dollars in federal loans or other assistance.

title: Unquestionably Alone at the Top
description: In the early morning after the Yankees last championship, in 2009, Mariano Rivera sat beaming at a table in a conference room across from the home clubhouse in the Bronx. It was informal, a few writers gathered around, asking if Rivera really meant what he had just said on the field, that he wanted to play five more seasons. Yes, Rivera insisted, he was serious.

title: Worry About a New Wave of Layoffs
description: Not again. That is the plea of many Americans fearful about their jobs as the economy falters.

title: Obama Proposes $320 Billion in Medicare and Medicaid Cuts Over 10 Years
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas budget director said Monday that the presidents new deficit-reduction plan would impose a lot of pain, and that is clearly true of White House proposals to cut $320 billion from projected spending on Medicare and Medicaid in the coming decade.

title: Proposition 8 Hearing Video Is Ordered Released by Judge
description: A federal judge has ordered the release of the video recordings of hearings on Proposition 8, Californias ban on same-sex marriage.

title: Guess Whos Not Coming to Dinner
description: Columbia University and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad might seem to be an odd couple, but for a while last week it looked as if they might be dating. A few years back, when an invitation (extended by a dean) to the Iranian leader generated outrage and bad publicity, Columbias president, Lee Bollinger, responded by trashing Ahmadinejad before introducing him. On Sept. 13 Fox News reported that an undergraduate organization  the Columbia International Relations Council and Association (CIRCA)  had set up a dinner, scheduled for the 21st, at which Ahmadinejad would interact with a group of students and, perhaps, with Bollinger.

title: Tax Plan to Turn Old Buildings Green Finds Favor
description: A business consortium that includes Lockheed Martin and Barclays bank plans to invest as much as $650 million over the next few years to slash the energy consumption of buildings in the Miami and Sacramento areas. It is the most ambitious effort yet to jump-start a national market for energy upgrades that many people believe could eventually be worth billions.

title: Afghanistan: Province Hit by 2 Attacks
description: A suicide bomber on a motorbike blew himself up outside a district police headquarters in a generally peaceful area of northern Afghanistan near the Turkmenistan border, killing four people. The attack was in the Aqcha District of Jowzjan Province, known for its carpet weavers. In a separate attack in Jowzjan Province, five border police officers were killed by a roadside bomb. Mullah Khudai Nazar Qumsayee, the chief of the provincial elders council, accused the government of neglect. The Taliban are now in the stage of infiltration in Jowzjan, he said, and are prodding mullahs to preach in their favor.

title: Voter Apathy Is Leaving Much of the City on the Sidelines of Democracy
description: I jumped in my car on the evening of last weeks special Congressional election in Brooklyn and Queens and switched to WCBS radio in hopes of catching some early returns.

title: Bloggingheads: A Smarter War on Terror
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Scott Atran of the University of Michigan debate how to wage a better war on terror.

title: A Desperate Overnight Drive to Get Out of Europe
description: AS an entrepreneur, I dont have a lot of time to myself since Im really focused on the business. So when Im in that airplane, I try to unwind. I laugh at myself because I take that time to watch movies, including some really bad ones that I wouldnt dream of seeing at a theater. But when Im on the plane, I dont care how bad a movie may be, Im watching it.

title: In Small Towns, Gossip Moves to the Web, and Turns Vicious
description: MOUNTAIN GROVE, Mo.  In the small towns nestled throughout the Ozarks, people like to say that everybody knows everybodys business  and if they do not, they feel free to offer an educated guess.

title: Spinoff Lesson Learned, Tyco Treads Carefully
description: Shareholders appreciate a good breakup story, and Tyco is giving them more to love. The company, an industrial manufacturing group, divided itself into three parts in 2007. Now one of them, Tyco International, is being carved into three more pieces. The companys shares gained on Monday amid a broad market sell-off. But while equity investors often see value in a less sprawling conglomerate, the same isnt always true for bondholders.

title: With Big Paydays at Stake, College Teams Scramble for a Spot
description: Universities around the country are tossing aside longtime rivalries, geographic sensibilities and many of the quaint notions ascribed to amateur athletics in an attempt to cash in on billion-dollar television deals and the financial security they provide.

title: Greece Nears the Precipice, Raising Fear
description: Slower economic growth throughout Europe, and probably in the United States. Huge losses by major European banks. Declining stock markets worldwide. A tightening of credit, making it harder for many borrowers to get loans.

title: Airport Maps and Apps to Guide a Hungry Traveler
description: IWAS rushing for a flight early one morning and grabbed the first convenient thing I saw for breakfast  a big, gooey Cinnabon from a counter near the gate.

title: A Glimpse of a Mayors Baronial Side, at Home
description: He has been known to serve tuna on crackers during cocktail hour. He prefers diners to power-breakfast spots like the Regency. His sartorial style remains buttoned down, with a salmon-color crew neck and matching socks about as gaudy as it gets.

title: A Call for Fairness
description: This time, President Obama did not compromise with himself beforehand, or put out a half measure in hopes of luring nonexistent Republican support. This time, he issued an unabashed call for economic fairness in cutting the federal deficit, asking as much from those on the economys upper rungs as from those lower down whose programs may be trimmed.

title: Hundreds of Civilians Flee the Struggle Over a Qaddafi Stronghold
description: SURT, Libya  During lulls between mortar and rocket barrages, hundreds of civilians fled this coastal city on Monday after five days of fierce clashes between fighters loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and former rebel fighters, which are settling into a stalemate and raising fears of another bloody siege in the still unresolved Libyan conflict.

title: Fighting Over Last Qaddafi Strongholds Continues
description: Despite control of the capital, Tripoli, the former Libyan rebels have yet to secure several towns and areas still largely loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: New Buffett Manager Gets Higher Taxes and Less Pay, by Choice
description: How would you feel about taking a pay cut and paying more in taxes?

title: 4 Insurers Will Supply Health Data
description: Several major health insurers have agreed to provide their claims data on a regular basis to academic researchers, in an unusual agreement that they say will open a window onto the rising costs of health care.

title: Building a Safer Haiti
description: Post-quake Haiti is a dangerous place, as a new report from the International Crisis Group makes clear. Hundreds of thousands of displaced people still live in poorly policed camps where they fall prey to rapes, robberies and other violent crimes. Prison escapees have regrouped in urban slums; drug traffickers and armed gangs are back in business.

title: Japan: Progress at Damaged Nuclear Plants
description: Japan is making progress in cooling the three damaged reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant and should be able to shut them down by years end, at least a month earlier than expected, the minister in charge of the disaster said Monday. Speaking at an international nuclear energy meeting in Vienna, the minister, Goshi Hosono, also promised to strengthen oversight of Japans nuclear industry by creating a more independent regulatory body by next spring. The Japanese government is responding to growing criticism at home and abroad of its inability to bring the reactors under control, and also of lax oversight that many say played a role in the accident. Also on Monday, about 60,000 anti-nuclear protesters gathered in Tokyo, in Japans largest demonstration since a huge earthquake and tsunami crippled the plant on March 11.

title: Fewer Teenagers in Lockups
description: Federal statistics released earlier this summer show that the number of juvenile offenders held under lock and key dropped by about 25 percent during the last decade, and by more than half in Vermont, Connecticut, New Mexico and Louisiana. Thats welcome news, given that young offenders who are locked up are more likely to become dangerous criminals than those who are supervised through community-based guidance programs.

title: Our Hidden Government Benefits
description: Ithaca, N.Y.

title: New Fields May Propel Americas to Top of Oil Companies Lists
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazil has begun building its first nuclear submarine to protect its vast, new offshore oil discoveries. Colombias oil production is climbing so fast that it is closing in on Algerias and could hit Libyas prewar levels in a few years. ExxonMobil is striking new deals in Argentina, which recently heralded its biggest oil discovery since the 1980s.

title: Giants Hope Stokley Can Be the Playmaker They Need on Third Down
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. The Giants search during training camp for a replacement for receiver Steve Smith included a former undrafted free agent, a veteran recovering from a knee injury and an unlikely 6-foot-6 target.

title: Obama Rejects Obamaism
description: Im a sap, a specific kind of sap. Im an Obama Sap.

title: New Challenges for Obama and Turkeys Premier
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama sits down with Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Tuesday at the United Nations, he will mark another chapter in what is perhaps the most intense relationship that he has cultivated with a foreign leader.

title: Tuesday: Echolocation Acronym
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  We havent seen Daniel Raymon around these American crossword parts since 2008 (Across Lite, Solution), although he does construct a cryptic crossword puzzle now and again.

title: Deer Hunts and Dirt Bikes
description: Paul Ryan may not be running for president this time around, but if you have any doubt about his ambitions for a long, prominent future in government, just look at his comments in a Q. and A. published in Sundays Times. Theyre a minor masterpiece of image calibration.

title: Diplomats Scramble as Palestinians Plan to Apply for U.N. Membership on Friday
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Monday that he would present an application for Palestine to join the United Nations immediately after he addresses the General Assembly on Friday, as diplomats worked frenetically to try to limit the fallout from the application.

title: Lottery Numbers
Defections Wont Sabotage Big East, Top Official Says
description: A defiant John Marinatto, the Big East commissioner, said Monday night that he was confident the league would emerge stronger from the loss of Syracuse and Pittsburgh to the Atlantic Coast Conference over the weekend.

title: No Extra Credit
description: What if everything that is happening in Washington right now is just meaningless noise?

title: Grand Jury Is Set to Act in Ticket-Fixing Inquiry
description: The grand jury that has been hearing evidence in the long-running police ticket-fixing investigation is expected to begin deciding on charges in the case as early as Tuesday, and people with knowledge of the matter said as many as 17 officers  among them a lieutenant and two sergeants would most likely face charges.

title: Queens Woman Testifies She Killed Her Husband in Self-Defense
description: A Queens secretary accused of killing her husband testified on Monday that she shot him in self-defense when he pointed a loaded pistol at her head after she had refused to accompany him on a Florida vacation.

title: The Fallen Face of the Mets
description: ATLANTA  The emptiness of his teams existence in the final weeks of baseballs regular season has reduced David Wright, the tireless worker, the true company man, into something of an office drone, punching the clock, playing out the string.

title: Moving Jobs Across Hudson, Company Wins Tax Breaks From Both Sides
description: Pearson Education could teach someone a few things about how to play one state off against another.

title: TimesCast | Diplomats Arrive in New York
description: The Palestinian plan to apply for United Nations membership dominated conversations behind the scenes as world leaders gathered in New York.

title: Pre-Election Polls Underestimate the Success of Women Candidates
description: In the run-up to 2008, there was no end of speculation about the so-called Bradley Effect or Wilder Effect  the theory that polls tend to overestimate the vote share of black candidates  and what it meant for Barack Obama. But the actual evidence for this effect is weak. Whatever effect may have existed when Tom Bradley and Douglas Wilder were running for office does not exist now.

title: MacArthur Foundation Selects 22 Geniuses

MacArthur Foundation.

title: Out and Proud to Serve
description: WASHINGTON  Now it can be told: A prominent gay rights advocate who called himself J. D. Smith is in fact 1st Lt. Josh Seefried, a 25-year-old active-duty Air Force officer. At 12:01 a.m. Tuesday, he dropped the pseudonym, freed from keeping his sexual orientation secret like an estimated tens of thousands of others in the United States military.

title: Giants Margin of Victory Cant Conceal Concerns
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  If the preseason was a series of disastrous car crashes for the Giants defense, then the offense was a group of rubberneckers, standing idly by as the wreckage piled up around them.

description: preen \pren\ verb

title: Joe Dressner, Importer of Old World Wines, Dies at 60
description: Joe Dressner, an importer whose advocacy of Old World wines made without chemicals or manipulation inspired a sort of natural wine avant-garde, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60.

title: James M. Cannon, an Adviser to Ford, Dies at 93
description: James M. Cannon, a former journalist who advised top policy makers in Washington, including President Gerald R. Ford, for whom he told New York City that it was on its own in coping with its 1970s fiscal crisis, died on Thursday at a hospice in Arlington, Va. He was 93.

title: Kurt Sanderling, Eastern Bloc Conductor, Dies at 98
description: Kurt Sanderling, an often acclaimed German-born conductor who spent most of his career in the Communist world after finding refuge from the Nazis there during World War II, died on Saturday in Berlin. He was 98.

title: NYT Front Page for 09/20/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/20/11

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Papers Tuesday
description: The effects of the 6.8-magnitude earthquake that struck Sikkim on Sunday evening continued to surface as the death toll in India, Nepal and Tibet reached 71, while many more are feared dead buried under the debris of buildings. (Hindustan Times) At the epicenter of the quake, in north Sikkim,the count rose to 41 on Monday. Sikkim Chief Minister Pawan Kumar Chamling said that along with the national highway, state highway and other important linking roads, the electricity transmission lines and water supply have also been affected. Though nearly 6,000 army and paramilitary forces personnel were deployed, landslides and blocked roads hindered their ability to reach the most severely affected areas. (Times of India)Narendra Modi continues to dominate headlines as he ended his three-day fast with a speech urging India to dream like Gujarat.(Indian Express) He also announced a one-day fast in every district of the state to strengthen the spirit of unity and brotherhood. While his closing speech steered clear of the 2002 riots, he attempted to reach out to the Muslim population with claims to pluralism and Urdu advertisements drawing a parallel with Roza  the monthlong fast during Ramadan. (Hindustan Times) However, when a maulvi, or religious scholar, offered him a skullcap as a mark of respect Modi refused, accepting a shawl instead.

title: Giants Replay: Sept. 19
description: The Giants overcame numerous problems on offense to beat the rams 28-16 on Monday night.

title: I Did Not Pay a Bribe: Vaccinations
description: The Anna Hazare movement has sparked a national outpouring of confession and complaint about bribe-paying. Distraught parents searching for missing children, commodity traders, home buyers, rickshaw drivers  people from all walks of life  have come forward with tales of being forced to hand cash to government employees to secure a job, a birth certificate, a home or even their familys safety.

description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, The Changing Face of the Burning Man Festival.

description: SANA, Yemen  Street battles raged for a third day on Tuesday in Sana, Yemens capital. A dozen protesters were killed as the conflict between government security forces and soldiers loyal to an army commander who has defected threatened to derail hopes for a resolution of the nations months-long political stalemate.

description: Lionel Anderson is an academic adviser at The Fox School, the undergraduate and graduate business school at Temple University, where he leads an initiative to raise graduation rates. A decade ago, he received a New York Times College Scholarship, which he used to attend the University of Pennsylvania and earn bachelors and masters degrees.

description: ISTANBUL  A bombing attack in central Ankara on Tuesday killed three people and wounded at least 34, the interior minister said, in the first deadly bombing in Turkeys capital in more than four years. Three of the wounded were in critical condition late Tuesday.

description: A provision of the new child nutrition bill requires schools to serve more fresh produce and less whole milk in lunchrooms, but they also may be forced to raise prices.

title: My Struggle With Pricing
description: We had plenty of inquiries, but no sales in the last week of August and the first two weeks of September. Frankly, Im a little bit nervous. Dry patches are not unheard of in this business, but three weeks is about as long as I have gone without a new order. Maybe it was just the end of summer, and decision makers werent around to make decisions. We could well get a clump of new business soon  we have lots of proposals sitting out there, the clients swear that the jobs are still alive, but still. Why dont they pull the trigger? Is it fear of a recession? Or could it be our pricing? At the beginning of August, after months of good sales, I made a very slight adjustment to our pricing, adding in an extra 2 percent for the salesmen. Did that slight hike make a difference?

title: Solar Installations Rise, but Manufacturing Declines
description: Installations of solar panels are still expanding in the United States, but manufacturing is down, and a great deal of factory capacity is idle, according to a report on the solar energy market for the second quarter of this year.

title: Battling for Street Fare Honors
description: Awards aficionados mourn no more  the Emmys may be over, but a contest perhaps more relevant to New Yorkers daily lives fast approaches.

title: When Its Payback Time in the Gilded Hamptons
description: The president hasnt punished the rich, and neither has Congress. There is plenty of resentment for the wealthiest Americans, who have coasted through the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression without a tax increase or a dip in lifestyle.

title: Visions of an Age When Oil Isnt King
description: Daniel Yergin is Americas most influential energy pundit, and the book that put him on the map was The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power (1991). It was a best seller, won a Pulitzer Prize and was tailored into a popular PBS mini-series. In the two decades since, Mr. Yergin, operating as a kind of one-man think tank, has had a virtual monopoly on the subject of energy and geopolitics. Such is his influence that one half expects his competitors to file antitrust litigation against him.

title: Asked & Answered | Christopher Bollen
description: As the longtime editor of downtown magazines like V and Interview, the writer Christopher Bollen has lived for years at the center of New York life in all of its diverse iterations, from creative glitz through cutthroat entrepreneurialism to the desperation bred by failed dreams. In Lightning People (Soft Skull, $25), his first novel, Bollen turns his inside-as-inside-gets perspective and experience with young creative Manhattanites into fertile literary ground, cultivating a tale of the city as universal and globe-spanning as it is singular and all his own. Bollen will take part in a talk, and a reading, at the Union Square Barnes & Noble on Thursday. Following the release of his book last week  and the expected release party filled with art and fashion luminaries  The Moment sat down with Bollen to ask a few questions.

title: The Dangler Zone
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Reflections on a Parking Meter
description: Not to make too much of a relatively minor event, but when Manhattans last old-time parking meter was yanked down on Monday, it meant the end of a symbolic target for some rebellious spirits.

title: Music Video | Girls
description: The band, Girls, premieres the music video for "Honey Bunny" at The Moment blog.

title: The TV Watch: Two and a Half Men Offers a Charlie Sheen Roast of Its Own
description: The Charlie Sheen roast on Comedy Central was a cake walk compared with the season premiere of Two and a Half Men on CBS on Monday. That wasnt a sitcom romp, it was more like watching Iraqis tear down statues of Saddam Hussein in the early days of the American-led invasion.

title: Do I Have To Read Ron Suskinds Book?
description: OK, obviously I do have to read his account of what went wrong. But I was tearing my hair out, very much in public, over the missed opportunities early in the Obama administration in real time, as they happened; I dont see much point in dwelling on them again, at least for now  maybe Ill want to do postmortems after Rick Perry is sworn into office.

title: T Exclusive Video | Honey Bunny by Girls
description: San Franciscans sometimes get a bad rep. On behalf of all of the Bay Area (or so it seems), watch the Girls frontman Christopher Owens play about town singing lyrics like, They dont like my bony body, they dont like my dirty hair, in their new video for the track Honey Bunny, off their recently released sophomore album, Father, Son, Holy Ghost (True Panther Sounds). Surprisingly, the title of this record, which was released last Tuesday to rave reviews, does not directly refer to Owenss childhood in the infamous Children of God cult, he said. Instead, the moody album  filled with heavy metal riffs that channel Fleetwood Mac, and light 60s strumming that brings you back to the Beach Boys, supported by hallowing gospels  reaches down deeper than that: to Owenss relationship with women, primarily his mother. This record is no doubt less lo-fi than their first, but the straightforward and honest sentiment Owens and the bassist and producer J.R. White bring feels evermore present. Currently on a United States tour, Girls talked to The Moment about their new song Honey Bunny, which Owens initially wrote using his cellphone, and the video, imagined by White. Girls will play at New Yorks Bowery Ballroom on Thursday and Friday.

title: Georgia Pardons Board Denies Clemency for Death Row Inmate
description: ATLANTA  Barring an unimaginable legal reversal, Troy Davis will be executed by lethal injection at a Georgia prison on Wednesday.

title: There Are Worse Things Than Inflation
description: Like me, Tim Duy comes down hard on Paul Volckers inflation-is-historys-greatest-monster op-ed. I pointed out that the last time we were in an economic trap resembling our current predicament, inflation actually helped get us out. Duy adopts a somewhat different but complementary approach: he asks just how bad the evil inflationary 1970s actually were. And the answer is, not nearly as bad as the noninflationary 00s. For example:

title: Romney Recruits Congressional Republicans
description: Mitt Romney is stepping up his effort to consolidate the support of the Republican establishment and announced on Tuesday that he was forming a Congressional team to recruit party leaders to join his campaign.

description: Stocks rose for most of the Wall Street trading session on Tuesday before faltering in the final hour as investors weighed the prospects for progress on debt problems in Greece and possible new action by the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy, analysts said.

description: Updated, 12:18 p.m. | Seventeen people were injured when a building scaffold collapsed onto a city bus at West 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Harlem around 9:25 a.m. Tuesday, the Fire Department said. Fire officials described the injuries as minor and not life threatening and said no one was missing.

description: The finalists for the Vendy Awards, given annually to street vendors, are Solber Pupusas and Mexican Tamales Guadalupe, both in Brooklyn; Chimichury el Malecn, Washington Heights; Eggstravaganza, the Upper East Side; Sams Falafel and Souvlaki GR, both in the financial district; and the Trini-Paki Boys Halal Food, Midtown, City Room reports.

title: Can the Paddlefish Sustain Itself?
description: Fisheries biologists in the northeastern reaches of the Mississippi River Basin report mixed success so far in a joint effort to restore paddlefish, a prehistoric native that disappeared during the industrialization of the region a century ago.

description: What do you do after you retire at 41 from a popular and influential rock band? If youre James Murphy, frontman of the indie dance act LCD Soundsystem, you dabble. That includes cooking with Inaki Aizpitarte, chef of Le Chateaubriand in Paris, for Le Grand Fooding, the offbeat French festival of culinary arts in Manhattan. Read more from Melena Ryzik on Diners Journal.

title: Safety Agency Investigates Ford Minivans and the Jeep Liberty
description: Following the report of a death and three injuries, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has begun investigating collapsing tire jacks on about 206,000 Ford Freestar and Mercury Monterey minivans from the 2004-5 model years. In a separate action, the agency has upgraded its investigation into rear suspension failures on about 200,000 Jeep Liberty S.U.V.s from the 2004-5 model years.

title: Assassination Deals Blow to Peace Process in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An assassin with explosives hidden in his turban was ushered into the home of the head of Afghanistans peace process on Tuesday, embraced him and then exploded the bomb, killing him and dealing a potentially devastating blow to the effort to reconcile with the Taliban and end 10 years of war.

title: Face of Mets Franchise Has Undergone Changes
description: As Andrew Keh wrote in Tuesdays Times, David Wright is coming to the end of the worst season of his career statistically. There are no clear answers for what has caused the arc of his career to streak downward at such an alarming rate at such a young age. But clearly Wright, once an All-Star and expected to man third base in Flushing for years, is uncomfortable with his own performance and with struggles of the team.

title: Exercise Spurs Teenage Boys to Stop Smoking
description: For teenagers struggling to quit smoking, a new study has some advice. To break the habit, try breaking a sweat.

title: State Investigates Report That Cattle Prod Was Used on Disabled Man at Group Home
description: ALBANY  State officials are investigating an accusation that a state worker repeatedly used a cattle prod on a developmentally disabled resident at a group home outside Albany.

title: Diner Musical, by Barry Levinson and Sheryl Crow, Is Setting a Place on Broadway
description: Will this be the first Broadway musical where youll have to pass a football trivia contest before they let you take your seats? A singing, dancing version of Diner, Barry Levinsons 1982 coming-of-age comedy about a group of friends growing up in Baltimore in 1959, is headed to Broadway next year, its press representatives said on Tuesday. Mr. Levinson, who directed the original film and earned an Academy Award nomination for its screenplay, will write the book of the Diner musical, and Sheryl Crow will write the music and lyrics; Kathleen Marshall, a recent Tony Award-winner for her choreography of Anything Goes, will direct and choreograph this production.

title: A Ballet First: An American to Join the Bolshoi
description: David Hallberg, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will join the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow, the first American to do so. The Bolshoi said he would have a starring role for the 2011-12 season.

title: Ex-A.I.G. Chief Hosts Perry Fund-Raiser
description: Rick Perry minces no words in declaring what he thinks of the 2008 TARP bailout of big banks, saying in his book that such programs turn America upside down, totally undermining the idea of limited government, free markets and federalism.

title: Farewell, Dams. Hello, Salmon?
description: A symbolic turn for salmon habitat restoration in Washington State was marked over the weekend as government officials, tribal members, scientists and engineers gathered for the beginning of the largest dam removal ever in the United States. Two hydroelectric dams are to be dismantled, restoring the Elwha River on the Olympic Peninsula to its natural course.

title: Alexander to Resign Senate Leadership Post
description: UPDATE 3:25 p.m.: Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, the Senates third-ranking Republican, announced on Tuesday that he will step down in January as chairman of the Senate Republican Conference and will not seek a leadership post in the next Congress.

title: Trading Scandal Could Hasten Changes at UBS
description: 8:55 p.m. | Updated  LONDON  As a special UBS committee starts to dissect the unauthorized trades that cost the Swiss financial firm $2.3 billion, UBS executives arrived in Singapore on Tuesday to discuss the future of its investment banking business.

description: Thinking Cap is about work in progress in the world of ideas.

title: GrubHub Raises Another $50 Million, Acquires Dotmenu
description: GrubHub, a service that allows users to order takeout or delivery food from their computers or through mobile applications, has raised $50 million in venture capital. The company, which raised a previous round of $20 million six months ago, will also announce Tuesday that it has acquired Dotmenu, another online food delivery network.

title: Bengals Marvin Lewis Fails on Fourth Down
description: Theres an interesting argument on the Cincy Jungle Web site about whether Coach Marvin Lewis made the right call on going for it on fourth down with the Bengals trailing, 24-22, on Sunday. The Bengals were on Denvers 36-yard line with 3 minutes 9 seconds left, and Lewis bypassed a 53-yard field-goal attempt. (A pass by Andy Dalton was incomplete, and the Bengals turned the ball over on downs and went on to lose.)

title: Making Your Retirement Savings Plan More Equitable
description: How about spurring retirement savings by swapping tax breaks based on income for flat-rate tax credits?

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Burberry
description: Consider Burberrys history as a heritage brand and it follows that wind and weather were the inspiration for this seasons beauty. The hairstylist Neil Moodie wanted to make each girl look as if shed just been out in the crisp air for a walk. He created loose, tousled strands by prepping with Bumble & Bumble Styling Lotion and then using a large-barrel curling iron. This easy approach was in contrast to the polished 1960s girl of last season  especially when topped off with cheery pompom hats. As for makeup, Wendy Rowe used Burberry Beautys new Fresh Glow foundation all over the skin with Russet Blush and Tulip Pink lip color. On the eyes were a trio of shadows: Almond, Taupe and Pale Barley, a gray-gold used at the inner corners.

title: Current TV Hires Cenk Uygur
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated Cenk Uygur, the television and Web show host who left MSNBC in a messy public separation this summer, is joining MSNBCs fledgling competitor, Current TV.

title: Trying to Reverse Post-9/11 Slump in Chinatown, Jostling Hub of Gems and Foot Rubs
description: It was little more than 10 years ago that Vincent Fung could count on a steady trickle of office workers from the World Trade Center area or Wall Street to wander into his jewelry shop in Chinatown. His customers would often splurge on diamond rings or watches because they had just saved money eating a $5.25 chopstick lunch along Mott or Pell Streets.
