title: Politicians, Love Em or Hate Em
description: David Brooks: Politicians, they break your heart. Of course when you admire a politician you know its going to be a bumpy ride. They are driven by circumstances and the jostle of competing constituencies, so you have to allow them a lot of leeway and never give up on them, unless they do something extraordinarily wrong.

title: Obama's United Nations Address
description: In his address to the General Assembly, President Obama reiterated the American position that peace between Israel and the Palestinians will not come through statements and resolutions at the U.N.

title: A Hip-Hop Playlist That Helped Inspire a Play
description: Jonas Hassen Khemiri, the author of the play Invasion!, has cited the authors Marguerite Duras, Italo Calvino and Julio Cortzar as inspirations. But the muses who really sing for Mr. Khemiri go by the names Nas, Dogg and Pharoahe.

title: Falcone Under Fire From G.O.P. Over LightSquared
description: Another group of lawmakers have taken aim at the hedge fund manager Philip A. Falcone, asking for details of his communications with the White House about a telecommunications company he is backing.

title: Whats Happening in This Video?
description: Our colleague J. David Goodman is seeking help from readers in deciphering the above video above. The video shows a dramatic moment of gunfire in the suburbs of the Syrian capital, Damascus. Mr. Goodman asks: Is there an exchange of fire from off camera? Or Are the security forces on screen the only ones shooting?

title: Dressing for Excess | Daphne Guinness at F.I.T.
description: Its tempting to dismiss the Daphne Guinness exhibition at the Museum at F.I.T., which features the extraordinary wardrobe of one of the fashion worlds most visible eccentrics, as an attempt to cash in on the publics appetite for narcissistic excess. But the truth is that the pint-size brewery heiresss passion for design is not only inimitably extreme, its completely sincere. Her funds might run as deep as her walk-in closets, but unlike countless other couture clotheshorses, Guinness doesnt fetishize fashion as a status symbol. Instead, over the years, she has developed a sartorial persona thats one part Victorian damsel, one part sci-fi geisha and 100 percent off-the-wall.

title: Moodys Cuts Ratings on Three Big Banks
France Breaks With Obama on Palestinian Statehood Issue
description: UNITED NATIONS -- President Nicolas Sarkozy of France broke sharply on Wednesday with the effort by the Obama administration and some Europeans to quash the effort by the Palestinians for recognition here, instead calling for enhancing their status in the General Assembly to that of an observer state.

title: Giants React to Talk of Faking Injuries
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants Deon Grant and Jacquian Williams simultaneously fell to the ground clutching their legs in the first quarter of Monday nights victory over St. Louis, Rams quarterback Sam Bradford was visibly perturbed. He screamed toward the Giants defense as he walked off the field during the injury timeout.

title: A Different View of Munch at Paris Exhibition
description: PARIS  The Norwegian artist Edvard Munch has long been associated with emotional instability, melancholia, bursts of paranoia, recurring illnesses and alcoholism. The exhibition Edvard Munch: The Modern Eye that opened at the Pompidou Center here on Wednesday certainly reflects the torment he suffered throughout his life.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: Popping the Question: Will You R.S.V.P. Already?

title: Clyfford Still Paintings to Go to Auction
description: In August officials of the City and County of Denver announced that they had chosen Sothebys to sell four canvases by the Abstract Expressionist painter Clyfford Still to raise money for the endowment of the new Clyfford Still Museum, which is to open there on Nov. 18. The agreement called for Sothebys to try to sell the four as a group to a museum by Monday; if it were unable to do so, the works  which together are estimated to be worth more than $50 million  would then go to auction separately. Christies, the rival auction house that had competed for the sale, was so miffed by Denvers selection of Sothebys that it hired lawyers and lobbyists in an unsuccessful effort to stop the arrangement.

title: White Lies and Worse
description: My friend Roberta has been looking after her mother for years. Shes been concealing the truth from her for years, too. Robertas mother is pretty healthy at age 92, exuberantly odd but lucid  wildly wrong about many things, but shes not demented, her daughter told me. But shes prone to periods of severe anxiety, which then produce stomach pain and indigestion.

title: The Caucus | Israel and the 2012 Race
description: Sept. 21, 2011  A look at complicated politics concerning Israel playing out in the campaign. Also, Mitt Romneys attempt to beef up his credentials as a regular guy.

title: Caucus Video: Israel and the 2012 Race; Mitt Romneys Regular Guy Credentials
description: Mark Landler looks at the complicated politics around Israel playing out in the campaign. Also, Mitt Romneys attempt to beef up his credentials as a regular guy.

title: Well-Grounded Ambitions in London
description: London

title: Martino Gampers Home Away From Home
description: To New Yorkers, the word condo can bring up cringe-worthy thoughts of the characterless, paper-thin new builds going up in every unclaimed inch of Manhattan. But Condominium, a new exhibition by the designer Martino Gamper at the Franco Noero gallery in Turin, Italy, is anything but characterless.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

title: Lobbyists Line Up to Sway Special Committee
description: WASHINGTON  With television cameras rolling last week, aerospace executives warned of dire consequences if Congress cuts hundreds of billions of dollars in Pentagon spending, and they promised a full-throttled campaign to stop it.

title: Guccis New Deco: Hard Going
description: Tom Ford left such an indelible mark at Gucci that when he showed fringed leather skirts and sexy peasants top in London this week, a few guests were surprised, and naturally thought of his Gucci years. My take on the London show was that while it was not as loaded with personality and ageless styles as his first Tom Ford womens line a year ago, the show suggested that he might have felt the need to beef up the day clothes and evening separates. Some of those styles might need a better reinterpretation, looking ahead, but why completely reinvent the Ford look?

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 21
description: United States golfers retained the Junior Solheim Cup with a dramatic victory in Ireland, and the Rugby World Cup continued in New Zealand.

title: Conviction of Syrian Arms Dealer Is Upheld
description: A federal appeals court in Manhattan on Wednesday unanimously upheld the convictions of a Syrian arms dealer and two associates who had been charged in an international sting operation run by the government that defense lawyers had criticized as having unfairly ensnared people.

title: The Caucus | 'Regular Guy' Romney
description: Sept. 21, 2011 - Ashley Parker on Mitt Romney's attempts to beef up his credentials as a "regular guy."

title: The Daily Shoe | Gucci
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Back for More: The Disturbing Mushroom of Lincoln Place
description: With fall just around the corner, youve probably been asking yourself, Whats up with the Disturbing Mushroom of Lincoln Place?

title: Pictures of the Day: Palestine and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Palestine, India and Mexico City.

title: Fed Will Shift Debt Holdings to Lift Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve announced an unconventional plan on Wednesday to reduce borrowing costs for businesses and consumers, trying once more to spur economic growth despite urgings from Republicans that it refrain from any expansion of its stimulus program.

title: NATO Extends Libya Bombing Campaign
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  With armed loyalists of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the fallen Libyan leader, still ensconced in his hometown and a few other redoubts as the seven-month-old Libyan conflict winds down, NATO announced a three-month extension of its bombing campaign on Wednesday.

title: Workshop Production May Help Yank! March on Broadway
description: Yank!, a musical that gained a following during its 2010 Off Broadway run, in part because of its provocative love story between World War II servicemen, has lead actors in place for a four-week developmental workshop this fall that might be a prelude to a Broadway production.

title: Daphne Guinness Finds a New Talent, Hogan McLaughlin
description: The style icon arrived at a show of her wardrobe at F.I.T. in a coat by a young talent whose work bears a striking affinity to the otherworldly designs of Gareth Pugh and Alexander McQueen.

title: Allowing Teenage Boys to Love Their Friends
description: IT is occasionally true that the spark that ignites ones grand, all-consuming work is struck early in life  even by happenstance.

title: Updates on Greenlands Ice
description: New research on the dynamics of Greenlands ice sheets complicates efforts to forecast sea level rise in this century, as the Green Blog reports. Expanding fields of crevasses appear to be limiting the flow of water to the base of the ice through tube-like moulins. That flow has been thought to ease the seaward movement of the ice over bedrock. But the crevasses also warm the ice as liquid water descends deep inside the frozen mass, with that process also potentially speeding its flow. This diagram shows the two types of plumbing:

title: New Dresser, Made to Order
description: DAPHNE GUINNESS sauntered into the exhibition of fashions from her wardrobe at the Fashion Institute of Technology last week wearing a gunmetal cutaway coat that lent her an astral glow. Its designer? Why, Hogan, she casually dropped.

title: The End of R.E.M., and They Feel Fine
description: R.E.M., the underground band from Athens, Ga., that helped invent the alternative-rock sound of the 1980s, said on Wednesday that its members were splitting up after 31 years of making music together.

title: Response to Poor Parents
description: 11:44 a.m. | Updated On Motherlode on Tuesday, the Harvard psychologist Richard Weissbourd took issue with, among other things, an article my colleague Motoko Rich wrote for the Week in Review last spring. Many of you disagreed with Dr. Weissbourds interpretation of Ms. Richs piece. So did Ms. Rich, who sent along this clarification and response:

title: Vick Joins Eagles at Practice but Status Is Unclear
description: PHILADELPHIA  Eagles quarterback Michael Vick, who is recovering from a concussion, participated in the teams walk-through practice Wednesday morning, but his availability for Sundays game against the Giants remained unknown.

title: Watch This | The Only Watch Auction in Monaco
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#523", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);On Sept. 22, The Only Watch charity auction benefiting Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy will be held in the principality of Monaco at 4 p.m.  Greenwich Mean Time +1, to be exact. Now in its fourth edition, this prestigious auction will feature one-of-a-kind timepieces from 40 of the worlds greatest watchmakers. With the Monaco Yacht Show also on site, expect this already dense part of the Cote DAzur to be gridlocked with luxury travelers and watch connoisseurs, auction paddles in hand, though bidding online and by phone is also an option for those staying stateside. Here are a few of the shows expected highlights. Window shoppers are welcome.

title: Emilio Romano Named President of Telemundo
description: 11:15 a.m. | Updated Emilio Romano, the former chief executive for Grupo Mexicana de Aviacin, the Mexican airline carrier, has been named president of Telemundo, the Spanish language network division of NBCUniversal.

title: Lady Antebellum Grabs Top Spot With New Album
description: Lady Antebellum, the country-pop trio that swept the Grammy Awards this year, opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with its new album, Own the Night (Capitol Nashville). It sold 347,000 copies in the United States in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

title: Pressuring the Fed Can Backfire
description: In a statement this afternoon, the Federal Reserve announced that it was engaging in more stimulus, by extending the average maturity of the securities on its balance sheet. This was basically what markets had expected, even though the Republican Congressional leadership wrote a widely reported letter to Ben S. Bernanke, the Fed chairman, urging him not to engage in any more easing.

title: S.E.C. Stumbles Over Its Lawyers Ties to Madoff
description: Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme badly damaged the reputation of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which missed numerous opportunities to stop it. Now, a report by the S.E.C.s inspector general is likely to tarnish the agency further by dissecting an apparent conflict of interest of its former general counsel, David M. Becker, who advised the S.E.C. on how it should deal with Mr. Madoffs investors even though he and his family inherited a Madoff account in his mothers estate.

title: Teaching and Learning About Evolution With The New York Times
description: A profile of the evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins in the Sept. 20 edition of Science Times encapsulated his thinking about evolution:

title: Why Its Not Easy to Freeze Your Childs Credit File
description: In her job as an analyst specializing in the retail banking world, Julie McNelley talks to a lot of bank executives. Recently, she says, she has heard concerns about child identity theft involving the use of a minors Social Security number to commit financial fraud.

title: New Girl a New Hit for Fox in Its Debut
description: The series premiere of New Girl, starring Zooey Deschanel, charmed its way to a ratings victory for Fox on Tuesday night, becoming the highest-rated program of the evening among the broadcast networks in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic and drawing in more than 10 million viewers.

title: Doodling Away on Our Cover
description: Its very easy to fall into clichs for an issue on education. Lined notebook paper, chewed pencils and stacks of books were all out of the question. We knew that designing something original for the magazine would be a challenge.

title: The Place | Budapest, Part One
description: PERIOD PIECESAs retro mania sweeps through Budapest, the remnants of socialism are taking on an ironic sense of style.

title: Longevity Gene Debate Opens Trans-Atlantic Rift
description: A trans-Atlantic dispute has opened up between two camps of researchers pursuing a gene that could lead to drugs that enhance longevity. British scientists say the longevity gene is nearing the end of its life, but the Americans whose work is under attack say the approach remains as promising as ever.

title: Echoes of Top Gun at Iraqs Navy Day Ceremonies
description: UMM QASR, Iraq  Twenty five years ago, I woke up early on a Saturday morning, watched the movie Top Gun and began dreaming of becoming a heroic naval aviator like Tom Cruises character Maverick.

title: Judge Sets February Start for Trial on AT&T Deal
description: The federal judge overseeing the Justice Departments lawsuit seeking to block AT&Ts takeover of T-Mobile USA has set a Feb. 13 date for a six-week trial.

title: For Smith, Time With Giants Is in the Past
description: PHILADELPHIA  The loss of Steve Smith to the Philadelphia Eagles has been evident for the Giants this season in everything from the play of Eli Manning to the comments of the offensive coordinator Kevin Gilbride. Smith, however, does not seem to share the Giants sense of longing.

title: On 100th Birthday, a Salute from San Diego State
description: Hugh McArthur won Southern Californias coveted Dudley Cup interscholastic tennis championship in 1929, led the 1932 San Diego State tennis team, and played competitive tennis in seven decades as he built a career in small business.

title: R.E.M. Remembered
description: It was the summer of 1983. I was just out of high school, and I had by this point repudiated all my Ted Nugent, Led Zeppelin and Rush records. I was a new waver now  at least as much as you could be in suburban Pittsburgh. There were exactly two record stores that sold good music. The best one, Jims Records in Bloomfield, a working-class neighborhood in eastern Pittsburgh, was about a 45-minute drive for me. I had only $10, and I had narrowed my choices down to Care, the debut LP of a British band called Shriekback, and Murmur, R.E.M.s debut LP. For no reason that I recall, I went with the Shriekback. It was a good record. The next week, I picked up Murmur.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Ex-Goldman Employee of Insider Trading
description: 8:16 p.m. | Updated

title: Experimental Treatments for Macular Degeneration
description: Millions of Americans live with macular degeneration, a leading cause of vision loss among older people, and Stargardts disease, a similar condition that arises in late childhood. Stephen Rose, chief research officer for the Foundation Fighting Blindness, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about these retinal degenerative diseases. Here, Dr. Rose responds to reader questions about potential treatments for macular degeneration and Stargardts disease that are currently under investigation.

title: Draw Your Own Citi Field Blueprints
description: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson made it pretty clear this week that changes would be coming to Citi Field. Changes to the dimensions of the playing field, that is, if not to the lineup the team puts on that field.

title: Musicals Festival Diary: Money Worries
description: The New York Times asked the actress Donna Lynne Champlin, who is also a new mother, to be a guest blogger as she rehearses for Jane Austens Pride and Prejudice, a Musical, part of the New York Musical Theater Festival. Here she recounts a meeting about a week ago that helps explain what happens when actors meet paperwork.

title: Will Developers Adopt Adobe Flash 11?
description: Adobe, the software company, introduced on Wednesday the latest version of the Adobe Flash Player, which it hopes will broaden the appeal of the software to televisions and 3-D gaming. But the company will have to persuade developers to adopt the software forinteractivityon the Web and online video as many opt for HTML5 instead.

title: This Years Hot TV Trend Is Anatomically Correct
description: Forget the singing competitions, cop shows, fairy-tale dramas and the Mad Men-style melodramas. For network television this is the season of the vagina.

title: Read This at No Risk to Your Eyes
description: In the subway tube the other morning, my car whooshed past a billboard with a veiled threat: something bad is happening to my eyes.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the West Bank, India and Mexico City.

title: The Crustacean-Covered Volvo and Other Oddities That Thrive in Queens
description: Its a 1984 Volvo, said Richard Carter, crimping a wire on a plastic lobster while the strains of Rock Lobster by the B-52s drifted through Flushing Meadows Corona Park.

title: Suicide Draws Attention to Gay Bullying
description: Five months ago, Jamey Rodemeyer, a Buffalo junior high school student, got on his webcam and created a video urging other gay teenagers to remain hopeful in the face of bullying.

title: Lens: Myrto Papadopoulos
description: Myrto Papadopoulos  Greece

title: No Cards, No Cash. Just a Phone.
description: Plenty of companies would love to get their hands on our wallets. But Google wants to go one step further: it wants to be our wallets.

title: Doubts Gone, Yankees Take Title in East
description: After a quiet off-season in which the Yankees failed to sign the elite pitcher Cliff Lee and saw their bitter rival acquire two marquee hitters, many predicted they would finish behind the Boston Red Sox in the American League East.

title: A Model Professor
description: At a time when tree climbing and the Lord of the Rings language Elvish are both taught at the university level, who could argue that the world of fashion modeling is not also worthy of academic scrutiny? Ashley Mears, a young assistant professor of sociology at Boston University, just came out with her first book, Pricing Beauty (University of California, $27), which succeeds at dissecting the multibillion-dollar global modeling industry not only through traditional methods like interviews and data analysis, but also by resorting to a more gonzo means of academic inquiry. To study models, Mears actually became one.

title: Boses New SoundLink Wireless Speaker
description: There are two schools of thought about the audio equipment maker Bose.

title: Incumbency a Nonfactor in Party Fund-Raising
description: Incumbency, it turns out, does not always have its privileges.

title: TimesCast | September 21, 2011
description: President Obama addresses the United Nations General Assembly; the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof interviews Irans president; and Israels role in the 2012 presidential race.

title: Peace Now, or Never
description: Jerusalem

title: Starter Chic for the Stubbled
description: DIRTBAGS gone legit: New York wouldnt be what it is without them. You know the kind: four days of beard, late lunches at the Smile, late nights at the Boom Boom Room, a getaway house in a shambled corner of Duchess County chosen equally for its anti-Hamptons statement as for the fact that it reminds their renters  were still renting here  of the hellholes they left behind to get to the city in the first place. Theyre creators, if indeed the occasional tangible product, and a very intangible life, can be called creation.

title: Art and Islam
description: A look at the new Islamic galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Apps Can Help Make Dessert, and Wont Sneak a Cookie
description: Of all mobile app users, home cooks may get the most value for the least money.

title: Excerpt: 'Unforgettable'
description: The CBS drama is about a police consultant who remembers almost everything.

title: An Eloquence in Groping for Words
description: Whether plain or fancy, all words are destined to fail on occasion. Thats why so many of us freeze up when we try to write a condolence letter to someone who has just lost a partner or family member. Whatever phrases spill out look so vain, so entirely not up to the occasion. Death, with its conferral of permanent emptiness, swallows up and spits back anything we might say to put it in its place.

title: Browsing the Web by text message; a recent multimillion-dollar hack attack; tech news.
description: Stefan Gromoll, a co-founder of the DOTGO, explains how his companys technology allows people to get information from Web sites by text messaging. David Perry, the global director of education at Trend Micro, offers a security perspective on a recent hacking operation that hauled in three million dollars in six months  and may have compromised several corporate internal networks along the way. This weeks Tip of the Week highlights the Safari Reading List and tech-news roundup of the week takes a look at Google Wallet and the grand opening of the Google Plus social network to the masses, as well as Netflixs new split personality and satellite parts falling from the sky.

title: Survival and Second Chances in Untamed Appalachia
description: Like Charles Fraziers earlier novels, Thirteen Moons (2006) and the best-selling Cold Mountain (1997), his suspenseful, if often heavy-handed, new book, Nightwoods, conjures the untamed land of southern Appalachia with a natives unsparing love and wary respect. Although this novel is set in the early 1960s  not the 19th century like its predecessors  it too recounts both a love story and a story of survival and endurance.

title: Text of the Feds Statement On Monetary Policy Moves
description: The following is the full text of the statement released on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve:

title: For Womens Road Records, No Men Allowed
description: BERLIN  Now added to the list of banned performance-enhancing substances for female distance runners: men.

title: All the News You Want, When You Want It
description: Each morning, bleary-eyed, I retrieve the newspaper, glance at the headlines and toss it on the coffee table to read later.

title: Want More Information? Just Scan Me
description: DURING New York Fashion Week earlier this month, Quick Response (QR) codes  square, checkered symbols that can be scanned with ones smartphone  were as omnipresent as chunky black booties.

title: With $6 Million in New Financing, Zimride Has Some Car Seats to Fill
description: Zimride, a Silicon Valley start-up looking to bring carpooling into the age of social media and smartphones, announced this week that it closed $6 million in its first round of venture capital investment.

title: The Kings of Studios Now Revel in the Road
description: Steely Dan rested suavely on its laurels at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night. The concert was part of a seven-night stand featuring live versions of full albums, among them The Royal Scam, from 1976, performed on Tuesday and also slated for the last Beacon show on Friday.

title: Korean Nuclear Envoys Hold Constructive Talks
description: BEIJING  Meetings between the chief nuclear envoys of North and South Korea were constructive, negotiators said, even though the talks did not produce any breakthroughs on the longstanding impasse over the Norths refusal to give up its nuclear program.

title: The Place | Budapest, Part Two
description: BOTTLE STOPS

title: Excerpt: '2 Broke Girls'
description: The CBS sitcom stars Beth Behrs and Kat Dennings.

title: A Shifting Electorate: The Vanishing Rural Voter
description: Voters who live in rural areas are often at odds with their suburban and urban counterparts when it comes to national politics. And as the number of rural voters dwindle, so does their influence  which could have broad implications for how the Republican primaries and the general election play out in 2012.

title: More Interior Scientists Are Taking Heat
description: Scores of scientists work for the Interior Department on issues involving birds and bees, foxes and foxgloves, and all manner of other species and their habitats. But in the eyes of the general public they tend to be virtually anonymous, at best names in italics at the end of a Federal Register notice.

title: Chinatown to Join Roster of Business Improvement Districts
description: The twisting, bustling streets of Chinatown have been given that ubiquitous bureaucratic designation, business improvement district, by a unanimous vote Wednesday of the City Council.

title: Lars von Trier Says Actually, He Isnt Sorry
description: The Danish film director Lars von Trier, who found himself at the center of controversy for saying he was a Nazi at a Cannes Film Festival press conference in May, told GQ magazine that although he had apologized for the remark at the time, he was not sorry about the remark  only that he didnt make it clear that he meant it to be a joke.

title: For Shapely Brows, Put Down the Tweezers
description: TAKE your tweezers, Maribeth Madron, a makeup artist and eyebrow specialist in New York, will say to about a quarter of her clients, and put them in a glass jar and freeze them.

title: YouTube Will Now Convert Videos to 3D
description: YouTube is announcing today a new feature to convert existing uploaded videos to 3D. By tonight, users clicking the Edit Info button on an uploads Watch page will see the option to convert already-uploaded or new standard two-dimensional clips to 3D.

title: Excerpt: 'Charlie's Angels'
description: The ABC series is a remake of the 1970s show.

title: Interview: Andrew Haigh
description: Andrew Haigh, the writer and director of "Weekend," discusses his film.

title: AOLs Stock Plummets, Again
description: Another day, another AOL stock plunge.

title: Peter Gatien, Club King Without a Club
description: TORONTO is not New York. The streets are too wide and clean, the subway too straightforward, the street fashion seemingly nonexistent. Its not the kind of city where youd expect to find someone who once made a fortune off New Yorks freakish glamour and lust for late-night fun.

title: Trial Run
description: The hair wars are heating up. Last Friday, Drybar  the West Coast-based blow-dry chain  opened at 4 West 16th Street in Manhattan, featuring chick flicks (subtitled so they can be enjoyed despite the din) and iPhone charging. Its the first of two Manhattan outposts slated for fall (the other will be in Midtown), offering $40 blowouts  regardless of hair length. Since the price is set, theres no pressure, Alli Webb, a Drybar founder, said at the press preview as she masterfully styled me.

title: TV Chat: Ask the Critics
description: Which new TV shows are worth a try? Which returning ones deserve a second look? The New York Times critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger were discussing all things television Thursday afternoon with Times readers. Mr. Genzlinger, wondering if he needs a therapist, or perhaps a priest, or maybe a neurosurgeon, reported that two of his favorite new shows so far this season were aimed at demographics that he is decidedly not in: The Secret Circle on CW, and 2 Broke Girls on CBS. But to Mr. Hale those choices were perfectly understandable.

title: Excerpt: 'Prime Suspect'
description: The NBC series is a remake of a British series.

title: Kindle Connects to Library E-Books
description: For years the availability of free e-books from libraries was something of an underground secret.

title: Scene City: Hey You Look Familiar
description: After a staged reading of the play 8, real people involved with the Proposition 8 trial and the fight to legalize gay marriage in California mingled with the stars who played them.

title: Excerpt: 'Revenge'
description: The ABC series stars Emily VanCamp as a vengeance seeker in the Hamptons.

title: House Rebukes G.O.P. Leaders Over Spending
description: WASHINGTON  House Republican leaders suffered a surprising setback on Wednesday when the House rejected their version of a stopgap spending bill, leaving unclear how Congress will provide money to keep the government open after Sept. 30 and aid victims of a string of costly recent natural disasters.

title: Views of Perry Turn More Negative Since First Debate
description: Whether Mitt Romney has gained ground on Rick Perry in the Republican primary race is questionable. Polls released since Mr. Perrys first debate on Sept. 7 show him leading Mr. Romney by an average of 8 percentage points. By contrast, Mr. Perry led Mr. Romney by 11 points in polls released between the announcement of his candidacy on Aug. 13 and the Sept. 7 debate.

title: Female Detectives Revived: One Tough, Others Stylish
description: The heroine of Prime Suspect takes a punch. Actually, she is beaten and almost killed after single-handedly confronting a crazed suspect. The next day, her face is swollen and bruised.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Sept. 22
description: Four questions for Nadine Ferber Abramcyk, workwear with girlish touches, hybrid shoot books, and more.

title: Jeter Gets the Last Laugh
description: Fans who were calling for Derek Jeter to step aside earlier in the season better be careful what they wish for, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Jeter Gets the Last Laugh
description: Fans who were calling for Derek Jeter to step aside earlier in the season better be careful what they wish for, says William C. Rhoden.

title: New Ways to Dance, Found in the Eyes of Others
description: As experimental choreographers and dancers working in New York in the 1990s, Wally Cardona and Jennifer Lacey knew each other without truly knowing each other. But they did share one heady dance experience: before Ms. Lacey moved to Paris in 2000, they took part in an improvisation in the East Village. My memory of it was like: Ah! Shell cut me! Mr. Cardona said. That was my image of Jennifer. She was so sharp. She was like a knife.

title: Angry Birds
description: Although ostrich esh is promoted as a leaner, more healthful alternative to other meats, the bird itself can be a health hazard to ostrich farmers.

title: Striving for Objectivity, First in Molecular Biology, and Then in Choreography
description: Artists very quickly acquire inescapable summaries. (Think of Robert Mapplethorpe: culture wars photographer.) Xavier Le Roy, when not saddled with conceptual choreographer gets molecular biologist turned dance artist.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: Bermuda Bowl Competitors Fight Online in a Practice Bout
description: Last Sunday the two American teams in next months Bermuda Bowl world team championship played against each other over 48 boards on Bridge Base Online.

title: Hey, You Look Familiar
description: REALITY television could not hold a candle to the piece of reality theater presented on Monday. Why bother with a housewife or anything like a Snooki, when you could see John Lithgow, Morgan Freeman, Christine Lahti, Ellen Barkin and Cheyenne Jackson playing the real people in a dramatization of the Proposition 8 trial in California?

title: Peters Mountain Works
description: When John Peters, the guy who created the modern messenger bag, invites you up to his home in Saugerties, N.Y., to see his latest project, you go and look. But mostly you listen. Peters, whose tall and skinny frame can be attributed to the years he spent climbing in New York, New Hampshire and beyond, touches on about 20 things at the same time  from A.T.V.s to Levon Helms Midnight Rambles. But its talk about his latest collection of bags, called Peters Mountain Works, that overshadows all. The line is the culmination of many things: the sewing skills that Peterss mother taught him growing up in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; the collection of packs he later started in New York with a fellow climber he met at the Shawangunks; the now ubiquitous line of cordura messenger bags that Peters created (that line, with the red and white skyscraper logo), which would begin its takeover of Manhattan in the early 1980s  a little hillbilly line from Upstate, he calls it, though it was anything but.

title: Green Houses Grow on the National Mall
description: Free for dinner in Washington? Nineteen groups of architecture students will be serving meals next week at houses they have built in West Potomac Park, adjacent to the National Mall, as part of the Department of Energys biennial Solar Decathlon, a kind of Americas Got Talent for green architecture. The ambience at their dinner parties is one of 10 areas the students will be rated on. Others include market appeal, design, adequacy of hot water and affordability (a category added after a $2 million house from Germany won the 2009 competition).

title: Poker Site Fires Back Over Ponzi Scheme Charge
description: Prosecutors are throwing the book at Full Tilt Poker. A lawyer for the embattled online poker company is throwing a book back: the dictionary.

title: A Sweet Little House in Toronto
description: Dating to the 1930s and covering 2,442 square feet of space, the house recently underwent a complete renovation.

title: Wall St. Protests Continue, With Arrests at Morning March
description: Four protesters were arrested in the financial district on Wednesday in the demonstrations that have been going on in and around Wall Street since Saturday, the police said.

title: House Hunting in ... Toronto
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM THREE-AND-A-HALF BATH BRICK HOUSE IN TORONTO

title: My Three Favorite Novels to Read as a Teenager
description: Once you move past Are You There God? Its Me, Margaret, by Judy Blume, which is the perfect thing to read (if youre a girl) right before full teenagerness sets in, these three books immediately come to mind. Thinking back, I couldnt remember much about the plots, but what stayed with me through the years is the feeling they left me with. A sense of unsettled discomfort, but also an excitement at the realization that they provided a window onto the next more complicated, confusing  and perhaps cruel  phase of life.

title: On the Case: Investigator, Billionaire and Some Nosy Software
description: Person of Interest represents a reunion: J. J. Abrams, executive producer, and Michael Emerson, star, together again and hoping to recapture some of that Lost magic.

title: Twitter Starts Selling Political Ads
description: Twitter began selling political advertising on Wednesday to about a half-dozen presidential candidates and national party committees under a pilot program that allows specific posts to appear in the timelines of people who follow campaigns and to pop up when certain search terms are used, Twitter officials announced.

title: On Location | Sweden
description: The narrow, triangular house, built in a lakeside suburb of Stockholm, has all three facades obscured by trellises and is surrounded by gardens.

title: A House Enveloped in Greenery
description: VIKSBERG, Sweden  For nearly three decades, there was little about their surroundings that Elisabeth Krausz and Peter Sjogren found disagreeable when they lived in Ostermalm, an affluent enclave in Stockholm. They were near ornate castles, cobblestoned streets and harbors dotted with pristine white boats.

title: Excerpt: Person of Interest
description: The CBS series stars Michael Emerson and Jim Caviezel.

title: Robert Wilson, Director, on His Passion for Chairs
description: While he is best known for his theatrical work, the avant-garde stage director and playwright Robert Wilson is an all-around creative soul who, among other things, also paints, draws, sculptures and designs lighting and furniture. Mr. Wilson earned a degree in architecture from Pratt Institute and at one point studied with the architect Paolo Soleri in Arizona. And his furniture  mostly chairs  are at museums like the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and the Centre Pompidou in Paris.

title: Produce Importer in Food Safety Fight
description: When health investigators identified imported cantaloupes as the source of a salmonella outbreak early this year, the importer agreed to a recall. But now that company, Del Monte Fresh Produce, is trying to block additional restrictions on melon imports, setting off an unusually public battle between the produce industry and food safety regulators.

title: Homes for $1 Million
description: A contemporary in Boulder, Colo., a condo in an 1890 building in Boston, and a circa 1780 house in Virginia.

title: What You Get for ... $1 Million
description: BOULDER, COLO.

title: In Connecticut, Customizing a Modular House
description: A Lakeville couple created a loftlike home from a prefabricated shell and filled it with furniture of their own design.

title: Shopping for Art Deco Objects
description: The London designer Guy Oliver shopped for pieces in the 1920s style, both originals and reproductions.

title: Sales at Missoni Home, Alessi and Others
description: Calico Corners is taking 20 percent off fabric, trimmings and furniture, through Sept. 24 (Manlius fabric by Thom Filicia, regularly about $53 a yard, is about $42); (800) 213-6366.

title: For Michele Varian, Roomier Quarters
description: Michele Varian was an early adopter of Crosby Street. Her home furnishings store has had two spots on the now-coveted block between Broome and Grand Streets in the last decade. Last week, she moved again, to a space on Howard Street recently vacated by Ted Muehling (who opened his new store two days ago at 52 White Street).

title: KleinReids New Chalices and Goblets
description: Prime, a series of voluptuous hand-turned porcelain vessels with walnut pedestal bases, is the newest collection from the New York design studio KleinReid. Weve been in a chalice-and-goblet phase, explained David Reid, one of the designers.

title: Wade Graham on Fashioning a California Eden
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Market Ready
description: This is the first in a regular series of articles on strategic home repairs and redecorating that can be done to prepare a home for sale.

title: For Kids, a D.I.Y. Web Site
description: Last winter, Timothy Dahl, founder and editor of the six-year-old home improvement blog Charles & Hudson (charlesandhudson.com), and his wife, Laura, a fashion designer, learned that she was pregnant. In addition to the usual prenatal preparations, they developed Built by Kids (builtbykids.com), a Web site devoted to do-it-yourself projects that parents and children can collaborate on, like herb gardens planted in a wheelbarrow, refurbished tatami tables and handmade wagons. The tasks were tested and refined during a series of daylong workshops with friends at the couples Los Angeles bungalow.

title: Art Deco Objects
description: WHEN the ballroom at Claridges hotel, one of Londons oldest Art Deco buildings, was in need of refurbishment not long ago, the powers that be called on Guy Oliver. Mr. Oliver, 42, is the managing director of the interior design firm Oliver Laws and an authority on the period. He did the interiors of Bryanston Court, the hotel where Wallis Simpson once lived, and is consulting with the Cleveland Museum of Art about a future exhibition on the 1920s style.

title: Making a Prefab Home Their Own
description: Lakeville, Conn.

title: An American Eden in Los Feliz
description: Wade Graham, a garden designer, created an idyll at a 1924 Spanish colonial revival home in Los Angeles.

title: Designers and Their Kickstarter-Funded Projects
description: From furniture to iPhone stands to jellyfish tanks, a sampling of design projects that drew supporters on Kickstarter.

title: On Kickstarter, Designers Dreams Materialize
description: PAULA PATTERSON was back in her studio the other night, where she has spent nearly every weeknight and too many weekends to admit since January. From her day job as a graphic designer at an executive search firm in Midtown, she takes the subway and the fickle B61 bus to Brooklyn (I dont know why they print a schedule, she said). That leaves her about two hours to build another V-Luxe, the iPad stand she designed as a birthday gift for her boyfriend last summer and soon after decided to market online.

title: Millionaires, The Middle Class, and Taxes  Actual Numbers
description: Further to this post about whether the Obama/Boo-Fay  sorry, Obama/ Buffett with two ts  claim is true: the Tax Policy Center has new numbers about the distribution of average tax rates by income class. Consider, in particular, the estimates of the combined income and payroll tax by income class; Ive deleted a couple of columns to make the thing fit with more or less legible type:

title: Facebooks Latest Updates Have Fans and Foes
description: Its been a busy couple of months for Facebook and its 750 million users.

title: Belge Epoque
description: Before Christina Vantzou, a Kansas City, Mo.-born art student, fell in love with an American expat during a layover in Brussels seven years ago, she had never given the city a second thought. She assumed it was as bland as everyone said, and when she packed her bags and moved there soon after, she found plenty of Europeans who agreed. The people I was hanging out with at the time referred to it as the Mexico of Europe, she says. Everyone wanted to go to Paris or London or Amsterdam, and Brussels was just this weird place in the middle.

title: New Round of Measures for Austerity in Greece
description: ATHENS  Facing mounting pressure from the foreign lenders keeping it solvent, the Greek government on Wednesday announced additional  and deeply unpopular  austerity measures, including scaling back the public sector and cutting pensions.

title: Fighting Corruption in the Puerto Rico Police Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bahrain Story: The Governments Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Drama at a Georgia Prison
description: Troy Davis filed an eleventh-hour plea Wednesday asking the United States Supreme Court to stop Georgia authorities from executing him for the murder of an off-duty police officer.

title: Top Donors to the Deficit Committee Members
description: Table of top donors to deficit committee members.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Browsing by Texting
description: Smartphones and tablets have changed the way people get information from the Web, but not everyone has, wants or can afford an expensive mobile device. But what if you could use a basic feature available on almost every cellphone to get information from Web sites just by sending simple text messages? Stefan Gromoll, a former astrophysicist and now a co-founder of the company Dotgo, explains just how to do that with the technology he helped develop.

title: Rangers Concussion Was Not Disclosed
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The disclosure by the Rangers this week that defenseman Marc Staal sustained a concussion last February has put a spotlight on the N.H.L.s policy on public disclosure of injuries.

title: Nunez Fills In With a Homer
description: Yankees infielder Eduardo Nunez has done a lot of filling in this season. In Wednesdays first game, he did his part to fill in part of the playoff picture, stroking an 0-1 pitch over the left-field fence to tie the score, 2-2, in the eighth, helping the Yankees to a 4-2 win over Tampa Bay and a postseason berth.

title: Moodys Downgrades Credit Ratings of Three Large Banks
description: Moodys cut its credit ratings Wednesday on three large banks  Bank of America, Citigroup and Wells Fargo  underscoring the challenges the sector still faces three years after the onset of the financial crisis.

title: Hewlett-Packard Weighs Deal Options
What Do Test Scores Tell Us?
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: A Disruptive Force for Opposing Offenses
description: It was just another play in a long season, late in the first half on a sunny Sunday during a forgettable game last year between Oakland and Arizona.The Cardinals were driving, with a second-and-10 on the Raiders 33-yard line.The All-Pro Larry Fitzgerald was in the left flank, with nothing but grass and a lone Raider near him.At the snap, Fitzgerald took a hard step inside, setting up that solitary Raider to be beaten outside when Fitzgerald broke back toward the sideline, the route designed for a lobbed pass over his defenders head.

title: Ohio Woman Describes Becoming a Suspicious Person
description: On the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Shoshana Hebshi, 35, a freelance writer and stay-at-home mother of 6-year-old twins from a suburb of Toledo, Ohio, was on a plane flying from Denver to Detroit when something she  or another passenger in her row of seats  had done caused the government to scramble F-16 fighter planes and escort Frontier Airlines Flight 623 until it landed safely. The plane was taken to a remote part of the airport, and armed federal authorities handcuffed Ms. Hebshi and her seatmates and took them off the plane. She was placed in a jail cell, strip-searched and interrogated by the F.B.I. before eventually being released. The two men in her row were also allowed to go. Ms. Hebshi says she believes she was detained because she is dark-skinned  she is half Arab, half Jewish. She described her seatmates as Indian. The F.B.I. says it was responding to reports that Ms. Hebshi and the men were behaving suspiciously. But Ms. Hebshi said she was never told what about her behavior, or that of her seatmates, had been alarming to others on the plane. Ms. Hebshi discusses:

title: The Place | Hollywoods Budapest
description: On film, Budapest rarely plays itself. In Evita, it was Buenos Aires. In Munich, it was Munich. Last year, The New York Times called the Hungarian capital Hollywood on the Danube. But while Budapest stands in for many different cities, Rome is increasingly becoming one of its more convincing performances. The city is transformed into Rome in this years Anthony Hopkins thriller The Rite, while Etyek, just west of Budapest, serves as the Eternal City forThe Borgias, a Showtime series about a 15th-century Italian dynasty, in which Jeremy Irons stars as Pope Alexander VI.

title: TimesCast | Obama Speaks at U.N.
description: President Obama addresses the United Nations General Assembly and the Palestinian Authoritys bid for statehood.

title: PGA Finale Sends Players Back to Math Class
description: ATLANTA  This weeks farewell event of the PGA Tour season is two competitions wrapped in one. For fans, and even some contestants, it can be as puzzling as an enigma wrapped in a riddle.

title: After Weeks of Jitters, a Sense of Calm
description: After a few weeks of sweaty palms, sleepless nights and a relentless sense of panic for some college administrators, Wednesday was the first time in weeks that a relative sense of calm took over the college sports landscape.

title: Slavery Becomes a Personal Question Online
description: Do you know how many slaves work on your behalf?

title: Tampa Bay Is Hampered by Struggling Offense
description: The San Francisco Giants last season called it torture, and watching the Tampa Bay Rays, you understand why. It really is hard to win without scoring many runs. The Giants somehow won the World Series last fall with an offense that scored fewer runs than the league average. Now the Rays hope to squeeze into the playoffs the same way.

title: Taking a Stand, and Shedding Arafats Shadow
description: UNITED NATIONS  At the baronial Morgan Library in Midtown Manhattan the other night, President Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, stood quietly along the edge of a diplomatic reception, avoiding the animated gossip and flowing Champagne.

title: Whitman at H.P.? The Idea Distresses the Tech World
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As speculation swirled Wednesday that Meg Whitman might be brought in to save the troubled Hewlett-Packard, the tech world rendered a verdict: You have got to be kidding.

title: A Papal Homecoming to a Combative Germany
description: BERLIN  Instead of a pleasant visit to his native land, the trip to Germany this week by Pope Benedict XVI promises to be a journey to one of the front lines in the battle over the future of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: 2 Defendants Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
description: Two of the more colorful characters caught in the governments vast insider trading investigation were sentenced on Wednesday, three weeks before its central figure  Raj Rajaratnam  was set to learn his fate.

title: Bullying of Gay Students, and Suicides
description: To the Editor:

title: Century After It Was Banned, Place of Honor for Twain Tale
description: CHARLTON, Mass.  It took only 105 years, but Eves Diary is back on the shelf.

title: The Value of Microfinance
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodrich Sale for $16 Billion Is Confirmed
description: 11:14 p.m. | Updated  United Technologies has agreed to buy the Goodrich Corporation for $16.4 billion in cash, the companies said late on Wednesday, in an effort to expand in the fast-growing commercial aviation business.

title: Breaking News: The Civil War Is Over
description: Judicial opinions on the constitutionality of the new health care law are pouring out of the federal courts. With the general expectation that the Supreme Court will have to resolve what is now a clear conflict between two federal courts of appeals, the individual lower-court decisions have pretty much ceased to make news. By the time the Supreme Court rules, if and when it does, a decision earlier this month by the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., throwing out Virginias challenge to the statute without reaching the ultimate constitutional question, will be all but forgotten.

title: An Interview With Mahmoud Ahmadinejad
description: The following is a transcript of my conversation with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran. The interview was conducted in New York City on September 20, 2011, and served as the basis for this column.

title: Baby Steps
description: My parents left New York City in 1979 and moved north to a Mayberry manqu in Westchester called Irvington. That was just what bourgeois couples did when they were expecting. You cant really blame them. They had spent three years as interns and residents in hospitals in the South Bronx, taking care of patients with gunshot wounds and reviving heroin addicts. The apartment theyd lived in had been burglarized, and besides, they were children of the suburbs themselves.

title: Radical Clerics Path, Now at a Crossroads, Could Turn Iraq, Too
description: BAGHDAD  In a classroom in Sadr City, the bustling neighborhood of the Shiite poor, dozens of men in white shirts and black pants received the most basic of Islamic religious instruction: how to wash before praying.

title: Opposing Views on Perry as Job-Creating Master
description: During Rick Perrys first political campaign almost 30 years ago, a supporter at one stop suggested he take credit for the rain that had broken a dry spell the night before. But his father warned, Son, you can take credit for the rain if you want, but theyll blame you for the drought.

title: For-Profit Colleges, Vulnerable G.I.s
description: Washington

title: Duda Pulled After Crashing Into Wall
description: ST. LOUIS  Right fielder Lucas Duda, who crashed into the wall in right-center field in the first inning while attempting to field a ball hit by Albert Pujols, began experiencing dizziness and was removed in the third.

title: Voting to Hire a Chief Without Meeting Him
description: The mystery isnt why Hewlett-Packard is likely to part ways with its chief executive, Lo Apotheker, after just a year in the job. Its why he was hired in the first place.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mangold Stows Crutches, but Jets Have Their Doubts
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Nick Mangold, the All-Pro center, showed up in the locker room Wednesday with his sprained right ankle in a large, black walking cast. This was good news. Mangold did not need the two crutches propped in his locker.

title: Judge Rejects Challenge to Voting Rights Law by County in Alabama
description: Ruling that the intentional voter discrimination that led to the passage and multiple extensions of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 still exists, a federal judge in Washington on Wednesday dismissed an Alabama countys claim that portions of the act were unconstitutional.

title: What Would Willow the Cat Do?
description: Right now youre probably asking yourself: What has Congress been up to since it raised the debt ceiling?

title: Lurid Confession, Delivered in Calm Tones, Shocks Court
description: NEW HAVEN  The judge at the Cheshire triple-murder trial abruptly sent jurors home about 10 minutes early on Wednesday, saying that one of the panel members was having a tough time with the evidence.

title: Children of the Corn
description: By late summer, most of the corn in America is head high and bristling. The stalks stand shoulder to shoulder like an army without rank, their sharp-edged, swordlike leaves forming a nearly impenetrable wall. A modern cornfield would have rebuffed Cary Grant in North by Northwest because there are no rows to speak of, only a dense lattice of intersecting spears. This corn  grown by the tens of millions of acres  has been genetically engineered, altered by having stacks of apparently desirable traits wedged into its genetic code. Saving the kernels of engineered corn in the fall to plant in the spring is both illegal, because of company patents, and largely irrelevant, since the plants they yield, which contain a packet of foreign genes, wont necessarily resemble the parent crop. Nearly all the corn you see anywhere in our nation of corn is this years model, new and, so they say, improved.

title: Obama Rebuffed as Palestinians Pursue U.N. Seat
description: UNITED NATIONS  A last-ditch American effort to head off a Palestinian bid for membership in the United Nations faltered. President Obama tried to qualify his own call, just a year ago, for a Palestinian state. And President Nicolas Sarkozy of France stepped forcefully into the void, with a proposal that pointedly repudiated Mr. Obamas approach.

title: Free Speech on the Sidewalk
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in a ruling that should cause some cities and towns across the country to snap awake and reread the Constitution, has upheld the rights of day laborers to gather and speak freely in public as they look for work.

title: A Warning Light to Alert the I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund has a new crystal ball of sorts. The lender has found a measure of credit growth that could predict problems. It makes China look precarious and heralds turbulence elsewhere, too.

title: $5 Million Payment to End Suits Over Death of 13-Year-Old Boy in State Care
description: ALBANY  The State of New York has agreed to pay $5 million to settle two civil suits brought by the family of a boy with autism who died in state care, among the larger wrongful-death settlements ever paid by the state.

title: Bill to Legalize Fireworks Awaits Cuomos Decision
description: In much of the country, the Fourth of July is synonymous with backyard fireworks displays. Not so in New York, which is among the dwindling number of states where such fireworks are illegal.

title: Governors Right-Hand Man Returns to Private Sector
description: Nearly five years ago, Steven M. Cohen, a federal prosecutor turned white-collar criminal defender, agreed to leave the courtroom and serve a two-year stint as the chief of staff for the states newly elected attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: With Help From Friends, Folk Art Museum Will Stay Open
description: The quilts will live to see another day.

title: Public Said to Be Misled on Use of the Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON  Two United States senators on Wednesday accused the Justice Department of making misleading statements about the legal justification of secret domestic surveillance activities that the government is apparently carrying out under the Patriot Act.

title: Thursday: Taking Ones Sweet Time
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Some of you will probably disagree with me, but I am of two minds on this puzzle.

title: After the Hard Life of Prison Comes the Hard Life of the Outside World
description: The mundane business of choosing a toothbrush evokes a small crisis in the confusing new life of Monty (Alfredo Narciso), the ex-convict hero of After., a quiet new drama by Chad Beckim that opened Wednesday night at the Wild Project in the East Village. Monty isnt prepared for the daily onslaught of decision making required in civilian life. Hes been incarcerated for 17 years  just about half of his life  and the task of reintegrating into a world he barely recognizes leaves him feeling alienated at every turn.

title: Illinois Redistricting Forces Republican Face-Off
description: CHICAGO  Voters in at least one Illinois congressional district will have to choose between two Republican incumbents next year after Representative Joe Walsh announced Wednesday that he will seek re-election in a new district, pitting him against a fellow Republican, Representative Randy Hultgren, in a primary.

title: The Return of the Elwha River
description: Over the next three years, two huge hydroelectric dams on the Elwha River in Washington State, built early in the last century, will be dismantled to restore ancient salmon runs. This is a tribute to the tenacity of the citizens and environmental groups who helped make it happen. It is also an example of the good that can be done with genuine bipartisan collaboration.

title: Selling Travel With Words, Not Images
description: TRAVEL industry advertising tends to focus on the fantasy of travel, beckoning cubicle dwellers with film of remote beaches where couples run in slow motion, and where opulent hotel rooms include flowers and Champagne.

title: Drama at a Georgia Prison
description: Troy Davis, who was convicted of gunning down a Savannah police officer 22 years ago, was executed Wednesday.

title: Measuring the Recessions Toll
description: Which states had the largest change in poverty rates and median household incomes from 2007 to 2010.

title: Cyprus: Turkey Announces Rival Gas Deal
description: Turkey and the breakaway Turkish part of Cyprus signed a deal on Wednesday to prepare legal grounds for gas exploration around the disputed island in an immediate response to drilling by Greek Cypriots that started early this week. Since the Greek Cypriot Administration has started the drilling activity on Sept. 19, as already announced, a continental shelf delimitation agreement has been signed today, a statement from the Turkish Foreign Ministry statement said. The deal signed by Turkeys Prime Minister, Tayyip Erdoan, and Dervis Eroglu, the leader of the Turkish Cypriots, while attending the United Nations General Assembly in New York, takes into account the legitimate, equal and inherent rights of the Turkish Cypriots like those of the Greek Cypriots over the whole continental shelf of the Island, it said. Turkey has called the search for gas reserves in Eastern Mediterranean by the internationally recognized Greek Cypriot state a provocation, when Ankara supports sharing the regions natural resources equally between the Turkish and Greek communities. The energy reserves in the area have also been explored recently by Israel, which is likely to increase diplomatic and military tensions in the region. SEBNEM ARSU

title: Bloggingheads: Vaccines and Teen Sex
description: Adam Serwer, left, of Mother Jones and Daniel Foster of National Review debate vaccination for sexually transmitted diseases.

title: A Few Words With Irans President
description: Before sparks began flying between me and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, he began my interview with an unusual olive branch: I would like to, with your permission, greet all of your readers as well as Web viewers and wish all of them the success and blessings of the Almighty.

title: LivingSocial May Postpone I.P.O. and Focus on Fund-Raising
description: LivingSocial is considering postponing an initial public offering in favor of collecting about $200 million in a fund-raising round that would value the online coupon company at about $6 billion, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: In Mothers Trial, Man Tells of His Fathers Rage
description: The 21-year-old son of a Queens mother on trial for killing her husband described his father in court on Wednesday as a terrifying and volatile man who had threatened to kill him, his sister and his mother, and whose abuse of his mother ranged from belittling her to pounding her head with his fists.

title: Taxes, the Deficit and the Economy
description: Republicans, predictably, are denouncing President Obamas proposal to raise taxes on wealthy Americans and corporations to help wrestle down the nations budget deficit and pay for his job creation plan.

title: An Interview With Mahmoud Ahmadinejad
description: While speaking with the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof, the Iranian president discusses Syria, the 2009 uprising in his own country and whether Iran is a better democracy than the United States.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,467 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: In Scramble for Land, Group Says, Company Pushed Ugandans Out
description: KICUCULA, Uganda  According to the companys proposal to join a United Nations clean-air program, the settlers living in this area left in a peaceful and voluntary manner.

title: Staying With Children, and Out of Prison
description: From her bare kitchen window, Denise Urquidez can see the big grassy backyard that became a haven for her two young sons. And she wonders.

title: Split Decision and Barbed Comments Show a Court Deeply Divided on Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON  An appellate court decision on Wednesday revealed deep and lingering divisions among a dozen judges over the governments wiretapping powers and the courts ability to regulate them.

title: Even Without Its Bar, Catskill Tavern Still Serves Flood-Bruised Town
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y.  This small town, tucked along the banks of a creek in the Catskill Mountains, was ravaged by Tropical Storm Irene. Main Street was practically washed away, and many of its 650 residents were forced to take shelter at area missions.

title: Corruption Inquiry Rocks Kuwait
description: CAIRO  Two of Kuwaits largest banks thought it a bit suspicious when about $92 million was transferred into the accounts of two members of Parliament.

title: Global Effort to Recruit Teachers Expands
description: Teach for All, an international network of educational nonprofit groups modeled on Teach for America, has grown rapidly since its founding four years ago and now has some 1,500 teachers heading classrooms in more than a dozen countries, with recruiting under way in many more, the groups founder, Wendy Kopp, said on Wednesday.

title: Russian Nationalist Urges Support for Putin
description: MOSCOW  An influential nationalist leader urged his followers on Wednesday to throw their support behind Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, telling them that they will no longer have to shiver at street demonstrations because the Kremlin will grant them access to executive and legislative power.

title: Lawmaker From Nevada Faces Inquiry on Ethics
description: WASHINGTON  Nevada Republicans have filed an ethics complaint against Representative Shelley Berkley, Democrat of Nevada, accusing her of using her office to enrich herself by promoting legislation and intervening with federal regulators to help out her husbands medical practice.

title: U.A.W. Shelves Chrysler Talks and Turns to Ford
description: DETROIT  The United Automobile Workers union said late Wednesday that its next target for reaching a new labor agreement would be the Ford Motor Company, signaling that it was having difficulty coming to terms with Chrysler.

title: Stocks Decline a Day After Fed Sets Latest Stimulus Measure
description: A day after the Federal Reserve announced another measure to bolster the economy, world financial markets tumbled Thursday on fears that governments around the globe collectively still were not doing enough to stimulate growth.

title: Mets Dream About Next Year and Alterations to Citi Field
description: ST. LOUIS  One day after General Manager Sandy Alderson provided reporters with the clearest indication to date that the Mets would make significant changes to the dimensions at Citi Field, he began working on enlightening the men who will play there next season.

title: Idea of One Person One Party Makes for a Crowd in Switzerland
description: ZURICH  When Matthias Phm formed his new Swiss political party, he was determined to reach out to what he considered an underrepresented group. So in May, he created the Anti PowerPoint Party, whose stated mission is to advocate for those souls who, every month, are obliged to be present during boring presentations in companies, universities, or at other institutions, and who had up to now no representation in politics.

title: Battle for Libya | September 21, 2011
description: Rebel fighters fired toward pro-Qaddafi forces from the western outskirts of Surt.

title: Two Arrested in the Killing of a Student
description: Two suspects in the killing of a star high school basketball player in Harlem were arrested on Wednesday in Columbia, S.C., the police said.

title: Norma H. Johnson, 79, Dies; Oversaw Lewinsky Inquiry
description: Norma Holloway Johnson, the chief judge of the United States District Court in Washington who oversaw the grand jury investigation into President Bill Clintons affair with Monica Lewinsky, died Sunday at her brothers home in Lake Charles, La. She was 79.

title: College Football Live Blog: Join the Party
description: Paul Myerberg of The Times will be hosting his own college football watch party all day Saturday, right here at The Quad. Hell bring you highlights and analysis from games around the country, with feeds by Tom Spousta at the Oklahoma State-Texas A&M game and Ray Glier from Arkansas-Alabama, and spend some time answering your questions.

title: Season Is Catching Up to Beato
description: ST. LOUIS  Before taking the mound in the seventh inning of the Mets game against the Cardinals on Wednesday night, Pedro Beato had not pitched since Sept. 15.

title: Brian J. Kelley, Onetime Spying Suspect, Dies at 68
description: Brian J. Kelley, an American counterintelligence expert who helped focus attention on a possible Russian spy in Washington, only to be wrongly suspected of being a K.G.B. mole himself, died on Monday at his home in Vienna, Va. He was 68.

title: Even Beckett Cannot Put a Halt to the Red Sox Slide, as Orioles Rally Late
description: BOSTON  In a period of uncertainty and raw nerves, the Red Sox seem assured of only two reliable dynamics: Josh Becketts right arm and the Yankees.

title: Gen. Donn A. Starry, Cold War Strategist, Dies at 86
description: Donn A. Starry, a retired four-star general and the chief architect of the cold war military strategy for repelling a tank-heavy Soviet invasion of Western Europe, died on Aug. 26 at his home in Canton, Ohio. He was 86.

title: Recipes: Slaws Eight Ways
description: Fennel, beets, kohlrabi, even seaweed: If you can slice it, you can transform it into a surprising slaw.
