description: Milan

title: Fendi: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Milan

title: MaxMara: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Milan

title: Shred Your Inhibitions and Embrace a Surprising Slaw
description: You tell me what a slaw is; I cant really give you a definition. Classic coleslaw is usually made of mayonnaise, shredded cabbage and maybe some other stuff  except when it isnt. (I can tell you for certain that koolsla means cabbage salad in Dutch.)

title: I.T. Departments Lose Their Clout Over Phone Choices
description: Corporate I.T. departments once passed judgment on every kind of technology used in the workplace. Employees had little choice of laptops and mobile phones. But today, because of a gradual loosening in company policies, employees have far greater say.

title: Word of the Day | exemplary
description: exemplary \ig-zem-pl-re\ adjective

title: New Enrollment Dips a Bit at U.S. Graduate Schools
description: Enrollment of new students at graduate schools in the United States dropped slightly from 2009 to 2010, despite an 8.4 percent increase in applications. It was the first decline in first-time graduate enrollment since 2003, according to the Council of Graduate Schools, and came after a 5.5 percent increase the previous year.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
description: Is there a war raging within the government about who failed to properly monitor the sale of valuable mobile phone spectrum? The Indian Express reports that the Finance Ministry sent a letter saying the home minister, P. Chidambaram, who was finance minister at the time of the sale, agreed to sell the mobile phone spectrum at fixed prices rather than auction it. Congress quickly said that Mr. Chidambarams integrity was not in doubt, but the letter raised questions about who knew what, and when, during Indias biggest corruption scandal. (Indian Express)The cost of the damage in the Sikkim earthquake is likely to top $20 billion, state officials said, and the death toll may yet rise. In one North Sikkim village, 120 people have vanished. The government is pledging compensation for those killed and injured and those who lost their property. (NDTV)

title: NYT Front Page for 09/22/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/22/11

title: Data Show Countys Pain as Economy Plummeted
description: GREENWOOD, S.C.  The Greenwood Mills Matthews Plant once employed three generations of Frances Flahertys family. Her grandmother, father and brother made textiles there  denim for jeans and khaki for military uniforms.

title: 35 Seconds
description: Landslide season was supposed to be over. The wet weather had lingered last week as we waited for the monsoons final retreat and the clear skies of October. In Sikkim, landslides are the earths accompaniment to the monsoons, but this year had been merciful, so far.

title: Injuries, Most of Them Real, Continue to Plague the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Starting in training camp, and continuing through the preseason and into the regular season, the Giants have been dealing with a seemingly never-ending deluge of injuries. Season-ending injuries. Nagging injuries. Knee injuries. Foot injuries. And now even fake injuries.

title: Drama at a Georgia Prison
description: Troy Davis filed an eleventh-hour plea Wednesday asking the United States Supreme Court to stop Georgia authorities from executing him for the murder of an off-duty police officer.

title: One in Five New York City Residents Living in Poverty
description: Poverty grew nationwide last year, but the increase was even greater in New York City, the Census Bureau will report on Thursday, suggesting that New York was being particularly hard hit by the aftermath of the recession.

title: India: Sikkim Quake Toll Now Put at 68
description: A company building a hydroelectric power plant confirmed Wednesday that 17 of its workers had died and seven were critically injured as a result of the earthquake that shook the Himalayas in and around the northeastern Indian state of Sikkim on Sunday. The states chief minister, Pawan Chamling, told reporters that 68 people had been killed in Sikkim, and that the property damage exceeded $20 billion. Indian soldiers and rescue workers raced to clear debris and rescue those who remained trapped by landslides. Relief work is going on at war footing, Mr. Chamling said. All the roads are broken and damaged. All the water pipelines are damaged. All the electric lines are damaged and disrupted. It will take months to repair all that. Officials at the company building the plant on the upper reaches of the Teesta River said in a statement that none of the workers had been on duty because it was a Sunday, but had been killed by landslides.

title: In Uganda, Losing Land to Planted Trees
description: According to a report by the aid group Oxfam, the Ugandan government and a British forestry company forcibly expelled more than 20,000 people from their homes in recent years.

title: Britain: Memoir of WikiLeaks Founder Arrives, but Without Its Author
description: The autobiography of the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange will be released on Thursday, despite his withdrawing cooperation for the book, his British publisher said Wednesday. The publication of Julian Assange: The Unauthorized Autobiography follows a contentious battle, according to a statement from the publisher, Canongate Books. Mr. Assange said last December that he had reluctantly signed a book deal worth as much as $1.7 million. I dont want to write this book, but I have to, he told reporters, citing a costly continuing legal battle to avoid extradition to Sweden from Britain to face allegations of sexual abuse there. According to the Canongate statement, Mr. Assange gave 50 hours of interviews to a writer enlisted to help him. But when he saw the first draft of the book in March, he declared All memoir is prostitution, and sought to cancel the contract. In New York, Alfred A. Knopf canceled its contract for the Assange memoir.

title: Unesco in Partnership to Train School Principals in 3 Nations
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is to announce Thursday a partnership with the Varkey GEMS Foundation to train 10,000 school principals in India, Ghana and Kenya. The foundation is the philanthropic arm of GEMS Education of Dubai, United Arab Emirates, a provider of for-profit, private education in Europe, Asia and Africa. By training principals, the program aspires to benefit thousands of teachers and up to 10 million children. The foundation will contribute $1 million toward the partnership.

title: Manchester City Invests in Itself, Using Barcelona as a Model
description: Correction appended below.

title: Corrections: September 22
description: FRONT PAGE

title: California: Police Charged in Killing
description: Two Fullerton police officers face felony charges in a beating in July that left a homeless man dead, the Orange County district attorney said Wednesday. Officer Manuel Ramos was charged with second-degree murder and involuntary manslaughter in the beating of Kelly Thomas, 37, a drifter with schizophrenia who died five days after the encounter with the police, who were responding to reports of attempted break-ins to cars. Cpl. Jay Cicinelli was charged with involuntary manslaughter and excessive use of force.

title: Better Screening Test Is Sought to Detect Infections in Organ Donors
description: Improvements are needed in the screening of organ donors to protect transplant patients from hepatitis B and C, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Wednesday. Transplant centers already test both living and dead donors for those diseases, but many centers use an older type of blood test that cannot detect an infection that was acquired very recently. A newer technique, nucleic acid testing, can find infections earlier. For hepatitis C, for instance, the older test cannot detect the disease during the first 70 days after infection. But nucleic acid testing can find it after seven days. The newer test is already used to detect H.I.V. Infections in organ recipients prompted the new recommendations. From 2007 to 2010, the C.D.C. confirmed dozens of cases of hepatitis B and C and H.I.V. caused by transplants; some patients died.

title: A $42 Million Gift Aims at Improving Bedside Manner
description: CHICAGO  Carolyn Bucksbaum still bristles about an arrogant physician who brusquely dismissed her intuition about her ailment decades ago. It turned out she was right. The physician was wrong.

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 22, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, Rays Pizza, the First of Many, Counts Down to Its Last Slice.

title: Loan Ranger
description: On a hot summer day in Manaus, Brazil, Diana Taylor, the former banking superintendent of New York and longtime companion of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, was strolling through a slum. A city of about two million in the middle of the Amazon, Manaus is where the Boston-based microfinance group Accin International started an ambitious lending operation in February, and Taylor, who is chairwoman of the groups board, had flown down with a delegation of staff and investors to observe how the experiment was coming along on the ground. Nearly six feet tall, thin and wearing large, round sunglasses, khaki pants and leather driving moccasins that had the kind of distressed effect only years of wear can produce, Taylor did not blend in.

title: Sept. 22, 1862 | Preliminary Emancipation Proclamation Announced
description: On Sept. 22, 1862, President Abraham Lincoln issued the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, which declared that some slaves would receive their freedom on Jan. 1, 1863. The New York Times printed the proclamation in its  Sept. 22 edition.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 22, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Families of Bloody Sunday Victims to Be Compensated
description: LONDON  The British government will compensate relatives of victims of the 1972 Northern Ireland shootings by British troops that became known as Bloody Sunday, the Defense Ministry said on Thursday.

title: The End of Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: Note: This edition of 6 Qs uses two articles and a Times Topics page; each question links to the piece in which answers to that question can be found.

title: In Uganda, Losing Land to Planted Trees
description: According to a report by the aid group Oxfam, the Ugandan government and a British forestry company forcibly expelled more than 20,000 people from their homes in recent years.

title: In the Grecian Caves Where Time Slows Down
description: Time slows down in the caves of the Kale. For five families who still live inside the caves along the border between Greece and Turkey, daily life is simple. Wake up. Eat. Nap. Have some coffee.

title: Can the I.M.F. Save the World?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: A Conversation With: Sudhir K. Jain
description: Professor Sudhir K. Jain is an expert in earthquake engineering, and member of several global groups devoted to reducing fatalities during earthquakes. His mantra, and that of many other earthquake experts, is simple: earthquakes alone dont kill people, poor engineering does.

title: How Impulsive Are You?
description: Forty years ago, a researcher tested the self-control of 4-year-olds by offering them the choice of one marshmallow immediately or two marshmallows 15 minutes later. Years later, the 4-year-olds who delayed their gratification were more successful and less likely to abuse drugs than their more impulsive peers. Do you have good self-control? Does your level of self-control seem to resonate in other areas of your life?

title: Pope Weathers Protests and Boycotts in First Official Visit to Germany
description: BERLIN  Pope Benedict XVI divided the capital of his native land on Thursday, celebrating Mass for more than 60,000 followers while thousands of opponents marched through the streets to protest his visit.

title: Rex vs. Hue, and Other Topics
description: Rex Ryan and Hue Jackson. Two tough guys, two hard-nosed coaches. Both were assistants on the 2008 Baltimore Ravens team that lost the A.F.C. championship game to Pittsburgh. Theirs is just one of the story lines going into Sundays game between two franchises  the Jets and the Raiders  that have a long and rich history together.

title: Changes to OnStars Privacy Terms Rile Some Users
description: A new set of terms and conditions for OnStar, the General Motors-supported safety and connectivity system, is generating privacy concerns among some subscribers, many of whom have long raised questions about the potential for abuse. For years, some G.M. car and truck owners have posted elaborate instructions to Internet forums and user groups detailing how to disable built-in OnStar equipment to prevent any tracking of their vehicles.

title: College Counselors Convene in the Big Easy
description: Guidance counselors and admissions officers from across the country are gathering in New Orleans on Thursday for the annual meeting of the National Association for College Admission Counseling.

title: In Paris, Auctioning the Fairground Delights of Yesteryear
description: Until amusement arcades and electronic games muscled in on the action, Parisian fairs were the ultimate in popular entertainment, vibrant with life and color  and gloriously free from political correctness. Now pieces of those fairgrounds can be yours for the having, as a unique collection of games and rides will be on show at the Porte de Versailles exhibition space, from Sept. 23 to 26, before being sold at the Htel Drouot auction room, on Sept. 28 and 29.

title: The Early Word: Setbacks
description: In Todays Times:

title: Obamas Tax Dj Vu
description: After several dispiriting months of watching their president try and fail to find consensus with Republicans, liberals are once again feeling buoyant this week. Thats because President Obama has at last adopted a defiantly populist tone, unveiling a proposed tax increase on the wealthy as his signature issue for however long this particular phase of his peripatetic presidency lasts.

title: Schwarzenegger to Publish Memoir
description: 1:25 p.m. | Updated Arnold Schwarzenegger has led a life that is made for storytelling: Austrian immigrant comes to the United States as an elite bodybuilder, gains fame and wealth as an international movie star, marries a Kennedy and, even more improbably, is elected governor of California.

title: How One Small Group Sets Doctors Pay
description: Despite decades of warnings of a primary care crisis and the fact that some 60 million patients are without primary care doctors, the medical profession has continued to produce legions of specialists.

title: Starting the Netflix of Flowers
description: Last year, two software geeks whod never been anywhere near the flower business  in fact, one of them is, quite literally, allergic to it  started H.Bloom, an online, subscription-based floral delivery service that operates in New York, Chicago and Washington.

title: Globalization Meets Beethoven in Mumbai
description: Recently, this story about how dairy farms in northern Italy had come to rely heavily on the labor of Punjabi immigrants generated a lot of interest. But the traffic hasnt flowed only one way. As Indias economy has expanded, guest workers from around the world have flocked to the subcontinent. Dancers from Eastern Europe frequently appear in Bollywood films; pilots from the United Kingdom are in the cockpits of Indian planes; and the offices of some of Bangalores computer companies could be mistaken for the sets of a Benetton advertisement.

title: Bright, Blinking Beacons That Are Still Easily Missed
description: Neon signs flash and blink and blare. They outline leggy dancers; they scream out LIQUOR; they direct you toward a hotdog. Yet in hyper-stimulated New York, even things designed to be noticed go unnoticed. That is why one woman set about documenting them.

title: Japanese Steel Makers Move Forward on Deal
description: After months of negotiations, Nippon Steel and Sumitomo Metal Industries have hashed out crucial parts of a deal, paving the way for a merger in October 2012 that would form the worlds No. 2 steel maker.

title: Bill for Madoff Trustee Rises to $224 Million
description: Irving H. Picard, the trustee who is liquidating Bernard L. Madoffs investment business, and his law firm asked a judge to approve $45 million in fees for four months work, a number that would bring their total fees in the case to $224 million.

title: Debate Preview: Six Things to Watch
description: The Republican campaign for president remains a geographically limited affair as the candidates bounce between a handful of crucial, early-voting states like Iowa, New Hampshire and Florida.

title: Why Passing Totals Can Be Deceiving
description: Weve seen monstrous passing numbers in this young N.F.L. season. With the rule changes and proliferation of spread offenses, those numbers will only climb in the coming years.

title: The War on Insider Trading: Market-Beaters Beware
description: How much time should Raj Rajaratnam spend in prison? Rajaratnam is the hedge fund founder who was convicted in May of trading on illegal stock tips  tips that produced fantastic results for his Galleon Group. Federal authorities compare him with notorious white-collar crooks like Bernie Madoff and Jeffrey Skilling, and they argue for a long time behind bars. His lawyers, however, say Rajaratnam is a lesser-order felon  not . . . as culpable as a defendant who affirmatively steals, as they put it in a pre-sentencing memorandum. The lawyers raise a problem of culture and law: Is insider trading merely an illicit version of a common American cleverness, trading on gossip from a colleague or friend that helps the trader and hurts no one? Or is it the quintessential Wall Street crime, one that has undermined Americans faith in the markets?

title: Romance and Reflection, Hand in Hand
description: MOST romantic movies are so determined to chart the course of a love story  how boy meets girl leads to happily or unhappily ever after  that they miss the intensity and import of beginnings. But the new British film Weekend, like its closest American predecessor Before Sunrise, lingers on the initial sparks of an erotic and emotional connection. As a one-night stand turns into something more, the film explores the notion that to meet someone new, not least a potential partner, is also to rethink who you are, an invitation to shape and refine the self you wish to project. A story about falling in love that is also a tale of identity and self-definition, it is perhaps all the more resonant for taking place between two gay men.

title: Ghostly Images of Satellite Falling to Earth
description: An amateur astronomer in France captured video of an American satellite as it tumbled through space toward an expected impact with Earth sometime on Friday, according to NASAs latest projections.

title: One-Stop Shopping in Milan
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#283", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);London has Selfridges, Harvey Nicks and Liberty; New York has Bergdorf Goodman, Barneys and Saks; and Paris has Le Bon March, Les Galeries Lafayette and Au Printemps. Milan, on the other hand, has been conspicuously lacking in luxury department stores. But that all changed earlier this month, with the opening earlier of Excelsior, a multilevel shopping destination with a fashion sense that runs the gamut from Dries Van Noten to Balmain (the renowned local boutique owner Antonia Giacinti is a consultant), a trio of restaurants from the local celebrity chef Davide Oldani and departments stocked with everything from retro-fabulous meat slicers to flower arrangements by the edgy florist Numero 9. The former cinema has been reimagined by the architect Jean Nouvel as an ode to the history of film: floors are laid out as parapet balconies, and wraparound L.E.D. screens show a continuous stream of film stills. Even the sales clerks dress the part. The women who work in the cosmetics and fragrance hall on the first floor wear stripy Breton tops, cropped black trousers and ankle-strap heels and the guys who sell mens clothes on the second floor sport tartan shirts, chinos and solid ties. Despite the inauspicious location, right next to a low-end mall, and the coy facade (Nouvel hid the entrance behind a giant louvered blind, and there are no window displays), we foresee a flurry of fashion-week pilgrimages.

title: When Should a Team Pull the Plug?
description: When we last took a look at Adam Dunn he was hitting .165 and his slump seemed a mystery to everyone including him. Now, with a little more than a week remaining in the season, Dunn has improved all the way to a .166 batting average.

title: Live Hearing: Mullen and Panetta at Armed Services Committee
description: 12:46 p.m. | Updated  The hearing has concluded, but Admiral Mullen made news during the proceedings by connecting Pakistans intelligence agency with the insurgents who attacked the embassy in Kabul last week. Elisabeth Bumiller reports, in comments that were the first to directly link Pakistans powerful spy agency, the Inter-Services Intelligence Directorate, or ISI, with an assault on the United States, Admiral Mullen went further than any other American official in blaming the ISI for undermining the American military effort in Afghanistan.

title: Pushed to Background, Yankees Posada Finally Gets the Spotlight
description: When the others from the Class of 1995 had signature moments this season, Jorge Posada was there. When Derek Jeter smashed a homer for his 3,000th hit, back in July, Posada was waiting at the plate to embrace him. When Mariano Rivera broke the career saves record, on Monday, Posada pushed him back to the mound, to bask in the fans adulation.

title: Solheim Teammates Have Common Bond
description: PRATTVILLE, Ala.  Juli Inkster, a pro golfer since 1983, was working on her game on the driving range at the recent Navistar L.P.G.A. Classic wearing an eggplant-colored skirt that hung loosely off her hips and stopped an inch above her knees. The rookie Ryann OToole walked by in a sky blue micro-miniskirt.

title: Signature Center Will Have Theater Named for Romulus Linney
description: The playwright Romulus Linney has been associated with the Signature Theater Company since its first season, in 1991, when he was its founding playwright-in-residence.

title: Interesting Encounters on the Way to the Singapore Grand Prix
description: SINGAPORE  Traveling to the so-called flyaway races in Formula One can be a big adventure on its own. Most of the Formula One paddock travels by air to the races around Europe, but traveling to the far-flung races, like this weekends Singapore Grand Prix, can be far more interesting.

title: Interesting Encounters on the Way to the Singapore Grand Prix
description: SINGAPORE  Traveling to the so-called flyaway races in Formula One can be a big adventure on its own. Most of the Formula One paddock travels by air to the races around Europe, but traveling to the far-flung races, like this weekends Singapore Grand Prix, can be far more interesting.

title: Showing His Mastery Just by Standing Still
description: The flamenco dancer Israel Galvn combines complete command of his medium with a phenomenally fertile range of off-beat stylistic ideas. He gives you  deliberately  the impression that traditional flamenco is too small to contain all he needs to do in terms of rhythm and drama. You see him suddenly balance on one leg and turn the sole of his raised shoe upward so that he can slap out a beat with his hands; he even taps one percussive phrase on his front teeth. These are gimmicks. As with many of the greatest flamenco dancers, the intensity with which he presents himself is always on the cusp of absurdity. But he makes his effects feel both enjoyable and necessary. They work because theyre part of the witty, odd flamboyance that characterizes his dance theater, but even more because theyre part of the rhythmic outpouring that turns his dance into music. Though he shows that he can do quite an assortment of the foot trillings that abound in flamenco, he refuses to indulge himself in that kind of bravura: he steers clear of flamenco clich. Its extremely rare in any genre to see a dancer of this singular imagination and authority.

title: Week 3 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Bedbug Pesticides in Excess Hurt People, Too
description: Fear of bedbugs may have driven people across the country to overuse common pesticides, leading to one death and more than 100 cases of insecticide poisoning in seven states, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Thursday.

title: Republicans Attack on Handling of Stimulus Money and Green Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  The battle over Solyndra, the California solar equipment manufacturer that took $528 million in government loan guarantees and then declared bankruptcy, moved on to a second House committee on Thursday as Republicans broadened their attack on the Obama administrations management of stimulus money and its pursuit of alternative energy as a way to spur employment.

title: Old Saturn Plant Could Get a Second Chance
description: SPRING HILL, Tenn.  When General Motors stopped building cars here two years ago, as the auto industry hit rock bottom and tens of thousands of assembly-line jobs evaporated nationwide, Chad Poynor packed up and moved to Michigan to keep working at another plant.

title: Whose Subsidies Trump Whose?
description: Renewable energy deserves subsidies, its partisans say, because conventional energy sources have enjoyed bigger subsidies for decades. The latter is a hard proposition to quantify, but a new report by a venture capital firm that specializes in renewables takes a stab at it.

title: The Elephant in the Room, at a Vuitton Celebration
description: Katie Grand, the British stylist and magazine editor who has worked with Marc Jacobs on his Louis Vuitton collections for nearly a decade or, as she said, like a million years, walked into an exhibition of his designs at 8:30 p.m. on Wednesday and saw, for possibly the millionth time, a video in which she describes the collaborative process.

title: My Three Favorite People Named Greg
description: Ive always had a bit of trouble with the extended version of my first name. Gregory. It just feels a little too proper, doesnt it, as if it would be silly for me not to receive a dozen Faberg eggs upon the occasion of my birth. (When you combine it with my middle name, you get Gregory Paul. I think we can all agree thats pretty papal-sounding for a Jew.) Anyway, another bummer about my name, especially when I was young and cared about this sort of thing, was that I had very few other Gregorys to look up to. The name didnt have the famous person starting lineup of a Michael or Matthew or David. I mean, Greg Gumbel seems nice and all.

title: Pakistans Spy Agency Is Tied to Attack on U.S. Embassy
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top military official said Thursday that Pakistans spy agency played a direct role in supporting the insurgents who carried out the deadly attack on the American Embassy in Kabul last week. It was the most serious charge that the United States has leveled against Pakistan in the decade that America has been at war in Afghanistan.

title: We Must Cooperate on Nuclear Safety
description: A nuclear accident anywhere has the potential to be a nuclear accident everywhere. That is why it is encouraging that the United Nations this week is examining the lessons and implications of the accident at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant in Japan, the worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl in 1986.

title: Assange Lashes Out at Release of Unauthorized Autobiography
description: Last week, it was an eBay auction of WikiLeaks memorabilia inscribed by Julian A.

title: Pandit Named Chairman of Clearing House Board
description: The Clearing House Association, one of Wall Streets oldest and most influential lobbying groups, has tapped Citigroups chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, to lead its supervisory board.

title: Cuomo Puts Schedules on New Transparency Site
description: 6:24 p.m. | Updated ALBANY  Seeking to fulfill a campaign promise, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday began publishing portions of his daily schedule on a new government Web site that he said would function as a virtual town hall.

title: Dozens Hurt by 2 Bombs in Capital of Dagestan
description: MOSCOW  A coordinated pair of explosions in the capital of Dagestan early Thursday killed at least one person and wounded dozens more in the violence-plagued republic in Russias North Caucasus region, officials said.

title: Central Park Boathouse Owner Agrees to Contract With Union
description: The bitter, boisterous 44-day strike at the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park has come to an end, as the two sides announced on Thursday that they had reached a tentative four-year union contract, City Room reports.

title: Support the Palestinian Bid for Statehood
description: THE United States should support the Palestinian Authoritys bid for statehood at the United Nations. The Palestinian people deserve a state now. As the current debate unfolds, I am reminded of what the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said in 1965: The time is always right to do whats right.

title: Israels New Labor Leader Faces a Party in Decline
description: JERUSALEM  The election of a new leader of Israels historic but severely diminished Labor Party prompted talk of a possible revival on Thursday. But analysts were predicting a modest comeback in the best case, with a special emphasis on socioeconomic issues.

title: Getting Cash in Exchange for a Short Sale
description: To avoid further clogging the already sluggish home foreclosure pipeline, some lenders have been offering cash incentives to strapped homeowners at risk of foreclosure to complete short sales and move out of their homes.

title: For Restless Lawmakers, Accord Proves Elusive
description: WASHINGTON  Again?

title: Hollywood Assessing New Rules Governing Oscar Campaigns
description: Hollywood consultants and strategists are still chewing over new regulations governing Oscar campaigning announced by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Wednesday, and wondering to what extent they represent a clampdown on vote scrounging, and to what extent they are a relaxation? The Academy occasionally tweaks its rules for conduct leading up to the Oscars, and the changes this time covered a range of topics.

title: A Mother Looks for Justice, Not Closure
description: Many an advocate is forged in tragedy.

title: Plan for Trading Limits Goes International
description: International politicians and regulators urged the United Nations on Thursday to add a new item to its already packed agenda: speculative commodities trading.

title: After Flopping on Broadway, High Is Hitting the Road
description: Matthew Lombardos addiction-themed drama High was one of the fastest flops on Broadway in recent years, closing just five days after opening last April in spite of the star power of its leading lady, Kathleen Turner. Having lost its entire investment of $1.8 million in New York, why is High now poised to become the relatively rare Broadway play to go on national tour?

title: Arms Sale Draws Angry, but Familiar, Reaction
description: BEIJING  Confirmation of a $5.8 billion package of weapon sales by the United States to Taiwan drew an angry reaction from China on Thursday, with newspaper editorials accusing the Obama administration of betrayal and the Foreign Affairs Ministry warning of serious harm to relations.

title: Meg Whitman Is Named Hewlett-Packard Chief
description: Hewlett-Packard replaced its embattled chief executive on Thursday with the former eBay chief executive Meg Whitman, saying that the companys strategy to transform its business was sound, but that it needed new leadership to carry out the plan.

title: Commuter Nation
description: The average time it takes Americans to commute to work is 25.1 minutes, according to a new report based on Census data from 2009. Of all metropolitan areas, New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island area has the longest average commute time in the country, at 34.6 minutes, and has the highest share of its workers using public transportation to get to work.

title: Color Recasts Itself as a Facebook Photo and Video App

The service seemed to have everything going for it: an accomplished serial entrepreneur at its helm and $41 million in the bank from noted investors like Bain and Sequoia Capital.

description: In what turned out to be a bad case of over expectations, the Fox network and its biggest star, Simon Cowell, posted disappointing ratings for the premiere of the widely-anticipated singing competition, The X-Factor, Wednesday night.

title: Assessing a Web Site That Wants to Be the eHarmony of Hiring
description: Last week, we took a look at DirectApproachSolutions.com, a Web site that claims to have a fresh approach to matching job candidates and jobs. I asked readers to weigh in with some thoughts about the sites overall design and functionality.

title: Book Report: Oils Long Goodbye
description: Michael Levi, who analyzes energy, security and climate issues for the Council on Foreign Relations, is among the first of my contacts on fossil fuel trends to plow through all 804 pages of The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World.This is the new book on humanitys energy sources and choices by Daniel Yergin, who gained fame and influence for his Pulitzer-winning 1991 account of the history of oil, The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power (1991). (The Questwas praised by Dwight Garner in The Times earlier this week).

title: Harsh Words From Turkey About Israel, and From Iran About United States
description: UNITED NATIONS  Evidently heedless of American attempts to engineer a thaw in Turkish-Israeli relations, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey used his appearance before the annual General Assembly on Thursday to enumerate a long list of grievances with Israel, a former regional ally.

description: 1:56 p.m. | Updated  Adding more announcements from conference.

title: Will London (By Way of Cyberspace) Be New Route for Pippin To Broadway?
description: A circus-like revival of the popular 1970s musical Pippin, which director Diane Paulus was aiming for Broadway in the 2012-13 season, is in limbo now that another production of the show  this one inspired by virtual reality games  will open this fall in London at the Menier Chocolate Factory, which has a track record of moving revivals to Broadway.

description: In 2001, I wrote about a then-little known company called Netflix. Reading it now, I cant help smiling. Ah, sweet navet!

title: Viral Theory Is Set Back in Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Study
description: Dashing the hopes of many people with chronic fatigue syndrome, an eagerly awaited study coordinated by government health agencies has not confirmed a link between the illness and a virus called XMRV or others from the same class of mouse leukemia viruses.

title: Silver Lake and DST Begin Tender Offer for Alibaba Shares
description: An investment group that includes Silver Lake Partners and DST Global said Thursday that it would begin a $1.6 billion tender offer for shares in the Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant.

description: In the race to invest in the latest and greatest Internet start-ups, Goldman Sachs is not sitting on the sidelines.

title: Classroom Overcrowding at 10-Year High, Union Says
description: After years of staff attrition and budget cuts, the number of overcrowded classrooms in city schools is now the largest it has been in 10 years, the teachers union says. Nearly 7,000 classes are over their contractual limits this year, according to the union, the United Federation of Teachers, an increase of almost 1,000 from last year. The unions president, Michael Mulgrew, cited the numbers in pleading for the city not to cut the school budget again. We have to stop this craziness, he said. Read more on SchoolBook

title: First Fines Over Wearing Full Veils in France
description: PARIS  For the first time since the passage of a law banning the wearing of full veils in public, a French court on Thursday fined two women for wearing the niqab, an Islamic facial covering that leaves only the eyes uncovered.

title: Satellites Fall Becomes Phenomenon
description: The odds that a falling satellite will kill you on Friday are probably zero  but maybe not quite.

title: Rating the No. 1s: Wonder Woman, Nightwing and More
description: Two Times staffers and comic-book fans, George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler, will review all 52 DC Comics titles that have been rebooted as part of a companywide effort to revive the brand. In the fourth of five weekly installments they discuss Wonder Woman, Catwoman, Nightwing and others that were published on Wednesday. Next week theyll look at Flash, Aquaman, and more.

title: Europe Looks for Ways to Prod Growth in Greece
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union said on Thursday that it was exploring new ways to try to stimulate economic growth in Greece, with one senior official acknowledging that Greek citizens were on the verge of rejecting any more austerity measures.

title: A Lack of Lending at European Banks Increases the Fear of Stagnation
description: FRANKFURT  This was supposed to be the month that European banks went back to debt markets to refill their coffers. It is not working out that way.

title: Execution Offers Little Closure in Debate
description: After decades of litigation, the final legal ruling allowing the execution of Troy Davis was a one-sentence order from the United States Supreme Court so terse that it could have fit neatly into a Twitter message with room to spare.

title: Model-Morphosis | Anabela Belikova at Gucci
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Anabela Belikova from IMG before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath for CoverGirl and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Joyeux Anniversaire (un peu tt), Lady Liberty
description: After a slightly rocky summer for French-New York relations (see: Strauss-Kahn, Dominique), Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France stood Thursday morning before a mist-enshrouded Statue of Liberty to praise the enduring friendship symbolized by the monument.

title: What Profit Hath A Man Of All His Labor?
description: Im in a weird mood as the markets tumble. It will pass, but right now I feel like the preacher in Ecclesiastes, wondering about the point of it all.

title: Single-Sex Education Is Assailed in Report
description: Single-sex education is ineffective, misguided and may actually increase gender stereotyping, a paper to be published Friday asserts.

title: Artsbeat: Sept. 22, 2011
description: Alastair Macaulay on a big week for ballet, and Randy Kennedy on the Metropolitan Museum of Arts new Islamic art galleries.

title: Zombies and AMC Take a Page From the Bravo Playbook
description: Just as Bravo has a talk show about its gossipy Housewives (and its other hit shows), AMC will soon have a talk show about its gory zombie drama, The Walking Dead. The channel said Thursday that the half-hour show, called Talking Dead, would start on Sunday, Oct. 16 at 11 p.m., the same night that the second season of the drama has its premiere. It will then move to a Friday night time slot.

title: Yum Sells 2 Fast-Food Chains
description: Yum Brands announced on Thursday that it had found buyers for two fast-food chains, Long John Silvers and A&W Restaurants. The prices were not disclosed.

description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#438", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Samantha Casolaris Milan Fashion Week photo diary.

title: Theater Talkback: Stage Stars From the Comfort of Your Couch
description: The fall season has arrived, and beloved stage favorites are everywhere: Laura Benanti, Patrick Wilson, Katie Finneran. Only this season you dont actually have to leave your apartment to watch them at work. They are all joining the ranks of the televised. All are taking (we may hope; perhaps they dont) temporary leave from regular stage work to appear in new series beginning in the next few months.

title: The Arab Spring Finds Itself Upstaged by a New Season
description: UNITED NATIONS  Hillary Rodham Clinton, sharing a podium during the United Nations General Assembly with half a dozen of the worlds most powerful political women, was waxing enthusiastic about the success of the Arab uprisings when she gave a sudden shout-out to Tunisia.

title: Familiar Face Flashes the Leather in the Stands
description: Raul Lopez is having a pretty good year at Yankee Stadium, too.

title: Attitudes on Aptitude: Analyzing the Drop in SAT Reading Scores
description: Overview | Why have SAT reading scores hit an all-time low? In this lesson students investigate the question, and, by extension, the test itself, through research and analyzing possible contributing factors. They then choose from a variety of going further activities to write about what they have learned.

title: Yahoo Wants People to Share
description: Yahoo is making its news more social.

title: The Place | Budapest, Part Four
description: PREP SCHOOLThough Budapest is often stand-in for other cities in the movies, there is no shortage of cultural output celebrating the city itself. Here, a few notable valentines, classic and contemporary, to Hungarys capital.

title: Popular Liqueur Hires Ad Agency for U.S. Market
description: Jgermeister, the liqueur known for its racy promotions, is hiring the first advertising agency to work on the brand in the United States in 25 or more years.

title: New California Law Lets Bartenders Be More Creative
description: It is no longer illegal for a California bartender to put a basil leaf in a bottle of gin.

title: New Space, New Art
description: Photos of the new contemporary galleries at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $34,600,000
description: The $34.6 million sale of a co-op at 927 Fifth Avenue by William Lie Zeckendorf, a developer of 15 Central Park West, was the biggest of the week, according to brokers who handled the deal.

title: The Roman Spring of Ms. Prada
description: Miuccia Prada spent her summer vacation in northern Argentina. Karl Lagerfeld was at home in St.-Tropez, ducking camera-snapping tourists. Somehow, though, their spring collections brought us all to Italy, or at least our idea of an Italian holiday. Neither show was a movie-still occasion, but the cottony, upswept hair and glitter-coated eyelids at Fendi might make you think of a 1960s film star. The collarless, knee-length satin coats and pleated chiffon dresses at Prada did the same.

title: Tailgating Recipes: Cheddar Bacon Ranch Pulls
description: If you liked last weeks On Wisconsin Six-Pack Brat Stew, perhaps youll consider pairing it with an appetizer, this weeks Cheddar Bacon Ranch Pulls from Stephanie Parker.

title: G.M.s Plant in Spring Hill, Tenn.
description: The General Motors factory in Spring Hill began as an innovative experiment, but has been idle since 2009.

title: Antidote du Jour
description: As Yves Smith says. That last post was pretty downbeat, so heres a bit of joy as an offset:

title: 36 Hours in Perugia, Italy
description: IF Italy were a dartboard, the city of Perugia would most likely be its bulls-eye. Equidistant from Florence and Rome in the bucolic, central Italian region of Umbria, Perugia is an enchanting hilltop city with a compact historic center that is a rambling maze of medieval streets. Although many associate Perugia with the controversial murder trial of the American Amanda Knox, this forward-thinking city maintains a friendly appeal. In 2008, an eco-friendly high-tech light rail line called the MiniMetr made its debut, zipping visitors into the city center from outer areas and keeping its historic streets mostly car-free. Instead, the streets jam with visitors during two popular annual events: a summer jazz festival that attracts the music worlds biggest acts, and Eurochocolate, a huge autumnal chocolate festival that this year runs Oct. 14 to 23.

title: 36 Hours in Perugia, Italy
description: Perugia is equidistant from Florence and Rome in the bucolic, central Italian region of Umbria.

title: Oh My God Artworks to Visit Neue Galerie
description: Ronald S. Lauder rarely lets a day go by without looking at paintings, sculptures, drawings, decorative objects or beautiful books. He peruses catalogs from around the world, visits dealers and auction houses, views countless images that pour into his office from everywhere. Mentally he divides what he sees into three categories: Theres the Oh, the Oh My and the Oh My God, Mr. Lauder said this week, perched on a Josef Hoffmann sofa in his commodious office on the 42nd floor of the General Motors building, with staggering views of Manhattan and walls filled with paintings by Egon Schiele, Gerhard Richter, Oskar Kokoschka and Joseph Beuys. Ive chosen only the Oh My Gods.

title: David Hallberg to Appear on The Colbert Report
description: Stephen Colbert better brush up on his plis. On Dec. 7, the Comedy Central pundit will play host to David Hallberg, the American dancer who announced earlier this week that he will join the Bolshoi Ballet  the first time an American has enlisted with the Russian company. Mr. Hallberg, a principal dancer at The American Ballet Theater who hails from Rapid City, S.D., will start at the Bolshoi on Nov. 4. The Colbert Report has previously featured dance luminaries like Savion Glover and cast members from the Broadway musical Fela. Mikhail Baryshnikov has showed up too, but not to dance, so Mr. Hallberg will be the first ballet dancer to perform on the show. A spokeswoman for the show suggested that viewers might be surprised at Mr. Colberts dancing abilities too.

title: In Reversal, Bachmanns Struggles Now Include Fund-Raising
description: In Michele Bachmanns latest campaign video, she stands for 1 minute, 25 seconds next to what looks like a plastic plant, her voice tinny and echoing because it was not recorded with a microphone on her lapel.

title: Cellphone Service Coming to the Subway
description: It may be that no technological advancement in New York transportation history has been so equally desired and dreaded, but the ability to chat on a cellphone in the subway will finally be available  though in a very limited way  next week.

title: Ecotalitys Fast-Charging Units: Good News for Leaf Owners and (for Now) Nobody Else
description: To date, the story of electric vehicles and charging infrastructure has been a tale of chickens and eggs. It is still unclear, however, whether E.V.s are birthing the infrastructure, or infrastructure companies are laying the way for E.V.s.

title: U.S. Reopens Its Embassy in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The United States formally reopened its embassy in Libya on Thursday as the returning ambassador said that his government was cautiously optimistic about the countrys future and already trying to help American companies exploit business opportunities here.

description: Stock markets plunge on recession fears; the Op-Ed columnist Joe Nocera on investor confidence in Washington; and 20 percent of New Yorkers now live in poverty.

title: A Skate Shop Where Visitors Can Defy Gravity
description: A FEW blocks from the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, skateboarders swoop and cluster in front of a warehouse like shore birds with their sights on a big fish. Long-haired, debonair and often handsome, these flocks  urban warriors who live by the board  seem oblivious to the cars rushing down North 11th Street, and to anything else, because theyve landed at home base: KCDC Skateshop, a nucleus of New Yorks skateboarding scene.

title: Edward Villella to Step Down From Miami City Ballet

Mr. Villella, a former principal dancer with New York City Ballet, who founded the company with Toby Ansin in 1985, is leaving to continue other professional pursuits.

description: Ralph Esmerian, the bankrupt jewelry dealer, has been selling off possessions, including gems, furniture and books. In July he was sentenced to six years in prison for financial frauds totaling more than $210 million. His companies collections have been turned over to dealers and auction houses.

title: Silence From the Court
description: ON Wednesday night, Troy Davis was executed for a crime he may or may not have committed. But the real crime on Wednesday night was the action  or really the lack of action, the absolute radio silence  of the United States Supreme Court, which, as the nation watched and waited, did nothing for 203 minutes past the scheduled execution time. Or at least nothing anyone could see.

title: Vendor Is Ousted as City Plans to Renovate Tavern Site
description: An owner of one of the three temporary food trucks at the former site of Tavern on the Green in Central Park said city officials have told him that they may not renew his contract for next year because major work on the site was possible.

description: Atlantic City

title: McCotter Ends Long-Shot Presidential Bid
description: 6:10 p.m. | Updated Representative Thaddeus McCotter is ending his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination after three months in the race, according to his Congressional office.

title: Lawyer Defends Role in S.E.C. Madoff Case
description: David M. Becker, the former general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Congress on Thursday that he had done nothing wrong in handling the agencys work related to Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme.

title: Genny Is Back on the Runway
description: For much of the 1970s, for all of the 1980s and for part of the 1990s, Genny was an Italian label you could rely on for structured tailoring that felt like sportswear. Part of its success was because of the special relationship between Gianni Versace, who consulted on the line, and Donatella Girombelli, who ran the manufacturing company that produced Genny and several other labels, like Byblos. Shortly after Prada acquired the label in 2001, it sort of fell off the fashion map, and hasnt been produced since 2004.

title: Facebook as Tastemaker
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook, the Webs biggest social network, is where you go to see what your friends are up to. Now it wants to be a force that shapes what you watch, hear, read and buy.

title: School Officer Uses Mace to Break Up Fight, Spraying 9 Bystanders
description: Nine bystanders in the hallway of a Bronx high school were hit with mace when a school safety officer sprayed at a student in an attempt to break up a fight on Thursday morning, the police said.

title: Slavery Museum Files for Bankruptcy
description: The United States National Slavery Museum, an organization founded by the former Virginia governor Douglas L. Wilder to build a museum in Frederickburg, Va., that would discuss that chapter in American history, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Richmond Times-Dispatch reported that the museum indicated in its bankruptcy filing that it had $3 million in unsecured debts. Among its unpaid bills is one for more than $215,000 in property taxes owed on the 38-acre parcel where the museum was to have opened several years ago. Since then, the proposed museums director has departed, its board has stopped meeting and some people who gave artifacts to the museum have asked for their return.

title: Survivor Tells of Taliban Plot in Former Afghan Presidents Assassination
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In his first public appearance since rushing back to Afghanistan after the assassination of the countrys leading peace broker, a solemn President Hamid Karzai said Thursday that the Taliban had gained access to their target by wooing senior leaders with an audio CD suggesting that peace was within reach.

description: SANA, Yemen  A tenuous truce showed signs of falling apart on Thursday here in Yemens capital, as clashes intensified between government forces and troops loyal to a military commander who defected months ago to protect antigovernment protesters.

description: Classical

description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Filings for Jobless Benefits Fell Last Week, Data Shows
description: Applications for jobless benefits decreased 9,000 in the week ended Sept. 17 to 423,000, Labor Department figures showed Thursday. But that was higher than the 420,000 claims forecast, according to the median estimate in a Bloomberg News survey of economists. The average number of claims in the past month rose for a fifth straight week, to the highest level since July 16.

title: Throwing a Digital-Age Curveball
description: The hungry heart of Moneyball, a movie about baseball in the digital age, is a beautiful hard case named Billy Beane. Coiled yet cool, Billy has the liquid physical grace and bright eyes of a predator. He was built to win. Even his name, with its short syllabic bursts, sounds ready for ESPN exultations. That hes played by Brad Pitt giving the quintessential Brad Pitt performance just seals the deal. It didnt turn out that way, and in 2001 this high school star turned major-league washout was no longer a player but the general manager of the Oakland Athletics, the little team that could but didnt.

title: Bill Clinton Back to Work With a New Book

description: Pop

title: A Writers Voice, Now Muted but Still Lively
description: Roger Ebert has written more than a dozen books about movies. He has also written one about the mystery and romance of the rice cooker. And he presides over what may be the most industrious blog in all of moviedom, rogerebert.com, which is packed with news, reviews and so much savvy miscellany that it has attracted a very large following.
