title: Personal Capital Aims to Be Next-Generation Financial Adviser
description: When Bill Harris thinks about investment advisers that cater to the wealthy, he said he envisions someone with graying hair behind a mahogany desk who has a parent-child relationship with clients.

title: Australian Aborigine Hair Tells a Story of Human Migration
description: A lock of hair, collected by a British anthropologist a century ago, has yielded the first genome of an Australian Aborigine, along with insights into the earliest migration from the ancestral human homeland somewhere in northeast Africa.

title: Photos of the Moment | Prada
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#401", 592, 500, true, chameleonData);Sonny Vandeveldes Milan Fashion Week photo diary.

title: At Least His Abs Get a Workout
description: You will then be responsible for the death of all your friends ... on Facebook, the archvillain (Michael Nyqvist) of the risible thriller Abduction warns the baby-faced Nathan Harper (Taylor Lautner), a sort of teenage Jason Bourne in search of his true identity. Did I say risible? At the screening I attended, that threat prompted hoots of derisive laughter, as did other howlers, including, Im not dying here; theres a bomb in the oven.

title: Billy Elliot by Way of Kitchen, With a Pinch of Sweeney Todd
description: The fragrance of crispy browned bread  the only dish his mother knew how to cook without ruining it  is the Proustian madeleine that unlocks the memories of Nigel Slater, the narrator of Toast. A Billy Elliot of the culinary arts who grows up in the West Midlands city of Wolverhampton, England, Nigel is a sensitive misfit biding his time until he flees his mildly oppressive nest to find work as a chefs assistant in a London hotel.

title: What Leaders Look Like: A Continental Shift
description: If you still think that African art is not your thing, theres an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum that may change your mind. Its called Heroic Africans: Legendary Leaders, Iconic Sculptures, and its as beautiful to look at as a show can possibly be.

title: Bill Clinton Back to Work With a New Book
description: Former President Bill Clinton is offering up a plan to fix the economy and push the United States into the future in a new book to be published by Knopf in November. In Back to Work, Mr. Clinton will make the case for why government matters, explaining his ideas on energy, job creation and financial responsibility, his publisher said on Thursday. Read More on ArtsBeat

title: A Four-Star for a Special Visit
description: The inbox on Mr. Critics computer beeped and booped with questions this week about where to eat with brothers and wives, about where to eat on an Upper East Side art crawl, and about where to eat after a wedding in Central Park. I did my best to answer. In October I take my leave of this job to take on new duties at The New York Times. (Hey, Mr. Editor!) But in the meantime you may address your questions about city restaurants to dinejournal@nytimes.com. And follow me on Twitter: @samsifton.

title: Spare Times for Sept. 23-29
description: Around Town

title: TimesCast | Slipping Into Poverty
description: September 22, 2011 - New census data shows that one in five New Yorkers lives under the poverty line, the highest level in a decade.

title: A Morning After That Turns Into a Dance of Discovery
description: The collapse of sexual taboos has caused some trouble for love, or at least for love stories. That sex often precedes emotional intimacy  or proceeds without it  is a fact of life that movies, with their deep and longstanding investment in romance, especially have a hard time dealing with. Contemporary sexual mores tend to be explored either with grim, punitive realism (as in Steve McQueens Shame, soon to play at the New York Film Festival) or with cute and careful wishful thinking.

title: In Whitman, H.P. Gains a Prolific Deal Maker
A High-Minded Pavilion for a Day on the Sand
description: THE grand pavilion at Orchard Beach is worthy of Mussolini or Speer  a vast, spare arcade, dwarfing the human figure. Overlooking Long Island Sound in the Bronx, it also has a humanistic side, as an ennobling public work of democratic ambition. Neither is enough to keep the seaside air from destroying this 1936 bathing complex.

title: A Skateboard Shop Where Visitors Challenge Gravity
description: A few blocks from the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, skateboarders swoop and cluster in front of a warehouse like so many shore birds with their sights on a big fish. Long-haired, debonair and often handsome, these flocks  urban warriors who live by the board  seem oblivious to the cars rushing down North 11th Street, or to anything else, because theyve landed at home base: KCDC Skateshop, a nucleus of New Yorks skateboarding scene.

title: Not So Ugly Betty
description: For over a decade, the British fitness line Sweaty Betty has been sold almost exclusively on its home turf. This fall, the collection  favored by fit and fabulous stars like Victoria Beckham, Elle Macpherson, Julianne Moore and Amber Valletta  arrives stateside for the first time via quarterly catalogs and its new Web address, sweatybetty.com. The brands co-founder, Tamara Hill-Norton, said she had always dreamed of expanding to the United States. In the U.K., exercising is still often seen as a chore, says Hill-Norton, who started the company with her husband, Simon, in 1997. In the U.S., people push the boundaries and look for exciting new ways to keep it fresh. So now we Yankees can sweat in style with black and white printed pants  In the Hamptons, everyone seemed to love them  or a killer kickboxing number (as seen here on the model Flaviana Matata).

title: Relief and Optimism At the Folk Art Museum
description: When the American Folk Art Museum was considering dissolving altogether and dispersing its art, New York City faced the prospect of losing a 50-year-old cultural institution that houses a major collection of important works by self-trained and outsider artists. So the citys cultural affairs commissioner, Kate D. Levin, was understandably relieved when the museums board voted Wednesday evening to continue as an independent operation. This is a wonderful outcome, Ms. Levin said in a telephone interview on Thursday. Its great for the institution to be able to keep its mission intact and keep its collection under its own stewardship. Having been driven by financial straits to default on its construction bonds and sell its building on West 53rd Street, the museum had been considering a transfer of its collections to the Smithsonian along with a possible long-term loan to the Brooklyn Museum. Now, the museum said, it will attempt to move forward in its smaller building in Lincoln Square. The museum was rescued by pledges of donations from its trustees and from the Ford Foundation. The museum would not specify the terms or amounts of these gifts. The museum also announced on Wednesday that a number of institutions are interested in collaborations. People are increasingly recognizing the value and the excitement of folk art, outsider art, Ms. Levin said. Other museum directors are realizing how this could make a meaningful contribution to the kind of shows they want to curate.

title: Vetting the Lender
description: BEFORE buying a house, borrowers will undoubtedly do a thorough check of the property, examining its structural soundness and the surrounding neighborhood, among other things; they will research the best type of loan, comparing interest rates, terms and fees. But not all borrowers do due diligence on their lenders.

title: Responding to the Anniversary of 9/11 With a Call to Erode Cultural Borders
description: It would have been inconceivable to let the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks pass without commentary from the Kronos Quartet, a group that has long insisted that embracing the breadth of the worlds music can be the key to peace and understanding.

title: Dickens the Man, Foibles and All
description: Devotees know these sketched figures almost as if they were relations: the lean urchin approaching his shocked overseer with an empty bowl, begging for more; the dreamy girl on a wind-swept sea coast, a beached boat for her home; the bald, vested gentleman with an ornate pocket watch, pontificating while waiting for something to turn up. There are dandified Pickwickians, ethnic villains, wide-eyed innocents, all part of an immensely rich exhibition of manuscripts, photographs, letters, illustrations and artifacts that opens on Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum, to honor the 200th anniversary in 2012 of Charles Dickenss birth.

title: Invitation to the Voyage
description: Algus Greenspon

title: Sterling Ruby and Lucio Fontana
description: Andrea Rosen

title: Ann Pibal: Drmn
description: Meulensteen

title: Haim Steinbach: creature
description: Tanya Bonakdar Gallery

title: TimesCast: Slipping Into Poverty
description: The newest figures from the Census Bureau show that poverty grew nationwide last year. New York City was hit especially hard, reported Sam Roberts todays Times.

title: The Post-Black Condition
description: Much has been written on the benefits that accrued to the generation of African-Americans reaping the rewards of the civil rights revolution. But we have heard surprisingly little from those in the post-civil-rights age about what these benefits have meant to them, and especially how they view themselves as black people in an America now led by a black president. In his new book, Tours aim is to provide an account of this post-black condition, one that emerged only in the 1980s but by the 90s had become the new black.

title: After a Life Shakeup, Physician, Reveal Thy True Self
description: Is there a displaced doctor in the house? Yes; more than one, actually.

title: One Town, but Two Markets
description: OVER the last six months or so, it seems several New Jersey towns have developed symptoms of split personality  at least when it comes to their real estate markets.

title: Good Works With a Bad Attitude
description: There are some real people and some true stories that seem to have been dreamed up by committees of eager Hollywood screenwriters. Sam Childers is one such case. A former drug dealer and a member of a Pennsylvania motorcycle gang, Mr. Childers underwent a religious conversion and has, since the late 1990s, devoted himself to helping orphans in war-torn East Africa. His approach to humanitarianism is unorthodox, to say the least. Rather than stay out of the fight, he has sometimes embroiled himself in combat, particularly against the Lords Resistance Army, a militia led by Joseph Kony that has long terrorized parts of northern Uganda and southern Sudan.

title: Exploration of Stillness and a Lightsaber Battle
description: Stillness is a rare commodity in New York, with its eight million residents and the commuters and visitors who move through the city every day. The Guggenheim is striving to achieve it in stillspotting nyc, a two-year exhibition by architects, composers and other artists that explores sound in the urban environment.

title: Italys Troubling Earthquake Prosecutions
description: 11:09 p.m. | Updated below |You may be aware of the effort under way in Italy to convict six scientists and a public official for manslaughter for statements they made about the improbability of a big earthquake as low-level tremors unnerved citizens in the Abruzzo region of central Italy in late March 2009. On April 6, the medieval town of LAquila was devastated by a 6.3-magnitude earthquake.

title: A Wing Where Contemporary Art Can Converse
description: Last weekend, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, celebrated the opening of its new Linde Family Wing for Contemporary Art, which would seem to represent a major commitment to collecting and exhibiting the art of our time. It should be noted, however, that the new wing is not actually new. It is the old, I. M. Pei-designed wing from 1981, formerly used for rotating exhibitions, now refurbished, repurposed and renamed. And while a lot more contemporary art is now on view, you dont get the feeling that the old, small-city provincialism has been replaced by a new, fiercely ambitious cosmopolitanism.

title: Google Wallet
description: David Pogue offers a parody look at how Google Wallet intends to replace the credit cards in our actual wallets. (Dont cut up your plastic quite yet.)

title: Ingenuity Is a Thing With Feathers
description: Hats. Most of us have had a few. Some have been loyal standbys, providing a modicum of style while shielding us from the elements. A few have consistently, perhaps inexplicably, buoyed our spirits and sense of savoir-faire. Still others have been, well, humbling. The outcome of misguided infatuations in stores or at street vendors, hats tend to fester in the upper reaches of our closets. My most memorable hat failure was a molded white linen number of rather Amish severity by Comme des Garons, long since deaccessioned. Im proud to have been its owner, actually, even though I think I wore it exactly once, in Europe, to and from which it traveled in its own hatbox.

title: A World of Influences, but Still Self-Possessed
description: The first newish song in Beiruts show at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night was Vagabond, a perky testimonial about finding oneself alone and unmoored, despite what sound like some diligent precautions. Against a backdrop of accordion, electric bass, trumpet and drums, Zach Condon sang the first verse in a steady voice, applying vibrato to the very end of each line:

title: Coffee, Tea or Nostalgia?
description: Younger siblings know how hard it is to live up to a gifted firstborn.

title: Obama Takes Jobs Fight to His Adversaries Turf
description: CINCINNATI  President Obama was back on the road on Thursday to sell his jobs plan  at an aging and overtaxed bridge connecting the home states of his chief Republican antagonists in Congress, Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio and Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Senate minority leader.

title: A Sound Reverberating Far Beyond Seattle
description: Theres a lot of terrific music in Pearl Jam Twenty, Cameron Crowes documentary about the Seattle band Pearl Jam, honoring its two-decade career. And excellent concert footage. But before viewers learn this venerable ensembles story, much less see its members rock out on screen, they are subjected to Mr. Crowes voice-over account of his own early discovery of the Seattle scene.

title: On Our Radar: Solar Venture Misses Loan Deadline
description: The manufacturer First Solar says it will not be able to meet a Sept. 30 deadline to receive a federal loan guarantee for a solar power plant it is building in California. [Reuters]

title: Does That New Honda Announcer Sound Familiar?
description: American Honda Motor is changing the announcer in its commercials again, hiring the actor Jason Bateman to be the voice of its national brand advertising.

title: The Daily Shoe | Prada
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#110", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Common Application to Get Electronic Facelift
description: 9:11 p.m. | Updated This post has been updated to reflect comments this evening from Rob Killion, executive director of the Common Application Inc.

title: Perry Calls Prayer Vital to His Life
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas appeared in front of religious conservatives here before the Republican presidential debate, telling the crowd of hundreds that prayer had helped him succeed in life and politics.

title: Director Hates Stupidity, Hypocrisy and Critics
description: Apparently fed up with the traditional system of film distribution  and in particular with the critics who insist, out of spite or inertia, on reviewing whatever opens in theaters  Kevin Smith is taking his new movie, Red State, directly to its audience. The film, which was shown at the Sundance Film Festival last January, has been available for home viewing since Sept. 1, via cable television, iTunes and other platforms. For those who insist on seeing it the old-fashioned way, on a big screen from an upholstered seat with a cup holder attached to the arm, there will be screenings in select cities on Sunday night, with Mr. Smith making an appearance to do what he does best, which is rant, tell stories and shoot the breeze with his fans.

title: African Chronicles
description: Images from Heroic Africans: Legendary Leaders, Iconic Sculptures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: In Praise of the Teenage Brain
description: The developing teenage brain  stupid, irrational and reckless  is best suited to select a college, so suggested Jonah Lehrer, a neuroscience writer and an author of How We Decide, in his keynote speech Thursday kicking off the 67th annual convention of the National Association for College Admission Counseling, or Nacac, in New Orleans.

title: Joe Nocera On the Economy
description: The Op-Ed columnist Joe Nocera compares Washingtons current handling of the economy to conditions in 1931, when the country was struggling during the Great Depression.

title: Finding a New Tail for Winter
description: Dolphin Tale, the story of a maimed dolphin named Winter and the people who rescue her, is pitched awfully young, without a shred of the satire or subtlety that is generally found in films aimed at tweeners and above. Thats not a bad thing; it just means accompanying grown-ups or older siblings will have to choke down a sizable dose of schmaltz with their fish milkshakes.

title: Starchitects on Parade
description: Gehry and Ando and Nouvel, oh my! How a sleepy vineyard in Provence landed the biggest names in architecture.

title: Could Have, Should Have: What Composers Wished Theyd Written
description: In 1995 the Library of Congress asked Stephen Sondheim to draw up a list of songs he wished he had written, some of which were performed at a concert in honor of his 70th birthday. This weekend a passel of would-be Sondheims (and Larsons, and Porters) will unveil their work as part of the New York Musical Theater Festival, which runs through Oct. 16. In the spirit of the Sondheim list (published in The New York Times in 2000), we asked composers in this years festival: What song do you wish you had written? Which song in your show expresses your voice? And why? Many of their responses follow. Information about the festival is at www.nymf.org.

title: Turning a Blighted Area in Central Suffolk Into a Hub
description: Ronkonkoma

title: Rise and Fall of a Nightclub Impresario
description: As druggy as the club scene it depicts, Limelight shapes the career of Peter Gatien, the Canadian entrepreneur who ruled New York City nightlife in the 1980s, into a ball of confusion and hyperbole.

title: Good Riddance, Irene
description: IN mid-August, a moving company delivered Jason and Kristis Cartozians belongings to the three-bedroom Tudor they had just bought in Port Chester. It had passed all building code inspections with flying colors. Among other things, inspectors deemed the house, the couples first, watertight and fit to withstand a strong storm.

title: Problems? Talk to the Parrot
description: A man with little to say falls for a woman who says too much in A Bird of the Air, an offbeat romance fueled by pets and pithy aphorisms.

title: No News Is Bad News in N.B.A. Labor Talks
description: The time to broker an N.B.A. labor deal without harming the preseason had most likely already passed by the time negotiators gathered Thursday morning in Manhattan. When they parted ways in the afternoon, a deal still out of reach, it guaranteed that training camps and exhibition games would be canceled for the second time in league history.

title: Bloomberg Defends Livery Cab Proposal
description: With Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo expressing doubt about legislation allowing street hails of livery cabs in much of New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vociferously defended the measure on Thursday as crucial to the citys economic well-being.

title: Goldman Names New Head of Europe and Asia Pacific Mergers
description: Goldman Sachs has named Gregg Lemkau, a longtime deal maker, as its head of mergers and acquisitions for Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia Pacific countries, the firm announced in an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook on Thursday.

title: Washington, D.C., 4:43 P.M.
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat, at the unveiling of his portrait in the hearing room of the House Ways and Means Committee, which he led until 2010.

title: Kidnap Victim Sues U.S. Over Abductors Parole
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The kidnap victim Jaycee Dugard filed a complaint for damages against the federal government on Thursday, charging that its parole agents did not adequately monitor Phillip Garrido, a convicted sex offender who was on federal parole when he abducted Ms. Dugard in 1991.

title: In Early Stages of Marathon, Burress Is Still Finding His Way
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Plaxico Burress spent two hours each day he served in prison running 300-yard sprints and catching passes from inmates who regarded themselves as some of the N.F.L.s legendary quarterbacks.

title: Rays Roll Over Yankees Reserves
description: 11:10 p.m. | Updated  The names of five Yankees regulars were missing when the lineup for Thursday nights game against Tampa Bay was posted on the clubhouse door at 5 p.m. The starters who played in a dreary 15-8 loss to the Rays did poorly and were out of the game in a hurry.

title: Warners (Real) Big Tent on Deficit Reduction
description: Senator Mark R. Warner, a first-term Democrat from Virginia, just will not give up on the idea of a grand deficit-reduction bargain between the two parties. He is even providing the table.

title: In a Hungarian Town, Faces of the Diaspora
description: Documentaries have become so involving, entertaining and provocative that we almost forget the genres root purpose: to document. Leave a record. Preserve the facts.

title: Special Ops Agent, Lured Back From Retirement
description: Dont let the title fool you. Killer Elite has next to nothing to do with the 1975 film The Killer Elite, which had both an extra word in its title and an openly dissatisfied Sam Peckinpah (We have no script) in the directors chair. The old thriller was based on the novel Monkey in the Middle; the new one originated with The Feather Men, a British book that was sold as nonfiction but may not have been. The earlier film starred James Caan and Robert Duvall as professional killers; the new one has Jason Statham and Robert De Niro as elite mercenaries. Peckinpah tried to turn his into a mockery of itself, while the new flicks director, Gary McKendry, has stumbled into accidental near-parody.

title: Breaking Barriers to Ride the Waves
description: Ted Woodss documentary White Wash wants you to know that white guys arent the only ones who surf. Mr. Woodss movie  part history lesson, part sports film, part polemical essay  has a complicated story to tell, about black surfers and, more broadly, about African-American history and the history of surfing.

title: Q & A
description: No Co-op Fee for the Kitty

title: Stephen Mueller, Color Field Painter, Dies at 63
description: Stephen Mueller, a New York painter who expanded and refined the vocabulary of 1960s Color Field painting into deliriously buoyant mystical-comic works, died on Sept. 16 in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: In Europe, a Chorus of Outrage Over a U.S. Execution
description: PARIS  Even in a region long disdainful of American attitudes toward the death penalty, public officials, editorial writers and activists across Western Europe reacted with fury on Thursday to news that Troy Davis was executed in Georgia on Wednesday night.

title: A Mideast Moment at the United Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: Filmmakers Explorations of Sex and Jealousy
description: Somebody must think Joe Swanbergs mumblecore mush is worth the time it takes to watch it, because he keeps making it. But anyone who sees his insufferable Art History and doesnt wish for the 74 minutes back has an empty life indeed.

title: Follies Will Be Still Here For Three Weeks Longer
description: The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of Follies will extend its limited engagement by three weeks, through Jan. 22, 2012, the shows producers plan to announce on Friday. The slightly longer run will give the musical a better chance of turning a profit  a benchmark of success that has long eluded the show, beloved by many musical theater fans for its score by Stephen Sondheim.

title: Dealing a Blow to the Cardinals, the Mets Storm Back Late to Prevail
description: ST. LOUIS  Terry Collins, a postgame outburst or two aside, has been an unconditional champion of his players this season. They made him proud, persevering through major trades and cosmically unfortunate injuries.

title: Fake-Injury Issue Puts Giants on the Defensive
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The practice of faking injuries is not a recent phenomenon in the N.F.L. Defenders have long flopped on defense in order to slow the game or disrupt offensive momentum. If coordinated correctly  and rarely is it not  the ploy can be effective. It is, however, supposed to go unnoticed. But when scrutiny is focused on the tactic, a question arises: is the strategy good old-fashioned gamesmanship or does it go beyond the bounds of fair play?

title: Son Takes His Famous Father Out of the Shadows
description: Carl Colbys smart, fact-packed film The Man Nobody Knew operates on many levels, all riveting. Primarily an account of the career of his father, William Colby, director of the Central Intelligence Agency from 1973 to 1976, it traces a history ending in 1996, when his body washed ashore eight days after he embarked on a late-afternoon solo canoe outing in Maryland. While reviewing the turbulent period spanning Vietnam and President Richard M. Nixons resignation, we also witness the arc of a marriage, the death of a daughter and the seeming disillusionment of a selfless, if steely-eyed and implacable, civil servant.

title: Trekking Mountains to Get to School
description: More bittersweet story than compelling documentary, Journey From Zanskar follows a Tibetan monk, Geshe Yonten, whose vow to help liberate beings from suffering starts at home, in Zanskar. High in the mountains in the northwest corner of India (in the troubled state of Jammu and Kashmir), Zanskar is a small island of Tibetan Buddhism (population less than 14,000) surrounded by a sea of Hinduism and Islam.

title: Questioning the Morality of the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiny Neutrinos May Have Broken Cosmic Speed Limit
description: Roll over, Einstein?

title: Solheim Cup Generation Gap
description: Juli Inkster, the nine-time Solheim Cup veteran, is older than the parents of her rookie teammate Ryann OToole. Still, the golfers have a lot in common, as is made plain in the feature I wrote on them.

title: Adoptions From China: Seeking the Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: The latest Republican debate and moves by the Federal Reserve that caused the stock markets to plunge.
description: The latest Republican debate and moves by the Federal Reserve that caused the stock markets to plunge. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris, and Deputy Political Editor Gerald Mullany join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: Idiocy and Advocacy
description: The medical community was outraged after the Republican presidential candidate Michele Bachmann called a vaccine to prevent cervical cancer dangerous, and then passed on a know-nothingism from a stranger who said it could lead to mental retardation.

title: From a School Band, Soul and Funk, and Heart
description: You may never have heard of the Kashmere Stage Band, but by the end of Thunder Soul you will wonder why. A big-hearted, back-in-the-day tribute  and a stand-alone argument for public-school music programs  Mark Landsmans bittersweet documentary has designs on your feet, heart and mind.

title: Low Testosterone Levels
description: To the Editor:

title: Flawed Lawyer, Fighting the Good Fight
description: Movies with agendas can be tough to pull off, and Puncture is no exception. Notable at least in part for its fumbled potential, this health-care-industry melodrama possesses all the right ingredients: an idealistic young lawyer, a corrupt corporate villain and a sympathetic victim. It just fails to assemble them into a compelling whole.

title: Republican Candidates Debate in Florida
description: Nine candidates in the presidential race gather for a debate in Orlando, Fla.

title: No Right to Anonymity
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Throws Open Window Into Mets Owners Holdings and History
description: Over the 30 years that Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz have owned part or all of the Mets, their other business interests had remained largely out of view. Even as Wilpons profile in baseball grew, he and Katz were rarely referred to as anything more than real estate moguls who gave generously to charities.

title: Partner Says Inquiries Into Madoff Stirred Relief
description: Arthur Friedman oversaw the hundreds of accounts the owners of the Mets opened with Bernard L. Madoff during their decades of investing. He distributed annual statements, handled deposits and on occasion even tried to replicate Madoffs strikingly consistent returns.

title: A Spiritual Quest
description: With a title like In Search of God you can bet that this documentary, directed and conceived by Rupam Sarmah, isnt afraid to ask the big questions: What is the purpose of life? What happens after death? And, of course, where do you find God?

title: Port Authority Not Liable in Bombing, Court Rules
description: In a sharply divided decision, New Yorks highest court ruled on Thursday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was not liable for damages in the 1993 terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center, which killed six people and injured about 1,000 others.

title: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan
description: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan

title: Lost Baby Orcas Rich Social Life
description: There is a gossamer lyricism to The Whale, a documentary about an orca that became separated from its pod and adopted the residents of Nootka Sound in British Columbia as much as they did him. Like humans, orcas are highly social creatures, and Luna, as he was called, was the life of the party. The nuance of his gestures were wondrous to behold: playful, exuberantly extending the fin of friendship, he even helped timber workers in the area, pushing logs through the water with his nose.

title: Mark Varian
description: Mr. Varian, 62, is the president of John Gallin & Son, a family-owned construction company that specializes in commercial building interiors for both landlords and tenants. Its client list has included major developers like the Durst Organization and the Rudin Management Company, as well as corporations like Disney and NBC Universal.

title: Europe Denies 2 Nations Entry to Travel Zone
description: BRUSSELS  Preoccupied with fears of increased migration from the south, the European Union told its two newest members, Romania and Bulgaria, on Thursday that they would have to wait to join the blocs passport-free travel zone.

title: Fall
description: A film by Shirin Neshat, an artist, addresses the famine in Somalia. It is one in a series of films that marks the changing seasons.

title: Personality for Him; Practicality for Her
description: FOR most of his six years in New York, Paul Pinizzotto leased a three-bedroom duplex in a squat, no-frills building in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The rent ended up at $2,250 a month. Over the years, he rented out the extra bedrooms to a series of roommates.

title: September Swoon Torments Red Sox
description: With a loss Wednesday night at home to the last-place Orioles (the third in four games), the Red Sox fell to 5-16 in September. On Sept. 1, they started the day with a division lead of one and a half games and a wild-card lead of seven and a half games. Given their lead of two games over the Tampa Bay Rays, the Red Sox appear capable of making the postseason, but only while stuck in reverse.

title: Rape Case Is a Rarity in Chinese Justice System
description: BEIJING  One morning in May, government officials assembled the 700 students of Ashi townships middle school, in the southeastern Chinese province of Guizhou, for a lesson on the importance of abiding by the law. Rule No. 1, they said, was simple: If you break the law, you will be punished.

title: Bullying as True Drama
description: THE suicide of Jamey Rodemeyer, the 14-year-old boy from western New York who killed himself last Sunday after being tormented by his classmates for being gay, is appalling. His story is a classic case of bullying: he was aggressively and repeatedly victimized. Horrific episodes like this have sparked conversations about cyberbullying and created immense pressure on regulators and educators to do something, anything, to make it stop. Yet in the rush to find a solution, adults are failing to recognize how their conversations about bullying are often misaligned with youth narratives. Adults need to start paying attention to the language of youth if they want antibullying interventions to succeed.

title: A Couple Meet in a Bar. Where Could This Lead?
description: Theres only a shred of plot in Noah and the Tower Flower, but theres plenty of energy to spare. More often than not, thats enough to carry this bittersweet, 75-minute play.

title: Freedom Through Bondage
description: In the spring of 1861, two men appeared before the St. Louis County clerk to sign a document. One of the men, as described in detail in the documents margins, was a barber and boathand, 37 years old and 5 feet 7-and-a-half inches tall. Other such documents described signees as light, dark, copper, high yellow, bright  and even though it did not say so here, everyone knew the man who signed his name in a wide script, Moses Dickson, was a free African American.

title: Cunninghams Legacy Lives On in Classes
description: Merce Cunninghams artistic heirs plan to offer classes in his technique after his dance company ceases operations at the end of the year, company officials said on Thursday. The Merce Cunningham Trust said Robert Swinston, the companys director of choreography, would teach classes starting in April at City Center, where the trust will take up offices. Jean Freebury, a former company member, will also teach Cunningham technique at the Mark Morris Dance Center starting in December, and a course will be offered at Dance New Amsterdam. Cunningham died in 2009, several months after a plan had been put in place to phase out the company. The trust is assuming oversight of Cunninghams work and is taking over for the Merce Cunningham Dance Foundation, which will close next year. Plans for teaching Cunninghams technique had been unclear until now. The foundations executive director, Trevor Carlson, was also appointed as the fifth trustee, the trust said.

title: Feeling at Home in Atlanta, P.G.A. Champion Is Back in Lead
description: ATLANTA  As Keegan Bradley flew into his favorite new town this week and rode on its congested highways, fond memories came flooding back.

title: The Amateur Ideal
description: The 1910s and 1920s were the golden age of the amateur ideal. On the golf courses, Bobby Jones, the greatest amateur golfer of all time, won a string of major championships.

title: Haiti Leader Is Opposed to Reduction of U.N. Force
description: A plan to cut the number of United Nations peacekeepers in Haiti drew a rebuke on Thursday from its president, Michel Martelly, who said in an interview that he would not even think of reducing the force because the country remained unstable and the national police were not ready to take over.

title: Recalling a Cruel Father, and Defending the Woman Who Killed Him
description: The question was not quite a taunt, but kind of an eyebrow hoisted noisily, theatrically and tactically in a Queens courtroom.

title: Panic Over Bedbugs Can Create More Health Risks Than Their Bites
description: As bedbugs have made a comeback, aided by resistance to pesticides and spread by worldwide travel, scientists have found that panic over the blood-sucking pests may be more dangerous than their bite. Some people are misusing poisonous chemicals in a desperate bid to eradicate the pests, federal officials said Thursday.

title: New Condos: Survivor Edition
description: DURING the real estate boom, it seemed that every day brought news of a new condominium project in New York. Big or small, classic or modern, luxurious or merely comfortable  there would be something to satisfy both buyers needs and buyers wallets.

title: For Many, a Life-Saving Drug Out of Reach
description: Mark Kinzly saved two lives this week. But he wouldnt have been here to help if a friend hadnt once done for him what hes now repeatedly done for others  provide overdose victims with Naloxone, the antidote that revived them.

title: Bradley Arrives in Egypt; Signs Deal on Thursday
description: 9:14 p.m. | Updated  Bradley signed his contract with the Egyptian federation on Thursday and to CNN Arabic:

title: After the Lehman Storm, a Calmer Life and a New Book
description: Jared Dillian, a former Lehman Brothers trader, was strolling through the Museum of American Finance, located in an old bank building on Wall Street, when he stopped in front of a placard that read: Remember that the stock market is manic-depressive.

title: Lottery Numbers
New Head at Fieldston School Is an Unconventional Choice
description: Sitting amid unpacked boxes in his office overlooking Central Park this month, Damian J. Fernandez, the new head at the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, took a moment to reflect on Felix Adler, the educator and social reformer who founded Fieldston in 1878 as a tuition-free school for workingmens children.

title: Woman, 87, Dies in an Apartment Fire
description: A fire in an apartment in the Bronx on Thursday killed an 87-year-old woman and critically injured her 91-year-old husband, the authorities said.

title: The Social Contract
description: This week President Obama said the obvious: that wealthy Americans, many of whom pay remarkably little in taxes, should bear part of the cost of reducing the long-run budget deficit. And Republicans like Representative Paul Ryan responded with shrieks of class warfare.

title: Shutdown a Step Closer as Senate Kills House Bill
description: WASHINGTON -- The Senate voted Friday morning to reject the House's stopgap spending bill, less than 12 hours after the House's Republican leaders had forced it through on their second try.

title: Signing Drilling Leases, and Now Having Regrets
description: DRYDEN, N.Y.  Four years ago a man and a woman knocked on Katharine D. Dewarts door, offering easy money for the use of her land.

title: Chief Sells $25 Million in Shares of Jefferies
description: The chief executive of a Wall Street investment bank sold a large stake in his company to pay off a personal debt on Thursday, a move that frightened its shareholders during an already scary day in the markets.

title: Texas Death Row Kitchen Cooks Its Last Last Meal
description: HOUSTON  For decades, Texas inmates scheduled to be executed had at least one thing to look forward to: a last meal. Earl Carl Heiselbetz Jr. ordered two breaded pork chops and three scrambled eggs in 2000. Frank Basil McFarland asked for a heaping portion of lettuce and four celery stalks in 1998. Doyle Skillern ate a sirloin steak in 1985.

title: Spains Banking Mess
description: Its not just sovereign debt.

title: The Palestinians Bid
description: Last year, President Obamas speech to the United Nations was full of promise and determination to advance Palestinian statehood through negotiations with Israel. This year, his address was about lowering expectations and a dispiriting realpolitik as the president spoke of how peace is hard and vowed to veto the Palestinians bid for statehood if it came to a Security Council vote.

title: Yankees-Red Sox Forecast? Showers, Thunderstorms
description: Rain has followed the Yankees around all season, so it is hardly a surprise that more wet weather is in the forecast for the teams final three home games of the season, all against the staggering Boston Red Sox. What impact any downpours may have on the tight wild-card race remains to be seen.

title: The Fed Defies the G.O.P.
description: Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, showed courage facing down powerful Republicans on Wednesday and pressing forward with his efforts to spur economic growth by pushing down long-term interest rates to lower the borrowing costs of businesses and families.

title: Friday: Factor Affecting Google Search Results
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  When you write about something that is created by different people every day, like, oh, I dont know, crossword puzzles, you cant play favorites. Every puzzle is a piece of art unto itself, and each one deserves to be enjoyed and evaluated (notice I didnt say judged) on its own merit. Its not easy; there are bound to be constructors whose styles I am more in sync with than others. Still, we make every effort to be fair and balanced here, dont we?

title: From Cruise Control, a Shift to Panic Mode in Boston and Atlanta
description: For the Boston Red Sox, the failures of the last week have amounted to some grim theater: Josh Beckett, their best pitcher, getting beaten up by the Baltimore Orioles, who were ostensibly eliminated from meaningful competition months ago.

title: Way of the Wolf in Wyoming
description: Wolves remain on the endangered species list in one state: Wyoming. That protection is about to go away after Interior Secretary Ken Salazar cut a bad deal with Wyomings governor, Matt Mead, to turn wolf management over to the state.

title: In Spain, Loans Soar, Problems Follow
description: With Spains economy weak and home prices falling, bad loans are growing.

title: Mom-and-Pop Pharmacy Bill
description: Legislation approved by both houses of the New York State Legislature purports to be a benefit to consumers but looks more like a favor to retail drug lobbyists that could actually drive up costs for consumers. Gov. Andrew Cuomo would be wise to veto it.

title: Applying to College in the United Kingdom
description: Interested in more than a semester abroad but unsure of how to navigate a foreign admissions system?

title: In New Book, Clinton Offers Fiscal Fix
description: Former President Bill Clinton is offering up a plan to fix the economy and push the United States into the future in a new book to be published in November by Knopf.

title: Ticket-Fixing Inquiry Turns Into Scandal About Leaks
description: Early one morning last September, more than 50 members of the Police Departments Internal Affairs Bureau gathered in Lower Manhattan during a continuing investigation into widespread ticket-fixing by New York officers. They were briefed and divided into teams, and then they piled into cars and vans bound for all 12 precinct station houses in the Bronx and others around the city to seize copies of tens of thousands of summonses.

title: More Offices Let Workers Choose Their Own Devices
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Throughout the information age, the corporate I.T. department has stood at the chokepoint of office technology with a firm hand on what equipment and software employees use in the workplace.

title: U.S. Shockwave
description: Stocks steeply declined soon after the Federal Reserve offered a grim assessment of the economy.

title: Obama to Waive Parts of No Child Left Behind
description: Criticizing Congress for months of inaction in updating No Child Left Behind, President Obama on Friday offered to lift the laws most onerous provisions, including its 2014 deadline for bringing all students to proficiency in reading and math, for states that promise to follow his administrations own school improvement agenda.

title: Julius Blank, Who Built First Chip Maker, Dies at 86
description: Julius Blank, a mechanical engineer who helped start a computer chip company in the 1950s that became a prototype for high-tech start-ups and a training ground for a generation of Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, died on Saturday in Palo Alto, Calif.. He was 86.

title: Photoshop Elements 10 Hits Shelves
description: Adobes new Elements 10 is out, providing the most feature packed version yet, with more powerful tools, upgrade to old features, and powerful new features  and thats the problem.

title: A Gold Rush Wanes as Hedge Funds Sell
description: Is the smart money fleeing gold?

title: Making a PC That Is Abroad Look Like It Is in the U.S.
description: Sept. 23, 5:05 p.m. | Updated  Correcting reference to VPNs  they are networks, not bits of software.

title: Perry and Romney Come Out Swinging at Each Other in G.O.P. Debate
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  In their third debate in as many weeks, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas engaged in a sometimes heated back and forth over immigration, health care and entitlements, their rivalry dominating a stage that included seven other candidates struggling to catch up in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: May the Best Recipe Win (but Dont Forget the Chicken and Mayo)
description: WITH tough economic times making Americans choosier about what they stock in their pantries, Hellmanns is aiming to convince consumers that mayonnaise is a staple cooking ingredient and not just a sandwich spread.

title: In Rush to Assist a Solar Company, U.S. Missed Signs
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas visit to the Solyndra solar panel factory in California last year was choreographed down to the last detail  the 20-by-30-foot American flags, the corporate banners hung just so, the special lighting, even coffee and doughnuts for the Secret Service detail.

title: Republicans Debate in Orlando
description: The Republican candidates gathered at the Orange County Convention Center in Orlando, Fla., for a debate on Thursday night.

title: TV Deal May Help Secure the Big 12
description: The dysfunctional family that is the Big 12 Conference appears to be headed for a respite from its flurry of infighting, flirtations and general disagreements.

title: In Debate, Republican Candidates Trip Over Foreign Policy
description: During Thursday nights Republican debate, Mitt Romney repeated the familiar Republican charge that President Obama has apologized for the United States around the world. It is true that early in his term, Mr. Obama promised to abandon policies of his predecessor, George W. Bush, on issues like the military prison in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and a foreign policy in Iraq and elsewhere that Mr. Obama described as unilateral.

title: With a Joint Statement, the Leading Economies Try to Reassure World Markets
description: WASHINGTON  The worlds major economies released an unexpected joint statement Thursday night reiterating their commitment to the stability of banks and financial markets, seeking to soothe nervous investors on six continents.

title: Corrections: September 23
description: FRONT PAGE

title: First Solar Says It Wont Meet U.S. Loan Guarantee Deadline
description: First Solar, a major solar panel manufacturer, said Thursday that it would not be able to accept a partial loan guarantee of $1.93 billion for a giant solar farm in San Luis Obispo County, Calif., because it could not meet the statutory deadline of Sept. 30 to complete the Energy Departments requirements.

title: Etro: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Milan

title: Versace: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Milan

title: Residents Prepare for Red Rivers Crest
description: Residents of North Dakota and Minnesota evacuated their homes and secured levees as the Red River rose to its highest level in 112 years.

title: Word of the Day | sinecure
description: sinecure \si-ni-kyur, si-\ noun

title: Battle for Libya | September 22, 2011
description: Anti-Qaddafi fighters remained locked in standoffs with Qaddafi forces in Sabha, Surt on the Mediterranean coast and Bani Walid in the desert south of Tripoli.

title: A Strategic Risk in the Feds Plan
description: Financial markets are tiring of the Federal Reserves love offerings. The central bank has long been able to soothe nervous investors with rate cuts or newly printed money. But markets on Thursday spurned the announcement of the Twist, an operation to lengthen the maturity of $400 billion of the Feds $1.7 trillion Treasury holdings.

title: Fact Checking the G.O.P. Debate in Orlando
description: Examining Perrys Explanation on HPV Vaccine

title: Fears Gnaw at Liberalism
description: Judy Rothman is a lifelong Democrat who says, Im not 100 percent sure yet that I wont vote for Obama. She finds herself leaning that way, though  solely because of a vague sense of unease about the depth of President Obamas support for Israel.

title: Only Palms Are Swaying
description: Munching on a buttered bagel at a bookstore, Helen Wagner and her partner, Clifford Turkel, said they knew exactly why President Obama looked to be stumbling and sliding his way toward the election.

title: An Enthusiasm Cools Down
description: For Melissa Balaban, 46, talking about President Obama feels like criticizing a close friend. She knows he could do better, she said, she really wants him to do better, but she will stick with him even in difficult times.

title: Jewish Votes, Some of Them in Play
description: American Jews have long proved a solid voting bloc for the Democratic Party, with about four out of five voting for President Obama in 2008, according to exit polls. Jewish voters are driven by a broad range of concerns, but for some the security of Israel is dominant. Now, with the peace process in the Middle East at a stalemate and Palestinians taking their case for statehood directly to the United Nations, Republicans are stepping up their efforts to peel off Jewish voters.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
description: The Congress party appeared to close ranks behind Home Minister P. Chidambaram after he was blamed by a party colleague for not doing enough to prevent the 2G spectrum scam. (The Hindu) The CBI found no wrongdoing on the decisions he took relating to the 2G spectrum during his term as finance minister. (Times of India) But the resolution on this controversy will have to wait until next week when Prime Minister Manmohan Singh returns from the United States.

title: NYT Front Page for 09/23/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/23/11

title: A. Richard Turner Dies at 79; Wrote Inventing Leonardo
description: A. Richard Turner, an expert on the Florentine Renaissance whose landmark 1993 study, Inventing Leonardo, traced the protean outlines of Leonardo da Vinci through his interpreters and their preoccupations over the last 500 years, died on Sept. 9 in Cape May Court House, N.J. He was 79.

title: A Motor Home Capital Teeters in an Economic Crisis
description: In Lane County, Ore., a good part of the economy depends on that strain of American wanderlust requiring a toilet, bed and kitchenette just a few rumbling feet behind the wheel. And that's the problem.

title: Gold to the Rescue to Fix Denver Capitol
description: DENVER  Colorados Capitol dome topped out around the turn of the last century, sheathed in shimmering gold leaf from a local mine even as the great gold boom that had built the territory and filled it with rip-snorting mine-towns and gaudy excess was nearing its end.

title: Readers and Bookworms, Your Days Are Coming
description: When Jack Boulware and Jane Ganahl, a pair of San Francisco writers, gathered together a few dozen authors for two days of literary events back in 1999 and called it Litstock, they figured it would be a one-time affair.

title: Crime Rises in Oakland, and Dim Lights Get Blame
description: By day, True Vine Ministries on Isabella Street in West Oakland serves as a center for Bible study and worship.

title: Off-Label Use of H.I.V. Medications Is Catalyst for More Controversy
description: At a cafe on 18th Street in San Francisco, David sipped coffee and talked about the regimen of daily H.I.V. pills he recently started: Viread in July, and then last month, Isentress. He looked exhausted.

title: Rules for Identifying Clean Dirt to Be Considered
description: Questions about the earthiest of matters  whether there is such a thing as clean dirt and, if so, does it exist in Chicago?  are at the heart of a bitter policy fight between two powerful, politically connected industries: landfill and quarry operators.

title: Populist Candidate Wins Zambian Presidency
description: The opposition leader in Zambia, Michael Sata, who is known as King Cobra for his aggressive tactics and silver-tonged rhetoric, was elected president, defeating the incumbent candidate whose party had been in power for two decades, The Associated Press reported.

title: Hunger in America, Visible if You Look for It
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Exonerated of Crimes, but Compensated Differently
description: Entre Nax Karage spent more than six years in prison for the rape and murder of his girlfriend. But in 2005, DNA evidence proved he was innocent, and he was released. The state paid him about $158,000 in compensation.

title: Farmers Seek to Raise Standards for Berries
description: Organic-produce buyers who think they are striking a blow against a chemical-heavy industrial food system may be surprised when it comes to one of Californias signature fruits: those organic strawberries that overflow from baskets at local farmers markets are not nearly as organic as they may think.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Cook County Overtime Costs Running Far Over Budget
description: As president of the Cook County Board, Toni Preckwinkle shifts into high gear this month in an effort to pass the budget. Overtime expenses that are 50 percent over budget seem certain to draw scrutiny.

title: Wheres That Attention? Im Running, You Know
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Should Alligators Return to San Jacinto Plaza?
description: EL PASO  Ask El Paso old-timers about their fondest memories of downtown, and they will almost certainly mention the alligators.

title: A Victory Restores Smiles at Notre Dame
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Blinding Officials to a Solar Energy Companys Condition
description: Government documents are evidence of a major lobbying campaign that appears to have blinded government officials to Solyndras true financial condition.

title: Going Hungry Gets Results, Mostly
description: In India, it seems the only way to get heard is to go hungry. But would-be fasters better get in line: anyone with an ax to grind or a cause to promote appears ready to starve to get their way.

title: After Four Months, Saleh Is Back in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  President Ali Abdullah Saleh made a sudden return to Yemen on Friday after almost four months in a Saudi hospital, stunning his partisans and opponents alike, leaving many wondering whether his presence here in the capital would calm or worsen the political crisis that has gripped Yemen for six months.

title: Staying Undefined at the Antifolk Festival, and Thats Fine
description: Some music scenes are too mischievous to die.

title: Shares Post Modest Gains After a Punishing Week
description: Stocks in the United States and Europe edged higher on Friday but still finished the five-day trading period sharply lower after some of the steepest declines in weeks.

title: Sept. 23, 1952 | Nixons Checkers Speech
description: On Sept. 23, 1952, Richard Nixon, California senator and running mate of the Republican presidential candidate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, gave a televised address defending his acceptance of more than $18,000 of secret  though legal  funds from political donors. The scandal threatened Mr. Nixons position on the ticket, as many Republicans called for General Eisenhower to choose a new running mate.

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 23, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, The Last Days of the Old Parking Meter.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 23, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: China Questions 5 South Koreans Detained Near Its Border With the North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Five South Koreans, including three journalists affiliated with the mass-circulation daily JoongAng Ilbo, have been detained and questioned by the Chinese authorities along Chinas border with North Korea, the South Korean government and the newspaper said on Friday.

title: American Hikers Freed From Iran
description: WHEN were two American hikers freed from a prison in Iran?

title: Farmers in Chinas South Riot Over Seizure of Land
description: BEIJING  Rioters in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong have besieged government buildings, attacked police officers and overturned SWAT team vehicles during protests this week against the seizure of farmland, said officials in Shanwei, a city that skirts the South China Sea not far from Hong Kong.

title: Q & A With Lydia Polgreen
description: On Tuesday, Lydia Polgreen hosted our first live Facebook discussion about India. Ms. Polgreen, The Timess New Delhi-based South Asia correspondent since 2009, answered a series of thoughtful questions from readers on a range of topics, from corruption to Kashmir to H1B visas and more. Below is a transcript of the discussion. Stay tuned for more live Facebook chats in the months to come, and please subscribe to Ms. Polgreens updates on Facebook, which you can do at facebook.com/lpolgreen. On Twitter, youll find her at @lpolgreen.

title: NYCDesi: Husain on the Block
description: Shivani Vora is India Inks tireless reporter in New York, where she will be exploring art, fashion, entertainment, food and black tie events with an Indian flavor.

title: Week 3 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Packers (2-0) at Bears (1-1)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Packers 3.Jay Cutler is a 50-Tesla, super-cooled, solenoid-style electromagnet for criticism. He can attract scorn from hundreds of miles away. Everything about Cutlers career is polarizing: the gaudy statistics that contrast his 35-35 win-loss record; his penchant for turnovers; his snippy, irritable public demeanor; and his career-long association with mercurial offensive masterminds like Mike Shanahan, Josh McDaniels and Mike Martz, who only magnify his peculiar attraction-repulsion effect.Last seasons N.F.C. championship game became Ferris Cutlers Day Off, with the (somewhat) injured quarterback looking less willing than able on the sideline as his backups got battered by the Packers. It was the type of nonperformance that defines a career, fairly or not, and a win Sunday could deflect a tiny bit of criticism. Unfortunately, Cutlers Bears are 1-4 against the Packers in the past two seasons, and their offensive line is still bad enough to make even the toughest quarterback consider using a sick day. Pick: Packers

title: The Early Word: Regrouping
description: In Todays Times:

title: A Portable Playground Moves to London
description: The playground that launched a thousand smiles in lower Manhattan has made its way to London, ready to entertain children on the other side of the Atlantic. This playground is actually a portable set of oversize building blocks made from sturdy, colorful components that were developed by the architect David Rockwell.

title: With Battery From Texas, E.V. Bus Begins Its Rounds at Heathrow
description: Heathrow Airport continues to offer a friendly testing ground for new electric-vehicle technologies.

title: Q&A: Playing YouTube Videos on the TV
description: Q.

title: Do Boys Have Less Intense Friendships Than Girls?
description: How important are your friendships? How do you think boys friendships differ, in general, from girls? Do you agree with the author of a recent book that the friendships boys have as younger children often fade in intensity in adolescence and after? If so, why do you think that is? Do you think everyone needs intimate friendships to be healthy and happy? Why or why not?

title: South Korean Bank Chief Apparently Kills Himself, Police Say
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The head of a South Korean savings bank appeared to have jumped to his death on Friday, police officials said, as prosecutors expanded their investigation into an alleged corruption scandal by raiding his and six other banks and seeking to arrest a former senior aide to President Lee Myung-bak.

title: Hey, Whered Everybody Go?
description: Ebb tide: the period between high tide and low tide during which water flows away from the shore. Also called falling tide.
