title: Also, Commodities
description: You may recall that last fall and into the spring there were a lot of people  notably, but not only, the Ron Paul types  who pointed to rising commodity prices and claimed that they were a signal of inflationary doom just over the horizon.

title: Irish Confusion
description: Via Brad DeLong, I see that Tyler Cowen has decided that a small uptick in Irish GDP and a decline in interest rates from nosebleed levels to levels that only signal a significant default somehow refutes Keynesian economics.

title: Cracker Barrel Adopts Poison Pill
description: 12:11 p.m. | Updated Cracker Barrel Old Country Store said on Friday that it had adopted a shareholder rights plan, or a poison pill, after an activist investor moved to shake up the board and gain a major stake in the restaurant and retailer.

title: Within Him, Without Him
description: TO the fans who thought they knew him George Harrison was both omnipresent and enigmatic. Of the four members of the worlds most famous band, the Beatles, Harrison made the least effort at being a public figure, and though he shared himself in recordings as disparate as the catchy pop of Taxman, the desolate strains of While My Guitar Gently Weeps and an album of spiritual chants and music that he produced for the Radha Krishna Temple, he could be inscrutable and distant behind it all. Even as he sang Got My Mind Set on You, his consciousness seemed to be focused somewhere else entirely.

title: Speaking for the Quiet Beatle: Olivia Harrison Discusses the George Harrison Film
description: The four men who made up the Beatles are, to the vast majority of us, larger-than-life figures who made a tremendous and lasting impact on music, film and fashion and in numerous other arenas of popular culture. But to a select few, they are just  or are also  people: friends, siblings, parents, husbands. Among the members of that exclusive club is Olivia Harrison, who married George Harrison in 1978 and remained with him until his death in 2001. Ms. Harrison, who is the mother of Harrisons son, Dhani, does not consider herself a celebrity and does not fully embrace the spotlight, but she has become a guardian of her husbands legacy and of the mementos and artifacts he left behind at Friar Park, their sizable estate in Henley-on-Thames, England.

title: Origins of the Euro Crisis
description: Kash Mansori has an excellent post about the origins of the euro crisis. He documents the fact  which the Germans cannot bring themselves to acknowledge  that fiscal irresponsibility had very little to do with it. And he shows that what really predicts who found themselves in crisis was capital inflows:

title: Giving: The Magic Bus Auction in Mumbai
description: Charitable giving in India surpasses Brazil and China, but pales in comparison to most Western countries, a fact that has prompted criticism and prodding by other philanthropists, particularly given the vast disparity in wealth here. The question Are rich Indians turning their back on the poor?, is asked often, even here in our own comment section. Talk to charity organizers, executives starting NGOs, doctors who do hours of volunteer work or hundreds of others, though, and a very different picture emerges.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 3s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Autumn Unfolds in a Patch of Urban Forest
description: This morning at 5:04, autumn arrived. In New York City as elsewhere, the natural year is winding down, and in just a few weeks, it will be winter. The changing of the seasons is an intricate process involving much more than the turning and falling of the leaves and the growing chill. But often in this city, we do not slow down to notice.

title: Meg Whitmans Other Problem: The Economy
description: As much as any damage caused by Lo Apothekers inability to successfully communicate or execute his decisions during his 11-month tenure atop Hewlett-Packard, new chief executive Meg Whitman is concerned about what has happened to H.P.s competitive environment.

title: Perrys Immigration Problem
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  In 2007, Senator John McCain of Arizona discovered the hard way that a moderate approach to illegal immigration was a nonstarter in the Republican presidential contest.

title: A Serious Case of the Hiccups
description: After the case was posted on The New York Times Well blog on Sept. 12, more than 275 readers offered their thoughts on what was going on with this patient. Many also suggested hiccup remedies.

title: Saturday Nights on St. Mary Street
description: After having spent five boisterous years wandering the Saturday-night streets of Cardiff, Wales, Maciej Dakowiczs bar for amusement is set pretty high.

title: Flight or Fight
description: My husband and son took a New York-to-Milwaukee flight that was supposed to leave Friday at 11:29 a.m. The flight boarded after 4 and didnt leave the gate until 4:40, and a half-hour later the pilot announced it would be another hour until takeoff. At that point a devout Jewish family, worried about violating the Sabbath, asked to get off. Going back to the gate cost the plane its place in line for takeoff, and the flight was eventually canceled. Was the airline right to grant that request? M. W.,NORWALK, CONN.

title: Did I Know You at Camp?
description: Toshi Ito, 86 years old but still bright-eyed and striking, contemplated a life-size photograph of herself that hung on the museums wall. She was 18 at the time it was taken. Im wearing my red boots, she pointed out.

title: A Serious Case of Hiccups
description: THE PATIENT'S STORY A 46-year-old man came to the Metropolitan Hospital on Manhattans Upper East Side early one afternoon. He had a case of the hiccups that wouldnt go away. The problem started two days earlier. In the midst of what seemed a perfectly ordinary day, he started to hiccup and wasnt able to stop. He tried all the usual treatments. He held his breath. He drank glass after glass of cold water. He thought scary thoughts. But no matter what he did, every 20 to 30 seconds, his chest would jump, and then his throat would close, cutting short the involuntary intake of air. After two days of nonstop hiccupping, he went to the hospital.

title: The Soap Opera Is Dead! Long Live the Soap Opera!
description: The soap opera, one of the nations most underappreciated art forms, is in serious trouble. On Sept. 23, All My Children concludes its 41-year run, and with it, unthinkably, will disappear the genres most celebrated siren, Susan Luccis Erica Kane Martin Brent Cudahy Chandler Montgomery Montgomery Marrick Marrick Marrick Montgomery.

title: The Fogies of South Park
description: You guys have long taken pride in being iconoclasts. But last night I watched elderly people literally dance out of the theater after The Book of Mormon. Is it upsetting to be the toast of Broadway? Matt Stone (sitting): Were solidly middle-aged ex-iconoclasts. And its not like kids have great taste.

title: The Iron Lady as Anti-Muse
description: In the endlessly popular musical Billy Elliot, the villain is played not by an actor but by a larger-than-life puppet with a gigantic head, an effigy of the kind that sometimes still appears at European protest rallies. This one has a beaked nose, a pronounced overbite and upswept blond hair, a visage immediately familiar to anyone who remembers the 1980s, and one that theatergoers  paying $100 a ticket for a dose of solidarity with the beleaguered British proletariat in the age of late capitalism  are eager to boo. Who was that lady? one of my children asked as we departed a recent matinee performance, not having recognized the Iron Lady.

title: The Closer
description: When a lender forecloses on a property, one of the first things he does is send somebody out to see if there is a house still standing and whether theres anybody living there. Thats my job. Sometimes the houses are crack dens or meth labs, sometimes the sites of cock- or dog-fighting operations, sometimes the backyard is filled with pot. And sometimes the house is a waterfront mansion in a gated golf community worth well over seven figures. Variety is the rule.

title: A Long Day at The Office With Mindy Kaling
description: In the last few months, Twitter followers of the writer and actress Mindy Kaling have been treated to these observations:

title: Model-Morphosis | Bette Franke at D&G
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Bette Franke from DNA before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Dancing on the Edge
description: On a balmy night this April, when young people in Egypt, Syria, Yemen and Bahrain swarmed the streets to protest repressive regimes, Beiruts 20-somethings were partying on the rooftop of a new American-style restaurant. It was opening night for this latest branch of the countrys popular Crepaway restaurants, and because it sits right on the citys former Green Line  the no mans land that separated the Christian East from the Muslim West during Lebanons 15-year civil war, which ended in 1990  there were slickly designed posters depicting army tanks with the words the art of peace on every wall.

title: Friday Reading: Report Assails Single-Sex Education
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Fill-In | Extreme Fitness
Amid Statehood Bid, Tensions Simmer in West Bank
description: QUSRA, West Bank  In this Palestinian village where a mosque was defaced and cars were burned, young men now patrol nightly against settler intruders. Nearby, Jewish settlers worry that Palestinian militants buoyed by international support of their statehood will step up attacks. Settler rapid response teams are practicing with M-16s; women are learning to shoot handguns.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Amid Warning Signs, Hints That Europeans May Step Up Action
description: WASHINGTON  Rising alarm that Europe is not addressing its economic problems with sufficient speed or force pervaded and soured the annual gatherings here on Friday of economists and policy makers from around the world.

title: Parent Trigger Law to Reform Schools Faces Challenges
description: COMPTON, Calif.  The promise sounded alluring and simple: if enough parents signed a petition, their childrens struggling school would be shut down and replaced with a charter school.

title: My Unfinished 9/11 Business
description: Bill Kellers belated conclusion that the Iraq war has been a monumental blunder is welcome to this reader, who marched with hundreds of thousands to protest the impending attack. As the old saying goes, it takes a big man to apologize, and the recent denials of reality and culpability from Dick Cheney, John Yoo and others show that some are not so open to evidence  or ethics. But given the many tragic consequences in terms of lives lost, our economy derailed, our reputation besmirched and more, even Kellers candidness elicits a long sigh and the resigned sentiment better late than never  I guess.

title: The Buildup
description: On the day of the earthquake, I was in Lower Manhattan, at St. Pauls Church, looking out at One World Trade Center. I had ferried up from New Jersey on this spectacularly clear day to take a Patriots Walking Tour of Lower Manhattan, and, like Sam Anderson, I was immersed in comparisons and contrasts of the present to the past, a living history packed into a square mile of real estate. The tour covered 26 years, including Washingtons installation as the first president. The big theme was that a relatively small number of people in this intensely important area made a crucial difference, not just to the city but to the world. The current architecture is designed to be tall. I believe it is also designed to be optimistic and a continuum of change in typical American style.

title: U.S. Pushes Europe to Act With Force on Debt Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, increasingly alarmed by the spillover effects of Europes financial crisis, has begun an intensive lobbying campaign to persuade Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and other leaders to ramp up efforts to stem any contagion from the debt crisis in Greece.

title: Debate Reinforces Republican Concerns About Perry
description: Prepare yourself for at least one news cycle filled with questions about whether Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has lost his status as the Republican presidential front-runner.

title: Romney Leads Endorsement Race
description: In their book, The Party Decides: Presidential Nominations Before and After Reform, the political scientists Marty Cohen, David Karol, Hans Noel and John Zaller find that endorsements  not polls, fund-raising numbers or media hits  are the best early indicators of success in the presidential primaries.

title: Wildlife Confidential
description: The headline of this post is the name for a book (and perhaps documentary) Ive wanted to create for years, given my decade-long fascination with camera traps, which have become a valuable tool in conservation biology (check this Google Scholar search for research using camera traps).

title: Yanks on the Tube Sept. 23-25: A Weekend TV Guide
description: 4:15 p.m. | Updated to reflect updated TV listings

title: Stuffing the Mets Suggestion Box
description: After Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson made it clear there would be changes to Citi Field this off-season, readers had plenty of ideas when the Bats blog asked for suggested alterations to the ballpark that could put the Mets back on the winning path.

title: Photos of the Moment | Max Mara
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#799", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Making the Case for Detroits Future
description: Its far too early to say Detroit is on the way back; its property values are still falling and its debt is still rated as speculative. But as he approaches the midpoint of a four-year term, Mayor Dave Bing is pointing to signs that the citys breathtaking decline may have bottomed out.

title: Under One Roof
description: One afternoon with the 12 members of the Lee family  the grandfather, his children, their spouses and their children  in their shared Chinatown building.

title: Life in the Lee Family
description: Scenes from the Lee familys household, where three generations live together in one building in Chinatown, an arrangement both retro and revolutionary.

title: Three Generations Under One Roof
description: SEVEN oclock on a Thursday morning: time for bao, Chinese breakfast buns. Dressed for school in striped leggings and a pink shirt, Mebrat Yong, 9, waited for the baby sitter to arrive at her familys building in Chinatown with a red shopping bag filled with the steaming treats from her uncles bakery a few blocks away. Mebrat was dividing up this days buns.

title: Taking Sides on Syracuses Big East Exit
description: John Wallace and Pearl Washington, the former Syracuse basketball stars, are on opposite sides regarding their alma maters decision to leave the Big East for the Atlantic Coast Conference in the midst of major realignment.

title: Ashley Fiolek | Dirt Devil
description: The dirt-bike racer Ashley Fiolek, 20, is the first woman in motocross to be signed to a major corporate team, the youngest to win the American womens motocross championship and the only woman to twice take home the gold in motocross at the X Games. And in a sport in which sound is essential, she has done all of this without the ability to hear. I have been told that most people use sound to know when to shift, says Fiolek, who has been deaf since birth. I feel when my motorcycle needs to shift. The engines vibrations change and I know its time. At 5-foot-2 and 110 pounds, Fiolek might be Honda-Red Bulls most petite team member, but her next goal is decidedly large: to be the first woman to compete in a mens race. My fans really want to see me qualify, she says.

title: Bill Keller on Religion
description: In a recent article, The New York Times Magazine implied that Pastor John Hagee has a favorite candidate in the 2012 presidential election. Like most Americans, Hagee has not yet decided whom he will support. Contrary towhat is written, Hagee has never referred to Catholicism as a godless theology of hate. When he used those words, Hagee was referring to general Christian anti- Semitism, not to any particular denomination.Further, the coverage asserts that Hagee has a poor relationship with the Catholic community. This is also untrue. Bill Donohue, the president of the Catholic League, very recently put out a press release entitled Pastor John Hagee Deserves Better Than False Accusations, in which he directly refutes such assertions.The article also grossly oversimpli!es a sermon Hagee gave concerning the Holocaust and the rise of modern Israel. While some took offense to the sermon, the coverage fails to mention that in Hagees subsequent reconciliation with the Anti-Defamation League, its national director, Abe Foxman, thanked Hagee, the founder of the largest pro-Israel group in America, for having devoted [his] life to combating anti-Semitism and supporting the State of Israel.

title: Runway In Review
description: D&GDesigners: Domenico Dolce & Stefano GabbanaDate and Location: Thursday, Via Piave, 24Photos: slide show

title: After Today Show Appearance, Willow the Cat Is Headed Home
description: Willow the prodigal cat is back in the arms of her Colorado family.

title: Palestinians Rally in West Bank for Abbas Speech; Clashes Reported
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Palestinians thronged the central squares of Ramallah and other cities of the West Bank on Friday to watch President Mahmoud Abbas address the United Nations and formally announce the Palestinians request for full membership in the world body.

title: Two Steps Back, 26.2 Miles Forward
description: BERLIN  The world-record holder in the womens marathon and owner of the three fastest times ever run, Paula Radcliffe of England did not know if she had it in her legs to keep going.

description: Monday offered Two and a Half Men. Wednesday and Thursday offered one-and-a-half women.

description: NOW is not the time for Honda to rest the updated 2012 Civic on its ancestors laurels. The compact car market is stacked.

title: A Glimpse Into the Lesser Known
description: The fashionable Italians pressing against the entrance of a building on the Via SantAndrea in Milans designer shopping district Thursday night were not pushing and shoving their way in to see a Versace show, nor that of Armani or Dolce & Gabbana. They wanted to see Angelos Bratis and Stella Jean, and nearly a dozen designers whose names are largely unrecognizable.

title: Backtracking to Get Around Lake Michigan
description: RACINE, Wis.  Ive had about enough of cities and suburbs for the time being. Too many decisions to make. Too many parked cars to circumvent. Too many traffic lights. Ive been going out of my way to seek out bike routes, but getting to them is hard work.

title: Acceleration Problems Lead to $715,000 Fine Against Bad Boy Buggies
description: A Mississippi company will pay a $715,000 fine to the Consumer Product Safety Commission to settle the agencys allegations that the company hid an unintended acceleration defect with its electric off-road buggies.

title: British Regulator Hires KPMG for Rogue Trading Inquiry
description: LONDON  Britains financial regulator said Friday that it had appointed accounting firm KPMG to help with the investigation into unauthorized trading at UBS.

description: The United Nations General Assembly meeting, often filled with scripted moments of political drama, is not generally associated with Hollywood thrills.

title: Humbling Loss to Australia Shows How Far U.S. Has to Go
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand  The 67-5 score may not have been flattering, but Colin Hawley of the United States Eagles would not trade the experience of playing Australia for anything.

title: Arrests Shed Light on a Black Market in Pesticides
description: Dominican immigrants in Washington Heights have long had a ready weapon against vermin: Tres Pasitos, or Three Little Steps, a granular product so named because after rats eat it, they walk three steps and die.

title: My Last Back-to-School Night
description: As those of you who follow me on Twitter and Facebook might already know, Thursday night was my very last back-to-school night as a parent. The evening was tinged with the bittersweet tones that are part of most parenting milestones, moments that mark both an ending and a beginning at the same time.

title: Eurovillains
description: It took bad thinking and bad policy by many players to get us into the state were in; rarely in the course of human events have so many worked so hard to do so much damage. But if I had to identify the players who really let us down the most, I think Id point to European institutions that lent totally spurious intellectual credibility to the Pain Caucus. Specifically:

title: Banks Increase Holdings in Derivatives
description: Even as federal regulators ratchet up scrutiny of the derivatives market, Wall Street is diving deeper into the $600 trillion industry, a new government report found.

title: DealBook Off the Record: I.P.O. Blues
description: The world of finance is a sophisticated and serious place, full of powerful, serious people and important  uh  serious  ideas. You get the picture.

title: Notes from a Friday in the Singapore Paddock
description: SINGAPORE  The heat was low on Thursday in Singapore, but today it feels like the traditional oven mixed with a humidity strong enough to steam a bowl of noodles. But that has not prevented the paddock in Singapore from brimming over with guests, announcements, media and other moments worth noting.

title: Notes from a Friday in the Singapore Paddock
description: SINGAPORE  The heat was low on Thursday in Singapore, but today it feels like the traditional oven mixed with a humidity strong enough to steam a bowl of noodles. But that has not prevented the paddock in Singapore from brimming over with guests, announcements, media and other moments worth noting.

title: Nighttime Sexual Assault Is Latest in Park Slope Area
description: A 29-year-old woman was sexually assaulted in Brooklyn Wednesday night in what the police said was the 10th such attack since March in and around Park Slope and the nearby neighborhoods of Greenwood Heights and Sunset Park.

title: Palestinians Request U.N. Status; Powers Press for Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS  President Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, formally requested full United Nations membership for his as yet undefined country on Friday. But before the thunderous applause greeting his announcement in the General Assembly had faded, international powers laid out a new plan to resume direct Israeli-Palestinian peace talks that was designed to delay a contentious vote on the Palestinian request as long as possible.

title: Bachmann Urges Conservatives to Stick to Their Values
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  As she struggles to become a major player again in the Republican nominating fight, Michele Bachmann has settled on an appeal aimed directly at the heart of the conservative Tea Party movement.

title: Tour talks about his new book, Whos Afraid of Post Blackness?; Maureen Dowd reviews the new memoir by film critic Roger Ebert; and best-seller news.
description: This week, author and journalist Tour talks about his new book, Whos Afraid of Post Blackness?; Maureen Dowd reviews the new memoir by film critic Roger Ebert; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: The Diva, Defined: Netrebko Has Arrived
description: EXCUSE me, the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko declared at a recent dress rehearsal of Donizettis Anna Bolena, the operatic melodrama about Henry VIIIs unlucky second wife, which will open the Metropolitan Operas 128th season on Monday evening. She walked to the edge of the stage and peered into the dark, near-empty auditorium.

title: Up Front: Orlando Patterson
description: Orlando Patterson, who reviews Tours Whos Afraid of Post-Blackness? on the cover of this week's issue, was born in Jamaica and served for years as an adviser to Michael Manley, the former socialist prime minister.

title: SantAngelo Raises Arizona
description: For nearly three decades beginning in the 1960s, the designer Giorgio SantAngelo held fashion insiders in his sway. Among these was the editor Diana Vreeland, who famously urged SantAngelo, an architect and industrial designer by training, to make accessories and clothes. She sent me to Arizona, SantAngelo once said, with Veruschka, the model, four suitcases full of fabrics, wires and tape and told me to wrap and tie everything as I wanted and then she gave me eight pages in the magazine. That editorial, set in the Painted Desert, photographed by Franco Rubartelli, and published in Vogue in 1968, forged SantAngelos career. Now, 22 years after his death, SantAngelos creative force returns to Arizona in the form of a retrospective  the designers first  at the Phoenix Art Museum.

title: Tea Party Group to Form Super PAC
description: The Tea Party-linked conservative group FreedomWorks will create a Super PAC with the goal of raising $20 million during the 2012 election cycle, exploiting shifts in campaign law that permit independent groups to collect and spend unlimited amounts of money advocating for and against candidates.

title: Stars Add New Tunes to Country Kings Lyrics
description: BOB DYLAN has long claimed Hank Williams as an influence and an inspiration. In his 2004 memoir, Chronicles Volume One, Mr. Dylan recounted his discovery of that country giants music in the 1950s. I became aware that in Hanks recorded songs were the archetype rules of poetic songwriting, he wrote. The architectural forms are like marble pillars.

title: The N.B.A. Cancels 43 Preseason Games
description: Forty-three exhibition games were wiped from the N.B.A. calendar Friday, the first significant fallout from a labor crisis that could soon threaten the regular season.

title: Camera Inside Car Captured Tsunami Wave
description: Immediately after the March earthquake and tsunami in Japan, The Lede posted many videos as water engulfed whole communities on the countrys northeastern shore with lethal force.

title: It Started With a Book
description: To the Editor:

title: The Etiquette of Autographs
description: A nice side effect of being invited to speak at literary festivals as a writer is that you enjoy privileged access as a reader. Writing, if you like, is the Trojan horse of reading. At the Jaipur Literature Festival in India last year, I met Steve Coll (Ghost Wars) and Lawrence Wright (The Looming Tower). What struck me  and I mean this as a compliment  was the speed with which Lawrence (to you) went from being the author of a stonking great masterpiece to just Larry, a guy I was hanging out with. Ditto Bobby (Roberto) Calasso. Well, thats not quite true. I didnt exactly hang out with Calasso and I never called him Bobby, but I did meet him, several times. Id love to say I can prove it, but I cant. That is, I didnt get any books signed.

title: The Roger Ebert Show
description: Roger Ebert could be a cocksure prat.

title: Neal Stephensons Novel of Computer Viruses and Welsh Terrorists
description: Let us say that novelists are like unannounced visitors. While Norman Mailer and Saul Bellow pound manfully on the door, Jonathan Franzen and Zadie Smith knock politely, little preparing you for the emotional ferociousness with which they plan on making themselves at home. Neal Stephenson, on the other hand, shows up smelling vaguely of weed, with a bunch of suitcases. Maybe he can crash for a couple of days? Two weeks later he is still there. And you cannot get rid of him. Not because he is unpleasant but because he is so interesting. Then one morning you wake up and find him gone. You are relieved, a little, but you also miss him. And you wish hed left behind whatever it was he was smoking, because anything that allows a human being to write six 1,000-page novels in 12 years is worth the health and imprisonment risk.

title: A Noncollegial Debate About Bicycles
description: It is nothing new, of course, for the subject of bicycles in New York City to provoke impassioned arguments. From bike shares to bike lanes, the battle lines are often clear.

title: How Do You Get to Broadway? Go to a Basketball Camp
description: During rehearsals last fall the actors in the Broadway play Lombardi learned virtually every inspirational maxim uttered by the legendary Green Bay Packers coach. But at least they didnt have to run drills  unlike the cast of the coming Broadway musical Lysistrata Jones, a comic look at a college basketball team on a long losing streak.

title: How Will We Fuel the Future?
description: At the influential TED conference last year, Bill Gates declared that if he were allowed one wish to improve humanitys lot over the next 50 years, he would choose an energy miracle: a new technology that produced energy at half the price of coal with no carbon dioxide emissions. He explained that hed rather have this wish than a new vaccine or medicine or even choose the next several American presidents. To help understand the reasoning behind Gatess thinking, one should read Daniel Yergins intelligent new opus, The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World.

title: Some Actors Work Both Sides of a Script
description: AT the end of a 90-minute conversation Jesse Eisenberg announced that what he really would like to do is write a musical. To which Zoe Kazan responded, Thats the most impressive thing youve said this whole time. Mr. Eisenberg answered back by listing other comments he had made. Musical theater totally trumps that, she retorted.

title: Its Safe to Go Outside: NASA Says Its Falling Satellite Will Miss the U.S.
description: Hours after it was supposed to have made a fiery plunge back to Earth, a wayward NASA satellite was still in orbit, and space experts were still uncertain when exactly it would fall.

title: The Less Than Heroic Christopher Columbus
description: In 5,000 years of recorded history, scarcely another figure has ignited as much controversy. Each second Monday in October, the familiar arguments flare up. Christopher Columbus, rediscoverer of America, was a visionary explorer. He was a harbinger of genocide. He was a Christianizing messiah. He was a pitiless slave master. He was a lionhearted seaman, a rapacious plunderer, a masterly navigator, a Janus-faced schemer, a liberator of oppressed tribes, a delusional megalomaniac. In Columbus, Laurence Bergreen, the author of several biographies, allows scope for all these judgments. But Christopher Columbus was in the first place a terribly interesting man  brilliant, audacious, volatile, paranoid, narcissistic, ruthless and (in the end) deeply unhappy.

title: At Home With Karl Marx
description: I first encountered the Marx family story in the back of a London magazine, Mary Gabriel writes in the opening line of her intimate account of Karl Marx and his family. It is not a reassuring start for the reader, particularly when the publisher promises a book that uncovers the unyielding love that bound together a man and woman in the midst of historys whirlwind. Gabriel should try to have whoever came up with that one fired.

title: What Our Siblings Do to Us
description: Scribbling Younger Brother:

title: The Case for Countering Chinas Rise
description: It seems inevitable that Chinese-American relations will increasingly come to preoccupy the world. The United States continues to be the only global superpower, but in the not-too-distant future China promises to acquire the status of an equal or near equal. How this relationship evolves during a period when the balance of power between them is shifting so rapidly is inevitably a cause for concern.

title: A British Town Under Close Surveillance
description: As he demonstrated in his 2008 novel The Northern Clemency, which was a finalist for the Man Booker Prize, Philip Hensher knows how to populate his fiction with a range of characters whose stories are kept moving by deft shifts in perspective. Before we can tire of one character, were observing the scene from the point of view of that persons child or spouse or neighbor. The result is a portrait of a community in which were delighted not to live: a milieu that makes our own seem, by contrast, paradisiacal.

title: A Thriller, With Apologies
description: I fear you will make a mistake.

title: Familiar Face, New Wrinkle
description: TESTED 2012 Aston Martin Virage Volante

title: Keeping Hybrid Weirdness at Bay
description: BETHLEHEM, N.H.

title: A Novel and a Memoir of the Mennonite Way
description: Irma Voth, the narrator of the Canadian writer Miriam Toewss new novel, has a name that sounds as if shes a plucky 19th-century heroine, and she has a life imported from another century as well. Irma is a Mennonite living on an isolated farm near the city of Chihuahua, Mexico, where her family fled from Canada after the death of Irmas older sister.

title: Inside the Orgone Box
description: In the classic confessional memoir The God That Failed, Arthur Koestler describes some of the characters who made up the constituency of his Communist Party group in Berlin in the early 1930s:

title: Photos of the Moment | Albino
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#348", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Weekend Fare
description: Mad. Sq. Eats is open daily 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. through October 21 at Worth Square, near Fifth Avenue and 24th Street, in the Flatiron District. A rotating cast of stands, from restaurants like Junoon, to the Hong Kong Street Cart, will be selling food.

title: A Novel of Stormy Children and Angry Parents in Upstate New York.
description: A good three-quarters of the way through Justin Torress first novel, We the Animals, readers might find themselves wondering how the narrator  7 years old at the start and unnamed throughout  keeps his sanity in check. He has seen his mother, delirious and half-deranged from working the overnight shift at the local brewery, scream at him and his two older brothers at 8 on a Sunday evening: Why arent you in school? Hes seen her make a meatloaf one morning and then call them to dinner as they come down to breakfast, half asleep. Hes seen her carried into the house by his father, her cheeks swollen purple, and been told that the dentist had been punching on her after she went under. Hes seen her dragged and forced, by that same father, into a bedroom, behind the door of which the word stop has no meaning. And when his father disappears for a time, hes seen his mother take to the couch for days, miss work, stop eating, stop cooking for them, and drop her head and fall asleep at the kitchen table, surrounded by full ashtrays and empty bottles.

title: We the Animals
description: NEVER-NEVER TIME

title: Inside the List
description: OPEN MIKE: Michael Moore scores his fifth best seller this week with Here Comes Trouble: Stories From My Life, which enters at No. 8. The cover shows the pie-faced provocateur as a sweetly smiling toddler on a tricycle, but inside, Moore is as pugnacious as ever, inveighing against familiar targets like George W. Bush and corporate stooges, along with the crazed New Yorker who tried to stab him with a No. 2 pencil after a news conference for Fahrenheit 9/11, not to mention the more heavily armed crazies who forced him to seek protection from ex-Navy Seal members after he denounced Bush at the 2003 Academy Awards. Moore also briefly wanders into the Mommy Wars, denouncing the pushers of baby formula. An entire generation of us were introduced in our very first week to the concept that phony was better than real, that something manufactured was better than something that was right there in the room, Moore writes. Later in life, this explained the popularity of the fast food burrito, neocons, Kardashians and why we think reading this book on a tiny screen with three minutes of battery life left is enjoyable.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE GRIEF OF OTHERS,  by Leah Hager Cohen (Riverhead, $26.95.) Complex but fundamentally decent characters hurt one another and are hurt by forces greater than themselves in Cohens novel, as a family sinks beneath the weight of a terrible secret.

title: Living In | Hells Kitchen North
description: As memories of street crime have receded, and luxury developments have risen, the name Hells Kitchen has acquired a kind of gritty cachet.

title: With All Its Contrasts, It Needed an Alias
description: NOT long ago, a Midwestern couple arrived at 48th Street near Ninth Avenue to inspect the $399,000 co-op that their 20-something son wanted them to help buy. After looking over the place, a railroad one-bedroom in a tenement walk-up, the mother looked quizzically at the agent, Donald Kemper, and said, Now tell me, am I in Hells Kitchen, or am I in Clinton? Mr. Kemper, a Prudential Douglas Elliman vice president who lives in the area, replied, It depends which one youre more comfortable with.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE PAIN CHRONICLES: Cures, Myths, Mysteries, Prayers, Diaries, Brain Scans, Healing, and the Science of Suffering,  by Melanie Thernstrom (Picador, $17.) This expansive mix of medical reportage, history and memoir explores our relationship to pain  from the horrors of surgery before anesthesia to todays subtler problems of misdiagnosis. Thernstrom also reflects on her own battle with a degenerative spinal condition.

title: When a Dictionary Could Outrage
description: A passel of double-domes at the G. & C. Merriam Company joint in Springfield, Mass., have been confabbing and yakking for 27 years  which is not intended to infer that they have not been doing plenty work. Thus began an editorial that appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12, 1961, excoriating the recently published Websters Third New International Dictionary.

title: Remorse Breeds Rebellion Against Fracking
description: As I report in Fridays Times, many landowners who leased their lands for natural gas drilling in upstate New York are now having second thoughts.

title: Giving the Fed a Good Grade
description: Its been a rough week for the Federal Reserve, as its latest plan to stimulate growth was greeted by the sound of falling stock prices.

title: How to Illustrate the Most Surreal Country on Earth
description: Being a design director is not just about luxury cars, slim-fitting black suits, modern eyeglass frames, exotic vacations and multiple homes. Sometimes we actually have to execute. Below are seven (there were several more) options for this weeks cover of Libyas ousted leader, Col. Muammar Qaddafi.

title: Two States, One Capital?
description: Jerusalem, a city where religions and cultures converge, and often clash, is claimed by both Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Coachs Mission: Selling Temple in a Pro Sports Town
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Steve Addazio looks out from his corner office on the second floor of the soon-to-be-expanded football facility at Temple, he often sees one of this citys many commuter trains rumble past his window.

title: Rachel Katz and David Darwin
description: AS a shy and awkward teenager, David Matthew Darwin learned to juggle, play the harmonica and wrap his legs around the back of his head  sometimes all at once  as a way to attract the attention of girls.

title: Stirring the Pot | Time/Food at Abrons Art Center
description: Over the past three years, the New York-based, itinerant art organization e-flux has been cultivating a large-scale micro-economy through a project called Time/Bank. Physical branches at museums in Den Haag and Frankfurt circulated an alternative currency whose notes, designed by the artist Lawrence Weiner, are printed in denominations of hours. During these exhibitions, anyone could spend time helping others to earn bills, which are redeemable for daily items, groceries, art books and other staples. Julieta Aranda and Anton Vidokle, the artists who founded Time/Bank, call it a platform that enables people to get things done without using money  indeed, to this day the bank is still functioning, globally, with more than a thousand users who deposit time into the Time/Bank Web site and withdraw it in the form of skills performed by others.

title: Ex-UConn Star Charged in Ponzi Scheme Case
description: Tate George, the former N.B.A. player and the chief executive of a real estate development firm, surrendered Friday to federal authorities and will face charges that prosecutors say are related to running a Ponzi scheme.

title: The Caucus | Key Moments From the Debate
description: Sept. 23, 2011  Reporters look at five moments from the debate in Orlando, Fla., and their importance going forward in the Republican race.

title: Shutdown Closer as Senate Blocks Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  An impasse between the House and Senate over a bill to keep the government open after Sept. 30 and provide aid to natural disaster victims deepened Friday as the Senate easily shot down a House measure passed just hours before.

title: Caucus Video: Five Key Moments From the Debate
description: Reporters look at five key moments from the debate in Orlando, Fla., and their importance going forward in the Republican race.

title: Habitats | Prospect Heights
description: Illya Azaroff and Kristi Spessard live with their two sons in an unassuming red brick apartment house that is light, bright and airy inside.

title: Netanyahu Visits 9/11 Memorial, With Bloomberg as Guide
description: Against a strikingly lighted backdrop of water plunging into the footprints of the twin towers, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his wife laid a wreath at the National September 11 Memorial on Thursday night, near the names of some of the four Israeli citizens who died in the attacks.

title: Wrapped in Plain Brick
description: THE leafy streets of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, are lined with gracious brownstones and town houses built in the 19th century for well-to-do families who appreciated their stately proportions and exquisite detailing. Interspersed with these showstoppers are more modest three-story apartment buildings, home to the servants who tended to those grand single-family homes and to the dockworkers who toiled at the nearby Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Judges Compete for Law Clerks on a Lawless Terrain
description: Federal judges are entrusted with interpreting and applying rules fairly and consistently. Except, it seems, when it comes to hiring their own staff.

title: Leaving Sewa Bay by Sailboat
description: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

title: Potential Suitors Emerge for London Metal Exchange
description: LONDON  The London Metal Exchange said Friday that it had received several expressions of interests for the company and was considering its options.

title: Sometimes, Its Not You, or the Math
description: ON my first date with Mark, he asked how long it had been since my last relationship.

title: Abbass United Nations Address
description: Resisting American pressure, President Mahmoud Abbas formally requested United Nations membership.

title: Worlds Oldest Operating Car Returns, Under Steam Power, to the Auction Dais
description: There are classic cars, and there are cars pulled from motorings fossil record. And when this 1884 automobile built by De Dion, Bouton & Trpardoux crosses the auction block on Oct. 6 in Hershey, Penn., it will do so as the oldest road-going original car in the world.

title: Now, Democrats Want Solyndra Backers to Testify
description: Whats next in the Solyndra hearings?

title: About That Crush ...
description: One of my good friends has had a crush on a guy for several months. Its become clear to her that he is not romantically interested. I met the guy separately, at a party, and weve become involved. It looks as if it may last. I havent told my friend yet, and have no idea if, when or how to tell her. Whats the etiquette here?

title: China, Driver of World Economy, May Be Slowing
description: HONG KONG  Is Chinas economy in trouble, too?

title: Generation X in a Time Capsule
description: EVERY generation gets the rock documentary it deserves. As he followed the young Bob Dylan in 1965, D. A. Pennebaker captured a singer-songwriter in transition from boyish folkie to wary, druggy and dandified rebel in Dont Look Back. Martin Scorseses Last Waltz found the Band, Van Morrison, Joni Mitchell and Mr. Dylan under the influence of money and the effects of a long 60s hangover. The 80s brought Penelope Spheeriss Decline of Western Civilization Part Two: The Metal Years, a sort of real-life Spinal Tap. With the long-delayed DVD release this month of David Markeys Sonic Youth tour documentary, 1991: The Year Punk Broke, Generation X, characteristically tardy, finally gets its shot.

title: Photos of the Moment | Etro
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#353", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);Sonny Vandeveldes Milan Fashion Week photo diary.

title: Romneycare Cost Massachusetts Jobs, Perry Tells Conservatives
description: UPDATE 2:25 p.m.: ORLANDO, Fla.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas again attacked Mitt Romneys Massachusetts health care law on Friday, telling conservative activists that it had cost jobs in the state.

title: Discovering Lund, Sweden
description: Thick with history, both modern and ancient, making it an ideal overnight visit from Copenhagen.

title: A College Town With a Bit of Viking Mayhem
description: WITH its cobblestone streets, vibrant intellectual community and relaxed ambience, Lund is an archetypal college town in Swedens southernmost county of Skane (pronounced SKOH-nah). Surrounded by farmland and rolling fields, the town  founded sometime around 990, when the region was still part of Denmark  is thick with history, both modern and ancient, making it an ideal overnight visit from Copenhagen.

title: Red Bulls Suspend Marquez for a Match
description: Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe on Friday suspended defender Rafael Marquez for Saturdays match against visiting Portland after the clubs Mexican international was critical of his teammates after Wednesdays 3-1 loss to Real Salt Lake. The Major League Soccer club confirmed Backes decision to banish Marquez, who has appeared in only 15 of the teams 29 league matches because of injuries and international duty. The decision will probably will spare Marquez another negative reaction from the clubs fans. The match is expected to be sold out in the 25,000-seat Red Bull Arena. Marquez was booed by the fans in the Arenas South Ward, home to the teams most dedicated fans.

title: Franca Sozzani Hates Fashionistas
description: Franca Sozzani, the outspoken editor in chief of Italian Vogue for 23 years, has been in the news a lot lately after publishing issues with provocative themes, like one with only black models in 2008, or the so-called curvy issue this summer. She also pushes a lot of hot-topic buttons on her blog and Twitter accounts.

title: Woven Stories of War in Washington
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington recently unveiled The Invention of Glory: Afonso V and the Pastrana Tapestries, four enormous pieces created by Flemish weavers in the 1470s. Commissioned to applaud King Afonso V of Portugal, who invaded Moroccan coastal cities in the mid-15th century, the tapestries never made it to Lisbon. Instead, they languished in the Spanish town of Pastrana: moth-eaten, faded and rarely seen.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 23
description: Subjects include Wall Street protests, a building collapse in Harlem, and Manhattans last old-style parking meters.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 23
description: The day in sports included a 1-2 victory by Frenchmen in the under-23 road race at the world championships in Copenhagen.

title: From Boston Blogs, the (Discouraging) Word on the Red Sox
description: On Bostondirtdogs.com, the most recent Red Sox score is listed this way: Baltimore 6, Choking Dogs 4. On Survivinggrady.com, a fan named Denton offers this assessment: As much as it pains me to say it, the Red Sox are done. I will root for them as tirelessly as I have all season, but todays game tells the tale. This team is missing whatever it is; heart, guts, mental toughnessthat makes a championship team. The headline on a Sept. 19 post on Sawxblog.com: Dead Team Walking. And over at Soxaholix.com, Hart Brachen gets darkly comic.

title: Coming Home
description: The choreographer Pedro Ruiz is the first Cuban-American to create a work with a Cuban dance troupe in Cuba. A documentary about his trip airs on WNET Sept 29.

title: Ratings for X-Factor Hold Steady on Second Night
description: Fox executives checking out the second-day ratings for their much anticipated new singing competition, The X- Factor, likely let out a giant sigh of relief on Friday, as the numbers showed that most viewers from the first night liked what they saw and came back for more.

title: Alan Light and Ben Ratliff open up the Lost Notebooks of Hank Williams; and The Timess music critics look ahead to some of this falls most notable releases and tours.
description: On this weeks Popcast, Alan Light talks about The Lost Notebooks of Hank Williams, and Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss upcoming fall CD releases including Feist, Drake, Tom Waits and Miranda Lambert. Ben Ratliff, host.

title: Ladies, Get Your Guns
description: Dont let the dcor fool you: the stylists at thenewly opened Tommy Guns salon inWilliamsburg, Brooklyn, are as skilled at tending to womens tresses as they are to mens. Despite the fact that the space looks very masculine, like a traditional barbershop, 60 percent of our clientele are women, says the Tommy Guns founder Russell Manley. Highlights, single process color, keratin blowouts  we excel at everything a salon does.

title: Sept. 25  Oct. 1
description: Pop

title: Crisis in the Horn of Africa: Understanding the Famine in Somalia
description: For todays lesson, we did something a little different: We collaborated with the Global Nomads Group, an international organization that creates interactive educational programs  video conferences, videos and other learning materials  for students about global issues, to foster dialogue and understanding about the world.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Mythic Tales of Man and Gods
description: The comics medium has grown adept at translating legendary stories from history  R. Crumbs adaptation of The Book of Genesis and Eric Shanowers series of graphic novels depicting the Trojan War, Age of Bronze, being recent examples.

title: The West, When It Was Still Wild
description: WESTERNS are only one of the genres represented in Treasures 5: The West, 1898-1938, the fifth boxed set of DVDs in the essential series Treasures from American Film Archives, produced by the National Film Preservation Foundation.

title: Festivals As Cultural Cuisinarts
description: Portland, Ore.

title: Explaining Capital Punishment to Children
description: In the Opinion pages on Thursday, two legal experts, Dahlia Lithwick and Lisa T. McElroy, criticize the three-hour radio silence of the Supreme Court on Wednesday night, while it considered, and ultimately rejected, a stay on the execution of Troy Davis, a convicted killer.

title: An Untethered Approach Is Back in Style
description: JOHN CORIGLIANO had no illusions about the difficulty of the project he had agreed to undertake for the New York Philharmonic. The commission was for a work to commemorate the anniversary of Sept. 11, and it was the orchestras second request. Soon after the terrorist attacks the Philharmonic asked him for a first-anniversary tribute to those who had perished. Mr. Corigliano declined, feeling that the shock was too fresh, and the orchestra turned to John Adams, who provided the luminous, deeply moving On the Transmigration of Souls.

title: Adventures in the Orgasmatron
description: Introduction

title: Fall Cooking With Greens
description: We may be seeing the first burnt-orange and fiery reds of fall foliage, but farmers markets and Community Supported Agriculture baskets are still laden with deep greens like Swiss chard, broccoli rabe and bok choy. If your produce basket is overflowing, here are five new recipes from Martha Rose Shulman that will get you cooking with greens.

title: Citys Top Lawyer Details Payouts of $561 Million in Lawsuits
description: The citys top lawyer has called for changes to laws in civil cases that he said often allow plaintiffs to be compensated too generously for claims that they bring against the city.

title: Two Peoples, One Capital?
description: Jerusalem, a city where religions and cultures converge, and often clash, is claimed by both Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Big Deal | Reading, Writing and Real Estate
description: It was unusual in the post-housing-crash world that Michael L. Breaux fell for an apartment at PS90, a once-decrepit public school in central Harlem converted to a mixed-income condominium in 2009, before seeing a finished unit.

title: Steps in the Palestinian Bid for U.N. Membership
description: While the Palestinian request for membership at the United Nations is unlikely to succeed, here are the steps in the process.

title: Minds on the Seafloor, Eyes on the Ice Ahead
description: Bernard Coakley, a marine geologist with the University of Alaska at Fairbanks, writes from the Arctic Ocean, where his team is reconstructing the geologic history of the Chukchi Shelf and the Chukchi Borderland.

title: Zuckerbergs Unspoken Law: Sharing and More Sharing
description: One of the most telling moments of Mark Zuckerbergs presentation Thursday morning in San Francisco was a reference to a technology company he said he deeply admired. It wasnt Apple, though his turn on stage seemed to lift several pages from the Steve Jobs playbook. It wasnt Google, from which he has plucked some of his key lieutenants.

title: The Castles of Moravia
description: THE dark forest felt familiar enough, alternating raggedy oaks and silver beech trees in the dense array found throughout Central Europe. Along the trail, the ubiquitous woodland plants of the Old World  nettles, burdock, fennel and sorrel  grew in their standard summertime abundance. But when we rounded a corner into a meadow, we suddenly seemed to have entered another country, if not another era. Above us soared a stone triumphal arch, perhaps 100 feet tall, topped with life-size nudes. Four immense decorative columns faced us, with ornate bas-relief plasterwork and a mysterious inscription reading Has tibi, blanda soror Phoebi, sacravimus aedes. Intactus semper crescat tibi lucus honori. It looked like an ancient Roman monument, but of far more recent vintage and located about 700 miles too far north.

title: Tackling Maines Rugged Side by Bike
description: OUR ragged band of bike riders pedaled down Crooked Lane in search of a rest stop. In front of an old stone barn, amid a pastoral setting that is part Rockwell and part Czanne, Harry Owen and his dog Rufus were waiting for us.

title: Restaurant Report: Septime in Paris
description: Before he surrendered to his love of cooking, Bertrand Grbaut already had a degree in literature and had worked as a graphic designer. So its no surprise that the delicious market-driven contemporary French dishes that have been tantalizing Paris at his restaurant, Septime, are aesthetically flawless and come seasoned with a subtle literary sensibility.

title: In Brazil, a Second Life for the Favelas of Rio de Janeiro
description: ON a recent Friday night in Rio de Janeiro, a mix of young locals and tourists sipped caipirinhas and danced along to a samba-infused rock band at the Maze, a combination bed-and-breakfast and night club. The moonlit vistas of Sugar Loaf and Guanabara Bay commanded nearly as much attention as the music; between sets, partiers flooded up to the roof for fresh air and to take in a view that bests those of any hotel on Ipanema Beach.

title: In Massachusetts, Hints of a Town, Now Revitalized
description: Pittsfield, Mass., which had fallen on hard times, has begun to reawaken with the openings of galleries, boutiques and restaurants.

title: My Favorite Place: Little Compton, R.I.
description: MY favorite places, like my favorite people, tend to be complicated. Perhaps even difficult. I like strong character, with an I-dare-you-to-like-me attitude, cut with the zest of simple charm. I know, I know. You can waste a lot of time with these types, going nowhere fast. But Ive come to appreciate the value in going nowhere. Which is why my favorite place in the world happens to be just down the street from me  the public beach in Little Compton, R.I.

title: Hotel Review: In London, Hotel Verta
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Moravias Castles
description: The architectural landscape of South Moravia is a surprising profusion of castles and chateaus.

title: Edible Selby | Tokyo Calling
description: Yoshiyuki Okada was the manager of a theme-park-like izakaya, or Japanese-style tapas bar, when, in 2001, he decided he wanted more freedom  like the freedom to dye his hair platinum and play punk music at full volume. Okada ventured to Tokyos modish Daikanyama neighborhood to open his own, much smaller izakaya, Tatemichiya, where customers dine on yakitori and deep-fried octopus balls to the blaring guitars of the Ramones, the Sex Pistols and Japanese punk bands like the Stalin and Cobra. Though many of Tokyos izakayas have switched to gas or electric cooking, Okada insists on grilling with live coals. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Netanyahus United Nations Address
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel addressed the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Links: The Week in Food
description: According to a recent study, the single greatest reason why so many of us are now obese is that so few of us are now smoking. Damned if you do

title: Two States, One Capital?
description: Jerusalem, a city where religions and cultures converge, and often clash, is claimed by both Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Popcast: Opening the Lost Notebooks of Hank Williams
description: This week Popcast takes a listen to new songs by an artist who died in 1953.

title: On Our Radar: Putin Covets Northeast Passage
description: In a bid to register its stake in the energy-rich Arctic as climate change erodes polar ice, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pledges to turn the Northeast Passage into an important shipping route and modernize ports and airfields in the region. [Agence France-Presse]

title: Weighty Saxophone and Soft Harmonies
description: Mark McGuire

title: Fighting Threats to Mind and Country
description: Charlotte, N.C.

title: A Franchise Is Redesigned
description: The ninth generation of the Honda Civic has arrived, but in some ways the older models had more charm.

title: A Steady Presence Out of the Limelight
description: AT a recent press luncheon in Manhattan to promote both the PBS documentary Prohibition and the HBO series Boardwalk Empire, a fictionalized treatment of the era, all attention was on two men at the head of one very long table: Terence Winter, the HBO shows creator, and Ken Burns, the PBS filmmaker.

title: X Factor Holds Steady in the Ratings
description: The ratings for The X Factor premiere on Wednesday may not have met expectations, but the second episode last night at least held steady. With 12.5 million viewers, the overall ratings matched the debut episode, while the 18-to-49-year-old audience dropped off by just 2 percent. It was enough to give Fox a victory in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49 demographic for the night, representing Foxs first ratings win ever for a Thursday during premiere week. CBS once again finished first in total viewers, led by two episodes of Big Bang Theory (averaging 14.4 million viewers) and its new drama Person of Interest (13.2 million), according to Nielsen data. However, Person of Interest fell in its second half-hour and was fourth in the 18-to-49 category for its 9 p.m. time slot, behind X-Factor, Greys Anatomy on ABC and Whitney on NBC.

title: His Fans Campaign for a Tombstone for the Original King of Mambo
description: Arsenio Rodrguez was the original mambo king, one of the inventors of that genre as well as of the music that later came to be known as salsa. But no tombstone marks his grave at the Ferncliff Cemetery in Westchester County, and with the centennial of his birth having arrived, a group of his admirers have begun a campaign both to remedy that lapse and to get a street named for him in New York City.

title: London Design Festival | The Wrap-Up
description: The London Design Festival may end on Sunday, but it leaves visitors with lots to remember.

title: Yemen's President Returns
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh has made a dramatic and sudden return to Yemen.

title: Scenes From Prohibition
description: Prohibition, the new documentary by Ken Burns and Lynn Novick, will have its premiere on PBS on Oct. 2.

title: Worst No Longer Describes New York Commuting Time
description: Consider it the statistical equivalent of a fender-bender: New York State has finally been bumped from first place for the longest commute.

title: Far From the Factory, Adding Final Touches
description: PORT NEWARK, N.J.

title: A Small Sampling of Anti-Thatcher Songwriting
description: This weeks Riff by A.O. Scott touches upon the inadvertent cultural influence of Margaret Thatchers icy reign, particularly among musicians. Weve gathered a sampling of some of the musical remnants from her most famous loathers:

title: Pages From the Glossies
description: In addition to Prada, Jil Sander, Dolce & Gabbana, Gucci, et al, a must-see on this seasons Milan fashion week calendar is Lei e le Altre, an exhibition at the Museo della Permanente, culled from the archives of RCS Periodici, the publishing company behind titles like Max, Amica, LEuropeo and the legendary but defunct Lei. Curated by Maria Luisa Frisa and designed by Arabeschi di Latte, the dense, labyrinthine installation presents style milestones at every turn, including Jackie Kennedy on a Roman holiday, Franoise Hardy in 1970s-era Yves Saint Laurent and fashions current patron saint, Lady Gaga. But the view is ultimately panoramic: Fashion can be used to read and interpret society, and to tell stories about the evolution and emancipation of women, Frisa says. Here fashion acts not only as a reflection of social change, but as a driving force behind it  and not just on paper.

title: Designing Sustainable Structures From the Land Up
description: The Solar Decathlon, an Energy Department competition in which college teams design and build energy-thrifty solar-powered structures,kicked off today on the National Mall. (The video above is the entry from the University of Maryland; background below.)

title: Crafting an Application Essay That Pops
description: Stanford Universitys application for admission includes a prompt directing students to write a letter to their future freshman roommates. The exercise is a good one for all applicants  regardless of their interest in Stanford  as a fun, fresh jumping-off point in the essay writing process, Rebecca Joseph, a professor of education at California State University, said on Friday.

title: Never Too Old to Quit
description: Perhaps youve heard of the damage is done scenario. An elderly family member started smoking as a young person, maybe a teenager, tucking a pack of cigarettes into his rolled-up shirtsleeve or into her purse. Decades later, despite wall-to-wall anti-smoking ads, despite smoking being outlawed in nearly every public space, perhaps despite family pleas or doctors admonitions or even a heart attack, that person remains a smoker.

title: Late Trade by Diamondbacks Recalls Deal From the Past
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks have a magic number of one to clinch the N.L. West. But they are taking no chances, acquiring a left-handed reliever, Mike Zagurski, from Philadelphia on Friday for a player to be named.

title: The Low-Inflation Trap (Slightly Wonkish)
description: Looking at recent numbers, Ive realized that theres something else to worry about, beyond all the usual concerns. Let me call it the low-inflation trap; its something were very, very close to getting into.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from West Bank, New York, Afghanistan and Libya.

title: Photos of the Moment | Blumarine
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#340", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Solyndra Officials Take Fifth at House Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Stony-faced, the chief executive and chief financial officer of Solyndra, the bankrupt solar company, took the Fifth Amendment on Friday before a House subcommittee as they were verbally pummeled by committee members until Democrats complained that the badgering was becoming unseemly.

title: Splurging on Everything but the Dress
description: BRIDES who have decided not to sell the farm for a wedding gown are upgrading their ensemble with the power of a couture accessory.

title: Lens blog: Moises Saman in Libya
description: Lens blog: Moises Saman in Libya

title: A Teacher? This Actor Fits the Part
description: In the 10th-floor classroom, students were gathered round with coursework packets and coffee cups. The instructor tapped his red pen against a long, wooden table.

title: Book Review Podcast: Tours Whos Afraid of Post-Blackness?
description: On the cover of this Sundays Book Review, Orlando Patterson reviews Tours new book, Whos Afraid of Post-Blackness?, a work that examines the many meanings of being black in a post-civil-rights era.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from West Bank, New York, Libya and Afghanistan.

title: A Sweeter Side of Focaccia
description: My first taste of Concord grape focaccia was at Gramercy Tavern. I was working on a cookbook with the pastry chef Claudia Fleming and the dish was one of her specialties  with a few tweaks. Instead of the traditional olive oil, she used melted butter in the dough, which gave it a milder, less assertively savory flavor. She always said the focaccia reminded her of hot buttered toast with Concord grape jelly on it, and I would have to agree.

title: Lara & Robert
description: In this homemade video, Lara Dolan and Robert Banks discuss how they met at a small consulting firm outside of Washington, DC.

title: A Web Tool That Lets You Automate the Internet
description: The phrase if this, then that is a bit of programming-speak: you tell the computer that if this happens, it should perform this action.

title: Amanda & Justin
description: In this homemade video, Amanda Speiser and Justin Karp recall meeting through a blind date recommended by family and friends.

title: Little Dutch Girl
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#836", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Readers Questions About Autism
description: The New York Times has received hundreds of letters in response to Autistic and Seeking a Place in Adulthood, Amy Harmons article last Sunday about a 22-year-old New Jersey man, Justin Canha, who has autism and is struggling to be independent.

title: Is the Amazon Press Conference About a Color Kindle?
description: On Friday, Amazon sent an e-mail to technology bloggers and journalists announcing a press conference to be held in New York on Wednesday.

title: Laura & Weston
description: In this homemade video, Laura Fenton and Weston Wells recall meeting at a mutual friend's birthday party.

title: My Three Favorite Food Delivery Systems, Japan
description: It was that first visit to Japan, in 1992, during a journalism fellowship. We checked into the Y.M.C.A. hotel in Tokyo, a bunch of rubes from the States, and there on the sixth floor was a vending machine that dispensed . . . beer. We swooned. Regular cans, tall boys and what looked quarter-size kegs. After the long flight from the East Coast, there could have been nothing more beautiful. Since then Ive collected impressions of unusual food- and drink-dispensing systems in Japan. My favorites:

title: The Stelvio Pass in an Audi R8 5.2 FSI V-10 Quattro: Paradise or Purgatory?
description: STILFERSJOCH, Italy  Some say the highway through northern Italys Stelvio Pass is the greatest driving road in the world.

title: Focaccia Thats Worth a Little Extra Effort
description: SCHIACCIATA CON LUVA, a rustic, focaccialike flatbread enriched with olive oil and studded with grapes, is the kind of harvest snack traditionally baked in Tuscany when the wine grapes are inky purple on the vines and the people hungry in the fields.

title: Channel Surfing: Family Guy Returns, Zingers Intact
description: Seth MacFarlane drew a lot of notice early this week as roast master of the lets-cook-Charlie-Sheen extravaganza on Comedy Central, but hows he doing in his day job? We find out on Sunday when Family Guy, his long-running animated hit, starts a new season on Fox. And the season premiere is a shocker, in a sense: Can it be that this show, now nearing its zillionth episode, has never done a Peter-wins-the-lottery story line before?

title: Joanna & Blake
description: In this homemade video filmed at the airport, Joanna Ganson and Blake Pritchett recall meeting at a US embassy party in Azerbaijan where they were both posted through the Foreign Service.

title: Pop God Dives Into World of Ballet
description: Paul McCartneys first ballet score, Oceans Kingdom, is in no way an important addition to the corpus of ballet music, but it deserves a better staging than the one its been given by New York City Ballet. Never less than agreeable, it has plenty of color and melody. Curiously, it sounds as if it had been composed in the neo-Romantic era before the Beatles: some of its most expansive tunes have hints of Borodin and Samuel Barber; some of its atmospheres evoke Ravel; and its jolliest passages are on the cusp of Bernsteins Candide.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 23
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: 7 Ways to Automate Your Life With ifttt
description: Ever wish you could get a text message every time someone tagged you in a Facebook photo? Or that you could record notes to yourself that are transcribed and sent to your e-mail account?

title: Reviewing the Honda Civic
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman spends time with a few members of the ever-growing Honda Civic family.

title: Jeff Sommer and Floyd Norris on Operation Twist and the markets, David Gillen and Liz Alderman on Christine Lagarde and the I.M.F., David Barboza on the Chinese economy, and Christina Romer on the Obama jobs plan.
description: Jeff Sommer and Floyd Norris on Operation Twist and the markets, David Gillen and Liz Alderman on Christine Lagarde and the I.M.F., David Barboza on the Chinese economy, and Christina Romer on the Obama jobs plan.

title: When Judges Break Their Own Rules
description: I have a new article online about the ordeal that law students go through if they want to be hired as clerks for federal judges.

title: Fluxus at Grey Art Gallery
description: The exhibition explores works from the international network of Conceptual artists.

title: How to Revisit an Iconic Photograph
description: This fall is a busy one for the photographer Alec Soth, who most recently shot Portraits From a Job-Starved City for the magazine. Soth is showing new photographs at the International Photography Festival of Rome and at the Wattis Institute for Contemporary Arts in San Francisco. And later this month, at the NY Art Book Fair, Soths publishing company, Little Brown Mushroom, will introduce three new books: A Head with Wings, by Anouk Kruithof, The Little Brown Coloring Book, by Jason Polan and Bunny Boy Goes to Rome by the Soth family. In a series of e-mail exchanges, condensed below, I asked Soth about his latest work.

title: For a Bills Fan, a Glimmer of Hope
description: On Sunday, the Bills (2-0) will try to reverse a humiliating 15-game losing-streak against the mighty Patriots (2-0) at Ralph Wilson Stadium in Orchard Park. Since beating the Pats, 16-13 in an overtime thriller on Nov. 5, 2000, the team has lost 20 of its last 21 games to their division foe in a stretch where the Patriots have taken home the Vince Lombardi trophy three times while the Bills have failed to make the playoffs even once.

title: Icahn Withdraws From Proxy Fight at Clorox
description: Carl C. Icahn has cut short his effort to replace the board at Clorox, he disclosed in a securities filing on Friday, after failing to win enough support from other shareholders.

title: Kicking Out of Bounds Easier Said Than Done
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Once the weeping subsided and rationality returned, most Giants fans were left with one simple question in the aftermath of last seasons Week 15 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, a game that will always be remembered for DeSean Jacksons game-ending 65-yard punt return for a touchdown:

title: A Tax Plan That Might Not Be So Painful
description: If youre among the households with earnings of $200,000 to $350,000 or so, you can be forgiven at this point for thinking that you have a giant target on your back.

title: Michele Bachmann and the Making of an Acolyte
description: ANNANDALE, Minn.  At first glance, Bradlee Dean seems straight out of a casting call for aging rockers  the hair cascading down his back, the arms wrapped in tattoos and the passing of years that have filled out his face, now in sharp contrast to the slender features in the soft-focus studio portrait from his younger days.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 23
description: More Photographs

title: When Your Therapist Is Only a Click Away
description: THE event reminder on Melissa Weinblatts iPhone buzzed: 15 minutes till her shrink appointment.

title: Now Online | T Travel Fall 2011
description: The fall travel issue of T explores the art of the tour, starting with the model Lara Stone, who heads home to the Netherlands for a romp through her old stomping grounds. The performer Casey Spooner, of the art-rock group Fischerspooner, takes us from stage to stream on his whirlwind trip through four countries. And Diana Taylor, the board chairwoman of the microfinance group Accin  and Mayor Bloombergs longtime companion  leads the way to Manaus, Brazil, where the organization recently began making loans. Along the way we stop in Beirut to find the city eternally optimistic in the wake of the Arab Spring; Provence, where one of the worlds most reclusive patrons has turned his vineyard into an architectural theme park; and the Tuscarora Reservation in New York State, for a look at how the tribes heritage corn has survived the ages, and why it matters to agriculture. Elsewhere, Daphne Merkin looks for retail therapy in Jerusalem, The Selby discovers punk-rock tapas in Tokyo, and Jeremy Irons reveals his Budapest, part of an up-to-the-minute guide to Hollywood on the Danube. See all the storieshere.

title: Opposition Leader Is Handed Reins in Zambia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Zambian opposition leader Michael Sata, a 74-year-old veteran politician who had whipped up not-so-subtle anti-Chinese sentiment (China runs several big mines in Zambia), handily won the presidency in election results announced Friday.

title: Dancing of the Streets, Stripped Down to Its Art
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Its easy to imagine Sonia Destri rehearsing with Companhia Urbana de Dana, her all-male Brazilian troupe that specializes in contemporary dance and hip-hop. Or at least this is my fantasy: the moment just before a dancer is about to spin on his head or whip a leg around in a windmill, she hollers, Freeze!

title: Snooping in the Age of E-book
description: I RECENTLY attended a chaotic, kid-friendly gathering at the home of a friend. On my way to the bathroom to seek some solace, I decided to indulge in one of my favorite antisocial activities: scrutinizing someone elses bookshelf. For a veteran sleuth, a bookshelf can offer a trove of insights worthy of any Freudians couch. Does a person alphabetize the books or clump them? Do they arrange their books by genre, order in which they were purchased, or color? Are these books unopened hardcovers or dog-eared paperbacks?

title: Debt Levels Alone Dont Tell the Whole Story
description: AS the worlds central bankers and finance ministers gather in Washington this weekend for the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, government debt is at the top of the agenda. Some governments can no longer borrow money and others can do so only at relatively high interest rates. Reducing budget deficits has become a prime goal for nearly all countries.

title: With the Help of Unusual Outsiders, Finding Love in Strange Objects
description: The process behind Tool Is Loot, the collaboration between Jennifer Lacey and Wally Cardona that had its premiere at the Kitchen on Thursday, was willfully, even perversely circuitous.

title: Buffett Rule Is More Complicated Than Politics Suggest
description: WHAT percentage of your annual income do you pay in taxes  as much as Warren Buffetts secretary? If not, what is the likelihood that you will soon?

title: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
description: With the Yankees almost-annual trip to the postseason officially booked, and the rival Red Sox fading fast, Yankees fans did their best to explode Twitter this week in a fit of joy and schadenfreude.

title: Staring the Audience Down to Send a Message
description: Shy Showoff, the title of the piece for three that Heather Olson presented at the Chocolate Factory on Wednesday, almost works as a self-description of her intriguing stage persona. When she stares spectators down, as she often does, she projects a feeling of distrust, her head retracting into her elegant neck. You could say shes a deer caught in the stage lights, if the idiom connoted animal alertness rather than dumb paralysis. This deer has some De Niro in her: You lookin at me?

title: Accounting Change Cuts Groupons Revenue
description: Groupon disclosed a major accounting change on Friday, essentially halving its once-jaw-dropping revenue after it encountered resistance from regulators with its filing to go public.

title: A Marilyn Obsession
