description: SINCE her death in 1962, Marilyn Monroe, whom Norman Mailer called the American mans sweet angel of sex, has never wandered far from popular imagination or the souvenir shop. Yet with the 50th anniversary of Ms. Monroes mysterious death approaching, her image is experiencing something of a cultural moment, even by ageless icon standards.

title: Noticed: Marilyn Monroe
description: With the 50th anniversary of Ms. Monroes mysterious death approaching, her image is experiencing something of a cultural moment, even by ageless icon standards.

title: Groupon C.O.O. Quits to Return to Google
description: The chief operating officer of Groupon, Margo Georgiadis, has stepped down after about five months at her post, the chief executive, Andrew Mason, announced on the companys blog on Friday.

title: Break Is Found in Manhattans Eruv, a Crucial Aid to Observant Jews
description: A detail of a map of the Manhattan eruv, showing the area where a gap was found, near the United Nations. View Manhattan Eruv Map in a larger map.

title: The Daily Shoe | Versace
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Grades Slip in Annual School Progress Report
description: More schools received low marks in New York Citys School Progress Report after a rule that kept their grades from dropping too quickly was lifted. The annual evaluation also used a new curve that assigned more Ds and Fs than last years system did. The end result: More schools can be considered for closing or transformation.

title: An Uptick, but Is It Enough?
description: Six months ago, Keli Goff, a blogger, political commentator and self-appointed fashion industry watchdog, chided designers for their near-exclusion of black models on the runways. Most shows, she wrote on her Web site, Loop21.com, were about as diverse as a Tea Party rally. Of 144 shows last spring, she reported, 25 featured no black models at all, while others included only one or two.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 23
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Wall Street protests, a building collapse in Harlem and Manhattans last old-style parking meters.

title: In a Chinese Tournament, the Visitors Lead the Way
description: Just before the Tianjin Binhai Cup world mens elite tournament in China, there was a three-day event for the Zhejiang Huamen Cup, from Sept. 7 to 9. In it, four foreign teams joined eight Chinese teams to play a round robin of 16-board matches.

title: Global Arms Sales Dropped Sharply in 2010, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The global economic crisis may set off upheaval and even unrest, but the ability of the worlds governments to buy new military hardware was sharply curtailed last year by strains on their national treasuries, according to a new Congressional study.

title: Liberating Viewers, and the World, With Silliness
description: Fed up with being hounded by the New York State attorney generals office over alleged zoning violations in the early 1970s, George Maciunas, the real estate developer, graphic artist and leading light of Fluxus, the international network of Conceptual artists, created an artwork that doubled as a defense against subpoena-wielding enforcers. He attached four industrial-size paper-cutting blades to the grungy yellow front door of his Manhattan apartment.

title: The Curls Carrie White Left Behind
description: Ms. White, who styled the hair of Marlon Brando, Elizabeth Taylor and Elvis Presley, played a part in originating the look of her time.

title: The Curls She Left Behind
description: Los Angeles

title: Photos of the Moment | Moschino
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#907", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Oysters Take a Dip in Butter
description: ITS a funny thing about oysters. Its O.K. to eat them elsewhere than by the sea. They travel, a boon for many a landlocked diner.

title: Red Pepper Mayonnaise, Nearly Effortless and Worth It
description: While raw oysters are wonderful, a good fried oyster is a pretty fine thing too. And though restaurant versions can be fine, often they just get a roll in some corn meal or dry crumbs before getting tossed in the deep-fryer. It is too bad. There is a tastier, better way.

title: Dodging the Proposed 2013 Tax Increase
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I use the presidents efforts to have the six-figure set pay more in taxes as an excuse to remind the world about the mysterious under-use of flexible spending accounts.

title: The Possible Unintended Consequences of Higher Taxes
description: Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about President Obamas proposal to make Americans who make more than $1 million a year pay at least the same percentage of their earnings as middle-class earners.

title: Alphabet Soup
description: THE teenage girl wearing jean shorts and a bikini top sunbathing at Long Beach, N.Y., on a recent hazy Saturday found her friends hilarious  if youre willing to take her word for it.

title: Readers Respond to Bill Kellers About-Face
description: Bill Kellers article, My Unfinished 9/11 Business, provoked a lot of responses.

title: Medal of Honor Nominee Picks Up a Supporter
description: The campaign to have the Medal of Honor awarded to an Army sergeant who died while pulling fellow soldiers from a burning vehicle in Iraq got a new boost on Friday from a well-known military historian.

title: Jewel-Box Rooms and Baubles to Match
description: MURIEL BRANDOLINI is having quite a moment.

title: Bill Cunningham | Zip It
description: The one-piece dress is back. Zipped on in 30 seconds, it eliminates the time-consuming thought that goes into dressing in multiple separates.

title: TimesCast | September 23, 2011
description: Palestinians formally request United Nations membership; global powers push for Mideast peace talks; and Yemen's leader returns.

title: A Game That Honed the Skills of Writers
description: Jim Butcher is known to millions as the author of the best-selling series of Dresden Files novels featuring Harry Dresden, a professional wizard who works in a noirish Chicago as a private investigator.

title: Taco Truck Operator Honored as Most Heroic Vendor
description: The Vendy Awards, founded to recognize the citys mobile vendors selling the most delicious food, have named the first winner of the Most Heroic Vendor award. It is Patys Tacos, an uptown stalwart that is leading the legal challenge to a city law prohibiting sales of merchandise from metered parking spots.

title: A Look at PolitiFact Grades of Candidates
description: In politics, sifting for the truth can be a difficult endeavor. Black and white are rare commodities, and most often voters, the press, politicians and political observers are left trading in grays.

title: Strauss-Kahn Will Face French Accuser
description: PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn will come face to face with the French writer who has accused him of attempted rape as part of an investigation into the womans accusations, the Paris prosecutor said Friday.

title: Data as Art, as Science, as a Reason for Being
description: Anyone walking past Lincoln Center during the last few days, and glancing downward at its new access road, Jaffe Drive, would have seen what seemed to be a slightly eccentric art installation. A long band of animated colored lights would snake across a 123-foot-long wall of LEDs as a digital clock counted backward. Then that band might suddenly twist and wind around itself, erupt into curves, contort into waves, and, just as unexpectedly, subside again into temporary linear calm.

title: The Menil Is to Return Frescoes to Cyprus
description: ROME  The Menil Collection in Houston announced on Friday that next year it would return to the Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus 13th-century Byzantine frescoes that have been one of the museums main attractions for more than a decade.

title: Compassion, Ethics and Responsibility in Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: The High Low | Muji Knit Blazer
description: What: Muji knit blazer (black and charcoal gray)How Much: $110Who: Jason Rider, T Magazines mens fashion editor

title: Reading Into Changes in Romneys Book
description: 8:32 a.m. | Updated In the battle of the book reports between Rick Perry and Mitt Romney, score one for the Texas governor.

title: Saying It With Flowers, but Still Putting Anguish Front and Center
description: Theres no hiding in Girls, the two-man project of Christopher Owens and J R White, though its really just the showcase for the self-lacerations of Mr. Owens, whose shaky and piercing vocals slice neatly through whatever else is happening around them.

title: Mad for Metro-North, a Rail Rider Is on a Mission
description: EVERY weekday, Emily Moser rides the Metro-North Railroad from Goldens Bridge to White Plains, N.Y., and unlike most of the other passengers, she relishes every moment of the round trip, which takes an hour and 10 minutes. Where others see generic train stations whose functional, if uninspired, construction hides hints of past glory, Ms. Moser sees art.

title: Footnote
description: The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of the 1971 musical Follies will extend its engagement at the Marriott Marquis Theater by three weeks, through Jan. 22, the producers announced Friday. The slightly longer run will give the musical a better chance of turning a profit  a benchmark of success that has long eluded the show, beloved by many musical theater fans for its score by Stephen Sondheim.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Is Heading to China
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra will spend a week in China next May, giving performances, coaching sessions, master classes and workshops, the orchestra said. The visit is the first of what the orchestra called a pilot partnership with the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing. (Its president, Chen Ping, pictured, shakes hands with Allison Vulgamore, president of the orchestra.) The Philadelphia Orchestra was the first major American orchestra to perform in China, in 1973, and now joins a growing number of Western cultural institutions establishing ties in a country with a hunger for Western classical music. As China builds more and more halls in its many big cities, the need for high-level performers has increased, and in many cases engagements in China provide much-needed cash for Western ensembles.

title: Bill Cunningham | Zip It
description: The one-piece dress is back. Zipped on in 30 seconds, it eliminates the time-consuming thought that goes into dressing in multiple separates.

title: This Sunday: Our Man in Tripoli
description: This week, we have Robert F. Worths third cover story in 6 months. In the spring, he was in Libya just as the revolution against Qaddafi was exploding. Then he went to Yemen, where he explored the fierce rivalries that are driving that country apart. And now hes back in Libya, reporting on the bizarre vacuum created by the tyrants collapse. A safe, functioning democracy seems a long way off, to say the least.

title: Getting an Easy Laugh
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox News-Google Republican Presidential Debate
description: The following is a transcript of the Republican presidential debate in Orlando, Fla., as provided by Federal News Service.

title: Long-Term Care in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 23, 2011
description: Rebel fighters continued battling Qaddafi loyalists in Bani Walid and Surt.

title: Pakistan Scorns U.S. Scolding on Terrorism
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The public assault by the Obama administration on the Pakistani intelligence agency as a facilitator of terrorist attacks in Afghanistan has been met with scorn in Pakistan, a signal that the country has little intention of changing its ways, even perhaps at the price of the crumpled alliance.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 11 FLORIDA STATE AT NO. 21 CLEMSON

title: Big Audience for Latest Debate
description: More than six million people watched the Republican presidential primary debate on Fox News on Thursday night, the biggest audience for any of the six debates this year.

title: Yahoo Confirms It Has Heard From Potential Buyers
description: Tony Avelar/Bloomberg NewsYahoos headquarters in Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: Podcast: On the Fed, Christine Lagarde and China
description: The Federal Reserve started Operation Twist, but the stock market was unimpressed.

title: Dont Ask
description: We really wanted to move things to a higher plane. But they keep having these debates.

title: Journalist Is Detained in China for Article on Sex Slaves
description: BEIJING  For a nation not yet inured to lurid and senseless crime, a report that a former civil servant in central China kept six women enslaved in an underground bunker  and that he killed two of them  was shocking enough.

title: Horse Therapy and Vitamin Smoothie
description: Mike Repole built his fortune in the food and beverage industry  he was a founder of Vitaminwater and is the chairman and primary shareholder of Pirate Brands snacks and Energy Kitchen fast-food restaurants. Seven years ago, he found a sure way to spend that fortune, buying a thoroughbred racehorse, but it was not his style to stop at one. Repole Stable has 78 horses based at Belmont, N.Y., two of them stars: Uncle Mo, whose Triple Crown season was derailed by a liver ailment; and Stay Thirsty, who ran second in the Belmont Stakes and won the Travers at Saratoga in August. Both are entered in races on Saturday  Uncle Mo in the Kelso Stakes and Stay Thirsty in the Jockey Club Gold Cup  to prepare for the Breeders Cup at Churchill Downs in November. Mr. Repole, 42, who grew up in Queens, lives on the North Shore of Long Island with his wife, Maria, 40. ROBIN FINN

title: A Tryout Program for the Unemployed
description: ATLANTA  Desperate to find a way to get the nations long-term unemployed back to work, President Obama and Republican leaders are supporting the expansion of a novel jobs program in Georgia to any other state that wants it.

title: Yelling Fire on a Crowded Runway
description: Milan

title: Obama Turns Some Powers of Education Back to States
description: With his declaration on Friday that he would waive the most contentious provisions of a federal education law, President Obama effectively rerouted the nations education history after a turbulent decade of overwhelming federal influence.

title: Tales of Two Presidents and a Crooner
description: IT is well known that President Grover Cleveland, once governor of New York, probably fathered a son while still a bachelor. In A Secret Life: The Lies and Scandals of President Grover Cleveland (Skyhorse Publishing), Charles Lachman, a television producer and author of a book about the Lincolns, delves deeply into the affair (immortalized in the rhyme Ma, ma wheres my pa? Gone to the White House, ha, ha, ha), its aftermath and Clevelands subsequent marriage to a woman 28 years younger than he was.

title: Tropical Storm Is Long Gone, but an Evacuation Still Holds
description: It is like something out of one of its namesakes novels. The classic dark and stormy night. A cliffside collapse leading to a dramatic post-midnight evacuation and now, almost a month later, poetic types wandering homeless. And the setting is appropriately literary: The Villa Charlotte Bronte, an elaborate, eccentric sand castle of co-op apartments perched majestically on a cliff 150 feet above the Hudson and Harlem Rivers in Spuyten Duyvil, the Bronx.

title: Investing in Helping Adults With Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: When Storms Rush In, a Waiting Game Begins
description: In the old days, nothing delayed or postponed a college football game. Athletes played through blizzards, 60-mile-per-hour winds and pounding rain.

title: At UBS, Its the Culture Thats Rogue
description: When Kweku Adoboli was arrested for an illicit trading scheme that cost his employer, the global bank UBS, $2.3 billion in losses, he was instantly labeled a rogue trader, suggesting he was an unprincipled scoundrel acting alone.

title: Accused of Fighting for Qaddafi, a Libyan Towns Residents Face Reprisals
description: SURT, Libya  On the edge of this city where Libyas war goes on, several men from the town of Tawerga sat on the patio of a mosque, having fled their homes and traded one war zone for another. Rockets fell nearby, but that was just one of their problems. Men with guns, their former neighbors from the city of Misurata, stood above them, accusing them of grave betrayals.

title: Stance on Immigration May Hurt Perry Early On
description: With a single phrase implying his opponents are heartless, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas plumbed a profound divide between his views on illegal immigration and those of many grass-roots conservatives, who up to now have been the core of his support for the Republican nomination.

title: A Big 12 Rivalry Game That Could Be No More
description: The passion in his voice is unmistakable when Oklahoma State Coach Mike Gundy speaks about the dysfunctional mess the Big 12 has become. Gundys emotion reflects the belief among his fellow coaches that the Big 12, with three conference teams ranked among the top eight in the nation, should be celebrating instead of negotiating its future.

title: Yahoo Review Will Take Months
description: Yahoos co-founders and its chairman have acknowledged that it would take months, not weeks to complete a strategic review of companys business, implying that any decision about reviving or selling the Web portal could take some time.

title: State Says It Analyzed Test Erasures for Cheating; 62 Schools Proved Suspect
description: Cheating scandals have been rolling up the East Coast like a hurricane this year, from Atlanta to Washington, Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

title: On a Mission to Help Chile Until the Very End
description: SO PAULO, Brazil

title: Students Battle a Dallas Cowboys Unit Over College Apparel
description: The Dallas Cowboys have a new merchandising arm that recently jumped into the business of producing college-logo apparel for leading universities, but the Cowboys subsidiary has already encountered a stubborn opponent  student groups that contend it is using overseas sweatshops.

title: How Do You Say Economic Security?
description: IN the face of nothing but bad economic news, Americans often take heart in remembering that we have been here before  during the Great Depression, when conditions were far worse than they are today  and we survived.

title: Orlando Brown, Who Sued N.F.L. Over Errant Flag, Dies at 40
description: Orlando Brown, a bruising offensive tackle for the Cleveland Browns and the Baltimore Ravens who was temporarily blinded in one eye by a referees errant penalty flag, leading him to file a $200 million lawsuit against the National Football League, was found dead Friday in his Baltimore apartment. He was 40.

title: U.S. Quietly Supplies Israel With Bunker-Busting Bombs
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has quietly supplied Israel with bombs capable of destroying buried targets, like terrorists arms caches or perhaps sites in Iran suspected of being part of that nations nuclear weapons program, American officials said Friday.

title: In Need of Win, the Red Sox Get Only Questions
description: Under the gray sky and soggy conditions that washed out Friday nights game against the Yankees, Boston Red Sox General Manager Theo Epstein sat in the visitors dugout and refused to accept that his teams fortunes were just as gloomy.

title: Perrys Bad Night
description: Gloom pervades the land. Some people believe its the economy. Others blame the weather. I think its because the country is gradually coming to grips with the fact that Mitt Romney is going to be the Republican nominee for president.

title: Gunning for Wall Street, With Faulty Aim
description: By late morning on Wednesday, Occupy Wall Street, a noble but fractured and airy movement of rightly frustrated young people, had a default ambassador in a half-naked woman who called herself Zuni Tikka. A blonde with a marked likeness to Joni Mitchell and a seemingly even stronger wish to burrow through the space-time continuum and hunker down in 1968, Ms. Tikka had taken off all but her cotton underwear and was dancing on the north side of Zuccotti Park, facing Liberty Street, just west of Broadway. Tourists stopped to take pictures; cops smiled, and the insidiously favorable tax treatment of private equity and hedge-fund managers was looking as though it would endure.

title: After Defecting to Turkey, a Top Syrian Army Officer Mysteriously Reappears
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Some say he went shopping and never returned. Others say he was a bargaining chip in a clandestine prisoner swap between Syria and Turkey. Still others insist that he was betrayed.

title: M.L.B. Seeks Approval of Judge to Sell Dodgers
description: Major League Baseball objected Friday to a plan proposed by the Los Angeles Dodgers to auction their media rights and asked a bankruptcy court judge to authorize the sale of the team owned by Frank McCourt.

title: Allies of French President Are Questioned in Graft Inquiry
description: PARIS  Three allies of President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Friday found themselves the focus of an expanding investigation into a 17-year-old case involving suspected corruption in the sale of submarines to Pakistan.

title: In Time of Scrimping, Fun Stuff Is Still Selling
description: With a flat job market and an economy that will not improve, Americans are once again buckling down and cutting back.

title: The Phony Solyndra Scandal
description: If Brian Harrison and W. G. Stover, the two Solyndra executives who took the Fifth Amendment at a Congressional hearing on Friday, ever spend a day in jail, Ill stand on my head in Times Square.

title: Lean Toward the Sunny Side, but Dont Overdo It
description: IHAVE trouble with optimism. I would like to be a more optimistic person, and sometimes I can be. But theres a long tradition of pessimism in my family; our attitude is that looking on the bright side, or expecting the best, is nave at best and folly at worst.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,765 American service members who have died since the start of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Money on Mind, Points Leaders Stumble
description: ATLANTA  It would be the elephant in the room, if East Lake Golf Club had walls and a roof.

title: After Report on Speed, a Rush of Scrutiny
description: Once upon a time, the only thing that traveled faster than the speed of light was gossip.

title: An Air of Sophistication, and Aiming for More
description: THE WOODS AT HOLLOW BROOK, which opened to the public several months ago, has both the advantages and disadvantages of being a restaurant in a private golf club.

title: Giving New Life to Brick Ovens Where Hippies Once Roamed
description: The list of things tinctured by the earth in this tiny central Colorado town might well start with Kyle McKelligotts face, and his T-shirt  both streaked on a recent afternoon with a working masons signature stone dust and mortar.

title: Lieutenant Ingrahams Short Commish
description: The monotony of Army life often left Aaron Ingraham lonely and bored. His thoughts typically turned inward, where he fixated on two topics: money and position.

title: No Flash, Just Smash From Eagles Fullback
description: PHILADELPHIA  In the Philadelphia Eagles locker room, a succession of stalls along one wall includes spaces for the high-profile stars DeSean Jackson, Jeremy Maclin and Steve Smith. Owen Schmitt takes his place in the middle.

title: Transatlantic and Validus Sign a Confidentiality Agreement
description: Transatlantic Holdings and Validus Holdings  said on Friday that they had signed a confidentiality agreement, setting up negotiations that could lead to a merger of the two reinsurance companies.

title: Borough President Seeks Limits on Stop-and-Frisk
description: The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, arguing that Police Department practices are creating a wall of distrust between officers and minorities, plans to call this weekend for a major re-examination of the departments stop-and-frisk policy.

title: Trailing G.O.P. Rivals Hope for an Opening
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  As they toil in the shadow of the front-runners, the other Republican presidential candidates are offering starkly different visions of how the party might win the White House without Mitt Romney or Rick Perry.

title: The Latest Ugly Truth About Pakistan
description: Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is a truth teller. He led the way among senior uniformed officers in urging repeal of the unconscionable dont ask, dont tell policy on gays in the military and pressed to shift more troops from Iraq to Afghanistan.

title: Mets Rained Out at Citi Field, Which in Their Case May Be a Good Thing
description: The Mets presence Friday at Citi Field, where they will play the final six games of their season, served as a reminder of how different their fortunes have been this season at home and on the road.

title: Cuban Minister Leaves a Door Open to Americans Release
description: A week after an effort to gain the release of an American jailed in Cuba ended in recriminations, the Cuban foreign minister said Friday that the door remained open to free him on humanitarian grounds, but only with a reciprocal effort from the United States.

title: Corrections: September 24
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: A Vintner Gets Personal
description: Like chefs hungry to start their own restaurants, many winemakers thirst to have personal labels. Adam Suprenant, who is working on his 14th Long Island vintage this year, has been one of them.

title: Finding a Place at the Greek Table
description: FALLING between Long Islands casual gyro spots and the high-priced Greek palaces serving fish priced by the pound, Neraki Greek Mediterranean Grill filled a niche when it opened in May in Huntington.

title: A Career Criminals Prints Link Two Lives Upended Decades Apart
description: In 1983, a police officer from Bushwick with scars from six gunshot wounds from his right shoulder to his left hip was lucky to be alive, and he darn well knew it, so he put in his papers after 22 years on the job. In the next neighborhood over, Greenpoint, an immigrant jeweler arrived that year, eager to work. They were both Polish, both Brooklyn family men, but at the time, their similarities ended there.

title: State of the Republican Field
description: At a few points in their careers as governors, Rick Perry and Mitt Romney used the powers of state government to help their citizens. Mr. Romney helped create a health insurance system to cover his states uninsured population; Mr. Perry provided in-state college tuition for some illegal immigrants. At every presidential debate, however, each attacks the other for these accomplishments, unaware of how ridiculous they sound.

title: Do Admissions Interviews Matter?
description: Interviewing with a college is a signal of an applicants interest in actually attending, said Karen Richardson, associate director of admissions at Tufts University, on Friday.

title: Another Ridiculous Standoff
description: Congress has lapsed into its now familiar crash-and-burn mode as House Republicans and Senate Democrats continue to fumble what should be the simple task of passing a temporary spending measure needed to prevent the government from shutting down after next Friday.

title: Saturday: Bum Rap
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  So, for years and years, the deal was that the early to midweek New York Times crossword puzzles had themes, the Friday and Saturday ones did not, and then we got our theme back on Sunday. Lately, however, I feel like Ive been seeing an increasing number of entries that have enough in common that one could consider them a minitheme of sorts. This does not bother me; it almost seems like value added to an already challenging puzzle. Its just interesting to note how puzzle styles evolve over the years.

title: Grandmotherly Bangladesh Leader Unfazed by Problems at Home
description: While Bangladeshs prime minister has been attending the United Nations this week, stock market investors back home rioted over steep losses, the police arrested hundreds of Islamist protesters and the main political opposition party threatened a general strike for Saturday, when it is her turn to speak at the annual General Assembly.

title: Lottery Numbers
Yankees Dodging Weather and Juggling Lineup in Push for Home Field
description: The Yankees game Friday night against the Boston Red Sox was postponed because of rain, resulting in a day-night doubleheader Sunday at Yankee Stadium that will be their fifth this season, their third in the last month and their second in five days.

title: Time for Bratwurst, Beer and Lederhosen
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: For Bloomberg, Waste Mars Another Digital Project
description: Soon after becoming mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg announced a plan to modernize the computer system that handles personnel information for New York Citys vast work force. The $66 million project was to be one of the signature technological innovations of his tenure.

title: British Lawyer Wants U.S. Hearing on Phone Hacking
description: LONDON  A lawyer representing some of Britains phone hacking victims said on Friday that he was planning legal action in the United States against the News Corporation, the parent company of Rupert Murdochs global media empire.

title: Flushing Meadows Welcomes the Aztecs
description: If you happen to be in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens on Saturday morning, head to the shores of Meadow Lake and find the little wooden boat that looks like it was painted by parrots. If its yellow, green, red, orange and blue, thats the one: a trajinera, a replica of a traditional Mexican flat-bottomed barge.

title: Police Memo on Marijuana Warns Against Some Arrests
description: Amid criticism about the way New York City police officers enforce marijuana laws, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly issued a memo to commanders this week reiterating that officers are not to arrest people who have small amounts of marijuana in their possession unless it is in public view.

title: Gilding the Lobster to Celebrate a Watch
description: We had to squint. The light bouncing off the more than 30 carats of tooth-size diamonds on our wrist seared our retinas. Then we had to sit down. The wristwatch we tried on at the opening party for the Swiss watch company Vacheron Constantins first American shop, on Madison Avenue, on Tuesday night cost $905,000.

title: Distinctive Mission for Muslims Conference: Remembering the Holocaust
description: One afternoon this week, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran addressed the United Nations General Assembly, once again casting doubt that the Holocaust had occurred. Almost exactly 24 hours earlier, an otherwise obscure college student in Morocco named Elmehdi Boudra was convening a conference devoted not to denying the Holocaust but to remembering it.

title: Cuomo Rejects Bill Legalizing Fireworks Sales
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vetoed on Friday legislation that would have legalized sparklers and other similar types of small fireworks across the state, except in New York City, citing safety concerns.

title: California: Muslim Students Guilty
description: A jury in Orange County found a group of 10 Muslim students guilty of two misdemeanors for conspiring to interrupt a speech by the Israeli ambassador to the United States at the University of California, Irvine. Prosecutors argued that the ambassador, Michael Oren, had been silenced after several students interrupted with coordinated shouts of protest. The defense lawyers for the group of Muslim students said that they had simply engaged in a typical form of protest and were being unfairly singled out by the district attorney. The judge ruled that the students would have to serve 56 hours of community service and up to three years of probation.

title: Big 12 Exploring Options
description: Chuck Neinas, the Big 12s interim commissioner, said there was some resistance among Missouris Board of Curators about remaining in the conference. Youve got to be concerned about it, he said, adding, I do believe in the end it will be resolved and that those issues are going to be addressed.

title: Labor Department Postpones Guest Workers Wage Increase
description: The Labor Department late Thursday announced a 60-day delay in wage increases for foreign guest workers under the federal H-2B program. Employers in the program have argued that the steep and sudden increases, scheduled to take effect Sept. 30, could put many of them out of business, costing American jobs. Louisiana employers sued the department, and Senators Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana and Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland, both Democrats, said they would try to have the wage increases canceled.

title: 35 Cookies, 7 Biscotti and ...
description: For several years, Beldotti Bakery has been one of the most popular stands at New Canaans Saturday Farmers Market. So its nondescript home in the Newfield Shopping Plaza in Stamford is a bit surprising. Even with three small tessera-topped tables out front, Beldotti, tucked next to a vacant storefront at the far left end of the strip, is easy to overlook. Until you get inside, that is, where the talents of its bakers are immediately evident.

title: Spains Big Flavors, in Small Portions
description: SMALL plates are not the only offerings at Bistro Mediterranean and Tapas Bar, but the kitchen turns out such a delicious and diverse collection that they are impossible to resist.

title: Rhode Island: New Fiscal Plan for Bankrupt Central Falls
description: The state-appointed receiver in Central Falls has submitted a plan to return the bankrupt city to solvency over the next five years, in part by sharply reducing benefits for public employees and retirees. The plan needs approval from a bankruptcy judge, and could change, depending on the outcome of negotiations with the citys labor unions. In addition to cutting pension and health benefits, it seeks to raise property taxes and restructure certain city departments. The city has already reduced its work force by 32 percent since May 2010. The receiver, Robert G. Flanders, said the plan would ensure balanced budgets starting in 2013.

title: Congress Questions Union on H.G.H. Test Timetable
description: With negotiations to begin a program to test N.F.L. players for human growth hormone at a standstill, 14 members of Congress, led by the former N.F.L. quarterback Heath Shuler, have sent a letter to Commissioner Roger Goodell and the union chief DeMaurice Smith asking for an explanation of their positions on the test and an expected start date for the testing.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: An Activist and a Canal

title: Tribute in White for Cricket Patriarch
description: THE crisp white of the cricket uniform is a familiar sight on Sundays in Richmond Hill, Queens, but on Monday it was mixed with black. Traffic clogged the roads around the stately St. Pauls Lutheran Church as hundreds of people streamed in for the funeral of the cricket umpire everyone knew as Uncle Jerry.

title: It Takes a Village
description: Around the corner came a little golden ball of sunshine named Madison, dressed head to toe in pink, hair arranged in Afro puffs, one wrist covered in turquoise beaded bracelets, arms opened wide. She wrapped those arms around a teachers legs, hugged them close and looked up with the kind of smile that sets the world right.

title: Midwest Farmers Are on Alert Against Pig Thieves
description: LAFAYETTE, Minn.  Here in pig country, the pigs are vanishing.

title: Reyes Playing What Could Be Final Games as a Met
description: The Mets six-game homestand to close their season may represent Jose Reyess final games in the teams uniform. And Reyes, who will be a free agent after this season, said it was inevitable for such thoughts to cross his mind.

title: Its a Giant Person! And Its a Tree? Its Art
description: Katonah, N.Y.

title: Bloggingheads: Are Green Jobs a Scam?
description: Katherine Mangu-Ward, left, of Reason and Erica Grieder of The Economist debate the economics of "green jobs."

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Jets Defense Wounded With Loss of Revis
description: A capsule look at the Jets 23-20 win in overtime against the Dolphins on Sunday.

title: Much Ado, With Summer Suits and Sundresses
description: Imagine a pretty patio outside an Italian villa on a summer day in the 1920s (or at least in some calm, more gracious time between the world wars). An aria is playing on the gramophone. A tray full of wine glasses is on the dining table. The men are in light summer suits; the women in sundresses or sportswear. In this bucolic setting, two couples fall in love, although it takes some work to get one of the couples to admit it.

title: In Picasso Etchings, a Focused Look at an Artist in Flux
description: Pablo Picasso needs no introduction, but you do have to orient yourself whenever you touch down on a body of his work. After all, he lived through multiple wars, artistic revolutions and domestic regimes. He worked in several mediums, helped invent one (collage) and marveled over another (cinema). However, the beauty of Picassos Vollard Suite: The Sculptors Studio, on view at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, is that it doesnt require an extensive Picasso review to understand. Instead, it focuses on a small body of work  a group of etchings made from 1933 to 1934  that encapsulate many of the artists concerns during that period.

title: Invitation to an Exhibition: Let the Mentoring Begin
description: Juried exhibitions, in which the works have been selected from a pool of submissions, used to be more common, although artists have long expressed conflicted feelings about them. They are one of the best ways for little-known artists to get their work shown in major museums or galleries, yet charges of favoritism and nepotism have dogged juried exhibitions for centuries.

title: Oscar Handlin, Historian Who Chronicled U.S. Immigration, Dies at 95
description: Oscar Handlin, a prolific, Pulitzer Prize-winning historian whose best-known book altered public perceptions about the role of immigration in the arc of American history, died on Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 95.

title: A Minister With an Eye for Images
description: THE title of the current exhibition at the Southold Historical Society, The Versatile Reverend, aptly describes its subject, a man who was both a clergyman and a professional photographer. He was a very busy minister, said Geoffrey K. Fleming, the director of the Southold Historical Society, discussing the Rev. Loren A. Rowley (1858-1918), a Baptist minister and sometime photographer whose work is on display at the Society through Oct. 9.

title: Emilio Pucci: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Milan

title: Jil Sander: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Milan

title: Bottega Veneta: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Milan

title: A God With Baton vs. the Mets Mortal Needs
description: Some in the business call it Peters Dilemma.

title: Fleeing Home, With the Promise of Safety Uncertain
description: As Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces left Tawerga, virtually all estimated 30,000 residents fled, fearing reprisal from neighbors in Misurata.

title: Pope Visits Venerated Lutheran Monastery
description: BERLIN  Pope Benedict XVI made a historic visit on Friday to the monastery where Martin Luther studied before he initiated the Reformation that led to a split from the Catholic Church nearly 500 years ago.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: A look at some of the long-form journalism we have been reading this week:

title: Being Comfortable in Your Own Skin (Tone)
description: I am Indian  but after more than 15 years of living abroad, some aspects of Indian life feel fresh, if not new or altogether welcome.

title: Gunmen Storm Police Training School in Pakistan
description: Elite police forces recaptured a police training school after four gunmen took it over in an eight-hour siege near Lahore, Pakistan.

title: Satellite Ends Fall, Likely in the Pacific
description: A dead NASA satellite, intently tracked by people around the world over the last couple of days, finally fell back to Earth  and it may turn out that no one will ever know when and where it fell.

title: New York on the Sound Stage
description: New York is a changeling, a different city to everyone who passes through. The premiere of the fall TV season will reflect that: Just last month, a record 23 prime-time shows filmed here, thanks in part to recent tax breaks.

title: Congress Pushing N.F.L. Over H.G.H. Testing
description: With negotiations to begin a program to test N.F.L. players for human growth hormone at a standstill, 14 members of Congress, led by the former N.F.L. quarterback Heath Shuler, sent a letter to Commissioner Roger Goodell and the union chief DeMaurice Smith asking for an explanation of their positions on the test and an expected start date for the testing.

title: Violence Surges in Yemen Despite Call for Cease-Fire
description: SANA, Yemen  A day after President Ali Abdullah Saleh returned to this battered country calling for a cease-fire, his forces escalated attacks on the opposition on Saturday, leaving more than 40 people dead across the capital.

title: The Weekend Word: Sequel
description: Todays Times

title: The Case for Buying Low on Perry
description: The political betting market Intrade, as of this writing, gives Mitt Romney a 44 percent chance of winning the Republican nomination. I have been pretty bullish on Mitt Romneys chances of securing the nomination for several months now, and I would probably be a buyer at that price.

title: Rogue Trading Leads UBS Chief to Resign
description: LONDON  The Swiss banking giant UBS said on Saturday that its chief executive, Oswald J. Grbel, had resigned over a rogue trading scandal that shook the European banking sector and raised new questions about the adequacy of financial regulation.

title: Putin Once More Moves to Assume Top Job in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, who transformed post-Soviet Russia by imposing Kremlin control over most aspects of public life, moved on Saturday to return to the presidency and could remain until 2024, giving him a rule comparable in length with that of Brezhnev or Stalin.

title: Arrest in Air Gun Shooting Near Popes Mass in Germany
description: BERLIN  The German police said Saturday that they had arrested a man suspected of shooting a security guard with an air gun in the eastern city of Erfurt shortly before Pope Benedict XVI was about to celebrate Mass.

title: Bookshelf
description: The Italian auteur Paolo Sorrentinos first novel,  Everybodys Right (Europa Editions, $15), is about an aging musician, a nightclub crooner who loses his mind in Brazil after his starlight begins to dim. It has parallels with his latest film This Must Be the Place, a similarly strange tale in which Sean Penn plays a catatonic, lipsticked rock star in the Robert Smith mold.

title: Radioactivity in Japan Rice Raises Worries
description: TOKYO  Government officials on Saturday ordered more tests after detecting elevated levels of radiation in rice crops near the crippled nuclear power plant at Fukushima.

title: Solving the Financial Crisis
description: Never mind all the bleak stuff Ive been writing lately. A solution is at hand! All we need to do is use some of those faster-than-light neutrinos to send a message to the past, warning them not to deregulate (and not to let Greece join the euro).

title: Europe Seeks to Ratchet Up Effort on Debt
description: WASHINGTON  Under increasing pressure from global investors and world leaders, European government officials indicated Saturday that they were working to intensify their response to the continents growing debt problems. It was an acknowledgment, after weeks of public stonewalling, that a plan announced in July had failed to calm financial markets.

title: Bully for the Baltics?
description: Ive noted that Tyler Cowen and others seem, mysteriously, to believe that any uptick in Irish GDP somehow refutes Keynesian analysis; Ive been seeing a lot of similar stuff about the Baltic nations, whose experience is supposed to prove that austerity works.

title: The Unsinkable Donatella Versace
description: A nice aqua glow bathed the stone walls of the Versace headquarters on Via Gesu, formerly the palazzo home of Gianni Versace. The runway was a white glassy streak and the first models  Lindsey, Nyasha, Abbey Lee  came out with bouncy curls and pure white outfits tipped in pale sea prints.

title: Photos of the Moment | Versace
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#335", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Mme. Lagarde Goes to Washington
description: MARSEILLE, France

title: Old-School Cornerbacks Have Taught a New Generation
description: One day during his rookie season with San Diego in 2006, Antonio Cromartie sat mesmerized in front of a television. His position coach, Kevin Ross, had summoned him to watch two cornerbacks who set the standard for excellence. Finding videotape was easy: they played for the same team, at the same time.

title: After Cancer, an Ex-Prodigy Was Undrafted but Unbowed
description: WAYNE, Pa.  Before Mark Herzlich became the linebacker who overcame cancer, he was another football prodigy with a familiar dream.

title: Actually, Citi Field Is Not That Bad for the Mets
description: It appears that three seasons of pinning the Mets offensive problems on the ballpark have finally led to action. General Manager Sandy Alderson said last week that the team would decide next month about adjusting the dimensions of the widely criticized Citi Field, and If we do something, it wont be subtle.

title: Vettel Takes Pole, Moves Closer to Title
description: SINGAPORE  It is a good thing that the images on local television of the Formula One track and cars and the Singapore skyline at night were beautiful. Because the qualifying session of the Singapore Grand Prix was not.

title: Vettel Takes Pole, Moves Closer to Title
description: SINGAPORE  It is a good thing that the images on local television of the Formula One track and cars and the Singapore skyline at night were beautiful. Because the qualifying session of the Singapore Grand Prix was not.

title: Variety:  A Calculating Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Setting aside how much I hate calculus and never understood a thing they tried to teach me in that class (I think they passed me mostly because they just felt sorry for me), I really enjoyed this Acrostic. Its always intriguing to hear personal anecdotes about people who lived so long ago, and its confirmation that while times may change, people stay relatively the same.

title: Live Analysis: College Football Week Four
description: Paul Myerberg will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can alsofollow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: New Zealand and England Roll to Wins in World Cup
description: Host New Zealand beat France, 37-17, on Saturday in the Rugby World Cup to take control of its group, while England moved clear in its group by routing Romania, 67-3.

title: N.F.L. Sees Signs That Players Think Before They Hit
description: Curtis Lofton had dropped into coverage near Atlantas goal line last Sunday night, knowing that Philadelphia tight end Brent Celek, slicing into the middle of the Falcons defense, would be the hot read for Michael Vick.

title: Pinto Beans and Rice
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Roasted Chicken and Potatoes
description: Adapted from How to Cook Everything, by Mark Bittman (John Wiley & Sons, 2008)

title: Road Food, Bad Food
description: The photographer Daniel Borris found that American road food is one long highway of plastic sameness  not only is nothing healthy, but nothing is different.

title: Sport Grows, and Grows More Perilous
description: MONTREAL  When the Belgian cyclist Wouter Weylandt was killed in a crash during the Giro dItalia in May, the commemoration began immediately. Each rider wore a black ribbon, and Weylandts initials and race number, 108, were painted across the remaining finish lines and appeared at the bottom of the official results with the slogan Always With Us.

title: With Woods in, 3 on Bubble for Presidents Cup
description: ATLANTA  After the second round of his final audition for the United States Presidents Cup team, Bill Haas met the squads assistant captain, who told him, You played really well.

title: Mr. Young, Mr. Ryan, Mr. Rivera Will Be Joining You
description: Mariano Rivera is unique. Quite simply, there has never been another pitcher like him.

description: Antonio MarrasDesigner: Antonio MarrasDate and Location: Friday, Viale Alemagna, 6Photos: slide show

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Whos That Girl?
description: As I was walking down Via Bigli just before noon, on my way to a Ferragamo preview appointment, a black sedan pulled up outside a gray stone building and a pair of bodyguards materialized on either side of the car. I saw a flash of blond hair through the side window, on a woman drinking from a water bottle, and thought for a moment that it was Donatella Versace. But as soon as the doors opened, I realized that it was Lindsay Lohan.

title: 30 Seconds With Joe Namath
description: Joe Namath led the Jets to an upset over the Baltimore Colts in Super Bowl III, the teams only championship. This years Topps football cards capture the greatest players and moments in Super Bowl history. Some cards contain codes that can be entered in the Super Bowl Legends Giveaway at toppslegends.com for a chance to win prizes, including a card signed by Namath, 68, who was in Manhattan recently to promote the contest.

title: Remembering Orlando Brown the Football Player
description: He may be remembered more for his lawsuit against the N.F.L., but few players got more out of what they were given than Orlando Brown. He achieved his potential. Brown was found dead on Friday in his apartment in Baltimore. He was 40 years old:

title: Libyan Fighters Renew Attack on Qaddafis Hometown
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Fighters trying to root out loyalists of the fugitive Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi renewed their attack on his hometown, Surt, on Saturday as his daughter Aisha became the latest family member to broadcast a recorded taunt of the provisional authorities struggling to replace his government.

title: Speculators Get a Break in New Rule
description: ALOAF of whole wheat. A gallon of gasoline. A pair of Levis. Americans are paying more for many basic items this year, making tough economic times even tougher.

title: As Red Sox Keep Sinking, True Fans Suffer With a Smile
description: The torrential rain that ultimately doomed Friday nights Yankees-Red Sox game was gloomy enough. But the atmosphere in the grand ballroom of the Yale Club, where the Blohards had assembled that afternoon for their semiannual luncheon, seemed grimmer still: greeting diners on a gigantic screen by the dais was a picture of a man in a Red Sox shirt, poised to jump off Bostons Tobin Bridge.

title: Jil Sander: Thinking Positive
description: Raf Simons brought a big blast of fashion to the Jil Sander runway today, a firmly modernist view expressed in almost every detail.

title: Early Access as a Fast Track to Learning
description: This interview with  David Barger, president and chief executive of JetBlue, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Scientists Want Publisher to Refreeze Greenland
description: The news release promoting the latest edition of Britains influential Times Comprehensive Atlas of the World hailed it as the Greatest Book on Earth.

title: Robots Extract Coolant From Old Refrigerators
description: RECYCLING refrigerators  especially those made more than 15 years ago  is a tricky job. The coolant in old appliances (now banned from newer versions) can cause serious trouble, warming the atmosphere and depleting the ozone layer.

title: Amid Baseballs Ups and Downs, a Definite Drop
description: The string of numbers looks as if it could have come from any major league baseball season in the past decade. Batting average: .266. On-base percentage: .336. Runs per game: 4.51.

title: The Side Effects? Well, There Is One...
description: Tara Parker-Pope is the editor of The New York Timess Well blog.

title: Cuomo Answers Questions From the Public, at His Kitchen Table
description: Over his years in politics, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has answered countless questions behind a lectern or surrounded by a gaggle of reporters. On Saturday morning, he fielded some in a very different venue: on a laptop in his kitchen.

title: In Vote for M.V.P., a Question of What One Is
description: The voting for the Most Valuable Player awards will be fascinating this year. Strong contenders come from also-ran teams. Playoff-bound contenders have teammates who could spoil their chances. A pitcher is a strong contender for the first time in 20 years. The tricky part for voters is defining the word value.

title: After Perrys Debate Showing, Eyes Turn Toward Christie
description: The reignited effort by Republican activists and donors to persuade Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey to run for president may say more about the jittery state of the partys major financial backers than it does about any possibility Mr. Christie will change his mind and announce a campaign.

title: Egypts Military Leader Testifies at Mubarak Trial
description: CAIRO  Egypts military ruler, Field Marshal Mohamed Hussein Tantawi, testified Saturday at the trial of his onetime patron and colleague, former President Hosni Mubarak, in a closed hearing that disappointed prosecutors who had hoped he would help determine whether the ousted Egyptian leader conspired to order the killing of unarmed demonstrators in his final days in power in February.

title: Getting By, U.S.A.
description: Warroad, Minn., is dominated by the factory of Marvin Windows & Doors. The company has refused to lay off workers since the economic crisis began. Now it is getting ready for a worsening economy.

title: Housing Slump Forces Cuts at a Company Town
description: WARROAD, Minn.

title: No Terror Link Seen in Mans Arrest at J.F.K.
description: A man who was arrested at John F. Kennedy International Airport with a stun gun and similar devices in his luggage for a flight to Saudi Arabia was released on Friday evening without bail, the authorities said.

title: Battle for Libya | September 24, 2011
description: Fighters for Libyas interim rulers entered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi s hometown of Surt on Saturday in a surprise assault that NATO said it backed to halt brutal acts by followers of the ousted regime.

title: Bahrain Vote Erupts in Violence
description: JERUSALEM  As the government of Bahrain held parliamentary elections Saturday, hundreds of protesters clashed with security forces while trying to make their way to Pearl Square, the site in the capital where the kingdoms pro-democracy movement got started early this year and was heavily suppressed.

title: Economic Reforms Likely to Continue Under Putin
description: MOSCOW  During his two terms as president, Vladimir V. Putin muscled a new kind of capitalism onto the Russian stage, blending government and private business, jailing tycoons and demanding control of the commanding heights of the economy, the petroleum companies that now pump more oil than Saudi Arabia.

title: In Arizona, Complaints That an Accent Can Hinder a Teachers Career
description: PHOENIX  When Guadalupe V. Aguayo puts her hand to her heart, faces the American flag in the corner of her classroom and leads her second-graders in the Pledge of Allegiance, she says some of the words  like allegiance, republic and indivisible  with a noticeable accent.

title: A Quick Note On Inflation
description: People like Greg Mankiw are relaxed about the inflation situation; Im worried that it will get too low. But there are always people popping up in various places arguing either that (a) the official numbers vastly understate true inflation or (b) recent inflation has been pretty high, and we should be worried about it going still higher.

title: Dickey Takes No-Hit Bid Into 7th Inning
description: The Mets have done the Philadelphia Phillies the favor of padding their statistics the past five seasons, including the present one, each ending with the Phillies winning the National League East.

title: Mexico Turns to Social Media for Information and Survival
description: MEXICO CITY  Before the police or news reporters had even arrived at the underpass outside Veracruz where gunmen held up traffic and dumped 35 bodies at rush hour last week, Twitter was already buzzing with fear and valuable information.

title: For Romney and Perry, a Day on the Island
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich.  Mitt Romney returned to the summer playground of his boyhood on Saturday morning, shortly before Gov. Rick Perry of Texas addressed hundreds of Republican activists and donors there.

title: An Improbable Unifier Presides Over Baylor
description: WACO  Based solely on his brief tenure, Ken Starr might reasonably conclude that one of the annual summer duties of a Baylor University president is scrambling to preserve the Big 12 Conference.

title: The Middleman Is Thriving on the Internet
description: San Francisco

title: Despite Housing Slump, Small-Town Company Keeps Its Workers
description: When times got tough at Marvin Windows and Doors, the company  which employs 2,000 in a 1,700-person town  adopted a no-layoff policy.

title: Vermont Town Shaken by a Co-op Killing
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  For many who frequent the Brattleboro Food Co-op, getting wine advice from Richard Gagnon was a pleasing ritual. His knowledge was encyclopedic, and after years as the wine manager, he was a fixture in the homey downtown store.

title: A Summer of Struggles Pays Dividends
description: Hou Yifan is the womens world champion, but she is also only 17 and continues to evolve as a player, which should scare her rivals.

title: Perry and Romney Set Clear Lines of Attack
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich.  Gov. Rick Perry and his aides in Texas have spent hours studying old footage and records of Mitt Romney, stretching back nearly two decades, building a list of issues on which they believe Mr. Romney has waffled or wavered, seeking to brand him as inauthentic.

title: Helping Somali Famine Victims
description: My Sunday column is about the famine in Somalia, and the overlay of violence and rape on top of it. Its hard to know the scale of the violence, but I finished my reporting convinced that this is an instance of mass rape.

title: Monitoring Rights in Chechen Region, a Month at a Time
description: GROZNY, Russia  They never go out alone, and when they are in their small apartment here in the capital of Chechnya, a flat screen on the wall displays a continuous feed from security cameras in the hall and stairway outside.

title: Cleared of Rape but Lacking Full Exoneration
description: RICHMOND, Va.  One Sunday morning in February 1984, Thomas Haynesworths mother sent him to the Trio supermarket to pick up some bread and sweet potatoes.

title: Staying Open to Opportunity
description: IGREW up outside Albany, N.Y. When I was about 14, I got to work for the Washington Redskins. My father, a family physician, cared for the mother of the coach, George Allen. For two summers, I spent two weeks at the teams training camp, handing out towels and water to legendary players like Joe Theismann. I even traveled with the team to a couple of preseason games, where Id try to catch kickoff balls from Mark Moseley during the pregame warm-up. It was a kids dream.

title: A Humanitarian Catastrophe
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof visits the worlds largest refugee camp, home to hundreds of thousands of Somalis who are fleeing famine, drought and war.

title: Light Hand on Officeholders in Reporting Free Trips
description: While Mayor Rahm Emanuel prepares to release his 2012 city budget next month, Alderman Daniel Solis (25th Ward) will be bicycling in the Netherlands. But Mr. Solis will not be on a European vacation; he will be peddling amid the canals of Amsterdam on a study trip paid for by a bicycling advocacy group.

title: Working Relationships Across Generations
description: Q. As an older worker, you sometimes find it frustrating to work with and manage people who are in their 20s. Is it you or is it them?

title: Public-Housing Tenants Report Troubles at Their New Home
description: On a cold morning last December, a former teachers aide and grandmother named Annie Ricks was the last tenant to leave the last high-rise building at the Cabrini-Green public-housing development. The focus of national news-media attention, she was the star of the end of an era.

title: Now You Dont See Extra Fees, Now You Do
description: IN this episode: more on fees.

title: Congressmans Remarks Stir the Blogosphere
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Telling Men the Truth about Sex and Prostate Cancer
description: Many surgeons and radiation centers tout promising statistics when they talk to men about the risk of sexual side effects from prostate cancer treatment. But as I write in the Sunday Review, new research published last week finally offers men some straight talk about what to expect from treatment for prostate cancer.

title: Is Junk Food Really Cheaper?
description: THE fact that junk food is cheaper than real food has become a reflexive part of how we explain why so many Americans are overweight, particularly those with lower incomes. I frequently read confident statements like, when a bag of chips is cheaper than a head of broccoli ... or its more affordable to feed a family of four at McDonalds than to cook a healthy meal for them at home.

title: The Gap Year: Breaking up the Cradle to College to Cubicle to Cemetery Cycle
description: 9:12 a.m. | Updated An earlier version of this post provided an outdated reference to Robert S. Clagetts position at Middlebury College. He is a former dean of admissions at the college.

title: Crime, Sex, Politics and Regular Folks
description: SCENE: The original Playboy Club, on Walton near Michigan Avenue, circa 1961, painstakingly resurrected at the sprawling Cinespace soundstage in Douglas Park 50 years later.

title: Russians See Shift in Power as Business as Usual
description: MOSCOW  After months of speculation and what seemed to be orchestrated suspense, the news on Saturday that Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin planned a return to the presidency next year seemed to cause little more than ripples of interest on the streets of Moscow.

title: Justin N. Feldman, 92, Dies; Opposed Tammany Hall
description: Justin N. Feldman, a Manhattan lawyer who helped manage Robert F. Kennedys 1964 New York Senate campaign and whose deep involvement in city politics extended from the 1940s through the 1980s, when he helped broker a $5.6 billion rebuilding program for the citys public transportation system, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Clarion Alley
description: Fences, garage doors, buildings and even the pavement in Clarion Alley are splashed with brightly colored, constantly changing paintings. This unofficial, longstanding street-art scene on a vibrant artery between Valencia and Mission Streets has been guided since 1993 by volunteer members of the Clarion Alley Mural Project, or CAMP. LOUISE RAFKIN

title: As California State Tuition Rises, Financial Aid Offices Struggle to Adjust
description: On what should have been a carefree day of reconnecting with friends and settling into new classes recently, more than two dozen students at the University of California, Berkeley, sat in uneasy silence outside the financial aid office.

title: Bay Trail Is Inching on, Neither Easily Nor Cheaply
description: One of the Bay Areas newest waterfront walkways is set to open this fall in Oakland. It is one-tenth of a mile long, and it cost $1.6 million to build.

title: Sunday: Entwisted
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome to the Sunday puzzle, where the entries not only sparkle, they dance. Well, when I say dance, what I really mean is that some of the letters are doing the Twist. Paul Hunsberger is back with his third puzzle and today he takes the letter N, twists it 90 degrees, and creates a set of punny phrases that had me laughing out loud.

title: One Dark Night in My Neighborhood
description: On the day last month when the earthquake touched us so timidly, I came home late, near midnight, and parked my car close to the cluster of small, tidy housing projects near my apartment in Brooklyn.

title: A High-Rise Condo Project Signals a Change at City Hall
description: Last year, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors voted, 10 to 1, to quash a condominium project planned for 555 Washington Street, in the shadow of the Transamerica Pyramid. The vote stunned the developers, who were backed by former Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. and Rose Pak, the Chinatown power broker.

title: If It Looks Like a Bear, and Moves Like a Bear ...
description: AFTER a week in which stocks sank more than 6 percent, the sell-off in equities that began five months ago is coming perilously close to bear market territory.

title: Google Doodle Honors Jim Henson and Friendly Monsters
description: Saturday marks what would have been the 75th birthday of Jim Henson, the puppet pioneer and beloved conductor of many a fuzzy childhood friend, from Big Bird to the Cookie Monster. In his honor, todays Google Doodle, which represents the company logo on the search engines home page, is an interactive puppet show, designed by Google and the Jim Henson Company.

title: A Plan on Jobs Deserves a Hearing
description: ABATTLE is brewing over President Obamas $447 billion jobs plan. Its a sound proposal, but you might not know that listening to some of the arguments against it. They may sound plausible, but they dont stand up to scrutiny. Here are four of them.

description: To the Editor:

description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: Dan Fogelman
description: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

title: Model-Morphosis | Joan Smalls at Blumarine
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Joan Smalls from IMG Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Charlotte Tilbury for M.A.C. and hair by Sam McKnight for Pantene. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: When the MOB Takes the Field, Stodginess Scatters
description: Jason Cohen writes a column for the Texas Report.

title: Not-So-Smart Cities
description: Greg Lindsay is a visiting scholar at the Rudin Center for Transportation Policy and Management at New York University and the co-author of “Aerotropolis: The Way We’ll Live Next.”

title: The Price of Political Gossip
description: HAS American political life become a carnival so invasive, indiscriminate and sometimes even crude that it repels some of the best potential officeholders and almost guarantees that the most important business of the country wont be properly done? I wonder sometimes. I wondered in particular last week.

title: Fed Up With the Author of Fed Up!?
description: IN a flash, Rick Perry has gone from Republican front-runner to cycling domestique, riding in front of the pack and taking all the wind  or in this case, hot air  to allow the team leader to pedal in the slipstream.

title: Now You See It, Soon You Wont
description: Jesse Kornbluth is the editor of HeadButler.com.

title: Whatever Happened to the American Left?
description: Michael Kazin is a professor of history at Georgetown, a co-editor of Dissent and the author of American Dreamers: How the Left Changed a Nation.

title: Obama and Bill Clinton Tee Off
description: Oh, to be a fly on the golf cart.

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: The European debt crisis flares again and brings down stock markets, Hewlett-Packard ousts a chief executive and hires a replacement, and a poker Web site is accused of being a fraud.

title: A Son Returns to the Agony of Somalia
description: K'Naan is a musician and poet.

title: Worried Greeks Fear Collapse of Middle Class Welfare State
description: ATHENS  Sitting in the modest living room of the home she shares with her parents, husband and two teenage children, Stella Firigou fretted about how the family would cope with the uncertainties of an economy crashing all around them. But she was adamant about one thing: she would not pay a new property tax that was the centerpiece of a new austerity package announced this month by the Greek government.

title: Connected, Darkly, to Jane Fonda
description: Patricia Bosworth is the author of Jane Fonda: The Private Life of a Public Woman.

title: Why Rent When You Can Nest?
description: Gregory Warner is a reporter at Marketplace, the public radio show about business and economics.

title: Tampering With the Electoral College
description: The Electoral College has stood in the way of full American democracy for more than two centuries, and usually any attempt to reduce its influence is welcome. But it would be better to leave the College alone than manipulate its workings to give one party an advantage over another, as Republicans in Pennsylvania are trying to do. The effort is both entirely legal and entirely wrong, and demonstrates why electoral reform is so urgently needed.

title: President Obamas Medicare Proposals
description: President Obamas plan to cut $248 billion from Medicare over the next decade as part of his deficit reduction plan has drawn heat from all sides.

title: Where Abortion Rights Are Disappearing
description: Thirty-eight years after Roe v. Wade recognized a womans right to make her own childbearing decisions and legalized abortion nationwide, a newly intensified drive by anti-abortion forces who refuse to accept the law of the land has seriously imperiled womens ability to exercise that right. Opponents of abortion rights know they cannot achieve their ultimate goal of an outright ban, at least in the near future. So they are concentrating on enacting laws and regulations narrowing the legal right and making abortion more difficult to obtain.

title: Help Wanted: Leadership
description: TO Barack Obama, John Boehner, Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell, Nancy Pelosi and Eric Cantor, I just have two words of advice: Herbert Hoover.

title: Justice After Troy Davis
description: ITS easy to see why the case of Troy Davis, the Georgia man executed last week for the 1989 killing of an off-duty police officer, became a cause clbre for death penalty opponents. Davis was identified as the shooter by witnesses who later claimed to have been coerced by investigators. He was prosecuted and convicted based on the same dubious eyewitness testimony, rather than forensic evidence. And his appeals process managed to be ponderously slow without delivering anything like certainty: it took the courts 20 years to say a final no to the second trial that Davis may well have deserved.

title: On Top of Famine, Unspeakable Violence
description: IMAGINE that youre a Somali suffering from the drought and famine in that country. One of your children has just starved to death, but theres no time to mourn. Depleted and traumatized, you set off on foot across the desert with your family, and after 15 exhausting days finally reach what you believe is the safe haven of Kenya.

title: The Solyndra Panic
description: In August, Solyndra, a California-based solar panel maker, announced it would file for bankruptcy. The collapse cost 1,100 workers their jobs and American taxpayers $535 million in loan guarantees that Solyndra had received under a Congressionally authorized program to encourage young companies to develop clean-energy technologies.

title: Herman Cain Wins Florida Straw Poll
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Herman Cain, the former chief executive of Godfathers Pizza, won the Florida straw poll today, defeating second-place Rick Perry after the Texas governor worked the crowd of activists with a breakfast speech Saturday morning.

title: Delay Kindergarten at Your Childs Peril
description: Sam Wang is an associate professor of molecular biology and neuroscience at Princeton. Sandra Aamodt is a former editor in chief of Nature Neuroscience. They are the authors of Welcome to Your Childs Brain: How the Mind Grows From Conception to College.

title: Tangled Relationships in Jerusalem
description: CONFLICT of interest, or the appearance of it, is poisonous in journalism. This is particularly so when it relates to reporting on Israel and the Palestinians, a subject that draws a steady stream of skepticism about New York Times coverage from readers and partisans on all sides.

title: Making It Big in Pictures
description: The Hollywood sign was not always the global symbol and tourist magnet that it is today. Here are some highlights in its long history:

title: Stalking the Biggest Star in Hollywood: Its Sign
description: HOLLYWOOD  Tom LaBonge, a jolly and energetic Los Angeles councilman, steered his city car along the perilously narrow roads curving through the Hollywood Hills, turned a corner and hit the brakes. A couple were standing obliviously in the road, cameras aimed at the Hollywood sign looming overhead in all its cinematic glory.

title: Small Donors Are Slow to Return to the Obama Fold
description: They were once among President Obamas most loyal supporters and a potent symbol of his political brand: voters of moderate means who dug deep for the candidate and his message of hope and change, sending him $10 or $25 or $50 every few weeks or months.

title: Brutal Haqqani Crime Clan Bedevils U.S. in Afghanistan
description: This article was written by   Mark Mazzetti,   Scott Shane and  Alissa J. Rubin.

title: A New Law on School Fitness Data Faces Obstacles
description: Texas children are fat  and getting fatter.
