description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Strawberry Hopes Reyes Stays Put
description: In 1990, Darryl Strawberry left New York to sign a more lucrative contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers. It was the end of an era for the Mets that featured a World Series title, 252 home runs and a long string of controversies.

title: Yankees Kick Red Sox When They Are Down
description: In a somber visitors clubhouse, Jon Lester, the primary culprit in the latest disaster from the Boston Red Sox, was asked to explain how a pitcher who was so good could pitch so poorly.

title: Maris Honored at Yankee Stadium
description: It was a scene Roger Maris himself would not have imagined back in 1961 when he deposited a home run over the short porch in right field to etch his name in history: his wife, Pat, and six children standing on the infield grass at Yankee Stadium, receiving a thunderous ovation from the crowd in recognition of his record-breaking feat.

title: 80 Arrested as Financial District Protest Moves North
description: The police made scores of arrests on Saturday as hundreds of people, many of whom had been encamped in the financial district as part of a lengthy protest, marched north to Union Square. As darkness fell, large numbers of officers were deployed on streets near the encampment in Zuccotti Park, at Broadway and Liberty Street, where hundreds more people had gathered.

title: In Bear Attack, Hunter Killed Hunter, Autopsy Shows
description: It turns out that the hunter in Idaho who the authorities thought was killed by a wounded grizzly bear was actually shot by his young hunting companion, who was trying to kill the bear, an autopsy has revealed.

title: No Room, and No Relief, for Arkansas at Alabama
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Alabama defensive end Quinton Dial shoved Arkansas quarterback Tyler Wilson to the ground after Wilson had thrown a pass, and an official tossed a yellow penalty flag at Dials feet. The personal foul happened on the sideline not far from Nick Saban, the Crimson Tide coach, but Saban did not raise a ruckus or scold Dial.

title: With 47 Completions, No. 7 Cowboys Prevail
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  Panic should have crept into Oklahoma States playbook, what with only a field goal to show in a first half so lacking in rhythm that the Cowboys looked incapable of completing the two-step, much less a comeback.

title: Baddeley and Mahan Share Lead in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  The views were largely unobstructed outside the gallery ropes Saturday at the Tour Championship, the FedEx Cup playoff finale that could not compete with another college football game day in the South. The sparse crowds did not seem to bother Aaron Baddeley, who is playing for a gallery of one.

title: Corrections: September 25
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Duda and Isringhausen May Not Return
description: Manager Terry Collins said Saturday that Lucas Duda and Jason Isringhausen might not return this season. Duda has been bothered by headaches, and Isringhausen has been out with a herniated disk in his back.

title: Mets Pascucci Perseveres
description: For Valentino Pascucci, who hit a game-tying, pinch-hit home run for the Mets against the Phillies in Game 1 of a doubleheader on Saturday, it has been a long journey since he was first drafted in 1996 by the Milwaukee Brewers. He did not sign with the Brewers, and was subsequently drafted by the Montreal Expos in 1999.

title: Lottery Numbers
East Lakes No. 18, a Sudden Stop to a Days Walk
description: ATLANTA  To the typical PGA Tour player, a formidable par-3 18th hole is as unappetizing as a hole-in-the-wall diner. The preference is higher-par holes, where one can take risks and be more likely to finish a round with a birdie or eagle while injecting drama by shuffling names on the leader board.

title: Romney Plays Up His Michigan Roots
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich.  Mitt Romney returned to his home state Saturday with plans to give Michigan a special treat come January of 2013.

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: CHRIS FORCIER The Furman player and member of a quarterbacking family had seven touchdown passes to break the programs single-game record in a 62-21 victory over visiting Presbyterian. Forcier was 12 of 16 for 226 yards, and also rushed for a 13-yard touchdown. The previous record was five, by Hugh Swilling against Virginia Military in 1991 and Jordan Sorrells against Wofford in 2009.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: The list of paramedics selected for this years Hajj pilgrimage includes two government employees who are ineligible for Hajj deputation, Greater Kashmir reports, saying that rules have been broken by the central and state government to accommodate these two candidates. The Ministry of External Affairs guidelines say all candidates have to be recommended by the directorate of health services of a concerned state. (Greater Kashmir)

title: At Designblok, High Design Comes to Prague
description: What used to be limited to fashion and interior decoration, now encompasses everything from cars to cuisine. High design is everywhere, and in Prague its celebrated annually at Designblok, running this year from Oct. 4 to 9. Over the course of the weeklong festival, manufacturers, retailers, studios and designers come together to show off their latest and greatest creations.

title: Lessons for Fire-Stricken Texas from Down Under
description: With dry hot winds putting a large area of east Texas under a red flag fire warning even as the cleanup continues in dozens of communities already swept by flames, I thought it worth getting some insights from John McAneney, the director of Risk Frontiers, a natural hazards research center at Macquarie University in Australia. title: Catastrophic Stability
description: I look a fair bit at bond market breakevens  the difference in interest rates between regular bonds and inflation-protected bonds of the same maturity, which give a measure of inflation expectations. Its not a perfect measure by any means, since there are issues of risk and liquidity, and anyway what bond investors expect isnt necessarily reasonable. But breakevens do give a quick read on the issue, and can be helpful in thinking about where we are.

title: The Lion King Remains a Box Office Leader

That animated film, re-released by Walt Disney Studios in 3-D, took in an estimated $22 million for a two-week total of $61.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics.

title: A Final Bullfight in Catalonia, but the Tradition Goes On Elsewhere
description: The last bullfight in Spains Catalan region was expected to draw 20,000 spectators to a bout, or corrida, on Sunday at Barcelonas Monumental bullring featuring the popular matador Jos Toms, my colleague Raphael Minder reports.

title: Amazon Has High Hopes for Its iPad Competitor
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One after another, like moths to a flame, technology companies have been seduced into entering the market for tablets. Apple made it look so irresistible, with 29 million eager and sometimes fanatical consumers snapping up an iPad in the devices first 15 months.

title: Colin Powell Book Is Coming in May
description: Colin Powell has written a book revealing the lessons that shaped his life and career, to be published by HarperCollins in May, the publisher said on Sunday.

title: Coaches on the Hot Seat
description: 7:22 p.m. | Updated Coach Mike Locksley was fired Sunday, New Mexico announced. The associate head coach George Barlow will serve as the interim coach for remainder of the season.

title: From a Can of Spray Paint, a Portrait of a Player
description: ATLANTA  The man with the black Sharpie in his hand was eyeing the golfers on the range Sunday but it was not an autograph he was seeking.

title: A Fierce Primordial Land Holds Mankinds Only Hope
description: Is Foxs Terra Nova, with Steven Spielbergs name at the top of its long list of executive producers, the best of a generally unremarkable bunch of new network shows this fall? Possibly, though to make that argument you need to work around the fact that its without doubt the squarest, most old-fashioned series to hit television since  well, since Mr. Spielbergs Falling Skies on TNT this year.

title: In Catalonia, a Last Day of Bullfighting
description: Barcelona bid farewell to bullfighting on Sunday with a corrida in La Monumental bullring featuring Jos Toms, Spains most popular matador.

title: Afghans Hold Man Tied to Top Negotiators Death
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan officials said Sunday that they had arrested a man connected to the Taliban militants who sent a suicide bomber to kill the leader of Afghanistans peace process.

title: Union-Owned Bank Finds Help in Ross and Burkle
description: The nations only union-owned bank is getting a lifeline from two financiers: Wilbur L. Ross Jr. and Ronald W. Burkle.

title: L.S.U. Claims Top Spot
description: Louisiana State climbed to No. 1 in The Associated Press college football poll for the first time since 2007, when it won a national championship. The Tigers held the top ranking for four weeks during the regular season that year.

title: Back From Iran, U.S. Hikers Share Tales of Strife
description: The two American hikers who were held in Iran on espionage charges say they kept their days strictly regimented, running laps, weight-lifting water bottles, discussing literature and quizzing each other, in an effort to stay physically and mentally fit while in captivity. They spent 781 days that way in the notorious Evin prison in Tehran.

title: Excerpt: 'Dancing with the Stars'
description: The professional dancers are becoming the stars of the talent competition.

title: Vick Breaks Hand During Loss
description: PHILADELPHIA  Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Michael Vick broke his right hand during a 29-16 loss to the Giants on Sunday afternoon.

title: Dream Game for Receiver; Dream Victory for Giants
description: PHILADELPHIA  In a locker room teeming with soaked players and bustling reporters, Victor Cruz stopped amid the chaos for a bit of polish.

title: Photos of the Moment | Sportmax
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#284", 592, 500, true, chameleonData);Danilo Scarpatis Milan fashion week photo diary.

title: A Memoirist Ever Ready to Inhabit Another Role
description: John Lithgow is probably best known for playing oddballs and weirdos: a psychotic physicist in Buckaroo Banzai, an extraterrestrial college professor on the long-running sitcom 3rd Rock From the Sun and most recently the creepy serial killer Arthur Mitchell in the Showtime series Dexter. With his big, almost hulking frame and long, quizzical-looking face, Mr. Lithgow on screen or onstage effortlessly manages to seem like a panic-stricken creature imprisoned in the wrong body.

title: After Long Hours, Red Sox Keep Slim Lead
description: The Yankees did not have much to play for Sunday  or did they? With a division title and home-field advantage through the American League playoffs tied down, Manager Joe Girardi rested four of his starters for each game of a doubleheader Sunday against the reeling Boston Red Sox.

title: For Meter Feeders, a Favor Grows Complicated
description: Its usually busy behind the deli counter at the Milano Market, on Broadway near 113th Street in Morningside Heights. So some of the workers who leave their cars at metered parking spaces out front have always relied on Steve Hann, a sidewalk book vendor, to replenish the meters throughout the day.

title: Death, Sewage ... and a Few Laughs
description: Dublin by Lamplight, part of the 1st Irish Theater Festival at 59E59 Theaters, tries to juxtapose the serious with the silly. Yet the silliness is so untamed it overwhelms the productions potential for a truly affecting experience.

title: Jazz Classics, Still of the Moment
description: Theres a rumor going around that Im 90, Jon Hendricks remarked from the stage of Frederick P. Rose Hall on Saturday evening, as he flashed a sly believe-it-or-not smile. In his imagination, he admitted, he was still only 11.

title: In China, a Slam Hard to Beat
description: We continue to look at the final round of the Zhejiang Huamen Cup, played this month in Beijing.

title: Hallucinatory to Folk-Rock in an Instant
description: In the rain at Central Park SummerStage on Friday night, Wilco started its set by implying that it wasnt going anywhere soon. No snappy opening ditty for this concert; instead, Wilco played the two extended songs that end and start The Whole Love, its new album.

title: The Pas de Deux Between Art and Dance
description: Picasso and Massine, Graham and Noguchi, Rauschenberg and Cunningham: visual art and dance have a long history of entanglement. Heres another pair to add to the list, Kimberly Bartosik and Jonathan Allen. Ms. Bartosiks i like penises: a little something in 24 acts was presented Thursday night at Danspace Project, in conjunction with the French Institute Alliance Franaises Crossing the Line festival.

title: The Keaton Film Was Silent; Now, Cue the Kazoos
description: At the peak of the silent-film era movie theaters provided nonstop work for instrumental musicians in America. In most houses just a single pianist would play, usually improvising, and often folding in songs or classical pieces. Some theaters had organs equipped with sound effects to evoke thunderstorms and galloping horses. Large auditoriums brought in whole instrumental ensembles, working from cue sheets provided by the studios with specific titles keyed to moments in the film.

title: Reviving a Pulsing Memory of New York, Bass Line and All
description: Embrace for a moment the idea that the most important band to emerge from early-2000s New York wasnt the Strokes but the Rapture. Sure, the Strokes went on to arenas, to overblown follow-up albums, to myth, all while the Rapture idled, then fizzled, then reconstituted, only to fizzle some more.

title: Plenty of Artistic Pressure for a Saxophone Student
description: Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to improvise freely on alto saxophone throughout the premiere of a concerto not only inspired by Ornette Coleman, one of the most natural melodists and distinctive improvisers in American music, but also actually intended for Mr. Coleman to perform. You should evoke the works dedicatee without merely mimicking his sound and gestures.

title: Monday: Party South of the Border
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Boy, summer sure went by quickly, didnt it? Im told that it is now fall  lower temperatures, sweater weather, falling leaves, football  although its been incredibly warm and humid here at Wordplay.

title: Quixote, Colbert and the Reality of Fiction
City Ballet at Koch Theater
description: New York City Ballet performed works by Balanchine and Wheeldon on Saturday.

title: Healthy Again, Phillies Return to Playoff Gear
description: Just before noon Sunday, Ryan Howard ambled toward Hunter Pence in the visitors clubhouse at Citi Field sporting a wide grin that displayed equal doses of boyish enthusiasm and relief.

title: French Left Takes Control of the Senate
description: PARIS  The French left laid claim to control of the Senate on Sunday, the first time the indirectly elected upper house will not be controlled by the right since the founding of the Fifth Republic in 1958.

title: An Oil Ad Vexes the Saudis
description: OTTAWA  Environmental concerns over Canadas oil sands have driven a debate over the process that has lasted for years. Now, some in Canada are trying to change the conversation.

title: Balanchines High Society, on Earth and in the Firmament
description: What good company New York City Ballet was on Saturday night. The audience, happy to do its part, applauded heartily through numerous curtain calls.

title: Dealing With an Identity Hijacked on the Online Highway
description: DESPITE his prominent position as a Republican candidate for president, Rick Santorum has lost control of his online identity. And for all the snickering online about it, his predicament stands as a chilling example of what it means to be at the mercy of the Google algorithm.

title: A Man Entrapped in a Host of Webs
description: Lost Memory of Skin is a major new work by Russell Banks destined to be a canonical novel of its time. That is not to say it is without problems. It engages the reader in one long wrestling match. It is sometimes marred by condescension. But it delivers another of Mr. Bankss wrenching, panoramic visions of American moral life, and this one very particular to the early 21st century. It tells of a plugged-in, tuned-out Internet culture lost in the misty zone between reality and imagery, no longer able to tell the difference. And it explores the terrible, dehumanizing consequences of choosing to live this way.

title: Performing Arts Group Names a New Leader
description: The Association of Performing Arts Presenters has announced the appointment of Mario Garcia Durham as its new president and chief executive. Based in Washington, the association fosters continued growth and development in the performing arts presenting field and its professionals with over 1,400 members worldwide. It also holds an annual conference in New York, the worlds largest annual performing arts industry gathering. Mr. Durham is the fifth executive director since the organization was founded in 1957. Since 2004, he has been the director of artist communities and presenting at the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Dayton Literary Prize
description: Chang-rae Lee and Wilbert Rideau have won the 2011 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for fiction and nonfiction, the organizers of the award said. Mr. Lee, above left, was chosen for The Surrendered, a novel that explores the relationship between an orphan of the Korean War and an ex-G.I., while Mr. Rideau, above right, won for In the Place of Justice, a prison memoir. The runners-up were Maaza Mengiste for Beneath the Lions Gaze and Isabel Wilkerson for The Warmth of Other Suns. The awards will be presented at a ceremony on Nov. 13 in Manhattan. The Dayton Literary Peace Prize was created in 2006 to honor writers whose work promotes peace, social justice and global understanding. Each winner will receive a $10,000 prize.

title: Alec Baldwin Sets Record Hosting SNL
description: The actor Alec Baldwin, below, set a record on Saturday as the most frequent host of Saturday Night Live, returning for a 16th time and, in doing so, breaking a tie with Steve Martin. But the start of the 37th season of SNL set no ratings record; the show posted a 5.0 overnight rating, according to Nielsen, down from a 5.3 rating for last seasons first episode, which Amy Poehler hosted. Still, the show outperformed several other of its recent season premieres, and NBC said that it ranked ahead of any prime-time shows on the broadcast networks on Saturday. Mr. Martin appeared to acknowledge Mr. Baldwins record, but he could return soon: he has a film called The Big Year to promote next month.

title: Lysistrata Jones Cast Faces Basketball Practice
description: The young cast of the coming Broadway musical Lysistrata Jones, a comic look at a college basketball team on a long losing streak, will take part in a five-day basketball camp being organized next month by Chris Mullin, a New York City basketball star in the 1980s and a retired N.B.A. star who was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame this year. In a telephone interview Mr. Mullin said that Paula Herold  a family friend who is a producer of Lysistrata Jones  reached out to him about helping improve the skills of the fictitious Athens University squad members, who show off basketball moves throughout the musical. I thought itd be fun to get involved and see what I could do to polish up the playing, make it look more authentic and sharpen the choreography for Broadway, said Mr. Mullin, who was born in Brooklyn. Only so much basketball polish can be achieved in five days, he said, so he plans to focus on fundamentals like dribbling, passing and body movement, as well as off-court swagger and attitude. The Lysistrata actors current skills range from good to minimal, people involved with the show said. The men in the cast, below left, will attend the camp for its entire run, while most of the women will attend the first two days. Several of the women play cheerleaders who also handle the ball here and there, a spokesman for the show said. With a book by the Tony Award nominee Douglas Carter Beane (Sister Act, The Little Dog Laughed) and music and lyrics by Lewis Flinn, Lysistrata Jones is scheduled to begin preview performances at the Walter Kerr Theater on Nov. 12 and open on Dec. 14.

title: As X Factor Ratings Are Solid, Sitcoms Show New Life
description: Mike Darnell, the longtime head of reality programs for the Fox Broadcasting network, conceded he pulled an all-nighter  or two  last week as he and his Fox colleagues sweated out the first two nights of ratings for their highly anticipated singing show, The X Factor.

title: Saudi Monarch Grants Women Right to Vote
description: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia on Sunday granted women the right to vote and run in future municipal elections, the biggest change in a decade for women in a puritanical kingdom that practices strict separation of the sexes, including banning women from driving.

title: Photos of the Moment | Emilio Pucci
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#632", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Danilo Scarpatis Milan fashion week photo diary.

title: Frank Driggs, Collector of Jazz Photos, Dies at 81
description: Frank Driggs, a writer, historian and record producer who amassed what is considered the finest collection of jazz photographs in the world, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Magazines Begin to Sell the Fashion They Review
description: On Park & Bond, a new e-commerce site for designer mens wear, Jim Moore, the creative director for GQ, can be found describing a red Calvin Klein turtleneck as something that can take that gray flannel suit and give it a little bon vivant. The sweater, which costs $225, is tagged as a GQ Pick, inside the GQ Store.

title: Wendy's Little Wendy
description: Wendy Thomas, after whom the Wendy's restaurant chain is named, appears in a commercial for a new line of cheeseburgers to be sold by the restaurant.

title: Protesters Bare All Over a Proposed San Francisco Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Perhaps it should not be a surprise that San Francisco does not have a law against being naked in public, nor that a small, unselfconscious segment of the citys residents regularly exercise that right.

title: Netflix Secures Streaming Deal With DreamWorks
description: LOS ANGELES  DreamWorks Animation, the company behind successful movie franchises like Madagascar and Shrek, said it had completed a deal to pump its films and television specials through Netflix, replacing a less lucrative pact with HBO.

title: Tennessee Senator Takes a Stand for Compromise
description: WASHINGTON  Insiders could spot the constraints on Lamar Alexander in the Senate at least six years ago, as the two parties fought over judicial nominations.

title: Divers Set Sights on Silver-Laden WWII Ship
description: In 1941, a Nazi torpedo tore a hole in a British merchant ship carrying a fortune in silver to England from India. The ship was part of a convoy headed for Liverpool, but it went down about 300 miles southwest of Ireland, disappearing in icy waters nearly three miles deep, deeper than the resting place of the Titanic.

title: Former Rebels Rivalries Hold Up Governing in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  When the fighters who ousted Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi find caches of weapons from his arsenals, they do not entrust them to Libyas new provisional government. Instead, they haul them back to their hometowns, like Misurata, Zintan, Yafran or Rujban. And when they capture members of the Qaddafi government, the fighters say, they cart them home as well.

title: Prophylactic Du Jour
description: Tomorrows column is going to be depressing. So, to help you get through it:

title: Strategies for Raising SAT Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: After 27 Years, an Answer to the Question, Wheres the Beef?
description: AS the hamburger wars heat up, Wendys is rolling out the biggest weapons in its marketing arsenal, asking a familiar question again and bringing back some famous names.

title: Yards Pile Up Against Jets, and the Concerns Creep In
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  A boisterous crowd beyond the south end zone wore black-and-silver pirate costumes and gorilla suits and chain mail, and mocked and taunted and yelled at the Jets. The fans were mostly harmless, certainly not as terrifying to the Jets as what occurred between the sidelines. Their defenders grasped at air. They lay flattened on the grass. They failed to stop a Raiders offense despite knowing exactly what was coming.

title: Retailers Are Put on the Spot Over Anti-Gay Aid
description: The culture war over gay rights has entered the impersonal world of e-commerce.

title: Hearst and HGTV in a Rare Entry at the Newsstand
description: With the economy sputtering, throw pillows and wicker baskets may not be at the top of many Americans shopping lists. Nor perhaps is a glossy magazine about where to buy them and how to make them pop against your freshly painted pale avocado walls.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: The murder trial of Barbara Sheehan, the Queens school secretary who shot her husband with 11 bullets, often bears the hallmarks of a dysfunctional wake.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: Life is a knuckleball, fluttering and veering out of control, just like the Red Sox increasingly miserable season.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Halloween Disruption for Martha Stewart Fan
description: When Mary Findley sat down at her kitchen table to read the special Halloween issue of Martha Stewarts magazine this year, she noticed something strange about a photo of a chocolate cake titled the Macabre Manse.

title: The S.S. Gairsoppa
description: Footage, provided by Odyssey Marine Exploration, of a sunken World War II ship that went down about 300 miles southwest of Ireland, disappearing in icy waters nearly three miles deep.

title: Once-Big Lead Keeps Shrinking as Braves Bats Continue Slump
description: WASHINGTON  A group of Atlanta Braves sat around a table in the visitors clubhouse Sunday morning and casually talked about their fantasy football lineups and the race for the National League most valuable player.

title: As Sides Dig In, Panel on Deficit Has an Uphill Fight
description: WASHINGTON  As if expectations were not low enough for the special Congressional committee charged with writing a deficit-reduction deal, they seem to be falling by the day as the two parties harden their positions on spending and taxes.

title: City Aide in Spotlight After Being Detained
description: Kirsten John Foy says that everything happens for a reason  and that the reason he and a black New York City councilman, Jumaane D. Williams, were briefly detained by the police at a parade on Sept. 5 was to call attention to racial bias in policing.

title: Obamas Plan to Reduce the Deficit
description: President Obama outlined a plan on Sept. 19 to trim budget deficits by $3.1 trillion over the next 10 years. Republicans have said they will oppose the plan because it includes tax increases. Here is a step-by-step explanation of how the deficit totals are calculated and a breakdown of how the plans savings would be achieved.

title: Religion in the Rainforest
description: Morgan Harrington, an Australian anthropologist, is studying traditional beliefs in small villages deep in the rainforest of Indonesia.

description: A look back at the Giants 29-16 upset victory over the Eagles:

title: Pennies From Many
description: AS Congress considers President Obamas job package, one measure seems to have rare bipartisan support: a proposal to loosen some of the outdated securities regulations that hamper small businesses in raising capital.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: WikiLeaks Founder, in a Gilded British Cage
description: ELLINGHAM, England

title: Videos Show Police Using Pepper Spray at Protest on the Financial System
description: For a few moments on Saturday, the confrontations between the police and the protesters just south of Union Square in Manhattan seemed fairly typical. People pushed, the police shoved and arrests were made, and in the many videos recording the protest, it was not always clear which of the three had come first.

title: After Four Weeks, Title Favorites Are Emerging
description: Tucked beneath a layer of scandal and amid a conference landscape that nearly had seismic change, there has been an actual 2011 college football season. And in the blur of the first few weeks in which most of the dominant story lines remained off the field, the season has already passed its one-quarter mark.

title: A Campaign Finance Ruling Turned to Labors Advantage
description: WASHINGTON  Labor unions are seizing on last years landmark Supreme Court campaign finance ruling to change how they engage in politics, developing ambitious plans to influence nonunion households in the 2012 election and counter corporate money flowing into outside conservative groups.

title: Why the Antichrist Matters in Politics
description: Pullman, Wash.

title: Europe Stews on Greece, and Markets Sweat Out the Wait
description: European leaders headed home from a weekend of meetings in Washington vowing bolder steps to address widening anxiety about the Continents debt burden. But it will most likely be weeks or even months before any new action comes to pass.

title: As Gangs Move In on Mexicos Schools, Teachers Say Enough
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico  The message is delivered by a phone call to the office of one school, a sheaf of photocopied papers dropped off at another, a banner hung outside a third.

title: Two Great Shots Bring a Big Victory (and Bonus)
description: ATLANTA  Bill Haas had one shoe in the water and the other on land, his awkward pose metaphorically capturing his position as the Tour Championship reached a gripping conclusion Sunday night.

title: The Once Great Are Left Adrift
description: Even great companies can make failure into a tradition. That seems to have happened at UBS, Yahoo and Hewlett-Packard. The prognosis for all three isnt good.

title: Euro Zone Death Trip
description: Is it possible to be both terrified and bored? Thats how I feel about the negotiations now under way over how to respond to Europes economic crisis, and I suspect other observers share the sentiment.

title: Lottery Numbers
Wired Platforms at Last. Oh No, the Boss Is Calling!
description: Perhaps no space in New York City is governed by as complex a set of social rules as the cramped subway car, that lurching human Petri dish that has spawned a thousand sociology papers. Its nuanced etiquette is known to generations of New Yorkers: head down, body clenched, contact of eyes or limbs a no-no.

title: Giants Replay: Week 3
description: The Giants, taking advantage of big plays on offense and Michael Vicks broken hand, won, 29-16.

title: Sentencing Shift Gives New Leverage to Prosecutors
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  After decades of new laws to toughen sentencing for criminals, prosecutors have gained greater leverage to extract guilty pleas from defendants and reduce the number of cases that go to trial, often by using the threat of more serious charges with mandatory sentences or other harsher penalties.

title: Jets Replay: Week 3
description: Darren McFadden and the Raiders rushing offense ran all over the Jets.

title: Mandatory Minimums Put Power in Prosecutors Hands
description: In cases like that of Shane Guthrie, mandatory sentencing minimums have given prosecutors more muscle to extract guilty pleas from defendants and avoid trial.

title: An Indefensible Punishment
description: When the Supreme Court reinstituted the death penalty 35 years ago, it did so provisionally. Since then, it has sought to articulate legal standards for states to follow that would ensure the fair administration of capital punishment and avoid the arbitrariness and discrimination that had led it to strike down all state death penalty statutes in 1972.

title: Up South
description: Abraham Lincoln may have won Indiana in the 1860 presidential election, but on a summer night in Greencastle, Ind., locals could see just how much the state was split between Unionists and Confederate sympathizers. On the evening of July 21, 1861, residents had gathered at the railroad depot, where the telegraph dripped news from the wires indicating the rising or falling tide at the distant battle at Bull Run. Eager anticipation turned to dismay when they learned that, at the end of the day, the tide had turned and the North had suffered a shocking defeat. But not everyone at the depot was discouraged: the face of Judge Delana Eckels, who publicly sided with the South even as he held a leading position in the community, was wreathed in smiles at the news of the Union armys panicked retreat.

title: Weighing the Risk
description: After suffering a concussion a week ago, William C. Rhoden asks, should Michael Vick really have played against the Giants?

title: New Havens Teacher Improvement Plan
description: Like most school systems that serve disadvantaged children, New Haven, an urban district with a high poverty rate, has faced enormous challenges in improving the quality of instruction. But its political leaders and teachers union took a bold step last year in agreeing to a new teacher evaluation system that aims to reward excellent teaching and to retrain or remove poor performers. The first years promising results show what can be done when the two sides commit to reform.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS This weeks data will include new-home sales for August (Monday); the S.& P./Case-Shiller housing price index for July; consumer confidence for September (Tuesday); durable goods orders for August (Wednesday); final second-quarter gross domestic product; weekly jobless claims; pending home sales for August (Thursday); personal income and spending for August; the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index for September; the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for September (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Bringing Your Own Plastic Seat Cover to the Movies
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Video: Weighing the Risk With Vick
description: After suffering a concussion a week ago, Michael Vick played against the Giants. William C. Rhoden wonders if he should have.

title: The Secrets of a Principal Who Makes Things Work
description: One columnists idea of a good principal:

title: In Japan, the Summer of Setsuden
description: After a long, hot and dark summer in Japan, the days are cooler and the nights are brighter. For this the Japanese can give thanks not just to September, but also to setsuden, or energy saving, an ambitious and strikingly successful campaign to conserve electricity after the March earthquake, tsunami and nuclear-plant disasters.

title: Battle for Libya | September 25, 2011
description: Qaddafi loyalists attacked the city of Ghadamis. Transitional government leaders said they discovered a mass grave.

title: Angels Playoff Chances Fade With a Three-Run Lead Blown in the Ninth
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  For the Los Angeles Angels, reaching the American League playoffs will mean not only ambushing the Boston Red Sox and the Tampa Bay Rays but a third, unseen opponent: probability.

title: Libyans Say Qaddafi Loyalists Mounted Raid From Algeria
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  In a rare cross-border incursion, fighters loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi drove cars full of weapons into Libya from across the Algerian border and attacked former rebel forces, Libyan military officials said Sunday.

title: For Russias Liberals, Flickers of Hope Vanish
description: MOSCOW  When Lyubov Volkova, 63, woke up on Sunday, it was a few moments before she remembered what had happened.

title: In a TriBeCa Park, a Question of Law and a Religious Symbol
description: Ralph Musolino unreeled his Stanley tape measure across the walkway of a small park in TriBeCa, marking off space for the construction of a Jewish ritual hut known as a sukkah, while Rabbi Zalman Paris, in auburn beard and tzitzit fringes, crouched nearby holding the tapes other end.

title: N.B.A. Stars Find a Place to Play: A Philadelphia Arena
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Palestra is a college gymnasium with uneven bricks, stained yellow window panes on its ceiling and a creaky hardwood floor, where the lines on the court were pasted by hand Saturday night after a womens volleyball match.

title: Justice and the Suffolk County Police
description: Suffolk County, N.Y., has seen some of the countrys most shameful political battles over day laborers and a string of violent crimes against Latinos, most notoriously the fatal stabbing of an Ecuadorean, Marcelo Lucero, in 2008 by a gang of teenage boys who had made a sport of hunting and assaulting dark-skinned men.

title: Torrey Smiths Dream Start for the Ravens
description: The Ravens drafted Torrey Smith out of Maryland in April in the hope that he could be a credible downfield target for Joe Flacco and open some room underneath for Anquan Boldin. When Smith struggled in the preseason, Baltimore moved quickly to acquire someone who could do that job better, picking up Lee Evans in a trade with Buffalo.

title: In Speech, Yemen President Confirms Support for Transfer of Power
description: SANA, Yemen  In his first speech since returning to Yemen, President Ali Abdullah Saleh confirmed on Sunday that his deputy remained authorized to sign a transfer-of-power agreement that would lead to early presidential elections, but he did not make any new concessions.

title: Flood Victims Getting Fed Up With Congress
description: TUNKHANNOCK, Pa.  Standing in the living room of their house, now full of mud, slime and debris, Helen and Peter Kelly cannot believe that Congress is bickering over disaster aid to people like them.

title: Nepalese Sightseeing Plane Crashes, Killing 19
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Nineteen people, including three Americans, died in a plane crash in Nepal on Sunday as they headed back to the capital, Katmandu, after a sightseeing tour of the mountains, including Mount Everest, officials said.

title: An Interview With Carla Sozzani
description: Suzy Menkes, fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune, speaks with Carla Sozzani about her creation of a retail concept that blends art, fashion, music and design under one roof.

title: Team Approach to Presidents Cup Coverage
description: The Golf Channel will carry the Presidents Cup  the international team match-play competition between United States and non-European teams in November  live from Melbourne, Australia, while NBC will show the weekend events on tape.

title: Question Mark for Jets Defense
description: A look back at the Jets 34-24 loss to the Raiders:

title: Up From the Ashes, a Symbol That Hate Does Not Win
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.

title: Frank Driggs Collection
description: In a series of bulging file cabinets in his Greenwich Village home, Mr. Driggs kept nearly 100,000 images, alphabetized by subject, which he supplied for a fee  provided he took a liking to the person making the request  to newspapers, magazines and television programs, including Jazz, Ken Burnss multipart TV documentary.

title: Short of Victory, Mahan Still Has Plenty to Smile About
description: ATLANTA  While the golf audience was riveted by the FedEx Cup points race  otherwise known as Who Wants To Be A Millionaire-Times-10?  Sundays final round of the Tour Championship turned into a decent little affair on its own merits.

title: Giants Ross Plays Role of Star Against Eagles
description: PHILADELPHIA  All week Aaron Ross sounded like a broken record of political correctness.

description: Milan

That was in stark contrast to the first leg of his Libyan assignment spent in a press pool covering the forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi  at times even confined to his hotel room. title: Seamless Acquires Menupages in Race for Restaurants

title: Arthur Conan Doyles First Novel Is Published in Britain
description: Before he earned worldwide acclaim as the creator of Sherlock Holmes, a struggling physician named Arthur Conan Doyle tried his hand at a different kind of fiction writing: a novel from the perspective of a 50-year-old man who is confined to his room when he has an attack of gout. The original manuscript of that novel, titled The Narrative of John Smith, was lost in the mail en route to Conan Doyles publishers, and though he later rewrote it from memory, the book was never published in his lifetime. Conan Doyle was later to remark: My shock at its disappearance would be as nothing to my horror if it were suddenly to appear again  in print.

It was his third consecutive victory, having logged wins at Monza in Italy, Spa-Francorchamps in Belgium and the Hungaroring in Hungary, and his ninth over all in 2011.

title: Best-Selling Author Gives Away His Work
description: A publishing industry that is being transformed by all things digital could learn some things from Paulo Coelho, the 64-year-old Brazilian novelist. Years ago he upended conventional wisdom in the book business by pirating his own work, making it available online in countries where it was not easily found, using the argument that ideas should be disseminated free. More recently he has proved that authors can successfully build their audiences by reaching out to readers directly through social media. He ignites conversations about his work by discussing it with his fans while he is writing.

title: Space Invader
description: For the L.A. artist Sarah Cain, space is more than just physical  its also psychic and emotional. I try to morph the three, says Cain, whose site-specific work dips into a playfully vivid palette that defies her contemplative nature. Cain used abandoned buildings to develop her style, and some of her earliest efforts, along the dirt roads of her native upstate New York, went entirely unseen. A 2004 installation in a squat in San Franciscos North Beach, however, brought her the attention of the art world. She is now represented by Honor Fraser in L.A. and Anthony Meier Fine Arts in San Francisco and was recently commissioned by LAND (Los Angeles Nomadic Division) to do an installation in a former Masonic lodge in Marfa, Tex. On view through Dec. 4 as part of a suite of public projects, Forget Me Not takes its name from the flower pin once worn by the Masons and later adopted by the Nazis. Supreme Being (above), a three-dimensional canvas bordered in gold leaf, is the only component Cain created off-site for the piece; its diagonal stripes were traced from the floorboards in her studio.

title: A Cuban-American Choreographs a Dance in Havana
description: The choreographer Pedro Ruiz is the first Cuban-American to create a work with a Cuban dance troupe in Cuba. A documentary by Julie Cohen about his trip will be shown on WNET on Sept 29.

title: Leading Off: World Goes Mad, or at Least Football Does
description: If you went on vacation for a few weeks, left the country, put the iPhone on airplane mode and left it there, it would be easy to return and wonder if the sports world had gone completely off the rails. We know this from personal experience. But, as it turns out, it was not necessary to leave the country and turn off your smartphone to feel unmoored. In fact, you could have watched every second of the Lions and Bills starting the season 3-0, with a few glimpses over at the Browns going 2-1, while still trying to wrap your head around the Colts without Peyton Manning and still wonder what in the world is going on.

One is that many other foods that are every bit as beneficial, like greens, dont enjoy the same degree of public acclaim. Another is that yogurt has been sustaining people all around the world since long before the dawn of advertising.

title: Hidden in the Middle

Namely, the hypothetical position self-proclaimed centrists want somebody to take  Michael Bloomberg, a chastened Obama, whatever  is almost always the position actually held by the Democratic party. But to seem balanced, the pundits involved have to ignore that inconvenient fact.

title: A Patch of Rain, but a Bigger Patch of Luck
description: SOUTH HAVEN, Mich.  Three thousand miles into my trans-America bicycle journey  my odometer clicked over on Saturday  Ive finally been stymied by the weather. I had an exceedingly pleasant passage across Lake Michigan on the high-speed ferry from Milwaukee to Muskegon, during which I made occasional forays on deck to stand up to a cold wind that seemed capable of slinging me overboard. But Im now pinned by that same wind (or so it seems) to the eastern shore of the lake, heading south. It has also been raining, so my days in the saddle have been relatively short and very damp. (Thank goodness for hot showers and motel guest laundries.) Now, though I need to turn east lest I end up back in Chicago, the rain is persisting and the wind has grown only stronger. Im frustrated and eager to put some miles behind me, but to ride in intermittent, sometimes forceful downpours (thunderstorms are forecast) into a 15- to 20-mile-per-hour blow strikes me as foolish, or worse  no fun.

title: The Redshirting Debate Continues
description: Another article you have probably seen and likely talked about today appears in the Sunday Review section. In the article Delay Kindergarten at Your Childs Peril, two neuroscientists, Sam Wang and Sandra Aamodt, take on a practice that has become increasingly popular: holding kindergarten-age children back for a year in what the authors describe as an attempt to give them a leg up on peers. It is called redshirting (a term taken from the loophole college athletes use to prolong their eligibility), and it happens to 1 in 11 children in the kindergarten age group. Many parents have chosen to do it thinking they were helping their children. They arent, the authors argue.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: American Advertising Federation, Washington, named seven executives to be the 2011 members of its Advertising Hall of Achievement, recognizing the accomplishments of men and women age 40 and under. The inductees in the 19th class are: Jonathan Bauer, partner and head of strategy at Droga5; Carolyn Everson, vice president for global marketing solutions at Facebook; Eric Hadley, general manager of worldwide marketing for Bing and MSN at Microsoft; Brian Monahan, managing partner for the intelligence practice at Magna Global, part of the Mediabrands division of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Amy Powell, executive vice president for interactive marketing strategies and film production at Paramount Pictures, part of Viacom; Iain Tait, global interactive creative director at Wieden & Kennedy; and Hamdi Ulukaya, president and chief executive at Chobani, part of Agro Farma. Mr. Ulukaya will also receive another honor, the Jack Avrett Volunteer Spirit Award, at an induction ceremony on Nov. 2.

title: In Riddle of Mideast Upheaval, Turkey Offers Itself as an Answer

These days, its prime minister may be the most popular figure in the Middle East, its foreign minister envisions a new order there and its officials have managed to do what the Obama administration has so far failed to: position themselves firmly on the side of change in the Arab revolts and revolutions.

title: Back to the Future
description: Postwar California provided the perfect environment for modernism to flourish. Newly available materials like machine-molded plywood combined with mass production to revolutionize furniture design; industrial steel transformed residential construction; and the regions comfortable climate invited indoor-outdoor living. This month, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art presents California Design, 1930-1965: Living in a Modern Way, a survey of Californias homegrown style including the iconic 1945-49 Eames House (a room from which will be installed as part of the exhibition), Barbies circa 1962 Dream House (complete with cardboard hi-fi/television console) and a 1952 desk (top left) by Greta Magnusson Grossman. In New York, the Museum of Arts and Design offers a counterpoint with Crafting Modernism (Oct. 12 to Jan. 15, 2012), a look at the American Studio Craft Movement, which embraced traditional techniques like woodworking, weaving and silversmithing to produce radical results, like Vladimir Kagans trippy mosaic tile table or Jan de Swarts 1965 blanket chest (top right).
