description: When the White House announced We the People, an online system for petitioning the government, they no doubt hoped it would become a high-minded way for citizens to interact with their political leaders.

title: The Caucus | Rick Perry's Challenges
description: Rick Perrys difficult week and what to watch for as he tries to regain his footing. Also, a report from Washington as lawmakers again flirt with a government shutdown.

title: Retired Bob Lutz Adds Via Motors to His Brand Advisory Portfolio
description: At 79 and nominally retired, Robert A. Lutz, the former vice chairman of General Motors, seems to be neglecting his shuffleboard game.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 26
description: Wales had a big day at the Rugby World Cup, eliminating Namibia, 81-7.

title: Jailed for Switching Her Daughters School District
description: Kelley Williams-Bolar, 41, a single mother from Akron, Ohio, was convicted of two felony crimes in January and jailed for nine days after she falsified documents so she could enroll her daughters  one a third grader, the other in junior high  in a neighboring, higher performing school district. This month, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio reduced the convictions, which were for records tampering, to misdemeanors. He said the original punishment had been too harsh. Ms. Williams-Bolar, who works as a teachers aide in an Akron public school, is pursuing a degree in family child development. A criminal felony would have hindered her chance of getting a teachers license. Though the case focused attention on the disparity in the academic quality of school systems, Ms. Williams-Bolar said she did not do it to gain an educational advantage. She explains:

title: Obama Proposes Protecting Unemployed Against Hiring Bias
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has not been particularly successful in fostering the creation of jobs. But he thinks he has found a way to pry open doors in the workplace for many of the unemployed, especially those who have been out of work for a long time.

title: Bloomberg Supports Relief From No Child Law
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pledged his support on Monday for the Obama administrations plan to give states relief from the most onerous provision of the Bush-era No Child Left Behind law. We shouldve, couldve, wouldve, but were not going to reach all of the goals, Mr. Bloomberg told reporters at NBCs Education Nation summit. The law would require all students to be proficient in reading and math by 2014, but Mr. Bloomberg said schools ought to be judged by more than just how well their students do on standardized tests. Read more on SchoolBook.

title: Photos of the Moment | Dolce & Gabbana
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#364", 592, 500, true, chameleonData);Sonny Vandeveldes Milan fashion week photo diary.

title: 3-0 Records Bring Hope to Buffalo and Detroit
description: It has been 11 seasons since the Buffalo Bills or the Detroit Lions went to the N.F.L. playoffs. Thats a lot of Matt Millen drafts, botched quarterback anointings and coaching changes (11 combined) to wade through as a sort of stress test for fans.

title: One Answer to Adoptions Difficult Questions
description: After I wrote about child trafficking and international adoption from China, an adoptive mother contacted me with a story she said she had to share: how she went back to China to seek the truth about her daughter.

title: What We Eat, Where We Sleep: Documenting Daily Life to Tell Stories
description: In August, two slide shows were published on NYTimes.com that both seemed so useful for classrooms that we saved them until the school year began to present together in a lesson.

title: Manchester City and Financial Fair Play
description: Jer Longman has an article for Tuesdays editions of The Times about Manchester City and the multimillion-dollar spending spree it has used to propel itself into the highest levels of European soccer. But the articles main thrust is a look at FIFAs new Financial Fair Play rules, and whether City  and other big clubs  might be circumventing them, and whether anyone should have a problem with that.

title: The Caucus | Government Shutdown?
description: Sept. 26, 2011 - Jennifer Steinhauer reports from Washington as lawmakers again flirt with a government shutdown.

title: Scripted Drama Cant Touch Footballs Supremacy
description: Although final audience numbers were not yet available on Monday, the Sunday Night Football game (the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Indianapolis Colts 23-20) once again carried NBC to a ratings victory. Among scripted entertainment shows, the series premiere of Pan Am on ABC took off with 10.9 million total viewers, a higher total audience than its lead in, Desperate Housewives (9.8 million viewers). A new timeslot and an Emmy win for Julianna Margulies (not to mention a dynamite new haircut, with bangs) did not translate to a ratings increase for The Good Wife on CBS. That legal drama attracted 10.5 million viewers, down from 12.9 million for last seasons premiere episode.

title: Scuffle at the United Nations Ends in an Apology to Turks
description: Resurgent Turkey has become a Middle East story to watch, and just how perilous standing in its way can be became abundantly clear to a few somewhat hapless United Nations security guards during the annual General Assembly meeting of world leaders.

title: Milestone Moment for S.E.C. in Insider Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission trumpeted it as a milestone: its first insider trading case involving an exchange-traded fund. That occurred last week when the S.E.C. accused a former employee of Goldman Sachs and his father of trading ahead of the firms hedging transactions to limit its exposure to an E.T.F.

title: Sentence of the Week: Wide, Slightly Burred, Crimson Edition
description: No time for any fancy introduction this week  look at all the sentences:

title: The Daily Shoe | Marni
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company in Berlin
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 13th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Berlin.

title: Monday Matchup, Redskins at Cowboys
description: Redskins (2-0) at Cowboys (1-1), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Cowboys by 5

title: Coming Soon: A National Strategy on Alzheimers
description: People concerned about Alzheimers disease and its effect on families, on the health care system, on the country as a whole, have lobbied for years for a national action plan. How should the nation confront a disease projected to afflict more than 13 million Americans by 2050  a disease gaining on cancer as the illness Americans dread most?

title: Mixed Reaction to Europes Talk of Bolstering a Bailout Fund
description: FRANKFURT  Wedged between impatient financial markets and restive voters, European political leaders struggled on Monday to formulate a bolder response to the sovereign debt crisis, including possibly expanding the firepower of the euro zones bailout fund.

title: Paula Radcliffe on Motherhood and Marathons
description: At the Berlin Marathon this weekend, 37-year-old Paula Radcliffe of England placed third, easily qualifying for the Olympic Games in London next year. Ms. Radcliffe holds the world record for the marathon, but this was her first such race in nearly 23 months after giving birth to her second child.

title: Losing Faith in Government
description: Washingtons dysfunctional political climate not only makes it harder for Congress to pass sound economic policy. It also means that whatever policies Congress manages to pass may be ineffective anyway, since Americans have lost so much confidence in their governments ability to help.

title: For Bills Fans, Now More Than a Glimmer of Hope
description: Bills fans didnt make off with the goal posts at Ralph Wilson Stadium on Sunday but after the stunning come-from-behind, 34-31 win over the Patriots, beleaguered Bills backers everywhere are feeling strangely optimistic about a team few believed in prior to the start of the season.

title: Alls Fair in NYC
description: First the Frieze Art Fair announced the inauguration of its New York offshoot, in May 2012. Now, another high-end fair, the Pavilion of Art & Design (or PAD) is coming to New York for the first time, from Nov. 10 to Nov. 14 at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: Ford Mulling E.V.s and Lincolns for China
description: In China, local manufacturers and Western automakers are in collaboration mode, particularly in the development of electric vehicles. Alan R. Mulally threw Fords hat in the ring on Saturday in an interview with Bloomberg Television, during which the chief executive gave indications that Ford may build E.V.s there.

title: S.E.C. Weighs Action Against Standard & Poors
description: Standard & Poors, the ratings agency, is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission over a complex mortgage security called Delphinus that was issued in 2007 just as the housing market began to collapse, according to a financial filing by the companys parent, McGraw-Hill, The New York Times reports. Read more

title: Historical Opera Is Canceled in Beijing
description: An opera about Sun Yat-sen, Chinas first president and Nationalist leader, has been canceled shortly before its scheduled opening at the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing because of official objections to the music, according to the composers representatives. The work, Dr. Sun Yat-sen by Huang Ruo and a production of Opera Hong Kong, was to have opened on Friday, roughly coinciding celebrations of the 100th anniversary of the Chinese revolution. Mr. Ruos management, Karsten Witt Music Management in Berlin, said a government official had gone to rehearsals and decided that the music was inappropriate.

title: Civil Rights Era Artifacts
description: At Queens College, a collection of Civil Rights era artifacts has sprung to prominence.

title: Red Sox Bloggers Reprieve From the Gloom
description: A sort of gallows humor overtook Red Sox bloggers as the team orchestrated its incredible late-season swoon, so Sunday nights dramatic 14-inning victory over the Yankees threw in a new twist.

title: How small fixes can save millions and a new study on the consequences of prostate cancer.
description: How small fixes can save millions and a new study on the consequences of prostate cancer.

title: 2012 Camaro ZL1 Sells for $250,000 at Auction
description: At the Barrett-Jackson auction in Las Vegas on Saturday, Rick Hendrick, owner of the motorsports team that has placed three of its four drivers in the Nascar Chase for the Sprint Cup, bid the winning amount of $250,000 for the first 2012 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 to be offered to the public. Full proceeds from the sale of the 580-horsepower coupe, which was first displayed at the Chicago auto show in February, were destined for the Y.M.C.A. of Southern Nevada.

title: Model-Morphosis | Josephine Skriver at Emilio Pucci
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Josephine Skriver before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Lisa Butler and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Coffee Drinking Linked to Less Depression in Women
description: Morning pick-me-up? For many women, the mood-elevating effects of a cup of coffee may be more than fleeting.

title: Small Fixes: Paper Diagnostics
description: Donald G. McNeil Jr., a science reporter for The New York Times, explains a liver damage test that fits on a postage stamp and could cost less than a penny.

title: Charles Isherwood on the Stephen Sondheim  James Goldman musical Follies.
description: Charles Isherwood on the Stephen Sondheim  James Goldman musical Follies.

title: New Follies Shows Broadway Earning Potential
description: The new Broadway revival of the Stephen Sondheim-James Goldman musical Follies grossed more than $1.12 million last week, breaking into the the theatrical box office million-dollar club for the first time and edging the long-running musical Jersey Boys out of the Top 5 shows in ticket sales. The Follies windfall represents the highest one-week gross for a Broadway production with music and lyrics by Mr. Sondheim. The previous one-week high for a show by Mr. Sondheim, who has been writing Broadway shows for 55 years, was $1.03 million for the revival of A Little Night Music during New Years week in 2009-10.

title: TimesCast | September 26, 2011
description: The Senate votes to stem a government shutdown; Netflix cuts a streaming deal with DreamWorks; and a sit-in protest near Wall Street persists with no end in sight.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Yemen, Germany and New York.

title: On the Atlanta and St. Louis Blogs, Some Wishin and Mopin
description: Blogs covering the Red Sox specialize in anger and angst, but theres still room for hand-wringing by sites devoted to the Braves and Cardinals, who also happen to be competing for a playoff spot.

title: Lawyer for Hikers Freed by Iran Denies Abuse Claims
description: The Iranian lawyer for the two American hikers released on bail and repatriated last week after a two-year odyssey through Irans penal system appeared to distance himself from his clients in an interview published on Monday, calling their accusations of mistreatment baseless and politically motivated.

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 26, 2011
description: Rebel fighters clashed with Qaddafi loyalists near Sirte, a city on the Mediterranean about 230 miles east of Tripoli.

title: Malawis Man at the U.N.
description: On Sept. 15, just in time for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, City Room asked a question: What nation that you probably wouldnt hear about would you like to hear about? Or, more precisely, what nations diplomats would you like to find out about?

title: Israeli Panel Offers $8 Billion Plan to Address Economic Inequality
description: JERUSALEM  A government-appointed committee on socioeconomic change, set up in the wake of the social protests that swept Israel this summer, proposed new policies on Monday that are intended to ease the high cost of living. The plan would cost an estimated $8 billion over five years, to be financed partly by cuts to the defense budget.

title: Apple Restores Some Final Cut Features
description: As I had mentioned in a previous post, editing pros are up in arms because Apple removed some important features from its well liked editing software, Final Cut. Well, editors, you can lower your weapons, a least a bit.

title: Photos of the Moment | Gianfranco Ferr
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#761", 592, 500, true, chameleonData);Samantha Casolaris Milan fashion week photo diary.

title: Alvin Ailey Signs Longterm Deal With City Center
description: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has signed its first multiyear agreement with City Center, according to officials of the two companies who were scheduled to announce that arrangement on Tuesday.

title: Delegating Economic Policy to the Technocrats, and Away from Democracy
description: In a column in The New Republic, Peter Orzsag, President Obamas former budget director, argues for making the countrys policy-setting less dysfunctional by making it less democratic. One means for reducing politicized gridlock, he says, is to delegate more authority to depoliticized commissions of experts.

title: Partisans Prepare for Keystone XL Hearings
description: Opponents and supporters of the controversial Keystone XL pipeline project are gearing up for a pivotal round of public meetings around the country this week  forums that could play a role in whether the huge project receives final approval from the State Department by years end.

title: Leyland Reveals Whats Beneath Crusty Exterior
description: Detroit Tigers manager Jim Leylands reputation as a rough hewn baseball character comes from his sometimes testy exchanges with the news media, umpires and his own players. It doesnt help that some of these exchanges occur when he has his mouth full of food during postgame news conferences in his office.

title: Numberplay: Celebrating the Modern Classics
description: Today I want to celebrate two of the greatest puzzles/games ever invented: the Rubiks Cube and the game of Scrabble. Though both are relatively modern, unlike ancient classic games like chess, their place in the eternal Puzzle Hall of Fame is assured.

title: Critics Picks: The Gambler
description: A. O. Scott discusses risk in the 1974 film starring James Caan, Paul Sorvino and Lauren Hutton.

title: The Group Treatment for AIDS
description: Patient groups share the burdens of living with AIDS.

title: Look of the Moment | Chlo Grace Moretz
description: The Look: Buzzing  a black lace appliqu over bumblebee-yellow skinnies paired with a leather jacket up top and a punch of red polish on the nails.

title: A Simple Solution to Prevent Cervical Cancer
description: With vinegar and a little training, great strides are being taken in preventing cervical cancer globally.

title: Pairings: Peppers Stuffed With Merguez
description: The pinot noirs from New Zealand threw acidity, sweetness, spice, mint and some funk at our palates. With this dish we are throwing those very same elements back at the wine.

title: In Wine, Friendliness Isnt Always Enough
description: I NEVER like to try your patience, but please bear with me as we delve into a knotty gray area of wine terminology. The notion in question is structure, along with several related terms, like shape, focus, precision and definition.

title: Hell and Back
description: A clip from the documentary film, "Hell and Back" by photojournalist Danfung Dennis.

title: Hell and Back
description: An embedded video clip from the documentary film, "Hell and Back" by photojournalist Danfung Dennis.

title: Multimedia: Snapshots and a Secret at the Museum of Sex
description: During the 1950s, a professor and tattoo artist named Samuel Steward chronicled his sex life in drawings, letters, photographs, sexual paraphernalia and other items, and in so doing created documentary evidence of his experience of gay life and homosexuality in American culture at that time.

title: Who Will Techno the Technocrats?
description: Catherine Rampell comments skeptically on Peter Orszags call for delegating more policy to panels of nonpolitical experts. Id add that this is an odd time to make such a proposal. Yes, the political world is deeply dysfunctional  but whats equally remarkable is just how terrible the judgment of the supposed experts has been. Its not just the complete failure to foresee this crisis. Fancy international organizations have been persistently offering disastrous advice, counseling austerity and interest rate hikes just as the recovery, such as it is, stumbles. Politicians say dumb things about monetary policy  but so does the ECB.

title: Melodrama Returns, Flaunting Its Chaos and Clichs
description: According to the Metropolitan Playhouse From Rags to Riches has not been revived in New York for more than 100 years. After seeing the play youll wonder if the last troupe to stage it has yet recovered from the experience. A sprawling tale assembled from dozens of styles, genres and plots, the show is by turns slapdash, bewildering, rousing and ridiculous. Its also more appealing than it has any right to be.

title: TimesCast | A Hollywood-Netflix Pact
description: Securing crucial content for its streaming service, Netflix outbids HBO to debut movies from DreamWorks Animation.

title: Photos of the Moment | Giorgio Armani
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#900", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Scotland Asks Libya for Help Finding Lockerbie Evidence
description: LONDON  Scotlands chief prosecutor has asked Libyas new government to assist in tracking down documentary evidence and witnesses for a possible new trial for those responsible for the Lockerbie airliner bombing.

title: Sharing Burdens of Living With AIDS
description: NKONDEDZI, Mozambique  Rogerio Bernardo slung a black satchel over his shoulder and waited by the roadside in the morning mist for a bush taxi. In dusty wingtips, frayed pants and a gray pinstripe suit coat so big it swallowed his slender frame, he looked like any peasant farmer dressed up for a trip to town.

title: Netflix to Stream DreamWorks Films
description: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss a new deal whereby Netflix will stream DreamWorks Animation movies for home viewing. The agreement is billed by the companies as the first time a major Hollywood supplier has chosen Web streaming over pay television.

title: City Opera Fills In Blanks in Its Schedule
description: The New York City Opera on Monday filled in some blanks in the schedule for its peripatetic season. Its fall concert, on Nov. 17, will feature the songs of Rufus Wainwright at the Rose Theater. Opera singers and Mr. Wainwright will perform. The company is giving his opera Prima Donna its American premiere in February at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. City Opera said on Monday that Jayce Ogren would conduct Prima Donna, and that Rebecca Taichman would direct the previously disclosed production of Telemanns Orpheus at the Museo del Barrio in May. The company, which announced in the spring that it was leaving Lincoln Center, presented most of its sharply reduced season at a news conference in July.

title: Chelsea Clinton Joins Board of Dillers IAC
description: Chelsea Clinton has joined the board of IAC/InterActiveCorp, the Internet media company controlled by Barry Diller.

title: Thats a Lot of Veggies
description: Dolce & Gabbanas prints of zucchini and other vegetables brought to mind Pradas bananas (and monkeys) as well as Stella McCartneys lemons from a year ago, in both color and spirit. Apparently the planting season isnt over.

title: Huntsman Spot in Oct. 18 Debate Endangered
description: Jon Huntsman, the former governor of Utah, has been in every presidential debate since he threw his hat in the ring last June.

title: Cuomo Vows to Broker Deal for Hailing Livery Cabs
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo pledged on Monday to help broker a deal on a bill that would make it legal to hail livery cabs on most New York City streets, giving new momentum to a plan whose political support had flagged in recent days.

title: Dialing Back the Clocks to the Court of Louis XIV
description: The landmark production of Lullys Atys that the expatriate American early-music pioneer William Christie conducted at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1989 and 1992 was a groundbreaking experience for many listeners, offering tantalizing insights into the relatively unfamiliar genre of French Baroque opera. The works sumptuous delights made a similarly impressive splash last week, when Mr. Christie and his ensemble, Les Arts Florissants, returned to the academy with a re-creation of this decadently costumed and choreographed production.

title: Far From Any Lab, Paper Bits Find Illness
description: BOSTON  While other scientists successfully shrank beakers, tubes and centrifuges into diagnostic laboratories that fit into aluminum boxes that cost $50,000, George Whitesides had smaller dreams.

title: Christie Blocks Tax Credit for Jersey Shore
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Monday blocked a $420,000 tax credit that the states Economic Development Authority had approved last week.

title: Jets Bring Injuries Back From Oakland
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets announced Monday that quarterback Mark Sanchez sustained a minor break in his nose in the Jets 34-24 loss to the Raiders on Sunday and will have to wear a visor for a few weeks.

title: Mining the Mother Lode of Elizabethan Composers
description: Kenneth Weiss, though born and trained in New York, has built a distinguished career in Europe as a harpsichordist and opera conductor. Lately, he has also spent a lot of time at the Juilliard School, where he is on the faculty of the historical performance program and where his performances both as a continuo harpsichordist in Juilliard Baroque and as a recitalist have been ear-catching and edifying: most notably, in a dramatic traversal of Bachs Goldberg Variations in January.

title: Discriminating Against the Unemployed?
description: The Times has just published an article about a provision in President Obamas jobs bill that would prohibit employers from discriminating against job applicants because they are unemployed. The article reports:

title: Autonomy C.E.O.: We Are Still H.P.s Future
description: If Hewlett-Packards ouster last week of its chief executive means software is no longer front and center in the companys future, no one told Mike Lynch, the chief executive of Autonomy.

title: Message Meets the Marketplace
description: Take debut albums with a grain of salt these days, especially in hip-hop, where the robustness of the mixtape circuit and the Internet as a promotion vehicle have ensured that artists begin to form their identities and have entire careers long before the vampiric record business has its way with them. As they are, debut albums  with other peoples hands in the pie  tend to show artists whove been reformed and remolded. What other people want from them, it often turns out, isnt what they wanted from themselves.

title: On Obama Turf, A Plea for Clinton Intervention
description: LOS ANGELESAs the presidents motorcade whisks him from Los Angeles International Airport to West Hollywood for the first of two fund-raisers on Monday night, he may notice signs of dissatisfaction: Posters of Mr. Obamas secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton, have been plastered around the city, with the caption Save Us Hillary.

title: Seduction, Sometimes With a Shout
description: A veneer of dreaminess hangs over the music of Porcelain Raft, the one-man project of Mauro Remiddi. He sings emotional declarations with a quaver, over gentle and astral music that sounds as if it were being played at a distance, just out of direct earshot.

title: TimesCast | Protesting to What End
description: September 26, 2011 - Protesters occupy a park near Wall Street for a second week, despite arrests and no clear message.

title: Framing Works With Dance, Words, Screens and Web Browsers
description: Musicians who grew up in the age of television and rock shows have become increasingly intent on replacing the stand-and-play recital format with technologically and conceptually fresher approaches. The Kronos Quartet, Ethel and the cellist Maya Beiser have been presenting semistaged programs for years, often with video and computer sound, and productions of that sort have become the standard at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Next Wave Festival.

title: For Neonatal Jaundice, a New Option in Resource-Poor Nations
description: Neonatal jaundice, a condition caused by excess bilirubin in the blood, affects most babies in the first few days of life when their livers are just beginning to function. It gives the skin a yellowish tint, but normally it goes away after a week or two without treatment, and the condition has no lasting consequences.

title: Safe Birth Kits to Reduce Infant Mortality
description: Babies arrive in this world on their own blissful schedules, regardless of war or natural disasters  or the availability of a doctor.

title: The Small Fixes Challenge
description: Do you think you could help solve one of the world's health problems? Take our Small Fixes Challenge!

title: Brewing Up Double-Edged Delicacies for Mosquitoes
description: On what food do mosquitoes live? Orgiastic gouts of human blood that distend their abdomens and render them almost unable to move  right?

title: Folding Saris to Filter Cholera-Contaminated Water
description: Rural Bangladeshi women often pour sweetened drinks through a piece of sari cloth to get rid of leaves, insects and other visible debris. But disease-causing micro-organisms are thousands of times smaller than the pores in the fabric and slip right through.

title: Self-Adjustable Eyeglass Lenses
description: In developed countries, getting glasses is a simple matter: Visit an optometrist, get a prescription and have it filled at a corner store. Not so in the developing world, where there are few optometrists and little money for luxuries like eyeglasses.

title: LifeStraw Saves Those Without Access to Clean Drinking Water
description: More than a billion people dont have reliable access to clean drinking water. Boiling kills most germs in water, but requires fuel and doesnt remove dirt. In recent years, sand and ceramic filters have become more common, but these tend to be more expensive and usually dont catch all the microbes.

title: A Way to Check That Drugs Are Not Counterfeit
description: Counterfeit drugs are a $200 billion industry worldwide. In some countries, up to half of all medicines available at pharmacies are fake or low-quality. Each year more than half a million people worldwide die while using bad drugs to treat malaria and tuberculosis alone.

title: The PeePoo, a Biodegradable Toilet for the Developing World
description: It looks like a plastic bag, but in fact the PeePoo is a single-use biodegradable toilet for the developing world. After it is used, the bag is knotted and then buried or sold back to the manufacturer. A lining of urea crystals in the bag helps transform the waste into fertilizer.

title: An Entrepreneur Creating Chances at a Better Life
description: If necessity is the mother of invention, Paul Polak is one of its fathers.

title: Kits Using Naloxone Revive Addicts After Opiate Overdose
description: Next to car crashes, opiate overdoses are the leading cause of accidental death in the United States. In Europe, a lethal overdose occurs every hour.

title: Fighting Cervical Cancer With Vinegar and Ingenuity
description: POYAI,  Thailand  Maikaew Panomyai did a little dance coming out of the examination room, switching her hips, waving her fists in the air and crowing, in her limited English: Everythings O.K.! Everythings O.K.!

title: The Simplest Health Solutions? Its Complicated
description: Its not that the American health system is completely deficient in small, clever, inexpensive fixes. Its just that sometimes theyre awfully hard to find.

title: Shades of Race
description: Our design director, Arem Duplessis, designed this weeks cover of the Book Review. Take a closer look here.

title: Like a Wetsuit, but It Can Save a Hemorrhaging Mother
description: In poor countries, women tend to give birth at home or in small clinics. If a mother suffers from bleeding in such a setting, she risks shock, organ failure and eventually death. Short of an airlift to a hospital where transfusions and surgery are available, there is often little to be done.

title: Volunteers Forge Better Care in Thailands Villages
description: BAAN MAE PING, Thailand  The ailments that bedeviled past generations in this mountainside hamlet are fading away. The parasite that causes malaria has been vanquished from the surrounding jungles, and villagers say it has been years since a baby died before turning 1 year old, once a common heartbreak.

title: A Household Shower From Hardware-Store Staples
description: Showering with soap and water is more than just comforting; it can reduce the chances that a child who plays in filthy gutters gets sick. But for many people in developing countries, showers are an unaffordable luxury.

title: Obstacles Slow an Easy Way to Prevent H.I.V. in Men
description: One of the most promising, proven methods for preventing H.I.V. in Africa is being implemented much more slowly than international health authorities recommended.

title: Micronutrient Vitamin Powders for Children
description: Babies cannot swallow vitamin pills, but in the developing world, there are many who need the nutritional boost that vitamins can provide.

title: How Tiny Errors in Africa Led to a Global Triumph
description: When I helped run a measles immunization program in West Africa in the 1960s, I learned that in global health small things can spell the difference between a major success and a colossal failure.

title: Helping Newborns Breathe, No Spanking Required
description: Many babies, especially premature ones, have trouble breathing. They can sometimes be jump-started by massage (which replaced the old tradition of smacking a babys bottom to make it cry) or with a neonatal respirator.

title: Drugs to Curb a Deadly Inheritance
description: The medicines that prevent the transmission of H.I.V. from mother to child are highly effective when they are used properly  that is, taken at the right time in gestation and in the right doses by both mother and newborn. But in resource-poor countries, mothers often give birth at home and rarely visit health clinics. So the problem is getting the medicines to the mothers and babies who need them, and making sure the doses and timing are right.

title: Setting the Stage Alight With Fleeting Flames
description: The Brazilian artist Michel Groisman devises what could best be described as intimate performance installations. In Porta das Mos, or Door of Hands, he shows the possibilities of hand movement when certain fingers are restricted. His interactive pieces encourage family attendance; two of the works he presented at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, last weekend were recommended for those 6 to 12. (This is hardly the norm in experimental performance.) On Friday night he presented his solo Transferncia (Transference), a corporeal conversation between fire and air.

title: An Aid Worker Writes: Hope and Exasperation at a Kandahar Hospital
description: Each time I walk along Mirwaiss crowded corridors, or visit the wards bustling with mothers and sick children, it is a new experience. No two visits are ever the same. There are more patients, more anxious mothers, more men gathered in gossiping groups on the stairwells; more prayer beads turning, more busy staff, more noise.

title: Brunch, With a Menu of Ballads
description: A pianistic meteor shower prefaced the jazz pianist Barbara Carrolls searching performance of the title song of Kurt Weill and Maxwell Andersons 1949 musical Lost in the Stars on Sunday afternoon at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel. Even if you didnt know the words, to hear Ms. Carroll, and her longtime colleague Jay Leonhart on bass, explore this ballad of cosmic loneliness and desolation was to be transported on a metaphysical voyage through time and space toward an unknown destination.

title: So Far, So Good
description: From Oct. 7 to July 2012, the Centre Pompidou-Metz will present Bivouac, a retrospective dedicated to the work of the designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec. Its like a big family dinner where everybody shows up, says Erwan (above, seated). The family, in this case, is the brothers radically original work, from Lit Clos of 2000, a raised, semi-enclosed bed like a bird cage, to Ploum, a new sofa for Ligne Roset, which they compare to a very ripe fruit. This is the Bouroullecs first major show in their native France, organized by ambience and demarcated by supersize versions of their room-divider designs, including the plastic seaweed-inspired Algues and their textile Clouds; one long wall will hold nearly 300 drawings. To coincide with the show, Phaidon is releasing a new monograph of their work. Were still young, so a celebration of our career is nice but a little anxiety-inducing, said Ronan, the older of the two, who recently turned 40. Each time we do an exhibition it feels like: thats done, lets move on to something else. That something else will be a permanent lighting installation for the Gabriel staircase in the Chteau de Versailles.

title: Investigations Into the Aggressive Use of Beats
description: Though Greg Fox isnt a singer, he has been the lungs of the sort-of-metal band Liturgy, from Brooklyn. His drumming often comes in blast-beats, long runs of eighth notes played on snare and cymbal and kick drum, all of them stressed. His playing, like that of Keith Moon and Tony Williams, isnt just a bottom layer, but a dramatic arc that keeps rising in the song. His beats bounce and swing and breathe, and break out of their own enclosures.

title: Print Crush
description: Carla Sozzani has been celebrating the 20th anniversary of her shop Corso Como 10, which is still a magnate for editors and retailers attending the shows in Milan. She sent over a little package  I knew instinctively it was chocolates. But the circle-print paper, repeated for the bag and box and candy wrapping, could almost make you forget what was inside. Almost. Happy birthday, Corso Como 10!

title: For the Bears, a Fake That Was Almost Fabulous
description: Coming soon to a playing field near you is a trick play so clever its likely to be imitated on punt returns throughout the land. Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers, speaking for the team that got duped, called it the most incredible play Ive ever seen, a convincing pantomime that left people wondering what the heck just happened. His teammate Greg Jennings thought it was the best play Ive ever seen.

title: Solar Oven Outhouse for Safer Fertilizer
description: Human waste makes good fertilizer, but it can be smelly and dangerous to handle when fresh.

title: Angry Reaction to Spotifys New Facebook ID Requirement
description: For months various digital music services have been jealous of the close link that appeared to be developing between Facebook and Spotify, the European company whose cloud music player finally arrived in the United States in July. Mark Zuckerberg, Facebooks chief executive, was a vocal fan of Spotify, and when the social media giant announced a string of new features on Thursday, Daniel Ek, Spotifys chief, was right there on stage with him.

title: Oil Spill Affected Gulf Fishs Cell Function, Study Finds
description: A minnowlike fish that is a major source of food in wetland marshes along the Gulf of Mexico is showing early signs of biological damage from the BP oil spill, a peer-reviewed study published on Monday found.

title: Touring the Ruins of the Old Economy
description: Michael Lewis possesses the rare storytellers ability to make virtually any subject both lucid and compelling. In his new book, Boomerang, he actually makes topics like European sovereign debt, the International Monetary Fund and the European Central Bank not only comprehensible but also fascinating  even, or especially, to readers who rarely open the business pages or watch CNBC. The book could not be more timely given the worries about Europes deepening debt crisis and the recent warning issued by Christine Lagarde, managing director of the I.M.F, that the current economic situation is entering a dangerous phase.

title: History Thats Written in Beads as Well as in Words
description: Distressed by most historians overwhelming preoccupation with the modern world, an unusual coalition of scholars is trying to stage an intellectual coup, urging their colleagues to look up from the relatively recent swirl of bloody conflicts, global financial exchanges and technological wonders and gaze further back, toward humanitys origins.

title: Obama and Young Guns Make Silicon Valley Pitches
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated Six miles from where President Obama held a Town Hall on Monday with LinkedIns executives in Mountain View, Calif., to discuss his jobs plan, the House Republican leaders who describe themselves as The Young Guns gathered at Facebooks headquarters for a 6 p.m. ET live discussion on their vision of what needs to be done to jumpstart the economy.

title: TimesCast: Wall Street Protests Continue
description: Protesters in downtown Manhattan continued to occupy a park near Wall Street and have organized themselves for a prolonged stay.

title: cancer embed
description: cancer embed

title: Albums by Mindless Behavior and LeAnn Rimes
description: MINDLESS BEHAVIOR

title: Critics Picks Video: The Gambler
description: In this weeks Critics Picks video, A. O. Scott looks back at the 1974 film The Gambler, directed by Karel Reisz.

title: Its Easy to See It Raf Simonss Way
description: MILAN

title: Sheen Settles Two and a Half Men Suit
description: The protracted conflict betweenCharlie Sheen and Warner Brothers Television ended quietly on Monday when the two sides agreed to settle a lawsuit the actor filed after the studio fired him from the hit CBS sitcom, Two and a Half Men.

title: Wall Street Ties Bring Peril for Democratic Lawmaker
description: Jim Himes, a second-term congressman from Connecticut, is a surviving member of one of Washingtons most endangered species: a Democrat with Wall Street ties.

title: Facebook Forms a PAC
description: Facebook wants more friends. And its willing to pay for them.

title: Four Syrian Soldiers Reported Killed in Escape Attempt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces killed four soldiers on Monday as they attempted to escape a military camp, and the army tightened its grip on towns across the country to quell dissent against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, activists said.

title: After the Palestinian Bid at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: KidTech: Glasses With a Videocamera Inside
description: The dream of concealing a tiny video camera inside a pair of glasses dates back to the days of Dick Tracy, but these days a child can have the real thing, with the Spy Net Stealth Recording Video Glasses, in toy stores this month from Jakks Pacific. And they really work.

title: Turkish Paper Lists Israelis It Says Were in Flotilla Raid
description: ISTANBUL  A Turkish newspaper published the names and photographs on Monday of more than 140 Israeli soldiers who the paper said took part in the raid on a Turkish flotilla to Gaza last year that ended with the death of nine passengers and created a diplomatic standoff between Turkey and Israel.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,468 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,769 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Full Appeals Court Wont Be Asked to Rule on Health Care Law
description: The Justice Department announced on Monday that it would not ask the full Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit to reconsider a three-judge panels ruling against the 2010 health care law. That presumably leaves the government to appeal its loss directly to the Supreme Court, although Tracy Schmaler, a Justice Department spokeswoman, declined to comment on the next steps. The Supreme Court has already received one of the multitude of federal cases challenging the constitutionality of the laws individual insurance mandate. It arrived in July from the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, which upheld that provision on a 2-to-1 ruling. A month later, the Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, ruled 2 to 1 against the mandate.

title: Indiana: Five Bodies Found In Two Neighboring Houses
description: Law enforcement officers on Monday were investigating the deaths of five adults whose bodies were found on Sunday afternoon in a rural area of southeast Indiana. The bodies were discovered near Laurel, southeast of Indianapolis, after someone noticed a child wandering alone in a roadway and called law enforcement authorities for help. Officials searching the area found five bodies  one man at one house, and two men and two women at another house across the street. At least some of them had been shot, the authorities said. The state police said it was unclear whether more than one person had fired a gun, or whether anyone who fired the gun was among the dead. Still, they advised local residents to take extra precautions as the investigation continued.

title: Nikon Joins the Mirrorless Movement
description: Nikon has joined the ranks of camera manufacturers trying to pull of a neat trick  building a compact camera that combines the photographic quality of an SLR with the simplicity of a point-and-shoot.

title: Doctors Who Give Good Care, and Are Caring
description: To the Editor:

title: The Group Treatment for AIDS
description: Patient groups share the burdens of living with AIDS.

title: The Wall Street Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Land in Winter Classic, Then in an On-Ice Controversy
description: PHILADELPHIA  Monday was a busy day for the Rangers: a lunchtime visit to Citizens Bank Park here for the announcement of the Jan. 2 Rangers-Flyers Winter Classic and the HBO 24/7 series leading to it; a final preseason game before a late-night flight to Europe and a hectic series of matches crisscrossing that continent; and new questions about the status of defenseman Marc Staal.

title: In Defense of Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: When Comics Depict Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Title Easier to Figure, if Not to Win
description: ATLANTA

title: Alabama Inmate Sues to Read Southern History Book
description: The past is never dead, though at the Kilby Correctional Facility outside of Montgomery, Ala., it seems it is not particularly welcome.

title: Japan: Aides Convicted in Campaign Finance Case
description: A court on Monday convicted three former aides of Ichiro Ozawa, the embattled Japanese political kingmaker, of charges related to political campaign financing. The convictions dealt Mr. Ozawa a setback just as his own trial in the scandal was set to begin next week. The aides were sentenced to as many as three years in prison for misreporting almost $6 million in Mr. Ozawas political funds. Widely credited with engineering the governing Democratic Partys historic victory two years ago, Mr. Ozawas backroom-style of politics has made him the target of repeated investigations by prosecutors.

title: China: Officers Suspended in Sex Slave Case
description: Four police officers in the city of Luoyang in Henan Province have been suspended because of negligence in the case of a former firefighter who imprisoned six women in a dungeon, raped them and forced them to be prostitutes and perform erotic shows on the Internet, according to an article in China Daily, an English-language newspaper. The suspect, Li Hao, has been accused of killing two of the women.

title: MSNBC Is Close to Falling to Third Place in Cable News Ratings
description: How badly has MSNBC been hurt by the loss of Keith Olbermann? Enough, apparently, to be on the verge of falling back into third place among the cable news networks.

title: Kodak Stock Dives After Credit Line Is Tapped
description: Eastman Kodak has been struggling to reinvent itself for decades. So when Antonio M. Perez, the chief executive, announced in July that he was confident that Kodak could transform itself into a profitable and sustainable digital company by 2012, many investors were skeptical.

title: Dylan Paintings Draw Scrutiny
description: The freewheeling artistic style of Bob Dylan, who has drawn on a variety of sources in creating his music and has previously raised questions of attribution in his work, is once again stirring debate  this time over an exhibition of his paintings at the Gagosian Gallery on the Upper East Side.

title: Replacements Help Re-energize Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Mario Manningham was confined to the sofa Sunday, a concussion leaving him little choice but to watch his team play the Philadelphia Eagles alongside his girlfriend and his 15-month-old son, Mario Jr.

title: Alcohol Isnt Worth the Trouble for Some Chain Restaurants
description: Some restaurant chains are turning to the bottle during the rough economy, but the liquoring up has produced mostly headaches, not happiness.

title: Bloggingheads: Endless Progress
description: John Horgan, left, of Scientific American and David Deutsch of the University of Oxford discuss the future of human progress.

title: A Better Way to Fix No Child Left Behind
description: Washington

title: A Diversity Bake Sale Backfires on Campus
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  A bake sale sponsored by a Republican student group at the University of California, Berkeley, has incited anger and renewed the debate over affirmative action by asking students to pay different prices for pastry, depending on their race and sex.

title: To Save on Health Care, First Crack Down on Fraud
description: Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Gas Flaring in North Dakota
description: Every day across the western half of North Dakota 100 million cubic feet of natural gas is deliberately burned by oil companies rushing to extract oil from the Bakken shale field and take advantage of the high price of crude. The gas bubbles up alongside the oil, and with less economic incentive to capture it, the drillers treat the gas as waste and simply burn it.

title: Declaring an Arrival, With a Little Help From New Yorkers
description: EVERYONE recognizes I  NY and its variants like I (Red Cross) NY, I (Tropicana orange) NY and I (Apple) NY. An initiative to mark the arrival of a Chicago agency in New York City takes the form of I (cursor) NY.

title: Facebook iPad App Still Snagged in Negotiations
description: It was almost ready to make its long-awaited debut.

title: Factory Field Trip
description: Charlotte, N.C.

title: Hotel Rates, in Some Cities, Seem Fully Recovered
description: MONDAY morning, I was looking out my home office window in Tucson at Big Red, parked beside a 25-foot saguaro. Big Red is my beloved 1994 Ford F-150 pickup truck, purchased last winter for $500 from friends who were no longer using it. It has 298,818 miles on the odometer, and it still runs beautifully  like any good old F-150.

title: A Governing Coalition, Increasingly, of the Unwilling
description: LONDON  With the leaders of both parties in the governing coalition pledged to uphold their pact until a new election in 2015, Britain, at least on the face of it, has the basis for political stability as it wrestles with the financial crisis roiling Europe and the apparent drift of Britains own economy toward stagnation.

title: Red Sox Stagger, Trip and Fall Into a Tie
description: BALTIMORE  Boston Red Sox fans were already making their presence felt by midafternoon Monday, in the bars across the street from Camden Yards, or circling the ballpark perimeter, red-shirted and red-faced over their sad September state of affairs.

title: After Feisty Fund-Raising, a More Sociable Obama
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  President Obama met his dream date on Monday at a town hall meeting in Silicon Valley: a balding, soft-spoken former Google employee who said he was so rich he did not have to work anymore and begged Mr. Obama to raise his taxes.

title: Managers Pushed for Fake Job-Placement Numbers, Ex-Workers Say
description: Despite the downturn in the economy, our Workforce1 career centers are on pace to match last years record-setting total of more than 17,000 job placements. But we can do more.

title: In Turn to Politics, Facebook Starts a PAC
description: Facebook wants more friends. And it is willing to pay for them.

title: Medal of Honor Recipient Gets Extension for Fire Dept. Application
description: A Marine who fought his way into an ambush in Afghanistan to rescue dozens of people wants to continue to save people by becoming a New York City firefighter.

title: Braves Feel Pressure but Cant Avoid a Loss
description: ATLANTA  The Braves were laughing early Monday evening. If such behavior sounds odd for a team in free fall, well, you have not seen the backup catcher David Rosss impressions of characters from the comedy Major League.

title: Alimony in Massachusetts Gets Overhaul, With Limits
description: BOSTON  Gov. Deval Patrick on Monday signed into law new limits on alimony in Massachusetts, sharply curbing lifetime alimony payments in divorce cases and making a series of other changes to a system that critics considered outdated.

title: Wealthy, Influential, Leaning Republican and Pushing a Christie Bid for President
description: They are rich. They are unattached. They are looking for a little excitement.

title: Contract Negotiations With Ford Intensify as the Union Prepares for a Strike
description: DETROIT  Contract talks between the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company intensified Monday, but the union was preparing for a strike in case a deal could not be reached.

title: How to Mimic Berkshires Bet
description: Warren Buffett isnt too old to try something new. His Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate said on Monday that it might buy back an unlimited amount of both classes of shares, at up to a 10 percent premium over book value. Many investors like to copy what Mr. Buffett does, but stock repurchases are best left to the Oracle of Omaha. If shares of other companies were truly undervalued, Berkshire probably wouldnt be buying its own.

title: The Lost Decade?
description: If you want a big swig of despair, listen to the people who know something about the global economy. Roger Altman, a former deputy Treasury secretary, is arguing that America and Europe are on the verge of a disastrous double-dip recession. Various economists say it will be at least another three years before we see serious job growth. Others say European banks are teetering  if not now, then early next year.

title: Freezing in the Arctic and Sweating in Sudan, but on Time in Chicago
description: IVE been traveling all my life. Its part of my DNA, and in many ways defines me and the work of my family.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Pentagon Budget and the Deficit
description: It was not just two mismanaged wars and trillions of dollars in misconceived and poorly supervised weapons contracts that drove Pentagon spending to unsustainable levels over the past decade  about $700 billion for last year alone. Military pay, benefit and retirement costs rose by more than 50 percent over the same decade (accounting for inflation). Leaving aside Afghanistan and Iraq, those costs now account for nearly $1 out of every $3 the Pentagon spends.

title: Trouble With Marijuana Arrests
description: Commissioner Raymond Kelly of the New York Police Department came forthwith too little, too late when he issued a memo directing officers not to arrest people caught with small amounts of marijuana unless the drug is in plain public view. A 1977 law decriminalized minor possession, yet tens of thousands are arrested every year.

title: Critiqued by Namath, Ryan Stands Ground
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan has never been one to bite his tongue. His unconditional confidence borders on irritating cockiness to some, and he is not afraid to express his opinion that the Jets are the best team in the N.F.L.

title: Bully for Garibaldi
description: The tiny Mediterranean island of Caprera, near Sardinia, was not the sort of place to find an American diplomat in the late summer of 1861, but thats precisely where Henry Shelton Sanford landed late in the afternoon of Sept. 8. It had been a long, involved trip: he came from Brussels to Genoa by train, secretly chartered a ship to avoid public notice and, on the night of Sept. 7, sailed through the Ligurian Sea to Sardinia. Landing late the next day, he hired a small boat to take him to Caprera, then walked more than a mile on a narrow path across the rocky, windswept island.

title: Saudi Arabia and Its Women
description: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia deserves credit for his long overdue decision to give women the right to vote, to run in municipal elections and to be appointed as full voting members of the Majlis Al-Shura, a government advisory group. It is a first step toward moving his country into the modern world but not nearly enough.

title: Pakistanis Tied to 2007 Border Attack on Americans
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A group of American military officers and Afghan officials had just finished a five-hour meeting with their Pakistani hosts in a village schoolhouse settling a border dispute when they were ambushed  by the Pakistanis.

title: Council Plans to Investigate Digital Effort by the Mayor
description: The City Council said Monday that it would investigate cost overruns and delays in the Bloomberg administrations project of modernizing the personnel system for the municipal work force.

title: In North Dakota, Flames of Wasted Natural Gas Light the Prairie
description: NEW TOWN, N.D.  Across western North Dakota, hundreds of fires rise above fields of wheat and sunflowers and bales of hay. At night, they illuminate the prairie skies like giant fireflies.

title: Climate Change and the Exodus of Species
description: To most humans, so far, climate change is still more of an idea than an experience. For other species, it is an immediate reality. Many will be left behind as the climate alters, unable to move quickly enough or with nowhere to move to. Others are already adapting. An iconic example of these swift changes is the recent discovery that Atlantic and Pacific populations of bowhead whales  long kept apart by the frozen Arctic  are now overlapping in the open waters of the Northwest Passage.

title: Cities With the Highest Poverty Rates in 2010
description: Percentage of the population living in poverty.

title: Reading, Pa., Knew It Was Poor. Now It Knows Just How Poor.
description: READING, Pa.  The exhausted mothers who come to the Second Street Learning Center here  a day care provider for mostly low-income families  speak of low wages, hard jobs and an economy gone bad.

title: Can I Get One Sheet of the Lady Gagas ...
description: Lets face it: the United States Postal Service has not been known for its pizazz in stamp design. But starting next year, along with weather vanes and bonsai plants, there may be some startling new options for those who choose to pay their bills by mail and send their love letters sealed with a kiss.

title: Mets Loss Takes Back Seat to Reyess 3 Hits
description: The final series of the Mets season opened Monday night at Citi Field, and even though the outcomes will be irrelevant, the games have taken on an added dimension because of the interest surrounding a singular player: Jose Reyes.

title: Fighters Enter Qaddafi Stronghold City as Toll Rises
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Fighters battling Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis loyalists on Monday entered the coastal city of Surt from the east as residents fleeing the besieged city, one of the loyalists few remaining strongholds, warned of an escalating toll from the fighting.

title: Leaders of Labor Coalition Deny Bat-Swinging Extortion
description: Two leaders of a minority labor coalition pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges that they used their organization, United Hispanic Construction Workers, as a baseball-bat-wielding criminal enterprise that threatened and extorted its way onto construction sites across Manhattan and the Bronx over the last 16 years.

title: Paying for Security
description: The Obama administrations proposal to raise the security fee for air travelers  part of its overall plan to reduce the budget deficit  has reignited a debate over who should pay the bill for aviation security: airlines and their passengers, or all taxpayers.

title: Doors Swinging Open
description: Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Palestinians Security Council Application Goes to a Committee
description: The Security Council decided to meet on Wednesday morning to refer the Palestinian membership application to the Councils membership committee. All 15 Council members have a representative on the committee. Given the sensitivity and interest of the issue, it will be heavy with ambassadors this time around, diplomats said. Even as the review is proceeding, both the United States and the Palestinians have been lobbying over the eventual vote in the Council, which is still weeks if not months away. Should the Palestinians fail to muster the nine votes they need to move their application forward, the United States will not be put in the awkward position of vetoing the membership bid.

title: Tuesday: Beatle Lover
description: Administrivial Comment Alert!  Its time once again to feed the moderating emus in the back room, so the comment section of Wordplay will be down from 11:30 P.M. E.T. Monday through mid-morning E.T Tuesday. You will be able to read comments during that time, but will not be able to leave a comment. Thanks for your patience and please feel free to discuss the puzzle both before and after those times. UPDATE: The emus are still hungry, so commentary might be sparse for the time being. Thanks for your patience and we hope to have this restored soon.

title: In Consultants Trial, Defense Attacks Mayor
description: The story of how a Republican political consultant came to be accused of stealing more than $1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in 2009 can be traced to the mayors re-election campaign in 2005, a lawyer for the consultant said on Monday.

title: Jessy Dixon, Gospel Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 73
description: Jessy Dixon, a singer and songwriter who helped popularize gospel music with his energetic style and who found a wider audience touring and recording with Paul Simon, died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 73.

title: Lawyers Say Strauss-Kahn Is Covered by Immunity
description: Lawyers for Dominique Strauss-Kahn are asking a judge to dismiss a sexual-assault lawsuit against him, saying he was entitled to immunity under a United Nations convention that protects the heads of specialized agencies.

title: On Defense, Jets Resolve to Restore Reputation
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Through three games, a pattern has emerged for the Jets defense. When it faces an overmatched quarterback playing without his top receiving option, the Jets win by 29 points. When it faces experienced quarterbacks flanked by multiple big-play threats, the Jets wobble and lurch, casting their reputation into doubt.

title: Obama Aide Takes Top Spot in Re-election Campaign
description: Another senior aide to President Obama plans to leave the White House for a top spot in his re-election campaign as the White House continues to shift into election mode.

title: Goldman Sachs Draws Up Deeper Cuts
description: Goldman Sachs, bracing for what could be one of its worst quarters since it went public 12 years ago, is preparing to expand its cost-cutting initiative by hundreds of millions of dollars, a move that could lead to additional job losses at the Wall Street bank.

title: Thefts of Electronic Devices on Subways Rise
description: If the sight of New Yorkers using their iPhones and iPads on the subway has become ubiquitous, so too has a criminal corollary: thefts of such devices on the subway continue to rise, especially on weekends.

title: Video Shows Washington Monument During Earthquake
description: The National Park Service said Monday that the Washington Monument would remain closed indefinitely because of damage sustained in a 5.8-magnitude earthquake that rattled the East Coast in August.

title: Wall Street Demonstrations Test Police Trained for Bigger Threats
description: When members of the loose protest movement known as Occupy Wall Street began a march from the financial district to Union Square on Saturday, the participants seemed relatively harmless, even as they were breaking the law by marching in the street without a permit.

title: Douglas LaChance, Who Led Newspaper Deliverers Union, Dies at 69
description: Douglas LaChance, who led the powerful union that represented New York City newspaper deliverers in the 1980s and 90s and whose crafty, two-fisted approach led to a prison term on racketeering and extortion charges, died on Wednesday, in Long Beach, N.Y. He was 69.

title: SecondMarket, an Exchange Without the Volatility
description: Francis Specker/Bloomberg NewsBarry Silbert, chief executive of SecondMarket.

title: Corrections: September 27
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Wangari Maathai
description: Dr. Maathai, the first African woman to win a Nobel Peace Prize, died at the age of 71.

title: Is New Yorks Tech Boom Sustainable?
description: The battle royale brewing between New York and Silicon Valley to be the nations dominant epicenter for tech innovation and hot start-ups wages on.

title: Mo Rothman Dies at 92; Revived Interest in Charlie Chaplin
description: Mo Rothman, a film executive and entrepreneur who was instrumental in reviving interest in Charlie Chaplins movies in the 1970s, and who orchestrated the aging stars triumphant return to the United States in 1972 after a bitter, self-imposed exile of 20 years, died on Sept. 15 in Los Angeles. He was 92.

title: Yanks Set Own Agenda as Division Rivals Battle to Finish
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  It was a night for cheering at Tropicana Field on Monday  for the exploits on the field and for events taking place in Baltimore that were illuminated on the out-of-town scoreboard.

title: A Way to Make Motor Fuel Out of Wood? Add Water
description: A Georgia company says it has overcome a major roadblock in turning agricultural waste into vehicle fuel and other useful chemicals by experimenting with a technology that treats the waste with compressed water heated to very high temperatures.

title: Freddie Mac Loan Deal Defective, Report Says
description: Freddie Mac used a flawed analysis when it accepted $1.35 billion from Bank of America to settle claims that the bank misled it about loans purchased during the mortgage boom, according to an oversight report scheduled for release on Tuesday.

title: More Gloom Lies Ahead for Cities, Report Says
description: Nearly a third of the nations cities are laying off workers this year. More than half have canceled or delayed infrastructure projects. And two out of five have raised their fees.

title: College Graduation Rates Are Stagnant Even as Enrollment Rises, a Study Finds
description: A report to be released on Tuesday by a group seeking to raise college graduation rates shows that despite decades of steadily climbing enrollment rates, the percentage of students making it to the finish line is barely budging.

title: Word of the Day | thrifty
description: thrifty \thrif-te\ adjective

title: Nagging Fears on Europe Slow a Wall Street Rally
description: Is the rally in the markets showing signs of ending?

title: What Avery and Simmonds Said, in Their Own Words
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Rangers had already started boarding the buses that would take them to the Philadelphia airport and from there to Prague on Monday night as Wayne Simmonds was answering reporters questions about the homophobic slur he may have used against Sean Avery.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
description: 10 Janpath was abuzz on Monday as Congress Party President Sonia Gandhi held separate meetings with Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee and Home Minister P. Chidambaram (Indian Express). The meetings were related to controversy over a note sent by the Finance Ministry, which suggested that Chidambaram  in his previous role as finance minister  failed to check ex-Telecom Minister A. Raja, the man at the heart of the 2G scam. Will Sonias involvement quell war (Times of India)?

title: NYT Front Page for 09/27/11
description: NYT Front Page for 09/27/11

title: A Conversation With Rajendra K. Pachauri
description: Rajendra K. Pachauri is the chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and head of The Energy and Resources Institute (TERI) in New Delhi, a non-profit focusing on research in the field of energy efficiency and sustainable development.

title: Australia Says It Will Open Combat Roles to Women
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australias female soldiers will soon be able to serve in all front-line combat roles, the government announced on Tuesday.

title: Champions League Tuesday Preview: Citys Strutting, Bayerns Cruising, Uniteds Limping
description: Tuesday brings eight more games on the second matchday of the group stage in the UEFA Champions League. Manchester City will be out to prove something, Manchester United will be out to avoid more injuries, and Ajax and Real Madrid will get together and talk about the good old days when everyone agreed they both played prettier soccer than Barcelona.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 27, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 27, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, Divers Set Sights on Silver-Laden WWII Ship.

title: September 27, 1964 | Oswald Acted Alone, Says Warren Commission Report
description: On Sept. 27, 1964, the Warren Commission released its 888-page report on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. It dismissed any conspiracy theories, concluding that Lee Harvey Oswald had acted alone shooting Kennedy and Texas Gov. John Connally, and that Jack Ruby had acted alone in killing Oswald days later.

title: Saudi Women Win the Vote
description: WHO announced Sunday that women would be able to vote and run in municipal elections for the first time in the history of Saudi Arabia?

title: Hell and Back Again
description: As the Afghan war neared a decades worth of combat, casualties and headlines, the photographer and filmmaker Danfung Dennis was looking to jolt peoples consciousness.

title: Are the Web Filters at Your School Too Restrictive?

Thats two fortunate breaks at a time of need for New Jerseys club.

description: The Greek Parliament voted late Tuesday in Athens to back a hugely unpopular property tax, one of a series of new austerity measures. The vote could clear the way for a crucial injection of international financing meant to at least temporarily stave off a default on government debt.

Its a big waste and it contributes to global warming, as even oil executives concede.

The children, who the police said were living in a van with their parents, were described as being disheveled but in apparently good condition.

title: Far North of Selma, an Allotment of Civil Rights History
description: They came from fraying binders, from forgotten boxes in storage units, from cobwebbed closets. They had been in Mississippi and South Carolina and Georgia, and included a wallet-size photograph of a familiar preacher with a dream. Their destination was a drab office space in the back of a library in Queens.

title: Markit Drops Out of Race for London Clearinghouse

title: Low Consumer Confidence Suggests Hiring Is Still Weak
description: Confidence among the nations consumers stagnated near a two-year low in September, and the share of households that said it was difficult to find a job climbed to the highest level in almost three decades, a research group said on Tuesday.

title: After War, From Wife to Caregiver
description: April Marcum has joined a community of spouses, parents and partners who drop most everything in their lives to care for injured loved ones returning from war.

title: Looking After the Soldier, Back Home and Damaged
description: RAY CITY, Ga.  April and Tom Marcum were high school sweethearts who married after graduation. For years, she recalls, he was a doting husband who would leave love notes for her to discover on the computer or in her purse. Now the closest thing to notes that they exchange are the reminders she set up on his cellphone that direct him to take his medicine four times a day.

title: Wife, Mother, and Now, Caregiver
description: A growing community of spouses, parents and partners, confronted with damaged loved ones returning from war who can no longer do for themselves, drop most everything in their own lives to care for them.

title: Tuesday Reading: Coffee Linked to Less Depression in Women
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Report Says Vehicle Fuel Should Be the Priority, Not Electricity
description: Research on solar and wind power is all well and good, but a self-assessment by the Department of Energy has found that in the great scheme of energy needs, the government is not investing enough in transportation energy, an area in which those renewable power sources do not play a role.

title: Guns N Roses and Eric B. & Rakim Are Nominated for  Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
description: Guns N Roses, the hard rock band whose glory days were in the 1980s, and Eric B. & Rakim, one of the most influential rap groups of that era, were among the 15 artists nominated for induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame next year, the hall announced this morning. Both were nominated in their first year of eligibility.

title: Shanghai Subway Accident Injures Hundreds
description: SHANGHAI  Hundreds of people were injured here on Tuesday when a subway train slammed into the rear of another train in a sprawling transit line that opened just last year. The accident cast new scrutiny on the safety record of Chinas rapidly modernizing mass transit rail systems.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Goldman Sachs Draws Up Deeper Cuts | Goldman Sachs, bracing for what could be one of its worst quarters since it went public 12 years ago, is preparing to expand its cost-cutting initiative by hundreds of millions of dollars, a move that could result in additional jobs being eliminated.

title: Work in Progress
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#924", 592, 500, true, chameleonData);Paul Barbera shoots slick interiors for clients like Elle Decoration and Vogue Living. But before he ventured into the studios of the 32 designers in his new book Where They Create (Frame Publishers, $45), he begged them not to clean up. Its not like messy wall, messy table, pencil on floor and rubbish near door equals great artist, Barbera insists, but those intimate details make for rich material. Matali Crassets personal library, Maarten Baass prototypes and even the crudely fashioned cardboard strip that keeps Confetti Systems air-conditioner from jostling its hand-cut garlands reveal what its really like inside a designers world.

title: September Collapse of Red Sox Could Be Worst Ever
description: After beating the Texas Rangers on Sept. 3, the Boston Red Sox were 84-54. Although half a game behind the Yankees in the American League East, the Red Sox had a nine-game lead over the Tampa Bay Rays for the wild card and roughly a 99.6 percent chance of making the playoffs.

The loser of that battle will face the Yankees in the first round.

We are all scared of what will come next, he said, turning to a man seated beside him, Robert, an Iraqi refugee who escaped the sectarian strife in his homeland.

title: Setting the Stage for Romance
description: The artist Karen Kilimnik tends to work in small, intimate canvases and props, tackling subjects like Kate Moss or the battles of Napoleon with seeming fairy tale romance. For Psych, a new production choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky for the Paris Opera Ballet, Kilimnik started from a selection of pre-existing paintings to create five massive, dreamlike backdrops, including an enchanting, moonlit forest and a garden resplendent with clouds, flowers and perfume bottles. She then augmented these with rhinestones, glitter and, for good measure, a host of two-dimensional objects like the five-foot snail that enters and exits the stage at various points during the performance. Being able to work on this scale was a dream in itself. It was wonderful, she said.

title: A Climate Analyst Analyzes His Own Approach to CO2
description: 7:23 p.m. | Updated Robert Socolow of Princeton University has written Wedges Reaffirmed, an essay published today by The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists and Climate Central.  The piece examines lessons hes learned since he and a colleague, Stephen Pacala, co-authored Stabilization Wedges: Solving the Climate Problem for the Next 50 Years with Current Technologies in 2004. The influential paper, published in Science, divided the challenge of keeping emissions of greenhouse gases through mid-century at levels prevailing in the 2000s into seven wedges of carbon dioxide reductions  through switching to renewable and nuclear power, ramping up energy efficiency, ending deforestation and taking action in other areas. (The new essay adds two wedges because the scope of the challenge has grown in the last seven years.)

title: Do-Good Design | The Pink Swan Project
description: For the second year in a row, an iconic modernist chair has been transformed by a star-studded roster of designers to benefit the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. Following the success of its Pink Wishbone Project, in which designers put their own spin on Hans Wegners classic Wishbone chair, SUITE New York, the Manhattan design showroom that is the projects mastermind, organized the Pink Swan Project for 2011. It lets 18 A-listers in design, fashion and architecture loose on Arne Jacobsens Swan chair, which is manufactured by the Danish company Fritz Hansen. The one-of-a-kind chairs will be up for auction from Oct. 1 to Oct. 31 on CharityBuzz.

title: Kennedy Center to Replace Its Pipe Organ
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington said it would replace the long-maligned organ in its concert hall with a new 5,000-pipe instrument built by Casavant Frres of St-Hyacinthe, Quebec. The existing organ, which was built by Aeolian-Skinner and installed in 1972, has been criticized by performers and reviewers for its poor functioning and musical inadequacy. A 1997 renovation of the hall made the problems worse. It was getting to the point where it was ruining performances, said Jeff Weiler, an organ consultant hired by the Kennedy Center. The new organ will be installed starting next summer, with a 61-pipe stop incorporated from its predecessor. The instrument will cost more than $2 million, the Kennedy Center said. David M. Rubenstein, the Kennedy Centers chairman and the managing director of the Carlyle Group, a private equity firm, is paying for the new organ and its installation.

title: Koch Endorses Obama in 2012
