My take is that both restaurants in some way speak to the void left in Manhattan by the closing of Florent a few years ago. You may agree or disagree. But keep your language clean!

title: Latin Grammys to Honor Shakira
description: Shakira, the pop diva from Colombia, will be honored as the person of the year at the Latin Grammys in November. The president of the Latin Recording Academy, Gabriel Abaroa Jr., said the singer was being honored for her philanthropic work as well as her successful recording career. At 34, Shakira is the youngest person to receive the tribute from the 12-year-old group, which was formed to present a Latin version of the Grammy awards. Past recipients have included Carlos Santana, Julio Iglesias, Gloria Estefan and Ricky Martin. One of the most successful Latin artists to cross over into English-speaking radio, Shakira has won two Grammys and three Latin Grammys. She enjoyed a world-wide smash hit in 2006 with Hips Dont Lie. She has done charity work since she was 18 years old, when she started the Pies Descalzos Foundation, an organization that provides schools to poor children in Colombia.

title: The Mexican Drug Wars, on Twitter: Using Social Media for Social Action

In this lesson, students examine how social media is being used by various factions in the Mexican drug wars and then draw comparisons to other examples where people have used social networks for other causes and actions. They then develop proposals for how digital media can be used to address an issue of concern.

title: Profile in Style | Paul de Zwart
description: No stranger to brand building (he was a co-founder of Wallpaper magazine and Winkreative), the London-based entrepreneur crystallized the concept for his fledgling furniture company, Another Country, while searching for some simple bedside tables and stools for his country house. I realized there was a dearth of well-made, well-priced design with a modern craft heritage, he says. His solution? An affordable line of pared-down pieces that are handmade in England from sustainable woods. Were going for timeless over trendy. Go to anothercountry.com. See our interactive feature >>

title: Will High-Deductible Health Insurance Plans Become the Norm?
description: As the cost of health insurance continues to rise, workers can expect to see high-deductible plans, with ever-higher deductibles, becoming the norm, the president of the Kaiser Family Foundation predicts.

title: Going Public Without Going Public
description: In his column today, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes about how SecondMarket is serving as something of an eBay for shares of private companies.

title: The Toll of Politics on Well-Being
description: With Americans confidence in government at historic lows, it may not be surprising to learn that people are so fed up with politicians and politics that even talking about them makes people feel worse about their lives.

title: Europe Readies Plan for Tax on Financial Transactions
description: 6:09 p.m. | Updated

title: OnStar Backtracks on Collection of Data From Ex-Subscribers
description: Having been criticized by customers and United States senators for a week, OnStar announced Tuesday afternoon that it would not track the vehicles of customers who had canceled their subscriptions to the service. Instead, those subscribers who wanted to retain the two-way cellular connection between OnStar and their vehicles would have to opt in for the feature.

title: A Night at the Comedy Club
description: Despite Indias notorious cultural conservatism, stand up comedy is flowering in nightclubs and restaurants.

title: Should Energy Drinks Be Sold on Campus?
description: Red Bull and its energy-drink cousins have fueled many college students through long nights of paper writing. But, taking its in loco parentis duty seriously, the University of New Hampshire is considering a ban on such nonalcoholic beverage stimulants, Inside Higher Ed reported Tuesday.

title: As Like Buttons Spread, So Do Facebooks Tentacles
description: When you click a Facebook Like button on other Web sites to tell your friends about a cool band, favorite political candidate or yummy cake recipe, you may know that you are also giving intelligence to Facebook the company, which makes money through targeted advertising.

title: Experts Urge Testing of Ban on Use of Food Stamps for Soda
description: In an influential medical journal, two prominent experts on nutrition are assailing the federal governments rejection of New York Citys proposal to ban the purchase of sodas with food stamps.

title: Thinking About Sovereign Bankruptcy
description: I am just back from presenting a paper at the European Law and Economics Association annual meeting, held this year in Hamburg, Germany. And of course the topic on everyones lips at every coffee break, lunch and paper session was the Greece-French-Bank-Generalized-Euro-Zone Panic of 2011.

title: Does Economics Still Progress?
description: In a few hours Sylvia Nasar and I will have an on-stage dialogue at the 92nd Street Y, centered around her new book The Grand Pursuit, which offers a set of fascinating portraits of the makers of economics. (Irving Fisher invented the Rolodex?) But as I was reading her book I have to admit that I found myself wondering whether theres much to celebrate.

title: Another Round of Nice Chianti: Silence! The Musical to Reopen
description: Fewer tap-dancing lambs? Less cannibalism? The creators of Silence! The Musical, a theatrical parody of the 1991 film The Silence of the Lambs, have sliced 10 to 15 minutes from the production that had a popular run Off Broadway this summer in preparation for a new, open-ended engagement starting Oct. 25 at a slightly larger theater downtown, the producers of the show announced on Tuesday.

title: New Transatlantic Suitors Said to Include Former Treasury Official
description: A former government official who helped bail out the American International Group and a onetime head of General Re are part of a group that has begun merger talks with Transatlantic Holdings, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

title: Mix and Maxed
description: Ive always made stuff and wanted to know how things worked, says Bethan Laura Wood, a 28-year-old British product designer who studied under Martino Gamper and Jurgen Bey, and whose work was featured with that of her mentors at the cutting-edge Milan gallery Nilufar in April. Wood takes nuts-and-bolts materials to fantastic places; her Moon Rock tables are inlaid with laser-cut plastic laminate, as is her Particle jewelry (shown here), inspired by lowly particle board. Woods own look, a confection of glitter, pattern and wrapping, has evolved since her teen years from a defense against bullying classmates (I thought Id give them a reason) into a form of play. Look for Wood at the Pavilion of Art & Design London show this month.

title: James Rubin Abruptly Departs Bloomberg
description: 5:03 p.m. | Updated James P. Rubin, a former assistant secretary of state hired by Bloomberg News just 10 months ago to help lead its new opinion-writing section, has left his job after a rocky start.

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 27, 2011
description: Fighters for Libyas new government claimed to have seized the port in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis tribal hometown of Surt on Tuesday.

title: What Do Small-Business Owners Want?
description: Small-business owners are often described in monolithic terms. But as I rediscovered during a conversation with three women who run companies, their goals and motivations tend to vary. When I met recently with Jessica Johnson, Susan Parker and Carissa Reiniger of our newly formed business group, we talked about their long-term goals. (Alexandra Mayzler, the fourth member of the group, couldnt make the meeting.) I was particularly curious about their thoughts and attitudes about eventually exiting the companies that they or their families  in the cases of Ms. Johnson and Ms. Parker  built.

title: Summer Squash, Tahini and Yogurt Dip
description: Just when I thought I would never find anything new to do with the two small summer squash that were lingering in my refrigerator I came across this dish in Paula Wolferts book The Cooking of the Eastern Mediterranean. A simple combination of cooked squash, drained yogurt, garlic and tahini, its another example of how you can make yogurt dips with just about any vegetable.

title: D.M.V. to Drop Eye Exam for License Renewals
description: New York drivers worried about having to read a line on an eye chart to renew their license can rest easy.

title: TimesCast | September 27, 2011
description: Leaders from Greece and Germany meet to avert a Greek default; Republican donors look to Gov. Chris Christie as a presidential candidate; and engineers assess the Washington Monument for quake damage.

title: The Creations of Interpreters: Conductors as Composers
description: Unlike pianists and violinists, conductors dont start perfecting their technique as 5-year-olds. They usually start with an instrument and undertake the full rigors of musical training, including theory and composition studies, before they take up the baton for the first time. Some abandon composition early; some continue to compose throughout their conducting careers, hoping to leave a legacy that will survive them in ways that their performances will not.

title: Mche Salad With Yogurt Dressing
description: Mche is a delicate green also known as lambs lettuce, and its now available in many Whole Foods stores and other supermarkets in the United States. It has a rich nutritional profile: It is very high in vitamin C, beta carotene, omega-3s and iron (it has even more than spinach). I love the contrast here between the mild, subtle mche and the sharp, pungent garlic-spiked yogurt.

title: Israel Angers Palestinians With Plan for Housing
description: JERUSALEM  Israel announced plans on Tuesday for 1,100 new housing units in an area of South Jerusalem outside Israels pre-1967 boundaries. The move reflects Israels continued rejection of Palestinian demands for a halt in settlement construction as a condition for peace talks.

title: Suge Knight to Produce Soundtrack for Showtime Documentary About Suge Knight
description: Suge Knight, the founder of Death Row Records who played a leading role during a turbulent and violent period of hip-hop history, will the be subject of a feature-length documentary on Showtime, the network announced Tuesday. The filmmakers said Mr. Knight had agreed to give extensive interviews about his life and the rapid rise and slow fall of his record label; he is also producing a soundtrack for the film. The film will be directed by Antoine Fuqua, who directed Training Day and Brooklyns Finest, and will be produced by Bradley J. Fischer, who produced Black Swan and Shutter Island. No release date has been announced.

title: For Investors, Russias Putin Is Good for Business
description: MOSCOW  A consensus is emerging among bankers, economists and companies that evaluate market risk that the return of Vladimir V. Putin as Russias president will be a net positive for foreign investors  regardless of whether they support the politics of it.

title: For Christie, Speculation Has Rewards  and Risks
description: Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, has been swept up in a high-stakes political game of will-he-or-wont-he that has already delivered him valuable rewards, but also carries the threat of potent risks.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, the Philippines and China.

title: An Unearthed Treasure That Changed Things
description: The literary critic, theorist and Shakespeare scholar Stephen Greenblatts new book, The Swerve: How the World Became Modern, is partly about an obsessive book collector, and it begins, appropriately enough, with a book purchase of the authors own.

title: Reduced Role for Rooney on 60 Minutes
description: Andy Rooney, whose folksy and often curmudgeonly essays have been a staple of 60 Minutes for more than three decades, will end his regular weekly appearances on the program, CBS said Tuesday.

title: Blending the Unfamiliar With the Ordinary Is a Recipe for Selling Out the Show
description: Among the reasons that the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center could call the concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday a gala was that it opened a new season. That was accurate, but also mundane. Looking around the auditorium, you were confronted with a more compelling cause for celebration: on a Monday night, offering a program largely comprising unfamiliar works, the society had sold every available seat.

title: Using His Noodle
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#413", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Anna Bolena at the Metropolitan Opera
description: The companys first production of this breakthrough Donizetti work from 1830 was led by the soprano Anna Netrebko as the titular Anna.

title: A Perfectly Civil Encounter Between an Activist and a Lawyer
description: Anyone expecting to see sparks fly when the activist investor Barry Rosenstein met Martin Lipton, the father of corporate defense strategies, for the first time on Tuesday might have mistaken the pair seated onstage as a jovial father-son pair.

title: Our Lives Are So Similar. Oh, Were Married!
description: Kenneth Tynan was among the first English critics to recognize how influential Eugne Ionesco was going to be, and one of the first to panic about it.

title: Echoes Greet Tampa Bays Historic Charge
description: The idea of the Tampa Bay area as a great baseball market hasnt been in vogue for a long time, perhaps as long ago as the second game in franchise history in 1998, which didnt sell out.

title: Two Aides to Weiner Find a Home in the Bloomberg Administration
description: Former Representative Anthony D. Weiner may have dashed his chances of becoming New Yorks next mayor, but two of his former aides are going to work at City Hall anyway, for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Watchlist: A New Truth Is Out There
description: If youre looking for the next big thing  O.K., the next pretty decent thing  in original online video, youll want to check out RCVR, a science-fiction series from Machinima thats posting new episodes on Wednesdays. (No. 2 goes up this week.)

title: Street Style Photos: Trench Coats
description: The best of readers street fashion submissions for the week of Sept. 19.

title: A Blurry Look at the Child Prisoner of Guantnamo
description: Painfully stark yet utterly magnetic, You Dont Like the Truth: 4 Days Inside Guantnamo presents excerpts from the 2003 interrogation of the 16-year-old Omar Khadr, a Canadian citizen accused of killing an American soldier during a firefight in an Afghan village.

title: Foo Fighters in Concert
description: On Monday night at the Izod Center Dave Grohl stood on a 20-foot riser alone with an acoustic guitar. His vulpine teeth flashed, and his black dress-shirt was soaked through. He hadnt changed it during the break.

title: Theyve Arrived, Like Old Times
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the second half of This Is a Call, the forthcoming biography of Dave Grohl written by the British journalist Paul Brannigan, the narrative shifts completely and some new motifs emerge. That shift comes after the violent end of Nirvana, in which Mr. Grohl played drums, loudly and elegantly; its when the book becomes the story of the Foo Fighters, the band Mr. Grohl started in 1994 and built into a major work of commerce.

title: Wrap Yourself in Noodles
description: ONE thing that makes New York a great food city: last years exotic becomes this years everyday. Now, news that an excellent ramen joint with house-made broth has opened in Midtown can be processed calmly, without the hysterical excitement that can lead to disappointment.

title: How Climate Change Could Hurt Yellowstone National Park
description: Before the end of the century, Yellowstone National Park could experience summers that feel like Los Angeless, according to a report released Tuesday. These warming temperatures will imperil everything from native cutthroat trout to aspen forests and the $700 million in annual economic activity that they and other gems in the park generate by attracting tourists, the report said.

title: Anna Bolena at the Metropolitan Opera
description: The companys first production of this breakthrough Donizetti work from 1830 was led by the soprano Anna Netrebko as the titular Anna.

title: Girardi Flips Cano and Teixeira in Yankees Lineup
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Only four days before the start of the playoffs, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi switched around his lineup Tuesday night, swapping Mark Teixeira and Robinson Cano in the batting order. Teixeira, who had batted third most of the season, was dropped to fifth, with Cano taking Teixeiras place as the No. 3 hitter.

title: Mr. Watson. Come Here. The A Train Is Running Late.
description: For Kym Bernazky, it began with a familiar bubble. She sent back a bubble of her own.

title: Europe Nears Agreement on Bailout Fund That May Be Inadequate
description: PARIS  Angela Merkel, Germanys chancellor, finds herself once again in the politically perilous position of balancing the future of Europe and its common currency against a German public that is unhappy at the price the country will have to pay. And, as before, as the euro crisis has unfolded, she finds herself fighting for measures that most experts have already dismissed as inadequate.

title: The Visual Languages of an Emmy Award Winner
description: On Monday night, The New York Timess multimedia project A Year at War won an Emmy Award in the New Approaches to News and Documentary Programming category for current news. The interactive series chronicles the lives of a single American battalion over their yearlong deployment in Afghanistan.

title: Lumire | The Louvre Less Traveled
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#54", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Company Pays $1.3 Million for Tavern on the Greens Name
description: A licensing company has agreed to pay $1.3 million to use the name Tavern on the Green for restaurants outside metropolitan New York, under a deal approved by Taverns bankruptcy trustee.

title: TimesCast | Christie for President?
description: September 27, 2011 - Prominent Republican donors try to draft New Jersey Governor Chris Christie into the presidential campaign.

title: Excerpt: 'Suburgatory'
description: The ABC sitcom is about a father and daughter who move to an oddball suburb.

title: Old World Flair for American-Made Cheese
description: Everyday mozzarella seem dull next to burrata, a pouch of mozzarella enclosing cream and mozzarella shreds. Its mainly been imported. But Maplebrook Fine Cheese in Bennington, Vt., is one of a growing number of American cheesemakers doing their own stretching and filling. Domenico Marchitelli who came here from Apulia, the home of burrata, makes an excellent one for them.

title: Brief Dramatic Encounters
description: One measure of success for a festival of microplays is how much it frustrates. Each work is so short, the theatrical equivalent of speed dating. How often do you find yourself wishing for more time with the disparate characters whizzing by?

title: Ruling Limits Financial Exposure of Mets Owners
description: A federal judge awarded both sides a partial victory Tuesday in the $1 billion lawsuit brought against the owners of the Mets by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff  allowing the suit to go forward, but limiting how much money the trustee may ultimately be able to recover.

title: Drugs, Risk and the Myth of the Evil Addict
description: My column on making Naloxone available over-the-counter to reverse overdoses drew many plaudits and two main strands of criticism. One group argued that addicts arent worth saving and we need to cut the drug supply; the other said that Naloxone, also known by its brand name, Narcan, is too risky to be available without a prescription.

title: The Sticks, With Jet Propulsion
description: Its no coincidence that the last two months have brought television shows with Hillbilly, Truck Stop and Rednecks in their titles. Or that seemingly half the new reality series this summer and fall are set in Texas.

title: Mitten Alert: Canadians Come to SoHo
description: IN the 1960s, the United States underwent the British invasion, experienced sartorially via white go-go boots, Mary Quant miniskirts and jagged haircuts by Vidal Sassoon. Fifty years later, we have the mop-topped Canadian Justin Bieber and the concomitant fashion contributions of  what? American Apparel, founded by the puckish Montrealer Dov Charney? Club Monaco, conceived in Toronto? Clompy John Fluevog footwear?

title: Newsboy Strike? Sing All About It
description: With its spring-loaded backflips, airborne spins, rambunctious kicks and balletic pivots, the athletic ensemble in Newsies the Musical, which opened on Sunday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., puts up a persuasive struggle against corporate greed. But the irrepressible physicality of that scrappy band of ragamuffins is just part of what turns this canny stage transformation of Disneys 1992 big-screen misfire into a crowd pleaser.

title: Little Miss Sunshine and American Psycho Musicals Get Starry New York Readings
description: Two closely watched musicals under development  stage adaptations of the film Little Miss Sunshine and of the novel-turned-movie American Psycho  have been moving forward recently, theater executives familiar with both projects said on Tuesday.

title: TimesCast | Euro Debt Crisis
description: Greek and German leaders meet in Berlin to bolster confidence and avert a Greek debt default.

title: Our New Emmy
description: Last night, we were thrilled to win a News and Documentary Emmy for our portfolio Fourteen Actors Acting. Congratulations are also in order to the New York Times team that won an Emmy for the series A Year at War.

title: Making Sense of a Tidal Wave of Data
description: Bernard Coakley, a marine geologist with the University of Alaska at Fairbanks, writes from the Arctic Ocean, where his team is reconstructing the geologic history of the Chukchi Shelf and the Chukchi Borderland.

title: Dining Calendar
description: The Flavors of Africa

title: Reactions to a New Plan for CO2 Progress
description: Earlier today I posted an essay by Robert Socolow, a seasoned energy and climate analyst at Princeton University, in which he proposes a new approach to overcoming resistance to actions that could limit emissions of greenhouse gases even as humanitys energy appetite grows in coming decades.

title: Bosnian Food in St. Louis
description: Inside a few of the food shops and restaurants that Bosnians have opened in St. Louis, nearly two decades after refugees fled the former Yugoslavia.

title: Foods of Their Homeland, Now Mainstreamed
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Roger Ebert: What Is Criticism For?
description: Part 2: The celebrated film critic reflects on the purpose of film criticism and explains what hes tried to achieve with his reviews.

title: Roger Ebert: An Instant Mutual Sympathy
description: Part 10: The celebrated film critic discusses his friendships with the filmmakers Werner Herzog and Ramin Bahrani.

title: TimesTalks | Roger Ebert: Preview
description: The celebrated film critic talks about his illness, his long career writing about the movies and his memoir, Life Itself.

title: Roger Ebert: 3-D Is an Abomination
description: Part 9: The celebrated film critic shares his thoughts on whether there are any good 3-D movies and if video games can be art.

title: Roger Ebert: Talking Through the Camera
description: Part 6: The celebrated film critic explains the factors that made reviewing films on a TV show a challenge.

title: Roger Ebert: Life Is a Learning Process
description: Part 11: The celebrated film critic shares which movies have meant the most to him during his illness and throughout his life.

title: Roger Ebert: Learning on the Job
description: Part 4: The celebrated film critic reminisces about his early days as a movie reviewer and talks about how the discipline has evolved.

title: Roger Ebert: The Siskel and Ebert Game
description: Part 5: The celebrated film critic reflects on his relationship with the critic Gene Siskel.

title: Roger Ebert: Theres Always Been Junk
description: Part 8: The celebrated film critic talks about his nostalgia for classic films and how streaming technologies are changing the way people watch movies.

title: Roger Ebert: Life Itself
description: Part 7: The celebrated film critic talks about what his illness has taught him, and explains what led him to write a memoir.

title: Roger Ebert: Becoming a Blogger
description: Part 3: The celebrated film critic talks about how his illness led him to discover a new medium and transformed his writing.

title: Roger Ebert: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the film critic Roger Ebert.

title: Newsies the Musical
description: Photos of the show at the Paper Mill Playhouse.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Salad With Stone Fruit, Blue Cheese and Chicken Skin
description: Adapted from Mitch Prensky, Supper, Philadelphia

title: Flooded Farmers Learn to Be Creative
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y.

title: All About Apples (and Eating Them)
description: Autumn is not only apple season, its also apple book season. The handsome Apple Lovers Cookbook has a section covering 59 kinds of apples with a description and color portrait of each. A one-page rundown lists apples according to taste and texture; there is apple history, and summaries of apple festivals, apple products, ciders and apples by mail. The heart of the book gives savory and sweet recipes, including an adaptation of Michael Fields chicken liver pt with apple. And the challah baked with diced apples and raisins falls into the category of Why didnt I think of that?

title: In Debate About Food, a Monied New Player
description: LAST week, a new public-relations campaign about agriculture got off to a splashy start. With full-page ads in newspapers and panel discussions live-streamed on the Internet, the newly formed U.S. Farmers and Ranchers Alliance began what it called a bid to reshape the dialogue about the American food supply.

title: Upstate Butchers Come to Brooklyn
description: Jessica and Joshua Applestone made their name butchering pasture-raised beef, pork and lamb, and teaching others the art, in their shop in Kingston, N.Y. Now they have a store in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Fresh meat from upstate is available as steaks or chops, or cut to order. They also carry organic poultry, 14 kinds of sausages, offal and veal from time to time, and will have turkeys for Thanksgiving. They cure their own bacon. Prepared foods like chili, stocks, pot pies and meatloaf are also sold. The manager, Jason Fox, above right, with Mr. Applestone, above left, and Bryan Mayer, a butcher, encourages customers to order in advance.

title: Chickens Attraction Is Truly Skin Deep
description: THERE are white-meat people and there are dark-meat people; there are those who swear by the drumstick, thigh or breast.

title: Trailer: Footloose (2011)
description: A preview of the 2011 remake of "Footloose."

title: Seizing Populist Mantle, Obama Pushes Jobs Bill
description: DENVER  After two days of energetically raising money in the rarefied precincts of Hollywood and Silicon Valley, President Obama stopped at a big-city high school here on Tuesday to push for new ways to spend money.

title: A Grittier Soul, but a Remake Fans Will Recognize
description: FOR members of a certain generation there are few movie moments more perfect than the scene of Kevin Bacon in a white tank top and jeans working out his adolescent angst against a warehouse backdrop. His compact body slides by the grimy walls, and his white sneakers pop while Moving Pictures Never blares. (Listen closely, and you can still hear the echo of squeals in response.) But almost 30 years have passed since Footloose came out and teenagers of a new era are more likely to ask: Kevin who?

title: A $50 Billion Claim of Havoc Looms for Bank of America
description: Bank of Americas potential liability for bad mortgages  in the tens of billions of dollars  is well known. But Bank of America is haunted by other demons from the financial crisis, the most significant one being a lawsuit arising from its troubled Merrill Lynch acquisition.

title: Hitting Machine Slows: Suzukis Streak Nears an End
description: It was the first thing that Raul Ibanez wanted to discuss. It was all that Jack Wilson was thinking about, too.

title: Justices Will Hear Appeals on Immigrants Residence
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to decide whether the length of immigrants lawful residence in the United States should be considered in determining whether their children may be deported.

title: Governing by Crisis
description: Thanks to some good luck and expert government accountants, the Federal Emergency Management Agency will limp, exhausted and nearly broke, to the end of the fiscal year on Friday. That removes its budget as the latest excuse for House Republicans to slash domestic programs they dont like and momentarily defuses their threat to shut down the entire government to get their way.

title: Three-Pronged Plan to Rescue Europe
description: For the rest of Europe to protect itself against a Greek default, it needs a three-pronged plan of attack. It ought to include as much as 200 billion euros to recapitalize banks across the region; extra liquidity, again for banks; and a beefed-up bailout fund to help Italy, if needed. The drumbeats suggest Europe is moving in that direction. But, as always, the fear is that it will be too timid.

title: Which Putin Will Emerge in New Presidency?
description: MOSCOW  We know Vladimir V. Putin will rule Russia for the foreseeable future. The question is, which Mr. Putin?

title: Googles Biggest Threat Is Google
description: Google faces antitrust inquiries and competition from all corners. But its biggest threat is Google itself, Larry Page, its chief executive and co-founder, said Tuesday.

title: Backing Indie Bands to Sell Cars
description: A crowd of young music fans gathered outside the Roxy Theater in Hollywood one Saturday afternoon recently, jostling for free T-shirts. As Repulsion, a band of the grisly heavy-metal style known as grindcore, blasted through songs like Pestilent Decay and Splattered Cadavers, dozens of fans on their way in and out of the club scooped up the garments, printed with a gory design typical of the genre.

title: The Assassination Next Door
description: FOR the last nine years, I have lived part time in Afghanistan, in a house in the Wazir Akbar Khan neighborhood of Kabul. In the past, when I gave directions to my house, I mentioned the well-known landmark next door: the home of Burhanuddin Rabbani, the head of the High Peace Council and a former president and leader of the mujahedeen. As Afghanistans security situation has steadily deteriorated, people have been more and more hesitant to visit me; few of my acquaintances wanted to risk being near the home of the man responsible for trying to negotiate peace with the Taliban.

title: Placing a Bet on Brazil
description: MEXICO CITY  As the United States and Europe face a bleak financial reality, Latin America hums along with continued growth and optimistic predictions for the next few years.

title: This War Can Still Be Won
description: Washington

title: Short-Term Fixes That Take Time and Resolve Little
description: WASHINGTON  It was a telling moment Monday night when Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, called a deal to keep the government open for a few more weeks a win for everyone.

title: Political Waves From a Solar Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Researching the Sneeze and How to Handle It
description: THE paper products aisle generally is not seasonal, with consumers using about the same amount of toilet paper, napkins or paper towels every month. But not so with facial tissue: as cold and flu season rears its congested head, monthly sales increase as much as 65 percent over the summer months.

title: Cellphones in the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Street Stops by the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Data and the Quality of Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida: Customs Chief Arrested in Pornography Case
description: The head of Immigration and Customs Enforcement for South Florida was arrested Tuesday on child pornography charges. Anthony V. Mangione, 50, who led the Miami-based office since 2007, was placed on paid administrative leave in April after federal agents seized his home computer and began to investigate images of alleged child pornography. Mr. Mangione, a 27-year veteran of ICE and its precursor, the United States Customs Service, is expected to appear in federal court in Fort Lauderdale on Wednesday. The agency has made cracking down on child pornography a priority, and as chief of the South Florida regional office, Mr. Mangione was aggressive in his efforts. Too many children are victimized by predators that target the most vulnerable among us  our children, Mr. Mangione said in a 2009 news release about the sentencing of a man on pornography charges. The Justice Department and the F.B.I. declined to comment on the case.

title: For Hackers, the Next Lock to Pick
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hackers have broken into the cellphones of celebrities like Scarlett Johansson and Prince William. But what about the rest of us, who might not have particularly salacious photos or voice messages stored in our phones, but nonetheless have e-mails, credit card numbers and records of our locations?

title: Shared Meals, Shared Knowledge
description: This year, Slow Food USA, which defines slow food as good for its eaters, its producers and the environment  a definition anyone can get behind  set out to demonstrate that slow food can also be affordable, not only a better alternative to fast food but a less expensive one. The organization issued a $5 Challenge with the inspired rallying cry of take back the value meal, which in most fast food restaurants runs somewhere around five bucks.

title: Mets Have Major Objection to a Yankee Team in Newark
description: On paper, it was the perfect solution. The Yankees Class AAA affiliate would play next season in Newark while its stadium near Scranton, Pa., was renovated. Players would be a short drive from Yankee Stadium, and fans would be able to see the teams budding stars for a fraction of the price of going to a game in the Bronx.

title: Survey Sees Major Expansion of Worlds Data Centers
description: The next great expansion of the worlds digital infrastructure is under way in developing markets like those of China, Brazil and Argentina, according to a global census of the industry released on Monday.

title: F.D.A. Lifts Restrictions on Melons
description: Faced with a lawsuit by a major produce grower, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday lifted import restrictions on cantaloupes from a Guatemala farm that had been linked to a multistate salmonella outbreak.

title: The Fundamental Right
description: The right to vote is sometimes said to be the most fundamental in American democracy. Yet legal challenges to the federal voting rights law are increasing even as they highlight the racial injustices that make it essential.

title: A Lifeline for Refugees
description: One year ago, Congress gave a temporary lifeline to thousands of older and disabled refugees. It extended for another 12 months their eligibility for cash assistance under the Supplemental Security Income program, which, for many, was their only source of income. That Congress had to do this was an unfortunate side effect of a 1996 law that placed strict time limits on benefits for refugees who did not become citizens within seven years.

title: Gov. Christie vs. Jersey Shore
description: We share with Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey a dim view of the MTV reality show Jersey Shore. It is a classic example of tasteless programming that tediously mocks Italians and the State of New Jersey.

title: A Political Wifes Influence on an Issue
description: Four years after Gov. Rick Perry issued an executive order that would have made Texas the first state to require that sixth-grade girls be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted disease linked to cervical cancer, its genesis remains a mystery. Opponents, including Representative Michele Bachmann, suggest the governor was influenced by close ties to lobbyists for the vaccine maker, Merck, or donations from the drug company.

title: Recipes for Chicken Dishes
description: Unexpected ways to prepare chicken at home: steamed in sake, glazed with pomegranate, rolled with scallions and more.

title: Backlog Found in Action on Presidential Pardons
description: The presidents power to reduce sentences and grant pardons is infrequently used, and backlogs in responding to clemency petitions are common, according to a new audit report from the Department of Justice.

title: 2 for 2, or 2 for 1?
description: Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel, the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and President Obama all spoke at the U.N. last week and, honestly, it is hard to decide whose speech was worse. Netanyahus read like a pep rally to the Likud Central Committee. Abbass read like an address to an Arab League meeting. Obamas read like an appeal to Jewish voters in Florida. The president meant well, but domestic politics required that he whisper where he once spoke bold truths to both sides.

title: Grand Jury Begins to Vote in Bronx Ticket-Fixing Case
description: The Bronx grand jury that has been hearing evidence on allegations of widespread ticket-fixing by police union officials began Tuesday to vote on whether to bring charges against those suspected of helping other officers and friends evade summonses, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Lightning Strikes for Red Sox and Rays
description: BALTIMORE

title: U.S. Reduces Estimate of Same-Sex-Couple Households
description: The Census Bureau on Tuesday greatly lowered its estimate for the number of same-sex-couple households in the United States, saying an inconsistency in the responses on census forms had inflated the numbers.

title: The Online Powerhouses Get Comfortable Orbiting Madison Ave.
description: Next week, when 60,000 people in marketing and communications are expected to descend on New York for Advertising Week, some of the worlds largest tech companies will be taking center stage.

title: Filling the Void Left by Borders
description: It is tempting to view the demise of the Borders Group as a dark cloud over the future of bookselling, and certainly the disappearance of hundreds of bookstores leaves a lot of vacancies where readers once browsed the aisles.

title: Cathy Horyns Milan Report
description: Cathy Horyn discusses the standout collections from Milan Fashion Week.

title: Rights Collide as Town Clerk Sidesteps Role in Gay Marriages
description: LEDYARD, N.Y.  Rose Marie Belforti is a 57-year-old cheese maker, the elected town clerk in this sprawling Finger Lakes farming community and a self-described Bible-believing Christian. She believes that God has condemned homosexuality as a sin, so she does not want to sign same-sex marriage licenses; instead, she has arranged for a deputy to issue all marriage licenses by appointment.

title: Instead of Waiting for Storm Aid, Going Online in a Do-It-Yourself Movement

description: The battle against high-priced tutors is heating up at Riverdale Country School.

title: Decoding the God Complex
description: WASHINGTON

title: N.B.A. Talks Resume, but Little Is Revealed
description: David Stern was smiling Tuesday afternoon  not because the N.B.A. ended its lockout, but because he has become mindful that every facial tic now fuels a dozen interpretations about the state of labor talks.

title: State Workers Union Rejects Contract, Risking 3,500 Layoffs
description: ALBANY  The second-largest union of New York State employees has rejected a package of wage and benefits concessions negotiated by the Cuomo administration, blowing a hole in the state budget that could now prompt the largest wave of layoffs in two decades.

title: Christie Adds Little New, but Fails to Quell the Talk
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey failed to address intense speculation about his presidential ambitions on Tuesday night during a foreign policy address at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in California.

title: In Pakistani Media, the U.S. Is a Target for Acrimony
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The United States might still be weighing its options about how to deal with Pakistan, but many politicians, retired army generals and popular television talk show hosts here have already made up their minds that America is on the warpath with their country.

title: Collins Is Signed Up; Reyes Keeps Lighting It Up
description: On the day the Mets exercised Manager Terry Collinss club option for the 2013 season, Jose Reyes provided a jolt of excitement in what could be his next-to-last game in a Mets uniform.

title: Champions League Wednesday Preview: Messi Chasing History, Torres Chasing Goals
description: Matchday 2 of the UEFA Champions Leagues group stage comes to a close with eight games on Wednesday. Across the continent, perhaps the most interesting games will be in Spain, where Fernando Torres will be trying to score in his third straight game; and in Belarus, where another hat trick for Barcelonas Lionel Messi (he has two in his last three games) will put the 24-year-old Argentine into second place among the clubs career goal-scorers, surpassing Laszlo Kubala.

title: Wednesday: Misers Cry
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  What kind of CLOUT do you have in your everyday life?

description: Suzy Menkes, the fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune, speaks with the creative director of Gucci as it celebrates its 90th anniversary with a new museum in Florence.

title: Hes Written a Play. Whos the Author?
description: Early in The Submission, Jeff Talbotts perky tale of racial pride and prejudice in the theater, a fledgling playwright praises a friends recently completed script. Its so ... producible, he says in wonder. Four characters? One set? I mean, it could be done, you know?

title: A Family Tries to Blend Despite Some Curdling
description: California dreams wither under a blazing sun in Lemon Sky, a 1970 drama by Lanford Wilson that has been affectionately revived by the Keen Company at the Harold Clurman Theater. Among the most autobiographical works by Mr. Wilson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright who died earlier this year, this simultaneously wry and plaintive memory play explores a painful passage in the life of a 17-year-old Nebraska boy who is reunited with his estranged father for an uneasy late attempt at father-son bonding.

title: A Spray Like a Punch in the Face
description: Last week, a girl in the Bronx pulled out a can of pepper spray and used it in a fight with two other girls in her high school, an event that resulted in her arrest, her mothers arrest and a report on WNBC.

title: As Thousands Leave Libya, and Jobs, Niger Feels Impact
description: NIAMEY, Niger  For tens of thousands of people from Niger, the downfall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has been an economic catastrophe, plunging them suddenly from a world of good pay in Libya back into the precarious universe of their home country, one of the poorest and most dependent nations on earth.

title: Documenting the Watch List Process
description: F.B.I. documents open a window into the secretive process by which officials place the names of people suspected of links to terrorism on a watch list.

title: Even Those Cleared of Crimes Can Stay on F.B.I.s Watch List
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is permitted to include people on the governments terrorist watch list even if they have been acquitted of terrorism-related offenses or the charges are dropped, according to newly released documents.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,770 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Virtual World Surges in New York
description: The rapidly shifting partnership between online giants and Madison Avenue has driven the move from back-office cubicles to elaborately designed corporate suites in New York intended to impress advertisers.

title: N.H.L. Will Not Discipline Player Over Slur Allegation
description: The N.H.L. ruled Tuesday that it lacked sufficient evidence to determine whether Flyers forward Wayne Simmonds directed a homophobic slur at the Rangers Sean Avery during a preseason game Monday night in Philadelphia.

title: As a Consultant Stands Trial, Bloombergs Style Comes Under Scrutiny
description: Kevin Sheekey, a former deputy mayor and now a gilded operative for Bloomberg L.P., sat in a witness chair in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Tuesday and affected a political handlers insouciance.

description: Times Square, whose fiery neon signs and jumbo billboards make it the epitome of larger-than-life New York, is about to get a modern, minimalist sprucing up.

As Scorn for Vote Grows, Protests Surge Around Globe
description: MADRID  Hundreds of thousands of disillusioned Indians cheer a rural activist on a hunger strike. Israel reels before the largest street demonstrations in its history. Enraged young people in Spain and Greece take over public squares across their countries.

title: Health Insurers Push Premiums Sharply Higher
description: Major health insurance companies have been charging sharply higher premiums this year, outstripping any growth in workers wages and creating more uncertainty for the Obama administration and employers who are struggling to drive down an unrelenting rise in medical costs.

title: Corrections: September 28
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Real Madrid Outshines Ajax
description: MADRID  On Saturday, Real Madrid beat its newly promoted neighbors Rayo Vallecano, 6-2. But with Barcelonas awe-inspiring 5-0 thrashing of Atletico Madrid later that evening, it was up to Real Madrid to return serve and deliver the message that the two giants of Spain still tower over La Liga  and perhaps of all soccer.

title: With Yankees Looking Ahead, the Rays Keep Pace
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The most critical moments of the Boston Red Sox season flickered on television in the Tampa Bay Rays clubhouse. Most players sipped beer and rooted loudly for their new favorite team, the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Appeal Trial Nears End for American Student
description: PERUGIA, Italy  Femme fatale or hapless young American woman abroad? Sex-starved she-devil or bright-eyed ingnue who liked to affectionately rub noses with her new Italian beau?

title: Braves Stumbling as Two Veterans Struggle With Slump and Injury
description: ATLANTA  On a night of desperation for the Braves, the spotlight was trained Tuesday on their two deans.

title: New Jersey Fugitive Is Caught in Portugal After 41 Years
description: The search for George Wright had long ago gone cold. A convicted murderer, Mr. Wright escaped from prison in New Jersey, hijacked a plane to Algeria and disappeared  all back in the early 1970s.

title: Saudi Arabia: 10 Lashes for Driving
description: Two days after King Abdullah granted women the right to vote and run for public office, starting in 2015, a court on Tuesday sentenced a woman to 10 lashes for violating religious rules prohibiting women in the kingdom from driving, activists and local news media said. The woman, Shaimaa Ghassaneya, was found guilty of driving in Jidda in July. Her sentence was unusually severe for the crime, which typically results in several days of detention. Activists said she planned to appeal. More women have been encouraged to violate the driving ban in recent months, as part of the social media-driven Women2Drive campaign. At least two more were expected to stand trial in the coming months.

title: Egypt: Pipeline to Israel Attacked
description: Militants on Tuesday attacked a pipeline carrying natural gas from Egypt to Jordan and Israel. It was the sixth attack on the pipeline since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak in February. Security officials said the militants set off an explosion at a pumping station outside the town of Al Arish in the northern Sinai Peninsula. Two people were killed and several buildings were damaged. Israel usually relies on Egyptian gas to meet 40 percent of its electricity needs, but damage from an attack in July brought shipments to a halt. The authorities did not name suspects in the attack.

title: Turkey Seeks Mediation on Drilling
description: Turkey is proposing that the United Nations create a commission to mediate an agreement on revenue sharing between Greek and Turkish Cypriots before any gas exploration begins off the divided island in the Mediterranean. Prime Minister Najib Mikati of Lebanon said he had agreed to hold off on any accord in an area of ocean where the claims of Cyprus, Lebanon and Israel overlap until the mediation is completed. Diplomats said that an agreement between Lebanon and Cyprus would virtually assure that the three countries agreed to the demarcation of their exploration zones. Turkey has threatened to use warships to prevent any drilling until there is an agreement between the Cypriots about the proceeds.

title: How Exercise Can Strengthen the Brain
description: Can exercise make the brain more fit? That absorbing question inspired a new study at the University of South Carolina during which scientists assembled mice and assigned half to run for an hour a day on little treadmills, while the rest lounged in their cages without exercising.

description: When Julian Bond, the former Georgia lawmaker and civil rights activist, turned to teaching two decades ago, he often quizzed his college students to gauge their awareness of the civil rights movement. He did not want to underestimate their grasp of the topic or talk down to them, he said.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
description: Indias prime minister, Manmohan Singh, said his government would stay the course (Indian Express) in spite of efforts by the opposition to force early elections. We have a mandate for five years, he said aboard his special Air India plane as he returned to New Delhi from New York. They cannot force an early election. This is not the way. (Hindustan Times). In a rare bit of good news for the government, the Central Bureau of Investigation told the Supreme Court it saw no need to investigate the role of PalaniappanChidambaram, the home minister,in the telecom licensing scandal. (The Hindu).

title: Wilson Greatbatch, Inventor of Implantable Pacemaker, Dies at 92

title: D.I.Y. Steaks on the Battlefield in Afghanistan
description: It was cold and quiet up on the Abas Ghar ridge. The soldiers were on the third day of a combat operation aimed at flushing out insurgents in the Korengal Valley  widely considered one of the deadliest places for American soldiers in Afghanistan. Many took the lull in fighting as an opportunity to open up an MRE (Meal, Ready-to-Eat) ration pack. Sergeant Stichter sat beside a large tree, spreading the contents of a tube of jelly over a beef patty. Sterling Jones watched the process and chuckled to himself, We eat our boredom.

title: A Crisis of Confidence Deep in the Heart of Texas
description: Back in 1944, an advertising executive named John Randolph put together a booklet called Texas Brags. It was an offshoot of an ad campaign for Jax beer, and it contained some fun facts about my home state, including If all the hogs in Texas were one big hog, he could dig the Panama Canal with three roots and a grunt. Or The King Ranch is so big that there is a months difference in seasons between the northern and southern parts. And Son, it is very rude to ask a man where he is from. If he is from Texas, you will find out, and if hes not, dont embarrass him.

title: What Five Living People Should Be on the New Postage Stamps?
description: The United States Postal Service announced this week that it was tossing out its rule that its stamps honor only dead individuals and will be featuring the living as well. What five living Americans would you like to see honored with commemorative stamps? Do you think the Postal Service is right that stamps featuring living people will create some excitement and even prompt some young people to engage with snail mail? When do you mail things?

title: Tip of the Week: Browser Shortcuts
description: Live hyperlinks are great for whisking you to the Web in a hurry, but addresses formatted as regular text still require cutting and pasting into the browser to get you to the page. If you use Mozilla Firefox or Googles Chrome browser, you can save a step. After copying the Web address from text, right click on the browsers address bar and choose the Paste and Go option to automatically zip over to that page.

title: Docks That Do Not Discriminate
description: There are so many iPod, iPhone and iPad docks out there it makes you wonder if manufacturers have given up supporting other phones and portable media players. In a way they have: they generally make more money selling iPod docks than making devices compatible with every single phone under the sun. However, there is hope.

In a article for The New Republic, he argues for taking power away from a gridlocked government and giving it to independent institutions that will make decisions without undue pressure from politicians or voters.

title: Mother Modern
description: Getting a read on the city of Los Angeles has never been easy. Twenty years ago, when my husband was offered a job in L.A., we left New York. I figured that as a writer, my work was portable, and as an urbanite, I would easily adjust. But Los Angeles, with its shifting perspectives and unwieldy size, was perplexing. When we first arrived, I spoke with an architectural historian on the verge of relocating. He offered me one salient tip before making his exit: The two most interesting things about Los Angeles, he said, are the domestic architecture and the ephemeral population. He was right: the stream of characters is constant, and the number of exceptional houses is astonishing. And as the critic Reyner Banham had so famously done before me, I got my drivers license, began reading Esther McCoy and learned to love Los Angeles.

title: Live Chat About Park51 With Its Developer, a Times Reporter and Frontline

Two wild-card races tied going into the final day? Really? A catcher from Yale making his first start and saving the Red Sox? The Rays turning a triple play? Two potentially epic collapses still teetering on a cliff? You half expect the Wizard to peek out from behind the curtain and say, You guys enjoying all of this?

description: WASHINGTON  Thousands of sexual assaults that occur in the United States every year are not reflected in the federal governments yearly crime report because the report uses an archaic definition of rape that is far narrower than the definitions used by most police departments.

title: Girl on Wheels

With Miss Linas Ballerinas, by Grace Maccarone; Pirates and Princesses by Jill Kargman and Sadie Kargman; and the Very Fairy Princess series by Julie Andrews and Emma Walton Hamilton in the last year alone, Davenier seems to have become the visual chronicler of contemporary kindergarten girlhood.
