title: Amazons Tablet Leads to Its Store
description: With a glossy 7-inch color touch screen and a dual-core processor, the Kindle Fire, a new mobile device introduced by Amazon on Wednesday, sure looks like a tablet, and one not so different from the Apple iPad.

title: In a Former Arsenal, a Museum for Ukrainian Art and Culture
description: What is the paradox of Ukraine? asked Natalia Zabolotna, the director general of Mystetskyi Arsenal, a national art and culture museum that opened Sept. 9 in Kiev. Ukraine gave the world very many geniuses, but theyre not listed as Ukrainian due to Ukraines geopolitical situation. Not many people know that Kazimir Malevich was born in Kiev.

title: At Seton Hall, Sharp Cuts in Tuition for Those With Good Grades and SATs
description: My colleague Richard Perez-Pena reports in an article just posted on The Timess Web site that beginning next year, Seton Hall University, a private institution in New Jersey, will reduce its regular sticker price by two-thirds, or $21,000, for those early applicants with strong academic credentials.

title: American Ballet Theater to Begin Training Course in Russia
description: American Ballet Theater is taking its traditions into a center of the dance world. The company said on Wednesday that it would present a weeklong course on its training techniques in St. Petersburg, Russia, home of the Mariinsky Theater  the former Kirov  and a venerable part of ballet history. Ballet Theater will hold the five-day session starting on Oct. 31 to present its national training curriculum, which the company said had certified 550 teachers across the United States since 2008, when it began. The curriculum combines artistic training with the basics of dancer health and child development, Ballet Theater said. The news follows a recent announcement that one of the companys stars, David Hallberg, would take on a principal dancer position with the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, the first American in such a role.

title: In Brooklyn, Horn Lessons by a Rabbi Ring Out
description: In his corner of Brooklyn, he has the status of a Louis Armstrong, though he is a young man with a different kind of horn.

title: Fees, Fees, Everywhere Higher Bank Fees
description: Average fees for withdrawals from out-of-network automatic teller machines, as well as fees for bounced checks, have hit new highs, according to Bankrate.coms annual checking account study released this week.

title: For the Mets, a Traditional Ugly Ending
description: The Mets may have been relieved that they won a victory in court on Tuesday, but their fans a few hours later were reminded of how snake-bitten the club is.

title: Four Legs and an Eye for Landscaping
description: I DIDNT want a dog. Theyre needy and messy, you have to walk them, and they get between people. There had been a stepdog, Rudy, my girlfriends large black, placid Labrador and German shepherd mix, and it is true that my dad loved Rudy because he was the only member of the family willing to share his luncheon meats. But Rudy had driven me to a Jungian analyst after I had yelled, What is this dog doing on the bed? and Lois had replied, What are you doing on the bed?

title: Ominous Signs for the Class Act
description: Is the Obama administration backing away from the Class Act?

title: New Clues on Whereabouts of Qaddafi and Sons
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the fugitive former Libyan leader toppled from power a month ago, is likely to have taken refuge near the Algerian border under the protection of sympathetic nomadic tribesmen who have fought for him, an official of the new Libyan government said Wednesday.

title: Negotiations Dont Need a Star Presence, Wade Says
description: Fate, and a new business endeavor, brought Heat guard Dwyane Wade to Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday, just as a critical round of N.B.A. labor talks got under way. Even from 20 blocks away, Wade seemed pessimistic about the potential for a breakthrough.

title: Brooklyn Residents Push to Halt Sex Attacks
description: They will employ neon-shirted escorts, self-defense classes, green whistles and park protests. They will fill subway stations with fliers in Spanish, Chinese, English and maybe Polish that warn of an assailant or assailants on the loose. They may even do a light show in a dark train entrance, in their pleas for better-lighted spaces to the Department of Transportation.

title: Styled to a T | Hugo Frana
description: The Designer

title: Le Cirque in India
description: If youre in Delhi and want a taste of the Upper East Side, glide up to the 10th floor of the new Leela Palace Hotel, in the embassy district, for some black cod, foie gras, lobster risotto and chocolate souffl at Le Cirques wood-paneled Indian outpost.

title: Polls Agree: Food System Needs Fixing
description: With the Farm Bill fast approaching, and the congressional Super Committee taking a hard look at which farm programs to cut and which to preserve, this is a good moment for Americans to let their feelings on these things be known. The Environmental Working Group (EWG) has just released a compelling comparison of two brand new polls detailing Americans views of our current food system. One poll was commissioned by the conservation-minded David and Lucile Packard Foundation, the other by the U.S. Farmers and Ranchers Alliance, (USFRA) a well-funded group intent on advancing the interests and restoring the image of big agriculture.

title: Signature Theater Company Announces Plays and Discounted Tickets
description: Signature Theater Company will produce Off Broadway world premieres next year of plays by the Pulitzer Prize winner Edward Albee, Katori Hall (The Mountaintop) and Kenneth Lonergan (The Starry Messenger), as well a new work by Will Eno (Middletown) and three dramas by the South African playwright Athol Fugard. James Houghton, artistic director of Signature, also announced on Wednesday that all tickets for the regular runs of productions would be sold for $25 during the next decade, an extension of this nonprofit theater companys landmark program to make shows more affordable to audiences.

title: Tiebreaker Mania: Lets Play Two?
description: There is nothing like teams playing one game for the right to advance to the playoffs, and perhaps the greatest thing about this baseball season is that there may be two such games. Should the race for the wild card end in a tie in each league  an outcome easy to picture because both races are tied entering the final games Wednesday night and none of these teams are playing each other  Thursday could feature two tiebreaker games, which would be a first.

title: G.M. Contract Approved, With Bonus for Workers
description: DETROIT  A new four-year contract between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union will increase the companys labor costs by only 1 percent annually and protect its strong balance sheet, G.M. executives told analysts Wednesday.

title: Cracker Barrel Uses Soft Touch to Keep Pursuer at Bay
description: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store is the latest public company to come under siege by a one-man activist force. But instead of the usual suspect, Carl C. Icahn, the activist force is Sardar Biglari, chief executive of the publicly traded Biglari Holdings. Most people know Biglari Holdings by its primary subsidiary, Steak n Shake.

title: The Geometry of Pasta
description: In Pasta by Design (Thames & Hudson, $30),the architect George L. Legendre presents a taxonomy of 92 noodles with mathematical exactitude, schematics and trigonometric equations as well as cooking times and serving suggestions. The blog for T: The New York Times Style Magazine has a slide show.

title: In Norway, Heads, They Win
description: Odd Grenland of Norway knows a head-turner when it sees one.

title: Bachmann Gives Dont Settle Speech at Liberty University
description: Representative Michele Bachmann on Wednesday repeated the phrase dont settle over and over to students at Liberty University, founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell, referring to their choice of major, a spouse and a career, as well as their dreams for the countrys future.

title: Help Wanted: Busybodies With Cameras
description: SEOUL, South Korea  With his debts mounting and his wages barely enough to cover the interest, Im Hyun-seok decided he needed a new job. The mild-mannered former English tutor joined South Koreas growing ranks of camera-toting bounty hunters.

title: Photo Replay: Sept.28
description: A long jumper participated in an original promotion of a new car in London and pro tennis tournaments continued in Bangkok and Tokyo.

title: Inspecting Your Insurance Premiums
description: Some employees might think this is open season, not open enrollment. The Kaiser Family Foundation survey that came out Tuesday painted a dismal picture of sharply raising health insurance premiums this year, even as any recovery in the economy appears stalled.

title: Face Time | Dr. Cheryl Karcher
description: Dr. Cheryl Karcher is a super-knowledgeable, insightful and informative dermatologist who happens to look much younger than her 53 years. She doesnt wear makeup very often; as long as she has her tube of Aquaphor, shes happy. She obviously knows a thing or two. Theres a dermatologist in the house  lets get the skin care scoop!

title: Officers Pepper-Spraying of Protesters Is Under Investigation
description: Updated 8:44 p.m. | The police and Manhattan prosecutors are separately examining a high-ranking officers use of pepper spray on a number of female protesters at a demonstration on Saturday.

title: The Caucus | Keeping Speculation Alive
description: Sarah Palin and Chris Christie benefit even if they never run for president. Also, reader feedback to an article today on the wife of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

title: The Difficulty of Drawing Lines Around Ice
description: The embarrassing error made by cartographers at a HarperCollins subsidiary recently put climate scientists on the attack against publishers over the extent to which Greenlands ice sheet has retreated. But after the scientific strike force had done its work and the publishers apologized, a point of agreement between the two emerged.

title: Caucus Video: The Palin and Christie Strategies
description: Sarah Palin and Chris Christie benefit even if they never run for president. Also, reader feedback to an article today on the wife of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

title: Once Again, They Like Ike
description: The primly corseted silhouettes of the late 1950s are back, based on Milan and New York shows.

title: For Need for Speed Gamers, a Dream Garage Is Getting Dreamier
description: Whether in Frankfurt or Las Vegas, professional models are fixtures of the auto-show circuit. Now theyre crossing over into the virtual realm.

title: Doubling Up on Triple Crowns
description: The profile of a Cy Young Award winner has changed drastically in the last few seasons, with wins clearly no longer among the main criteria (just ask Zack Greinke and Felix Hernandez.) Regardless, it is hard to believe that a pitcher winning the triple crown of his league would fall short.

title: Once Again, They Like Ike
description: IS fashion stagnant? Not really, though to gaze at the latest round of runway shows, you might think so. In New York, and in Milan this week, designers embraced the primly corseted silhouettes of the American midcentury with an extravagant fervor. Their outpouring of springtime sheaths, cocktail frocks, camp shirts and circle skirts, all emblems of late 1950s bourgeois chic, seemed worthy at times of Suzy Parker, their collections like outtakes from a Slim Aarons shoot.

title: My Three Favorite Teams  Despite Everything
description: Losers. I love them. Thats why my three favorite sports teams are the Cleveland Cavaliers, the Cleveland Indians and the Cleveland Browns. As every Cleveland sports fan knows, we havent finished on top in a major sport since 1964, when the Browns won their last NFL championship  before it was even the Super Bowl. The Indians last won the World Series in 1948, and the Cavaliers have never been champions.

title: Seattle Firm Struggles in the Biggest Market
description: Glassybaby is a creator and purveyor of small hand-blown glass cups used as decoration, vases and candleholders. Founded in 2001 by Lee Rhodes, the 97-employee company runs three stores and a glass-blowing studio in Seattle, as well as a store in New York City (the cups are also sold online). Ms. Rhodes projects that revenue for the company this year will be $6 million.

title: Things Every Dog Should Know
description: Does your dog know its own name?

title: For Advertising, Study Says More Screens Are Better
description: 12:59 p.m. | Updated The conventional wisdom deems that many consumers may become confused or overwhelmed when ads are aimed at them on different screens in multiple media. However, according to new research from Nielsen, which was commissioned by Google, marketers may benefit from such cross-platform exposure.

title: From Soldier to Student, a Bumpy Road
description: In between patrols, the guys in my platoon talked about going to school one day, as if it were something just barely out of reach. Many of us were ready to leave the military to start new lives. But when I enrolled in college after coming home from Iraq, I quickly learned that the buddy-centric Army culture ingrained in me did not fit well with student life.

title: Can This Retailer Make It in New York?
description: A case study weve just published details the predicament faced by Glassybaby, a creator and purveyor of small hand-blown glass cups that come in lots of colors and are used as decorations, vases and candleholders. Founded in 2001 by Lee Rhodes, the 97-employee company operates three stores and a glass-blowing studio in Seattle, as well as a store in New York.

title: Interns, Unpaid by a Studio, File Suit
description: Two men who worked on the hit movie Black Swan have mounted an unusual challenge to the film industrys widely accepted practice of unpaid internships by filing a lawsuit on Wednesday asserting that the production company had violated minimum wage and overtime laws by hiring dozens of such interns.

title: A Pipeline Divides Along Old Lines: Jobs Versus the Environment
description: GLENDIVE, Mont.  The final days of rancorous public debate over a $7 billion oil pipeline that would snake from Canada through the midsection of the United States have taken on an unexpected urgency this week, as the economic and environmental stakes of the massive project snap into focus at a time of festering anxiety about the nations future.

title: Reyes, in Batting Race, Goes 1 for 1, Then Exits
description: 4:12 p.m. | Updated With Postgame News Conference

title: GLAAD Cites Fox as Most Inclusive of Gay and Lesbian Characters
description: Of all the broadcast networks, Fox is the most inclusive of gay and lesbian characters on its prime time shows, and CBS is the least inclusive, according to a study released on Wednesday by the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, or GLAAD.

title: Christie and Bipartisanship: A Reality Check
description: If he runs for president, Chris Christie might highlight the themes he mentioned in his speech at the Reagan Presidential Library on Tuesday night, promising a new era of bipartisanship and compromise like the one he largely takes credit for achieving as governor of New Jersey.

title: Guys, Skip the Break-In on These Louboutins
description: PARIS

title: Center Stage
description: With its shimmering vision of a fairy-tale realm where grace and good manners prevail, Oliver Messels production of The Sleeping Beauty for Sadlers Wells (later the Royal) Ballet, in 1946, raised the curtain on Londons postwar recovery and held a mirror to Englands sense of pride. When the ballet was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York three years later, applause greeted the scenery  a magnificent palace extending into the wings and beyond, set in a stately park among ancient trees. The Sleeping Beauty was such a success that Messel never lived it down. For decades, it has been the basis of his reputation, and so irresistible and magical is its spell that, had he done nothing else, it would have been enough.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: N.F.L. Says Players Union Delaying H.G.H. Testing This Season
description: A program for human growth hormone testing in the N.F.L., which the league promoted last month as a done deal, appears highly unlikely for this season. It has become bogged down in a technical dispute among the league, the players union and the international testing agency advising both groups.

title: Tony Bennett Sells Great for a Man His  or Any  Age
description: Billboards headline says it all: Tony Bennett Becomes Oldest Living Artist to Top Billboard 200.

title: The Caucus | Readers on Anita Perry
description: Sept. 28, 2011  Susan Saulny looks through reader feedback on the wife of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Libya and Germany.

title: The Almost-Lost Poem That Changed the World
description: History can be fatal to literature. Aeschylus wrote 80 or 90 plays, and Sophocles 120, yet we have just seven of each. Didymus Chalcenterus of Alexandria reportedly wrote 3,500 books; not one exists today. Between classical antiquity and us, there has been a hecatomb of words. They have been burned, thrown away, lost to mold or pulverized. They have been rubbed off so that vellum and papyrus could be reused. Bookworms have eaten them by the dictionary-load.

title: Talking With Massimiliano Giornetti of Ferragamo
description: MILAN

title: Starz Gives Boss Second Season Even Before the Series Premiere
description: Sensing  or at least fervently hoping  that it has a hit on its hands, Starz Entertainment, the premium cable service, announced Tuesday that it would renew the drama series, Boss, starring Kelsey Grammer, for a second season even before the show has its premiere on Oct. 21. The show features Mr. Grammer as the fictional mayor of Chicago, suffering from a degenerative brain disorder that is causing his world to slowly collapse.

title: Doctor Said Jackson Was in Perfect Health, Witness Says
description: LOS ANGELES  Prosecution witnesses testified Wednesday at the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, Michael Jacksons personal physician, that Dr. Murray had insisted that the singer was in perfect health in the days before Mr. Jacksons death and had originally sought $5 million for his services during a series of concerts.

title: How Weird Can It Get?
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

title: Tucson Shooting Suspect to Have More Treatment
description: TUCSON  A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that Jared L. Loughner would undergo four more months of treatment in a federal psychiatric facility to see if he recovers enough to stand trial on charges that he killed six people and wounded 13 others, including Representative Gabrielle Giffords, on Jan. 8.

title: Pace to Bring Performances to Lower Manhattan
description: Responding to what it sees as a cultural need in Lower Manhattan as plans for a proposed performing arts center at the World Trade Center site remain up in the air, Pace University announced this week that it will begin a new annual series of performing and visual-arts programs at its 650-seat Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts on Spruce Street near City Hall.

title: Nowhere to Go but Up? Analyzing Economic Measures in a Downturn
description: Overview | How do we know when the economy is in a recession? How do key economic indicators perform in a downturn? In this lesson, students create graphs of various economic measurements, using quantitative and qualitative reasoning skills to compare, contrast and correlate the performance of measures like gross domestic product, unemployment and personal income.

title: Global Athlete
description: The IHT editor Tom Sims runs the Berlin Marathon as he begins his journey to meet global athletes finding inspiration and fitness while experiencing different countries and cultures.

title: Eurofile | We Dare You to Get a Reservation
description: Though la rentre, or the fall season, which begins when privileged Parisians return to work in September after their long summer holidays, traditionally sees the citys gastronomic calendar come to a roiling boil, a spate of midsummer openings stole some of autumns usual heat: notably, Au Passage, a hip new bistrot a vins; Neva Cuisine, an excellent modern bistro behind the Gare Saint Lazare; and Agap Sustance, a tiny but brilliant contemporary French table in the heart of touristy Saint-Germain-des-Pres. Still, the coming of that delicious season when Paris gutters start filling up with bronze-colored chestnut leaves just wouldnt be the same without a new restaurant or two to create to create a reservations frenzy, and distinguish for all the world those who are in the la loop.

title: Is This Man the G.O.P.s Best Bet for 2012?
description: Gail Collins: David, are you reconciled to the fact that Mitt Romney is going to be the Republican presidential nominee?

title: SAT Fraud in New York State Exposed
description: A 19-year-old college student from Long Island allegedly charged local high school students up to $2,500 each to sit for the SAT in their name, the Associated Press reported on Wednesday.

title: Tigers Awaiting Playoff Fate
description: The Detroit Tigers know just about everything about their upcoming playoff run, except for one big thing: their opponent. The Yankees, Red Sox, Rays are factors in the unsolved equation, but much can still be revealed about what the Tigers intend to do in their first post-season since 2006.

title: In Arizona, a Sly Form of Flattery
description: PHOENIX  Most of the fans had left the ballpark by the time the Diamondbacks Ryan Roberts came to the plate Tuesday night in the bottom of the tenth inning with his team down to its final out in a game with enormous postseason implications.

title: A Century of New York in Color
description: Color Photographs of New York City

title: If a Close Shave Is Just Too Close
description: IN a world where men sport permanent stubble on their faces, the capacity to grow a thick, bristly beard in just 48 hours can be considered an evolutionary advantage. Alas, not one conferred upon Clinton Weber, the smooth-cheeked runway model forced to endured a futile stubble trim backstage at the Duckie Brown show during New Yorks Fashion Week.

title: Trial Run
description: LIKE strawberries in winter, 24/7 stubble was not what nature had in mind. These new stubble trimmers  electric razors engineered to reduce facial hair to a shadow  help subdue natures intent, but not without a battle. The question is whether the occasional war wounds (red skin, uneven stubble, precious minutes squandered over the sink) are worth the spoils. (Prices listed are provided by the manufacturers.) DOUGLAS QUENQUA

title: In Trading Scandal, a Reason to Enforce the Volcker Rule
description: As a draft of the Volcker Rule has made the rounds in the last several weeks, it has alternatively caused fits of despair and cries of exultation. And thats just among the proponents of the regulation.

title: Embracing a Snow Bowl
description: When the N.F.L. decided the site of the 2014 Super Bowl would be the new Giants/Jets stadium in the Meadowlands, an involuntary shiver went through the league, visions of snowplows and Eskimo masks dancing through everyones heads.

title: Inspector May Have Used Pepper Spray on Others, Video Shows
description: The deputy police inspector accused of sending a blast of pepper spray toward four female protesters on Saturday may have used the spray on others that day.

title: U.S.: 5 Guys for 2 Friendlies
description: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann of the United States may have an impressive pedigree and a million-dollar smile, but he also has a 0-2-1 record and an increasingly anxious fan base. Klinsmann needs to start winning games (or does he?), and the upcoming exhibitions against Honduras and Ecuador would be an ideal time to start.

title: Charisma and Chris Christie
description: Last nights quasi-campaign speech at the Reagan Library notwithstanding, Chris Christie almost certainly isnt running for president. If he were to run for president, he could easily end up proving a kind of Fred Thompson-Rudy Giuliani hybrid  a late-entering Northeastern moderate savior figure who never figures out how to campaign effectively and ends up being consigned to a spoiler role. No candidate looks as appealing the day after they get in the race as they did the day before, and a relatively inexperienced blue state governor running for the Republican nomination at a moment of national crisis is unlikely to prove an exception to this rule.

title: Rocking the Palazzo With Gucci
description: FLORENCE, Italy

title: Scene City: Gucci Museum
description: For Milan Fashion Week, Gucci celebrates its new museum in Florence.

title: Greek Bonds Lure Some, Despite Risk
description: LONDON  Greece may never be able to pay off its huge debts, but its bonds, long scorned by investors, are suddenly being gobbled up by hedge funds.

title: Iran Mass-Produces New Missile and Rejects Hot Line Idea With America
description: Iran announced the mass production of a new cruise missile on Wednesday, the latest in a series of belligerent-sounding proclamations from that country in the face of its increased isolation by a Western-led group of nations worried about Irans nuclear program and avowed hostility toward Israel.

title: Supreme Court Is Asked to Rule on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to hear a case concerning the 2010 health care overhaul law. The development, which came unexpectedly fast, makes it all but certain that the court will soon agree to hear one or more cases involving challenges to the law, with arguments by the spring and a decision by June, in time to land in the middle of the 2012 presidential campaign.

title: Credit Cards Aimed at College Students
description: The new rules restricting aggressive credit card marketing on campus, included in the CARD Act of 2009, seem to have reduced the practice, says a report from Credit.com.

title: Romney Keeps Sights on Obama
description: GOFFSTOWN, N.H.  Though Republican Party leaders have spent the last week casting about for an alternative to the current crop of 2012 presidential hopefuls  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey comes to mind  Mitt Romney used a town-hall-style at Saint Anselm College on Wednesday to attack President Obama, mentioning his Republican rivals only when asked.

title: If Holly Golightly Had a Grandson
description: AT 30, Ari Seth Cohen already possesses a vintage soul. Neatly coiffed, sporting a polka-dot shirt and dapper sport coat, he has a tidy, calm mien that evokes the days before leisure became an extreme sport.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

title: A Detective Who Gazes Into the Abyss
description: IN the increasingly bland, featureless landscape of TV crime drama it is somehow heartening to come upon a homicide detective who can be called, as the hero of Luther is, His Satanic Majesty  by a co-worker, no less. That tantalizing sobriquet pops up early in the first episode of the seriess second season, now on BBC America, and it should be music to the ears of genre fans who prefer their crime fighters tormented.

title: Fashion Bloggers, Posted and Represented
description: LINDSEY CALLA, the 27-year-old behind the fashion blog Saucy Glossie, sat in a Midtown cafe one recent afternoon and offered a guiding career principle: You should work and make money.

title: Reyes Hits, Then Sits and Eventually Celebrates
description: Citi Field was expected to be the stage Wednesday for a bit of drama featuring one of baseballs most effervescent characters.

title: The Daily Shoe | Dries Van Noten
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#147", 592, 400, false, chameleonData); T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Perry Walks Back on Heartless Remark
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said Wednesday that it was inappropriate of him to have branded as heartless those who oppose tuition breaks for the children of illegal immigrants.

title: TimesCast | September 28, 2011
description: Amazon introduces a new tablet; lawyers assess the competency of the accused Gabrielle Giffords shooter; and Al Qaeda urges Iran to stop promoting 9/11 conspiracies.

title: Now Pitching for the Yankees: Dellin Betances
description: The Yankees are putting a fairly representative lineup on the field Wednesday night in a game that means everything to their opponent, the Tampa Bay Rays, and very little to them.

title: Quiet for Years, Italian Church Blasts Behavior of the Nations Political Elite
description: ROME  Over the last several years, the Roman Catholic Church in Italy has largely looked the other way as reports emerged of sex and corruption scandals among the countrys political elite, many of them centered on Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. But a recent published account of a party at Mr. Berlusconis home, where one female guest was said to have performed a striptease dressed as a nun, might have been more than the church could stand.

title: Homes for $529,000
description: A Victorian near Philadelphia, a house in Chattahoochee Hills, Ga., and a loft in a former industrial building in Chicago.

title: What You Get for ... $529,000
description: MEDIA, PA.

title: UBSs New Chief: We Will Keep Our Investment Bank
description: In case UBS employees still doubted the Swiss banks plans to keep its investment banking operations, the firms new interim chief executive reiterated that the division was not going anywhere.

title: Parking Rules
description: On Thursday and Friday,

title: Reliable Sources in an Age of Too Much Information
description: A few days ago I was interviewed about the challenges and opportunities in reporting on complicated, but consequential, science (climate change being a prime example) for the Journalists Resource project of Harvards Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy. The centers Web site is full of useful background and tools for writers, including a journalists primer onstatistical terms used in research studies and a short reflection on online research by Alexis Madrigal of The Atlantic.

title: Myths and Legends Open Paris Ballet
description: PARIS  History and tradition, the present and the new. That seems to be the thinking behind the Greek-myth pairing of Serge Lifars 1950 Phdre and Alexei Ratmanskys new Psych with which the Paris Opera Ballet has just opened its season here. (In another nod to tradition, the opening-night gala last week was canceled because of a technicians strike. Plus a change, etc.)

title: Shopping Snapshots: Sept. 29
description: Ferragamo starts a trend; the southern end of the High Line becomes a fashion draw; and other items.

title: Fixed-Gear Bicycles are an American Fixture in Paris
description: PARIS

title: Fukushimas Contamination Produces Some Surprises at Sea
description: Six months after the accident at Fukushima Daiichi, the news flow from the stricken nuclear power plant has slowed, but scientific studies of radioactive material in the ocean are just beginning to bear fruit.

title: Coal + Ice in Beijing
description: A behind-the-scenes video of the "Coal + Ice" exhibit presented by the Asia Society at Three Shadows Photography Art Center in Beijing. (Video courtesy of the Asia Society.)

title: Reports About Australias Privately Run Immigration Detention System
description: No country has more completely outsourced immigration enforcement  with more troubled results  than Australia. Two investigations, from 2011 and 2004, identified areas of noncompliance and breaches of detainees human rights.

title: Costumes for a Kid-Cool World
description: LEGGY Blake Lively look-alikes pressed their lips to martini glasses, wearing sequined designer dresses with plunging necklines. Wall Street guys in untucked dress shirts hassled bull-necked club managers for prime tables. Deafening dance music blared, as swirling searchlights swept the crowd.

title: Clip: Carnage
description: A scene from Carnage, the new film from Roman Polanski.

title: In California, a New Lemon Law to Protect Used-Car Shoppers
description: A new California law, the first of its kind in the nation, is requiring new- and used-car dealers to check their used vehicles against a federal government database and mark them with a red warning sticker if they find a serious problem.

title: Announcement of 2017-25 Federal Fuel Efficiency Standards Delayed Until November
description: The federal government has delayed its release of 2017-25 targets for Corporate Average Fuel Economy, or CAFE, until mid-November, according to the Environmental Protection Agency. The news marks a delay from the Obama administrations original intention to have the standards out by the end of September.

title: Israelis Happy at Home but Glum About Peace
description: JERUSALEM  With the start of the Jewish New Year at sunset on Wednesday, a traditional time for stock-taking in Israel, the public mood seemed paradoxical: a growing disillusionment with the prospect of Middle East peace yet a marked sense of satisfaction with life here.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Pakistan and Libya.

title: Fox Quickly Endorses New Girl
description: The Fox network quickly made it official on Wednesday: it believes it has a breakout hit with the new comedy New Girl.

title: TimesCast | Al Qaeda and Ahmadinejad
description: September 28, 2011 - Al Qaeda urges Iran to stop promoting 9/11 conspiracy theories.

title: In Venice, a Home Ensconced in Glass
description: A dilapidated 17th-century stone building on a canal was transformed into a contemporary home.

title: Old Venetian Meets Modern
description: VENICE  As the director general of the City of Venice, Marco Agostini is more knowledgeable than many Venetians about the 15th-century Palladian palaces and decorous Gothic villas that make up some of the most striking examples of Italian architecture.

title: Watchdogs Call Out 4 Nonprofits as Too Political for Tax Exemption
description: 6:04 p.m. | Updated Advocates of tighter campaign laws asked the Internal Revenue Service on Wednesday to examine the activities of four tax-exempt organizations that are expected to play a major role in influencing the 2012 elections, arguing that the groups should be required to register as political organizations, lose their tax exemptions and disclose their donors.

title: Joe Jonas Comes of Age
description: THERE is power in numbers, and so a lone Jonas walking into a Midtown Manhattan restaurant does not have nearly the oomph of a threesome. Joe Jonas, middle child of the phenom Jonas Brothers, went nearly unrecognized over a long lunch at Asia de Cuba recently, perhaps because most of the other diners were, you know, adults.

title: Attack Kills Police Officers in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Eight police officers were killed overnight at a hilltop checkpoint in the fourth episode in three months taking aim at the police in Helmand Province.

title: Not Just Made in China, But Designed There, Too
description: Beijing Design Week, which runs from Sept. 26 to Oct. 3, will showcase more than 2,000 works from some 30 countries  and, perhaps more significant, it will highlight Chinas resolve to become a cultural superpower. Installations span the city, from the 751 industrial district and the sleek Sanlitun neighborhood to the China Millennium Monument, where the British designer Paul Cocksedges massive piece  30 sheets of rolled steel engraved with classical Chinese and English poetry  anchors this years Guest City and embodies the weeks spirit of aesthetic exchange. The week also marks the opening of the First Beijing International Design Triennial, organized around the theme of Ren: Good Design and held at the National Museum of China. Ren, which loosely translates as caring for others, locates curatorial efforts in a communal context that jibes, at least ideologically, with the countrys political principles and sets a positive agenda for the hothouse environment of contemporary China.

title: Skin-Deep Beauty? It Looks Like Chicken

title: Moms a Drunk, Dads a Writer: A Recipe for Disaster and a Memoir
description: Its all about the wisecracks for Jeanne Darst, a memoirist who sticks to the crazy-family template in Fiction Ruined My Family. Ms. Darst grew up with her parents alcoholism, social pretensions, delusional behavior and financial instability. She and her three sisters played peculiar games. (Youre Patty Hearst, and were the S.L.A.) She began drinking heavily herself and took temporary jobs (like hydrangea window-box gardener), failing at all of them. She watched as her parents marriage broke up and tried not to mimic their behavior.

title: Crooks Onstage (Madoff, et al.) in Washington

Madoff, the reviled mastermind of the Ponzi scheme that appalled the world just as the financial tailspin began, has faded from the front pages, his monstrous crimes overshadowed by the continuing financial woes that lack easily identifiable (and imprisonable) villains. He will doubtless serve the rest of his life in prison. But here he was onstage, in the form of a fictionalized facsimile, in Deb Margolins long-aborning play, Imagining Madoff, which ended its run at Theater J here over the weekend.

That was enough to earn Zooey Deschanel, who plays the adorkable Jess, and her colleagues the embrace of the network, as Bill Carter reported on Media Decoder: The network ordered 11 more episodes, for a total 24 for the year, a signal that it wants as much New Girl as it can possibly get.

title: For Deals, Wall Street Goes East
description: In 1902, the International Banking Corporation, a predecessor of Citigroup, went in search of the next big gold rush. But it did not go west. It opened up small outposts in Shanghai, Calcutta and Manila. In 1914, another Citigroup ancestor opened a branch in Buenos Aires, becoming the first big American player in the city.

title: The value of e-mail; new solid-state hard drives; Amazons new tablet; tech news.
description: David Streitfeld of The Times technology desk provides commentary on the current state of the tablet-computer wars and what Amazons entry into the fray means for Apples stranglehold on the market. Jeff Hardy and Derek Curtis, two vice-presidents of SmarterTools, Inc., explain why an e-mail address is a valuable piece of currency to companies and advertisers. Larry OConnor, the founder and president of Other World Computing, discusses the technical advantages of solid-state drives. This weeks Tip of the Week offers shortcuts for working with plain-text Web addresses. The tech-news roundup takes a look at Facebooks latest privacy flap and Spotify integration  as well as upgrade announcement this week for the Firefox browser, Adobe Photoshop Elements and Microsofts Windows Phone operating system.

title: Tutu and Dalai Lama Criticize South Africa Over Visa Delay
description: South Africas failure to issue a visa to the Dalai Lama, or even respond to his repeated requests for one, was sharply criticized on Wednesday by the Dalai Lama and by Desmond Tutu, the former Archbishop of Capetown. The two men called the failure disrespectful.

title: Mondo Collection in the Flatiron District
description: As its name implies, the Mondo Collection, a new showroom in the Flatiron district, carries the work of designers from around the world.

title: Beijing Gallery Puts a Focus on Global Warming
description: BEIJING  When George Mallory made a reconnaissance trip to the gargantuan glaciers at the foot of Mount Everest in Tibet before his ill-fated attempt to climb the mountain, he took photographs and noted the splendor: Here is a pure beauty of form, a kind of ultimate harmony, he wrote.

title: Reflections of Rugby Underdogs
description: In Wednesdays paper The Times ran an article on the large number of blowout games at the Rugby World Cup. The American team finished 1-3 at the Cup, beating Russia and putting in creditable performances against Italy and Ireland, but was on the wrong end of one blowout, losing, 67-5, to Australia.

title: Hedge Fund Manager Gets 60 Years for Fraud
description: A hedge fund manager convicted of running a $100 million scheme that preyed on retired investors was sentenced on Wednesday to 60 years in prison, the latest eye-popping penalty to come from a federal white collar case.

title: Christie, Clinton and the Calendar
description: Im sympathetic to the medias obsession with Gov. Chris Christies possible-but-unlikely entry into the Republican nomination race in one sense: he is one of the most natural communicators since Bill Clinton. (Also, its a slow news week.) He has superstar talent, something that some of the other Republican candidates have lacked, and its the kind that could appeal to both primary and general election voters.

Im inclined to agree, though Im not sure what accounts for the buildup or even if there is anything to it.

title: Standout Season Amid a Trying Year

title: Where the Going Is Rough, the Giants Hold Their Ground

A standard short-yardage running play is the rough equivalent of Grand Central Terminal at 5 p.m. The offensive players are the sea of people headed home, shoulder to shoulder as they move toward the tracks in unison. The defensive players are the unlucky reverse commuters, straining against the surge and struggling to get up the platform stairs amid an onrushing mass of humanity.

title: Door Knockers

At the same time, they had to satisfy their clients, whose many requirements included floors that would not warp or squeak.

title: Spiraling Guitar Solos to Pace or Stoke Songs

A half-dozen songs later, all played solo with guitar, they had barely rested. His fingers had done dazzling things: fingerpicking that could be pristine and meditative or pointedly aggressive, counterpoints of staccato thumb-picked bass lines and gliding melodies, quasi-Baroque austerity leading into frenetic strumming.

title: The Architect Jeanne Gang on Winning a MacArthur Fellowship
description: In 2010, Jeanne Gang, of Studio Gang Architects, changed the skyline of her hometown, Chicago, with Aqua, an 82-story tower. Girded by irregular thin concrete balconies, the building seems to flutter with the winds that gust off nearby Lake Michigan.

description: LOS ANGELES  As the actor David Hornsby tried to list all of the hats that he wears  television actor, writer, producer, father of a newborn son  an apt metaphor came to his mind.

description: The thorny dilemmas that can be posed by efforts at architectural preservation are rearing their heads again in New York City in the case of a landmark building on Fifth Avenue that is considered to be the very model of Modernism.

title: Not All Buy Christies Assertions of Bipartisanship
description: If he runs for president, Chris Christie might highlight the themes he mentioned on Tuesday night in his speech at the Reagan Presidential Library, promising a new era of bipartisanship and compromise like the one he largely takes credit for achieving as governor of New Jersey.

title: Flamenco Aflame
description: Its easy to overlook the many thrilling features of purely formal beauty in Soledad Barrios dancing. Though wrist-circlings abound in flamenco, she can accentuate them so that they become spirals of smoke. Raising both arms with elbows sharply bent, she creates a geometry thats very satisfying. She can also soften those elbows so that the raised arms become a single compelling crescent, facing up to the sky or down to the earth. As she stands with legs apart, the lines of her arms and legs answer each other like the bowl and base of a grand goblet. Her walk seems not a succession of steps but a single flowing movement.

title: Sales at Vitra, Broadway Panhandler and Others
description: Dining tables, consoles, cocktail tables and end tables will be up to 80 percent off at Evanson Studios, from Friday to Sunday (the Astor dining table, originally about $19,000, will be about $6,900); 1 Bond Street (Broadway), loft 5B, (212) 777-6943 or evansonstudios.com.

title: Shanahan Is Enforcing the Rules With Gusto
description: Brendan Shanahan was at work Wednesday, doing more of what he has done frequently this preseason: deciding whether to suspend an N.H.L. player for delivering a dangerous check.

title: On Ducking Challenges to Naturalism
description: In response to the question posed in my previous essay in The Stone  What is naturalism?  Alex Rosenberg defines it as the philosophical theory that treats science as our most reliable source of knowledge and scientific method as the most effective route to knowledge. His post, Why I Am a Naturalist, nicely exemplifies one of my main complaints, by leaving it unclear what he means by science or scientific method, even though it is crucial for what he is committing himself to as a naturalist. Still, there are clues. He describes the test of knowledge that scientific findings attain as experimental/observational methods, which suggests that theorems of mathematics would not count as scientific findings. The impression is confirmed by Professor Rosenbergs phrase mathematicians and scientists, as though he doesnt see mathematicians as scientists. Thats bad news for his naturalism, for mathematical proof is just as effective a route to knowledge as experimental/observational methods. Of course, since the natural sciences depend on mathematics, Rosenberg desires to find a place for it  but admits that he doesnt know how.

description: Flipping through photo albums with family and friends seems quaint in todays hyper-digital world.

description: WASHINGTON  The Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency announced on Wednesday that it had arrested 2,901 immigrants who have criminal records, highlighting the Obama administrations policy of focusing on such people while putting less emphasis on deporting illegal immigrants who pose no demonstrated threat to public safety.

description: A federal judge on Wednesday upheld most of the sections of Alabamas far-reaching immigration law that had been challenged by the Obama administration, including portions that had been blocked in other states.

description: The world has barely dug out of recession and the global economy is again slowing dangerously. Most leaders seem eager to make things even worse.

title: An Invitation to Overreach
description: The rise in mandatory minimum sentences has damaged the integrity of the justice system, reduced the role of judges in meting out punishment and increased the power of prosecutors beyond their proper roles.

title: Director Said to Be Leaving Port Authority Next Month
description: Christopher O. Ward, who jump-started development of the stalled World Trade Center site and memorial and oversaw a significant toll increase on the Hudson River crossings, intends to resign as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to two people familiar with his plans.

title: Mexico: Uncertain Ruling on Abortion
description: After a closely watched debate, Mexicos Supreme Court refused to throw out a state anti-abortion amendment on Wednesday. Although 7 of the 11 justices agreed that the Baja California State amendment was unconstitutional, the court was one vote shy of the supermajority needed to strike it down. After Mexico City became the only place in the country to legalize abortion in 2007, 17 states altered their constitutions to declare that life begins at conception. President Felipe Caldern and his wife, Margarita Zavala, intervened in the debate, urging the justices to let the state laws stand. The court will consider a challenge to another states anti-abortion law on Thursday.

title: Support for the 9/11 Memorial
description: Now that the 9/11 memorial at the former World Trade Center site is open to the public, the federal government should provide financial assistance to help keep it maintained and operating in the years ahead.

title: Decision May Affect Olympic Eligibility
description: A ruling this week by the Court of Arbitration for Sport may determine whether athletes like LaShawn Merritt, the Olympic 400-meter track champion, and others who have been sanctioned for doping violations will be eligible to compete in the 2012 London Games.

title: A Call for Opening Up Web Access at Schools
description: Students at Silver Creek High School in Longmont, Colo., held a graffiti debate on censorship on Wednesday: Should schools block Web sites? On sheets of white butcher paper hanging in the library, they wrote lists of the pros and cons of online access.

title: Iran: Production of New Missile Begins
description: Iran announced the mass production of a new cruise missile on Wednesday, the latest in a series of belligerent-sounding proclamations from that country in the face of its increased isolation by a Western-led group of nations worried about Irans nuclear program and avowed hostility toward Israel. Brig. Gen. Ahmad Vahidi, Irans defense minister, said the new missile, first unveiled a month ago and known as the Qader, which means able in Persian, had been mass-produced as quickly as possible, the countrys state-run media reported. The missile, designed to destroy warships and coastal targets, has a range of about 125 miles, the news media said.

title: President Putin Redux
description: Russias next presidential election is not until March but  barring an unexpected turn  the winner is pretty much decided.

description: After two years of posturing, threats and toilsome labor talks, the N.B.A. has reached its moment of truth, with nothing less than the season at stake.

title: Yemen: Rebels Shoot Down Military Jet
description: Rebel tribesmen in a mountainous region just north of Yemens capital, Sana, shot down a military aircraft on Wednesday, the Defense Ministry said. The Soviet-era plane crashed as it was carrying out a routine task this morning, according to the statement, which was published on a Web site run by the ministry. Northern tribesmen loyal to opponents of President Ali Abdullah Saleh have been battling government forces in the area since March, when they prevented a brigade of Republican Guards, a division of the armed forces led by Mr. Salehs son, from entering the capital.

description: The men showed up in a small town in Australias outback early last year, offering top dollar for all available lodgings. Within days, their company, Serco, was flying in recruits from as far away as London, and busing them from trailers to work 12-hour shifts as guards in a remote camp where immigrants seeking asylum are indefinitely detained.

description: September 28, 2011  Lawyers in Tucson argue whether Jared L. Loughner, the accused shooter of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, is mentally competent to stand trial for murder.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Pucks: Final Roster Decisions for the Rangers, Islanders and Devils
description: In the N.H.L. world of guaranteed one-way contracts  by which established veteran players make the same salary even if sent to the minors the notion of widespread competition for jobs in training camp is primarily a myth. There are, however, a few spots still open on the rosters of the Rangers, Islanders and Devils with a few exhibition games remaining.

title: Signs of a Crash Ahead, Not a Recession  Reuters Breakingviews

description: The American midfielder Stuart Holden, who returned to Boltons first-team lineup last week after missing six months with a knee injury, will miss at least six more months after a setback. The club said in a statement that a routine follow-up on his knee revealed cartilage damage.

title: Chili? Beer? Organizing the Details of a Tailgate Party
description: Some people have no interest in tailgating, and thats fine.

title: Make Sure the Problem Is Not in Your Chair
description: If you use your laptop on your lap, or leave it plugged in all the time, you may well be cruising for what some experts call Picnic (Problem in Chair Not in Computer) or ID-10t (idiot) errors  computer problems caused by clueless users. Technical support professionals say these errors are responsible for at least half of all computer repairs.

title: As State Issues Layoff Notices, Unions Leaders Stand by Vote Against a Contract
description: LATHAM, N.Y.  Even as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo sent layoff notices to the first of 3,496 employees he is vowing to let go, leaders of New Yorks second-largest union of state workers said Wednesday that they did not intend to ask their members to reconsider the proposed contract they had rejected.

title: U.S. Backs New Loans for Projects on Energy
description: As the federal fiscal year ends, and with it the part of the stimulus program that finances some energy loans, the Energy Department issued $1.07 billion in loan guarantees on Wednesday afternoon, for two solar energy production plants, and on Thursday it plans to announce $156 million in grants for high-risk but potentially high-reward research projects.

title: Yemen: Succession Plan May Be Near
description: An agreement between Yemens government and its opponents on how to carry out a transfer of power has overcome setbacks caused by the outbreak of violence in the capital last week and is near completion, Yemeni officials said. One of the high-ranking officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the negotiations were continuing, said some details were pending, but he expected a final version to be agreed upon by the two sides in the coming week. President Ali Abdullah Saleh, thus far, has cooperated with the plan, the official said. The agreement, if finalized, would be an important breakthrough in the standoff between the governing party and the opposition. However, the actual transfer of power document, known as the gulf initiative, would still have to be signed by the Yemeni vice president in order for a full transfer of power from Mr. Saleh. Mr. Saleh made a surprise return to Sana on Friday after nearly four months in Saudi Arabia. He had been receiving treatment there for wounds suffered in a June bomb attack on the presidential palace.

title: Romney Waits as G.O.P. Flirts With Alternates
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican who may have the strongest shot of winning the White House, at least in the eyes of President Obama and his advisers, is Mitt Romney. Now, if Mr. Romney could only persuade Republican voters.

title: Baseballs Wild Card Race
description: On the final night of the regular season, there are four teams on the verge of a postseason berth.

title: A Hijacker, a Longtime Fugitive and, Now, a Prisoner
description: Capt. William H. May noticed the man who started the trouble. The priest.

title: Russia: At Least 4 Are Killed by Car Bomb
description: At least four people, including a police officer, were killed in a car bombing on Wednesday in the volatile Russian region of Dagestan, Russias Investigative Committee said in a statement. The explosion occurred in the village of Khadzhalmakhi when a group of officers were inspecting a vehicle rigged with an explosive device. In addition to the police officer, three civilians were killed as they passed by in another vehicle. The Ria Novosti news agency reported that the civilians had ignored warnings not to drive close to the suspicious vehicle. Violence occurs regularly in the restive, predominantly Muslim region of the North Caucasus where Dagestan is located. Wednesdays explosion came just days after a series of car bombings in Dagestan that killed six people and injured at least 60.

title: Mapping the Cotton Kingdom
description: Weve grown used to seeing our lives mapped. The 2010 Census has provided material for a host of new maps that profile Americans in myriad ways, from population dynamics to social and economic patterns. But the role of maps in visualizing United States Census results is actually a practice that originated 150 years ago, in the crisis between North and South.

title: Iran: Lawyer for Hikers Is Arrested
description: Security forces on Tuesday raided the home of the lawyer who had represented the American hikers who were released last week, and they briefly detained him at Evin Prison in Tehran, where the hikers were held for 781 days. It was strange to see an arrest warrant issued for me, as arrest warrants are usually issued for murderers or fugitives, the lawyer, Masoud Shafiei, told the International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran a few hours after his release. Mr. Shafiei said the officers took his passport and a computer and documents from his office before returning them. Much of his interrogation, he added, concerned the two Americans, Joshua F. Fattal and Shane M. Bauer, who were sharply critical of the Iranian government after their release.

title: Move in Palestinian Membership Bid
description: The Security Council took the formal step on Wednesday of referring the Palestinian request for full membership in the United Nations to the special committee that is to consider it, consisting of a diplomat from each of the 15 states on the Council. The first meeting is scheduled for Friday, with the ambassadors expected to represent their countries. The Palestinian envoy, Riyad Mansour, said the Israeli announcement of 1,100 new settlement houses on occupied territory was a challenge to the international community at a time when it was seeking renewed peace talks. Ron Prosor, the Israeli ambassador, said the new houses were part of Jerusalem, which will be included in future negotiations. Only direct talks, not solutions imposed from the outside, will achieve peace, Mr. Prosor added.

title: Rwanda: France Refuses to Extradite Presidents Widow
description: An appeals court in Paris on Wednesday rejected an extradition request for the widow of Juvenal Habyarimana, the Rwandan president whose plane was shot down in 1994, touching off the massacres of more than 500,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu. The present government has wanted Agathe Habyarimana to return home to Kigali to face charges of genocide and crimes against humanity. Although living in France, she was refused political asylum in 2004 and lost her appeal as well, because French judges had found she was a central figure and exercised real power in the Hutu government that orchestrated the genocide. Yet she was allowed to remain in France and her extradition was not expected this time because French courts have previously refused to hand over suspects to Rwanda for fear that they would not receive a fair trial. The reasoning of the Paris court was not immediately available.

title: India and Pakistan Take Step Toward a Deal on Trade
description: India and Pakistan on Wednesday announced a plan to normalize bilateral trade, long hampered by mutual suspicion and animosity. The commerce ministers from the two countries made the announcement in New Delhi as part of an effort to repair relations that were severely damaged by an attack in Mumbai by Pakistan-based terrorists in 2008. In a joint statement, the ministers said the countries would lay out a timeline in November for dismantling of all nontariff barriers and carrying out the obligations they had previously agreed upon as part of the South Asian Free Trade Agreement.

title: States Putting Hopes in Bottoms Up to Help the Bottom Line
description: ATLANTA  Drink up, America. The government needs the money.

title: New Push for Help in Solving a Prosecutors 2001 Murder
description: SEATTLE  Ten years after a federal prosecutor here was shot to death while sitting at a computer in his basement, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and other federal law enforcement officials announced a new effort on Wednesday to seek public help in the investigation through a multimedia advertising campaign.

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 28, 2011
description: Thousands of the former rebels waited around Surt to enter the home town of Libyas ousted leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, while injured fighters were tended to in Bani Walid and Ras Lanuf.

title: Why Doctors Order So Many Tests
description: One afternoon when I was running later than usual, I recognized a familiar face among the patients waiting to see me. A voluble newspaper fanatic, the gentleman, in his 70s, was usually eager to discuss the latest headlines with me. That day, however, he was remarkably quiet. He was suffering from the flu. Im really feeling no good, he rasped.

title: Word of the Day | blare
description: blare \bler\ verb and noun

title: Turkey: Kurdish Party Agrees to End Boycott of Parliament
description: Turkeys pro-Kurdish party on Tuesday ended its four-month long boycott and agreed to join the parliamentary efforts to obtain a political resolution to the Kurdish conflict at a time when separatist violence has escalated in urban areas. Following the elections on June 29, deputies of the Peace and Democracy Party, or BPD, have refused to take their oaths in protest of court rulings that barred six of their elected members, currently in jail on terror-related charges, from joining the assembly. Security operations against Kurdish political activists with suspected links to the Kurdish Workers Party, or PKK, fighting for autonomy in the predominantly Kurdish southeast cast a shadow over political efforts to resolve the conflict, analysts say.

title: A Hijacker, a Longtime Fugitive and, Now, a Prisoner
description: George Wright, a convicted murderer who was among a group of hijackers who got away with $1 million in 1972, was finally taken into custody in Portugal on Monday.

title: British Soccer Officials Intrigued by N.F.L.s Rooney Rule
description: Hearing the words Rooney Rule and English soccer in the same breath may lead to this question: What has the Manchester United striker Wayne Rooney been up to now?

title: Braves Complete Collapse in 13-Inning Loss to Phillies
description: ATLANTA  In the baseball version of death by a thousand cuts, the Atlanta Braves culminated a collapse of epic proportions Wednesday with a 4-3 loss in 13 innings to the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
description: Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee wrote to the prime minister and Sonia Gandhi Wednesday, clarifying details of the controversial 2G memo being attributed to his ministry. The inter-ministerial note is a background paper and cannot be used as evidence in the court of law, he said, adding that it was prepared after a series of meetings attended by officials from several ministries, including those from the prime ministers office. (The Hindu)

title: Rays Cap Unlikely Journey to Playoffs
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  For much of the night, the outcome of the American League wild-card race seemed as if it would be decidedly different. The Yankees were battering the Tampa Bay Rays, and the Boston Red Sox were beating the Baltimore Orioles.

description: NYT Front Page for 09/29/11

title: A Changing War
description: In nine months in one of Afghanistans more violent areas, Company C of the First Battalion, 26th Infantry, has been a witness to a subtly changing war.

title: Rodriguez Expects to Play in Game 1
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Alex Rodriguez said he felt a little soreness in his surgically repaired right knee after playing for two days on the artificial turf at Tropicana Field. He was scratched from Wednesdays lineup for precautionary reasons.

title: What is Swaraj? Rethinking Self-Rule in the New India
description: Passionate and combative reader response to my essay, The Grammar of Anarchy published here on Sept. 17, makes one thing clear: Not only does the Anna Hazare movement of this past summer evoke strong reactions among readers, but the diverse legacies of founding figures like Mohandas Gandhi and Bhimrao Ambedkar, and the meaning of a defining text like the Constitution of India, also continue to matter deeply to the way in which Indians conceive of their political life well over six decades after independence from British rule.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 29, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Sept. 29, 1957 | New York Giants Play Last Baseball Game
description: On Sept. 29, 1957, the New York Giants baseball team played its final game in Manhattan. The Giants moved to San Francisco the following year, while its National League rivals, the Brooklyn Dodgers, moved to Los Angeles.

title: Bill Buckner Strikes Again
description: The Boston Red Soxs odds of reaching the playoffs peaked on Sept. 3. Following a 12-7 win against the Texas Rangers, they held a 9-game lead over the Tampa Bay Rays with 24 games to play, giving them a 99.6 percent chance of making the post-season.

title: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 29, 2011
description: The question was written by Susan Behrens, author of Grammar: A Pocket Guide. It comes from the article, Cancers Secrets Come Into Sharper Focus.

description: Who remembers that the Toronto Blue Jays beat the New York Yankees, 6-to-5, at Yankee Stadium on April 15, 1983?

title: Newspaper Confirms Release of South Korean Journalists in China
description: SEOUL, South Korea  China has released five South Koreans, including three journalists, who were detained while on a reporting trip along Chinas border with North Korea last week, a spokesman for the reporters newspaper said on Thursday.

title: Do You Know People Who Cheat on High-Stakes Tests?
description: A 19-year-old college student from Long Island allegedly was paid up to $2,500 a student to take the SAT exam for at least a half-dozen students at his former high school. What do you think of this news? Could it happen at your school? Do you know students who cheat on high-stakes tests, whether the SAT, another standardized national or state test, or important tests given at your school?

title: Poetry Pairing | That Unlucky Man
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Wislawa Szymborskas Identification with a news story about the death of Ida, a polar bear in Central Park, as well as an Op-Ed by Diane Ackerman about Idas companion, Gus, the Lonely Polar Bear.

title: Anticorporate Music Personified, In Close-Up, on an Intimate Stage
description: During one of many small logistical adjustments at Roseland on Wednesday night, Thom Yorke of Radiohead invited the crowd to picture a smoother, more elaborate show. The piano would rise out of a trap door, he suggested, instead of being wheeled across the stage. There would be no dead air. Somehow a giant inflatable pig would be involved.

title: For Jets, Clamors of Doubt Are Familiar
description: After the Jets 45-3 loss to the Patriots last December, I wrote that no matter how successful the Jets were, the teams doubters would never be far behind.

title: At Two Prague Spots, Tapas Is an Unlikely Success
description: Tapas, those small, fresh and flavorful dishes of Mediterranean specialties, are catching on in a country whose cuisine tends to be larger and heavier. Although you wont be getting tapas in Prague free with a drink  as you might in a Spanish city  two new restaurants in the Czech capital are taking the tapas concept and giving it a local twist.

title: Force India Formula One Racecar Goes Under the Brush for Charity
description: BMW has been unwrapping one-off art cars for over three decades, but the Force India Formula One team may have one-upped the Germans with a well-worn racer that has circled 16 circuits under the steady hands of Giancarlo Fisichella.

description: Anxiety runs high at Kettering University, formerly G.M. Institute, where students who once trained to work in the auto industry are looking outside their chosen field.

title: Spain Calls Off I.P.O. for National Lottery
description: Spain has shelved a planned initial public offering for just under a third of the national lottery operator, saying poor market conditions meant it would probably not have raised the amount the government wanted.

title: U.S. Senate Delegation Offers Praise and Caution to Libyas New Leaders
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Four Republican senators visited Tripoli on Thursday, the most prominent official American delegation to travel to the Libyan capital since the fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis government more than a month ago, and they said the former insurgents who toppled him were inspiring activists in Syria, Iran and even China and Russia.

title: From Chennai, the Sari With a Phone Pocket
description: In Chennai, even as the young have switched to jeans and skirts in the name of modernity and comfort, the sari still remains the preferred attire for many. The silk sari is reserved for those special occasions (like weddings) when it is worth even bearing the terrible Chennai heat to flaunt that latest design.

title: Thinking About Layoffs Again
description: Everyone else has gone, and Im sitting in my office, checking our cash-flow numbers. Three weeks without sales mean much less cash on hand than usual (we normally expect to collect $20,000 a week in deposits). Im not in trouble yet  we still have more than $150,000 in the bank  but next week Im scheduled to pay my people, and thats $35,000, every two weeks. And the news from the outside world is dreadful: Europe is collapsing, the stock market is collapsing, the government is likely to stop spending, it never ends.

title: In Fast-Gentrifying Bed-Stuy, a Celebration of Early Black Settlers
description: On a clear spring day in 1968, residents of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, including retirees and Boy Scouts, were on their hands and knees, digging underneath the intersection of Troy Avenue and Dean Street in what would become a major neighborhood archaeological excavation.

title: Strauss-Kahn and French Accuser Are Questioned
description: PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn was brought face to face on Thursday with the French writer who has accused him of trying to rape her eight years ago. In two hours of police questioning, Mr. Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, continued to deny any wrongdoing, one of his lawyers said.

title: Musical Festival Diary: Surprised by a Sell-Out
description: The New York Times asked the actress Donna Lynne Champlin, who is also a new mother, to be a guest blogger as she rehearses for Jane Austens Pride and Prejudice, a Musical, part of the New York Musical Theater Festival. Here she wonders what shes doing in a sold-out show.

title: Perry Slumps in Polls, but Not to Romneys Gain
description: There have been three scientific national polls released of Republican voters since the Sept. 22 debate: a CNN poll that was conducted over the last weekend, and polls by Fox News and Economist/YouGov released on Wednesday.

title: Theyre, Like, Awesome Opera Singers
description: ON the last day of summer three tenors were taping the Today show.

title: Matthew Weiners Mad House
description: The force behind "Mad Men," is particular about his Spanish Colonial in Los Angeles. Very particular.

title: Into Africa
description: In centuries past, Africa was known as the Dark Continent, which originated less as a slur than as a testament to the deficiency of mapmakers: clueless about the continents interior, they would often just blot it out, as if the place didnt fully exist. Opacity still marks the popular conception of Africa, especially when it comes to its cities, which take a back seat to safari-ready grasslands and oceans of desert. To change this, the celebrated London architect David Adjaye began a decade-long quest to photograph Africas urban spaces  practically all of them, save the war-torn Somali capital, Mogadishu. The project is really fueled by the widespread misconception of Africa as an impoverished or unpeopled expanse, said Adjaye, who was born to Ghanaian parents in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. I was born in a metropolitan city; I was born in a cosmopolitan condition among different groups of Africans, Indians and Chinese.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: E-Mails Value
description: Social media and real-time forms of communication like text messaging and chat give people plenty of ways to quickly connect with friends, family and colleagues, so what does that mean for humble old e-mail? Not much, according to Jeff Hardy and Derek Curtis, two vice-presidents at the software-management company SmarterTools, who explain on this weeks podcast why your e-mail address is still a highly valued piece of personal informationand why free e-mail isnt exactly free.

title: Supreme Court Ruling Could Revive Health Care for 2012 Campaign
description: The White Houses decision to seek a quick ruling on President Obamas landmark health care law will inject the controversial issue back into the nations political bloodstream at the height of the 2012 presidential campaign.

title: Pirates, Assassins and Other Altered States
description: Bernard Coakley, a marine geologist with the University of Alaska at Fairbanks, writes from the Arctic Ocean, where his team is reconstructing the geologic history of the Chukchi Shelf and the Chukchi Borderland.

title: Bahrain Court Hands Down Harsh Sentences to Doctors and Protesters
description: A court in Bahrain sentenced a protester to death on Thursday for killing a police officer in March, and it issued harsh prison terms to medical workers who treated protesters wounded during the months of unrest there this spring, according to the official Bahrain News Agency. The punishments drew strong criticism from rights groups.

title: Climate Equation: Coal + Ice = ?
description: We like to think of awe-inspiring landscapes as timeless. Certainly that was the way I regarded the Rongbuk Glacier when I first visited it in the fall of 2001. I was backpacking through Tibet for five weeks and had decided to stop overnight at the north base camp of Mount Everest, which was a short side trip from the road to Nepal. There, red-robed monks at a Tibetan monastery welcomed visitors.

title: N.F.L. Game Probabilities Are Back, With One Adjustment
description: Game predictions are back for 2011. As always, the probability model is based on passing, running, turnovers and penalty efficiency. But now, running is represented by Success Rate (SR) rather than Yards Per Carry (YPC). SR is the percentage of runs in which the a teams point expectancy (based on down, distance and yard line) has improved.

title: Keeping (Weaker) Eyes on the Road
description: Dr. Paul N. Orloff has been examining eyes for three decades, and a verity he has learned is that people are often the worst judges of their own vision. Everybody says they have normal eyes, said Dr. Orloff, an ophthalmologist in Manhattan. Their vision gets worse, and they dont even know it because the change is subtle.

title: Nokia to Eliminate 3,500 More Jobs
description: BERLIN  Nokia, the Finnish cellphone maker, said Thursday that it would eliminate 3,500 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, by closing a factory in Romania and transferring production to more efficient plants in Asia.

title: Thursday Reading: Preparing a Stay Bag for Winter Storms
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Unrecoveries and the New Normal
description: Larry Mishel has a very good piece systematically debunking the zombie claim that fears of regulation are holding back job creation. There is, literally, not a shred of evidence for this claim  not in the numbers, not in what businesses say. Yet it has been eagerly adopted not just by Republican politicians but by Chicago economists, Federal Reserve presidents, and more. I think the willingness of so many people to completely abandon any intellectual principles here, so that they can play for Team Republican  or maybe we should call that Team Oligarch  is part of what has me down these days.

title: For Christie and 2 Senators, Animus Is Mutual
description: When floods ravaged New Jersey in August, the states three top elected officials  Gov. Chris Christie and Senators Frank R. Lautenberg and Robert Menendez  joined President Obama in touring damaged areas.

title: Peltz Drops Bid for Family Dollar
description: Nelson Peltz, the investor who made a play for Family Dollar earlier this year, has dropped his bid after the retailer agreed to appoint his partner to its board.

title: Leading Off: Three Minutes That Rewrote History
description: For all the extended nuttiness, the long-form dramatic arc that was the final month of baseballs regular season, the blown bed times and the drawn-out agony that made the Red Sox and Braves collapses seem like they were stuck in slow motion, the end came in one roller coaster swoosh.

title: A Safer Shoulder Workout

title: X-Factor Recap: Now You See the Judge, Now You Dont
description: Halfway through yet another unrewarding installment of The X Factor on Fox on Wednesday night  one decent performance in two hours  it struck me that there is still a way for Simon Cowell to salvage this show, which so far has mostly served to prove the proposition that the singing-competition genre has played itself out.

title: One Strike Away and Then
description: Much is being said and written about the symmetry of baseballs amazing night, with the rain in Baltimore and the extra innings in St. Petersburg, Fla., conspiring to produce concurrent endings in the American League wild-card race only a few minutes apart in different cities Thursday morning.

title: Pro-Assad Protest Temporarily Traps U.S. Ambassador

description: The real estate listing and brokerage site Redfin has added a tool that gives home sellers access to details about the performance of real estate agents in more than a dozen major markets.

title: Kosovos Serbs Pressed to End Autonomy Push
description: MITROVICA, Kosovo  After years of impasse between the national government of Kosovo and ethnic Serbs demanding autonomy within their northern enclave in the new country, international pressure has intensified on the Serbs. And while the immediate result has been minor clashes, there is new hope for some movement toward a resolution for the last geopolitically unsettled chunk of the former Yugoslavia.

title: House Approves Stopgap Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Thursday gave quick approval to a stopgap spending bill that will finance the government for the first four days of October, until lawmakers can return and vote on a more ambitious seven-week spending bill.
