description: BEIJING  Twelve government employees have been fired and stripped of their Communist Party membership after an investigation into allegations that family planning officials kidnapped children in an impoverished rural area in the southern Chinese province of Hunan, Peoples Daily, the partys official newspaper, reported Thursday.

title: Bargemusic May Be Out of Dry Dock Soon
description: 4:33 p.m. | Updated Bargemusic, the floating concert hall moored near the Brooklyn Bridge that was shut down because of problems with its emergency exit gangway, may be open sooner rather than later.

title: In the Moments Before Deportation, Holding On to Hope
description: With shoes piled at the entranceway, the Habib house in Woodside, Queens, appeared to be having a celebration Wednesday night  teenagers drew on bright paper on the living room floor; women in headscarves and flowing salwar kameez dresses passed out cupcakes after a hearty meal of chicken biryani; kids bounced on leather couches and swung miniature American flags.

title: Feeling Soggy Under Brooding Skies
description: MONTPELIER, Ohio  Feeling a little pruney here. For several days now  pretty much since I wrote about how lucky Ive been with the weather  the skies have been broodingly gray, the air has been heavy, the wind has been contrary and chill, and for a few hours each day Ive been rained on. A couple of the days I could have stayed put, I guess, but at this point my legs start pedaling in the morning whether Im on the bike or not, and rain is hardly catastrophic. Anyway, now that the Yankees are in the playoffs, I want to be home for the World Series. (Am I confident theyll make it? Not really. As everyone knows, they dont have the starting pitching.)

title: Traveling Tellers, With Electronic Gear, Take Banking to Rural India

title: Theater Talkback: Plays About Plays, and How They Play
description: When Hamlet says The plays the thing he isnt extolling the general importance of theater. The prince of Denmark has in mind a particular play, with a very particular purpose. He calls it The Mousetrap, because it is devised to catch the conscience of a king, his uncle, whom he suspects of murdering his father.

title: With Tomatoes and Stern Words, Assad Supporters Strike Back

title: Affirmative Action in Admissions Protested With Pro-Rated Pastries
description: A club of college Republicans at the University of California, Berkeley organized a rather nontraditional protest of affirmative action this week: a bake sale.

title: Chasing Suspicions Of an Enemy Within
description: Nobody likes a naysayer. Until, of course, it becomes clear that yes was the wrong answer.

title: For Rays to Win, They Need Moore
description: 11:01 p.m. | Updated The Rays announced that Moore will indeed be their Game 1 starter. Kudos to Joe Maddon for cementing Tampa Bays reputation as the most forward-thinking franchise in the game.

title: Cash-Short, U.S. Weighs Asset Sales
description: WASHINGTON  Like Americans trying to raise quick cash by unloading their unwanted goods, the federal government is considering a novel way to reduce the deficit: holding the equivalent of a garage sale.

title: Job Losses Across the Developed World
description: Across the developed world, the biggest job losses in the 2008-9 downturn were in mining, manufacturing and utilities, according to new data from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Weak Legs Solved!
description: On Wednesday I challenged readers to figure out a fascinating case of a 52-year-old father of two disabled sons who experienced sudden weakness in his legs, low potassium and hyperthyroidism. More than 220 of you shared your thoughts and, astonishingly, 61 reached the correct diagnosis.

title: Seeing Things | Studio Visit: Lecia Dole-Recio
description: Cardboard shapes and cutouts were stacked on a table, jars of brightly colored paints lined a shelf, and the floor was covered with paint-spattered paper when I visited the Los Angeles artist Lecia Dole-Recio in her studio. Dole-Recio was hard at work on a new series of paintings for several solo exhibitions this fall, including a show at Richard Telles Fine Art in L.A. that is on view through Oct. 15 and an exhibition at the Secession in Vienna that opens in December.

title: After Online Campaign, Chinese Dog Meat Festival Is Canceled
description: BEIJING  In the whirlwind of growth that is modern China, the loss of ancient traditions often provokes dismay and outrage.

title: On Our Radar: China Orders Checks on Toxic Chemicals
description: Responding to protests that broke out after a toxic spill scare, China orders nationwide safety and environmental checks at plants that make dangerous chemicals. [Reuters]

title: Duck and Cover! Courtney Love to Tell All in Memoir
description: A tell-all memoir from Courtney Love will be released by William Morrow next fall, the publisher said on Thursday. Ms. Love, the musician and actress, will give an account of her life from childhood to the present, including tales from her own band, Hole, her stints in Hollywood, her marriage to Kurt Cobain and her relationships with Billy Corgan and Edward Norton. Ms. Love will work with a co-writer, Anthony Bozza.

title: Victory Dances, a Batting Title and Another Dose of Martyrdom
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

title: Sylvia Robinson, the Mother of Hip-Hop, Dies at 75
description: Sylvia Robinson, the singer, songwriter and record producer who formed the Sugar Hill Gang and made the first commercially successful rap recording, died early Thursday morning at a hospital in New Jersey. She was 75.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Carven
description: Its not spring for Guillaume Henrys girl  its summer. Shes warm, flushed from wandering through the woods, and as night falls she decides to pull back her wind-whipped hair. Texture without intention, is how Romina Manenti explained the feeling intended for the low ponytails backstage at Carven. She used Bumble and Bumble Thickening Spray and then Shine Brilliantine to coat the hair, which she then separated into two parts twisted inward, secured with an elastic. As if shes been outside all day, is how Nina Haverkamp described the makeup: a messy eyebrow, shiny taupe eyelid and slightly tinted lip. The mouth was prepped with Homeoplasmine from the pharmacy, which Haverkamp then wiped away to apply a dab of foundation. As for the specifics of the shadow, it was a combination of Mattese NYC shades that are no longer available: C51, the taupe and C80 (a shiny pink), if you wish to try and track them down.

title: Signing Off in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  When future filmmakers set the Iraq War to music, they will have eight years of spins from soldier-disc jockeys to draw on, a repository of songs that represents the tastes of a generation of warriors.

title: In European Crisis, Experts See Little Hope for a Quick Fix
description: It has happened time and again in recent months as Europes debt crisis has played out. Stocks stage a strong comeback on expectations that a solution has been found. Then they quickly resume their decline as hopes dissipate, leaving investors puzzled and frazzled.

title: Wheres My Boehner Boom?
description: Heres a question I havent seen asked: If fear of future regulations and taxes is holding business back, as everyone on the right asserts, why didnt the Republican victory in the midterms set off a surge in employment?

title: Its Spider-Man: Turn on the Lawyers, With Taymor Arbitration Hearing Set for Next Week
description: Julie Taymor will square off next week against the theater producers who fired her in March as director of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark as the two sides begin arbitration proceedings over more than $500,000 in royalties that Ms. Taymor says she is owed.

title: Twitter Study Tracks When We Are :)
description: However grumpy people are when they wake up, and whether they stumble to their feet in Madrid, Mexico City or Minnetonka, Minn., they tend to brighten by breakfast time and feel their moods taper gradually to a low in the late afternoon, before rallying again near bedtime, a large-scale study of posts on the social media site Twitter found.

title: 4 Face-Offs With Fracking Regulators
description: New Yorks charged debate over the natural gas extraction process known as hydrofracking will soon move to the face-to-face stage. At hearings set for November, pro- and anti-drilling forces will get a chance to address state regulators directly.

title: Banking in Villages, via Human A.T.M.
description: Thousands of human A.T.M.s are bringing banking to rural India, Vikas Bajaj reports Thursday. With the help of 60,000 correspondents, banks in India have set up 74 million bank accounts in hard-to-reach areas.

title: The Onions Twitter Posts Draw Scrutiny
description: The United States Capitol Police on Thursday said they were investigating The Onion, a satiric media organization, for making false reports on Twitter claiming that there was a hostage situation inside the Capitol building.

title: Pictures of the Day: Chile and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Chile, Pakistan, China and Britain.

title: Beach & Michael
description: In this homemade video, Michael Silver and Catherine Beach Lagassa recall meeting junior year at Michael's fraternity party at Northwestern.

title: Baseball Announces Times for First Four Days of Playoffs
description: When the playoff teams finally fell into order after the season ended Wednesday night, baseball could finally go to work on the playoff schedule. Here are the starting times for the first four days of games. All times are Eastern. All games will be broadcast on TBS, except one game as shown on TNT.

title: 150 Questions to Write or Talk About
description: For almost two years now, weve posted a fresh Student Opinion question every weekday.

title: Photos of the Moment | Rochas
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#613", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Schohajas Paris fashion week photo diary.

title: For Venture Capitalists, New Frontiers
description: A small network of angel investors and venture capital firms is developing to nurture young start-ups in the Middle East. DealBook's Evelyn Rusli speaks to a venture capitalist active in the region.

title: My Three Favorite Reinterpretations of Yankees Hats
description: In honor of the Yankees 16th trip to the postseason in the last 17 seasons, here are some extraordinary ways to express your team pride.

title: Photos Taken by the Cameras
description: Compact S.L.R.s from Nikon and Pentax offer professional results despite their tiny size.

title: Women Spared Deportation to Bangladesh, for Now
description: Nadia Habib and her mother, Nazmin Habib, are not being sent back to Bangladesh just yet.

title: Jackson Doctor Delayed Calling 911, Witness Says
description: LOS ANGELES  One of Michael Jacksons staff members testified on Thursday that on the day of the singers death, he saw Jackson lying on a bed while his personal physician gave him chest compressions with one hand. He also said the doctor had asked him to put various medical supplies in a bag before calling 911.

title: The Uncertain Life
description: My mother had just completed her first physical in about seven years. The new physician was young, energetic and articulate. His respectful handling of my 92-year-old mother had already earned my trust. Mom, who has a pacemaker and vascular dementia, is proud and easily insulted.

title: Tigers Rotation Heavy on Potential, Right-Handers
description: The last time the Detroit Tigers played in the postseason, in 2006, starting pitcher Justin Verlander was viewed as a possible star of the future. The wild card Tigers started that playoff run against the heavily-favored Yankees, and found a way to win, 3-1. That started a roll that lasted until the World Series, where the Tigers stumbled and won one game against the Cardinals.

title: ArtsBeat | September 29, 2011
description: Jon Pareles on the legendary Malian guitarist Boubacar Traor, Mike Hale on three new television shows and Vikas Bijaj on standup comedy in India.

title: A Lot of Music, and a Little Protest, as Hasidic Jews Come to Ukrainian Town
description: Happy New Year from Ukraine!

title: Candidates Spouses Make Fund-Raising Push
description: In the final days before the close of the third quarter fund-raising period, the presidential candidates are bringing out the big guns: their spouses.

title: Portland Design Beyond Put a Bird on It
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#650", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: The Baseball Gods Have Spoken
description: I have written before about the folly of Major League Baseballs plans to expand its postseason by two teams, creating a sudden-death wild card playoff in both leagues. This foolishness is probably a done deal: Rumor has it the new playoff system could into effect as early as next season, or 2013 at the latest. But if I were the owners and players, I would interpret last nights extraordinary finish to the regular season as a sign from the baseball gods, warning them to reconsider their playoff-expanding madness before its too late.

title: When Bakers Go Bad
description: A good friend of ours is a tremendous baker. She often wins our annual community bake-off. Last month, she sent us some whoopie pies that were, frankly, inedible. Next weekend is the bake-off, and when I asked what she would be entering (assuming it would be her killer carrot cake), she said, I think Ill do those whoopie pies again. Should we have said something about them last month? Should we say something now? Larry, Philadelphia

title: Jon Pareles on Metals, the new album by Feist; a conversation with and performance by the rising French Moroccan singer Hindi Zahra; and reviews of new albums by Mindless Behavior, LeAnn Rimes, Bill Frisell and John Scofield. Ben Ratliff is the host.
description: Jon Pareles on Metals, the new album by Feist; a conversation with and performance by rising Moroccan singer Hindi Zahra,.reviews of new albums by Mindless Behavior, LeAnn Rimes, Bill Frisell and John Scofield. Ben Ratliff is your host.

title: Saudi Men Go to Polls; Women Wait
description: CAIRO  Saudi men voted in local elections on Thursday for just the second time in the history of the conservative kingdom, but the polls remained closed to a majority of the Saudi population, including women, who were promised the right to vote in municipal elections scheduled for 2015 in a royal decree issued last week.

title: The Glory of Sweep Panorama
description: In my Times column today, I reviewed radical new cameras from Nikon and Pentax  two new entries in the race to perfect the pocket S.L.R. They have interchangeable lenses but have bodies small enough for a pants pocket.

title: North Street Capital Buys Spyker for $43.5 Million
description: The Swedish company that owns Saab agreed on Thursday to sell its Spyker Cars unit, a maker of ultra-high-end sports cars, to the American private equity firm North Street Capital for 32 million, or $43.5 million.

title: Strong Second Half Lands Tigers at Yankees Door
description: A. L. division series matchups: Tigers vs. Yankees | Rays vs. Rangers

title: Germany Approves Bailout Expansion, Leaving Slovakia as Main Hurdle
description: BERLIN  Removing another significant obstacle in the European debt crisis, the German Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Thursday for the expansion of the bailout fund for heavily indebted European countries. The front now shifts to tiny Slovakia amid questions about an approval process already months long and still not complete.

title: General Motors to Equip Crossovers With Front-Center Air Bags
description: On Thursday at its Milford Proving Grounds in Michigan, General Motors showed a new safety feature intended to increase occupant safety in the event of a side-impact collision. If the vehicle were hit, an air bag positioned between the driver and front passenger would deploy.

title: Photos of the Moment | Balmain
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#299", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Kava Gornas Paris fashion week photo diary.

title: Wozniacki Lets Match Slip Away
description: No. 1 Caroline Wozniacki suffered a blow to her hopes of ending 2011 atop the W.T.A. rankings Wednesday night in Tokyo, falling 7-5, 1-6, 6-4 to 43rd-ranked Estonian Kaia Kanepi in her third round match in Ariake Coliseum at the Toray Pan Pacific Open.

title: Stanton Is Just Getting Started
description: He passed Ted Williams and Andruw Jones earlier this month. He fell one short of Mickey Mantle and ended up tied with Bob Horner. Its safe to say that Mike Stanton of the Marlins put himself in some distinguished company among 21-year-old home run hitters.

title: Banks Adding Debit Card Fees
description: Starting Saturday, big banks must comply with a new regulation that caps the fees they can charge merchants for processing debit card purchases. But some consumers are already seeing the impact of the change, in the form of higher fees charged on their checking accounts, as banks seek to recoup lost revenue.

title: Where the Sandwiches Are Named for Everyman
description: The sandwiches at Papa Johns Deli on City Island in the Bronx are priced for workers grinding out a living on a city paycheck.

title: Revealing the Layers of Cubas Architecture
description: The Cuban government may be sending a subtle message to potential American tourists that preserved architecture and antiques collections are viewable throughout the island. Four new coffee table books on the subject have been published, and the authors report few restrictions on what they could document.

title: Week 4 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Neighborhood Joint | The City Quilter
description: Patrons browse books and fabrics on West 25th Street, the heart of the citys quilting community.

title: Naeem Khans Spring 2012 collection at The Fashion Week in New York
description: Models walk the runway unveiling Naeem Khans Spring 2012 collection at The Fashion Week in New York on Sept. 15, 2011.

title: Mapping Through Georgia
description: Im a huge fan of the Timess Opinionator series that is taking us day by day through the Civil War; todays entry, about how Frederick Law Olmstead used cartography as a weapon of diplomacy, is great fun.

title: A Closer Look at CO2s Long Goodbye
description: Sept. 30, 10:04 a.m. | Updated Theres been a steady stream of distracting commentary here and elsewhere positing that carbon dioxide, the greenhouse gas at the heart of concerns about a growing and hard-to-reverse human influence on climate, is far more ephemeral than climate scientists assert.

title: The Revolution Arrived, Then It Was Drawn
description: A powerful country is a bloody, chaotic mess. Its public coffers have been drained dry by useless wars and wanton misspending. Private wealth is locked in the hands of a grasping few.

title: Forays Beyond Home for Celebrity Chefs
description: In the latest batch of new hotel restaurants, a trio of European celebrity chefs travels far and wide.

title: 36 Hours in Krakow, Poland
description: IN Krakow, Polands second city, comparisons are unavoidable. The Old Towns stately main square, ringed by outdoor cafes and dominated by the twin spires of a magnificent church? Like Pragues, but larger. The hilltop castle lording over a languorous river? Like Budapests, but older. The rollicking night-life scene thumping in grimy tenements? Like Berlins, but tamer. But this rejuvenated city now also packs some original surprises. Museums are sprouting in formerly dilapidated factories, and offbeat art galleries are showcasing works from the citys creative class. Shiny new restaurants are claiming space among their bohemian brethren, infusing the once-staid local food scene with fresh, modern fare. All this means that Krakow may soon be the cool, post-Communist enclave with which Europes next crop of emerging cities is compared.

title: 36 Hours in Krakow
description: Museums are sprouting in formerly dilapidated factories, and off-beat art galleries are showcasing works from the citys creative class.

title: When the Streets Were Meaner, the Times Even Leaner
description: In the 1970s, when Leland Bobb took these pictures, photography was still just a hobby for him. He was the drummer in a band called City Lights that played the downtown scene, where he eventually photographed the Ramones, Mink DeVille, Patti Smith, Television and others.

title: Coco Rochas New Focus
description: Several months ago, the Canadian model Coco Rocha was trolling the personal technology blog Mashable, which is, apparently, something she does quite frequently with her artist husband, James Conran. James and I are big electronic buffs and whenever we find out about new cool things, were like, How can we get our hands on these things? Rocha said in a telephone interview.

title: The obstacles facing President Obama in his bid for re-election and the latest news on the Republican candidates for president.
description: The obstacles facing President Obama in his bid for re-election and the latest news on the Republican candidates for president. White House correspondent Helene Cooper and deputy political editor Gerry Mullany join Michael Shear, chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com.

title: Setting Fund-Raising Expectations, a Day Before the Deadline
description: Welcome to a contest some of the top-tier candidates for president seem eager to avoid winning: Who can show the most robust fund-raising numbers in the third quarter, which ends on Friday at midnight?

title: A Piece of Brooklyn in Philadelphia: 3rd Ward Collective Branches Out
description: 3rd Ward, the five-year-old Brooklyn arts and design collective, is expanding to Philadelphia, the organization announced on its blog.

title: Where Novices and Artists Indulge the Quilter Within
description: THE stores are already stuffed with polar fleece, Gore-Tex and Thinsulate. But as temperatures dip, one unassuming shop in Midtown Manhattan has everything needed to weather an old-fashioned winter in the oldest of ways  though you should start sewing now. Its the City Quilter, the heart of New Yorks quilting community for nearly 15 years and a destination for fabric lovers from around the world.

title: Popcast: Two Chanteuses
description: On this weeks show, The Timess music writers discuss a popular singer-songwriter who is returning after a long absence, and talk to and hear a performance by another who is starting to come into her own.

title: Huntsman Moves Headquarters to New Hampshire
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is moving his presidential campaign headquarters to New Hampshire from Florida, aides said Thursday, a decision that underscores that his path to the nomination is wholly dependent on trying to score an upset in the nations first primary.

title: Animals Are Outside Today
description: Animals Are Outside Today

title: Nina Ricci: Heirloom Flowers
description: The extended summer weather in Paris may have made for an appropriate backdrop for spring collections that have been heavy on the bandeau-and-long-skirt look thats been playing everywhere from Prada in Milan all the way to the Nina Ricci show on the Avenue Foch tonight.

title: X-Factor Lifts Fox
description: Fox executives breathed a sigh of relief on Wednesday night as The X-Factor posted strong second-week numbers, leading the broadcast network to a No. 1 finish in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and averaging 11.5 million total viewers.

title: Odette Fada Is Returning, With a Chelsea Market Restaurant
description: Odette Fada, the longtime chef at San Domenico, and then its offspring, SD26, will be the chef at a restaurant that the Italian pasta brand Giovanni Rana is opening this winter in Chelsea Market.

title: TimesCast | September 29, 2011
description: President Obama faces a changing electoral landscape; the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on Bahrain's latest crackdown; and Islamists prepare for elections in Egypt and Tunisia.

title: Rating the No. 1s: Aquaman, Flash, and More
description: Two Times staffers and comic-book fans, George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler, have reviewed all 52 DC Comics titles that have been rebooted as part of a companywide effort to revive the brand. In the last of five weekly installments they discuss Aquaman, Superman, Flash and and others that were published on Wednesday.

title: Prosecutors Seek to Unseal Rajaratnams Medical History
description: Federal prosecutors moved on Thursday to unseal court documents listing some of Raj Rajaratnams medical conditions, arguing that the convicted insider trader was hiding behind unspecified health problems to justify receiving a lighter sentence.

title: Why Lehman May Be a Long, Slow Train Ride
description: In 1970 the Penn Central railroad unexpectedly filed for bankruptcy, nearly taking down the money market in the process. It was the biggest bankruptcy case of its time, and litigation surrounding the case continued well past the turn of the century.

title: Gracious Home
description: Maison Gerard: The new outpost of Gerardus Widdershoven and Benoist F. Druts blue-chip gallery, on East 10th Street in Manhattan, features Art Deco, midcentury and contemporary furnishings in a former 1970s-era beauty parlor that is strikingly industrial and surprisingly intimate. Go to interactive feature >>

title: U.S. Picks 22 for 2 October Friendlies
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the U.S. national team, on Thursday named a 22-man roster for two coming friendly matches  against Honduras in Miami Gardens, Fla., and Ecuador in Harrison. N.J.

title: A Two-Bedroom Trial Balloon
description: EVER since her childhood in the Tokyo suburbs, Mariko Izawa Sheldons dream was to live in New York City. When I saw pictures I was so impressed, she said. I determined someday, someday I will live here.

title: Notes From Google Zeitgeist
description: At Zeitgeist, the annual conference that Google hosts for its advertisers and other customers, the conversation ranged far from technology. But Google being Google, it always came back to the ways in which technology is changing the world, from Googles collective brain to whether social media is journalism. Here are a few excerpts from the conference, held Monday and Tuesday in Paradise Valley, Ariz., from my Twitter feed, @clairecm; YouTube and the Web.

title: A Tea Party Darlings Offer on Social Security
description: The writings of Friedrich Hayek, the 20th century free-market enthusiast and Nobel laureate, have long been a favorite of libertarians, who have used them to argue that government programs like Social Security and Medicare put the nation and its people on what Hayek called The Road to Serfdom.

title: Dimons Bathroom Gets a Diner Double
description: A commode fit for a Wall Street C-suite has made its way to the unlikeliest of places: a greasy-spoon diner on Manhattans Lower East Side.

title: For Children
description: For Children

title: The Case for Hiring a Lawyer
description: FIRST-TIME buyers in New York City confront a series of choices: co-op or condo, high-rise or walk-up, a second bathroom or just steps from the subway? But there seems to be consensus on at least one decision  whether to hire a real estate lawyer.

title: Ecclestone Talks of Cheating, Back in the Days
description: An interview appeared Thursday on the official Formula One Web site in which both Bernie Ecclestone, the series promoter and owner of the Web site, and Christian Horner, the director of the Red Bull team, discuss common themes.

description: Greg Bishop of The Times, along with The Quads veteran contributor Zach Hillesland, will be hosting our college football watch party all day Saturday, right here at The Quad. Hell bring you highlights and analysis from games around the country and spend some time answering your questions.

title: Is the End Near for the PlayBook?
description: OTTAWA _ A semiconductor analysts in London, John Vihn of Collins Stewart, said in a investment note on Thursday that Research in Motion may have stopped production of its BlackBerry PlayBook tablet and may stop the development of all tablets.

title: Sparkle Spot
description: Irene Neuwirth prefers to keep things low key. The Los Angeles-based fine jewelry designer has never been one for pop-up shops or Fashions Night Out extravaganzas. But when BOFFO, the art and culture nonprofit, approached her about participating in its annual designer series, Neuwirth just couldnt resist. When I was a CFDA/VogueFashion Fund finalist, I became really friendly with Richard Chai, says Neuwirth, by way of explaining her excitement about working with BOFFO, the group that initiated Chais memorable ice age pop-up last year. After visiting Richards shop, I thought, What a cool project. This is something I would like to be a part of. Neuwirths shop (57 Walker Street), which features a starry metal installation by the architect Marc Fornes of The Very Many and a living wall of lush green plants, is open until Oct. 12 and stocks Neuwirths one-of-a-kind rainbow moonstone pendant necklaces and pieces from her new diamond collection. I love the contrast between my very modern and feminine gems and Marcs really modern and conceptual work, Neuwirth says.

description: Movies

title: Peoria Got a Raise
description: In the first quarter of this year, the average weekly wage in the United States increased by 5.2 percent, to $935, compared to the same period last year. But in Peoria County, Ill., workers received an average raise of 18.9 percent, to $944.

title: An Exclusive Clip From Carnage
description: The 49th New York Film Festival opens Friday with the North American premiere of Roman Polanskis latest film, Carnage. Above is an exclusive first look at a scene starring Jodie Foster, John C. Reilly, Christoph Waltz and Kate Winslet.

title: Oh, the Devilish Delights Of the Old-School Diva
description: Under Peter Gelb as general manager, the Metropolitan Opera is a tasteful place. New productions tend to be handsome and conscientious. Singers are usually prepared and intelligent. Acting is well considered and thoughtful. Sanity prevails, and opera is the better for it.

title: Late Night Icons See Their Ratings Slide
description: 1:14 p.m. | Updated The decline of televisions two big late-night stars was more noticeable than ever during televisions premiere week, as The Tonight Show With Jay Leno and the Late Show With David Letterman were both beaten by ABCs Nightline  a first during that week.

title: Violin Voices, Both Distinct And Unified
description: Juilliard Baroque, the ensemble drawn from the faculty of the Juilliard Schools historical-performance program, devoted its first concert of the season, at the schools Paul Hall on Tuesday evening, to an intriguing byway of the Baroque repertory: music for three violins.

title: A Tribute to a Reporter With Legendary Drive and Swagger
description: In 1997, the Daily News columnist Mike McAlary interrupted his treatments for cancer to interview Abner Louima and write about the brutalization of the Haitian immigrant at the hands of the police. His series of columns  the first one telling New Yorkers to be afraid, be very afraid if this story is true,  won a Pulitzer Prize for commentary. Mr. McAlary died of colon cancer on Christmas Day 1998 at age 41.

title: In Oporto, Fado Makes a Comeback
description: Fado, that wonderfully melancholic music of Portugal, had almost disappeared from Oporto, the northern city known for its sweet, tawny port wine and the Douro River, which draws flocks of trekkers and river barges. Fado lived on in Lisbon, but in Oporto most fado houses had closed.

title: Creating Some of That New Black Magic
description: In the unlikely event that a modern version of Frank Sinatras Rat Pack restores Mad Men-era lounge singing to the forefront of pop fashion, Seth MacFarlane shows potential to compete for the title New Chairman of the Board, or at least a latter-day Dean Martin. Known as the creator of Family Guy, Mr. MacFarlane, 37, turns out to be a devotee of the American Songbook.

title: Spare Times for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: 2011 New Yorker Festival (Friday through Sunday) Some say talk is cheap, and it will at least be reasonably priced for a good number of the talks, panel discussions and other events that are part of the annual cultural festival sponsored by The New Yorker at locations around New York City. All things literary is the focus: a plethora of authors, including, above, Joyce Carol Oates and Jonathan Franzen, and, below, Junot Daz, will take part in discussions with titles like The Dark Side, Writing About America and The Reliable Narrator. But there will also be screenings, a brunch and conversations on myriad topics with actors like Ralph Fiennes, Steve Martin and Edie Falco. Musicians and singers like Barbara Cook and the National will perform and take part in interviews. Although events may be listed as sold out on the Web site, some tickets are still available to each. Those can be bought on Friday from noon to 4 p.m. at the SVA Theater, 333 West 23rd Street, Chelsea. (A limited number of tickets to many offerings can also be purchased on the day of the event at its location.) And, for those who prefer to observe while sitting at home, some conversations will be streamed live online via FORA.tv for $9.95 a program. For a schedule and ticket prices, newyorker.com/festival; for online information, FORA.tv. The Talk of the Town is the talk of the town. (Anne Mancuso)

title: A Musical Version of Gatsby, Four Decades Late
description: Renewed attention to The Great Gatsby has come in the form of huge Jazz Age lawn parties, seven-hour staged readings and even a 3-D movie, filming now in Australia. But here comes Ben West, who has dug into the past to produce his own tribute to F. Scott Fitzgeralds great novel: a musical.

title: Cult Hits, Carnage and Even Chaplin
description: Is more more? Is it better? Moviegoers may be wondering the same thing when faced with the astonishment of offerings in this years New York Film Festival. In addition to a main slate dotted with some of cinemas brightest stars  Michelle Williams! Bela Tarr!  this year there are screenings of old goodies like Charlie Chaplins Gold Rush; a documentary program; dozens of hot-off-the-iMac avant-garde attractions; a 37-title tribute to the Japanese studio Nikkatsu; and free talks with movers and shakers.

title: Priming a City Dweller for Soaring Peaks
description: WHEN I lived in New York City long ago, I never thought Id need an altitude adjustment. But after my love for skiing had goaded me into moving to the winter sports paradise of Utah, I learned that being able to handle the soaring peaks of the Wasatch Front and the Rocky Mountains in Colorado required serious physical preparation.

title: Loren Munk: Location, Location, Location,Mapping the New York Art World
description: Lesley Heller Workspace

title: Brian Jungen
description: Casey Kaplan

title: Frank Benson: Human Statue (Jessie)
description: Taxter & Spengemann

title: Definitions: Shalva Alkhanaidze, Natela Grigalashvili, Guram Tsibakhashvili
description: Newman Popiashvili Gallery

title: Adam Marnie: Locus Rubric
description: Derek Eller Gallery

title: An Architectural Whodunit
description: IT has been a burr under my architectural saddle for at least a decade: a gnarled fragment of an Art Nouveau building, as deformed as the hunchback of Notre Dame, just off Brooklyns elegant Grand Army Plaza.

title: Privacy Groups Ask F.T.C. to Review New Facebook Features
description: If you listen to Lionel Richie several times a week, do you want that popping up on your Facebook page for all the world to see? What if you click on a glowing obituary of Osama bin Laden? How about details of where you like to jog daily at twilight?

title: Jeff Nichols on 'Take Shelter'
description: Jeff Nichols, the writer and director of Take Shelter, discusses his film.

title: Siah Armajani: 1957-1964
description: Meulensteen

title: A New Couch for Freud to Rest On
description: AFTER most performances of the Off Broadway drama Freuds Last Session the actor Martin Rayner, who portrays Sigmund Freud, stands by the exit to conduct a behavioral study of his own. After thanking theatergoers for attending, he asks them how they heard about the production, which has been playing since July 2010 at a theater at a Y.M.C.A on the Upper West Side of Manhattan: a relatively long and financially promising run at a location off the beaten track.

title: A Trip to China Can Make a Guy Hate His iPhone
description: MIKE DAISEY, one of the great solo storytellers of contemporary theater, has traveled the world performing sharp, polemical and extemporaneous monologues about Amazon.com, national security, James Frey and a host of other subjects. He brings his latest piece, The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, to the Public Theater from Oct. 11 through Nov. 13.

title: Hungary Blames the Banks
description: Homeowners took risks in 2005 and 2006 that came to seem foolish, if not reckless, and wound up with mortgages they could not afford. Some blamed the banks for luring them into taking the risks. The banks offered some modifications, but said they believed it was the homeowner who should suffer for gambling and losing.

title: A Young Man at Sea, Searching for Himself
description: No phone, no pool, no pets, no cigarettes. Ultimate freedom. Thats part of what Christopher McCandless, the idealistic and doomed young hero of Jon Krakauers nonfiction book Into the Wild, scratched onto the walls of an abandoned bus in remote Alaska. It was the same bus in which hed later, in winter, starve to death.

title: Fury Cannot Touch Me
description: WHEN I went to drop off my 5-year-old granddaughter at my sons house earlier this summer, I saw a plastic garbage bag jammed full of his clothes on the front porch. His wife had put him out. And I bet she was pretty angry when she did it. People who put their loved ones stuff in black garbage bags are making a statement, and its not, Lets settle this like adults.

title: A Splintering Psyche or Omens of Disaster?
description: Youve got a good life, Curtis, says Dewart, Curtiss best friend and co-worker. (Dewart is played by Shea Whigham, Curtis by the amazing Michael Shannon.) I think thats the best compliment you can give a man: take a look at his life and say, Thats good.

title: Arizona to Hold G.O.P. Debate on Dec. 1
description: CNN and the Arizona Republican Party will hold a presidential primary debate on Dec. 1, the network announced on Thursday.

title: Waste Not, Want It
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#715", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);Pascale Mussard lifts the top of the large packing crate, and I look inside. She has already shown me around her workroom at Herms, a treat for anyone interested in how things are made, and now she is permitting me a peek at a project to which she is profoundly attached. I find it hard not to crack a smile at her kindergarten-teacher gravity, enhanced by the canvas apron that covers her long white Indian linen dress. Strands of blond hair escape from her bun.

title: For Novices and Artists, a Place for the Quilter Within
description: The stores are already stuffed with polar fleece, Gore-Tex and Thinsulate. But as temperatures dip, one unassuming shop in Midtown Manhattan has everything needed to weather an old-fashioned winter in the oldest of ways  though you should start sewing now. Its the City Quilter, the heart of the citys quilting community for nearly 15 years and a destination for fabric lovers from around the world.

title: Chinese Stocks Plummet on News of Justice Department Inquiry
description: Shares of some Chinese companies listed on exchanges in the United States tumbled on Thursday after a top American regulator said that the Justice Department was reviewing accounting irregularities at various companies based in China.

title: The Healing Powers of a Friendship When Lifes Complications Strike
description: 50/50, a feel-good and slightly bad comedy-drama about a young mans fight against cancer, aims to put a tear in your eye and a sob in your throat, if not for long. Certainly the waterworks dont need much plumbing, as might be expected when the 27-year-old Adam (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), a Seattle radio producer, learns that he has a malignant spinal tumor. Shock and grief and bewilderment ensue as do jokes about barbered testicles and the wisdom of playing the C (as in cancer) card with chicks.

title: 400 Years Old and Ageless
description: WASHINGTON  The race, we know, is not to the swift. And we are well acquainted with the fate of a kingdom divided against itself. We may tell it not in Gath, and publish it not in the streets of Ashkelon, yet that still, small voice will be clearly heard. We reap far more than a whirlwind from the phrases and rhythms left to us by the King James translation of the Bible, whose 400th anniversary is being commemorated this year.

title: Determining a Homes Value
description: AGAIN and again, you hear about mortgage rates hitting historic lows; now youre thinking its time to refinance. But one hitch may hold some homeowners back: declining property values.

title: European Union Looks East at Summit, and Sees Trouble on Horizon
description: BRUSSELS  The idea was to concentrate on closer trade ties and visa liberalization, as leaders of the European Union and six eastern neighbors began two days of talks in Warsaw.

title: L.I.R.R. Service Is Knocked Out by Lightning Strike
description: Updated, 12:30 a.m. Friday | Service on the Long Island Rail Road was largely suspended out of Penn Station and Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn Thursday evening after a lightning strike near the Jamaica hub of the railroad knocked out signal systems. Officials were warning customers that the continuing trouble with the signals would most likely affect service Friday morning.

title: The Pentagon Budget, Under Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Knowing Guidelines for Co-op Loans

title: Hanging With Cattelan
description: THE artist Maurizio Cattelan, like Andy Warhol before him, has always loved a good doppelgnger, someone to send in his stead for lectures and appearances while he finds something more interesting to do. For several years, in a stunt that became something of an artwork in its own right, the curator Massimiliano Gioni presented himself at public events as Mr. Cattelan, thoroughly confusing everybody.

title: Putting Names to the Greats of Indian Art
description: Art historians rarely rest, and the world is generally a better place for their exertions. Scholars of the great painting traditions of India, for example, have taken knowledge of their subject to new levels in the past few decades, with their assiduous combing of documents, deciphering of inscriptions and scrutinizing of artworks.

title: When Life Becomes Art
description: At the Olympic Restaurant on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, customers who heed the call of nature are in for a pleasant surprise. The grungy stairway leading to the second floor is ominous, but on opening the door to the unisex lavatory, they will discover a clean, well-lighted bathroom with the black tile floor, sleek stainless steel fixtures, dark wood wainscoting and gleaming white sink of a high-end corporate washroom. It is a work of art  not just figuratively, but literally. Called Power Toilet / J.P. Morgan Chase, it is a fully functional copy of an executive bathroom at that investment banks offices, created by the collaborative art-making group Superflex.

title: Personal Beliefs on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Meal on Death Row
description: To the Editor:

title: Good at Chess? A Hedge Fund May Want to Hire You
description: Boaz Weinsteins opening move on Wall Street came as a result of chess.

title: A Good Principal
description: To the Editor:

title: Ryan Freedman
description: Mr. Freedman, 29, is the chairman and chief executive of Corigin Holdings, a real estate development and investment company based in New York, and one of the largest private providers of student housing to New York University.

title: TimesCast | Bellwether States
description: September 29, 2011 - President Obama focuses on the changing electoral dynamics in certain swing states.

title: Raid the Archives With Caution
description: PARIS

title: The Bisexual Squid
description: To the Editor:

title: Wonder of the Age
description: An exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art focuses on identifying Indian artists.

title: Taxes and Infrastructure
description: To the Editor:

title: A Teenager and a Poem in the Post-9/11 World
description: Margaret is about Lisa, a Manhattan teenager whose life of relative ease and entitlement becomes entangled with the fate of a middle-aged woman named Monica. A viewer may pass some of the interesting, meandering first hour of this movie  Kenneth Lonergans long-awaited, star-crossed follow-up to You Can Count on Me  wondering when Margaret will show up. She does, sort of, by means of an English class recitation of Spring and Fall, by Gerard Manley Hopkins, a stirring and enigmatic Victorian poem addressed to a young girl of that name.

title: David, Delacroix, and Revolutionary France
description: Images from the exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum.

title: Congress Wants Meeting With N.F.L., Union and Anti-Doping Agency to Discuss H.G.H.
description: WASHINGTON  The leaders of the House committee that investigated steroid use in baseball reached out Thursday to the leaders of the N.F.L., its players union and the United States Anti-Doping Agency to broker a meeting about the leagues stalled testing program for human growth hormone.

title: From Run-Down to Renovated
description: NEWARK

title: 10 Years of Hope, Trying to Save Abandoned Newborns
description: When Bloomington police officers pulled a newborn baby from a toilet early Sunday, it was the first time in more than a year that an unwanted Illinois infant had been left in a potentially dangerous place.

title: Afghanistans Leaders Sour on Pakistan and Peace Talks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans president and other senior leaders announced Thursday that they were rethinking the countrys relationship with Pakistan and its negotiations with the Taliban because talks had yielded so little.

title: The Keys to Victory
description: States like Colorado and Virginia may be the Democrats must-win states.

title: Newsies Catches Broadways Attention
description: New York theater owners have approached Disney Theatrical Productions about mounting the companys Newsies the Musical on Broadway this season after the new show received strongly positive reviews this week at the Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey, according to people familiar with the discussions.

title: Extra! Bizarre Sales Spike for 2 Papers
description: It is possible there is some larger lesson for ailing newspaper sales in the sudden good fortune of The Suffolk Times and The Riverhead News-Review, two modest Long Island weeklies that saw an unprecedented sales spike last week as mysterious buyers swooped in to buy every copy they could.

title: From a Video Clip, a Reality Star in Trading
description: Wall Street now has its equivalent of a reality TV star. A clip from the BBC of a self-described trader admitting to dreaming of financial doom as a money spinner has spread like wildfire over the Internet. The would-be Gordon Gekko doesnt work for a Wall Street firm, but his vulgar amorality offers a description of trading that has struck a chord with a public smoldering over bank bailouts.

title: A Tale of Russia Haunted by Ghosts and the Living Dead
description: My Joy, a stark, moody, often beautiful-looking dark fable from Russia, opens with the image of mixing, churning concrete thats soon followed by a shot of a man being tossed into a trough by several others and covered with the gray gunk. The filmmaker, Sergei Loznitsa, never returns to this terrible scene (its either a murder or a funeral), which passes without explanation even as it creates an air of dread that instantly settles around the young truck driver, Georgy (Viktor Nemets), who sets the story in cryptic motion.

title: Madoff Trustee Says Effect of Ruling Wont Be as Bad as First Thought
description: The trustee for Bernard L. Madoffs fraud victims said on Thursday that he had overestimated how much his recovery efforts would be affected by a court ruling this week in his case against the owners of the New York Mets.

title: McGraw-Hill in Talks to Lead Stock Indexes Joint Venture
description: Two of the best-known stock market gauges in the world  the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poors 500  may share the same home under a deal being discussed.

title: Lowly Orioles Took the Spoiler Role to New Heights
description: It is hard to refer to a team that won 69 games and finished 28 games out of first place as a giant killer, but the Baltimore Orioles spent the last few weeks as a thorn in the side of the American League titans.

title: Making Change Happen, on a Deadline
description: The PreFabricated Building Parts Production Enterprise in Addis Ababa is a state-owned company that makes concrete walls and other structures, mainly for the Ethiopian governments low-cost housing program. Public-sector construction companies in the third world are not generally known for energy, flexibility, risk-taking or creative thinking. PreFabricated, in other words, does not seem like the kind of business that would or could do astonishing things in a hurry.

title: In Russia, Turning Back the Clock
description: Washington

title: Bold Commercials and Flavors Aim to Spice Up Chilis Brand
description: IN a new ad for Chilis, the 36-year-old restaurant chain, an office worker in his 20s approaches the cubicle of a co-worker, and asks, Hey Jill, you want to go to Chilis tonight?

title: Mining Past Boyfriends for Husband Material (You Never Know)
description: If nothing else the ramshackle, scatterbrained rom-com Whats Your Number? confirms the arrival, heralded by Bridesmaids, of a new subgenre, the smutty chick flick, into the Hollywood mainstream. The girl talk of Ally Darling (Anna Faris), a rude, free-spirited bachelorette in her 30s who is still looking for the one, and her friends involves breezy jokes about penises and vaginas.

title: Judge Delays Blagojevich Sentencing Indefinitely
description: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois who tried to sell President Obamas Senate seat, has waited three months to learn his fate after being convicted on multiple corruption charges. Now he will have to wait longer.

title: That Gallery Facade Sure Looks Familiar
description: Matthew Marks arrived at Ellsworth Kellys studio in Columbia County, N.Y., last year with an architectural model of his new Los Angeles-area gallery. It was meant as both visual aid and inspiration. Mr. Marks was hoping to entice Mr. Kelly into creating something for the buildings facade.

title: The Enduring Appeal of the Barn-Style Home
description: A Barn Home in Kent, Conn.

title: Element of Indian Culture Feeds a Rising Crime Wave
description: A husband, wife and their 6-year-old son had just returned from the airport to their suburban home in Fremont. It was a sunny Sunday afternoon, Sept. 11, as they unloaded luggage from their car. Seemingly out of nowhere, two men appeared, one pointing a handgun.

title: The Call of Converted Barns
description: ROXBURY

title: Optimism of Intellectuals Ebbs in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  In a note to friends brimming with defiance and poetic musings, citing as inspiration Jesus, Imam Hussein, Gandhi, Che Guevara and the Buddha, Hadi al-Mahdi prophesized his own murder.

title: After Arrest, a Wider Inquiry on SAT Cheating
description: When Samuel Eshaghoff, a 19-year-old sophomore at Emory University, was arrested on Tuesday for allegedly accepting money to take the SAT for six Long Island high school students, testing officials said it was an isolated event. But school officials and prosecutors disagree, and a continuing investigation is focusing on other schools and students.

title: Her Mom, Her Dad and Some Former Friends
description: Toward the end of Sarah Palin: You Betcha!, Nick Broomfield (who directed this documentary with Joan Churchill) shouts a question from the floor of one of Ms. Palins speaking engagements.

title: In Fruitvale, Merchants Are Armed and Wary
description: At Esparzas Jewelry in the Fruitvale section of Oakland, the owner, Rodolfo Perez, works the counter with a .38-caliber revolver strapped to his belt.

title: An Ailing Asian Art Museum Adopts a New Attitude
description: Its kind of weird to be here, said Sanjay Patel, a Pixar animator, standing on a stage Tuesday inside the Asian Art Museum. Normally you would see Buzz or Woody or Mr. Incredible or Sulley or Carl from Up.

title: Gingrichs Newer, and Longer, Contract With America
description: Newt Gingrich stood alone on a stage in a Des Moines auditorium on Thursday, flanked only by two banners, propped up like tricolor tablets, that outlined his 21st Century Contract With America.

title: Housing Debate Unfolds in Shadow of a Living Wall
description: VERNIER, Switzerland  Alexa Magalhaes has no plans to move from the apartment building where she has lived for the last six years, and why should she? As one of the largest such buildings on earth, it provides for just about all her needs, she says.

title: A.C.C. Falls Short in a Critical Measure of Success
description: The former Florida State coach Bobby Bowden now spends his days golfing, watching football and crisscrossing the country giving motivational speeches.

title: Rising From the Streets, a Band and Spirits
description: The joy is palpable when Staff Benda Bilili plays the World Music Festival in Oslo. A heart-racing energy pumps the musicians and transports the audience. The band celebrates by sipping wine with the Argentine ambassador, smoking substances in hotel rooms and reflecting on an improbably successful European tour.

title: Owsley Brown II, Liquor Company Chief, Dies at 69
description: Owsley Brown II, who expanded his familys Kentucky liquor company to reach a global market for its brands, among them Jack Daniels Tennessee Whiskey, Southern Comfort and Finlandia vodka, died on Monday in Louisville, Ky. He was 69.

title: Advocates Visa Delay Stirs Questions
description: Kerim Yildiz, a leading human rights advocate for the Kurdish people, was for two decades a frequent visitor to the United States. A British citizen living in London, he regularly lectured at American universities, caucused with other human rights advocates and briefed government officials in Washington.

title: An Unusual Group of Student Journalists Steps Up
description: In a small second-floor office south of Market Street in San Francisco last week, Sandra Legler asked seven high school students how they thought people communicated before smartphones and the Internet.

title: The Oracle-H.P. Rivalry, PowerPoint Version
description: 9:21 a.m. | Updated Corrected reference to an advanced chip H.P. was helping to develop.

title: From Dump to Paragon of Ecology: A First Peek
description: As befits what used to be the worlds largest landfill, the future Freshkills Park on Staten Island may represent the planets greatest act of ecological atonement.

title: United Nations Land Deal Could Help Finance East River Esplanade
description: The mile-long stretch of waterfront from 38th to 60th Streets is a huge gap in the effort to stretch a park the length of Manhattan. Here are the elements of a deal that could provide financing to build it.

title: Recent Executive Severance Packages
description: Top executives who have left their companies recently, and even been fired, have walked away with severance packages that dwarf those for ordinary workers, who typically receive two weeks pay.

title: Outsize Severance Continues for Executives, Even After Failed Tenures
description: The golden goodbye has not gone away.

title: A Tiger and a Yankee Ponder Baseballs Thrilling Finishes
description: Wednesday night is still a blur to the baseball-loving world. Certainly it is to Phil Coke, a pitcher with the Detroit Tigers, who knows he is back in the Bronx ready to face his old team. The rest of it, he isnt sure.

title: Liberated, but They Have to Live There
description: Washington

title: Stay Away From Those Creepy Locals
description: The impalement is a nice touch. The death by wood chipper, pretty sweet. But the best bit of comedy in the ridiculously gory Tucker and Dale vs. Evil eviscerates the field of psychology with no bloodshed at all.

title: Bloggingheads: Sexist Obama?
description: Amy Sullivan, left, of Time and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate the role of women in the Obama White House.

title: Few Bright Spots in Perrys Health Care Record
description: At campaign stops and in the three Republican presidential debates he has participated in so far, Gov. Rick Perry has made a sport out of bashing the 2006 state health insurance plan of former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts. He has not missed a chance to yoke Romneycare to Obamacare, the federal health care reform that Republicans largely revile.

title: Activists in Arab World Vie to Define Islamic State
description: CAIRO  By force of this years Arab revolts and revolutions, activists marching under the banner of Islam are on the verge of a reckoning decades in the making: the prospect of achieving decisive power across the region has unleashed an unprecedented debate over the character of the emerging political orders they are helping to build.

title: TimesCast | Post-Islamism and Elections
description: September 29, 2011  As senior U.S. officials meet leaders in Libya, Islamists in other liberated countries debate their evolving role in scheduled elections.

title: Behind the Wheel, Moving Up
description: THE man whom I shall call J showed up at my friends apartment one evening. My friend had warned me that J was dropping in to talk about hard times  he had lost his job heading a television channel, was going through a bitter divorce and had been reduced to living with his parents. But in spite of all this and the oppressive Delhi heat, J looked neat and composed. He began talking about problems with his wife, and his in-laws.

title: Prisoners Renew a Protest in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Corrections officials in Sacramento said Thursday that they would discipline inmates who participated in a renewed hunger strike to protest conditions in the states highest-security prisons, where some prisoners have been held in virtual isolation for decades.

title: Banks to Make Customers Pay Fee for Using Debit Cards
description: Bank of America, the nations biggest bank, said on Thursday that it planned to start charging customers a $5 monthly fee when they used their debit cards for purchases. It was just one of several new charges expected to hit consumers as new regulations crimp banks profits.

title: The Camera Doesnt Lie, Does It?
description: Ever feel your life is one big movie? Archie Williams, the high school hero of Archies Final Project, does. Thats because he goes nowhere without his video camera, taping all he sees. So when Archie (the talented Gabriel Sunday, also one of the screenwriters) decides to kill himself  his final project for school and for keeps  its no surprise that he wants to do it on camera.

title: The Limits of Empathy
description: We are surrounded by people trying to make the world a better place. Peace activists bring enemies together so they can get to know one another and feel each others pain. School leaders try to attract a diverse set of students so each can understand what its like to walk in the others shoes. Religious and community groups try to cultivate empathy.

title: Sometimes the Bear Gets You
description: GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.  In bear country, you listen for a crunch of twigs under a sharpened paw the size of a catchers mitt, and imagine that behind every tree lurks the swollen head and tiny eyes of the grizzly with the apt Latin name  ursus arctos horribilis.

title: Pepper Spray and a Police Dept. Whose Power Grows Unchecked
description: As a leading expert in government management, Raymond W. Kelly did not disappoint on Wednesday when he was asked about the actions of a senior police commander who pepper-sprayed four protesters standing on a sidewalk, then walked away without a glance as they rolled on the ground, screaming in pain.

title: Phony Fear Factor
description: The good news: After spending a year and a half talking about deficits, deficits, deficits when we should have been talking about jobs, job, jobs were finally back to discussing the right issue.

title: Violent Revenge, No Guns Required
description: Everything feels secondhand in Guy Moshes Bunraku, a potpourri of genres that ends up a morass of clichs. For starters, theres the plot: in a postapocalyptic dystopia where firearms are forbidden (but everyone seems to have knives, swords or brass knuckles), the taciturn Drifter (Josh Hartnett, with an unbecoming mustache) walks into town with a mission against the kingpin, Nicola (Ron Perlman, coasting through another hulking-strongman role), who runs a gambling den and brothel and keeps a woman named Alexandra (Demi Moore) as a courtesan. With the help of a friendly saloon keeper (Woody Harrelson, well compensated, I hope), Mr. Hartnett teams with Yoshi (the androgynous Japanese pop singer Gackt), a blade-slinging dutiful son with his own vendetta against Nicola. The two lead an insurrection against Nicolas empire. Thats all the exposition I can muster, Im afraid.

title: An Icy Political Vision
description: Taxes, spending and jobs dominate the conversation in Washington, but there is a great deal more at stake in next years election, as Republicans know well. It sometimes seems as if they are the only ones who talk about their values, but they put forward an elitist and narrow vision that largely favors the upwardly mobile, the healthy, the native-born American and the needs of the corporation.

title: New Chief of Hospitals Has a History of Cost Cuts
description: As the second in command of New York Citys public health and hospital system, Ramanathan Raju helped initiate a plan to close a $1.2 billion budget deficit in four years.

title: A Night of Twists and Collapses
description: It was March Madness on the diamond, four elimination games taking place simultaneously. In Major League Baseball on Wednesday, a six-month schedule came down to one frantic, interwoven scramble.

title: Pakistani Politicians Reject Mullens Charges
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Even as it revealed growing skepticism toward Pakistans powerful military, an extraordinary national security conference ended here late Thursday with a statement rejecting as baseless allegations from Americas top military official that Pakistan was facilitating militant attacks in Afghanistan.

title: An Ill-Fated Journey Into Cambodia
description: Loosely based on the fate of Errol Flynns only son, Sean (woodenly portrayed by Joshua Fredric Smith), a photojournalist who disappeared in Cambodia in 1970, The Road to Freedom is a bona-fide howler.

title: Fatal Accident Puts Focus on Deportation Program
description: BOSTON  A fatal accident that the police say involved an illegal immigrant driving drunk has stirred outrage in Massachusetts and put Gov. Deval Patrick on the defensive for his resistance to a federal program intended to deport criminals.

title: Venezuela: Conductor Killed in Train Collision
description: The collision of two commuter trains in a tunnel outside Caracas on Thursday killed the conductor of one train and injured 30 passengers, officials said. Nstor Reverol, the vice minister for citizen security, said the trains were carrying about 300 passengers when the accident occurred near the suburb of Charallave. Transportation Minister Francisco Garcs said an investigation was under way.

title: Land Deal With U.N. Would Fill a Big Gap in the Waterfront Greenway
description: For at least a decade, the United Nations has coveted a playground just south of its landmark tower, where it would like to construct a new building. For just as long, city and state officials have longed to fill in the largest remaining gap in the Manhattan Waterfront Greenway, from 38th to 60th Streets on the East River, but have not had the money.

title: Bob Cassilly, Playscape Creator Fueled by Whimsy, Dies at 61
description: The epiphany for Bob Cassilly came when he was building an underground city in the dirt beneath the porch of his family home. Eavesdropping on his parents adult conversation, he thought, What a shame not to be 11.

title: Assessments of Schools Are Flawed, Report Says
description: In 20 years of near-constant reform efforts, Chicagos elementary school students have made few gains, high school students have advanced, and the achievement gap between poor and rich areas has widened, a major University of Chicago study found, contradicting impressions created by years of Chicago Public Schools testing data.

title: More of the Same Wont Save Europe
description: The German Parliaments move to expand the euro-zone bailout fund on Thursday is welcome, but the European debt crisis is no closer to resolution than it was two months ago. Even with Germanys roughly $287 billion increased contribution, the fund is still too small to provide more than a few days of calm to jittery markets.

title: William Henry Hurlbert and the Diary of a Public Man
description: William Henry Hurlbert stared out from his cell in the Richmond, Va., city jail, which fronted on a downhill section of Marshall Street, close to where the interstate highway runs today. By the end of September 1861 he had been confined there for three months, locked in amid the midsummer heat. He learned to make do with small pleasures, notably the chance for daily exercise in a small yard, 90 by 20 feet, topped by a 30-foot brick wall. Born in South Carolina, he had lived his adult life in New England and New York City. In fact, not long before his imprisonment, Hurlbert had been the chief editorial writer for The New York Times. Why had his life changed so dramatically?

title: The Dismal Ruling in Alabama
description: A federal judge has upheld most of Alabamas new immigration law, the nations harshest and most radical attempt to harness a states power to find and punish illegal immigrants. The consequences for Alabamans will be serious  not just for the undocumented, but for their blameless citizen children, for those who are mistaken for unauthorized immigrants and for farmers and other business owners ensnared in the law.

title: The Joys of Retirement
description: A wearisome mix of miserableness and dark humor, Mammuth paints a depressing portrait of a class-bound France while trying to provide a measure of redemptive freedom for its working-class hero, played by Grard Depardieu.

title: Yemen: President Says His Rivals Must Leave First
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh said Thursday that he would not step down while his strongest rivals remained in power. Mr. Saleh told The Washington Post and Time magazine that his main opponents, a general who defected and a rival clan, would have to be removed for any political transition to go through. He also procured a decree from a government-financed committee of Yemeni religious scholars declaring that it is sinful to protest against the state and that security forces are fighting for the sake of God. What happens at demonstrations and sit-ins in residential areas and public roads is ungodly, reads the decree, or fatwa. Mr. Saleh, who recently returned to Yemen after nearly four months of medical treatment in Saudi Arabia, has used such fatwas for political benefit in the past.

title: Whats a Teacher Worth?
description: American Teacher doesnt come close to doing what it sets out to do, but it does end up as a heartfelt, bittersweet portrait of several teachers as they make the difficult decision of whether to stick with the profession.

title: Iran: Bankers Return Sought in Bank Scandal
description: Prosecutors in Iran issued a public warning to a prominent banker that he will become the prime suspect in a huge embezzlement scandal if he does not return to the country, the Mehr News Agency reported Thursday. The banker, Mahomud-Reza Khavari, abruptly resigned as the managing director of Bank Melli, Irans largest commercial bank, on Tuesday and flew to Canada after the bank was among several implicated in what prosecutors said was a $2.6 billion scheme to use forged letters of credit to acquire privatized government assets. Spokesmen for the bank told Iranian news outlets that Mr. Khavari had gone to Canada for ordinary business reasons.

title: He Sure Looks a Lot Like That Singer
description: I bet the singer-songwriter Goh Nakamura is way more interesting than the singer-songwriter Goh Nakamura.

title: Clip: Human Centipede 2
description: A scene from The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence).

title: A Bad Union Vote
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomos administration sent notices on Wednesday to 3,496 state employees that their jobs would be eliminated in 21 days. For that bad news, the workers can thank their union. On Tuesday, the New York State Public Employees Federation, representing 56,000 state employees, rejected a fair five-year contract that would have frozen base wages for three years and raised employee contributions to health coverage.

title: China: Alternative to Peace Prize Is Canceled
description: The Ministry of Culture has canceled a prize that a group of Chinese had come up with as an alternative to the Nobel Peace Prize, which was given to an imprisoned dissident, Liu Xiaobo, last year. The organizers of the Chinese version of the Nobel, the Confucius Prize, had intended to give it in December to one of eight nominees, among them Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian prime minister, and a young Tibetan man whom the Communist Party had appointed to be the Panchen Lama. But the Culture Ministry said the group, called the Traditional Culture Protection Department of the Association of Chinese Indigenous Arts, was in violation of ministry rules and had to disband. Last year, the Confucius Prize was given to Lien Chan, a Taiwanese politician who had supported greater ties between China and Taiwan. He learned of the award only when journalists called him.

title: Friday: Officially Starts to Work
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Recently, I have been the lucky recipient of mail from people who tell me that they do not always understand when I am joking. This is totally understandable, of course; humor is subjective, much like curly hair or freckles. Im sorry, thats genetic. I always get those two confused. Anyway, I felt bad that some readers were missing out on the fun, so as a public service to those who tend to miss my humor, Ive decided today to highlight all of the jokes in this post from hereon in both clearly and definitively through the use of a highly technical punctuation symbol, the asterisk. This is especially important in the next paragraph, as it will hopefully keep me from being sued by people who dont realize that I am operating strictly from the Soupy Sales School of Humor Writing.

title: Lottery Numbers
Main Concern for Aces: Batters, Not Each Other
description: Heavyweight boxers trade punches, tennis players exchange ground strokes and basketball players go one on one. In baseball, the direct confrontations are usually between two distinct groups: hitters and pitchers.

title: Battle for Libya | Sept. 29, 2011
description: Libyans attended the funeral of an anti-Qaddafi fighter in Tripoli while former rebels shelled the city of Surt.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Roddick to Seek Players Views on Union
description: Andy Roddick is willing to pay his dues.

title: An Interview With Guillaume Henry
description: Suzy Menkes, fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune, speaks with the designer about his inspiration for the modern Carven girl, and designing affordable fashion with a vision.

title: Delay in Decision on Eligibility
description: The Court of Arbitration for Sport has delayed until Oct. 6 its ruling about the Olympic eligibility of some athletes who have served doping suspensions. That judgment will decide the validity of an International Olympic Committee rule that bars from the next Olympics any athlete who has served a doping suspension of six months or longer, even if that ban ends before the Games.

title: Klinsmann Selects Team for Friendlies
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national team, named a 22-man roster for two coming friendly matches  against Honduras on Oct. 8 in Miami Gardens, Fla., and Ecuador on Oct. 11 in Harrison, N.J. The United States has yet to win a game since Klinsmann (0-2-1) replaced Bob Bradley over the summer.

title: Austin Studies Power Grid, Including Plug-In Cars
description: One morning this week, several dozen residents of northeast Austin gathered to inspect three plug-in Volt cars. They peered at the electric and gasoline engine components beneath the hood and took turns sitting behind the wheel.

title: Obama Charts a New Route to Re-election
description: WASHINGTON  With his support among blue-collar white voters far weaker than among white-collar independents, President Obama is charting an alternative course to re-election should he be unable to win Ohio and other industrial states traditionally essential to Democratic presidential victories.

title: Parking Rules
description: On Friday, because of the second day of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Cromarties Ribs Might Be Hurting, but His Pride Is Just Fine
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Four days after a loss in which he was penalized four times, fumbled away a kickoff and bruised his ribs and a lung  all in the span of 3 hours 18 minutes  Jets cornerback Antonio Cromartie was back at practice, not rattled at all.

title: Playing the Inmate Card Skews Redistricting
description: Texas prison inmates cant vote, so most counties ignore them. But they can change the value of your votes for Congress and the State Legislature.

title: Kansas: Judge Refuses to Block Abortion Law
description: A federal judge on Thursday declined to halt a Kansas law that limits the availability of insurance coverage for abortions. The American Civil Liberties Union had requested a temporary injunction against the law, which was approved by the Legislature this year, while the group fights the law in court. Judge Wesley Brown of Federal District Court said the A.C.L.U. of Kansas and Western Missouri had failed to prove its contention that the Legislature had approved the law to make it more difficult to receive abortions in the state. The law, which took effect in July, bars insurers from offering coverage for abortions as part of basic health plans. Exceptions are made if a womans life is at risk. A hearing on the lawsuit is scheduled to be held next month.

title: Just the Thought of New Revenue Makes Mouths Water
description: Its a function of fiscal dehydration and desperation that Mayor Rahm Emanuel is drooling over the prospect of casino revenues.

title: Rangers Rotation Is a Strong Suit, Even Without Lee
description: A.L. division series matchups: Tigers vs. Yankees | Rays vs. Rangers

title: Turnover-Prone Giants Turn Stingy
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Except for perhaps frigid weather or an errant punt, few things will make Coach Tom Coughlins cheeks flush faster than a turnover by the Giants. Careless fumbles. Interceptions on tipped passes. Balls thrown directly to the opposing team. These things make Coughlin angry.

title: Common Ground for Legal Adversaries on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  The 2010 health care overhaul law has provoked an unprecedented clash between the federal government and 26 states, dividing them on fundamental questions about the very structure of the federal system. But the two sides share a surprising amount of common ground, too, starting with their agreement in briefs, filed on Wednesday, that the Supreme Court should resolve the clash in its current term.

title: Tampa Bay Takes Its Buzz to Texas
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Dan Johnson tapped the screen of his smartphone amid the unpacking of bats and gloves as the Tampa Bay Rays moved into the visitors clubhouse here, a place few thought they would see less than 24 hours earlier. Indeed, a jubilant buzz tinged with disbelief remained from their 8-7, 12-inning victory over the Yankees, and Johnson and the Rays were still absorbing the reality that they had reached the playoffs.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 29
description: The day in sports, from surfing off the coast of Cape Town, South Africa, to a very quiet day in the Mets clubhouse.

description: ENSENADA, Mexico  The opening ceremony of a border governors forum here had it all: mariachi singers and a fireworks show entertained dignitaries who vowed to renew a spirit of cooperation between the states lining both sides of the United States-Mexico border.

description: The season has been unusual and, at times, painful for Jorge Posada, but the reward at the end of all the turmoil and inactivity is a spot on the postseason roster in an everyday role.

description: Kendall Square, the high-I.Q. neighborhood bordering the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, bears no resemblance to Hollywood. But a close look reveals one common element: a star-paved Walk of Fame, not for screen legends but for legendary innovators.

description: Dave Hill, a 13-time winner on the PGA Tour whose outspoken ways sometimes overshadowed his shotmaking, died on Tuesday in Jackson, Mich. He was 74.
