description: Sylvia Robinson, a singer, songwriter and record producer who formed the pioneering hip-hop group Sugarhill Gang and made the first commercially successful rap recording with them, died on Thursday in Edison, N.J. She was 75.

title: Philip Hannan, 98, Dies; New Orleans Archbishop
description: Retired Archbishop Philip M. Hannan, a confidant to President John F. Kennedy and the leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New Orleans for more than 20 years, died on Thursday at a hospice in New Orleans. The archbishop, who delivered the eulogy for President Kennedy in 1963, was 98.

title: What Does Tony Pulis Have to Do?
description: The table never lies is a clich, and frequently subject to scrutiny this early in the season. Six games into the Premier League campaign, there are already a few exceptions to the saying.

title: Newswallah: Whats in the English-Language Press Friday
description: The controversy behind the 2G-spectrum allocation continues to dominate headlines as Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee and Home Minister P. Chidambaram appeared together before the media to declare a truce (Times of India). In a 12-line statement meant to put an end to the rift between the two senior members of the UPA cabinet, Mr. Mukherjee distanced himself from the March 2011 Finance Ministry note thatsuggested Mr. Chidambaram as Finance Minister in UPA-1 could have blocked A. Rajas contentious decision not to auction 2G spectrum. The revelations came as a result of reported pressure from Congress Party chief Sonia Gandhi to present a united front (Hindustan Times).

title: A Conversation With Ela R. Bhatt
description: Ela Bhatt, a Gandhian and a lawyer who founded the Self Employed Womens Association in Gujarat, is sometimes referred to as the mother of microfinance. She helped start Mahila Sewa Co-operative Bank in 1974, two years before Muhammad Yunus began the project that would later become Grameen Bank.

description: INTERNATIONAL

description: A video that the police released this week of a shooting in Brooklyn shows the exacting care with which a group of criminals can handle a deadly weapon.

title: New Zealand Suffers Double Ratings Downgrade
description: HONG KONG  Standard & Poors lowered New Zealands credit rating one notch Friday, adding the country to a lengthening line of developed economies whose credit profiles have been undermined by high debt and the uncertain global economic outlook.

title: News Quiz | Sept. 30, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Sept. 30, 1938 | Hitler Granted the Sudentenland by Britain, France and Italy
description: In the early hours of Sept. 30, 1938, leaders of Nazi Germany, Great Britain, France and Italy signed an agreement that allowed the Nazis to annex the Sudetenland, a region of Czechoslovakia that was home to many ethnic Germans.

title: Indian-Americans Targeted in Gold Thefts
description: Indian-Americans, who are known for owning high-quality gold of 20 and 22 karats have become targets in a number of thefts in Northern California, New York Times partner The Bay Citizen reported on Thursday.

description: WASHINGTON  Anwar al-Awlaki did not leave much of a trail, frustrating the American and Yemeni intelligence officials pursuing him over the last two years.

description: WHAT did sociologists study to learn about peoples mood patterns?WHAT did they conclude?

title: Master Painters of India, Now in New York
description: Wonder of the Age: Master Painters of India, 1100-1900, newly opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York is in effect an epic and immersive progress report on historians attempt to track and name Indian artists who worked hundreds of years ago, writes Roberta Smith in The New York Times.

title: L.I.R.R. Expects Near Normal Morning Service
description: Following a lightning strike that disrupted Long Island Rail Road service just in time for Thursday nights eastbound commute, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced the resumption of near normal service for Friday mornings commute.

title: Week 4 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Jets (2-1) at Ravens (2-1)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Ravens by 3.5.Any team coached by a member of the Ryan family does not so much play a 16-game schedule as careen from bitter rivalry to bitter rivalry, each game becoming the kind of over-boiled grudge match usually settled with suplexes and folding chairs at ringside. It happened to Buddy Ryans Eagles, and it has happened to Rex Ryans Jets.Jets-Cowboys becomes Rex Ryan against Rob Ryan. Jets-Patriots becomes Rex Ryan against Bill Belichick. Jets-Ravens devolves into Rex Ryan against the team that declined to promote him to head coach when he was its defensive coordinator. Next time the Jets face the Raiders, it will be Rex Ryan against the team that broke his quarterbacks nose. Even Rex Ryan could not muster a feud with the Jaguars, but Joe Namath got into the act this week, so if you play the current Jets against the 1968 version in a video game, that is now a grudge match, too.Granted, the presence of the ex-Ravens Bart Scott, Jim Leonhard and Derrick Mason on the Jets roster does give the game a familiarity-breeds-contempt angle. This is a family game, but its also a heated rivalry, said Ravens defensive end Terrell Suggs, perhaps not realizing that Jets charity softball tournaments are also heated rivalries. Youve got to go beat up on the ones you love. In other words, this time its personal. Just like all the other times. Pick: Jets.

title: Rangers Set Lines in Prague; Staal Resumes Skating
description: In a game far, far away from Manhattan, and not even available to the faithful via Web stream in North America, Rangers Coach John Tortorella decided to play his projected top forward lines together for the first time in training camp. Well, almost.

title: Madrid Market Highlights Indie Design
description: A few blocks away from the fans and flamenco-themed souvenirs in Madrids Puerta del Sol, tourists and street performers give way to Nmada Market (Calle Atocha 24; www.nomadamarket.com), a three-day independent design fair brimming with finds created by over 130 emerging designers from Spain, Portugal, Italy and France.

title: The Money Flow From Households to Health Care Providers
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: The Early Word: The Road Less Traveled
description: In Todays Times

title: With Cross-Country Trip, Hyundai Highlights Need for Hydrogen Fueling Infrastructure
description: The Hyundai Tucson Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle parked in a third-floor lobby at the Hilton New York on Wednesday was no show car. It spent much of September on the road, traveling more than 4,500 miles from San Francisco to New York to promote awareness of childhood cancer, as well as the need for a hydrogen fueling infrastructure.

title: Myanmar Backs Down, Suspending Dam Project
description: BANGKOK  In a rare concession to public pressure, Myanmars government on Friday ordered the suspension of a controversial hydroelectric project financed and led by a state-owned Chinese company.

title: Do Apps Help You or Just Waste Your Time?
description: On Monday, a mobile phone app that reports all things related to the trial of Conrad Murray, Michael Jacksons personal doctor, was released. By Thursday, it had become a top seller. Did you or anyone you know buy it? Do you or anyone in your family use apps on your mobile phones? If so, what do they help you do?

title: The Other India: Mangalajis Tamasha Party
description: Tamasha artist Mangala Bhansode is all curves and ample bosom and when she hollers in English I know you want it, but youre never going to get it, lyrics from the hit Bollywood song Sheila ki Jawani, the audience responds with frenzy. Flinging in the air their homespun Gandhi caps, woolen scarves and gloves, even the blankets theyd brought along, they yell back in English: Once More! Once More! Once More!

title: Taking It to the Streets
description: Theres a reigning joke that commands everyone to set their clocks to Pacific Standard Time this weekend, as the decade-in-the-making horde of exhibitions and events in and around Los Angeles chronicling the areas postwar art scenes finally kicks off. Perhaps the most countercultural and sunshiny of the opening parties will be the Tresspass Parade barnstorming Downtown L.A.s historic Broadway district on Sunday morning. The event  helmed by the genre-bending artists Arto Lindsay and Rirkrit Tiravanija, and organized by former the Milan gallerist Emi Fontanas Pasadena project space West of Rome  is a celebration of Southern Californias time-honored tradition of festive dissidence.Floats, costumes and other parade paraphernalia should be done up in subversive style. And there will be T-shirts!  onto which 2-D luminaries like John Baldessari and Barbara Kruger will emblazon call-to-action slogans.

title: Customers Say the Darndest Things
description: As you might have suspected, I have had many opinions about restaurants over the years, but I have never approached the owner of one of them and told him or her how I would improve his or her lifes work. So it is with admiration and puzzlement that I listen to all the guests who call me to their table or track me down to offer their sage suggestions. While 95 percent of the comments are insightful and positive, those other 5 percent stick to the ribs like a good porterhouse, which we do not serve and which is a constant source of contention.

title: Why Magazine Publishers Like the Fire
description: Magazine publishers see tremendous potential in the Fire and hope that the device can do for their business what the Kindle did for books: bring droves of new customers into a business that is having difficulty retaining its traditional print readers.

title: S.&P. 500 Declined 14% in 3rd Quarter
description: Stocks fell on Friday, sending the Standard & Poors 500-stock index to its biggest quarterly drop since 2008  14 percent. Reports from China and Germany fueled the decline on concerns that the global economy is slowing.

title: Global Warming Could Cost Canada Billions, Study Warns
description: A report by an advisory board to the government of Canada estimates that the effects of global warming will cost the countrys economy 5 billion Canadian dollars a year by 2020 and that those costs will rise substantially afterward.

title: Life on the Trail: The Struggle to Stay Healthy
description: My first time out on the campaign trail, I got impossibly sick. I started feeling not that great in Iowa, progressed to a hacking cough during my seven-hour Detroit airport experience (thunderstorm-related delays), and by the time I stumbled into New Hampshire, I was ready to abandon the entire enterprise.

A recession in Europe looks more likely than not; and the question for the United States is not whether a lost decade is possible, but whether there is any plausible way to avoid one.

title: Steve Martin and the Steep Canyon Rangers Win Top Bluegrass Prize
description: He may have lost his crown as the person who has most often hosted Saturday Night Live, but Steve Martin has since claimed another prize that we dont see Alec Baldwin taking away from him any time soon. On Thursday night Mr. Martin and his bluegrass band, the Steep Canyon Rangers, were named entertainer of the year at the International Bluegrass Music Association Awards in Nashville, The Associated Press reported.

title: Inflation Jump in Europe Complicates Life for E.C.B.
description: PARIS  A surprisingly strong increase in euro zone consumer prices, reported Friday, suggests that the European Central Banks effort to combat the sovereign debt crisis could be hampered by inflation.

description: Yemens official news agency reported that the young Web-savvy American thought to be behind Inspire, a magazine for Al Qaeda, was killed in the same Friday strike that killed the radical cleric Anwar al-Awlaki.

title: Leading Off: Its (Useless) Prediction Time
description: Baseballs playoff prediction season is mercifully short, which is almost impossible to say about anything else about the game, and we should all be grateful for this. If the events of the past few weeks have taught us anything, its that we know nothing. Thats all of us, pundits, casual observers, former players now wearing TV makeup and hairspray. We all had as good a chance as the fish in our living room tank of predicting what happened at the end of this season.

title: Markets Can Be Very, Very Wrong
description: Muller, Mendelsohn, and Nordhaus have a new paper in the American Economic Review that should be a major factor in how we discuss economic ideology. It wont, of course, but let me lay out the case anyway.

description: Our photographic memory of New York  its ragamuffins and ruffians, dandies and dowagers  has been frozen in black and white. Until now.

description: Jurgen Klinsmann has made his roster selections for the United States national teams upcoming friendlies against Honduras and Ecuador, and regardless of how you feel about his squad, this weeks curated list of televised games features Yanks who made the cut.

title: Hussein Chalayan: Fashion Sparked by Wit
description: A good designer is like an attentive waiter: he is there to serve his guests and quietly depart. Fashion, as Cristobal Balenciaga famously and sourly observed at the end of his career, is a dogs life. Ah, but if only he had known Hussein Chalayan, he might have at least savored the human comedy.
