title: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 20,000 Honda Odysseys for Power Liftgate Failures
description: Early in 2010, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration gave up trying to force Honda to recall defective liftgates on its 2005 minivans. That hasnt prevented the agency from opening a new investigation into a similar problem on 20,000 Odysseys from the 2009 model year.

title: A Stylish Spin on Web Fashion
description: Its a pleasure to see Alessandra Facchinetti back on the runway. You may remember her from her brief moment at Gucci, in 2004, when she succeeded Tom Ford. Then, following Valentinos retirement, she took over the creative direction at that house. It was, let us say, an impossible job, and her first ready-to-wear collections were tentative. At the time I thought: too many hands in this kitchen. But then she delivered a gorgeous haute couture collection for Valentino that I still vividly remember, the kind of witty femininity that could let in some much-needed air.

title: Ireland Triumphs!
description: Or, maybe not.

title: Kurdish Protesters Enter Newspapers Office in London
description: Nearly a dozen Kurdish nationalists burst into the London office of The Guardian newspaper on Friday, demanding greater coverage of Kurdish issues and creating a chaotic scene that briefly alarmed the staff.

title: Up Front: John Sayles
description: In 1975, Raymond Sokolov wrote in the Book Review about a first novel, Pride of the Bimbos, in which a midget named Pogo seeks happiness and self-fulfillment as the shortstop of a softball team that plays in drag. The book (an oddly unsettling satire of American machismo, Sokolov concluded) was by a young man named John Sayles, who quickly brought out another novel, Union Dues, and a story collection, The Anarchists Convention, before going on to become one of Americas best-known independent filmmakers.

title: William Kennedy Goes to Cuba and Back
description: William Kennedys new novel, Changs Beads and Two-Tone Shoes, is his most musical work of fiction: a polyrhythmic contemplation of time and its effects on passion set in three different eras, a jazz piece unafraid to luxuriate in its roots as blues or popular ballad or to spin out into less melodic territory.

title: Are You My Father, Orson Welles?
description: One of the first interviews I ever did, in the mid-1980s for Elle magazine, was with Michael Lindsay-Hogg, who had just directed the original New York production of Larry Kramers Normal Heart. This, I must admit, interested me less than office gossip alleging him to be the unclaimed son of Orson Welles, by his mother, the actress Geraldine Fitzgerald.

title: Jim Harrison Stalks a Cult Leader
description: It is now 55 years since my last book report, which is a long time to live with a guilty conscience. So here it is: In the spring of 1956 I wrote a highly favorable review of the Bible without reading a word of it, and it was the last A I ever got in English. Why it has taken so long to come clean Im not sure, except I have always been extremely sensitive about my academic reputation.

title: The Money May Be Lacking, but a Library Refuses to Go Quietly
description: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I.

title: The Indomitable Will of Gustav Mahler
description: Idealistic, fantastic, grotesque, violent, tender, sarcastic, confrontational, confessional, the symphonies of Gustav Mahler (1860-1911) are among the most profoundly autobiographical of all composed music. I have written into them, in my own blood, everything that I have experienced and endured, he confided to a friend after finishing the Second Symphony. For all its professional, emotional and physical crises, Mahlers life was exemplary for an artist who, no matter how loud the outside world might pound on the walls of his concentration, vigilantly maintained an unobstructed direct line to his creative self, keeping it uncorrupted and unblocked to the end.

title: Growing Up With Irne Nmirovsky
description: On Dec. 17, 1941, a year and a half into the Nazi occupation of France, an Aryan French governess named Julie Dumot, living in the quiet provincial village of Issy-lvque, received a contract from a Parisian publisher for a novel called Les Biens de ce Monde (All Our Worldly Goods). That governess worked in the household of a 38-year-old Russian-born Jewish author who saw herself as culturally French but who, under the restrictive laws of the Vichy regime, was no longer permitted to publish under her own name. The books chapters had already appeared serially in the spring of 1941, without a byline, in the far-right newspaper Gringoire, which blended virulent opinion pages with apolitical literary content. But Les Biens de ce Monde appeared in book form only in 1947, five years after the death of its true author, Irne Nmirovsky, at Auschwitz.

title: The Doctors Who Killed a President
description: "Charlie said, 'Hell,If I am guilty,Then God is as well.'But God was acquittedAnd Charlie committedUntil he should hang."

title: T. S. Eliots Rattle of Miseries
description: Grover Cleveland was still president when T. S. Eliot was born. His earliest surviving letter was written to his father from the family summer home in Gloucester, Mass. The 9-year-old Tom Eliot was deferential, curious in a boyish way, concerned about some missing sunflowers and a broken microscope. A shy child, he suffered from a congenital hernia and once asked his nurse why the naked boy in a book wore no truss.

title: The Criminal Genius of Caravaggio
description: In one of the last pictures he ever painted, a grim and startling Resurrection altarpiece, Caravaggio showed a scrawny, bedraggled Jesus Christ slipping out of the tomb and making off alone by night, like a criminal escaping from his guards, in the words of an 18th-century Frenchman. Shock was the conventional response to this painting (eventually destroyed by earthquake, along with the church where it hung). The artist himself was on the run at the time, wanted for murder and so jittery that he slept in his clothes with a dagger always at hand. Whatever he set out to paint, Andrew Graham-Dixon writes in his gripping biography, he always ended up painting himself.

title: The Obama White House That Couldnt
description: Bloated, portentous, reeking of self-importance, Ron Suskinds Confidence Men is the most frustrating of books. A truly groundbreaking inside account of the first two years of economic policy making in the Obama White House, Confidence Men is at least 200 pages too long. Suskind tosses off contentious opinions about the economy as if they were accepted wisdom. He introduces characters who lack even a marginal connection to his narrative. Theres not a blind alley he wont stroll down, at least for a while.

title: Pursuing Palin
description: Sarah Palin's sprint from Wasilla housewife to national political sensation may have no parallel in modern American politics, but Joe McGinnisss book The Rogue: Searching for the Real Sarah Palin proves that she didnt come out of nowhere. God gave Palin her first push toward politics when she was a mere 24 years old, as her spiritual mentor Mary Glazier explained at a religious conference in June 2008.

title: The Weapons That Were Not There
description: Every attentive reader of Intelligence and U.S. Foreign Policy, Paul R. Pillars long-needed examination of just what the Central Intelligence Agency got right or wrong before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq in 2003, will find one observation or another that seems more disquieting than the rest. I havent quite decided which of two deserves pride of place on my own list: The fact that the Bush administration never formally debated whether it was a good idea to invade Iraq? Or that Pillar, who ran the National Intelligence Councils shop for the Middle East during both events, cannot tell us the true reasons the Bush administration invaded?

title: The Origins of Religion, Beginning With the Big Bang
description: In October 1963, the sociologist Robert N. Bellah gave a lecture at the University of Chicago on the subject of religious evolution. Clifford Geertz, the widely respected American anthropologist, was only partially impressed. I loved your talk even though I disagree with it entirely, he told Bellah afterward.

title: Eight-Feet Female and Working for P. T. Barnum
description: We just cant get enough of the sideshow. Bearded ladies, wolf boys, giants: in the sideshows heyday, their physical differences made them objects of fascination, gawked and giggled at. In contrast, novels like Darin Strausss Chang and Eng and Katherine Dunns Geek Love have evoked the rich inner lives of those on display rather than their visible differences. Stacy Carlsons first novel, set in P. T. Barnums American Museum, aims for, but doesnt quite reach, similar insights.

title: On the Wrong Side of the New Ireland
description: So many people have emigrated from Ireland over the centuries that the diaspora far outnumbers those in the home country. The old joke goes that if all Irish returned, the island would sink under their weight. Most departed to seek jobs. Others, like the narrator of On Canaans Side, Sebastian Barrys new novel, were chased out with I.R.A. henchmen in hot pursuit.

title: Life Onstage With John Lithgow and Hal Holbrook
description: Two new actor memoirs follow a similar script, from regional dues-paying to career triumph. Both authors learn their craft on small stages throughout America, spend time at Harvard, occasionally talk about themselves in the third person and grow apart from their first wives. But where one book is warm and generous, the other is cold and bleak.

title: An Unrepentant Adulterer
description: As The Forgotten Waltz opens, a young married woman named Gina Moynihan is kissing an older man, Sean, upstairs in his house, when Gina realizes they are being observed by Seans daughter, Evie. Seans wife calls up to Evie to rejoin the party downstairs, and despite what she has just witnessed, the child, who has burst out laughing at the sight of her father and Gina embracing, seems reassured.

title: American Dreamers
description: To the Editor:

title: A View of Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Empowerment Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: Reading Alberto Moravia in Silvio Berlusconis Italy
description: In its culture as in its politics, Italy lives under the shadow of Silvio Berlusconi. With his endless legal entanglements and sexual imbroglios and his colorful manner of governing (or not governing), it often feels as if the prime minister has taken all the oxygen out of the room, the airwaves, the entire republic. How did we get here? is the dominant  indeed often the only  topic of conversation in Italy today.

title: Photos of the Moment | Ann Demeulemeester
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#32", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Schohajas Paris fashion week photo diary.

title: Calculated Murder
description: Wouldnt it be nice, Leonard Rosen asks in his first novel, ALL CRY CHAOS (Permanent Press, $29), if the broken world we live in could be mended by the application of some universal mathematical formula? James Fenster, a Harvard professor whos in Amsterdam to deliver a paper before the World Trade Organization, has been working on that very thing. But before he can deliver his remarks on The Mathematical Inevitability of a One-World Economy, a bomb charged with rocket fuel delivers a surgical strike on his hotel room.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Tickets are still available for some events during this weekends New York City Wine and Food Festival, which is sponsored by the Food Network and runs through Sunday. There are tastings, cooking demonstrations, seminars, special dinners and cook-offs throughout the city. Tickets are $20 to $250, with the proceeds benefiting the Food Bank for New York City and Share Our Strength.

title: Across the Ocean, With Five Small Children
description: When you have five children under the age of 6, every family outing becomes an exercise in logistics. When planes and passports are involved, you might as well be planning to invade Normandy.

title: Buffett Takes His Case to Wall Street
description: Few billionaire investors possess the influence of Warren E. Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway. With his companys stock buybacks making waves and a tax proposal dubbed the Buffett Rule aimed at the wealthy, Mr. Buffett has thrust himself in the headlines.

title: Perry Suggests Romney Inspired Obamacare
description: 12:46 p.m. | Updated Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, still reeling from a debate performance that upset many of the bedrock conservatives he considers his base, came out swinging Friday against his rival Mitt Romney, accusing the former Massachusetts governor of backing policies indistinguishable from those of President Obama and having paved the way for Obamacare.

title: Cooking With Yogurt
description: At my house, yogurt is a snack food, a dessert or something to be mixed in a smoothie. But as Martha Rose Shulman explains in this weeks Recipes for Health, yogurt can add flavor and texture to a number of savory dishes. She writes:

title: Tailgating Recipes: D.T.s Crab Gumbo
description: So far this season, weve had recipes that have included brats and bacon from college football fans. We thought it was time to hear from our N.F.L. readers and maybe get a taste of seafood.

title: Owner Goes All In on the Brewers
description: MILWAUKEE  Mark Attanasio was born in the Bronx, lives in Los Angeles, owns a first-place baseball team in the Midwest and runs a company that manages $11 billion in investments. He did not get all that by being superstitious, so when Attanasio arrived at his ballpark on Sept. 23 dressed for a postgame celebration, it should not have been surprising. He knows what he is doing.

title: Whats Going On Below Murrays Cheese Shop
description: There are five caves underneath Murrays Cheese Shop, the downtown magnet for fromage fanatics in the West Village. Day after day, hour by hour, wheels of cheese are ritually flipped and rinds are carefully washed in temperature-and-humidity-controlled environments that are meant to follow the precise cheese-aging principles of affinage.

title: North Koreas Dear Young General Has Made His Mark
description: SEOUL, South Korea  It is a telling sign of who is the rising star in North Korea: state-run television showing octogenarian party secretaries bowing to a man their grandchildrens age before accepting the smiling mans handshake or kowtowing to his instructions.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 4s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Big Data: Sorting Reality From the Hype
description: The quest to find decision-making insights in the modern data flood is certainly an appealing notion.

title: The Contrarians
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#866", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Florida Moves Up Primary Date, Scrambling Calendar
description: UPDATE 5 p.m.: Florida has decided to hold its Republican primary on Jan. 31 next year, ignoring party rules that require later voting and likely pushing a string of other states to move their contests up.

title: Yellows Enter the Forests Palette
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week.

title: In Irenes Wake, High and Dry Enough?
description: WHEN Hurricane Irene roared up the East Coast this summer and drew a bead on Manhattan, hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers were surprised to learn they had something in common: They were living in Evacuation Zone A and potentially at imminent risk of being flooded out of their homes.

title: A Town Center in the Works for Coram
description: Coram

title: Yankees Complete First-Round Playoff Roster
description: The Yankees submitted their roster for the American League division series, and there were no major surprises on it. The Tigers also have submitted theirs.

title: Judging a Long, Deadly Reach
description: WASHINGTON  The killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen struck on Friday by a missile fired from a drone aircraft operated by his own government, instantly reignited a difficult debate over terrorism, civil liberties and the law.

title: The New Kid in Town: Charlie Cox on Boardwalk Empire
description: Joining an acclaimed series already in progress can be a fraught proposition. But the British actor Charlie Cox faced an additional obstacle when he signed on to HBOs Boardwalk Empire for its second season: Hed never seen the show.

title: E.P.A. Charts Risks of a Ubiquitous Chemical
description: So you wanted to clean grease off a bit of machinery. The year was 1956 or 1971 or even 1993. Your cleaner of choice was probably the industrial degreaser trichloroethylene, a petroleum-based clear liquid that was as common in mid-20th-century America as Ipana toothpaste, Crackerjack and asbestos. It was used in dry-cleaning, in machine shops and on military bases.

title: Editors Choice
description: WHOS AFRAID OF POST-BLACKNESS?WHAT IT MEANS TO BE BLACK NOW,  by Tour (Free Press, $25.) Interviews with 105 prominent African-Americans suggest that todays black identity has cleared the way to a liberating pursuit of individuality.

title: Paperback Row
description: BEFORE YOU SUFFOCATE YOUR OWN FOOL SELF,  by Danielle Evans (Riverhead, $15.) Following girls and young women who are intelligent, gutsy and black, Evanss whip-smart first story collection charts the universal pitfalls of coming-of-age in 21st-century America. In Virgins, the bittersweet opening story set the day after Tupac got shot, two 15-year-olds yearn to be more grown-up while preserving something of their innocence.

title: Fill-In | October Events in History
Inside the List
description: SAY IT AINT SO, JOE: Ron Suskinds Confidence Men: Wall Street, Washington, and the Education of a President, new at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list, may have grabbed all the serious news headlines, but Joe McGinnisss Sarah Palin tell-all, The Rogue (No. 10), has made for way better copy, much of it scabrously negative. Janet Maslin, writing in the daily New York Times, dismissed its scoops as dated, petty and easily available to anyone with Internet access, shamelessly padded out with pointless details about the pet birds McGinniss kept in his temporary home next door to the Palins in Alaska (The grebe chicks have hatched!) and hearsay about the condition of the Palins toilet. Palin filed her own review in the form of a letter to McGinnisss publisher threatening to sue. Even Palins mullet-loving near-miss son-in-law, Levi Johnston, took time out from promoting his own anti-Palin book, Deer in the Headlights, to trash McGinnisss feebly sourced claim that the former Alaska governor had used cocaine.

title: Will Amazon Buy Palm for Its Patents?
description: To protect Fire, will Amazon buy Palm?

title: Pushing for More Independent Charters
description: A few years back, before every September brought with it several new charter schools opened by management organizations, there were independent schools with dreams of copying themselves many times over.

title: Teachers Teaching Teachers, on Twitter: Q. and A. on Edchats
description: Like other groups with shared interests, from epidemiologists to James Joyce fans to locked-out N.F.L. players, teachers are turning to Twitter to collaborate, share resources and offer each other support.

title: Challenging Dollar-Cost Averaging and Other Bad Ideas
description: SINCE mid-August, world markets have repeatedly moved with stomach-churning ups and downs. And in response, many investors feel they must take some action for fear that doing nothing will cost more than doing something.

title: More on the Class Act
description: Perhaps feeling that the Class Act was twisting slowly, slowly in the wind, the assistant secretary of aging, Kathy Greenlee  who would direct the program if the Department of Health and Human Services actually goes ahead with it  posted on an H.H.S. blog this week.

title: Hearst Sells Cycle World to Bonnier
description: Cycle World, one of the leading magazines about motorcycles, has been sold by Hearst to Bonnier Corporation, the companies said on Friday.

title: Killing of Awlaki Is Latest in Campaign Against Qaeda Leaders
description: Anwar al-Awlakis lectures were linked to several investigations in the United States, Britain and Canada.

title: In Los Angeles, the Avanti as a California Start-Up Story
description: Among the stars of California Design, 1930-1965: Living in a Modern Way, an exhibition opening Saturday at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, is a white Studebaker Avanti.

title: John Lithgow discusses his new memoir, An Actors Education; Joe Nocera reviews Ron Suskinds Confidence Men; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
description: John Lithgow discusses his new memoir, An Actors Education; Joe Nocera reviews Ron Suskinds Confidence Men; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: For Nature Lovers Who Also Shop-Hop
description: ALTHOUGH it is 70 miles from Manhattan in New Haven County, Orange may not seem New England-quaint from a car stuck in traffic on the Boston Post Road, where a mishmash of signs for chain stores alternates with a tangle of telephone wires.

title: Share Your European Culinary Discoveries
description: In this weeks special Europe issue, we asked correspondents with decades of culinary experience across Europe among them to share a few of their favorite food discoveries.

title: Photos of the Moment | Rick Owens
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#27", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: An Open Invitation to Eat in Copenhagen
description: ON a recent Friday afternoon in Copenhagen, a female busker with a guitar stood on the cobblestones of Israels Plads, a large square in the city center, strumming a spirited version of Street Life, the classic 1970s funk song.

title: A Ballet Star Leaps Into the Unknown
description: WOMEN love Charles Askegard. Or at the very least, the women of New York City Ballet do. Since joining that company in 1997 he has performed with almost every ballerina in the companys esteemed ranks. But after next Sunday those dancers are going to have to do without their tall, elegant partner, when Mr. Askegard retires from City Ballet at the last matinee of the season, in a program that features some of his favorite roles.

title: Arizona Made Serious Gains Under Gibson
description: A.L. division series matchups: Tigers vs. Yankees | Rays vs. Rangers

title: Old and New, a Tale of Heroes and Villains
description: THERE is a rich legacy of recordings of Beethovens opera Fidelio, including the 1962 account on EMI with Otto Klemperer conducting the Philharmonia Orchestra and Chorus in a majestic performance. The colossal tenor Jon Vickers sings Florestan, a Spanish nobleman unjustly imprisoned for his liberal sympathies by a tyrannical governor, and the distinguished mezzo-soprano Christa Ludwig is Florestans wife, Leonore, who, disguised as a young man, finds a job in the prison where her husband is held in order to rescue him.

title: Cuomo Talks Tough on Union Layoffs and Redistricting
description: An uncompromising Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, facing a union that has refused to agree to wage and benefits concessions and a Legislature that is insisting on redrawing the states political map, said Friday that he would follow through on threats to lay off several thousand state workers and to veto the lawmakers redistricting plan.

title: In Brooklyn, A New Leader Who Knows No Boundaries
description: ITS not as if Alan Pierson were hunting for a new job. A lean, sharp and energetic 37-year-old conductor, Mr. Pierson has made an enviable name for himself over the last decade as the artistic director of Alarm Will Sound, a vital, omnivorous 20-member chamber ensemble formed in 2001 by graduate students at the Eastman School of Music in Rochester.

title: Log In
Photo Replay: Sept.30
description: The day in sports was capped by a suspension of Game 1 of the Yankees American League division series against the Tigers in the Bronx.

title: Questioning a Standard Piece of Investment Advice
description: The long list of economic problems around the world  from high unemployment and legislative gridlock in the United States to deep debt problems in Europe  makes these scary times for investors, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week. The usual advice is to focus on a long-term plan and not abandon it when the times get tough.

title: Brewers Tunes, Cardinals Pitchers, and Arizona Turkeys
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

title: Oct. 2  8
description: Dance

title: Obama Hailed After Awlaki Killing, but for How Long?
description: The killing of Anwar al-Awlaki in an American missile strike on Friday cements President Obamas record as a relentless hunter of Al Qaeda terrorists. Whether that success in counterterrorism will help Mr. Obamas overall image as a leader is less certain.

title: Allison Pataki and David Levy
description: THE first meeting between Allison Pataki and David Levy, at the Yale hangout Old Blue in the fall of 2003, might well have been their last.

title: Pampering, Even From the Drivers Seat
description: The Bentley Mulsanne is a movable penthouse that is a pleasure to take from the chauffeur and drive yourself.

title: Japan Lifts Evacuation Advisories Near Nuclear Plant
description: TOKYO  Despite continued fears over radiation levels, Japan lifted evacuation advisories for an area spanning five towns and cities around a tsunami-ravaged nuclear power plant on Friday, the first such move since multiple fuel meltdowns at the site led to a substantial radiation leak and forced more than 100,000 surrounding residents to flee.

title: Awlaki Killing Incites Criticism on Left and Libertarian Right
description: For civil libertarians,  the killing of the radical cleric Anwar al-Awlaki was not a triumph for a military approach to terrorism but rather an example of its greatest shortcoming: a lack of due process.

title: Beware of Killer Brassieres, and Dont Die at Midnight
description: The 10th Victim

title: Big Deal | At the Level Club, Funky for Sale
description: Outside, the Level Club, a condominium on the Upper West Side, still bears many signs of its original purpose: It was the headquarters in the 1920s for social and business gatherings of a group of Freemasons known as the Levelers.

title: Radiohead Show Definitely Not Going to Happen, Band Says
description: Updated, 3:55 p.m. | Laura Eldeiry, a spokeswoman for Radiohead, said that the band would not be playing a show at Zuccotti Park on Friday that had been announced by Occupy Wall Streets organizers.

title: Runway in Review
description: Ann DemeulemeesterDesigner: Ann DemeulemeesterDate and Location: Thursday, Sept. 29, Couvent des Cordeliers, 15 Rue de lEcole de Medecine, 6ePhotos: slide show

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: School Tensions
description: Among the new paperbacks this week are two stories set in the post-kindergarten pre-college days of learning. Diary of a Zombie Kid, at No. 5, is about a student in fifth grade who comes down with a zombie virus. Troubling, to be sure, but maybe itll let him get out of gym class?

title: DealBook: Regulators Scrutinize Google-Motorola Deal
description: Antitrust regulators have asked for more information on Googles proposed $12. billion acquisition of Motorola Mobility, the two companies disclosed on Wednesday.

title: Bloomberg Hints That Wall St. Protesters Could Overstay Welcome
description: The Occupy Wall Street protesters may not be able to camp out in a downtown park indefinitely, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned on Friday morning.

title: U.S. Ambassador to Syria Describes Attack on Convoy
description: In a post on his Facebook page, the American ambassador to Syria, Robert Ford, said the attack on his convoy was more violent than previously reported.

title: Bread, Apricots and Truffles, at the Source
description: A roundup of foods worth traveling for.

title: The Caucus | Terrorism and Politics
description: Sept. 30, 2011 - Mark Landler on the complicated political reaction to the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki. Also, Mitt Romney sits for an interview with Mike Huckabee, his 2008 rival.

title: Bloomberg to Testify at Trial of Consultant
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is scheduled to take the witness stand Monday morning to testify against a Republican political consultant accused of stealing more than $1 million from him, according to two people familiar with the trial schedule.

title: Rewarding C.E.O.s Who Fail
description: Lo Apothekers short, turbulent reign as the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard was by nearly all accounts a disaster. The board demanded his resignation, and if ever there was a case for firing someone for cause, this would seem to be it.

title: An Iranian Hit, but No Preconceptions, Please
description: The Iranian director Asghar Farhadi has been in New York all week, preparing for the showing of his film A Separation as part of the main slate at the New York Film Festival on Saturday and Sunday. But he has also been keeping a worried eye on the situation back home, where a pirated DVD version of his film, a box office and critical success, has suddenly gone on sale.

title: Caucus Video: Terrorism and Politics
description: Mark Landler on the political reaction to the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki. Also, Mitt Romney sits for an interview with Mike Huckabee, his 2008 rival. Michael D. Shear reports.

title: ARK Rally Veloster to Have Debut at SEMA
description: The new Hyundai Veloster three-door hatch, with a styling profile that would never be called restrained, is getting a loud, rally-car makeover in advance of the Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show, commonly known as SEMA, in Las Vegas.

title: Dior: Chic and Safe but With Buzz
description: From the hubbub at Dior, with vamping socialites and a front row of LVMH brass, including its chairman, Bernard Arnault, and the habitually leather-clad architect Peter Marino, one would have thought de Gaulle had come back from the dead. I guess Dior is France. The flying colors, though, were the grays and creams of the house, mixed with palest blue and a dash of poppy red.

title: Stuck in Bed, at Hospitals Expense
description: ON Jan. 4, 2010, Raymond Fok was changing trains on his way to kidney dialysis treatment when he collapsed on the Canal Street subway platform. Emergency medical technicians examined him and took him by ambulance to the nearest hospital, New York Downtown, near the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge. Workers in the emergency room recorded that Mr. Foks speech was slurred and that he was lurching from side to side when he walked.

title: As X Factor Lifts Fox, Charlies Angels Comes Down to Earth
description: The X Factor once again carried Fox to a Thursday-night victory in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic, despite dropping 12 percent from last weeks premiere. The talent show averaged just under 12 million total viewers over a two-hour period.

title: Photos of the Moment | Delfina Delettrez
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#724", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Morning Take-Out
description: McGraw-Hill in Talks to Lead Stock Indexes Joint Venture | McGraw-Hill, the owner of Standard & Poors, is in advanced talks with the CME Group Inc., which owns Dow Jones Indexes, about forming a joint venture, according to people briefed on the matter who were not authorized to speak publicly.

title: Can Reyes Ever Carry Mets to Title?
description: Jose Reyes has his batting title, but what good does that do Mets fans who have to spend another October watching other teams play, says William C. Rhoden.

title: S.E.C. Faults Credit Raters, but Doesnt Name Them
description: WASHINGTON  An examination of credit ratings agencies by the Securities and Exchange Commission found repeated instances of the companies failing to follow their own procedures or to manage conflicts of interest adequately, according to an S.E.C. staff report issued Friday.

title: Fighting Erupts on Somalias Border With Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Intense fighting erupted along the Kenya-Somalia border on Friday as the Shabab militant group tried to take back a slice of strategic territory from militias allied with the Somali government. At the same time, Shabab fighters are breaking up camps for victims of Somalias famine, sending tens of thousands of starving people straight back into drought-stricken areas.

title: Unwelcome Guest of Honor at Festivals
description: Fresh from trips to the Toronto and Telluride film festivals, The Timess co-chief film critics, Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, survey the film landscape.

title: Red Sox: No Decision Yet on Franconas Future
description: Red Sox management met with Manager Terry Francona on Friday to discuss his future, but General Manager Theo Epstein said no decision would be made or announced on Friday.

title: In Wilson and Kinsler, a Rerun the Rays May Not Want to See
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Its been a joyous, month-long magic-carpet ride for the Tampa Bay Rays, albeit a nerve-wracking one. But theyll face a sobering reality in Texas Rangers leadoff hitter Ian Kinsler and Fridays Game 1 starter C.J. Wilson, two players who crushed the Rays hopes in last years American League division series.

title: A New England Noah, Rounding Up His Ark of Vintage Autos
description: HUDSON, Mass.

title: A Car Collection of the Big and Smaller
description: Charles Gould has been collecting cars since he was a young man and now has filled two warehouses.

title: Turkeys Rifts With 2 Nations Worry a Top NATO Official
description: BRUSSELS  NATOs secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, expressed disquiet on Friday about tensions over natural gas exploration in the Mediterranean between a newly assertive Turkey and Cyprus, as well as Turkeys strained relations with Israel, saying that they were both a matter of concern.

title: A Bright Forecast for Direct Marketing
description: Forecasters are predicting that despite the concerns about the direction of the economy, spending for direct marketing advertising will continue to grow.

title: Long Island SAT Fraud Prompts Wider Investigations
description: In Fridays Times, Jenny Anderson reports that theSAT fraud exposed this week in Great Neck, N.Y., is suspected to reach wider than initially imagined, perhaps implicating students at other Long Island high schools.

title: Tigers Choose Penny, Leave Pauley Off Playoff Roster
description: Tigers Manager Jim Leyland has ended the playoff roster suspense, and it came with some surprises. Starting pitcher Brad Penny, who was on the bubble, has made the cut for the 25-man roster over David Pauley. (The Yankees submitted their roster earlier.)

title: Remixing Trivia With Music Videos
description: WOODY THOMPSON put the word out last year: He was getting the band back together. It had been eight years, and he could hardly believe it, but the moneymen had come knocking again. The only problem: Almost everybody he reached was shaking his or her head. No.

title: Workouts From Church and the Afterlife
description: This May Be My Last Time Singing

title: Ska-Punk Rockers, Way Ahead of the Curve
description: FOR more than a quarter century the Los Angeles band Fishbone has been making music critics reach for their hyphens. Its been called ska-punk, punk-funk and ska-punk-funk-metal. The Rough Guide to Rock deemed Fishbones music jazz/hard rock/ska/funk; a Rolling Stone writer threw up his hands and went with orgasmic urban gumbo. None of these labels aptly sum up the sound of a band that seems to have ingested a centurys worth of American and Caribbean popular music, nor do they capture the manic spirit of the groups concerts, which earned Fishbone a reputation as one of the worlds great live acts. In a new documentary, Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone, the record producer David Kahne dispenses with the hyphens altogether. Fishbone, he says, is simply weird.

title: On Our Radar: Dam Halted in Myanmar
description: A day after Brazils controversial Belo Monte dam was halted by a court order, Myanmars president says he is suspending construction of the Chinese-backed Myitsone dam on the Irrawaddy River. He cites the desire of the people. [The Guardian]

title: Music Review: Bach: 5 Keyboard Concertos
description: BACH: 5 KEYBOARD CONCERTOS

title: Cylinders Missing, but Not Missed
description: TESTED 2012 BMW Z4 sDrive 28i

title: A Threat to the Job Security of White-Glove Chauffeurs
description: THE Bentley Mulsanne, it turns out, is a pleasant car to drive.

title: An Indie Queen Cranks Up Operas Amps
description: IN a studio on the far West Side of Manhattan a gaggle of young women, numbering close to 40, almost all under 25, sat splayed in slumber party mode on a rehearsal room floor. Dressed mostly in leggings and the appropriate American Apparel accoutrements, hair coolly mussed, they kept their eyes focused on one woman in the room while they quietly sang. Their voices were soft until joined by the guttural force of Karen O and her undeniably female yelp. Its a sound that has filled arenas but will next be heard on a theatrical stage.

title: Model-Morphosis | Dempsey Stewart at Rick Owens
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Dempsey Stewart from Wilhelmina before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Luica Peroni for M.A.C. and hair by Luigi Murenu for John Freida. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: "Don't Steal the Jacket"
description: Monclers video clip of Bruce Webers film, Dont Steal the Jacket.

title: Cucina dellArte: High-End Dining in Italy
description: A TIMID speaker of foreign tongues, I had scrawled the address on a piece of paper, so I didnt have to say the numbers and words, and the taxi driver studied it, perplexed for a few seconds, then tickled.

title: In Europe, Cooking Classes for Every Palate
description: As much as the Eiffel Tower or the Sistine Chapel, food is a bona fide European tourist attraction. Alas, the pleasures of the table are fleeting. Participate in a cooking class, however, and you can extend the experience far beyond your flight home. The following programs from around Europe, all given in English, focus on regional cuisines and seasonal ingredients, allowing you to bring the tastes of your trip back to your home kitchen.

title: Tasting Istanbul, From Humble to High Cuisine
description: SOMETIMES I think its no accident that Istanbuls telephone area code is 212. Despite its minarets and its hilly cobblestone streets, its Grand Bazaar and the sapphire waters of the Bosporus that glide through the city like a liquid sash, this eastern metropolis has a New York state of mind.

title: Unforgettable Foods, from Austrian Apricots to Parisian Butter
description: Is there anything more intrinsic to a place than its food? Yes, we can order up slices of Italian prosciutto in Chicago and buy French butter in Brooklyn, but in Parma or Paris those foods take on a special significance. For travelers, food conveys the essence of a place. With that in mind, we asked correspondents with decades of culinary experience across Europe among them to share a few of the foods that are worth traveling for.

title: Dining in Italy
description: In Italy, one can eat in the kinds of avant-garde places that sophisticated travelers more commonly associate with France or Spain.

title: A Taste of Istanbul
description: Despite its minarets and its hilly cobblestone streets and its Grand Bazaar, this eastern metropolis has a New York state of mind.

title: Cooking Schools Across Europe
description: Participate in a cooking class and you can extend the experience far beyond your flight home.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Athne in Paris
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Bellying Up to the Time When America Went Dry
description: Tune in a documentary about the Civil War and you expect it to resonate in the present, since the racial issues that emanated from the era of slavery are still very much with us. But a program about Prohibition? Flappers in speakeasies and biddies beating temperance drums: hardly seems a recipe for modern-day relevance.

title: Photographer Declares Bridge-Clambering Days Done
description: After 18 long years, the e-mail began, I photographed my last bridge.

title: Edible Selby | A Movable Feast
description: When Caroline Burnett decided to open Heroes, in Berlins Neuklln district, her initial emphasis was not on food. The cafe was a pretext for the art, says Burnett, an American editor who curates art shows in a dynamic exhibition space in the back. Today she and her partner, Damien Poinsard, a French-born cook who helps run a theater group on the side, are drawing regulars as much with their down-home fare as with their roster of up-and-coming artists. Crepes and quiches are standards; specials depend on whos cooking. If Poinsard is in the kitchen, the menu might include pot au feu or stewed chicken; when Burnett is in, she says, the special is likely to be meatloaf, reflecting her nostalgia for home. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Channel Surfing: Hunt for the I-5 Killer
description: The Lifetime network may be on no ones list of prestige television outlets, but give it this: Its getting better and better at the women-in-jeopardy movie. It serves up another on Sunday night, Hunt for the I-5 Killer, and solid performances in the central roles make this one of its better offerings.

title: When Glass Ceiling Is a Positive
description: THE craze for panoramas swept America in the 1840s, inspiring both P. T. Barnum and Henry Wadsworth Longfellow.

title: Austria Passes Expansion of Euro Bailout Fund, With Opposition Limited but Loud
description: BERLIN  Austria on Friday became the latest country to sign off on the expansion of the euro currency zones bailout fund for heavily indebted countries, following a bruising debate in Parliament that underscored the politicaltensions behind the search for a solution to Europes financial woes.

title: Mystery at Martin Margiela
description: Waiting for the Maison Martin Margiela show this afternoon, I was horrified, and slightly entertained, to hear the tale of Drew Elliotts amazing adventure ride into Paris from the airport that morning. First, Mr. Elliott, of Paper Magazine, was on a delayed flight that arrived six hours late. Then his cab driver, halfway into the city, received a cellphone call alerting him that his wife had gone into labor. The driver pulled over and deposited Mr. Elliott and his luggage on the side of the road.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $20,000,000
description: A condominium at 988 Fifth Avenue that closed for $20 million was the highest sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com.

title: Short-Termism and Energy Revolutions
description: The calls these days for a technological energy revolution are widespread. But how do you spark breakthroughs when the natural bias of businesses, investors and governments is toward the here and now?

title: Pasta With Cauliflower
description: Mark Bittman reaches back into the Minimalist vault to share one of his favorite recipes.

title: The Minimalist: Pasta With Cauliflower
description: Ive been making this pasta for a very long time, probably since the 1980s, since its derived from a Marcella Hazan recipe. Its dead simple  one of the things that I love about it  and you can precook the cauliflower a day ahead or so if youd like. I usually do the whole thing at once: cook the cauliflower in water, scoop it out and then, later, cook the pasta in the same water. Its already boiling, and you want the taste of the cauliflower anyway, so why not?

title: Sports of The Times: Reyes Wins, Mets Lose
description: Jose Reyes has his batting title, but what good does that do Mets fans who have to spend another October watching other teams play, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Image slideshow Battle for Libya | September 30, 2011
description: Fighters for Libyas new rulers were forced to regroup Friday on the edge of Surt, as pro-Qaddafi snipers halted a two-week-old assault on the ousted leaders hometown.

title: Are Barefoot Shoes Really Better?
description: Barefoot running may be trendy, but for scores of runners who train on urban streets or rocky trails, running without foot cover isnt an option. As a result, many runners have switched to minimalist sports shoes that add a thin layer of protection without detracting from the feeling of running barefoot.

title: Channel Surfing: Around the World in 80 Ways
description: You might not think of a zip line as a mode of transportation, and in the opening episode of Around the World in 80 Ways, Dennis Anderson and Robert Mariano sure look as though they wish that whoever arranges the adventures for this new program hadnt thought of it as one either.

title: Can a Dinner Party Be Stress-Free?
description: For experienced cooks, seeing whats in your fridge and thinking of a simple way to prepare it is a terrific weeknight strategy. But a dinner party is rarely the time for spontaneity, even for veterans, and for those who are unsure of their skills, a dinner party can be downright terrifying.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Christian Dior
description: At around 12:30 backstage at Dior, a model let out a shriek just as Pat McGrath was discussing products necessary for fatigued or bug-bitten skin (as was the case in mosquito-ridden Milan). The timing was uncanny, as the provocateur was a large grasshopper that managed to make his rounds all the way over to where Orlando Pita was working on hair. Mosquitoes in Milan and grasshoppers, er sauterelles  not the garden variety  at the Musee de Rodin: oh my! The look, according to Pita was very fresh and modern, turning a page from the past, at least for this season. This meant a twist of a bun with a side part and slight wave in the front created by using Pitas Plump for volume, control hairspray and dry shampoo. The trick was that there was no ponytail beneath to hold the hair; it was deceptively simple. For makeup, McGrath went with a contoured eye and classic, beautiful red lip. One of the 28 members of McGraths team brought a face by for her approval. Dont forget, kids: not a hard lip with pencil, I prefer the finger, its softer. This is what made the lady modern. Three of Diors reds were used, chosen based on the clothes: red orange, blue orange and pinky red. Nails were also a mix of five shades: Incognito, a nude; Riviera, an orange; Waterlily, a green; Forget me not, a lavender; and Lucky, a red.

title: Recipes | Starters
description: Dinner party starters.

title: Yesterdays Vision Of Tomorrow
description: Filmmakers have long been imagining the near future, and it is rarely bright.

title: Recipes | Main Courses
description: Main courses for a dinner party.

title: Recipes | Desserts
description: Desserts for a dinner party.

title: Readers Respond to the Education Issue
description: Paul Toughs article on teaching character and Cliff Levys article on putting his kids in a Russian school were our most-discussed stories last week.

title: The Food & Drink Issue
description: Everything you ever wanted to know about food (but didnt know whom to ask).

title: The Money Is Gone, but the Winery and a Womans Resolve Remain
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Patricia Kluge appeared for years to be one of the nations wealthiest divorcees, with a breathtaking Virginia mansion known as Albemarle, an ample jewel collection and a river of cash from her ex-husband, the late media magnate John Kluge.

title: Mythbusters on Cars vs. Motorcycles: Which Is Greener?
description: In a revelation sure to disquiet Vespa-riding urbanites and independent streamliner engineers, a study conducted in conjunction with a recent episode of Mythbusters, the Discovery Channel program, found that cars were greener than motorcycles.

title: Anita Hills Long Memory
description: Your new book, Reimagining Equality, deals with how race and gender intersect. How do you think the reception to your testimony during Clarence Thomass confirmation hearings would have been different if you were a white woman accusing a white employer of sexual harassment?  Lets not be entirely deceived about this. Im not sure that the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate at large were really ready to deal with gender discrimination no matter who was alleging it. I dont know that they understood how important the issue was to the integrity of the Supreme Court and to the fitness of the individual who was going on the court. Think about how it might have been different if I had been white and Thomas were, as he is, an African-American male. And just think about one particular senator, Strom Thurmond. Given his history and his constituency, I think he would have been hard pressed to treat a white woman accusing a black man in the same way he treated me.

title: The Motivational-Speaker Smackdown
description: Jock Elliott paced the events room of Ballys Hotel in Las Vegas. Sixty-four years old, with a silver mustache and mild features, Elliott flew in a week before from Brisbane, Australia. The jet lag had worn off, but it was 6:10 a.m., and he had had only one cup of coffee  in a paper cup no less. I hate coffee in paper cups, he said. Its appalling. So uncivilized.

title: Vicious Cyclist
description: A food-delivery person who couldnt find a spot on a pole chained his bike directly to mine instead. I only had an hour for lunch, so when he didnt return after a few minutes, I removed my chain and locked both our bikes to the pole. Then I walked to lunch instead of cycling. When I returned, I freed both bikes. He was predictably upset. Was my instinct to teach a lesson unethical? ANTHONY B., NEW YORK

title: Future Shock
description: Since Georges Mlis took audiences on a trip to the Moon in 1902, filmmakers have been putting their visions of the future on the big screen. While some have focused on extremely distant time frames, many have tackled eras not too far from their own. The latest to look at the near-future is Real Steel (opening Friday), which sets its sights on 2020. By then, according to the film, the new sport of robot boxing will have emerged, with machines replacing people in the ring. The director, Shawn Levy, said he was more interested in telling a humanistic story (featuring Hugh Jackman, right, and the young Dakota Goyo) than creating a heavily sci-fi feel.

title: The First Pear Salad of Fall
description: FICKLE consumers that we are, the next seasonal beauty is what we fall for. Not to slight late-season peaches, or the good tomatoes, eggplants and peppers that may remain, but its the early autumn fruits that now beckon. Succulent grapes, new-crop apples, quinces, pomegranates and persimmons are all parading their cool-weather costumes. Why resist?

title: Troubled Poker Site May Be Bought by French Entrepreneur
description: Full Tilt Poker players may yet be able to cash out.

title: AT&T Moves to Dismiss Lawsuits by Sprint and Cellular South
description: The legal fusillades have continued in the battle over AT&Ts proposed $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile USA, as the company sought on Friday to take shots at competitors seeking to stop the takeover.

title: Boubacar Traor in Brooklyn
description: Jon Pareles looks at the Malian Singer

title: Video: Boubacar Traor in Brooklyn
description: An excerpt from this weeks ArtsBeat video captures the Malian singer and songwriter Boubacar Traor playing a song during sound check for a recent show at the Bell House in Brooklyn. Born in Mali in 1942, Mr. Traor first came to prominence in the early 1960s. His humble background made it difficult for him to make money as a musician. He dropped out of the music scene until he reemerged with a surprise appearance on Malian television in 1987. He has been recording and touring intermittently ever since.

title: Car Bomb at Funeral in Iraq Kills at Least 7 and Hurts Scores
description: BAGHDAD  A large car bomb exploded Friday evening at a funeral in the southern Shiite town of Hilla, leaving several people dead and more than 60 wounded. It was a deadly reminder that even as American forces prepare to withdraw and officials claim success in stabilizing Iraq, random attacks and assassinations are still daily occurrences.

title: A Lego Game Where Your iPhone Is the Judge
description: How quickly can you build a fish out of Legos? How about a ship, or a tree? Lego: Life of George, available in stores tomorrow, lets you test your pattern-matching skills under pressure, providing you have a camera-equipped iPhone or equivalent, and a free app called Life of George which is your blueprint, timer, progress tracker, and  most interestingly  your judge.

title: Inquiry Clears S.E.C. in Mark Cuban Insider Trading Case
description: 8:51 p.m. | Updated

title: The Daily Shoe | Lanvin
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Pork Cutlets With the Wisdom of Two Continents
description: I HAD always thought that schnitzel came in one flavor  veal  until a trip to Vienna several years ago set me straight.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fresh
description: Singing colors and patterns left their mark on the recent New York fashion collections and on the city.

title: Homemade Tonkatsu Sauce
description: If you dont have a bottle of tonkatsu sauce in your pantry but want to experience its sweet and tangy flavor with pork katsu, there are several good-looking recipes floating around the Internet. Here are a few likely candidates. I havent tried them, so if you do, we would love the feedback!

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 30
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Wall Street protests, cellphone service in the subways, and a private island for sale off the Bronx.

title: No Fins? No Problem: Jellyfish Have Their Ways
description: For animals that drift through the sea without the benefit of eyesight, jellyfish have managed to survive remarkably well. In fact, in areas where overfishing and habitat destruction have reduced fish populations, jellyfish are now becoming the dominant predators.

title: Kodak Hires Legal Adviser Amid Talk of Bankruptcy
description: 9:12 p.m. | Updated

title: Bachmann Video Aims at Perry on Immigration
description: All week Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has been attacked by Republican rivals over immigration, and on Friday, Representative Michele Bachmann delivered one of the sharpest tongue-lashings of all.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Philippines, Libya and Yemen

title: With Nebraska in Town, Madison Gets Ready to Jump
description: When Nebraska travels to Wisconsin for its Big Ten inauguration Saturday night, the game will resonate as a cultural event as much as a sporting contest. Wisconsin is bracing for the presence of some 30,000 Nebraska fans in Madison this weekend, many of whom do not have tickets and are just tagging along for the revelry and history.

title: Sweet Pears, Good Cheese and Bitter Greens
description: With cool weather at hand and, with it, early autumn produce, Im almost completely ready to leave summer behind. I will still be cooking with tomatoes, but they have been banished from the salad bowl. Now I want pears.

title: Upping the Ante
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#206", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: TimesCast | September 30, 2011
description: A drone attack in Yemen kills United States-born Qaeda leader Anwar al-Awlaki; a look at Awlaki's influence on young Muslims; and a 2007 interview with Samir Khan, who also died in Friday's attack.

title: G.M.s Road From Prosperity to Crisis
description: Major events in the history of General Motors.

title: Book Review Podcast: Memoirs by Hal Holbrook, John Lithgow and More
description: In the book review, Ada Calhoun reviews new memoirs by Hal Holbrook and by John Lithgow, who appears on this weeks podcast. The relentlessly likable Lithgow, she writes, is

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, the Philippines, Libya and Yemen.

title: Jeff Sommer with Floyd Norris on the troubles in Europe and the world economy, David Gillen and Bill Vlasic on the 2008 auto crisis, and Tyler Cowen on the logic for tax increases.
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Floyd Norris on the troubles in Europe and the world economy, David Gillen and Bill Vlasic on the 2008 auto crisis, and Tyler Cowen on the logic for tax increases.

title: Reporter Threatens to Name Names in Phone Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  A reporter who is among the 16 people arrested and then freed on bail in the phone hacking case that has shaken Rupert Murdochs media empire in Britain warned his former bosses on Friday that he planned to break his silence on the scandal in a civil court case. He said that he would reveal those who were responsible for the phone hacking.

title: Cuomo Said to Have a Leading Candidate to Run the Port Authority
description: Patrick J. Foye, a longtime figure in the public life of the New York City region, is a leading candidate to become executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to a person familiar with the selection process.

title: My Three Favorite Out-of-the-Way Spots
description: Exiting an airport in a foreign country is one of the worlds best feelings. The air smells different, the signs are mostly incomprehensible. Sometimes confusion or the occasional panic sets in. Where do I go? Whos going to take me there? But that is all part of the rush. Here are my three favorite out-of-the-way spots.

title: The Character Test
description: The formula presented in Paul Toughs article of allowing an insulated child to experience little failures might improve his or her resilience a notch, but I disagree that it will result in grit. If possession of grit can lead to much greater rewards in life, why would we presume that you can attain grit through a low-risk strategy of relatively innocuous negative experiences? Go find a kid who has been exploited or abandoned, and you will find a soul with grit to spare. Provide that kid with resources for his goals, and youll manufacture a success story. But dont imagine that a caring parent will ever be willing to employ a strategy in advance that allows a child to undergo the searing experiences required for the formation of real grit.

title: Strangers in a Strange School
description: I read Cliff Levys article with great interest, because I, too, lived in Russia and put my children in Russian schools. Like the authors children, my two daughters didnt know a word of Russian. They did not, however, find themselves bewildered and isolated. They spent four years in public schools, enjoying every moment of their time with Russian classmates and teachers. They were never teased or mocked, as Levys children were in their private school. Another difference was cost. Annual tuition at the private school was $10,000. The education that my children got in public schools was gratis.

title: Not All Superheroes Are Equal (At Least the Second Time Around)
description: The critical response to the introduction of 52 new No. 1 issues in the DC Comics universe has varied wildly, from excitement to outright disdain. Since the initiative began at the end of August, two staff members of The New York Times have reviewed each No. 1 on the ArtsBeat blog. Here the two, George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler, sum up their responses and offer a list of the 10 books that drew their sharpest reactions, sometimes for the wrong reasons.

title: Reviewing the Bentley Mulsanne
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich drives the Bentley Mulsanne, a luxury saloon in the classic British heavyweight mold, clocking in at nearly three tons.

title: F.D.A. Approves Breathing Device for A.L.S. Patients
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a device that stimulates the diaphragm to assist breathing for some people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, better known as A.L.S. or Lou Gehrigs disease.

title: Clashes Continue as Thousands Protest in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Friday in demonstrations that seemed to be dwindling in size, while clashes continued between security forces and army defectors in central Syria, residents and witnesses said.

title: Puzzling It Out
description: I love how Rick Owens continues to find expression in couture volume and small gestures. Here are two examples from his spring collection: cotton tunics or jackets (some with a hint of a peplum) with a drawstring at the waist that can be released for a different shape, and the geometric show-closers in paper-thin leather. Mr. Owens said the idea evolved from working with his fur atelier. Obviously the process was quite laborious.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 30
description: Week in Culture Pictures

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 30
description: More Photographs

title: Francona Out as Red Sox Manager
description: The Boston Red Sox announced Friday that they would not pick up their option on Terry Franconas contract, parting ways with the manager who led them to the World Series championships in 2004 and 2007 after decades of failure. Francona, who managed eight seasons in Boston, oversaw a collapse this season in which the Red Sox lost 20 of 27 games in September to lose their playoff spot to the Tampa Bay Rays.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Isabel Marant
description: No product was used by Stephane Lancien backstage at Isabel Marant to create mussed hair meant to look as if a girl had just been for a spin in a convertible. Sexy  but by mistake, said Lancien of the messy, haphazard style. The face was more low key. Its my makeup in real life, said the model Snejana Onopka of Karim Rahmans work. A longtime collaborator with Marant, Rahman managed to make sense of the designers taste for duality. She likes color; she doesnt like color. She likes lipstick; she doesnt like lipstick, he said. Its a fine balance. This effect was created using foundation mixed with moisturizer and a flush of LOral Glam Bronze in Golden and Universal Sun all over the face and close to the nose like sun marks. There was no mascara, but brown kohl was penciled between upper and lower lashes and blended with the finger. Lips were a bright salmon  LOral Colour Riche Pink Passion  apparently the anti-color, anti-lipstick of lipsticks.

title: Signaling Can Win the Game, So Brush Up on Your Defense
description: When you and your regular partner get together, what aspect of your game do you discuss?

title: Out of the Box
description: Several years ago, in the late 80s, I met my friend Tim Blanks over lunch at the Fiera in Milan. In those days, most of the designers, with the notable exception of Giorgio Armani, showed in the Fiera, including Gianni Versace, and it was convenient to stay for lunch; the food was good, too. Afterward, Tim and I walked to the Romeo Gigli store, then in a Renault garage that in time became Corso Como 10. Everyone seemed to make that pilgrimage, so popular were Mr. Giglis trousers, coats and sari-colored shirts that they became a fashion uniform.

title: The Young Gallerists
description: TO describe the retrospective of Richard Hambletons art that was recently held at the Phillips de Pury & Company galleries as a zoo doesnt even take into account the woman who strapped a bug-eyed monkey puppet to her chest. About 2,000 partygoers were crowding two floors at the auction house on Park Avenue, including wealthy Upper East Siders and a parade of models from New York Fashion Week, many sipping from flutes of Champagne.

title: The Freedom to Choose Your Pronoun
description: AFEW weeks ago, Katy Butler, 16, updated her status on Facebook with an enthusiastic shout-out for Google+, the social networks latest rival. Oh my God Google! I love it! I was signing up for Google+ and they asked me my gender and the choices were male, female or OTHER!!!!! Oh ya Google!

title: At the Center of a Trial, a Shabby Queens Home
description: In the gilded, leafy confines of Forest Hills Gardens in Queens, the house on Greenway North and Puritan Avenue stands out for its shabbiness.

title: Now Online | T Design Fall 2011
description: The fall issue of T Design goes all over the map, visiting an 18th-century fantasy in Chicago, a contemporary art-filled aerie in Manhattan, a supernatural lighting installation in Munich and an off-the-grid vacation spot in Uruguay. It also recalls a chronicler of California Modern architecture and a young London designer who performs alchemy on unlikely materials. See all the stories here.

title: Question: Why Pay Bank Fees?
description: The news on Thursday that Bank of America is imposing a $5 monthly fee on people who have the nerve to use their debit card to buy things probably should not have come as much of a shock.

title: A Rising Fear of an Extended Downturn
description: MORE Americans think the job market is bad now than at any time since 1982, when the country was in a severe recession.

title: Why Havent You Switched Banks?
description: In this gig, I run into all sorts of examples of mystifying consumer behavior. One of the big ones, however, is why people keep their checking accounts at big, national banks.

title: App Smart Extra: An App for Deer Hunters
description: This weeks App Smart column identified new apps that help people maximize their success in an activity largely dominated by carnivores  namely the tailgate party.

title: For $35,800, Obama Is the Only Constant
description: AND so, it turns out, not all $35,800-a-plate fund-raisers are created equal.

title: Fast Vocal Muscles Are Behind Bats Skill
description: The last thing an insect hears before it is eaten by a bat is what scientists call the terminal buzz, a sonar-based call that bats use to track their prey. Bats can produce these echolocation calls at a rapid rate, up to 190 calls per second; they also use the buzz to navigate.

title: D.M.V. Quickly Reviews Policy to Waive Vision Test for Renewals
description: New York drivers might not get a pass on taking a vision test to renew their licenses for very long.

title: California Quits States Talks With Banks on Mortgages
description: A decision on Friday by a California official to withdraw from negotiations with large banks over their mortgage practices threatens to derail a broad settlement that the Justice Department has been brokering for nearly a year.

title: Substance, Captured With Style
description: Much of the time, a documentary is a movie with something to say and a lot of people talking. The current boom in nonfiction filmmaking has been fed, to a large extent, by the impulses of advocacy journalism, according to which the job of the filmmaker is to bring attention to a problem in the world and to assemble experts and eyewitnesses qualified to explain it. While there is nothing wrong with this model  and much to admire about films that seek to instruct and inspire their audiences  it can be wearying and limited. There is so much social concern, so many talking-head interviews wrapped around snippets of archival footage, and, too often, not enough art.

title: Iceland, Rising From Its Ashes With Films
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  Iceland is a country of upheavals, natural and artificial, literal and figurative, so it should be no surprise that the featured Icelandic selection at the eighth annual Reykjavik International Film Festival is Volcano, directed by Runar Runarsson, which opens with spectacular scenes of the Eldfell volcano chewing the bones of a small island town in 1973.

title: Well Fed but Not Stuffed
description: PARIS

title: So Far, Sales for New DC Comics Are Super
description: In June DC Comics fans were left shaking in their Superman skivvies after the publisher announced that it would reset all its continuing series and reintroduce their heroes, as if they were appearing for the first time. The hope was to entice new readers by simplifying decades of lore.

title: Channel Surfing: Free Agents, the British Version
description: Theres no law that says British television has to be better than American. The science-fiction series Outcasts, a Terra Nova forerunner recently shown on BBC America, was pretty dreadful. The American Office was sometimes better than its British counterpart.

title: A Chicago Cautionary Tale: Fan Is Still Short for Fanatic
description: Taxi to the Dark Side, the title of Alex Gibneys best-known film (an Oscar winner in 2008), is also a good general description of his documentaries. As a sports film, Catching Hell might sound like a change of pace for a director whose subjects have included torture, fraud, influence peddling, terrorism and Eliot Spitzer. But as usual, Mr. Gibney wants to take us to a frightening place.

title: Yemenis Say They Have Bigger Problems Than Al Qaeda
description: SANA, Yemen  On the streets of Sana, the nations conflict-stricken capital, the news of the death of Anwar al-Awlaki, the Yemeni-American propagandist for Al Qaeda who inspired jihadists around the world, was largely overshadowed by the continuing domestic turmoil here.

title: Moving Out of New York Is Just a Bad Idea
description: Whenever a movie character decides to abandon a successful career to spend more time with my family, scenes of domestic bliss rarely follow. Dream House is no exception, though this crackpot thriller from the usually competent Jim Sheridan leaves only one mystery unsolved: what on earth was he thinking?

title: Very Late in His Career, a Composer Tries a Flute
description: Elliott Carter completed his Concerto for Flute and Ensemble in March 2008, back when he was only 99. The astonishingly prolific Mr. Carter is about 10 weeks shy of 103. Since he turned 100, he has written 14 works.

title: With Bach as Innocent Bystander, Message for the Senses, Not the Mind
description: Say youre a person who adores Bach. Say you rarely go to see dance (too busy listening to Bach). Given these circumstances, you might logically conclude that there is no such thing as too much Bach.

title: Burning the Diaries
description: I JUST burned 40 years worth of diaries. I didnt plan to  or rather, I had always planned to, once I knew I was dying, or so old that I would soon lack the energy to gather wood. But I woke one morning and knew it was time to let it all go.

title: Blend of Music and Mystery: A Mixed Bag
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The cross-pollination of the mystery and the musical theater does not have a fertile history. There was Rupert Holmess Mystery of Edwin Drood, of course, about half of City of Angels and, more recently, John Kander and Fred Ebbs Curtains. But even that great puzzler fan Stephen Sondheim, co-writer of both a mystery play and a mystery movie, has never actually concocted a true mystery musical, although his Grand Guignol masterwork, Sweeney Todd, is rich in suspense and richer still in bloody murder.

title: With Paris on Her Mind
description: LOLA BURSTEIN RYKIEL, 25, the United States director of public relations for Sonia Rykiel, is the designers granddaughter. Her father is Simon Burstein, the chief executive of Browns fashion boutique in London. Raised in Paris, Lola now lives in New York. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: Band Kicks Up a Sweat Storm Onstage
description: Need housing for the night: six men, either shirtless and moist or sweating through their shirts; carrying instruments, some of them large; unlikely to stay still for long periods of time.

title: Look of the Moment | Kanye West
description: The Look: Jeans and a Jacket  one would hardly recognize the reliable gray T-shirt and everyday black denim under that dazzling red blazer.

title: Clearing House Group Assails Bank Capital Rules
description: When several big banks faced extinction three years ago, many people wondered how such sophisticated institutions had failed to maintain rainy-day funds.

title: Just Cant Say Goodbye to Gotham
description: The Love Letter Youve Been Meaning to Write New York is not a production that satisfies on certain conventional levels: the concept and plot are strained, many of the performers are awkward amateurs, much of the script is hackneyed.

title: Adobes Announcement Competes With Apples
description: Are you excited about the announcement next Tuesday morning? You know the one, from that Silicon Valley tech company that begins with an A?

title: Bloggingheads: Fantasies of Christie
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate the presidential buzz around Chris Christie.

title: Every Action Produces Overreaction
description: During their first week, members of Occupy Wall Street, the ideologically vague and strategically baffling effort to redress social inequities, put together a library on the north end of Zuccotti Park whose disparate offerings included Last Exit to Brooklyn; Gay Taleses article in The New Yorker on the collaboration of Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga; and Abbotts Digest of New York Statutes and Reports, Volumes 4, 9, 33 and 34. By the middle of last week, as the numbers entrenched in the park grew, copies of Animal Farm, Barbara Ehrenreichs Nickel and Dimed and Meltdown, a book outlining the 2008 financial crisis, were well placed. Specific ambitions still had not emerged, but a new intensity had begun to replace the limp theatrics.

title: Despite Upgrades, L.I.R.R.s Reliability Issues Return With a Bolt of Lightning
description: This was supposed to be the year that the troubles on the Long Island Rail Road came to a halt.

title: Airborne
description: My median altitude tomorrow will be around 37,000 feet. Expect no posts.

title: N.F.L. Denies Pryors Appeal
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell affirmed Friday the five-game suspension he gave the former Ohio State quarterback Terrelle Pryor, saying he had improperly manipulated the N.F.L.s eligibility rules when he intentionally took steps to ensure that he would be declared ineligible for further college play and would be able to enter the N.F.L. via the supplemental draft.

title: Jets Face an Imposing Obstacle in Ngata
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Because the Jets face the Baltimore Ravens on Sunday, and probably because he used to coach him, Rex Ryan has spent part of this week making Haloti Ngata sound more like an action hero than a 6-foot-4, 330-pound defensive tackle.

title: Week in Pictures for Sept. 30
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Wall Street protests, cellphone service in the subways, and a private island for sale, off the coast of the Bronx.

description: ON a side street in Park Slope, Brooklyn, Austin Horse cobbled together an impromptu podium last weekend out of a plastic milk crate and a case of Red Bull.

title: Umenyiora May Return Against the Cardinals
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Osi Umenyiora has been the Giants All-Pro defensive end in absentia this season. But there is a strong possibility that Umenyiora, who is recovering from knee surgery, will return to the business of playing football.

title: Espresso and the Incredible Hulk
description: As chief creative officer of Marvel Entertainment, Joe Quesada, 49, keeps fans of the Incredible Hulk, Spider-Man and the rest happy. Part of his job is to make sure that the characters stories have a smooth transition to film and television. On Sundays, he becomes the fan, cheering for his daughter at figure-skating tournaments or rooting for the Mets. He lives with his wife, Nanci, 49, and their daughter, Carlie, 10, in a loft in the Flatiron district, along with their yellow Lab, Zoe, and two cats, Mucha and Nutley. They also have a house in New Jersey.  ELISA MALA
